headline: Millionaire Chess to Hit Las Vegas, in Gambit to Raise Game’s Profile With Big Prizes
abstract: The tournament is intended to be the first step in a multiyear plan to organize and run tournaments with big prize funds.
lead_paragraph: Next month, more than 500 chess players from 39 countries will arrive at the Planet Hollywood Casino in Las Vegas to compete in a tournament with the biggest prize fund in chess history — $1 million. And despite all of the players paying at least $1,000 each in entry fees, the tournament organizers will almost certainly lose hundreds of thousands of dollars.

headline: Study Suggests a Rebound for Union Jobs in New York
abstract: An annual study scheduled to be released this week found that the proportion of working-age residents who were members of unions had increased in the last 18 months to nearly one in four.
lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, labor leaders were fretting over the steady erosion of New York City’s reputation as a bastion of unionization. The share of working-age city residents belonging to labor unions was in what they feared was an inexorable decline.

headline: A Donor’s Passion Animates the Gamecocks’ Success
abstract: Joe Rice, a South Carolina alumnus who has donated about $5 million to the university’s athletic program, and other boosters could become more essential as a result of the O’Bannon ruling.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Under the generous shade of oak trees in a parking lot across the street from Williams-Brice Stadium last Thursday afternoon, as many as 100 people mingled between a catered buffet and a trailer with an amply loaded bar.

headline: NATO Set to Ratify Pledge on Joint Defense in Case of Major Cyberattack
abstract: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When President Obama meets with other NATO leaders later this week, they are expected to ratify what seems, at first glance, a far-reaching change in the organization’s mission of collective defense: For the first time, a cyberattack on any of the 28 NATO nations could be declared an attack on all of them, much like a ground invasion or an airborne bombing.

headline: Mental Floss Is Buoyed by Online Video
abstract: Mental Floss has become one of the magazine industry’s biggest video success stories by deploying a secret weapon — the author and YouTube star John Green.
lead_paragraph: For decades, magazine editors often relied on a handful of maxims to attract readers: Young is better than old. Pretty is better than ugly. Rich is better than poor. Film stars outsell television and music stars. Anything sells better than politics, and nothing sells better than a dead celebrity.

headline: Obama and the Warmongers
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president’s deliberative approach to the ISIS threat may be drowned out by the chants for blood.
lead_paragraph: We seem to be drifting inexorably toward escalating our fight with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, as the Obama administration mulls whether to extend its “limited” bombing campaign into Syria.

headline: Sport Turns a Corner and Sees Its Future, at 200 M.P.H.
abstract: The Spanish motorcycle rider Marc Márquez, 21, is a phenomenon known for his aggressive racing techniques, but he has maintained a humble off-track persona.
lead_paragraph: SILVERSTONE, England — Some Spanish journalists know him as El Niño — the kid — while some English reporters have called him the Smiling Assassin, for his genial nature off the track and the killer instinct he displays once his helmet is on.

headline: Amazon Bets on Content in Deal for Twitch
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Twitch has built a platform that hosts live events akin to the N.F.L., the United States Open or the X Games — and it has the audience to show for it.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, I spent time on Twitch.tv watching people watch people play StarCraft II, Call of Duty and League of Legends.

headline: U.S. to Report Its Trade Balance, and E.C.B. to Convene
abstract: Economists expect a slight widening in the trade deficit, and the European Central Bank is to meet on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT IS EXPECTED TO WIDEN

headline: Chris Kirk’s Torrid Round May Alter Some Ryder Cup Plans
abstract: Kirk, ranked 14th in Ryder Cup points, shot a 64 at the Deutsche Bank Championship on Sunday, and he could improve his chances to be picked for the Ryder Cup team with another solid round Monday.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Chris Kirk went head-to-head with the world’s top-ranked golfer Sunday and more than lived to tell about it. He matched that golfer, Rory McIlroy, shot for shot, beginning the day with two birdies and ending it the same way.

headline: Labor Today
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Editorials', 'Income Inequality', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Labor Day', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Five years into an economic recovery in which corporate profits have surged, the number and quality of jobs are still lagging badly, as are wages and salaries.
lead_paragraph: In the months before Labor Day last year, job growth was so slow that economists said it would take until 2021 to replace the jobs that were lost or never created in the recession and its aftermath.

headline: Showboat Casino Closes Amid Tears and Questions About Atlantic City’s Direction
abstract: Showboat, a New Orleans-themed casino owned by Caesars Entertainment, closed on Sunday at 4 p.m. Revel will shut its doors 37 hours later, early Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — One casino here closed on Sunday and another will be shuttered this week, the latest signs of the reckoning underway for New Jersey’s faded gambling mecca.

headline: How to Buy a Mine in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The state’s mine legislation is bad from an environmental point of view; it is even more shocking from an ethical viewpoint.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and the Republican-controlled State Legislature approved the world’s largest open-pit iron ore mine, a gash in the northern part of the state that could be as long as 21 miles, a half-mile wide and 1,000 feet deep.

headline: Desperately Dry California Tries to Curb Private Drilling for Water
abstract: Farmers have long believed that landowners controlled groundwater, but the state legislature passed new controls that establish a framework for managing water withdrawals through local agencies.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — The small prefab office of Arthur & Orum, a well-drilling outfit hidden in the almond trees and grapevines south of Fresno, has become a magnet for scores of California farmers in desperate need of water to sustain their crops. Looking at binders of dozens of orders for yet-to-be-drilled wells, Steve Arthur, a manager, said, “We’ve got more stacked up than we’ll do before the end of the year.”

headline: Tony Stewart’s Return to Sprint Cup Series Ends With Blowout
abstract: Stewart crashed into a barrier and blew a tire in his return to Nascar competition Sunday. He had taken a three-week hiatus from racing after his car fatally struck a fellow driver at a short-track event.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Ga. — In just a few blazing minutes, Tony Stewart unleashed pent-up racing emotion that had swelled for three weeks.

headline: Start-Ups Accrue Funding in Case of Leaner Times
abstract: Some entrepreneurs say worries about a possible downturn are partly why they are stocking up on financing, essentially taking out insurance on the risk of harder days ahead.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, right before the dot-com bubble popped, Lawrence Coburn quit his corporate job and dove into the Internet gold rush, raising $600,000 from friends and family — including his grandmother — for a consumer ratings site he founded called RateItAll. At the time, virtually any idea, no matter how far-fetched, seemed to hold the promise of a high-flying initial public offering, making it easy to attract financial backing.

headline: Lifting the Soul, and the Spanish Economy, Too
keywords: ['Pilgrimages', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Despite the sagging Spanish economy — or perhaps because of it — the pilgrimage to the shrine of St. James in northwestern Galicia has become a booming part of modern Spain’s tourism industry.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain — There are the pilgrims who hobble along with a staff, painstakingly making their way through a monthlong journey of contemplation. Then there are the others, looking all the fresher for walking a shorter route or paying a tour operator to carry their backpacks, and more likely to be clutching a cellphone or a guidebook.

headline: P.R. Firm for Putin’s Russia Now Walking a Fine Line
abstract: Ketchum’s staff members who provide public relations advice to Russia must avoid being seen as defending acts contrary to American interests while still providing some luster for a lucrative client.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, executives from the public relations firm Ketchum flew to Moscow to secure an account that has since been worth tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Odd Strokes Delight in Era of Uniformity at U.S. Open
abstract: Looking to mimic the likes of Roger Federer and Serena Williams, professional tennis players have adopted many similarities in their swings, with some exciting exceptions.
lead_paragraph: In a digital, mass-market age, the artisanal has plenty of cachet and the price tag to go with it.

lead_paragraph: MIRA LOMA, Calif. — Week after week, Guadalupe Rangel worked seven days straight, sometimes 11 hours a day, unloading dining room sets, trampolines, television stands and other imports from Asia that would soon be shipped to Walmart stores.

headline: Safer Electric Zoo Festival Brings Serious Beats and Tight Security
abstract: A year after two attendees died from drug overdoses, the electronic music festival on Randalls Island had a host of new safety measures amid increased scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: A year after deadly drug overdoses at the annual Electric Zoo music festival caused promoters to cancel the event’s final day, tens of thousands of ravers arrived on Randalls Island over Labor Day Weekend to find drug-sniffing dogs, a heavy police presence and guards who searched pockets, bags and even shoes for illicit substances.

headline: Ukrainian Woman, Held Up to Public Abuse, Is Released
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Irina Dovgan was wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and forced to stand on a sidewalk while holding a sign that read “She kills our children,” as passers-by slapped, kicked and spit on her.
lead_paragraph: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — A woman whose public abuse by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine roused anger over her treatment and concern for her fate has been freed from detention and allowed to leave rebel-controlled territory.

headline: A New Police Force in a Changed Camden
abstract: Sixteen months after Camden, N.J., eliminated its Police Department and replaced it with a county department, its crime rate has dropped and new policing strategies have helped ease tensions.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen months after Camden, N.J., eliminated its Police Department and replaced it with a county department, its crime rate has dropped and new policing strategies have helped ease tensions.

headline: Camden Turns Around With New Police Force
abstract: Since moving to a county-run police department, Camden, N.J., one of the nation’s poorest and most dangerous cities, has altered its culture to overcome years of mistrust.
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN, N.J. — In the summer of 2012, the year this city broke its own record for homicides, there were 21 people murdered here. This summer, there were six.

headline: And He’s Off: A Track Legend Calls It a Career
abstract: Tom Durkin, who called more than 80,000 horse races with an imaginative and captivating style, worked his final race on Sunday at Saratoga Race Course.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It was noon, and Tom Durkin was marking up his program with pastel colors for a final time, matching a kaleidoscope of jockey silks to the appropriate horses in each race. His binoculars were within arm’s reach, as was the coat hanger with a makeshift clipboard that holds his program and hangs around his neck as the thoroughbreds he describes make their way around the racetrack.

lead_paragraph: Not long after his father died, Tim Wu remembers, an uncle barged into his house in Toronto and snatched a fistful of Chinese-language materials from a file cabinet because of fears that the “secret police” would get them first.

lead_paragraph: During her roller-coaster political career, Kathy Hochul has been a rising star in the Democratic Party, a victim of its upstate troubles and a retired government employee who became a banking executive. And that is just since 2011.

abstract: The country’s top politicians on Sunday approved the delivery of thousands of machine guns and hand grenades, as well as hundreds of antitank missiles, to Kurdish forces battling Islamic militants in Iraq.

headline: Don’t Catch What Ails Your House
abstract: It doesn’t take a flood to encourage the growth of mold in a home. A moist environment will do. A runny nose, coughing and all the rest typically follow.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, my husband and I bought a vacation home in the foothills of the Catskills. The inspector who checked out the property failed to note three critical facts: The house had three flat roofs (in snow country), no drainage from the muddy crawl space and no insulation under the floors.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) TRANCE (2013) Danny Boyle’s thriller begins in an auction house, where the heist of a Goya leaves Simon (James McAvoy), an employee charged with safeguarding the work, with amnesia and unable to reveal where the painting is. Vincent Cassel plays Franck, the leader of the men behind the theft — and, it turns out, Simon’s business partner. And Rosario Dawson, above, is the hypnotherapist who holds the key to Simon’s memory. “Mr. Boyle, as always, works hard to cast a spell in ‘Trance,’ and his energy and commitment to the audience’s entertainment are evident in every scene,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film from the director of “Trainspotting” and “Slumdog Millionaire.” “But there are times when it feels as if he’s throwing everything at the screen — the throbbing music, bleeding fingers, narrative U-turns and the startling sight of a naked Ms. Dawson striding toward the camera as strategically shorn as a Renaissance nude — less because he wants to distract you from the big reveal than to obscure the material’s thinness.” She added, “That doesn’t lessen the movie’s appeal while you’re watching it, though it drastically shortens the afterglow.”

headline: A Racing Giant’s Final Stretch

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Emily Bazelon on Medical Abortion Through the Mail

headline: What Happens When Health Plans Compete
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: As more insurance companies enter a market, premiums tend to go down — but more in some places than in others.
lead_paragraph: As a candidate in 2008, President Obama promised that health reform would reduce family premiums by up to $2,500, equivalent today to about a 15 percent reduction from the 2013 level. Though Mr. Obama might have been including the effects of premium subsidies in his calculation, a key premise of the Affordable Care Act is that competition among health insurers will drive premiums downward. So it’s worth asking: How much savings can additional competition produce?

headline: 1914: Russian Army Scores Victory
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Russia enjoys a victory in Galicia in 1914.
lead_paragraph: Every particle of evidence available indicates that Russia, in addition to the victories she has won over the Germans in Eastern Prussia, has inflicted a staggering defeat on the Austrian armies in Galicia. The Austrian right wing was turned and cut to pieces. The Russians took 30,000 prisoners. Along the Vistula, where the Russians attacked the Austrian left wing, fortune fluctuated for a little time, until the arrival of a strong body of reinforcements enabled the Russians to make an offensive movement of overwhelming effect and to drive back the enemy and capture a great number of cannon. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1914

headline: China Authorizes Local Governments to Issue Bonds
abstract: The lifting of a 20-year ban represents a fundamentally different approach to a chronic problem: how to finance projects like roads and bridges without unsustainable levels of debt.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Finance Ministry released on Monday a long list of amendments to the country’s budget law that included removing a 20-year ban on local and regional governments from issuing bonds.

headline: Drone Developers Consider Obstacles That Cannot Be Flown Around
abstract: With the recent demonstration of a drone-based delivery system by Google, the tech industry’s enthusiasm for the devices seems undimmed — but some issues will be difficult to solve.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The tech industry’s enthusiasm for building small delivery drones may be getting ahead of figuring out what to do with them.

headline: Is Rational Water Management Finally Emerging in Dry California?
abstract: California legislators, and farmers, begin to adjust well-drilling practices to suit a drier reality.
lead_paragraph: I encourage you to read Felicity Barringer’s article on California’s effort (finally!) to exert some control on groundwater pumping.

headline: Seeking Facts, Justices Settle for What Briefs Tell Them
abstract: The justices are hungry for the data in amicus briefs, but a law professor argues that some of the briefs cite questionable materials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court received more than 80 friend-of-the-court briefs in the Hobby Lobby case. Most of these filings, also called amicus briefs, were dull and repetitive recitations of familiar legal arguments.

headline: A Twitter Full of Made-Up Words, an Avant-Garde Fashion Instagram and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.

headline: Christie Studies Foreign Affairs for a 2016 Test
abstract: Aides to the New Jersey governor say his journey to Mexico is about economic ties and commitment to Hispanic voters back home, but it will also offer him a chance to demonstrate a grasp of international affairs as he considers a run for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: A few days after Russian forces invaded Crimea, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was asked at a confidential meeting of Republican activists how he would have handled the situation differently from President Obama.

headline: High Health Plan Deductibles Weigh Down More Employees
abstract: Just as employers replaced pensions with retirement savings plans, more large companies appear to be making a similar cost-sharing shift with health plans.
lead_paragraph: Anita Maina was working on an arts and crafts project she found on Pinterest — creating a table out of wood and cork — when she ripped off a fingernail while removing staples from a piece of wood.

headline: Obama Calls for Minimum Wage Rise and Equal Pay as Elections Approach
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: With the midterm elections in sight, President Obama went to Milwaukee to try to refocus attention on an economic policy issue that could help his party.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — President Obama on Monday renewed his call to raise the federal minimum wage and to protect the right to equal pay for women as the midterm elections come into sight.

headline: Yves Carcelle’s Legacy
abstract: After his death yesterday, Yves Carcelle, the longtime chief executive of Louis Vuitton, is being remembered for his approach to both his brand and his professional relationships.
lead_paragraph: News of the death yesterday of Yves Carcelle, the longtime chief executive of Louis Vuitton who helped create one of the cornerstones upon which the modern luxury industry was built, has hit his former colleagues and competitors hard.

headline: From Afar, the United States Seems at Odds With Its Ideals
abstract: A mysterious sign at the protests in Ferguson, Mo., bespoke a larger truth: America has lost influence by failing to embody its own creeds.
lead_paragraph: Among the tear gas and the milk, the battle tanks and the upraised hands, the bottle bombs and the tender embraces, the protests in Ferguson, Mo., brought out a mysterious sign. The sign bobbed in the crowd one evening. Like so many tenuous claims, it even got to be on CNN. No one knew much about the sign, which made it more ominous. The sign said, “ISIS here.”

headline: Business Fliers on a Budget, and Seats That Don’t Budge
abstract: As tensions over cramped conditions flare on planes, seats that do not recline may begin to show a certain appeal.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — BEN BALDANZA, chief executive of Spirit Airlines, does not seek out business travelers. Nor does Andrew C. Levy, president of Allegiant Air.

headline: U.N. to Send Team to Iraq for Inquiry on ISIS Acts
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The council adopted a resolution without a vote, calling for a team to be sent to Iraq to look into killings and other atrocities.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations Human Rights Council decided Monday to send a fact-finding team to Iraq to investigate possible war crimes by Islamic extremists after hearing senior human rights officials detail mass killings and other atrocities committed “on an unimaginable scale.”

headline: Politics-Minded Marine Group Targets ‘Ocean Enemy #1’
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Law and Legislation', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Oceans and Seas', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An ocean conservation group dives into the gritty world of congressional politics.
lead_paragraph: Randy Olson, who shifted long ago from an academic career in marine biology to a focus on filmmaking, science communication and effective storytelling, offered this “Your Dot” contribution on Ocean Champions. This group has the simple – if daunting — goal of electing or re-electing lawmakers who fight for the oceans. Congressional politics is a rough-and-tumble arena and the group, as Olson describes in the context of a Florida race, is not afraid to play hard. Here’s his piece:

headline: Ants on a Triangle
abstract: From Google’s Peter Norvig: a puzzle about colliding ants.
lead_paragraph: The first of our challenges this week came out of a recent conversation I had with Peter Norvig, director of research at Google. (Are you on fire to learn programming? Check out Dr. Norvig’s Teach Yourself Programming in Ten Years.) This simple puzzle has plenty of room for exploration, so let’s jump in. It’s time for —

headline: Man, 20, Is Charged With Fatal Stabbing in S. I. Home Invasion
abstract: A man, 67, was killed and his wife was seriously wounded during a robbery Sunday night; the police said they had a suspect in custody.
lead_paragraph: A man was charged on Monday with killing a man and seriously injuring his wife in a home invasion on Sunday night on Staten Island, the police said.

headline: Israeli Couscous, Eggplant and Tomato Gratin
abstract: An eggplant Parmesan of sorts on a bed of Israeli couscous is a good way to use the fresh tomato sauce you’ve made over the summer, though canned tomatoes will work, too.
lead_paragraph: This is an eggplant Parmesan of sorts on top of a bed of Israeli couscous. If you’ve made fresh tomato sauce over the summer or you’re still finding wonderful tomatoes at the farmers’ market, use fresh tomato sauce; otherwise, use canned tomatoes for your marinara sauce. You can substitute cooked grains for the Israeli couscous; if you don’t tolerate gluten, try the recipe using cooked brown rice. I like to use Japanese or baby Italian eggplants.

headline: Israeli Couscous with Sautéed Cherry Tomatoes and Basil
abstract: A simple, quick dish with few ingredients and lots of flavors.
lead_paragraph: This is a simple dish with few ingredients and lots of flavor. The sauce, inspired by Melissa Clark’s Pasta with Burst Cherry Tomatoes, is incredibly sweet and wraps itself around each nugget of couscous deliciously. Cherry tomatoes break down in a hot pan in about five minutes, collapsing just enough to release some juice, which quickly thickens and caramelizes a bit. You want the tomatoes to stay mostly intact so you don’t have skins floating in sauce, but you need to cook them long enough to achieve the caramelized flavor that makes a tomato sauce sweet.

headline: Israeli Couscous, Bean and Tomato Salad
abstract: Finely chopped tomatoes seasoned with garlic, balsamic vinegar and basil serve as dressing and vegetale in this main dish salad.
lead_paragraph: 3/4 pound ripe, sweet tomatoes, finely chopped (about 1 1/3 cups chopped)

headline: Romaine Salad with Couscous Confetti
abstract: A lemony, colorful mix of chopped peppers and couscous adds substance to this romaine salad.
lead_paragraph: This is a lemony, colorful mix of romaine, couscous and peppers. You can use regular couscous or Israeli couscous. I categorize this as a salad with grains rather than a grain salad (I know, couscous isn’t a grain, but it plays a grainy role here), as there’s more lettuce than couscous.

headline: Brown Rice and Barley Salad with Sprouted Red Lentils and Green Beans
abstract: This hearty salad, with a creamy, spicy dressing, can be made with a number of different grains.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been making iterations of this hearty whole grain salad tossed with a creamy, curry-spiced dressing since my earliest days of vegetarian cooking. My choice of grains for this version was a function of what I found in my pantry and my refrigerator: enough brown rice and barley to combine for a salad but not enough for a more substantial dish. Farro or spelt would also work. The split red lentils, soaked just long enough to soften and begin to sprout, contribute color and texture along with their grassy flavor. Tossing the grains with lemon juice while they’re still warm intensifies the flavors.

headline: Solar Company Seeks Stiff U.S. Tariffs to Deter Chinese Spying
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Solar Energy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: An Oregon-based solar company is proposing that punitive tariffs be imposed on Chinese manufacturers that have benefited from online espionage.
lead_paragraph: In the daunting battle against corporate online espionage worldwide, one major solar company wants to deploy a powerful and novel weapon: higher tariffs.

headline: Supporting South Carolina Football
abstract: Images of the Gamecocks’ supporters on the football team’s opening night, including of the donors Joe and Lisa Rice and the university’s tailgating scene.
lead_paragraph: Images of the Gamecocks’ supporters on the football team’s opening night, including of the donors Joe and Lisa Rice and the university’s tailgating scene.

headline: Parents Who Left Britain With Ill Son Fight Order to Return
abstract: The parents of Ashya King, 5, who has a brain tumor, attended an extradition hearing in Spain, where they had taken their son after leaving a British hospital against doctors’ orders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The wrenching tale of a British boy with a brain tumor and his parents, who were arrested after fleeing the country with him to seek treatment abroad, entered a new phase on Monday as the parents attended an extradition hearing in Madrid and refused to return to Britain.

headline: A Photographer’s Paradise in America
abstract: Soon after arriving in New York in the mid-1960’s, Jean-Pierre Laffont discovered that — unlike anywhere else — his new neighbors respected him and his profession.
lead_paragraph: Soon after arriving in New York in the mid-1960’s, Jean-Pierre Laffont discovered that — unlike anywhere else — his new neighbors respected him and his profession.

headline: On Rockaway Reef, Taking Dinner to Go, on the Point of a Spear
keywords: ['Fishing, Sport', 'Boats and Boating', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Series']
abstract: Eschewing the traditional rod and reel, spear fishermen dive about 40 feet under brown-green water to capture bass, porgies and triggerfish.
lead_paragraph: Aboard a vessel known as the Spearboat on a recent Monday afternoon, the squeak of rubber fins on a fiberglass floor mixed with the wheeze of divers taking in big gulps of air. Tanned hands rubbed diluted hair conditioner onto the inside of neoprene suits. The boat’s captain, a steely Russian immigrant named Yuri Krainov, eyes striped by sunglass tan lines, quieted the engine as he steered toward a spot over the artificial Rockaway Reef, in the waters near Breezy Point.

headline: A Lab Among the Leaves
abstract: To prove a decades-old hypothesis about how nutrients are transported in plants, a biologist set up shop 40 feet high in a red oak tree.
lead_paragraph: To prove a decades-old hypothesis about how nutrients are transported in plants, a biologist set up shop 40 feet high in a red oak tree.

headline: In Interviews, 3 Americans Held in North Korea Plead for U.S. Help
abstract: The three were interviewed by CNN and The Associated Press, and the choreography of the interviews suggested that North Korea wanted to use the prisoners as bargaining leverage.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea granted two United States news organizations interviews with three incarcerated Americans on Monday, with each prisoner apologizing for violating its laws and beseeching Washington to send a high-level emissary to negotiate their release.

headline: Exploring a Tree One Cell at a Time
abstract: A 20-year quest to prove a longstanding hypothesis about how nutrients are transported may come to an end thanks to tiny needles that probe leaves 40 feet up an oak tree.
lead_paragraph: PETERSHAM, Mass. — Not every scientist would choose to spend a peaceful summer Sunday morning perched on a jittery scaffold 40 feet up a red oak tree, peering through a microscope to jab a leaf with a tiny glass needle filled with oil.

headline: The Role of Social Media in Wiping Out Passenger Pigeons, and Conserving Species Now
abstract: Social media helped push the passenger pigeon to extinction. Now they may help forestall some species’ vanishing.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:15 p.m. | As you may have noted, this is the centennial of the extinction, on Sept. 1, 1914, of the passenger pigeon, which once darkened skies in flocks of a billion or more birds. First, here’s a look back at one of the odder ramifications in 1937 — a market in rare passenger pigeon eggs:

headline: Giving Robots That Human Touch, How Trees Really Work, Low Carb Versus Low Fat
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Oils and Fats', 'Carbohydrates', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Robots may already think faster than we do, but they are just starting to be able to move like us; one researcher has set out to prove an 84-year-old hypothesis about how trees move nutrients around; a lower-carb, higher-fat diet may be better for you than a low-fat diet.
lead_paragraph: Robots may already think faster than we do, but they are just starting to be able to move like us; one researcher has set out to prove an 84-year-old hypothesis about how trees move nutrients around; a lower-carb, higher-fat diet may be better for you than a low-fat diet.

headline: An Icy Answer to the Mystery of the Moving Death Valley Stones
keywords: ['Rock and Stone', 'Research', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: At last, researchers have figured out the phenomenon known as the “sailing stones,” and the trails they leave, in the desert.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have solved a longstanding mystery that has befuddled scientists and tourists alike: why rocks on a dry lake bed in Death Valley National Park in California occasionally move.

headline: In Performance | Conrad Tao
abstract: The pianist and composer Conrad Tao performs the third movement of Prokofiev’s Seventh Piano Sonata.
lead_paragraph: The pianist and composer Conrad Tao performs the third movement of Prokofiev’s Seventh Piano Sonata.

headline: Inflation, Septaphobia, and the Shock Doctrine
abstract: False consciousness among the 1 percent?
lead_paragraph: The bad news from Europe is a reminder that the basic insight some of us have been trying to convey, mostly in vain, ever since 2008 remains valid: the great danger facing advanced economies is that governments and central banks will do too little, not too much. The risk of elevated inflation or fiscal difficulties is dwarfed by the risk of ending up trapped in a deflationary vortex. This view has been overwhelmingly supported by recent experience — if you acted on what they were saying on CNBC or the WSJ editorial page, you would have lost a lot of money. Yet the power of the hard money/fiscal austerity orthodoxy (yes, market monetarists want one without the other, but they have no constituency) remains immense. Why?

headline: Yves Carcelle, Empire Builder at Louis Vuitton, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Carcelle, who led the Louis Vuitton brand and later ran LVMH’s fashion division, was the main architect of an expansion into Asia and other international markets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Yves Carcelle, the charismatic executive who transformed Louis Vuitton from a staid French maker of handbags and travel trunks into one of the world’s most recognizable luxury brands, died on Sunday in Paris. He was 66.

headline: Novak Djokovic and Serena Williams Escape U.S. Open Heat as Quickly as Possible
abstract: Serena Williams reached the quarterfinals at a major for the first time this year, but Eugenie Bouchard was upset. Novak Djokovic won and will play Andy Murray.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s name had just been announced as the winner at Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday afternoon when Novak Djokovic, the No. 1 seed in the men’s draw, seemed to wake to the realization that he was battling more than just the veteran Philipp Kohlschreiber.

headline: Kate Bush Bombards British Album Chart
abstract: The singer’s return to performing has sent eight of her albums to the British Top 40.
lead_paragraph: Kate Bush set the bar high for herself when her 1978 debut single, “Wuthering Heights,” topped the British music charts, making her the first woman to have a self-written No. 1 in the United Kingdom. More than three decades later, Ms. Bush, 56, is setting records again.

headline: How Fighting in Pakistan Affects War Against Polio
abstract: While some Taliban factions have banned vaccinations since 2012, fleeing refugees often encounter vaccinators.
lead_paragraph: Fierce fighting in Pakistan is harming and helping the country’s drive to eradicate polio.

headline: 1939: German Troops Invade Poland
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: War breaks out in Europe in 1939.
lead_paragraph: War broke out in Europe yesterday at about dawn. Nazi German troops invaded Poland — Warsaw sources said on four fronts — and, last night, with bombing planes and tanks were striving to break down the resistance of Marshal Smigly Rydz’s armies. As Warsaw invoked its pact with France and Britain, both nations prepared to carry out their pledge by decreeing general mobilization and warning Hitler the promise to Poland would be fulfilled if he did not halt hostilities and order his men back to the Reich. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1939

headline: Carrying the Burden of Longevity
abstract: Meryl Comer has written a heartbreaking account of caring for both her husband, who has been debilitated by early-onset Alzheimer’s disease, and her mother, who has the late-onset variety.
lead_paragraph: I met Meryl Comer once, briefly, at a conference, and recall the juxtaposition of her sleek beauty and harrowing personal story: her husband, once chief of hematology and oncology at the National Institutes of Health, debilitated by early-onset Alzheimer’s disease, and her mother with the late-onset variety, both living in her suburban Maryland home, under her care.

headline: Tiny, Vast Windows Into Human DNA
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Fruit Flies', 'Worms', 'ANIMALS', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: In the fruit fly and the worm Caenorhabditis elegans, scientists have found a choreography of genes strikingly similar to human DNA, with the potential for insights into genetic disorders.
lead_paragraph: In the history of biology, two little animals loom large.

headline: Carol Vadnais, All-Star and Stalwart on the Rangers, Dies at 68
abstract: Vadnais, who began his career when the N.H.L. had six teams, won Stanley Cup titles with Montreal in 1968 and Boston in 1972 before playing with the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: Carol Vadnais, a six-time N.H.L. All-Star who played for Stanley Cup championship teams with the Montreal Canadiens and the Boston Bruins and who became a mainstay of the Rangers’ defense in the 1970s and early ’80s, died on Sunday in Laval, Quebec. He was 68.

headline: Geckos on Mission Die Aboard Russian Spacecraft
abstract: Five geckos launched into space for an experiment on sexual reproduction in near-zero gravity were found dead after their spacecraft returned to earth, the Russian space agency said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Five geckos launched into space by Russia for an experiment on sexual reproduction in near-zero gravity were found dead on Monday after their spacecraft returned to earth, the Russian space agency Roscosmos announced in a statement.

headline: British Leader’s Plan Targets Jihadists’ Passports
abstract: In announcing new police powers, Prime Minister David Cameron was trying to show toughness in the face of young British Muslims’ going off to fight in Syria and Iraq,
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron, trying to show toughness in the face of young British Muslims’ going off to fight in Syria and Iraq, proposed legislation on Monday that would give the police the power to seize the passports of Britons suspected of having traveled abroad to fight with militant groups.

headline: Patient Voices: Pancreatic Cancer
abstract: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Seven men and women speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Seven men and women speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.

headline: 2 Sides Cite Discrimination as Battle on Texas Voting Law Heads to Court
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Identification Devices', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Justice Department lawyers say a law requiring voters to show photo identification is unfair to blacks and Hispanics, while Texas argues that Southern states are being unfairly targeted.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Minority groups and Democrats in Texas have loudly opposed a state law requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification before casting their ballots. But one of the law’s biggest critics can be found not in Texas but in Washington — Eric H. Holder Jr., the United States attorney general.

headline: NATO Weighs Rapid Response Force for Eastern Europe
abstract: NATO leaders are expected to respond to increased Russian intervention in Ukraine by establishing a force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Ukrainian leaders warned on Monday of “a great war” with Russia, NATO leaders meeting in Wales this week were expected to endorse their most concrete response yet to increased Russian military intervention in Ukraine: establishing a rapid-reaction force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe, officials of the alliance said.

headline: With Coughlin Preaching Patience, a Rookie Receiver Is Taking Time to Heal
abstract: A week away from the Giants’ season opener, Coach Tom Coughlin told the injured Odell Beckham Jr., “Whatever it takes to get over this, let’s do it.”
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For several months, Tom Coughlin’s mood when it comes to Odell Beckham Jr.’s nagging hamstring injury has mirrored the attitude of most Giants fans.

headline: From J’ouvert to the Parade
abstract: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West Indian American Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West Indian American Day Parade.

headline: From J’ouvert to the Parade
abstract: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West American Indian Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: Celebrations in Brooklyn on Monday highlighted the rich cultural traditions of the West American Indian Day Parade.

headline: Libyan Militias Seize Control of Capital as Chaos Rises
abstract: A new stage in a power struggle has resulted in rival centers of government, one in Tripoli, and the other in Tobruk.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The government of Libya said Monday that it had lost control of its ministries to a coalition of militias that had taken over the capital, Tripoli, in another milestone in the disintegration of the state.

headline: If 2 New Yorkers Shared a Cab ...
abstract: A team of mathematicians and engineers has calculated that if taxi riders were willing to share a cab, New York City could reduce the current fleet of 13,500 taxis up to 40 percent.
lead_paragraph: It may be anathema to New Yorkers. But a team of mathematicians and engineers has calculated that if taxi riders were willing to share a cab, New York City could reduce the current fleet of 13,500 taxis up to 40 percent, in that way unclogging traffic, conserving fuel and fighting air pollution.

headline: Lars von Trier Returning to TV
abstract: Mr. Von Trier’s English-language series will be titled “The House That Jack Built,” but little else is known about it.
lead_paragraph: The Danish director Lars von Trier is planning to make his first television series in two decades, a producer for the project recently announced. The English-language series will be titled “The House That Jack Built” and produced by Louise Vesth, who first spoke about the project while promoting her latest collaboration with Mr. von Trier, a five-and-a-half-hour director’s cut of his film “Nymphomaniac,” at the Venice Film Festival.

headline: Fast-Food Workers Seeking $15 Wage Are Planning Civil Disobedience
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Minimum Wage', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Labor organizers hope to recruit home health care aides to join in protests in 100 cities on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The next round of strikes by fast-food workers demanding higher wages is scheduled for Thursday, and this time labor organizers plan to increase the pressure by staging widespread civil disobedience and having thousands of home-care workers join the protests.

headline: A Playwright Named Desire: The Battle for Art and Sanity
abstract: John Lahr’s biography “Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh” draws on a wealth of letters and journals to explore the synergy between his life and his plays.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of biography, the writer Justin Kaplan was known to say, is: “Shoot the widow.” But John Lahr’s new biography, “Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh,” originated with something closer to a literary commando raid.

headline: A Call for a Low-Carb Diet That Embraces Fat
abstract: In a finding that upends long-held notions about a healthy diet, a major study shows that avoiding carbohydrates and eating more fat contributes to weight loss and fewer cardiovascular risks.
lead_paragraph: People who avoid carbohydrates and eat more fat, even saturated fat, lose more body fat and have fewer cardiovascular risks than people who follow the low-fat diet that health authorities have favored for decades, a major new study shows.

headline: Painful Class Conflict and Youthful Disaffection: Everybody Sing!
abstract: “Dead Behind These Eyes” is a karaoke play that uses video, dance and lyrics to tell a story in a small space.
lead_paragraph: In a black-walled basement room at an East Village karaoke bar, we received the welcome news: No one would be forced to sing. The makers of “Dead Behind These Eyes,” which is billed as a karaoke play, understand the need in this era of immersive theater to keep the bashful from bolting.

headline: Renter’s Insurance Offers a Hedge Against Dorm-Room Mayhem
abstract: College students would do well to make sure their personal belongings are covered in the event of fire, theft, vandalism or natural disaster.
lead_paragraph: In the excitement of heading off to college, students may not stop to think about whether they need insurance for all the possessions they’re bringing with them. But that laptop, stereo and other expensive devices — not to mention textbooks — may be worth protecting with a renter’s policy.

headline: Country Gal Feels the Pressure of Being Tough
abstract: The singer Miranda Lambert took her “Platinum Tour” to Bethel, N.Y., mixing noble sentiments and rowdy poses.
lead_paragraph: BETHEL, N.Y. —  Miranda Lambert has proved, over a decade-long major-label career, that vulnerability and nuance can share an agenda with her higher-proof concerns: the heady blend of whiskey, tobacco and reprisal that has defined a country-spitfire persona. She’s now one of the biggest names in her field, and evidently regards her platform as a chance for something greater than self-definition.

headline: A Stroll Among the Racks
abstract: “Dressing America: Tales From the Garment Center” tells stories about the people who built New York’s fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: They still give tours of the New York garment district. In “Dressing America: Tales From the Garment Center,” a one-hour documentary Tuesday on WNET in New York, Michael Kaback, a tour guide, points out important buildings: 498, 500 and 512. If you were part of the rag trade, as people in the business seem to love to call it, you never bothered with the rest of the address (Seventh Avenue), he explains. But you may also notice the people walking on the sidewalk behind Mr. Kaback, almost all dressed in T-shirts and jeans.

headline: New Music From Earth, Yob and Jeezy
abstract: Among new albums, Earth’s “Primitive and Deadly,” Yob’s “Clearing the Path to Ascend” and Jeezy’s “Seen It All.”
lead_paragraph: EARTH

headline: A Life Lost in Translation Without Much to Translate
abstract: “The Dog,” by Joseph O’Neill, is a first-person narrative of an expat lawyer in the Persian Gulf whose life is going nowhere.
lead_paragraph: Like his critically acclaimed 2008 best seller, “Netherland,” Joseph O’Neill’s new novel, “The Dog,” concerns a man who finds himself increasingly isolated after the unraveling of a relationship, and stranded in a foreign city.

headline: Readers’ Thoughts on Spotless Minds and Big Weddings
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Social science

headline: A Performance Hybrid as Unexpected as Dance on the Radio
abstract: “Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host” is an unconventional collaboration between Ira Glass and the choreographer Monica Bill Barnes.
lead_paragraph: Things not usually found in a modern dance show in New York: batons, bubbles, disco balls, tinsel and public-radio personalities. But those and other sparkly accouterments were on hand recently in a Brooklyn studio where the dancers Monica Bill Barnes and Anna Bass, in Rat Pack-style suits one minute and slinky sequin gowns with sneakers the next, rehearsed for the New York premiere of their show “Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host,” at Town Hall, Sept. 10 to 12.

headline: The New History Wars
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Education', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Students need an unvarnished picture of our past and the skills to understand and interpret that picture.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WITH the news dominated by stories of Americans dying at home and abroad, it might seem trivial to debate how history is taught in our schools. But if we want students to understand what is happening in Missouri or the Middle East, they need an unvarnished picture of our past and the skills to understand and interpret that picture. People don’t kill one another just for recreation. They have reasons. Those reasons are usually historical.

headline: Why New York City Opposed Abe Lincoln
abstract: In the 1864 election, Gotham delivered nearly twice as many votes to the president’s opponent, George B. McClellan.
lead_paragraph: New York may have been the largest city in the Union during the Civil War, but most of its inhabitants were strongly opposed to the conflict – if not downright hostile to the Union’s war aims. During the secession crisis of 1861, the pro-Confederate mayor Fernando Wood even proposed seceding from the Union and establishing itself as an independent city-state, neither for nor against the North or the South.

headline: The Pleasures of Drinking, and the Risks
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Mark Bittman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Idealism on Screen and Behind the Scenes
abstract: The Telluride Film Festival features several notable films, including “Mr. Turner,” “The Imitation Game” and “Wild.”
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — “There is no place for cynicism in the reviewing of art.” Those words — a line of dialogue from “Mr. Turner,” Mike Leigh’s splendid, sprawling film about the life and loves of an artist in mid-19th-century England — are a fine motto at any time, but they are especially germane in the season of film festival frenzy. Looking at movies and thinking about the prizes they might win is a relatively benign and locally contagious form of cynicism. The antidote is the idealism, the sincere love of the cinema, that also flourishes here, nearly 9,000 feet above sea level and almost six months away from the Oscars.

headline: A Mission for Remote-Controlled Bugs
keywords: ['Butterflies and Moths', 'Remote Control Systems', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Researchers are working with living moths and cockroaches on a project that could make them useful in searches through rubble.
lead_paragraph: Researchers from North Carolina State University are trying to turn a living moth into a remote-controlled robot, or biobot. By attaching tiny electrodes to the moth, they can monitor the electrical signals the moth uses flight to communicate with its muscles. The researchers, also working on a similar project with cockroaches, believe that insect biobots could be used to search through rubble during rescue missions.

lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — For decades, the pesh merga have enjoyed a fearsome reputation as unconquered mountain warriors, a storied band of guerrilla fighters who became the official guardians of the Kurdish enclave in northern Iraq. But when fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria rolled into Kurdistan in August, the pesh merga fled the front line, just a half-hour’s drive from the territorial capital, Erbil.

For the next half-hour, the players dutifully signed their names for the smattering of fans who came to the tiny gym here on the outskirts of town.

abstract: This summer, the bad guys have looked energetic while the good guys have looked tired, putting the norms of civilization under threat.

As Henry Kissinger said, once you get in government you are not building up human capital; you are just spending it down. People in senior positions are simply too busy to learn fundamental new viewpoints. Their minds are locked within the ones they brought into power.

abstract: Congress once acted productively in a bipartisan spirit to protect clean air, clean water and endangered species. What happened?

For those with long memories, it also commemorates a time when Congress could act productively in a bipartisan spirit that yielded not only these two laws but, within a few short years, landmark protections for clean air, clean water and endangered species.

headline: The New Political Rating System That Shows the Stakes This Year
abstract: In most of the closest congressional races, the two candidates are far apart ideologically.

Yet the race in Iowa is worth an extra dash of attention, not only because it’s been among the most entertaining – full of target practice, hog castration and the Koch brothers – but also because of the ideological distance between the two candidates. It’s even bigger than in many other races.

headline: Father Seeks Answers in Death of Son, Who Police Say Shot Himself While Cuffed

How did he die?” he asked as he stood in the morgue of Iberia Parish, a county in southern Louisiana best known for producing sugar cane and Tabasco hot sauce.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The scene was apocalyptic: a torrent of water from a ruptured pipe valve bursting through Sunset Boulevard, hurling chunks of asphalt 40 feet into the air as it closed down the celebrated thoroughfare and inundated the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles. By the time emergency crews patched the pipe, 20 million gallons of water had cascaded across the college grounds.

headline: Universal Pre-K Takes Off

lead_paragraph: The start of public school on Thursday in New York City should be the usual merry scramble of chattering children and stressed (or relieved) parents. There will also be something new: a fresh crop of 4-year-olds, more than 50,000, embarking on the first day of free, full-day, citywide, city-run prekindergarten.

headline: For Penn Station Diners, Nowhere to Go but Up

Others make it as far as the soft pretzels, sagging meekly behind glass, or the pizza shops whose fumbled marinara sauce has fused semipermanently to the floor.

headline: Israel: U.N. Chief Criticizes Seizing of West Bank Land
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations added his voice on Monday to the criticism of Israel over its seizing of nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land in a Jewish settlement bloc near Bethlehem.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations added his voice on Monday to the criticism of Israel over its seizing of nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land in a Jewish settlement bloc near Bethlehem. Israel’s action on Sunday, Mr. Ban said in a statement, “risks paving the way for further settlement activity, which — as the United Nations has reiterated on many occasions — is illegal under international law and runs totally counter to the pursuit of a two-state solution.” Palestinians, who aspire to create a state on territories captured by Israel in the 1967 war, denounced the new land seizure by Israel and said it would further aggravate relations, less than a week after a cease-fire agreement brokered by Egypt was reached to halt 50 days of fighting between Israeli forces and Palestinian militants in Gaza. American and British officials also criticized the land seizing, calling it counterproductive, while Egypt’s Foreign Ministry said it would have “negative consequences on the peace process.”

headline: Champion Shows Few Signs of Slowing
abstract: Serena Williams’s performance Monday was inconsistent, a little sloppy, and it didn’t really matter.
lead_paragraph: There she was warming up in the midday sun, in pancakes of humidity that called to mind midsummer Manila, wearing a black petticoat. Just to look at her smacking balls in that garb was to feel the sweat start to trickle down your back.

The hernias often return, but major complications are rare. Hospital stays are usually short.

headline: After Years of Frostiness, a Selective Co-op Tries a Friendlier Facade
abstract: River House has been a difficult place to afford and an almost impossible place to gain board approval. But with luxury rivals now blanketing the city, the place is slowly softening its image.
lead_paragraph: Even two or three years ago, it would have been all but impossible to write this column. At River House, the mythic and monolithic co-op overlooking the East River, the only thing stouter than the limestone brick walls towering above East 52nd Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive were the building’s standards. Those inside would call them traditions; everybody else might regard them as pretensions. Almost no one got in, and news barely escaped.

lead_paragraph: “People don’t think about the fact that there are pipes under the ground that are 100 years old until one blows. You don’t hear a politician say, ‘I’m going to make your pipes work.’”

headline: The New Unofficial Scent of New York City
keywords: ['Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Next month, Joya will unveil a new perfume oil named for the odorloss Foxglove plant and inspired by Manhattan's Central Park.
lead_paragraph: As a co-founder of the international fragrance design trade show Elements, Frederick Bouchardy has sniffed countless New York-inspired scents over the years — “but I never found one that smelled like New York to me,” the Manhattan native says. Next month, Bouchardy, who is also the brains behind the Brooklyn-based fragrance studio Joya, offers his olfactory take on his hometown with the launch of a new perfume oil, Foxglove. “I grew up on the Upper West Side across the street from Central Park,” he says, “so the Park was my initial muse, and then it became an exploration of the entire botanical history of all the parks and wetlands here.”

The investigation was expected to reach its first target as early as Tuesday, people briefed on the matter said, with Mr. Schneiderman’s office taking aim at Evans Bank, a regional lender whose business in the Buffalo area dates to 1920, accusing it of denying mortgages to African-Americans regardless of their credit.

Why, then, the vociferous protests?

headline: 1889: British Traders in East Africa
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A correspondent compares British and German settlements in East Africa in 1889.
lead_paragraph: ZANZIBAR — I have just returned from Mombasa, the headquarters of the Imperial British East Africa Trading Company, and I am pleased to be able to chronicle what a difference exists in the state of affairs at that place, and at the German settlements further south. If one excepts a few turbulent spirits, the native population of Mombasa may be said to be absolutely quiet, and to be very well disposed indeed towards the Company and its servants. I attribute the excellent feeling that there predominates between natives and Europeans, at a time when the entire coast line near Zanzibar is very much disturbed, owing to the repeated aggression of the Germans. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1889

headline: 10 Years On, Scaffolding in Harlem Is Still a Shelter for Noxious Acts
abstract: The structure has become a favored spot for drug deals and neighborhood drama, angering locals who have been trying for years to get it removed.
lead_paragraph: Most nights, Roy Scott Jr. sleeps in a wheelchair, with his left arm draped over a blue scaffolding pipe, his graying curls shielded from rain by the rusting planks overhead. This is not the reason that the tunnel-like wood-and-steel structures called sidewalk sheds shroud walkways across New York City. They are supposed to catch debris from repairs overhead.

headline: New Life for Some Pulp Fiction by Gore Vidal
abstract: “Thieves Fall Out,” written by Gore Vidal under the name Cameron Kay and published in 1953, will come out in April in a new edition.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, when Gore Vidal was at the start of his career as a novelist, he did what lots of writers do to make ends meet. Between literary novels he cranked out pulp fiction, written quickly under a pseudonym – or, in Vidal’s case, three pseudonyms. As Edgar Box he wrote three mystery novels, which were reprinted with his approval during his lifetime (he died in 2012). He wrote a romance novel under the name Katherine Everard that remains a rarity. And as Cameron Kay — a name he borrowed from a great uncle — he wrote “Thieves Fall Out,” a crime thriller set in Egypt during the 1952 revolution there.

headline: Airstrike in Somalia by U.S. Forces Targets Shabab Leader

headline: The Economic Price of Colleges’ Failures
abstract: Many students do not learn critical-thinking skills in college, and they’re suffering in the job market, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the sociologists Richard Arum and Josipa Roksa dropped a bomb on American higher education. Their groundbreaking book, “Academically Adrift,” found that many students experience “limited or no learning” in college. Today, they released a follow-up study, tracking the same students for two years after graduation, into the workplace, adult relationships and civic life. The results suggest that recent college graduates who are struggling to start careers are being hamstrung by their lack of learning.
