lead_paragraph: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, said that the “party of war” in Kiev was trying to disrupt peace negotiations between Russia and Ukraine.

headline: Today in Small Business: Made in the U.S.A.
abstract: Women are opening businesses in Detroit. More workers are claiming wage theft. And the advantages of being employed by your children.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Some of New York’s Signature Dishes Are Yours to Take Out
abstract: At many of the city’s best restaurants, popular dishes are available in a takeout version — if you go get them yourself.
lead_paragraph: A few of the city’s best restaurants quietly offer some of their specialties in a takeout version that can be ordered for home to serve one or two, or a party. But you’ll need a bicycle, because they don’t deliver.

headline: T Time | Hotelier Sean MacPherson
abstract: Hotelier Sean MacPherson shows T his newest property, the Ludlow, and reminisces about New York’s Lower East Side in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Hotelier Sean MacPherson shows T his newest property, the Ludlow, and reminisces about New York’s Lower East Side in the 1980s.

headline: Why a Breakup of Citigroup Is Still a Good Idea
abstract: The advantages of splitting up the huge New York bank extend beyond the stock market to global regulators and even taxpayers, Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Breakingviews proposed an “extreme idea” to Citigroup’s then-leader, Charles O. Prince III. The $240 billion market capitalization of the New York bank was lower than the worth of its parts valued separately. By splitting into three separate units, the idea was, Mr. Prince could hand shareholders an extra $50 billion or so, the equivalent of one entire U.S. Bancorp at the time.

headline: Ads for Marathon Tap Into New York City Spirit
abstract: “Get your New York on,” the campaign, by Rage, Grace & Partners urges.
lead_paragraph: A campaign to promote the next running of a premier marathon is getting into a New York state of mind.

headline: Obama to Visit Estonia to Reassure Baltic Allies Over Russia
abstract: President Obama’s trip, on the eve of a NATO summit meeting, is intended to show Baltic leaders that the United States and Europe are serious about defending them.
lead_paragraph: KEFLAVIK, Iceland — With concerns rising about Russia’s intervention in Ukraine, President Obama will use a visit to neighboring Estonia on Wednesday to reassure fretful allies that the United States and Europe are serious about defending them from a newly aggressive Russia.

headline: Palestinian Leaders Seek Actions in Security Council and Court
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A senior aide to Mahmoud Abbas said he would seek a Security Council resolution to compel Israel to withdraw.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Israel’s 50-day war with Palestinian militants in Gaza was a “game changer” that persuaded the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, to shelve the already moribund American-sponsored peace talks and decide to join the International Criminal Court, even if that meant defying the United States, a senior Palestinian leader said Tuesday.

headline: Questions for the Government in an Insider Trading Case
abstract: Catching an insider trader is usually a good thing. But when the investigation results in allowing a crime to take place, that can be troubling, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: What if the government knows a crime is about to take place but does nothing to stop it and instead allows the crime to happen so it can gather additional evidence for a later prosecution? When the crime is insider trading, perhaps the fact that there are no individual victims justifies allowing someone to use confidential information to earn illegal profits. But there is still something troubling when a crime that can be easily stopped is allowed to occur.

headline: ISIS Says It Killed Steven Sotloff After U.S. Strikes in Northern Iraq
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'News and News Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The group released a video showing the beheading of a second American, blaming President Obama for the death and raising the pressure on him to order strikes on the group in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An Islamic militant group released a video on Tuesday showing the second beheading of an American hostage in two weeks and blamed President Obama for the killing. The video raised the pressure on the president to order military strikes on the group in its sanctuary in Syria.

headline: Staten Island Congressman’s Fraud Trial to Start After Fall Elections
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The move by a federal judge clears what could have been a substantial obstacle to Representative Michael G. Grimm’s bid for a third term.
lead_paragraph: The federal fraud trial of Representative Michael G. Grimm will begin on Dec. 1, clearing what could have been a substantial obstacle to his re-election efforts.

headline: New Bars Offer Barrels, Beer and Boilermakers
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Basements and Cellars', 'Bartenders']
abstract: This fall, rooftop, basement and vault are among the sites of the city’s new drinking dens.
lead_paragraph: The demise of one of last fall’s splashiest new bars, the 1970s-themed Golden Cadillac, has created a sort of downtown drinking diaspora. Most of its partners are back in the same space with a new venture, Boilermaker; one, Greg Boehm, is also opening an East Village saloon, Mace, while the former Cadillac barman Giuseppe Gonzalez will unveil Suffolk Arms just blocks away. Three live bars for one dead one? Pretty good bargain, I’m thinking.

headline: Where to Eat, Unwind and Caffeinate Downtown During New York Fashion Week
abstract: Our list of nine can’t-miss new places to visit between shows includes an Italian restaurant imported from the Hamptons, the best bakery in TriBeCa and much more.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week unofficially kicks off tomorrow. And since the shows have become decentralized in recent seasons — with many marquee events now taking place in lower Manhattan —  trekking between runway presentations and store openings also provides ample opportunity to explore what’s new on the downtown food scene. With this in mind, we rounded up the best spots below 14th Street to find the perfect croissant (hint: it’s in an arcade), drink a flat white, slurp oysters atop the deck of a 142-foot schooner, enjoy an al fresco cocktail or savor a breakfast sandwich after midnight.

headline: Meet Two Business Owners With Opposing Views on Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: We invited small-business owners who were willing to open their doors to an elected official for a day to let us know by email. Two owners did.
lead_paragraph: Last month, in a discussion about how raising the minimum wage might affect small companies, we noted that there could be more empathy among elected officials for how entrepreneurs manage their businesses. Inspired by the suggestion that members of Congress ought to try managing a small business for a week, we invited small-business owners who were willing to open their doors to an elected official for a day to let us know by email.

headline: 1914: City Prepares for War Wounded
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A town in France prepares to host wounded soldiers in 1914.
lead_paragraph: AIX-LES-BAINS — In spite of the deadly silence which has reigned here for more than a fortnight now, Aix has not been idle. There is hardly a person here, native or visitor, who has not done a little to help. Wonders have been achieved in all the hotels, schools and garages in establishing hospitals and ‘‘cantines,’’ and everything is now in readiness to receive the wounded. About 1,200 beds are installed, and it is touching to see how much hard work has been done and real sacrifice has been gladly made. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1914

headline: DNA Evidence Clears Two Men in 1983 Murder
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Two mentally disabled half brothers who were convicted in the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl 30 years ago were declared innocent and ordered released by a judge.
lead_paragraph: LUMBERTON, N.C. — Thirty years after their convictions in the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl in rural North Carolina, based on confessions that they quickly repudiated and said were coerced, two mentally disabled half brothers were declared innocent and ordered released Tuesday by a judge here.

headline: Daughter Confirms Joan Rivers Is Still on Life Support
abstract: Melissa Rivers said she and her family were grateful for the support.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers remains on life support on Tuesday, days after she was hospitalized in Manhattan, her daughter, Melissa Rivers, said.

headline: A Virtual Jeff Koons Work to Grace Garage Magazine
abstract: Readers of Garage Magazine can examine a new virtual artwork by Mr. Koons through an app.
lead_paragraph: Garage Magazine, an art, fashion and literary magazine that publishes twice a year, will include a surprise for its readers in its seventh issue, due on Thursday: a virtual art work, created for the publication by Jeff Koons. The work, “Lady Bug,” is virtual in the sense that it can be seen only on mobile devices, by way of the Garage Mag app. Viewers will be able to use the app and their devices to walk around the piece – virtually – and see it from all angles.

headline: Andy Murray Reviews His Place Among the Big 4
abstract: In a Q. and A., Murray spoke about his role in tennis’s Big 4 and his familiarity with his U.S Open quarterfinals opponent, Novak Djokovic, whom he has played 20 times.
lead_paragraph: As Andy Murray reaches the pointy end of the draw at the United States Open, he finds a familiar face in Novak Djokovic waiting in the quarterfinals. Murray and Djokovic have met 20 times, four in Grand Slam finals (each winning twice). In his latest conversation with The New York Times, Murray discusses his role in the so-called Big 4, the four players who have dominated men’s tennis in the past 10 years. In previous interviews at the U.S. Open, Murray has discussed his perspective on this year’s tournament, female coaches in tennis, the idea of an independent Scotland and his favorite stops on the tour. This interview has been condensed and edited.

headline: Putin’s War of Words: A Roundup
abstract: A review of comments by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meant to inspire nationalist support at home and encourage pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the president of the European Commission, “If I wanted to, I could take Kiev in two weeks.”

headline: Nude Photos of Jennifer Lawrence Are Latest Front in Online Privacy Debate
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Celebrities', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: After a trove of nude photos of celebrities was posted online, some champions of anything-goes social media were rueful.
lead_paragraph: Perez Hilton has made a career of posting anything and everything about celebrities and their lives. On Tuesday, he thought better of it.

headline: Active Role in Class Helps Black and First-Generation College Students, Study Says
abstract: A study of college students found that the trend toward more class participation, and away from a traditional lecture-based approach, raised average test scores, with bigger gains for some.
lead_paragraph: The trend away from classes based on reading and listening passively to lectures, and toward a more active role for students, has its most profound effects on black students and those whose parents did not go to college, a new study of college students shows.

headline: Lessons Learned from the Ebola Epidemic
abstract: Global awareness of the Ebola epidemic has not translated into effective action. As organizations such as Samaritan’s Purse and Doctors Without Borders continue to engage in the fight against the deadly virus, here are some lessons learned to date.
lead_paragraph: On July 24, I wrote on this blog that the Ebola epidemic was spinning out of control and pleaded with the international community to join my organization, Samaritan’s Purse, on the front lines of the fight against this deadly disease.

headline: Motorsports: Labor Day Weekend Rewards for Power, DeJoria, Kahne and Márquez
abstract: Will Power won his first IndyCar championship title; Alexis DeJoria beat John Force in the N.H.R.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: Will Power, capping what he said was 15 years of hard, often frustrating work, was officially crowned champion of the IndyCar series on Sunday at an awards ceremony in Los Angeles. Power had clinched the title by finishing ninth in the season finale Saturday in Fontana, Calif. His teammate, Helio Castroneves, needed to win the race to beat Power for the title. He came in second, foiled by a time-consuming stop-and-go penalty for a pit stop infraction. Tony Kanaan won the event.

headline: Creating a Homework Habit
abstract: The real point of homework doesn’t lie in the completion of the homework. It lies in learning how to sit yourself down and get it done.
lead_paragraph: Homework.

headline: Richard Nixon’s Signature Draws Attention to Nu Skin
abstract: A signature on a document in Nu Skin’s latest quarterly filing with the S.E.C. turned out to be a typo, not a blast from the past.
lead_paragraph: Former United States presidents don’t typically become bankers after their time in office. Nor, for that matter, do they come back from the dead.

headline: Pakistani Lawmakers Support Premier
abstract: The lawmakers met in an emergency session to express support for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, after violent protests had appeared to bring the government to the brink of collapse.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani lawmakers met in an emergency session on Tuesday to express support for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, after days of violent protests had appeared to bring the government to the brink of collapse.

headline: Federal Program Helps Keep Some Delinquent Borrowers in Their Homes
abstract: A program to sell delinquent mortgages to private investors is producing modest returns when it comes to keeping borrowers in their homes.
lead_paragraph: A four-year program by a federal housing agency to sell its most delinquent mortgages to private investors is producing modest returns when it comes to keeping those struggling borrowers in their homes.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Cash Gift to Republican Candidates
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Post-McCutcheon, money is everywhere, and most of it is going to Republicans.
lead_paragraph: The instant the Supreme Court demolished overall donation limits in April, the money burst forth from the dam. As The Washington Post reported this morning, more than 300 donors immediately wrote checks beyond the old limit of $123,200, adding $11.6 million to the political system that would not have been allowed earlier.

headline: Fantasy Football: Waiver Wire Picks for Week 1
abstract: A look at players worth considering this week who are likely to be available on your league’s waiver wire.
lead_paragraph: While the rest of your league was busy “winning” your draft (and telling you about it), they were also leaving good players on the waiver wire for Week 1, and possibly beyond.

headline: Book Portrays Eichmann as Evil, but Not Banal
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A German philosopher, Bettina Stangneth, explores the voluminous memoirs of Adolf Eichmann, and her country’s reluctance to prosecute him.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 years after its publication, Hannah Arendt’s “Eichmann in Jerusalem” remains enduringly controversial, racking up a long list of critics who continue to pick apart her depiction of the Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann as an exemplar of “the banality of evil,” a bloodless, nearly mindless bureaucrat who “never realized what he was doing.”

headline: A Delano in Las Vegas
abstract: The Delano Las Vegas hotel, sibling of the Miami Beach original, will open Tuesday with 1,117 suites.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas has hotels that pay homage to Paris and Egypt and Lake Como, Italy. Beginning Tuesday, the new Delano Las Vegas will channel a closer-to-home destination: Miami.

headline: Tony Soprano Is Dead
abstract: Notes on a cultural controversy.
lead_paragraph: After a week away from blogging, I think it’s best to return first to relatively unimportant subjects, and put off writing on Russia, Rotherham, ISIS and other matters until I’m a little more re-acclimated. So here are a few thoughts on a cultural controversy that flared up while I was away, when a writer for Vox, Martha Nochimson, apparently got David Chase on the record saying that Tony Soprano had, in fact, survived the famous cut to black at the end of “The Sopranos” … implying that the blackout was not, in fact, a Tony’s-eye view of the gangster’s own whacking.

headline: Sean MacPherson on His New Hotel, the Ludlow
abstract: The owner of The Ludlow, a new hotel on the Lower East Side, talks about the city’s past and how much it has changed since the ’80s.
lead_paragraph: In the latest installation of our T Time video series, T’s online director Jesse Ashlock interviews Sean MacPherson, the hotelier who created the Maritime and the Jane. MacPherson talks about his new hotel, the Ludlow, located on the Lower East Side, and how the city has changed since the ’80s.

headline: Colts’ Owner Is Suspended and Fined After a Guilty Plea
abstract: The Colts owner Jim Irsay was suspended and fined $500,000 by the N.F.L. on after he pleaded guilty Tuesday to a misdemeanor related to a March traffic stop.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell suspended the Indianapolis Colts owner Jim Irsay on Tuesday for six games and fined him $500,000 for violating the league’s personal conduct policy when he was arrested on the suspicion of being intoxicated while driving near his home in Carmel, Ind. Goodell imposed the punishment hours after Irsay pleaded guilty in court to impaired driving.

headline: Scouting the Scene
abstract: Intent on getting it right, the Mexican chef Enrique Olvera is out studying New York restaurants before opening his own, Cosme, one of the season’s most anticipated newcomers.
lead_paragraph: Being hailed as one of the greatest chefs on the planet is nice and all, but when it comes to success in the New York restaurant scene, that and $2.75 will buy you a quick ride on the F train to indifference.

headline: He Said, She Said, and Getting It Right About Voter ID
abstract: Two recent articles draw complaints about false equivalency.
lead_paragraph: Two recent articles on voting disputes would have benefitted greatly from a single clarifying sentence – one that would have cut through the “he said, she said” language that so many readers understandably tell me they dislike.

headline: How Can Men Help Prevent Sexual Assault?
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Mentors', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Sexual assault is a problem on college campuses. But are colleges offering students useful strategies for steering clear of dangerous situations, for themselves and for others?
lead_paragraph: As the summer wanes, college students are moving into their dorms to get ready for a new semester. But this year, male students say they aren’t as eager to flirt and drink as they have been in years past.

abstract: 5,680 entries ago, we began our Summer Reading Contest. Today, reluctantly, we announce our final winner — congratulations Ted Zhu! — and our usual long list of runners-up and honorable mentions.

keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A lack of flexibility and a slow check-in process contribute to a migration away from the cultural center during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Nothing fades faster than a shiny new toy.

headline: Home Depot Investigates a Possible Credit Card Breach
abstract: The retailer said it was investigating a report that customer credit and debit card data was stolen from its systems and put up for sale online.
lead_paragraph: Home Depot said on Tuesday that it was investigating a report that customer credit and debit card data was stolen from its systems and put up for sale online.

headline: Europe Crisis Is Resistant to Medicine of Low Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: The European Central Bank’s negative rates strategy has not worked as planned, which is why it is under increasing pressure to try something else.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It is getting harder and harder to find free parking for large sums of euros.

headline: At 28, Peng Shuai Advances to Her First Grand Slam Semifinal
abstract: Peng Shuai, the highest-ranked Chinese player in the U.S. Open with Li Na injured, ousted Belinda Bencic in the quarterfinals to continue her strong run.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Open began, Peng Shuai said she did not relish being the highest-ranked Chinese player in the tournament, preferring that Li Na is around, absorbing most of the pressure and attention from the Chinese fans who have become quite a cheering section in Flushing Meadows in recent years.

headline: ‘New Berlin’ or Not, Leipzig Has New Life
abstract: Many locals have proposed Leipzig, Germany, as Europe’s new home base for voguish 20-somethings, and the city has been born anew as a cultural mecca.
lead_paragraph: By 1989, Leipzig stank. The East German industrial hub was said to have the worst air in the country — if not the continent. Factories belched tons of sulfur dioxide into the skies and the polluted waterways reeked. But just a quarter-century later, Leipzig has shed its reputation as Germany’s “poverty capital” and entered safely into the realm of poverty chic; it has been born anew as a cultural mecca — and, just maybe, the “New Berlin.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Terún in Palo Alto, Calif.
abstract: This year-old restaurant wears a derogatory term for Southern Italians as a badge of honor.
lead_paragraph: In Piedmontese slang, Terún is a derogatory term for Southern Italians. “It means rednecks or hicks,” said Franco Campilongo, who hails from a small town in Calabria, the toe on Italy’s boot. But rather than taking the term (pronounced tay-ROON) as an affront, Mr. Campilongo wears it as a badge of honor — as does his year-old restaurant in Palo Alto.

headline: Larry David’s ‘Fish in the Dark’ to Open on Broadway in March
abstract: Mr. David’s play will begin performances on Feb. 2 at the Cort Theater and open on March 5.
lead_paragraph: “Fish in the Dark,” the new Broadway play written by and starring Larry David, will begin preview performances on Feb. 2 at the Cort Theater and open on March 5, the producer Scott Rudin said on Tuesday. Additional cast members were also announced: the Tony Award nominee Jayne Houdyshell (“Well”), Rosie Perez (“Fearless”), Jonny Orsini (“The Nance”), Jake Cannavale (“Basilica”), and Jerry Adler (“The Sopranos”).

headline: David Lynch’s Doughnut Obsession
abstract: The first major retrospective of the filmmaker’s work opens this month in Philadelphia, where Federal Donuts will serve up sugary confections as an homage to his films.
lead_paragraph: Trippy dream sequences. Doppelgängers. Laura Dern. One associates them all with the fun-house mirror maze of a David Lynch project. But doughnuts? From Special Agent Dale Cooper’s insatiable sweet tooth on “Twin Peaks” to the metaphor Lynch uses in the 2012 documentary “Meditation, Creativity, Peace” (“Transcendental Meditation gives an experience much sweeter than the sweetness of this doughnut”), sugary fried rings have popped up throughout the filmmaker’s cabalistic canon. And so, Michael Solomonov, the chef and co-owner of Philadelphia’s Federal Donuts, jumped at the invite to make confections in honor of the first major retrospective of Lynch’s work, at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (where Lynch studied painting in the late ’60s). With names like Blue Velvet and Good Coffee — a “Twin Peaks” reference — Solomonov’s creations are an homage to the master of magical realist cinema. There’s one, though, that won’t see the light of day: the David Lynch. “I would have done a little clove and allspice, to get at the Indian-mystical thing, and a bit of malt powder since he used to have a daily milkshake,” Solomonov says. “Plus a healthy dose of windowpane LSD.”

headline: Hotel Review: Fletcher Hotel in Amsterdam
abstract: Comfortable with a shower in the middle of your room? You just might be ready for a stay at this property that’s six miles outside the city center.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Steven Sotloff: Another ISIS Atrocity
abstract: The killing of Mr. Sotloff is likely to increase the pressure on President Obama to authorize greater military involvement in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine that anyone was surprised by the news of yet another atrocity by the terrorist group that styles itself as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, as if there is anything Islamic – or religious in any way – about these thugs, or that they represent any kind of “state.”

headline: Laughs Draw a Crowd to McNally’s ‘It’s Only a Play’
abstract: Terrence McNally’s “It’s Only a Play,” a showbiz send-up with Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, had strong sales in its first preview performances.
lead_paragraph: Broadway has been light on comedies lately, but its latest one looks to be a hit. “It’s Only a Play,” a showbiz send-up featuring Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick – the stars of the 2001 musical smash “The Producers” – grossed $793,046 last week for its first five preview performances, which were all sold out. According to box office data released on Tuesday by Broadway producers and theater owners, “It’s Only a Play” also had an average paid admission of $146.81, with only the hits “The Book of Mormon” and “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” drawing higher average ticket prices.

headline: Wheelies: The Corvette Sinkhole Filled Edition
abstract: The National Corvette Museum decides to fill the sinkhole that swallowed eight cars; Aston Martin takes a Nissan executive as chief.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Grand Stage for a Second Act
abstract: After a painful breakup with former business partners, the restaurateur Chris Cannon is aiming for a comeback in a lavish New Jersey project.
lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, N.J. —  Chris Cannon’s lavish new hive of restaurants in this suburban town is wrapped in gilded splendor. A long, thin reflecting pool, flanked by urns, stretches out in front of what looks like a Mediterranean palazzo. Inside, there’s an imperial staircase of Italian marble and thick columns that soar to the ceiling.

headline: Daria P. Salusbury
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Ms. Salusbury is a senior vice president in charge of the luxury residential leasing operations for the Related Companies.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Salusbury, 60, is a senior vice president in charge of the luxury residential leasing operations for the Related Companies. The rental portfolio consists of about 6,000 units, mostly in New York, with more planned in Related’s coming Hudson Yards development and other projects.

headline: Awesome Road Trip for Andy Murray’s Fans From Down Under
abstract: The Andy Boys, a group of young Murray fans from Australia, made the trip to this year’s U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: In January 2007, Andy Murray was ranked 17th, another up-and-coming player in the orbit of Roger Federer. But Nick Holloway saw something special in Murray and set out to do something about it.

headline: New York Fashion Week Guide: Whom and What to Know
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: A guide to the key players as designers prepare to roll out the garments.
lead_paragraph: As the United States Open winds down to its final chaotic days, another late-summer New York spectacle takes its place, one with its own crowds, prized seating spots, celebrity sightings and, of course, winners and losers. Yes, we are talking about New York Fashion Week. The spring/summer season is upon us, with more than 100 shows taking place between now and next Thursday, followed by the same again in London, Milan and Paris until the first week of October. Fashion month has become a cultural phenomenon as globally pervasive as the ginkgo tree. You can’t avoid it, so you may as well embrace it, and find out what you should be ready to discuss during cocktail parties and water cooler conversations everywhere. Indubitably, questions of geopolitics and the stagnant European economy are more important, but think of it this way: What happens at fashion week will inform in large part the shape — literally — your identity will take six months from now. So in the interests of self-awareness (anduseful banter), following is my crib sheet for what to watch, whom to know and where to focus during the collections.

headline: Three Roads to Hard Money
abstract: But why did they converge?
lead_paragraph: So, a hedge fund manager, a right-wing politician, and a freshwater economist walk into a restaurant and order wine. No, this isn’t the setup for a joke — it’s a real story. We don’t actually know what they talked about, but all three have been prominent in warning that the Fed is embarked on a dangerously inflationary path. And as I have written many many times, this inflation paranoia has proved remarkably resilient, enduring despite five-plus years of utter empirical failure. Why?

headline: Bank Seizure Leaves Bulgarians Stranded
abstract: Businesses and individuals with about $4 billion in frozen deposits at Bulgaria's fourth-largest bank are struggling to pay their bills after a government takeover of the lender in June.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — What seemed at first to be a short-term banking crisis is looking more like a chronic condition.

headline: There Is No Secondi Choice
abstract: Pasta takes center stage at Bar Primi in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Main courses are never as good as the starters, people like to say. I’ve always argued that a good chef won’t let that happen, but I have to admit that it does seem true for a lot of Italian restaurants, at least in New York City. There are exceptions, of course, but as a general rule, it’s all downhill after the spaghetti.

abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Arizona Police Report Says Parents Didn’t Realize Daughter Had Shot Gun Instructor
abstract: The report detailed the death of an instructor at a shooting range in White Hills, Ariz., after a 9-year-old lost control of an Uzi.
lead_paragraph: When the police arrived, the shooting range instructor who had been accidentally shot by a 9-year-old girl with an Uzi was still breathing, lying on the ground and moaning as a colleague tried to stanch the bleeding from a bullet wound to his head, according to a police report released on Tuesday.

headline: Enrique Olvera’s Love for Avocado Filled Vegetarian Tacos
abstract: In its most basic form, an avocado taco is like a two-bite couplet in praise of Mexican ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Most top chefs will tell you the same thing: When they finally escape from the elaborate labors they oversee in the kitchen, they crave late-night street food that’s poetically simple and satisfying — hot dogs, fried rice, a bowl of noodles. For Enrique Olvera, that hand-to-mouth haiku can be found in avocado tacos, which he scarfs down around the clock. He eats them for breakfast; he eats them in the middle of the night. They serve as both “a comfort,” he said, and “a cultural expression.”

headline: A Tip Sheet for a Season of Surprises
abstract: Florence Fabricant lists the most interesting and important restaurants that will open soon.
lead_paragraph: The coming months promise a rich menu of options: fried chicken, Asian-Latino fusion, snack stands and opulent new dining rooms.  Florence Fabricant describes the highlights. (Dates may change.)

headline: Anne Griffin Seeks to Void Prenuptial Agreement With Ken Griffin
keywords: ['Child Custody and Support', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Ms. Griffin responded to her husband’s divorce petition with a formal request for sole custody of their three children.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:47 p.m. | When the billionaire hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin moved to divorce his wife of 11 years this summer, his action took many by surprise.

headline: Cara Delevingne’s Quilted Leather Mulberry Backpack
abstract: Just in time for a new school year and the spring/summer 2015 fashion shows, these black bags are the ultimate in chic-yet-practical carryalls.
lead_paragraph: A leather quilted backpack, like the one Cara Delevingne designed for her new Mulberry collection that hit stores yesterday, is an obvious choice for glamming up back-to-school wardrobes. And in all black, it’s also a smart carryall for the fashion set during the spring/summer 2015 shows, which kick off tomorrow in New York.

headline: Two Met Opera Unions Ratify Contracts
abstract: Two unions represented by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees ratified the contracts negotiated with the opera late last month.
lead_paragraph: Two of the Metropolitan Opera unions represented by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees have ratified the contracts negotiated with the opera late last month. One of the unions, Local 1, which represents the carpenters and those responsible for the lighting, sound, props and set construction, approved a six-year agreement; the other, Local 764, representing those who work in the costume shop and who dress the singers, approved a four-year contract.

headline: With Storms Outside, Inner Conflicts Swirl
abstract: In Ben Lerner’s latest novel, “10:04,” New York itself is more than a mere backdrop.
lead_paragraph: In the new issue of Tin House, the literary quarterly, there’s a terrific conversation — conducted on Google Chat — between Annie Nugent Baker, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, and the novelist Benjamin Baker Nugent, her brother.

headline: A Kingdom for Some Fans
abstract: “The Quest” combines live-action role playing with an elimination competition in a show with ogres, castles and armor.
lead_paragraph: I could have spent my television time over Labor Day weekend catching up on any number of brainy, critically beloved shows in preparation for the fall season. Instead, I was sucked into a world of inept archery and ill-fitting armor, where people who have no business trying to save a kingdom have been given the responsibility to do just that.

headline: Depression, a Persistent Demon, Stalks One Family for Generations
abstract: “Rocks in My Pockets,” an animated feature, explores a family’s struggles with depression.
lead_paragraph: With “Rocks in My Pockets,” Signe Baumane presents a sharp, surprising and funny animated feature, plumbing the depths of depression via her family history. Guided by Ms. Baumane’s almost musically accented voice-over, this hand-drawn debut feature is based upon the mental struggles of her Latvian grandmother and other relatives. It’s told with remorseless psychological intelligence, wicked irony and an acerbic sense of humor.

headline: Circus Tent Boxers in Australia’s Outback
abstract: Looking to make pictures of Australia that did not involve surfers or kangaroos, Viviane Dalles cast her luck with an itinerant boxing show.
lead_paragraph: Looking to make pictures of Australia that did not involve surfers or kangaroos, Viviane Dalles cast her luck with an itinerant boxing show.

abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: FanDuel, an Online Fantasy Sports Site, Raises $70 Million
abstract: FanDuel has obtained financing from investors led by Shamrock Capital Advisors, NBC Sports Ventures and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
lead_paragraph: The trading of athlete on fantasy sports sites may be fake, but the business is real — as are the investment dollars flowing into the industry.

headline: Q. and A.: Ren Jianming on the Fight Against Corruption in China, and His Own Solution
abstract: Ren Jianming, one of China’s leading experts on corruption, discusses the enormous scale of the problem and the challenge of keeping government functioning while pursuing it “to the end,” as President Xi Jinping has vowed.
lead_paragraph: Ren Jianming is one of China’s leading corruption researchers and an expert on one of the hottest topics in the country: President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption campaign, which is netting hundreds, and possibly thousands, of officials, including very senior ones.

headline: Milly’s Michelle Smith on Navigating New York Fashion Week with Kids
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Museums', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The designer, who has two children and is showing her spring/summer 2015 collection on Monday, shares recommendations for where to eat and hang out with youngsters (and how grown-ups can perk up, or at least look the part).
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week throws the work-life calculus into chaos for just about everyone in the industry. But its hectic schedule is especially challenging for parents of young children. The designer Michelle Smith of Milly, who will present her spring/summer 2015 collection on Monday and is also the mother of a seven-year-old girl and five-year-old boy, has more experience than most in navigating the unique demands of the week (which also coincides with back-to-school time).

headline: Will China Defeat Obesity?
abstract: If it goes the way of the West, its gains in life span may be eroded.
lead_paragraph: Say what you will about the Chinese, but they know how to make wholesale changes, and sometimes those changes are inarguably for the good. As noted in an editorial in The Lancet last week, the life span of the average person in China in 1950 was 40 years; by 2011 it was around 76. (The average life span in the United States in 2011 was 79.)

headline: Still Dealing in Intimacy After All These Years
abstract: Richard Schechner, 80, talks about his latest work, “Imagining O,” and pairing erotica and contemporary avant-garde.
lead_paragraph: Two women, robed in black, gazed at each other across a low table at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University. They were rehearsing “Imagining O,” Richard Schechner’s reinvention of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet” and Pauline Réage’s novel “The Story of O,” which opens next Wednesday as part of the Peak Performances series. Mr. Schechner, as brash as he is gentle, asked the actresses to work the scene again. “I want absolute intimacy,” he said.

headline: A View of the Heavens Needs Some Retouching
abstract: “Meeting,” by James Turrell, one of the most popular installations at MoMA PS1, with its open roof, is in need of restoration and has been closed for over a year.
lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, MoMA PS1, the Museum of Modern Art’s outpost in Long Island City, Queens, quietly shut the door on one of New York’s most beloved works of art. “Meeting,” James Turrell’s room-size installation whose roof opens to the sky, on view since 1986, has been closed to the public as the museum and the artist decide how to restore it.

headline: More Than a Million Ukrainians Have Been Displaced, U.N. Says
abstract: An estimated 260,000 people have fled to different regions of the country, and 814,000 have left the country to escape the fighting.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Amid rising international tension over Ukraine, the United Nations’ refugee agency said Tuesday that the fighting there had displaced more than a million people and warned of “devastating consequences” if it did not end soon.

headline: Tested to Extremes
abstract: The way to ensure a Rolex wearer can go faster, further and deeper.
lead_paragraph: The way to ensure a Rolex wearer can go faster, further and deeper.

headline: A Family Album
abstract: When your father is a rock star — in this case, Jeff Tweedy of Wilco — banding together to make an album might make more sense than rebelling.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — One summer afternoon, at the industrial loft space where he rehearses and records, Jeff Tweedy was sitting in a corner with a guitar across his lap, rooting his way around an impromptu cover of Neil Young’s “Cinnamon Girl.” By his side was a drummer who is not a member of Mr. Tweedy’s influential rock band, Wilco, but who has worked closely with him for many years, and who kept an enthusiastic and undeterrable beat while watching him contend with some awkward chord changes.

headline: Hotel Dining, Updated Chinese and More
abstract: Counting down the surprises in New York’s new crop of restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Great restaurants no longer wait for fall. Consider Bâtard and Racines NY, which both arrived in the last few months. Nonetheless, armed with my shiny new pencil case and notebook, I anticipate the fresh crop of restaurants the way I do the new theater and opera seasons.

headline: Reading the Paper With Gay Talese
abstract: Mr. Talese, the best-selling author and former Times reporter, talks about articles in the newspaper that piqued his interest.
lead_paragraph: Gay Talese, best-selling author (and former Times reporter), has a white, low-slung 1957 TR3 convertible and a routine. “My routine is I get in the TR3 and drive to this gas station in Roxbury, Conn., early in the morning, get the paper and come back home. No one is up, the dogs are not up, the wife is not up, and for the next two and a half hours, I read the paper, alone.”

headline: U.N. and Medical Group Make Appeals for Ebola Aid
abstract: United Nations officials urged diplomats to cable their capitals to send money, doctors and protective gear to the affected region, while Doctors Without Borders called for countries to send biohazard experts.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations and the medical aid group Doctors Without Borders each issued urgent appeals on Tuesday for international aid to contain the Ebola outbreak in West Africa.

headline: Concours Season in the East: At Lime Rock Park, a More Relaxed Atmosphere
abstract: A concours and vintage racing weekend in Connecticut is quite a contrast for a reporter just back from the Pebble Beach extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: LAKEVILLE, Conn. — Returning from nine days on the Monterey Peninsula, having tried to see as much as possible of the extravaganza of events leading up to the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance, it was a refreshing change to drop into this picturesque village in the northwest corner of Connecticut and to what might be called the real world of auto shows and vintage car racing, Lime Rock Park’s Historic Festival 32.

headline: In Hobby Lobby Ruling, a Missing Definition Stirs Debate
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision in the Hobby Lobby case raises the question of how to define a “closely held corporation,” Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision in June that some companies did not have to provide contraceptive coverage for their employees only started the debate.

headline: Video Shows Panic in Liberia as Man Wanders Out of Ebola Clinic
abstract: A man suspected of having Ebola sowed panic in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, when he wandered out of a treatment center.
lead_paragraph: As Liberia struggles to contain the deadliest Ebola outbreak on record, health workers say that fear of the disease, and the stigma of being identified as a possible carrier, is creating a hostile environment for those seeking treatment.

abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Waging Desperate Campaign, Iraqi Town Held Off Militants
abstract: The siege of Amerli, a northern Shiite Turkmen community, is thought to be the first instance in which a town has kept ISIS at bay since the group began its march through Iraq.
lead_paragraph: AMERLI, Iraq — The children lined the unkempt boulevard in this northern Iraqi town on Tuesday to welcome some of the men who had saved them from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Help Families From Day 1
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Income Inequality', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Land Use Policies', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Living Wage']
abstract: Universal pre-K is a huge step forward. Now let’s start earlier.
lead_paragraph: THE opening of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s universal pre-kindergarten program this week will give 53,000 children access to free, full-day pre-K in New York City, compared with 20,000 enrolled last year. This is well worth celebrating, and other cities and states should follow suit. But this investment in school preparation is not enough. If we want to close the income-based achievement gap, we need to begin much earlier.

headline: Dealing With Iraq, Syria and ISIS
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Responses to opinion articles about the Mideast turmoil.

headline: Culinary Trends in New York
abstract: The hot dishes, drinks and other details to watch for in restaurants this fall.
lead_paragraph: FLYING COLLARS With just one to an animal, fish collar is a rarity saved for specials at places like Alder. Pork collar is in steadier supply than fish collar, and is the star of the charcoal grill at Kang Ho Dong Baekjeong in Flushing, Queens, and soon, Manhattan. — Pete Wells

headline: Gaël Monfils vs. Roger Federer: Expect Sparks to Fly at the U.S. Open
abstract: The charismatic Monfils upset No. 7 Grigor Dimitrov on Tuesday, setting up a rematch with Federer just a few weeks after the two players last met.
lead_paragraph: As Gaël Monfils played in the fourth round of the United States Open on Tuesday, it was impossible to tell that he was winning his match in straight sets, or that he had not dropped a set in the tournament.

headline: Is 'Don't Do Stupid Stuff' the Best Foreign Policy?
abstract: Is caution and deliberation rather than quick action a better way to serve the national interest in a treacherous world landscape?

headline: Conshohocken, Pa., an Old Steel Town, Now an Office Hub
abstract: Land, location and transportation have attracted office developers to Conshohocken, about 15 miles northwest of central Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa. — The view from the 15th floor of the Eight Tower Bridge office building here looks over two interstate highways, a commuter rail line, an old warehouse and a riverside stand of woods.

headline: U.S. Health Agency Advises More Vigilance on Campuses
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Students (in US)']
abstract: The new recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention came as thousands of foreign students and workers, and Americans who have been traveling abroad, began arriving on campuses to start a new school year.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has advised American colleges and universities, and any students or staff arriving from nations hit by the Ebola virus, to take precautions against spreading the disease that go beyond what most schools have done.

headline: Think Tank to Ponder a Future for Ballet
abstract: Four years after warning that ballet is dying, a historian has founded a center at New York University that will enlist arts professionals and scholars to examine its future.
lead_paragraph: When she wrote “Apollo’s Angels,” her sweeping history of that most evanescent of art forms, ballet, the dancer turned historian Jennifer Homans was widely hailed for taking an engaging, scholarly approach to more than four centuries of dance. But within the dance world, her book became famous — or perhaps infamous — for its final 10 pages, a downbeat epilogue in which Ms. Homans sounded a blunt warning, writing, “I now feel sure that ballet is dying.”

headline: Executive Director Leaving Friends of the High Line
abstract: After leading Friends of the High Line for eight months, Jenny Gersten plans to return to full-time work in the arts.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Friends of the High Line introduced its new executive director, Jenny Gersten, on its website, saying that even though she had been on the job for only a few weeks, “we feel like this dynamic New York City native is already part of the family.”

headline: India: Militants Are Killed in Shootout in Kashmir
abstract: The Indian authorities said they killed three antigovernment militants Tuesday after a shootout in the Indian-administered region of Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: The Indian authorities said they killed three antigovernment militants Tuesday after a shootout in the Indian-administered region of Kashmir. Indian forces had surrounded the militants’ house when the men inside began firing, officials said. Vijay Kumar, the area police chief, said the police had taken the father of one fighter to the site to ask him to surrender, but the man refused. The authorities said that the men were members of Jaish-e-Muhammad, a banned organization.

headline: Bracing for New Challenges in Year 2 of Health Care Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: Early troubles under the Affordable Care Act are expected to be replaced by new difficulties as insurance prices fluctuate and more people sign up.
lead_paragraph: The first year of enrollment under the federal health care law was marred by the troubled start of HealthCare.gov, rampant confusion among consumers and a steep learning curve for insurers and government officials alike.

headline: After Eric Cantor’s Exit, House Turns Sympathetic Ear From Big Business to Oil and Gas
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Eric Cantor’s departure drives home a new political landscape: Wall Street has lost its most persuasive advocate, while oil and gas industries are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Eric Cantor’s move on Tuesday to a boutique investment firm in New York drove home a new political landscape emerging on Capitol Hill as the Republican leadership reshuffles in the House: Wall Street and Big Business have lost their most sympathetic ear, oil and gas industries are on the rise, and Louisiana once again has a booming voice at the table.

headline: Report Counters Claims of Migrant Abuse
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: Inspectors for the Department of Homeland Security’s found no evidence of “systemic abuse” at detention facilities, a report said.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have found no evidence to support a complaint that young migrants crossing the border illegally had been subject to “systemic abuse” in detention, according to a report released Tuesday by the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security. The report also found that conditions had improved notably since mid-July in border stations where the young migrants were detained.

headline: ‘The Simpsons’ Marathon Lifts Ratings for Fledgling FXX Network
abstract: The 12-day, round-the-clock marathon, which also included the two-hour 2007 theatrical movie, produced ratings about three times as high as executives at the channel expected.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century ago, the animated comedy “The Simpsons” put the fledgling Fox network on the map as the fourth broadcast network. Now, with a much-promoted marathon of all 552 episodes that ended Monday, “The Simpsons” has repeated that feat, lifting a year-old cable channel called FXX to the top ranks of the 105 cable networks measured by the Nielsen Company.

headline: Louisiana: U.S. Joins Inquiry Into Death in Police Car
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The United States Justice Department said on Tuesday that it was investigating the death of Victor White III, 23, who died while in custody of Iberia Parish sheriff’s deputies in March.
lead_paragraph: The United States Justice Department said on Tuesday that it was investigating the death of Victor White III, 23, who died while in the custody of Iberia Parish sheriff’s deputies in March. The local coroner determined that his shooting death in the back of a police cruiser while his hands were cuffed was a suicide. His family has disputed details of the shooting and called for a federal investigation, comparing his death to the fatal police shooting of another young black man, Michael Brown, in Ferguson, Mo. The United States attorney for the Western District of Louisiana, Stephanie A. Finley, said on Tuesday that the F.B.I. had been “working parallel” with the current investigation by the Louisiana State Police, and that the federal investigation would “supplement, rather than supplant,” the state investigation. Officials from the F.B.I., the United States attorney’s office and the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division will review the results of the investigation and determine whether to investigative further and whether any civil rights violation occurred, Ms. Finley said.

headline: Lida Moser, Photographer and Journalist, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Lida Moser excelled in capturing the realities of New York life.
lead_paragraph: Lida Moser excelled in capturing the realities of New York life.

headline: Halliburton to Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Damages in Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The settlement, a fraction of the damages paid by companies involved in the accident, goes a long way toward resolving Halliburton’s exposure to liability claims.
lead_paragraph: Halliburton, the company contracted by BP to cement the ill-fated Macondo oil well in the Gulf of Mexico, has reached a $1.1 billion settlement with thousands of businesses, individuals and local governments that suffered losses from the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion, the company and plaintiffs announced on Tuesday.

headline: N.F.L. Season Is About to Begin. Any Questions?
abstract: Submit your questions about the start of the N.F.L. season, and Times reporters will respond beginning on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.'s regular season begins Thursday night, when the Seattle Seahawks, the defending Super Bowl champions, host the Green Bay Packers. On Sunday, Rex Ryan’s Jets will play host to the Oakland Raiders, and on Monday night, Eli Manning and the Giants will take on the Lions in Detroit.

headline: Ready, Aim, Fire. Not Fire, Ready, Aim.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: Just what are we really dealing with in ISIS?
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been excoriated for declaring that “we don’t have a strategy yet” for effectively confronting the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS. In criticizing Obama for taking too much time, Representative Mike Rogers, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, told “Fox News Sunday” that “this ‘don’t-do-stupid-stuff’ policy isn’t working.” That sounded odd to my ear — like we should just bomb somebody, even if it is stupid. If Obama did that, what would he be ignoring?

headline: Lida Moser, Photographer With an Urban Eye, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms. Moser’s photography captured the reality of life in New York City and she also created a classic series on rural Quebec in 1950.
lead_paragraph: Lida Moser, whose genre-spanning photographs appeared in magazines including Look, Esquire and Vogue during their heyday in the 1950s and ’60s and who went on to write about photography for The New York Times, died on Aug. 11 near her home in Rockville, Md. She was 93.

headline: Charles Bowden, a Writer on the Edge
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Books and Literature', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media', 'Editorials']
abstract: Instead of looking away, Mr. Bowden chose to write deeply researched books about the borderland drug war and its many slaughters.
lead_paragraph: As a 1916 book about “the newspaper trade” put it, the reporter’s job is “to see for the unseeing and to become a public observer for the benefit of those who cannot observe.”

headline: Revival of Species Puts Some Fish Back on Plates
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Cod (Fish)', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish Farming', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: Dozens of species of popular West Coast rockfish that were once so overfished that the fishing grounds were declared a federal economic disaster are now abundant.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of species of popular West Coast rockfish that were once so overfished that the fishing grounds were declared a federal economic disaster are now abundant. The Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch program, considered the most influential guide to hundreds of species of popular fish, on Monday issued a report encouraging consumers to eat 21 species of rockfish it had long warned cooks to avoid. Many fish sold on menus as snapper, black cod and rock cod were moved to favorable categories, along with recommendations for consumers to choose more sablefish and petrale sole. The revival of the fisheries began in earnest in 2000, when they were near collapse and fishing families were facing bankruptcy. A series of quotas, improvements in gear, better monitoring of catches and the creation of protected areas to preserve fish habitat brought improvements in stocks off the shores of California, Washington and Oregon, said Frank Lockhart of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s West Coast fisheries division.

headline: Bernard F. Fisher, Honored for Bold Vietnam Rescue, Dies at 87
abstract: Despite warnings, the aviator landed on an embattled airstrip where another flier had crashed, taxied under heavy fire to find him, and got his comrade and himself out alive.
lead_paragraph: Col. Bernard F. Fisher, who received the first Medal of Honor awarded to an aviator during the Vietnam War for a daring rescue of another pilot in the face of enemy fire on an airstrip, died on Aug. 16 in Boise, Idaho. He was 87.

headline: Holiday Inn Express Tries Funny to Sell Free Breakfast
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The Funny or Die comedian Jim Gaffigan is promoting the hotel chain in Internet videos and digital-radio ads.
lead_paragraph: HOLIDAY Inn Express is bringing its longtime “Stay smart” advertising campaign into the 21st century by making it largely digital, with a Funny or Die comedian as its spokesman.

headline: New York Cancels or Postpones Opening of 45 Pre-K Programs
abstract: Nine sites that would have served 265 students will not open because of safety concerns or other issues, officials announced two days before the first day of school.
lead_paragraph: Nine private programs that were to offer free, city-financed prekindergarten this year will not open because of safety concerns or other issues, and 36 programs will not be ready to open on Thursday, the first day of school, New York City officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Alaska Race Sees Democrat Quit Campaign for Governor
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Governors', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Byron Mallott said he would withdraw and run instead for lieutenant governor alongside an independent candidate, Bill Walker.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The race for governor of Alaska took a decided turn into the wild on Tuesday when the Democratic candidate, Byron Mallott, said he would withdraw and run instead for lieutenant governor alongside an independent candidate, Bill Walker.

headline: Judge Rejects Defense’s Criteria for Convicting Ex-Governor Bob McDonnell as Jury Gets Case
abstract: The case against Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen, who are facing corruption charges, will go into its second day of deliberations.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The jury weighing the fate of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, on corruption charges that could send them to prison is set to deliberate Wednesday for a second day after hearing a lengthy set of instructions in which the judge seemed to side mostly with prosecutors.

headline: Israel Says Hamas Is Hurt Significantly
abstract: In a recap of the 50-day war in Gaza, Israel says that it killed several hundred militants, and that militant groups operating in Gaza still have as many as 3,000 rockets on hand.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — A senior Israeli military intelligence official acknowledged on Tuesday that only several hundred Hamas operatives out of a total that he put at 16,000 were killed during this summer’s 50-day war in Gaza, leaving the group’s fighting force largely intact.

headline: Cuomo Is Running but Isn’t One to Talk About It
abstract: The week before the Democratic primary, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo continues to avoid uttering the name of his Democratic opponent, Zephyr Teachout, let alone debating her.
lead_paragraph: Next Tuesday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s name will appear on the Democratic primary ballot across New York State.

headline: Berkeley Pushes a Boundary on Medical Marijuana
abstract: Berkeley, a California city that has prided itself on its liberal policies, will require medical marijuana dispensaries to donate at least 2 percent of their cannabis to low-income residents.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Since the birth of the Free Speech Movement half a century ago, this city has prided itself on its liberal values and policies, be they generous benefits for the needy or a look-the-other-way attitude toward marijuana use.

headline: $1.4 Billion in Penalties Is Sought in California Gas Blast
abstract: Four years after eight people died and dozens were hurt in a natural gas explosion in San Bruno, Calif., the Pacific Gas & Electric Company was hit with a proposed $1.4 billion penalty for suspected safety violations.
lead_paragraph: Four years after a natural gas explosion tore through a neighborhood of San Bruno, Calif., killing eight people and injuring dozens of others, some of them seriously, the Pacific Gas & Electric Company has been hit with a proposed $1.4 billion penalty for suspected safety violations.

headline: Ukraine, Caught in a Vise
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Behind the continuing military conflict in eastern Ukraine lies an economic split. The country is moving toward Europe, straining its longstanding ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Behind the continuing military conflict in eastern Ukraine lies an economic split. The country is moving toward Europe, straining its longstanding ties with Russia.

headline: The Elections Cop Invites Mischief
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees', 'Elections']
abstract: The Federal Election Commission has made a travesty of its mission by giving violators permission to break the limits on spending and disclosure.
lead_paragraph: The country’s increasingly lawless political system needs a traffic cop to set clear rules and rein in violators who think nothing of breaking the spending limits. That’s supposed to be the job of the Federal Election Commission, but the agency has made a travesty of its mission, encouraging bad behavior rather than stopping it.

headline: All That Back and Forth at the U.S. Open, Between Doubles Partners
abstract: Doubles players treat points as baseball or football players might, mapping out tactics in advance and using the between-point encounters to prop each other up.
lead_paragraph: It happens after almost every point in professional doubles tennis matches, as predictably as the ritualistic high-fiving and fist-bumping the players cannot seem to live without. The point is won or lost. The partners convene. And they have a little chat.

headline: NATO’s Urgent Challenges
abstract: The alliance needs unite to push back against Vladimir Putin’s expansionist tendencies.
lead_paragraph: More than anyone, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has set the agenda for NATO’s 65th summit meeting this week, which could well be the most consequential since the Cold War ended.

headline: U.S. and Europe Are Struggling With Response to a Bold Russia
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Officials hope that any new measures will have more impact than the economic sanctions imposed on Moscow so far.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and European officials are struggling to devise a response as Russia bears down on Ukraine, searching for new measures that will have more impact than the economic sanctions imposed so far, without risking major damage to their own industries or a military escalation that could spiral out of control.

headline: In Ryder Cup Picks, Results Are Not Everything
abstract: The final players were selected on Tuesday for the United States and European teams that will play in the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A few of the best golfers in the world this summer got a taste of what it is like to be a fringe player in the National Football League. Like Champ Bailey, Robert Meachem and Shayne Graham, all formerly of the New Orleans Saints, the PGA Tour pros Chris Kirk, Ryan Moore and Brendon Todd spent the past several weeks auditioning for a 2014 roster spot, only to fail to make the final cut.

headline: Widening the Lens on Blame
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A report from the National Institute of Justice urges systemic reviews of serious mistakes made in criminal justice, rather than a focus on a single culprit.
lead_paragraph: Mistakes come in different shapes.

headline: Midterms on the Menu
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Kale (Vegetable)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Hey David, here we are again. I would personally like to thank the voters in Arkansas, Alaska, North Carolina, Iowa and Louisiana for throwing the fate of the Senate into turmoil and giving us a hot new election season to talk about.

headline: Absurd or Astute: Brazil’s Political Ads
abstract: To capture attention and votes in Brazil’s fall elections, candidates use free allotted airtime to release outrageous and provocative ads.
lead_paragraph: To capture attention and votes in Brazil’s fall elections, candidates use free allotted airtime to release outrageous and provocative ads.

headline: Brazil’s Politicians Often Play the Clown in Ads
abstract: Before the Oct. 5 elections in Brazil, candidates are creating jaw-dropping campaign advertisements to grab hold of voters’ attention and to stand out.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — An auditor flies through the air like Superman, shooting laser beams from his eyes. A clown channels the spirit of a septuagenarian pop star. A dermatologist concludes a tirade by simply screaming at viewers, “My name is Havanir!”

headline: New York Installs Speed Cameras Near Schools
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Education (K-12)', 'Cameras']

lead_paragraph: With public schools set to open on Thursday, New York City officials have hurried to slow traffic using their newest tools: cameras equipped with radar to gauge the speed of passing vehicles.

headline: Monument Seeks to End Silence on Killings of the Disabled by the Nazis
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Disabilities', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Among the last to have their suffering acknowledged, some 300,000 intellectually disabled people were added to the list of those to be remembered as victims of the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The first to be singled out for systematic murder by the Nazis were the mentally ill and intellectually disabled. By the end of World War II, an estimated 300,000 of them had been gassed or starved, their fates hidden by phony death certificates and then largely overlooked among the many atrocities that were to be perpetrated in Nazi Germany in the years to follow.

headline: Race Advantages
abstract: In which Peter A. Collins disproves Aesop.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today in bathroom humor, we have a puzzle by Peter A. Collins that is a paean to the loo.

headline: What Makes People Poor?
abstract: Before we can get serious about inequality, the left, the right and the center need to realize that they have a lot to learn from each other.
lead_paragraph: Let’s imagine for a moment that there are no political pressures distorting our discussion of poverty and that we can look at it as a technical problem, not a moral one.

headline: Second Trial Approaching for Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor
abstract: John G. Rowland, who has already spent time in prison for corruption, is now accused of obstructing justice, falsifying documents and committing other violations of campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — The accusations are similar. The judge will be different.

headline: NoHo Real Estate That Comes With a Tale of Murder
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The owner of a building at 31 Bond Street emphasizes its desirable neighborhood, but in 1857, a sensational crime was committed at the site.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of crime, 31 Bond Street casts a particularly creepy spell. An 1833 New York guidebook rhapsodized that the marble-trimmed brick rowhouses in what is now NoHo “may vie, for beauty and taste, with those of the finest cities of Europe.”

headline: Sleep-Deprived, but Into the Next Round
abstract: Kei Nishikori advanced to the U.S. Open quarterfinals by defeating Milos Raonic in a five-set match that started on Monday night and ended Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: As the players grew red in the face and called for the trainers on a muggy Tuesday at the United States Open, the thought of a night match sounded like relief.

headline: Changes Made at Fire Academy After Drug-Resistant Staph Infections
abstract: The department cleaned high-risk areas and ordered changes in a training exercise after 22 students contracted a bacterial infection.
lead_paragraph: The New York City fire commissioner has ordered a change in training exercises at the fire academy on Randalls Island after a number of probationary firefighters contracted the drug-resistant bacterial infection MRSA.

headline: Lower-Frequency Platform IEX Raises Funding to Become Full Stock Market

headline: Yankees’ Offense Fades Along With Heat of Red Sox Rivalry

lead_paragraph: The days of on-field brawls, bullpen invaders and hit batsmen — all the ingredients that have made the rivalry between the Yankees and the Red Sox so volatile and compelling over the years — now seem little more than a faint recollection.

headline: Gaël Monfils Forces Grigor Dimitrov Into Mistakes in U.S. Open Win
abstract: Grigor Dimitrov, the No. 7 seed, could not find the proper court positioning to deal with the fleet-footed Gaël Monfils in their fourth-round match.

headline: CVS Stores Stop Selling All Tobacco Products
keywords: ['Drugstores', 'Customer Relations', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The company has adopted a new name, CVS Health, and stopped selling tobacco products in an effort to redefine itself as a health care destination for consumers.
lead_paragraph: At a CVS store near Times Square, the shelves are notable for what they no longer display: cigarettes. Now the only smoking products to be found are those that could help customers quit.

headline: Can Exercise Cause A.L.S.?
keywords: ['AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS', 'Concussions', 'Exercise', 'Nerves and Nervous System', 'Sports Injuries']
abstract: Physical activity, whether at work, in sports or during exercise, did not increase people’s risk of developing amyotrophic lateral sclerosis — unless there was a history of multiple hits to the head.
lead_paragraph: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis has been all over the news lately because of the ubiquitous A.L.S. ice bucket challenge. That attention has also reinvigorated a long-simmering scientific debate about whether participating in contact sports or even vigorous exercise might somehow contribute to the development of the fatal neurodegenerative disease, an issue that two important new studies attempt to answer.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Esquire) MY FRIENDS CALL ME JOHNNY Jean Pigozzi, below — the heir to a European automobile fortune, as well as a photographer, art collector, technology investor and creator of the men’s clothing brand LimoLand — hosts this new talk show, in which he interviews famous friends. In this premiere episode, he flies to Budapest for a small role in Brett Ratner’s latest film, “Hercules”; gets some tips in the art of seduction from the French writers Virginie Mouzat and Capucine Motte; and heads back to Los Angeles to interview Dov Charney, the recently deposed founder of American Apparel.

headline: Wes Welker Suspended Four Games for a Banned Substance

lead_paragraph: Less than a week before their season-opening clash with one of their principal rivals, the defending American Football Conference champion Denver Broncos learned Tuesday that wide receiver Wes Welker, a pivotal weapon in their offense, would be suspended four games for violating the N.F.L.’s policy on performing-enhancing substances.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, September 3, 2014

lead_paragraph: “A long time ago, I wanted to find me a good wife, I wanted to raise a family, I wanted to have my own business and everything. I never got a chance to realize those dreams. Now I believe that God is going to bless me to get back out there.”

headline: 2 South Korean Soldiers Die in Anti-Captivity Training
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Torture']

lead_paragraph: In “Brothers Convicted in 1983 North Carolina Murder Are Freed After DNA Tests,” Jonathan M. Katz and Erik Eckholm report on the release of two men who spent decades in prison for a crime they did not commit.

headline: From Taiwan, Broad Support for Democracy in Hong Kong
