lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s main political parties say they support Hong Kong residents’ calls for a greater say in choosing their leader following Beijing’s decision to limit electoral reforms in the semiautonomous Chinese city.

headline: Putin Lays Out Proposal to End Ukraine Conflict
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia listed seven steps that he said were necessary for a cease-fire in the conflict in eastern Ukraine and said that he and the president of Ukraine, Petro O. Poroshenko, had a similar understanding about what was needed.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — On the eve of a NATO summit meeting focused on Russian aggression, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia unveiled on Wednesday a seven-point peace plan for Ukraine while President Obama and other Western leaders tried to keep the spotlight on the Kremlin’s role in stoking the conflict there and the penalties it should suffer for doing so.

headline: Test Yourself | Teenagers Favor Tech Over Clothes
abstract: Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are seven paragraphs from the Aug. 27 article “Plugged-In Over Preppy: Teenagers Favor Tech Over Clothes.”

headline: How Many Outsiders Does It Take to ‘Bear Witness’ in Ferguson?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: In what has been the most news-filled summer in recent memory, our leaders in the media-political class “started a conversation,” whatever that means.
lead_paragraph: The spectacle began, as it often does, with a local tragedy. Last month an unarmed black teenager named Michael Brown was shot by a police officer in Ferguson, a suburb of St. Louis. In a less media-saturated time, we might have gone on to consider this serious news event on its own terms, with journalists providing facts and insights, and politicians pondering a course of action. But in the mixed-up scrum of politics and media that our so-called national conversation has become, a serious news event is only the start of the news. Soon after the shooting, the suburb of Ferguson became a roiling caldron of outside observers, all bent on “bearing witness” to the situation.

headline: Job Creation Should Be Policy Priority, O.E.C.D. Report Finds
abstract: High joblessness in the developed world results mostly from the tepid pace of recovery, data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development shows.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — High unemployment rates in most of the developed world are mainly a result of the tepid economic recovery, rather than a lack of appropriate skills in the work force, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report on Wednesday.

headline: Emoji for Breakfast, Dinosaur for Lunch
abstract: From the “emoji diet” to Gwyneth Paltrow’s detox, tales of diet experiments can illuminate how we eat.
lead_paragraph: Now that emojis have been analyzed, debated and used as the basis of a messaging app, it’s no longer enough just to talk about them. We must eat them.

headline: Will What Happened in Ferguson Change Anything?
abstract: Did you follow the news about the death of Michael Brown and the protests in Ferguson, Mo.? If so, what reactions did you have? Do you think anything will change — either in St. Louis or nationally — as a result of the protests? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news about the Aug. 9 death of Michael Brown and the subsequent protests in Ferguson, Mo.? If so, what reactions did you have?

lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — President Obama vowed on Wednesday to punish the Sunni militants whose videotaped beheadings of two American journalists he said had “repulsed” the world, saying the United States would lead a regional and international coalition to beat back the terrorists.

headline: Western Companies Appear to Push Back Against Chinese Crackdown

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For months, foreign companies in China have been quietly enduring increased scrutiny from Chinese government antitrust enforcers, issuing only occasional terse statements as they have been increasingly targeted by surprise raids on their offices, protracted investigations of their operations and escalating fines.

headline: Fukushima Workers Who Fled May Have Received Garbled Orders, Reports Say
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: Some 650 workers who fled the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactor plant without permission during the 2011 tsunami may have thought they had been ordered to evacuate, Japanese news media report.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — About 650 workers who fled the stricken Fukushima Daiichi power plant without permission at the darkest moment of the 2011 nuclear accident may have left because they thought they had been ordered to evacuate and were not knowingly violating orders, according to new details of the episode reported in recent days by Japanese news media.

headline: LVMH Boss and Hermès Family in Pact
abstract: The agreement would leave Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, with about 8.5 percent of Hermès International and end a bitter four-year battle.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has been nearly four years since the fashion mogul Bernard Arnault shocked the French business world and added billions to his fortune by stealthily obtaining a large stake in Hermès, the jewel of the luxury world.

headline: Per Capita Medicare Spending Is Actually Falling
abstract: If the pattern continues, as the Congressional Budget Office forecasts, it will be a rarity in the Medicare program’s history.
lead_paragraph: Medicare spending isn’t just lower than experts predicted a few years ago. On a per-person basis, Medicare spending is actually falling.

headline: How Investors Can Kill a Business Without Losing Money Themselves
abstract: It all starts so well. You meet venture capitalists and deliver a knockout pitch. They love it, you exchange business cards, they set out the next steps – and then you fall into the trap.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of a trap into which I’ve fallen twice at Posse. Investors often set the trap unknowingly – no harm is intended – while they are figuring out whether they would like to invest. Both times this happened I felt heartbroken and exhausted, with my business in turmoil. We were lucky to survive.

headline: 1914: Turkish Desire for War
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Ottoman Empire', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Turkey considers entering WWI in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Reports of German successes, skilfully exaggerated, have enormously reinforced the following of Enver Pasha, and telegrams from Constantinople speak of war as inevitable. Turkey would attack Russia in the Caucasus and Greece at the same time, if Bulgaria will permit the Ottoman troops to traverse her country. It is known that the Russophile party in Sofia is in the ascendant. The Bulgarians are afraid that Turkey, if victorious, would refuse to evacuate the strip of territory traversed by her troops on their way to attack Salonica. It should be added that Russia has declared at Sofia that if the passage of Turkish troops is permitted she will disembark troops at Varna. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 4, 1914

headline: Making the Leap From Web to Mobile Apps Easier
abstract: Most people don’t like to download mobile apps. But when they do, they spend nearly all of their time in them. A new start-up called DWNLD is promising to make it cheaper and easier for publishers to convert their sites into attractive apps.
lead_paragraph: There’s a curious paradox at the heart of mobile apps: Most people don’t like to download them. But when they do, they spend nearly all of their time in them.

headline: 1939: War on Germany Declared
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: France and Britain declare war against Germany in 1939.
lead_paragraph: A quarter of a century after the outbreak of the World War, France and Britain again went to war with Germany yesterday. Britain was in a state of war at 11 a.m., while France entered the war at 5 p.m. The immediate cause was the failure of Chancellor Adolf Hitler to reply to the ultimatum sent him by the two countries demanding that he withdraw his troops from Poland. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 4, 1939

headline: Morning Agenda: Debating a Court’s Definition
abstract: A missing definition in the Hobby Lobby case. | The trading platform IEX raises $75 million. | Dollar store battle heats up. | An unusual signature in a recent regulatory filing drew attention to Nu Skin.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court ruled in the Hobby Lobby case that companies with religious owners could not be required to provide contraceptive coverage for their employees, it did not apply the decision to all corporations, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Instead, the court merely held that for-profit “closely held corporations” could be exempt from providing the coverage under the Affordable Care Act, raising questions about what, exactly, this phrase meant.

headline: Interest in Solar Water Heating Spreads Globally
abstract: Many developing countries, which struggle with high energy prices relative to income, have embraced the technology.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To produce milk and cheese for the world, dairies need cows and grass. But they also go through enormous amounts of hot water each day to flush out milk lines and clean other equipment. And so farmers on King Island, part of the Australian state of Tasmania, were delighted when workers began installing solar arrays on their dairies’ rooftops to capture the energy of the harsh Australian sun and use it to heat water.

headline: Vamp It Up
abstract: After so many sporty seasons, brooding underworld looks finally get their moment out of the sun.
lead_paragraph: After so many sporty seasons, brooding underworld looks finally get their moment out of the sun.

headline: Gay Groups to March in St. Patrick’s Day Parade as a Ban Falls
abstract: The decision to allow a gay group to march under its own banner in the New York parade ends a policy that has prompted protests, court battles and bitter debate for decades.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of the New York City St. Patrick’s Day parade said on Wednesday that they were lifting a ban on openly gay groups marching under their own banner, bringing to a close more than two decades of bitter protests and controversy that thrust an annual celebration into the national gay rights debate.

headline: Obama Condemns Sotloff Execution
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Muslims and Islam', 'International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president said that the killing of an American, Steven Sotloff, by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria only strengthened the United States’ resolve “to take the fight against these terrorists.”
lead_paragraph: The president said that the killing of an American, Steven Sotloff, by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria only strengthened the United States’ resolve “to take the fight against these terrorists.”

headline: Money in a Time of Zero
abstract: This was all predictable — and predicted.
lead_paragraph: My old teacher Charles Kindleberger used to say that anyone who spends too much time thinking about international money goes mad; he meant that people start obsessing about the international role of the dollar or whatever, and start to think that it’s the most important thing in the world, when it’s actually fairly trivial. What he didn’t say, but seems obvious these days, is that a similar thing happens to people who spend too much time thinking about money in general — specifically, on trying to decode money’s true meaning and find the real, true measure of the money supply; they end up starting to believe that everything in economics hinges on getting that measure right, when in fact almost nothing does.

headline: In the Parching West, It’s Beginning to Feel like 1159
abstract: To find a similar period of Western drought to the current recent span, you’d have to go back to 1159.
lead_paragraph: Doyle Rice has an invaluable piece in USA Today placing California’s persistent and exceptional* drought in the broader context of a very dry West — and the even broader context of the last 1,000 years or so.

headline: With Galaxy Note 4 Release, Samsung Still Betting on Big Phones
abstract: The company is rushing to announce new large-format phones in advance of Apple’s big – and possibly big-screen – announcement next week.

headline: Lawmakers Love AmeriCorps, but Won’t Expand It
abstract: Republicans well aware of the good work being done by AmeriCorps nevertheless shrink from voicing objection when their colleagues put it on the chopping block.
lead_paragraph: Like so much gone awry in Washington of late, the failure to expand AmeriCorps, the nation’s main public service program, is largely the fault of the right-wing Republicans who now control the House and keep approving extreme budget resolutions calling for the program’s elimination.

lead_paragraph: Light from exploding stars can live on in the form of echoes, rippling across space and illuminating clouds of dust and gas that might otherwise be invisible.

headline: The V838 Monocerotis Star Still Has Astronomers’ Heads Exploding
abstract: The eruption of a star 20,000 years ago made it a million times as luminous as the sun, and its violent beauty still echoes through space.
lead_paragraph: For astronomers and aficionados of cosmic violence, an obscure star known as V838 Monocerotis has turned out to be a gift that has kept on giving for a long, long time.

abstract: On its 125th anniversary, Barnard College, which operates in partnership with Columbia University, is asserting its campus individuality with a new graphics campaign.

headline: Shanghai Museum Unveils Memorial to Jews Who Found Haven in City
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: By the beginning of World War II, more European Jews fleeing Nazi persecution had fled to Shanghai than any other city in the world. A newly dedicated memorial lists thousands who made there way there.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:11 a.m. ET| The Shanghai Jewish Refugees Museum unveiled a memorial wall on Wednesday listing the names of 13,732 Jews who found a haven in the Chinese city during World War II.

headline: E.U. Urges Sharing Data to Avert Air Disasters
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Europe’s top aviation safety agency called on national governments to better enable international regulators and airlines to assess the risks of flying over conflict zones.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Responding to the downing of a Malaysian passenger jet over eastern Ukraine in July, Europe’s top aviation safety agency urged national governments on Wednesday to share intelligence data with the aviation authorities to better enable international regulators and airlines to assess the risks of flying over conflict zones.

headline: Theodore Wafer Sentenced to 17 Years in Michigan Shooting of Renisha McBride
abstract: Mr. Wafer, who was found guilty of second-degree murder and other charges after shooting and killing Ms. McBride on the front porch of his suburban Detroit home, was sentenced to a minimum of 17 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The defendant stood facing the judge in Wayne County Circuit Court here on Wednesday, speaking tremulously and in a low voice, and apologized to the family of Renisha McBride, the 19-year-old woman he shot and killed on the front porch of his suburban home last year.

headline: Chris Evans Will Answer Reader Questions
abstract: Chris Evans will be at the Toronto International Film Festival this week with his directorial debut, “Before We Go.” And he’ll be taking your questions while there.
lead_paragraph: From sci-fi protagonist to comedy player to, yes, the Human Torch and Captain America, the actor Chris Evans has brought an interesting collection of characters to life on the big screen. Now he’s going to work behind the camera as well. On Sept. 12, Mr. Evans will premiere his directorial debut, the romance “Before We Go,” at the Toronto International Film Festival. He and Alice Eve star as two strangers  who connect one night at Grand Central Terminal after a missed train.

headline: Former Goldman Banker Joins Perella Weinberg
abstract: Stefan Green, formerly of Goldman Sachs, has joined Perella Weinberg Partners as a partner.
lead_paragraph: Stefan Green, formerly of Goldman Sachs, has joined Perella Weinberg Partners as a partner.

headline: Centerview Hires Former Bank Bailout Adviser to Britain
abstract: Robin Budenberg, who helped advise the British government on its bank bailouts during the financial crisis, has joined Centerview Partners as its chairman in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The boutique investment bank Centerview Partners said on Wednesday that it had hired Robin Budenberg, a former investment banker who helped advise the British government on its bailouts of the Lloyds Banking Group, Royal Bank of Scotland and other banks during the financial crisis.

headline: Voting Restrictions Are Key Variable in Midterm Elections
abstract: Eight states have narrowed early-balloting opportunities, and three of them feature Senate races that could decide which party holds a majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Voting in midterm elections, which will determine control of Congress, ends this fall. But it starts in North Carolina this week.

headline: Senate Control May Turn on Who’s More Unloved, Obama or G.O.P.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: President Obama’s approval ratings are low, hurting Democratic candidates, but the Republican Party is also far from popular.
lead_paragraph: With the campaign season officially begun, Republicans hold a modest but clear advantage in the fight for control of the Senate. Leo, The Upshot’s Senate model, gives the G.O.P. a 66 percent chance of winning a majority.

headline: Chinese Authorities Search for Whereabouts of Toxic Capsules
abstract: An investigation is underway to track the whereabouts of 90 million drug capsules contaminated with the heavy metal chromium that were released to the market in China earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:51 p.m. ET| An investigation is underway to track the whereabouts of 90 million drug capsules contaminated with the heavy metal chromium that were released to the market in China earlier this year, according to officials in the eastern province of Zhejiang.

headline: W.H.O. Concerned About Another Ebola Cluster in Nigeria
abstract: William Pooley contracted the disease in August while volunteering as a nurse in Sierra Leone but recovered after 10 days of treatment in London.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization expressed worry on Wednesday about a second cluster of Ebola virus patients in Nigeria — in the center of its oil industry — because one of the three confirmed victims was a doctor who had treated patients and socialized after he became contagious.

headline: 9 Things You Maybe Didn’t Know About Mitch McConnell
abstract: Here are a few more facts about the Mitch McConnell, his state and his opponent, Alison Lundergan Grimes, that you may not know.
lead_paragraph: If you read my magazine article about Senator Mitch McConnell and what may be his final campaign this fall, you’ll learn that he loves Morris’ Deli (check the photo), owns both a BlackBerry and an iPad and has, by Senator Harry Reid’s count, orchestrated 442 filibusters since President Obama took office. Here are a few more facts about the senator, his state and his opponent, Alison Lundergan Grimes, that you may not know:

headline: Enchanted Words
abstract: Kelly Barnhill’s “The Witch’s Boy” is set in an absorbing world of kingdoms and prophecies in which transformation comes through language, courage and self-awareness.
lead_paragraph: Every avid reader shares the belief that words are powerful. Words can hurt; they can heal, save, inspire, destroy and create. As Kelly Barnhill writes in “The Witch’s Boy,” her latest middle-grade novel, “a word, after all, is a kind of magic.” It’s a story with many alluring elements, including a boy who is rejected by his village after surviving an accident that killed his identical twin; a bandit king’s motherless daughter; a wolf; and a little clay pot full of magic. Barnhill (“Iron Hearted Violet,” “The Mostly True Story of Jack”) creates an absorbing world of kingdoms and prophecies in which transformation comes through language, and through courage and self-awareness as well.

headline: Chappaqua, N.Y.: A Hamlet in a Woodsy Setting
abstract: Changes may be on the horizon for this leafy hamlet with meandering country roads, stone walls and little shops where the sales people know everyone by name.
lead_paragraph: “When I tell people we live in the woods, I really mean that,” said Paul Keyes, describing his life in Chappaqua in northern Westchester. “When I pull off the road after the long trip home from work and finally come up our driveway, I feel like I’ve gone on vacation to the Adirondacks.”

headline: Real-World Development
abstract: The New York Times continued our technology internship program this summer, and Danielle Rothermel, one of the interns in this year’s class, discusses what she learned.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times continued our technology internship program this summer, and Danielle Rothermel, one of the interns in this year’s class, discusses what she learned.

headline: Penguin Random House Plans to Combine 2 Units
abstract: The company said in a statement Wednesday that the Penguin Adult and Berkley/NAL groups would join to form the Penguin Publishing Group.
lead_paragraph: In the latest reorganization at Penguin Random House since the two publishers merged last year, the company will combine two units in another effort to streamline its operations.

headline: Quality of Life Improving Across Wall Street, Report Says
abstract: The Blackstone Group was deemed the best bank to work for in North America, according to a report by Vault.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s efforts to improve working conditions for junior bankers appear to be paying off.

headline: The Battle for New York Schools: Eva Moskowitz vs. Mayor Bill de Blasio
abstract: The fight between two liberal crusaders with profoundly divergent ideas about how to aid and educate the disempowered.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon this summer, Eva Moskowitz, who runs Success Academy Charter Schools, showed me her senior yearbook. “I was the editor,” she said. We sat in a half-furnished office at the construction site of her charter network’s first high school. A buzz saw shrieked in the background. She graduated in 1982 from Stuyvesant, the most selective of New York City’s public high schools. “I got completely engaged in how to take this sentimental book and make it a much bigger project.” She fought to publish photographs capturing the political protests of that time — against nuclear weapons, against American aid to the government in El Salvador. To go with the pictures, she wrote a manifesto, concluding: “We do not live in a vacuum.”

headline: North Carolina Men Are Released After Convictions Are Overturned
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Henry Lee McCollum, 50, was released a day after a North Carolina judge threw out his conviction in a 1983 rape and murder. Mentally disabled, he must now learn to live in a world he has not experienced since he was a teenager.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Henry Lee McCollum had barely slept in days, terrified that his dream of 31 years — being released from North Carolina’s death row — might not come true.

headline: The Sportier Side of Fall Men’s Fashion
abstract: There’s a relaxed athleticism coursing through men’s fashion, taking inspiration from the street and mixing it with the office.
lead_paragraph: There’s a relaxed athleticism coursing through men’s fashion, taking inspiration from the street and mixing it with the office.

headline: Dan O’Brien and Suzan-Lori Parks Win Horton Foote Prize
abstract: Mr. O’Brien’s “The Body of an American” received the award for outstanding new American play, while “Father Comes Home From the Wars (Parts 1, 2, & 3)” by Ms. Parks was selected for promising new American play.
lead_paragraph: The playwrights Dan O’Brien and Suzan-Lori Parks are the 2014 recipients of the Horton Foote Prize, given every other year to honor excellence in American theater. The prize committee announced on Wednesday that Mr. O’Brien’s “The Body of an American” received the award for outstanding new American play, while “Father Comes Home From the Wars (Parts 1, 2, & 3)” by Ms. Parks was selected for promising new American play.

headline: Why Leaked Nude Photos Are Another Frontier for Feminists
abstract: After nude photos of famous women were leaked on the Internet, many observers are asking if online harassment of celebrities and women can be reined in or punished.
lead_paragraph: “A trove of nude celebrity photos spread like wildfire across the Internet over Labor Day weekend,” Mike Isaac writes for The New York Times. “The photos, which included images of the actress Jennifer Lawrence and the model Kate Upton, became available after someone — and who did it is unknown — posted the pictures to 4chan and Reddit, two hugely popular anonymous online message boards.”

headline: 2014 Fantasy Football Weekly Player Rankings
abstract: Jason and Justin Sablich provide weekly player rankings for standard and PPR scoring formats. They will be updated throughout the season.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich provide weekly player rankings for standard and PPR scoring formats. They will be updated throughout the season.

headline: Obama Urges NATO to Help Ukraine
abstract: President Obama pushed the alliance to send a message of support to Ukraine and to help modernize and strengthen its security forces.
lead_paragraph: President Obama pushed the alliance to send a message of support to Ukraine and to help modernize and strengthen its security forces.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
abstract: Demand for property around Lake Tegernsee far exceeds supply, with no new plots available to build homes in the valley between the mountains and lake.
lead_paragraph: A THREE-BEDROOM COTTAGE IN THE BAVARIAN ALPS

headline: Obama, in Estonia, Calls Ukraine Conflict a ‘Moment of Testing’
abstract: In a speech in Estonia, President Obama cast Russia as the aggressor in Ukraine and said borders could not be redrawn “at the barrel of a gun.”
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — President Obama on Wednesday called the conflict in Ukraine a “moment of testing” for the United States and Europe, and condemned Russia’s intervention as a “brazen assault” on the nation’s territorial integrity that warrants a unified response.

headline: Deportations Have ‘No Observable Effect’ on Crime Rate, Study Concludes
abstract: An analysis by two law professors concludes that Secure Communities, a federal program intended to improve public safety, has had “no observable effect” on crime rates.
lead_paragraph: Six years after the federal government opened an immigration enforcement program intended to improve public safety, deporting hundreds of thousands of people, many of them convicted criminals, a new study has concluded that the program has had “no observable effect on the overall crime rate.”

headline: Today in Small Business: The Coolest New Businesses in New York
abstract: Leadership techniques that do not work. Mistakes that e-commerce sites make. And nine things not to do when trying to sell a business.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Prosecutor on Insider Trading Cases Heads to Private Practice
abstract: Antonia M. Apps, the lead federal prosecutor in the criminal trial last year of Michael Steinberg, is taking a job with the law firm Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy.
lead_paragraph: The ranks of the federal prosecutors who played a major role in the crackdown on insider trading continues to thin.

headline: 36 Hours in Nashville
abstract: Music City is amped for a comeback, driven by local creativity, entrepreneurship and a D.I.Y. attitude.
lead_paragraph: Music City is amped for a comeback, driven by local creativity, entrepreneurship and a D.I.Y. attitude.

headline: Lisa D’Amour’s ‘Airline Highway’ Coming to Broadway
abstract: It will be the first new play by a woman to make it to Broadway since 2013.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan Theater Club executives announced on Wednesday that they would produce a new play on Broadway by a female writer in the spring of 2015 – the first in two years, to the frustration of many artists. The play, “Airline Highway,” a dark comedy by Lisa D’Amour about a gathering of friends in the parking lot of a rundown Louisiana motel, will begin preview performances at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on April 1, 2015, and open on April 23, in time to qualify for the 2015 Tony Award nominations. It will be the first Broadway production for Ms. D’Amour, who won an Obie Award and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist for her play “Detroit.”

headline: 36 Hours in Nashville
abstract: Sure, you can still tap your feet to a country beat in Music City, but keep exploring and you’ll find everything from enticing shops to a dynamic food scene.
lead_paragraph: Country music is alive and well in Nashville; you might even see a young family in broad daylight practicing their line dancing on the sidewalk outside a bar downtown — all in cowboy boots, including the toddler who just learned to walk. But these days, there’s much more to the Tennessee capital than country. One of seven cities chosen to begin Google for Entrepreneurs Tech Hub Network, Nashville is bustling with new business. The dynamic food scene draws an international clientele and chefs from bigger cities. There’s money to preserve historic buildings and revitalize neighborhoods, like Germantown, which was established by European immigrants in the 1850s. Add a farmers’ market, some enticing shops and a batch of very stylish hotel rooms, and it’s hard not to conclude that the city is changing its tune — or at least adding a few new riffs.

headline: First Vaccine for Dengue Fever Shows Promise in 2nd Big Trial
abstract: A French drug company said that use of the vaccine cut the risk of getting dengue by 60.8 percent and those vaccinated had an 80 percent lower risk of being hospitalized for the disease.
lead_paragraph: An experimental vaccine against dengue fever being developed by Sanofi proved about 60 percent effective in its second large clinical trial. The results could clear the way for the introduction of the world’s first inoculation against the disease, which is mosquito-borne and becoming an increasing threat.

headline: Michael Sam Gains Second Chance by Joining the Cowboys’ Practice Squad
abstract: Sam, a defensive lineman who is the first openly gay player to be drafted by an N.F.L. team, was released by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The rookie defensive lineman Michael Sam, who was released by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday, joined the practice squad of the Dallas Cowboys on Wednesday. Sam, the first openly gay player drafted by an N.F.L. team, had failed to win a spot with the Rams despite a solid showing in the preseason in which he had 11 tackles and three sacks.

headline: Finnish Conductor Will Be First Woman to Lead Helsinki Philharmonic
abstract: Susanna Malkki has been named music director of the Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Susanna Malkki, a Finnish conductor who has appeared often in New York and has made a powerful impression in both new music and the standard repertory, has been appointed chief conductor of the Helsinki Philharmonic Orchestra, the orchestra announced. She will be the first female music director of the orchestra, which was founded in 1882 and describes itself as the first professional symphony orchestra founded in the Nordic countries.

headline: Gina Sanders Named President of Global Development at Condé Nast
abstract: Ms. Sanders previously worked as president and chief executive officer of Fairchild Fashion Media, which Condé Nast sold to Penske Media last month.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of major changes at Condé Nast, the magazine publisher has created a new role for a longtime executive, Gina Sanders, who will become president of the company’s global development.

headline: An Artistic Clan Under One Roof
abstract: Blythe Danner plays the high bohemian matriarch of an artistic clan in “The Country House,” the new play by Donald Margulies.
lead_paragraph: Blythe Danner should have no trouble finding her way around the title structure of “The Country House,” the new play by Donald Margulies. In this latest offering from the author of “Dinner With Friends,” Ms. Danner plays the high bohemian matriarch of an artistic clan. This enduringly graceful actress knows from creative offspring, being the mother of the film star Gwyneth Paltrow and the director Jake Paltrow.

headline: Surviving Battle With Amazon, Entrepreneur Picks New Fight
abstract: A textbook rental service changed course after Amazon, a supplier, cut it off. The service found a lucrative niche working with campus bookstores.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Alan Martin was attending Webster University, pursuing a master’s degree in procurement and acquisitions at a campus in Utah, when he realized he was able to sell his used textbooks for about the same price he had paid for them.

headline: Court Challenge to New Inversion Rules Would Face Long Odds
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As the government considers new regulations to curb inversions, a review of Tax Court cases shows the rules would most likely withstand any legal challenge, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department is considering new regulations that would make corporate inversions less profitable. Hedge fund managers, investment bankers and others are handicapping the timing and scope of any new rules and to whom they would apply. Possibilities include further limiting earnings stripping, reclassifying certain debt held by United States subsidiaries of foreign corporations as equity or restricting the repatriation of untaxed offshore cash from corporations that have gone through an inversion.

headline: In the Studio | Jason Wu
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Jason Wu chats with Vanessa Friedman about his evolution from a doll clothing designer working out of his living room to an established fashion designer with a sizable and sophisticated showroom.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wu chats with Vanessa Friedman about his evolution from a doll clothing designer working out of his living room to an established fashion designer with a sizable and sophisticated showroom.

headline: What’s Inside Jason Wu’s Office
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: For the fashion designer Jason Wu, his office holds both inspiration and sentiment. And then there’s that cat.
lead_paragraph: Where does a collection begin? In the mind and imagination of a designer, of course, but also in a physical space, an insider sanctum that is almost never seen by consumers: the office and atelier. In many ways, these private spaces reflect the choices and points of view that inform fashion as much as any runway show. If in doubt, simply consider the outtakes from a series of behind-the-velvet-curtain videos in which designers from New York to Paris invited The New York Times into their professional lives. First up: Jason Wu, who opened his namesake label in 2006 and shot to fame as the designer of Michelle Obama’s inaugural gowns, in his New York office. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Glenn Close’s Characters
abstract: Glenn Close is returning to Broadway for the first time in nearly 20 years to star in Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance.” She talks about what has drawn her to various roles in theater and film.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Close is returning to Broadway for the first time in nearly 20 years to star in Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance.” She talks about what has drawn her to various roles in theater and film.

headline: Weekly Quandary: Should You Push a Child to Play a Sport?
abstract: Have you pushed a child into a sport or onto a team, and was it a success? Or are there other ways of making friends and staying active?
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary came via email: Should you make a child who is not interested sign up for a sport?

headline: Balancing Bliss and ‘Dark Sadness’
abstract: Glenn Close is returning to Broadway for the first time in 20 years this fall in Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance.”
lead_paragraph: SCARBOROUGH, Me. — When Glenn Close first visited this beach town a decade ago, she walked into a kitchen and found a stuffed white bunny in a pot on the stove. It was yet another “Fatal Attraction” joke, but this time, Ms. Close laughed: She was smitten with the prankster, David Shaw, a venture capitalist she had started dating. Later, on the lawn of his waterfront home, they put on inflatable sumo wrestler suits and bumped bellies until Ms. Close was flailing like a turtle on its back. They married in 2006, and Ms. Close has since become a summertime Mainer, even mastering beach bocce ball with a zeal that would impress Patty Hewes, her cutthroat character on the cable series “Damages.”

headline: Marching While Gay: It’s Now O.K.
abstract: The organizers of New York’s St. Patrick’s Day parade will finally allow gay participants.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of New York’s St. Patrick’s Day parade have bowed to pressure and will allow a group of gay NBC employees both to march and to acknowledge while they are marching that they are, in fact, gay.

headline: Hit by Russian Boycott, European Union Increases Marketing Budget for Its Farm Goods
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'International Relations']
abstract: Polish apple growers and Finnish cheese producers are particularly exposed to agricultural sanctions, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union’s agriculture commissioner said Wednesday that he planned to double the amount of money available for promoting the sale of farm goods, in an effort to counteract the effects of a boycott by Russia, an important export market for European producers.

headline: Short, Spare and Spirited
abstract: Tantalizing theater comes in small packages this season.
lead_paragraph: Keep it simple. Keep it short.

headline: Superhero, Psycho, Statesman (Singing!)
abstract: Innovative musical theater Off Broadway is having a fertile season, with characters including superheroes, a serial killer and Alexander Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: The words “Broadway” and “musical” have become so tethered in the popular imagination that it is worth reminding people that much of the most innovative musical theater in New York — make that virtually all of the most innovative musical theater in New York — happens Off Broadway. While Broadway must play it safe, relying on tried (and trite) formulas to rope in the crowds, artists can take chances Off Broadway, where the stakes are lower, the audiences more adventurous and the landscape more nurturing to new ideas.

headline: France Postpones Delivery of Warship to Russia
abstract: The decision by President François Hollande indicates that Western governments are becoming more assertive in confronting Russia over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France threw a highly contentious arms deal with Russia into doubt on Wednesday over the Ukraine crisis, saying it was premature to schedule the delivery of a sophisticated French-built warship to the Russian Navy.

headline: New Kids, New Kids, What a Helluva Team
abstract: “On the Town” marked the Broadway debut of Leonard Bernstein, Jerome Robbins, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, a foursome known as “the kids.”
lead_paragraph: By November 1944, the director, producer, playwright, sometime actor and full-time theater maestro George Abbott had already exerted his legendary control over Jimmy Durante, various vaudevillians looking to go legit and even, in “Jumbo,” a live elephant. But the roomful of tyros that had assembled in rehearsals for “On the Town” posed a new challenge for the 57-year-old “Mr. Abbott,” as everyone called him.

headline: Another Argument (and Diversion) Over a Reclining Seat
abstract: A Delta flight was diverted on Monday after passengers began arguing about a reclining seat–the third flight in less than two weeks that made an unscheduled landing after disputes over reclining between travelers.
lead_paragraph: A third flight in less than two weeks made an unscheduled landing Monday night because of passengers fighting over reclining seats. Delta Flight 2370, on its way from La Guardia Airport to Palm Beach International, was diverted to Jacksonville when one passenger began yelling at the woman sitting in front of her for reclining her seat, ABC News reported.

headline: It Was Fun Being the Hero Who Saves the Day
abstract: But those days are over. Here’s why I’m changing the way I manage.
lead_paragraph: In a previous post, I offered a preliminary post-mortem in which I talked about some of the things we learned from our nearly disastrous handling of one customer’s order. In this post, I want to wrap up this series of posts by talking about how my thinking about my own role at the company has changed.

headline: In Hermès Agreement, a Rare Retreat by a Luxury Deal Maker
abstract: Bernard Arnault will distribute to shareholders the stake he built up in Hermès. But Groupe Arnault will retain 8.5 percent of its capital, suggesting it is keeping its long-term options open, Carol Ryan of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Arnault has conceded defeat.

headline: The Five Best Men’s Collections That Won’t Be Showing During Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: A first look at standout designs for spring/summer 2015, which the New York designers won’t be sending down a runway or presenting by appointment.
lead_paragraph: For men’s wear, New York Fashion Week has become less a traditional week of shows and more a smattering of presentations. Some designers have elected to forgo presentations and editors’ previews altogether, including these five up-and-comers who challenge the heritage-based “all-American” aesthetic that has become typical of many New York men’s wear labels. Here T offers an exclusive first look at their spring/summer 2015 collections.

headline: Chris Cillizza Plays Our Senate Forecasting Game
abstract: The Washington Post political analyst expects Senate races to be subject to powerful local dynamics in 2014, rather than be swept up in a national wave.
lead_paragraph: We are inviting political experts to play our Predict the Midterms game, and we’ll be talking to them about their entries. Our first such entrant is Chris Cillizza, founder of The Fix blog at The Washington Post.

headline: How to Find Special Characters on an iPad
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Tablet Computers', 'iPad', 'Computer Keyboards', 'Bluetooth Wireless Technology']
abstract: Plus, copying files from an Android tablet.
lead_paragraph: Q. I connected a Bluetooth keyboard to my iPad Air, and by accident I found a few special characters like §, Ç and ß that appear with certain keystrokes. How do I find out the key combinations for more international characters and symbols?

headline: Diversity in Action, as Well as in Words
abstract: New ABC shows feature an Asian family comedy, a black actress as the star of a new drama, and a black family comedy.
lead_paragraph: It seems like a parody put together by a coalition of the activist groups that have dogged television networks for years about their halfhearted (or less) commitment to presenting a range of racial and ethnic groups among their series:

headline: ZenPayroll Gives Small Business the Tech Tools of Big Business
abstract: For all the crowing about small business as an engine of the economy, makers of business software have focused on big companies. Now a group of cloud-based services focusing on the little guy.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the talk of this being the entrepreneurial age, the times — and technology — still favor the big guy.

headline: A Long Gestation for U2’s Next Album
abstract: U2’s newest album was supposed to come out in 2014, but plans for the album have been changing since 2009.
lead_paragraph: U2, the Irish band formed way back in 1976, has long been feeling like a lonely upholder of the mantle of the Big Rock Band: the kind that headlines stadiums and lodges songs deep in the public consciousness. Its pealing guitars and martial beat have cast a long musical shadow over all the bands in its wake — from Coldplay to OneRepublic to Imagine Dragons — who strive to write high-minded rock anthems. Yet U2 has also sought to expand, and at times escape, its own signature sound.

headline: The Road to Amerli
abstract: Last week, Azam Ahmed traveled with a photographer and a fixer, to Amerli, the only town to have successfully defended itself against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, to interview villagers.
lead_paragraph: Azam Ahmed is a Times correspondent in Kabul. This week he traveled with a photographer and a fixer to Amerli, the only town to have successfully defended itself against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, to interview villagers.

headline: Inviting Young Readers to Take Sides in a Crayon-Labor Dispute
abstract: The publisher of “The Day the Crayons Quit,” a best seller about a group of disgruntled crayons who go on strike, is inviting children to take sides.
lead_paragraph: “The Day the Crayons Quit,” a cheeky illustrated book about a group of disgruntled crayons who go on strike, is the kind of surprise best seller that no one sees coming. The book, which has more than a million copies in print, recently went into its 10th printing. It’s been on The New York Times best-seller list for more than a year. This past July, it was optioned for film by Universal Pictures.

headline: D-Day for Pre-K
abstract: Across New York City, teachers and parents scrambled to be ready for the start of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s expanded prekindergarten program on the first day of the new school year.
lead_paragraph: Across New York City, teachers and parents scrambled to be ready for the start of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s expanded prekindergarten program on the first day of the new school year.

headline: Neiman Marcus to Join the Manhattan Elite
abstract: Neiman Marcus, to open in 2018, is the first retailer announced for the Hudson Yards complex on the Far West Side.
lead_paragraph: It took 107 years, but Neiman Marcus is moving to Manhattan.

headline: Where to Print Those Vacation Photos
abstract: We tested several sites to help you decide where to print your shots. Here’s what we found.
lead_paragraph: Barry Schwartz, the psychologist and author of “The Paradox of Choice,” once said: “With so many options to choose from, people find it very difficult to choose at all.” That’s how I feel when I want to print a few vacation photos. The Internet is rife with companies willing to print your digital snapshots for little more than the cost of a Cronut. But which sites produce the most eye-catching prints?

headline: Sony and Asus Jump Into Smartwatch Fray
abstract: Consumers appear to be unimpressed by smartwatches. But tech companies continue to make new ones in the hope that one of them will catch on.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Many of the world’s largest technology companies are finding it tough to persuade people to splurge on new devices ike smartwatches and fitness bands.

headline: Hamas Emerges Buoyant Despite Bloodshed and Devastation in Gaza
abstract: Polls show an unprecedented spike in support for Hamas despite a lack of basic needs like electricity and clean water, as Gaza residents blame others for the devastation.
lead_paragraph: BEIT HANOUN, Gaza Strip — Ismail Haniya, the top Hamas leader in Gaza, worked the crowd in what used to be the Boura neighborhood of this battered northern border town, kissing the cheeks of elders and the foreheads of masked fighters. He waved at the women standing in front of makeshift huts next to the homes flattened in Israeli attacks, as children watched from atop concrete piles where green Hamas flags were planted as though on conquered lands.

headline: A Legacy Helps Young Photographers
abstract: After the death of Ian Parry, his friends and colleagues established a scholarship to nurture and encourage young photographers.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — An exhibit of scholarship winners and runners-up of the Ian Parry Awards will show this week at Visa Pour l’Image festival.

headline: Commitments on Three Fronts Test Obama’s Foreign Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: New defensive initiatives, in Asia and Europe and against Islamic extremists, are bound to upend President Obama’s military budget plans and challenge his military doctrine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In vowing in Estonia on Wednesday to defend vulnerable NATO nations from Russia “for as long as necessary,” President Obama has now committed the United States to three major projections of its power: a “pivot” to Asia, a more muscular presence in Europe and a new battle against Islamic extremists that seems very likely to accelerate.

headline: Casting Director Noah Shelley’s Brooklyn-Centric New York Fashion Week Black Book
abstract: The fashion industry veteran, who oversees the runways for clients such as Opening Ceremony and Maison Kitsuné, offers suggestions for on-the-go eating, dressing and more.
lead_paragraph: As one half, with Angus Munro, of the agency AM Casting, Noah Shelley oversees the look of the runways for such design houses as Opening Ceremony and Maison Kitsuné (in New York), Preen and Erdem (in London) and Ann Demeulemeester and Rick Owens (in Paris). An industry veteran who once ran the studio of the photographers Inez Van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, Shelley divides his time between Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn, and the Venice Beach section of Los Angeles, where he escapes for regular surf trips. T caught up with Shelley between New York Fashion Week castings to hear his suggestions for on-the-go eating, dressing and functioning in style.

headline: Federal Judge, Bucking Trend, Affirms Ban on Same-Sex Marriages in Louisiana
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Until Wednesday, there had been 21 consecutive federal court decisions finding gay marriage bans unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A federal judge here upheld the state’s ban on same-sex marriage on Wednesday, going against what had been a unanimous trend of federal court decisions striking down such bans since the Supreme Court ruled on the matter last year.

headline: A Deep Breath Before the Runway
abstract: The Council of Fashion Designers’ Health Initiative has focused in years past on the problems of eating disorders and underage models. This year, it is urging deep breaths.
lead_paragraph: Founded in 2007 as public-relations triage in an industry oft-accused of both superficiality and excess, the Council of Fashion Designers’ Health Initiative has focused in years past on the problems of eating disorders and underage models. This year, it is urging deep breaths.

headline: Antibiotics Eliminated in Hatchery, Perdue Says
keywords: ['Poultry', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The poultry producer’s step was its latest in addressing concerns from consumer and regulators over the effects of animal husbandry practices on antibiotic resistance.
lead_paragraph: Perdue, one of the country’s largest poultry producers, said on Wednesday that it would no longer use antibiotics in its hatcheries, one of the last places it was using such drugs routinely.

headline: ISIS Is a Disgrace to True Fundamentalism
abstract: If these so-called fundamentalists believe they have found their way to Truth, why are they threatened by nonbelievers?
lead_paragraph: It has become a commonplace in recent months to observe that the rise of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, is the latest chapter in the long story of the anticolonial awakening — the arbitrary borders drawn after World War I by the great powers being redrawn — and simultaneously a chapter in the struggle against the way global capital undermines the power of nation states. But what causes such fear and consternation is another feature of the ISIS regime: The public statements of the ISIS authorities make it clear that the principal task of state power is not the regulation of the welfare of the state’s population (health, the fight against hunger) — what really matters is religious life and the concern that all public life obey religious laws. This is why ISIS remains more or less indifferent toward humanitarian catastrophes within its domain — its motto is roughly “take care of religion and welfare will take care of itself.” Therein resides the gap that separates the notion of power practiced by ISIS from the modern Western notion of what Michel Foucault called “biopower,” which regulates life in order to guarantee general welfare: the ISIS caliphate totally rejects the notion of biopower.

headline: Joan Rivers Is Moved Out of Intensive Care
abstract: She has been hospitalized for almost a week after undergoing outpatient surgery.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers was moved out of intensive care almost a week after she was first hospitalized in New York, her daughter, Melissa Rivers, said on Wednesday.

headline: Isis, the Industry Group, Is Changing Its Name
abstract: Several wireless companies formed Isis in 2010 to encourage the development of wireless payment technology.
lead_paragraph: Isis has a branding problem.

headline: Uber Continues to Operate in Germany, Despite Court Ruling
abstract: Despite facing a potential ban and possible fines in Germany, Uber has not only continued to operate in the country, it has seen an increase in activity there.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A day after Uber, the popular ride-hailing service, was barred from operating in Germany, the company was still taking bookings.

headline: August Sales Fall for G.M. as Trucks Lift Chrysler
abstract: General Motors’ sales streak came to an end with a 1 percent decline in August, but Chrysler sales jumped 20 percent; Ford sales were flat.
lead_paragraph: Though battered by the recall of millions of vehicles and revelations that it failed to fix a deadly defect in its ignition switches, General Motors maintained a monthly winning streak in selling vehicles since March.

headline: Disney Details a New, Boy-Centric Animated Movie
abstract: “Big Hero 6” is about a teenage robotics prodigy who must save his city from a madman.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Disney’s last animated movie, “Frozen,” made little girls go berserk. Is Disney’s next big-screen cartoon, “Big Hero 6,” about to do the same thing for their brothers? What exactly happens in “Big Hero 6,” anyway?

headline: Calico, Google’s Anti-Aging Company, Announces New Research Facility
abstract: A Google-backed biotech company plans to build a new Bay Area-based facility to research diseases that afflict the elderly, such as neurodegeneration and cancer.
lead_paragraph: In the world according to Google, cars drive themselves, deliveries are dropped off by drones and eyeglasses double as computers. Also, people live forever.

headline: Texas Abortion Clinic to Reopen After Ruling
abstract: Whole Woman’s Health will reopen a clinic serving poor women in the Rio Grande Valley after a judge ruled that Texas’s new strictures were too restrictive.
lead_paragraph: An embattled abortion clinic in McAllen, Tex., which was the last provider of abortions in the vast Rio Grande Valley when new state restrictions forced it to stop last fall, will start operating again by this weekend, its owner said Wednesday, after last week’s favorable decision by a federal judge.

headline: Serena Williams Romps at U.S. Open and Will Face Ekaterina Makarova in the Semifinals
abstract: Williams came back to beat Flavia Pennetta, 6-3, 6-2, after Makarova downed Victoria Azarenka, 6-4, 6-2.
lead_paragraph: Three games into her match against Flavia Pennetta on Wednesday night, Serena Williams had been broken twice and trailed by 3-0.

headline: Putin on Ceasefire Plan With Ukraine
abstract: Russian president Vladimir V. Putin discussed the steps necessary for a ceasefire agreement between his country and Ukraine on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Russian president Vladimir V. Putin discussed the steps necessary for a ceasefire agreement between his country and Ukraine on Wednesday.

headline: Out of Jail, British Couple Reunite With Ill Son
abstract: Brett and Naghmeh King were released three days after being arrested for taking their 5-year-old son to Spain for alternative treatment for a brain tumor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The parents of a 5-year-old boy with a brain tumor who were arrested after taking him out of Britain to seek alternative treatment were reunited with him on Wednesday after their release from a Spanish prison.

headline: What You Get for ... $2,000,000
abstract: Water views in Puerto Rico and Maine, and a townhouse in South Carolina
lead_paragraph: VIEQUES, P.R.

headline: A Better Flu Shot
abstract: A high-dose vaccine prevents older adults from catching the flu more effectively than the standard vaccine, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: For the past four years, doctors’ offices, medical clinics and pharmacies have offered older adults high-dose versions of the annual flu vaccine. The hope was that this alternative would better protect seniors, but scientific evidence proving its effectiveness has been lacking.

headline: ‘It’s Not Me, It’s the Story’
abstract: Julianne Moore, who’s equally at home in indies and big-budget projects, goes out on an emotional limb with David Cronenberg’s “Map to the Stars.”
lead_paragraph: In her long and enviable career, Julianne Moore has made a point of appearing in both big-budget pictures like “Non-Stop,” the recent Liam Neeson thriller, and in underfunded independent films like “What Maisie Knew,” where the costume budget was so skimpy she wound up lending the production some of her own clothes. This season, she’s in the third installment of the “Hunger Games” trilogy, which opens Nov. 21, and also in David Cronenberg’s newest film, “Maps to the Stars,” scheduled to be released before the end of the year. Though set in Hollywood, “Maps” was mostly shot in Toronto, to save money, and this time Ms. Moore had to scrounge some jewelry and handbags.

headline: USA Today Cuts 70 Employees From Newsroom and Business Staff
abstract: The layoffs equaled less than 10 percent of the work force. USA Today is the flagship paper of the Gannett Company.
lead_paragraph: USA Today, the Gannett Company’s flagship paper, laid off roughly 70 people on Wednesday. The cuts appeared to be equally split between employees in the newsroom and other departments, and they equaled less than 10 percent of the total work force.

headline: Wheelies: The Little Landie Edition
abstract: Jaguar Land Rover announces pricing for the 2015 Land Rover Discovery Sport; BMW recalls about 30 more cars because of Takata air-bag parts.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Kindred Spirits Try Something New
abstract: Bill Hader and Kristen Wiig, formerly longtime co-stars on “Saturday Night Live,” take on dramatic roles in “The Skeleton Twins.”
lead_paragraph: The last time most people saw Kristen Wiig and Bill Hader together, the two were probably wearing wigs while hosting a game show, making out with family members or giving unnecessarily detailed California traffic directions on “Saturday Night Live.” The next time audiences see them together, it won’t be so funny. In the opening scene of the writer-director Craig Johnson’s “The Skeleton Twins,” opening Sept. 12, the two actors best known for Gilly and Stefon wield their hard-won chemistry to portray a brother and sister who decide to attempt suicide on the same night.

headline: Unusual Drama School in Rome Is Set to Expand
abstract: The Pathological Theater, a drama school in Rome for people with mental illness, is on its way to becoming a full-fledged university.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Changing people’s perceptions of mental illness has been a longtime mission for Dario D’Ambrosi, an Italian avant-garde actor and author. For the past five years, he has led Teatro Patologico, or the Pathological Theater, an innovative drama school here that offers classes to people with mental disabilities. Now Mr. D’Ambrosi is trying to turn his school into a full-fledged university.

headline: How Ukraine Helped Galvanize NATO
abstract: A look at how the threat of further Russian aggression has helped to unify NATO.
lead_paragraph: A look at how the threat of further Russian aggression has helped to unify NATO.

headline: Sound, via Bluetooth, Straight to Speakers
abstract: With this complex technology, finding the right speaker comes down to the little things.
lead_paragraph: BLUETOOTH wireless technology is helping take music out of headphones and back into speakers. But finding the speakers that best suit your needs means deciding among shape, color and extra features you wouldn’t normally associate with listening to music.

headline: Rock and Enroll
abstract: Scholarly musicians prove that Ph.D.s can play.
lead_paragraph: Scholarly musicians prove that Ph.D.s can play.

headline: David Hare’s ‘Skylight’ Coming to Broadway From London
abstract: The Broadway revival of “Skylight” will include its London stars, Bill Nighy and Carey Mulligan.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest hits in London this summer, a revival of David Hare’s drama “Skylight” starring Bill Nighy and Carey Mulligan, will transfer to Broadway and begin performances on March 16 at the Golden Theater, the producers announced on Wednesday. Directed by the Tony Award winner Stephen Daldry (“Billy Elliot”), “Skylight” is likely to be a force in the 2015 Tony races, given the strong critical acclaim by British and American theater critics for the production.

headline: Conceptual Anarchy
abstract: When Pierre Huyghe’s art heads to Los Angeles for his highly anticipated American retrospective, it’s not clear which of his works-in-progress will be fully incubated.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Pierre Huyghe has long loved “Locus Solus,” Raymond Roussel’s 1914 novel about an inventor who invites friends to a secluded estate to show off his creations, one of which is a tank filled with cadavers that re-enact the most important moments of their former lives, animated by a miraculous substance called resurrectine.

headline: Prehistoric Tools to Matisse Cut-Outs
abstract: The array of museum shows opening across the country this fall feels promising, almost an embarrassment of riches.
lead_paragraph: Check your frequent flier miles. The array of museum shows opening across the country this fall feels promising, almost an embarrassment of riches.

headline: Upstairs, a Walk on the Wild Side
abstract: The High Line at the Rail Yards opens on Sept. 21, with lush plantings, picnic tables, a seesaw for children and a wild, untouched section as you head west.
lead_paragraph: When the High Line at the Rail Yards, the final section of the elevated park, opens on Sept. 21, we will no longer have to stop at 30th Street and stare longingly through the construction gate at the Queen Anne’s Lace blooming in wild profusion along the old tracks.

headline: In Museums, Masters Old and New
abstract: A busy and well-balanced art season lies ahead, offering museumgoers Cubists, European and Latin American modernism, textile sculpture and Renaissance pagans.
lead_paragraph: On paper, the 2014-15 art season looks unusually well balanced, with no foreseeable leaps in the dark, but not much dead space either. It’s anchored by a substantial old-master lineup, including a big blast from Spain. “Goya: Order and Disorder” opens at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, on Oct. 12, and in early November acres of El Greco roll out at the Metropolitan Museum and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, commemorating the 400th anniversary of that ever-popular artist’s death.

headline: Transforming, but Not Disrupting
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Urban Areas', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Art']
abstract: Many American urban projects opening in the coming months are not large-scale institutions but hybrids being constructed in locations not necessarily known for design.
lead_paragraph: The new building in Dudley Square in Boston doesn’t look like anything else in sight. And yet it fits right in. That’s a good description of the tempered ambition of many American urban projects opening in the coming months: They aren’t disruptive but (their supporters hope) transformative, and their shapes, even their sparkle, come from understanding past civic hopes and redesigning them to meet the future. The curvaceous brick cornice of the Bruce C. Bolling Municipal Building in Dudley Square knits together three historic buildings, provides offices for 500 employees of the Boston Public Schools and incorporates an old rail track into its ground-floor plan, the better to connect the building to the adjacent bus station.

headline: Grading Teachers, With Data From Class
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Panorama Education, aided by prominent tech investors, is refining student feedback through innovative data collection. School systems are embracing the concept.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through the last school year, Leila Campbell, a young humanities teacher at a charter high school in Oakland, Calif., received the results from a recent survey of her students.

headline: Florida Prosecutors Face Long Odds When Police Use Lethal Force
abstract: Florida’s experience shows that it is extraordinarily difficult to prosecute, let alone convict, law enforcement officials for killing someone in the line of duty.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For decades Florida has had a history of deadly, racially tinged police confrontations, many of them involving unarmed men, which have led to riots, protests and a steady undercurrent of rancor between minorities and the police. But in the past 20 years, not a single officer in Florida has been charged with using deadly force.

headline: Buy Downstage, Sell Upstage
abstract: “Trade Practices,” presented on Governors Island, explores investing and market forces using swordplay and song-and-dance numbers.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who took a bath in the 2008 economic crisis might feel a little nervous crossing the water to Governors Island to witness that dunking all over again. In “Trade Practices,” the director Kristin Marting and the designer David Evans Morris transform Pershing Hall, a handsome former administrative building, into the headquarters of Tender Inc.

headline: Seeing Women as Key to Economy, Japan’s Leader Names 5 to Cabinet
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s reshuffled cabinet was an apparent nod toward his promises to raise the status of women in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan unveiled a reshuffled cabinet on Wednesday that included five women, an apparent nod toward his promises to raise the status of women in the workplace. The appointments tie the record for the number of women in top political positions in Japan.

headline: A Panoramic View From the Top of the U.S. Open
abstract: From the top of Arthur Ashe Stadium, a look at Tuesday’s match in which No. 2 Roger Federer dispatched No. 17 Roberto Bautista Agut.
lead_paragraph: From the top of Arthur Ashe Stadium, a look at Tuesday’s match in which No. 2 Roger Federer dispatched No. 17 Roberto Bautista Agut.

headline: Damaged but Dogged, She Prays for Her Art
abstract: Dylan Landis’s “Rainey Royal,” a novel composed of 14 episodes in a troubled girl’s life, smolders with the question of how far she will go to get a sense that she matters.
lead_paragraph: It could be a scene from “A Clockwork Orange,” or from Michael Haneke’s sadistic film “Funny Games.” A pair of insouciant stalkers overtake a young couple outside the West Village building where they live and nudge them at gunpoint up the steps and into their apartment. Chatting desultorily, weapon at the ready, the marauders steal money, photographs, letters, a watch, a cape, as their helpless victims look on, fearful and incredulous. The thieves are two “sexy” and “delectable” 16-year-old girls in tie-dye head scarves and lime-green earrings. Their names are Rainey Royal and Tina Dial, and they are best friends. The heist was a stunt, a game to test their loyalty to each other — “the wary warmth of equals” — a game that went too far.

headline: Jenna Lyons of J. Crew’s Beauty Routine
abstract: For Ms. Lyons, beauty is in the particulars.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Lyons, the president and executive creative director of J. Crew, was born in Boston and raised in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. Known for her idiosyncratic mix of quirk, prep and tailoring, Ms. Lyons has emerged in recent years as a fashion star, including cameos on the HBO series “Girls.” She lives in SoHo with her 7-year-old son, Beckett. The J. Crew spring collection will be shown on Tuesday.

headline: A U.S. Open Keepsake, Soaked With Sweat
abstract: After matches, young tennis fans seek autographs and photos, but the real competition is for the players’ soaked terry-cloth wristbands.
lead_paragraph: With the match at Arthur Ashe Stadium nearing its apparent conclusion, the scramble in the stands began. Hordes of children — mostly boys, and many spurred on by eager parents — seemed to materialize from nowhere, racing down the aisles to the front row, behind the players’ chairs.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 1 Player Tiers
abstract: Quarterback Aaron Rodgers slides down while running backs Montee Ball and Marshawn Lynch have an edge on Eddie Lacy, Arian Foster and DeMarco Murray.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Ariana Grande Is No. 1
abstract: Ms. Grande opened at No. 1 on this week’s album chart with “My Everything.”
lead_paragraph: Susan Boyle and Ariana Grande may not have a lot in common, but they do share one distinction on Billboard’s album chart: they are the only female performers in the last five years to reach No. 1 with their first two records.

headline: George Clooney to Direct Film on Phone-Hacking Scandal
keywords: ['Movies', 'Books and Literature', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The film will be based on “Hack Attack: The Inside Story of How the Truth Caught Up With Rupert Murdoch,” by the British journalist Nick Davies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — And Rupert Murdoch thought his newspaper phone hacking scandal had faded from the headlines.

headline: Alexander Wang’s Designs
abstract: A look back at Mr. Wang’s collections.
lead_paragraph: A look back at Mr. Wang’s collections.

headline: After Slow Growth, Experts Say, Health Spending Is Expected to Climb
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: After four years of very slow growth, the spending increase is linked to expanded coverage through the Affordable Care Act and to improvements in the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Government experts on Wednesday predicted a rebound in national health care spending as expansions in coverage and improvements in the economy take hold after four years of exceptionally slow growth in the nation’s medical bills.

headline: Action Films May Spur the Need to Feed
abstract: A study suggests that what you watch on TV affects how much you eat. For example, those watching “The Island” ate more than Charlie Rose viewers.
lead_paragraph: Action films may get the heart racing, but they may expand your waistline, a new study suggests.

headline: Picasso Museum to Reopen at Last, With New Leader
abstract: The Picasso Museum in Paris, under a new director, Laurent Le Bon, is to reopen after five years of renovation, a staff revolt and other drama.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With his horn-rimmed glasses and charcoal-gray suits, Laurent Le Bon is an unlikely Zorro to rescue the long-closed Musée Picasso here in the Marais quarter.

headline: Alexander Wang, Serving Two Masters
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Design']
abstract: At age 30, Alexander Wang has emerged as the most successful fashion designer of his generation, producing collections for both his own house and that of Balenciaga. Can Mr. Wang prove the skeptics wrong?
lead_paragraph: The list of what the 30-year-old designer Alexander Wang does not look like is long.

headline: A Passionate Version of Love That Scratches and Bites
abstract: The German singer Ute Lemper performed fiery renditions of Neruda’s poems at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: The seam of feral imagery that winds through the love poems of the great Chilean writer Pablo Neruda gives them a visceral intensity that makes the romantic effusions of many English-language poets seem flowery and incorporeal. As the German chanteuse Ute Lemper sang her settings of Neruda’s works at 54 Below on Tuesday evening, her beautiful but sometimes abrasive voice bit and scratched like a lover in the throes of uncontrollable passion.

headline: Justine Kurland’s Vivid, Haunting Photographs of Men and Cars
abstract: The photographer’s first New York solo show in five years captures the dark side of the American dream.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Justine Kurland has taken photographs during annual cross-country journeys from New York to the Pacific Northwest that reveal the double-edged nature of the American dream. A lifelong nomad (she grew up traveling to Renaissance festivals, where her mother sold hand-sewn clothes), her tools are her 4×5 camera and her van, which allow her to dwell, briefly, in the worlds of the marginal figures she photographs. First, there were the girls she cast as runaways, forging into forests and swimming holes. Later came images of commune members in wilderness idylls and panoramas of westbound freighters and the hobos who ride them.

headline: An App for Last-Minute Flights
abstract: Flight Tonight, a new digital application, provides travelers with a search service to find the most affordable flight leaving from a nearby airport in the next 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: Travelers who dig the spontaneity that services like Hotel Tonight afford will be happy to hear that the last-minute booking game has expanded to airline apps as well.

headline: Advocating for the Regular Guy During Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The men’s wear shows start off the week with little of the hoopla accompanying the women’s wear shows. Some lines are now ganging together on the opening day of #NYFW to stage presentations at Industria Superstudio.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows the men’s wear element of New York Fashion Week exists in a kind of calendric no-man’s land. For lots of reasons — market segment, scale of economic values, cultural disposition — women’s wear is the big tent event at the circus. Though the men’s wear shows start off the week, they do so mostly at out of the way locations with little of the hoopla that accompanies the women’s wear shows at Lincoln Center, and for an audience of news media and buyers that seems like a traveling fraternity.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 1 Player Picks
abstract: Highlighting some of the players to consider starting, and those to avoid, in Week 1 of the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: We’re very excited to welcome you back to a brand new fantasy football season.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Fever Burns
abstract: Is “Frozen” fever easing? Not if Disney can help it.
lead_paragraph: Is “Frozen” fever easing? Not if Disney can help it. The ABC special “The Story of Frozen: Making a Disney Animated Classic” drew about 4.7 million viewers on Tuesday night, according to Nielsen data.

headline: Fox to Announce Deal With Smartphone Video App
abstract: Fox Sports will use the Burst app to put video on its digital platforms and social media to send viewers to its televised programs.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Levy co-founded Burst in 2010, he envisioned a mobile application that would allow parents to record and share short videos of their children playing sports. Now, sports media companies are using Burst’s technology at much bigger events.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Levitating With the Butterflies
abstract: At Valentino on Fifth Avenue, sharp right angles and a chilly aesthetic for soft romantic ideas (and Mr. Snuffleupagus, too).
lead_paragraph: A ROSY-CHEEKED young buck stood just past the entrance of the new Valentino flagship in Midtown at 5 p.m. on a recent Friday, proffering glasses of Champagne and those pastel macarons that have descended upon Gotham the last few years like a fleet of small U.F.O.s.

headline: Yup, Those Guys Are Still Around
abstract: New albums from Maroon 5 and Counting Crows bring back voices of other times.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the voice of an era is the one that you forget all about, the one that was so ubiquitous and inoffensive, it practically became background noise.

headline: Patrick McEnroe Out as U.S.T.A. Player Development Head
