abstract: McEnroe’s efforts have borne the brunt of the criticism as Americans have lost their place in the upper echelon of professional tennis.
lead_paragraph: With the doldrums of American tennis on display at the United States Open, Patrick McEnroe will leave his job as head of player development for the United States Tennis Association, the U.S.T.A. announced Wednesday.

headline: Should The Times Have Observed a Complete Blackout on ISIS Video Images?
abstract: Three issues related to the brutal death of Steven Sotloff.
lead_paragraph: Where does newsworthiness end and manipulation begin? How should news organizations handle a brutally violent video that is clearly intended as a terrorist propaganda and recruitment tool?

headline: Arts Center at Ground Zero Shelves Gehry Design
abstract: The board of the performing arts center planned for the World Trade Center scuttled Frank Gehry’s plan and will select a new design.
lead_paragraph: The board of the performing arts center planned for ground zero has scuttled the design for the building by Frank Gehry, the project’s original architect, and will instead select a design from a field of three finalists.

headline: Voices Unleashed, Paying No Mind to Limits
abstract: In short programs at the Resonant Bodies Festival, vocalists mixed their own works with pieces by contemporaries and modern masters.
lead_paragraph: Every voice contains special notes. At the finals of the Operalia competition in Los Angeles last weekend, one soprano showed off a mostly ordinary sound in a selection from Bellini’s “La Sonnambula” — but an ordinary sound capped by a stunning high F.

headline: A Big Gain at World Youth Teams in Istanbul
abstract: The 15th World Youth Teams here last month had a new event for kids, this year for anyone born after Dec. 31, 1998. The event will surely expand in the future.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The 15th World Youth Teams here last month had a new event for kids, this year for anyone born after Dec. 31, 1998. There were only seven teams playing, but the event will surely expand in the future.

headline: How a Revelation About Hello Kitty’s Identity Blew Everyone’s Mind
abstract: Last week, an anthropologist revealed that Hello Kitty may not in fact be a cat. The information caused a global uproar and a discussion about the identity of cartoon characters.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The Los Angeles Times broke the news of the century. Or so it would seem by the shockwaves it sent through the Internet.

headline: Bring a Connoisseur’s Eye and a Toothbrush
abstract: Antony Gormley sculpts a hotel suite.
lead_paragraph: The British sculptor Antony Gormley recently completed a work called “Room.” You can see it jutting from the upper floors of a 1926 building in the Mayfair neighborhood of London. For about $4,119 a night, you can book it.

headline: A Gallery Gets Wider and Wackier
abstract: Kasher Potamkin opens in Chelsea with an eclectic display of art and design. If it’s not nailed down, you can probably buy it.
lead_paragraph: Steven Kasher has moved and expanded. His New York art-photography gallery is now in a 6,000-square-foot space at 515 West 26th Street. And part of the gallery, which opens Saturday, will be devoted to Kasher Potamkin, a new business headed by Mr. Kasher and Andi Potamkin. Asked to describe the product mix, Ms. Potamkin quoted Edgar Allan Poe: “There is no exquisite beauty ... without some strangeness in the proportion.” She may have been referring to several mounted fluffy rabbit derrières by Ghyslain Bertholon, or beaded taxidermy-like sconces by Nancy Josephson. Kasher Potamkin has adopted an instant-gratification sales policy: Buy it, walk out with it. This applies to everything in the shop, including Ms. Potamkin’s own desk, designed by her fiancé, Jordan Blackmore. Prices range from $250 for a L’Enchanteur ring to $60,000 for a pair of Haas Brothers Beast stools. Information: 917-265-8060 or kasherpotamkin.com.

headline: Producing Concrete Results
abstract: Alessi expands its universe of materials.
lead_paragraph: Alessi, the Italian housewares company, is associated with objects that are gleaming and voluptuous, or bright and cartoonish, but certainly not concrete. Now, that popular industrial material has found its way to the collection through a competition for young designers sponsored by Italcementi, the manufacturer of a new cement mortar. Luca Galbusera from Italy prevailed in a field of 200 innovators working with the material, which is said to combine the strength of concrete with the malleability of plastic. His winning entry was a fruit bowl, named La Trama e l’Ordito (“warp and weft” in Italian), after its basket-weave pattern. The bowls are 16 inches in diameter and 11 inches high and come in blue and red. They will be available in mid-October for $450. For information or to order: 212-941-7300.

headline: Is It Done Yet?
abstract: A woodworker spent years polishing his latest pieces.
lead_paragraph: Michael Robbins, a 31-year-old self-taught woodworker in Columbia County, N.Y., spent three years perfecting his latest introduction, the Taza lounge chair. The piece went through several experimental versions, including one with a seat of canvas webbing, but in the end, a leather sling won out. Mr. Robbins also recently rolled out his Bridle bench, right, which, like the chair, had been “sitting around the shop for a while,” he said. The solid ash top is laminated with bridle leather, and an arc of brass adds a nice architectural detail while supporting the structure. The Taza lounge is available in four woods and four shades of leather, for $2,850; the Bridle bench ranges in length from 5 to 10 feet, in a choice of four woods and four leathers; it starts at $1,675. Information: 315-761-8010 or mchlrbbns.com.

headline: Discounts at ABC Carpet & Home, From the Source and Classic Rug Collection
keywords: ['Carpets and Rugs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Sales on rugs, furniture and home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: All products are up to 80 percent off during ABC Carpet & Home’s Bronx warehouse sale, through Sept. 14 (the Edge rustic dining table, originally, $2,995, is $1,599); 1055 Bronx River Avenue (Watson Avenue), Bronx; 718-842-8772.

headline: Andrew Madoff, Who Told of His Father’s Swindle, Dies at 48
abstract: Mr. Madoff, the last surviving son of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff, had mantle-cell lymphoma.
lead_paragraph: Andrew H. Madoff, the last surviving son of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff, died on Wednesday in a Manhattan hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment for cancer. He was 48.

headline: ‘Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The production will close in January after a run of nearly two years. A national tour is scheduled to begin in October.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway production of “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” will close on Jan. 3 after a run of nearly two years, the producers announced on Wednesday. The show opened in March 2013 to mixed reviews and went on to receive nine Tony Award nominations that year, including for Laura Osnes in the title role; it won only for the costumes by William Ivey Long.

headline: Here, Ansel! Sit, Avedon!
abstract: As cameras for animals become more readily available, pet photography is exploding.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — It was in 2007 that Juergen Perthold, an engineer living in Anderson, S.C., strapped a tiny camera of his own design to the collar of his cat, Mr. Lee. When the images Mr. Lee captured while roaming around their neighborhood were posted online, they went, predictably, viral. Mr. Lee received a flurry of attention from the international media and became the star of a documentary, “CatCam: The Movie,” which made the film festival rounds in 2012 and even won a few awards.

headline: In His Basement, the Bowery
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: A self-appointed guardian of the neighborhood’s vanishing history turns his home into a museum.
lead_paragraph: Adam Woodward rarely leaves his Lower East Side neighborhood, and then only grudgingly. He hates the thought of missing even the smallest change on one of the strangest and most historic thoroughfares in the country, the 400-year-old stretch of road known as the Bowery, which has seen more than its share of demolition and transformation in recent years.

headline: A House Built to Baffle
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In the Hamptons, a home set in an “acoustical shadow” is spared nearby traffic noise.
lead_paragraph: It took this reporter a few minutes to realize what was missing from the house that Paul Masi, owner of the architecture firm Bates-Masi, built two years ago for his family. While their three young children played upstairs, Mr. Masi and his wife, Liz, both 42, sat at a table in the open kitchen and living area, explaining their initial concern about building on the half-acre lot in the center of town, which they bought for $840,000 in 2012. It was when Mr. Masi mentioned the proximity to the main drag that everything clicked.

headline: Your Grandma’s Maker Faire
keywords: ['Art', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: The Minnesota State Fair is a reliable source of mind-blowing handicrafts.
lead_paragraph: FALCON HEIGHTS, Minn. — In the 12 days leading up to Labor Day, more than 1.8 million visitors attended a design expo that has been held annually since 1859. Granted, most of them didn’t know they were attending a design expo; they came for the midway or the mini-doughnuts. But as a popular showcase for American vernacular design, the Minnesota State Fair wins the blue ribbon.

headline: Toronto Films Lurk in the Dark Heart of Los Angeles
abstract: With movies like “Nightcrawler,” the Toronto International Film Festival finds its sweet spot among slightly complex would-be crowd pleasers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The actor Jake Gyllenhaal recently explained Lou Bloom, the twisted crime videographer he portrays in the movie “Nightcrawler,” which is set for a world premiere on Friday night at the Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and India.

headline: Tony West, Top Nemesis of Big Banks, Is Leaving Justice Department
abstract: Mr. West, whose departure is effective Sept. 15, extracted more than $30 billion in settlements with Wall Street banks over toxic mortgage securities.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street will soon bid farewell to the man it loves to hate.

headline: When the Visitors Don’t Walk So Lightly on the Land
abstract: “Gringo Trails,” a documentary by Pegi Vail, considers the impact adventure tourists have on the exotic locations they visit.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need to be a Werner Herzog hero plunging into the Amazon to realize that backpackers seeking adventure can take a toll on the environment. “Gringo Trails,” a documentary from the anthropologist Pegi Vail, explores the impact of adventure vacations on communities and biodiversity.

headline: Anti-Pop Star (Except for Those Hooks)
abstract: Charli XCX, a Myspace prodigy, is developing into a more mature performer.
lead_paragraph: At this point, Charli XCX has been a pop star — or, at least, a sub-type of one — three times over. She was a Myspace prodigy (remember those?) when she was barely a teenager. She was then an on-the-rise singer with a distinct voice and pugnacious attitude. And lately, she’s been the sort of singer-songwriter who helps those around her become even more famous and stays along for the ride.

headline: Q. and A.: Cai Guo-Qiang on Art, the Death of Nature and China’s Modern Reality
abstract: The celebrated artist Cai Guo-Qiang discusses his art and a new exhibit, “Cai Guo-Qiang: The Ninth Wave.”
lead_paragraph: Last month, the artist Cai Guo-Qiang opened his new solo exhibit at the Power Station of Art in Shanghai with a literal bang — one of his trademark explosion events that this time had many local residents ducking for cover.

headline: Music From the Beloved Country
abstract: Celebrating the 20th anniversary of apartheid’s end in South Africa with music at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall is marking 20 years after the end of apartheid with a monthlong festival of music from South Africa, where the long history of tribal, urban, colonial and imported traditions continues to create unexpected hybrids. There are familiar names, like the high-stepping choir Ladysmith Black Mambazo (performing on Oct. 18 with additional guests) and the trumpeter Hugh Masekela, who is sharing a bill with the courageous and nimble-voiced singer and songwriter Vusi Mahlasela on Oct. 10, both at Carnegie Hall. Abdullah Ibrahim, the pianist from Cape Town, brings his rolling, sonorous vamps to Zankel Hall on Oct. 17.

headline: Saluting a Label’s Legacy
abstract: “Nonesuch Records at BAM” celebrates the 50th-anniversary of this prestige record label at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The emblematic concert program in Nonesuch Records at BAM — a 50th-anniversary celebration for a prestige record label, running Tuesday through Sept. 28 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music — will feature two founding fathers of Minimalism, performing landmark works. Or perhaps a magisterial yet mischievous singer-songwriter from Brazil. Or a brilliant jazz pianist in league with a virtuoso mandolinist. Or the former frontman of an era-defining hard-rock band, rolling up with a rootsy new caravan.

headline: What Amy Sedaris Took from ‘Dallas’
abstract: The actress and author on her housewares designs for Fishs Eddy.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Amy Sedaris, the actress, author and D.I.Y. enthusiast, introduced a line of home accessories at Fishs Eddy. Her 10-piece collection for the eccentric housewares emporium includes dish towels, glassware, food storage containers and trays, with patterns and phrases adapted from earlier projects.

headline: The Death of Michael Brown: Teaching About Ferguson
abstract: Ideas, questions and resources from our audience, The Times and around the web for addressing this summer’s events in Ferguson, Mo., in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 24, a St. Louis County grand jury announced that it has brought no criminal charges against Darren Wilson for the fatal shooting of Michael Brown. Thousands took to the streets in cities across the country — from Los Angeles to Atlanta to New York — to protest the decision.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Eleanor Rigby’
abstract: The writer and director Ned Benson narrates a sequence from his drama “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them.”
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Ned Benson narrates a sequence from his drama “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them.”

headline: Immersive Sound Fills a Factory
abstract: The Basilica Soundscape festival offers two days of aggressive and immersive music.
lead_paragraph: Basilica Soundscape, a two-day festival of sound, sight and taste in Hudson, N.Y., on Friday and Saturday, could one day be to New York City mavens of aggressive and immersive music what Glyndebourne, the opera festival 60 miles south of London, is to classical audiences.

headline: Take Note of These Back-to-School Aids
abstract: Apps can put a dictionary, graphing calculator, organizer and more in the palms of students’ hands.
lead_paragraph: ALL around the world, students in colleges and schools are getting back to work. And alongside traditional textbooks and notepads, millions of smartphones and tablets — which spent the vacation taking photos, making selfies and messaging friends — will be in book bags for more serious purposes. With the right apps, a mobile device can be a student’s best friend.

headline: App Smart | Back to School
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will get you equipped for the new school year, including helping to keep track of test dates or homework deadlines.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will get you equipped for the new school year, including helping to keep track of test dates or homework deadlines.

headline: Giving the Milky Way a New Sense of Place
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Milky Way Galaxy']
abstract: The supercluster of galaxies that includes the Milky Way was outlined and named Laniakea, Hawaiian for “immense heaven.”
lead_paragraph: For the first time, astronomers have outlined and named the network of galaxies that includes the Milky Way, adding a line to our cosmic address and further defining our place in the universe. They call it Laniakea, which is Hawaiian for “immense heaven.”

headline: Step by Step, Scaling New Heights
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Windbreakers as a high-style piece of outerwear; chunky platform shoes; a collection of knitwear made by an all-women cooperative in Nepal and more.
lead_paragraph: Step by Step, Scaling New Heights

headline: Tech, Meet Fashion
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Tech wearables’ genre of ugly may be ending as Intel and Opening Ceremony collaborate on MICA.
lead_paragraph: It’s time we stopped calling the current crop of gadgets “wearable tech.” Instead, I propose we start giving them a more appropriate name: “ugly tech.” Because let’s be realistic, most wearables today are really, really ugly.

headline: Bring Back the Party of Lincoln
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'United States Economy']
abstract: What happened to the G.O.P.’s vision of broader opportunity?
lead_paragraph: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. — FOR all the differences between establishment Republicans and Tea Party insurgents, their various efforts to rebrand the Grand Old Party tend to start from a common premise: the belief that Ronald Reagan was the quintessential Republican, and that his principle of defending wealth and the wealthy should remain the party’s guiding vision.

headline: Nine Things to Hate About Packing School Lunches (and How to Fix Them)
abstract: I choose to pack lunches for my children — but I also choose to make it easier to do.
lead_paragraph: There are far worse things than packing school lunches. In fact, I kind of like it — at no other time of day do I feed a captive, hungry audience with no other options who also can’t ask me, ever so politely, if they can have something else. If I didn’t want to do it, I’d have my children do it; they’re in eighth, fifth and third grade and they’re capable. Instead, I choose to load the boxes — and once I identified, and largely eliminated, the things about the process that I hated, our mornings (and my evenings) improved.

headline: New Roku and TiVo Devices Make Cutting the Cable Cord Plausible
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television', 'Cable Television', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: Complex Internet-to-TV setups have long discouraged many from doing away with their cable, but the technology is finally becoming more approachable.
lead_paragraph: CUTTING the cable television cord has always sounded nicer than it really is.

headline: Tech to Cut the Cable Cord
keywords: ['Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Cable Television']
abstract: Molly Wood reviews new devices from Roku and TiVo that offer Internet-enabled alternatives to costly cable TV plans.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood reviews new devices from Roku and TiVo that offer Internet-enabled alternatives to costly cable TV plans.

headline: At WWD, a New Owner Tries to Change Course
abstract: Jay Penske seeks a larger staff and expanded online presence.
lead_paragraph: The day after Condé Nast announced last month that it was selling Fairchild Fashion Media for a reported $100 million, the new owner, Jay Penske, held several meetings with staff members of its crown jewel publication, Women’s Wear Daily.

headline: Tragedy or Triumph
abstract: In a Supreme Court case over presidential recess appointments, functional pragmatism wins over rigid formalism in constitutional interpretation.
lead_paragraph: It’s more than two months since the Supreme Court issued its eagerly awaited decision in the recess appointments case, National Labor Relations Board v. Noel Canning. You may recall that by a vote of 9 to 0, President Obama “lost” this case, in as much as the court held that his recess appointments of three members of the labor board were unauthorized by the Constitution’s recess appointments clause.

headline: New York Fashion Week’s Shopping Events
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Band of Outsiders, 3.1 Phillip Lim and Céline spice up New York Fashion Week
lead_paragraph: Openings

headline: A Montage of Iconic New Wave Movies, Via the New York Fashion Film Festival
abstract: In this new series, Chris Labzda and Bon Duke, the co-founders of the New York Fashion Film Festival, curate a short film each week for T. This week’s installment: A collage of classics overlaid with sound from Lauren Wolkstein’s “Social Butterfly.”
lead_paragraph: In this new series, Chris Labzda and Bon Duke, the co-founders of the New York Fashion Film Festival, curate a short film each week for T.

headline: Why Fashion’s Night Out Faltered
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Fashion’s Night Out left a hangover but not much profit, store owners say.
lead_paragraph: Amid the attention surrounding New York Fashion Week, few seem to have noticed the quiet disappearance of Fashion’s Night Out, which began with great fanfare in 2009 and lasted all of four years, going on hiatus in 2013.

headline: Discovery and Rediscovery
abstract: This fall offers treasures from three centuries, from Seattle and Phoenix to Florida and New York.
lead_paragraph: The choreography of the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries all offer much to anticipate in the next six months. The early Danish ballet master August Bournonville — whose work cleanses the palate with both the felicity of its dance construction and its open temperament — has scarcely been represented in America since the 2011 visit of the Royal Danish Ballet. An end to this drought comes Jan. 13 through 18, when that company’s soloists perform an anthology of his dances at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Elephant in the Room
abstract: The Clintons use an inflatable pink elephant at fashion week to help fight the ivory trade.
lead_paragraph: Over the next week, as the fashion world heads to Milk Studios in West Chelsea to see one of Made Fashion Week’s 15 runway shows, it will be greeted by a guest: a giant pink elephant.

headline: Fest Packed With Artists Bursting Out of the Box
abstract: The Crossing the Line festival will include the debut of the Argentine visual artist Fernando Rubio, and present works by Trajal Harrell and Xavier Le Roy, among others.
lead_paragraph: Crossing the Line, a playful and probing interdisciplinary festival now in its eighth year, hosts an array of artists who refuse to be bottled up and labeled. The pickings are eclectic, from the debut of the Argentine director and visual artist Fernando Rubio, who places seven actresses in white beds in Hudson River Park — in 10-minute cycles, they whisper memories to audience members — to Xavier Le Roy’s sophisticated yet accessible exhibition of movement and conversation, “Retrospective,” at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens. In other words, Crossing the Line, which runs from Sept. 8 through Oct. 20 at various New York locations and is presented by the French Institute Alliance Française, is nothing if not an adventure.

headline: A Couple of Genius Moves
abstract: The choreographers Kyle Abraham and Jodi Melnick seem ready to make a splash this season.
lead_paragraph: If much is expected of those to whom much is given, then the pressure on the choreographer Kyle Abraham is mounting. Since the 2010 debut of his first full-length piece, “The Radio Show,” the high-profile offers and lucrative prizes have been piling up. He has gotten commissions from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the ballerina Wendy Whelan. On top of many other awards, he was named — in 2013, at 36 — a MacArthur Fellow, an honor that comes with $625,000 and the connotation of “genius.”

headline: Fashion History, on the Catwalk Once More
abstract: Models from decades past are coming to New York to strut in a performance piece.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of yet another cycle of fashion weeks, Olivier Saillard, the fashion historian and director of the Palais Galliera museum in Paris, is coming to New York with a message: “We are in a moment that’s very bizarre in fashion,” he said. “There are too many clothes.”

headline: Incoming! Video Games Zero In
abstract: The new season comes with an array of promising video games, including Destiny (Paul McCartney! Peter Dinklage!) and Fantasia: Music Evolved (Mozart! Lady Gaga!).
lead_paragraph: Readers do not expect a year’s new crop of novels to eclipse the Western canon. Nor do filmgoers anticipate that this fall’s Oscar bait will surpass a century’s worth of cinema. Yet many video game players, wedded to notions of technological progress rather than artistic experimentation, believe that a new batch of consoles should be accompanied by a wave of games superior to all that came before.

headline: Untold Stories After the Arab Spring
abstract: A new website and book feature the work of North African photographers whose projects show aspects of life overshadowed by the region’s tumult.
lead_paragraph: A new website and book feature the work of North African photographers whose projects show aspects of life overshadowed by the region’s tumult.

headline: Fashion Week Now Spring 2015
abstract: See what you missed.
lead_paragraph: See what you missed.

headline: Sugar, Spice and Guts
abstract: In many movie genres, the representation of girls and women is improving. But there’s a long way to go.
lead_paragraph: Girls grow up on big and little screens, and sometimes the thinking about girls and girlhood grows, too. Inspired by Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood” — a magnificent film that tells the story of a boy’s life from 6 to 18 — we are taking a look at how girls are growing up in the movies. American mainstream cinema, a timid enterprise dependent on formulas and genres, can be mind-blowingly retrograde when it comes to women and girls. And while an occasional woman or girl rules the box office, too many of their on-screen sisters are sidelined or just left out of the picture.

headline: Modern Romance, With Laughs
abstract: ABC’s “Manhattan Love Story” and NBC’s “A to Z” are taking the same unusual approach to romantic comedies.
lead_paragraph: Are you one of the people mourning the loss of the old-fashioned (as in 1990s) rom-com? Do you feel that romantic comedies haven’t been the same — or haven’t even existed — since the last time Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks made a movie together?

headline: Argentine Economist Says Bond Holdouts Should Be Paid
abstract: Domingo Cavallo, the architect of Argentina’s 2001 debt restructuring, says the country should comply with a U.S. judge’s decision.
lead_paragraph: BRETTON WOODS, N.H. – Domingo Cavallo, the architect of Argentina’s first debt restructuring deal in 2001, has a solution for the country’s worsening debt drama: pay the holdouts.

headline: A Reading of “In The Bois De Vincennes” by Matthew Rohrer
abstract: The poet reads his verse about the City of Light.
lead_paragraph: The poet reads his verse about the City of Light.

headline: Giving Up My Small-Town Fantasy
abstract: I moved to Hudson, N.Y., to slow down and save money. I didn’t know I’d feel so lonely.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, after a Pilates class in a studio above my former office, I rolled up a mat while the teacher spoke to another student, someone who seemed new in town — a potential friend. Lingering near the exercise bikes, I pretended to stretch, and then edged in to the conversation.

headline: From Now On, Women Save the World
abstract: Hollywood has finally realized that movies starring women can make major money, and a wave of sequels and new films with female protagonists is on its way.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood has long known that women are better customers than men. It’s right there in the annual reports from the Motion Picture Association of America: Moviegoing in the United States and Canada was 52 percent female last year. Just as it was five years earlier.

headline: It Was Good Enough for Frasier and Mary
abstract: The coming season will have TV series set in Battle Creek, Mich., and Seattle, among other places.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when the New York Yankees were on the road playing the Baltimore Orioles, Brandon McCarthy, the Yankee pitcher, made this wisecrack via Twitter: “forgetting to pack my wearable ‘NO, I HAVEN’T SEEN THE WIRE’ sandwich board before coming to Baltimore has proven to be disastrous.”

headline: Shades of Hillary in TV Dramas
abstract: Shows like “State of Affairs,” “Madam Secretary” and “Political Animals” have characters with uncanny similarities to former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Shows like “State of Affairs,” “Madam Secretary” and “Political Animals” have characters with uncanny similarities to former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: As Football Season Appears, So Do the Fall Campaigns
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Football']
abstract: Madison Avenue is bringing out major campaigns intended to put consumers in the mood for fall shopping, with an eye on Christmas.
lead_paragraph: MANY retailers and clothing companies have already started their autumn advertising efforts. Now comes the rest of Madison Avenue, taking advantage of the start of a new football season to bring out major campaigns intended to put consumers in the mood for fall shopping — and to begin thinking about, yes, Christmas.

headline: Path of Stolen Credit Cards Leads Back to Home Depot Stores
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft', 'Credit Cards', 'Debit Cards', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Bank and computer security company employees and law enforcement officials are tracing the track taken by the latest batch of stolen cards.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There are two tracks to finding the identity of a company that has been hit by cybercriminals. Both of them involve going backward.

headline: Characters Inspired by You-Know-Who
abstract: “Madam Secretary,” “State of Affairs” and other new prime-time dramas offer heroines who advise the Oval Office and influence global events.
lead_paragraph: It could have been that photograph of Hillary Rodham Clinton in the White House Situation Room watching, hand over mouth, as cameras showed the SEAL Team Six raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound.

headline: A Love Story: His and Hers and Theirs
abstract: Ned Benson spent nearly a decade working on “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby,” and ended up making not one film but three, with the same cast.
lead_paragraph: Boy meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love, get married, start a family, confront a crisis, split apart. It’s one of the oldest stories ever told, and writers and filmmakers are always searching for new ways to tell it: exactly the challenge that the screenwriter and rookie director Ned Benson faced in making “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby,” which opens Friday.

headline: Looking Back at Love, and Memories Differ
abstract: “The Affair,” a new Showtime drama series, is about an extramarital romance in which both parties, a married waitress and a married schoolteacher, are not easy to judge.
lead_paragraph: Imagine an extramarital love affair in which neither party can be blamed. Or, at the very least, both are especially hard to judge.

headline: ISIS, Deep in the Heart of Texas
abstract: A legitimate threat from foreign forces should not be used as fodder for anti-immigrant, enforcement-over-citizenship border politicians.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, is coming … to Texas? Yes, if you listen to conservatives, particularly those from Texas.

headline: Michael Bloomberg to Return to Lead Bloomberg L.P.
abstract: Only eight months after ending his final term as mayor of New York City, Michael R. Bloomberg has decided to resume the leadership of his business empire.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg has decided to reassume the leadership of his business empire only eight months after ending his final term as mayor of New York.

headline: Tracing Cyberattacks
abstract: A reader discusses the difficulty of identifying the source of cyberattacks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After Beheadings, Pressure on Obama
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article about the beheading of the journalist Steven Sotloff and to a column by Frank Bruni about President Obama’s statements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Community Service for Teenager Who Climbed Trade Center
abstract: Justin Casquejo, 16, also voluntarily turned in a 1,200-word essay reflecting on the consequences of his behavior, prompting praise from the judge.
lead_paragraph: Six months ago, Justin Casquejo, a 16-year-old from Weehawken, N.J., with a penchant for promoting his aerial exploits on Twitter, scaled 1 World Trade Center, making observers blanch and leaving officials unsettled.

headline: E-ZPass and Rental Cars
abstract: James L. Ferrara of M.T.A. Bridges and Tunnels responds to an About New York column.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Retirement on the Road?
abstract: A retiree, content at home, writes that she would find constant travel “isolating.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nevada and Tesla Hint at Site of Factory
abstract: Tesla has been seeking incentives from states to build a factory that would produce batteries for its electric cars and for use on the power grid.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Nevada and Tesla Motors, the electric car company with gigantic ambitions, will be “making an affirmative announcement” on Thursday about the construction of a huge battery factory, a person involved in the negotiations said on Wednesday.

headline: Australian Leader Seeks Deal to Sell Uranium to India
keywords: ['Uranium', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty', 'International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said ahead of a visit to India that a uranium sale deal would help support “the world’s emerging democratic superpower.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia announced in Parliament on Wednesday that he hoped to sign a deal this week to export uranium to India, even though India has not ratified the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

headline: For New York Legislators, Indictments Are No Obstacle to Seeking Re-election
abstract: Three state senators, each with more than 10 years of experience in office, will appear on primary ballots on Tuesday, despite having been indicted during the last 18 months.
lead_paragraph: State Senator John L. Sampson, a Brooklyn Democrat charged with embezzlement and an attempted cover-up, has observed that an opponent’s military service helped ensure him of the “presumption of innocence.”

headline: Walking Out of a Show
abstract: Thomas J. Vinciguerra, a frequent contributor to The Times, cites the example of Wolcott Gibbs, a onetime New Yorker theater critic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: So Good to Be Bad
abstract: Hope Davis (“Allegiance”), Yael Grobglas (“Jane the Virgin”), John Carroll Lynch (“American Horror Story” and Robin Lord Taylor (“Gotham”) embrace their roles as the season’s bad guys.
lead_paragraph: Villain, nemesis — whatever the label, it’s not always easy being mean.

headline: Drug Overdose Deaths
abstract: Matt Curtis, the policy director of Vocal New York, a grass-roots group, responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Former First Lady of France Colors In Details of an Affair
abstract: Valérie Trierweiler, France’s former unofficial first lady, has written a book describing her version of events that led to her separation with President François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Now she has her say.

headline: 3rd Missionary With Ebola Is Identified
abstract: Dr. Rick Sacra, 51, was sickened in West Africa while delivering babies at a hospital in Liberia.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The third American sickened in West Africa with the Ebola virus was identified on Wednesday as a 51-year-old doctor from the Boston area who was delivering babies at a hospital in Liberia.

headline: An Actor-Director Above Suspicion
abstract: In “Gone Girl,” Ben Affleck — husband, father, actor and Oscar-winning producer — stretches even further with his most complex performance.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — “They disliked me, then they liked me. They hated me, and now they love me.”

headline: Another Shadow in Ferguson as Outside Firms Buy and Rent Out Distressed Homes
keywords: ['Landlords', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: In Ferguson and other close suburbs of St. Louis, out-of-state investment firms have bought distressed homes to rent them out, a consequence of foreclosures from the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Ethel Walker and her daughter Tasha pay $650 a month to rent a home in Ferguson, Mo., from an investment firm 1,800 miles away in Los Angeles. A few miles from the Walkers, Corey Bryant and his mother are renting a two-bedroom home in Ferguson from the same California firm.

headline: Tax Break for Sports
abstract: Should pro sports leagues enjoy nonprofit status?

headline: After Decades on CBS, U.S. Open Will Switch Channels Full Time
abstract: The men’s singles final scheduled for Monday will be the final U.S. Open match carried by CBS, for now. Next year ESPN takes over coverage of the tournament.
lead_paragraph: When the United States Tennis Championships became the U.S. Open in 1968, CBS Sports televised the tournament from the Forest Hills section of Queens, with Bud Collins and Jack Kramer calling matches that featured Arthur Ashe’s milestone victory in the men’s final.

headline: New Rules May Allow Benefits Long Denied to Vietnam-Era Veterans
abstract: Thousands of Vietnam-era veterans denied benefits because of less-than-honorable discharges may be eligible for upgrades if their misconduct was related to post-traumatic stress disorder.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Vietnam-era veterans barred from receiving benefits because of less-than-honorable discharges may be eligible for upgrades under a new set of guidelines released by the Defense Department on Wednesday.

headline: Clip: ‘The Boxtrolls’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Anthony Stacchi and Graham Annable.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Anthony Stacchi and Graham Annable.

headline: Justice Dept. Inquiry to Focus on Practices of Police in Ferguson
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Racial Profiling', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The inquiry is in addition to the F.B.I. civil rights investigation that is looking specifically into the shooting of Michael Brown on Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department will open a broad civil rights investigation into police practices in Ferguson, Mo., where a white police officer killed an unarmed black teenager last month and set off days of racially charged unrest, the city’s police chief and other officials said Wednesday.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. 1, Czech Republic 0
abstract: Rating the performance of United States players in Wednesday’s international friendly in Prague.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Despite missing many of its veterans, the United States men’s national team opened the cycle that will lead to the 2018 World Cup with a hard-fought exhibition win over the Czech Republic on Wednesday in Prague.

headline: Searching for Ways to Improve Yankees’ Anemic Lineup
abstract: The Yankees, who entered Wednesday averaging 3.96 runs a game, a mark that ranked 12th in the American League, have not hit this poorly in decades.
lead_paragraph: Some of the Yankees wear T-shirts under their jerseys with a three-word slogan — more like an exhortation — on the back: DO YOUR JOB! Carlos Beltran wore his on Wednesday. Like most of the hitters, though, he has not answered the demand.

headline: A Civilization Separated by Manholes
abstract: A graphic novelist, a concept artist, film directors and others collaborated to visualize a German Expressionist-tinged fantasy world for “The Boxtrolls.”
lead_paragraph: Adapted from Alan Snow’s novel “Here Be Monsters!,” “The Boxtrolls” follows miniature beings who wear boxes and live beneath the towering town of Cheesebridge. That split makes for two distinct visual worlds in the movie, directed by Anthony Stacchi and Graham Annable, who moved away from the book’s illustrations.

headline: Regulators Propose Rule to Reduce Risk of Derivatives
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The industry has not applied margin requirements evenly across the system. The proposed rule aims to change that.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators announced on Wednesday an overhaul of a murky Wall Street market that gained infamy during the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: Final Touches Range From Flowery to Frantic as Expanded Pre-K Awaits Start
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign promised free prekindergarten for every 4-year-old, and his administration has invested mightily in quickly bringing that plan to life.
lead_paragraph: The sounds of scissors slicing through construction paper and transparent tape being torn from rolls filled every room at the Kaleidoscope Early Childhood Development Center in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, on Wednesday. After weeks of hiring teachers, filling seats and ordering furniture, the Kaleidoscope staff was putting the finishing decorative touches on its classrooms, readying for the first day of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s signature initiative: a vast expansion of full-day prekindergarten.

headline: The Down Side of Reclining
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The airplane-seat debate has become a bit of an aviation crisis, so maybe it’s time for Congress to take up the issue.
lead_paragraph: I am trying to imagine how our national leaders would react if they got caught in a reclining airplane seat crisis. You know what I mean. If they were flying to some important meeting and the person in front flopped back into their personal space, crunching a laptop or bruising a knee.

headline: To Lure Tourists, a Remote Village in Spain Turns Its Eye to the Arts
abstract: An art festival has sprouted up to support Spanish artists in hopes of also drawing tourists to the remote village of Genalguacil.
lead_paragraph: GENALGUACIL, Spain — This Spanish village has a new cemetery, though no one has ever been buried in it. Built before the onset of the financial crisis, and against the wishes of residents who wanted their final resting place to be in the old village cemetery, it was yet another Spanish investment plan that failed.

headline: Credit Rating Reform Comes Up Short
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Two new rules issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission are only modest improvements to a process that requires substantial reform.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the financial crisis was the corrupted process by which bad mortgages were packaged into toxic securities with stellar credit ratings. The credit rating agencies that gave out those high grades were paid by the banks, which securitized the loans and sold them to investors.

headline: Michael Brown Never Faced Serious Felony Charge, St. Louis Official’s Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: News outlets had sought to unseal any court records that might exist for Michael Brown. Also Wednesday, Missouri’s governor lifted the orders establishing a state of emergency and activating the National Guard.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Michael Brown, the unarmed black teenager shot and killed by a white police officer here last month, had no serious felony cases filed against him as a juvenile, a lawyer for a St. Louis County official said Wednesday.

headline: Steven Sotloff, U.S. Hostage Slain by ISIS, Was Also a Citizen of Israel
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Jewish roots and Israeli past of Steven J. Sotloff, a journalist from Miami, were kept hidden until hope for his survival was no longer possible.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The beheading of Steven J. Sotloff, the American journalist from Miami who had been held hostage by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, suddenly loomed larger for many Israelis on Wednesday when it emerged that he held Israeli citizenship and had lived and studied in the country for a few years.

headline: The Innocent on Death Row
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Editorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The exoneration of two North Carolina men provides a textbook example of so much that is broken in the American justice system.
lead_paragraph: The exoneration of two North Carolina men who spent 30 years in prison — one on death row — provides a textbook example of so much that is broken in the American justice system. And it is further evidence (as though more were needed) that the death penalty is irretrievably flawed as well as immoral.

headline: Wes Welker’s Suspension Gives Broncos One More Dose of Uncertainty
abstract: Welker will be barred for four weeks for taking performance-enhancing drugs, but football players tend to take such uncertainty in stride.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — Football coaches tend to be fluent in John Wayne-ese. So Colts Coach Chuck Pagano got on a call with reporters on Wednesday and described Denver quarterback Peyton Manning as a “man’s man.”

headline: House Candidate Testifies of Pressure to Hire Rowland for Campaign
abstract: Mark Greenberg testified that in 2009, former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut suggested that he be hired as an adviser and paid with money funneled from outside the campaign.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — “I happen to like John Rowland, and I liked meeting him,” Mark Greenberg said on Wednesday from the witness stand at the federal courthouse here. But, he explained, “I was not interested in signing a $35,000 contract for the campaign” with him.

headline: Detroit Plan for Its Debt Is Debated in Court
abstract: The trial that will decide the fate of Detroit, the largest city ever to seek bankruptcy protection, began as a lawyer for the city on Wednesday urged a judge to approve the city’s blueprint for shedding $7 billion of its debts.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A lawyer for this city on Wednesday urged a judge to approve Detroit’s blueprint for shedding $7 billion of its debts and devoting about $1.5 billion toward restoring city services over the next decade, describing the plan to emerge from bankruptcy as Detroit’s “last, best chance” for a comeback.

headline: Fund-Raiser Pleads Guilty to Organizing Straw Donors for Michael Grimm’s Campaign
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Tax Evasion', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Diana Durand illegally funneled more than $10,000 into the 2010 campaign of the congressman, who is seeking a third term in November.
lead_paragraph: A woman who raised funds for Representative Michael G. Grimm pleaded guilty on Wednesday to illegally funneling money to his 2010 campaign.

headline: Cuts at W.H.O. Hurt Response to Ebola Crisis
abstract: The epidemic has exposed gaping holes in the ability to tackle outbreaks in an increasingly interconnected world, where diseases can quickly spread from remote villages to cities housing millions of people.
lead_paragraph: With treatment centers overflowing, and alarmingly little being done to stop Ebola from sweeping through West African villages and towns, Dr. Joanne Liu, the president of Doctors Without Borders, knew that the epidemic had spun out of control.

headline: Back in Politics, Quinn Will Be Adviser on Abortion-Rights Strategy
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, the former City Council president, has joined the board of Naral Pro-Choice New York to help elect supportive state senators.
lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn, the former speaker of the City Council, is the first to admit that her restful year out of the spotlight was a change of pace. “It wasn’t what I planned,” she said this week, laughing. “But you know what they say: People plan, and God laughs.”

headline: Missing Russian Photographer Was Killed in Ukraine
abstract: Andrei Stenin was killed in an attack on a convoy in Ukraine last month, Russia’s state news agency reported on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Russian photojournalist Andrei Stenin, who went missing while embedded with separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine last month, was killed in an attack on a convoy four weeks ago, Russia’s state news agency reported on Wednesday.

headline: Pakistan: Protesters Told to Pull Back
abstract: Protest leaders in Islamabad said Wednesday that their supporters would vacate the Parliament area, where they converged last week, after violent clashes with the police.
lead_paragraph: Protest leaders in Islamabad said Wednesday that their supporters would vacate the Parliament area, where they converged last week, after violent clashes with the police. Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a firebrand cleric, made the announcement but told supporters, “We will not leave Islamabad till the resignation of Nawaz Sharif,” the prime minister. Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaaf, the political party of the opposition leader Imran Khan, has also ordered its workers to leave the area. Mr. Qadri’s and Mr. Khan’s parties are now negotiating with the leaders of other parties to break a deadlock that has paralyzed the city. Formal talks between representatives of the government and protesters are expected Thursday.

headline: Go Crazy
abstract: Samuel “Not The Newscaster” Donaldson goes crazy, but in a good way.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The entry IN PEN for the clue “Improper way to take the SAT” made me laugh, not because using pen is such an egregious mistake, but because I have seen how students look at the SAT as a life experience and, from what I saw, using a pen was the least of their worries.

headline: Christie Addresses Trade in Mexico
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey arrived in Mexico on Wednesday as part of a three-day trade mission.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey arrived in Mexico on Wednesday as part of a three-day trade mission.

headline: Lifting Trophy and Profit
abstract: The financial boost that accompanies a Super Bowl victory can quickly disappear, one reason the Seahawks are taking nothing for granted.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — These are salad days in the N.F.L.’s Pacific Northwest outpost. After years of false starts and near misses, the Seahawks are the reigning Super Bowl champions. Their brash defense, energetic offense and outspoken coach are beloved in this region.

headline: In Speech on Mexico Trip, Gov. Christie Lays Out Vision for Energy ‘Renaissance’
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Pipelines', 'Natural Gas', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey called for an end to Washington’s 40-year ban on crude oil exports and faster approval of natural gas pipelines between the United States and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey offered a prescription for what he called a “North American energy renaissance” in an expansive speech here, calling for an end to Washington’s 40-year ban on crude oil exports, faster approval of natural gas pipelines between the United States and Mexico, and construction of the Keystone XL pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

headline: Mazda Unveils All-New Miata
abstract: Mazda introduced the 2016 Mazda MX-5, known in the United States as the Miata, in Japan, Spain and California.
lead_paragraph: Mazda revealed its all-new 2016 MX-5 Wednesday, holding simultaneous press events in Japan, Spain and California. Popularly known as the Miata, the MX-5 is the best-selling two-seat sports car ever, and nearly one million have been sold since Mazda introduced it in 1989 for the 1990 model year. The car is expected to go on sale next year.

headline: Which Colleges Do Students Pick?
abstract: A survey of 104,000 students reveals how students chose when admitted to two or more colleges.
lead_paragraph: A survey of 104,000 students reveals how students chose when admitted to two or more colleges.

headline: Bail Is Revoked for Driver in Crash That Killed 4-Year-Old
abstract: After being pulled over on Sunday, Franklin Reyes, 18, hit the accelerator, dragging an officer 100 feet and nearly hitting a pedestrian, a criminal complaint said.
lead_paragraph: An unlicensed teenage driver who fatally struck a 4-year-old girl while fleeing the police last year had his bail revoked on Wednesday after he was arrested in a similar episode.

headline: Tour Championship’s Unlikely Pairing
abstract: Hunter Mahan and Phil Mickelson have advanced to every Tour Championship since its 2007 inception.
lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — The seed was planted by Hunter Mahan, who described his proudest accomplishment in golf as a Sports and Leisure question worthy of Trivial Pursuit.

headline: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Gives $14,000 Back to Chicago for Travel
abstract: Mr. Emanuel’s repayments, which included interest, were a result of a new city policy that seeks to ensure that Chicago taxpayers are not charged for fund-raising trips.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel paid back about $14,000 to the city this year after courting campaign donors while traveling at taxpayer expense, a spokesman for the mayor said Wednesday.

headline: VFiles: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 3, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Giants Still Working to Solidify Front
abstract: The former 49er Adam Snyder, a versatile offensive lineman, joined the Giants on Wednesday as guard Geoff Schwartz, an off-season acquisition, was put on an injured reserve list.
lead_paragraph: The Giants on Wednesday signed a new offensive lineman, Adam Snyder, a 10-year veteran released last week by the San Francisco 49ers. At the same time, the Giants put one of their chief off-season acquisitions, the free-agent guard Geoff Schwartz, on a restricted form of injured reserve, which will allow Schwartz, if healthy, to return to play at midseason.

headline: Aural Journey Into the Spiritual
abstract: The White Light Festival, which strives to explore the power of music and the arts to reveal a spiritual dimension, enters its fifth year with an enticing lineup.
lead_paragraph: Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, took a lot of kidding, even some carping, from concertgoers and critics when she inaugurated the White Light Festival in 2010. The lofty goal of this venture was to explore the power of music and the arts to reveal the dimensions of our inner lives. The programs, Ms. Moss asserted, would offer a “spectrum of artistic expression that moves us inward and expands our spirit.”

headline: First, the Sound of Violins
abstract: Anne-Sophie Mutter will play the opening concert at Carnegie Hall, while Christian Tetzlaff kicks off the season at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: No mere gala fluff for these openings.

headline: Preview: Green Bay Packers at Seattle Seahawks
abstract: The Seattle Seahawks, coming off a Super Bowl win, open the season against the revamped Green Bay Packers.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m., NBC

headline: Diva’s Vocal Itinerary Makes Stop in Venice
abstract: Joyce DiDonato will be featured in Carnegie Hall’s Perspectives series this season, programming her own repertory and highlighting new discoveries.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall’s Perspectives Series, which offers artists at the height of their careers a chance to program their favorite repertory and highlight new discoveries, features the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato this season. A complete artist whose virtuosity meshes to vivid effect with her charismatic stage presence, Ms. DiDonato has programmed some of the composers who have long been an integral part of her career.

headline: Scotland’s Identity, Put to a Vote
abstract: In a testimony to democratic values in Britain, the Scots will soon vote on whether they should be an independent country without the threat of reprisals.
lead_paragraph: In two weeks, Scottish voters will be asked to answer a simple question — “Should Scotland be an independent country?” — with a simple “yes” or “no.” The choice, of course, is far from simple.

headline: Andrew McLaglen, Director in the Heyday of TV Westerns, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. McLaglen directed stars like John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, James Arness and James Stewart, as well as many western television shows.
lead_paragraph: Andrew V. McLaglen, a British-born director whose work in American westerns on television and in the movies starred such notable screen cowpokes, gunslingers and lawmen as John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, James Arness and James Stewart, died on Saturday at his home in Friday Harbor, Wash. He was 94.

headline: A Nation’s Musical Blend, Unfurled
abstract: The Ubuntu festival, featuring the trumpeter Hugh Masekela, the pianist Abdullah Ibrahim and the soprano Pretty Yende, will run from Oct. 8 through Nov. 5.
lead_paragraph: Ubuntu: loosely, “I am because you are.” This fall, the Nguni Bantu term for human kindness, in usage across South Africa, becomes the rallying cry for Carnegie Hall’s festival dedicated to the music of that nation. As such, it celebrates a sense of community that has been tested for much of that country’s recent history, and that continues to be redefined today, 20 years after the arrival of democracy.

headline: Surviving an ISIS Massacre
abstract: ISIS massacred hundreds of Iraqi military recruits in June 2014. Ali Hussein Kadhim survived. This is his improbable story. [Includes graphic images.]
lead_paragraph: ISIS massacred hundreds of Iraqi military recruits in June 2014. Ali Hussein Kadhim survived. This is his improbable story. [Includes graphic images.]

headline: De Blasio Endorses Hochul, Cuomo’s Pick for Lieutenant Governor
abstract: Kathy Hochul, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s running mate, received her biggest and most unlikely endorsement yet: from Mayor Bill de Blasio, who pronounced her a “true progressive.”
lead_paragraph: When Kathy Hochul served in Congress, she received an A rating from the National Rifle Association. As the Erie County clerk, she took a hard line on undocumented immigrants, pledging to inform the local sheriff about anyone who arrived at her office without valid papers.

headline: With Sense of Balance, Caroline Wozniacki Quiets Critics
abstract: Wozniacki has used employed a conservative style that has been consistent but has not led to any major titles.
lead_paragraph: It is an oft-repeated maxim in many sports, but there is room for questioning it when it comes to tennis: Can defense win championships?

headline: Escaping Death in Northern Iraq
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Ali Hussein Kadhim, an Iraqi soldier, was captured with hundreds of other soldiers by Sunni militants in June. As a Shiite, he was marked for death. [Video includes graphic images.]
lead_paragraph: DIWANIYA, Iraq — Ali Hussein Kadhim, an Iraqi soldier and a Shiite, was captured with hundreds of other soldiers by Sunni militants in June and taken to the grounds of a palace complex in Tikrit where Saddam Hussein once lived.

headline: When Reporting Is Dangerous
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Steven Sotloff, James Foley and other journalists on the front lines make us better informed.
lead_paragraph: My heart broke for Steven Sotloff, the second American journalist beheaded in Syria, not only because of the barbarity ISIS inflicted on him but also because he died trying to push back against the trend in news coverage.

headline: Charles Bowden, Author With Unblinking Eye on Southwest, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Bowden’s work explored the brutality of life along the border between the United States and Mexico, underscoring the complexities of the drug trade.
lead_paragraph: Charles Bowden, an author and journalist acclaimed for his vivid, unsparing and often lyrical portrayals of life in the Southwest, particularly the brutality on the border between the United States and Mexico, died on Saturday in Las Cruces, N.M. He was 69.

headline: Another Endurance Test on the Way to the Semifinals
abstract: Kei Nishikori battled through another five-set match, defeating Stan Wawrinka and becoming the first Japanese man to make a semifinal of the United States championships since 1918.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three days, Kei Nishikori found himself battling through a fifth set, fighting fatigue as much as his opponent, and somehow ending up the last player standing.

headline: In Irish Enclaves, Support and Relief as St. Patrick’s Parade Lifts Ban on Gay Groups
abstract: Many Irish-Americans in New York City welcomed the change, as well as the opportunity to put the controversy behind them.
lead_paragraph: The decision to allow gay groups to participate in the New York City St. Patrick’s Day parade was met mostly with support and relief on Wednesday in the city’s Irish neighborhoods and bars.

headline: Kuroda Is Sharp, Even if Some of the Yankees’ Play Is Not
abstract: Hiroki Kuroda allowed one run in seven innings, striking out eight, as the Yankees, who got hits from seven players, kept their dwindling playoff chances afloat.
lead_paragraph: The first hit Hiroki Kuroda allowed Wednesday night glanced off him and caromed just to the left of second base. Derek Jeter ranged over carefully, cleanly scooped up the ball and fired it to first base, just a split second late, as the runner crossed the bag.

headline: Granderson and Mets Pondering Spring
abstract: Curtis Granderson has had success in his career, but he is trying to avoid a label that has often applied to the Mets’ free-agent acquisitions: flop.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Mets still have almost a month of games remaining, but it seemed understandable on Wednesday that their manager was discussing Curtis Granderson’s season in the past tense. It has been one to forget for Granderson, who has three years left on his expensive contract. The spring cannot come soon enough.

headline: David Carr Interviews Dean Baquet
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Careers and Professions', 'Helicopters', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Dean Baquet, executive editor of The Times, answered questions on journalism.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, David Carr, a media columnist, interviewed Dean Baquet, the executive editor, before an audience of Times Premier subscribers. Mr. Baquet also answered questions from the audience.

headline: Ryan McGinley’s Nude Model Wallpaper
abstract: For an exhibition in New York that opens this weekend, the artist photographed over 200 men and women in their birthday suits.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: E.C.B., Despite Mounting Pressure, May Wait and See
abstract: The European Central Bank meets on Thursday and is widely expected to gauge the results of a new loan program before taking further stimulus steps.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank is expected to leave its main interest rate at a record low on Thursday, waiting to see the effect of a program to encourage bank lending before it resorts to more powerful but riskier measures to stimulate the faltering eurozone economy.

headline: Rdio Moves to Free Music Model to Compete with Spotify and Others
abstract: Rdio’s new design draws heavily on an Internet radio format popularized by Pandora.
lead_paragraph: In the face of growing competition in the streaming music market, Rdio, a four-year-old service that charges for online subscriptions, has moved into a new phase with abundant free music — as well as free music’s ever-present companion, advertising.

headline: Vice Lands 2nd Investment, to Fuel Expansion
abstract: The $250 million investment from Technology Crossover Ventures comes on the heels of financing from A&E Networks.
lead_paragraph: Vice Media, the rabble-rouser of the news and entertainment business, has landed a pair of investments totaling $500 million to fuel the expansion of its media empire.

headline: Eclectic Lineup for CBGB Festival
abstract: The third CBGB Music and Film Festival will take place Oct. 8-12 in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The indie bands We Are Scientists and Surfer Blood will rub shoulders with ’70s and ’80s groups like Devo and Jane’s Addiction, the R&B singer Macy Gray and the electronica artist Robert DeLong at the third CBGB Music and Film Festival, a five-day celebration of diverse streams of rock and alternative music – as well as film about the music world. The festival will run Oct. 8 through Oct.12, organizers said, at sites in Manhattan — including Times Square, Center 548, Bowery Electric, City Winery and Pianos — and in Brooklyn, at Baby’s All Right, the Bell House, Saint Vitus, the Knitting Factory and the Trash Bar.

headline: Put the Physical in Education
abstract: A study suggests that exercise can help kids, especially those with A.D.H.D., focus in class.
lead_paragraph: When confronted with an overly active child, many exasperated teachers and parents respond the same way: “Sit still!” It might be more effective, though, to encourage the child to run. Recent research suggests that even small amounts of exercise enable children to improve their focus and academic performance.

headline: Word of the Day | skinflint
abstract: This word has appeared in two New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: skinflint •\ˈskin-ˌflint\• noun

headline: The Race Gap in America’s Police Departments
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities']
abstract: Hundreds of police departments across the nation have forces with a white percentage that is more than 30 percentage points higher than the communities they serve.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of police departments across the nation have forces with a white percentage that is more than 30 percentage points higher than the communities they serve.

headline: W.H.O. Leader Describes the Agency’s Ebola Operations
abstract: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, described how the agency offered assistance in the Ebola crisis.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Chan, director general of the World Health Organization, based in Geneva, flew to New York on Monday for several days of meetings in the United States focused on the international fight against the Ebola outbreak. Before walking to her first meeting and then tucking into her favorite East Side noodle dive, she sat down for an interview about Ebola.

headline: Why Colleges With a Distinct Focus Have a Hidden Advantage
abstract: Looking at where students who gain admission to numerous colleges choose to go reveals some surprises.
lead_paragraph: Take a look at any of the most widely followed ratings of America’s colleges and universities, and almost all of the top-ranked schools will have this in common: They want to appeal to everyone, or at least everyone with a brilliant mind and a work ethic to match.

headline: For Stan Wawrinka, Margin Between Winning and Losing at U.S. Open Is Thin
abstract: Stan Wawrinka led Kei Nishikori in many statistical categories but lost their quarterfinal match in five close sets.
lead_paragraph: With so many momentum swings, so many spectacular points, so many half chances and incredible shots and ridiculous winners down the line, what ultimately mattered the most in the quarterfinal match between Kei Nishikori and Stan Wawrinka?

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:45 A.M. (TCM) FANNY AND ALEXANDER (1983) Two young Swedish siblings (Bertil Guve and Pernilla Allwin) find their joyful lives in 1907 Uppsala upended when their father suddenly dies, and their mother (Ewa Froling) marries an authoritarian bishop (Jan Malmsjo) and moves with her children into his bleak palace, haunted by the ghosts of his dead wife and daughters, with nothing but the clothes on their backs. “Even as you watch Ingmar Bergman’s new film, ‘Fanny and Alexander,’ it has that quality of enchantment that usually attaches only to the best movies in retrospect, long after you’ve seen them, when they’ve been absorbed into the memory to seem sweeter, wiser, more magical than anything ever does in its own time,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “This immediate resonance is the distinguishing feature of this superb film, which is both quintessential Bergman and unlike anything else he has ever done before.”

headline: Breaths of Fresh Acting Talent
abstract: The new season comes with five standout performances from recent Hollywood arrivals.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Waterston, “Inherent Vice”

headline: The U.S. Open Under the Lights
abstract: A panoramic view of Arthur Ashe Stadium after nightfall during Roger Federer’s match against Roberto Bautista Agut.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of Arthur Ashe Stadium after nightfall during Roger Federer’s match against Roberto Bautista Agut.

headline: In China, Seeking Equality in Education for Disabled Migrants
abstract: School started in China this week, but one group of students was missing, say civil society groups: the disabled children of migrant workers. The groups have appealed to the government to change this.
lead_paragraph: They’re migrants, they’re children, and they’re disabled — a combination that means they are almost entirely overlooked in society.

headline: Novak Djokovic Defeats Andy Murray to Reach U.S. Open Semifinals
abstract: Murray used a barrage of baseline forehands to keep the match close, but he struggled through pain as Djokovic took command and advanced to his eighth straight semifinal in Flushing Meadows.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray blasted forehands as he had perhaps never blasted forehands before. He played with fire and conviction, but there has rarely been a tennis champion better at absorbing pace and ambition than Novak Djokovic.

headline: Untold Stories After the Arab Spring

The most haunting images showed hundreds of mourners gathered around coffins, chaos and stampedes of people with fire blazing behind them.

headline: Chekhov’s ‘The Seagull,’ Adapted and Updated for Beijing

lead_paragraph: Anton Chekhov said of his play “The Seagull” that it had “little action and lots of talk about love,” according to Gavin Quinn, the director of a zany adaptation of the Russian classic that opens Thursday at the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing.

headline: A Debate Fueled by Carbs (or the Lack Thereof)
abstract: A new study has found that low-carb diets may be better for cardiovascular health than low-fat ones. But one doctor says focusing on low anything is the wrong approach.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that a low-carb diet may be better for cardiovascular health and weight loss than a low-fat one. However, Anahad O’Connor writes at The New York Times that “the findings are unlikely to be the final salvo in what has been a long and often contentious debate about what foods are best to eat for weight loss and overall health.”

headline: Do You Like Watching Other People Play Video Games?

The Q70 sport sedan, for instance, was known until the 2014 model year as the M; now Infiniti has thrown another letter into the alphabet soup by offering a long-wheelbase version for 2015, the Q70L.

headline: Why Many Small Businesses Cannot Be Sold
abstract: You and your advisers need to figure out which information is sensitive and find a way to protect it, while also providing all of the information needed by potential buyers, competitors or not. At least, that’s what you do if you really want to sell your business.
lead_paragraph: Many business owners have a dream of selling their business some day. But many of those businesses will never be sold. You can see this simply by reviewing the number of businesses listed for sale each month on the website BizBuySell.com.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — EVERY September, the campuses of Peking and Tsinghua Universities, often called the Harvard and M.I.T. of China, brim with eager new students, the winners of China’s cutthroat education system. These young men and women possess the outlook of cosmopolitan youth worldwide: sporting designer clothes and wielding high-end smartphones, they share experiences of foreign travel and bond over common fondness for Western television shows like “The Big Bang Theory” and “Sherlock.”

headline: 1939: Fighting on Western Front
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Fighting has started all over Europe in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Guns roared yesterday on the western front. A Nazi imitation of Von Tirpitz’s submarine the Frightfulness (Schrecklichkeit) was held responsible for the sinking of the 13,500-ton British liner Athenia, carrying 1,400 passengers, of whom about 300 were Americans, off the northwest coast of Scotland. In the furious fighting in Poland, the Germans were reported to have employed asphyxiating and mustard gas, together with an unknown chemical. Royal Air Force planes made an uneventful round trip into Germany during which they scattered more than 6,000,000 leaflets containing a proclamation to the German people, London announced. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 5, 1939

Not to worry if it seems that the well might dry up of East London lads or toned Iowa farm boys or wan Eastern European starvelings. There is always another mall to scout; another vein to mine.

lead_paragraph: The flow of techies seeking to shake up the food business is picking up.

headline: The Odds and Ends of New York
abstract: “A Brief History of New York: Selections from ‘A History of New York in 101 Objects, ’ ” at the New-York Historical Society, presents an intriguingly eclectic collection.
lead_paragraph: From a human perspective, there’s no such thing as an objective object. Anything that comes to a person’s attention — a rock, a tree, a dog, a painting, another person — will evoke ideas, feelings, memories and fantasies. Every object tells a story.

headline: 1964: New York Disappoints French
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French tourists were not impressed with New York in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French tourists find New York not worth more than a four-day stay, the afternoon newspaper ‘‘Paris-Presse’’ said today [Sept. 4]. Among their complaints according to the paper’s New York correspondent are that they catch cold from the air-conditioning, to which they are unaccustomed, that there is nothing worth seeing in New York aside from the three major museums, that the World’s Fair is too hot and over-commercialized, that there are no bidets in hotel rooms, and that no one understands French. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 5, 1964
