headline: How People Feel About Their Employer-Sponsored Health Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Results of surveys may be helpful in evaluating early results from the new Affordable Care Act plans.
lead_paragraph: We’re still waiting to get really good information about how people who have bought health plans on the new state marketplaces are liking them. There’s some early polling evidence that people are happy to have coverage — but also some accounts that people are frustrated by small doctor networks and struggling to afford medical care even after getting insurance.

headline: Why Flunking Exams Is Actually a Good Thing
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Memory', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: To learn how to study, start by bombing a pretest.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that on Day 1 of a difficult course, before you studied a single thing, you got hold of the final exam. The motherlode itself, full text, right there in your email inbox — attached mistakenly by the teacher, perhaps, or poached by a campus hacker. No answer key, no notes or guidelines. Just the questions.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Glamorous Actresses Playing Tarnished Characters
abstract: Jennifer Aniston, Jennifer Connelly and Reese Witherspoon are turning in low-glitter performances in films playing the festival.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:15 p.m. | TORONTO — It takes a brave actress to rough herself up and appear on-screen without all the tricks and trade-craft that make beautiful people even more so in the movies.

headline: Tracing Jewish History Along the Rhine
abstract: On a journey that starts in Cologne and heads south, finding echoes of a sometimes distant past.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1963, when I was 12, my parents, German-speaking Jewish refugees from Vienna, took us children on a boat trip up the Rhine. It was our first time in Germany, the country that had annexed our parents’ native Austria and sent them running for their lives. Family sentiments ran strong: longing spiked with anger, nostalgia with regret. All I really cared about were the castles crowning every slope and the chocolate-covered marzipan. But when we rounded a boulder-strewn bend in the river — “The Lorelei,” the legendary perch of the siren who lured boatmen to their doom — my mother was so moved she leapt up and declaimed, in German: “I don’t know what’s come over me, / That I should be so sad.”

headline: Teaching Children Empathy
abstract: Empathy isn’t just taking another perspective. Con men can do that. In order to be empathetic, children need to know how to value, respect and understand another person’s points of view, even when they don’t agree.
lead_paragraph: When Harvard University’s Making Caring Common Project released their report, “The Children We Mean to Raise: The Real Messages Adults Are Sending About Values,” many parents and educators — myself included — were surprised to learn that despite all our talk about instilling character and empathy, kids may value academic achievement and individual happiness over caring for others. In the report, the authors explained that the children’s values reflected what they believe adults value.

headline: Stephen D. Isaacs, Journalist and Educator, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Isaacs grew up in a newspaper family and worked in print and broadcast journalism before joining Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism.
lead_paragraph: Stephen D. Isaacs, who at 26 became city editor of The Washington Post and went on to become a prominent journalist and academic at Columbia University, died on Aug. 28 in Austin, Tex. He was 76.

headline: Michael Aram on the Artisans of Delhi
abstract: The home décor designer, a regular at Delhi’s bazaars and craft markets, talks about where he spots designers and watches craft demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: When the home décor designer Michael Aram first toured the bazaars of Old Delhi, in 1988, he didn’t expect to return to his home in New York City with a new profession, let alone one that would lead him to set up shop in India.

headline: Death, Recovery and Hope at a Hospital During Drawdown
abstract: At Bagram Airfield north of Kabul, a surgeon at Craig Joint Theater Hospital makes his rounds and reflects on his service at the largest American hospital in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: These days most NATO forces in Afghanistan rarely, if ever, leave the secured perimeters of their bases. While safer, life on base produces a complicated proximity to the realities of war — we’re both close and far away. At Bagram Airfield north of Kabul, the line between life and death is often clearest in the largest American hospital in the country, Craig Joint Theater Hospital.

headline: Europe’s Big Push for Growth Is More About Trust Than Anything

headline: Rogue Trader Jérôme Kerviel to Be Released From French Jail

headline: Independent Now a Real Contender in the Kansas Senate Race

Plagued by residency issues, he won the Republican nomination with only 48 percent of the vote, and polls showed a surprisingly tight race in one of the most conservative states in the country.

headline: A Measurement of ‘Terrorism’ in 1964, Canada Included
abstract: “Terrorism” appears in The Times’s 1964 archive in relation to various countries. Perhaps the most surprising mention, for today’s readers, is Canada.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Canadians’ Concern on Terrorism Rises” appeared on Sept. 1 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: NATO Prepares New Sanctions Over Russian Action in Ukraine
abstract: At NATO’s summit meeting, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said he would seek to establish “a bilateral cease-fire” on Friday between the country’s armed forces and pro-Russian separatists.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Wales — Amid talk of a possible cease-fire between Ukrainian forces and Moscow-backed separatists, President Obama and European leaders at a NATO summit meeting here on Thursday prepared a new round of sanctions against Russian officials, banks and enterprises that could be imposed as early as Friday.

headline: Shellshocked Ukrainians Flee to New Lives in Russia
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians have found their way into Russia, clinging to promises of work, shelter, pensions and a path to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Russia — Oksana Shevelina, 62, who came here with her elderly mother just a few days ago from their home in eastern Ukraine, squinted at a map of the Russian Federation.

headline: Seeking a Pipeline, U.S.T.A. Turns to the College Game
abstract: The U.S.T.A.’s four-day tournament for top college tennis players is a clear statement that it has begun to view college programs as viable training grounds for the pro ranks.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, some of the nation’s best college tennis players made a rare appearance at the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. The occasion was the start of a four-day tournament, sponsored by the United States Tennis Association and held with the blessing of the N.C.A.A., that is part of a high-profile initiative to reinvigorate and promote intercollegiate tennis.

headline: Wheelies: The Thrifty G.M. Pickups Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue']
abstract: G.M. says its Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon midsize pickups will get 26 m.p.g. on the highway; the price of the 2015 Toyota Sienna is $1,680 more than the 2014 model.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: F.C.C. to Promote Choices for High-Speed Broadband
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Tom Wheeler, the commission’s chairman, said the panel would not seek greater regulation but would encourage provider choice where it did not exist.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans lack real choices among providers of high-speed Internet service, with fewer than one in four homes having access to two or more providers of the broadband speeds that are quickly becoming “table stakes” in modern communications, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday.

headline: New York Fashion Week Spring/Summer 2015: Antonio Azzuolo
abstract: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Unicef Report Details Endemic Violence Against Children
abstract: One in 10 girls worldwide have been forced into a sexual act, and six in 10 children ages 2 to 14 are regularly beaten by caregivers, according to Unicef.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — One in 10 girls worldwide have been forced into a sexual act, and six in 10 children ages 2 to 14 are regularly beaten by parents and caregivers, according to a report issued Thursday by the United Nations’ children’s agency, Unicef.

headline: Today in Small Business: Suppose Your Company Name Is Isis
abstract: Gallup reports that new businesses are starved for financing and in decline. How to start a business with a friend (and stay friends). The struggle to find skilled workers.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Properly Scholarly Attitude’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing features Adelaide Crapsey’s poem “The Properly Scholarly Attitude” and the Op-Talk feature “Children Need Free Play, but Are ‘Unschoolers’ Giving Them Too Much?” by Hanna Kozlowska.
lead_paragraph: We ring in the new school year with our first Poetry Pairing of the season: Adelaide Crapsey’s poem “The Properly Scholarly Attitude” and the Op-Talk feature “Children Need Free Play, but Are ‘Unschoolers’ Giving Them Too Much?” by Hanna Kozlowska.

headline: A New Food Tour in Prague
abstract: Eating Prague Tours includes visits to a pastry shop, a brew pub and historic sites.
lead_paragraph: The food tour company that started in Rome and expanded into London and Amsterdam has made its debut in Eastern Europe.

headline: Collection | Poetry Pairings
abstract: This feature, in which we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to match poetry with Times content, has been going strong since 2010. Here is the full list of pairings to date.
lead_paragraph: Our Poetry Pairings feature, a collaboration with the Poetry Foundation, has been going strong since the summer of 2010, presenting classic and contemporary poems alongside New York Times articles and photography.

headline: Miranda Lambert and Blake Shelton Among Country Music Award Nominees
abstract: Other top nominees for the Country Music Association awards are Keith Urban, George Strait and Luke Bryan.
lead_paragraph: When the Country Music Association hands out its annual awards in a ceremony televised from Nashville on Nov. 5, Miranda Lambert and her husband, Blake Shelton, will be direct competitors. Both are nominated for the entertainer of the year honor, as well as for single of the year (“Automatic” in Ms. Lambert’s case; “Mine Would Be You,” in Mr. Shelton’s). The association announced the award nominees on Wednesday.

headline: Chicago Symphony Association Names a New President
abstract: Jeff Alexander, president and chief executive of the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, will take over as president of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra Association in January.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra Association had been searching for a new president since Deborah F. Rutter announced in December that she planned to leave in June to become president of the Kennedy Center. Now the board has named Jeff Alexander to the post, starting Jan. 12. The association oversees the orchestra and related entities.

headline: Father Charged With Murder in Hot-Car Death, and Death Penalty Is Weighed
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A grand jury in suburban Atlanta issued an eight-count indictment against Justin Ross Harris, whose 22-month-old son, Cooper, died in June.
lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — The suburban Atlanta father whose toddler died in June after being left in a hot vehicle was indicted Thursday on murder charges.

headline: IV Misplaced in Oklahoma Execution, Report Says
abstract: Officials at the prison also erred by covering the inmate’s groin, where the injection was made, preventing them from seeing the problem.
lead_paragraph: An official report released Thursday about a bungled execution in Oklahoma in April says that an improperly placed intravenous line in the prisoner’s groin allowed the drugs to perfuse surrounding tissue rather than to flow directly into his bloodstream.

headline: Dynamic Planet: Under the Volcano in Papua New Guinea
abstract: Three views of a violent volcanic eruption in Papua New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: A caldera is the cauldron-like depression formed when a volcanic eruption empties a shallow chamber of magma and the cone collapses. If the volcano is at sea level, the result, after the passage of time, can be a fine harbor.

headline: Report on Clayton Lockett Execution
abstract: The Oklahoma Department of Public Safety released this report of its review of the events leading up to and during the bungled execution of an inmate in April.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Department of Public Safety released this report of its review of the events leading up to and during the bungled execution of an inmate in April.

headline: Stan Goldberg, Who Drew Archie for Decades, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Goldberg, who drew Archie comics for more than 40 years, also worked closely with artists like Steve Ditko, Jack Kirby and Stan Lee.
lead_paragraph: Stan Goldberg, who drew Archie comics for more than 40 years, notably a series beginning in 2009 in which an adult Archie finally marries — both Betty and Veronica, in alternate timelines — died on Sunday at a hospice in the Bronx. He was 82.

headline: No Comment Necessary: 30 Years in Jail for Nothing, but ‘the Process Worked’
abstract: Thom Tillis, the Republican nominee for the Senate election in North Carolina, had an interesting take on a wrongful conviction.
lead_paragraph: Henry Lee McCollum and his half-brother, Leon Brown, were released from prison in North Carolina on Wednesday after having spent decades in jail for a crime they did not commit. That night, ThinkProgress asked Thom Tillis, the North Carolina House Speaker and Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate seat currently occupied by Kay Hagan, if anything needed to change in light of the case.

headline: Sergio Rodrigues, Father of Brazilian Furniture Design, Dies at 86
abstract: His tables, chairs and other living accessories were said to reflect the sociable, witty nature of the Brazilian national character.
lead_paragraph: Sergio Rodrigues, whose tables, chairs and other living accessories set the standard for modern furniture design in his native Brazil and who forged a path to the international market for his countrymen, died on Monday at his home in Rio de Janeiro. He was 86.

headline: Russia Resettles Refugees From War-Torn Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Russia is promoting a huge resettlement program to encourage refugees to put down roots in far-flung cities across Russia.
lead_paragraph: Russia is promoting a huge resettlement program to encourage refugees to put down roots in far-flung cities across Russia.

headline: BCBG Max Azria: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Hurricane Sandy Recovery Program in New York City Was Mired by Its Design
abstract: Thousands of families remain frustrated by the city’s residence rebuilding program, Build It Back, which has been stalled by design and execution problems largely attributable to the Bloomberg administration.
lead_paragraph: The night Hurricane Sandy struck, Jayme and John Galimi swam out the front door of their home in Broad Channel, Queens, into the rising waters of Jamaica Bay with their five children, the youngest clinging to his father’s back.

headline: Wedding Q.&A.
abstract: Whether to bring a fiancé to the wedding if they were not directly invited; and when and how to say ‘last call.’
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, a Fiancé Appears

headline: Getty Grants for Personal Photo Projects
abstract: This year’s winners have tackled themes from South Africa’s post-apartheid generation to the lives of Arab women.
lead_paragraph: This year’s winners have tackled themes from South Africa’s post-apartheid generation to the lives of Arab women.

headline: Living With Schizophrenia: The Importance of Routine
abstract: My story, as with so many stories of recovery, isn’t over. The biggest things in my life are now my friends and family, my work and my daily routine.
lead_paragraph: I can remember the early days of having schizophrenia. I was so afraid of the implications of subtle body language, like a lingering millisecond of eye contact, the way my feet hit the ground when I walked or the way I held my hands to my side. It was a struggle to go into a store or, really, anywhere I was bound to see another living member of the human species.

headline: Michael Katz, Who Challenged View of Poverty, Dies at 75
abstract: Professor Katz, who taught at the University of Pennsylvania and was a founder of its urban studies program, challenged the prevailing view in the 1980s and ’90s that poverty stemmed from the bad habits of the poor.
lead_paragraph: Michael B. Katz, an influential historian and social theorist who challenged the prevailing view in the 1980s and ’90s that poverty stemmed from the bad habits of the poor, marshaling the case that its deeper roots lay in the actions of the powerful, died on Aug. 23 in Philadelphia. He was 75.

headline: A Day in the Life | Rosetta Getty
abstract: T follows fashion designer Rosetta Getty through a day in New York City as she works on her spring/summer 2015 collection, takes in a show at Gagosian and scouts locations for a lookbook photo shoot.
lead_paragraph: T follows fashion designer Rosetta Getty through a day in New York City as she works on her spring/summer 2015 collection, takes in a show at Gagosian and scouts locations for a lookbook photo shoot.

headline: A Book Bound in Human Skin? Sorry, Not This Time.
abstract: A book at Juniata College in Pennsylvania believed to be bound in human skin turns out to have been bound in sheepskin.
lead_paragraph: Three months after scientists at Harvard confirmed that a 19th-century French treatise in one of its libraries was almost certainly bound in human skin, another institution has put a supposed anthropodermic binding in its possession to the test and come up wanting.

headline: Coach: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Senegal Is Only the Start
abstract: Café Rue Dix is a bistro in its broadest, most generous definition: a restaurant firmly of its Crown Heights neighborhood but cosmopolitan in outlook.
lead_paragraph: The first Senegalese dish I ate at Café Rue Dix looked a lot like Vietnamese spring rolls: pale, crackly bundles with bubbled bits of rice paper shearing off, backed by frills of kale. They came with a dark dipping sauce as vinegary and lime-bright as nuoc cham.

headline: Senate Forecast Update: What Will Greg Orman Do?
abstract: Now that Chad Taylor has dropped out of the race in Kansas, our revised Senate forecast gives Republicans a 60 percent chance to take the Senate.
lead_paragraph: How does the big political news out of Kansas affect the odds in our Senate forecasting model?

headline: Ruling on the 2010 Gulf of Mexico Oil Well Blowout
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: U.S. District Court Judge Carl J. Barbier ruled on Thursday that BP was grossly negligent in the oil rig explosion that killed 11 workers, spilled millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches.
lead_paragraph: U.S. District Court Judge Carl J. Barbier ruled on Thursday that BP was grossly negligent in the oil rig explosion that killed 11 workers, spilled millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and soiled hundreds of miles of beaches.

headline: Rosetta Getty Prepares for New York Fashion Week
abstract: In this exclusive video, the designer gives T a glimpse into her creative process.
lead_paragraph: Since launching her namesake ready-to-wear line last fall, the Los Angeles-based fashion designer Rosetta Getty has been quietly assembling a wardrobe of easy, elegant garments for women like her, who want to be able to seamlessly and stylishly transition from grade school drop-offs to after-work events. Instead of one-off looks, Getty creates collections that build off each previous season’s pieces, which lends a thoughtful cohesion to her line. As she prepared to unveil what’s next for spring 2015, Getty gave the filmmaker Marissa Kaiser a glimpse into her creative process on the eve of fashion week in New York.

headline: Google’s F.T.C. Tab for Charges Rung Up by Children: $19 Million
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mobile Applications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The Internet giant is the latest tech company to settle an FTC complaint that it didn’t do enough to block unexpected charges on smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Here are some reasons people might not want children to play with their phones: They don’t want them to accidentally call their boss. They don’t want them to become mindless phone addicts like themselves. Also, they don’t want get stuck with a $200 bill for digital coins, virtual lives and other video game perks that cost real-world money.

headline: National G.O.P. Moves to Take Over Campaign of a Kansas Senator
abstract: The campaign of Senator Pat Roberts, and the hopes of Republicans for taking control of the Senate, have been threatened by the sudden withdrawal of the Democrat in the race.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — National Republicans on Thursday moved to take control of the campaign of Senator Pat Roberts of Kansas by sending a longtime party strategist to the state to advise him, a day after his hopes for re-election and those of his party for taking control of the Senate were threatened by the attempted withdrawal of the Democrat in the race.

headline: Former Israeli President Proposes Global Peace Initiative in Talks With Pope
abstract: Shimon Peres presented a plan to create “a sort of United Nations for religions,” based on the assumption that religion rather than nationalism is at the root of most current conflicts.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Shimon Peres, the former president of Israel, met with Pope Francis on Thursday to present his plan to create “a sort of United Nations for religions” to address the nature of contemporary conflicts.

headline: When Protégée Resents Mentor
abstract: A teacher who is a mentor to a colleague finds she is meeting resistance to her guidance.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Libya Militia Fighting Takes Toll on Civilians, U.N. Says
abstract: Violence in Tripoli and Benghazi in recent weeks has killed hundreds of people, the United Nations said in a report that described summary executions, abductions and torture.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Fighting among militias in and around the Libyan cities of Tripoli and Benghazi in recent weeks has killed hundreds of people, including many civilians, the United Nations said Thursday in a report that described summary executions, abductions and torture taking place in a growing “climate of fear.”

headline: Al Qaeda Announces New Branch in India
abstract: In a video posted online, the Al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahri announced the establishment of Qaedat al-Jihad in the Indian Subcontinent.
lead_paragraph: In a video posted online, the Al Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahri announced the establishment of Qaedat al-Jihad in the Indian Subcontinent.

headline: How Caffeine Evolved to Help Plants Survive and Help People Wake Up
abstract: In a new study, an international team of scientists has sequenced the genome of Coffea canephora, one of the main sources of coffee beans.
lead_paragraph: Every second, people around the world drink more than 26,000 cups of coffee. And while some of them may care only about the taste, most use it as a way to deliver caffeine into their bloodstream. Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychoactive substance in the world.

headline: Guinness World Record Book Acknowledges Metallica, Eminem and Miley Cyrus
abstract: Metallica is listed in “Guinness World Records 2015″ as the first rock band to perform on all seven continents.
lead_paragraph: Metallica, Eminem, One Direction and Miley Cyrus are among the musicians who have found their way into “Guinness World Records 2015,” which will be published next week.

headline: M.L.B. Hires Bryan Seeley to Lead Investigations Unit
abstract: Seeley, who has served as an assistant United States attorney in Washington since 2006, inherits the unit that handled the Alex Rodriguez doping case.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball on Thursday appointed Bryan Seeley as its new head of investigations, the latest step in an overhaul of the department since the Alex Rodriguez doping case.

headline: Braun’s Old Look Is New Again
abstract: The German company known for a historically minimalist aesthetic resurfaces its original analog wristwatch design from 1989.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Braun.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Back to School, 1940
abstract: On Sept. 8, 1940, The New York Times reminded 1,100,000 children and 40,000 teachers that New York City schools started the next day. This year New York City public schools began their new year on Sept. 4.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 8, 1940, The New York Times reminded 1,100,000 children and 40,000 teachers that New York City schools started the next day.

headline: First Arrest Made in 2012 Steroid Medication Deaths
abstract: Federal authorities said they arrested Glenn Adam Chin, the head pharmacist of the New England Compounding Center, whose contaminated drugs led to 64 deaths.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities made the first arrest in the case of the New England Compounding Center, a Massachusetts-based drug maker whose tainted steroid pain medication killed dozens of people across the country in 2012.

headline: Federal Judge Orders Ohio to Undo Cuts to Early Voting
abstract: The preliminary injunction issued by Judge Peter C. Economus was a setback for Gov. John R. Kasich, and could affect the upcoming elections in Ohio, a closely contested swing state.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday blocked Ohio’s cuts to early voting and ordered the state to establish additional polling days before November’s elections, saying the reductions would disproportionately harm the poor and members of minority groups.

headline: Lending Club May Need to Justify Its Valuation
abstract: As Lending Club, a peer-to-peer lender, plans an initial public offering, there are reasons to be cautious, write Antony Currie and Daniel Indiviglio in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Lending Club is positioning itself as one of the biggest challengers to American banks. The company is growing quickly, has backing from the likes of Google and counts the former Morgan Stanley chief John J. Mack and former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers among its directors. It’s also planning an initial public offering. But there are reasons to be cautious.

headline: Former Governor in Virginia Guilty in Bribery Case
abstract: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were convicted of doing favors for a businessman in exchange for gifts and loans.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were convicted of corruption in federal court on Thursday, after a trial that shattered the political career of the onetime Republican star and peeled back the couple’s private life to the bone.

headline: New Light on Hamas Role in Killings of Teenagers That Fueled Gaza War
abstract: Israeli documents cite no evidence that the top leaders of Hamas had prior knowledge of a plot involving the abduction and killing of three Israeli teenagers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The abduction and killing of three Israeli teenagers in the occupied West Bank in June, which helped fuel the biggest escalation in Palestinian-Israeli tensions in years, was set in motion by Hamas operatives from a local Palestinian clan and was financed with about $60,000, mostly obtained through a relative who worked for a Hamas association in Gaza, according to official Israeli documents released on Thursday.

headline: Apple Plans Smartwatch and Larger iPhones
abstract: The watch, which is expected to include fitness tracking and wireless payment, will be the first new product unveiled under Tim Cook, who replaced Steve Jobs in 2011.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple wants to make a big splash, it returns to its history.

headline: New York Police Officers to Start Using Body Cameras in a Pilot Program
abstract: A federal judge had ordered the department to test the cameras for one year in five police precincts, though the introduction of the cameras was not done in consultation with the court.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department will begin equipping a small number of its officers with wearable video cameras, a pilot program geared toward eventually outfitting the nation’s largest police force with technology that promises greater accountability.

headline: Jameis Winston Case Said to Be Subject of Florida State Inquiry
abstract: A female student accused the quarterback of the top-ranked Seminoles of sexually assaulting her in his apartment in December 2012.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 21 months after a female student accused Jameis Winston, Florida State’s marquee quarterback, of sexually assaulting her in his apartment, the university has begun a disciplinary inquiry into the case, the woman’s lawyer said Thursday.

headline: Cornered, They Reach for Their Sex Pistols
abstract: “Kelly & Cal,” starring Juliette Lewis, centers on a punk rocker turned bored suburban mother who takes up with a 17-year-old in a wheelchair.
lead_paragraph: The distance between riot grrrl and suburban mom is quite a stretch. But as middle age approaches, time has a way of landing mouthy young rebels in roles they never expected to inhabit. Take Juliette Lewis, the personification of scary defiance alongside Woody Harrelson as her partner in crime in “Natural Born Killers.”

headline: DreamWorks Chooses Chief From Ranks of Television
abstract: Michael Wright, who has worked at Turner Broadcasting for the last 14 years, will succeed Stacey Snider as chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Steven Spielberg’s struggling live-action movie company, DreamWorks Studios, announced on Thursday that it would part ways with its longtime chief and named a former television executive to succeed her.

headline: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the Rookies, Part 2
abstract: We continue our breakdown of the top fantasy-relevant rookies with the wide receiver and tight end positions.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom in fantasy football has traditionally been to avoid rookies. While some are more flash than substance, rookies should not be underestimated or ignored.

headline: Celebrating American Quilts in Shows and Books
abstract: American quilts, from the traditional to the maverick, are the subject of books and exhibitions this fall.
lead_paragraph: Quilt scholars are debunking a few myths this fall.

headline: Intimate Feelings, Especially for Herself
abstract: In “Wetlands,” a teenager with no bodily inhibitions hopes to reconcile her divorced parents.
lead_paragraph: The title of “Wetlands” strongly suggests a nature documentary, and that’s not so far off the mark. Doing — and smelling and tasting — what comes naturally is the singular obsession of the film’s rollicking heroine, Helen (Carla Juri, sensational), an 18-year-old student of vaginal flora and bodily fluids. Helen’s cheerfully experimental sex life and rebellious attitude toward personal hygiene may shock her Catholic mother, but her unwavering affection for her body, in all its secreting glory, is nothing less than thrilling.

headline: ‘Obamacare’ Challengers Lose Again
abstract: The federal appeals court in D.C. tossed out a ruling that would have gutted the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, as almost everyone predicted it would, the federal appeals court in Washington, D.C., voted to toss out a three-judge panel’s ruling upholding the latest attempt to kill “Obamacare.” The full 11-member court is scheduled to rehear the case on Dec. 17.

headline: Renee Zellweger in Red-Hot Carolina Herrera
abstract: The actress stunned at an FIT event honoring Carolina Herrera last night.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Renee Zellweger

headline: Mazda Reveals Little About the 2016 Miata
abstract: For months, Mazda has kept all details about its fourth-generation MX-5 secret, and although its looks are now public, not much else is.
lead_paragraph: MARINA, Calif. — Well, the new Mazda MX-5 Miata looks pretty.

headline: Between Gaza and Israel, a Border Crossing in Need of Travelers
abstract: The Erez crossing, which has been dramatically restricted since 2007, is a critical part of the effort to maintain a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: EREZ CROSSING, at the Israel-Gaza border — At 375,000 square feet, the terminal through which travelers pass between Israel and the Gaza Strip is a vast, high-tech hangar with a capacity of 45,000 people per day. Current traffic: 400 or fewer.

headline: Joan Rivers, a Comic Stiletto Quick to Skewer, Is Dead at 81
abstract: From the stage and the red carpet, Ms. Rivers reveled in skewering the rich and famous with cutting remarks and a caustic wit.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers, the raspy loudmouth who pounced on America’s obsessions with flab, face-lifts, body hair and other blemishes of neurotic life, including her own, in five decades of caustic comedy that propelled her from nightclubs to television to international stardom, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 81.

headline: Joan Rivers: 50 Years of Funny
abstract: Moments from the groundbreaking career of Joan Rivers.
lead_paragraph: Moments from the groundbreaking career of Joan Rivers.

headline: Joan Rivers Overcame the ‘Handicap of a Woman Comic’
abstract: Ms. Rivers’s reputation as a snarky fashion commentator has somewhat obscured her trailblazing comedy career.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers, the irreverent comedian known for her sharp wit and sharper tongue, died Thursday in Manhattan. She was 81.

headline: For Dante de Blasio, It’s Back to School (With Mayoral Escort)
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who for years drove his son to school, dropped him off at Brooklyn Technical High School for the first day of his senior year.
lead_paragraph: Exiled parents sulked on a tree-lined block in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, across from a high school where administrators were gently — but insistently — making it clear that the time had come to let go.

headline: Greetings From the NYT 4th Down Bot
abstract: I exist for just one purpose: to encourage smarter thinking about N.F.L. fourth downs.
lead_paragraph: Hello again, my friends. My name is NYT 4th Down Bot, and I exist for just one purpose: to encourage smarter thinking about N.F.L. fourth downs. I analyze every single fourth down of every game, every week, in real time. I come in peace.

headline: 4th Down: When to Go for It and Why
abstract: The NYT 4th Down Bot gives you the basics so that you can get on the bandwagon in 2014.
lead_paragraph: This post is meant to be a quick tutorial on fourth-down strategy, neatly summarized in the chart above. (You can also read a post that explains the history of me — the NYT 4th Down Bot.)

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Dangerous for Evil
abstract: Bad economic ideas as enablers of bad policy.
lead_paragraph: “It is ideas, not vested interests, which are dangerous for good or evil.” So declared Keynes at the end of The General Theory; although I don’t think he appreciated the extent to which vested interests can buy the ideas they want to hear. Anyway, this seems relevant to Brad DeLong’s flashback to 2009, when I was lamenting bad ideas from freshwater economists and Justin Fox was dismissing them as having no influence on policy.

headline: Warhol’s Presley and Brando Head to Auction
abstract: Andy Warhol paintings of Elvis Presley and Marlon Brando will be put up for sale in November at Christie’s.
lead_paragraph: Whom would you prefer to live with, Elvis Presley or Marlon Brando?

headline: A Princess Bride in a Digital Forever
abstract: Ari Folman’s allegorical movie “The Congress” stars Robin Wright as a midcareer actress named Robin Wright, whom a studio wants to digitize for posterity.
lead_paragraph: Ari Folman’s genre mash-up “The Congress” could use a freakier title, something either more appealing or appalling to go with the weird, sometimes wonderful visions flowing through it. Not that it’s all entirely strange. There’s the opening image, for starters — a close-up of Robin Wright’s face, a familiar, delicate facade that’s well enough known to ignite a chain of signification: beauty, actress, star, Sean Penn, “House of Cards,” “The Princess Bride,” middle age, under-sung, career rebirth.

headline: Relentless, With No Off Switch
abstract: Joan Rivers seemed as if she just couldn’t stop herself from telling jokes, driven by a desperation that was all her own.
lead_paragraph: Her delivery was like an automatic sprinkler: fast, relentless and sometimes prone to stick, soaking a comic riff into a muddy swamp.

headline: ‘Doctor Zhivago’ Musical Coming to Broadway
abstract: A musical adaptation of “Doctor Zhivago” is expected to begin performances at the Broadway Theater in the spring of 2015, with another new musical, “King Kong,” in discussions to move into that theater after the “Zhivago” run ends.
lead_paragraph: A musical adaptation of “Doctor Zhivago” is expected to begin performances at the Broadway Theater in the spring of 2015, with another new musical, “King Kong,” in discussions to move into that theater after the “Zhivago” run ends, according to three theater executives familiar with the plans. The Broadway, a prime house for musicals, is coming open with Wednesday’s announcement that “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” will close on Jan. 3.

headline: Opposition Grows in Europe to Google Antitrust Proposal
abstract: Microsoft and two trade groups for German publishers said the plan to reduce Google’s dominance of the search market was inadequate.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Microsoft and the German publishing industry on Thursday stepped up pressure on the European Union’s antitrust chief to make radical adjustments to a proposed antitrust settlement with Google, or effectively leave resolution of the case to his successor.

headline: For NATO Yes, For Kiev No
abstract: Why the West’s response to Putin should draw bright lines without courting reckless war.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few weeks, heavier Russian incursions into the Ukrainian east reversed Ukraine’s push to reclaim its separatist provinces, and over the last week the West has responded — with a French decision to (finally) suspend a promised warship sale to Russia; with news that the upcoming NATO conference will consider the creation of a new rapid reaction force for Eastern Europe; and with a forceful Obama speech this week in Tallinn, Estonia, that both condemned Russian aggression and strongly reaffirmed NATO’s official commitment to the defense of the Baltic states. And these Western steps may (or may not, who can say?) have influenced Moscow’s sudden enthusiasm for a cease-fire and peace talks … albeit, of course, on terms favorable to Vladimir Putin’s desire to keep Ukraine divided, Russian-influenced and weak.

headline: Getty Grants for Personal Photo Projects
keywords: ['Apartheid (Policy)', 'Arabs', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: This year’s winners have tackled themes from South Africa’s post-apartheid generation to the lives of Arab women.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — The Getty Images editorial grant winners were awarded today at Visa Pour l’Image festival.

headline: Senate Modeling
abstract: Wonk heaven.
lead_paragraph: The stakes in this year’s midterms aren’t as high as in some elections; Republicans are sure to retain control of at least one house, Obama will still be president, so gridlock continues. Still, some things will be at stake — for example, whether the Congressional Budget Office turns into an adjunct of the Heritage Foundation. And whatever happens, it will be held up as giving somebody or other a mandate for something or other. So it’s definitely interesting to watch.

headline: Stories Writ in Eyebrow Pencil
abstract: John Waters describes his 50-year retrospective at the Film Society of Lincoln Center as the first nonironic career tribute he has ever received.
lead_paragraph: JOHN WATERS has been thinking a lot about the half-century lately.

headline: Duckie Brown: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Jazz to End Summer in Rockaway Beach and Brooklyn
abstract: There’s late-summer music this weekend at the Rockaway Beach Jazz Festival and the Baby Grand Weekend in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: With relatively comfortable temperatures and the dynamic mix of activities that his brood has undertaken, the last several weeks made up one of the more fulfilling Augusts the Miser can remember. Is it so wrong, then, to want to eke out one last weekend in the warmth of the sun?

headline: Gareth Pugh on Nick Knight, Holiday Packages and the Enduring Appeal of ‘The Wicker Man’
abstract: The London-based designer, who presents for the first time in New York this season, on his influences.
lead_paragraph: Today, the London-based designer Gareth Pugh, who has received years of acclaim for his bold collections and sometimes outlandish runway shows, will present at New York Fashion Week for the first time. Except it’s not a fashion show per se, but rather what’s being touted as a “live, immersive fashion experience,” incorporating videos by Pugh’s longtime collaborator Ruth Hogben and choreography by Wayne MacGregor.

headline: Gay-Marriage Bans Fall in Wisconsin and Indiana
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The three-judge panel ruled the gay marriage bans violated the federal Constitution, thereby increasing the number of states where same-sex marriage will be legal to 21.
lead_paragraph: Only nine days after hearing arguments in the case, a federal appeals court in Chicago declared the bans on same-sex marriage in Indiana and Wisconsin to be unconstitutional on Thursday, adding to the list of marriage cases that could wind up before the Supreme Court in the year ahead.

headline: Time Out Dubai
abstract: Joseph O’Neill’s “The Dog” is about a lost and tormented New York lawyer working in Dubai for a family of Lebanese billionaires.
lead_paragraph: The number of serious literary novels that take for their setting the desert city of Dubai could be numbered on a hand’s digits, with the thumb, ring finger and pinkie unused. When the editors of Time Out Dubai enumerated their “Top 10 Books” about — and set in — Dubai, they came up with, among others, the following: “Carte Blanche,” a James Bond novel by Jeffery Deaver; Ben Mezrich’s “get-rich-quick story” “Rigged”; and Candace Havens’s “Charmed and Dangerous: Bronwyn the Witch No. 1.” Of that last, the venerable travel guide remarks: “This chick-friendly romance by U.S. resident Havens takes an adventurous turn when Bronwyn, a 25-year-old witch from Texas, accepts a job with the British prime minister and finds herself traveling to Dubai, where she meets a sheikh who insists she accept the use of his private jet.” You get the picture.

headline: The Big Sweep
abstract: Police officers and criminals are hard to tell apart in James Ellroy’s novel of 1940s Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Few writers, once established in the public consciousness, have changed their style as drastically as James Ellroy. In his early days, Ellroy wandered through the boneyards of 1980s pulp, channeling Jim Thompson and Dashiell Hammett before he found his own voice with a trilogy of contemporary novels about a troubled, racist genius cop named Lloyd Hopkins. Hopkins was morally despicable in the day-to-day, but compared with the monsters he fought in the neon-drench of underworld Los Angeles, he was quasi-­angelic. When Ellroy closed out the Hopkins trilogy with “Suicide Hill” in 1986, he shuttered his interest in topical culture as well and moved into the second incarnation of his career, that of the wildly romantic yet increasingly bilious chronicler of Los Angeles in the years immediately following World War II.

headline: SS-­Obersturmbannführer (Retired)
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In his years in Argentina, Adolf Eichmann remained a convinced Nazi, proud of his wartime achievements.
lead_paragraph: Ever since his capture in the early 1960s, Otto Adolf Eichmann, who was in charge of Jewish affairs during the Third Reich, has been the subject of unsettled and passionate controversy — centered, above all, on Hannah Arendt’s portrait of him at his 1961 trial. Her “Eichmann in Jerusalem” in many ways mirrored Eichmann’s own self-presentation. She insisted that, contrary to expectations, the man in the dock was not some kind of demonic Nazi sadist but a thoughtless, relatively anonymous, nonideological bureaucrat dutifully executing orders for the emigration, deportation and murder of European Jewry. Arendt’s insights — that genocide and bureaucratic banality are not necessarily opposed, that fanatical anti-Semitism (or for that matter, any ideological predisposition) is not a sufficient precondition for mass murder — remain pertinent.

headline: On the Border, a Fall From Grace
abstract: In “Frontera,” directed by Michael Berry, Ed Harris plays a retired sheriff in modern-day Arizona challenged by events at a border crossing.
lead_paragraph: The image of Ed Harris in a cowboy hat, astride a horse, in “Frontera” is as resonant a symbol of American stoicism as Gary Cooper, glowering and tight-lipped, in “High Noon.” In this first feature directed by Michael Berry, Mr. Harris, the square-jawed 63-year-old actor who portrayed John Glenn in “The Right Stuff,” plays Roy, a retired sheriff in southern Arizona. And when the camera gazes up at him, tall in the saddle, he exudes a righteous, buck-stops-here stubbornness.

headline: Refuge and Renewal on Lake George
abstract: In this corner of the Adirondacks, elements of modern life yield to more timeless pursuits.
lead_paragraph: It’s the fireflies, and the stars, that get me every time. Those winking lights, bobbing along the ground and filling up the night sky with their impossible density, signal an alternate reality to the artificially haloed urban evening I’m accustomed to in the San Francisco Bay Area. In this little corner of the Adirondack Mountains, other signals — cellphone, for one, or car headlights — are spotty, or altogether absent. Much of modern life is filtered out through the dense trees and mountains on the winding approach to Lake George. What remains — a place to run around in the woods — is time-tested and true.

headline: Art From a Sojourn or Two to India
abstract: “Francesco Clemente: Inspired by India” at the Rubin Museum of Art, his first retrospective in New York in more than a decade, ties the peripatetic Italian-born painter to a single country.
lead_paragraph: “Francesco Clemente: Inspired by India,” at the Rubin Museum of Art, ties the peripatetic Italian-born painter to a single country. The exhibition is also something of a comeback, the first Clemente retrospective in New York in more than a decade, although at just 20 works or so, it’s not exactly comprehensive.

headline: What Was Your Favorite Joan Rivers Joke?
abstract: The Times asked readers on Twitter to share their favorite Joan Rivers zingers and one-liners.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers was admired for her fashion sense, her perseverance and the longevity of her career. But she was best remembered for her jokes. For that reason, The Times asked readers on Twitter to share their favorite zingers and one-liners delivered by Ms. Rivers over the arc of her comedic career.

headline: A Singer of Soul Goes in Search of His Own
abstract: Tim Sutton’s “Memphis” follows a blocked songwriter (Willis Earl Beal) as he struggles to rediscover his muse.
lead_paragraph: “Everything is artifice,” declares Willis (Willis Earl Beal), the melancholy, creatively blocked singer, songwriter and restless dreamer at the heart of “Memphis,” a soulful cinematic tone poem written and directed by Tim Sutton. This luminescent second feature from Mr. Sutton was inspired partly by the legend of O. V. Wright, an African-American blues and gospel singer who had several R&B hits in the 1960s and early ’70s and died in 1980 at 41.

headline: How Rotherham Happened
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Observers uncover how a combination of “unwitting racism” and unapologetic misogyny facilitated the sexual abuse of 1,400 minors in a North English town.
lead_paragraph: To the American ear, the town of Rotherham, nestled in the West Riding of Yorkshire, sounds romantically British. And while a cursory Google Image search reveals the redbrick rowhouses, idyllic front gardens and august churches one expects in such a locale, a quick glance at recent coverage of the town divulges its sinister underside.

headline: Garmin Blends an Activity Tracker With a Smartwatch
abstract: Consumers suddenly have many wearable computing devices to choose from. The question is whether they will want any of them.
lead_paragraph: Is it an activity tracker or a smartwatch?

headline: Marin Cilic Reaches U.S. Open Semifinals; Bryan Brothers and Martina Hingis Close In on Doubles Titles
abstract: Marin Cilic reached his first Grand Slam semifinal in four years. Bob and Mike Bryan are in the men’s doubles final, and Martina Hingis advanced to the women’s doubles final with Flavia Pennetta.
lead_paragraph: More than four years have passed since Marin Cilic’s last Grand Slam semifinal appearance, an eternity in tennis years. The span included the peak of Cilic’s years as a Croatian prodigy, a player graced with size and skill, but he never seemed to live up to the promise.

headline: Early Voting in Ohio, Despite Republican Objections
abstract: A federal judge on Thursday said Ohio could not cut the voting period.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge’s decision this morning to allow early voting in Ohio is a big victory for those who think voting should be easier and more accessible. It was also a remarkable decision in purely human terms, showing a deeply compassionate understanding of the lives of the low-income people who have been the most harmed by Republican efforts to put barriers around the ballot box.

headline: ‘The Middle East Revealed: A Female Perspective’ and ‘Syria in 1940’
abstract: A show intends to criticize “Middle Eastern” and “Arab” stereotypes, but in some cases reinforces them.
lead_paragraph: The four-artist show called “The Middle East Revealed: A Female Perspective” is an apt addendum to the New Museum’s “Here and Elsewhere,” an exhibition of contemporary art from the Arab world. But this show deals in “Middle Eastern” and “Arab” stereotypes, intending to criticize them, but only, in some cases, reinforcing them.

headline: New York Is Named Best U.S. Bicycling City, Potholes and All
abstract: New York City earns Bicycling magazine’s top ranking, edging out cycling meccas like Portland and Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Despite its pothole-pocked pavement, oblivious pedestrians, vocal anti-bike contingent, traffic-weaving cab drivers and legions of delivery guys riding the wrong direction, New York has been chosen the best cycling city in the country by the editors of Bicycling magazine.

headline: Joan Rivers’s Death Under Investigation by New York State Health Department
abstract: The Health Department is looking into the circumstances surrounding the comedian’s experience at an outpatient surgery clinic in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Health Department is investigating the circumstances that led to the comedian Joan Rivers’s death on Thursday, one week after she lost consciousness at an outpatient surgery clinic on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, a spokeswoman for the agency said.

headline: F.D.A. Allows First Use of a Novel Cancer Drug
abstract: The treatment unleashes the body’s immune system against tumors, and will initially be used against advanced melanoma.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first of an eagerly awaited new class of cancer drugs that unleashes the body’s immune system to fight tumors.

headline: Rene Ricard: ‘Remember’
abstract: This show is a poignant reminder of the polymorphous talent and erudition of Rene Ricard, who died in February.
lead_paragraph: This bittersweet show is a poignant reminder of the polymorphous talent and erudition of the poet, painter, aesthete and man about town Rene Ricard, who died in February at the age of 67. It contains 13 works dated from 1978 to 2012. Most are thrift store paintings to which Ricard added excerpts from, or the titles of, his poems in cursive, using a paint-laden brush.

headline: Tech Giants Embrace the Smart Home, but Consumers Remain Skeptical
abstract: At a consumer electronics conference in Berlin, a number of companies are demonstrating technology meant to connect parts of the home to computers and the Internet. But do consumers want these devices?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Tech companies want to make your house smart.

headline: Georgia Hilmer Transforms Backstage at Creatures of the Wind
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Georgia Hilmer before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Bernard and hair by Anthony Turner.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Warm Up
abstract: Details magazine, Style.com, VFiles and Standard hotel get an early start on New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Details magazine, Style.com, VFiles and Standard hotel get an early start on New York Fashion Week.

headline: Amie Siegel: ‘Provenance’
abstract: Stylish aesthetics and fashionable conceptualism trump documentary realism in “Provenance,” an extremely suave film by Amie Siegel.
lead_paragraph: Stylish aesthetics and fashionable conceptualism trump documentary realism in “Provenance,” an extremely suave film by Amie Siegel. The 40-minute movie is an instance of institutional critique, an art genre that tries to expose and subvert the workings of the capitalist art market. Specifically, it’s about the trade in furniture produced for Chandigarh, the utopian city in northern India whose master plan was conceived by Le Corbusier and his team and built between 1951 and 1965.

headline: Peter Coffin: ‘Living’
abstract: Mr. Coffin uses them to recall utopian schemes from the ’60s and ’70s, from biospheres and eco-villages.
lead_paragraph: In the basement of Red Bull’s lavish studio facilities in Chelsea is the latest iteration of Peter Coffin’s best-known work: “Music for Plants,” a project started in 2002 in which a wall of plants, nestled under the sidewalk grating — the original version was actually a greenhouse — is accompanied by music specially commissioned from Pauline Oliveros, Yoko Ono, Alice Coltrane, Arto Lindsay, Laurie Anderson, Sonic Youth and other artists.

headline: Witnesses to the Collapse
abstract: Rory Kennedy’s documentary “Last Days in Vietnam” examines the fall of Saigon and the evacuation of Americans and Vietnamese.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most striking thing about “Last Days in Vietnam,” Rory Kennedy’s eye-opening documentary about the 1975 evacuation of the American Embassy in Saigon, is how calmly it surveys what was once among the angriest topics in American political life. The story is full of emotion and danger, heroism and treachery, but it is told in a mood of rueful retrospect rather than simmering partisan rage. Ms. Kennedy, whose uncle John F. Kennedy expanded American involvement in Vietnam and whose father, Robert F. Kennedy,  became one of the ensuing war’s most passionate critics, explores its final episode with an open mind and lively curiosity. There are old clips that have never been widely seen and pieces of information that may surprise many viewers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Germany, Indonesia and Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Germany, Indonesia and Brooklyn.

headline: Visionaries Inhabiting the Margins
abstract: The New York folk painter Ralph Fasanella and the Dutch outsider artist Willem van Genk have thrilling, complementary shows at the American Folk Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: It’s thrilling to start the season with an in-depth introduction to an outstanding artist you’ve barely heard of. That thrill is currently provided by the American Folk Art Museum and its concise, electrifying survey of Willem van Genk, a Dutch self-taught outsider who died in 2005 at 78. In addition, this show is brilliantly paired with one devoted to the formidable folk painter and well-known New Yorker, Ralph Fasanella (1914-97), that focuses on what might be called his history paintings. The fertile exchange between these ambitious, encompassing visions is one of the best things you’ll see this fall.

headline: Mortgage Problems When Buying Outside the Box
abstract: Homes deemed unusual may be desirable for some to own, but even borrowers with excellent credit may have trouble obtaining sufficient financing to purchase them.
lead_paragraph: Homes deemed unusual may be desirable for some to own, but even borrowers with excellent credit may have trouble obtaining sufficient financing to buy them.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: For Tavi Gevinson, Fashion Takes a Back Seat, for Now
abstract: Tavi Gevinson, the teenage fashion star turned Broadway actress, won’t be much of a player at New York Fashion Week this season.
lead_paragraph: Tavi Gevinson, the teenage fashion star turned Broadway actress, won’t be much of a player at New York Fashion Week this season.

headline: Unmasked, a Rapper Exults in Tradition
abstract: Your Old Droog’s debut concert at the Studio at Webster Hall testified to an enduring longing for a purist form of rap, the kind from before the mid-1990s.
lead_paragraph: In June, a rapper named Your Old Droog posted a self-titled EP on his Soundcloud page — no photos, no videos, just songs. The music was scratchy boom-bap hip-hop, in the vein of New York rap before the flash of the mid-1990s swallowed it whole. Your Old Droog rapped forcefully, in breathless complex rhyme, and with a sly, mildly scraped tone that to many, sounded a little too familiar.

headline: What the Monks Can Teach Us
abstract: “The Rule,” by Marylou and Jerome Bongiorno, is about St. Benedict’s Prep, an urban school run by the monks of Newark Abbey.
lead_paragraph: “The Rule,” a film about St. Benedict’s Preparatory School in Newark, opens with the implied promise that the methods used there can solve all of urban America’s educational problems. Though it has interesting elements, it doesn’t really deliver on that promise, leaving it feeling more like a promotional video than like a rigorous documentary.

headline: In Orlando, a Farm-to-Table Focus
abstract: Restaurants and a brewery at the Grande Lakes Orlando resort in Florida will emphasize homegrown ingredients.
lead_paragraph: The Grande Lakes Orlando resort, an enclave near Walt Disney World and Universal Orlando, is embracing the farm-to-table movement with new restaurants and a microbrewery.

headline: Making Wispy Summertime Music in Glasgow
abstract: Fresh out of a psychiatric clinic, a young woman in Glasgow teams up with a lifeguard and a rich girl to form a band in “God Help the Girl.”
lead_paragraph: If the music of the Scottish indie-pop group Belle and Sebastian sets your teeth on edge, then prepare for extreme dental discomfort after watching “God Help the Girl,” the directing debut of one of the band’s founders, Stuart Murdoch.

headline: A Lightning Rod in a Game With Bats
abstract: “No No: A Dockumentary” looks at the career of Dock Ellis, a pitcher with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
lead_paragraph: The Dock of “No No: A Dockumentary” is Dock Ellis, the Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher who famously claimed he had thrown his 1970 no-hitter against the San Diego Padres while on LSD. In recounting Ellis’s career, the director, Jeffrey Radice, deftly crosscuts interviews with Ellis, who died in 2008, with those of teammates, friends and former wives, to depict an occasionally volatile athlete who was more thoughtful than many assumed and who became a dedicated addiction counselor.

headline: Puss Battles Sourpuss Over Old Magician’s Fate
abstract: In “Thunder and the House of Magic,” an abandoned cat lands in the eccentric home of an elderly magician, whose greedy nephew wants to sell it.
lead_paragraph: THUNDER AND THE HOUSE OF MAGIC

headline: The Jill Soloway Starter Kit
abstract: Jill Soloway has been exploring themes like community, gender and relationships since the dawn of the ’90s, or long before her latest show, “Transparent,” ever came along. Here’s a sparse sampling of that work.
lead_paragraph: While working on my profile of Jill Soloway in the Aug. 31 magazine, I learned that a true picture of who she is — someone who gathers people, someone who constantly questions cultural norms — can be seen by looking at a history of her work. Soloway has been exploring themes like community, gender and relationships since the early 1990s. Here’s a sparse sampling of her work:

headline: At This School, ‘B’ Is for Blood
abstract: In “Innocence,” the new girl at school encounters a bloodsucking culture.
lead_paragraph: INNOCENCE

headline: Liquidity for Banks, This Time Defined
abstract: The rules the Federal Reserve approved this week are intended to ensure that banks have enough ready liquidity to survive a crisis of 30 days, which proved not to be the case in the 2008 crisis.
lead_paragraph: “The total capital ratio is well in excess of the 10 percent regulatory threshold.”

headline: History Loves Company
abstract: Ken Follett’s epic three-volume sweep through 20th-century history ends with “Edge of Eternity,” which spans three decades and at least five nations.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Aug. 8, 1974, many Americans gathered before their television sets to watch Richard M. Nixon announce his intention to resign as president of the United States. That moment is part of “Edge of Eternity,” the last and fattest installment in Ken Follett’s 20th-century trilogy. And for him, the political is always very personal. So a man and a woman sit watching Nixon’s fall. They have been platonic friends for years. They cheer, and then they start kissing, and wind up having fantastic sex. (Duration: half a page out of 1,098.) This is Mr. Follett’s favorite way to keep history interesting.

headline: For a ‘Don Giovanni’ Fan, a Hedonism Driven by Fear
abstract: In “Naked Opera,” a man of mysterious means spends his cash on performances of “Don Giovanni” across Europe and on a steady succession of what appear to be male escorts.
lead_paragraph: Over 10 years ago, in the documentary “Cinemania,” Angela Christlieb and Stephen Kijak profiled a few obsessive New York moviegoers, cranky and snobbish devotees of the city’s bountiful repertory cinemas. With “Naked Opera,” Ms. Christlieb gives us another eccentric fanatic in Marc Rollinger, a man of mysterious means from Luxembourg who spends his cash on “Don Giovanni” performances across Europe and on a succession of what seem to be male escorts.

headline: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s ‘Disservice to Democracy’
abstract: By not appearing with his challengers in a debate, Mr. Cuomo deprives voters of a vigorous discussion of state issues.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, who has a huge war chest, is presumed to be far ahead in Tuesday’s Democratic primary race. That assumption, however, should not allow him to shrink from a debate with Zephyr Teachout, his gutsy opponent. Ms. Teachout, a Fordham University law professor, has already appeared alone on NY1 on Tuesday after Mr. Cuomo refused to participate in a debate. At Democratic clubs and other forums, the governor has avoided taking on his opponents, and, on Thursday, Ms. Teachout debated Rob Astorino, the Republican nominee, on WNYC — also minus the governor.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Wayside Motor Inn’
abstract: Kelly AuCoin and Quincy Dunn-Baker in a scene from the A.R. Gurney play, at the Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: Kelly AuCoin and Quincy Dunn-Baker in a scene from the A.R. Gurney play, at the Signature Center.

headline: Down to Rio With a Haunted Avenger
abstract: A traumatized ex-Marine descends into the favelas of Rio de Janeiro to investigate the brutal beating of his sister.
lead_paragraph: FALCON RISING

headline: Off the Runway: Day 1
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Photos from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Hitchhiker on an Electronic Road
abstract: “Nam June Paik: Becoming Robot” a large exhibition at Asia Society Museum, explores the artist’s use of technology.
lead_paragraph: If you want someone to praise or blame for the relentlessly wired, chatty, information-soaked 21st-century world we inhabit, the artist Nam June Paik is an apt candidate. Credited as the founder of video art in the 1960s, he turned television into an interactive vehicle for radical theater. He invented the phrase “electronic superhighway” and imagined beta versions of smartphones, Google Glass, distant learning, YouTube, Instagram and the Internet itself.

headline: Letting the Brain Out to Play
abstract: The Brooklyn Brain Jam unites heady delights for a festival of educational entertainment.
lead_paragraph: PIZZA, terminators and weird Turkish cinema will jostle for position on Sunday in the “first annual” Brooklyn Brain Jam, a festival of fascinating but generally useless information at the Bell House in Gowanus. The event brings together four of New York’s leading purveyors of out-there entertainment — Nerd Nite, the Story Collider, the Big Quiz Thing and Kevin Geeks Out — in a mixed rotation that suggests live-show channel surfing.

headline: An Elvis Impersonator Who’s the Real Deal
abstract: “The Identical” portrays a man who is unaware that he was separated from his twin as a baby and makes a career of imitating his famous brother’s act.
lead_paragraph: The son of a preacher man has a secret past in “The Identical,” a jukebox musical that takes time revealing its goofy absurdity.

headline: Young Love, in the Shadow of 9/11
abstract: “But Always,” directed by Snow Zou, follows two friends and later lovers from childhood in Beijing to New York.
lead_paragraph: BUT ALWAYS

headline: Investment in Latin America Falls 10% in First Half
abstract: Investments totaled $2.6 billion, according to a survey largely dependent on self-reporting by investors.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Private equity and venture capital investments in Latin America dropped by 10 percent in the first half of this year compared with figures in the period a year earlier, the Latin American Private Equity and Venture Capital Association said on Thursday.

headline: Destination: Atlanta
abstract: William T. Sherman’s 1864 campaign to take the Georgia city was one of the bloodiest of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: One hot August day in 1864, Cpl. Joseph W. Ely of the 19th Michigan sat down in his camp in northern Georgia to write his sister Adelia. Ely’s regiment had been engaged in almost constant marching and fighting since the Atlanta Campaign began three months earlier. Now the men were on the outskirts of Atlanta, hunkered down in trenches under deadly rifle and artillery fire.

headline: You Don’t Like That Routine? Just Wait Five Minutes
abstract: The DanceNow festival continues through Saturday at Joe’s Pub, showcasing 10 performances of less than five minutes each per night.
lead_paragraph: The DanceNow festival confronts one challenge — that of performing dance on the tiny stage at Joe’s Pub — by adding another: No work may exceed five minutes. This makes for a speedy show, even though 10 different acts share each of the four evenings. Adding to that forward-driving energy is a contest. Each night, the audience chooses a winner, who receives a creative residency in Bucks County, Pa. On Sept. 13, the top 10 return for an encore presentation. A check, a residency and support for a fully produced show go at the end to one contestant chosen by the organizers.

headline: Inside the Players Lounge at the U.S. Open
abstract: Photographs by Mark Peterson of tennis players at rest — or as close as they can get to rest during the tournament.
lead_paragraph: In a lounge on the second level of Arthur Ashe Stadium, players competing in the United States Open can play foosball, watch television and relax with their coaches and family members. The photographer Mark Peterson, who most recently shot Rand Paul for the magazine, visited the lounge during the tournament’s first week.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Creatures of the Wind Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Tome: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Garth Brooks Embraces Digital Music and Unveils Online Store
abstract: GhostTunes, which offers Mr. Brooks’s complete catalog of music for $30, also carries songs from other artists, including Brad Paisley and Maroon 5.
lead_paragraph: Garth Brooks has finally gone digital, with an iTunes rival of his own.

headline: 8 Portland, Ore., Meals for $8 or Under
abstract: From a sandwich that’s “just automatically delicious” to an item that “boggles the mind,” here’s a menu for frugal eats in the Northwest city.
lead_paragraph: Portland, Ore. — bike-friendly and, to this New Yorker, shockingly affordable — might also be the most delicious small city in America. So, finding myself there with about 30 hours to spare at the end of a West Coast trip earlier this week, I didn’t have to think too hard about a plan: rent a bike and look for a few cheap meals around the city.

headline: Block That Scam
abstract: Advice on how to help someone who may be a victim of a swindle; dealing with wrong-way bikers; letting a younger sister wear what she wants.
lead_paragraph: My godfather is nearing 80. He retired comfortably but is not rich. Over dinner, he mentioned some projects that made my husband and me fear that he is being taken advantage of: He sent $15,000 to a foreign country to help an aid group build a farm; he sold his home to an overseas buyer, but first he redecorated it to suit the purchaser’s taste. He is independent and seems sharp, but these stories set off alarm bells. Should we share our concerns?

headline: At Coach, Side-Swept, ’70s-Style Mock Bangs
abstract: The look complemented the retro teenage-Americana theme of the collection.
lead_paragraph: At Coach’s spring/summer 2015 show today, the models’ side-parted hair was combed over to create curtainlike, ’70s-inspired faux bangs. The look complemented the retro teenage-Americana theme of the collection — pastel miniskirts, fluffy snorkel jackets, metallic clogs — as did the makeup, a slight wash of sparkling eye shadow and barely pink mouths that looked as if they’d been glazed with strawberry Lip Smackers.

headline: Chianti Classico’s Emotional Tug
abstract: Long before most Americans knew anything about Italian wine or food, there was Chianti.
lead_paragraph: Wine School, a monthly column, invites you to drink wine with Eric Asimov. September’s wine was Chianti Classico; Mr. Asimov shares his reaction to the wine and addresses readers’ thoughts and questions below the assignment.

headline: Appeals Court Says Men Alleging Sex Abuse Waited Too Long to Sue Yeshiva University
abstract: The three-judge panel declined to reinstate a lawsuit filed by 34 victims who said they were abused in high school by rabbis from the 1970s to the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court panel ruled on Thursday that dozens of men who say Yeshiva University covered up their sexual abuse at the hands of rabbis cannot sue for damages because too many years had elapsed since the abuse took place.

headline: Holding Onto That Summer Glow at Creatures of the Wind
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: As an alternative to bronzer, a new golden beige lipstick mimicked the natural flush of the model’s cheeks.
lead_paragraph: The start of New York Fashion Week might mark the unofficial beginning of fall, but backstage at Creatures of the Wind this morning, the designers Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters were still in summer mode. Dressed in t-shirts and looking laid-back as usual, the pair talked about exploring distant horizons with their prints and patterns, and the casual appeal of their debut shoe collection (“they’re really meant to be an extension of a summer shoe,” Gabier said, glancing at the sporty slip-ons at his feet). The models’ hair and makeup evoked the same breezy vibe. “Everything is relaxed and easy, with a certain softness to it,” Peters said. During casting earlier this week, on a day marked with humidity and thunderclouds, the makeup artist James Boehmer noted the natural flush evident on everyone’s skin. So instead of using bronzer on the cheeks, he dabbed on the new Nars Lipstick in Ligueria (out this spring) to recreate that moment. “This gives you that overheated effect,” he explained, tapping in the golden beige pigments. Outside the show, where the temperature was in the low 80s, the same tawny glow was easy to spot.

headline: You Asked About Football; Our Reporters Answered
abstract: Times reporters respond to a sampling of readers’ questions about the coming season.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.'s regular season began Thursday night, when the Seattle Seahawks, the defending Super Bowl champions, defeated the Green Bay Packers, 36-16. On Sunday, Rex Ryan’s Jets will play host to the Oakland Raiders, and on Monday night, Eli Manning and the Giants will take on the Lions in Detroit.

keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Insurance', 'Life Insurance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | A federal panel is proposing to assign MetLife to a club it does not want to join, by initially voting on Thursday to deem it a “systemically important financial institution” and thus subjecting it to more intensive regulation than most other life insurers.

headline: ‘Pretesting’ and Other New Ideas to Help Kids Learn
abstract: New research in learning offers new techniques for students: Play teacher. Take a break. Walk around. Get some sleep.
lead_paragraph: Pretesting has become one of the hottest areas of learning science. As Benedict Carey describes in “Why Flunking Exams Is Actually a Good Thing,” the idea is pretty straightforward in classrooms: Give students an exam that includes the material that will be tested on the final, but doesn’t replicate that exam. The (bombed) first-day test tunes students’ brains to receive the material to come — and they tend to do better in class.

headline: Why Do Doctors Commit Suicide?
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Medicine and Health', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: A culture of stoicism puts fledgling physicians at risk.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — TWO weeks ago, two medical residents, in their second month of residency training in different programs, jumped to their deaths in separate incidents in New York City. I did not know them, and cannot presume to speak for them or their circumstances. But I imagine that they had celebrated their medical school graduation this spring just as my friends and I did. I imagine they began their residencies with the same enthusiasm for healing as we did. And I imagine that they experienced fatigue, emotional exhaustion and crippling self-doubt at the beginning of those residencies — I know I did.

headline: Roosevelts to the Rescue
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: As president, you get only a few real moments of testing, but the right judgment can make a difference in history.
lead_paragraph: The Obama presidency is mired in mediocrity, his and ours. Foreign policy is cribbed and cautious, moving along with a deliberative pace our do-it-now society doesn’t tolerate. At home, Obama’s greatest achievements — health care for millions, and raising an economy from the dead while Europe couldn’t get out of the grave — are almost unknown.

lead_paragraph: For more than a decade Joan Rivers was known in the fashion world for her caustic one-line fashion critiques. “She looked like a decorative toilet seat cover,” Ms. Rivers said of the actress Tina Fey at the 2010 Golden Globe awards.

abstract: Many people were fearful that the army could not repel an attack on Maiduguri by the Islamist militants, who have taken over other cities in the region.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Amid fears that Islamist militants were closing in on the major city in Nigeria’s northeast, hundreds of residents were said to be fleeing Maiduguri on Thursday in the face of doubts that the army could repel an attack on the metropolis of more than one million people.
