lead_paragraph: For three days, the former chief of the Israeli military’s Palestinian Affairs Department delivered important, if a bit dry, testimony in the terrorism financing trial of Arab Bank in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Reclaiming  ‘We the People,’ One Person at a Time
abstract: A methodology that aims to ease partisan divide through personal connections could have advantages both in politics and personal life.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, I had the opportunity to participate in a retreat led by the renowned author and activist Parker J. Palmer. The retreat was based on a methodology called a Circle of Trust, drawn from Palmer’s writings, intended to help people step back from the noise of modern life, reflect, and return more centered and effective in their vocations. I was amazed at how, in just two days, this process brought 40 individuals together into respectful and strikingly honest discourse. It helped participants connect to their core values and sparked many new relationships.

lead_paragraph: Readings Around Town (through next Friday) A wide range of authors will be in the spotlight next week, starting on Monday at the Strand Book Store, where crime and suspense are the focus of a reading with Megan Abbott, whose latest novel is “The Fever,” and Chelsea Cain, who recently released “One Kick.” At 7 p.m., 828 Broadway, at 12th Street, East Village; purchase of either book is required for admission. Also on Monday, at 7 p.m., Donald Antrim, a MacArthur fellow, will read from his new collection of stories, “The Emerald Light in the Air,” at McNally Jackson, 52 Prince Street, between Lafayette and Mulberry Streets, SoHo; free.

headline: As Prekindergarten Expands in New York City, Guiding Guided Play
abstract: The overarching theory is that children will acquire knowledge and social skills through interactive guided play.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, more than 50,000 public school children in New York embarked on their formal education as the city officially began its expanded prekindergarten program, the marquee undertaking of Bill de Blasio’s mayoralty. The days leading up to the start of the school year were as frantic as anyone might have predicted — staffing and supplying the program have been compressed into just a few months. Facing safety concerns and other issues, several centers were unable to open; others faced delays.

headline: On Schedule, Pools’ Workers Drain the Last Drops of Summer
abstract: Within 40 hours after the last swimmers left the pool decks on Labor Day, workers had drained more than 15 million gallons of water from 55 pools across New York’s five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: The last inches of water glistened tantalizingly in the twilight at the Van Cortlandt Park pool, where the air was warm and heavy on Tuesday evening. A bandage floated in one lap lane. An abandoned swim shirt billowed in another. A few fallen leaves, harbingers of autumn, drifted listlessly.

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computer Security']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hackers breached security at the website of the government’s health insurance marketplace, HealthCare.gov, but did not steal any personal information on consumers, Obama administration officials said Thursday.

headline: A Soccer Team Struggles to Remake Its Identity
abstract: Major League Soccer is running Chivas U.S.A. as it undergoes a rebranding and seeks a new owner and a stadium of its own.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — It was 20 minutes before kickoff, and the Commander stood ready. Richard Escuita, a retired Army sergeant who introduces himself by his nom de guerre, was dressed in black commando boots, military supply pants, black gloves, a black beret and a black Chivas de Guadalajara jersey.

headline: Requiem for a Pomeranian
abstract: Lucy Morganstern, a violinist with the American Ballet Theater orchestra and the American Symphony Orchestra, has a side practice conducting memorial ceremonies for deceased pets.
lead_paragraph: “This is a chance for you to commune with Logan,” said Lucy Morganstern before tucking her violin under her chin and launching into an improvised minor-key dirge that at times seemed to evoke a puppy’s plaintive cry.

headline: A Lost Way, a Lost Year for the Red Sox
abstract: Boston, among the worst teams in the major leagues this season, has lost several key contributors from last season’s championship team and has started over.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox made their final Bronx statement of 2014 on Thursday with a collapse that fit their season. Koji Uehara served up homers to Mark Teixeira and Chase Headley in the bottom of the ninth that lifted the Yankees to a 5-4 victory.

headline: The Body and the Spirit
abstract: Trying to understand the strong visceral responses to the executions of the American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff.
lead_paragraph: Like everyone, I was revolted by the beheadings of the American journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff. It wasn’t just that they had been killed — though that is horrendous enough — it was the monstrous way the deed was done.

headline: Bloomberg Returns to an Organization Looking for a Vision
abstract: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s next job is to unify a sprawling company that has grown exponentially in his absence and pilot it in a turbulent media environment.
lead_paragraph: IN late 2007, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rolled his chair over to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff’s desk inside the bullpen at City Hall and suggested that they go to a nearby table to talk. The mayor knew that Mr. Doctoroff was six weeks away from leaving city government to return to Wall Street. But he had another idea.

headline: Fed Says Growth Lifts the Affluent, Leaving Behind Everyone Else
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Economic growth since the Great Recession has improved the fortunes of the most affluent Americans as the income of most American families continues to decline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Economic growth since the Great Recession has improved the fortunes of the most affluent Americans even as the incomes and wealth of most American families continue to decline, the Federal Reserve said Thursday.

headline: The Deflation Caucus
abstract: What is it that makes a powerful faction in our body politic demand tight money even in a depressed, low-inflation economy?
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the European Central Bank announced a series of new steps it was taking in an effort to boost Europe’s economy. There was a whiff of desperation about the announcement, which was reassuring. Europe, which is doing worse than it did in the 1930s, is clearly in the grip of a deflationary vortex, and it’s good to know that the central bank understands that. But its epiphany may have come too late. It’s far from clear that the measures now on the table will be strong enough to reverse the downward spiral.

headline: For Coed U.S. Open Event, Reaction Seems to Be Mixed, Too
abstract: Mixed doubles matches, which feature few recognizable names, rarely draw large crowds and are played only at Grand Slam and Olympic tournaments.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, before the women’s singles semifinals at Arthur Ashe Stadium, two Grand Slam champions will be crowned at the United States Open. But most fans will have no idea who they are.

headline: Classic Cherry Hills Course Gives Nothing Away
abstract: Rory McIlroy, Gary Woodland and Jordan Spieth are tied for the lead at the BMW Championship in a first round that was not completed Thursday.
lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — Rory McIlroy was lining up his second shot, a putt from off the green, on the par-4 second hole at Cherry Hills Country Club on Thursday when a duck emerged from the lake to the left of the green, flapped its wings and, between pecks at the grass, craned its neck in McIlroy’s direction, as if angling for a better look.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 4, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Hong Kong’s Democrats Clamor for Spot on Crowded U.S. Agenda
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The United States is sending Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, to China this weekend, to meet with Chinese leaders, where she will discuss Hong Kong, the near collision of a Navy surveillance plane and a Chinese jet and nuclear talks with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pro-democracy advocates in Hong Kong are girding for what some predict will be a tense final showdown with the Chinese government over whether Beijing will permit genuine democracy to take root in the former British colony.

headline: For Immigration Lawyers, a Surprise Speaker Who Asks Them to Change Lives
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor of the Supreme Court, a Bronx native, was a surprise speaker on Thursday at the inaugural class of the Immigrant Justice Corps.
lead_paragraph: The fresh-faced lawyers included refugees from violence and persecution in Central America, as well as the grandchildren of refugees from Eastern Europe. They arrived at the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan, on Thursday in similar shades of gray and black suits, poised to continue their training in a new program to help represent immigrants.

headline: Town Becomes a Beer Ad, but Residents Don’t Feel Like a Party
abstract: Anheuser-Busch will fly 1,000 young adults to a Colorado ski town for a weekend of spring-break-style revelry, a stunt designed to publicize Bud Light.
lead_paragraph: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo. — Workers have been busy in this bucolic, out-of-the-way ski town: The streets have been painted blue, as have the light poles. Blue props and fencing have been hauled in, rendering the place almost unrecognizable. And as final preparations take place for a three-day party, many residents are fuming, cursing the town for approving a clandestine deal to let a giant beer company turn it into a living advertisement in exchange for $500,000.

headline: In Afghanistan, Time for Compromise
abstract: The failure to reach a power-sharing deal by the two candidates vying for president could have catastrophic consequences.
lead_paragraph: Having spent several weeks auditing ballots in Afghanistan’s fraud-plagued presidential vote, election officials there are expected to declare a winner within days. If the two candidates vying for the post fail to reach a power-sharing deal beforehand, the announcement could easily kick off a wave of unrest that would all but guarantee a catastrophic wind-down to America’s longest war.

headline: A Blunt Defense of Marriage Equality
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Editorials', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: A federal appellate court offered important reasoning behind its decision to strike down same-sex marriage bans in Wisconsin and Indiana.
lead_paragraph: As important as the federal appeals court ruling was on Thursday declaring same-sex marriage bans in two states to be unconstitutional, the clarity and blunt reasoning behind the decision was equally momentous.

headline: Encouraging End-of-Life Talks
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Doctors', 'Editorials', 'Elderly', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Advance planning for care at the end of life may finally be about to overcome politics, as insurers begin to pay for the discussions.
lead_paragraph: There is reason to hope that a degree of sanity may be returning to the touchy issue of advance planning for medical care at the end of life. Just five years ago, Republican politicians, Sarah Palin prominent among them, were falsely charging that President Obama’s health care reforms would create “death panels” that could cut off care for the critically ill to save money on health care costs.

headline: Blurring Line Between Snack and Meal, Mac and Cheese to Graze On
abstract: Stouffer’s is trying to lure shoppers from the snack aisle with Mac Cups, a version of its popular macaroni and cheese in containers that are about the size of a single-serve yogurt.
lead_paragraph: SITTING down to three square meals daily is going the way of the landline, as consumers increasingly graze throughout the day and eat what had once been standard between-meal fare like yogurt and granola bars as meals. Americans eat only snacks, including produce like fruit and cut vegetables, at mealtimes 40 percent of the time, and that is expected to increase over the next five years, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm.

headline: Sunday Talk Show Guests
abstract: Since 2008, more than 1,500 people have appeared on five Sunday news and political talk shows: “Meet the Press,” “Face the Nation,” “This Week,” “Fox News Sunday” and “State of the Union.” Many are familiar faces in Washington, where lawmakers, consultants and pundits routinely sound off on the week's news, while others come from the worlds of entertainment and sports. Researchers at American University have collected more than 9,000 appearances. Below is a listing of those guests, excluding network employees or contracted regular guests.
lead_paragraph: Since 2008, more than 1,500 people have appeared on five Sunday news and political talk shows: “Meet the Press,” “Face the Nation,” “This Week,” “Fox News Sunday” and “State of the Union.” Many are familiar faces in Washington, where lawmakers, consultants and pundits routinely sound off on the week's news, while others come from the worlds of entertainment and sports. Researchers at American University have collected more than 9,000 appearances. Below is a listing of those guests, excluding network employees or contracted regular guests.

headline: High Whimsy and Low Expectations at the Meat Market
abstract: “Red Eye of Love,” like “The Fantasticks,” is about a boy, a girl, crushable ideals, minimal scenery and tinkling piano music.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you have sometimes wondered, when you’ve run out of worthier things to think about, what that airiest of musicals, “The Fantasticks,” might be like if it developed a social conscience.

headline: Back in the Kitchen, They Have Lives, Too
abstract: The play “My Mañana Comes” follows the stresses of four busboys at an Upper East Side restaurant.
lead_paragraph: In the back of a ritzy Upper East Side restaurant, busboys in black jackets fill breadbaskets, garnish plates, roll napkins and silverware into tidy cylinders. Their gestures are precise, their actions rote. It’s a slog. It’s a dance. It’s a living.

headline: Strangers in the Night, No Glances
abstract: A. R. Gurney’s “The Wayside Motor Inn,” being revived by the Signature Theater Company, presents five short dramas spliced together.
lead_paragraph: The lives of people in transit intersect without actually touching in “The Wayside Motor Inn,” a minor-key but cleverly constructed play by the veteran A. R. Gurney, being revived by the Signature Theater Company. From our point of view, the characters seem to share the same space, a tidy but soul-crushingly generic room in a motel on the outskirts of Boston. But we soon gather that each of the play’s five pairs of characters occupy different rooms. Their stories — of broken marriages, sexual ambivalence, late-life malaise, father-son conflict — are merely superimposed upon one another so that they seem to be taking place simultaneously.

headline: Eugenia Washington to George Washington
abstract: The return of Joe Krozel, who apparently enjoys standing on his head.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — If you have ever seen an ambigram, which is a word or phrase that reads the same way in different orientations, you’ll understand what Joe Krozel has done here. Except that he’s taken it in a totally different direction and done it with Morse code.

headline: Why Don’t Americans Take Vacation?
abstract: Are they pressured to leave time off unused, or do they enjoy work more than play?

headline: On Ukraine, the West Sidesteps a Fraught Term
abstract: After four months of fighting in eastern Ukraine, few countries have chosen the word “invasion” to describe the slow-burning war.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Whether on the streets of Budapest in 1956, the mountains of Afghanistan in 1979 and again in 2001 or in the swampy forests of Grenada in 1983, invasions have tended to be noisy, unmistakable affairs that screamed their purpose from the start.

headline: Study of Jewish Women Shows Link to Cancer Without Family History
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Research', 'Tests (Medical)']

lead_paragraph: Women of Ashkenazi Jewish descent who tested positive for cancer-causing genetic mutations during random screenings have high rates of breast and ovarian cancer even when they have no family history of the disease, researchers reported Thursday.

headline: With Hopes Going, Going, Yankees’ 9th-Inning Blasts Are Gone, Gone
abstract: Mark Teixeira and Chase Headley homered in the ninth inning to lead the Yankees’ comeback win over the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz stopped for a second and watched, holding his pose, his bat in his right hand, as the ball he had just clobbered sailed into the night sky. The Yankee Stadium crowd gasped and then let out a hushed murmur as Ortiz rounded the bases, patted his chest and, at home plate, pointed to the sky. For a moment, it felt like October.

headline: British Premier Offers to Expand Assistance to Kurdish Forces in Iraq
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain offered on Thursday to arm Kurdish forces fighting Islamist militants and refused to rule out British airstrikes in Iraq and possibly Syria.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain offered on Thursday to arm Kurdish forces fighting Islamist militants and refused to rule out British airstrikes in Iraq and possibly Syria. Britain has delivered nonlethal supplies to Kurdish fighters, who are on the front line of the battle against the militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and it has helped to transport ammunition provided by others. Mr. Cameron’s comments suggest that Britain could begin to supply ammunition directly to Kurdish forces. In a BBC interview, Mr. Cameron refused to rule out airstrikes but said they would not take place in Iraq before the formation of a new government in Baghdad. He also suggested that there might not be any legal impediment to attacking militants in Syria without the agreement of Syria’s government because it had committed “war crimes” against its own people and was therefore “illegitimate.”

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) SAVING MR. BANKS (2013) Tom Hanks stars as Walt Disney in this Disney movie about the making of a Disney movie: specifically “Mary Poppins,” which, at the time of its creation in the early ’60s, was the most expensive live-action film the studio had produced. Eventually it became one of the most beloved, too, and one of the biggest moneymakers. Emma Thompson (above, with Mr. Hanks) is the author P. L. Travers, who conjured the magical nanny, and is something of a crank. “I won’t have her turned into one of your silly cartoons,” she says of her creation, stiffly, lips pursed. There’s a back story too, in which Travers is a little girl (Annie Rose Buckley) in a dusty town in Australia, where her hopelessly alcoholic father (Colin Farrell) can barely hold on to his bank job. “Fans of the book and the earlier movie will know that Mr. Banks is the father of the children cared for by Mary Poppins, but even those entirely innocent of her previous literary and cinematic incarnations — if such people exist — will find this movie accessible and enjoyable,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this movie directed by John Lee Hancock. “That is part of the Disney brand, of course: fun for everyone, with a spoonful of therapeutic medicine to help the sugar seem nutritious.”

headline: Weighing In on Paid Interethnic Marriages in Xinjiang
keywords: ['Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Marriages', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: In an effort to defuse ethnic tensions, a county in a Western region of China is trying to encourage marriage between Uighurs and Han by offering cash and other incentives. Two experts put the efforts into context.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times reported on officials in a county in the western region of Xinjiang offering cash and other incentives to encourage more interethnic marriages, with the goal of defusing ethnic tensions. Many Chinese officials are concerned about increasingly violent conflicts between Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking, mostly Muslim people who populate large parts of Xinjiang, and the Han, the dominant ethnicity in China. At a two-day work forum on Xinjiang in May, President Xi Jinping called for new policies to better assimilate Uighurs into mainstream Chinese society.

headline: So Bill Gates Has This Idea for a History Class ...
abstract: Should one of the world’s richest men get to dictate the future of how we learn about our past?
lead_paragraph: In 2008, shortly after Bill Gates stepped down from his executive role at Microsoft, he often awoke in his 66,000-square-foot home on the eastern bank of Lake Washington and walked downstairs to his private gym in a baggy T-shirt, shorts, sneakers and black socks yanked up to the midcalf. Then, during an hour on the treadmill, Gates, a self-described nerd, would pass the time by watching DVDs from the Teaching Company’s “Great Courses” series. On some mornings, he would learn about geology or meteorology; on others, it would be oceanography or U.S. history.

headline: Why #RussiaInvadedUkraine Matters
abstract: Linguistic clarity is essential for moral clarity. Retweet that.

abstract: Consumer prices in Germany rose less than 1 percent in the last year, the most in the four largest countries in the eurozone.
lead_paragraph: EUROPE has an inflation problem. Prices are not rising fast enough.

headline: Morning Agenda: Europe’s Bond-Buying Bet
abstract: The European Central Bank will start buying loan-backed bonds. | MetLife plans to fight stricter regulation. | Puerto Rico’s electric power authority has hired a restructuring supervisor. | Defining liquidity for banks.
lead_paragraph: E.C.B. GAMBLES ON BOND-BUYING PROGRAM | Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday that the bank would soon start to buy bonds that are backed by loans made to consumers and companies, DealBook’s Peter Eavis and Alexandra Stevenson write. With the move, the central bank is gambling on a complex securities market that for several years has been struggling to get back on its feet. The purchases could make up a substantial share of the roughly 1 trillion euros, or $1.3 trillion, that Mr. Draghi implied that the bank was prepared to spend.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Job Growth Is Sluggish, Raising Fear of Malaise
abstract: With only 142,000 jobs added, August was the first month since January in which the economy failed to add at least 200,000 jobs. Unemployment fell slightly to 6.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Missing: nearly three million American workers.

headline: The Pedicab Was the Last Straw
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: On a day of accidents, presidential motorcades and resulting traffic jams, a visitor tried to avoid the mess in a human-propelled vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Whale of a Recovery for California’s Blue Whales
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Whales and Whaling']
abstract: Blue whale populations off the West Coast appear to be approaching pre-slaughter abundance.
lead_paragraph: The blue whale, the biggest animal on the planet, was hunted with abandon in the Pacific Ocean until the early 1970s. The species has been rebounding ever since, but a slowdown in the growth of the population frequenting waters off the California coast was a concern. Now it turns out to be a promising sign of recovery.

headline: Alibaba Said to Pick New York as Kickoff for Roadshow
abstract: The company plans to begin its roadshow on Monday, according to people briefed on the matter, kicking off a 100 meetings in roughly 10 days.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group may be one of China’s Internet giants, but the e-commerce behemoth is planning to start investor presentations for its long-awaited initial public offering in New York.

headline: Taking a Naked Selfie? Your Phone Should Step In to Protect You
abstract: Our phones don’t do nearly enough to protect our most sensitive documents: indelicate photos of ourselves.
lead_paragraph: What should smartphone makers do about nude selfies? Should they encourage us all to point our phones away from our unclothed bodies — or should they instead decide that naked selfies are inevitable, and add features to their products that reduce the chance that these photos could get hacked?

headline: There’s More to Estate Planning Than Just the Will
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Trusted friends and family members need to know how to get access to bank and online accounts, and even your home after you die.
lead_paragraph: WILLS, health care directives, lists of passwords to online accounts. By now, most people know they should prepare these items — even if they haven’t yet — and make them available to trusted family members before the unthinkable, yet inevitable, happens.

headline: Documents to Share
abstract: Some documents that advisers suggest family members make available to each other.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the documents that advisers suggest family members make available to each other.

headline: Obamacare Life Spiral
abstract: Success feeds on itself.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein directs us to the latest from the Kaiser Family Foundation, which asks what the average Obamacare 2015 premium increase will be for those places for which we have full information — and finds that premiums will actually decline slightly. Ezra tries to get us to appreciate just how good the Obamacare news has been with a thought experiment:

headline: Family Dollar Rejects Revised Bid by Dollar General
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Family Dollar said on Friday that it had formally rejected a revised $9.1 billion offer from its larger rival, arguing that new measures meant to provide assurances about antitrust risk were insufficient.
lead_paragraph: Despite eliciting a higher takeover bid by Dollar General, Family Dollar remains unswayed by its rival’s acquisition efforts.

headline: Jobs Report: Not Good, but Not Terrible Either
abstract: The numbers are in line with the basic pattern of the last few months: The economy is mending more strongly than it had been.
lead_paragraph: First, the good news, if it can be called that: The new numbers on how the United States job market fared in August aren’t cover-your-eyes terrible. Nothing in this report should send anyone running to the hills in fear.

headline: Billy Reid and Alabama Chanin’s Homegrown Cotton
abstract: An inside look at the pair’s two-year process behind a new limited-edition collection, which began with an organic crop in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: An inside look at the pair’s two-year process behind a new limited-edition collection, which began with an organic crop in Alabama.

headline: British Response to Election Limits Upsets Activists in Hong Kong
abstract: Some advocates had hoped Britain would respond more harshly to China’s move to restrict democracy in the city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For months, democracy advocates in Hong Kong have called for an open election for the city’s leader and for international pressure to be exerted on Beijing to not interfere with Hong Kong’s autonomy.

headline: Ukraine Deal Imposes Truce Putin Devised
abstract: Whether the cease-fire between Ukraine’s government and separatists lasts will probably be determined by the outcome of negotiations over the political future of the southeastern region.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — After five months of intensifying combat that threatened to rip Ukraine apart and to reignite the Cold War, the Ukrainian government and separatist forces signed a cease-fire agreement on Friday that analysts considered highly tenuous in a country that remains a tinderbox.

headline: Ebola Is Taking a Second Toll, on Economies
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Epidemics', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: The disease, and the hysteria it has caused, is already having a serious economic impact, in part because some countries are closing down borders.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Airlines have canceled their flights to the countries most affected. Prices of staple goods are going up, and food supplies are dwindling. Border posts are being closed, foreign workers are going home and national growth rates are projected to plummet.

headline: Corner Closet Opens Up a Bit Wider
abstract: Trevor Burgess of C1 Financial and Jason Grenfell-Gardner of IGI Laboratories are part of a generation that doesn’t conceal sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: After C1 Financial’s chief executive, Trevor Burgess, rang the opening bell and posed outside the New York Stock Exchange with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers cheerleaders on Aug. 14 to celebrate his Florida-based company’s first day of trading, he received a message from Jason Grenfell-Gardner, the chief executive of the pharmaceutical company IGI Laboratories:

headline: Chiquita’s Inversion Plan Hits Snag as I.S.S. Recommends Vote Against Deal
abstract: Two influential shareholder advisory services suggested that the company entertain an offer from Brazilian buyers.
lead_paragraph: Chiquita Brands International’s plans to strike an inversion deal suffered another blow on Friday, as two influential shareholder advisory services suggested that the company instead entertain an unexpected takeover offer from an unlikely pair of Brazilian buyers.

headline: Joan Rivers and the Front Page
abstract: The obituary for the longtime comedian was an unquestioned choice for the front page.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers was a popular comedian, no doubt. But we asked Dean Baquet, the executive editor, why he decided to place her obituary on the front page this morning.

headline: Poor Start Dooms Tomas Berdych Against Marin Cilic at U.S. Open
abstract: Berdych’s first service game revealed problems with his serve and forehand that would last the rest of his quarterfinal match against Cilic.
lead_paragraph: You cannot read too much into a player’s form after one game, but Tomas Berdych’s start in his quarterfinal match against Marin Cilic was an ominous sign in an eventual 6-2, 6-4, 7-6 (4) loss.

headline: Phil Ochs Archives Go to Woody Guthrie Center
abstract: Archival material by and about Phil Ochs, the influential 1969s folksinger, has been donated to the Woody Guthrie Center in Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: Phil Ochs’s archival materials, including lyrics, scrapbooks filled with articles by and about him, photos and posters, have been donated to the Woody Guthrie Center, in Tulsa, Okla. The center is an archive and educational facility that opened in April 2013 with the goal of preserving not only Woody Guthrie’s materials – his complete archives are housed there – but also the archives of musicians and artists in other disciplines who were influenced by him.

headline: Vienna State Opera’s Music Director Resigns
abstract: The general music director, Franz Welser-Möst, cited “irreconcilable differences” for his decision and withdrew from all his scheduled performances there.
lead_paragraph: The Vienna State Opera was thrown into turmoil just days after its new season began when its general music director, Franz Welser-Möst, abruptly resigned on Friday and withdrew from all his scheduled performances there, citing “irreconcilable differences of opinion regarding the company’s artistic planning and profile.”

headline: 1914: Italian Mobilization Expected
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy prepares for a general mobilization in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ROME — It is said that a general mobilization is imminent, and that General Nava will immediately assume chief command of the Italian army. The order for the general mobilization has not yet been signed, but it is believed it will be signed during the day. In the meantime the mobilization is proceeding actively by means of individual orders. Throughout the kingdom enlisting is proceeding actively. On the other hand, despatches from Milan say that between Bozen and Franzens Feste travellers have noticed numerous entrenchments prepared by the Austrian army, armed with guns turned upon Italy. In the north of Venetia large Italian forces are ready to march. The despatch of an ultimatum to Austria is expected every minute. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 6, 1914

headline: Wary ‘Normal’ in Ferguson, Mo.
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After the killing of a black teenager by a white police officer sparked a string of protests in Ferguson, Mo., the town is returning to a new normal as scars of the unrest remain.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month has passed since Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, was fatally shot by a police officer, Darren Wilson, in Ferguson, Mo. The confrontation sparked a string of protests that lasted for more than a week. A small stretch of West Florissant Avenue, where businesses were looted and nightly protests would sometimes crescendo into violent clashes, became the backdrop for a national debate about racism and the militarization of police forces.

headline: Letters: Poor Little Lambs
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of William Deresiewicz’s “Excellent Sheep” and more.
lead_paragraph: Poor Little Lambs

headline: Medical Memoirs
abstract: New books by Terrence Holt, Judy Melinek and T. J. Mitchell, and Paul A. Marks and James Sterngold.
lead_paragraph: INTERNAL MEDICINE  A Doctor’s Stories  By Terrence Holt  Liveright, $24.95.

headline: Brandishing a Gun to Woo Voters
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Firearm ads come and go as political staccato punctuating the electioneering season.
lead_paragraph: “They call me a long shot,” Estakio Beltran, a congressional candidate in Washington state, declares in a TV ad, never once disclosing that he’s a Democrat but taking aim with his shotgun at a piñata — an elephant piñata in case anyone doubts what he’s gunning for. Bam! the gun goes off and the sad-eyed, paper-tattered toy elephant topples. Mr. Beltran’s ad is one of many bamming and kerpowing across the land from candidates pandering to gun enthusiasts. He may not win an election, but his seems the most entertaining or at least the silliest. Particularly so when he racks the empty shell from his gun in macho triumph and rides off like Clint Eastwood, heading east toward the Capitol on a loping donkey (a Democratic donkey?).

headline: Getting to the Heart of Things
abstract: Matthew Thomas, who earned two master’s degrees in writing, says the workshop environment “serves its purpose and then you have to move on.”
lead_paragraph: Matthew Thomas’s debut novel, “We Are Not Ourselves,” is reviewed this week by Maggie Scarf.

headline: Family Circle
abstract: This first novel probes the lives of three generations of an Irish-American family in the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: As a young woman training for a graduate degree in nursing administration, Eileen Tumulty longs for the day when she will marry and take another name. It’s the thoroughgoing Irishness of Tumulty, with its redolence of “peat bogs and sloppy rebel songs” and deep defeat, from which she yearns to detach herself. She wants the sort of bland, decorous WASP name that will label her as an unhyphenated American. Bright, attractive and strong-willed, Eileen is passionately ambitious, determined to shake off the poverty-haunted, alcohol-ridden atmosphere of her childhood and achieve not only wealth and comfort but a sense of belonging. Shame is the deeply buried force that drives her.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: REIGN OF ERROR: The Hoax of the Privatization Movement and the Danger to America’s Public Schools,  by Diane Ravitch. (Vintage, $16.95.) In her influential 2010 book, “The Death and Life of the Great American School System,” Ravitch joined the vocal opposition to school choice and testing. In “Reign of Error,” she focuses more directly, and polemically, on the attempt to replace public schools with a free-market system, which she argues has fed on the myth that schools are failing.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BONE CLOCKS,  by David Mitchell. (Random House, $30.) In this latest head-spinning flight into other dimensions from the author of “Cloud Atlas,” all borders between pubby England and the machinations of the undead begin to blur.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: With Ebola back in the news, readers are returning to Richard Preston’s scientific adventure story “The Hot Zone,” which is No. 17 on the paperback nonfiction list.
lead_paragraph: Going Viral: Twenty years ago, Richard Preston scored a nonfiction hit with his scientific adventure story “The Hot Zone,” about an outbreak of Ebola virus among quarantined monkeys in Virginia — the book spent almost two years on the hardcover and paperback lists before fading away in June 1996. (That was a good time for science journalism. During its run, Preston’s book shared space on the list with Oliver Sacks’s collection of neurological case studies “An Anthropologist on Mars” and Nicholas Negroponte’s technology primer “Being Digital,” which predicted the end of fax machines and CD-ROMs.) Now, with Ebola back in the news because of its fatal spread through West Africa, readers are returning to “The Hot Zone.” The Associated Press reported last month that Anchor Books, the paperback publisher, had printed 70,000 new copies, and the book is currently at No. 17 in its 50th week on the paperback nonfiction list. “The thing is,” Preston told CNN early in August, “Ebola has been pulling surprises on all of us. I don’t think anybody really expected that Ebola had the potential to do something like get into the cities and get out of control. But, you know, most of the experts I’m talking to are saying that they are pretty well convinced that, you know, they will be able to get it under control, but there’s huge concern about the possibility that Ebola could get into a major city.” The virus’s return is obviously bad news. But it does retroactively absolve “The Hot Zone” of a charge Colin Harrison leveled against it in the Book Review a few years after its publication. “The outbreak in Virginia resulted in exactly zero human cases,” Harrison noted, complaining about the “happy frenzy” of media attention the story had received. “It was the first time that everyone knew about a disease that nobody had. It was the first time that a virus was famous for being famous.” Now we know we were right to panic.

headline: Between Women
abstract: The third novel in Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan series tracks a long and complicated friendship.
lead_paragraph: Elena Ferrante is one of the great novelists of our time. Her voice is passionate, her view sweeping and her gaze basilisk. Her subject is the domestic world, and part of her genius lies in her capacity to turn this sphere into an infernal region, full of rage and violence, unlimited in its intellectual and emotional reach. Ferrante’s view of family life is anything but sentimental, anything but comforting.

headline: Future Footprints
abstract: Diane Ackerman surveys the technology and innovations that define our human-dominated epoch.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in history, a sentient species, Homo sapiens, has become a force of such magnitude that our impacts are being written into the fossil record. We have decisively changed the carbon cycle, the nitrogen cycle and the rate of extinction. We have created ­new atomic isotopes and plastiglomerates that may persist for millions of years. We have built mega­cities that will leave a durable footprint long after they have vanished. We have altered the pH of the oceans and have moved so many life-forms around the globe — inadvertently and ­intentionally — that we are creating novel ecosystems everywhere. Since the late-18th-century industrialization that marks the Anthropocene’s beginnings, humans have ­shaken Earth’s life systems with a profundity that the paleontologist Anthony Barnosky has likened to an asteroid strike.

headline: Girlhood Gone
abstract: Sex and cruelty are tools a 14-year-old uses to cope with a devastatingly irresponsible father in 1970s Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: It seems endemic to the enterprise that fiction writers must fall good and hard for their characters — how else could we stand to live with them for weeks, months, years, in sometimes tortuous isolation? As in marriage or a long affair, this abiding attraction can twist and turn into revulsion or obsession. It can also wax and wane. The writer can stray and then beg for forgiveness, banging on a shut door to be let back inside. In conjuring “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,” Mark Twain became captivated by Huckleberry Finn, Tom’s “idle and lawless and vulgar and bad” sidekick, so much so that Twain rode Huck on to glory with his subsequent masterpiece. J. D. Salinger’s beloved Holden Caulfield appeared in several stories, both published and unpublished, before he found his home in “The Catcher in the Rye.” And, as any fan knows, Salinger had a hell of a time kicking the Glass family to the curb; its members own or make appearances in all three of Salinger’s story collections, as well as in new collections (fingers crossed) that are rumored to be ­forthcoming.

headline: Impossible Mirrors
abstract: A Brooklyn-based narrator preoccupied with identity decides to help his best friend have a child.
lead_paragraph: Early in “10:04,” Ben Lerner’s frequently brilliant second novel, the central character — a refraction or avatar of this ­Brooklyn-based author — describes visiting the Metropolitan Museum with a female friend: “We often visited weekday afternoons, since Alex was unemployed, and I, a writer.” Together they look at a melodramatic 19th-century genre painting of Joan of Arc, which the narrator claims is one of his favorite pictures. Lerner uses the strikingly unlovely word “coconstructed” to describe the shared nature of their experience: “We would work out our views as we coconstructed the literal view before us.” A few paragraphs on, he and an 8-year-old boy are seen “coconstructing a shoe-box diorama.” Later he can be found letting an Occupy protester shower in his apartment, wondering if it’s possible to “coconstruct a world in which moments can be something other than the elements of profit.”

headline: His Manifest Destiny
abstract: A fictional memoir narrated by Estebanico, a Moroccan slave and the first black explorer of America.
lead_paragraph: In 1527, the Castilian conquistador Pánfilo de Narváez and a crew of 600 men sailed from Spain to the Gulf Coast of the United States to claim “La Florida” for the Spanish crown. Laila Lalami recounts the voyage — and its brutal aftermath — in her new novel, “The Moor’s Account,” from the perspective of Estebanico, a ­Moroccan slave of one of the explorers. It’s a fictional memoir, told in a controlled voice that feels at once historical and contemporary, that seeks to offer a truer account of the expedition than the official (and hopelessly biased) version of events provided by Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca, one of the other three survivors.

headline: Toxic Relationships
abstract: A small town falters after an industrial disaster.
lead_paragraph: A sinister oily sludge — improperly buried toxic waste reasserting itself — has wormed its way out of the ground in a small Texas town. Birth defects and cancer rates have soared; houses have been abandoned and razed. Now, years later, a peculiar collective amnesia has set in, and only one woman is still fighting the City Council, which has cleared the land for redevelopment, and the predictably sleazy real estate magnate who will profit from the job.

headline: Weird Science
abstract: A flavor chemist lands a job as an animal tester and is disturbed by the effects a new sweetener appears to have on his rats.
lead_paragraph: It’s a very “now” premise: the confessional narrative of a food scientist complicit in the development of a chemical additive that has played a sneaky role in America’s obesity epidemic. The nonfiction shelves already abound with gastro-exposés (hello, Michael Pollan, Marion Nestle and Michael Moss), so why not fiction?

headline: Hour of the Wolf
abstract: Grief and cold dominate this novel set in remote Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Early in William Giraldi’s fierce, extraordinary new novel, “Hold the Dark,” the nature writer Russell Core tracks a pack of wolves deep into the Alaskan tundra. The wolves, it seems, have been taking children from a nearby village, and Core, a wolf expert, has been summoned by the latest victim’s mother to “get her boy’s bones and maybe slaughter the wolf that took him.”

headline: Minority Report
abstract: A journalist examines Asian-American manhood and the cultural stereotypes that shaped his coming-of-age.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing subtle or coy or particularly evocative about the title of “Big Little Man: In Search of My Asian Self,” a memoir by the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Alex Tizon. In fact, the title is so straightforward that when I was asked to write this review, I felt vaguely offended by the idea that my editor would push such an obvious identity-politics project on me, perhaps believing that I, by dint of being “Asian-American,” must therefore have some special insight into Tizon and this search for his Asian self. I am 20 years younger than Tizon and grew up in snooty college towns and attended schools where I was taught that there was a hierarchy of race writing. The immigrant experience was not enough in itself, and when I read the self-evident title of Tizon’s book, I flashed back to a fiction workshop in ­Columbia’s M.F.A. program and a ­professor who told me that the book I was working on — a book much like Tizon’s — could “definitely be published,” but wondered if there was anything I could do to elevate it into something more “interesting.” I recognized the code immediately — anything labeled “the immigrant experience” would be considered earnest and déclassé, and would therefore need to be gussied up in fashionable literary frills. For the next year, I wrote bad evocations of Lydia Davis, Lorrie Moore, Barthelme and Borges. My protagonists, God help them, became whiter and whiter.

headline: Dubliners
abstract: A series of challenges unsettles an extended family’s comfortable existence.
lead_paragraph: We spend our lives tumbling through time, carried along as it eddies and pools, buckles and loops, stutters and flies. As T. S. Eliot put it in the opening lines of “Burnt Norton,” “Time present and time past / Are both perhaps present in time future, / And time future contained in time past.” We like to think that time is ours to waste, but it is we who pass through time, wasting only ourselves.

headline: The Age of Hobsbawm
abstract: This collection of reviews and lectures, posthumously published, mourns the end of European high culture.
lead_paragraph: A 1980 television film written by the British director Stephen Poliakoff depicted an interminable train journey through Europe, in which a young Englishman is trapped in a cramped compartment with a pompous Viennese matron, played by Peggy Ashcroft. The woman is rude and vain, but the film, “Caught on a Train,” refuses to despise her: Instead it recognizes that she is an elderly ambassador for a world that is about to pass away, the lost civilization of prewar Europe.

headline: Art of Murder
abstract: In Louise Penny’s “The Long Way Home,” Chief Inspector Armand Gamache follows a lost artist’s perilous journey to find himself.
lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, every writer of small-town mysteries must confront the occupational hazard of running out of murderers and victims. Louise Penny, who sets her enchanting stories in a sheltered Quebec village she calls Three Pines, keeps inventing new ways to avoid the inevitable reckoning. In THE LONG WAY HOME (Minotaur, $27.99), she makes the task more challenging by putting her detective out to pasture. Chief Inspector Armand Gamache has retired from the Sûreté du Québec to live a contemplative life, enjoying the company of his eccentric neighbors and hoping to be anointed with the “balm in Gilead” that will “make the wounded whole” and “cure a sin-sick soul.” Gamache is moved by the plight of one neighbor, Clara Morrow, a painter whose husband, Peter, left home when her artistic reputation eclipsed his own — promising to return in exactly one year, presumably after intense soul-searching. But that anniversary has come and gone without any word, and Clara is afraid Peter’s in terrible trouble, might even be dead. Clutching at a few meager clues, the most intriguing being some atrocious paintings Peter sent to his sister’s child, Gamache and Clara follow the lost artist’s perilous journey to find himself.

headline: The Earth Stood Still, but the Game Played On
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Cold War Era', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Yankees and the Cardinals met for Game 7 of the World Series as a series of momentous events shook the world.
lead_paragraph: The “split screen” convergence of important news this summer — from Russia, Ukraine, Israel, Gaza, Syria, Iraq and Ferguson, Mo. — recalls an astonishing day 50 years ago next month. On Thursday, Oct. 15, 1964, the Yankees played the Cardinals at Busch Stadium in St. Louis. It was the deciding game of that year’s World Series, and, off the field, it seemed that all hell was breaking loose.

headline: New York’s Once and Future Mansions
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Historic townhouses that have been turned into schools or chopped up into apartments are now being renovated and returned to their original use as single-family homes.
lead_paragraph: When the architect/designer Ogden Codman Jr. built himself a splendidly self-indulgent 40-foot-wide limestone mansion on East 96th Street in 1913, he built it to last, and it did.

headline: Home Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Watching the Sun Set on the Summer Movie Season
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Movies', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Frank and Ross debate the union of church and real estate in “Love Is Strange” and explore future dystopias in “The Giver.” And one columnists pleads: Stop giving actors extra credit for playing gay.
lead_paragraph: Ross Douthat: Now is the Indian summer of our moviegoing discontent, when the temperatures still feel appropriate to midsummer blockbusters but the studios are dumping dreck that would be more at home in the wintry graveyard of late January. (As well as satisfying the millions who were apparently clamoring for a “Forrest Gump” IMAX re-release.) But there are still interesting things to talk about, and I’ll start in with the movie that’s supposed to be the great exception to the current doldrums — “Love Is Strange,” in which John Lithgow and Alfred Molina play longtime companions who tie the knot, only to have Molina’s character lose his job as a music teacher at a Catholic school because the bishop found out about his nuptials, which forces them to sell their tastefully shabby New York apartment and crash (separately, miserably) with their relatives while they try to get on the list for a rent-controlled living situation, with various uncomfortable interpersonal consequences for everyone concerned.

headline: Under Cover: What Is Bill Gates Smiling About?
abstract: Damon Winter recently spoke about what it was like to photograph one of the wealthiest people in the world, and what it took to get him to crack a smile.
lead_paragraph: Do an image search for Bill Gates, and you’ll find plenty of photos of him speaking at events but few formal portraits. So when Dan Winters, a photographer based in Austin, Tex., agreed to shoot Gates for the cover of the Sept. 7 Education Issue to accompany the story by Andrew Ross Sorkin, he knew he wanted to do it in classic portrait-style fashion — in a way that is “timeless and not pegged to any one time or concept,” as he put it. Recently, Winter spoke about what it took to get one of the wealthiest people in the world to crack a smile.

headline: Regulator Tightens Grip on Video Streaming Websites
abstract: Operators in the $2 billion market will have to get licenses for foreign films and TV shows.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government’s main regulator for entertainment on Friday tightened control over the broadcasting of foreign content over the Internet, dealing a blow to the nation’s booming online video streaming market.

headline: Joan Rivers Is Remembered at a Book Party for Betty Halbreich
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Parties (Social)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The comedian forged a close friendship with the author, who is a personal shopper at Bergdorf Goodman.
lead_paragraph: On Betty Halbreich’s desk at Bergdorf Goodman are a number of mementos she’s held on to during her 37 years there as a personal shopper: a photo of Isaac Mizrahi with Ms. Halbreich’s daughter Kathy; a pincushion given to Ms. Halbreich by the costume designer William Ivey Long, whom Ms. Halbreich helped on a number of Broadway shows. Also a chocolate gun in a plastic box that was sent over a year or two ago by her close friend and client Joan Rivers.

headline: Puerto Rico Luring Buyers With Tax Breaks
abstract: Puerto Rico’s status as a tax haven is beginning to catch on, and some are betting big bucks that the trickle of Americans buying property there will soon become a stream.
lead_paragraph: Alex Lemond is among a new wave of New Yorkers trading in their Manhattan condominiums for beachside villas in Puerto Rico. The former hedge fund honcho moved to San Juan from New York last year, and his company, the Encanto Group, is investing hundreds of millions of dollars in developing luxury real estate on the Caribbean island.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: How New Yorkers got along with the wars happening in Europe in 1914 and 1939 through a mammoth musical spectacle and the World’s Fair, respectively.
lead_paragraph: 100 Years Ago

headline: Today in Small Business: Target and Starbucks Go Small
abstract: Job growth slips. Small-business borrowing rises. Don’t post pictures of your customers online without reading this.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Crackdown on Corruption, Even Mooncakes Are Not Exempt
abstract: No longer just a symbol of auspicious reunions, the mooncake has become an emblem of the corruption that the Chinese government under Xi Jinping is eager to stop.
lead_paragraph: For generations, Chinese families have celebrated the Mid-Autumn Festival, which falls on Monday this year, by coming together under the light of the year’s brightest full moon to share mooncakes, sweet pastries stuffed with fillings like lotus seed or red bean paste whose round shape symbolizes unity.

headline: Strikes Killed Militant Chief in Somalia, U.S. Reports
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The Pentagon said it had confirmed that airstrikes Monday killed the leader of the Shabab, the Somalia militant network affiliated with Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Wales — After four days of monitoring cellphone traffic, questioning Somali officials on the ground and poring over reports from both American and British intelligence agencies, the Pentagon on Friday announced that American airstrikes against the Shabab, the Qaeda-linked militant network in Somalia, had succeeded in killing the group’s leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, one of the most wanted men in Africa.

headline: Obama Enlists 9 Allies to Help in the Battle Against ISIS
abstract: President Obama escalated the response to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria on Friday, recruiting allies to help crush the group and outlining a strategy that echoes the war on terror.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Wales — President Obama escalated the American response to the marauding Islamic State in Iraq and Syria on Friday, recruiting at least nine allies to help crush the organization and offering the outlines of a coordinated military strategy that echoes the war on terror developed by his predecessor, George W. Bush, more than a decade ago.

headline: Anatomy of an Authentic Apology
abstract: Dov Seidman, in an Apology Watch Q. and A., discusses with Kevin Rudd, the former prime minister of Australia, how he delivered an apology in 2008 to Australia’s indigenous community and followed it up with meaningful action.
lead_paragraph: “Words can sometimes, in moments of grace, attain the quality of deeds.” — Elie Wiesel

headline: 1939: Roosevelt Signs Neutrality
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States remain neutral in the European conflict in 1939.
lead_paragraph: President Roosevelt signed a proclamation of United States neutrality in the European conflict and followed this action by another proclamation wherein was invoked the arms embargo against belligerents under the neutrality act. Safety measures for ships transporting Americans from the war zone to the United States appeared to be summarized in two ideas:

headline: Settlement Is Approved in Central Park Jogger Case, but New York Deflects Blame
keywords: ['Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The five men who were convicted will share $41 million, or about $1 million for each year spent in prison.
lead_paragraph: A $41 million settlement for five men whose convictions in the 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned was made final on Friday, with the deal including unusual language that sought to absolve New York City from blame.

headline: The Women of West Point
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: Few collegians work as hard as the U.S. Military Academy’s 786 female cadets.

headline: The Jobless Rate: The Worst Benchmark, Except for All the Others
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The drawbacks with the unemployment rate as a measure of economic health are well known. But finding a better alternative is tricky.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate’s reputation as a reliable economic indicator has taken a beating in recent years. But what’s the better alternative?

headline: A Wedding Dress I Never Expected: A Sari
abstract: Marrying into a Kolkata family, I discovered an India I’d kept at bay.
lead_paragraph: Ten minutes after meeting my future mother-in-law, I was wearing only underwear and socks. Acres of magenta chiffon and piles of gold sequins and faux-emerald jewelry — the regalia for my engagement ceremony — lay on the bed. I sucked in my stomach as she deftly wrapped the fabric around my waist. But in the Kolkata humidity, the sari clung to my skin like Saran Wrap. My consternation must have been apparent, because she rushed to reassure me. “Don’t worry!” she said warmly. “You will look sundor!” That means beautiful in Bengali.

headline: Who Made That Cocktail Shaker?
abstract: Plus: Rules for what should always be shaken, never stirred.
lead_paragraph: In 1848, George Foster, a reporter for The New York Tribune who spent his nights searching for good stories in the city’s seedier quarters, marveled at the way a bartender made a drink: “With his shirt sleeves rolled up, and his face in a fiery glow [he] seems to be pulling long ribbons of julep out of a tin cup.”

headline: Reply All: The 8.24.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: IS EUGENIE BOUCHARD TENNIS’S NEXT BIG SHOT?

headline: Is It Wrong to Watch Football?
abstract: In light of recent discoveries about concussions, a football fan questions his support.
lead_paragraph: I’ve recently begun to question my support for the N.F.L. I suspect that the recent discoveries about concussions and the prevalence of early-onset dementia among players are just the tip of the iceberg. Is it unethical to support a league that seems to know it is detrimental to the health of its participants? And if so, what should my response be? Don’t go to games? Don’t buy merchandise? Don’t watch on television? Start actively opposing the N.F.L.? Write letters? DARREN WILLIAMS, DALLAS

headline: Louisiana Judge Rejects Suit Over Landrieu’s Residency
abstract: A state district judge on Friday threw out a lawsuit claiming that Senator Mary L. Landrieu lives full time in Washington and cannot represent Louisiana, saying it was premature.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — A state district judge on Friday threw out a challenge to Senator Mary L. Landrieu’s bid for re-election in Louisiana.

headline: Home and Occasional Film Set
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The filmmaker Ira Sachs’s family includes his husband, Boris Torres, their twins, and the children’s mother, Kirsten Johnson.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Ira Sachs’s two-bedroom apartment on lower Fifth Avenue, where he has lived for 15 years, is a much happier place than it used to be. He memorialized the sad times by using the art- and book-filled apartment as a primary location for his 2012 movie, “Keep the Lights On,” a fictionalized version of his tumultuous 10-year love affair with an addict.

headline: Make Music New York Going Global With Talk Series
abstract: Make Music New York will explore ethnic musical styles from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Make Music New York, the citywide festival that takes place on the summer and winter solstices, began experimenting in January with a new series, Make Music Monthly, at which public discussions of musical topics were presented at the Cornelia Street Café and were made available as podcasts on Make Music New York’s website.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Looting (Crime)']

lead_paragraph: Scars from days of unrest remain along the main street in Ferguson, Mo., as residents and businesses try to get on with their lives.

headline: Prabal Gurung Steps Into Footwear
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Photography', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: For spring/summer 2015, the designer is launching his first complete shoe range under his own label.
lead_paragraph: Prabal Gurung‘s runway shoe collaborations with Casadei, Nicholas Kirkwood and Manolo Blahnik have, in recent seasons, proven as creative as his clothes. Now, for spring/summer 2015, the New York-based Nepalese designer is launching his first complete footwear range under his own label. Inspired by Gurung’s favorite artists — Tracey Emin, Zaha Hadid, Cecily Brown, Georgia O’Keeffe, Cindy Sherman and Frida Kahlo — the heels, flats and boots will appear for the first time at his runway show on Saturday. “We kept to how we design clothes — mixing luxurious textures and vibrant colors,” Gurung explains. Styles are finished off with black insoles for a graphic effect, while the spiky silver buckles, he says, “give everything that bite.”

headline: The Shearing of the Rockfall
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The Rockfall, completed in 1910, has been relieved of much of its original ornament.
lead_paragraph: It’s a perfect crime, really. There’s no blood, and there are no sign of struggle, no marks at all, although plenty is missing. Certainly, the statute of limitations has long ago passed in the case of the mutilation of the intricate front of the Rockfall apartment house, at 111th Street and Broadway. But then, is facade-icide even a crime at all?

headline: A Spotlight on Sarasota Architecture
abstract: The SarasotaMOD Weekend in October will feature tours of the city’s notable architecture.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the mid-20th-century Sarasota School of Architecture have been visiting the Florida city for years, seeking out examples of buildings that architects designed to adapt modernist principles to the tropical environment.

headline: Big Ticket | Duplex Sets a Record at $71.3 Million
abstract: A duplex apartment at the exclusive 740 Park Avenue was the sale of the week; it set a record for New York City co-ops after a bidding war.
lead_paragraph: A much-coveted front corner duplex apartment at 740 Park Avenue, New York City’s billionaire magnet, sold for $71,277,500 after a masters-of-the-universe-only bidding war that spiked its $48 million asking price skyward. It was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: George R. R. Martin to Appear at 92nd St Y
abstract: George Martin, author of the “Song of Ice and Fire” series, will be promoting his new book at the 92nd St. Y.
lead_paragraph: The Seven Kingdoms will meet the Five Boroughs — or Manhattan, at least — when George R. R. Martin touches down at the 92nd Street Y on Oct. 26 for his only United States appearance this year discussing and promoting his new book, “The World of Ice and Fire: The Untold History of Westeros and the Game of Thrones.”

headline: Reading The Times With Delia Ephron
abstract: The author Delia Ephron reveals what she read in The Times this week.
lead_paragraph: Delia Ephron, the author, most recently, of the memoir “Sister Mother Husband Dog (Etc.),” reads The Times at around 8 in the morning, while stretched out on a window seat, ideally with the sun streaming in. She says she always reads The Times “as a real newspaper”: in print.

headline: New Answers About Carbs and Fat
abstract: New York Times health reporter Anahad O’Connor answers questions about the latest research on low-carb eating.
lead_paragraph: New research showing that a low-carbohydrate diet is better for weight loss than a low-fat diet has renewed interest in low-carb eating. To help explain how the latest study is changing the way we think about dieting, the New York Times health writer Anahad O’Connor replies to an edited selection of comments and questions from readers.

headline: Bonanza of Talent Out West
abstract: Ten football teams in the powerful Pac-12 — including No. 13 Stanford and No. 14 U.S.C., which play Saturday — have returning starting quarterbacks this season.
lead_paragraph: Saturday’s college football game between 13th-ranked Stanford and No. 14 Southern California provides more than an early-season peek at how competitive the powerful Pacific-12 Conference is. It demonstrates just how competitive it is to be a Pac-12 quarterback these days.

headline: A View Worthy of an Aria

lead_paragraph: A spacious two-bedroom co-op at the Hampshire House that captivated the Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti some 30 years ago with its treehouse vistas of the entirety of Central Park is poised to enter the market at $13.7 million.

headline: Hiring Data Isn’t Strong Enough to Lift Democrats’ Hopes for November
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The tepid growth in August will probably not change voters’ gloom about the economy much, which voters usually hold the president’s party responsible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Friday’s disappointing jobs report for August, Democrats can pretty much give up any remaining hopes that voters will shake their gloom about the economy before this fall’s midterm elections.

headline: Jane Pratt: She’s Still So Sassy
abstract: On Sundays, Ms. Pratt, the creator and editor in chief of the website xoJane, goes out with her daughter, Charlotte, 11, and sees friends.
lead_paragraph: Jane Pratt is the creator and editor in chief of the website xoJane, where beauty stories like “How Sunless Tanner (And Other Beauty Rituals) Helped Me Finally Quit Smoking” run beside columns by celebrity friends like Courtney Love and the popular confessional series “It Happened to Me.” Ms. Pratt, 51, has been a media maven since the 1980s, when at age 24 she started Sassy, a magazine for teenagers, which had fans including Johnny Depp. In 1997, she founded Jane magazine to cater to the aging Sassy demographic. Ms. Pratt lives in a loft in TriBeCa with her daughter, Charlotte, 11, and two dogs, Balloon, a Shih Tzu-poodle mix, and Lemon, a Maltese.

headline: Malnutrition Crisis in Sudan
abstract: A Unicef document cites stunning levels of malnutrition in Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an internal UNICEF document citing stunning figures for malnutrition in Sudan, particularly in Darfur. It has been 11 years since the killing began in Darfur, and the news coverage has abated–partly because it is so difficult to get access to the story (I haven’t received a Sudan visa in years). But this document suggests that the suffering continues at horrifying levels.

headline: Obama: The Goal Is to ‘Dismantle’ ISIS
abstract: The president commented on the battle against the Islamic State during a news conference at the NATO summit in Wales.
lead_paragraph: The president commented on the battle against the Islamic State during a news conference at the NATO summit in Wales.

headline: Atlanta Orchestra Leaders Make a Plea for Musicians During Labor Talks
abstract: The Atlanta Symphony’s music director and principal guest conductor urge management to acknowledge the players’ concessions.
lead_paragraph: Since the days when it was led by Robert Shaw, the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra has won a reputation far outside the South for its tours and Grammy Award-winning recordings. It continues to win accolades far and wide under the musical leadership of Robert Spano.

headline: Billy Reid and Alabama Chanin’s Homegrown Cotton
abstract: An inside look at the two-year process the two brands underwent to produce a new limited-edition collection, which began with planting and harvesting an organic crop in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of nature’s seasonal yield of ingredients.

headline: What I Learned on My Vacation
abstract: Taking time off is a first step. Learning to simply, and deeply, relax is just as important, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: My first vacation epiphany occurred while taking my two dogs for a walk on the beach at 6 one evening in early August. I’ve always considered walking the dogs obligatory but not especially enjoyable, and I fobbed it off on my wife as often as possible, since she seemed, mysteriously, to enjoy it. But on this night, with the waves lapping on the shore and almost no one in sight, I found myself in a state of deep quiet and contentment. I was happy, nearly rapturous, just walking and taking in the scene.

headline: ‘Every Night It’s As If We’ve Never Had to Make Dinner Before.’
abstract: Two working parents. Two busy kids. One family that arrives home every evening, starved. Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches all of us in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal.
lead_paragraph: Meet Julie.

headline: Credit Card Offers Are Not Always What They Seem
abstract: It’s important to check carefully for “surprise” interest in all those offers of no, or low, interest on balance transfers that arrive in the mail.
lead_paragraph: The offers stuffing your mailbox can sound enticing: Transfer a balance from a high-rate credit card to a new card and pay no interest for six months, a year or even longer.

headline: Negotiators on Ukraine Cease-Fire
abstract: Two pro-Russian rebel leaders, the Ukrainian president and an envoy for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe discussed the cease-fire reached between the separatists and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Two pro-Russian rebel leaders, the Ukrainian president and an envoy for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe discussed the cease-fire reached between the separatists and Ukraine.

headline: For Toronto’s Little India, a New Crowd
abstract: Affordable rents are drawing artists and young families to this east-end enclave.
lead_paragraph: Sari shops and curry emporiums still dot Gerrard Street, the main artery in Toronto’s Little India. But over the last decade, much of the city’s South Asian population has decamped for suburbs like Brampton and Rexdale. Now, as artists and young families move into the neighborhood’s neat single-family homes, Gerrard Street’s affordable storefronts are attracting creative entrepreneurs priced out of trendier districts. The fresh crop of businesses is giving this east-end enclave a vibe that’s both edgy and homey. And with a wave of Irish immigrants settling nearby side streets, a distinctive lilt can now be heard on the strip.

headline: Mud, Worms and Ropes: A One-Day Survival Course
abstract: A class from the Bear Grylls Survival Academy teaches participants tricks for negotiating the wild.
lead_paragraph: When foraging in the wild, one of the best reliable sources of protein is an earthworm. To serve: Use your fingers to wring the slime past the midsection. Snap off the bottom half — mostly intestines anyway — and put the rest in your mouth. Swallow quickly so it doesn’t wiggle on the way down.

headline: To Ride Again Another Day in Colorado
abstract: Months after heavy rains flooded Boulder, a former resident returns to assess the area’s cycling culture.
lead_paragraph: If you ride a bicycle more than casually, you probably already know about Boulder, Colo. Its altitude, endless hills and nearly perpetual sunshine make it a big draw for the pedal-powered and regularly ensure it a top spot on lists of America’s most bike-friendly cities.

headline: Some Chinese Tourists Visit New York but Sleep in New Jersey
abstract: With the number of Chinese tourists to New York soaring, New Jersey has become an unlikely base camp for many of them.
lead_paragraph: The day began early. By 7:30 a.m., the 56 tourists from China were standing in line in the parking lot of the hotel in which they had spent the night.

headline: The Math (and Chemistry) of Marriage
abstract: Two scientists who met in high school finally find each other again.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, Eric Moore sat just two seats away from Maria Nedwidek in an honors chemistry class at the renowned Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan. And their yearbook photos were just two rows apart. Yet he rarely spoke to her.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York City Parks
abstract: Readers ask questions related to a park in Manhattan and another in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can you tell me about the park in Washington Heights that a man created to honor his wife after he was accused of poisoning her?

headline: Simply Unacceptable
abstract: For every simple problem there is an answer that is murky, complex, and wrong.
lead_paragraph: Chris Dillow makes a good point about economics and maybe public affairs in general: There is often a tendency to go for simple stories that aren’t true –as H.L. Mencken said, “For every complex problem there is an answer that is clear, simple, and wrong.” But it also often happens that the answer is simple, but people refuse to accept that simple answer. That is, the reverse of Mencken’s proposition also applies: For every simple problem there is an answer that is murky, complex, and wrong.

abstract: The workers are OK.
lead_paragraph: Claims that there is a huge “skills gap”, that much of our unemployment is structural, reflecting an inadequately prepared work force or something like that, generally rest on claims that we have an unusual situation in which many jobs are vacant even as many workers remain unemployed. For example, at the beginning of this year Jaime Dimon co-authored a piece on the alleged skills gap that began,

headline: When ‘The Hokey Pokey’ Just Doesn’t Cut It
abstract: How to keep young and old alike grooving on the dance floor? Hire a top club D.J.
lead_paragraph: Even if it’s 6 p.m. on a Saturday night, some brides and grooms want a wedding reception that pulsates with that wee-hours-of-the-morning nightclub vibe. Because of that, more couples are eschewing the live band to create high-energy dance extravaganzas and hiring nationally known disc jockeys who regularly headline nightclubs from New York to Las Vegas to Los Angeles.

headline: For Bob McDonnell, a Miscalculation at the Scene of a Blunder
