headline: When Philanthropy Is Weird
abstract: Whether they’re linked to leaked nude photos or a relatively tame bucket of ice, stunt-based philanthropic efforts have their critics.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a strange week for philanthropy. Just as media outlets began assessing the effects of celebrities pouring ice on their heads for charity, Redditors decided to donate money in response to Jennifer Lawrence’s nude photos. The practice of linking charitable giving to other activities — some just odd, some ethically questionable — seems to be growing in prominence, with what some say are not entirely positive results.

headline: Happy 75th Birthday, Verdura
keywords: ['Art', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: The brand puts final touches on a retrospective exhibition, co-curated by Carolina Herrera, and introduces the 75th design in its numbered cuff series.
lead_paragraph: This week, the American fine jeweler Verdura celebrates its 75th anniversary. To mark the occasion, the brand is putting the final touches on “The Power of Style: Verdura at 75,” an exhibition that opens next month in a new gallery space adjacent to its Fifth Avenue flagship. Over 150 jewels and objets d’art by the company’s late founder, Duke Fulco di Verdura, will be on view alongside over a selection of designs, paintings and photographs from the company’s archives.

headline: S.E.C. Names First Ombudsman

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has chosen Tracey L. McNeil, an agency veteran and former corporate lawyer, to “act as a liaison in resolving problems that retail investors may have” with the agency.
lead_paragraph: Investors are a fussy sort, quick to gripe about a shady broker here or a new regulation there. Now someone will actually have the job of listening to them.

headline: Two Vaccines to Protect Against Ebola Could Be Available Within Weeks
abstract: The vaccines would first be given to health care workers most at risk of exposure to the disease in West Africa, the World Health Organization said.
lead_paragraph: Two potential vaccines against the deadly Ebola virus ravaging West Africa could be available as soon as November and would first be given to health care workers most at risk of exposure to the disease there, the World Health Organization announced on Friday.

headline: A Picture of Dementia
abstract: A documentary airing on PBS provides a cleareyed account of one family’s struggle with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: When the documentary filmmaker Banker White began turning his camera on his family in 2009, his mother had undertaken a project of great personal importance: She wanted to compile material for a book about her own mother, a Massachusetts painter named Marian Williams Steele, who died of Alzheimer’s disease in 2001.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Biggest Pot Dealer in New York City History
abstract: An elaborate case led to the discovery, and subsequent arrest, of Jimmy Cournoyer, a French Canadian playboy and international criminal.
lead_paragraph: One day in January 2007, the disgruntled ex-girlfriend of a Queens pot dealer walked unprompted into the district office of the Drug Enforcement Administration on Long Island. Sitting down with an agent, she bitterly gave vent: Her former boyfriend, the father of her child, was selling weed.

headline: Obama ‘Hopeful’ Over Ukraine Cease-Fire

abstract: The president said he was hopeful but skeptical about a cease-fire agreement that was reached Friday between pro-Russian separatists and Ukraine.

headline: Virginians, Surprised by Ex-Governor’s Conviction, Ponder the Fallout
abstract: Politicians consider new ethics rules in a state with notoriously lax ones and the possible consequences if state legislators do not substantially limit gifts public officials can receive.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — A day after Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia was convicted on 11 counts of conspiracy, bribery and extortion, and his wife, Maureen, on nine counts, Virginia was still picking through the wreckage and trying to figure out what comes next.

headline: Many in West Africa May Be Immune to Ebola Virus
abstract: If such people can be identified, they could be a help in fighting the outbreak. They could tend to the sick, bury the dead and give antibodies. But finding them will not be easy.
lead_paragraph: Although few medical experts realize it, part of the population in West Africa is immune to the Ebola virus, according to virologists who specialize in the disease.

headline: Couscous Salads, Big Bowls and Casseroles
abstract: An annual summer pantry clean-out inspires three new grain salads, and Israel couscous pasta and an eggplant and tomato gratin.
lead_paragraph: I’m continuing this week with my summer pantry clean-out, determined to put some of the partly filled bags of grains I’m finding to new uses. One item I found was a half-filled packet of Israeli couscous, which also goes by its North African names of moghrabiyeh and muhammas. Whatever you call it, it’s a spherical product made, like regular couscous, from durum wheat, more akin to pasta than to grains, but I use it like a grain in salads, big bowls and casseroles.

headline: Jet Carrying Contractors Is Ordered to Land in Iran
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States attributed the episode to a bureaucratic issue and not a larger political incident. The plane was later allowed to depart Iran, and by Friday night, had landed in Dubai, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A charter airplane carrying American military contractors through Iranian airspace was instructed to land in Iran on Friday, but the United States attributed the episode to an easily corrected bureaucratic issue and not a larger political incident between two countries with a long history of hostility.

lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss new projects by Ms. Grande and Ms. Bush.

lead_paragraph: At the Marriott Chicago O’ Hare, the standard junk-food-filled vending machine is getting an upgrade: the 470-room property has introduced a healthy food option in its lobby adjacent to the reception desk.

headline: 1936: John F. Kennedy Goes Sailing
abstract: John F. Kennedy was a teenager when he stepped out of his powerful father’s shadow and into the pages of The Times, for a sailboat race off Long Island.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

lead_paragraph: Taking account of its gasoline, diesel and high-performance GTI variants, the latest Golf highlights Volkswagen engineering at its best.

headline: Suppose You Threw an Ice Bucket Challenge and Nobody Came?
abstract: Advice on how to handle the A.L.S. ice bucket challenge — whether or not you’ve been challenged.
lead_paragraph: I see that after coming up with the most successful fund-raiser in the history of man, the A.L.S. ice bucket challenge is getting the inevitable pushback: The chief executive of the A.L.S. association makes too much money, it’s an exercise in narcissism, not enough of the money is going to research.

headline: Reports on Maker of Artificial Heart Shake Up Its Stock
abstract: Carmat shares jumped after French news media reports said that its device had been implanted in a second human patient.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The stocks of biotech and medical device start-up companies are notoriously volatile. And the French company Carmat, which has been trying for years to bring an artificial heart to the market, felt that pull on Friday as investors bid up its stock.

headline: Liking Work Really Matters
abstract: Being interested in a task is essential to being good at it.
lead_paragraph: WE have all had to work on tasks we detest: Calculus homework, for example, is boring and hard. As soon as we start, we feel mentally exhausted, and the quality of our work suffers.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Weaker and Weaker Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 19-year-old man who suddenly collapsed at work after months of weakness and fatigue dotted with episodes of nausea and vomiting.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 19-year-old man who suddenly collapsed at work after months of weakness and fatigue dotted with episodes of nausea and vomiting. More than 500 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses. And more than 60 of you nailed it. The cause of this man’s collapse, weakness, nausea and vomiting was…

lead_paragraph: Popcast returns with a What We Did On Our Summer Vacation edition.

abstract: An aging German maintains its moves, but stumbles over the numbers.
lead_paragraph: An aging German maintains its moves, but stumbles over the numbers.

headline: The World Is Ending, and Readers Couldn’t Be Happier
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Just when it seemed that enthusiasm for dystopian novels might have peaked, a new crop of such books is stirring excitement.
lead_paragraph: Emily St. John Mandel doesn’t seem like the paranoid type. Cheerful and preternaturally poised, she spends her free time tending to the flower beds in her rooftop garden in Brooklyn and working on her rudimentary French.

headline: A Solid Gold Structure for $26,000
abstract: The new 2015 GTI might have its best shot to move from cult favorite into the mainstream. This GTI is quite likely the best all-around automobile for less than $30,000.
lead_paragraph: For 30 years, when enthusiasts have debated which cars best blend performance, practicality and price, the Volkswagen GTI has loomed large.

headline: Big-Ticket Engineering at a Deep Discount
abstract: Americans are wising up to the virtues of hatchbacks, and the restyled Volkswagen Golf for 2015 gives them good reasons. It is longer and wider and is available with a fuel-sipping diesel engine.
lead_paragraph: Taking account of its gasoline, diesel and high-performance GTI variants, the latest Golf highlights Volkswagen engineering at its best. A Euro-sporty hatchback that the world has long embraced, the Golf helped VW to sell five million cars in the first half of 2014, sneaking past General Motors and barely trailing Toyota as the global sales leader.

headline: Chef Nick Anderer on Rome, Pizza and His New Restaurant, Marta
abstract: The man who has teamed up with Danny Meyer on two New York restaurants reveals how his mom’s cooking and a junior year abroad shaped him.
lead_paragraph: After stints at the acclaimed restaurants Babbo and Gramercy Tavern, the New York chef Nick Anderer teamed up with Danny Meyer in 2010 to open the Roman-style trattoria Maialino. Now the pair is back with a new spot, the soon-to-open wood-fired-oven pizzeria Marta, inside the reopened Martha Washington hotel. In the fifth installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Anderer shares how his mom’s cooking and spending his junior year of college in Rome shaped his culinary sensibility.

headline: Justin Tuck Brings Defensive Flair to MetLife Stadium, as a Raider
abstract: Tuck, a longtime defensive standout with the Giants, is now with Oakland and will face the Jets on Sunday in East Rutherford, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The former Giant Justin Tuck wants to make the most of what may be a bleak season, starting Sunday against the Jets when he plays at MetLife Stadium for the first time as a member of the Oakland Raiders.

headline: As Its I.P.O. Nears, Alibaba Gets Ready for a Splashy Debut
abstract: The company, which runs two huge online marketplaces in China, plans to kick off a long-awaited roadshow for potential investors on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | It began as a small Internet upstart in China, but now the Alibaba Group is preparing for a splashy debutante party that will stretch from New York to Hong Kong and back again.

headline: VW Shows Off Its 2015 Lineup
abstract: VW assembled turbo, diesel and even electric-power cars and crossovers in Northern Virginia for journalists to sample.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBURG, Va. — Volkswagen occupied a corner of Northern Virginia’s lush horse country with a collection of its newest vehicles recently, affording a group of journalists a closer look at its 2015 model line. With a chance to sample VW’s wares came an opportunity to reflect on the automaker’s struggle to meet its ambitious sales goals in North America.

headline: Mooncakes Are a Must as Chinese Festival Nears
abstract: Like fruitcakes in the West, mooncakes are a seasonal gift that everyone loves to hate, with an estimated $2 billion in annual sales in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At the Lin Heung Tea House here, staff members rushed around with piles of mooncakes in their trademark gold, blue and red tins.

headline: Federal Sale of Troubled Mortgages Draws Criticism From Community Groups
abstract: A research report says that the government should give nonprofit groups a better chance to buy distressed mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Community advocacy groups are giving mixed grades to a federal housing agency initiative that has resulted in the sale of nearly 100,000 distressed mortgages to mainly private investors, especially when it comes to keeping borrowers in their homes.

headline: In Inventive Cooking, British Show the Way
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi and Diana Henry have mastered the art of combining familiar and global flavors in ways that entice.
lead_paragraph: Time was, when you talked about Britain’s global reach, you were referring to colonies, not cuisine. Though the empire ranged far and wide, you would never know it from the chip butties (a French fry sandwich) and mushy peas on plates back home; we Americans took particular joy in poking fun at that.

headline: Her Villages
abstract: Images by the photographer Arlene Gottfried are featured in “East Village Our Village,” an exhibit that reopens at the Lower Eastside Girls Club on Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain warmth in Arlene Gottfried’s photos of East Harlem, the Lower East Side of Manhattan and Williamsburg, Brooklyn. It is not necessarily nostalgia for a bygone era, but a true appreciation for the kind of neighborhood life that gave those places a distinct feel before waves of gentrification pushed up rents and pushed out locals.

headline: Video: The Volkswagen Tiguan Has Soul, but It Costs Plenty
abstract: There is a lot to like about the 2014 Volkswagen Tiguan, but when stacked up against competitors, it may not add up.
lead_paragraph: This week in Automobiles, Lawrence Ulrich looks at the 2015 Volkswagen Golfs with the gasoline TSI and diesel TDI engines. The Golf now rides on VW’s new and highly versatile MQB platform, which is expected to be the foundation for 40 different Volkswagen Group products, from Audi to Skoda.

headline: A Scare and a Disheartening Victory
abstract: Wozniacki beat Peng in a semifinal match when Peng retired because of a heat-related illness with the score, 7-6 (1), 4-3. Wozniacki will face Serena Williams in the final.
lead_paragraph: For Caroline Wozniacki, watching her opponent being carried from the court in a wheelchair was not how she wanted to celebrate reaching the United States Open final. Instead of reveling in her accomplishment, Wozniacki was worrying about Peng Shuai, who had succumbed to heat illness during their semifinal match Friday. At one point, Wozniacki had rushed around the net to comfort Peng before she decided to retire from the match.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Last Days in Vietnam.”

headline: At Mocha Hookah in Brooklyn Heights, Tasting Mint, Orange and Home
abstract: Mocha Hookah, a 24-hour hookah bar and cafe on Atlantic Avenue, is probably the only public place to smoke a water pipe in the heart of brownstone Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: New York is famously the melting pot. But in reality, maybe the city is more like a Middle Eastern meze platter: varied tastes and colors neatly and randomly assembled to please a range of tastes. This is the case at Mocha Hookah, a 24-hour hookah bar and cafe on Atlantic Avenue, and probably the only public place to smoke a water pipe in the heart of brownstone Brooklyn. There, on a recent Wednesday night, three friends huddled around an iPhone, drinking milkshakes and blowing sweet smoke from a burbling glass carafe.

headline: Paintings Stolen from Peruvian Church Are Returned by Federal Investigators
abstract: United States officials have returned nine 18th century paintings to Peru, six years after the works by Miguel Cabrera were stolen from a church in Lima.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials on Friday announced the return of nine paintings by the 18th century Mexican artist Miguel Cabrera to Peru, six years after they were stolen from a church in Lima, the Peruvian capital.

headline: Can’t Place That Smell? You Must Be American
abstract: Anthropologists and psychologists are finding that sensory perception is culturally specific.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — WE think of our senses as hard-wired gateways to the world. Many years ago the social psychologist Daryl J. Bem described the knowledge we gain from our senses as “zero-order beliefs,” so taken for granted that we do not even notice them as beliefs. The sky is blue. The fan hums. Ice is cold. That’s the nature of reality, and it seems peculiar that different people with their senses intact would experience it subjectively.

headline: Gen-Z Driver, Cool for School
abstract: Anthony Di Liberto, 16, of New Jersey has yet to take his driver’s test, but he already owns, and cherishes, a 1962 Chrysler Newport.
lead_paragraph: NEW MILFORD, N.J. — The course of Anthony Di Liberto’s passion for car culture is neatly summed up in two snapshots.

headline: During a Season for New Devices, a Tough Market for Smartphone Makers
abstract: At the IFA consumer electronics show in Berlin, most of the major smartphone makers introduced new devices, features or pricing in attempts to distinguish themselves within a crowded industry.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The holiday shopping season is still months away. But the world’s technology giants are already trying to position their latest smartphones, televisions and other devices for their annual push to consumers around the globe.

headline: An 18-Foot Bridge for the Generation Gap
abstract: It’s not the fastest car in the lot, but this Chrysler is just right for a high school senior steeped in the ’60s.

abstract: Estonia accused Russia of kidnapping an intelligence officer, while Moscow suggested he was a spy, heightening tensions already strained over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A strange incident near the Russian-Estonian border on Friday ended with an Estonian intelligence officer in Russian custody and the two countries trading sharply contradictory allegations about what happened.

headline: Small Plane Leaves Rochester and Crashes Off Jamaica; Two Are Dead
abstract: Larry Glazer, a real estate developer from the Rochester area, and his wife, Jane, were aboard the single-engine aircraft, which may have had low oxygen levels.
lead_paragraph: A small plane from western New York that briefly flew through Cuban airspace after overshooting its intended destination in Florida crashed off the coast of Jamaica on Friday, federal aviation officials said.

lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — ON Sept. 18, residents of Scotland will head to voting booths to answer the question, “Should Scotland be an independent country?”

lead_paragraph: Plácido Domingo has extended his contact as the general director of the Los Angeles Opera through the 2018-19 season, the company announced Friday.

headline: Studying Ebola, Then Dying From It
abstract: We could have stopped this epidemic, and saved my colleagues’ lives.
lead_paragraph: IN late May, a woman was admitted to the Kenema Government Hospital’s maternity ward in Sierra Leone after a bloody miscarriage. Augustine Goba, director of the hospital’s diagnostic laboratory and my longtime collaborator, ran a series of sensitive molecular tests and detected the first case of Ebola infection in the hospital, and one of the first confirmed cases in the country. Dr. Sheik Humarr Khan, Sierra Leone’s leading virologist, and other medical staff members isolated the patient and wore gloves, gowns and masks while treating her. She survived and made a full recovery, and no one else was infected.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wales and More
abstract: Photos from Wales, Ukraine, Bosnia and Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Wales, Ukraine, Bosnia and Liberia.

headline: What Does the Middle Class Need?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Student Loans', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Last night, Senator Elizabeth Warren and New York Times columnist Paul Krugman sat down to discuss the minimum wage, consumer financial protection, student debt, access to health care and other issues facing our nation’s middle class.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Elizabeth Warren went to college, it cost $50 a semester. “That opened about a million doors for a kid like me,” she told the audience Thursday night at the City University of New York, where she and New York Times columnist Paul Krugman joined professor of political science Janet Gornick in conversation. “I want every kid to have that same kind of fighting chance to build a future.”

headline: Filling the Empty Nest With Animals
abstract: They have always helped me. When I was young, my dog Poochie was my therapist.
lead_paragraph: Within a week of dropping off our daughter at college, we brought home a puppy. The reason, I persuaded my husband, was to help her younger brother feel less alone — even though we already had two cats.

headline: Financial Schemes Against the Elderly Are Increasing
abstract: Advice to help older adults avoid financial abuse from those they trust.
lead_paragraph: WHEN a longtime friend asked for a loan to help get her boyfriend back on his feet, Maria Voltl, 84, decided to help. Ms. Voltl had lent money to her friend before, and it had always been paid back. So without consulting a professional, she handed over $500,000.

headline: Choosing Stability Over Spectacle
abstract: The sinkhole that opened under the National Corvette Museum increased attendance, but the requirements and costs of maintaining it are forcing the museum to fill the hole.
lead_paragraph: BOWLING GREEN, KY. — What can you do with what may be the best-known sinkhole in history?

headline: Fixing a Hole, Despite Popular Demand
abstract: A sinkhole at the National Corvette Museum that gobbled up eight Corvettes last February will be filled rather than preserved as a draw for tourists.
lead_paragraph: A sinkhole at the National Corvette Museum that gobbled up eight Corvettes last February will be filled rather than preserved as a draw for tourists.

headline: Wallops of Exuberance With Traces of Yearning
abstract: Jack Antonoff, also the guitarist in Fun., performed with his new band, Bleachers, at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: It’s a perennially heartwarming story arc: Sensitive nerdy guy faces trauma, discovers his inner strength and emerges as a hero brimming with compassion. That’s the spirit of Jack Antonoff’s songs for Bleachers, which played to a sold-out crowd at Webster Hall on Thursday night. Fans responded to choruses like “I can’t believe I captured your heart” and “If you’re feeling small, I’ll love your shadow” with singalongs and joyful squeals.

headline: Getting a Real Charge Out of Ghostly Visitations
abstract: Based on “Ghost Asylum” and “Angels Among Us,” there just may be an alternative energy source to harness in the spirit world.
lead_paragraph: With surprisingly little fanfare, the great question that theologians and philosophers have wrestled with since antiquity has been answered: Our existence definitely, positively does not end with death. The dead hang around the worldly realm so their spirits can be used to power hair dryers and hot tubs.

headline: Don’t Tell the Parking Attendant: The New Corvette Is a Snitch
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Parking Garages and Lots']
abstract: The 2015 Corvette offers a built-in video camera for recording not only weekend track times but to also keep an eye on the valet.
lead_paragraph: Soon, every moment of your life may be recorded on video, even when you’re behind the wheel. Even when you’re driving someone else’s car.

headline: Melding Two Flickr Accounts Into One
abstract: Plus, pulling up a Google search by voice on your desktop computer.

headline: The 2014 Heisman Watch
abstract: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.
lead_paragraph: A look at the top players in contention for college football’s highest honor.

headline: The Arc of a Transgender Life
abstract: “As One,” Laura Kaminsky’s chamber opera about a transgender protagonist, has debuted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of operas are about characters finding themselves and their place in society. Laura Kaminsky’s “As One,” a chamber opera commissioned by American Opera Projects, which received its premiere on Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space, has a novel twist.

headline: Rarity Returns: Jazz Club for Duos
abstract: Mezzrow, a cozy jazz piano room in Greenwich Village, is the latest effort to fill a void left when Bradley’s closed in 1996.
lead_paragraph: Johnny O’Neal was smartly dressed for formalities on Wednesday night, in a tuxedo vest, for the first official set at Mezzrow, a spruce new addition to the Greenwich Village jazz circuit. But as he did his part to break in the room, he put little stock in ceremony.

headline: Salute the Seahawks, With a Hint of Pine Needles
abstract: Football fans from the Pacific Northwest will appreciate this week’s drink, while others might appreciate it from a safe distance.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season began Thursday night just the way last season ended: with a decisive victory by the Seattle Seahawks.

headline: John Paulson Bids Good Riddance to Summer
abstract: John A. Paulson’s hedge fund suffered across-the-board losses in July and did only marginally better in August, according to an update to investors.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund magnate John A. Paulson seemed to be enjoying himself at the United States Open on Wednesday night, watching Novak Djokovic defeat Andy Murray.

headline: Waleska Gorczevski Transforms Backstage at Jason Wu
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Waleska Gorczevski before (left) and after (right) makeup by Diane Kendall and hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: The Cavendish Invitational Opening Team Event
abstract: The Cavendish Invitational is the biggest money bridge tournament of the year.
lead_paragraph: The Cavendish Invitational started in New York City in 1975. It moved to Las Vegas in 1997. And since 2012, it has taken place in Monaco. It is the biggest money bridge tournament of the year.

headline: Preserving the Lighthouse, Not Just the Light
keywords: ['Lighthouses and Lightships', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: In recent years, New York-area lighthouses have been slowly rehabilitated, though in almost every case, their renovation and maintenance are being handled by people with little public funding.
lead_paragraph: Like many of the people who grew up in Port Ewen, N.Y., about 100 miles north of New York City along the Hudson River, Pat Ralston has a deep affection for the Esopus Meadows lighthouse. Perched on pilings about a half-mile offshore from the neighboring town of Esopus, the squat, white-clapboard house with a red tin roof was a landmark, and its keepers — who often lived there with their families — were local celebrities.

headline: Counting on Cannabis to Build Buzz
abstract: An indie distribution company tries to create a marijuana product tie-in to promote the film “Tusk,” set for a world premiere at the Toronto film festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In a daring marketing ploy, the indie film company A24 has struck a deal with a Los Angeles medical-marijuana dispensary to sell two new cannabis strains under brands associated with Kevin Smith’s outré horror flick, “Tusk.” The film, about a guy who is slowly turning into a walrus, is set for a world premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday night.

headline: The Human Condition in Soviet Ruins
abstract: Nadav Kander’s photos explore long-abandoned Soviet sites that didn’t even appear on maps until the fall of communism.
lead_paragraph: Nadav Kander’s photos explore long-abandoned Soviet sites that didn’t even appear on maps until the fall of communism.

headline: Nonoo: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: The Catwalk Leads to the Lounge
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: New bars, lounges and clubs that hope to lure the stylish pack.
lead_paragraph: New York night life is frequently maligned as sluggish and homogenized in comparison with its reckless past, but each September offers an opportunity for redemption. As usual, New York Fashion Week’s homecoming of debutantes and jet-setters coincides with a panoply of new options for depravity, each jostling for the fickle affections of the cool-kid aristocracy.

headline: The Question of Coverage for Ride Service Drivers
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Two companies that bring together drivers of private cars and potential passengers have been battling over who provides insurance, and when.
lead_paragraph: There is a pervasive attitude in a prominent corner of the technology industry that goes something like this: If you’re helping people rent (not share, rent) spare bedrooms or rides in their cars, then the usual regulations and niggling insurance issues should not apply. Entrepreneurs start useful services, attract millions of users, cross their fingers and hope nobody dies before the government minders and other scolds catch up.

headline: Martynka Wawrzyniak Turns Daily Meals Into Conceptual Art
abstract: The artist’s new show at Envoy Enterprises NYC includes a year’s worth of lunch and dinner napkins and sugar sculptures of body parts.
lead_paragraph: The artist Martynka Wawrzyniak has dedicated herself to “exposing and sharing very precise details of my daily private experiences,” she says. “It is up to the viewer to digest and interpret this collection of evidence and paint their own picture of my personality and lifestyle.” Beginning Sunday, her latest personal disclosure will hang from the ceiling of Envoy Enterprises NYC: a 100-foot-long polyester-cotton sculpture made from 365 dinner napkins stained with the imprint of Wawrzyniak’s lips during last year’s dinners. Nearby are 365 6-by-6-inch paper lunch napkins colored with mouth dabs following her morning consumption of vegan green juice. Both series are presented in chronological order — the fabric pieces sewn consecutively and the paper napkins framed in calendar formation. Connecting them thematically and corporally are castings of the interior of Wawrzyniak’s mouth and the hollow of her stomach made from sugar, a food that she avoids.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Happy Bill Murray Day!
abstract: The Toronto International Film Festival set aside a day to honor the actor, who joked, “It’s always been all about me. From the beginning.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — After days of semi-fervent speculation about whether the man himself would show, Bill Murray made a late-afternoon appearance at the Toronto International Film Festival, which had christened Friday “Bill Murray Day.”

headline: Off the Runway: Day 2

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the second day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Heir’s Not Apparent
abstract: A legal battle over the work of the photographer Vivian Maier could hide it away for years.
lead_paragraph: The story of the street photographer Vivian Maier has always been tangled — she worked much of her life as a nanny, keeping her artistic life a secret, and only after she died in 2009, at the age of 83, nearly penniless and with no family, were her pictures declared to be among the most remarkable of the 20th century. Now a court case in Chicago seeking to name a previously unknown heir is threatening to tie her legacy in knots and could prevent her work from being seen again for years.

headline: Photorealism’s Lasting Influence
abstract: “Still Life: 1970s Photorealism” is on view through Nov. 9 at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. The exhibition originally opened at the Yale University Art Gallery in 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Still Life: 1970s Photorealism” is on view through Nov. 9 at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. For information: (516) 484-9337 or nassaumuseum.org. The exhibition originally opened at the Yale University Art Gallery in 2013. Following are excerpts from Martha Schwendener’s review, published online in The New York Times on Feb. 7.

headline: Down Syndrome and Quality of Life
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article, “The Truth About Down Syndrome.”

headline: Sturdy Silver Sandals at Peter Som
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: footwear designed in collaboration with Christian Louboutin, which matched the easy vibe of the clothes.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Phragmites: A Fluffy Path to Global Rule
abstract: The great reed (Phragmites australis) is a handsome plant, especially at this time of year. But the reed’s beauty is little consolation for its rampant invasion of wetlands.
lead_paragraph: The great reed (Phragmites australis) is a handsome plant, especially at this time of year, when it is plumed with a purple shock of flowers airily waving 15 feet above our heads. But the reed’s beauty is little consolation for its rampant invasion of wetlands.

headline: Oil Spill Penalty Will Hurt, but Not Cripple, BP
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)']
abstract: The British oil company faces up to $18 billion in civil penalties, but appeals and a growing cash flow could limit the damage to its bottom line.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — BP fought long and hard to avoid the defeat it suffered in court on Thursday when a federal judge ruled that the oil company was chiefly responsible for the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion, opening the door to new civil penalties that could potentially amount to $18 billion.

headline: Unconventional Makeup Pointers Backstage at Jason Wu
abstract: The makeup artist Diane Kendal created a dewy eyeliner effect for a gaze reminiscent of her current muse, the British actress Charlotte Rampling.
lead_paragraph: Makeup artists often slick on creams and colors in ways that seem natural to their tribe but are rather unexpected for the rest of us. Consider the British pro Diane Kendal. Backstage at Jason Wu this morning, she traced Lancôme Le Crayon Khôl in Black Coffee, a dark brown liner, around models’ eyes, then grabbed some Q-Tips, dipped them in face cream and partially removed the strokes she had just laid down. It was puzzling until Kendal explained what she was doing. “The cream takes off some of the liner and leaves a beautiful residue and sheen on the lid,” she said. “This gives you that soft, dewy effect.” Another surprise: dabbing on Lancôme Aquatique Waterproof Eyecolour Base in Sienne, a brown primer of sorts, in lieu of eye shadow to define the eyes, without being obvious about it. The final look hinted at the cool, smoldering gaze of Kendal’s muse-of-the-moment: British actress Charlotte Rampling. Or any woman, for that matter, who is “sexy but in a natural, effortless way,” Kendal added.

headline: A Model’s Life, Chapter 2
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Models (Professional)', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Andreja Pejic’s claim to fame as a male model was a certain androgyny. Now that she’s a woman, will fashion’s doors still be open for her?
lead_paragraph: Andreja Pejic, who stands 6-foot-1 in stocking feet, and a good deal taller than that in heels, looks every bit the model. She is possessed of bottle-blond hair that falls past her shoulders, full lips, a wasp waist and a pair of Cindy Crawford beauty marks just north of her upper lip. (Even Ms. Crawford has only one.)

headline: Players in the Coalition Against ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration is now leading a coalition of nations to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is now leading a coalition of nations to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 2
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: It was a day filled with half-clothed male models, comments about shoes and tennis references. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, celebrities, media personalities and other fashion fans gathered at spots across Manhattan to celebrate the first day of New York Fashion Week. Morning brought heat, humidity and half-clothed male models strutting down the Parke & Ronen runway, though few complained. Shoes remained a topic of conversation for our writers as the shows went on. At Jason Wu, a 3-D, living, breathing Karlie Kloss made her first appearance at Fashion Week, while at Rebecca Minkoff the entertainment factor was turned up high with unexpected props. Other shows, such as Cushnie et Ochs, Wes Gordon and Adam Selman, kept the day exciting, and tennis was on the minds of some.

headline: U.S. Open Men’s Semifinals Feature 2 Rejuvenated High Seeds
abstract: Novak Djokovic, who will face Kei Nishikori, has recovered from his poor play at two lead-up events. Roger Federer, who will play Marin Cilic, survived match points in the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: The second Saturday of the United States Open is no longer super, with the women’s final moved to Sunday, but an afternoon of the men’s semifinals is still worthy of a pretty lofty adjective.

headline: Lessons in Brooklyn, Harlem and Whimsy
abstract: A look at two books on education issues in New York City and a newly reissued 1964 guidebook.
lead_paragraph: Think of them as back-to-school bookends to the last half-century of desperate and sometimes self-destructive debate over educational policy in New York.

headline: From Ashe to Williams, Rackets of U.S. Open Champions
abstract: The evolution of the tennis racket from wood to graphite has helped transform the sport into a game of power and spin.
lead_paragraph: The evolution of the tennis racket from wood to graphite has helped transform the sport into a game of power and spin.

headline: Andrew Kay, Pioneer in Computing, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Kay’s company Kaypro produced the Kaypro II computer, a hit in the 1980s, but fell into bankruptcy after being left behind by an industry coalescing around the MS-DOS operating system.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kay, the designer of an early portable computer, the Kaypro II, that became a smash hit in the early 1980s before his company fell into bankruptcy in the ’90s as the computer industry leapfrogged ahead of him, died on Aug. 28 in Vista, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Fixing Penn Station
abstract: Richard T. Anderson of the New York Building Congress responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Joan Rivers’s Funeral Instructions, Scarlett Johansson’s New Arrival and Karl Lagerfeld’s Mini-Me
abstract: Plus, Bill de Blasio attempts to show off his fashion cred, Gisele Bündchen keeps adding new campaigns and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Camping Out With the Office
abstract: WeWork, which rents shared office space, runs a short, adults-only summer camp for its members.
lead_paragraph: In the hope of finding fellowship with other entrepreneurs, David Heath decided to attend “Summer Camp” — a three-day networking and music festival in upstate New York hosted by WeWork, a company that rents shared office spaces. It was late August, the beginning of the off-season for summer camps like the one at which the event was held.

headline: How to Get Over That Ex
abstract: What is the lure of a finished relationship? And how do you get over it?
lead_paragraph: The God of Love, Plato wrote in “The Symposium,” “lives in a state of need.” Nowhere is this need more palpable and vibrant than in the lover who pines for an ex: to have once reached the mountaintop but now to find oneself deep in the valley is to fully apprehend the limited charms that lie at the intersection of flop sweat and a truculent burro.

headline: Christie’s Trip Looks Like a Campaign for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The tour of Mexico by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has some of the trappings of a presidential campaign, with local traffic stopping for his motorcade, with aides enforcing protocol and with efforts to put the governor in the best possible light.
lead_paragraph: PUEBLA, Mexico — Perhaps it was the war room set up for Gov. Chris Christie’s staff in a hotel here, filled at all hours with laptop-wielding aides and a generous supply of beef medallions with green peppers.

headline: A Manhattan Post Office Is the Only Address Some People Have
abstract: Armando Calderon is one of many who share a single mailing address: 390 Ninth Avenue, New York City’s main post office, is where the homeless get mail — or don’t.
lead_paragraph: The men and women start lining up around 9:45 a.m. along an imposing gray wall of the James A. Farley Post Office, that grand Manhattan landmark with sweeping front steps and soaring columns facing Eighth Avenue.

headline: Since Nazi Occupation, a Fist Raised in Resistance
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In 1941, Manolis Glezos and a friend ripped the Nazi flag down from the Acropolis in Athens. Now 92, he continues to take to the ramparts as a leftist member of the European Parliament.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — AS protests swirled in Athens during the Greek financial crisis, a silver-haired octogenarian could be seen on the front lines, raising a fist at the riot police as they shot tear gas into his face. Other times, even on the same day, the same man might be standing in front of Parliament, insisting that lawmakers repudiate an austerity package demanded by the country’s creditors, which he said would only throw Greece into greater hardship.

headline: Homegrown Plays Reach New Jersey’s Stages
abstract: Six premieres by playwrights with ties to the Garden State are scheduled to be part of the state’s 2014-15 professional theater season.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, I am totally taking over New Jersey,” said Nikkole Salter, laughing. The Obie Award-winning co-author of the AIDS drama “In the Continuum,” Ms. Salter will have new plays produced at Luna Stage and Crossroads Theater Company this season.

headline: Atlantic City’s Next Gamble
abstract: Lessons from the boss of the original boardwalk empire.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — NUCKY JOHNSON’S town can still throw a party. Tens of thousands of fans recently flocked to Atlantic City for two free concerts on the water’s edge, first by Blake Shelton and then by Lady Antebellum. With casinos shutting their doors, leaving thousands jobless, these are just the type of fun events that the resort city needs if it is to survive. But some businesses misbehaved. Several casinos charged concertgoers $50 for parking, five to 10 times the usual rate. Some people in this city never miss the opportunity to sacrifice long-term vision for a fast buck.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius Covers John Lennon
abstract: Soothes the soul.
lead_paragraph: I was going to do something clever and all, but my heart wasn’t in it after a very tough week. Here’s one of my favorite bands doing a lovely cover:

keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Google, Apple, Intel and Adobe filed papers asking the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals to spurn Judge Lucy H. Koh’s rejection of their $324.5 million antitrust settlement as too meager.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley is holding on tight to its wallet.

headline: Passion for the Pill
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: In Congressional races across the country, women’s issues are looming large. Just listen to some of the Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: Republican candidates are falling madly in love with contraception.

headline: Jobs Stall and So Does the Economy
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Editorials', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Plentiful jobs at good pay, the critical underpinning of a strong economy, are still not in the cards.
lead_paragraph: The employment report for August suggests that any remaining hope for an economic upsurge in the second half of 2014 is largely unrealistic. The new data, which shows job creation down sharply last month, is consistent with more of the same sluggish growth that has long been the norm. Plentiful jobs at good pay — the critical underpinning of a strong economy — are still not in the cards.

headline: Two Cities With Blazing Internet Speed Search for a Killer App
abstract: Both Kansas City, Mo., and Kansas City, Kan., have Google Fiber, a high-speed fiber-optic network, and are having a hard time figuring out what to do with so much power.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A team of computer programmers here set out to learn how many cute kitten photos can be downloaded in one second on their Internet network, one of the fastest in the country.

headline: On Wheels, Too, the Game Shifts Toward Speed
abstract: With better chairs and more mobile athletes, the pace of wheelchair tennis is getting quicker, and players are using harder shots with more spin.
lead_paragraph: Like the tennis being played at Arthur Ashe Stadium, wheelchair tennis has become faster-paced with more of a reliance on power.

headline: N. Hoolywood: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: In California Governor’s Race, the Risks of Running a Low-Risk Campaign
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown faces a little-known challenger, as well as the possibility of a second term without a voter mandate or much political capital.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — When the one-and-only scheduled debate in the California race for governor came to its end Thursday evening, the moderator, remarking on how spirited it had been, suggested that Gov. Jerry Brown, the Democrat, agree to another.

headline: T-Mobile Accuses Huawei of Theft From Laboratory
abstract: T-Mobile said in a lawsuit filed in Seattle that thefts by employees of the Chinese smartphone maker included part of a robotic arm used for testing handsets.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile has filed a lawsuit against the Chinese smartphone maker Huawei Technologies, accusing the manufacturer of stealing technology, including part of a robot’s arm, from T-Mobile’s Bellevue, Wash., headquarters.

headline: Charlie Powell, a Standout Regardless of the Sport, Dies at 82
abstract: Described by a San Diego newspaper as “arguably the greatest athlete ever to come out of San Diego County,” Powell excelled at pro football, baseball and boxing.
lead_paragraph: The often-told story about Charlie Powell is that as a 20-year-old defensive end playing his first game for the San Francisco 49ers in 1952, he sacked Bobby Layne, the legendary quarterback for the Detroit Lions, 10 times.

headline: Out to the Cemetery, It’s Showtime Again!
abstract: The Gateway Playhouse version of “The Addams Family,” in Bellport, alters the Broadway production, and the changes make for an engaging show.
lead_paragraph: Uncle Fester floats through the air as he sings a love song to the moon. Gomez is torn between a promise to his daughter to keep a secret and his pledge to keep no secrets from his wife, Morticia. Wednesday, their daughter, is in love. Pugsley, her younger brother, just likes to wallow in torture.

headline: New York Will Require More Builders to Add Affordable Units
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Zoning']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s planning chief, Carl Weisbrod, disclosed a new policy to spur construction of housing for low- or middle-income residents.
lead_paragraph: The next time a New York City developer seeks permission to replace a derelict factory with a shimmering condo tower, the heated swimming pool and sky-lit roof lounge will have to be accompanied by another amenity: affordable housing.

headline: Indian Leader’s Talk to Schoolchildren Draws Fire
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who rarely speaks to reporters, answered children’s questions on Friday as part of a nationwide broadcast to mark Teacher’s Day. His opponents said the event highlighted the heavy-handedness of his government.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday appeared before millions of India’s schoolchildren, answering respectful questions with an avuncular twinkle for an hour and a half, and telling stories about his own school days.

headline: Fox Sports Develops Champions League Highlights Channel
abstract: Fox Sports plans to broadcast the group stage of the UEFA Champions League with Multimatch 90, a channel similar to NFL RedZone that will show up to eight games at a time.
lead_paragraph: When DirecTV introduced its Red Zone Channel in 2005, N.F.L. fans discovered a new way to watch Sunday afternoon games. Instead of sticking with one game from start to finish, or toggling between two network games, the Red Zone took viewers on a frenetic, stadium-hopping tour to show teams advancing closer to end zones.

headline: The ‘Secure Communities’ Illusion
abstract: A federal program intended to improve public safety by deporting unauthorized immigrants convicted of crimes had no effect on the crime rate.
lead_paragraph: Who could fault a program with a name like “Secure Communities”? This is the federal initiative, begun under President George W. Bush and vastly expanded by President Obama, to make sure that everyone arrested by local police anywhere in the country has his or her immigration status checked.

headline: Focused Ferocity by Serena Williams on a Stage She Owns at the U.S. Open
abstract: Having won her semifinal against Ekaterina Makarova in one hour, Williams is poised to capture her third U.S. Open title in a row.
lead_paragraph: If there is one tennis showplace that has been Serena Williams’s proving ground, it is Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: The Price of Glory
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Football (College)', 'Executive Compensation', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Football', 'Research']
abstract: College football coaches are grossly overpaid — just like C.E.O.s.
lead_paragraph: “Are Football Coaches Overpaid?” asks a new paper by two Vanderbilt University professors, Randall S. Thomas of the law school, and R. Lawrence Van Horn of the school of management. It’s amazing the things academics can find worthy of study, isn’t it?

headline: A Cease-Fire in Ukraine
abstract: It would be a mistake to assume that the agreement guarantees a quick or easy path to stability for the country.
lead_paragraph: With pressures building on all sides, the adversaries in the war in Ukraine announced a cease-fire on Friday. Combat in the contested southeastern region that killed some 2,600 people in the past five months paused, perhaps for a while.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 5, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Cuomo Assuming Campaign Mode Just Days Before Votes Are Cast
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is expected to win his primary on Tuesday, is making his first outing in an election season in which he has largely ignored his opponent, Zephyr Teachout.
lead_paragraph: Heading into the final weekend before the primary, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is starting to look like a candidate.

headline: Iran Fails to Address All Nuclear Concerns, U.N. Says
abstract: Prospects for an agreement over Iran’s nuclear program appeared to suffer a setback when a United Nations monitoring agency said the Iranians had yet to meet two measures to ensure that their activities are peaceful.
lead_paragraph: Prospects for an international agreement over Iran’s disputed nuclear program appeared to suffer a setback Friday when a United Nations monitoring agency said the Iranians had yet to meet two of five confidence-building measures to ensure that their activities are purely peaceful.

headline: Getting the Catch Directly to the Restaurant
abstract: Dock to Dish delivers catch to restaurants within 24 hours, creating a farm-to-table framework for seafood that some high-caliber chefs are taking advantage of.
lead_paragraph: When Dock to Dish became an instant success in Montauk last summer, it made sense. The community-supported fishery dovetailed with a growing sustainable fishing movement and a community-supported agriculture initiative already embraced by many locals. People could now pick up their black sea bass alongside their baskets of pea shoots and snapdragons — all they had to do was pay upfront and take what the ocean provided.

headline: Offering Designers a Blank Canvas
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: From vacant spaces she makes glittering white boxes, in which designers and companies paint their vision.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, if you have attended runway shows for Ralph Lauren, Prabal Gurung or Edun, or been to parties for the Whitney Museum of American Art or Google product debuts, you’ve been to an event held with the Skylight Group.

headline: Hope for Japan, Decades After a Disturbing Loss
abstract: Kei Nishikori is the first Japanese man to reach a Grand Slam singles semifinal since Jiro Satoh, who threw himself off a ship a year after playing in a semifinal at Wimbledon in 1933.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon at the United States Open, Kei Nishikori will become the first Japanese man to compete in a Grand Slam singles semifinal in 81 years.

headline: Bruce Morton, Veteran CBS News Reporter, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Morton, who covered major news events such as the Vietnam War and the space program, gained a reputation as a solid reporter of expansive breadth and expertise.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Morton, an award-winning reporter during what CBS News veterans considered the organization’s glory days, from the 1960s through the 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 83.

headline: Another Life in the Many Lives of Zaldy
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Zaldy returns to New York Fashion Week, where he says, “I just want to do my pure vision and see it through.”
lead_paragraph: Hanging upside down on a support pillar in Zaldy’s spacious atelier is what looks like a body wrapped in garbage bags ready to be disposed of in the New Jersey marshlands.

headline: A Conductor Promotes Risk-Taking in Music Programs
abstract: Toshiyuki Shimada seeks to redefine the boundaries of the Eastern Connecticut Symphony Orchestra and the Yale Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Coolly chatting last month amid the commotion at Yale’s soon-to-be-renovated Hendrie Hall, Toshiyuki Shimada hardly seemed the type to make waves. But that is what Mr. Shimada, the music director and conductor of both the Eastern Connecticut Symphony Orchestra and the Yale Symphony Orchestra, has done.

headline: A Noise Only He Can Hear Doesn’t Keep García From a Round for All to See
abstract: Sergio García had 12 putts through 12 holes and finished with 21 on his way to a second-round 64 and a one-shot advantage at the BMW Championship.
lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — Sergio García became aware of a beeping sound in his left ear on the sixth green of his round on Friday at Cherry Hills Country Club. He kept yawning and stretching his jaw to try to make his ear pop, to no avail.

headline: A Mixed Bag of Looks: Coach, Peter Som, Jason Wu and Creatures of the Wind
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Alexandra Jacobs reviews the collections of Coach, Peter Som, Jason Wu and Creatures of the Wind.
lead_paragraph: Coach has left the stable, and the horses are running wild down the road.

headline: Marjorie Strider Dies at 83; Pop Artist Satirized Men’s Magazines
abstract: Ms. Strider slyly subverted her male counterparts’ takes on consumerism and the female form.
lead_paragraph: Marjorie Strider, a Pop artist who slyly subverted her male counterparts’ takes on consumerism and the female form, creating images of packages that oozed their contents and women whose curves jutted from the picture plane, died on Aug. 27 at her home in Saugerties, N.Y. She was 83.

headline: Fresh-Hued Cuisine in a Rustic Home
abstract: One Twenty One, in North Salem, has a great-looking redesign and a new farm-to-fork menu, both all the more appealing for their lack of pretense.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on the veranda at One Twenty One on an August night, with cicadas whirring like windup toys, we sipped wine, ate homemade pickles and watched the traffic go by. The driver of an equestrian tractor-trailer, its sides emblazoned with the word “HORSES,” applied his spluttering Jake brakes and tooted his horn. The young man at the wheel of a hot little Mitsubishi revved his engine and laid rubber in a show of machismo. A pickup truck towing a speedboat, its bed crowded with inner tubes and waving revelers, slowed to the pace of a float in a small-town parade.

headline: Monique Lhuillier: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Things That Didn’t Happen in ‘Miss Julie’
abstract: Four short plays examine various aspects of “Miss Julie,” August Strindberg’s 1888 drama about a chauffeur and the boss’s daughter.
lead_paragraph: A staple of the theater is deconstructed, reconstructed, teased or rewritten through the sensibilities of four different writers in “Bastards of Strindberg,” a collection of short plays inspired by “Miss Julie,” being presented at the Lion Theater by the Scandinavian American Theater Company. August Strindberg’s heated drama about the combustion that occurs when a footman and a count’s daughter spend a tempestuous night together has remained surprisingly present on both stage and screen. A new film version with Jessica Chastain and Colin Farrell is due soon, and a South African production was acclaimed when it played at St. Ann’s Warehouse in 2012. Now the play has been put under a refracting lens by two Swedish writers, Lina Ekdahl and Andreas Boonstra, and two Americans, David Bar Katz and Dominique Morisseau.

headline: Most Seeming-Virtuous Queen
abstract: A throwback to my childhood, by James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle by James Mulhern made me feel like a child again.

headline: Dressed for the New Idea of Success: Carlos Campos, David Hart, Lucio Castro
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Dressed-down men’s shows acknowledge the less formal reality of the workplace.
lead_paragraph: The thorny challenge faced by men’s wear designers is how to make an impact within a narrow design compass without resorting to outright gimmickry.

headline: At Cemetery, a Worker Falls Down on the Job
abstract: What happened to a grave digger in Queens could have been a scene in a black comedy: He slipped and fell into a grave.
lead_paragraph: They say grave diggers are the last ones to let you down.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 7 Michigan State visits No. 3 Oregon in a marquee nonconference game and No. 14 Southern California faces No. 13 Stanford this weekend.
lead_paragraph: 7 MICHIGAN STATE at 3 OREGON

headline: In Connecticut Ex-Governor’s Trial, a Window Onto Political Strategizing
abstract: Brian Foley, the husband of a former congressional candidate, testified in federal court about a meeting with former Gov. John G. Rowland that led to Mr. Rowland’s hiring as a campaign consultant.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — When Lisa Wilson-Foley, a Republican political hopeful in Connecticut, entered the 2012 congressional race, she and her husband, Brian Foley, had lots of money but not necessarily the political seasoning of some of her rivals.

headline: Rare Outbreak of Dengue Fever in Japan
abstract: Japan’s health minister on Friday urged the public not to panic after a popular park in central Tokyo was closed because of a rare outbreak of dengue fever.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s health minister on Friday urged the public not to panic after a popular park in central Tokyo was closed because of a rare outbreak of dengue fever. The Ministry of Health said that 70 people had been found infected with the dengue virus in the past week, in what it called the first outbreak in Japan since 1945. Dengue, which causes fevers and in rare cases death, is common in tropical climates, but not in temperate Japan. Officials said global warming might be playing a role in the spread of dengue to places like Tokyo. This year, Japan had an unusually hot and humid summer. The ministry said most of the people found infected had spent time in or near Yoyogi Park, where they were most likely bitten by mosquitoes that carried the disease. On Friday, health workers sprayed pesticides in the park to kill the insects. No one has died in the outbreak.

headline: A 65-Ton Dinosaur as a Distraction From NATO, Ukraine and ISIS
abstract: The important news was the convergence of a NATO summit meeting, the beginnings of a cease-fire in Ukraine and the commitment to destroy ISIS.
lead_paragraph: The important news was the convergence of a NATO summit meeting, the beginnings of a cease-fire in Ukraine and the commitment to destroy ISIS. Those events will shape the world. The news that won’t change anything is the discovery of a humongous dinosaur, and yet that may have been the most compelling story.

headline: Toronto Mayor Called to Testify in Canada
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Rob Ford, the mayor of Toronto, told reporters on Friday that he had been subpoenaed to testify at a court hearing related to efforts by his unofficial driver to recover a video showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine.
lead_paragraph: Rob Ford, the mayor of Toronto, told reporters on Friday that he had been subpoenaed to testify at a court hearing related to efforts by his unofficial driver to recover a video showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine. The driver, Alexander Lisi, was charged with extortion in connection with his efforts to recover the video, apparently made by drug dealers. Mr. Ford, who declined to comment further, will be required to appear next spring at a hearing to determine if there is enough evidence to send Mr. Lisi’s case to trial. Mr. Ford has confessed to smoking crack and excessive drinking.

headline: Washington Stopped Here; So Did Brando
abstract: Ordinary, a bar opened a year and a half ago in a vaunted historic space in New Haven, serves salty, savory dishes that stand up to complex cocktails and robust draft beers.
lead_paragraph: Outside New York City, good bar food can be dismayingly hard to find. Manhattan and Brooklyn proprietors have been nudging their bar menus into artisanal territory for a while; in the suburbs, though, many offerings seem stuck in a pre-Food Network wasteland of greasy wings and defrosted mozzarella sticks.

headline: In Remote Detention Center, a Battle on Fast Deportations
abstract: A corps of volunteers is changing the nature and purpose of a temporary outpost that the Obama administration set up to hold illegal immigrants briefly until they could be deported.
lead_paragraph: ARTESIA, N.M. — Sitting before a small video screen in a bare room in a remote corner of New Mexico, a young Honduran woman told her story this week to an immigration judge in Virginia. She had been serially raped, she said, spat upon and relentlessly hounded by a drug-dealing husband who regarded her as his property.

headline: Hague Prosecutors Ask to Delay Opening of Kenyan President’s Trial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday asked for another delay in starting the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, saying that they could not proceed because the government had so far refused to hand over most of the information they had requested.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday asked for another delay in starting the trial of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, saying that they could not proceed because the government had so far refused to hand over most of the information they had requested, including some of Mr. Kenyatta’s phone and financial records. Mr. Kenyatta, who took office in 2013, is accused of stoking violence after the 2007 election that left more than 1,000 people dead. His trial was to have started in February but it was postponed until Oct. 7 after prosecutors said key witnesses had been intimidated and access to others had been blocked. The three judges assigned to the case must decide whether to delay the trial again or end the proceedings for lack of evidence.

She had bruises and cuts. She told classmates she was being abused. Then she landed in the emergency room, her face swollen; dirty and emaciated.

headline: Candidate Not on Providence Primary Ballot Stirs Mayoral Field
abstract: With signature bombast and zeal, Vincent A. Cianci Jr. has exerted outsize influence as candidates scrambled to avoid indirectly helping him by splitting the vote.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — It seemed outlandish, unbelievable at first. Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the infamous former mayor of Providence whose two administrations were both cut short by felony convictions, announced earlier this summer that he wanted his old job back. With every ounce of the bombast and zeal that has, over the past several decades, made him this city’s premier practitioner of chutzpah, the man who served more than four years in federal prison is running for another four years as mayor.

More than a hundred worshipers had gathered well before the 10 a.m. Mass, and they were already chanting morning prayers in the language of their Lord.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) 12 YEARS A SLAVE (2013) In this Oscar winner for best picture, written by John Ridley and directed by Steve McQueen, Chiwetel Ejiofor, above, portrays Solomon Northup, a free African-American man who, in 1841, was kidnapped in Washington and sold into slavery. Paul Giamatti plays the brutish Louisiana trader who sells Solomon to William Ford (Benedict Cumberbatch), a seemingly decent plantation owner, who in turn sells him to Edwin Epps (Michael Fassbender) a drunken madman, who epitomizes the villainy of slave ownership. Lupita Nyong’o won a best supporting actress Oscar for her turn as Patsey, Epp’s favorite, whom he brutalizes. “Mr. McQueen’s sympathies are as unqualified as his control,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “There is much to admire about ‘12 Years a Slave,’ including the cleareyed, unsentimental quality of its images — this is a place where trees hang with beautiful moss and black bodies — and how Mr. Ejiofor’s restrained, open, translucent performance works as a ballast, something to cling onto, especially during the frenzies of violence.” And while these scenes are hard to watch, “the genius of ‘12 Years a Slave’ is its insistence on banal evil, and on terror, that seeped into souls, bound bodies and reaped an enduring, terrible price.”

headline: Breaking Loose From Big Festivals
abstract: Festivals, with their multiple stages and thousands upon thousands of attendees, are meant to serve as escapes.
lead_paragraph: Festivals, with their multiple stages and thousands upon thousands of attendees, are meant to serve as escapes. But what about when you need to escape from festivals? This weekend, just north of New York City, two separate events attempt to reclaim the idea of festivals for people seeking something more intimate.

headline: Glass and Reich Share a Stage
abstract: Artists frequently dislike the labels assigned to their work: Philip Glass prefers “music with repetitive structures” to “minimalism,” for example.
lead_paragraph: Artists frequently dislike the labels assigned to their work: Philip Glass prefers “music with repetitive structures” to “minimalism,” for example. But the minimalist label has stuck. As part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival, Mr. Glass will be joined by Steve Reich, another pioneer of the genre, for three programs that illustrate their aesthetic with some of their best-known works. The two ensembles they founded will perform, and for the first time in more than three decades, the two composers will collaborate onstage during several selections.

headline: Nucky Thompson, Back in the Day
abstract: HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire” begins its fifth and final season, debuting Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Be honest and true, boys/Whatever you do, boys/Let this be your motto through life,” a woman recites as a battalion of lads flit like fish through a watery underworld, grasping at gold coins raining down. Cut to the pier above, where the wealthy are toasting their sun-kissed summer by tossing away their money in Atlantic City, circa 1884. Thus begins the origin story of Nucky Thompson, a very good boy (played by Nolan Lyons) until Commodore Louis Kaestner, the power broker who becomes his mentor, gets hold of him in HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire.” Nearly 50 years later, the adult Nucky (Steve Buscemi) is fighting to go legit by courting the Bacardi Rum family in Cuba in the series’s fifth and final season, debuting Sunday. But as he gazes down at boys diving into the Havana harbor, his mind returns to his stormy New Jersey childhood, now a world apart in every conceivable sense.

headline: Olden Goldies and Wild Cards
abstract: It’s time to fall into dance: City Center’s 2014 Fall for Dance Festival unveils an early kickoff with two free evenings at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to fall into dance: City Center’s 2014 Fall for Dance Festival unveils an early kickoff with two free evenings at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. Presented in association with the Public Theater, the program covers a wealth of dance styles and just as many moods. The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company reprises Mr. Jones’s “D-Man in the Waters (Part 1),” created in 1989 in the thick of the AIDS crisis — it’s a piece about loss, resiliency and hope — while New York City Ballet offers William Forsythe’s “Herman Schmerman (Pas de Deux),” a sinuous duet set to an electronic score by Thom Willems. Hubbard Street Dance Chicago explores the heat of North Africa and Spain in “Gnawa,” Nacho Duato’s lively 2005 group work.

headline: Rossellini’s Eternal City
abstract: Many elements set the stage for Roberto Rossellini’s 1945 neorealist masterpiece, “Rome Open City.”
lead_paragraph: Many elements set the stage for Roberto Rossellini’s 1945 neorealist masterpiece, “Rome Open City,” his portrait of the Italian resistance under the Nazis, coming to Film Forum on Friday for two weeks in a new restoration. A city pockmarked by bombs and wartime poverty offered a gritty backdrop; Rossellini assembled a formidable crew, including Federico Fellini as a screenwriter and the actors Aldo Fabrizi and Anna Magnani (both better known for comic roles at the time); and he was ready to doff studio confinements and shoot on streets and rooftops to capture a documentarylike veracity.

headline: Calligraphy as Visual Poetry
abstract: Calligraphy has always been the premier classical art of the Islamic world.
lead_paragraph: Calligraphy has always been the premier classical art of the Islamic world, and it comes in many forms, some practical and workaday, others subtly expressive, reserved for religious texts and poetry. When produced by highly skilled hands, the style called “nasta’liq,” developed in Persia from the 14th to 16th centuries, is considered so beautiful as to be an aesthetic end in itself: Use it to copy a page from the phone book, and you’d still have visual poetry.

headline: Variety: A Very Berry Acrostic
abstract: An acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that you may find to be very berry.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I was planning to write this entire column substituting the “b” sound for the “m” sound, like in today’s quotation about holding one’s nose, but decided against it. It’s too buch, sorry, too much to ask of even the most stalwart copy editor.

headline: 1914: Despite War, ‘New York Herald’ to Stay in Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The New York Herald remains in Paris, despite the War.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Beginning with this issue, the price of the HERALD will be 25 centimes daily, instead of 15 centimes. The reasons for the increase are obvious. Owing to the war, advertisements, the main source of revenue for a newspaper, have almost completely disappeared. The HERALD at present is, therefore, being run at a loss of close upon 35,000 francs a week. That may be journalism, but it is not business. Consequently, the HERALD has to choose between suspending publication or raising its price.

headline: As Crises Pile Up, a President Sticks to His Deliberative Approach
abstract: President Obama’s determination to move deliberately and line up support from allies before confronting threats means that he has sometimes appeared to be a spectator to events outside his control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On his way to Europe last week for a crucial NATO summit meeting, President Obama passed a mostly sleepless night.

headline: The Jack Ma Way
abstract: Alibaba, started by Jack Ma in 1999, is about to sell shares in the United States that could value the company at about $160 billion.
lead_paragraph: At the resplendent China World Hotel in Beijing, scores of cameras snapped as colorful confetti floated down from the ceiling. It was Aug. 11, 2005, and this was the global coming-out party for Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce upstart. After months of frantic negotiations, the American Internet giant Yahoo had agreed to invest $1 billion in cash and create deeper business ties, in exchange for a 40 percent stake in Alibaba.

headline: Own a Piece of a PGA Tour Pro? A Start-Up Embraces That Idea

lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — Imagine if the opening bell rang next month on the new wraparound golf season and you owned stock in the next Jimmy Walker, whose fever chart in 2013-14 exhibited the same arc as a majestic drive. He won his first three PGA Tour events and is a lock for the season-ending Tour Championship.

lead_paragraph: LEBEDINSKOYE, Ukraine — The cease-fire between the Ukrainian government and Russian-backed separatists appeared in danger Saturday after just a day as several artillery barrages resumed around the city of Mariupol.

lead_paragraph: PINK HILL, N.C. — On many mornings, as tobacco plants tower around her, Saray Cambray Alvarez pulls a black plastic garbage bag over her 13-year-old body to protect her skin from leaves dripping with nicotine-tinged dew.

lead_paragraph: Serena Williams knows the drill. On Sunday, when she looks across the net during the United States Open women’s singles final, she will see a player she knows all too well and a person she absolutely adores. And this time it will not be her sister Venus.

headline: Limbo and Cruelty at Guantánamo
abstract: The decaying prison should have been closed years ago.
lead_paragraph: In the hideous beheadings of two American journalists, the Islamist killers dressed their victims in bright orange prison garb. This was widely taken as an allusion to the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba — the nightmarish American outpost where detainees have been held for 12 years and counting.

headline: From Bad to Worse With Ebola
abstract: A more coordinated and aggressive global effort is needed to fight the worsening Ebola outbreak in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: The widening epidemic of Ebola in West Africa looks worse with each passing day. The outbreaks in the hardest-hit countries — Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone — have outstripped the ability of humanitarian groups and fragile government health systems to treat the sick and slow the spread.

headline: Meant as Portraits, Seen as Hagiography

headline: Rape and Rotherham
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Priests', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The grim story shows how exploitation can flourish in different cultural contexts, and how insufficient any set of pieties can be to its restraint.
lead_paragraph: THERE are enough grim tidings from around the world that the news from Rotherham, a faded English industrial town where about 1,400 girls, mostly white and working class, were raped by gangs of Pakistani men while the local authorities basically shrugged and did nothing, is already slipping out of American headlines.

headline: Demanding More From College
abstract: In a world of many separate camps, college can and should be a bridge.
lead_paragraph: I’M beginning to think that college exists mainly so we can debate and deconstruct it.

headline: Is It WWIII or Just Twitter?
