headline: Leading From Within
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What’s the best way for the United States to address both ISIS and Vladimir Putin at once?
lead_paragraph: I DON’T know what action will be sufficient to roll back both the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, and Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, but I do know what’s necessary. And it’s not “leading from behind,” which didn’t really work for President Obama in Libya, and it isn’t simply leading a lonely and unpopular charge from in front, which certainly didn’t work for President Bush in Iraq. It’s actually reviving America’s greatest strategy: leading from within.

headline: Challenging the President ... but Only on the Golf Course
abstract: Marvin Nicholson, the White House travel director, who has played golf with the president about 140 times, rounds out the president’s foursomes and soothes his frayed feelings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At age 4, Marvin Nicholson hit his first golf ball on the nine-hole course his father had mowed into the front of the family’s farm in Ontario. By 7, he had won a Canada Dry Ginger Ale trophy for sinking a hole in one at the local public course. He caddied through college, carried Senator John Kerry’s clubs in Nantucket and then lugged so many of Mr. Kerry’s bags during the 2004 presidential campaign that he distributed business cards stamped with “Chief of Stuff.”

headline: From a Texas Company to a Political Maelstrom in the Syrian Civil War
abstract: The director of operations for a Texas-based telecommunications company became interim prime minister of the Syrian opposition coalition.
lead_paragraph: MURPHY, Tex. — Syrian politics were far from Suzanne Hitto’s mind when her husband called last year to tell her to hire a lawyer. She had not seen him in months, and he had already surprised her by quitting his job. Her first thought, sitting alone in her home in the Dallas suburb of Murphy, Tex., was that he wanted a divorce.

keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Parenting', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Children and Childhood', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: Judges can decide whether your kids play soccer or piano.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — MY wife and I disagree, sometimes vehemently, about how best to raise our four children. She’s a lawyer, and I am sure the thought of suing me has crossed her mind once or twice. But she cannot. American courts consistently refuse to entertain child-rearing disputes between married parents.

headline: Money and Influence in the Think Tank World
keywords: ['Think Tanks', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Foreign governments are a major source of money for think tanks in Washington, making donations, in many cases, with a goal of trying to influence United States foreign policy. The think tanks offer the donor governments special access to United States government officials, at times in exchange for the financial support. Here is a look at these ties.

headline: Center for Global Development and Norway
keywords: ['Think Tanks', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Norway entered into an agreement with the Center for Global Development, a Washington-based think tank that focuses on “how policies and actions of the rich and powerful affect poor people in the developing world.” The center was to work with Climate Advisers, a consulting firm, to persuade policy makers in the United States and other countries to increase funding for forest-protection programs, a top foreign policy priority of Norway. Such programs are known by the acronym REDD, for “reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation.”

abstract: Norway signed agreements with both the Center for Strategic and International Studies and Brookings asking the think tanks to conduct research focusing on issues related to the Arctic Circle and climate change. Norway has long been a global leader in pushing for action to combat climate change. Its state-owned oil company, Statoil, is also preparing to begin oil exploration work in the area, where large-scale melting in recent years has been attributed to climate change and global warming.

headline: Nick Bollettieri on the Dinosaur That Is the One-Handed Backhand
abstract: The legendary tennis coach who was recently inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame discusses the benefits and drawbacks of a disappearing stroke.
lead_paragraph: Wimbledon was where I did most of the reporting for my recent article on the fate of the one-handed backhand. Late in the afternoon on my last day there, I ran into the legendary tennis coach Nick Bollettieri. He was en route to an interview and I was heading for the airport, so our conversation about the one-hander was brief. A few days after my article was published, however, he emailed to say he wanted to talk some more about the one-hander. So last Saturday we met at the U.S. Open for that conversation. The 83-year-old Bollettieri was recently inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame, an honor granted in recognition of his role in nurturing some of the sport’s greatest talents, including Andre Agassi, Maria Sharapova, Monica Seles and Jim Courier. (Another Bollettieri disciple, the Japanese player Kei Nishikori, reached the semifinals of this year’s Open with a five-set victory Wednesday over Stan Wawrinka, who has what many consider today’s best one-handed backhand.)

headline: Two Young Stars Lead Teams to W.N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Chicago and Elena Delle Donne will face Phoenix and Brittney Griner in the W.N.B.A. finals when the best-of-five series begins Sunday in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Travel perks are scarce in the W.N.B.A., which requires its teams to fly in coach class to limit costs. So Elena Delle Donne of the Chicago Sky, who has been bothered lately by a sore back, felt especially grateful Friday morning as she settled into her seat on the Sky’s flight to Phoenix.

headline: A Note on the Dynamics of Misinformation
abstract: Fossils as well as zombies.
lead_paragraph: Very busy, so no substantive posting today. But I did want to share a thought from the past few days. I posted about the surprisingly good news, at least so far, on Obamacare premiums for 2015 — and as usual was met with a wall of rage from the right. The idea that this thing might be working inspires a level of anger nothing else (except maybe climate science) matches.

headline: An IndyCar Champion Who Stays Sharp by Driving Go-Karts
abstract: Will Power, the 2014 IndyCar champion, said in an interview that he was a big fan of rugby and cricket in his native Australia.
lead_paragraph: Will Power won his first IndyCar championship on Aug. 30 after finishing second in the series three times in the past four years. Among the perks of being champion were a visit to “Late Show With David Letterman” on Thursday and good seats to Roger Federer’s comeback victory over Gaël Monfils at the United States Open that night. That is nothing compared with the reception that awaits him in his hometown, Toowoomba, Australia. He is the first Australian champion of a major motor sports series since 1980. Power, 33, talked to editors of The New York Times last week about his journey. The interview has been condensed and edited.

headline: Evidence Grows of Russian Orthodox Clergy’s Aiding Ukraine Rebels
abstract: The Russian Orthodox Church has denied supporting separatist turmoil in Ukraine, but after rebels seized Slovyansk, evidence accumulated of close ties between the church and the pro-Russian cause.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — On an overcast day in April, staff members at the municipal museum in this eastern Ukrainian town noticed strange goings-on next door at a cultural center run by the Ukrainian arm of the Russian Orthodox Church.

headline: Kansas Governor Hopefuls Hurl Barbs in First Debate
abstract: Sam Brownback, the Republican incumbent, has found himself caught in a tough battle with Paul Davis, the largely unknown Democratic challenger, despite the state’s rich conservatism.
lead_paragraph: HUTCHINSON, Kan. — Debating for the first time in a tight governor’s race, the two major candidates offered few specifics on their visions for the state, but lobbed sharp attacks at one another Saturday before a feisty crowd at the Kansas State Fair that seemed befitting of a football game.

headline: To Draw in New Crowds, an Industry Bets on Itself
abstract: With the lure of quick cash winnings, Japan’s industry around the game of pachinko — part pinball, part roulette — is trying to reinvent itself by appealing to new customers and by cleaning up its image.
lead_paragraph: NAGOYA, Japan — Part pinball and part roulette, with the lure of quick cash winnings and little silver balls ricocheting off pins and bumpers, the Japanese game of pachinko once seemed a permanent feature of the nation’s postwar landscape, its arcade-style sounds and lights providing a blinking, cacophonous backdrop to life in Japan during the boom years.

headline: A Live Action Comic Book Brings Zygon to Life
abstract: “The Intergalactic Nemesis,” a touring show that has been staged at more than 100 venues worldwide, relies on an audience’s imagination to visualize its robots and aliens.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — The touring show “The Intergalactic Nemesis” is an adventure story featuring robots, aliens, time travel and magical powers. But its special effects take place exclusively in the audience’s mind, created through an alchemy of old media and imagination. “Twin Infinity,” the third book in the trilogy, premiered Friday night at Austin’s Long Center for the Performing Arts. The first book, “Target Earth,” will play in Houston on Sept. 30.

headline: Lillian Gobitas Klose, 90, Dies; Stood Against Mandatory Pledge
abstract: In 1935 Ms. Klose heeded a Jehovah’s Witnesses leader’s call to refuse to recite the pledge in compliance with biblical commands against idolatry.
lead_paragraph: Lillian Gobitas Klose, whose refusal, on religious grounds, to recite the Pledge of Allegiance as a seventh grader in a Pennsylvania public school in 1935 ignited national indignation, as well as a roiling legal fight that led to an expansion of First Amendment rights, died on Aug. 22 at her home in Fayetteville, Ga. She was 90.

headline: Texas A&M Fans Are Fluent in the Science of Yelling
abstract: Aggies supporters, who attend midnight yell practices, rely on hand gestures and well-rehearsed chants to become the 12th Man and inspire their team.
lead_paragraph: If a crowd’s cheers bolster players’ resolve and lead to better performances, that is usually a bonus. Cheers are intended primarily for the fans’ benefit: to make them feel helpful or, failing that, to give them something to do.

headline: Refugees Reshape Their Camp, at the Risk of Feeling at Home
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The construction of a public square in a deeply conservative Palestinian refugee camp has made some there feel more at home, a provocative concept in camps conceived as temporary.
lead_paragraph: AL FAWWAR, West Bank — Up a rutted alley, mothers in head scarves, seated under flapping cloth canopies, sip tea and weave baskets. They’ve gathered in a dusty, sun-bleached square, not much bigger than a pocket park, made of limestone and concrete, shoehorned into a warren of low, concrete and cinder-block houses. The square isn’t much to look at.

lead_paragraph: On the wall to the right of Derek Jeter’s locker is a poster of the Yankees’ 2014 schedule. No days are crossed off. None are circled. Nonetheless, he is surrounded by reminders that his career is running out.

headline: Judge Orders Texas to Pay Fees for Districts in Finance Case
abstract: Late last month, a judge ruled in favor of Texas school districts, saying the state’s school finance system leaves districts without resources to meet the state’s academic standards. The state plans to appeal.
lead_paragraph: If the Texas school districts that are challenging the constitutionality of the state’s school finance system ultimately prevail in their lawsuit, a result could be billions of dollars in extra funding from the state’s coffers for public education.

headline: The Trick Behind the Sporty Ponytails at Alexander Wang
abstract: The hairstylist Guido Palau put a high-gloss spin on the classic gymnasium ‘do.
lead_paragraph: Athletic shoes have a cultish appeal among fashion designers, and it would seem that beauty pros are similarly obsessed. Backstage at Alexander Wang this afternoon, both the hair and makeup teams talked about trainers as the inspiration behind the slicked-back, sporty looks given to the models. “It started with a fetish about sneakers,” said the makeup artist Diane Kendal of her conversation with the designer. “There were references to Stan Smith, Michael Jordan, New Balance.” The hairstylist Guido Palau ran with that concept, putting a new spin on the classic gymnasium ponytail. “It’s a bit futuristic,” he said of the low-slung style. “The tail is dry but there is a high gloss to the head.” Palau’s technique involved tightly combing back strands with generous amounts of Redken Hardwear 16 Super Strong Hair Gel around the crown, then misting Redken Diamond Oil High Shine Airy Mist (available in October) all over to provide a glistening effect. To finish, he secured hair with a simple black tie at the nape. “I can’t really move my neck too much!” joked the model Mari of the ultra-sleek result. Still, she proved to be a good sport. “But I can’t wait to see how it will look on the runway.”

headline: Notre Dame Gives Michigan a Powerful Parting Shot
abstract: The 16th-ranked Fighting Irish overpowered the Wolverines as one of college football’s oldest rivalries came to an end.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Michigan and Notre Dame have storied football traditions. They claim 22 national championships and 10 Heisman Trophy winners between them, and their recognizable helmets and fight songs typify the pageantry of an autumn Saturday.

headline: In the Wee Hours, Japan Erupts in Celebration
abstract: In Japan, tennis fans rejoiced as Kei Nishikori became the first man from Japan, and Asia, to reach a Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: Bleary-eyed and delirious, tennis fans across Japan reveled Sunday morning at history in the making. Kei Nishikori, the country’s 24-year-old tennis sensation, had just powered past Novak Djokovic to book a place at a Grand Slam final — a first for a Japanese player, and for a man from Asia.

headline: Factors at BMW, but Afterthoughts at Ryder Cup
abstract: Billy Horschel, who leads the BMW Championship; Ryan Palmer, who is in second; and Morgan Hoffmann, who is on fire, were not included on the U.S. team’s roster.
lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — Americans scampered up the BMW Championship leader board Saturday as if negotiating one of the area’s dirt trails. One United States-born player birdied eight of his first 12 holes at Cherry Hills Country Club. Two others were in first and second after the third round.

headline: Lexi Boling Transforms Backstage at Prabal Gurung
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Lexi Boling before (left) and after (right) makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Paul Hanlon.

headline: Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off
abstract: China is set to become the world’s largest market for the fledgling space tourism industry.
lead_paragraph: One night in June, Sheng Tianxing made good on his name, which translated literally means “sky travel.” With a single click online, he paid $100,000, about a third of his annual income, for a seat on a rocket that will carry him into space.

headline: Foreign Powers Buy Influence at Think Tanks
keywords: ['Think Tanks', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States International Relations', 'Research', 'Foreign Agents Registration Act']
abstract: Prominent Washington think tanks, nonprofits known for their impartiality, have received tens of millions of dollars from foreign governments while pushing United States government officials to adopt policies that often reflect the donors’ priorities, an investigation by The New York Times has found.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The agreement signed last year by the Norway Ministry of Foreign Affairs was explicit: For $5 million, Norway’s partner in Washington would push top officials at the White House, at the Treasury Department and in Congress to double spending on a United States foreign aid program.

headline: Quotations from Chairman Rex
abstract: Some of the more notable statements made by Jets Coach Rex Ryan since he charged into New York in January 2009, promising Super Bowls and vowing that no way would these be the same old Jets.
lead_paragraph: Some of the more notable statements made by Jets Coach Rex Ryan since he charged into New York in January 2009, promising Super Bowls and vowing that no way would these be the same old Jets.

headline: North Korea Says It Will Put American on Trial
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Matthew Todd Miller is accused of shredding his tourist visa and demanding asylum, which the North says is a “hostile act” against the country.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Sunday that it would put Matthew Todd Miller, one of the three Americans known to be held in the country, on trial in a week.

headline: Aggressive Play on Important Points Lifts Nishikori Over Djokovic
abstract: Top-ranked Novak Djokovic was uncharacteristically passive in the third and fourth sets of a loss to Kei Nishikori in the U.S. Open semifinals.
lead_paragraph: The points in Kei Nishikori’s stunning 6-4, 1-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 victory over Novak Djokovic on Saturday were even, but the timing was not.

headline: Sony’s Oscar Ambitions Show at Toronto Film Festival
abstract: At an annual dinner party here on Saturday, company representatives from Sony’s small film unit were privately predicting as many as three best picture nominees.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Make no mistake, Sony Pictures Classics is on the warpath. Sony’s New York-based art film unit has sometimes been content to sweep up Oscar nominations and awards in the foreign language film or documentary categories. Films like “Searching for Sugar Man” and “Incendies” were distributed by the classics unit.

headline: Oregon Surges Past Michigan State With Big Plays and Stifling Defense
abstract: Quarterback Marcus Mariota held up the offensive end for the Ducks, passing for 318 yards and three touchdowns.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — Behind quarterback Marcus Mariota and a defense that grew stingier as the game went on, No. 3 Oregon came from behind to beat seventh-ranked Michigan State, 46-27, in the first major nonconference clash of the college football season.

headline: New Drug Policy Is Likely for N.F.L.
abstract: The N.F.L. and the N.F.L. Players Association are nearing an agreement to overhaul the league’s drug policy.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. and the N.F.L. Players Association are nearing an agreement to overhaul the league’s drug policy. After years of negotiations, the sides have all but agreed on introducing testing for human growth hormone. The league may raise the threshold for triggering penalties for marijuana to bring the policy more in line with Major League Baseball’s. Penalties for out-of-season positive tests for amphetamines may also be loosened.

headline: U.S. Launches New Airstrikes on ISIS to Protect Dam in Iraq
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Levees and Dams']
abstract: The airstrikes were aimed at stopping militants from seizing the Haditha Dam and preventing the possibility of floodwaters flowing toward Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — In launching a fresh series of airstrikes against Sunni fighters in Iraq over the weekend, the Defense Department described a mission to stop militants from seizing an important dam on the Euphrates River and prevent them from unleashing floodwaters toward the capital, Baghdad.

headline: Facebook Generation Rekindles Expectation of Privacy Online
abstract: As our online personal information has become less and less personal, the privacy pendulum may now ready to switch directions.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg said in 2010 that privacy was no longer a “social norm.” But four years later, the pendulum might be ready to swing the other way.

headline: Game Plan for a Week of Family Dinners
abstract: Sunday dinner is burrito bowls, but Sunday is also shopping and preparation day for making things easier the rest of the week.
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches all of us in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal.

headline: Obama to Present Case for Broader U.S. Mission Against Militants
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: In an interview on NBC, President Obama said he would speak to the nation on Wednesday to try to make a case for launching a wider United States-led offensive against ISIS in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use a speech to the nation on Wednesday to make his case for launching a United States-led offensive against Sunni militants gaining ground in the Middle East, seeking to rally support for a broad military mission while reassuring the public he is not plunging American forces into another Iraq war.

headline: A College Education Should Include Rooming With a Stranger
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Dormitories', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Roommates']
abstract: Colleges are competing to attract top students with amenities like partitioned rooms. Should they offer choosing your own roommate, too, or no roommate at all?
lead_paragraph: For many college students, this week marked the first day of classes in a new semester. As first-year students adjust to a new schedule and a new environment, many also faced the awkward task of sharing a room with a total stranger.

headline: 1889: Research May Help Prolong Women’s Fertility
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A doctor in Paris worked on prolonging fertility in 1889.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Brown-Séquard, who recently returned to Paris from Brighton, where he has been passing his summer holidays, is still pursuing his investigations and experiments in reference to the method of increasing vitality. His studies are now directed towards accomplishing for women the same result that he maintains has been reached in the case of men — that is to say, the period of capacity for conception can be prolonged by subcutaneous inoculations with substances primarily obtained from female dogs. These researches have not yet arrived at a sufficiently advanced stage to convince Dr. Brown-Séquard that any practical application can be made in this direction at present, but several women have already called upon Dr. Brown-Séquard, and offered themselves as subjects for these inoculations.  — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 8, 1889

headline: How the Battleground Tracker Was Conducted
abstract: The YouGov online interviews of voters are being used to supplement, not replace, the Times’s traditional telephone polls.
lead_paragraph: Data in the second wave of the New York Times/CBS News Battleground Tracker are based on online interviews with 108,725 voters conducted Aug. 18 to Sept. 2 in all 50 states and 435 congressional districts across the United States.

headline: Shift in Alaska Helps Republicans Retain Senate Edge
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: After the latest batch of data from an online panel, our forecasting model gives the G.O.P. a 61 percent chance of retaking Senate control.
lead_paragraph: The Senate battleground remains broad and competitive, with 10 races within six percentage points, according to the second wave of data from the New York Times/CBS News/YouGov online panel of more than 100,000 respondents.

headline: Some Retail Workers Find Better Deals With Unions
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Working Hours', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Hourly workers often face unpredictable schedules and fluctuating hours each week, but at a Macy’s in Manhattan, a union has made a difference.
lead_paragraph: By now, the hardships endured by retail workers at clothing stores across New York City are achingly familiar: the frantic scramble to get assigned enough hours to earn a living on painfully low wages; the ever-changing, on-call schedules that upend child care arrangements, college schedules and desperate efforts to find second jobs.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Al Jazeera America) EDGE OF EIGHTEEN The Oscar-winning documentary maker Alex Gibney (“Taxi to the Dark Side”) is an executive producer of this new series, which chronicles life as a teenager in the United States in six episodes filmed from January through May by a group of 17- and 18-year-olds. These 15 students, including Brandon McCauley of Lebanon, Ohio, above, traveled to New York for a crash course in filmmaking from the directors Alexandra Pelosi (“Journeys With George”), Sam Pollard (“When the Levees Broke”) and Mr. Gibney. They received equipment and learned about storytelling, interviewing, cinematography, sound recording and editing. Then they returned home to document significant events and interview parents, teachers and other important people in their lives as professional producers sometimes worked alongside them to help them develop their stories.

headline: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Locks Out Its Players, Again
abstract: It is the second lockout in two years.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra began its second lockout in two years on Sunday when the ensemble’s management and its players, who accepted deep pay cuts two years ago, failed to agree on a new contract before a midnight deadline.

headline: Should an American Man Wear Shorts?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A single tweet relaunched the debate, and Op-Talk sought the expert opinion.
lead_paragraph: I spent the summer of 2011 in Paris, studying French at the Sorbonne (poorly) and clumsily attempting Continental panache. I cringe when I recall some of the outfit choices I made in an effort to blend in — among them one of those horribly clichéd Saint James Breton-stripe jerseys that render the wearer instantly identifiable as a tourist.

headline: Afghan Court Wastes No Time Sentencing 7 to Death in Rape Case
abstract: Four women were raped, robbed and beaten by a gang of 10 men, seven of whom were captured and convicted of adultery and armed robbery in a swift trial Sunday.

headline: 1914: French Press Misjudges U.S. Ambassadors
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The local press speculated about postings at the American Embassy in Paris in 1914.
lead_paragraph: Judging from their comments, some of the French newspapers take a rather erroneous view of the arrival in Paris of Mr. W. G. Sharp and Mr. Robert Bacon. The idea seems to prevail that the United States is now represented in Paris by a sort of diplomatic triumvirate. Such an idea, of course, is amusingly inaccurate. Mr. Myron T. Herrick, the American Ambassador, is in sole charge of the Embassy, and will remain in sole charge until the end of the existing crisis. Mr. W. G. Sharp, who will take over the Embassy when conditions permit Mr. Herrick to retire, is in Paris for the purpose of arranging details connected with the preparations for his residence here. As regards Mr. Bacon, who made a host of friends during his term as Ambassador, he is visiting Paris at this time on private business. The French press, in fact, in trying to read diplomatic significance into the presence in Paris of the three eminent diplomatists, is wasting its ingenuity. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 8, 1914

headline: One Last Appearance at Fashion Week for Joan Rivers
abstract: It seemed fitting that her funeral took place in the middle of a period of high fashion, in between shows for Victoria Beckham and Diane von Furstenberg.
lead_paragraph: It was perhaps fitting that the funeral for Joan Rivers at Temple Emanu-El on Sunday morning took place smack dab in the middle of New York Fashion Week, in between shows for Victoria Beckham and Diane von Furstenberg.

headline: How to Get the Purple Hazy Eyes at Derek Lam
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: For the designer’s spring/summer 2015 runway, the French makeup artist Tom Pecheux perfected natural violet eye makeup with layers of “bruisey” colors.
lead_paragraph: “I like when beauty has a little twist to it,” said the French makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage this morning. When workshopping the concept behind the beauty look at Derek Lam, Pecheux tried a few different options for the designer. “The first was all natural, no makeup, blah blah,” he said. “The girl looked like a flat wheel. So I said, ‘Let’s try a nude color,’ which was pretty but boring.” Eventually the face painter grabbed a rich violet color and smudged it over the lids: et voilà, that did the trick. “Derek said, ‘Oooh, I like that!’ ” exclaimed Pecheux, with an amused smile. Still, the “bruisey” shade, as Pecheux described it, required careful application. To avoid the illusion of being punched in the face, he traced MAC Fluidline in Deep Deep Brown along the upper lashes, then brushed on MAC Lipstick in Violetta, creating a soft pinky-lavender wash over the lids and up to the brows. “The lipstick is bright, so you only need a thin layer,” he insisted. To finish, he swept on a metallic taupe eye shadow, then etched a thin streak of white kohl pencil under the eyes to lend contrast. The last step: sheering out everything with his hands. “This is your best friend,” Pecheux said, waving his finger in the air. “Using your fingers with makeup brings so much sensuality and femininity to the face, and that’s what I want for spring and summer.”

abstract: As a boy, Nishikori, now a finalist at the Open, left the comfort of Japan for the unfamiliar and more competitive American tennis scene.

headline: At Altuzarra, Hairnets Get Chic
abstract: Wrapped in netting, the ladylike bun on the designer’s spring 2015 runway elevated the fresh femininity of the collection.
lead_paragraph: In pink gingham skirt suits and dresses, water color florals and pearls, the Altuzarra woman exudes a fresh femininity for spring 2015. And the ladylike updo on last night’s runway, a slicked back bun encased with netting that matched models’ hair colors, reinforced the sophisticated yet youthful tone.

headline: Natural Dam Collapses in Nepal, Washing Away Bridges
abstract: The dam created by a huge landslide last month across the Sankoshi River unleashed a wall of water that caused no casualties but might be a danger to villages in India.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — A natural dam created by a huge landslide last month across the Sankoshi River collapsed on Sunday, allowing a wall of water to course down the river and sweep away a giant excavating machine and many bridges.

headline: Britain Pledges More Self-Rule for Scots if They Reject Scottish Independence
abstract: With pro-union advocates losing ground in polls, a British official said there would be a plan for greater political and fiscal autonomy if Scots vote “no” on Sept. 18.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Shaken by polls showing momentum shifting toward independence for Scotland, the British government will offer proposals for greater political and fiscal autonomy for the Scots if they vote to remain within the United Kingdom in a referendum on Sept. 18, George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, said on Sunday.

headline: Oil Scandal Erupts Again as Brazilians Near Election
abstract: A former executive at Petrobras, now in jail, testified that many top political figures were involved in a kickback scheme, according to a magazine report.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — As Brazilians prepare to vote in a national election next month, a scandal involving the state-controlled oil giant Petrobras flared up again this weekend over testimony that implicated dozens of top figures in President Dilma Rousseff’s governing coalition in a vast kickback scheme.

headline: U.S. Open 2014: Caroline Wozniacki vs. Serena Williams Live Blog
abstract: Serena Williams hopes to salvage what has been a disappointing year (by only her lofty standards) Sunday, looking to win her first Grand Slam title of the year, against Caroline Wozniacki in the United States Open women’s final.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams further secured her place in history, winning her sixth United States Open title by defeating Caroline Wozniacki, 6-3, 6-3. The title was Williams’s 18th overall at a Grand Slam, matching the number won by Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova.

headline: ‘Guardians’ Draws Most at the Box Office, ‘Identical’ Very Few
abstract: The weekend after Labor Day is typically the worst of the box office year. But multiplexes over the last three days were particularly moribund.
lead_paragraph: The weekend after Labor Day is typically the worst of the box office year, as vacationing Americans return to the grind, and studios hold back new films. But multiplexes over the last three days were particularly moribund: The Top 10 ticket sellers were all holdovers, and the only new wide-release movie, a musical drama called “The Identical,” bombed in 11th place.

headline: Traditions Meld Deftly to the Contemporary

The first show, back in late August, was outdoors, against a backdrop of New York Harbor, Statue of Liberty and setting sun that both glorified the dancing and competed with it. The second installment, on Friday, took place inside the relative ordinariness of the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.

headline: Suitcase Yields a Monet
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A Monet landscape is the latest lost treasure to surface in Cornelius Gurlitt’s trove of European art.
lead_paragraph: A Monet landscape is the latest lost treasure to surface in Cornelius Gurlitt’s trove of European art. The painting was recently found in a suitcase that belonged to Mr. Gurlitt, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Gurlitt died in May at 81, a little more than two years after approximately 1,280 paintings and drawings by Picasso, Chagall, Gauguin and other modern masters were confiscated from his Munich apartment.  Mr. Gurlitt had inherited the paintings from his father, Hildebrand Gurlitt, a Nazi-era art dealer. The suitcase containing the Monet was left at a hospital where Mr. Gurlitt had stayed and was turned over to a court-appointed task force handling his estate, The A.P. reported. The work, a light-blue landscape painted on paper, is estimated to have been created around 1864.

headline: Let the River Run Wild
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Levees and Dams', 'Water', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Four dams on the Susquehanna are causing its death.
lead_paragraph: IF the Chesapeake Bay is America’s Estuary, then its largest tributary, the Susquehanna River, could arguably be called America’s River. But we certainly don’t treat it as a national treasure: This once magnificent watercourse, which runs through New York, Pennsylvania and Maryland toward the coast, is today an ecological disaster — largely thanks to four hydroelectric dams, built along its lower reaches between 1904 and 1931.

headline: Honoring Arthur Gelb
abstract: The family of Mr. Gelb will hold a public service on Tuesday at 1:30 p.m. honoring the former editor and critic for The New York Times who died in May at 90.
lead_paragraph: The family of Arthur Gelb will hold a public service on Tuesday at 1:30 p.m. honoring Mr. Gelb, the former editor and critic for The New York Times who died in May at 90. “Celebrating the Life of Arthur Gelb,” at the Eugene O’Neill Theater at 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan, will feature former colleagues, friends and family members as speakers. They include Maureen Dowd, Frank Rich, Bernard Kalb, Robert Klein, Gay Talese, Marian Wood and Mr. Gelb’s son Michael. Kelli O’Hara and Eric Owens will perform songs selected by the Gelb family. “It’s a not a memorial service,” Mr. Gelb’s other son, Peter,  the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, said Sunday by phone. “It’s meant to be a celebration of his life.” Admission is free.

lead_paragraph: As a beloved former member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, Annmaria Mazzini already has a loyal audience, or so it seemed on Saturday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, where a full and enthusiastic house turned out for a performance by her three-year-old troupe, Mazzini Dance Collective. lead_paragraph: Picture this: A New York City Ballet soloist, unusually radiant with creamy skin, eloquent feet and a vintage luster to her drama, watches in horror as her body begins to deteriorate. Her hair falls out. Her migraines become debilitating. The pounds pile on. If, in dance, the body is an instrument, what happens, as with Kathryn Morgan, when it betrays you?

headline: Trying to Figure Out Her Patients and Herself
abstract: “Once Upon a Time, Verônica” is a drama about a psychiatrist adjusting to professional and personal challenges in Recife, Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Every day, the young psychiatrist in Marcelo Gomes’s “Once Upon a Time, Verônica” treats ailing visitors at a public hospital in her city, Recife, Brazil. Some patients can’t quite convey their woes; they seem stymied by an ingrown inability to articulate their problems. The same might be said about their doctor, Verônica, whose rootlessness and vexation Mr. Gomes gingerly records in this poised feature.

headline: The Rise of the SWAT Team in American Policing
keywords: ['Police', 'Posse Comitatus Act (1878)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: SWAT teams, created to quell unrest in Los Angeles in the 1960s, are the principal beneficiaries of heavy-duty military equipment from the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Posse comitatus is not a phrase that trips lightly off every tongue. It is typically translated from Latin as “force of the county.” Anyone who has ever watched an old Western movie will instantly recognize the first word as referring to men deputized by the sheriff to chase down some varmints who went thataway. (Rappers and their tag-alongs later gave “posse” a different context.) The full phrase is more obscure, but the concept that it embraces is enshrined in American law. The Posse Comitatus Act, passed in 1878 at the end of Reconstruction and amended but slightly over the decades, prohibits the nation’s armed forces from being used as a police force within the United States. Soldiers, the reasoning goes, exist to fight wars. Chasing local wrongdoers is a job for cops.

headline: Sam Harris’s Vanishing Self
abstract: The well-known New Atheist makes a case for the value of “spirituality,” which he bases on his experiences in meditation.
lead_paragraph: Sam Harris is a neuroscientist and prominent “new atheist,” who along with others like Richard Dawkins, Daniel Dennett and Christopher Hitchens helped put criticism of religion at the forefront of public debate in recent years. In two previous books, “The End of Faith” and “Letter to a Christian Nation,” Harris argued that theistic religion has no place in a world of science. In his latest book, “Waking Up,” his thought takes a new direction. While still rejecting theism, Harris nonetheless makes a case for the value of “spirituality,” which he bases on his experiences in meditation. I interviewed him recently about the book and some of the arguments he makes in it.

headline: Crime, Bias and Statistics
abstract: A new report by the Sentencing Project lays bare the systemic effects of racial distortion.

headline: Scots, What the Heck?
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'British Pound (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Referendums']
abstract: The very bad economics of independence.
lead_paragraph: Next week Scotland will hold a referendum on whether to leave the United Kingdom. And polling suggests that support for independence has surged over the past few months, largely because pro-independence campaigners have managed to reduce the “fear factor” — that is, concern about the economic risks of going it alone. At this point the outcome looks like a tossup.

headline: Ukraine and Russia Face Gaps in a Truce and a Chasm on the Issues
abstract: Both sides agreed to a “decentralization of power” in Ukraine in the terms of a truce agreement, but just what form that may take remains one issue of contention.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Scattered fighting threatened a shaky cease-fire in eastern Ukraine on Sunday as officials now confront a task even more formidable than maintaining the truce: fashioning some form of decentralized governance in the war-ravaged region that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will accept and that President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine can deliver without turning his country against him.

headline: Miners Battle Black Lung, and Bureaucracy
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'Black Lung Disease', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: The disease appears to be on the rise again, and miners face addition distress over legalistic requirements that deny them benefits for years.
lead_paragraph: Black lung disease, the lethal hazard for coal miners that was thought to be on the wane, is far from finished. Autopsies of 24 miners who died in the Upper Big Branch mine explosion four years ago found that 17 of them had black lung, the crippling respiratory disease that left generations of miners hooked up to oxygen tanks.

headline: Giants’ New Tandem Eager to Prove Itself
abstract: What Eli Manning and his new offensive coordinator can or cannot achieve is the major subplot of the Giants’ first game of the year (and it may be the story of their season).
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Nine months ago, Eli Manning and Ben McAdoo barely knew each other. On Monday night in Detroit, though, their fates will be joined.

headline: Legal Use of Marijuana Clashes With Job Rules
abstract: Users are discovering that marijuana’s strides toward the mainstream are running aground at the office, where drug-free policies remain.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Brandon Coats knew he was going to fail his drug test. Paralyzed in a car crash when he was 16, he had been using medical marijuana since 2009 to relieve the painful spasms that jolted his body. But he smoked mostly at night, and said marijuana had never hurt his performance answering customer calls for a Colorado satellite-television provider.

headline: The Ebb and Flow of Health Spending
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act will greatly affect health care costs in the next decade and beyond, but in what ways is still unclear.
lead_paragraph: The latest federal estimates of health care spending offer some good news: The growth rate for spending in 2013 will remain at a low level for the fifth straight year. But the bad news is, spending is expected to rise faster than growth in the economy over the next 10 years.

headline: A Fairer Shot for Student Debtors
abstract: More must be done to improve the collection process for student loans.
lead_paragraph: This year, the federal government will pay companies that collect student loan payments about $600 million. Too often, those collectors fail to help millions of borrowers manage their accounts. Worse, some actually drive them deeper into debt.

headline: Voter ID on Trial in Texas
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Editorials', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Identification Devices', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: An absurdly strict law that accepts as proof of identity a concealed-weapon permit but not a student identification card is being challenged in court.
lead_paragraph: In April, a federal judge in Wisconsin invalidated that state’s voter-identification law, finding that it would disenfranchise hundreds of thousands of eligible voters in a phony attempt to prevent a problem — in-person voter fraud — that does not exist.

headline: Airlines Take the Bump Out of Turbulence
abstract: Stronger computing power, improved satellite and radar technology and more sophisticated scientific models give airlines a greater understanding of flying conditions.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, airlines got their weather reports by telex. Pilots pored over reams of paper and compared the forecasts with their flight plans. Once airborne, they depended on radio communications and rudimentary radar to avoid bad weather.

headline: Despite Sanctions, Cash Keeps Flowing at Playground for Russia’s Rich
abstract: Business owners in seaside resort towns like Italy’s Forte dei Marmi worry that further sanctions could hurt business, but so far the reach of big Russian money seems little affected.
lead_paragraph: FORTE DEI MARMI, Italy — In this seaside resort town that is Italy’s version of a Russian Riviera, where furs dangle in shop windows in August and beach clubs keep chilled bottles of vodka, a temblor of anxiety unnerved hoteliers and restaurateurs in March. Usually, the phones would ring with Russians booking rooms, villas, even helicopters. But the phones suddenly went quiet.

headline: Celebrating Glory, With Little Hope to Add to It
abstract: A ceremony for Derek Jeter, the Yankees’ retiring captain, honored a remarkable career that will be remembered as a success even if his team misses the playoffs this season.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jordan finished his Chicago Bulls career by making a shot that clinched an N.B.A. championship. Jordan did not quit for good right then, but popular mythology freezes him forever as a winner, his final moment unfolding like a dream.

headline: Rolling Up a Picasso
abstract: On Sunday, Picasso’s “Le Tricorne” was removed from the Seagram Building, where it had been on display for 55 years. Moving a canvas that age and size required extreme delicacy.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Picasso’s “Le Tricorne” was removed from the Seagram Building, where it had been on display for 55 years. Moving a canvas that age and size required extreme delicacy.

headline: Two Brothers Plus One More Title Equals 100
abstract: Bob and Mike Bryan defeated Marcel Granollers and Marc Lopez to win the United States Open doubles championship, their 100th title as a team.
lead_paragraph: Bob and Mike Bryan capped off a remarkable decade with a century.

headline: Political Shift Stalls Efforts to Overhaul Immigration
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Though granting legal status to undocumented immigrants once looked like an imperative for both parties, a surge of Central American migrants into the United States has rendered the issue too toxic for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time Senator Angus King called the White House to warn President Obama against taking executive action to overhaul the immigration system, officials were well aware they had a problem on their hands.

headline: The Moon Comes Around Again
abstract: Some astronomers dislike the whole supermoon hoopla, but it shines a light on lunar studies, a vibrant enterprise that is yielding a wealth of insights and surprises.
lead_paragraph: As the moon wheels around Earth every 28 days and shows us a progressively greater and then stingier slice of its sun-lightened face, the distance between moon and Earth changes, too. At the nearest point along its egg-shaped orbit, its perigee, the moon may be 26,000 miles closer to us than it is at its far point.

headline: Tennis World Wobbles as Competitive Axis Begins to Shift
abstract: The last time there was a Grand Slam men’s singles final without Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic or Andy Murray was at the 2005 Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: It takes a bold soothsayer to proclaim that Monday’s men’s final at the United States Open between Kei Nishikori of Japan and Marin Cilic of Croatia represents the end of the oligarchical tennis era ruled by the so-called Big 4.

headline: Veteran Democrat Faces Hurdles to Re-election
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: John F. Tierney, a representative for the North Shore of Boston and a nine-term Democrat, knows about tough races against Republicans, but he faces a strong primary challenge from an Iraq War veteran.
lead_paragraph: PEABODY, Mass. — Representative John F. Tierney, an embattled nine-term Democrat, knows about tough races.

headline: Questions of Bracket Biases After a U.S.C. Leader’s Outburst
abstract: Pat Haden, Southern California’s athletic director and a member of the College Football Playoff selection committee, argued with referees in an incident that spurred debate over the committee’s role.
lead_paragraph: Although the game most pregnant with national-title implications over the weekend was Oregon’s defeat of Michigan State, the 65-pound, gold-and-steel National Championship Trophy sat several hundred miles south on Stanford Stadium’s sideline during the Cardinal’s game against Southern California.

headline: After 55 Years in Vaunted Spot, a Picasso Is Persuaded to Curl
abstract: “Le Tricorne,” a 95-year-old stage curtain painted by Pablo Picasso, was removed from Manhattan’s Four Seasons restaurant early Sunday morning, but not before its frailty produced a few tense moments.
lead_paragraph: In the dead of night, a 95-year-old Picasso went under the knife.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: New Yorker Festival to Feature Larry David
abstract: Mr. David, Stephen Sondheim and Phil Jackson will appear in conversation with contributors to The New Yorker, organizers announced on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Quintessential New Yorkers lead the lineup for next month’s New Yorker Festival. The Manhattanites Larry David, Stephen Sondheim and Phil Jackson will appear in conversation with contributors to The New Yorker, organizers announced on Sunday. Mr. David, who is making his Broadway debut in “Fish in the Dark”  in March, will be paired with the editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick. “I think we’re going to do an in-depth discussion of ‘Palestinian Chicken,’  which is maybe the best episode of sitcom TV ever,” Mr. Remnick said in a phone interview, referring to a 2011 installment of “Curb Your Enthusiasm.” The festival, taking place Oct. 10 to 12, will also feature the films “Listen Up Philip,” directed by Alex Ross Perry, and “The Humbling,” directed by Barry Levinson; both directors will attend. Musical performers include Randy Newman and Sharon Van Etten. In addition, Edward J. Snowden and Ai Weiwei are scheduled to join via live stream and answer audience questions. More information is available at newyorker.com/festival; tickets go on sale Friday at noon online and at the School of Visual Arts theater box office in Chelsea.

headline: Palestinian Leader Assails Hamas, Calling Unity Pact Into Question
abstract: At an Arab League gathering, President Mahmoud Abbas accused Islamists of running a shadow government in Gaza despite a reconciliation pact with his Fatah faction.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority lambasted his faction’s longtime rival, Hamas, at a meeting of the Arab League over the weekend, deepening doubts about the durability of their reconciliation pact and potentially complicating reconstruction of the Gaza Strip.

headline: Police in Spain Arm Themselves With Social Media to Fight Crime
abstract: Spain’s national police have embraced social media, and police forces in Latin America and elsewhere have visited Spain to study the department’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — When a European arrest warrant was issued recently for Brett and Naghemeh King, who took their cancer-stricken child out of a Hampshire hospital in the south of England without permission, the Spanish police did what has become increasingly common in the search for missing or wanted people: They posted an alert on Twitter.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: At Beckham and Altuzarra, Risks Work
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: On the constantly rotating hamster wheel that is the fashion cycle, taking a chance on a collection that has not been fully worked through is a scary proposition.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the trickle-down theory works in ways you least expect. President Obama’s foreign policy catchphrase, “Don’t do stupid stuff,” for example, may have pundits in a dither over whether it is a cop-out or realpolitik deserving of praise, but for some designers in New York, it is clearly a principle that appears to make a whole lot of sense.

headline: Filmmaker Pins Hopes on a Beach Boy
abstract: William M. Pohlad, a movie producer and heir to a family fortune, hopes his second feature film directing effort in 24 years, a biopic about the Beach Boy Brian Wilson, is a charm.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The film producer William M. Pohlad has made his name in Hollywood backing award-winning films like “12 Years a Slave” and “Brokeback Mountain.” But he first tried his hand at directing, and his 1990 debut feature, “Old Explorers,” went virtually unseen, losing money for friends and family.

headline: Destroying ISIS May Take Years, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a phased campaign requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is preparing to carry out a campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria that may take three years to complete, requiring a sustained effort that could last until after President Obama has left office, according to senior administration officials.

headline: Grandma’s Meat Loaf? Hardly. Her Retirement Home Now Has a 3-Star Chef.
keywords: ['Food', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Baby Boomers', 'Elder Care', 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: The senior housing industry is preparing to serve a wave of residents who expect more than mush on their plates.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Some of the toughest reservations to get in this affluent suburb of Chicago are for the early tables at the Mather, a senior community of $1 million condominiums near Lake Michigan. Citrus-dressed duck breasts and “tomahawk” pork chops are on the menu, along with vegetables from a cooperative farm in upstate Wisconsin and house-made gelato.

headline: Searching for a League’s True Scale of Bigotry
abstract: Bruce Levenson, the Atlanta Hawks’ controlling owner, follows Donald Sterling as another league owner selling his team after showing an inherent bias against blacks.
lead_paragraph: For the second time since April, the N.B.A. has been rocked by a disclosure from a team owner that the presence of blacks at games negatively affects the bottom line.

abstract: Prabal Gurung’s collection appeared lost, but Ralph Rucci and Suno were on far surer footing.
lead_paragraph: Lodged in the bowels, or more precisely the great heaving stomach, of the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue on Saturday morning, I really felt for Prabal Gurung, who was showing there.

headline: Football’s in the Air, and in Denver, So Is the Sweet Smell of Herb

lead_paragraph: DENVER — Wait. Does that glittering stadium really look like a just-landed spaceship under a blueberry sky? Or is that just because, well, y’know. ...

headline: Penelope Niven, Carl Sandburg Biographer, Dies at 75
abstract: Ms. Niven’s groundbreaking books helped revive public interest in Carl Sandburg, Edward Steichen and Thornton Wilder.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Niven was a high school English teacher, nearing 40, when she began work on a biography of Carl Sandburg. She had never written a book before. She didn’t have a Ph.D. in literature and hadn’t even been that familiar with Sandburg’s work.

headline: G.M.’s Board Is Seen as Slow in Reacting to Safety Crisis
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After General Motors emerged from bankruptcy and a government bailout five years ago, the board of directors of the “new G.M.” was expected to keep a more watchful eye on a company that had gone seriously off track.

headline: Libraries in Brooklyn Add Hours and Staff
abstract: With an infusion of money from the City Council and mayor’s office, the system will, among other things, expand its efforts to help patrons with technology.
lead_paragraph: Even on a Friday morning, the Macon branch of the Brooklyn Public Library in Bedford-Stuyvesant was buzzing: Every computer was being used, laptops had been lent out, patrons were asking for résumé advice and more than a few people were reading actual books.

abstract: All of its main competitors report on themselves, but its editor in chief says doing so is “an inherent conflict of interest.”
lead_paragraph: On the Forbes list of the world’s billionaires, Michael R. Bloomberg appears at No. 15, with a net worth of $33.6 billion. But on his own company’s ranking, the Bloomberg Billionaires index, he appears nowhere.

lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILLS VILLAGE, Colo. — Ponte Vedra Beach, you have a problem. The FedEx Cup playoffs, instituted by the PGA Tour to deliver a fabulous finish to the season, has become a dusty stagecoach ride to exhaustion.

headline: Documentary Explores B-Film Kingdom of Golan and Globus
keywords: ['Toronto International Film Festival', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Memories stirred about the cousins who took control of the Cannon Group, which released films with stars like Bo Derek and Charles Bronson, weren’t warm and fuzzy.
lead_paragraph: In their assault on mainstream Hollywood, Menahem Golan and Yoram Globus tried almost everything. Mr. Golan, who died last month at the age of 85, and Mr. Globus were cousins who released through the Cannon Group cinematic sex romps like “Bolero” with Bo Derek, bloody vigilante sequels with Charles Bronson, and the occasional mésalliance with respected filmmakers like John Cassavetes and Jean-Luc Godard.

lead_paragraph: Peter Sculthorpe, who became one of Australia’s most celebrated composers by developing a distinctive aesthetic influenced by the country’s landscape and using indigenous instruments like the didgeridoo, died on Aug. 8 in Sydney. He was 85.

headline: Gustavo Cerati, a Star of South America’s Pop Scene, Dies at 55
abstract: Mr. Cerati had platinum success in the Spanish rock and pop world and worked with artists like Shakira.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Box office is down so far this year compared to 2013, so studios have less to divide. The top three each grossed more than $1 billion, with Sony fourth at $948 million. “Guardians of the Galaxy” took over No. 1 overall last week, so Disney may pass Fox, which has gone with a tried-and-true strategy: of it’s top six movies, all were sequels except for “The Fault in Our Stars” and “Mr. Peabody and Sherman,” above. Coming this year, several potential blockbusters, including an all-star “Exodus: Gods and Kings” (Fox), “Dumb and Dumber To ” (Universal) and “Annie” (Sony).

headline: A Few of Phillip Lim’s Favorite Fashion Week Things
abstract: To celebrate his show today and the opening of his new NoHo store, the designer lists a few of his essentials.
lead_paragraph: Though Phillip Lim has a reputation for keeping things low-key, this New York Fashion Week is a splashy one for the designer, who opens a new 3.1 Phillip Lim flagship store on September 10 at 48 Great Jones Street in NoHo. The 3,500-square-foot space, designed in collaboration with the London agency Campaign, features vintage furniture and artwork curated by Lim himself. Its look was inspired by Lim’s design studio, which he calls “the only space that I am offered where ideas become realized and my daydreams are romanced into realities.” The opening will also celebrate the release of a book showcasing photographs of the store in progress by the artist Bill Jacobson. Here, in honor of New York Fashion Week, the SoHo resident lists a few of his go-to things and places around town.

headline: Broken Windows (Real Ones) Surge in Public Housing
abstract: According to a report from the New York City comptroller’s office, windows across the city’s public housing complexes have fallen into a degree of disrepair that seems drawn from generations past.
lead_paragraph: The broken window has long had a particular hold on the New York City psyche; at turns an emblem of disrepair and an inspiration for the policing strategy that has helped guide the New York Police Department for more than 20 years.

headline: Facebook’s Feeds Give Videos a Boost

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO Signature) BEHIND THE CANDELABRA (2013) Michael Douglas, above, in a Golden Globe-winning role, stars as Liberace, and Matt Damon is Scott Thorson, his chauffeur, lover and adopted son, in this film from the director Steven Soderbergh and the screenwriter Richard LaGravenese. Set in Las Vegas; Los Angeles; and Palm Springs, Calif., the film chronicles the men’s relationship, as Liberace has Mr. Thorson cosmetically altered in his image and legally adopts him before discarding him for a younger model. “There’s something uncanny, even brilliant,” about Mr. Douglas’s impersonation of Liberace, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Sashaying across Las Vegas stages and epic suburban living rooms with a drum major’s puffed-up grandeur and a lounge lizard’s predatory smile, Mr. Douglas gives a performance so assured, so free of camp or cringe, that you quickly surrender any doubts you might have had about his playing a famously flamboyant, closeted-in-plain-sight gay entertainer.” Still, “a cerebral gloss on, and satire of, a big old Hollywood biopic,” Mr. Hale added, the film is “full of smart, funny details — perfectly sewn in place, like the rhinestones on one of Mr. Douglas’s blinding costumes — but it’s short on heart, or heat.”

headline: Murong Xuecun Says He Is Target of Twitter Smear Campaign

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Civilians in Space
abstract: What does it take for a civilian to book a flight on a rocket to space?
lead_paragraph: In “Wealthy Chinese Travelers Lining Up to Blast Off,” Cao Li writes about the frenzy for space travel for people who are not astronauts.

headline: The Human Condition in Soviet Ruins
abstract: Nadav Kander’s photos explore long-abandoned Soviet sites that didn’t even appear on maps until the fall of communism.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long day driving through the dust in Kazakhstan near the Aral Sea, Nadav Kander found his subject: a row of houses. The buildings were bathed in golden light and crumbling with age. Five stories high, they stood tall on the desolate landscape. They seemed almost human, and very sad.

headline: What Is the Point of College?
abstract: What factors should be considered in determining the value of a college education?
lead_paragraph: What is the purpose of attaining a college degree? Is it to ensure a life of financial stability? Is it to develop as a person and as a thinker?

headline: China’s Antitrust Campaign Seen as Possible Breach of W.T.O. Rules
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The United States Chamber of Commerce, in a report on Beijing’s aggressive enforcement of its antimonopoly law, raises the prospect of a formal trade complaint.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A United States business group said on Monday that China’s recent aggressive enforcement of its antimonopoly law could be a violation of its trade agreements, a claim that potentially raises the stakes in a recent pushback among foreign companies that say they are being discriminated against in China.

headline: Why the Baltic States and Poland Fear for Their Security
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Russia’s aggression in Ukraine has caused some Eastern European countries to recall World War II — and to push for action to avoid anything similar today.
lead_paragraph: With an unpredictable Russia looming over their eastern borders and a painful anniversary reminding them of their powerful neighbor’s biggest act of aggression — World War II — Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and Poland are sounding the alarm, warning that a European war, or even a global one, is increasingly possible.

headline: New York Today: Cuomo Emerges on Primary Eve
abstract: Monday: a rare campaign appearance, near-perfect weather, and cabs just for women.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this blessedly cooler Monday.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: FMC to Acquire Danish Insecticide Maker for $1.4 Billion
abstract: The deal to acquire Cheminova is expected to bolster FMC, a Philadelphia-based company that supplies insecticides, fungicides and other chemicals to the agriculture industry.
lead_paragraph: Auriga Industries of Denmark said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its insecticide maker, Cheminova, to the FMC Corporation for about $1.4 billion in cash, plus the assumption of debt.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Path to Re-election Is Looking More Assured
abstract: If there is any plausibly competitive state where we have a clear sense of the race, it is Kentucky. Prospects do not look good for the challenger.
lead_paragraph: Many Democrats considered Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader, deeply vulnerable at the beginning of the year. The polls showed a tight race in Kentucky, with his Democratic opponent, Alison Lundergan Grimes, often in the lead. His approval and favorability ratings were low, often beneath 40 percent.

headline: The SAT As a Brainwashing Tool? Chinese Shrug Off Fears
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: The Chinese state news media has cited concerns that the United States is indoctrinating Chinese students by including its founding documents upholding freedom and human rights in the SAT.
lead_paragraph: Although Chinese state news media have cited concerns recently that the United States is indoctrinating Chinese students by including its founding documents upholding freedom and human rights in the SAT, teachers and parents don’t seem to be too alarmed.

headline: Syria and Iraq Called Urgent by New U.N. Rights Chief
abstract: Pledging to be “firm, yet always fair,” Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein condemned Islamic extremism and urged international action to end conflicts in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein began his tenure on Monday as the United Nations human rights chief with a strongly worded statement in which he condemned Islamic extremism and urged international action to end conflicts in Syria and Iraq.

headline: New York Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 5
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen kick off the festivities at an unusually early hour, and the day ends with Rag & Bone and the first-ever presentation by Ralph Lauren’s Polo women’s wear.
lead_paragraph: It’s an early morning at New York Fashion Week. Ordinarily, key shows don’t get going until the more editor-approved hour of 10 a.m. or so, but Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen play by no one’s rules but their own. They may have the highest media profile of just about any designer showing during N.Y.F.W., but as proof of the seriousness of their intent, they’ve made an unfashionably early, unusually quiet and ruckus-proof slot their own. You can bet that top members of the industry will be in their seats at the stroke of 9.

headline: Taiwan Reels From Gutter Oil Scandal
keywords: ['Food', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Regulators are examining the extent to which substandard cooking oil has been exported to Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Taiwan are scrambling to control a tainted-cooking-oil scandal that has affected hundreds of manufacturers and raised fears about health risks posed in many commonly consumed food items.

headline: How Are American Families Doing? A Guided Tour of Our Financial Well-Being
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A new report says the economic recovery has not resulted in higher incomes for anyone other than those who were already doing well.
lead_paragraph: How are we doing?

headline: Ty Segall, Garage-Rock Whiz, Debuts a Clever New Video
abstract: The collage-inspired clip, premiering exclusively here, draws on MTV classics like “Sledgehammer” and vintage printed matter. An interactive version on Segall’s site lets the listener control the content.
lead_paragraph: Since releasing his debut in 2007, the golden-locked garage rocker Ty Segall has been shockingly prolific, releasing no fewer than nine full-length albums, not to mention his contributions to records by other bands like Fuzz, Sic Alps and White Fence, plus an LP recorded with his fellow singer-songwriter Mikal Cronin. With each outing, Segall has both refined and scuffed up his love for early-’70s rock. For his expansive new album, “Manipulator,” he eased off the gas pedal slightly, taking 14 months to write, record and even arrange a string section for it. The album’s sense of craft is mirrored by the video for the title track, made by the director Matt Yoka, which premieres here. An interactive version of the video, now live on Segall’s site, plays on the song’s title by allowing the listener to manipulate visual elements within the frame by pointing and clicking.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 8, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 9, 2014

headline: Representing Programmers as if They Were Celebrities
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business']
abstract: One client was hesitant to sign on with 10x Management, mostly because of the 15 percent fee. “That could be $30,000 or $40,000 a year,” he said. “That’s a lot of money.”
lead_paragraph: The pitch: Software developers may not be rock stars but they are in high demand and competition for them, especially among top tech companies, is fierce. Many choose to work as freelancers, taking on short and long-term assignments for a variety of companies. These developers are often better at writing code than they are at writing contracts, negotiating fees, or communicating with clients. 10x Management represents those freelance developers much the way talent agents represent entertainers.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Andrew Ross Sorkin on the Real Bill Gates
abstract: An interview about Sorkin’s article in the magazine’s special Education Issue.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Ross Sorkin, financial columnist for The Times, co-anchor of CNBC’s “Squawk Box” and the author of “Too Big to Fail,” wrote this week’s cover story about the plan by Bill Gates to introduce a new kind of history classes into high schools across the country.

headline: Daily Report: Health Apps May Be Key to Fate of Apple’s iWatch
abstract: Just as the iPod’s appeal relied in part on Apple’s music industry relationships, the future of its new wrist device may rest on courting health companies.
lead_paragraph: Apple was not the first to create a digital music player when it introduced the iPod 13 years ago. But the device, with its click wheel and slick integration with the iTunes software that ran on a computer, took digital music into the mainstream, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Reese Witherspoon, Producer
abstract: The actress spoke about her decision, four years ago, to address the lack of good female roles.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO—For the record, Reese Witherspoon was all glammed up when she took the stage to talk about her glamour-free “Wild” and “The Good Lie,” among other things, at the Toronto International Film Festival on Sunday.

headline: Another Royal Baby Is Expected for an Uneasy Kingdom
abstract: The announcement of the pregnancy set off speculation about whether it would influence a secession vote in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the rich, the powerful and the upper crust in England contemplate their families-to-be, it is said, they aim for a minimum of two children — an heir to their estates and a “spare” should misfortune befall the first.

headline: Salesforce.com to Set Up a Venture Capital Fund
abstract: The company says its existing investment arm has set up the Salesforce1 Fund, a $100 million pool of money earmarked for start-ups that can create apps for the Salesforce mobile app platform.
lead_paragraph: To help make sure that Salesforce.com can compete for the interest of mobile app developers, the corporate software powerhouse is taking an unusual step: setting up a special venture capital fund.

headline: Schools Become Homes for Refugees in Iraq
abstract: Schools in Dohuk, Iraq, in the Kurdish north, are filled with displaced Iraqis who fled the advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria this summer.
lead_paragraph: Schools in Dohuk, Iraq, in the Kurdish north, are filled with displaced Iraqis who fled the advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria this summer.

headline: Morning Agenda: Preparing for Alibaba
abstract: Alibaba begins a roadshow for potential investors. | Electrolux to buy G.E.’s appliance unit. | Goldman’s bylaws ambiguous on legal fees. | Dollar General’s next move.
lead_paragraph: As it gets ready to go public in what could be the biggest stock market debut ever in the United States, the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group will begin a roadshow for potential investors on Monday, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The tour, which will begin in New York, will encompass 100 meetings in 10 days. Two teams of senior executives, code-named red and orange, will travel with advisers across the United States and then to Europe, the Middle East and Asia.

headline: Opening Ceremony: The Play Is Not the Thing
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The brand’s play, one of fashion week’s most anticipated events, showcased a raft of celebrities and a lot of cliches.
lead_paragraph: I admit that on Sunday night, when I got out of the Opening Ceremony show — which is to say, the 30-minute play “100% Lost Cotton” created by the designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, in conjunction with the director Spike Jonze and Jonah Hill, the co-writers — I was not happy.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Days 3 and 4
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: It was a steamy weekend filled with fashion-related excitement. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: In this weekend’s heat and humidity, walking even short distances drew the risk of profuse outbreaks of sweat. Undeterred, fashion’s devotees took over the streets of Manhattan, their outfits unaffected by the weather. After all, there were shows to see — and at which to be seen. Saturday began with Lacoste and moved through Prabal Gurung, Ralph Rucci, Alexander Wang and Altuzarra. Sunday brought an even more packed schedule and a bevy of highlights: a model of the canine variety at Hood by Air; a dance performance at Tracy Reese; an unfortunate tumble at Thakoon; a supermodel from an earlier era at Diane von Furstenberg; and a one-act play at Opening Ceremony. The shows overflowed with celebrities, some of whom took a break to pay their respects to the queen of the red carpet, Joan Rivers, whose funeral took place Sunday afternoon.

headline: Chiquita Delays Shareholder Meeting to Talk With Bidders

lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:47 p.m. | Chiquita said on Monday that it had delayed a meeting for shareholders to approve a proposed inversion deal with its Irish rival Fyffes so that it could talk with two Brazilian companies that have made a joint bid for Chiquita.

headline: Twitter Begins Testing a ‘Buy’ Button for Instant Purchases by Its Users
abstract: The feature will allow users to buy products with a couple of clicks, and it comes after Facebook began testing a similar button in July.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter is already a real-time emporium for news, photos, video clips and 140-character snippets of thought. Now, the real-time social network wants to be a shopping mall for real products, too.

headline: How Mod

headline: A New Study Clarifies Treatment Needs for Water from Fracked Gas and Oil Wells
keywords: ['Environment', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Mines and Mining', 'Natural Gas', 'Shale', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: A new analysis of water from fracked wells around the country clarifies treatment needs.
lead_paragraph: A good post on InsideClimate News last week explored a new study of organic compounds and other constituents in the briny water that emerges from gas or oil wells created using the high-pressure process called hydraulic fracturing, or fracking. (This “produced water” is a mix of fracturing fluid and water from the rock layers being drilled.)
