headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: 1939: Letters Reaffirm City Ties
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The head of the city of Brussels exchanged friendly messages with London’s Lord Mayor in 1939.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Burgomaster Max of Brussels, famed as the man who reputedly refused to hand over the keys of the city to the invading Germans in 1914, has sent the following telegram to Sir Frank Bowater, Lord Mayor of London: “When Great Britain, faithful to its promise, courageously faces the trials of war, I express to you, to the members of the Corporation of your city and to the population of London my feelings of the most enthusiastic comradeship.” The Lord Mayor has sent the following reply: “It is with heartfelt gratitude that I reply to your telegram. The citizens of London never forget the great ties uniting our city and yours, and will ever remember your generous sentiments this time.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 9, 1939

headline: Activist Investor Barry Rosenstein to Join Walgreen Board
abstract: The appointment comes as Walgreen completes an acquisition of the British pharmacy chain Alliance Boots. Mr. Rosenstein will also recommend an additional director to the board.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Barry Rosenstein will join the board of Walgreen, the drugstore chain announced on Monday.

headline: No Glass Ceiling for Worker Bees
keywords: ['Bees', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: A study found that though an elite 20 percent of foragers did half of a hive’s foraging, once they were removed, other bees increased their activity.
lead_paragraph: The honeybee hive would not seem to be the place to look for individuality, flexibility in job duties and social mobility. But by using new techniques for analyzing bee behavior, researchers at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, recently found that the life of a bee is less rigidly determined than had been thought.

headline: ScienceTake | Rise of the Worker Bees
abstract: Who would have thought that the hive had room for social mobility?
lead_paragraph: Who would have thought that the hive had room for social mobility?

headline: Happy 350th Birthday, New York
abstract: Today is the 350th anniversary of the surrender of Dutch New Amsterdam to the British and the settlement’s renaming as New York; no official commemoration is planned.
lead_paragraph: Happy birthday, New York. Monday is the 350th anniversary of the surrender of Dutch New Amsterdam to the British and the settlement’s renaming as New York.

headline: A Punch Is Seen, and a Player Is Out
abstract: The Baltimore Ravens terminated Ray Rice’s contract on Monday, after a video, posted by TMZ earlier in the day, showed him punching Janay Palmer in an elevator in February.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League’s handling of a domestic violence case is under renewed scrutiny after a graphic video emerged Monday, leading to the termination of the Baltimore Ravens star running back Ray Rice’s contract and his suspension from the league.

headline: The Trillion Dollar Zombie
abstract: Shambling along, powered by affinity fraud.
lead_paragraph: I’ve often remarked on the remarkable tenacity of the inflationista doctrine (Santellinomics? CNBCnomics?) among investors, given the fact that believing the people who have been warning about soaring inflation and interest rates would have lost you a lot of money. How much money? Cordell Eddings at BrookingsBloomberg puts a number to it: $1 trillion in gains on U.S. government bonds since QE began. Actually, this is arguably a low estimate; if you really believed in this stuff, you wouldn’t just have failed to hold US debt, you would have bet against it — as, for example, John Paulson (as described in the article) and Eric Cantor did.

headline: India and Pakistan Strain as Flooding Kills Hundreds
abstract: Thousands more have been displaced in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir and in neighboring Pakistan. Rescue efforts were hampered Monday by high waters.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Relief operations struggled on Monday in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir and in parts of Pakistan where six days of rain and flooding have left hundreds of people dead.

headline: BB&T to Buy Kentucky Bank
abstract: BB&T said on Monday that it would acquire the Bank of Kentucky for $363 million in cash and stock.
lead_paragraph: BB&T, the nation’s ninth-largest bank based on deposits, said on Monday that it would acquire the Bank of Kentucky for $363 million in cash and stock.

headline: Would Ryanair Deal Make Economy Class Even More Crowded?
abstract: Bolstering its all-Boeing fleet, Europe’s largest airline by number of passengers announced a firm order for 100 high-density planes with an option to buy 100 more.
lead_paragraph: Is economy class about to get even more crowded?

headline: Jessica Chastain’s Unusual Love Story, Art Openings Galore and More From the Cultural Calendar
abstract: Plus, a natural beauty workshop in a teepee, a sound festival in upstate New York and more from the cultural calendar.
lead_paragraph: Monday, New YorkSee the work of some New York art stars’ weekly ceramics clubIts name notwithstanding, “Satan Ceramics,” a group show at Salon 94 Freemans, is more concerned with topical satire than pure evil. In it, the artists Mary Frey, Pat McCarthy, JJ PEET and Tom Sachs display works they dreamed up during their weekly ceramics get-togethers, including Frey’s unrideable porcelain skateboard and Sachs’s urinal made with porcelain, rope and kevlar.Salon 94 Freemans, 1 Freeman Alley, New York, salon94.com.

headline: Fighting the Gender Pay Gap
abstract: It’s the 21st century, and women may still earn less than men for doing the same work. There is just no reason for that.
lead_paragraph: My daughter started her senior year of high school this fall. With college fast approaching, I’ve had some fun discussions with her and family friends about future professions. One thing keeps coming up: It’s the 21st century, and our daughters may still earn less than men for doing the same work.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: News From the Advertising Industry

headline: 1964: Elderly Can Visit Kin in West
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Elderly East Germans allowed to visit relatives in the West in 1964.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — East German Communist leader Walter Ulbricht announced today [Sept. 8] that elderly East Germans will be allowed to visit relatives in the West. He said his Interior Ministry has been told ‘‘to make possible’’ visits of persons of ‘‘pension age’’ to their relations in West Berlin and West Germany. East German men get old-age pensions at 65 and women at 60. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 9, 1964

headline: Lasker Winner Calls for More Genetic Testing for Cancer
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: A geneticist wins a prestigious Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation award and uses the spotlight to call for much wider genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer.
lead_paragraph: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation awards — often called the “American Nobels” in medical science — were announced Monday morning, and one of the winners used the spotlight to call for greatly widening the use of genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer.

headline: Betting Markets Not Budging Over Poll on Scottish Independence
abstract: Prediction markets may not get it right every time, but they get it wrong less often than polls.
lead_paragraph: A poll published over the weekend suggesting that a majority of Scots will vote for independence Sept. 18 has both tanked the British pound and put the issue squarely in the international spotlight.

headline: Weekly Quandary: Changes to a High School Schedule
abstract: If your student is unhappy, do you encourage the child to advocate for a different schedule, regardless of the official word on allowable changes?
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary came via email: Should you help a high school student who doesn’t like his or her schedule to get it changed, and how?

headline: Koons Creating Sculptures for New Philanthropy Project
abstract: Project Perpetual will work with artists to raise money for humanitarian causes, with Jeff Koons being the first artist to take part.
lead_paragraph: Project Perpetual, a new philanthropy established to raise money for humanitarian causes by collaborating with artists, has enlisted Jeff Koons to create the first in a series of new works that will be used to raise money for the United Nations Foundation.

headline: Black Women Find a Growing Business Opportunity: Care for Their Hair
abstract: The Internet and the mounting popularity of naturally textured curls and braids have enabled African-American women to claim a bigger share of hair products industry.
lead_paragraph: Not much seems unusual about Judian and Kadeian Brown’s storefront in a tidy plaza off Church Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, a neighborhood where every block seems to have its own African hair-braiding salon.

headline: James Corden to Replace Craig Ferguson as Host of ‘The Late Late Show’ on CBS
abstract: Mr. Corden, a British actor and comedian, is virtually unknown in the United States, but has amassed a long list of credits in England.
lead_paragraph: In choosing James Corden on Monday to replace Craig Ferguson as the host of “The Late Late Show,” CBS seems to be making a statement.

headline: A World, From Scratch
abstract: “Utopia,” a new reality show on Fox, lets an odd assortment of types be themselves, together.
lead_paragraph: There are no rules, money or iPads on “Utopia,” a Fox reality show that began on Sunday. In this yearlong experiment in building a DIY society, viewers are invited, as the host put it, to “imagine throwing off the shackles of convention and conformity.”

headline: Lawmakers Approve Cabinet in Iraq, but 2 Posts Are Empty
abstract: Iraqi legislators approved a new power-sharing government led by the Shiite prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, but they left the two most divisive security posts unfilled, potentially extending a contentious debate.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi lawmakers approved a new power-sharing government led by Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi late Monday. But they left the two most divisive security posts unfilled, potentially extending a contentious debate even as American officials prepared a new campaign of military support for the Baghdad administration.

headline: Pakistan’s Deadly Floods
abstract: Flooding in Pakistan left at least 190 people dead and thousands stranded in swamped towns and villages.
lead_paragraph: Flooding in Pakistan left at least 190 people dead and thousands stranded in swamped towns and villages.

headline: Brushing Off Threats, E.U. Votes to Toughen Its Sanctions on Russia
abstract: European leaders on Monday endorsed an expansion of economic sanctions against Russia, but backed off putting the new measures into effect immediately.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Unswayed by threats of retaliation from Moscow, including a possible ban on airlines from Europe flying over Russia, European leaders on Monday endorsed an expansion of economic sanctions against Russia, but backed off putting the new measures into effect immediately.

headline: This Is Life Among the Roma, Europe’s Forgotten People

abstract: A short documentary sheds light on the desperate living conditions of Albania’s Roma — one of the most disenfranchised communities in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Roma are a historically nomadic, widely dispersed people of South Asian origin. They live primarily in Europe — where they constitute one of the largest ethnic minorities — and have done so for more than 1,000 years.

lead_paragraph: The economic turnaround in Youngstown, Ohio, is part of a transformation taking place across the heartland of the nation.

headline: Boom in Energy Spurs Industry in the Rust Belt
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Natural Gas', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Shale', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: Once-decayed steel towns and desolate rural regions are rising anew, their economies bustling as domestic oil and gas production surges.

headline: A New Season of Typecasting for N.F.L. Quarterbacks
abstract: So much is silly and reductive in the way we turn sports stars, including Andrew Luck and Peyton Manning, into characters in fate-driven morality plays.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Oh, God, he failed again. Andrew Luck, the superstar-almost quarterback for the Indianapolis Colts, faced Peyton Manning, the Old Man River of N.F.L. quarterbacks, in a Sunday evening clash of the titans.

headline: Bugs on a Square
abstract: Can you solve the classic Four Bugs on a Square puzzle?
lead_paragraph: This week we present our second consecutive insect challenge: the classic Bugs on a Square. This puzzle has been suggested by a number of readers over the years, including the software engineer Cem Ünsal, who has used the puzzle in dozens of interviews (we’ll hear about his experience at the end of this post). When a regular contributor, Dr. W, brought up the puzzle in last week’s Ants on a Triangle discussion I realized it was probably time to run the challenge as our main feature. Here’s how the Canadian mathematician John McKay phrased the problem in a recent email to me:

headline: Lew Says Administration Is Near a Decision on Curbing Corporate Expatriates
abstract: In an address, Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew said he would decide what action the administration can take to stop companies from moving abroad to avoid American taxes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said on Monday that he would decide “in the very near future” what regulatory action the Obama administration can take — given the partisan paralysis in Congress — to close some tax loopholes and reduce incentives for multinational corporations to avoid United States taxes by incorporating in other countries.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Versus Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: A Fast, Simple Dinner for a Monday Night
abstract: A detailed plan for getting dinner on the table tonight.
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active children. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach, from the popular blog Dinner: A Love Story, takes a recipe for chaos and coaches all of us in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal.

headline: Obesity Around the Nation
abstract: In 2013, adult obesity rates rose in six states – Alaska, Delaware, Idaho, New Jersey, Tennessee and Wyoming – which was a drastic shift from 2005, when the rate increased in every state.
lead_paragraph: Obesity rates in states around the country are beginning to slow, but the epidemic is still affecting the poor and minorities disproportionately, new research shows.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: DSW of Ohio selects Resource of Columbus to handle some assignments, including redesigning the company’s website.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Andreani joined I.d.e.a., San Diego, in a new post, senior vice president and executive creative director. He had most recently been creative director at McKee Wallwork & Company, Albuquerque.

headline: Today in Small Business: Twitter Tests a ‘Buy’ Button
abstract: What happened when one community increased its minimum wage to $15 an hour. How to value a franchising business. The founder of Chick-fil-A died Monday.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Chris Evans Answers Your Questions
abstract: Chris Evans answered reader questions at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — With his new movie “Before We Go,” Chris Evans is both filmmaker and actor. Last week, we asked readers what they would ask Mr. Evans, whose directorial debut has its premiere in Toronto on Friday. He sat down with us to answer a select number of those questions about his life and career. Here are those responses.

headline: Be Nice to Underlings, Jefferies Bankers Are Told
abstract: “Creating unnecessary projects or deadlines, or just being insensitive makes you a jerk,” two top Jefferies executives write in a letter to their bankers.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, analysts and associates in investment banks were required to work grueling hours. Pitch books assigned at 4 p.m. on Friday. Complex demands for mind-numbingly dense spreadsheets at 10 a.m. on Sunday. League table arranging to show that there are five planets or that Goldman Sachs is not really a top ranked adviser.

headline: An Industrial Rebound
abstract: The economic turnaround in Youngstown, Ohio, is part of a transformation taking place across the heartland of the nation.
lead_paragraph: The economic turnaround in Youngstown, Ohio, is part of a transformation taking place across the heartland of the nation.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: When once is not enough, for a commercial broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Iran’s Top Leader Undergoes Prostate Surgery
abstract: There was no word on whether the leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, 75, has prostate cancer, but doctors called the operation a success.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, underwent an operation on his prostate on Monday, according to state-run news media and a posting on his website. None specified whether the ayatollah, 75, has prostate cancer.

headline: MetLife Hopes Campaign Will Help Change Perceptions of Life Insurance
abstract: The campaign focuses on life, not death, in urging consumers to buy insurance.
lead_paragraph: A new campaign seeks to accentuate the positive about life insurance, promoting it affirmatively as a way to “live for” the loved ones in your life rather than taking a downbeat tack with terms like “death benefit” or “beneficiary.”

headline: Michael C. Hall Will Put on Heels as ‘Hedwig’
abstract: The “Dexter” star has previously sung on Broadway in “Cabaret” and “Chicago.”
lead_paragraph: The producers of the Broadway musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” have decided to keep the show running through the traditionally profitable winter holidays with a new star – Michael C. Hall of “Dexter” – in spite of mixed signs about ticket sales. The producers announced on Monday that Mr. Hall, who sang on Broadway as the M.C. in “Cabaret” and as Billy Flynn in “Chicago,” will play the transgender rock star Hedwig from Oct. 16 through Jan. 4, 2015.

headline: Martoma, SAC Capital Ex-Trader, Gets 9 Years in Prison
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Insider Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Mathew Martoma’s parents asked why his former boss, Steven A. Cohen, was not also charged with insider trading if their son had done something wrong.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:05 p.m. | The parents of Mathew Martoma, the former portfolio manager for SAC Capital Advisors, sat quietly through his insider trading trial this year. But moments after a federal judge sentenced Mr. Martoma on Monday to nine years in prison for carrying out one of the biggest insider trading schemes on record, his parents could contain themselves no more.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Titles, fundamentally based on the sciences, as selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
lead_paragraph: 1 IN THE KINGDOM OF ICE by Hampton Sides. Doubleday. An 1879 polar voyage gone terribly wrong.

headline: Flaming Lips Reveal Guest List for ‘Sgt. Pepper’s’ Cover Album
abstract: Contributors include Moby, Miley Cyrus, My Morning Jacket and Tegan and Sara on the tribute recording to be released on Oct. 28.
lead_paragraph: The Flaming Lips, the idiosyncratic Oklahoma band of neo-psychedelic tricksters, has been at work on a cover version of the complete “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” album for much of the last year. For the project, the Lips have brought in other musicians, turning the album into a starry tribute to the Beatles’ 1967 classic. On Monday, the group released the track list – not much of a surprise, since it mirrors the original – and more crucially, the guest list, which includes Moby, Miley Cyrus, My Morning Jacket, Tegan and Sara and others. The album will be released on Oct. 28.

headline: A Grand Slam Idea (With Drinks, of Course)
abstract: Denny’s adds cocktails to the menu of its first Manhattan restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Tommy’s Margarita. Denny’s.

headline: Chris Evans on His Most Challenging Role
abstract: The actor and director answers a question about what he sees as his most challenging role to play.
lead_paragraph: The actor and director answers a question about what he sees as his most challenging role to play.

headline: D.E.A. to Allow Return of Unused Pills to Pharmacies
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: The move by the Drug Enforcement Administration is intended to help reduced the stockpile of unused controlled drugs in homes, which until now could be handed over only to the police.
lead_paragraph: Concerned by rising rates of prescription drug abuse, the Drug Enforcement Administration announced Monday that it would permit consumers to return unused prescription medications like opioid painkillers to pharmacies.

headline: New Margaret Atwood Work Coming in … 2114?
abstract: As the first contributor to the Future Library project, Margaret Atwood is writing a work that won’t appear until 2114.
lead_paragraph: Fans clamoring for Margaret Atwood’s next work of fiction will need to take a serious chill pill, or even better, seek a full cryogenic freezing. The project she’s currently working on won’t appear until 2114.

headline: Laughs and Accolades as Clinton and Bush Introduce a Leadership Program
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Education', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The two former presidents exchanged compliments in Washington on Monday as part of an initiative involving four presidential libraries.
lead_paragraph: At a time of heightened partisanship in Washington, it seemed a brief respite to watch former Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton sit side by side on stage and gush about each other’s leadership and acute decision-making skills.

headline: Reddit and 4chan Begin to Button Up
abstract: The posting of dozens of provocative, private photos of celebrities brought attention and pressure for change to two freewheeling sites.
lead_paragraph: They say almost anything goes on the Internet. Except, that is, when the lawyers become involved.

headline: Honda Recalls 126,000 GL 1800 Motorcycles
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Hundreds of complaints about rear brakes dragging and heating up, in some cases causing a fire, prompted Honda’s second recall of the model.
lead_paragraph: Honda is recalling about 126,000 of its GL 1800 motorcycles for the second time because the rear brake can drag and possibly cause a fire, according to a report Honda posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website. The action covers the 2001-10 and 2012 model years.

headline: AT&T U-verse to Carry Rural Media Group’s RFD-TV
abstract: The rural-focused television network landed coverage on AT&T’s service after a monthslong campaign against a pair of proposed media mergers.
lead_paragraph: RFD-TV, the rural-focused television network, has landed coverage on AT&T’s U-verse television service after its monthslong campaign against a pair of proposed media mergers.

headline: Garance Doré’s Pinterest, A Goop-Approved Wellness Doctor’s Website and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: A Bond Fraught With Danger
abstract: “The Green Prince,” about a Hamas informant and his handler, is the third in a documentary trilogy by the Israeli director Nadav Schirman.
lead_paragraph: On newspaper front pages around the world late last month, a photograph from Gaza showed masked Hamas gunmen about to execute bound, kneeling prisoners suspected of collaborating with Israel. That same fate would probably have befallen Mosab Hassan Yousef, the protagonist of the new documentary “The Green Prince,” had this secret been discovered: For nearly a decade, he was an informant for Israel, operating at the highest levels of Hamas itself.

headline: Carlyle Deal Concludes a Lawsuit Against Private Equity
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The agreement to pay $115 million to settle accusations that it illegally colluded with its rivals to lower the prices of corporate buyouts ends a seven-year headache for the industry and brings the final tab to $590.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The final holdout in a sweeping lawsuit against some of the biggest private equity firms has agreed to a settlement, ending a seven-year headache for the industry.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Afghan Candidate Vows to Reject Disputed Vote
abstract: Abdullah Abdullah said he would not recognize any government formed on the basis of an audit, nearly complete, of the votes in his runoff election against Ashraf Ghani.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah once more brought Afghanistan’s troubled electoral process to the brink on Monday, insisting that he had won the disputed vote and vowing to reject any government formed on the basis of it.

headline: A Doctor’s Malaise, and a Profession’s
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Sandeep Jauhar tells the story of two midlife crises: the author’s own, and that of modern American medicine, now in about its fourth decade under managed care.
lead_paragraph: Sandeep Jauhar’s new memoir, “Doctored: The Disillusionment of an American Physician,” tells the story of two midlife crises: the author’s own, and that of modern American medicine, now in about its fourth decade under managed care. Both prove to be frustratingly intransigent, with only small signs of hope.

headline: Wall Street Hand Stays the Stormy Course at N.Y.U.
abstract: Martin Lipton is virtually guaranteeing the continuation of policies opposed by many N.Y.U. faculty members, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: Under the command and control of John Sexton, its president, and Martin Lipton, its chairman, for more than a decade, New York University has courted more than its fair share of controversy. So some might have expected that with the two stepping down over the next two years, new leadership might mean a fresh and less controversial direction.

headline: Germany Arrests 3 on Charges of Joining Somali Militants
abstract: The three men were arrested upon their return to Germany after receiving training and then fighting alongside militants from the group known as the Shabab.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Three Germans suspected of training and fighting with the Somali Islamist group known as the Shabab were arrested at Frankfurt Airport when they returned to Germany over the weekend, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
abstract: Parties for Band of Outsiders and Prabal Gurung.
lead_paragraph: Parties for Band of Outsiders and Prabal Gurung.

headline: If the Scots Gain Independence, Expect a More Conservative U.K.
abstract: The Labour Party would have a much harder path to a majority in future national elections.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks until the referendum on Scottish independence, a poll has found for the first time that the “yes” vote, which would split Scotland from England, Wales and Northern Ireland, was ahead of the “no” vote. Although it’s not at all certain that the survey is a reliable prediction of what will occur on Sept. 18, independence no longer seems like an impossibility (which it did a few short months ago, when the “no” vote was far ahead.)

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Returns to Form in Italian Grand Prix
abstract: Lewis Hamilton narrowed the Formula One points gap between himself and Nico Rosberg; Brad Keselowski won the last race of the regular Nascar season.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, the pole-position starter driving for Mercedes, recovered from a poor start to win the Italian Grand Prix on Sunday, pressuring his teammate, Nico Rosberg, into a mistake that caused him to cede the race lead.

headline: Philharmonic to Raise Funds for 2019 Renovation
abstract: The target date for Avery Fisher Hall’s renovation is now 2019, and the New York Philharmonic is planning a campaign to raise its share of the costs and double its endowment.
lead_paragraph: The target date to begin the long-delayed renovation of Avery Fisher Hall is now 2019, and the New York Philharmonic is planning a campaign to raise its share of the construction costs and double its endowment, the orchestra disclosed in a recent job listing.

headline: Walkabout: Airlines Say So Long to Turbulence, Hello to Cramped Seating
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Smoother Sailing Just a few years ago, pilots depended on radio communications and rudimentary radar to avoid bad weather. Now new generations of airplane radar systems allow for easy in-flight adjustments. (The New York Times)

headline: R.B.S. Tries to Paint Too Pretty a Picture for Citizens I.P.O.
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland is making a lot of rosy assumptions in valuing Citizens Financial ahead of its I.P.O., writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland is applying a fair amount of lipstick to its United States unit ahead of a planned initial public offering.

headline: A Sleep Sweet Spot
abstract: The most reliable workers are those who get seven to eight hours of sleep each night, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: The most reliable workers are those who get seven to eight hours of sleep each night, a new study shows.

headline: A New Host for “The Late, Late Show”
abstract: James Corden, a British comedian who is relatively unknown in the United States, has just been tapped as the next host of CBS’s “The Late, Late Show.” A sampling of Corden’s recent appearances.
lead_paragraph: James Corden, a British comedian who is relatively unknown in the United States, has just been tapped as the next host of CBS’s “The Late, Late Show.” A sampling of Corden’s recent appearances.

headline: Schomburg Center Plans Exhibition on ‘For Colored Girls’
abstract: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is mounting an exhibition in conjunction with the 40th anniversary of “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide When the Rainbow Is Enuf.”
lead_paragraph: Ntozake Shange’s “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” an audacious, feminist cry from the heart, started life in 1974 in a women’s bar in California, landed on Broadway shortly thereafter and by 2010 had morphed into a Tyler Perry film. Now, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Manhattan is mounting a visual arts exhibition entitled “I found god in myself: The 40th anniversary of Ntozake Shange’s for colored girls,” an exploration and interpretation of the now-classic work.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Carolina Herrera Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Nina Westervelt.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Nina Westervelt.

headline: Opening Ceremony: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Ukraine’s President Promises Protection
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine visited an eastern Ukrainian port and promised to defend it from pro-Russian separatists.
lead_paragraph: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine visited an eastern Ukrainian port and promised to defend it from pro-Russian separatists.

headline: When Family Dinner Doesn’t Satisfy
abstract: The pressures of dinner are causing stress for poor and middle-class families alike, say a team of sociologists. And, they argue, we can’t expect moms to do all the work of changing how America eats.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Sarah Bowen’s research project seems pleasant: The sociologist and her team sat down to dinner with American families. But what she found may be disturbing for proponents of family dinners — the meals were often times of worry and strife. And, she argues, we can’t expect moms alone to change the way America eats.

headline: Former Envoy Reported Facing a Federal Inquiry
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Money Laundering', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: Zalmay Khalilzad, a former American ambassador, is suspected of tax evasion and money laundering, and his wife’s accounts in Austria have been frozen, a magazine reported.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Zalmay Khalilzad, a former United States ambassador to Afghanistan, Iraq and the United Nations, is under investigation by the Justice Department for possible tax evasion and money laundering, an Austrian magazine reported on Monday.

headline: U.S.C.’s Pat Haden Fined for Altercation With Referees
abstract: Haden, Southern California’s athletic director, and Steve Sarkisian, its football coach, were reprimanded on Monday over a sideline debate with referees in Saturday’s game.
lead_paragraph: The Pac-12 Conference reprimanded Southern California’s athletic director, Pat Haden, and football coach, Steve Sarkisian, on Monday over a bizarre sideline debate with the referees Saturday in the Trojans’ 13-10 victory at Stanford.

headline: A Family Cycle of Diabetes
abstract: Children born to women who had gestational diabetes have a substantially higher likelihood of developing diabetes as teenagers, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Children born to women who had gestational diabetes have a substantially higher likelihood of developing Type 2 diabetes as teenagers, a new study shows.

headline: Broadway Won’t Dim Lights for Rivers
abstract: Broadway executives have decided not to dim the lights on theater marquees to pay tribute to Joan Rivers.
lead_paragraph: After closed-door deliberations, Broadway executives have decided not to dim the lights on theater marquees – an industry honor – to pay tribute to Joan Rivers, the comedian and television personality who also appeared on Broadway three times and earned a Tony Award nomination in 1994.

headline: Chinese Game Players Add to Apple's Bottom Line
abstract: China has become Apple's third-largest market for software sales, and a huge chunk of that comes through WeChat, an app used to play games.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Apple has a lot to thank people like Ms. Deng for.

headline: Jaguar Unveils XE Sport Sedan
abstract: Featuring an F-Type-style instrument panel and sedan ergonomics, the XE is scheduled to go on sale in North America in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Jaguar unveiled its XE Monday afternoon and said the sleek, compact sedan was expected to go on sale in North America in 2016.

headline: Caesarism Delayed
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Thoughts on a unilateral amnesty postponed.
lead_paragraph: Since I spent last month hammering away at the legitimacy of White House’s promised executive action on immigration, you won’t be surprised to hear that I have a few thoughts following the news that it’s been officially delayed, at least until after the midterm elections but with no date certain set. Three thoughts, to be specific:

headline: Finally a Change Atop FIFA? Don’t Count on It
abstract: Sepp Blatter, who is 78 and has been the president of FIFA for 16 years, announced that he hoped this would, in fact, not be his final term in office despite his age and the considerable potholes of his tenure.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter is a mutant immortal butterfly, a creature that spends years in a cocoon, oblivious to the world around him before emerging on a quadrennial basis to flap his wings, put on a short show of creativity and ambition and then, ultimately, collapse back into his self-important slumber.

headline: Blaming Gerrymandering Has Its Limits, as Pennsylvania Shows
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: Pennsylvania is an example of a big problem for Democrats in winning the House: the clustering of their voters around cities.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that Republicans have a huge advantage in the House. But there is a big debate about whether it’s because of partisan gerrymandering or because Democrats are gerrymandering themselves into urban, heavily Democratic districts. One reason the debate continues, despite a near consensus among political scientists, is because the “wasted votes” phenomenon is abstract and hard to illustrate.

headline: N.C.A.A. Decides to Roll Back Sanctions Against Penn State
abstract: By restoring Penn State’s bowl eligibility and full complement of scholarships, the N.C.A.A. launched the program that was shamed by a sexual-abuse scandal on a course to normalcy.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. on Monday restored Penn State’s postseason eligibility, removing one of the final hurdles in its football team’s path back to normalcy in the aftermath of the child sexual abuse scandal that engulfed the university nearly three years ago.

headline: Susan Dominus, What’s in Your Bag?
abstract: An impulse buy at Ikea became a loyal companion that ensured a reporter that everything was under control.
lead_paragraph: Oh, no. You’re a reporter on assignment and you’re riffling through your carryall. You think you’ve left something behind. Whether you find it or not can make or break your day. We asked several reporters what they need to do their jobs when they leave home or office. We’ll share their answers over the next few weeks.

headline: Turkey Is Courted by U.S. to Help Fight ISIS
abstract: Chuck Hagel, the defense secretary, met with Turkish officials on Monday to persuade them to join the coalition being formed to fight the Sunni militant group.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — The Obama administration on Monday began the work of trying to determine exactly what roles the members of its fledgling coalition of countries to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria will play, with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel huddled with the leaders of the one country the administration has called “absolutely indispensable” to the fight: Turkey.

headline: Jeffrey D. Dunn Named Chief of Sesame Workshop
abstract: Mr. Dunn, a former Nickelodeon and HIT Entertainment executive, replaces H. Melvin Ming, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization best known as the producer of PBS’s “Sesame Street,” has named a former Nickelodeon and HIT Entertainment executive, Jeffrey D. Dunn, as its president and chief executive.

headline: Human Misery and Menace, Run Amok
abstract: “Frontline,” on PBS, looks at the Ebola outbreak in West Africa and atrocities in Nigeria related to the hunt for Boko Haram.
lead_paragraph: The PBS series “Frontline” pours a double shot of dismal on Tuesday in a program that examines the Ebola outbreak in West Africa and atrocities in Nigeria related to the hunt for Boko Haram.

headline: Cuomo and Teachout Duel, if Only Briefly
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at a Times Square rally, made two unusual moves: He went after his rival Zephyr Teachout and backed state tuition aid for undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Zephyr Teachout, the liberal law professor waging a long-shot primary challenge against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, made a final plea to frustrated Democrats on Monday, while the governor touted his successes in Albany and assailed his opponent as unqualified.

headline: A Guitarist Lays Aside Abstractions and Keeps It Sweet, Giving What’s Required
abstract: Sir Richard Bishop’s guitar solo concert on Saturday in Brooklyn featured tonal, melodic and straightforward compositions, mostly his own.
lead_paragraph: Sir Richard Bishop stayed on his dulcet, decorous side at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn, which opened its season on Saturday night with a double bill of guitar solos from Mr. Bishop and Tashi Dorji. Mr. Bishop’s pieces, for electric guitar, were tonal, melodic and straightforward — mostly his own, although he did play a splintered, close-up version of the Beatles’ “She Loves You” that lingered over every iota of the song’s harmonic tension.

headline: Milly: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Pension Funds Join Lawsuit on High-Frequency Trading
abstract: Four pension funds, including one in Boston and another in Stockholm, claim that major stock exchanges improperly favored high-frequency traders at the expense of other investors.
lead_paragraph: A group of pension funds has joined with the City of Providence, R.I., in a lawsuit that claims that major stock exchanges improperly favored high-frequency traders at the expense of other investors.

headline: Ancient Greek Tomb Yields Two Large Statues
abstract: Archaelogists excavating what is described as the largest ancient tomb discovered in Greece say they have found two caryatids, large female figures apparently meant to guard the tomb’s treasures.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists excavating a recently discovered tomb at Amphipolis in northern Greece have found two caryatids – large female figures in tunics — placed as supports at the opening of the tomb, Agence France-Presse reported on Monday. The figures were holding up a lintel at the entrance, and were apparently meant to guard the treasures inside the tomb, which dates from the fourth century B.C. and which archaeologists described as the largest ancient tomb discovered in Greece.

headline: U.S. Open 2014 Live Blog: Marin Cilic Defeats Kei Nishikori for Men’s Title
abstract: After two stunning upsets in the semifinals, what had been an uneventful men’s tournament at the United States Open will culminate in one of the most unexpected finals in recent memory: 10th-seeded Kei Nishikori vs. 14th-seeded Marin Cilic.
lead_paragraph: Marin Cilic, the 14th seed, became the unlikeliest winner of a men’s Grand Slam title in a decade, beating 10th-seeded Kei Nishikori in a lopsided 6-3, 6-3, 6-3 rout in the United States Open men’s singles final.

headline: Striving for a Delicate Balance, Even in Times of Change
abstract: The Cassatt String Quartet’s performance at Bargemusic on Sunday was a program of works by Dvorak, Beethoven and Franck.
lead_paragraph: In the final movement of the Cassatt String Quartet’s performance of Dvorak’s “American” Quartet at Bargemusic on Sunday afternoon, a passing water taxi created a bow wake so strong that it sent a jolt through the barge, briefly pitching the stage forward. The violist Sarah Adams smiled as she shot a glance at her colleagues, who kept their eyes fixed on the music. In their playing, the wave did not register as so much as a hiccup.

headline: A Twitterholic and Green Blogger Assesses a Year of Living Offline
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Environment', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: A longtime environmental blogger and Twitter addict logs on after a year of self-imposed exile to the analog world.
lead_paragraph: You may be among those, like me, who confronted a great digital emptiness over the last 12 months as Grist’s prolific environmental and political blogger and Twitter presence David Roberts went into a self-imposed offline exile. He’s back, having learned a thing or two, and he charts his 12 months of analog living in the October issue of Outside Magazine. It’s this week’s essential reading for students in my Blogging a Better Planet course at Pace University.

headline: Pair of Partygoers Turn Up the Heat in the Kitchen
abstract: In Kim Davies’s “Smoke,” two strangers engage in erotic power games in a kitchen at an uptown sex party.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, the sexual power games in David Ives’s “Venus in Fur” seem distant, almost artificial.

headline: Moments of Color Amid a Steady Parade of White
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Abiah Hostvedt, a Jamaica born model, topped Models.com’s list of men cast to work on designer runways. Yet in numerical terms white models overwhelmingly dominated fashion week shows.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t believe we’re still having this conversation in 2014,’’ said Wendell Brown, the senior fashion editor of Esquire and a highly sought after fashion stylist, referring to a persistent tendency among designers to ignore what the writer Grace Paley once called New York’s gorgeous chromatic dispersion.

headline: European Commission Delays Google Antitrust Settlement After Competitors’ Complaints
abstract: A plan to give competitors more equal status in the results displayed by Google searches faces further scrutiny after objections by companies like Microsoft and German publishing groups.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Commission pressed Google for adjustments to a proposed antitrust settlement on Monday, further delaying a resolution of the long-running case.

headline: Braintree, Popular Payments Processor, to Accept Bitcoin
abstract: Many of Braintree’s clients are tech start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and TaskRabbit, businesses that are looking for easy ways to integrate payments into their products for a low cost.
lead_paragraph: Soon, you may be able to pay for your next Uber ride with Bitcoin.

headline: Exploring the Connection Between Alcohol and Dementia
abstract: Even in patients with “pure” Alzheimer’s disease or another kind of dementia, most experts recommend greatly moderating alcohol consumption or eliminating it.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a difference between alcoholic dementia and “regular” dementia in the elderly?

headline: White Lyan in East London: A Bar Beyond the Status Quo
abstract: A motivation for the White Lyan in East London was ingredient and production control, born of the question, “Is this the best version of the drinks we want to put out?”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More so than drinkers in American cocktail capitals like New York and San Francisco, barflies in London seem to like their drink with a side of theater. Artesian, a bar inside the luxe Langham Hotel, delivers its creations with a clown-car-full of circus tricks, from balloons filled with scent to actual smoke and mirrors. Nightjar, a speakeasy in East London, sends drinks out in vessels shaped like owls and top hats.

headline: What Made Me | Thakoon Panichgul
abstract: The fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul describes his childhood move from Bangkok to Omaha and how Bruce Weber’s photography inspired his American aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul describes his childhood move from Bangkok to Omaha and how Bruce Weber’s photography inspired his American aesthetic.

headline: London Calls Him to Dinner
abstract: On a trip to London last spring, Mark Bittman ate at Restaurant Story, Chiltern Firehouse, Gymkhana and Barnyard
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More or less chronologically, my favorite restaurant towns of the last 20 years have been New York, Paris, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and now, London. It’s been London for a few years, although a quarter-century ago — when the London restaurant scene began to explode — such a statement would have been unthinkable. Back then, I went and looked for eel pie. Back then, my attention was directed toward New York and Paris.

headline: Diving With Ironman
abstract: Off Greece, an expedition will soon use a dive suit that looks a lot like a superhero’s exoskeleton to try to recover more of the Antikythera Mechanism, a complex astronomical calculator.
lead_paragraph: Off Greece, an expedition will soon use a dive suit that looks a lot like a superhero’s exoskeleton to try to recover more of the Antikythera Mechanism, a complex astronomical calculator.

headline: Doctors’ Magical Thinking About Conflicts of Interest
abstract: A study finds that many physicians who vote on whether to recommend approvals of drugs have a financial interest in the drug or its maker.
lead_paragraph: When the Food and Drug Administration creates an advisory committee to help it decide whether to approve drugs, it often asks academic physicians to serve on the committee as external experts. This is supposed to help the committee render judgments that are unbiased and scientific.

headline: Your Evening Briefing

headline: Health Chief Seeks to Focus on Insurance Site
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, said that she would emphasize improving the management and operation of the site.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of Health and Human Services, said Monday in her first major speech that she wanted to move beyond the politics of health care and work with members of both parties to improve the management and operation of HealthCare.gov, the website used by millions of people to sign up for insurance coverage.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Rick Owens and Bill Maher
abstract: The fashion designer and the stand-up comedian tackle furry shoes, fancy toothpaste and a new film about Nick Cave.
lead_paragraph: Rick Owens, dark prince of fashion whose label has inspired a cultlike following, takes on Bill Maher, religion-skewering stand-up and polarizing late-night politico whose HBO series, “Real Time With Bill Maher,” is currently in its 12th season. A new live comedy show on the network airs this month. (A 25-foot sculpture of the California-bred Owens is currently on view at Selfridges in London to celebrate his limited-edition collection for the high-end department store.)

headline: In Performance | McElwee and Mendes

headline: Death by Audio to Close in November
abstract: The Brooklyn rock club and musicians’ work space, which sprang up in a Williamsburg warehouse in 2007, will close on Nov. 22.
lead_paragraph: Death by Audio, the Brooklyn rock club and musicians’ work space that sprang up in a Williamsburg warehouse in 2007, will be closing on Nov. 22, according to a note posted on club’s website on Monday.

headline: ‘Forum’ Revival Has Been Postponed
abstract: A Broadway revival of “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum” has been postponed now that the star, James Corden, has been named the new host of “The Late, Late Show” on CBS.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway revival of “A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,” which had been in the works as a vehicle for the Tony Award winner James Corden (“One Man, Two Guvnors”), below, has been postponed now that Mr. Corden has been named the new host of “The Late, Late Show” on CBS. A spokesman for the “Forum” producers said Monday that they had concluded “that time was beginning to run out to cast and produce” the revival, which was intended for the spring. The Tony Award nominee Alex Timbers (“Rocky,” “Here Lies Love”) had been on tap to direct the musical comedy, which has music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and won the best musical Tony in 1963. The spokesman had no additional details about a possible future for the project. Playbill.com reported the postponement on Monday.

headline: Star-Covered Booties at Tommy Hilfiger

headline: A Superhero of Sorts in a Hunt for Artifacts
abstract: When a team of archaeologists explore the site of an ancient shipwreck this month, they will use a suit evocative of “Iron Man” that will allow for longer dives.
lead_paragraph: An international team of archaeologists plans to return this month to the site of an ancient shipwreck off a Greek island. This time, they will have the aid of an advanced diving suit that will give them much more time to probe for new artifacts.

headline: Long View of History Includes Today
abstract: Henry Kissinger’s latest book, “World Order,” views history in the light of philosophy of realpolitik.
lead_paragraph: Given the multiplying foreign policy emergencies in the headlines, from the advance of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) to the face-off between Russia and Ukraine, the subject of Henry Kissinger’s new book, “World Order,” could not be more timely. However the reader may regard the author’s own historical baggage, the book puts the problems of today’s world and America’s role in that increasingly interconnected and increasingly riven world into useful — and often illuminating — context.

headline: New V.A. Secretary Says Hiring Spree Is Needed to Meet Patient Demand
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Robert A. McDonald, the new secretary of Veterans Affairs, said it would be difficult, but the department needed to hire “tens of thousands” of doctors, nurses and clinicians to reduce wait times.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The new secretary of Veterans Affairs said Monday that the department needed to hire “tens of thousands of new doctors, new nurses, new clinicians” — emphasizing the significance of a shortage of employees who are directly involved in treating patients, a factor many experts said was a main driver in the waiting-list scandal that rocked the agency this year.

headline: A War Is Long Over, but Many Still Seek to Learn Its Lessons
abstract: The historian Margaret MacMillan finds uneasy parallels between our time and 1914.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — Margaret MacMillan, who has written one of the best recent histories of the origins of World War I, finds the current fascination with the war gratifying but odd, even with this year’s 100th anniversary commemorations. She says she thinks that today’s interest lies as much in the very confusion surrounding the causes of the Great War as in the parallels to our own anxious, transitional time.

headline: An American Yazidi Trying to Save Iraqi Yazidis
abstract: Sharifa Khalil was just days old when her family crawled under a fence at the Iraq-Syria border in 1988 to escape Saddam Hussein’s rule. Now a resident of Lincoln, Nebraska, Sharifa is working with other members of the persecuted Yazidi minority to try to avert a genocide of the Yazidis back in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Sharifa Khalil was just days old when her family crawled under a fence at the Iraq-Syria border in 1988 to escape Saddam Hussein’s rule. She arrived in the United States at age 11, after years as a refugee, unable to speak or read English, but thrived in school, graduating high school with honors.

headline: NASA Missions Approved to Go On
abstract: In a presentation last week, NASA said that it would continue all seven of its long-running scientific missions, if the agency found the funds to do so.
lead_paragraph: Every two years, NASA reviews its long-running scientific missions — currently, the rovers trundling across Mars, the Cassini spacecraft exploring Saturn, and four others — to determine whether they are justifying their cost.

abstract: More than six months after protesters drove Viktor F. Yanukovych from power, his lavish estate displays how difficult it is to bring about a real break with Ukraine’s past.
lead_paragraph: VYSHOROD, Ukraine — It was supposed to become a Museum of Corruption, a triumphant trophy of Ukraine’s February revolution and a monument to its new leaders’ determination to uproot the lawlessness and avarice that blighted this country’s first two decades as an independent nation.

American University reallocated scholarships from well-off students to needy ones. Grinnell set a floor on the share of every freshman class – 15 percent – whose parents didn’t go to college.

Bratton sat before the New York City Council, his hands often posed flatly on the table before him, his Boston accent echoing through the packed hearing room as he responded to a succession of questions on his plans to overhaul officer training.

headline: Love as Addiction, and Accepting It
abstract: In new albums, Banks studies love as a compulsion, Lee Brice wrestles with his limitations, and Loudon Wainwright III deals with aging with wry smiles.
lead_paragraph: Romance demands warning labels on “Goddess” (Harvest), the debut album by Jillian Banks, the Los Angeles songwriter who simply calls herself Banks. “What if I said I would break your heart?/What if I said I had problems that made me mean?” she sings in “You Should Know Where I’m Coming From,” a dark piano hymn, then adds, “Maybe you can see that I just may be too crazy to love.” In “Alibi,” surrounded by synthesizer chords and twitchy programmed percussion, she realizes, “Something so warm turned out to be/Something that I should’ve known would be the death.”

headline: Among the Ancient Stones, Magic as Potent as Ever
abstract: How do you renovate ancient stone arrangements? At Stonehenge, that meant reconfiguring a highway and building a new visitor center.
lead_paragraph: WILTSHIRE DOWNS, England — Standing at the center of the Stone Circle of Stonehenge in the moments before dawn, lulled by low-hanging rain clouds, I am, for a while, unable to understand why so many pilgrimages have been made here. Sure, the setting is attractively pastoral, with gently rolling fields and dark patches of trees on distant hills. But the vista verges on the ordinary.

headline: Unlike Anything They Have Ever Seen Before
abstract: Two species of deep-sea dwelling, mushroom-shaped organisms discovered off the coast of Southeast Australia defy all existing classifications of life.
lead_paragraph: Two species of deep-sea dwelling, mushroom-shaped organisms discovered off the coast of Southeast Australia defy all existing classifications of life, researchers from the University of Copenhagen say. The organisms, described in the journal PLOS One, are multicellular and nonsymmetrical, and live 400 to 1000 meters deep. They have been classified in an aptly named new genus, Dendrogramma enigmatica.

headline: In-Flight Rage? Understandable, but Rare
abstract: Cramped conditions in the back of a plane can severely test passenger equanimity, as recent episodes over reclining seats illustrate. But such incidents are actually not common.

lead_paragraph: Ticket sales declined at every Broadway show last week except one: “It’s Only a Play,” the Terrence McNally comedy starring Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick, which became the rare Broadway play to gross more than $1 million for a week of preview performances.

lead_paragraph: In the latest installment of “By the Numbers,” we take a look at the storied 32-year career of the Zenned-out superproducer and Def Jam Records co-founder Rick Rubin. Here, T’s editors share their favorite tracks from Rubin’s wide-ranging catalog, a selection of which can be heard in a Spotify playlist at the bottom of the page.

(The conversation has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Knots Landing at Carolina Herrera
abstract: The painterly large-format prints and sculptural tailoring at today’s Carolina Herrera show called for a striking beauty look to match.
lead_paragraph: The painterly large-format prints and sculptural tailoring at today’s Carolina Herrera show called for a striking beauty look to match. Complementing the makeup — clean skin, bold lips — were slick, scraped-back buns that resembled dramatic half-tied bows in back. Thanks to extensions and plenty of gel, the looped dos appeared to defy gravity.

headline: New York Hires Consultant to Create Rikers Island Reform Plan
abstract: In a wide-ranging review of the jail complex, McKinsey & Company will spend at least three months at Rikers and the Correction Department’s offices.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of revelations about pervasive brutality carried out by jail staff and other serious problems at Rikers Island, New York’s correction commissioner announced on Monday that the city had hired the management consulting firm McKinsey & Company, mostly known for its work advising corporations, to develop a plan for reforms.

headline: At End of Long Road, an Effortless Victory

lead_paragraph: After the worry and the wait; after other years’ nerves and last year’s bitterness, it suddenly looked easy for Marin Cilic.

headline: What Will Doom the Death Penalty
abstract: Capital punishment is inefficient, exorbitant and unsatisfying.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — TO opponents of the death penalty, recent accounts of botched executions and DNA-based exonerations of death-row prisoners have revived hope that judges and voters will finally see capital punishment for what it is: an intolerable affront to human dignity.

headline: The Stresses That Put Doctors at Risk
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article about doctor suicides.

headline: The Secret Behind Donna Karan’s Elaborate Braids
abstract: Perhaps the most over-the-top take on New York Fashion Week’s breakout hairstyle yet, Eugene Souleiman’s complex plaits required four hands and two packs of hair extensions per model.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Donna Karan this afternoon, the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman was crouched on the floor, crisscrossing sections of hair, with two assistants by his side. It was a sea of hands weaving back and forth, like a carefully choreographed dance number. When he finished, he stood back from the plait he had just created and said, with a bemused smile, “I don’t even know what you call this braid!” But he was keen to describe his inspiration. “The textiles in the collection are Basquiat-like, or like a Miró print — everything is very illustrative,” he said. “So I wanted to make a braid like a paintbrush.” The technique required at least four hands and two packs of hair extensions per model, but wasn’t too high-fashion to escape a summer-camp reference: “It’s a bit like that style of braiding used to make keychains!”

headline: NATO Challenge on the Edge of Its Mandate
abstract: Some say its role is for members only, but others take a broader view of security concerns.

headline: A Bartender’s Tools Stir Up Trouble at Airport Security
abstract: If Charles Joly needs his muddlers, zesters and wine keys for a presentation on the art of bartending, he knows not to pack them in his carry-on.
lead_paragraph: IF I could have one of those sci-fi teleporters, I probably wouldn’t go to the airport. But that’s not happening, so I do what I have to do to get where I need to go.

headline: In Era of Iconoclasts, Imagination Took Wing on Beekman Place
abstract: Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of the shah of Iran and a crusading women’s rights advocate, found refuge in No. 29, while Paul Rudolph, the cerebral modernist and dean of the Yale School of Architecture, turned No. 23 into his personal laboratory.
lead_paragraph: Beekman Place is about as far off the beaten path as one can get in Manhattan. Stretching just two blocks between East 49th and East 51st Streets on a bluff overlooking the East River, it is one of the shortest streets on the island and looks like many others, with grand old townhouses and stately prewar apartment buildings.

headline: Ferguson Sets Broad Change for City Courts
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'City Councils']

headline: Thakoon Panichgul, All-American Fashion Designer, on His Influences

lead_paragraph: Since starting out a decade ago, Thakoon Panichgul has become a favorite of both editors and celebrities for his playful, approachable women’s wear. In the latest installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, the Thai-American designer, who showed his spring 2015 collection in New York yesterday, reveals how moving from Bangkok to Omaha at age 11 and discovering the photography of Bruce Weber shaped his distinctly American aesthetic.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 5
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Monday was a hectic day, capped off by a stream of hats that kept everyone talking. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: Opting for an “unfashionably early, unusually quiet and ruckus-proof slot,” Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen jump-started the fifth day of Fashion Week with The Row’s ethereal, airy show. Carolina Herrera’s colorful, flower-inspired designs came next, followed by a cacophonous drum set at Tommy Hilfiger (along with another sighting of the reality-star-turned-model Kendall Jenner).

headline: Washington: Closings and Layoffs for Megachurch
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: An evangelical megachurch based in the Seattle area has announced that it is closing several campuses and laying off staff members because criticism of the church’s founding pastor has caused a drop in attendance and contributions.
lead_paragraph: An evangelical megachurch based in the Seattle area has announced that it is closing several campuses and laying off staff members because criticism of the church’s founding pastor has caused a drop in attendance and contributions. The megachurch, Mars Hill Church, said it would merge three campuses in Seattle and end its affiliation with one in Phoenix; abandon a plan to open a campus in Los Angeles; and prepare to close a campus in Huntington Beach, Calif., unless fund-raising there improved. It also said it was laying off a significant but unspecified number of employees. The church has been hurt by criticism of its senior pastor, Mark Driscoll, a prominent speaker and author who has come under fire for his management style, which some found to be inappropriately bullying. Mr. Driscoll is on a voluntary leave while a church panel reviews complaints against him.

headline: Ebola Cases Reported Up Sharply in Liberia
abstract: The World Health Organization said the number of new patients in Liberia pointed to “a large but previously invisible caseload.”
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization issued a dire Ebola warning on Monday concerning Liberia, saying that the number of afflicted patients was increasing exponentially, that nearly all the country has confirmed cases and that all new treatment facilities were overwhelmed, “pointing to a large but previously invisible caseload.”

headline: Christie Unilaterally Lifts Sports-Betting Prohibition
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie issued a directive on Monday saying that the state would not prosecute casinos and racetracks for accepting wagers on most athletic contests.
lead_paragraph: In his most aggressive gambit yet to bring sports betting to the aid of New Jersey’s ailing casino industry, Gov. Chris Christie issued a directive on Monday saying that the state would not prosecute casinos and racetracks for accepting wagers on most athletic contests.

headline: Respiratory Virus Sickens Children in the Midwest
abstract: For reasons that are not yet clear, hospitals in the Midwest and West are seeing an unusually large spike in suspected cases and a large number of children who need critical care.
lead_paragraph: A virus that causes severe respiratory illness has sickened dozens of children in Illinois and Missouri and may be fueling outbreaks in at least 10 other states, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Monday.

headline: Magda Olivero, Frenzy-Inspiring Soprano, Dies at 104
abstract: Miss Olivero inspired deep devotion, as well as bootleg recordings and thundering ovations.
lead_paragraph: Magda Olivero, an Italian soprano who for decades whipped audiences around the world into a frenzy of adulation that was operatic even by operatic standards — despite the fact that by her own ready admission she did not possess an especially lovely voice — died on Monday in Milan. She was 104.

headline: They Built It. People Came. Now They Go.

abstract: A government program to solve Mexico’s chronic housing shortage produced huge developments without jobs or supporting services, forcing thousands of new owners to abandon their homes.
lead_paragraph: ZUMPANGO, Mexico — In an enormous housing development on the edge of this scrappy commuter town, Lorena Serrano’s 11-foot-wide shoe box of a home is flanked by abandoned houses. The neighborhood has two schools, a few bodegas and a small community center that offers zumba classes.

headline: Hawks Owner Had His Struggles With Two Atlanta Sports Franchises
abstract: Bruce Levenson, who said Sunday he would sell his controlling interest in the basketball team as a result of a racially charged email he wrote in 2012, also owned the N.H.L.’s Thrashers.

headline: When Yes Means Yes
abstract: The governor of California should sign a bill that requires colleges to redefine sexual consent from the traditional “no means no” with “affirmative consent.”
lead_paragraph: The California Legislature recently approved a bill that would require colleges receiving state-financed student aid to change the definition of consent in their sexual assault policies, replacing the traditional “no means no” standard with “affirmative consent,” known colloquially as “yes means yes.” The burden would rest on the student initiating sex to obtain a “yes,” rather than on the intended partner to convey a “no.” Gov. Jerry Brown has until the end of September to sign the bill, which he should.

headline: Advocates Voice Dismay Over Delay on Immigration
abstract: Immigration rights advocates accuse President Obama of bowing to partisan political interests by putting off promised executive actions.
lead_paragraph: For Seleste Wisniewski, a mother of four in Ohio, President Obama’s decision to delay executive action on immigration until after the midterm elections in November was an especially disappointing blow. It means that her Mexican husband is likely to be deported in the coming days.

headline: Obsolete Zero Tolerance on Pot
abstract: Many employers in states that have legalized recreational or medical marijuana are penalizing workers for off-premise activity that is legal.
lead_paragraph: Even marijuana companies don’t want their employees stoned on the job. But in states that have legalized marijuana for recreational or medical use, many employers have retained or imposed “no tolerance” policies, penalizing workers for off-premise activity that is perfectly legal.

abstract: President Obama will have to explain how the United States can avoid entanglement in another military morass if it moves more aggressively into Syria.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said on Sunday that now is the time “to start going on some offense” against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, the Sunni extremist group that is overrunning northern Iraq and has a stronghold in Syria. That would be a serious escalation of the American role there.

lead_paragraph: Serena Williams saved her up-and-down year by winning the United States Open, her 18th Grand Slam singles title, but she still had work to do after match point.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama addresses the nation on Wednesday to explain his plan to defeat Islamic extremists in Iraq and Syria, it is a fair bet he will not call them the “JV team.”

headline: Inversion Delusion
abstract: The argument is bogus that corporations leave the U.S. and set up overseas because of high corporate tax rates.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Tax Policy Center in Washington held a panel discussion on the subject of “corporate inversions” — the practice of taking over a small company in someplace like Ireland or the Netherlands, and then using that takeover to “relocate” to the foreign country for tax reasons. One of the panelists was John Samuels, the chief tax lawyer for General Electric.

headline: Climate Change Will Disrupt Half of North America’s Bird Species, Study Says
abstract: The National Audubon Society foresees danger for more than half of the 650 species of birds in North America.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore oriole will probably no longer live in Maryland, the common loon might leave Minnesota, and the trumpeter swan could be entirely gone.

headline: Somalia: Rebels Kill at Least 12 in Attack on Convoy
abstract: At least 12 people were killed and more than 27 were wounded when suicide bombers attacked a convoy carrying African Union troops and Somali officials, officials and witnesses said.
lead_paragraph: At least 12 people were killed and more than 27 were wounded on Monday when suicide bombers attacked a convoy carrying African Union troops and Somali officials south of the capital, officials and witnesses said. The convoy was traveling to Afgooye, about 18 miles south of Mogadishu, the capital, when it was attacked near the Calamada area, above, said Abdulkadir Mohamed Nur Siidii, a regional governor, who was riding in the convoy. One bomber detonated his explosives near a minibus, killing 12 civilians, and the other hit a vehicle in the convoy, officials and witnesses said. Two foreign military advisers and two African peacekeepers were among the wounded, the governor said, but civilians bore the brunt of the attack. The Islamist militant group known as the Shabab claimed responsibility for the attack. The leader of the Shabab, Ahmed Abdi Godane, was killed in a recent American airstrike, and the group has vowed to avenge his death.

headline: Shifting Polls in Scotland Send Investors Rushing for Shelter
abstract: A poll showing that Scottish voters for the first time favor independence set off a sharp decline in the British pound and the stocks of financial institutions with large operations in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Scotland, home to just five million people, has never weighed on the minds of currency traders and market investors the way that Russia or China or the eurozone has — until now.

lead_paragraph: Seven of Broadway’s 40 theaters will dim their marquee lights at 6:45 p.m. Tuesday to honor Joan Rivers, following an outcry among some theater producers and others that Ms. Rivers — a Tony Award nominee for best actress in 1994 — deserved the tribute.

lead_paragraph: It took six pitches for the Mets to flip what looked to be another dismal loss into a late win over the Colorado Rockies at Citi Field on Monday night.

lead_paragraph: TUXEDO, N.Y. — As New York State considers a roulette wheel’s worth of options for how it should enter the Las Vegas-style casino business, none is as audacious as the proposal of a Malaysian conglomerate called Genting Group.

headline: Where Nishikori Learned to Play, Support in Grand Proportions
abstract: A crowd of about 900 people gathered in Kei Nishikori’s hometown in Japan at 6 a.m. to watch him in the U.S. Open final, and they expressed pride despite his loss.
lead_paragraph: MATSUE, Japan — The residents of this town poured in by the hundreds in the predawn hours, filling the main auditorium at the Shimane Prefectural Convention Center to watch on a huge screen as their native son took a shot at winning the United States Open.

headline: Junior’s, Legendary Restaurant, Is to Stay in Brooklyn
abstract: After considering a sale of the two-story building, the owner of the spot famous for its cheesecake turned down several multimillion-dollar offers and chose to stay put.
lead_paragraph: Junior’s Restaurant has earned a lot of superlatives since it opened in Downtown Brooklyn on Election Day in 1950, among them the one that adorns every orange takeout box: “The Best Cheesecake in N.Y. — New York Magazine” (a distinction that dates to 1973, but still).

keywords: ['Street Performers', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Street Vendors (Non-Food)', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Councilman Andy King of the Bronx said he wanted characters to be licensed by the city and to submit to background checks and that he would introduce a bill this week to institute those requirements.
lead_paragraph: Over the vocal objections of several Elmos, a few Mickey Mouses and a Buzz Lightyear, a member of the City Council announced legislation on Monday to regulate Times Square’s ubiquitous costumed characters and their occasionally aggressive solicitations.

headline: The Times’s Baghdad Bureau Chief Answers Questions on Iraq
abstract: Tim Arango answered questions on Reddit about what it’s like to report from Iraq for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Tim Arango, The New York Times’s Baghdad bureau chief since 2010, answered questions on the popular “Ask Me Anything” section of the social site Reddit. Mr. Arango’s recent coverage has focused on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, as the Sunni militant group has seized territory across the region. He reported last week on the only known survivor of an ISIS massacre that took place in June.

headline: David Carr Interviews Dean Baquet

(13) ROBIN WILLIAMS REMEMBERED: A PIONEERS OF TELEVISION SPECIAL Pam Dawber, Henry Winkler, Yakov Smirnoff, Louie Anderson, Paul Rodriguez, Penny Marshall and Whoopi Goldberg, among others, pay tribute to Williams (above right, with Mr. Winkler), who died on Aug. 11.
