headline: Trial of Chinese Human Rights Campaigner Is to Begin
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Yang Maodong, better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, has long been at the forefront of contentious causes in southern China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The trial of Yang Maodong, a human rights activist accused of assembling a crowd to disrupt public order, will begin in southern China this week, his lawyer and his sister said on Tuesday. They said Mr. Yang, who has long been at the forefront of contentious causes, would fight the charge but acknowledged that he was likely to be convicted and imprisoned.

headline: Test Yourself | Texting Anxiety Caused by Little Bubbles

headline: Malaysian Jet Over Ukraine Was Downed by ‘High-Energy Objects,’ Dutch Investigators Say
abstract: The report shed no light on who was responsible for the crash.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Eight weeks after a Malaysia Airlines plane disintegrated over eastern Ukraine, killing all 298 people aboard and triggering a frenzy of East-West finger-pointing, investigators, in their first account of the calamity on Tuesday, released evidence consistent with an attack by a surface-to-air missile but shed no clear light on who was responsible.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | When Worker Bees Get a Promotion
abstract: How might scientists use similar data-rich surveillance to learn more about other insects’ behavior?
lead_paragraph: In the ScienceTake video “When Worker Bees Get a Promotion,” James Gorman explains new discoveries about bee behavior.

headline: Are Subprime Mortgages Coming Back?
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Economy', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Six years after the housing bust, the return of riskier mortgage lending may be inevitable — and welcome.
lead_paragraph: Ali and Mariluci Sleiman wanted to buy a house. The couple, who run a day care service inside their first-floor rental apartment, had outgrown their space in Taunton, a small city in southern Massachusetts. They also wanted to avoid answering to a landlord who might complain about 10 little kids running around all day. They were “desperate to buy a home,” Ali told me. And with good credit and $46,000 in joint income, they hoped they wouldn’t have a hard time getting a loan. So they were disappointed when the bank rejected their application, and then when a local credit union did too.

headline: Do Sports Teams Have a Responsibility to Hold Players to a Standard for Their Personal Conduct?
abstract: How seriously should teams take allegations and evidence of wrongdoing in players’ personal lives?
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Ravens dropped the star running back Ray Rice from the team after TMZ published a graphic video Monday of him punching his former fiancée, who is now his wife. Before the video had emerged, the N.F.L. had only suspended Rice in July for two games — a decision that drew immediate criticism from commentators to players to women’s advocates.

headline: Near Death, and Overmedicated
abstract: Why are patients with advanced dementia so often receiving “medications of questionable benefit”?
lead_paragraph: How sick and disabled, how far into advanced dementia, how close to death do elderly nursing home patients have to be before their physicians stop prescribing drugs that can cause uncomfortable side effects but show scant evidence of helping them?

headline: How Much of the Worst Summer of News Ever Can You Take?
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Ebola Virus', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: This summer has given us horrific news story after horrific news story. Does this inevitably lead to “compassion fatigue,” and if so, how can we fight it?
lead_paragraph: In case you’ve been living under a rock, this summer has been full of catastrophic news. Since June, Boko Haram has continued to kidnap girls and women in northeastern Nigeria, Ukrainian separatists shot down Malaysia Flight 17, the death toll in Syria surpassed 190,000 and thousands of children from Central America trekked to the United States border to flee unprecedented violence.

headline: A Witness to AIDS in South Africa
abstract: Joao Silva has watched South Africa’s response to the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic go from denial to ensuring those afflicted by the virus get the treatment and medications they need.
lead_paragraph: At the turn of the millennium, when the AIDS epidemic raged unchecked through South Africa with devastating consequences, the rural areas were worst hit. In the men’s ward of the impoverished Hlabisa Hospital in rural KwaZulu-Natal, patients shared mattresses on the floor, the terminally ill were sent home to die because of nonexistent facilities and unclaimed corpses were buried in unadorned mass graves on the outskirts of town.

headline: Chinese State Broadcaster Gets Its American Rices Confused
abstract: China Central Television used images of Condoleezza Rice in a report about a Beijing visit by Susan E. Rice, President Obama’s national security adviser.
lead_paragraph: China Central Television mistakenly used images of Condoleezza Rice, the former United States secretary of state who left office in 2009, in a report on Sunday about the national security adviser Susan E. Rice’s visit to Beijing, which continued on Tuesday. The state-run broadcaster quickly corrected the gaffe, however. A day later, it posted on its website a version of the English-language report complete with images of the Obama administration official, according to The South China Morning Post. (The correct Rice is pictured below.)

abstract: The list includes the Americans Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler; the British writers Howard Jacobson, Neel Mukherjee and Ali Smith; and the Australian author Richard Flanagan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American authors Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler are among the six writers selected for the shortlist of the 2014 Man Booker Prize for Fiction, announced on Tuesday. Also on the shortlist are three British writers — Howard Jacobson, Neel Mukherjee and Ali Smith — and the Australian Richard Flanagan. The winner of the prize, worth around $80,000 and widely considered the most prestigious literary award in Britain, will be announced on Oct.14.

abstract: Emperor Hirohito said attacking the United States was “self-destructive,” an official history of his reign says.

headline: In Queens, a Triple Killing Shows Signs of Financial Strife
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: All of the victims had stab wounds, and a suicide note was found on the body of Jong Lee, police said, leading the authorities to believe that Mr. Lee killed his wife and son before killing himself.
lead_paragraph: In a short note written in Korean to a relative, Jong Lee complained of having “too many problems” in his life. The note did not elaborate on the nature of his problems, but those who knew the Queens man were aware of serious financial setbacks for his family, according to a police official who viewed a New York Police Department translation of the document.

headline: Thousands of Migrants Forced to Leave Israel, Rights Group Says
abstract: Human Rights Watch said the immigrants, primarily from Sudan and Eritrea, had been obliged to return home even though they were at risk of imprisonment or persecution.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Thousands of Sudanese migrants to Israel and hundreds of Eritreans have returned to their home countries this year as a result of an Israeli policy that amounts to “unlawful coercion,” Human Rights Watch said Tuesday. The group said the migrants had been left few other options even though they were at risk of imprisonment or abuse at the hands of repressive governments back home, and despite protections Israel is obligated to provide under international treaties.

headline: Scale of Flooding Hinders Relief Efforts in India and Pakistan

lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — After nearly a week of incessant rains and flooding that have left hundreds of people dead in Pakistan and the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, rescue operations have been strained by the scale of the disaster and a collapse of communications networks in some areas.

headline: 1889: Italy to Expel Hungarian
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Hungarian patriot drew condemnation from Berlin in 1889.
lead_paragraph: TURIN — It is announced on good authority that, at the request of the German Government, Signor Crispi has decided to expel Louis Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot, from Italy. The reasons upon which the request is founded are the visit of 800 Hungarians to Kossuth, and the speech the latter made against the policy of the Tisza Ministry. Not long after this the hero of the insurrection of 1848 said that it was greatly to be regretted that Hungary and Italy had placed themselves in a position which might force them into a war with France. This naturally gave great offence at Berlin and Vienna, and the German Foreign Office sent a note to Rome to the effect that the toleration of such language was incompatible with the conventions of the Triple Alliance. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 10, 1889

abstract: If you’ve never heard the name Lloyd J. Austin, there’s a good reason

headline: 1914: Belgians Flood Battlefield
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Belgians flooded a battlefield to halt a German advance in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP — It is possible now to realize what took place on Saturday and on Sunday [Sept. 6] in the combat at Termonde. There were about 7,000 Belgians, and they had to retire after a stiff fight. Having been reinforced, they returned to the fray, and the Germans had to retire whence they had come. Then the defenders flooded the country by opening the dykes, and the retreating Teutons were caught. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 10, 1914

Responding to a question from a pregnant woman, he wrote: “Abort it and try again. It would be immoral to bring it into the world if you have the choice,” he wrote on Twitter. He said that he based this on his belief that suffering should be reduced whenever possible.

headline: Weaving a Tale of Love and Death in London

lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few years ago, the British novelist Sarah Waters was playing around with ideas for her next book when she remembered a notorious 1920s trial she had once read about. Known popularly as the Thompson-Bywaters case, it featured a penny dreadful’s worth of combustible ingredients: an unexciting husband, a faithless wife, her much younger lover and a cache of racy, damning love letters.

headline: Ignoring the Warnings for a Honeymoon in Mexico

But it was January, the dead of Montana winter, and we unbolted the back seat of the station wagon and transformed it into a camper, a mattress in back, curtains over the windows, surfboards on the roof.

abstract: This new spot aims to bring upscale Oaxacan dining to a city where that’s still a rarity.

Now he’s hoping to do the same in Mexico’s capital, where Oaxacan food — despite its reputation as a culturally rich, complex cuisine — is still rare as an upscale dining option.

headline: How Unemployment Insurance Helps Prevent Foreclosures
abstract: From July 2008 through December 2012, $250 billion in federally funded unemployment benefits helped homeowners avoid an estimated 1.4 million foreclosures.
lead_paragraph: An updated tally by Moody’s Analytics shows that 6.5 million homeowners have lost their homes in the housing bust so far.  And for most of them, the proximate cause of foreclosure was unemployment. Losing a job meant losing the income to pay the mortgage, while depressed house values meant that struggling homeowners could not tap their equity to help cover their monthly expenses or sell at a price high enough to pay off their mortgage.

headline: Violence Against Children: Difficult and Heartbreaking to Report
abstract: Kim Barker discusses the reporting of the story of 12-year-old Maya Ranot, who the authorities said told them she was starved and beaten by her father and stepmother.
lead_paragraph: In May, authorities found Maya Ranot, a 12-year-old girl, in a pool of blood in her Queens kitchen, her wrist cut to the bone. Allegations later surfaced that Maya had been locked up, starved and beaten at various times between December 2012 and last May in what one news outlet called a “house of horrors.” The Queens district attorney announced abuse charges against Maya’s father and stepmother in August. The stepmother was accused of slashing Maya’s wrist with a broken metal broom handle.

headline: Broadway Theaters Will Dim Lights for Joan Rivers After All

abstract: Investigators are increasingly finding evidence of prescription, over-the-counter and illicit drugs in pilots who die in accidents, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Pilots killed in airplane crashes in 2012 tested positive for drugs four times more often than those killed in 1990, according to a study by the National Transportation Safety Board, although drawing a causal link between drugs and crashes was difficult.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Keira Knightley and ‘Laggies’
abstract: The actress discusses her role in the comedy “Laggies,” directed by Lynn Shelton.
lead_paragraph: The actress Keira Knightley has two films at the Toronto International Film Festival, appearing both in the period drama “The Imitation Game” with Benedict Cumberbatch, and starring in “Laggies,” a Lynn Shelton comedy. In this video, she discusses the film about a young woman at a crossroads, and the friendship she develops with a teenager (Chloë Grace Moretz).

headline: Have Apple Questions? We Have Answers.
abstract: Submit your questions about Apple’s new products, and Times reporters will provide answers.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, there have been rumors and speculation about Apple’s product announcements on Tuesday. Now that the company has announced its new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus, as well as its new payments system, we can get some answers.

headline: Buy Condo, Then Add Parking Spot for $1 Million
abstract: Sick of dents, dings and parking musical chairs? Parking spaces in a SoHo condo are selling for more per square foot than the apartments upstairs.
lead_paragraph: What will $1 million buy in New York City? A diamond-encrusted Cartier men’s watch. A small fleet of 2014 Bentley Continentals. Or maybe your very own parking spot in SoHo.

headline: Rodarte: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Apple’s Live-Streaming Is Terrible
abstract: While the company makes its much-anticipated announcements about its new products, it seems to be having a lot of trouble with the live-streaming of the event.
lead_paragraph: Finally, Apple’s product announcements have arrived. But for anyone wanting to watch the live-streaming, well, it’s extremely awkward.

headline: Take-Private Deals Are Nearly Extinct on Wall Street
abstract: Take-private deals have totaled just $3 billion this year, compared with $80 billion for all of last year, Goldman Sachs analysts said in a research report.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firms of Wall Street have all but stopped taking companies private.

headline: An Apartment in the Marais, With Complications and Family Secrets
abstract: In “My Old Lady,” a failed American playwright inherits a splendid Paris apartment, but French law gives his tenant the upper hand.
lead_paragraph: Perky music and a suave, light-footed entrance by Kevin Kline as an American in Paris give the early scenes of “My Old Lady” the feel of a Franco-American comedy in the vein of Cédric Klapisch’s recent “Chinese Puzzle.” But the 75-year-old playwright Israel Horovitz’s screen adaptation of his own 2002 production is not what it initially appears to be.

headline: Ex-Player Charged in Sale of Pills to Derek Boogaard
abstract: Jordan Hart, 31, of New York, was charged on Tuesday in a conspiracy to sell prescription painkillers to Derek Boogaard, the former Rangers player who died of an overdose in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks before he died of an overdose in 2011, Derek Boogaard of the Rangers was excused from his substance-abuse rehabilitation in California and returned to New York. He drove to Long Island, as he had done many times in the months before, and paid a man for illegally obtained prescription painkillers. This time, rather than cash, Boogaard paid with a personal check.

headline: Hawke, Gere to Be Honored at New York Film Festival
abstract: The actors will be the subject of gala tributes.
lead_paragraph: The Film Society of Lincoln Center will honor Ethan Hawke and Richard Gere in separate tributes as part of the New York Film Festival. Each will be the subject of one of the festival’s “An Evening With…” programs – Mr. Hawke on Sept. 30, Mr. Gere on Oct. 8. The “An Evening With…” galas are meant to recognize “the work of individuals who have made significant artistic contributions to film culture,” the society said.

headline: Libyan Refugees Stream to Tunisia for Care, and Tell of a Home That Is Torn Apart
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A new surge of refugees has arrived in Tunisia as fighting has spread to the Libyan capital, Tripoli. Their accounts depict a country spiraling into chaos.
lead_paragraph: SFAX, Tunisia — Libyans seeking medical care and a refuge from war are filling the private clinics in this coastal Tunisian city for the second time in three years, bringing with them fresh accounts of the violence racking their country.

headline: Hopes for a Strong El Niño Fade in California
keywords: ['Drought', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Weather']
abstract: In its latest monthly forecast, the federal Climate Prediction Center said that while El Niño was still expected, it would not bring the heavy rains California needs to end its drought.
lead_paragraph: Long-term weather forecasters say it is now unlikely that a strong El Niño will develop this fall, dimming hopes in California for heavy rains that might bring relief from a severe drought.

headline: How It Happens | El Niño
abstract: The weather phenomenon known as El Niño can cause dramatic effects around the world. Henry Fountain explains where it comes from.
lead_paragraph: The weather phenomenon known as El Niño can cause dramatic effects around the world. Henry Fountain explains where it comes from.

headline: The Trick to Those Piercing Eyes (and Brows) at Rodarte
abstract: Backstage, the makeup artist James Kaliardos created a look infused with the designers’ own beauty tricks.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist James Kaliardos has lent his face-painting skills to the Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy for so many seasons now that he jokes, “we almost have a psychic connection.” And backstage at Rodarte’s spring/summer 2015 fashion show today, the runway look he created was evidence of that bond. On the eyes, he buffed a dark pink-brown tone from the new Nars St-Paul-De-Vence Duo Eyeshadow palette over the lid, pulling the shade around the outer corners in a downward arc. “It’s inspired by how Laura does her makeup,” Kaliardos noted of the quirky technique. “She does this thing where she drags down the corner of her eye shadow, and I thought, ‘That’s kinda cool.'” Underneath, he traced a thin line of Nars Larger Than Life Long-Wear Eyeliner in Rue Bonaparte to “lift up the eyes” and dusted on a gold metallic shade for a little glitz. But the real attention-getter: the faux piercings that half the models wore on their brows. “They’re just cool facial accessories,” Kaliardos said of the silver rings adhered with glue. The model Kristina Petrosiute appreciated the (temporary) shock value. “I took a photo and sent it to my boyfriend,” she said. “He was like, ‘You look weird!’ But I like it!” For Xiao Wen Ju, the experience might even lead to some real piercings. “The eyebrow is not my style, but maybe I would do the lip,” she said. “I think the lip is really sexy.”

headline: The Risk in the General Mills Deal for Annie’s
abstract: The maker of Cheerios is paying a 37 percent premium, for “natural” macaroni and cheese purveyor Annie’s Homegrown. But big companies often squash growth when they swallow small targets whole, notes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: General Mills risks smothering its latest acquisition target.

headline: Wheelies: The Sonata Star Power Edition
abstract: Hyundai says Paul Rudd will voice its national advertising; Dodge begins delivery of the 707-horsepower Challenger Hellcat SRT.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The Promise of Smoother Waters
abstract: Barchetta in Chelsea could turn out to be the seafood restaurant that downtown needs.
lead_paragraph: You can count on one hand the chefs in New York who serve bluefish. Narrow the list to those with the confidence to serve it raw, and you’re probably down to one finger and one name: Dave Pasternack.

headline: Michael Schumacher Moved Home to Continue Rehabilitation
abstract: The family of the former Formula One champion said his recovery from a skiing accident would continue at his estate on the shore of Lake Geneva.
lead_paragraph: The family of Michael Schumacher, the 45-year-old former Formula One champion, said Tuesday that he had been moved from a hospital in Lausanne, Switzerland, to the family estate 25 miles away on Lake Geneva. They also said that efforts to rehabilitate him after the severe brain injuries he suffered while skiing in France nine months ago “will continue from now on from home.”

headline: In Nashville, Cooking and the Kings of Leon
abstract: The Kings of Leon are among the producers of the Music City Food and Wine Festival in Nashville this month, which will include more than 30 cooking demonstrations and a Harvest Night concert.
lead_paragraph: In Nashville, it can be difficult to focus on anything but music, but this month the Kings of Leon, Nashville musicians themselves, are helping put the spotlight on the city’s culinary and cocktail scene at the second annual Music City Food and Wine Festival.

headline: Senator McCaskill’s Opening Statement
abstract: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri spoke Tuesday at a hearing by the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs on local police militarization.
lead_paragraph: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri spoke Tuesday at a hearing by the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs on local police militarization.

headline: A Simple ‘Dump-It’ Meal for a Busy Tuesday
abstract: A dinner designed for a parent with more on his or her mind than “I wonder if rice wine vinegar or tarragon vinegar would be better here.”
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches one family, and all of us, in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal. Find all the Boot Camp recipes here.

headline: Narrow Health Networks: Maybe They’re Not So Bad
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Plans that limit patients’ choices tend to be cheaper, but there has been concern they will restrict care. A study suggests this concern is overblown.
lead_paragraph: Lots of people shopping in the new health care marketplaces this year picked health plans that limited their choice of doctors and hospitals. The plans were popular because they tended to cost less than more conventional plans that covered nearly every health care provider in a region.

headline: New Restaurants for the Beekman Hotel
abstract: Keith McNally and Tom Colicchio will open outposts in the landmark building, Mission Chinese Food gets a permanent home and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 5
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: Parties for Tod’s store, Calvin Klein’s Reveal perfume and InStyle’s 20th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Parties for Tod’s store, Calvin Klein’s Reveal perfume and InStyle’s 20th anniversary.

headline: The Sex Abuse Tangle
abstract: From Rome to Rotherham, Horace Mann to Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column dealt with the extremely grim subject of the recent revelations about rape and official indifference in the English city of Rotherham, where Pakistani gangs “groomed” and sexually assaulted hundred and hundreds of (mostly white) girls and young women while social workers and cops seemed to look the other way. My piece tried to contextualize the grievous failure of the English authorities by linking the disaster to other high-profile cases of sexual abuse — in Roman Catholicism, of course, but also in New York’s private schools, at Joe Paterno’s Penn State, in Hollywood, elsewhere — and after the column appeared I noticed a few readers and Twitterers suggesting that as a  Catholic I have an ulterior motive in generalizing about sex abuse, because generalizations are a good way to evade or minimize the particular sins of my own church.

headline: Mining the Depths of Loss, Faith and Mortality
abstract: “Gabriel: A Poem,” by Edward Hirsch, and “Once in the West,” by Christian Wiman, use verse to grapple with grief.
lead_paragraph: Lord of the Torrent, King of the Sudden Impulse, Emperor of the Impetuous, Clown of God. The poet Edward Hirsch’s son, Gabriel, was a handful, and the author and others had many private names for him.

headline: The Pros and Cons of Avoiding Credit Cards
abstract: Many younger people are forgoing credit cards, but a downside is that they aren’t establishing a credit history.
lead_paragraph: Millennials are far more likely than older adults to make do without credit cards.

headline: Linen Makes a Comeback at New York Fashion Week
abstract: Thanks to a few of New York’s finest — Victoria Beckham, The Row and Theory — flaxen fabric is looking less shabby, more chic.
lead_paragraph: Flax isn’t usually thought of as a high-fashion fabric: The wrinkle-prone textile works well for lived-in bedding and loose, low-key layers for weekend jaunts around Brooklyn. But thanks to a few of New York’s finest — Victoria Beckham, The Row and Theory — linen has a new lease on life. Victoria Beckham showed a series of mid calf-length belted coats, sleeveless tops and slit skirts in the material. The Row’s ethereal spring collection opened with basket-weave linen dresses that coiled around the body like snakes. And in Theory’s finely executed minimalist collection, a linen sleeveless trench worn over trousers looked less shabby, more chic.

headline: Diesel Black Gold: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Aides to Ayatollah Khamenei Tweet From His Hospital Room
abstract: Updates from the bedside of Iran’s supreme leader during his recovery from prostate surgery may have been intended to preempt rumors about his health.
lead_paragraph: As Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, recovers from prostate surgery, his social-media team has been unusually busy, sharing images and video clips on his Twitter feed that show visitors from across the Islamic Republic’s political spectrum flocking to his hospital room to pay their respects.

headline: Introducing Apple Watch
abstract: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, introduced a smartwatch, a wearable device that combines health and fitness tracking with communications.
lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, introduced a smartwatch, a wearable device that combines health and fitness tracking with communications.

headline: Lack of Sleep Is Ruled Factor in 2013 UPS Plane Crash
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board also found other errors that contributed to a crash that is reopening a debate about fatigue for pilots hauling packages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Short of sleep, confused about their altitude and relying on inaccurate weather information, the crew members of a UPS cargo plane trying to land at the airport in Birmingham, Ala., omitted several crucial steps that might have kept them from flying their aircraft into the ground in August 2013, investigators of the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday.

headline: The iPhone 6 Goes Big, as Apple Aims Small With a Smartwatch
abstract: The company introduced two new smartphones with larger screens and the Apple Watch, entering a crowded field that has yet to capture popular enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — After three years as chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook is starting to crystallize his vision for the company.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Rodarte Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: In Letter to Botox Maker, Ackman Attacks Board Inaction on Merger Talks
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: After being relatively restrained for several months, William Ackman of Pershing Square attacked what he said were a litany of actions taken by Allergan to squash the Valeant and Pershing Square offer.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund manager, has a penchant for writing scathing letters to those who cross him. But since directing his firm, Pershing Square Capital Management, to partner with Valeant Pharmaceuticals on a joint bid for Allergan in April, Mr. Ackman has been relatively restrained.

headline: Dreaming of Fashion (Literally)
abstract: Jan Erickson was inspired to create Janska, a line of comfortable fleece apparel, after a 2002 dream. She’s committed to making the clothing in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Jan Erickson was inspired to create Janska, a line of comfortable fleece apparel, after a 2002 dream. She’s committed to making the clothing in the United States.

headline: Other Wireless Events Struggle to Compete With Apple
abstract: Apple may hog the spotlight when it holds a big product release. But that doesn’t mean other companies are going to schedule their events around a rival.
lead_paragraph: Today, most of the tech world is focused on Apple’s foray into larger-screened phones and wearable devices. But why read about that when you can read this post about everything else?

headline: A Summer Job Isn’t What It Used to Be
abstract: A summer job flipping burgers or bussing tables used to be a way for teenagers to earn some money and gain work experience. Increasingly, it’s an indicator of life in the working class. What changed?
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, hard-working high school students who took a summer job or worked part-time during the school year got an edge over their unemployed peers. Not only did they earn some pocket money — which many students saved for college — but they were also likely to see increased earning potential long after they graduated.

headline: Marcel Dzama, Kim Gordon and Tim Kingsbury of Arcade Fire on Their Offbeat Short Film
abstract: Shot as a tribute to David Cronenberg, it makes its U.S. premiere at David Zwirner gallery tonight. An exclusive clip appears here.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian-born artist Marcel Dzama is known for his Dadaist multidisciplinary work — drawings, puppets, dioramas — and his collaborations on standout music videos. He was an art director on “The Suburbs,” the inventive Arcade Fire short film, and co-directed the spooky “No One Does It Like You” for Department of Eagles.

headline: U2 Releases New Album for Free on Apple’s iTunes
abstract: With virtually no advance notice, U2 has released “Songs of Innocence,” its first album since 2009, for free on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: With virtually no advance notice, U2 has released “Songs of Innocence,” its first album since “No Line on the Horizon” in 2009. Like Beyoncé and Radiohead before them, U2 skipped the elaborate promotional buildup that usually precedes a long-awaited album release. Instead, at 2:55 p.m. Eastern time Apple announced that the album was being given free to every iTunes store customer in 119 countries through Oct. 13. It includes 11 songs and a “digital booklet” with liner notes by Bono, U2’s singer.

headline: Fantasy Football: Waiver Wire Picks for Week 2
abstract: A look at players worth considering this week who are likely to be available on your league’s waiver wire.
lead_paragraph: Today we “celebrate” a day that will live forever in fantasy football infamy. Two years ago, there were quite a few fantasy owners scrambling to pick up a little known receiver on the Dallas Cowboys who had just racked up 114 receiving yards and 2 touchdowns against the Giants.

headline: A Closer Look at the Ebola Epidemic in the Context of Ecological Health
abstract: There’s a chance the Ebola outbreak could spur increased conservation and surveillance in ecosystems that might harbor dangerous pathogens.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola epidemic continues to rage in West Africa, and while it is very unlikely to reach pandemic scale (see The Economist), the outbreak provides a reminder of the linkages between disrupted ecosystems and human illness.

headline: Richard W. Davidson
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Mr. Davidson is the president and chief executive of Century 21 Real Estate, one of the world’s largest real estate franchisers.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Davidson, 54, is the president and chief executive of Century 21 Real Estate, one of the world’s largest real estate franchisers, with 6,900 offices and 102,000 sales associates in 75 countries and territories.

headline: Pegula, Owner of Sabres, to Acquire Bills
abstract: Terry Pegula and his family, who won the bidding to buy the Buffalo Bills from the estate of Ralph C. Wilson Jr., vowed that the team is “here to stay.”
lead_paragraph: After a five-month search, Terry Pegula and his family have won the bidding to buy the Buffalo Bills, which were owned by the team’s founder, Ralph C. Wilson Jr., until his death in March.

headline: What to Make of Wendy Davis’s Abortion Revelation
abstract: The candidate for Texas governor has reinforced the wisdom of letting women sort out their medical options.
lead_paragraph: It is too early to say whether Wendy Davis’s revelation of her own abortion will help, hinder or have no effect on her underdog campaign to become the first Democratic governor of Texas in two decades.

headline: Most People Think They’re Special, but These Think They’re Divine
abstract: Milton Rokeach’s psychological study with three paranoid schizophrenics is the basis of the play “3 Christs.”
lead_paragraph: Peter, Paul and John look down from the stained-glass windows onto “3 Christs,” a play staged in the sanctuary of Judson Memorial Church. And boy, have these saints got some preaching to do.

headline: A Jet Flies, With Its Problems Never Far Behind
abstract: “Broken Dreams: The Boeing 787,” a documentary from Al Jazeera, examines the troubles of a once-promising new jet.
lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera network’s documentary division may not yet get a lot of attention in the United States, but “Broken Dreams: The Boeing 787” will certainly raise eyebrows. Any time you catch employees of an airplane manufacturer saying they wouldn’t want to fly on the company’s newest jet, you’re bound to make a few waves.

headline: Maja Solomon Transforms at Vera Wang
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Maja Solomon before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Paul Hanlon.

headline: Giving Voice to the Silent Faces of Couture
abstract: In “Models Never Talk,” organized by Olivier Saillard, former supermodels strutted and spoke about their glory days in couture.
lead_paragraph: Clothes may make the man, but does that apply to supermodels? On Monday, at Milk Studios in Chelsea, seven former European supermodels paraded in the most basic of outfits: black turtlenecks, black tights, black heels. Some added white shirts or smocks, but they all wore two most unusual accessories: a headset microphone and a battery pack.

headline: Beyond Salmon Burgers
abstract: A homegrown Alaskan has turned an old fishermen’s cove into a haven for artful, modern cooking.
lead_paragraph: HALIBUT COVE, ALASKA — Marian Beck needed a third hand.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Says Wireless Broadband Could Get Stricter Oversight
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Tom Wheeler said the commission was seriously considering subjecting mobile carriers to the same net neutrality regulations as providers of wired Internet service.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission warned the wireless phone industry on Tuesday that the commission was seriously considering subjecting mobile carriers to the same net neutrality regulations as providers of wired Internet service.

headline: Cheney Urges House G.O.P. to Abandon Isolationism
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Before President Obama’s address on ISIS, former Vice President Dick Cheney urged House Republicans to embrace a strong military and try to stop the establishment of a terrorist state in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the eve of President Obama’s address to the nation about plans for an escalation of military action in Iraq, former Vice President Dick Cheney came to Capitol Hill on Tuesday to urge House Republicans to embrace a strong military and reject a rising isolationism in his party, but did not discuss the specifics of confronting the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diesel Black Gold Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

headline: A Pursuit That Leaps, Crashes and Swings
abstract: The documentary “Born to Fly: Elizabeth Streb vs. Gravity” uses performance and rehearsal footage to help profile this choreographer.
lead_paragraph: By the time we hear the words “Being careful in an action enterprise is really frowned upon at Streb,” they’re pretty much redundant. We’ve already seen their speaker, Elizabeth Streb, an intense dancer and choreographer in her 60s, guide her troupe through moves that would give a mixed-martial-arts champion pause.

headline: Answers to Questions About Apple’s Announcements, Including the Watch and iPhone 6
abstract: We try to answer your pressing questions about Apple’s new line of products. It doesn’t look good for left-handed watches.
lead_paragraph: Updated | There had been weeks of rumors and speculation about what Apple would announce. On Tuesday, we got a glimpse of the company’s new offerings, which included two bigger versions of the iPhone, as well as a smartwatch, dubbed Apple Watch.

headline: New Emblem of an Elemental Conflict: Seized West Bank Land
abstract: Israel’s appropriation of nearly 1,000 acres of Palestinian territory has again illustrated the distance between the Israelis and the Palestinians months after the breakdown of American-brokered talks.
lead_paragraph: WADI FUKIN, West Bank — At the edge of this small Palestinian village, an asphalt road turns into a dirt path that winds through a fertile valley where natural springs irrigate lush plots planted with a rich ratatouille of vegetables, as well as orchards and vines. Goats graze on the steep, rocky slopes, some bare and rugged, others planted with olive and almond trees and pines.

headline: Restaurant Story
abstract: A chat with Tom Sellers, the chef at Restaurant Story in London.
lead_paragraph: A chat with Tom Sellers, the chef at Restaurant Story in London.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Mercedes Introduces the 2016 AMG GT
abstract: Mercedes says the electronics-laden grand touring car works well on the track and the highway.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz announced details about its 2016 AMG GT this week. The car’s proportions — long snout, low roof and wide track — make it clear that the GT is a sports car. In case there is any doubt, a powerful twin-turbo V8 hammers the point home. The surprise? Mercedes calls the trunk “practical.”

headline: Does the Apple Watch Look Good On? Assessing From a Fashion Point of View
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: The long-awaited, much-anticipated Apple Watch. Don’t call it an iWatch; this is a new era, people. OMG! OMG! OMG! And all that.
lead_paragraph: And so it has finally arrived: the long-awaited, much-anticipated Apple Watch. Don’t call it an iWatch; this is a new era, people. OMG! OMG! OMG! And all that.

headline: Russia’s Next Land Grab
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Putin playbook — stir up trouble so you can send in “peacekeepers” — is on view in the Caucasus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — UKRAINE isn’t the only place where Russia is stirring up trouble. Since the Soviet Union broke up in 1991, Moscow has routinely supported secessionists in bordering states, to coerce those states into accepting its dictates. Its latest such effort is unfolding in the South Caucasus.

headline: A Star From Winnetka Blows Into Town
abstract: Christine Ebersole brings both her inner hippie and the operetta starlet to her new show, “Big Noise From Winnetka,” at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: When Christine Ebersole was a child growing up in Winnetka, Ill., she recalled on Monday evening, she considered running away from home in the middle of winter because she didn’t want to continue piano lessons. In her fantasy, she would swim across Lake Michigan and find a new family with a fairer sense of justice. She never got farther than the back door.

headline: René Redzepi on Tortillas
abstract: In the test kitchen of Noma, the celebrated chef and his pastry chef, Rosio Sánchez, demonstrate the difficulties of making the Mexican staple.
lead_paragraph: In the test kitchen of Noma, the celebrated chef and his pastry chef, Rosio Sánchez, demonstrate the difficulties of making the Mexican staple.

headline: With Apple Watch, a Naming Tradition Ends
abstract: For 16 years, Apple has bestowed the prefix “i” on the names of most of its groundbreaking products, from the iMac to the iPad. Not so with the Apple Watch.
lead_paragraph: For 16 years, Apple has bestowed the prefix “i” on the names of most of its groundbreaking products, from the iMac to the iPad.

headline: Sophie Hannah Talks About Rebooting Agatha Christie’s Poirot
abstract: Ms. Hannah’s “The Monogram Murders” is the first new Poirot story since Christie’s death in 1976.
lead_paragraph: Literary reboots can be tricky. Many, like William Boyd’s James Bond novel and Joanna Trollope’s modern take on Jane Austen’s “Sense and Sensibility,” have received lukewarm reviews. Some are met with indignation bordering on outrage. “Worse than bad fan fiction” was what one reviewer called Sebastian Faulks’s attempt to channel P.G. Wodehouse in a new Jeeves and Wooster novel.

headline: The Push to Keep Scotland in the Fold
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron and his counterparts announced that they would fly north to campaign against dismemberment of the union with England.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — With nine days left before Scotland votes on whether to become independent, Britain’s leaders went into overdrive on Tuesday with efforts to keep the country intact.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Australia, India, Yemen and California.

abstract: Parties for Tod’s store, Calvin Klein’s Reveal perfume and InStyle’s 20th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: There was no sign of fatigue as Fashion Week entered its fifth night of partying. See more photos in the slideshow.

headline: Phone Giants Said to Be Near Joint Bid for Telecom Italia’s Brazil Unit
abstract: América Móvil of Mexico,  Oi of Brazil and Telefónica of Spain are coming together on a joint offer to buy Telecom Italia’s Brazil operations, TIM Participações, a person with close knowledge of the negotiations said.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — América Móvil of Mexico,  Oi of Brazil and Telefónica of Spain are coming together on a joint offer to buy Telecom Italia’s Brazil operations, TIM Participações, a person with close knowledge of the negotiations said on Tuesday.

headline: Night of Free-Flowing Verse, Booze and Elusive Connections on Dublin Bar Stools
abstract: “Boys and Girls,” Dylan Coburn Gray’s play at 59E59, follows four young hot-blooded people through a boozy night in Dublin.
lead_paragraph: The 1st Irish Theater Festival begins this season with Dylan Coburn Gray’s “Boys and Girls” at the 59E59 Theaters, a florid account of a night in Dublin. Ribald, lyrical and brisk (at 50 minutes), “Boys and Girls,” a Dublin Fringe Festival hit, renders in pungent language the contemporary adolescent and postadolescent experience in urban Ireland.

headline: Raver-Style Knotted Mohawks at Marc by Marc Jacobs
abstract: The hair at the show was a throwback to the ’90s-era versions of Gwen Stefani and Bjork.
lead_paragraph: Guests at today’s Marc by Marc Jacobs show were greeted with a tower of speakers and colorful lights that immediately read rave. And the parade of styles that followed — clubgoer clothes, latex layering pieces — continued with the theme. The beauty, meanwhile, was a throwback to the ’90s-era versions of Gwen Stefani and Bjork, especially the models’ faux Mohawks made of little hair knots.

headline: Mostly White Forces in Mostly Black Towns: Police Struggle for Racial Diversity
keywords: ['Police', 'Minorities', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: There are nearly 400 police departments where a predominantly white force serves in mostly minority towns, showing the difficulty, even where there is a will, in hiring more minorities.
lead_paragraph: MAPLE HEIGHTS, Ohio — The population of this working-class Cleveland suburb has gone from nearly all white to two-thirds black since its mayor declared more than 35 years ago that he did not know “what a minority is.” But its police and fire departments have not kept pace: The Maple Heights police force today still has only two black officers out of 35; the fire department is 100 percent white.

headline: Fashion Week Parties: Night 3
abstract: Parties for Band of Outsiders and Prabal Gurung.
lead_paragraph: Parties for Band of Outsiders and Prabal Gurung. See more photos.

headline: Discussing Online ‘Right to Be Forgotten,’ Google Takes European Privacy Tour to Spain
abstract: Google began in Madrid its seven-city tour of public meetings, hearing views from activists and members of the public about the best ways to remove certain links from its search results upon request.
lead_paragraph: As Google seeks expert advice on how to carry out its “right to be forgotten” court order in Europe, the company went to Spain on Tuesday, where the whole thing started.

headline: Facing Up to Threats of Nature
abstract: Works at the FringeArts festival in Philadelphia deal with the many ways both nature and human relationships can go wrong.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Weather has become unusually localized in this city. On a recent evening, there wasn’t a cloud in the sky. And yet it was raining hard, though only on a few isolated individuals in an alley near City Hall.

headline: Trump Entertainment Set to Close Taj Mahal Casino in Atlantic City
abstract: The company filed for bankruptcy protection and said the Taj Mahal, once the New Jersey city’s largest casino, would shut in November without union concessions.
lead_paragraph: The second poker chip dropped for Trump Entertainment Resorts on Tuesday, when the company filed for bankruptcy protection and threatened to close the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort in Atlantic City by Thanksgiving if it failed to cut expenses drastically.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 5
abstract: Scenes from Theory, ADEAM and Karen Walker on the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Last touches are put on a look for the Theory presentation on West 14th Street on the fifth day of New York Fashion Week. See more photos in slideshow.

headline: They’re a Bit Stiff, but Very Talkative
abstract: Twenty-nine statues in London and Manchester have recently been given a voice in “Talking Statues,” a public art project by the nonprofit Sing London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Queen Victoria was minding her own business, towering over Blackfriars Bridge in her usual way on a recent afternoon here, when a passer-by, a young woman visiting from South Korea, roused her to speak. The woman had just swiped her smartphone over a plaque at the bottom of Victoria’s statue, causing the phone to ring and prompting the former queen to speak.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 1
abstract: Photos from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center is once again filled with action on the first day of New York Fashion Week. See more photos in slideshow.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 2
abstract: Scenes from the second day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: A racquet becomes a microphone as models entertain themselves with their props, waiting for the À Moi show to begin on the second day of New York Fashion Week. See more photos in slideshow.

headline: Brooklyn Museum’s Longtime Director Plans to Retire
abstract: Arnold L. Lehman, the director of the Brooklyn Museum since 1997, has announced that he plans to leave the post next year.
lead_paragraph: After 17 often tumultuous years as director of the Brooklyn Museum, Arnold L. Lehman announced on Tuesday that he is planning to retire around June of next year.

abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Carl Icahn’s Firm Makes a Fat-Finger Error in S.E.C. Filing
abstract: News headlines briefly flashed that Carl C. Icahn had raised his stake in Gannett, the media company, to nearly 9 percent. But as it turns out, his firm simply made a typo in a regulatory filing.
lead_paragraph: Automated news headlines briefly flashed that Carl C. Icahn had raised his stake in Gannett, the media company, to nearly 9 percent from 6.6 percent.

abstract: The American Thoracic Society praises the drugstore chain’s decision.

headline: A Haven for Luxury Shoes Emerges on Madison Avenue
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Men and Boys', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Among male customers, there is a growing demand for luxury shoes, as new and well-known retailers line up along Manhattan’s Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Paul Wilson, the shoemaker at the John Lobb store on Madison Avenue, helps men order bespoke shoes and boots, made from leather and exotic skins like lizard and crocodile.

headline: Dennis Hopper Day Descends On Taos, N.M.
abstract: The legendary actor’s daughter Marin shares her account of the event, which featured a group motorcycle ride along the route of “Easy Rider.”
lead_paragraph: Marin Hopper, the daughter of the legendary actor, and the founder of the handbag line Hayward, shares her account of the first annual event, which featured a group motorcycle ride along the route of “Easy Rider.” The photographer Lisa Eisner captured the festivities as they unfolded.

headline: Destiny in Taos
abstract: In the late 1960s at the height of his career, Dennis Hopper left Hollywood for artistic bohemia in New Mexico. His daughter looks back on a man in search of free expression and a more contemplative way of life.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s at the height of his career, Dennis Hopper left Hollywood for artistic bohemia in New Mexico. His daughter looks back on a man in search of free expression and a more contemplative way of life.

headline: Requiring Consent to Sex on Campus
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article by Michael Kimmel and Gloria Steinem praising such policies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rural Capitals, Big-Time Problems
abstract: Moving a government to an isolated spot, as Argentina may do, can mean more corruption.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — WHILE the threat of another default still looms in Argentina, the country has made headlines for another reason: A growing number of its leaders, including President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, are starting to line up behind a proposal to move the capital from Buenos Aires to the much smaller (and reportedly sleepy) city of Santiago del Estero, in the middle-north of the country.

headline: Budget-Friendly Seattle, From Meals to Massages
abstract: The Frugal Traveler joins two friends from high school for a low-cost mini-reunion in the Emerald City.
lead_paragraph: My friend Doug and I approached the ticket counter at the Seattle Art Museum, where suggested admission is $19.50. “Is it true we can actually pay whatever we want to get in?” I asked. “Like, 1 cent?” It was, the man said, so long as we didn’t want to see the special exhibitions. And so in tandem we each plunked down a penny. The man did not flinch — or maybe flinched just a little — and printed out our tickets.

headline: A Complicated Optimist
abstract: My father could never, not for one second, believe that things were going to get worse.
lead_paragraph: My father, who died last week at 91, had a complex life that typified that of Jewish men of his generation. But of course when you know someone well, you see just how unusual that life is. Or was.

headline: Vietnam’s Photographic History, Told by the Winners
abstract: An exhibit shows how North Vietnamese photographers documented their country’s bloody war, volunteering to risk their lives.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit shows how North Vietnamese photographers documented their country’s bloody war, volunteering to risk their lives.

lead_paragraph: New York

lead_paragraph: Job Smeets and Nynke Tynagel talk about their collection of curated objects for Chamber boutique on Manhattan’s West Side.

headline: American Horror Story
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The status quo is cursed, but it’s not about to change. That’s the great, ugly paradox of the 2014 midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Like the smattering of other Americans who still pay close attention to the wearying spectacle of our country’s politics, I worry about what will happen on Nov. 4, the day of the midterm elections.

abstract: Should the family member  who does most of the housekeeping be compensated?
