headline: Iran’s Talks With Russia May Strike at Sanctions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Iranian negotiator at nuclear talks said his country would not countenance any new economic penalties imposed by the United States.
lead_paragraph: Iran sent new signals on Tuesday that it was seeking to subvert the Western sanctions on its contentious nuclear energy program, adding uncertainties in advance of another round of negotiations next week in New York before the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Serena Williams Takes a Swing at Designing
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Just two days after her United States Open victory, Serena Williams hosted her first-ever fashion show for HSN.
lead_paragraph: It was on the official calendar, but it didn’t look like your normal New York Fashion Week show. There was only one black car idling on West 46th Street. There were no street-style photographers outside the site. There was a red carpet.

headline: For U2 and Apple, a Shrewd Marketing Partnership
abstract: As part of its product announcement, Apple released U2’s new album free, but the band was paid in a carefully negotiated deal.
lead_paragraph: U2 may be giving a new album away, but it is still getting paid.

headline: Trojan Teams Up With MTV Again to Promote Condom Use, and the Brand
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Condoms', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: The Trojan brand and MTV continue their advertising partnership with a series of commercials urging couples to use a condom every time they have sex.
lead_paragraph: LIKE a couple seeking to spend more time together, the Trojan condom brand and the MTV cable channel are extending a partnership with a campaign, created internally at MTV, that will run online as well as on MTV and several channels that are MTV siblings under the Viacom umbrella.

headline: Looking Beyond China, Some Companies Shift Personnel
abstract: As businesses pay more attention to Southeast Asia, some are relocating executives to Singapore.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — General Motors moved the headquarters of its international division here from Shanghai last month. Archer Daniels Midland, the agribusiness giant, is gradually doing the same with its Asia and Pacific operations. Other multinationals, like IBM, have shifted staff members here from China for a few functions, like treasury operations.

headline: Lt. Gov. Lavon L. Heidemann of Nebraska Steps Down
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Domestic Violence', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Mr. Heidemann quit Tuesday amid domestic-abuse allegations, but his name might still be listed as a candidate in November.
lead_paragraph: Nebraska’s lieutenant governor, Lavon L. Heidemann, resigned Tuesday amid domestic abuse allegations. But because the deadline for being dropped from the ballot has passed, his name might still be listed as a candidate in November.

headline: Ukraine Town Bears Scars of Russian Offensive That Turned Tide in Conflict
abstract: Days after the Russian artillery units’ assault, Ukraine agreed to a cease-fire cementing the rebels’ hold on its southeast region.
lead_paragraph: ILOVAISK, Ukraine — Burned-out tanks, troop carriers and trucks still lie strewn on the roads and fields all around this town. The body of a Ukrainian soldier hangs doubled over an electric wire, flung up like a doll when his tank exploded. The charred corpse of another soldier lies inside the hull of the tank, a third putrifying torso is tangled in machinery on the road.

headline: Foundation Sends Kin of 9/11 Victims to College
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Colleges and Universities', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Families of Freedom, formed a week after the 2001 attacks, will continue to provide scholarships through 2030.
lead_paragraph: Sean Booker was a Xerox technician on the 93rd floor of the World Trade Center’s north tower. The Newark resident was at work when American Airlines Flight 11 crashed into the building on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Theory: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Canada Chases Down an Arctic Mystery, and Some See a Political Strategy
abstract: Canadian researchers say they have located a ship from Sir John Franklin’s disastrous expedition in the 1840s to map the Northwest Passage, an area of new international interest as Arctic ice retreats.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Some Canadians, particularly Prime Minister Stephen Harper, have long been taken with the story of the disastrous attempt by the British explorer Sir John Franklin to sail and map the Northwest Passage. So it was not surprising that Mr. Harper took it upon himself to announce on Tuesday that the sixth attempt by Canada’s government to locate wreckage from Franklin’s doomed voyage had been successful.

headline: An American Reporter’s Detention in Iran
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press', 'International Relations']
abstract: Journalists should not be jailed in Tehran to score political points.
lead_paragraph: More than seven weeks ago, Iranian authorities detained Jason Rezaian, The Washington Post’s correspondent in Tehran, and his wife, the Iranian journalist Yeganeh Salehi. Government officials have refused to say where they are being held or why. Their continued detention is as mystifying as it is outrageous.

headline: Fiji Government Says Its Golan Heights Peacekeepers Will Be Released Soon
abstract: The country’s 45-member United Nations peacekeeping contingent in the Golan Heights was seized by the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda nearly two weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: Fiji said Wednesday that its 45-member United Nations peacekeeping contingent in the Golan Heights, seized by the Syrian branch of Al Qaeda nearly two weeks ago, would be released soon.

headline: Tanaka Could Make a Return Before Season Ends
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka’s quest to return is more about determining whether he will be available in 2015 than it is about helping the Yankees’ faint postseason hopes.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Yankees season has dwindled to its final few weeks and the postseason has become a remote hope, Masahiro Tanaka is racing to return before it all ends, if only to show that he can.

headline: At Surgery Clinic, Rush to Save Joan Rivers’s Life
abstract: New York City officials said 10 emergency medical workers had arrived at a medical center in Manhattan after receiving a call that Ms. Rivers had gone into cardiac arrest.
lead_paragraph: The call came in to 911 one second before 9:40 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 28, from the staff at a clinic on East 93rd Street in Manhattan — a patient in cardiac arrest. The call was coded as “Segment 1,” the highest-level priority handled by 911, according to two New York City officials.

headline: Minecraft Is Expected to Be Acquired by Microsoft
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Acquiring the game would give Microsoft control of an online world that has defied many modern conventions to become a blockbuster success.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:08 p.m. | Microsoft is in advanced talks to acquire the maker of the game Minecraft for more than $2 billion, people briefed on the discussions said on Tuesday. The move was intended to ensure that one of the most popular games was available for the computing giant’s family of devices.

headline: A Jolt of Caffeine Is Much Needed: J. Crew, Phillip Lim, Rag & Bone and Tory Burch
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, J. Crew, Phillip Lim, Rag & Bone and Tory Burch present their Spring 2015 collections.
lead_paragraph: Sleep. Sleep of the evening, beautiful sleep. With apologies to the Mock Turtle of “Alice in Wonderland,” this is what most participants are craving by the midpoint of this elaborately constructed house of cards called New York Fashion Week.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 6
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Shows continued in full swing Tuesday, with a sparkly setup at Rodarte, a rave at Marc Jacobs and more. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, fashion devotees put on brave faces and headed into Central Park after dark. It was a bold move; bolder still was the Polo Ralph Lauren show, which took them there in the first place and featured holograms rather than flesh-and-blood models.

headline: Amid Intensifying Requests, American Military Aid to Ukraine Stalls
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Despite appeals from the Ukrainian armed forces, the United States has provided only a modest package of nonlethal assistance to the government in Kiev, and much of it has yet to arrive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite appeals from the Ukrainian armed forces, the United States has so far provided only a modest package of nonlethal assistance to the Kiev government, and much of it has yet to arrive.

headline: Arthur Gelb, Former Times Editor, Is Recalled as Kinetic and Filled With Wonder
abstract: Mr. Gelb, who was a top editor at The New York Times for more than 30 years, was remembered on Tuesday as having “a Twitter metabolism and a big-data appetite.”
lead_paragraph: “And remember, there’s a great deal of interest in this story,” Arthur Gelb often said as he sent reporters out on assignments for The New York Times, where he was a high-ranking editor for more than 30 years.

headline: It Takes a Mentor
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'Mentors', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Internships']
abstract: Gallup says successful students had one or more teachers who were mentors, and they had an internship related to what they were learning in school.
lead_paragraph: With millions of students returning to school — both K-12 and college — this is a good time to review the intriguing results of some research that Gallup did over the past year, exploring the linkages between education and long-term success in the workplace. That is: What are the things that happen at a college or technical school that, more than anything else, produce “engaged” employees on a fulfilling career track? According to Brandon Busteed, the executive director of Gallup’s education division, two things stand out. Successful students had one or more teachers who were mentors and took a real interest in their aspirations, and they had an internship related to what they were learning in school.

headline: Penn State Faithful Rejoice After Penalties Are Lifted
abstract: The news that bowl eligibility and scholarship figures were to be restored was deeply felt on a campus.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Coach James Franklin found out the news the same way many of his players and many Penn State students had: via Twitter.

headline: Violence Erupts in Yemen Capital After Weeks of Rallies
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Pro-government forces in the capital opened fire on Tuesday at thousands of demonstrators from the Shiite religious minority, killing six and injuring dozens, officials and witnesses said.
lead_paragraph: MUKALLA, Yemen — Pro-government forces in the capital opened fire on Tuesday at thousands of demonstrators from the Shiite religious minority, killing six and injuring dozens, officials and witnesses said.

headline: On the Runways to Other Worlds: Donna Karan, Maria Cornejo, Rodarte, Thom Browne, Vera Wang
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: At New York Fashion Week shows from Donna Karan, Maria Cornejo, Rodarte, Thom Browne and Vera Wang, even collections nominally inspired by real places had an otherworldly feel.
lead_paragraph: Fashion can often seem like an alternative cosmos, or a trip through the looking glass — say, when you are standing in Central Park and a three-story hologram of a runway appears, as it did Monday at the Ralph Lauren Polo show. Or when a Mad Hatter’s garden party is held, complete with girls dressed as shuttlecocks and badminton rackets and daisy chains, as it was at Thom Browne.

headline: Pakistan: Troops Fend Off Militant Attack in Karachi
abstract: The Pakistani Navy said it repelled a terrorist attack over the weekend after a six-hour exchange of fire at a naval dockyard in the southern port city of Karachi.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani Navy said it repelled a terrorist attack over the weekend after a six-hour exchange of fire at a naval dockyard in the southern port city of Karachi. Two militants were killed and four were arrested when they tried to attack, a navy spokesman said. A junior ranking officer was killed, while an officer and six sailors were wounded in the clash on Saturday night, the spokesman said. The Taliban claimed responsibility on Tuesday, according to the BBC. A Taliban attack on Karachi’s international airport in June prompted a military offensive against militants in the North Waziristan tribal region.  The attack on the dockyard is the second on a military facility since the offensive began.

headline: Hopes for Iraq’s New Government
abstract: The approval of a power-sharing government is an important building block, but hard work lies ahead for Prime Minister Abadi.
lead_paragraph: The Iraqi Parliament put in place an important building block of an anti-ISIS strategy on Monday when it approved, in record time, a new power-sharing government led by Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi. Harder work lies ahead as Mr. Abadi, a member of the Shiite majority, tries to manage sectarian rivals in his cabinet and unify a fractured country, all while working with the United States to eliminate a mortal threat from marauding Sunni militants who occupy a huge swath of northern Iraq.

headline: Fighting Back on Toll Fees for Rental Cars
keywords: ['Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Tolls', 'E-ZPass', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Now that many tollbooths no longer take cash, some rental car companies have made a hearty business out of paying the tolls themselves. But there’s a catch.
lead_paragraph: Now that many tollbooths are no longer taking actual, physical money, some of the country’s biggest rental car companies have made a hearty business out of paying the tolls themselves. And oh, yes: There’s a service fee for that. This summer, a couple from California visiting New York hired a car from Dollar Rent A Car. They discovered that $4.88 in tolls for twice crossing the Henry Hudson Bridge — where it is impossible to pay with cash — had become a $34.88 charge from Dollar.

headline: With Apple Pay, a Push Into Mobile Payments
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'E-Commerce', 'Credit Cards', 'Currency', 'Virtual Currency', 'Mobile Commerce', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Smartphones', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Apple introduced a payment system that joins forces with Macy’s, Whole Foods, Visa and other retailers and major credit card companies.
lead_paragraph: Tech evangelists have predicted for years a world in which people paid for retail goods with the wave of a smartphone, or the push of a smartphone button. For nearly as long, this so-called mobile wallet has yet to catch on.

headline: Another Broken Promise on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Editorials', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama said in June that fixing the immigration problem was urgent. Now he says doing anything about it will have to wait.
lead_paragraph: “America cannot wait forever,” said President Obama in June, when he denounced congressional paralysis on immigration reform and declared that he would soon act on his own to fix the problem. He promised to move by the end of the summer, presumably to suspend the deportations of many unauthorized immigrants — perhaps millions, though there is no way to know how many until a plan is unveiled.

headline: Megachurch With a Beat Lures a Young Flock
abstract: An Australian Pentecostal megachurch powered by a recording label that dominates Christian contemporary music, Hillsong has become a phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A toned and sunburned 32-year-old Australian with the letters F-A-I-T-H tattooed onto his biceps strode onto the stage of a former burlesque theater here and shouted across a sea of upstretched hands and uplifted smartphones: “Let’s win this city together!”

headline: With iPhone 6 and Smartwatch, Apple Is Back and Better Than Ever
abstract: Any question about how well Tim Cook is managing the reins of the world’s most valuable company will most likely be put to rest after Tuesday’s profusion of product announcements.
lead_paragraph: Four times before in its history, at media events planned with military precision, Apple introduced a new invention that radically altered how the technology industry conceived of its future. The company hopes it did that again for a fifth time on Tuesday by unveiling the Apple Watch, a stylish smartwatch that is the company’s first advance into a new product category since it created the iPad in 2010.

headline: Fed Proposes New Rule, and Wall St. Banks Feel the Pressure
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s proposal and other rules could increase pressure on big banks to reduce, or even sell, traditionally profitable operations like lending to hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks scrambled on Tuesday to determine how they might have to adjust their business models to comply with newly proposed rules that could push the banks to downsize.

headline: McEnroe’s Successor at U.S.T.A. Needs to Hit the Court Running
abstract: As the U.S.T.A. begins searching for an executive to replace Patrick McEnroe, it seems best that the organization focuses on candidates who do not have nearly as much to learn when they step into the role.
lead_paragraph: The French Open was in full swing this past spring, and Patrick McEnroe was reflecting on his six years as head of player development at the United States Tennis Association.

headline: Oscar de la Renta: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: A Step Toward Fairness in Ferguson
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Editorials', 'Racial Profiling', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Proposals to remake its court system and create a civilian review board for the Police Department speak to longstanding grievances in the black community.
lead_paragraph: The racially torn city of Ferguson, Mo., took an important step on Monday when the City Council announced proposals aimed at remaking its troubled court system and creating a civilian review board for the Police Department.

headline: $500 Million Stock Fraud Alleged in Brooklyn Court
abstract: Six people and six Belize firms were accused in a federal indictment of a complex scheme to launder money.
lead_paragraph: The undercover F.B.I. agent was explicit about his desire to break the law as he spoke to executives in Belize: I’m a U.S. citizen, he said, and a stock promoter. I want to open an offshore account that will let me conceal from the Internal Revenue Service and the Securities and Exchange Commission stock ownership and money transfers.

headline: Longtime Rivals Look to Team Up to Confront ISIS
abstract: As the United States and its allies look to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, longtime adversaries are scrambling to see if they can cooperate to defeat the rising threat.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As the United States and its allies look to fight the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, longtime adversaries with a common fear of the radical movement are scrambling to see if they can cooperate to defeat the rising threat.

headline: Pledging to Shield the N.F.L.’s Brand at All Costs
abstract: By prioritizing so-called league interests when initially punishing Ray Rice for a domestic abuse charge, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell blundered badly and ended up harming the league and its owners.
lead_paragraph: Had N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell watched the chilling Ray Rice elevator video through the lens of a father whose daughter was being beaten or a brother whose sister was knocked cold or a son whose mother was dragged and dropped outside an elevator, his actions surely would have been swift, severe and, most likely, permanent.

headline: Detroit Clears Crucial Hurdle on Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Credit and Debt', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The biggest opponent to Detroit’s blueprint for rising out of bankruptcy has reached an agreement with the city, court documents show, prompting an adjournment in a trial over the city’s plan.
lead_paragraph: The fiercest opponent to Detroit’s blueprint for erasing its debts and investing in city services has reached an “agreement in principle” with city officials, court documents filed Tuesday evening showed, clearing the way to end the city’s court fight over its future and emerge from bankruptcy far more quickly and smoothly than expected.

headline: Pakistan: 24 Killed When Mosque Roof Collapses
abstract: At least 24 people were killed and seven injured when the roof of a mosque in the eastern city of Lahore collapsed Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: At least 24 people were killed and seven injured when the roof of a mosque in the eastern city of Lahore collapsed Tuesday. The mosque, in the Darghawala neighborhood, caved in when noon prayer had just begun. Muhamad Usman, who led the rescue operation, said that all the victims were believed to have been found but that the search would continue.

headline: Gaza: Arrests Suggest Disagreement on Truce Details
abstract: The Israeli military arrested four fishermen early Tuesday in what Palestinian officials said was a violation of the cease-fire agreement signed last month.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military arrested four fishermen early Tuesday in what Palestinian officials said was a violation of the cease-fire agreement signed last month, but that the Israelis contended was an enforcement of their restriction of fishing to within six nautical miles of the Gaza coast. Nezar Ayash of the Gaza fishermen’s union said four men were arrested less than one mile off the coast near the northern town of Beit Lahiya. He said two fishermen were arrested in a similar incident last Wednesday. The Egyptian-brokered cease-fire announced on Aug. 26 restored a 2012 agreement that the fishing zone be doubled to six nautical miles from three. A spokeswoman for the Israeli military said the four men had “deviated from the permitted fishing zone” and “were over six miles away from the shore.”

headline: Prospect Park Alliance Gets New President
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

headline: Witness Details a Sham in a Deal With Rowland

lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — In three days on the stand, Brian Foley, the government’s star witness in a corruption case against John G. Rowland, the former governor of Connecticut, repeatedly told the court that he had taken pains not to put anything in writing that might expose the $5,000-a-month consulting contract he had engineered with Mr. Rowland as a sham.

headline: Cuomo Defeats Teachout, Liberal Rival, in the Democratic Primary
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his running mate, Kathy Hochul, captured the Democratic primary over two law school professors, Zephyr Teachout and Tim Wu.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York claimed the Democratic nomination for a second term on Tuesday, but at a considerable price: A liberal challenger with little money or name recognition, Zephyr Teachout, was on track to receive about a third of the vote, a signal of the potent dissatisfaction with Mr. Cuomo in his party’s left wing.

headline: Seeing Abuse, and a Pattern Too Familiar
abstract: After Ray Rice’s football contract was terminated by his team on Monday, Janay Palmer Rice became a public example of the complex psychology of women abused by men.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Janay Palmer Rice was a little-known figure, the 26-year-old partner of Ray Rice, the star running back for the Baltimore Ravens. But after Mr. Rice’s contract was terminated by his team on Monday, she became the most famous battered wife in the country, a fierce defender of her husband and, to domestic violence experts and survivors, an extraordinarily public example of the complex psychology of women abused by men.

headline: Marvin Barnes, Enigmatic Basketball Player, Dies at 62
abstract: Barnes helped Providence College reach the N.C.A.A. Final Four in 1973 and played in the A.B.A. and N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Barnes, one of basketball’s most talented and defiantly self-indulgent players, whose career dissolved in a haze of drugs and alcohol, died on Monday in Providence, R.I. He was 62.

headline: Mildred Friedman, 85, Dies; Curator Elevated Design and Architecture

lead_paragraph: Mildred Friedman, a curator at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis in the 1970s and ’80s who helped both the museum and the contemporary design and architecture it celebrated become objects of international acclaim, died on Sept. 3 in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: In Atlanta, Debating Race and Sports
abstract: In a region that is practically religious about sports, remarks made by Bruce Levenson — co-owner of the Atlanta Hawks — have become touchstones for larger questions about the city’s identity.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — James Reed, a 27-year-old African-American sports fan, has all kinds of issues with the assertions that Bruce Levenson, the leader of the ownership group for this city’s N.B.A. franchise, has made about the team and its followers.

headline: Bothersome Shoulder Ends David Wright’s Season

lead_paragraph: The Mets’ season had reached the point, in the second week of September, when it seemed they were most concerned about preparing for the next year. They wanted to cultivate their young talent, keep everyone healthy, and then, they hoped, win.

headline: Federal Report Describes Trouble for Some Birds
abstract: After the National Audubon Society released a report saying 650 bird species will be threatened by climate change, a report released by other agencies concluded that nearly one-third of American birds are in trouble.
lead_paragraph: A day after the National Audubon Society released a report saying that about half of North America’s 650 bird species will be threatened by climate change, a report released Tuesday by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and other federal agencies concluded that nearly one-third of American birds are in trouble. The State of the Birds, a comprehensive study by nearly two dozen government agencies and conservation groups that tracks species loss and the effectiveness of conservation efforts, found species in moderate to steep decline across habitats and ecosystems. But it also highlighted that conservation projects could be successful, as with wetland species, like mallards and blue-winged teals, which saw a 37 percent bump in population since 1968. “Conservation in one part of the country is not enough,” said Daniel M. Ashe, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service. “We have to see the larger picture of conservation.”

headline: The Curated Boutique Kiosk Rises Again in NoHo
abstract: The beloved design shop, which assembles geographically themed offerings of products from around the world, opens in a new location with a collection that surveys its own history.
lead_paragraph: “Location, location, location”: it’s the mantra of success for retailers, and few understand it better than the cult New York design shop Kiosk. After losing its second-floor digs on Spring Street in SoHo to impending demolition earlier this year, then doing a stint in a Union Square office building, it’s setting up a new temporary storefront in NoHo this Friday through February 1. (The Union Square location will remain open as the company’s outlet shop.)

headline: Drink Soda? Take 12,000 Steps
abstract: The risks of consuming fructose-rich sodas and processed foods drop substantially if you get up from your chair and move around, even if you don’t formally exercise, two important new studies find.
lead_paragraph: People who consume the sweetener fructose — which is most people nowadays — risk developing a variety of health problems. But the risk drops substantially if those people get up and move around, even if they don’t formally exercise, two new studies found.

lead_paragraph: With full control of the New York State Legislature within reach in November, Democrats on Tuesday expelled one indicted lawmaker, held fast to another and reaffirmed their support for an embattled Bronx power broker at the heart of much of the party’s recent turmoil.

headline: Rule Amended for Plate Collisions
abstract: A memo to umpires essentially said that if a runner is clearly out, and would have been so regardless of the catcher’s positioning, he will now remain out.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With the postseason just three weeks away, baseball has urged umpires to apply common sense to the rule on home plate collisions that has confounded players and fans all season.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) VACCINES — CALLING THE SHOTS In 2000, measles was declared to have been eliminated in the United States. But in July, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported 566 cases so far this year. “Nova” investigates the return of diseases preventable by vaccines, among them measles, mumps and whooping cough, which were largely wiped out in the United States a generation ago; the science of immunization; and, for the 10 percent of parents who choose to delay or skip their children’s shots, the risks of opting out, to them and to society. Above, a scene from the program.

keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Falsification of Data', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Inspectors General']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Administrators at 13 health care facilities run by the Department of Veterans Affairs have lied to investigators looking into the extent of waiting-list manipulation and other improprieties, the department’s acting inspector general said in Senate testimony on Tuesday.

headline: On New Album, Rock Veterans Revisit Youth
abstract: Featuring autobiographical lyrics and cathedral-scale production, U2’s album “Songs of Innocence”was released Tuesday as a free download on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: Memories are a blast on “Songs of Innocence,” the album that U2 released on Tuesday afternoon as a worldwide giveaway. With a title that echoes William Blake, the album is a blast of discoveries, hopes, losses, fears and newfound resolve in lyrics that are openly autobiographical. It’s also a blast of unapologetic arena rock and cathedral-scale production, equally gigantic and detailed, in the music that carries them.

Up close, near the left-field bullpen, the fourth seat in the seventh row of Section 159 is not much to see. It is an original model from this park, its color faded, its armrests lower than those of its neighbors. It sits a little more upright, too, and its back has no cup holder.

headline: Can We Have a Fact-Based Conversation About End-of-Life Planning?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The persistence of the “death panels” myth shows that the issue is vulnerable to exploitation by a demagogue.

After a failed attempt to deal with the issue as part of the Affordable Care Act, it may again be returning to the policy agenda. Can we avoid another catastrophic bout of misinformation?

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar General Goes Hostile
abstract: Dollar General takes its bid for Family Dollar directly to shareholders. | Microsoft near a deal for the maker of Minecraft. | Fed’s newly proposed rules put pressure on banks. | Detroit clears a bankruptcy hurdle.
lead_paragraph: Dollar General said on Wednesday that it was taking its $9.1 billion offer for Family Dollar directly to shareholders, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The move could further complicate Family Dollar’s deal agreement to sell itself to Dollar Tree for $8.5 billion. In a statement, Dollar General said it was offering to acquire all of Family Dollar’s shares for $80 each. That is the same bid that Family Dollar rejected last week, contending that the deal it agreed to with Dollar Tree had a better chance of passing muster with antitrust regulators. A hostile bid is likely to, at the very least, delay any deal between Family Dollar and Dollar Tree.

headline: Lena Dunham Is Not Done Confessing
abstract: The creator of “Girls” takes her comedic oversharing into print with her first book.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in Brooklyn, Lena Dunham and her sister, Grace, met up at a local hangout. Grace was nursing a sprained ankle she sustained a few nights earlier, after, by her account, “tripping into a pothole while running out of a queer-poetry reading.” Dunham was concerned about the injury but also enchanted by the phrase, and had been repeating it to people everywhere she went over the last several days.

headline: Nations Called Lax in Returning Art Looted From Jews
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A new report takes several countries to task for not following through on promises to research the background of art that may have been looted from Jews during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The Italian government has long used impassioned pleas, considerable research and international public pressure to support its demands, which were often successful, for the repatriation of its art and antiquities patrimony lost through looting. But in a report published Wednesday, Italy is identified as one of the countries doing the least to research or identify items that may been looted from Jews during World War II.

headline: Jean-Claude Juncker Names European Commissioners

headline: In Srinagar, Floodwaters Recede, but Anger Remains
abstract: As people continued to wait for rescue, fear was giving way to anger over what some saw as a slow response to the flooding that has left hundreds dead in India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — As people waited here for rescue on rooftops and balconies, fear was giving way on Wednesday to anger and resentment over what some saw as a slow response to flooding that began last week and has left hundreds dead in northern India and eastern Pakistan.

headline: Three Years After Fukushima, Japan Approves a Nuclear Plant
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The two reactors at the Sendai power plant on the southern island of Kyushu are the first to be certified as safe enough to restart.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For the first time since the Fukushima disaster three and a half years ago, Japan’s new nuclear regulatory agency declared Wednesday that an atomic power plant was safe to operate, in a widely watched move that brings Japan a step closer to restarting its idled nuclear industry.

headline: Chinese Drug Company Wins Approval to Make Generic Version of Viagra
abstract: A Chinese pharmaceutical company has received approval to become the country’s first official producer of a homegrown version of Viagra.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese pharmaceutical company has received the green light from China’s State Food and Drug Administration to become the country’s first official producer of a homegrown version of Viagra, Pfizer’s famous erectile dysfunction drug.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Why Pistorius Fascinates
abstract: Oscar Pistorius has been found guilty of culpable homicide in the killing of his girlfriend. A look back at what South Africans have called their “trial of the century.”
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius has been found guilty of culpable homicide in the killing of his girlfriend. A look back at what South Africans have called their “trial of the century.”

headline: Most Russian Forces Now Out of Ukraine, Kiev Says
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said the withdrawal of Russian forces augmented the chances for a lasting cease-fire in the southeast.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine said on Wednesday that the bulk of Russian forces had withdrawn from Ukrainian territory, a move that he said heightened the chances for a lasting cease-fire in the southeast.

headline: On Facebook, Nobody Knows You’re a Voter. Well, Almost Nobody.
abstract: Political organizations, with the help of social media, are connecting voters to their online profiles.
lead_paragraph: Your Facebook profile doesn’t have boxes to check which political party you belong to or whether you voted in the last election. But political organizations who already know that can now deliver Facebook ads to fit your political preferences.

headline: How Do You View Narendra Modi’s Visit to the U.S.?
abstract: The Times wants to hear from Indians living in the United States on what this visit means to them.
lead_paragraph: The Times wants to hear from Indians living in the United States on what this visit means to them.

headline: Latest Good News in Health Spending: Employer Premiums
abstract: The growth in employee plan premiums was only 3 percent in the last year, tied for the lowest rate of increase in 16 years of the Kaiser survey.
lead_paragraph: We’re in the midst of a rare slowdown in the growth of health spending. That slowdown just hit the employer health insurance market.

headline: 1889: Another Whitechapel Mystery
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A grisly discovery has London speculating about Jack the Ripper in 1889.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London in general and Whitechapel in particular were thrown into a feverish state of excitement this morning [Sept. 10] by the news that Jack the Ripper had murdered and mutilated his ninth victim. Both murder and mutilation were reported to be, and indeed proved to be, more horrible than in any one of the eight cases preceding. The quick and close review of facts by the police department led to the conclusion late this afternoon that the remains found did not represent Jack the Ripper’s handiwork, and this may or may not be true. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 11, 1889

headline: Those ‘Mysterious Deadly Virus’ Headlines? Don’t Panic. Do Watch That Cold, and Wash Your Hands.
abstract: Strains of enterovirus circulate every year. This year, the number of children affected is high, but the symptoms themselves (fever and coughing) are consistent with the way this virus has behaved in the past.
lead_paragraph: With reports of a respiratory illness that can require hospitalization and even intensive care affecting children across the Midwest and West, and breathless headlines like “Potentially Deadly Mystery Virus” and “Rare, potentially deadly ‘Enterovirus’ hits thousands of kids,” parents might be inclined to circle the wagons, or at the very least whip out the hand sanitizer. (One exaggerated report, which I won’t link to, read: “Enterovirus starts with wheezing and coughing, but within hours, kids stop breathing altogether.”)

headline: A 9/11 Shrine Where Families Mourned for Years, Now Open to Others
abstract: Painful, poignant and mostly secret, the chamber, until recently at ground zero, served as a private sanctuary and was transformed by mementos into a shrine.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Twenty stories above ground zero, its existence and whereabouts known only to those who needed it, the Family Room served for a dozen years as a most private sanctuary from a most public horror.

headline: Can Humans Get Used to Having a Two-Way Relationship with Earth’s Climate?
abstract: Can humans get used to having a two-way relationship with Earth’s climate?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, I was invited to write an essay on humanity’s troubled relationship with the changing atmosphere for a special issue of Audubon Magazine centered on the Audubon Society’s comprehensive new report on birds in a changing climate.

headline: Apple Pay Tries to Solve a Problem That Really Isn’t a Problem
keywords: ['Mobile Commerce', 'Credit Cards', 'Identity Theft', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Personal Finances', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: A new mobile payment service was unveiled Tuesday, but credit cards seem to work just fine.
lead_paragraph: I recently bought a cup of coffee, but I did not have any cash handy. I used a credit card, and the result was a veritable dystopia that will surely haunt my sleep forever.

headline: Yanks and Mets on Equal Footing in Long-Shot Chase for Playoffs
abstract: A look at the wild-card standings challenges the perception that the Yankees, even when they’re down, manage to play important games in September while the Mets do not.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have kept their heads above .500 this season, and the Mets, as is often the case, have not. And yet, entering Wednesday’s games, the Mets were as close to a wild-card playoff spot as the Yankees.

headline: Xiao Wen Ju Transforms Backstage at Rodarte
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Xiao Wen Ju before (left) and after (right) makeup by James Kaliardos and hair by Odile Gilbert.

headline: Group Urges Action Against Sexual Harassment on University Campuses
abstract: A group of professors and students have called on Chinese education officials and university administrators to take more vigorous action against sexual harassment on university campuses.
lead_paragraph: On the annual occasion in China for recognizing teachers’ contributions to society, a group of professors and students have called on Chinese education officials and university administrators to take more vigorous action against sexual harassment on university campuses.

headline: Sign of the Times | Fall Men’s 2014
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: T highlights the gender-bending trends from the Fall 2014 men’s wear collections.
lead_paragraph: T highlights the gender-bending trends from the Fall 2014 men’s wear collections.

headline: Interview: Lone Scherfig
abstract: The director discusses her drama “The Riot Club,” about a secret, misbehaving group of Oxford students.
lead_paragraph: The director discusses her drama “The Riot Club,” about a secret, misbehaving group of Oxford students.

headline: After Resisting Their Overtures, Chiquita Agrees to Talk With Brazilian Bidders
abstract: Chiquita, which had agreed to acquire an Irish rival in a so-called inversion deal, signed a confidentiality agreement on Wednesday with the Cutrale Group and the Safra Group, which made an unexpected buyout offer last month.
lead_paragraph: Chiquita Brands International, which until very recently was looking to acquire an Irish rival, is now thinking about selling itself.

headline: France Won’t Meet Budget Deficit Target Until 2017, Government Warns
abstract: The French economy is expected to expand at a tepid 0.4 percent pace in 2014, well below the 1.7 percent rate the government had forecast.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s economic recovery will be much more fragile this year than originally thought, and the government will not be able to meet targets for reducing the deficit for at least another two years in the face of sputtering growth, the French Finance Ministry announced on Wednesday.

headline: Film About Exiles Is Banned in Singapore
abstract: “To Singapore, With Love,” by the filmmaker Tan Pin Pin, will not be shown in Singapore.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia – A documentary about the lives of Singaporean exiles has been banned in Singapore on the grounds that it undermines national security.

headline: Readers’ Best Shots of the Supermoon
abstract: We asked readers to send us their best photos of the September 8-9 supermoon. Here is a gallery of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you happened to have looked up into the night sky this week. And maybe you noticed that the moon looks a bit bigger and a little brighter than normal. Your eyes aren’t playing tricks on you. The third supermoon since July is visible this week. A supermoon occurs when the moon is full at its closest approach to Earth. It appears about 30 percent brighter than average.

headline: Folk Tales for a New Age
abstract: Two new picture books have the feel of folk tales and a sweet, rustic appeal.
lead_paragraph: The most emotionally satisfying folk tales, for me, are the ones made up from scratch by a living author. Sometimes it’s fun to play cultural anthropologist, but sometimes, a tendril of my attention will drift away upon hearing the name Baba Yaga, say, or Rumpelstiltskin. Those stories contain some timeless, universal themes —growing up and finding one’s place in the world, figuring out when someone is trying to rip you off — but they’ve also been concocted to address concerns born of a specific time and place, and not this one.

headline: Today in Small Business: Internet Slowdown
abstract: The big news may turn out to be Apple Pay, which aims to replace the wallet. A small business tries to shake up the insurance industry. And Denny’s scores a marketing coup.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Cold Spring Harbor: Natural Beauty, Good Schools
abstract: With its winding, hilly roads and canopy of tall trees, Cold Spring Harbor retains a natural, bucolic setting attractive to many young couples from Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In January 2012, with three children and no backyard, Andrew and Kate Walton left Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, for a house on three acres in the historic waterfront hamlet of Cold Spring Harbor in the northwest corner of Suffolk County.

headline: Dick Cheney and Other Republicans Throw Stones at Obama From Glass House
abstract: The former vice president has made a second career of criticizing the president.
lead_paragraph: Since he left the vice presidency six years ago, Dick Cheney has made a second career of criticizing President Obama, usually for his record on terrorism. Mr. Cheney was at it again on Tuesday, using a meeting with House Republicans to skewer Mr. Obama and promote his only remedy for foreign policy problems: War.

headline: Judge Agrees to Delay Detroit Bankruptcy Trial
abstract: The move by a federal judge will give Detroit a chance to iron out the final details in a settlement with Syncora Guarantee, a bond insurer and the city’s most forceful and public critic.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge agreed on Wednesday to delay Detroit’s bankruptcy trial to give the city and its fiercest opponent a chance to finish a major settlement that could speed an end to the city’s court fight over its future.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Lone Scherfig on ‘The Riot Club’
abstract: The director discusses her drama “The Riot Club,” about a secret, misbehaving group of Oxford students.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Boys behaving badly only begins to describe  a secret society of Oxford students in “The Riot Club,” a new drama directed by Lone Scherfig. The film is based on the play “Posh,” by Laura Wade, and follows the members of a dining club who have a dinner party that gets considerably out of hand. In this video, Ms. Scherfig discusses the film and how class conflicts and elitism give way to egregious acts.

headline: 1906: ‘The Yankees’ Take the Field
abstract: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Training Dogs to Sniff Out Cancer
abstract: Scientists hope to isolate cancer chemicals that only dogs can smell, leading to the manufacture of nanotechnology sensors that are capable of detecting cancerous tissue.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — McBaine, a bouncy black and white springer spaniel, perks up and begins his hunt at the Penn Vet Working Dog Center. His nose skims 12 tiny arms that protrude from the edges of a table-size wheel, each holding samples of blood plasma, only one of which is spiked with a drop of cancerous tissue.

headline: What You Get For... $1,500,000
abstract: Mountain views in Colorado, a house/workshop in New Orleans and water views in Rhode Island
lead_paragraph: DURANGO, COLO.

headline: Time to Ban Middle School?
abstract: Middle school is notoriously unpleasant, and now research shows it may be bad for kids’ academic progress, too. Should it be abolished?
lead_paragraph: The sheer unpleasantness of middle school has become something of a cliché; “middle school dance” now stands as a shorthand for any socially awkward experience. And yet, for many of us, middle school is terrible, a time when childhood is sort of over but even the mixed blessings of adolescence have yet to fully present themselves. Now experts are beginning to propose a solution to the problem of middle school: abolish it.

headline: House Hunting in ... Hong Kong
abstract: The market continues to feel the effects of “cooling measures” put in place by the Hong Kong government two years ago and aimed at foreign buyers.
lead_paragraph: A ONE-BEDROOM APARTMENT WITH HARBOR VIEWS IN HONG KONG

headline: Even More On Scotland
abstract: Reassurances that seem way out of date.
lead_paragraph: I’m going on Channel 4 in a couple of hours, and doing more homework. One thing that is likely to come up is the fact that some reputable economists (pdf) have concluded that Scotland-on-the-pound would be OK. What’s my answer?

headline: In Search of the Perfect Taco
abstract: René Redzepi ignited an international culinary revolution with Noma, his restaurant focused on wildly innovative Nordic cuisine. Now, believing that Mexican food is the next big thing, the Scandinavian wunderkind eats his way across the country to deconstruct its secrets.
lead_paragraph: René Redzepi ignited an international culinary revolution with Noma, his restaurant focused on wildly innovative Nordic cuisine. Now, believing that Mexican food is the next big thing, the Scandinavian wunderkind eats his way across the country to deconstruct its secrets.

headline: Google Buys Lift Labs in Further Biotech Push
keywords: ['Biotechnology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', "Parkinson's Disease"]
abstract: Google has acquired Lift Labs, a Bay Area company that makes a high-tech spoon designed to make it easier for people with neurodegenerative tremors to eat.
lead_paragraph: A person could be forgiven for thinking that Google is a biotech company.

headline: A Simple Equation: More Education = More Income
abstract: The United States trails nearly all other industrialized nations when it comes to educational equality, and it shows in income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if the United States government taxed the nation’s one-percenters so that their post-tax share of the nation’s income remained at 10 percent, roughly where it was in 1979. If the excess money were distributed equally among the rest of the population, in 2012 every family below that very top tier would have gotten a $7,105 check.

headline: Cuomo Says He’s ‘Fine With 60%’ in Primary and Looks to General Election
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York assailed his Republican opponent, Rob Astorino, while Mr. Astorino said the governor’s showing in the Democratic contest was a “major embarrassment.”
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo does not see the primary result on Tuesday as anything resembling a rebuke.

headline: HPV Vaccine Program in Australia Shows Success
abstract: The rate of genital warts in young Australian women decreased by 61 percent after the initiation of a program to give free human papillomarivus vaccine.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, Australia began providing the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine free to girls 12 to 18 in a school-based program. Now researchers have calculated the effect on the incidence of genital warts in women 15 to 27.

headline: Release of iPhone 6 Delayed in China
abstract: Apple told the country’s three big mobile service providers that the new devices would not be available on Sept. 19, when sales start elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Apple is facing a potential setback in China, one of its biggest and fastest-growing markets, after the much-anticipated introductions here of the new iPhone models were delayed.

headline: Think Mick Jagger Is a Fossil? So Do Some Scientists
abstract: An extinct swamp creature whose fossils were found in Egypt has been named for Mick Jagger.
lead_paragraph: If the name had not been bestowed by a couple of fans, Mick Jagger might have cause to take umbrage: a newly discovered extinct swamp creature has been named Jaggermeryx naida — Jagger’s water nymph — in the singer’s honor. Two of the scientists who published a study on the animal and its discovery in this month’s issue of the Journal of Paleontology, Ellen Miller, of Wake Forest University and Gregg Gunnell, of Duke University, said that the animal’s mouth structure is what brought Mr. Jagger to mind. Mr. Gunnell, in a statement, described the structure as probably “a highly innervated muzzle with mobile and tactile lips.”

headline: Central Bankers Find Bubbles, but Are Cautious on Deflating Them
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Central bankers have seen signs of market exuberance, but the Federal Reserve has been slow to pop the bubbles, Jesse Eisinger writes in The Trade.
lead_paragraph: Central bankers have been attacked, justifiably, for having done little to quash the great credit bubble that led to the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Israel, Facing Criticism, to Investigate Possible Military Misconduct in Gaza
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The announcement appeared to be part of an Israeli effort to pre-empt international war crimes inquiries into the 50-day Gaza conflict.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel on Wednesday announced it had begun criminal investigations into five instances of possible military misconduct in the 50-day Gaza war, an implicit acknowledgment of sensitivity to the widespread criticism, even among allies like the United States, that Israeli forces had used excessive firepower in a number of highly publicized assaults in the Palestinian territory.

headline: Uncertain About Hiring, Some Companies Try ‘Test Drives’
abstract: Small companies find contract work a good way to assess candidates for permanent jobs, especially in certain types of positions.
lead_paragraph: Hiring and retaining employees is a struggle for all sorts of companies, but at smaller ones the stakes can be especially high.

headline: Chlorine Used as Weapon in Syria War, Group Says
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said in a report that the Syrian government has continued using chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A toxic chemical, probably chlorine, was used as a weapon to attack Syrian villages in April, an international watchdog agency confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Fiji, in Clarification, Says Peacekeepers Remain Held in Golan Heights
abstract: The Ministry of Information dialed back an earlier assertion that Syria-based militants would soon release 45 Fijian members of a United Nations peacekeeping force.
lead_paragraph: Fiji on Wednesday dialed back its assertion that 45 of its peacekeepers in the Golan Heights, captured by Syrian militants nearly two weeks ago, were about to be released.

headline: Obama, in Speech on ISIS, Promises Sustained Effort to Rout Militants
abstract: President Obama expanded the campaign against ISIS to include airstrikes in Syria and more American advisers in Iraq, but he sought to distinguish the new action from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday authorized a major expansion of the military campaign against rampaging Sunni militants in the Middle East, including American airstrikes in Syria and the deployment of 475 more military advisers to Iraq. But he sought to dispel fears that the United States was embarking on a repeat of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: A Slower-Paced, but Still Easy, Wednesday Meal
abstract: Last night’s Sausage with Spinach and Bean Mash was easy and “therapeutic.” Tonight, pouring sauce on chicken.
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches one family, and all of us, in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal. Find all the Boot Camp recipes here.Tuesday Recap

headline: Deezer Enters U.S. Market With High-Fidelity Music Service
abstract: The French streaming service, available in 180 countries, is introducing Deezer Elite in partnership with Sonos, the wireless speaker company.
lead_paragraph: The streaming music market keeps getting more crowded.

headline: Revisiting a Hurricane
abstract: Fifty years ago this week, Hurricane Dora, a Category 4 storm, caused severe damage in Florida and Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this week, Hurricane Dora, a Category 4 storm, caused severe damage in Florida and Georgia.

headline: ‘Wolf Hall’ and Its Sequel Aiming for Broadway After London Success
abstract: Producers are in talks about a New York run of the hit British plays “Wolf Hall” and its sequel “Bring Up the Bodies,” based on the historical novels by Hilary Mantel.
lead_paragraph: Broadway and London producers are in talks about a New York run of the hit British play “Wolf Hall” and its sequel “Bring Up the Bodies,” based on the historical novels by Hilary Mantel about Henry VIII and his adviser Thomas Cromwell, according to theater executives with knowledge of the discussions. No deals have been finalized, but the veteran Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel are aiming to mount the plays in the spring, possibly at the Winter Garden Theater, said the executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the talks are confidential.

headline: Diva to Die for Shakes It Anew
abstract: Sylvester, the flamboyant androgyne and disco diva, has now become fodder for the latest jukebox musical.
lead_paragraph: Donna Summer, Gloria Gaynor, Evelyn (Champagne) King, Vicki Sue Robinson, Amii Stewart: the disco era was prime time for divas of pop. But perhaps the flashiest disco diva of them all was actually a man who, aptly enough for a diva of any era, went by a single name. I speak, of course, of Sylvester, the flamboyant androgyne whose life has now become fodder for the latest jukebox musical to splash down onstage. “Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical” is the brainchild of Anthony Wayne (“Pippin,” “Priscilla, Queen of the Desert”), who wrote the book, directs with Kendrell Bowman and struts the stage of the Theater at St. Clement’s in the title role. As with many another musical drawing on chart hits, the show will weave Sylvester’s finest booty shakers — “You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real),” “Do Ya Wanna Funk,” “Dance (Disco Heat)” — into his life story. And let’s not forget this bonus: The show will feature Anastacia McCleskey and Jacqueline B. Arnold as the Weather Girls. Can we hope for a singalong? (Opens Sunday, 423 West 46th Street, Clinton, 866-811-4111, fabuloussylvester.com.)

headline: ‘Live From New York’: First Hosts for 40th Year
keywords: ['Television', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Chris Pratt, from NBC’s “Parks and Recreation,” and Sarah Silverman, a “Saturday Night Live” alumna, will each host one of the first two “S.N.L.” shows this year.
lead_paragraph: Heading into a season that will include a gala prime-time celebration of its 40th year on the air, “Saturday Night Live” will have its season premiere on Sept. 27, NBC announced Wednesday.

headline: Oscar Pistorius Murder Trial Verdict Is Due
abstract: The judge presiding over the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius, who killed his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, in February 2013, is set to pronounce her verdict this week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 18 months after he shot and killed his glamorous girlfriend, Oscar Pistorius, a onetime track star on a gilded trajectory of triumph and success, is set to face judgment on Thursday when the judge in his trial on murder and firearms charges pronounces her verdict.

headline: Chef Danny Bowien on the Five Lessons He’s Learned About Mexican Food
abstract: The man behind Mission Cantina and Mission Chinese shares some insights from his recent education on the cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The man behind the acclaimed Mission Chinese Food restaurants in San Francisco and New York has a cameo in Jeff Gordinier’s story “In Search of the Perfect Taco” in T’s Men’s Style Issue — a culinary odyssey in which the writer traveled with the Danish chef René Redzepi to discover Mexico’s many delicious dishes. Danny Bowien, of course, has gotten into Mexican food in a major way recently since opening Mission Cantina, in which he’s sought to put his own spin on that national cuisine in the same way that he did with Sichuan food at Mission Chinese. Here, Bowien reveals what he’s learned about Mexican cooking in the last year.

headline: CartoDB, Interactive Mapping Start-Up, Raises $7 Million
abstract: CartoDB, whose 30-person team is split between Madrid and New York, is the latest in a number of start-ups to offer services that try to make sense of the mountain of information readily available through the Internet.
lead_paragraph: When violent protests erupted in Ferguson, Mo., last month, tens of thousands of people took to Twitter to voice their anger under the hashtag #Ferguson.

headline: Chef René Redzepi on the Best Places to Eat in Mexico
abstract: The man behind Copenhagen’s Noma shares his can’t-miss culinary destinations in Mexico City, Oaxaca, Tulum and Mérida.
lead_paragraph: For “In Search of the Perfect Taco” in T’s Fall Men’s Style issue, Jeff Gordinier traveled to Mexico with the renowned Danish chef René Redzepi to explore the nation’s complex, misunderstood cuisine. Here, in his own words, are Redzepi’s greatest moments of gastronomic delight south of the border, which awakened him to the wonders of Mexican food.

headline: E.U. Antitrust Enforcer Will Be Margrethe Vestager
abstract: If confirmed, the former Danish finance minister will inherit delicate investigations into powerful foreign companies.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The nominee to be the next enforcer of the European Union’s far-reaching antitrust laws is Margrethe Vestager, a former Danish finance minister who would need to handle delicate investigations into powerful companies including the American technology giant Google and the Russian energy titan Gazprom.

headline: New York to Help Arts Groups Prepare for Emergencies
abstract: New York City officials on Wednesday said that they would help cultural organizations prepare for emergencies like Hurricane Sandy by sharing information about best practices.
lead_paragraph: To help arts organizations cope with another potential Hurricane Sandy, New York City on Wednesday announced it was creating a response and recovery network to reduce redundant communications, pool available resources and share best practices about emergency preparedness.

headline: Fashion Rocks Red Carpet
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Music']
abstract: Last night, some of fashion and music’s biggest personalities walked the red carpet to celebrate the marriage between the two disciplines at the Fashion Rocks event at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Last night, some of fashion and music’s biggest personalities walked the red carpet to celebrate the marriage between the two disciplines at the Fashion Rocks event at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: A Makeover for a Lisbon Food Market
abstract: The recently renovated Mercado da Ribeira in Lisbon, established in 1892, features traditional elements and contemporary cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The recently renovated Mercado da Ribeira in Lisbon, situated near the Tagus River since 1892, already qualifies as a major food destination.

headline: Netflix and Other Big Websites Protest Proposed Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The sites used a pinwheel icon, which means something is loading slowly, to show users what it would be like if Internet traffic was slowed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Dozens of websites joined a symbolic protest Wednesday against the Federal Communications Commission’s proposed rules governing net neutrality, which opponents say would result in Internet traffic being divided among fast lanes for companies that can afford them and slow lanes for everyone else.

headline: Botín’s Swashbuckling Style Hid a Cautious Streak
abstract: Emilio Botín’s ability to combine risk-taking with deep caution allowed him to keep his grip on Santander until his death at the age of 79, Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews writes
lead_paragraph: Emilio Botín transformed Banco Santander from a regional Spanish lender into a global giant. He was a merger mastermind who usually got the upper hand. With slicked-back hair and red tie, he flew in a private jet, conferring with presidents and prime ministers as easily as bankers and chief executives. Yet unlike many of his peers during European banking’s boom years, Mr. Botín also had a cautious streak. It is that, rather than his swashbuckling style, that allowed him to keep his grip on Santander until his death at the age of 79.

headline: Five Ballet Companies Join for Live Streaming ‘World Ballet Day’
abstract: The Australian Ballet, the Bolshoi Ballet, the National Ballet of Canada, the Royal Ballet and the San Francisco Ballet will offer a lengthy look behind the scenes in a 20-hour streaming event on Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an unprecedented bout of internationalism, five of the world’s major ballet companies will participate in a 20-hour-long live streaming event that will give ballet fans worldwide an intensive behind-the-scenes look at company classes, rehearsals and coaching.

headline: A Little Clarity in Arkansas as Tom Cotton Opens a Lead
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Arkansas could be the first state where the G.O.P. turns a big opportunity into a big lead in the polls.
lead_paragraph: There has always been something slightly peculiar about the Republican Party’s designation as the favorite to win the Senate this November. Among the competitive races, it hasn’t had a clear lead in the six states where it needs to win, and it has enjoyed a significant advantage in only three Democratic-held states: in South Dakota, Montana and West Virginia.

headline: Classical Playlist: Strauss, Bartok, John Dowland and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: RICHARD STRAUSS: ‘Elektra’Staatskapelle Dresden; Christian Thielemann, conductor; Evelyn Herlitzius; Anne Schwanewilms; Waltraud Meier; René Pape(Deutsche Grammophon)This seething reading of Strauss’s most astringent score, recorded live at the Berlin Philharmonie earlier this year, brings together as near an ideal cast of soloists as one could dream of. Evelyn Herlitzius, who triumphed in Patrice Chéreau’s production of “Elektra” at the Aix-en-Provence festival last year, reprises the title role with chilling intensity. Waltraud Meier as her mother, Klytämnestra, and Anne Schwanewilms as her sister Chrysothemis are impressive, too. Christian Thielemann stirs up a storm of brilliant colors in the orchestra. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: A Fractured Life, a Failed Marriage and 5 Small Bodies in Alabama
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']

headline: 1964: Palestine Exile Regime Planned
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Arab leaders create a Palestinian government and a liberation army in 1964.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, U.A.R. — Arab summit leaders today [Sept. 10] decided to create a Palestine government-in-exile and ‘‘liberation army’’ from among the refugees who left Israel during the 1948 war. Informed sources said Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Kuwait pledged $30.8 million for the upkeep of the army. U.A.R. President Gamal Abdel Nasser said he would place the Sinai peninsula and the Gaza strip ‘‘at the disposal of the Palestine organization.’’ He indicated this meant the organization would be allowed to establish headquarters and training facilities in these areas but did not mean Egypt was ceding the territory. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 11, 1964

headline: What Does the Apple Watch Mean for Travelers?
abstract: A look at whether wearable technology is really a game-changer for the traveler.
lead_paragraph: Updated, March 9, 2015, 1:52 p.m. | Apple’s new smartwatch can track your heart rate, pay for your Chicken McNuggets and give you turn-by-turn directions by sending vibrations to your wrist. You can even buy one in 18-karat gold. The device, the details of which will be revealed today during an Apple press conference, is the latest in slick, wearable technology, a growing category that includes Google Glass, Jawbone’s Up fitness tracker and Liquid Image’s goggle-cameras.

headline: From Kurdistan to Texas, Scots Spur Separatists
abstract: From Catalonia to Kurdistan, nationalist and separatist movements in Europe and beyond are watching the Scottish independence referendum closely.
lead_paragraph: STEENOKKERZEEL, Belgium — For Kurt Ryon, the mayor of Steenokkerzeel, a Flemish village 10 miles northeast of Brussels, watching the Scottish independence campaign in the final days before the referendum is like watching a good soccer match. “They were losing for the first half and most of the second half,” he said, “but now we’re in the 85th minute and they could be winning.”

headline: Under Cover: On Turning Lena Dunham Into a Neoclassical Bust
abstract: Victoria Diehl, a Spanish photographer who creates haunting hybrids of flesh and stone by melding images of human models and classical marble statues, talks about how she turned Lena Dunham into marble.
lead_paragraph: Once we settled on Lena Dunham as the cover subject for this week’s Culture Issue, the question was how to capture her quirky spirit as actor, writer and director. Jake Silverstein, the magazine’s editor, wanted to evoke classical art. The magazine’s design director, Gail Bichler, suggested turning Dunham into a sculpture, and Joanna Milter, deputy photo editor, had an idea for the artist to take that on: Victoria Diehl, a Spanish photographer who creates haunting hybrids of flesh and stone by melding images of human models and classical marble statues. Diehl had been on Milter’s radar since they met a few years ago at Photo España, an international photography festival. Last month, Diehl flew in from La Coruña, Spain, to photograph Dunham at Industria Superstudio in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, and then spent the next few weeks back in Spain composing the photo illustration above. Recently, Diehl talked about what it took to turn Dunham into marble.

headline: Apple’s Recipe for Emptying Pockets and Wallets
abstract: The tech giant has developed an iPhone payment system that looks secure and easy to use. Its new watch has the potential to replace car keys, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Apple has cooked up a recipe for emptying pockets and wallets.

headline: Family of Rikers Inmate Sues New York City Over His Death
abstract: Lawyers for Bradley Ballard, a prisoner who had schizophrenia and diabetes, say he was ignored for seven days while confined in a cell.
lead_paragraph: The night Bradley Ballard died, he lay naked on the floor of his cell in a mental health observation unit at Rikers Island, weak and covered with feces. He had not been given medication for his schizophrenia and diabetes. And, unbeknown to guards, he had tied a rubber band around his genitals, causing them to become badly infected, New York City investigators later concluded.

headline: At Michael Kors, Spotting Spring’s Most Wearable Hairstyle: Braids
abstract: Orlando Pita talks T through the creation of his easy-to-wear, low-slung version of the popular runway hairstyle this season.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not sure if she’s a girl who just got out of a car or a tornado in the Midwest,” joked the hairstylist Orlando Pita of the inspiration behind the blustery braids he created for the Michael Kors spring/summer 2015 fashion show this morning. “The look is very disheveled, very earthy and sensual.” And super low-maintenance, as the plaits didn’t require much prep work. “It’s the first show of the day, so the girls are coming in with really clean hair,” Pita noted. To build a tiny bit of grip and texture, he applied his Lift & Plump Volumizing Spray Mist followed by Schwarzkopf Osis+ Dust It mattifying powder, then started loosely braiding strands at the collarbone. “The hair drapes over the shoulders so it seems like that’s the length of the model’s hair,” Pita explained. Next, he blasted on dry shampoo and pulled out layers around the face, curling them with an iron for a messy, windswept feel. The look’s easy sophistication appealed to the model Maggie Rizer, who had just flown in from San Francisco, where she lives with her two toddler sons. “I love it,” she said of the unkempt braid. “It’s how my hair looks most of the time, only Orlando does it better!”

headline: Roger Goodell Asks Former F.B.I. Director to Investigate Ray Rice Incident
abstract: In a letter sent to team owners and presidents, the N.F.L. commissioner reiterated that the league had not seen the graphic Rice footage.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a graphic video surfaced showing the star running back Ray Rice knocking out his fiancée, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell continued to scramble to get ahead of the brewing controversy about whether he had seen the video before suspending the player for two games.

headline: Like Father, Like Daughter at Banco Santander

lead_paragraph: MADRID — Banco Santander decided on Wednesday to keep its leadership in the family by appointing Ana Patricia Botín as executive chairwoman to succeed her father, Emilio Botín, who died the night before.

headline: Nomination of Cecilia Malmstrom as E.U. Trade Envoy Signals Interest in U.S. Talks
abstract: Jean-Claude Juncker called on the Swedish Liberal Party member to focus on working toward “a reasonable and balanced” trans-Atlantic trade deal.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The selection of Cecilia Malmstrom on Wednesday to be Europe’s new trade chief suggests that Jean-Claude Juncker, the president-elect of the European Commission, is eager to restart stalled talks with the United States on the creation of a trade partnership.

headline: Melissa Auf der Maur Hosts Musical Festivals and Flea Markets in the Hudson Valley
abstract: The former bassist of Smashing Pumpkins and Hole and her filmmaker husband are luring culture-seeking Manhattanites upstate.
lead_paragraph: The proposed Marina Abramovic Institute has helped burnish the ongoing, artistic renaissance of Hudson, New York, but Melissa Auf der Maur got there first. In 2008, a gabled, 19th-century warehouse caught the attention of the former bassist of Smashing Pumpkins and Hole, who, along with her husband, the filmmaker Tony Stone, became, as she puts it, the space’s “creative directors, janitors and secretaries.” From spring to fall, they host concerts, film festivals, art exhibitions, flea markets and the extremely popular Ramp Fest, held in celebration of the forageable green onion. “The building is a symbol of the region,” Auf der Maur says of Basilica Hudson, “diverse, richly historic, magical, confusing.”

headline: Dia Art Foundation Appoints a Tate Modern Curator as Its Director
abstract: Jessica Morgan, most recently the curator of international art at the Tate Modern, will have fund-raising responsibilities as Dia’s director, including for a new Manhattan building.
lead_paragraph: The Dia Art Foundation, which turned 40 this year and is struggling to re-establish its presence in a Manhattan much more crowded and expensive than the one in which it was founded, announced Wednesday that it had chosen Jessica Morgan, a curator at the Tate Modern in London, to be its new director.

headline: 36 Hours in Cartagena
