lead_paragraph: Lining the ancient walls of Cartagena, Colombia, travelers find traditional food, beautiful beaches and a nightlife that heats up long after the sun goes down.

headline: 36 Hours in Cartagena, Colombia
abstract: From Old City strolls and sunset views to fried street snacks and late-night dancing, spend a weekend in this Caribbean city.
lead_paragraph: From afar, Cartagena’s skyline is deceptive. Its white towers rise above the Caribbean from a peninsula of tan sand and concrete, making it look like a bigger, beachier metropolis than it is. But with fewer than a million people, Cartagena is a sliver of the size of Rio de Janeiro or Los Angeles. One might expect the crisp new skyscrapers in Bocagrande to be in the midst of a vital, cosmopolitan downtown. Instead, Cartagena’s character — its lush plazas, fruit vendors and street art — is contained in two small, impossibly photogenic neighborhoods: the walled Old City and the rising barrio Getsemaní. There, in the birthplace of Gabriel García Márquez’s magical realism, are the city’s most refined restaurants, its museums and balconies that spill over with flowering bougainvillea. But even in its most energetic quarters, Cartagena is not so much a place to do, as a place to be.

headline: A Yalie’s Promising Future Competed With a Darker Side
abstract: In “The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace,” Jeff Hobbs writes about his roommate at Yale.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Hobbs and Robert Peace were roommates throughout their four years at Yale, class of 2002. Their friendship got off to a slightly bumpy start. Mr. Hobbs, a wealthy, second-generation Yalie who grew up in a house with a pool, had the impression that his future roommate came from a similar background, perhaps because Rob Peace had gone to a prep school and played water polo. But Rob was a black kid from a ghetto called Illtown, just outside Newark. And when they compared their fathers’ occupations, Jeff said “surgeon.” Rob said “inmate,” tactfully leaving out “convicted murderer.”

headline: What Janay Rice Wants
abstract: What impact does the video of Ray Rice punching his wife, Janay, have on her, and should news outlets take that into consideration?
lead_paragraph: On Monday, TMZ released a silent three-minute video showing the (now former) Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice assaulting Janay Palmer, his fiancée at the time, in the elevator of an Atlantic City hotel in February. Previously released footage showed Mr. Rice dragging an unconscious Ms. Palmer out of the elevator, a revelation that cost Mr. Rice a two-game suspension.

headline: Banging Out an Armistice on Keyboards
abstract: Two pioneers of Minimalism, the composers Philip Glass and Steve Reich, put aside a feud and performed together for the first time in over 40 years at the Next Wave Festival in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: There were no speeches, or stagy hugs, or arms lifted in reconciliation. Not even a handshake. Still, on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, two pioneers of Minimalism, the composers Philip Glass and Steve Reich, both 77, put aside a personal and professional feud that lasted more than 40 years and, for the first time since the early ’70s, performed together as they had in their early days so often and so momentously.

headline: Andris Nelsons Gets Ready to Lead the Boston Symphony
abstract: On Sept. 27, Mr. Nelsons, 35, will make his first appearance in Boston as the orchestra’s music director, taking his place in a youth movement that has swept across American podiums.
lead_paragraph: He was a terror at Tanglewood, the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, careening around the campus in a staff golf cart, his gangly 6-foot-2 frame spilling out of the driver’s seat. Andris Nelsons, the 35-year-old Latvian conductor who this month became the venerable orchestra’s music director, and who doesn’t even drive a car, had come upon a new toy.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 2 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: Highlighting some of the players to consider starting, and those to avoid, in Week 2 of the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: We’re guessing that not many fantasy football owners had Titans quarterback Jake Locker in their lineups in Week 1, but he was in full command against the Kansas City Chiefs, compiling 266 yards, two touchdowns and a 111.4 quarterback rating. Up next is a vulnerable Cowboys secondary, which was the second-best fantasy matchup for the position in 2013 and allowed 21 fantasy points to Colin Kaepernick in Week 1. With two great weapons in Kendall Wright and Justin Hunter, Locker’s health may be the only thing keeping him from a breakout season, and he’s still available to add in many leagues.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The PGA Tour has become such a ceaseless march that the winner of the FedEx Cup ought to be awarded a gold-plated treadmill. The new season will start three weeks after this one officially concludes Sunday at East Lake Golf Club.

headline: Gingham Checks In on the New York Runways
abstract: At Altuzarra, Oscar de la Renta and Diane von Furstenberg, the sweet, summery pattern packed a graphic punch in black and white.
lead_paragraph: After making a brief appearance last season at Céline, gingham has infiltrated the spring/summer 2015 New York runways. While the traditional colored checks seen at several shows reflect spring’s flora and fauna, we’re partial to these graphic black-and-white offerings. At Altuzarra, which opened with a series of effortless gingham dresses and separates, the black and white skirt suit was a standout. Oscar de la Renta showed a bigger check in the form of a midriff-baring two-piece skirt and top set — a refreshing new silhouette for cocktail dressing. Finally, at Diane von Furstenberg, two differently sized checks were fused together in a tank dress with a fluid, floor-grazing chiffon skirt.

headline: Sunnis in Iraq Often See Their Government as the Bigger Threat
abstract: Many Sunnis in Iraq do not support the Sunni militant group ISIS, but that has not stopped the Iraqi government from attacking them anyway.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A group of Iraqi Sunni refugees had found shelter in an abandoned school, two families to a room, after fleeing fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. They were gathered in the school’s courtyard last week when the Iraqi Air Force bombed them.

headline: Down a Rabbit Hole, Where Everything Makes Complete Sense
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s ballet “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” adds a prologue, a deanery, a rajah and a romance.
lead_paragraph: In Christopher Wheeldon’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” Alice doesn’t rush down the rabbit hole rashly, burning with curiosity. In this balletic adaptation of Lewis Carroll’s books, the heroine is dragged into her adventures. And her smiling passivity is only the worst of many things that go wrong in this cleverly constructed, scenically opulent, commercially successful 2011 production.

abstract: Poetry plays a big part in the one-man show “A Sucker Emcee,” “Ndebele Funeral” and the Irish play “Boys and Girls.”
lead_paragraph: In a shoe box cafe on a West Village side street, Craig Grant, known as muMs, had his back to the room. Then a young barista came to clear a cup away, Mr. Grant turned his head, and she stopped in her tracks. “You’re Poet,” she said, suddenly flustered, and he smiled and stuck his hand out to shake.

headline: The Making of Carolina Herrera’s Fashion Show
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: A fashion show like the one Carolina Herrera presented this week may be the most elaborately produced 12 minutes in show business.
lead_paragraph: At a little before 10 a.m. on Monday, the fifth day of New York Fashion Week, the backstage area at Lincoln Center was mobbed. Cameramen, designers, makeup artists and photographers were elbowing one another out of the way. The fashion executives Marc Puig and Ralph Toledano, each in expensively tailored suits, were chatting casually among the chaos. A few feet away, a member of Carolina Herrera’s atelier was steaming an enormous gown. And now it was showtime.

headline: Short-Seller Carson Block Says He’s Wary of Alibaba
abstract: “China is to stock fraud as Silicon Valley is to technology,” the founder of Muddy Waters Research said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:22 p.m. | In the world of the short-seller Carson Block, any Chinese company could be a fraud. Even Alibaba.

headline: Domestic Violence in The Times: From Civil Unrest to Spouse Abuse
abstract: The rise in the use of a phrase can often be connected with society’s increasing awareness of it as a problem, which is certainly the case here.
lead_paragraph: The attention this week to the domestic abuse case involving Ray Rice, a star running back who was fired by the N.F.L.'s Baltimore Ravens, reinforces a fairly recent trend: an increase in the phrase “domestic violence” in publications, including The New York Times.

headline: Hugo Boss: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: JDS Uniphase to Split Into 2 Companies
abstract: JDS Uniphase, a maker of fiber optic networking equipment, estimated that the move would reduce costs by $50 million while allowing the two independent companies sharpen their focus.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:11 p.m. | JDS Uniphase, a maker of fiber optic networking equipment whose share price has languished in recent years, said on Wednesday that it would split into two publicly traded companies in an effort to promote growth.

headline: Coleman Recalls Inflatable Swimming Tubes From Walmart
abstract: The company will take back 20,000 Sevylor River Racer tubes, which people use to float in the water, after consumers reported skin irritation, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: The Coleman Company, a manufacturer of camping and other outdoor equipment, has agreed to take more than 20,000 of its inflatable rubber tubes off the shelves at Walmart.

headline: Jean-Claude Juncker Seeks to Streamline Brussels Bureaucracy
abstract: The incoming president of the European Union’s executive branch, in nominating a new cabinet of commissioners, aims to appease a disenchanted public.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Jean-Claude Juncker, the incoming president of the European Union’s executive branch, sought to make his mark on Brussels on Wednesday, nominating a slate of new commissioners. But he also reduced their autonomy by adding a layer of oversight.

headline: Tough-Yet-Summery Sandals at Michael Kors
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Grecian-style wraparound leather sandals with an espadrille sole mounted on a rugged rubber bottom.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: After the Fashion, the Festivities
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Parties (Social)', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, the clothes have their moment in the spotlight, then it’s time to party (hashtags included).
lead_paragraph: Anyone who skipped through the countless fashion parties this past week can attest that the nightly spectacle has become as important for branding as the actual fashion shows.

headline: Back to School, to New Marching Orders
abstract: School was back in session across China last week, with some unique elements suggestive of how society is changing.
lead_paragraph: School was back in session across China last week, and in addition to the chaos seen in many countries — excitement over new friends and bags, horror at school lunches and having to wake up early — there were some uniquely Chinese elements.

headline: Coinbase Extends Bitcoin Access to International Customers
abstract: Coinbase, one of the most popular digital wallet providers, is expanding to 13 European countries by allowing those with authorized European bank accounts to buy and sell Bitcoins in exchange for euros.
lead_paragraph: Coinbase is taking its Bitcoin services to Europe in a move that could help expand the virtual currency’s reach.

headline: For Spring/Summer 2015, a Return to the Summer of Love
abstract: Translucent, long-sleeved frocks fit for flower children showed up at Tommy Hilfiger, Zimmermann and Vera Wang.
lead_paragraph: The ’60s and ’70s have been recurring themes on this season’s New York runways — most prominently at Tommy Hilfiger, who presented a literal ode to the rock music of that era. Standing out among the Sergeant Pepper looks were the ethereal, floor-grazing maxi dresses that closed the show. Translucent, long-sleeved frocks fit for flower children were also seen at Zimmermann, where different sheer prints were paneled together with romantic ruffles. Finally, at Vera Wang, the mostly black collection switched its tune when the model Daphne Groeneveld glided by in a pleated, floor-length chiffon gown with a micro-floral pattern.

headline: Ignore Endorsements From Politicians
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio endorsed Kathy Hochul for lieutenant governor, despite her unusually conservative record.
lead_paragraph: Tim Wu, who had hoped to be lieutenant governor New York, did surprisingly well in Tuesday’s primary for a candidate with no money and little name recognition among ordinary voters. He won 40.1 percent of the vote, and 27 of the state’s 62 counties.

headline: Who Needs Art? There’s Plumbing
abstract: Art is a form of pollution, in Alexander Melamid’s view, but plumbing ‘is invisible and an amazing human invention.’
lead_paragraph: It tickles Alexander Melamid, a 69-year-old conceptual artist and provocateur, that his Chelsea landlord has printed his name on the building’s tenant listing board as “Melamid’s Healing Shrine.” But so much amuses Mr. Melamid, a Russian-born painter with a ready cackle and a fondness for bear hugs, whose past provocations have included deep-frying photographs of artists like Andy Warhol, Picasso and Marcel Duchamp. It has long been Mr. Melamid’s mission to poke fun at the art world. His Art Healing Ministry, an ongoing project, proposes that certain extractions and gadgets involving the emanations of Great Works — Raphael, say, or Botticelli — could be cures for a grab-bag of ailments: bulimia, acne, anxiety.

headline: Outdoor Heirlooms: Dining Tables
abstract: Jonathan Olivares, an industrial designer in Los Angeles, searches for outdoor tables that can “facilitate conversation, conviviality and memorable meals.”
lead_paragraph: When you’re buying a table that you intend to put outdoors, the obvious thing to consider is what it’s made of — even if you live somewhere that’s temperate year-round. Jonathan Olivares, an industrial designer in Los Angeles, for example, said he sticks to “metals, woods, sometimes marble, stone and concrete.”

headline: Do I Need to Stage My Balcony Before Showings?
abstract: It’s always a good idea to stage your home, even the balcony.
lead_paragraph: Q. Do I need to stage my balcony before showings?

headline: The Elastic Interior
abstract: A forgotten space in a former schoolhouse leads to an urban dweller’s dream come true.
lead_paragraph: It’s a common enough dream for those who live in cramped urban spaces: Suddenly you notice a door you never realized was there and beyond it a room you didn’t know you had — or maybe an entire wing of your home, just waiting to be occupied.

headline: Preparing for Obama’s Speech
abstract: A look at how The Times planned for President Obama’s televised speech on the threat of ISIS.
lead_paragraph: Tonight President Obama addresses the nation on the threat of the Islamist State in Iraq and Syria. Times editors learned about the address Monday morning, and editors in New York and Washington, along with eight reporters, have been gearing up for coverage. They met Monday to discuss what to cover and how. Susan Chira, assistant managing editor, supplies an inside look at how the conversation and coverage took shape.

headline: Tell Us About Your Company’s Wellness Program
abstract: Does your company have a wellness program? The Times’s Health desk would like to hear about it for future reporting on this topic. Your responses will not be published, but a Times reporter or editor may follow up with you directly to learn more about your story.
lead_paragraph: Does your company have a wellness program? The Times’s Health desk would like to hear about it for future reporting on this topic. Your responses will not be published, but a Times reporter or editor may follow up with you directly to learn more about your story.

headline: For Many Iranians, the ‘Evidence’ Is Clear: ISIS Is an American Invention
abstract: The militant group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is meant to weaken Iran and its allies, many Iranians say.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranians are as obsessed as Americans these days with the black-clad gangs roaming Iraq and Syria and killing Shiites and other “infidels” in the name of Sunni Islam. At the supermarket, in a shared taxi or at a family gathering, conversations often turn to the mysterious group, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and how it came to be.

headline: What Makes a Nail Polish Worth $50?
abstract: “I couldn’t think about price,” Christian Louboutin said. ‘There was no reason to add an ordinary product to the beauty category.”
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Federica di Martino, a young actress visiting New York from Rome, sauntered into Christian Louboutin’s West Village boutique and slipped on a pair of six-inch stilettos. Perched on those heels, she was a knockout. But could she walk? Sure, she said, laughing as she leaned against the front door for support. “I can make it from here to the opposite end of the store.”

headline: 35 Arrested as Missouri Police Block Protest on Highway Over Teenager’s Shooting
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Although the demonstration, which formed shortly after 3 p.m., was generally peaceful, a handful of protesters hurled objects at officers, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Mo. — Demonstrators hoping to block Interstate 70 here on Wednesday to protest the fatal shooting of Michael Brown a month ago were barred by the police from entering the highway. The authorities said 35 people had been arrested, most for unlawful assembly but four for assaulting officers.

headline: Steve Jobs Was a Low-Tech Parent
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood', 'Smartphones', 'Tablet Computers']
abstract: Apple’s leader limited his children’s screen time, and a surprising number of other technology executives do too.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Jobs was running Apple, he was known to call journalists to either pat them on the back for a recent article or, more often than not, explain how they got it wrong. I was on the receiving end of a few of those calls. But nothing shocked me more than something Mr. Jobs said to me in late 2010 after he had finished chewing me out for something I had written about an iPad shortcoming.

headline: To Build a Fire Pit
abstract: Here’s what you’ll need.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you’ll need.

headline: Normcore Locks at Hugo Boss
abstract: Jason Wu’s minimalist collection was complemented by the models’ perfectly tame, freshly combed hair.
lead_paragraph: The beauty looks seen at this New York Fashion Week have been romantic, fun and experimental (especially Rodarte’s pierced brows and Marc by Marc Jacobs’s Bjork-ish buns). For most of us mere mortals, though, spring is really about fresh, glowing skin and effortless locks. At today’s Hugo Boss show, Jason Wu’s minimalist collection was complemented by the models’ clean, dewy makeup: nude lips, a barely-there dusting of taupe shadow. And on day seven of shows, there was something undeniably palate-cleansing about the Abbey Lee’s perfectly tame, freshly combed blonde hair, parted down the middle like a schoolgirl’s.

headline: Discounts at Minam, Artek, Michael McHale and Company C
keywords: ['Carpets and Rugs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Sales on throws, rugs, furniture and home furnishings.
lead_paragraph: Lostine wool throws are 50 percent off at Minam, while supplies last (originally $288 each, now $144); 215- 825-7276, minam.com.

headline: Beer With Its Own Accommodations
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Roughly 10 miles from the brewery, the Dogfish Inn welcomes dogs.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Dogfish Head, the craft brewer, opened the Dogfish Inn in the historic beach town of Lewes, Del., roughly 10 miles from the brewery. Designed by Studio Tack of Brooklyn, the rugged-good-looks hotel offers 16 rooms with wide balconies, custom-designed Woolrich blankets (handy in the off season), Tivoli radios, barware dedicated to beer drinking and artwork that pays tribute to one of the few remaining floating lighthouses in the United States (it’s docked a few hundred feet from the building). Almost needless to say, dogs are welcome, but call if yours weighs more than 80 pounds. “We get about 1,000 people a week who visit our brewery,” said Sam Calagione, an owner. “But now we get to hang out with them for 24 hours or more, rather than just an hour. It’s a natural extension of the Dogfish community.” Information: 302-644-8292 or dogfishinn.com.

headline: Baptism by Fire Pit
keywords: ['Fireplaces', 'Porches, Patios and Decks', 'Landscaping', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Brick and Tile']
abstract: After three failed attempts to build an outdoor fireplace, the writer emerged from his ordeal warmer, wiser and ready for s’mores.
lead_paragraph: In the 13 years we’ve owned our home, my wife and I have built three fire pits. The first was a rock ring in the woods, where we sat on boulders and invited armies of mosquitoes to mainline our blood while we pretended not to notice.

headline: Metal Makes a Connection in Lighting and Furniture
abstract: Gabriel Scott’s new showroom on Broome Street offers furniture and lighting with the firm’s signature combination of metal, mold-blown glass and Italian marble.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Kakon and Scott Richler have collaborated for a decade designing furniture and lighting; in 2012 they introduced their signature collection under the name Gabriel Scott. Now the Montreal natives (and brothers-in-law) are opening a New York showroom in the Brewster Carriage House, where coaches were once made. There they will show their new Harlow lighting collection of mold-blown, gem-shaped glass elements connected by metal prongs (a pendant starts at $2,950), and Prong tables with Italian marble tops on spiky metal legs (from $2,150). Other pieces on display include the Welles, a modular light system made of suspended clusters of blackened polyhedrons with metal interiors ($750 per polyhedron). Open Monday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; weekends by appointment, 372 Broome Street (Mott Street). Information: 212-837-2923 or gabriel-scott.com.

headline: Viacom Agrees to Offer 22 Networks on Internet-Enabled Sony Devices Later This Year
abstract: MTV, Nickelodeon and other Viacom networks will be offered later this year on some Sony devices, including web-connected televisions.
lead_paragraph: More choice is on the way for television viewers beyond paying for traditional cable and satellite packages.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Delpozo Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Industrial, but With a Softer Side
abstract: Roman and Williams introduces two collections of lighting as part of its R.W. Atlas housewares line for Waterworks.
lead_paragraph: Roman and Williams has added lighting to its R. W. Atlas housewares for Waterworks with two collections, Spunflower and Cupper. Robin Standefer, a founder of Roman and Williams, described the burnished nickel and brass lights as “fairly muscular and sturdy, but with a fine tactility.” In all, there are two pendants, two sconces and a chandelier, any of which can be described as industrial. But a closer look reveals some frills. The Spunflower pendant, for instance, has three tiers of milky white glass crowned with a rim of metal with tiny perforations. Ms. Standefer said these dots would temper any harshness. The quality of illumination in industrial fixtures is often “pure, tough and authentic,” she added, “but a light still has to be soft and beautiful.” Prices range from $1,200 to $3,500. The Cupper ceiling-mounted four-light pendant, shown, is $3,500. Information: 800-899-6757 or waterworks.com.

headline: Swimming Holes for City Folk
abstract: “Urban Plunge,” an exhibit of unconventional public pools, opens Sept. 13 at the Roca London Gallery, to coincide with the London Design Festival.
lead_paragraph: City waterfronts where swimming is banned have become pet peeves for Jane Withers, a London design consultant and a founder of Wonderwater, an environmental advocacy group. “Urban Plunge,” an exhibition that she curated at the Roca London Gallery, shows how natural bodies of water in metropolises have become primed for public dipping. Marshy basking spots for Londoners are being created in the Thames; Copenhagen already allows bathing in its harbor and the Manhattan coastline could soon have a floating cross-shaped swimming hole called +POOL. Amphitheaters, zigzagging boardwalks, and artificial hummocks surround the swimming areas, so bathers are not left vulnerable in open water. “I like the idea of these semi-wild experiences,” Ms. Withers said. The show opens to coincide with the London Design Festival, Sept. 13 to 21, but runs through Jan. 10, 2015. Information: 44-20-7610-9503 or rocalondongallery.com.

headline: The Dutch Are Back in Town
abstract: And this time their ships are laden with a new generation of thought-provoking objects and design ideas.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 24, in an avant-garde condo tower that butts up against the High Line, an unusual gallery called Chamber will open in Chelsea. Like a 17th-century cabinet of curiosities, it will be filled with the eclectic treasures of intrepid explorers.

headline: The Attack on ISIS Expands to Syria
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: In broadening the military operation beyond Iraq, President Obama moves the country back onto a war footing.
lead_paragraph: By the time President Obama announced the authorization of airstrikes in Syria Wednesday night, he clearly felt that he had little choice militarily or politically. For three years he resisted American military involvement in Syria, where the Assad government and rebel forces are engaged in a bloody civil war.

headline: Locations of Presidential TV Speeches Can Give Signals
abstract: Presidents have tended to reserve the Oval Office for their most important televised statements, but not always.
lead_paragraph: When the current Oval Office was built under Franklin Roosevelt’s supervision in 1934, featuring an Art Deco design that was fashionable at that moment, F.D.R. had no expectation that it would turn out to be a television theater for the president (his single TV appearance was giving a speech opening the New York World’s Fair in Flushing Meadows, Queens, in 1939). But that’s what it turned out to be.

headline: Dressing for New York City Fall Weekends
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Autumn (Season)', 'Hats and Caps', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Fall weekends present a chance to bring the right separates all together.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has brunched in Brooklyn knows that New York is a city that dresses on the weekend. The look, relaxed but put together, is quirkier than your office-appropriate work wear, but polished enough for an unexpected encounter with the boss. To make a casual style statement this fall, start with great separates: a pair of shorts, a classic peacoat. Top it off with fun accessories, and you’re ready to see and be seen.

headline: Anna Wintour’s Celebrity Extends to Theater
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Theater']
abstract: On Friday night, at Joe’s Pub, a sold-out crowd took in a one-man show about Ms. Wintour called “Ryan Raftery is the Most Powerful Woman in Fashion.”
lead_paragraph: The legend seems to grow larger every season. Outside Jason Wu’s fashion show in SoHo last Friday and the Diane von Furstenberg show on Sunday, two artists were selling a giant portrait of Anna Wintour. The asking price? $10,000.

headline: Detroit’s Bankruptcy Deal Hinges on 2 Banks
abstract: An innovative type of loan in 2005 now stands as a roadblock to Detroit’s exit from bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Syncora Guarantee, Detroit’s most vociferous adversary in bankruptcy, is close to a breakthrough settlement with the city, but before it can close the deal it must resolve a related dispute with two big banks, Bank of America and UBS.

lead_paragraph: From the East Village to Brooklyn, vintage clothing shops are riding the wave of ’90s nostalgia.

headline: Macworld to End Its Print Edition and Lay Off Many of Its Employees
abstract: The changing economics of print publishing in an increasingly digital world have forced many magazines to rethink their business models.
lead_paragraph: Macworld, a monthly technology magazine devoted to Apple products, laid much of its staff off on Wednesday and will stop publishing a print edition.

headline: A Chance at Anonymity, if Not a View
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: You might feel slighted, but a back-row spot at a New York Fashion Week show offers anonymity.
lead_paragraph: Is it lonely at the top? Not if you ask Melanie Woods, who, gazing from her Alpine perch at the rear of the Alexander Wang show on Saturday, found the ether as heady as the view. Ms. Woods, 31, a medical clinic coordinator visiting Manhattan from Memphis, chortled as she confided that she had scored her much-coveted ticket from a friend who works at Topshop. “I’m so excited by the models and the scene,” she said. “Everything is so rich. It gives me a rush.”

headline: Peru Investigates the Killing of an Environmental Advocate
abstract: The advocate, Edwin Chota, and three other men were killed in a remote part of the Amazon jungle on their way to meet with leaders of another village in the region.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — The authorities here are investigating the killing of an environmental advocate and indigenous leader who died along with three other men in a remote region of the Amazon jungle that he had sought to protect from illegal logging.

headline: Lured Back by a Cease-Fire in Ukraine, but Not Feeling at Home Yet
abstract: Many residents of Donetsk who had fled the fighting and returned on word of a cease-fire found a city that felt empty and still at war.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The bus station is bustling once again, with families unloading children, pets and bulging bags while waiting for connecting routes. Many are returning to Donetsk and surrounding areas after escaping the intense bombardment of the last few months, prompted by the announcement of a cease-fire but also by more prosaic things, like retrieving warm clothes and the return to school.

headline: Guilty Plea by American on Attempt to Help ISIS
abstract: The plea by the 19-year-old Colorado woman was over charges of conspiring to help the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni militant group.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Colorado woman pleaded guilty on Wednesday to conspiring to help the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni militant group, after she was caught trying to travel to Syria, federal prosecutors said.

lead_paragraph: “I have a suit, yes, a couple of suits,” Tim Coppens said before his men’s wear show last weekend. “I appreciate the construction aspect of a suit, and suiting is needed for certain ceremonial things.”

headline: Breaking My A.L.S. Promise
abstract: My husband made me swear to forget the disease that killed him. No fund-raising, no telethons, not even a bake sale.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Like most people, I was impressed and amused by the A.L.S. ice bucket challenge — that so many people got involved and that both funds and awareness were raised. But I was also conflicted.

headline: The Models Were a Mirage
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Those wearing pieces from the Polo for Women collection were displayed on a 60-foot-tall wall of water that rose from the Central Park Lake.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes fashion is all about timing. When the schedule for New York Fashion Week was completed a few weeks ago, one show that had been added to the roster — Polo for Women, to be held in Central Park — looked as if it might be problematic for some attendees.

abstract: A border police officer has been charged with assault after he was filmed beating Tariq Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian-American teenager, on the edges of a violent riot in East Jerusalem in July.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A border police officer has been charged with assault after he was filmed beating a Palestinian-American teenager on the edges of a violent riot in East Jerusalem in July, the Israeli Ministry of Justice said Wednesday in a statement.

headline: Mocking ISIS in Beirut
abstract: In Beirut, the band Al-Rahel Al-Kabir, or the Great Departed, has been performing a satirical hymn to the leader of ISIS to uproarious laughter.
lead_paragraph: As fear of militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria rises in the United States after the beheading of two American journalists, and President Obama lines up support for the use of force against ISIS, the backlash against the movement has already begun in the Arab world.

headline: Why Doesn’t the Apple Watch Have Wireless Charging? Because It Probably Wouldn’t Work Very Well.
abstract: Early reports said the Apple Watch might charge wirelessly. But wireless charging wouldn’t have worked well for the device.
lead_paragraph: The Apple Watch will not allow for wireless charging. To charge the device, you’ve got to connect it to a charging cable.

headline: Stop the Anti-Obamacare Shenanigans
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The courts should reject a perverse new challenge to the law’s health insurance subsidies.
lead_paragraph: SO far, opponents of the Affordable Care Act have lost every major battle to repeal or invalidate it. Some of them are now urging the courts to interpret the health reform law in a way that would guarantee its failure. This is a significant threat — potentially as grave as the previous main legal challenge to the law, which the Supreme Court rejected, 5 to 4, in 2012. If the new effort succeeds, it would create total chaos.

headline: The Digital Wallet Revolution
keywords: ['Mobile Commerce', 'Virtual Currency', 'Smartphones', 'Currency', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Apple’s payment system points toward a new era of commerce.
lead_paragraph: THIS week Apple announced two new pieces of hardware, the iPhone 6 and a “smartwatch.” But as flashy as they are, neither item is as groundbreaking as a piece of software that will accompany them: a digital wallet, allowing users to eschew cash and credit cards for a quick swipe of their device at the register.

headline: A View of Ground Zero
abstract: A panoramic view of the progress at the new World Trade Center site exactly 13 years after the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: A panoramic view of the progress at the new World Trade Center site exactly 13 years after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: T-Mobile’s Latest Freebies Revolve Around Wi-Fi
abstract: T-Mobile has gained millions of customers with the help of handing out free services, like unlimited music streaming and free international roaming. Now it is adding Wi-Fi-related technology to the mix.
lead_paragraph: Over the last year and a half, T-Mobile has lured millions of customers to its network with the help of giveaways, like unlimited music streaming and free international roaming.

headline: A Video Series Turns a Spotlight on Local Artists
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Each episode opens with text that indicates that it is presented by Windstream, but contrary to what is often the case with branded content, the company is never mentioned or even obliquely evoked otherwise.
lead_paragraph: AN online documentary about Porridge Papers, a company in Lincoln, Neb., that makes the type of deckle-edged recycled paper found in art supply and stationary stores, includes a field-trip visit by schoolchildren to the small mill and print shop.

headline: Human Rights Abuses Reported in Junta-Ruled Thailand
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Amnesty International cites at least one report of torture and hundreds having to report to the military, as well as heavy-handed restrictions on political expression.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — In the wake of the coup that overthrew the democratically elected government of Thailand in May, at least one activist says she was tortured while in custody, some 60 civilians face trials in military courts, and dissent and freedom of expression have been sharply restricted, according to a report by Amnesty International.

headline: Ex-Mets Executive Sues Jeff Wilpon, Citing Discrimination Over Pregnancy
abstract: Leigh Castergine, a former ticket-sales executive for the Mets, filed suit in federal court, accusing the team and its chief operating officer of discriminating against her for being pregnant without being married.
lead_paragraph: Leigh Castergine, a former top ticket-sales executive for the Mets, filed suit in federal court in Brooklyn on Tuesday, accusing the team and its chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, of discriminating against her for being pregnant without being married.

headline: Going After the Abusers
abstract: When police have evidence of domestic violence, should prosecution be mandatory?

headline: With Apple Pay and Smartwatch, a Privacy Challenge
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing', 'Mobile Commerce']
abstract: Apple faces two threats: one from hackers looking for ways to steal financial information, and another from regulators interested in ensuring that information gleaned from health monitoring devices stays private.
lead_paragraph: No one has considered Apple a serious data company, until now.

headline: Cereals Begin to Lose Their Snap, Crackle and Pop
abstract: The cereal business has been in steady decline for a decade as consumers opt for healthier options or food easier to eat on the run in the morning.
lead_paragraph: Cereal, that bedrock of the American breakfast, has lost some of its snap, crackle and pop.

headline: Mayor Agrees to Accommodate 4 Larger or New Charter Schools
abstract: Under a new state law, New York City must offer free space in public buildings or or help with the cost of renting private space.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration, which spent the winter in a bruising fight with charter school advocates, said on Wednesday that it would find space in public school buildings for four charter schools that want to open or expand next year.

headline: Mexico: Discovery of Coca Plants Puzzles Authorities
abstract: The authorities discovered and destroyed more than 1,600 coca plants this week near the Guatemala border, the first such find in Mexico in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: The authorities discovered and destroyed more than 1,600 coca plants this week near the Guatemala border, the first such find in Mexico in recent memory. Coca, from which cocaine is produced, is grown and processed primarily in Peru and Colombia, because the climate and soil are thought to be ideal there. Traffickers based in Mexico control much of the flow of the drug to the United States and around the world. But the authorities, drawn Monday to the hidden farm by a tip, were not sure if the coca plants were an experiment or a sign that drug lords are developing fields closer to their markets.

headline: An Eye in the Sky, Accessible to the Hobbyist
abstract: A drone model from DJI comes with a camera, GPS positioning and other features meant for producing high-quality still images and video.
lead_paragraph: Look to the sky and say “Cheese!”

headline: Elizabeth and James: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Astorino, Cuomo’s Opponent, Wants Voters to Know the Race Isn’t Over
abstract: Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, is a social conservative with little state name recognition and a small campaign budget. Still, he is enthusiastic about his chances of upsetting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in November’s election.
lead_paragraph: Andrew M. Cuomo is hoping this year’s campaign for governor effectively ended on Tuesday.

headline: Alibaba Is Bringing Luxury, Fast, to China’s Middle Class
abstract: The Internet giant is bringing e-commerce into the homes of China’s rapidly expanding middle class.
lead_paragraph: On a cold day in April, a group of New Zealand fishermen set out to harvest 50,000 large oysters from the waters of the South Pacific.

headline: Modified Training for Children Stirs New Debates
abstract: The U.S.T.A.’s rules for younger players continue to divide members of the tennis community, who often disagree about the best methods for attracting young athletes to the sport.
lead_paragraph: At 9 years old, J. C. Roddick, the nephew of Andy Roddick, was forging a path of his own in tennis. After years of showing promise in lessons at home in San Antonio, where he used a traditional racket, court and balls, he entered a local United States Tennis Association tournament in January 2012.

headline: Hashtag Nation: How About Subways?
abstract: A summary of New York Fashion Week, told through the tweets of editors and bloggers.
lead_paragraph: “On to the next” is a fashion week mantra, so perhaps it’s no surprise that traffic was a frequent gripe as the fashion flock traveled to shows. Happily for observers, all the waiting provided ample time for trendspotting and witty observations, which front row editors and bloggers dutifully shared on Twitter.

headline: As Old (and New) as Time: Michael Kors, Oscar de la Renta and More
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Michael Kors, Narciso Rodriguez, Oscar de la Renta and Sophie Theallet present their collections at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: It happened just before Marc by Marc Jacobs: the big style innovation the world was waiting for, the accessory that was to be a game changer, the most anticipated debut of the season, the Apple Watch, finally appeared.

headline: Reed Krakoff: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Shia LaBeouf Pleads Guilty for Outburst
abstract: Shia LaBeouf, charged with disorderly conduct after interrupting a performance of “Cabaret” by yelling and slapping Alan Cumming’s buttocks, must continue substance abuse treatment.
lead_paragraph: The actor Shia LaBeouf pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct on Wednesday in connection with a drunken outburst at a performance of the musical “Cabaret” this summer.

headline: An Amendment to Cut Political Cash
keywords: ['Constitutional Amendments', 'Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: A proposal to amend the Constitution would restore fairness to American politics by reducing the influence of big money.
lead_paragraph: There are 48 Democratic senators sponsoring a constitutional amendment to restore congressional control to campaign spending that is expected to come up for a vote later this week. They are not under the illusion that it will become the 28th Amendment soon, if ever. But their willingness to undertake a long and difficult effort shows the importance they attach to restoring fairness to American politics by reducing the influence of big money.

headline: Senate Hearing to Examine N.H.T.S.A.’S. Recall Response
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A committee hearing is scheduled to examine the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s execution and enforcement of safety laws, as well as its handling of the crisis that has engulfed General Motors.
lead_paragraph: A Senate hearing examining the federal agency that oversees car safety will feature testimony from government officials, safety advocates and a representative from the automobile industry.The hearing, chaired by Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, is planned for Tuesday, and will delve into the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s implementation and enforcement of vehicle safety laws, as well as the agency’s handling of the crisis that has engulfed General Motors. The company has recalled more than 29 million cars since January and failed for more than a decade to report to regulators and the public a defective ignition that has been linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Microsoft Sees More Than Fun in a Game Like Minecraft
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that gaming is central to many people’s lives, serving as an engaging mode of entertainment or merely a time killer.
lead_paragraph: Parents like Minecraft because it can be a creative outlet for their children. Teachers like the game because it can bring lessons to life. And Microsoft likes the game so much that the tech giant wants to buy Minecraft’s parent company for more than $2 billion.

headline: Spring Collections or Spring Break: Jeremy Scott and Marc by Marc Jacobs
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Jeremy Scott and Marc by Marc Jacobs present their collections at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Youth is wasted on the young, but fashion has a way of yanking it back. Guests at the Marc by Marc Jacobs show arrived at a rave temple, with enormous black speakers stacked like altars and bathed in neon glow. The Marc by Marc designers, Katie Hillier and Luella Bartley, don’t frequent raves as they once did while growing up in England in the 1980s and ’90s, circa rave’s first go-round.

headline: Prosecutors Are Pushing Prison Time for D’Souza
abstract: The conservative author and filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza could face 10 to 16 months in prison for illegally making $20,000 in donations to Wendy E. Long’s 2012 Senate campaign.
lead_paragraph: Saying that Dinesh D’Souza had not yet accepted responsibility for his crime, prosecutors asked a federal judge in Manhattan on Wednesday to sentence the best-selling conservative author and filmmaker to 10 to 16 months in prison for violating campaign finance laws.

headline: 10 of the Gallerist David Kordansky’s Top Cultural Influences
abstract: As he christens his new space in Los Angeles, he shares with T 10 of his cultural touchstones — including several artists he doesn’t represent but admires nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: As Jonathan Griffin writes in “The New Dealer” in T’s Men’s Style Issue, the gallerist David Kordansky has for more than a decade championed the work of emerging artists (both young and old) with uncommon zeal. As he christens his new 12,000-square-foot space in Los Angeles, Kordansky shares with T some of his cultural touchstones — including several artists he doesn’t represent but admires nonetheless.

headline: The New Dealer
abstract: David Kordansky might not be the biggest player in the L.A. gallery scene, but his manic enthusiasm and seemingly genuine determination to draw attention to underappreciated artists make him the most interesting by far.
lead_paragraph: David Kordansky might not be the biggest player in the L.A. gallery scene, but his manic enthusiasm and seemingly genuine determination to draw attention to underappreciated artists make him the most interesting by far.

headline: Group of Ex-Players Asks Court to Intervene in N.F.L. Concussion Case Settlement
abstract: The three-year legal battle against the league took an unusual turn when seven former players argued a federal appeals court should intervene in a proposed settlement before it is made final.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The winding three-year legal battle against the N.F.L. over its handling of concussions took an unusual turn Wednesday when seven former players argued that a federal appeals court should intervene in a proposed settlement before it is made final.

headline: Los Angeles Sees Raids Over Ties to Cartels
abstract: Federal agents arrested nine people and seized more than $65 million in cash and assets said to be linked to drug gangs through California fashion district businesses.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Federal agents conducted a series of raids on Wednesday morning across this city’s fashion district, sweeping more than 70 locations, arresting nine people, and seizing at least $65 million in cash and assets from organizations with ties to Mexican cartels, law enforcement officials said.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 7
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Wednesday brought more gingham, exposed midriffs and Miley Cyrus. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday morning began with a packed crowd for Michael Kors, who showed on-trend looks (gingham and midriffs, anyone?) and titillated his viewers with a few daring, not-safe-for-work moments of transparency. This restraint was followed by a much showier, kitschier lineup at Jeremy Scott‘s show, where Miley Cyrus and her tongue made numerous appearances. The pop singer was there to debut her “Dirty Hippie” collection of sparkly, colorful, toylike jewelry.

headline: New Drug to Treat Obesity Gains Approval by F.D.A.
abstract: About one-third of American adults are obese, so a successful weight loss drug could potentially have huge sales.
lead_paragraph: Can the third time be the charm for weight loss pills?

headline: New Military Campaign Extends a Legacy of War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama on Wednesday night may have ensured that he will pass his successor a volatile and incomplete war, just as he inherited one when he took office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In ordering a sustained military campaign against Islamic extremists in Syria and Iraq, President Obama on Wednesday night effectively set a new course for the remainder of his presidency and may have ensured that he would pass his successor a volatile and incomplete war, much as his predecessor left one for him.

headline: California Bill Sets Sights on Curbing Campus Sexual Assaults
abstract: The state is poised to become the first to require all colleges receiving state funds to bolster their efforts and require that students give active consent before all sexual activity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California is poised to become the first state to require all colleges that receive state funds to strengthen their policies on sexual assault by mandating that students give active consent to one another before all sexual activity, either by saying “yes” to a spoken query or by signaling assent in a nonverbal way.

headline: Grandma Never Knit Like This
abstract: Josh Bennett, a high-fashion knitter, pushes the traditional boundaries of the craft.
lead_paragraph: Forget the studies purporting to show that knitting can ease the somatic nervous system, reduce blood pressure, relax muscles and improve brain power while staving off dementia and reducing stress. Never mind the homely communitarianism of the all-male knitting circles that have popped up lately in bars and bookshops and under the trees in Bryant Park. Put aside the thrifty virtuousness of D.I.Y.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 10, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Josh Bennett’s List of Five
abstract: The knitter with a pneumatic physique and unorthodox knitwear creations talks about various favorites.
lead_paragraph: Josh Bennett knits. A 33-year-old New Yorker, his pneumatic physique and unorthodox knitwear creations for designers like Tommy Hilfiger, the Project Runway winner Irina Shabayeva and Michael Bastian have earned him the industry nickname “the Knituation.”

headline: Dee Milliner Returns to Jets in Time for Encounter With Aaron Rodgers
abstract: After facing Oakland and a rookie quarterback in Week 1, the Jets have no such luxury Sunday against Green Bay and Aaron Rodgers.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan and John Idzik stood beside the aerial lift separating the Jets’ two practice fields and fixed their gaze on the player wearing a green jersey, No. 27. There was Dee Milliner, in a helmet and shoulder pads, doing all the things that cornerbacks — healthy cornerbacks — are supposed to do.

headline: In Court, Mother Is Called Calm at Time of Son’s Death
abstract: In opening statements, prosecutors laid out their case that Gigi Jordan was methodical in giving her 8-year-old a fatal dose of drugs in a Manhattan hotel room in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Whatever drove Gigi Jordan to kill her 8-year-old son in 2010, the prosecution said on Wednesday that she was methodical and brutal in carrying out the crime: She pushed a poisonous mixture down the child’s throat with a syringe, bruising his face, then coolly wrote a letter to her financial adviser as the boy lay dying.

headline: Store Openings, New Collections and Sales Starting Sept. 11

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama makes a comeback from weeks in which he was attacked for everything from playing golf to saying “we don’t have a strategy yet.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough time to be a concerned citizen. The truth of the matter is, the job has always been messy.

headline: Critique From an Obama Fan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president is right to expand the attack on ISIS into Syria if it’s done prudently with modest goals.
lead_paragraph: I’m probably one of the few Americans left with some sympathy for President Obama’s foreign policy, and even I have to admit that his Syria policy has been a mess.

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: The president said the United States would lead a coalition against ISIS and laid out the four parts of the strategy.

headline: After Losing to Cuomo, Teachout Returns to a Law School Lectern
abstract: Zephyr Teachout, who lost the Democratic primary election to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, was back teaching property law at Fordham Law School on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Zephyr Teachout leaned on a wood lectern on Wednesday night as she cracked a joke about her unlikely bid for the Democratic nomination for governor of New York. Nearby, photographers jostled to get the best shot.

headline: Struggling to Gauge ISIS Threat, Even as U.S. Prepares to Act
abstract: As President Obama prepares to send the United States on what could be a yearslong military campaign, American intelligence agencies have concluded that the group poses no immediate threat to the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The violent ambitions of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have been condemned across the world: in Europe and the Middle East, by Sunni nations and Shiite ones, and by sworn enemies like Israel and Iran. Pope Francis joined the call for ISIS to be stopped.

headline: Mets Shift Daniel Murphy to Third, Giving Rookie a Shot at Second
abstract: Murphy is hoping for a smooth transition after Manager Terry Collins moved him from second base to third base.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Murphy, the Mets’ only All-Star this season, was out on the field alone Wednesday afternoon, taking ground balls at a position he had not regularly played in three years. After one throw, he held his follow-through, his wrist bent, not unlike a jump shooter.

headline: Weaving Their Tapestry of Murder and Mayhem
abstract: In “Juárez: A Documentary Mythology,” at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, actors recite the accounts of residents who have witnessed that border’s town’s cycle of violence.
lead_paragraph: He is a dashing man, charming us in scraps of old home movies and the stories his son tells. The New York director Rubén Polendo has made a theater piece examining his violence-ridden hometown, Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, and this man, who still lives there, is his father. “Mijo,” Mr. Polendo’s father tells him, “all this is very real. It’s sad, and it’s difficult. And it’s not a story, or a play, or a myth. It’s the life of a city.”

headline: This Love Dares to Speak Its Name, Explicitly
abstract: “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s searing and sensationally funny comedy, looks at attitudes toward gays in black culture.
lead_paragraph: In one of the sharpest scenes in “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s searing and sensationally funny comedy about the sometimes poisonous attitude toward homosexuality in black culture, an adolescent boy hesitantly tells his mother and stepfather that a man tried to follow him home from the library.

headline: Change of Heart
abstract: This crossword was the most-discussed puzzle at Lollapuzzoola 7, a tournament held on Aug. 9 in New York City, and there are some people who still haven’t forgiven Patrick Blindauer for it. Hint: Pay attention to the title of the puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., here’s the thing: I watched a lot of people solve this puzzle — or try to solve it — at Lollapuzzoola last month, and the results made even the judges grading the puzzles weep. So if you’re still wondering what just happened to you, this is the guy (below right) you should be mad at. And yes, I totally get the irony of my having taken his photograph with a lit light bulb over his head. Only someone as devious — sorry, I meant only someone as creative as Mr. Blindauer could have come up with a puzzle like this.

headline: The Cost of War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Americans must think about what it means to engage in another foreign war, and weigh that against the urgent needs we have at home.

headline: Online Petitions Proposed to Offer New Yorkers a New Way to Speak Out
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A councilman proposed creating a system, similar to the one used by the White House, to facilitate making requests to city officials.
lead_paragraph: Since introducing a petition site in 2011 and promising to respond to any request that received enough signatures, the White House has been compelled to release its beer recipe, inform Texas that it would not be permitted to secede and weigh the merits of a “Death Star” for national defense.

headline: Rob Ford, Toronto Mayor, in Hospital With an Abdominal Tumor
abstract: After more than a year of political turmoil punctuated by his admission of crack cocaine use and drunken escapades, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto was admitted to a hospital on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — After more than a year of political turmoil punctuated by his admission of crack cocaine use and drunken escapades, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto was admitted to a hospital on Wednesday after learning that he had an abdominal tumor.

headline: Defaced World War I Memorial in Brooklyn Is Rebuilt
abstract: The parks department unveiled a reconstructed Brooklyn monument, which had been ripped bare in Saratoga Park over the years, to soldiers from Bedford-Stuyvestant.
lead_paragraph: First, in 1970, the honor rolls were stolen — bronze plaques listing the 106 fallen World War I soldiers from the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn. Then, in 2000, a thief swiped the allegorical bronze figure at the center of the memorial.

headline: Obama’s Full Speech About ISIS
abstract: The president revealed the plan from the United States and its allies to combat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: The president revealed the plan from the United States and its allies to combat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Stabbing With Syringe in Nigeria Raises Concerns of Ebola as Weapon
abstract: The stabbing involved a federal air marshal at the airport in Lagos on Sunday. Initial tests on the substance in the syringe did not detect Ebola.
lead_paragraph: A federal air marshal was stabbed with a syringe at the airport in Lagos, Nigeria, on Sunday, an incident that is raising concerns about whether the deadly Ebola virus could be harvested from the widespread outbreak in West Africa and used as a bioweapon.

headline: Ex-Consultant Found Guilty of Fraud Tied to Lawmaker
abstract: Melvin E. Lowe was convicted of conspiring with State Senator John L. Sampson in an invoicing fraud. Mr. Sampson, under indictment on other charges, has not been charged in the case.
lead_paragraph: A day after State Senator John L. Sampson survived a heated primary in Brooklyn, one of his former consultants was convicted on federal corruption charges of conspiring with Mr. Sampson to steal $100,000 from the New York Democratic Senate Campaign Committee in an invoicing scheme.

headline: Carson Palmer, Like Eli Manning, Experienced the Jolt of a New System
abstract: The Cardinals’ quarterback was knocked from his comfort zone by a new playbook, something the Giants’ Manning is currently experiencing.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Arizona Cardinals quarterback Carson Palmer understands the growing pains that his Giants counterpart Eli Manning is enduring as he struggles to adapt to a new offense.

headline: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 2
abstract: In a new weekly video series about fantasy football, The Times assesses the fantasy points allowed per game for various positions. For Week 2, players may want to look at quarterbacks.
lead_paragraph: In a new weekly video series about fantasy football, The Times assesses the fantasy points allowed per game for various positions. For Week 2, players may want to look at quarterbacks.

headline: Bob Suter, Defenseman for ‘Miracle on Ice,’ Dies at 57
abstract: Suter, the father of the Minnesota Wild star Ryan Suter, returned from a broken ankle to help the United States hockey team win the gold medal in 1980.
lead_paragraph: Bob Suter, a defenseman who recovered from a broken ankle to help the “Miracle on Ice” United States hockey team win the Olympic gold medal in 1980, died on Tuesday in Madison, Wis. He was 57.

headline: Herbert Lottman, American Biographer of French Figures, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Lottman wrote about giants of French culture, commerce and politics, including Camus, Flaubert and Colette.
lead_paragraph: Herbert R. Lottman, an American who fell in love with Paris as a young man and stayed to write detailed, influential biographies of giants of French culture, commerce and politics, died on Aug. 27 at his home there. He was 87.

headline: Transcript of Obama’s Remarks on the Fight Against ISIS
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: “America will lead a broad coalition to roll back this terrorist threat,” President Obama said.
lead_paragraph: My fellow Americans, tonight I want to speak to you about what the United States will do with our friends and allies to degrade and ultimately destroy the terrorist group known as ISIL.

headline: White House Invites Congress to Approve ISIS Strikes, but Says It Isn’t Necessary
abstract: The Obama administration says the campaign is covered by the existing authorization to use military force against the perpetrators of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks — that is, Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that it needed no new approval from Congress to launch an open-ended air war in both Syria and Iraq against the group known as ISIS because the campaign is covered by the existing authorization to use military force against the perpetrators of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks — that is, Al Qaeda.

abstract: The photographer turned to rain, spiders and banana trees to create the images in her current exhibition.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: The Race for New York Bragging Rights Is Close
abstract: The Yankees’ and Mets’ positions in the complex and crowded wild-card standings were identical going into Wednesday, with one team stumbling out the door as the other tried to barge its way in.
lead_paragraph: Of all the metrics conveying the Yankees’ status at any given point this season, perhaps the most sobering came Tuesday. It was not just that the Yankees fell to five and a half games out of a playoff position with 20 games to play, or that their run differential dipped again.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (American Heroes) THE HORNET’S NEST (2014) The father-and-son journalists Mike and Carlos Boettcher tell the story of Operation Strong Eagle III in 2011, intended to oust Taliban forces from a part of Kunar Province in Afghanistan, and the single-day strike that turned into nine days of intense combat, killing six American soldiers. (Above, a memorial service.) Mike Boettcher “knew those men, puts faces to their names,” Daniel M. Gold wrote in The New York Times about this documentary, directed by David Salzberg and Christian Tureaud. “As he says, every soldier’s story is different, and they all bear telling.”

headline: Tianhe Chemicals Issues Rebuttal to Short-Seller Report
abstract: Saying its email system had been hacked, compromising discussions with the Hong Kong stock exchange, the Chinese company responded at length to the Anonymous Analytics report.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The head of a Chinese chemical company that was called a fraud last week in a short-selling research report responded on Thursday to what he called “falsified information and blatantly untrue statements.”

headline: Oscar Pistorius Not Guilty of Murder; Still Faces Lesser Homicide Charge
abstract: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is expected to rule on Friday on the remaining charge of “culpable homicide” in the killing of Reeva Steenkamp.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The Olympic athlete Oscar Pistorius was declared not guilty of murder on Thursday when the judge in his case said she accepted the main argument in his defense: that he believed he was firing at an intruder rather than at his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, when he killed her in a burst of gunfire through his bathroom door last year.

headline: Air France-KLM Restructuring Puts New Focus on Its Low-Cost Airline
abstract: The plan to invest about $1.3 billion to turn Transavia into one of Europe’s largest budget carriers has drawn strike threats from Air France pilots.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After almost three years of belt-tightening, Air France-KLM embarked on a new phase of transformation on Thursday, announcing an ambitious plan to shift a large part of its European operations to a low-cost subsidiary and raise its game against fast-growing Persian Gulf rivals.
