headline: Austrian Court Unblocks Assets of Former U.S. Ambassador’s Wife
abstract: A lawyer for the former envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, said a Viennese court had overturned a decision to freeze funds related to the transfer of nearly $1.5 million.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A Vienna court has unfrozen assets belonging to the wife of Zalmay Khalilzad, a former United States ambassador reportedly under investigation by the Justice Department on suspicion of tax evasion and money laundering, according to a statement from the couple and their lawyer on Thursday.

headline: The Death of Adulthood in American Culture
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Women and Girls', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Books and Literature', 'Television', 'Movies']
abstract: Charting the final, exhausted collapse of the adult white male, from Huck Finn to “Mad Men.”
lead_paragraph: Sometime this spring, during the first half of the final season of “Mad Men,” the popular pastime of watching the show — recapping episodes, tripping over spoilers, trading notes on the flawless production design, quibbling about historical details and debating big themes — segued into a parlor game of reading signs of its hero’s almost universally anticipated demise. Maybe the 5 o’clock shadow of mortality was on Don Draper (fig. 1) from the start. Maybe the plummeting graphics of the opening titles implied a literal as well as a moral fall. Maybe the notable deaths in previous seasons (fictional characters like Miss Blankenship, Lane Pryce and Bert Cooper, as well as figures like Marilyn Monroe and Medgar Evers) were premonitions of Don’s own departure. In any case, fans and critics settled in for a vigil. It was not a matter of whether, but of how and when.

headline: When Laughter Is Bad for Your Bank Account
abstract: A new study suggests that watching a funny video could lead to financial mistakes — especially in men.
lead_paragraph: Much coverage of money and happiness has focused on whether the former leads to the latter. But a new study suggests we might want to turn the question around: Could feeling good make you lose money?

headline: Facing ISIS and Evil in Iraq
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: Spurred by scenes of northern Iraq’s refugee crisis, Lynsey Addario soon found the story had become about the battle with violent Islamic fundamentalists.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when I am photographing a major news event, I am suddenly overwhelmed by helplessness. One day I am at home, watching dramatic images of Iraqi Yazidis fleeing for their lives being aired nonstop on 24-hour news channels. Days later, I am there, staring at tens of thousands of displaced Iraqis and feeling a 35-millimeter frame cannot capture the scope of devastation and heartbreak before me.

headline: Are Parents Violating Their Children’s Privacy When They Share Photos and Videos of Them Online?
abstract: Should parents be concerned about leaving an unwanted “digital footprint” for their child?
lead_paragraph: Parents seem to love posting videos and photos of their children online, sometimes for the whole world to see on YouTube and Facebook. But are children going to grow up regretting being a viral star? Should they somehow have a say in the matter?

headline: R.B.S. and Lloyds Bank Say They’ll Move if Scotland Votes for Independence
abstract: The moves by the Royal Bank of Scotland and the Lloyds Banking Group would be mostly technical. Both banks are expected to maintain jobs and significant banking operations in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:46 a.m. | LONDON — After months of trying to stay above the fray, two of Britain’s largest banks, Lloyds Banking Group and the Royal Bank of Scotland, said they would shift their bases to England if Scotland votes for independence next week.

headline: In China, a Search for Oscar Contenders
abstract: “Gone with the Bullets,” “Coming Home” and “Wolf Totem” are attracting notice as possible Academy Award entrants. A film from mainland China has yet to win an Oscar, and officials are eager for the cultural validation that the award would bring.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:59 a.m. ET| The question that hounds every major Chinese film director was asked of Jiang Wen at a news conference earlier this month in Beijing. Mr. Jiang and his business associates had organized the event to generate buzz over the upcoming “Gone with the Bullets,” a gangster film set in 1920s Shanghai that is a follow-up to “Let the Bullets Fly,” the top earner in the Chinese film industry four years ago.

headline: Journalists in China Describe Extortion
abstract: On state news media, several told of receiving money for producing positive articles, giving details of a practice said not to be uncommon in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Journalists who worked for a business news website under investigation in Shanghai have described a scheme of extorting Chinese companies, which were pressed to pay in return for the production of flattering articles or the burying of damaging ones, according to reports in the state-run news media.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: The City Remembers
abstract: Thursday: a Sept. 11 guide, moody weather, and the governor reviews his primary performance.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cloudy Thursday.

headline: When Election Polls Don’t Tell the Whole Story
abstract: Although polls are certainly important, they don’t tell the whole story. Here’s why not.
lead_paragraph: It’s after Labor Day, and a batch of new polls on this year’s midterm elections is released every day. Despite this torrent of polling data, our forecasting model — which currently gives Republicans a 60 perccent chance of winning control in the Senate — stubbornly refuses to believe that polls tell the whole story.

headline: New York Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 8
abstract: If you’ve made it this far, congratulations: We’ve reached the final day of fashion week.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve made it this far, congratulations: We’ve reached the final day of Fashion Week. Unless, of course, you’re an editor, stylist or retailer embarking on the full international circuit. In that case, gird yourself: Your flight to London leaves imminently, and the circus travels on.

headline: Do Workplace Wellness Programs Work? Usually Not
abstract: Programs to keep employees healthy are popular with their employers, but the evidence of their effectiveness is very thin.
lead_paragraph: Most news coverage of the new Kaiser Family Foundation annual survey on employer-sponsored health plans has focused on the fact that growth in premiums in 2013 was as low as it has ever been in the 16 years of the survey. But buried in the details of the report are some interesting insights into how employers think about controlling health care costs. One example is that they’re very fond of workplace wellness programs. This is surprising, because while such programs sound great, research shows they rarely work as advertised.

headline: Kerry Seeks Arab Consensus in Campaign Against ISIS
abstract: A joint communiqué issued by the United States and 10 Arab states endorsed a broad strategy to fight ISIS, but none of the Arab participants said precisely how they would help.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — Arab nations vowed on Thursday to “do their share” to confront and ultimately destroy the Sunni extremist group known as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. The promise came after the nations’ foreign ministers met here behind closed doors with Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Daily Report: In Popular Games Like Minecraft, Tech Titans See Potential Beyond Fun
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that games are central to many people’s lives, as players can spend months building estates and entire countries.
lead_paragraph: Parents like Minecraft because it can be a creative outlet for their children, Nick Wingfield reports. Teachers like the game because it can bring lessons to life. And Microsoft likes the game so much that it wants to buy Minecraft’s parent company for more than $2 billion.

headline: Apple’s Smart Smartwatch Play: Let Developers Find the Killer App
abstract: Apple isn’t trying to answer the question of why you need its new watch. It built one that a lot of people will want, and left it to the developers to do the rest.
lead_paragraph: When Apple unveiled the Apple Watch in Cupertino on Tuesday, the company left a few questions unanswered.

headline: Here’s How to Keep Competitors From Poaching Your Employees
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: It hurts when a company invests time, money and resources to train new hires, and then sees them walk out the door for a few dollars. It can be a huge and demoralizing loss for the culture and the profits of a company.
lead_paragraph: If there were any doubt about what is the hottest and most important issue to fast-growth entrepreneurs, we now know what it is. Hands down, it is the poaching of each other’s employees.

headline: 1939: Convict Who Fled Returns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A French fugitive returned to his country to enlist in the army in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LILLE — An escaped French convict, who fled the Guiana penal colony in South America 13 years ago, returned to France today [Sept. 11] to take his place in the ranks of the French Army. An acquaintance of the fugitive named Jean Pouille recognized him as he entered barracks here to sign up. During a violent argument in 1919, the convict killed a friend with a knife for voicing unpatriotic sentiments. Condemned to Guiana for 20 years, he escaped in 1926 to Brazil. In 1930, homesick, he went to Belgium, married, and settled in Antwerp and later in Ransart. This morning he arrived in Lille from Ransart and applied for enlistment. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 12, 1939

headline: CME Group Names Head of London Derivatives Business
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Cees Vermaas will join CME Europe Limited on Jan. 2 after serving as chief executive of NYSE Euronext Amsterdam since June 2010.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The CME Group said on Thursday that it had hired the former head of NYSE Euronext’s operations in Amsterdam as the chief executive of its London derivatives business, which had its debut this year.

headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba’s Key to Success
abstract: Alibaba brings luxury to China’s middle class. | Dollar store tug of war gets contentious. | Detroit’s bankruptcy deal hinges on two banks. | Fed slow to pop bubbles.
lead_paragraph: As the Alibaba Group prepares to go public, the Chinese company remains committed to making global e-commerce available to China’s expanding middle class, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. “The degree to which Alibaba can deliver on this promise will help determine how much the company is ultimately worth and to what extent it can open up the enormous Chinese market to both global retailers and small businesses in search of growth,” he writes.

headline: North Korea Returns a Defector to the South
abstract: Pyongyang said the 52-year-old man had entered the North through an unidentified third country to escape his economic difficulties in the capitalist South.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea returned a South Korean man on Thursday who had defected to the North, in the first such repatriation since October.

headline: Quiet Bartender’s Secret
abstract: In “The Drop,” based on a short story by Dennis Lehane, a decade-old unsolved murder casts a shadow on a Brooklyn bar.
lead_paragraph: Bob Saginowski, the hero and sometime voice-over narrator of “The Drop,” is a Brooklyn bartender. Not the currently fashionable kind — a liberal arts graduate with an armful of tattoos and a carefully cultivated beard who plies artisanal bitters and obscure craft beers — but a more traditional variety. He pours shots and brews to working stiffs in Giants jackets at a roughed-up establishment in a hipster-free, ungentrified and somewhat mythical stretch of the borough.

headline: Far From Home, Party Officials Feel the Stress, Study Finds
abstract: One of the Communist Party’s tools for curbing corruption — assigning officials to positions far from their homes — has inflicted emotional hardship and contributed to misdeeds, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: One of the Chinese Communist Party’s practices to curb corruption — assigning officials to positions far from their home base — has inflicted emotional hardships and actually contributed to misdeeds, according to a new study.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: The House, in Rare Unity With Obama, Will Leave the Trail for an ISIS Vote
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The vote, set for Monday, showed how quickly the politics of President Obama’s foreign policy have shifted after he vowed in a speech to the nation to degrade and ultimately destroy ISIS.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare show of unity with President Obama, House Republican leaders will summon their fractious members back to the Capitol a day early next week to push through legislation to authorize the military to train Syrian rebels for the fight against Islamist militants.

headline: Church Is More Informal, Like Society, Study Finds
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Protestant Churches', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Choir singing and vestment-wearing is down, while the use of visual projection equipment and the practice of jumping, shouting or dancing are up.
lead_paragraph: Religious institutions often see themselves as countercultural — outposts in an increasingly secular society that challenge the culture with views and practices that are no longer mainstream.

headline: Judge Delivers Oscar Pistorius Verdict
abstract: Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, has been cleared of all murder charges over the killing of his girlfriend. The trial’s judge will rule later on charges of culpable homicide.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius, the South African track star, has been cleared of all murder charges over the killing of his girlfriend. The trial’s judge will rule later on charges of culpable homicide.

headline: Signs of Hope in Chinese Attitudes Toward Japan
abstract: An annual survey showed a slight improvement in the way Chinese respondents view their Asian neighbors. However, in Japan, negative perceptions of China are at a record high in the study.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago this week, protesters marched outside the Japanese Embassy in Beijing denouncing Japan’s nationalization of uninhabited islands in the East China Sea claimed by both China and Japan. In other Chinese cities, looters stormed Japanese businesses and owners of Japanese cars were attacked.

headline: Qaeda Group Has Released 45 Members of U.N. Force
abstract: The peacekeepers, all from Fiji, were released from captivity in good condition after being held by a Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda for nearly two weeks, the United Nations said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Forty-five members of a United Nations peacekeeping force who had been held captive for two weeks by an affiliate of Al Qaeda in southern Syria were released on Thursday in good condition, the United Nations said.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Liberty and the World Trade Center, 1983
abstract: “On that day — the Sept. 11 that requires no year — the sun set on crushed buildings in a reimagined world. It set on a recontoured skyline and a haunted city. The equations of life no longer worked. That’s the way it seemed.”
lead_paragraph: On that day — the Sept. 11 that requires no year — the sun set on crushed buildings in a reimagined world. It set on a recontoured skyline and a haunted city. The equations of life no longer worked. That’s the way it seemed.

headline: Prospect of U.S. Attacks Captivates Syrians
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: There was intense debate on Thursday over whether airstrikes on ISIS would help or harm President Bashar al-Assad, his armed Syrian opponents and war-weary civilians.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The prospect of the first American attacks on Syrian soil during three years of brutal civil war captivated Syrians on Thursday, prompting intense debate over whether airstrikes on the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria would help or harm President Bashar al-Assad, his armed Syrian opponents and war-weary civilians.

headline: Former South Korean Spy Chief Convicted in Online Campaign Against Liberals
abstract: The court found that Won Sei-hoon, former head of the National Intelligence Service, had violated a law barring the agency from domestic politics.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A former South Korean intelligence chief accused of directing agents who posted online criticisms of liberal candidates during the 2012 presidential election campaign was convicted Thursday of violating a law that banned the spy agency from involvement in domestic politics.

headline: Sara Paretsky: By the Book
abstract: The author of the V. I. Warshawski novels, most recently “Critical Mass,” was hugely influenced by “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man”: “I felt as though I’d fallen into words and wanted to drown in them.”
lead_paragraph: The author of the V. I. Warshawski novels, most recently “Critical Mass,” was hugely influenced by “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man”: “I felt as though I’d fallen into words and wanted to drown in them.”

headline: A Conversation Spoken in Paint
abstract: The Abstract Expressionists Lee Krasner and Norman Lewis, not quite in the “in”crowd, have a dialogue of sorts in a show pairing them at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: Critics think they have the last word, but sometimes art keeps talking. In 2008, while organizing the Jewish Museum’s boisterous survey of Abstract Expressionism, “Action/Abstraction: Pollock, de Kooning and American Art, 1940-1976,” the curator, Norman L. Kleeblatt, noticed that two paintings — Lee Krasner’s “Untitled” (1948) and Norman Lewis’s “Twilight Sounds” (1947) — seemed to be speaking to each other. He had the good sense to listen and, later, to orchestrate a deeper conversation. The result is “From the Margins: Lee Krasner and Norman Lewis, 1945-1952,” a nuanced, sensitive and profound exhibition.

headline: Are You Crafty?
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Sorority members invest many hours in crafting, making gift baskets, baking personalized treats, decking out rooms. Share your handmade creations with Education Life. Selected readers’ photos will be published.
lead_paragraph: Sorority members invest many hours in crafting, making gift baskets, baking personalized treats, decking out rooms. Share your handmade creations with Education Life. Selected readers’ photos will be published.

headline: Was Warning in Antidepressants Article Too Conclusive?
abstract: An article on antidepressant usage during pregnancy raises objections from doctors and readers alike.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Monday, 10:42 a.m.

headline: 36 Horas en Cartagena
abstract: Alrededor de las paredes antiguas de Cartagena se encuentra comida tradicional, hermosas playas y una vida nocturna más caliente que el sol Caribe.
lead_paragraph: Alrededor de las paredes antiguas de Cartagena se encuentra comida tradicional, hermosas playas y una vida nocturna más caliente que el sol Caribe.

headline: Scot Backing Independence Says Rivals Use ‘Bullying’
abstract: A week before the vote, Alex Salmond lashed out at anti-independence forces and called for an inquiry into reports that the Royal Bank of Scotland might move to England.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — With tension rising a week before Scots vote on independence, Alex Salmond, the leader of the “yes” campaign, accused opponents on Thursday of bullying and subterfuge, and he demanded an official inquiry into disclosures that the Royal Bank of Scotland would shift its registered office to England in the event of a Scottish breakaway.

headline: On 9/11 Anniversary, Looking Back and Ahead
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: This year, as families of the victims gathered in Manhattan, at the Pentagon and in Pennsylvania, there was talk of new military campaigns in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: The morning after President Obama stood before a national audience to announce a new campaign against Islamist terrorism in the Middle East, Jordan Thompson stood before television cameras in Lower Manhattan for a few moments and read a short list of names.

headline: RadioShack Bankruptcy Filing Could Be Near
abstract: The company said it was in talks with third parties and financial stakeholders about a number of possible options but might have to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
lead_paragraph: RadioShack, the struggling electronics retailer that is quickly running out of cash, said on Thursday that it might have to file for bankruptcy protection, or even liquidate, if it cannot arrange a lifeline.

headline: China Fines Volkswagen and Chrysler for Antitrust Violations
abstract: Regulators imposed penalties totaling $46 million, saying the automakers conspired to keep prices high on cars and replacement parts.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese regulators fined Volkswagen and Chrysler for violating antitrust laws, announcing on Thursday the first monetary penalties against large multinational carmakers swept up in a broad investigation.

headline: U.S. and Europe Back New Economic Sanctions Against Russia
abstract: The measures, which will take effect on Friday, are meant to punish the country for its role in promoting separatist warfare in eastern Ukraine, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The United States and Europe agreed on Thursday to place additional economic sanctions on Russia over its role in promoting separatist warfare in eastern Ukraine despite a fragile new cease-fire that went into effect last week.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Drop’
abstract: Michael R. Roskam discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Roskam discusses a sequence from his film.

headline: Toronto 2014: Michael R. Roskam Narrates a Scene From ‘The Drop’
abstract: Michael R. Roskam discusses a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO —In the thriller “The Drop,” Tom Hardy plays a Brooklyn bartender with secrets. The film is adapted by Dennis Lehane from his short story “Animal Rescue.” In this video, the director Michael R. Roskam narrates a sequence from the film that reveals a little more to this bartender than meets the eye.

headline: A Hurricane in 1964, and What Came After
abstract: Since 1995, the average number of Atlantic hurricanes has risen to eight, although the last two years have been relatively quiet.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Hurricane Lashes 2 Florida Cities” appeared on Sept. 10 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: On a Day Devoted to Past Events, Focus on New Terror Link
abstract: As President Obama honored the victims of Sept. 11, 2001, the White House argued that he had the right to wage his new ISIS fight under the same legal authority he used for Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The morning after committing the nation to an expanded military campaign against Islamist terrorism, President Obama honored the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks as the White House argued that he had the right to wage his new fight under the same legal authority he used to hunt down Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda.

headline: When Sorrow Is Deeper Than Love
abstract: In chronicling the end of a marriage, “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby” crosses a landscape mined with loss, secrets and questions of identity.
lead_paragraph: “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby,” written and directed by Ned Benson, is a strikingly ambitious debut feature. Shot in and around New York, it sets out to chronicle the end of a marriage in all its emotional complexity.

headline: ZZ Top Cancels Tour After Dusty Hill’s Injury
abstract: A spokesman said that the band would continue touring in early 2015, and that many dates would probably be rescheduled.
lead_paragraph: When ZZ Top canceled several concerts in late August after the band’s bassist, Dusty Hill, injured his hip in a fall on the band’s tour bus, the bearded Texas bluesmen said that they expected to return to touring on Sept. 25. But Mr. Hill, 65, has not fully recovered, and on Thursday the band’s spokesman said that the rest of the autumn tour – 27 dates, through Nov. 1 – would be canceled. He said that the band would continue touring in early 2015, and that many of the dates would probably be rescheduled.

headline: The Void Beckons: It’s Time to Leap
abstract: In “Bird People,” a businessman and a maid at an airport hotel abruptly seek escapes from unhappy lives.
lead_paragraph: “Bird People” begins with a series of calm aerial views of human beings in transit: crossing the terminal concourse at Charles de Gaulle Airport, filing through the turnstiles at the nearby commuter rail station, dozing and daydreaming on the train. The images add up to an affecting composite picture of a familiar modern paradox. We never seem more alone, more adrift from one another, than when we are bustling along in impromptu crowds, migratory flocks of isolated souls.

headline: Thursday Dinner, Faster Than Delivery
abstract: Salad Pizza: If you’ve got a ball of whole-wheat pizza dough, you can get dinner on the table faster than you could get it delivered.
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches one family, and all of us, in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal. Find all the Boot Camp recipes here.

headline: 1964: Independence Threat Dropped
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: South Rhodesia’s independence was put off in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Southern Rhodesia’s threat to defy the British government and declare itself independent “has been chucked out the window for the time being,” Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith said today [Sept. 11]. But he is hopeful, he said, that Britain will grant independence before the end of the year. After a week of talks here, Mr. Smith and British Prime Minister Sir Alec Douglas-Home agreed in a communiqué that independence should come only when a majority of Rhodesians — black and white — show their approval of the present constitution. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 12, 1964

headline: What Does It Mean to Be Scottish?
abstract: Scotland will soon vote to remain within Britain or become a country of its own. Why did the independence campaign stay away from the fundamental question of Scottish national identity?
lead_paragraph: Next week, the people of Scotland will decide whether they want to remain with Britain or become an independent state. Until recently, polls steadily showed that the “unionist” option was winning over the independence one, but a poll released Sunday showed 51 percent favoring independence and 49 percent keeping the status quo — results that came as a surprise in the British Isles.

headline: How to Get to Manhattan? Save, Save, Save
abstract: Anne Gole had a plan, and saved for it: to live in an apartment on the East Side.
lead_paragraph: After her 2011 graduation from Binghamton University in upstate New York, Anne Gole returned home to Tenafly, N.J.

headline: ‘Under That Hood’ by JD & the Straight Shot
abstract: A cut from ‘Where I’ve Been,’ the latest album by James L. Dolan’s blues band.
lead_paragraph: A cut from ‘Where I’ve Been,’ the latest album by James L. Dolan’s blues band.

headline: Psychedelic Pastels Pop Up on the New York Runways
abstract: A palette of pale, powdery hues is sweeping the spring/summer 2015 shows.
lead_paragraph: A palette of pale, powdery hues is sweeping the spring/summer 2015 shows. Mara Hoffman, usually known for her saturated brights, went with softer tones this season for her signature geometric prints, such as a gridlike pattern seen on a plunge-front maxidress. Thom Browne’s predictably whimsical show featured a three-piece suit with a psychedelic swirl motif topped by a matching Stephen Jones hat. And the opening series of looks at Marc by Marc Jacobs’s rave-inspired presentation came in sorbet shades — lemon yellow, peach, sky blue — which popped against the neon-lit black backdrop.

headline: Eastman Chemical to Buy Taminco for $1.7 Billion
abstract: Taminco, which makes niche chemicals like alkylamines, went public last year under the control of Apollo Global Management.
lead_paragraph: The Eastman Chemical Company agreed on Thursday to buy the Taminco Corporation, a maker of specialized chemicals, for $1.7 billion in cash, becoming the third owner of the company in the last three years.

headline: Soccer Fans Supply Strong Voice in Scottish Independence Debate
abstract: Scotland’s soccer stadiums have become key battlegrounds for the yes and no campaigns leading up to next week’s vote on independence from Britain.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — In this city defined by the rivalry between its two biggest soccer clubs — Celtic and Rangers — there were no team colors on display Sunday night as fans filtered into a gloomy pub to watch Scotland play Germany in its first qualifying game for the 2016 European Championship. There is, however, more than soccer to talk about at the moment.

headline: Republicans Lead Most Governor’s Races, but Margins Are Small
abstract: The G.O.P. advantage is mainly a reflection of incumbency, with Pennsylvania’s Tom Corbett the exception to the trend.
lead_paragraph: Republicans hold a narrow but broad advantage across this year’s governor’s contests, according to the newest round of data from The New York Times/CBS News/YouGov online panel of more than 100,000 respondents. They hold at least a nominal lead in 22 of this year’s 35 governor’s races.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Death Spa’
abstract: Hank Cheyne plays the victim in this scene from Michael Fischa’s horror film, released in 1989, about a fitness center haunted by an evil spirit. The film is on Blu-ray, DVD and VHS from Gorgon Video.
lead_paragraph: Hank Cheyne plays the victim in this scene from Michael Fischa’s horror film, released in 1989, about a fitness center haunted by an evil spirit. The film is on Blu-ray, DVD and VHS from Gorgon Video.

headline: Return of the Boxes That Ate Your Brain!
abstract: As Gorgon Video plans back-catalog releases of old horror films featuring the original cover art, its production chief discusses some of the more eye-popping images.
lead_paragraph: The man looks too calm for someone getting an ax plunged into his shoulder. And the lady with crazy eyes might want to wipe the trickle of blood oozing from her mouth. Or maybe she likes it? Such is life on the cover of a Gorgon video box.

headline: The West Point Sisters
abstract: Thoughts on serving and sisterhood from the Efaw family, in which the mother, father and three daughters — so far — have gone to West Point.
lead_paragraph: So far, Amy and Andrew Efaw have sent three daughters to West Point, from which they themselves graduated in 1989. Alexandra, the oldest daughter and a recent graduate who was featured in this past weekend’s magazine, was thought to be, by her mother’s admission, “not West Point material.” But that daughter, who goes by “Alix,” instead extended the family connection to the military academy. “Once Alix got in, it became more attainable,” Amy says. “The others thought, ‘Well, if Alix can get in. . . .’ ” Two more Efaw siblings are still in high school — Aimee, who goes by Kat, in eighth grade and Andrew in 10th — and, says Alix, “I could totally see my kids coming to West Point and it kind of repeating itself.”

headline: How ‘How It Happens’ Happens
keywords: ['ANIMATED FILMS', 'Science and Technology', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Henry Fountain explains how the Science desk’s video series “How It Happens” is made.
lead_paragraph: “How It Happens” is a series of explainer videos that provide simple descriptions of the science behind headline-making stories. Henry Fountain, a science reporter, works with Aaron Byrd, in the video department, to create these animated videos. Henry explained the process for how these videos are made.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Proenza Schouler Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Wider War, A Weaker Case
abstract: Some doubts on the president’s expansion of our anti-ISIS campaign.
lead_paragraph: To date, America’s military re-engagement in Iraq — which officially began a month ago, when the president decided to support Kurdish forces in their battle with ISIS, and to hold out a carrot of military support to the central government in Baghdad in return for the defenestration of Nouri Al-Maliki — has gone about as well as could be reasonably expected.

headline: New York Commemorates a Somber Date
abstract: The city paused to honor the dead and pay tribute to the first responders on the 13th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The city paused to honor the dead and pay tribute to the first responders on the 13th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: When the Problem is Priorities, Don’t Blame Cooking
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Family dinner isn’t, and shouldn’t be, something to get through. It’s not a way station on the way to some goal. It is the goal, no matter what’s on the table — and it ought to be within everyone’s reach.
lead_paragraph: This week on Motherlode, has amounted to an embracing and a celebration of family dinners.

headline: A Kiss, a Sigh ... and a Postage Stamp

lead_paragraph: What makes a great love letter?

headline: David Mitchell Coming to New York for ‘Bone Clocks’ Tour
abstract: The novelist will tour ten American cities in September, including Boston, Houston, San Francisco and Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: The British novelist David Mitchell, whose intricately structured, innovative novels have won him a huge audience, and whose just-published “The Bone Clocks,” was one of the most anticipated novels of the year, clearly has mixed feelings about celebrity. He lives in a small village in Ireland, and recently said in an interview in The New York Times, “I live in faint dread of people coming to find me.”

headline: Japanese Newspaper Retracts Fukushima Disaster Report and Fires Editor
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Newspapers', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The move comes a month after The Asahi Shimbun retracted articles on another hot-button issue about Japan’s wartime legacy: women forced to serve in brothels.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The Asahi Shimbun, Japan’s second-largest daily newspaper, retracted an influential news report on the Fukushima nuclear disaster on Thursday after weeks of criticism from other news organizations.

lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss the new U2 album, released this week for free in iTunes.

headline: Hitting Hollywood With Wit and Hankie
abstract: Justin Elizabeth Sayre is busy, as a writer of “2 Broke Girls” and host of the monthly variety stage show, “The Meeting*.”
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Most of the show folk milling around the Warner Bros. lot here are surprisingly dull. You see a lot of self-important hiding behind sunglasses and we-take-this-stuff-seriously haircuts.

abstract: California passes a “Yelp Bill.” Employee health premiums rise only 3 percent. And how scared is the “dumb-watch” industry?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Q. and A. With Bill Cowher
abstract: Cowher, an N.F.L. analyst for CBS Sports, says the Seahawks are positioned to return to the Super Bowl, but a surprise team could be the Steelers, whom he coached for 15 years.
lead_paragraph: There were seven head coaching hires in the N.F.L. for the 2014 season. Bill Cowher was not among them. But he is fine to continue as a studio analyst for CBS Sports on “The N.F.L. Today.”

headline: Mining for Antibiotics, Right Under Our Noses
abstract: Scientists may have discovered the next source for creating bacteria-fighting medicines: the human body.
lead_paragraph: “Microorganisms are the best chemists on the planet,” declared Michael A. Fischbach, a chemist himself at the University of California, San Francisco.

headline: Dying of Ebola at the Hospital Door
abstract: Monrovia, the Liberian capital, is facing a widespread Ebola epidemic, and as the number of infected grows faster than hospital capacity, some patients wait outside near death.
lead_paragraph: Monrovia, the Liberian capital, is facing a widespread Ebola epidemic, and as the number of infected grows faster than hospital capacity, some patients wait outside near death.

headline: A Mystery of Chinatown
abstract: Don’t look to the address or sign out front for help in finding Taste of Northern China, but the griddle pancakes and Qishan noodles will be waiting.
lead_paragraph: It’s easier to stumble on Taste of Northern China than to find it. The address is 88 East Broadway, but the storefront is around the corner, on Forsyth Street, with a mysterious 106 above the door (a suite number, it turns out). The name Taste of Northern China appears on the menu but not on the sign out front, or at least not in English — the Chinese characters translate roughly as Northern Delicacies, with the not-so-helpful English addendum China Local Cuisine.

headline: Toyota Recalls 130,000 Tundra Pickups for Air Bag Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The side curtain air bags in CrewMax and Double Cab trucks might not deploy properly because of a panel that was installed incorrectly.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling about 130,000 Tundra pickup trucks from the 2014 model year because the air bags may not function properly, the automaker said in a news release Thursday.

headline: Creating the J. Mendel Beauty Look for Spring 2015
abstract: T was there during the hair and makeup test for for the designer’s show. Here, a look at some exclusive behind-the-scenes images and tales — including which hairdo didn’t make it down the runway.
lead_paragraph: “I like to be inspired by art, but this was really hands-on,” says Gilles Mendel, the creative director of J. Mendel. For his spring/summer 2015 collection, Mendel collaborated with the New York-based painter and visual artist Enoc Perez to create a series of graphic prints. “I started with three or four of his paintings, then found ways to transform them in my own way by changing the color palettes and molding the canvas to the shape of a woman,” Mendel explains. “It was sort of a puzzle to figure out.” It wasn’t the first time the duo had teamed up — last winter they released a book of collages — and in some ways, this collection continued the dialogue. “I sliced and collaged his prints, using these extraordinary fabrics, to create unexpected moments that aren’t entirely Enoc or me. It’s really a combination of both,” the designer contends. On the runway, Mendel wanted an equally dynamic beauty look. “The collection is really precise, slick and constructed, so I think the hair and makeup has to feel the same way,” he says.

headline: Transformative Travel, 4 Ways
abstract: Follow a photographer to Mexico and Hunter S. Thompson to South America, then head to Brazil for culture and the Galápagos for nature in this survey of four recent books.
lead_paragraph: Latin America has long attracted travelers seeking personal transformation. In the 1950s and ‘60s, the region — with its frenetic cities, uncertain politics, ancient cultures and wild landscapes — served as a sort of screen on which many young writers and artists projected their angst and aspirations. “My last chance to do something big and bad ... " is how an unknown Hunter S. Thompson viewed his own chaotic journey across South America in the early ‘60s.

headline: ISIS Fight Raises Fears That Efforts to Curb Iran Will Slip
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Until now, President Obama’s No. 1 priority in the Middle East had been clear: preventing Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to engage in a lengthy battle to defeat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria reorders the global priorities of his final years in office. The mystery is whether it will deprive him of the legacy he had once hoped would define his second term, or enhance it instead.

headline: Boutique Hotels Get a French Design Touch
abstract: Sofitel So boutique hotels feature the work of French designers like Karl Lagerfeld and Christian Lacroix.
lead_paragraph: For fashion- and design-oriented travelers seeking a touch of French style, the hotel brand Sofitel’s rapidly expanding Sofitel So luxury boutique hotels and resorts combine Gallic style with local culture.

keywords: ['Blood Donation', 'Poetry and Poets', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poetic recollection of trying to donate blood after the World Trade Center attack, and wondering why the hospital seemed so empty.
lead_paragraph: Read all recent entries and our updated submissions guidelines. Reach us via email diary@nytimes.com or follow @NYTMetro on Twitter using the hashtag #MetDiary.

headline: Calvin Klein’s Spring 2015 Collection at New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Calvin Klein at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Back From the Brink, Poetry Group Makes Cash Prizes Bigger Thanks to a Grant
abstract: The National Poetry Series, which was in danger of closing last year, increases the cash prizes for its Open Competition to $10,000 from $1,000.
lead_paragraph: The National Poetry Series has upgraded the prize available to the winners of its annual Open Competition for unpublished books of poetry. The series also announced the first five winners of the beefed-up award.

headline: Deal Reached on Gaza Reconstruction, Palestinian Leader Says
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Thursday night that he had reached an agreement with Israel and the United Nations to import reconstruction materials to the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said Thursday night that he had reached an agreement with Israel and the United Nations to allow imports of reconstruction materials into the Gaza Strip, apparently bypassing Hamas to fulfill a key tenet of the cease-fire agreement that halted hostilities on Aug. 26.

headline: In a Study, Text Messages Add Up to a Balance Sheet of Everyday Morality
abstract: A study looking at daily attitudes provided a rough idea of just what constitutes the moral content of a random day.
lead_paragraph: Committing a small act of kindness, like holding the door for a harried stranger, often prompts the recipient to extend a hand to others, but it comes at a cost, psychologists have long argued. People who have done the good deed are primed to commit a rude one later on, as if drawing on moral credit from their previous act.

headline: A Lost-and-Found Nomad Helps Solve the Mystery of a Swimming Dinosaur
abstract: A model of the largest known predatory dinosaur, and the only dinosaur known to spend much of its life in water, will be displayed in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The first bones came in a cardboard box. Nizar Ibrahim, a paleontologist, was in the Moroccan oasis town of Erfoud at the edge of the Sahara, returning from a dinosaur dig in the sands. Inside the box, brought to him by a nomad, were sediment-encrusted pieces more intriguing than anything he had found himself, including a blade-shaped bone with a reddish streak running through the cross section. He took the bones to a university in Casablanca.

headline: ‘Heidi Chronicles’ to Return to Broadway in February With Elisabeth Moss
abstract: The revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s Pulitzer- and Tony-winning play will star Ms. Moss, Jason Biggs and Bryce Pinkham.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s play “The Heidi Chronicles” will begin performances in February with Elisabeth Moss (“Mad Men”) in the title role and, as the two men in her life, Jason Biggs (the “American Pie” movies) and Bryce Pinkham (“A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder”), the producers announced on Thursday. The director will be Pam MacKinnon, who won a Tony Award last year for staging the revival of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,” while the actress Tracee Chimo (“Bad Jews”) will play several supporting roles.

headline: Ebola Cases Rise Rapidly in Congo
abstract: The World Health Organization said that the number of Ebola cases in the country was 62, up from 31 a week earlier, and that more than half the afflicted patients had died.
lead_paragraph: The number of Ebola cases in the Democratic Republic of Congo doubled over the past week to 62, the World Health Organization reported Thursday, and more than half the afflicted patients have died.

headline: How the Colts Hurt Themselves
abstract: It’s hard to win N.F.L. games in Denver, especially when you voluntarily give up possession of the ball.
lead_paragraph: Everything seemed to be going well for the Colts in the first minutes against the Broncos on Sunday. The Colts received the opening kickoff and needed only five plays to take the ball to the Broncos’ 36-yard line. Then the evils of fourth-down decision-making changed the game.

headline: In the Emergency Room, a Hidden Ailment
abstract: A small study found that many elderly patients turning up in one emergency room were malnourished.
lead_paragraph: Many seniors who seek care in emergency departments may be malnourished, a small study by researchers at the University of North Carolina suggests. The study is among the first to attempt to document the extent of this problem.

lead_paragraph: The latest step in the music industry’s slow-motion revolution over licensing came on Thursday, when Pandora Media announced that it had struck a direct deal for music rights with BMG, the world’s fourth-largest music publisher.

abstract: The new Dressage L’Heure Masquée watch only ticks away the minutes — because in this digital age, do we ever really not know what hour it is?
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Christopher David Ryan captures a timepiece from Hermès.

headline: Two Sides Sounding at BEAT Festival in Brooklyn
abstract: The modestly scaled and impeccably organized BEAT Festival, held across Brooklyn throughout the middle of September, offers mostly affordable or free events.
lead_paragraph: The Miser is not the first chap to wonder whether festivals have gotten rather out of hand. A “more is more” aesthetic seems to prevail — whether in size, sponsorship, controversy, or celebrity — and the Miser is becoming less and less inclined to indulge.

headline: ’60s Soul Claims Young Hearts ... and Feet
abstract: The monthly Dig Deeper concerts present forgotten soul artists from the ’60s and early ’70s like the 72-year-old soul veteran Paul Sindab.
lead_paragraph: BELTING out his chipper catalog of ’60s soul tracks, wiggling his hips and waving his arms euphorically, Paul Sindab looked every inch the suave soul veteran during his set at the Dig Deeper concert series in Brooklyn. He even deployed a few James Brown-worthy stage theatrics: To kick off his most recognizable hit, “Do Whatcha Wanna Do,” Mr. Sindab, 72, whipped off his spectacles and hurled them offstage in a devil-may-care flourish, the audience cheering on his gleeful abandon.

headline: Weary of War, but Favoring Airstrike Plan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Many Americans agree that ISIS is a threat to the United States, but many wonder whether the country should edge toward another war.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — A few months ago, Kevin Kinard, a 55-year-old utility worker here, had barely heard of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. But when the Sunni militant group beheaded a second American journalist, Mr. Kinard clicked on an Internet video of the execution — and lost sleep for two nights.

headline: Google Acquires Online Poll Company Polar
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Social Media']
abstract: The company’s team of engineers and designers will join Google’s social network, Google Plus.
lead_paragraph: In a move that could shore up the dire shortage of opinions on the Internet, Google has acquired Polar, an online poll company. The deal was announced on Polar’s website and through Google’s social network, Google Plus.

headline: Losing Is the Real Victory for One Family
abstract: “The Quitter,” directed by and starring Matthew Bonifacio, focuses on a washed-up baseball star.
lead_paragraph: THE QUITTER

headline: Unanswered Questions in R.B.S.-Lloyds Moving Plans
abstract: In moving, R.B.S. and Lloyds would reduce the chances of a run on deposits. But Scottish consumers need to know how the moves would affect them, George Hay of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Scotland’s largest banks have moved to head off a crisis. The Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group say they will shift their Edinburgh-based operations to London, should the Scots vote for independence on Sept. 18. That’s a step toward financial stability — but not if you’re a Scottish consumer.

headline: The Fashion Secrets of Kate Lanphear, T’s Outgoing Women’s Style Director
abstract: Today, it was announced that she will become the next editor-in-chief of Maxim magazine. As we revisit some of her most memorable outfits, she shares the details behind her incomparable look.
lead_paragraph: Today, it was announced that T’s women’s style director, Kate Lanphear, will become the next editor-in-chief of Maxim magazine. Beyond her vast and varied contributions to the world of T, Lanphear has also drawn a global following for her distinctive rock-inspired look — a look that made her one of the original stars of the street-style world and continues to exert influence today.

headline: Staging Shakespeare in a Pit, and Other Dubious Calls
abstract: In “The Emerald Light in the Air,” Donald Antrim’s short story collection, absurdity is in the details of the choices his characters make.
lead_paragraph: Donald Antrim is, after Thomas Pynchon, American literature’s presiding weirdo. He’s a trickster. His books are short, vivid, drastic and surreal, so much so that reading them is like driving 90 miles an hour while in third gear, in the back seat of a jalopy the author has stolen, while he disposes of his drugs by throwing them out the window.

headline: Mississippi Sounds Live on in New Musicians
abstract: “Take Me to the River” looks to the past and the future of a vanishing musical legacy.
lead_paragraph: TAKE ME TO THE RIVER

headline: Want an Abortion in Missouri? Wait 72 Hours.
abstract: The Republican-controlled state Legislature on Wednesday imposed a waiting period for women seeking an abortion.
lead_paragraph: Missouri’s Republican-controlled state Legislature on Wednesday imposed a 72-hour waiting period for women seeking an abortion, overriding a veto of the measure in July by the state’s Democratic governor, Jay Nixon.

headline: Capturing Apartheid’s Daily Indignity
abstract: Ernest Cole’s photographs capture what it was like to be black in apartheid South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Artists will stop making art about race when racism ends. I won’t be here when that happens, and you won’t either. But in the early 1960s, a brash, South African photographer in his 20s named Ernest Cole thought he just might be, once his pictures of his racially sundered homeland got out into the world. By the time he died in New York, homeless and street-stunned, some two decades later, he probably knew better.

headline: Reacting to Obama’s ISIS Speech
abstract: Readers discuss plans to expand a military campaign against Islamic militants.

headline: Jobless Rate May Be a Flawed Indicator for Fed Policy
abstract: The Federal Reserve has used the unemployment rate to indicate whether monetary policy should be tightened, but at least one economist argues that unemployment alone doesn’t tell the whole story.
lead_paragraph: The United States job market has been improving. But is it close to being good?

headline: World Leaders React to Obama’s Speech
abstract: Across the globe, countries responded to President Obama’s plan for the United States and its allies to combat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Across the globe, countries responded to President Obama’s plan for the United States and its allies to combat the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: HP Is Committed to the Cloud, Even if It Kills
abstract: Hewlett-Packard didn’t pay all that much for Eucalyptus, a maker of open source cloud computing software. But the deal said H.P. is willing to mess with its existing business lines.
lead_paragraph: For what probably amounts to a relatively small amount of money, Hewlett-Packard just made a big bet.

headline: Gems Among the Ruins
abstract: The Governors Island Art Fair makes use of the abandoned officers’ quarters to showcase video, installations and sculpture.
lead_paragraph: The Governors Island Art Fair is not your average art fair. Now in its seventh year, it’s a scrappy, low-budget event organized by a group of artists operating under the name 4 Heads. Works by 100 artists are displayed not in corporate white booths but in the rooms of four late-19th-century brick houses on Colonels’ Row where Army officers used to live. Each artist was given a room to use.

headline: And They Had Such Chemistry
abstract: In “Honeymoon,” wedded bliss in a rural cabin gives way to terror when a wife starts acting strange.
lead_paragraph: HONEYMOON

headline: Introducing a New Crowdsourced Feature: ‘NYTLNreads’
abstract: We’re experimenting with an informal new way to hear from students about what they’re reading in The Times and why. We invite both students and teachers to use this feature, and we’ll choose favorites to publish on Friday mornings.
lead_paragraph: Are your students or other young people you know reading The Times?

headline: Sobbing and Electricity: Sarah Lyall Awaits the Final Pistorius Verdict in Pretoria
abstract: Sarah Lyall is in Pretoria covering the verdict in the Oscar Pistorius case. While awaiting the final verdict, she reflected on the South African justice system and provided a sense of the scene inside and outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Lyall is covering the verdict in the Oscar Pistorius case. While awaiting the final verdict in Pretoria, she reflected on the South African justice system and provided a sense of the scene inside and outside the courtroom.

headline: As the World Turns
abstract: Henry Kissinger’s “World Order” brings together history, geography and modern politics in considering how to balance the competing desires of nations.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand the point of Henry Kissinger, play this mind game: Imagine that the nonagenarian had run American foreign policy since Sept. 11, 2001, instead of two groups that had spent much of the previous quarter-century condemning him. First came the democracy-touting neoconservatives, who saw his realpolitik as appeasement, and now liberal Democrats, who insist nation-building must begin at home — and therefore hate foreign entanglements, let alone grand strategies.

headline: Elusive Peace
abstract: Joe Klein reviews Lawrence Wright’s minute-by-minute account of the 1978 Camp David peace talks between Israel and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Global Warning
abstract: Francis Fukuyama chronicles international political history to define liberal democracy and discover how and why it develops.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Francis Fukuyama published an essay in The National Interest entitled “The End of History?” that thrust him into the center of public debate. Although often misunderstood and maligned, its central argument was straightforward and sensible: With the collapse of Communism, liberal democracy stood alone as the only form of government compatible with socio­-economic modernity. Over the years since, Fukuyama has continued to argue the case, and has now summed up his efforts with a two-­volume magnum opus that chronicles global political development from prehistory to the present. A quarter-century on, he remains convinced that no other political system is viable in the long run, but concludes his survey with a sobering twist: Liberal democracy’s future is cloudy, but that is because of its own internal problems, not competition from any external opponent.

headline: Curses! Over and Over Again
abstract: The Trailer Park Boys, the Canadian mockumentary franchise, creates a film outlet for its vaunted limited vocabulary.
lead_paragraph: SWEARNET

headline: For the Joy of Worship, However Arduous
abstract: Pan Nalin’s documentary “Faith Connections” examines the annual Kumbh Mela festival, which draws millions of Hindu pilgrims to a town in northern India.
lead_paragraph: Pan Nalin’s “Faith Connections” is not the first documentary to take a camera on a pilgrimage to the Kumbh Mela festival in India. Mr. Nalin applies an on-the-ground approach, mainly looking at holy men and lost boys at the gathering. But he lets the sprawl slacken his overlong film’s grasp and, strangely, underplays the nuances of the event’s spiritual aspects.

lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

headline: Are Biblical Epics Epically Racist?
keywords: ['Bible', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Darren Aronofsky’s “Noah” and Ridley Scott’s “Exodus” have been criticized for their lack of diverse casting. Does this demonstrate Hollywood’s problem with race, modern religion’s, or both ?
lead_paragraph: Whitewashing the Bible is nothing new. It has been a mainstay of Western culture for centuries — from pallid Byzantine icons to Leonardo da Vinci’s lily-white “Madonna of the Rocks” to Charlton Heston’s roles in “The Ten Commandments” and “Ben-Hur.”

headline: Like Tweedledum and Tweedledee, Only They’re Angsty
abstract: In “The Skeleton Twins,” Bill Hader and Kristen Wiig play twins who reconnect after a long impasse and jointly struggle with their present and past.
lead_paragraph: As “The Skeleton Twins” deftly glides between drama and comedy, it peels away layers of personal history in the lives of its troubled main characters, twin siblings estranged for a decade who share an eerie emotional synchronicity. At the very moment Maggie Dean (Kristen Wiig), a dental hygienist in upstate New York, is about to gulp a lethal fistful of sleeping pills, she receives a call informing her that her brother, Milo (Bill Hader), a failed actor in Hollywood, is in the hospital after slashing his wrists.

headline: Small Businesses See Only a Small Increase in Health Premiums
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Even with a smaller-than-expected increase in premiums, however, the share of small businesses offering health insurance to employees declined slightly.
lead_paragraph: The warnings this time last year were dire and widespread: Small businesses would face a double-digit rise in health care costs in 2014. But as it turned out, premiums for small businesses barely budged. According to the Kaiser Family Foundation’s 2014 Employee Health Benefits Survey, small-group health insurance premiums for individual coverage grew by just 1 percent this year, the slowest rate of growth since 2008. Family plans increased by 2 percent.

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 12-18
abstract: A selected guide to exhibitions, readings and other events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Harlem International Film Festival (through Sunday) Life in Harlem, elsewhere in New York and around the globe is the focus of this festival — the ninth — which began this week and will continue at two Manhattan locations: Maysles Cinema, 343 Lenox Avenue, at 127th Street, Harlem; and Columbia University, Dodge Hall, Broadway and 116th Street, Morningside Heights. Included are features, shorts, animated films and documentaries, with many followed by discussions.

headline: Their Own Imaginary Keynes (Wonkish)
abstract: What was Minsky talking about?
lead_paragraph: Lars Syll approvingly quotes Hyman Minsky denouncing IS-LM analysis as an “obfuscation” of Keynes; Brad DeLong disagrees. As you might guess, so do I.
