headline: Fantasy Football: Week 2 Player Tiers
abstract: Andrew Luck jumps into Tier 1 this week after an explosive second half performance last week against Denver.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Hertz Offers Icahn 3 Board Seats to Stave Off Fight
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The rental car company said that it has agreed to give Carl Icahn three director seats, in exchange for avoiding a potentially distracting fight for control of the board.
lead_paragraph: Many investors had expected that Carl C. Icahn‘s emergence as an investor in Hertz Global Holdings presaged a nasty corporate fight.

headline: Lonely Sea Mammal Seeks Tank Mate
abstract: “Dolphin Tale 2” is the story of the humans who love one brave dolphin and the race to find a new playmate for her, because otherwise they’ll lose her to another aquarium.
lead_paragraph: DOLPHIN TALE 2

headline: The Big Leagues
abstract: On the road with N.B.A. rookies Marcus Smart of the Boston Celtics, Doug McDermott of the Chicago Bulls and Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers.
lead_paragraph: On the road with N.B.A. rookies Marcus Smart of the Boston Celtics, Doug McDermott of the Chicago Bulls and Joel Embiid of the Philadelphia 76ers.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: The Big Leagues
abstract: A killer three-pointer no longer cuts it in the world of pro basketball. To succeed as a multimillion-dollar brand, an athlete needs business savvy, fashion know-how and good table manners. Welcome to the N.B.A.’s other training camp.
lead_paragraph: A killer three-pointer no longer cuts it in the world of pro basketball. To succeed as a multimillion-dollar brand, an athlete needs business savvy, fashion know-how and good table manners. Welcome to the N.B.A.’s other training camp.

headline: Draghi Says Government Spending Could Help Eurozone Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, encouraged countries to bolster bank lending and use deregulation to help entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, on Thursday stepped up pressure on countries like Italy to improve the climate for business. But he also said there was room for governments to use public spending to reinvigorate the stalled eurozone economy.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Changes $25 Tickets Program
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera is modifying its program that offers $25 tickets in some of the priciest sections of the opera house by moving it onto the web this season, rather than having patrons physically wait in line for a chance at seats.

headline: Sucked Into a Sinister Maw
abstract: In “At the Devil’s Door,” nothing good comes of selling your soul, especially when Satan is involved.
lead_paragraph: AT THE DEVIL’S DOOR

headline: New Eni Chief Investigated Over Nigeria Purchase
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Eni and Shell denied wrongdoing in their $1.1 billion acquisition of an oil block in 2011 from the Nigerian government.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Italian oil giant Eni confirmed on Thursday that its recently appointed chief executive and one of his key lieutenants were under investigation in Milan. Prosecutors there have opened an international bribery investigation over the company’s acquisition of an offshore oil block in Nigeria.

headline: If Driving Past Zombies, Don’t Stop
abstract: “Z Nation,” a series about life during a zombie apocalypse, has its premiere Friday on Syfy.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to fiction, the Syfy channel lives a double life. Its series are mostly straightforward, reasonably serious genre entertainment, sometimes high in their class, despite low budgets and expectations (“Battlestar Galactica,” “Continuum”). Its original films, on the other hand, are gleefully and notoriously schlocky, a living museum of B-movie practice and an invitation to communal pleasure: Here’s a joke. Be in on it.

headline: Who Said ‘Massive’ and ‘Foreboding’ Can’t Be Enjoyable?
abstract: The organist Paul Jacobs told a Juilliard audience that he holds the “difficult” composer Max Reger “near and dear to my heart.”
lead_paragraph: The program notes might have scared anyone away. Max Reger is “frequently described as one of the most ‘difficult’ composers in the whole classical canon,” they began, going on to call Reger’s musical language disorienting and complex, his harmonic and textural juxtapositions jarring and his music in general “something at once massive and foreboding,” all in the first paragraph.

headline: The Median Is the Message
abstract: “Broadway Morey Boogie” is a new public exhibition of 10 works by 10 different artists, placed on Broadway medians from Columbus Circle to 166th Street.
lead_paragraph: IF Con Ed were in the market for a mascot, this could be it.

headline: Searching for the Object of a Mailman’s Longing
abstract: In “Finding Fanny,” the actress Dimple Kapadia plays a busybody in a backwater town who joins others in doing a good deed.
lead_paragraph: FINDING FANNY

headline: Fantasies From Pandora’s Shoe Box
abstract: “Killer Heels,” a sweeping exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, drives home the notion that shoes are one of visual culture’s most freighted artifacts.
lead_paragraph: For me, the high point of the recent Emmy Awards broadcast was the sight of Sarah Silverman gathering up the voluminous skirts of her stunning dark-green gown and, in bare feet, dashing up to the stage, taking the steps two at a time. There, she accepted a writing award for her HBO comedy special “We Are Miracles,” her physical exuberance having already conveyed her excitement and even gratitude.

headline: Mired in an Abyss of Despair in Taipei
abstract: Few words are spoken in “Stray Dogs,” Tsai Ming-liang’s exercise in Asian miserablism, with the modern industrial cityscape of Taipei seen as a chilly wasteland.
lead_paragraph: The point of no return in “Stray Dogs,” Tsai Ming-liang’s glum, humorless exercise in Asian miserablism, is an 11-minute scene of a homeless man smothering and devouring a cabbage with a face painted on it.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 12-18
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: A Well-Behaved Bistro Classic for Chardonnay
abstract: A monkfish dish that plays nicely with Australian chardonnays
lead_paragraph: Raised in Australia’s cooler microclimates, these well-behaved chardonnays do not make stringent demands on the palate, the budget or the menu. The characteristic that defines them might be described as a certain racy tartness. They should not be bullied by what’s served alongside.

headline: Where We’re Getting the Money to Fight ISIS
abstract: The crackdown is costing roughly $7.5 million each day.
lead_paragraph: So far, the American military crackdown on fighters from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has been relatively cheap.

headline: Wine, Olive Oil and the Good Life in Uruguay
abstract: The Carmelo area, not far from Argentina, has recently gained attention as much for its wine as for being an awfully nice place to visit.
lead_paragraph: Our first lunch was laid out like a last supper. There, in the middle of a vineyard, underneath a billowing white cotton tent, a long wooden table had been set up, every inch of it covered with platters of food. There was the stuff you might expect at a picnic: bread, homemade and chewy; wedges of various cheeses arranged on wooden cutting boards; paper-thin slivers of prosciutto and salami. Then there were the local specialties — bowls of creamy spinach dip, stacks of freshly baked empanadas, stuffed with tuna and still steaming. And finally the wine, bottles of the heavy stuff this area was famous for and what brought us here in the first place.

headline: In Buenos Aires, a ‘Secret’ World of Dining
abstract: At “closed door” restaurants in the Argentine capital, the address is just part of the intrigue.
lead_paragraph: The entrance to the white colonial apartment building in the Villa Crespo area of Buenos Aires is fairly typical of four-story apartment buildings in the affluent neighborhood: marble-rich entranceway, elevator, winding staircase, the reverential hush that accompanies centuries-old palazzos. The building is, by any measure, an apartment building — that is, except for the second floor. That’s where a friend and I found Paladar, a dining room ablaze in flattering lighting. And, at the very Argentine dining hour of 11 p.m., it was packed. Half a dozen tables were full of chattering couples eating salads, sipping wine and apparently totally oblivious to the only two Americans in the place.

headline: Photos of the Day: New York and More
abstract: Photos from New York, Washington, Pennsylvania and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Washington, Pennsylvania and South Africa.

headline: Love and Neuroses in Mamaroneck
abstract: “The Man on Her Mind,” based on a play by Alan Hruska, deals with objects of desire, real and imaginary.
lead_paragraph: We’ve seen riffs before on imaginary or literary characters come to life, in films like “Ruby Sparks,” “Stranger Than Fiction” and “Fight Club.” More recently, “The One I Love” used the notion of a married couple’s idealized doppelgängers to make points about unrealistic expectations of a spouse. Add to these “The Man on Her Mind,” a glib, glossy take on a play by Alan Hruska performed at the Charing Cross Theater in London in 2012.

headline: Putting a New-Journalism Pioneer Into Perspective
abstract: “Smiling Through the Apocalypse: Esquire in the 60s” is Tom Hayes’s film about his father’s time as editor of the magazine.
lead_paragraph: SMILING THROUGH THE APOCALYPSE

headline: A Slow Flow From Down Under
abstract: Wines from Australia’s more serious producers, who are growing chardonnay in cooler climates more conducive to subtly expressive wines, are difficult to come by here.
lead_paragraph: Mention Australian chardonnays to a group of American wine fanatics and one result might be a resounding silence punctuated by feigned snoring. I know what they’re thinking and I understand completely. But it’s time to take another look at Australian chardonnays, and at Aussie wines in general.

headline: Roxy Paine: ‘Denuded Lens’
abstract: The main attraction in this exhibition is a spectacular life-size diorama representing an airport security gateway.
lead_paragraph: Roxy Paine is known for technically ambitious sculptures, like trees made of stainless-steel tubes, and computer-controlled machines that produce globby plastic sculptures. Lately he has taken to woodworking, creating realistic objects that look as if they had been transformed by a Midas with a wooden touch.

headline: Ranjani Shettar: ‘Night skies and daydreams’
abstract: Ms. Shettar has always found formal sources for her abstract work in the craft traditions of Karnataka, India.
lead_paragraph: One of Ranjani Shettar’s diaphanous, constellation-like sculptures of hand-molded wax beads and cotton thread, installed at the entrance to “On Line: Drawing Through the Twentieth Century,” at the Museum of Modern Art, made a stellar introduction to that 2010 show. A new, similar piece, called “Tuntoroo,” fills a room at Talwar Gallery. And here, in a way that wasn’t obvious at MoMA, light plays a big role in the work, as patterns of shadows cast on the wall compound its intricacy and emphasize its apparent fragility.

headline: A Weakness for Cops, a Crime to Solve
abstract: In “Archaeology of a Woman,” Sally Kirkland plays an ex-newspaper columnist battling dementia while a murder mystery unfolds.
lead_paragraph: Not everything in a movie needs to make sense, but when almost nothing does, it’s a problem. Even so, what the publicity notes are pleased to call a “disconcerting narrative structure” is far from the only issue with “Archaeology of a Woman,” Sharon Greytak’s confounding blend of long-ago murder and present-day dementia.

headline: Lily van der Stokker: ‘Huh’
abstract: The cartoonish verve of Lily van der Stokker’s irrepressible installations can sometimes disguise the originality and sharpness of her art.
lead_paragraph: The cartoonish verve of Lily van der Stokker’s irrepressible installations, which consist of walls and objects painted light, feminine shades, can sometimes disguise the originality and sharpness of her art. With subtle plays of cryptic phrases, color and forms, her best efforts appear adamantly cute until they start filling up with mixed signals of longing, conflict and repressed urges. “Huh,” her current piece, meditates on the illusion of equality between the sexes, and also in relationships between artists, regardless of their sex.

headline: ‘Dubuffet/Barceló'
abstract: This pairing of the postwar Art Brut leader Jean Dubuffet and the contemporary Spanish painter Miquel Barceló is predictably unbalanced but nonetheless stimulating.
lead_paragraph: This pairing of the postwar Art Brut leader Jean Dubuffet and the contemporary Spanish painter Miquel Barceló is predictably unbalanced but nonetheless stimulating. It includes a fantastic selection of Dubuffets from the 1940s and ’50s, among them his richly marbled “Texturologies” and earthy portrait heads — all of which make for an excellent prologue to the Museum of Modern Art’s fall exhibition “Jean Dubuffet: Soul of the Underground.”

headline: From Money, but So Much More Than That
abstract: “Altina” tracks the life of a tobacco heiress, artist and inventor who refused to be hemmed in by convention.
lead_paragraph: The tobacco millionaire Morris Schinasi had three daughters. There they are, in Peter Sanders’s sassy documentary “Altina,” in their 1920s cloches and fur-collared coats in front of the family mansion at 107th and Riverside in Manhattan. Two went on to conventional heiress lives, and then there was Altina.

headline: Carlos Ginzburg: ‘The Forgotten Vintage’
abstract: You get a sense of Conceptual Art’s mix of politics, perversity and humor in this survey of early work by Carlos Ginzburg.
lead_paragraph: The early days of Conceptual Art seem long ago and far away. But you get a sense of the movement’s mix of politics, perversity and humor in this survey of early work by Carlos Ginzburg, an artist and theoretician — were the two ever really separable in Conceptualism? — who was born in Argentina in 1946 and has lived in Paris since 1972.

headline: A Spy Shaped by Manipulation and Shame
abstract: Nadav Schirman’s documentary thriller “The Green Prince” tells the story of a Palestinian recruited as a spy by the Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security agency, and his Israeli handler.
lead_paragraph: The emotional core of “The Green Prince,” Nadav Schirman’s gripping documentary thriller, is the deepening relationship of Mosab Hassan Yousef, a Palestinian recruited as a spy by the Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security agency, and his Israeli handler. Mr. Yousef, whose memoir, “Son of Hamas,” inspired the film, wasn’t a Palestinian fighter infused with jihadist fervor. But because his father, Hassan Yousef, was a founder of Hamas, he was a prize catch for the Israeli agency, which manipulated him with diabolical efficiency to glean vital intelligence. In turn, he was protected from exposure.

headline: Now 11 Is the New 14, and the New 8
abstract: In Genevieve Bailey’s documentary “I Am Eleven,” 11-year-olds in 15 countries talk about home, school, war, love, marriage and visions of the future.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the simplest of ideas can prove surprisingly engaging, and not so simple after all. A case in point is “I Am Eleven,” a charming documentary by Genevieve Bailey built of interviews with 11-year-olds in 15 countries.

headline: Follow That Whale
abstract: “The Pirates,” directed by Lee Seok-hoon, is an action comedy that takes place on the high seas at the start of the Joseon dynasty.
lead_paragraph: Swords flash, whales splash, and flames erupt in Lee Seok-hoon’s new film, “The Pirates.” Besides joining some high-profile South Korean period pictures, this middling movie is also evidently an attempt to tap the appeal of the “Pirates of the Caribbean” franchise. But the slapdash adventures here lack compelling performers and bound merrily along without distinction.

headline: Government’s Threat of Daily Fine for Yahoo Shows Aggressive Push for Data
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Court documents shed light on Yahoo’s unsuccessful challenge of federal requests for warrantless surveillance of its foreign users.
lead_paragraph: The federal government was so determined to collect the Internet communications of foreign Yahoo customers in 2008 that it threatened the company with fines of $250,000 a day if it did not immediately comply with a secret court order to turn over the data.

headline: Louisiana’s Stillborn Constitution
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Reconstruction Era', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The state was occupied by the Union forces for years before it started reconstruction. So why did things go so badly?
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Eve 1863, Abraham Lincoln wrote to Maj. Gen. Nathaniel Banks in New Orleans to reassure him that he was master “in regard to re-organizing a State government for Louisiana” and “in regard to the military matters of the Department.” Frustrated at the slow pace of Banks’s reorganization efforts, the anxious president also entreated his commander of the Department of the Gulf to “give us a free-state re-organization of Louisiana, in the shortest possible time.”

headline: Marc Jacobs’s Spring 2015 Collection for New York Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Marc Jacobs at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Cities Compete to Be the Arena for Global Legal Disputes
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Municipalities around the world are working to attract bickering parties as part of an effort to become an international hub for arbitration proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The 48-mile Panama Canal expansion is an engineering marvel that promises to speed up international commerce and may be a boon for global ports. It is also one that involves lots of disputes over cost overruns and construction delays, and pushed completion beyond the canal’s 100th anniversary last month.

abstract: A doctor questions why the military continues to operate hospitals with low patient volume and inferior care.

headline: Sure Enough for the Two of Us
abstract: With him I wanted to be the fun girl. Then that all changed.
lead_paragraph: “I love love,” our boss said to Sam and me. “But you have to keep it out of the office, O.K.?”

headline: On the Sidelines, Subtle but Stylish
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The Fashion Week cameras were still trained on visitors swanning about in gilt, hoop skirts, bra tops and all manner of eye-popping finery. But often they missed the real novelty: many onlookers had sacrificed glitziness for comfort.
lead_paragraph: Parked on a ledge outside the Alexander Wang show at Pier 94, near Midtown’s western rim, Thia Lauraine was a picture of simplicity. Wearing a black silk tank dress that spilled to her ankles, Ms. Lauraine, an assistant to the street photographer Scott Schuman, said, “This is about as minimal as I can get.”

headline: New York Commemorates 9/11 Anniversary
abstract: The city paused to honor the dead and pay tribute to the first responders on the 13th anniversary of the attacks.
lead_paragraph: The city paused to honor the dead and pay tribute to the first responders on the 13th anniversary of the attacks.

headline: What We’re Afraid to Say About Ebola
abstract: We have to prepare for the chance that the virus becomes airborne.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — THE Ebola epidemic in West Africa has the potential to alter history as much as any plague has ever done.

headline: Slicked-Back Buns at Calvin Klein
abstract: Carefully composed twists offered a polished new interpretation of the classic greasy-hair-day updo.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Costa’s spring/summer 2015 collection for Calvin Klein was minimalism at its finest — which is to say, far more complex than it might have appeared from afar. The same can be said for the models’ hair. The slicked-back, carefully composed twists offered a polished new interpretation of the classic greasy-hair-day bun — a runway look that just about anyone can pull off at home.

headline: Aquifer Is No Quick Fix for Central Texas Thirst
abstract: Experts disagree how much water the Carrizo-Wilcox Aquifer holds and how long it would be able to sustain Central Texas’s growing population.
lead_paragraph: As drought continues to grip Central Texas, those looking to provide water to the region’s fast-growing cities and suburbs see a solution in a relatively untapped aquifer.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Sept. 14-20, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: U.T. Is Poised to Collaborate With Mexico on Research Projects
abstract: University of Texas System officials signed a letter of intent to work with the Mexican National Council of Science and Technology on a space-related project in Brownsville.
lead_paragraph: Randall Charbeneau, an assistant vice chancellor for research at the University of Texas System, was surprised to learn that the system did not have an agreement with Mexico to foster student and faculty exchanges and research collaboration.

headline: Video Nation
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'News and News Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We are roused to action by cruel realism, but only if it looks and sounds authentic. Reasoned calls to our better angels are no longer enough.
lead_paragraph: The barbarians in Iraq and Syria had been beheading innocents, raping girls and slaughtering “infidels” well before a single awful video appeared of an American journalist being executed by a masked fanatic. The world shrugged.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Housing Costs After Retirement
abstract: Paying off the mortgage isn’t the priority it once was, and for some, it isn’t possible. But a new report affirms that retirees who do so are considerably better off.
lead_paragraph: Paying off the mortgage isn’t the priority it once was, and for many households, it isn’t even a possibility. But a new report from Harvard University’s Joint Center for Housing Studies reaffirms the common belief that retirees who own their homes outright are considerably better off than those carrying mortgages or paying rent.

headline: Events on Long Island for Sept. 14-20, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Oh, Read the Blog
abstract: Answers to questions about family relationships, advice on etiquette, colleagues and handling a therapist.
lead_paragraph: Our son, who is in his 20s, posts online about major events in his life. But my husband and I don’t want to be part of his general audience on social media. We don’t read his blog or follow him on Twitter or Facebook. So, we are often the last to know about important events in his life because social media is his primary means of communicating with us. How should we let him know that we want to hear his news personally and directly from him?

headline: Georgia O’Keeffe Museum to Auction 3 Paintings
abstract: The Georgia O’Keeffe Museum plans to auction three of O’Keefe’s paintings to raise money for its acquisition fund.
lead_paragraph: “When you take a flower in your hand and really look at it, it’s your world for the moment,” Georgia O’Keeffe once said. “I want to give that world to someone else.”

headline: An Election in Search of a Mandate
abstract: With a governor’s campaign that is based more on personalities than on differences over particular policies, it might be hard for the winner to tell legislators that voters have delivered a set of marching orders.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz had a mandate.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: For a Week, Anyway, Rihanna Wears the Crown
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Like prom season, every New York Fashion Week has a reigning queen. This time around, Rihanna rules.
lead_paragraph: Like prom season, every New York Fashion Week has a reigning queen. This time around, Rihanna rules.

headline: In Iran, Mothers Dream of Missing Sons
abstract: In visions and doorways, Iranian mothers hold out hope their sons will one day return three decades after going missing in war.
lead_paragraph: In visions and doorways, Iranian mothers hold out hope their sons will one day return three decades after going missing in war.

headline: Obama’s Betrayal of the Constitution
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Constitution (US)', 'War Powers Act (1973)']
abstract: By forgoing Congress’s assent, he exceeds George W. Bush in imperial hubris.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — PRESIDENT OBAMA’s declaration of war against the terrorist group known as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria marks a decisive break in the American constitutional tradition. Nothing attempted by his predecessor, George W. Bush, remotely compares in imperial hubris.

headline: An Untapped Force in the Fight for Literacy
keywords: ['Education', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tutors and Tutoring', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: What if the Minnesota Reading Corps program, which uses AmeriCorps volunteers to tutor thousands of students, could be replicated in every state?
lead_paragraph: People disagree, quite strenuously, on the best curriculum for teaching children to read. But all participants in the reading wars agree on some other things: Early reading is crucial — a child who does not read proficiently by third grade will probably fall further and further behind each year. American schools are failing: two out of three fourth graders don’t read at grade level.

headline: ‘Shark Tank’ Companion to Be Unveiled by ABC
abstract: The Friday-night “Shark Tank” series has done so well on ABC that a related show, “Beyond the Tank,” will be added in the coming TV season.
lead_paragraph: “Shark Tank” has become a reliably popular show on one of television’s least popular nights, Fridays — so naturally, ABC wants even more of it.

headline: Spate of Suicides by Chinese Officials Tied to Drive Against Graft
abstract: Some researchers suspect the suicides may be linked to an anticorruption campaign begun last year by President Xi Jinping, the toughest in decades.
lead_paragraph: XIAOGAN, China — Li Haihua’s rise from poor farming boy to one of the most powerful officials in this city of one million people took decades, but his demise took seconds.

headline: How to Diversify Teaching
abstract: What can be done to make a career in education more attractive to men and people of color?

headline: With Gas Cut Off, Ukraine Looks West
abstract: Ukraine, which receives more than half of its supply from Russia, is looking to reduce its need amid a price dispute and military action with Russian separatists.
lead_paragraph: UZHGOROD, Ukraine — Keeping Ukraine warm keeps Andriy Kobolev up at night.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 8
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Scenes from Ralph Lauren and Dorin Negrau on the last day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Ralph Lauren and Dorin Negrau on the last day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Inflation Cult
abstract: We’re still trying to figure out the persistence and power of the people who keep predicting runaway inflation.
lead_paragraph: Wish I’d said that! Earlier this week, Jesse Eisinger of ProPublica, writing on The Times’s DealBook blog, compared people who keep predicting runaway inflation to “true believers whose faith in a predicted apocalypse persists even after it fails to materialize.” Indeed.

headline: A Velvety Mary Jane at Marc Jacobs
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a sandal with a crystal-encrusted heel.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: New York Fashion Week Social Media Roundup, Day 8
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The final day of New York Fashion Week brought celebrities and three major shows. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: Thursday was the last day of New York Fashion Week, but by far not the weakest. Ralph Lauren started the morning off with a safari-inspired collection that seemed more appropriate for a gala in New York than for the African plains and attracted a front row crowd that included Julianne Moore.

headline: Beleaguered Pakistani Capital Inches Back to Normal
abstract: Islamabad, which has been disrupted by vast traffic jams, barricaded streets and teeming political rallies, is slowly beginning to inch back to its usual routines.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — If there were just one image to evoke the chaos of the protests that have paralyzed this city and brought Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif’s government to the brink of collapse over the last month, it would surely be that of a shipping container.

headline: Sale in Utah Ends Fears of a Crimp in Tourism
abstract: Park City Mountain Resort was at the center of an eviction battle that ended with its sale to Vail Resorts, which operates an adjacent ski area.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A bitter fight in Utah over prime skiing terrain and millions of dollars ended Thursday, to the relief of town officials and business owners who feared that the feud could upend wintertime tourism in the mountain idyll of Park City.

headline: Imaan Hamman Transforms Backstage at Marc Jacobs
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in New York. Here, the model Imaan Hamman before (left) and after (right) makeup by Francois Nars and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Esquire Partners With 3 Agencies to Promote Male Mentorship
abstract: As part of a campaign to encourage men to mentor youths, the magazine has chosen three up-and-coming ad agencies: Makeable, 72andSunny and Barton F. Graf 9000.
lead_paragraph: ESQUIRE magazine is teaming up again with Madison Avenue for a new cause-marketing initiative, seeking to encourage more adult men to mentor boys and young men.

headline: Missouri Enacts 72-Hour Wait for Abortion
abstract: The Republican-controlled legislature enacted one of the most stringent waiting periods for women seeking abortions, overriding a veto by the state’s Democratic governor, Jay Nixon.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The Republican-controlled Missouri legislature has enacted one of the most stringent waiting periods for women seeking abortions, overriding a veto by the state’s Democratic governor, Jay Nixon.

headline: Marc Jacobs: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: New York
lead_paragraph: New York

headline: Noel W. Hinners, Voice for Scientific Research at NASA, Dies at 78
abstract: Dr. Hinners helped NASA launch some of its farthest-reaching scientific probes into space — to retrieve moon rocks, map the surface of Mars and peer beyond intergalactic dust to where stars are born.
lead_paragraph: Noel W. Hinners, a geologist and soil chemist who helped NASA launch some of its farthest-reaching scientific probes into space — to retrieve moon rocks, map the surface of Mars and peer beyond intergalactic dust to where stars are born — died on Friday in Littleton, Colo. He was 78.

headline: Richard Kiel Dies at 74; Played Jaws in Bond Films
abstract: Mr. Kiel, at more than seven feet tall, was a natural as a thug, giant, alien or other villain.
lead_paragraph: Richard Kiel, an actor whose intimidating frame and striking features made him a natural choice to play thugs, giants, alien creatures and villains of various stripes — notably Jaws, the assassin with metal dentition in two James Bond films — died on Wednesday in Fresno, Calif. He was 74.

headline: If Scotland Goes, Bankers Fear Britain Could Exit European Union
abstract: As Scotland prepares to vote on independence on Thursday, British bankers worry about an exit from the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tremors over a possible breakup of the United Kingdom have been felt here in recent days, as markets gyrate and banks make contingency plans.

headline: Obama’s Speech on Terror Draws 34 Million Viewers
abstract: Among the broadcast networks, NBC had about twice as many viewers as its primary news competitors.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s speech on the terror group ISIS attracted an audience of just over 34 million viewers Wednesday night, according to the Nielsen company.

headline: New Comic to Anchor ‘Update’ on ‘S.N.L.’
abstract: Michael Che, known for his role as a correspondent on Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show,” is joining “Saturday Night Live” and will co-anchor “Weekend Update.”
lead_paragraph: The new season of “Saturday Night Live” will have a significant change in its cast and its most prominent segment, “Weekend Update.”

headline: Bolstering a Vulnerable Russian Neighbor
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: Georgia takes another step in its long quest to join NATO. A visit by Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was symbolic as well.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel’s visit last weekend to Georgia was a reassuring gesture to a former Soviet republic that has assisted the United States in recent conflicts and is increasingly worried about Russia’s expansionist streak.

headline: Past, Present, Prologue at Calvin Klein, Hugo Boss and Proenza Schouler
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: New York Fashion Week ended on Sept. 11 with shows from Hugo Boss, Calvin Klein and Proenza Schouler, and some oblique acknowledgment of the day. Boss held its show at 4 World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: The fact that the final day of the New York collections also happened to be Sept. 11 is the sort of jarring coincidence that portends a collision of worlds: On that day, in this city, a tragedy occurred. Remembering it, how can we sit merrily by and look at skirts? It seems an impossible disconnect.

headline: Budget Cuts Reshape New York’s Public Housing
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Thousands of city renters who rely on public subsidies are being forced to pay more for housing or move into smaller spaces.
lead_paragraph: The crushing news came less than a year after Diane Robinson and her 24-year-old son moved into an airy two-bedroom apartment in the Bronx. The city, which helps pay her rent, wrote this summer to say she would have to downsize into a one-bedroom apartment or pay $240 more a month in rent.

headline: North Carolina Cuts Prison Time for Probation Violators, and Costs
keywords: ['Probation and Parole', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The measure is among several new policies that have helped the state reverse the increase in prisoners, and that officials hope will help curb crime and recidivism.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE RAPIDS, N.C. — André Duckett, 43, had an unpleasant surprise when he came in to see his probation officer. After missing some previous appointments, he had just failed a drug test, the officer told him, and he was going to spend the next three days in jail.

headline: Stressed Borrowers Rattle Resurgent Subprime Lending Industry
abstract: A rise in defaults indicates that borrowers with low credit scores may be stretched to the breaking point, which could affect consumer spending and the overall economy.
lead_paragraph: Subprime lenders have surprised everyone in recent years by churning out billions of dollars in loans that have not led to a pileup of bad debts.

headline: After a Two-Year Trek, NASA’s Mars Rover Reaches Its Mountain Lab
abstract: The Curiosity rover will begin its main science investigations on Mars at a three-mile-high mountain called Mount Sharp.
lead_paragraph: After two years of Mars enthusiasts asking, “Are we there yet?” the mission managers for NASA’s Curiosity rover can finally yell back, “Yes, we’re there!”

headline: War Sweeps an Israeli’s Davis Cup Swan Song to Florida
abstract: Andy Ram’s final goodbye after a decade and a half of playing Davis Cup doubles for Israel was moved from Tel Aviv to Sunrise, Fla., after the Israeli-Palestinian conflict erupted.
lead_paragraph: Win or lose, it was to be the grandest of goodbyes, and right in the veritable backyard. Tennis players are the most transient of athletes, but for his vocational finish Andy Ram had assembled a guest list of family and friends, swelling to nearly 500.

headline: On New York City Beaches, Endless Summer
abstract: For some, Labor Day marks the beginning of the choicest time on the city’s beaches, despite the city’s official policy of closing all the beaches to swimming after the holiday.
lead_paragraph: For most New Yorkers, Labor Day marks the end of the beach season, slamming the door shut on summer and shooing the crowds back to work and school.

headline: Pesticide Levels in Waterways Have Dropped, Reducing the Risks to Humans
abstract: Regulation has helped clean up agricultural and mixed-use waterways, but the ubiquity of some chemicals in household products has increased the threat to aquatic life in urban streams.
lead_paragraph: The development of safer pesticides and legal restrictions on their use have sharply reduced the risk to humans from pesticide-tainted rivers and streams, while the potential risk to aquatic life in urban waters has risen, according to a two-decade survey published on Thursday.

headline: Aid Worker Recovering From Ebola
abstract: Dr. Rick Sacra received two infusions of plasma from a missionary who had also been infected with Ebola.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rick Sacra, an American aid worker stricken with Ebola in Liberia, is making a remarkable recovery, his wife and doctors said Thursday.

headline: The Reluctant Leader
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: President Obama’s obvious reluctance about expanding the attack on ISIS may be his greatest asset.
lead_paragraph: Moses, famously, tried to get out of it. When God called on him to lead the Israelites, Moses threw up a flurry of reasons he was the wrong man for the job: I’m a nobody; I don’t speak well; I’m not brave.

headline: Father of 5 Slain Children Had Been Investigated
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Officials in South Carolina conducted two inquiries this year into the man suspected of killing his five children and abandoning their bodies in Alabama.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — The authorities in South Carolina conducted two inquiries this year into the behavior of a man suspected of killing his five children and abandoning their bodies in rural Alabama, but neither review led state officials to assume custody of the children.

headline: Upon Further Review
abstract: The N.F.L.’s response against Ray Rice shows that protecting another lucrative season is all it cares about.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League will have a hard time recovering from its cavalier mishandling of the domestic abuse case against Ray Rice, the gridiron star who punched his then-fiancée unconscious in February in an elevator in Atlantic City. At first, the league sought to minimize the incident by ordering a mere two-game suspension of the Baltimore Ravens running back, despite a security video excerpt showing him dragging the limp body of Janay Palmer, the woman who is now his wife, from the elevator. A police charge of felony assault followed soon after. As controversy grew, the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, apologized for his misjudgment and promised stronger punishments for players who attack their domestic partners.

headline: Legal Authority for Fighting ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'War Powers Act (1973)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: If Congress abdicates its responsibility in this military campaign, it will allow President Obama free rein to set a dangerous precedent.
lead_paragraph: As the Pentagon gears up to expand its fight against ISIS, a fundamentalist Sunni militant group that controls large areas of Iraq and Syria, Congress appears perfectly willing to abdicate one of its most consequential powers: the authority to declare war.

headline: Yura on Madison: A Magnet for School Parents
abstract: It is back-to-school season, and for many on the Upper East Side, that means it is time to go back to Yura on Madison, which has seven schools within walking distance of its location, at East 92nd Street.
lead_paragraph: It is back-to-school season, and for many on the Upper East Side, that means it is time to go back to Yura on Madison.

headline: Banks Did It Apple’s Way in Payments by Mobile
abstract: The eagerness of banks and card companies to work with Apple on its mobile payment system suggests Apple’s clout and the concern financial players have for their future.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s chief financial officer, Marianne Lake, took the stage at a financial conference on Tuesday under strict orders not to mention her company’s involvement in Apple’s new payment system.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 11, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbersfor New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: That Selfie Is So Good, It Could Help You Pay for College
abstract: Websites like GoFundMe and Crowdrise are part of a new generation of personal crowdfunding services helping needy students raise money for college.
lead_paragraph: WHEN 18-year-old Kiana Neisig added up her expenses for college, she found herself short of funds, even after receiving grants and student loans. So in June, a friend set up a profile for her on a crowdfunding website to help her seek donations of roughly $2,000.

headline: Ray Rice Is an Outlier: Most Domestic Abuse Suspects Play On
abstract: The emergence of a video this week in the Rice case raises questions about whether sports leagues should take more responsibility for domestic violence involving their athletes.
lead_paragraph: Brett Myers, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, was charged with assaulting his wife on a Boston street in 2006 after witnesses said he struck her in the face and pulled her hair. The Phillies put him on the mound as their starting pitcher about 36 hours later.

headline: Amid Tie Tacks, a Ring Worn by an Ancestor Who Was President
abstract: Theodore Roosevelt V was watching a film about his famous relatives when he saw the ring on his great-great-grandfather’s pinkie.
lead_paragraph: On the death of a family member, some things may be ridiculous to keep but impossible to throw away. In 2001, an 86-year-old man, retired from a brokerage house, died. His only grandson ended up with a worn leather case filled with the usual mess of things men of his grandfather’s generation tossed into jewelry boxes: cuff links, tie tacks, an Eisenhower campaign button and a few other pieces, including a big, worn ring.

headline: App Lists Exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum of Art
abstract: “What we think about is kind of the before, during and after experience,” said the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s chief digital officer, speaking of the museum’s new app.
lead_paragraph: Sree Sreenivasan, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s chief digital officer, provides helpful criteria for someone looking to evaluate the museum’s new app.

headline: With Eye on Scotland, Catalonia Hails Its Secession Bid
abstract: Artur Mas, the president of the regional government, is fighting opposition from Spain’s central government as the Nov. 9 vote approaches.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA — The world’s attention may be riveted on Scotland and its secessionist drive, but Thursday was Catalonia’s turn, as hundreds of thousands of flag-waving citizens rallied in the streets in what Catalan leaders hoped would be the prelude to the region’s own vote on independence from Spain.

headline: Philadelphia Nears Deal to Ease Marijuana Laws
abstract: A City Council plan to set modest fines for small amounts and no arrests won the support of Mayor Michael A. Nutter.
lead_paragraph: People in Philadelphia caught with small amounts of marijuana or smoking it in public may soon face no more than a written citation and a modest fine as the City Council moved Thursday to decriminalize the drug after a reversal by Mayor Michael A. Nutter.

headline: Witness for Arab Bank Says Disputed Payments Were Humanitarian
abstract: At a federal civil trial in Brooklyn, a former official of the institution, Shukry Bishara, said it forwarded money to families affected by the Palestinian uprising.
lead_paragraph: The witness talked about Arab Bank’s policies to guard against money laundering, and its efforts to identify transactions that might be linked to terrorists. He spoke of how Middle East terrorism hurt the bank’s business, and even how it affected his family.

headline: De Blasio’s Goal to Aid His Agenda: Put New York Senate in Democrats’ Hands
abstract: Two factors may improve Democrats’ chances: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s prodigious spending for Republicans will be out, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says he will be in.
lead_paragraph: In a windowless conference room in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday morning, Mayor Bill de Blasio laid out his next political battleground: the New York State Senate.

headline: Without Glamour of Dream Team, U.S. Is Again Dominating in Barcelona
abstract: The United States advanced to the final of basketball’s World Cup with a rout over Lithuania in Barcelona but little of the luster that Michael Jordan and company displayed there in 1992.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The modern-day version of USA Basketball began here 22 years ago, a group of superstar N.B.A. players (as well as Christian Laettner, who was leaving Duke) coming together to form the first Dream Team and bossing its way through the 1992 Olympics.

headline: U.S. Pins Hope on Syrian Rebels With Loyalties All Over the Map
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: President Obama’s determination to train moderate rebels in the battle against ISIS leaves the U.S. dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Obama’s determination to train Syrian rebels to serve as ground troops against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria leaves the United States dependent on a diverse group riven by infighting, with no shared leadership and with hard-line Islamists as its most effective fighters.

headline: Try as He May, John McCain Can’t Shake Falsehoods About Ties to ISIS
keywords: ['Social Media', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Arizona Republican has been hounded after a picture of him with members of the Free Syrian Army was misinterpreted and doctored purposely to make it appear that he supported ISIS, which he does not.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain was one of the earliest advocates of American military action against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. So it has been vexing for Mr. McCain to be battling persistent — and false — Internet rumors that he not only helped invent the group but also knows its leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-proclaimed caliph of the Muslim world and America’s latest Public Enemy No. 1.

headline: Interview: Jeremy Jordan & Anna Kendrick
abstract: The stars of the musical “The Last Five Years” discuss their film.
lead_paragraph: The stars of the musical “The Last Five Years” discuss their film.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Sept. 12, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Drop,” “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby” and “The Skeleton Twins.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Drop,” “The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby” and “The Skeleton Twins.”

headline: Desperate Fledglings, Flung From the Nest
abstract: Michael Cera, Kieran Culkin and Tavi Gevinson bring to full-blooded life the angst of bright and sullen young things in a Broadway revival of Kenneth Lonergan’s “This Is Our Youth.”
lead_paragraph: Just watch these bodies in motion: loping, flying, dancing, vamping and writhing at an altitude known only to the permanently high and perpetually crashing.

headline: Queen’s Music
abstract: Michael Wiesenberg’s Friday puzzle offers a lot of fresh fare.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Even though this is only Michael Wiesenberg’s second puzzle in The New York Times (in case you missed it, you can solve his debut puzzle here), he’s an old hand at constructing, which he will tell you more about in his notes below. You can tell that he’s done this before, because today’s puzzle is chock-full of interesting and unique entries, and very little junk, DEAR READER.

headline: Notre Dame and Under Armour Seek Win-Win With Apparel Deal
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Uniforms', 'Football (College)', 'College Athletics', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: In its game against Purdue, Notre Dame will wear specially designed uniforms from Under Armour, with whom it signed what is billed as the most valuable outfitting deal in college sports history.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Adam Clement, Under Armour’s creative director for team sports, traveled to Notre Dame’s Gothic-inspired campus last November after his upstart sports clothing company heard that one of the most valuable college programs might soon be in need of new sponsorship.

headline: Former Microsoft Executive and Obama Adviser Joins Venture Firm
abstract: Kurt DelBene worked at one of the technology industry’s largest companies and helped clean up one of the government’s biggest technology messes. Now he’s focusing on smaller organizations, joining a venture capital firm, Madrona Venture Group, to help start-ups.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Kurt DelBene worked at one of the technology industry’s largest companies and helped clean up one of the government’s biggest technology messes. Now he’s focusing on smaller organizations, joining a venture capital firm to help start-ups.

headline: Arabs Give Tepid Support to U.S. Fight Against ISIS
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Three years after the United States left Iraq, its return to the region is getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with allies finding ways to avoid specific commitments to an expanded effort against Sunni extremists.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Many Arab governments grumbled quietly in 2011 as the United States left Iraq, fearful it might fall deeper into chaos or Iranian influence. Now, the United States is back and getting a less than enthusiastic welcome, with leading allies like Egypt, Jordan and Turkey all finding ways on Thursday to avoid specific commitments to President Obama’s expanded military campaign against Sunni extremists.

headline: Former Assemblyman Turned Informer Avoids Prison
abstract: Nelson L. Castro, a former assemblyman from the Bronx who helped in the prosecution of a half-dozen people, was sentenced to probation and community service.
lead_paragraph: Nelson L. Castro, a former Democratic state assemblyman from the Bronx who secretly recorded conversations as a government informant, avoided prison on Thursday, largely because of his cooperation that a judge characterized as by all accounts “extraordinarily valuable, and indeed historic.”

headline: Bunny Mellon’s Keen Eye Is a Boon to Sotheby’s
abstract: Sotheby’s is planning to auction a trove that once belonged to Rachel Lambert Mellon, the matriarch of a family whose holdings rivaled some of America’s most well-known dynasties.
lead_paragraph: UPPERVILLE, Va. — Few people have ever visited Oak Spring Farms, the grand home here of Rachel Lambert Mellon, better known as Bunny. If they had, they would have seen a Pissarro, unframed like a flea market find, above the living room fireplace. Upstairs, a still life by van Gogh hung above her bathtub. Antique porcelains — cabbages, asparagus, artichokes — were artfully arranged on practically every surface.

headline: Runners Take the Place of Models During Fashion Week
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Running', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Oiselle, a women’s sports apparel brand, took the unusual approach of launching its spring 2015 line using professional runners on the runway.
lead_paragraph: The models at the Oiselle fashion show in New York this week were the first to admit it: They were more at home on a running track than on a runway.

headline: Waiting on the Wind
abstract: Situated along South Oyster Bay in Amityville on Long Island, the NY Kite Center has functioned as a kiteboarding school, gear shop and repair center since 2008.
lead_paragraph: On a late August afternoon, an adventurous group gathered on the second floor of a wind-battered former seaplane factory, eager to fly. They wiggled into their wet suits, tethered themselves to harnesses and inspected their winglike kites. There was only one thing left to do: wait for the wind.

headline: Data for a New York ‘Smellmap,’ Collected Sniff by Sniff
abstract: The artist and designer Kate McLean led an investigative tour of sidewalk odors in Brooklyn, documenting the city’s aromas.
lead_paragraph: If smell can define a place, New York in the summertime is not exactly a meadow of flowers. In the war between a sensitive nose and the city streets, the streets have the upper hand, assailing the nose with the odors of urine, decomposing garbage and clammy armpits. Mouth breathing is not only acceptable, but often necessary.

headline: Ex-F.B.I. Leader’s Ray Rice Inquiry Poses Risk
keywords: ['Football', 'Domestic Violence', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: An investigator tasked with sorting out the N.F.L.’s handling of the Rice case will want to be as thorough as possible and not appear in any way craven to his employer.
lead_paragraph: CBS altered its planned opening for the first night of its coverage of “Thursday Night Football” to cover the Ray Rice story.

headline: Doctor Present at Joan Rivers’s Procedure Wasn’t Authorized at Clinic
abstract: An ear, nose and throat specialist was said to have been in the operating room last month when the comedian went into cardiac arrest.
lead_paragraph: An ear, nose and throat specialist was present in the clinic operating room where Joan Rivers underwent a procedure last month — and where she went into cardiac arrest — even though the doctor was not authorized to practice medicine in the clinic, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Nationals Help Turn Mets’ Thoughts to Next Year
abstract: Washington scored all six of its runs off starter Bartolo Colon to take a big early lead and prevented the Mets from capitalizing on base-loaded situations in the seventh and eighth innings.
lead_paragraph: Across from the Mets’ dugout, high above Citi Field, hangs the out-of-town scoreboard, an array of boxes, tiny baseball diamonds, and lights. Between innings, Manager Terry Collins often glances up at it. He likes to keep track of the Mets’ next opponent, in particular, to see who is pitching and if the team’s bullpen is spent.

headline: Retired Gen. John R. Allen in Line to Lead Effort vs. ISIS
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Allen, who was the top American commander in Afghanistan, will coordinate the international coalition to fight the militant Islamist group, an official said.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — John R. Allen, the retired Marine general who served as the top American commander in Afghanistan, has been picked by the Obama administration to coordinate the international effort against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a senior administration official said Thursday.

headline: $290 Million Lost in Penny Stock Fraud, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The authors of rosy newsletters conspired with the owners of penny stocks to hype nearly worthless companies, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Investors would hear about the companies through newsletters emailed from websites that tout penny stocks, with names like PennyPic.com, OxofWallStreet.com and MonsterStox.com, their missives full of hyperbolic language and exclamation points.

headline: Yankees’ Hits Are Few, but Ex-Met Has a Big One
abstract: A three-run homer by Chris Young in the ninth helped the Yankees secure a win over the Rays in a game in which they were held hitless for seven and a third innings.
lead_paragraph: If the Yankees somehow reach the postseason, they may look back on Thursday night as the turning point in their difficult quest.

headline: FedEx Cup Leaders Share First Place in Tour Championship
abstract: The playing partners Chris Kirk and Billy Horschel, one-two in the FedEx Cup standings, shot 66s to lead the Tour Championship by a shot.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Tiger and Phil are absent. One-third of the field are first-timers at the Tour Championship. Conditions seemed ripe for some capricious results in the closeout event of the PGA Tour season.

headline: Takata Air Bag Defect: Relevant Documents
abstract: Regulatory documents from a 2009 federal investigation into Takata air bag ruptures.
lead_paragraph: Regulatory documents from a 2009 federal investigation into Takata air bag ruptures.

headline: Under Pressure From Fans, Giants Count on Eli Manning to Find His Feet
abstract: The new offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo, said Eli Manning and the rest of the team had made strides in the West Coast offense ahead of Sunday’s game against the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With Eli Manning struggling so far to acclimate to the Giants’ West Coast offense, the new offensive coordinator, Ben McAdoo, was asked Thursday if perhaps Manning’s skills were not suited to the new style of play.

headline: Air Bag Flaw, Long Known to Honda and Takata, Led to Recalls
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Honda and the air bag maker Takata did not disclose the dangers of exploding air bags for years, despite red flags, opting to settle confidential claims but not issue recalls.
lead_paragraph: An air bag exploded in a Honda Accord in 2004 in Alabama, shooting out metal fragments and injuring the car’s driver. At a loss to explain the incident, Honda and its Japanese air bag supplier deemed it “an anomaly” and did not issue a recall or seek the involvement of federal safety regulators.

headline: T.J. Lane, Killer in School Shooting, Is Caught After Prison Escape in Ohio
abstract: A 19-year-old Ohio man serving life in prison for killing three students in a high school cafeteria in 2012 briefly escaped from prison on Thursday, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Ohio man serving life in prison for killing three students in a high school cafeteria in 2012 briefly escaped from prison on Thursday, the authorities said.

headline: Jack O’Connell: Lust for Life
abstract: The actor is raw, uncensored and trying to keep it together long enough to live up to Hollywood’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: The actor is raw, uncensored and trying to keep it together long enough to live up to Hollywood’s expectations.

headline: The Personal Arcadia of John Richardson
abstract: Like the art historian himself, his Connecticut estate is grand, refined and a bit naughty.
lead_paragraph: Like the art historian himself, his Connecticut estate is grand, refined and a bit naughty.

headline: Art Basel Lends a Hand to Arts Crowdfunding Efforts
abstract: The Art Basel Crowdfunding Initiative will identify worthy arts-related fundraising projects selected by an independent jury.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s most prominent art fairs is hoping to garner support for nonprofit art organizations by lending them some street cred.

headline: Word of the Day | vivacious
abstract: This word has appeared in 79 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: vivacious •\və-ˈva-shəs also vi-\• adjective

headline: Notre Dame’s New Look
abstract: In its deal with Under Armour, a tradition-rich university is updating its team uniforms while keeping its treasured symbols.
lead_paragraph: In its deal with Under Armour, a tradition-rich university is updating its team uniforms while keeping its treasured symbols.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) JAMES McNEILL WHISTLER AND THE CASE FOR BEAUTY Kevin Kline lends his voice to Whistler (1834-1903), above, and Anjelica Huston narrates this documentary on the life of the American-born, London-based visionary and dandy who helped steer painting toward abstraction and what eventually became known as Modern art. Nearly 200 etchings, paintings and photographs provide an overview of Whistler’s art while shedding light on the reasons for his controversial reputation. Animations and re-enactments explore the creations of several of his most famous paintings — among them, “Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1,” popularly known as “Whistler’s Mother,” as well as “The White Girl,” “The Balcony” and “The Peacock Room.” The film, directed by Karen Thomas, coincides with Whistler exhibitions at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington and at museums in Japan. In “Royal Paintbox,” at 10, Charles, Prince of Wales, presents drawings, watercolors and oil paintings created by generations of Britain’s royal family — including some of his own — set against the estates of Balmoral Castle, Birkhall, Highgrove House, Windsor Castle, Frogmore House and Osborne House.

headline: What Might Happen If Iran Becomes America’s Covert Ally?
abstract: After President Obama’s speech announcing strikes against militant group ISIS, many have raised the possibility of cooperation with Iran. Can Iran become the United States’ unlikely ally?
lead_paragraph: In his speech to the nation Wednesday night, President Obama authorized strikes against ISIS, the militant group ravaging Syria and Iraq. The United States and its allies, the President said, will aim to “degrade and ultimately destroy” the group.

headline: A Conversation With Peter Thiel
abstract: The PayPal co-founder turned venture capitalist has a new book coming it. And with it, one of Silicon Valley’s most outspoken leaders explains why he so often tries to get people to see the world through a different lens.
lead_paragraph: Even for a self-made billionaire, Peter Thiel has strong opinions.

headline: A Trial Concludes, but for South Africans, the Debate May Be Just Starting
abstract: Oscar Pistorius was found guilty of a charge equivalent to manslaughter in the shooting of Reeva Steenkamp, but he was granted bail and will remain free until sentencing procedures on Oct. 13.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The murder trial of the Paralympic star Oscar Pistorius lurched to a close on Friday when he was convicted of culpable homicide in the shooting death last year of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp. But in a case that reflected South Africa’s complicated obsession with race, crime and celebrity, many South Africans found understanding the verdict to be as difficult as trying to fathom exactly what was in Mr. Pistorius’s mind the night he pulled the trigger.

headline: China Expands Investment in Tanzania
abstract: China is providing $412.5 million to build a logistics hub in the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam.
lead_paragraph: Next to the busy port of Dar es Salaam, the business capital of Tanzania, work is starting on a Chinese-financed, 150-acre logistics hub that will contribute to the already booming trade between China and Africa.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The trial of one of southern China’s most prominent dissidents was cut short Friday after he and another defendant said they would remain silent and their lawyers boycotted the proceedings. The lawyers said the trial was postponed and would resume at a later date.

lead_paragraph: The congressman talks to Jim Rutenberg about summer jobs, the government shutdown and his next chapter.

headline: Is Breakfast Really the Most Important Meal of the Day?
abstract: What do you eat for breakfast? How about the rest of your family?
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you sit down to a balanced meal of eggs, bacon and sliced fruit before school. Or a bowl of cereal with a banana. A Greek yogurt. A frozen waffle. A doughnut. Breakfast-to-go from a local fast-food joint. Or maybe you just skip it all together. How do you eat breakfast?

headline: In Iran, Mothers Dream of Missing Sons
abstract: In visions and doorways, Iranian mothers hold out hope their sons will one day return three decades after going missing in the war with Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Fatemeh Behboudi grew up surrounded by grief. She was born in Tehran during the 1980-88 war between Iran and Iraq. As the bodies of missing soldiers were discovered years after the war, her family attended mass funerals in their honor. Later, she covered these rites as a photographer.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 12
abstract: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images outside Joan Rivers’s memorial service and scenes from the primary election.
lead_paragraph: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images outside Joan Rivers’s memorial service and scenes from the primary election.

headline: The Lady Reappears
abstract: The French journalist Anne Sinclair, the ex-wife of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, resumes a public life with her memoir of her family’s place in art history.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A small portrait of Anne Sinclair as a blue-eyed little girl hangs in her impressive townhouse on the Place des Vosges here. Nearby, there’s a late Picasso watercolor of a figure in a wide-brimmed black hat. A replica of a Picasso still life — the original is in a vault — has pride of place above the living-room fireplace.

headline: Australia Raises Terrorism Alert Level to High
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Friday that there was “a body of evidence that points to the increased likelihood of a terrorist attack in Australia.”
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Prime Minister Tony Abbott raised Australia’s terrorism alert level from medium to high on Friday, after warnings from security officials that a growing number of Australians joining extremist groups, including the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, represents an increased threat to the country.

headline: NATO’s Hopes for Russia Have Turned to Dismay
abstract: In a declaration at a summit 24 years ago, NATO expressed elation at the thought of a democratic future for Eastern Europe, but those hopes seem so much dust today.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The NATO summit meeting last week in Wales was dominated by Russia’s military intervention in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Barclays said on Friday that John McFarlane, the chairman of the British insurer Aviva, would succeed David Walker, its chairman, who is set to retire next year.

abstract: Google has a new program in which it will offer start-ups $100,000 in credits on its Google Cloud Platform. The effort is the company’s latest attempt to take on Amazon Web Services, the leader in cloud services.
lead_paragraph: Google would like to make more money selling data storage on other services on its Google Cloud Platform, and it’s going after it the old-fashioned Internet way: Give stuff away and make it up on volume.

abstract: The measures take aim at financial, defense and industrial companies at the vanguard of a push by the Russian leader to replace wild free-market capitalism with state-led development.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and the European Union dealt a blow on Friday to Russian efforts to develop future oil sources in the Arctic and elsewhere, broadening and deepening the range of sanctions imposed on Moscow in retaliation for its intervention in Ukraine despite the potential cost to Western firms like Exxon Mobil and BP.

headline: NYTLNreads | Recommendations From a Humanities Class at High Technology High School
abstract: As our first post in the experimental feature NYTLNreads, we asked Sarah Gross, a teacher and Learning Network contributor, to tell us what articles her new ninth-grade class found most interesting in The Times this week.
lead_paragraph: This week we announced an experiment we’re calling NYTLNreads. We hope it will be a quick, informal way for your students to explore The Times and share the stories that interested them most.

headline: Ebola Outpaces Global Response, W.H.O. Says
abstract: A doubling of the number of new cases in Liberia this week from the week before is of particular concern, the U.N. health agency said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A month after declaring the Ebola outbreak in West Africa a global health emergency, the World Health Organization warned on Friday that the disease is still outpacing the international response to contain it.

headline: Thieves Follow the Money to Corrupt Officials’ Homes
abstract: Corrupt officials make ideal targets: They are known to keep large supplies of cash in their residences and are reluctant to report thefts for fear of a graft investigation.
lead_paragraph: The mid-20th century American outlaw Willie Sutton is often cited as saying that he robbed banks “because that’s where the money is.” Some thieves in China have gone after corrupt cadres for the same reason.

headline: The Fadeout of the Mileage Run
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Customer Loyalty Programs']
abstract: New rules for frequent flier programs emphasize how much you spend, not how far you go.
lead_paragraph: In February, a friend told me he couldn’t meet for dinner in Washington because he was flying to Amsterdam for the weekend. Emphasis on the word “flying.” His itinerary had him spending most of the weekend traveling, but he’d stay in Amsterdam for only 14 hours, after connecting through Paris and Istanbul to get there; his return trip involved a layover in Minneapolis.

headline: Daily Report: Government Threatened Steep Fines in Push for Yahoo Data
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Court documents shed light on Yahoo’s unsuccessful challenge of federal requests for warrantless surveillance of its foreign users.
lead_paragraph: The federal government was so determined to collect the Internet communications of foreign Yahoo customers in 2008 that it threatened the company with fines of $250,000 a day if it did not immediately comply with a secret court order to turn over the data, Vindu Goel and Charlie Savage report.

headline: 1939: Radio Station Charged
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: American broadcasters debated ways to present news of the war in Europe in 1939.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Charging that New York radio station WMCA has been intercepting secret government military messages from London and Berlin and rebroadcasting them as news, the Federal Communications Commission demanded today [Sept. 12] that the station show cause why its license should not be suspended. The investigation is the first case in which the commission has used its authority to deal with an offender under the terms of the neutrality act. Meanwhile, after an all-day session, representatives of the three major American broadcasting chains announced that they had agreed to present war news broadcasts so as to avoid “undue horror and suspense and will try to be temperate, responsible and mature in selecting material and the manner in which the facts are made public.” As far as possible, the chains said they would attempt to have the European broadcast conducted by Americans to insure the greatest degree of impartiality. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 13, 1939

headline: Morning Agenda: Banks Bow to Apple Pay
abstract: Banks eager to work with Apple on new mobile payment system. | Signs rattle subprime lending industry. | Bankers fear Britain’s exit from E.U. | Hertz and Icahn make peace.
lead_paragraph: BANKS BOW TO APPLE PAY | As Apple looks to assume a more central role in the financial universe with its new payment system, Apple Pay, the eagerness of banks and credit card companies to work with the technology giant underscores both its influence and the recognition among financial institutions that they face bigger challenges from upstart technology ventures, DealBook’s Nathaniel Popper writes. Apple Pay could threaten some revenue streams, but the banking industry appears willing to invest in programs like Apple’s that still respect the traditional financial system.

headline: Making Top Colleges Less Aristocratic and More Meritocratic
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Pell Grants', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Endowments', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: It’s not just the wealthiest colleges that can afford to be economically diverse. And government policies could also make a difference.
lead_paragraph: Education is supposed to be America’s primary engine for social mobility, but growing economic inequality is vividly reflected in our nation’s top colleges. At the nation’s most selective 193 colleges and universities, affluent students (those from the richest socioeconomic quarter of the population) outnumber economically disadvantaged students (those from the bottom quarter) by 14 to 1.

headline: Student Loan Debt Burdens More Than Just Young People
abstract: About two million Americans age 60 and older are in debt from unpaid student loans, according to data from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
lead_paragraph: JANET LEE DUPREE, 72, was surprised when she received her first Social Security benefits seven years ago. About one-fifth of her monthly payment was being withheld and she called the federal government to find out why.

lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group’s initial public offering was long expected to be a blockbuster. But a flood of orders for shares in the Chinese e-commerce giant has proved stronger than expected.

headline: Foreign Journalists in China See Decline in Reporting Conditions
abstract: Conditions for foreign journalists working in China have gone from bad to worse over the past year, according to a report issued on Friday by the Foreign Correspondents’ Club of China.
lead_paragraph: Conditions for foreign journalists working in China have gone from bad to worse over the past year, with the Chinese authorities increasingly seeking to influence coverage by intimidating reporters and their interview subjects, barring journalists from large portions of the country or by withholding visas and blocking the websites of overseas news outlets, according to a report issued on Friday by the Foreign Correspondents’ Club of China.

headline: Ian Paisley Dies at 88; Longtime Voice of Hard-Line Ulster Who Then Made Peace
abstract: The Protestant leader who vowed never to compromise with Irish Catholic nationalists accepted in his twilight a power-sharing agreement after decades of sectarian violence.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Ian Paisley, Northern Ireland’s firebrand Protestant leader, who vowed never to compromise with Irish Catholic nationalists, then, in his twilight, accepted a power-sharing agreement that envisioned a new era of peace in Northern Ireland after decades of sectarian violence, died on Friday in Belfast. He was 88.

lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide
