lead_paragraph: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa declared that Oscar Pistorius, the Olympic runner, is guilty of culpable homicide, equivalent to manslaughter, after being acquitted of murder.

headline: The Man Who Put the K in Kops
keywords: ['Movies', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: “The Mack Sennett Collection Volume One,” a Blu-ray set from Flicker Alley, assembles 50 shorts written, directed or produced by a master of silent comedy.
lead_paragraph: Mack Sennett (1880-1960) is famous for discovering Charlie Chaplin, creating the Keystone Kops, coining the term “bathing beauty” and being, as his front-page obituary in The New York Times called him, “the film pioneer whose name was synonymous with slapstick comedy.” All true, but as demonstrated by the 50 mainly short films digitally restored and gathered in a three-disc Blu-ray set, “The Mack Sennett Collection Volume One” (Flicker Alley), he was something more.

headline: When One Word Might Be the Wrong Word
abstract: On “responsible” policy, unions’ “stranglehold” and military “advisers.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, as I read The Times, a word will stop me cold. That happened yesterday morning as I read the photo caption on a timely Room for Debate about the videotaped assault by Ray Rice on his wife, Janay Palmer, that has been so much in the news. The word: “altercation.”

headline: Bright Green Pesto That Won’t Fade
abstract: How to make pesto that doesn’t fade from bright green to olive and four new ways to use it.
lead_paragraph: This is not the first time that I’ve devoted a week of recipes to pesto genovese – basil pesto. But it is the first time that I can vouch for a basil pesto that retains a gorgeous green color. I’ve been forever flummoxed by the color problem with pesto, the way it goes from bright green to olive drab so quickly. I’ve tried this and that – been told about citric acid, covering the pesto with olive oil, or even lemon juice (which makes little sense to me because acid usually turns bright green olive). Anyway, I read up on the problem this week and decided to try blanching the leaves.

headline: Writing as a Soldier and a Civilian
abstract: A soldier takes time out of uniform to pursue an MFA in writing, and discovers that what sets him apart, as a veteran at the keyboard, is not as important as the common ground he shares with other writers.
lead_paragraph: It is 12 a.m. in the land of the midnight sun. Seventy-two hours until deployment. I should be at home with my wife, Jen, and 6-month-old son or unpacking the house we bought recently. Instead, I’m on my bike riding home from the University of Alaska, Anchorage. A rowdy group rides down another trail that merges with mine, cycling in a pack in front of me. They laugh, pull beers from messenger bags, see me and offer me one. The exchange is tour-worthy. An anonymous rider pulls out a cold Olympia and reaches toward me. His eyes remain on the trail ahead, as do mine. I extend a blind left hand, close the gap, find the front of the can. For a moment we are connected by cheap beer. Then he lets go and it is all mine. I toast the rowdies and ride ahead.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan on ‘The Last Five Years’
abstract: The stars of the musical “The Last Five Years” discuss their roles in the film.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A couple sings its way through the exciting beginning and the difficult unraveling of a relationship in “The Last Five Years,” Richard LaGravenese’s film adaptation of Jason Robert Brown’s Off-Broadway musical. In this video, Anna Kendrick and Jeremy Jordan their roles, and their songs, in the film.

headline: Maastricht in a Kilt
abstract: Will Scotland make the euro mistake?
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis says more clearly what I’ve been trying to get at with regard to the economics of Scottish independence. It would be one thing to make the sober case that independence is worth it despite the economic costs and risks; but the SNP has been claiming that there are no costs and risks, which is just wrong.

headline: Why Everyone Should Be Waiting for Grimes’s Next Album
abstract: The 26-year-old musician made a record. Then she threw it out and started over.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Claire Boucher, the 26-year-old Canadian musician known as Grimes, briefly dabbled in the world of Billboard-chart pop. She wrote a song for Rihanna. After that, she went to a group songwriting boot camp, as she entertained the idea of receding from the intensifying spotlight she’d earned as an electro-pop phenom. “I thought, Oh, I don’t want to be a front person,” she says. “I want to write.”

headline: Viola Davis as You’ve Never Seen Her Before: Leading Lady!
abstract: After three decades of making kindly supporting characters memorable, she finally gets her star turn.
lead_paragraph: “Even when I get the fried-chicken special of the day, I have to dig into it like it’s filet mignon,” Viola Davis said. She was speaking not of meals, but of roles. During her 30-year career as an actress, Davis has played a crack-addicted mother (“Antwone Fisher”), the mother of an abducted child (“Prisoners”) and the mother of James Brown (“Get On Up”). Her characters often serve to “hold up the wall” of the narrative, she said, like the empathetic best friend in “Eat, Pray, Love” or the kindly stranger in “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.” Or the kindly mental-institution psychiatrist in “It’s Kind of a Funny Story,” the kindly rape-treatment counselor in “Trust” or the kindly medium in “Beautiful Creatures.”

headline: Hood by Air’s Collective Fashions
abstract: Shayne Oliver’s flights of fancy.
lead_paragraph: Shayne Oliver began the clothing line Hood by Air in late 2006 with almost no formal training. He and his collaborators — assembled largely from the downtown night life circuit — communicated their visions to fabricators via visual aid. “We’d go around with huge bags of clothes that had details we liked: ‘This stitch needs to look like this stitch,’ ” Oliver says, “because we didn’t know the technical terms.” Some ideas were hard to convey: “At one point, we wanted to make men look like schoolgirls, and we were explaining a piece to a seamstress. ‘It’s a schoolgirl basketball short.’ She was like, ‘That makes no sense.’ So we got a schoolgirl skirt and made a new pattern out of it, to show her it was feasible.”

headline: Paying for a Need for Speed
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Does asking a driver to “hurry” implicate the passenger in a speeding ticket?
lead_paragraph: A friend and I spent the weekend camping. On Monday morning, we were late getting on the road. I was going to be late for a summer course and asked my friend to hurry. At some point, I noticed that we were traveling at 130 m.p.h. I did not say anything because I wanted to make it back to class. Shortly after, we were stopped for speeding. My friend thinks I should help pay for the $500 ticket. I did not tell him to drive 130 m.p.h. Do I have an obligation to help with this ticket? NAME WITHHELD, HOUSTON

headline: Quvenzhané Wallis’s Secrets: Work Hard, Play Hard, Think About Polar Bears
abstract: The child actor on learning to have fun on set and weeping (and burping) on demand.
lead_paragraph: Quvenzhané Wallis’s career started with a little fib: that she was 6 years old. It was the minimum age to audition for the lead role in “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” and she was just shy. It worked. She landed the part and shot the movie in a soup-swampy Louisiana bayou town called Montegut, a short drive from her family’s home. A lesser child actor might have evaporated into the film’s momentous plot, but Wallis — with her watchful gaze, physical grace and talent for banshee-level shrieking — suffered no such fate, becoming the youngest person ever nominated for an Academy Award for best actress. Now 11 and in the sixth grade, she has built up a tiny but luminous list of credits that includes “12 Years a Slave” and a remake of “Annie” due out this December, in which she plays the title character.

headline: Who Made That Windshield Wiper?
abstract: Squeegees, suction and patent wars.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1902, an Alabama woman named Mary Anderson visited New York and was appalled by how the weather slowed down streetcars. Snow and sleet obscured the trolleys’ two-paneled windshields, forcing drivers to open both panes and peer through the gap between them. In her notebook, Anderson sketched out a solution: a squeegee wiper on the outside of the windshield, connected to a lever on the inside.

headline: How Trajal Harrell Mixes His Moves
abstract: The creative process of a fearless choreographer.
lead_paragraph: When the dancer and choreographer Trajal Harrell is working on new ideas, he likes to arrange his performers across “islands” — foot-and-a-half-high platforms padded with foam rubber. “I spread the islands out in different configurations, and the dancers improvise on them,” Harrell says. “All of a sudden the body is on a small white space. I can see very clearly what each dancer is doing. It’s a way to sketch. It’s an information generator.” Last month, Harrell, who divides his year between the United States and Europe, drifted amid islands in a Berlin rehearsal space. He gave the dancers directions that ranged from the blunt — “stop doing that” — to the fanciful — “move with the smell of fashion.” This session was practice for “Practice,” a not-quite-performance that Harrell was preparing to give in New York at the Museum of Modern Art, in which he would invite spectators to spy on his creative methods. “It’s a nightmare in many ways,” he says, “because I’m very private about my process.”

headline: The Family That Strays Together
abstract: What my relatives and I found when we got lost.
lead_paragraph: It was 75 degrees out and sunny. My sister-in-law decided that the afternoon was perfect for a hike, so my mother consulted her woefully outdated Appalachian Mountain Club guide, which she treats with a reverence that others reserve for the Bible; to her, revelations are contained in its pages.

headline: Living Art
abstract: Performers at Pageant of the Masters, an annual festival in Laguna Beach, re-enact Vermeer’s “The Allegory of Painting” and “The Concert.”
lead_paragraph: Performers at Pageant of the Masters, an annual festival in Laguna Beach, re-enact Vermeer’s “The Allegory of Painting” and “The Concert.”

headline: The Surreal Fine-Art Spectacle in Laguna Beach
abstract: Pageant of the Masters instills new life — literally — into classic art.
lead_paragraph: Paparazzi, if they had existed in 1880s France, would have followed Amélie Gautreau in a permanent cloud. Crowds gathered when she appeared in the streets of Paris. Newspapers reported her outfit changes. Royalty asked to meet her. Traditional beauty is rarely so exciting, but hers was unorthodox: She had a long neck, a big nose and skin so uncannily white that people argued over whether it was real or fake. Theories included that she covered her entire body with makeup or strategically dosed herself with arsenic. In an era of puffy, body-swallowing gowns, she wore snug dresses that showed off her curves; she put red makeup on the tips of her ears, just for extra drama. She was rumored to be sleeping with half the men in Paris. Every painter wanted to paint her, to be the great hero who fixed her image for a culture desperate to stare at it. But art — the translation of three-dimensional life into a flat, static illusion — was an act of magic with serious consequences. In a time before mass-produced cameras, an image was a heavy thing, laborious to make and hard to distribute. Instagram was Duragram. Amélie always refused.

headline: A Life-Saving Salt Binge
abstract: Decoding a young man’s exhaustion and mysterious craving for sodium.
lead_paragraph: Decoding a young man’s exhaustion and mysterious craving for sodium.

headline: Referendum in Scotland, Dissected by Investor
abstract: The foundation of Sir Tom Hunter, who built a fortune in athletic footwear, published a book dedicated to the independence referendum in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Growing up with the name James Stewart, I never thought of Scotland as anything but independent.

headline: David Lynch on His First Retrospective of Original Artwork
abstract: The director and artist talks T through some of his works on view this weekend in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Although he’s best-known for his middle-America-meets-the-macabre movies, David Lynch started out as a painter and has not put down his brushes in 40-something years. Not surprisingly, the director known for his darkly visceral vision creates canvases that are anything but pretty pictures.

headline: China Court Sentences 3 to Death Over Attack at Railroad Station
abstract: The defendants were found guilty of leading a terrorist group that killed 31 people at the railroad station in Kunming in March.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A court in southwest China on Friday sentenced three people to death and another to life in prison after finding them guilty of killing 31 people in a slashing rampage at a railroad station in early March, the official news media reported.

headline: Hispanic-Americans Work to Bolster Philanthropy at Home
abstract: Historically, wealthy Latin Americans have had little interest in philanthropic giving aimed at solving social problems, but that is slowly changing.
lead_paragraph: ALBERTO BEECK is having what would be considered a solid year for any businessman-philanthropist. In February, Mr. Beeck, who was born in Peru and fled to the United States after his country’s 1968 military coup, and his Cuban-born wife, Olga Maria, gave Georgetown University $10 million to start the Beeck Center for Social Impact and Innovation.

headline: What the Numbers Show About N.F.L. Player Arrests
keywords: ['Football', 'Domestic Violence', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Overall arrests are down, but some teams have persistent problems, and domestic violence continues to be an issue.
lead_paragraph: Off-the-field violence by professional football players is coming under new focus this week after the release of a video involving the star Baltimore Ravens running back Ray Rice, followed by a bungled response by the National Football League.

headline: Marc Jacobs: A ‘Slower’ Pace
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The clothes were an effective fusion of the designer’s own downtown sensibility and the experience gained in a French atelier.
lead_paragraph: And so the first leg of the four-week marathon that is fashion month (let’s be honest here) came to an end — with a thought: “There’s been so much going on. Can we move the house to a place where nothing ever happens and things are slower? I’ll be happy there.”

headline: New York Fashion Week: Marc Jacobs Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: U.S. Retail Sales Gain Slightly
abstract: On Friday, the Commerce Department reported a 0.6 percent increase in retail sales for August.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who waited to buy school supplies in a snaking checkout line at Staples last month may not be surprised that on Friday the Commerce Department reported a healthy 0.6 percent increase in retail sales for August.

headline: Kutiman Returns With More YouTube Sampling Madness
abstract: A new piece by the stylistically omnivorous musician and producer combines samples from YouTube videos
lead_paragraph: For Ophir Kutiel, a stylistically omnivorous musician and producer based in Tel Aviv, conventional sampling – taking a musical fragment from an existing recording to help build a new one – is kids’ stuff. Mr. Kutiel, who performs and records under the name Kutiman, has transformed sampling into a multimedia art, building his songs from bits of YouTube clips – the video as well as the audio – with amateur and instructional videos as his favored sources. He plans to post “ThruYOU Too,” his second collection of these pieces, on his YouTube page on Oct. 1. In the meantime, he is posting one song, “Give It Up” today as a teaser.

headline: Elderly New Yorkers, Here for the Duration
abstract: As city’s 60-plus population grows, landlords and co-op boards are confronting a host of new challenges.
lead_paragraph: Chuck and Cindy Nemser have lived in a townhouse in Park Slope for 47 years. Until she began suffering from unexplained nerve pain a few years ago, Ms. Nemser, 77, an art historian and writer, would happily retreat to her third-floor office where she could work undisturbed. There’s plenty of wall space for the couple’s art collection, and ample storage for Mr. Nemser’s cache of fishing poles.

headline: A Rebound Takes Root in Michigan, but Voters’ Gloom Is Hard to Shake
abstract: No state has seen stronger gains in employment since the recession, but the recovery has proved to be something of an abstraction to voters.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Another blustery Midwestern winter approaches, but along a blue-collar stretch of Leonard Street in this conservative, famously button-down city, an economic springtime has arrived.

headline: Let Us Help You, Hedge Funds Tell Puerto Rico
abstract: Hedge fund firms and investors have bought about 10 percent of the bonds of a beleaguered Puerto Rico, expecting a big return on their investment.
lead_paragraph: Forget, just for a moment, depictions of sharp-elbowed hedge funds, seizing Navy ships from deadbeat nations or pushing for federal investigations into the companies they are betting against.

headline: 10 Militants Held in Shooting of Malala Yousafzai, Girls’ Education Advocate, Pakistan Says
abstract: The militants have been accused of the 2012 attack on the schoolgirl, who was shot in head on a school bus in Swat Valley.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Ten militants have been taken into custody in connection with the 2012 shooting of Malala Yousafzai, a teenager who defied the Taliban with her outspoken calls for girls’ education, a spokesman for the Pakistani military said Friday.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: airline seats, averting diabetes and sleeping for productivity.
lead_paragraph: In the news: airline seats, averting diabetes and sleeping for productivity.

headline: Queens Library Leader on Leave as Inquiry Goes On
abstract: While officials investigate spending under Thomas W. Galante, the board of trustees moved to give the city comptroller full access to the library’s financial records.
lead_paragraph: As federal and city officials continue their investigation into spending at the Queens Public Library, the library’s board of trustees has placed its embattled leader on paid administrative leave.

headline: Massachusetts Town Shudders After Discovery of Dead Infants
abstract: Erika Murray, the 31-year-old woman who the authorities believe is the mother of the children, has been ordered held without bail.
lead_paragraph: When officers responded to a report of a crying, possibly neglected child at a modest house a block from police headquarters in Blackstone, Mass., they unwittingly uncovered a situation so horrifying that the police chief on Friday said it had tested the entire town.

headline: Today in Small Business: Dying Malls
abstract: Small businesses see only a small increase in health premiums. Small-business loans hit a record high for the third consecutive month. And there’s a black market for Olive Garden pasta passes.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Bushwick Takes the Spotlight
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A wave of condominium development is underway, but community groups worry that the projects could change the low-rise streetscape and displace some residents.
lead_paragraph: The appearance of a scantily clad, twerking Miley Cyrus at a recent party in Bushwick, Brooklyn, may be stealing headlines, but the arrival of new-construction condominium developments for the first time since the 2008 real estate crisis has also attracted attention.

headline: How Women Talk About Clothes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Dresses', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The new book “Women in Clothes” has incited countless conversations on the importance of what we wear, when, how and why.
lead_paragraph: “Who’s wearing a hand-me-down?” Leanne Shapton, one of the editors of the new book “Women in Clothes,” asked a largely female audience at a recent celebration for the book at powerHouse Arena, a bookstore and event space in Dumbo, Brooklyn. Numerous hands shot up in the air.

headline: No Comment Necessary: The Saudi Arabia-Syria Border?
abstract: A White House official said on Wednesday that “Saudi Arabia has an extensive border with Syria.”
lead_paragraph: A White House official said on a Wednesday conference call that he was confident “many countries” would “join a broader coalition through a range of actions” to fight ISIS. He noted that “governments in the region” view ISIS “as an existential threat” and that “Saudi Arabia has an extensive border with Syria.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Henry Kissinger’s ‘World Order’
abstract: This week, Henry Kissinger discusses “World Order”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Lawrence Wright talks about “Thirteen Days in September”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Henry Kissinger discusses “World Order”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Lawrence Wright talks about “Thirteen Days in September”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Henry Kissinger’s ‘World Order’
abstract: This week, Henry Kissinger and Lawrence Wright.
lead_paragraph: This week, Henry Kissinger and Lawrence Wright.

headline: Talking Bare Faces, ’70s Supermodels and Macarons with Francois Nars at Marc Jacobs
abstract: The legendary founder of Nars Cosmetics explains the show’s no-makeup directive and reflects on 20 years in the business.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the Marc Jacobs spring/summer 2015 show officially closed the curtain on New York Fashion Week. Backstage beforehand, the mood was decidedly mellow, as if everyone was relieved at having reached the final mile of a marathon. Classical music played, photographers casually milled about and the model Edie Campbell even chilled in a chair doing a crossword puzzle.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BLEEDING EDGE,  by Thomas Pynchon. (Penguin, $17.) The horror of Sept. 11 looms over Pynchon’s novel of New York in the vortex of the dot-com boom. When Maxine Tarnow, a fraud investigator pinballing between work and family, starts looking into a computer-security firm and its corrupt chief executive, she finds herself mixed up with an array of hackers, drug runners and entrepreneurs, some of whom begin turning up dead. Our reviewer, Jonathan Lethem, called this shaggy-dog conspiracy tale “dazzling and ludicrous.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE DOG,  by Joseph O’Neill. (Pantheon, $25.95.) In O’Neill’s disturbing, elegant novel, his first since “Netherland,” a lost and tormented New York lawyer recognizes more darkness within himself than in the iniquitous place he works, Dubai.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “The Secret Place,” by Tana French, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4, just after the critic Laura Miller recently argued that women write the best crime novels.
lead_paragraph: Unsolved Mysteries: Do women write the best crime novels? That’s the thesis of a recent essay in Salon by the critic Laura Miller, who argues that mysteries by men have grown sclerotic and predictable — locked into a hard-boiled formula little changed since the days of Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett. Meanwhile (Miller continues), women are mixing their crime stories with other genres, mining the emotional terrains of home and family to advance a field the editor Sarah Weinman calls “domestic suspense.” One novel that features prominently in Miller’s analysis is “The Secret Place,” by Tana French, which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. “A thin vein of the uncanny runs through most of French’s novels,” Miller notes: “mysteries that go unsolved, premises that flirt with impossibility, paranormal occurrences that may or may not be imagined.” I don’t know if Miller is right about men and women; who is? But she’s not wrong about French, whose books really do cultivate an appealing lack of resolution — at least in part, no doubt, because she jumps in without a plan. “When I start writing, I have the narrator, the basic premise and a load of coffee,” French told The Sunday Times of London in 2008. “I don’t even know ­‘whodunit.’ ” Not that she would let uncertainty keep her from a genre she loves. “Crime fiction is one of the best barometers of what’s going on at any different moment,” she added. “It’s about society’s highest priorities and deepest fears.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: Henry Kissinger’s ‘World Order’
abstract: Mr. Kissinger discusses his new book, and Lawrence Wright talks about “Thirteen Days in September: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, John Micklethwait reviews Henry Kissinger’s “World Order.” Mr. Micklethwait writes:

headline: Letters: Fabulist Tradition
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of William T. Vollmann’s “Last Stories and Other Stories,” Dana Goldstein’s “The Teacher Wars” and more.
lead_paragraph: Fabulist Tradition

headline: The Sound of the Words
abstract: John Darnielle, of the indie-rock band the Mountain Goats, talks about writing songs and his new novel, “Wolf in White Van.”
lead_paragraph: Since the early 1990s, John Darnielle has moved from cult favorite to mainstream success with his indie-rock band the Mountain Goats. (During its early years, the “band” was just Darnielle.) The New Yorker has called him “America’s best non-hip-hop lyricist,” and fans once petitioned the government to name him United States poet laureate.

headline: Poetry
abstract: New books by Simone Muench, Fanny Howe, J. D. McClatchy and Cynthia Hogue.
lead_paragraph: WOLF CENTOS  By Simone Muench  Sarabande, paper, $14.95.

headline: True Detective
abstract: Hercule Poirot reappears, courtesy of Sophie Hannah, years after solving his “last case.”
lead_paragraph: Nobody would dispute the fact that Hercule Poirot, the elegant Belgian detective, he of the patent-leather shoes and the waxed mustache, is dead. Agatha Christie brought him to an end in her appropriately named novel, “Curtain: Poirot’s Last Case,” and The New York Times itself marked his death with a fictional obituary. But the demise of the hero, and of the author, no longer needs to be the end of the story. The literary executors of James Bond’s creator, Ian Fleming, have held this view for some years, and there seems to be no end to the public’s enthusiasm for rewritten versions of a whole host of literary favorites.

headline: The Body’s Temple
abstract: In this Ian McEwan novel, a judge must decide the case of a teenage Jehovah’s Witness who refuses treatment for leukemia.
lead_paragraph: When Anne Darwin died just after her 10th birthday in 1851, her father “lost the joy of the Household.” No longer could he see “as plainly as others do, and as I should wish to do, evidence of design and beneficence on all sides of us. There seems to me too much misery in the world.” Charles Darwin’s faith was gone; he began writing “On the Origin of Species.” As Ian McEwan has told interviewers, “rather like Darwin when his favorite daughter died,” on Sept. 11 he “felt, more than ever,” that there was no God, and that “religion was distinctly unhelpful in making compassionate, reasonable judgments about people’s lives. On the whole, the secular mind seems far superior in making reasonable judgments.” In McEwan’s early novels, intelligent characters had often “slithered” along the “axis of belief and unbelief,” just as he had. Not anymore. Atheism and the secular state are under attack, and he must defend them.

headline: Facts, Lies and Artifacts
abstract: An antiquities collector disappears off the coast of Greece in 1905, and his wife discovers that his life was not what it seemed.
lead_paragraph: The 19th century was the Golden Age of Collectors. Or, depending on your perspective, the Gilded Age of Plunderers. From Lord Elgin’s marbles to Alfred Russel Wallace’s tropical fauna (over 80,000 beetles!) to Edward Drinker Cope’s dinosaur bones to Charles Frederick Newcombe’s Northwest Coast totem poles, it was the unquestioned privilege of the enlightened world to amass the specimens and relics of the dark one, and to study, paint or display them in cabinets and museums — or sell them. The nadir of this frenzy may have occurred when Robert Peary brought six Inuits from Greenland to New York to be housed at the American Museum of Natural History, an event that most likely inspired Andrea Barrett’s novel “The Voyage of the Narwhal.”

headline: Southern Exposure
abstract: Tony Earley’s stories include a skunk ape, a talking dog and the sometimes surprising, sometimes lonely lives of ordinary people.
lead_paragraph: Tony Earley’s elegiac new collection, “Mr. Tall,” begins in playful rhyme, with a couple named Darryl and Cheryl from Argyle, N.C. It ends some 240 pages later with a plea: “For God’s sake, don’t close this book.”

headline: Mission Almost Impossible
abstract: A whistle-blower describes his path from biker-gang leader to Muslim activist to spy for three Western intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: It was June 2010, and American intelligence agencies were desperate to track down Anwar al-Awlaki, the American cleric who had joined Al Qaeda and was believed to be plotting from the wilds of Yemen. But Awlaki had other things on his mind. From his hide-out, he sent an encrypted email to Morten Storm to thank him for dispatching to Yemen the Croatian convert to Islam who had become his third wife. She had turned out to be even “better than I expected and better than you described,” Awlaki wrote, adding a lascivious smiley face.

headline: Shakespeare for Survivors
abstract: After a pandemic kills most of the human race, a traveling theater company roams around, searching for an audience.
lead_paragraph: Emily St. John Mandel’s fourth novel, “Station Eleven,” begins with a spectacular end. One night, in a Toronto theater, onstage performing the role of King Lear, 51-year-old Arthur Leander has a fatal heart attack. There is barely time for people to absorb this shock when tragedy on a considerably vaster scale arrives in the form of a flu pandemic so lethal that, within weeks, most of the world’s population has been killed.

headline: Deciphering a Lost World
abstract: In a trilogy’s conclusion, the mysterious ecosystem known as Area X yields more of its secrets.
lead_paragraph: Published in quick succession this year, Jeff VanderMeer’s Southern Reach trilogy has kept readers on tenterhooks as they’ve waited for the latest installment of this pure reading pleasure. ­“Annihilation,” “Authority” and “Acceptance” — the titles suggest an especially terrible session of behavioral therapy — introduce Area X, a slice of coast in what appears to be the Florida panhandle. VanderMeer carefully grounds us in that region’s ecology: the palmettos, the black damselflies and the “wealth of birdlife, from warblers and flickers to cormorants and black ibis.” But he also immerses us in its everyday human life: bowling alleys, dive bars, mobile homes. This science fiction happens in our backyard.

headline: Worth Its Weight
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Gold Standard (Monetary)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A historian examines the rise of the gold standard and the economies that have embraced and abandoned it.
lead_paragraph: If you said that a principal cause of the 2008 financial crisis was an explosion in credit, most economic commentators would nod their heads in agreement. If you then said this credit boom was due to lax monetary policy, you’d still earn a healthy fraction of nods. If you then asserted that America’s departure from the gold standard caused the lax monetary policy, not many folks would be nodding. Nevertheless, this attenuated causal chain has been embraced by a motley collection of wonks, cranks and presidential candidates: Michele Bachmann, Glenn Beck, Steve Forbes, David Stockman and politicians whose last name is Paul. These gold bugs have a deep suspicion of fiat currency. They fret that governments that can just print money will be tempted to print even more, triggering inflation, currency depreciation and worse. Most citizens do not share this obsession, but they might share an unease about the dollar being backed by nothing more than a social convention to treat greenbacks as if they are worth more than the paper they are printed on.

headline: Jimmie Johnson on Nascar’s New Rules
abstract: The six-time champion stopped by The New York Times to explain the new elimination-style Sprint Cup format.
lead_paragraph: The six-time champion stopped by The New York Times to explain the new elimination-style Sprint Cup format.

headline: It’s True, You Can’t Fight City Hall
abstract: Over the years, many have tried to knock down City Hall, add onto it or move it elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: For much of the summer, roof repairs shrouded City Hall in a shimmery coat of white linen-like construction netting, barely visible as breezes rippled the sheets. Over the last two centuries, change has often been in the wind for City Hall and its surrounding park, as mayors, agencies, visionaries, grafters and others put forth ideas for an appropriate civic center — including getting rid of City Hall entirely.

headline: The Mystery of Apple Watch’s Battery Life
abstract: Apple had plenty to brag about at its event earlier this week. So it was particularly noticeable when Apple left out an important detail about the brand-new Apple Watch: the battery life.
lead_paragraph: Apple had plenty to brag about at its event earlier this week. Bigger iPhones. Sharper screens. Faster speeds. A shiny new watch. So it was particularly noticeable when Apple left out an important detail for the Apple Watch: the battery life.

headline: The End of a Week of Cooking, and a Weekend Plan
abstract: After a week of cooking, Friday is a night off before weekend meals and planning for next week.
lead_paragraph: Busy parents. Active kids. Families that arrive home every evening, starved. This week, in the series Dinner: The Boot Camp, Jenny Rosenstrach takes a recipe for chaos and coaches one family, and all of us, in the planning and preparation needed to turn it into a pleasant nightly meal. Find all the Boot Camp recipes here.

headline: 1964: Dr. King in East Berlin
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: East Berliners flocked to see Martin Luther King Jr. in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WEST BERLIN — The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. filled two churches to overflowing in Communist East Berlin today [Sept. 13]. So many East Berliners showed up to hear him deliver a sermon tonight in the Marienkirche, Berlin’s oldest Protestant church, that a second sermon was arranged in another church. Both talks stressed religious, rather than political, themes but in an obvious reference to the Communist-built wall that divides the city, Dr. King declared that “Christian love will overcome all man-made barriers.” His crossing into East Berlin was easier than most. When he arrived at the border, he realized be had forgotten his passport. But police at the Checkpoint Charlie crossing point recognized him and allowed him in without it. At a press conference, he had some sharp words for Republican presidential candidate Sen. Barry Goldwater. His election would bring dangerous signs of Hitlerism, he predicted. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 13, 1964

headline: Nascar Drivers Adjust, Slowly, to New Postseason Format
abstract: The system, known as the Chase Grid, includes new rules, more drivers and bracket-style elimination rounds.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Nascar’s newly formatted postseason will begin Sunday at Chicagoland Speedway, with 10 races to decide this season’s champion. Changes include a host of new bells and whistles, more drivers and bracket-style elimination rounds with catchy names.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Black Ties at Radnor
abstract: The Radnor Hunt Concours d’Élégance features classic Chryslers and Brough Superior motorcycles; Nascar and the N.H.R.A. begin championship countdowns.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Conversation Pieces (Not That He Needs Them)
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Mo Rocca, a CBS correspondent, lives with a collection of presidential memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: For years the “CBS Sunday Morning” correspondent Mo Rocca lived in Chelsea, moving from one rental to another. “It was fine,” said Mr. Rocca, who is also a contributor to “CBS This Morning” as well as the host of “My Grandmother’s Ravioli” on the Cooking Channel and a panelist on the NPR news quiz “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” Yes, it was fine, but also, frankly, a bit guilt-inducing to keep throwing away money on rent.

headline: Interview: Benicio Del Toro
abstract: The actor discusses playing the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar in the film “Escobar: Paradise Lost.”
lead_paragraph: The actor discusses playing the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar in the film “Escobar: Paradise Lost.”

headline: Playing Piano, and Blaming Woody Allen
abstract: Jeff Goldblum, leader of the Mildred Snitzer Orchestra, opening at the Café Carlyle on Tuesday, says he could have seen himself as a full-time musician rather than an actor.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Goldblum slipped behind the piano in Bemelmans Bar at the Carlyle Hotel one afternoon this week, to tinkle away at “Stella by Starlight” and to practice for the shows that he and his jazz band, the Mildred Snitzer Orchestra, will begin playing at the Café Carlyle on Tuesday night, in the group’s first New York engagement.

headline: Stopping Homebound ISIS Fighters
abstract: A look at how governments around the world have been dealing with citizens turning jihadists.
lead_paragraph: A look at how governments around the world have been dealing with citizens turning jihadists.

headline: New Contemporary Label Teams Composers With Artists
abstract: For VIA Records’ first three releases, the company has commissioned visual artists to work with the composers to create companion video works.
lead_paragraph: The enterprising composer and impresario Paola Prestini is starting a new contemporary music label, VIA Records, an offshoot of VisionIntoArt, the interdisciplinary arts production company she founded in 1999. And in the spirit of the parent company, the label will present collaborations between composers and artists in different fields: for the label’s first three releases, the company has commissioned visual artists to work with the composers to create companion video works.

headline: Off the Air, Onto the Stage
abstract: The popular radio show host Ira Glass performs with Monica Bill Barnes and Anna Bass in “Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host.”
lead_paragraph: Before you see “Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host,” you hear it. The male and female voices bantering in the darkened theater cheerfully argue about whether to begin the proceedings with talk, rather than dance, so as to “start with an idea,” the implication seeming to be that movement is less fit for conveying content.

headline: For Teachout, the Thrill of Defeat
abstract: Zephyr Teachout, a law school professor, challenged Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary, and won more than 30 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: Early in the summer, after Zephyr Teachout announced what appeared to be a quixotic bid to challenge Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary for governor, I met her for breakfast with a childhood friend of hers and a wealthy ideological soul mate she had known for some time through leftist circles in Brooklyn. The candidate was looking for someone to hold a fund-raiser for her, and not having much luck.

headline: Tavern on the Green’s Chef Leaves, Five Months After Its Reopening
abstract: Katy Sparks is stepping down at the restaurant in Central Park, which reopened last spring to poor reviews.
lead_paragraph: Less than five months after the revered but troubled Central Park restaurant Tavern on the Green reopened with a costly renovation, a new management and a new menu, its executive chef, Katy Sparks, has left.

headline: Toronto Festival 2014: Benicio Del Toro on Playing Pablo Escobar
abstract: The actor discusses playing the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar in the film “Escobar: Paradise Lost.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Family man, politician, ruthless drug lord. All of these sides of Pablo Escobar are explored in the thriller “Escobar: Paradise Lost,” directed by Andrea Di Stefano and featuring Benicio Del Toro as Escobar. The film follows a Canadian surfer named Nick (Josh Hutcherson), who, while spending time in Colombia, falls for Escobar’s niece (Claudia Traisac) and finds himself pulled into the drug kingpin’s dark world. In this video, Mr. Del Toro discusses his approach to the role.

headline: A Live Performance Extravaganza Comes to the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles
abstract: Step and Repeat, a Saturday series which kicks off this weekend, features new-media artists, poets, dancers, rappers, musicians and comedians.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles has gone through plenty of changes lately, beginning with the hiring of a new director, Philippe Vergne. One of Vergne’s first orders of business upon arriving was giving the confident staff he inherited — including the curator Bennett Simpson and the MOCAtv director Emma Reeves — the green light to move ahead with Step and Repeat, a monthlong series at the Geffen Contemporary. Over four consecutive Saturdays starting September 13 and ending October 4, the bill will be filled out with poets, DJs, bands, performance artists and comedians, including both familiar names and fledgling artists, in a kind of West Coast multimedia analog to MoMA P.S.1’s summer Warm Up series. It’s a major step forward in providing a showcase for live performance in Los Angeles.

headline: The Scorekeeper
abstract: Howie Karpin, 60, an official scorer for both the Mets and the Yankees, is now in his 16th full season of recording the game action.
lead_paragraph: For those keeping score, mark it as the 901st regular season game for the man in the khakis and T-shirt settling into the press box at CitiField on Tuesday night.

headline: In Greece, a Run With Some History
abstract: The Navarino Challenge, a series of runs in the southwest Pelponnesse of Greece, will feature the ultra marathon runner Dean Karnazes.
lead_paragraph: The ultra marathon runner Dean Karnazes will join participants of all ages and abilities for the Navarino Challenge, a series of runs through olive groves and along the country roads of Messinia in the southwest Peloponnese of Greece.

headline: Are You Catholic and Divorced? Share Your Experience
abstract: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists covering religion would like to hear from Catholics who have been divorced, and, in particular, from those who have remarried.

headline: No Need to Flip-Flop? An Argument for the Power of Persuasion
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Research', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A study showed that when state lawmakers sent constituents mail disagreeing with them, it didn’t cost them support.
lead_paragraph: Elected officials may have more power to shape public opinion than they realize.

headline: A Showplace for Art
abstract: An extravagant townhouse on Central Park West that retains its fanciful 1887 Queen Anne exterior, but received a rigorous renovation in 2006, is poised to return to the market.
lead_paragraph: An extravagant townhouse on Central Park West that retains its fanciful 1887 Queen Anne exterior, but received a rigorous renovation in 2006 that fast-forwarded its interior into a stark showplace for contemporary art, is poised to return to the market at $27.75 million. The annual property taxes on the residence, whose unusual attributes include a 60-foot lap pool and an onion dome skylight encircled by a Guggenheim-esque stairway, are $48,000.

headline: Making Romescada, the Catalan Fish Stew
abstract: This fish stew has hearty Mediterranean heft.
lead_paragraph: Romesco, the delicious rust-colored sauce from the Catalan region of Spain, is justly popular, served alongside grilled fish or as dip for vegetables. It is typically made with fresh and dried red peppers, roasted almonds and hazelnuts, a fair amount of garlic, and day-old bread fried in olive oil. These ingredients are pounded together (or, these days, whirled to a rough consistency in a machine), and olive oil is added until the mixture resembles a rough reddish mayonnaise.

headline: Dungeons, Dragons & Documentaries: A Film Conjures a Battle
abstract: Three filmmakers set out to tell the origin story of the fantasy role-playing game Dungeons & Dragons. Two years later, there is no documentary, only broken friendships and a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: For a certain sort of fan, the crowdfunding pitch was impossible to resist. Here was a chance, it announced, to support a documentary about the immortal saga of the legendary game that all but revolutionized modern life. No pressure.

headline: Truce Is Strengthening, Ukraine President Says
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko, who has been trying to generate a sense of momentum for a lasting cease-fire, also ruled out trying to take back Crimea by force.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — A week into a cease-fire between pro-Russia separatists and government forces in the east of Ukraine, President Petro O. Poroshenko said on Friday that the pact appeared to be growing stronger by the day, in remarks that conspicuously avoided direct criticism of Moscow.

headline: Big Ticket | Mansion in the Making for $45 Million
abstract: A historic building in the West Village ready to be repurposed as a single-family home was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: An imposing brick-and-limestone building that has stood guard at a historic corner of Greenwich Village for more than a century and performed a series of humble if necessary services — Catholic school, nursing school, training center for one of the city’s oldest charities, New York Foundling — sold for $45 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Where Their Designs Do the Talking
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Long the kooky aunt of Fashion Weeks, London’s show hub at Somerset House has gotten busier and slicker.
lead_paragraph: Long the kooky aunt of Fashion Weeks, London’s show schedule has gotten busier and slicker since Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter, was appointed chairwoman of the British Fashion Council. Speeches given this morning while I was still stumbling through customs emphasized tech, mobile devices, e-commerce, avatars, Twitter saturation and the online initiatives of the council’s chairman and so-called “digital and innovation pillar president,” Peter Fitzgerald.

headline: Troubleshooting a Balky Trackpad
abstract: Before dismantling your computer, try these steps.

headline: Middle-Aged Man Without a Horn
abstract: In his directing debut, the actor Don Cheadle portrays the trumpet genius Miles Davis during a difficult era in his career.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The elevator opens on the 20th floor of Carew Tower, a landmark 1930 office building overlooking the Ohio River here. On this overcast July morning, though, the space is not a bank or an insurance company, but the headquarters of Columbia Records circa 1980.

headline: Riffs on the Rock Documentary
abstract: Three movies — focusing on Nick Cave, Pulp and Willis Earl Beal — take an offbeat approach to telling musicians’ stories.
lead_paragraph: Even before the first-time feature directors Jane Pollard and Iain Forsyth knew how their film about the rock musician Nick Cave would take shape, they had a very clear sense of what it would not be. While most music documentaries are about an artist unmasked — the man behind the myth — or an artist battling band mates or record executives or inner demons, none of that applied to Mr. Cave.

headline: Home Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Looking Out for Yourself With Disability Insurance
abstract: As some employers push more of the onus for disability insurance onto their employees, here’s what you need to know to buy it on your own.
lead_paragraph: In case anyone has forgotten, we’re all basically on our own here in personal finance land.

headline: Nations Trying to Stop Their Citizens From Going to Middle East to Fight for ISIS
abstract: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — France wants more power to block its citizens from leaving the country, while Britain is weighing whether to stop more of its citizens from coming home. Tunisia is debating measures to make it a criminal offense to help jihadist fighters travel to Syria and Iraq, while Russia has outlawed enlisting in armed groups that are “contradictory to Russian policy.”

headline: Russia Scolds the U.S. Over Syria
abstract: A Russian ministry spokesman said that if President Obama proceeded with a plan for air strikes in Syria against ISIS, it would violate international law.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s latest foray into the international debate over Syria took chutzpah.

headline: Mike Mills Designs Pajamas for Sleepy Jones
abstract: The artist and filmmaker has created limited-edition sets of pill-printed pajamas for Andy Spade’s line of lazywear.
lead_paragraph: Now that New York Fashion Week has ended, those involved would love nothing more than the chance to sink into a pillow and doze off. Just in time for the most exhausted moment of the year, the artist and filmmaker Mike Mills has designed a limited-edition set of pajamas for Sleepy Jones, Andy Spade’s line of stylish lazywear. The navy-and-white sets, available in men’s and women’s tops and bottoms ($74-$165), come printed with Mills’s illustrations of the various sleep aids and anxiety pills taken by his friends. “My sleep is the first to go when I start worrying, thinking too much, when life turbulence hits,” Mills says. “I let all the thoughts you don’t want to think in.” Though it’s not the first time that the prescriptions we pop have made for a pop-art-meets-fashion motif (see Damien Hirst’s pharmaceutical-studded backpack for the Row), the pill pattern, in the case of these soft cotton pieces, offers both metaphorical and literal comfort.

headline: Young Households Are Losing Ground in Income, Despite Education
abstract: The Fed’s 2013 Survey of Consumer Finances indicates that the median family headed by someone under 35 was paid less, in inflation-adjusted dollars, than a similar family in 1989.
lead_paragraph: YOUNG families are better educated than ever before, but they are earning lower real incomes.

headline: The Memories Are Woven In
abstract: Choosing to wear a family wedding gown can be meaningful, if fraught.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to sentimentality, there are few events in life more steeped in it than the typical wedding. But when it comes to dressing for the occasion, many brides can’t wait to get their hands on the latest design from Vera Wang or Carolina Herrera.

headline: Orioles Lose Chris Davis to Drug Suspension Before Edging Yankees
abstract: Davis, Baltimore’s slugging corner infielder, was barred for 25 games after he tested positive for amphetamines.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Baltimore Orioles played their first game Friday without Chris Davis, the slugging corner infielder who was suspended earlier in the day for amphetamine use. It was devastating news because the 25-game suspension extends well into the postseason, where the Orioles seem destined to play.

headline: Can the Apple Watch Woo Traditional Watch Fans?
abstract: While the first wristwatches were developed in the 16th century, it took less than a day for the Apple Watch to become the only one people want to talk about.
lead_paragraph: “The Watch.”

headline: Tune In to The Times
abstract: Highlights from New York Times reporters and contributors’ interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

headline: Ford Recalling Older Escapes for a Stalling Problem
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles']
abstract: About 70,000 vehicles are affected from the 2005-8 model years.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 70,000 older Ford Escape and Mercury Mariner crossover utility vehicles because the electronics may overheat and cause the vehicles to stall, the automaker said in a report posted Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Parenthood Denied by the Law
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Child Custody and Support']
abstract: Jann Paczkowski has separated from her wife, whom she married after New York’s Marriage Equality Act, and is seeking visitation rights for the child they were raising. But a judge has ruled she has no claim to parentage.
lead_paragraph: The Marriage Equality Act, which New York State passed in June 2011, allowed Jann Paczkowski to marry her partner, Jamie, with the assurance that “the marriages of same-sex and different-sex couples” would “be treated equally in all respects under the law.” But when the couple separated and Ms. Paczkowski sought joint custody of the 2-year-old boy they were raising together, she discovered the limits of that assurance. On June 30, 2014, a judge in Nassau County family court ruled that Ms. Paczkowski did not have legal standing to seek access to the boy — because even under the Marriage Equality Act, she was not his parent.

headline: Veterans of Elite Israeli Unit Refuse Reserve Duty, Citing Treatment of Palestinians
abstract: In a letter sent to commanders and the prime minister, 43 veteran officers of a vaunted intelligence unit said they would refuse required reserve duty.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Denouncing Israel’s treatment of Palestinians under occupation, a group of veterans from an elite, secretive military intelligence unit have declared they will no longer “take part in the state’s actions against Palestinians” in required reserve duty because of what they called “our moral duty to act.”

headline: Brain Trauma to Affect One in Three Players, N.F.L. Agrees
abstract: The statements are the league’s most unvarnished admission yet that the sport’s professional participants sustain severe brain injuries at far higher rates than the general population.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League, which for years disputed evidence that its players had a high rate of severe brain damage, has stated in federal court documents that it expects nearly a third of retired players to develop long-term cognitive problems and that the conditions are likely to emerge at “notably younger ages” than in the general population.

headline: Arturo O’Farrill: (Don’t) Take Five
abstract: Mr. O’Farrill, the Grammy Award-winning pianist and composer, spends his Sundays in a frenzy of improvisation.
lead_paragraph: Arturo O’Farrill, the Grammy Award-winning pianist and composer, spends his Sundays in a frenzy of improvisation. By day he directs a youth orchestra, the Fat Afro Latin Jazz Cats. By night he takes the stage himself with his own group, the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra, at Birdland. On Sept. 20, the two groups will play together at Pueblo Harlem, a cultural festival. Mr. O’Farrill, 54, lives in Park Slope with his wife, Alison Deane, 62, a classical pianist. “I made one rule for myself, and I really try to live it: Play music you love, with people you love, for people you love,” Mr. O’Farrill said. “If I can’t be that kind of musician, I’ll drive a cab. Creating music based on art and giving away from your spirit is more important than making a living.”

headline: Cara Delevingne’s London Fashion Week Shortlist
abstract: The model shares her five favorite hometown hangouts, where she’s likely to spend downtime between the spring/summer 2015 shows there.
lead_paragraph: Today, the 22-year-old British model Cara Delevingne returns to her hometown of London to walk in the spring/summer 2015 shows there. The fashion-world darling, who introduced her eponymous Mulberry collection at an event in New York City on Monday and who stars in the new Burberry fragrance campaign alongside Kate Moss, is excited to be home with her family. When she has more time in London, she ventures out to Hackney Farm and London Zoo to frolic and play. But she has less ambitious plans for this whirlwind of a trip (including a pit stop at the Mulberry Store on New Bond Street “to look at my bags,” she says). Here, in five words or less, the girl with more Instagram followers than Lady Gaga shares her top 5 places to hang during London Fashion Week this season.

headline: More Time in the Sun for Club Med’s Shareholders
abstract: Investors challenged a management buyout offer. They lost in court, but now management is back with an improved $1.1 billion proposal, Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Club Méditerranée’s shareholders have been vindicated for refusing to throw in the towel.

headline: Rob Ford, Toronto Mayor, Withdraws Re-election Bid
abstract: Minutes after the announcement, a representative for Doug Ford, the mayor’s brother who is a City Council member, formally registered him as a mayoral candidate.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — While in a hospital for the treatment of a tumor, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto withdrew his bid for re-election Friday afternoon. Minutes later, a representative of Doug Ford, the mayor’s brother and a City Council member, formally registered him as a mayoral candidate.

headline: Separated by Decades, Reunited in Tears
abstract: Lynne Ditman and Richard Goldberg met when they were 17, but they did not revive their romance until after more than 40 years apart.
lead_paragraph: When Lynne Kornreich met Richard Goldberg, they were both 17, and it was the ’60s, but not the Swinging Sixties. She was a waitress and he was a busboy at the Sinclair Hotel in Bethlehem, N.H., which was the sort of resort one would have found in that era in the Catskills — where Melba toast and cottage cheese were once popular mainstays, and everyone ate as if it were the last meal.

headline: Argentina Rediscovers Its African Roots
abstract: From tango to tunnels, a nation begins to trace the once-robust culture of the slaves who were brought there.
lead_paragraph: The chapel in the small lakeside resort community of Chascomús is at best underwhelming. Its whitewashed brick exterior is partly obstructed by a tangle of vines and bushes, and its dim, one-room interior is no more majestic than its facade. Wooden pews and an uneven dirt floor are scarcely illuminated by sunlight from a single window. The gray, cracked, dusty walls are adorned with crosses, photos, icons — things people leave to mark their pilgrimage. A low front altar is layered with thick candle wax, flowers and a pantheon of black saints, Madonnas and African deities like the sea goddess Yemanja of the Yoruba religion.

headline: Surveying São Paulo’s Music Scene With Céu
abstract: The Brazilian singer offers a selective list of spots for catching live acts in the sprawling city.
lead_paragraph: About 15 years ago, when the Brazilian singer Céu returned home to São Paulo after a year of soaking up New York City’s indie rock, jazz and hip-hop sounds, she decided she wanted to add songwriter to her job description.

headline: Three Sides of Ecuador
abstract: On a journey through the diverse South American country, taking in the coast, the mountains and a town with colonial charm.
lead_paragraph: Two and a half hours and still no sign of llamas. We should have been winding our way through lush forests and mountain lakes instead of the never-ending banana plantations we continued to see outside our rented four-wheel drive. It was time to turn our dying iPhone’s navigation system back on and confirm the inevitable. Somewhere between sprawling Guayaquil and the quaint cobblestone streets of Cuenca my husband and I had made a wrong turn. And now, on the second leg of our Ecuadorean road trip, with my mother consoling our hungry 4-year-old in the back seat, we had a decision to make: Do we turn back and take the well-trodden route through Cajas National Park we had originally planned to drive, or push onward, not knowing what the road conditions might be ahead, how long our journey would take or if our daughter would nap along the way?

headline: Accord Calls for Jury Pool of 2,000 in Boston Bombing Trial
abstract: The proposal indicates the magnitude of the task in the case against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused of planting the bombs that killed three people at the marathon.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The prosecution and the defense in the trial over the Boston Marathon bombings have agreed to an elaborate process by which a jury may be selected to hear the case against the defendant, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

headline: Rift Emerges Before Vote in Sweden as Immigration Tests a Tradition of Openness
abstract: National elections will be held on Sunday, and the center-right government has lost some supporters to an anti-immigrant alternative.
lead_paragraph: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden — Refugees from Syria and Iraq are pouring into Sweden at a record pace, placing strains on welfare, schools and housing. With national elections imminent, the center-right government is watching some of its supporters desert it for a populist, anti-immigrant alternative.

headline: Democrats Are Seeing More Daylight in Path to Senate Control
abstract: With small leads elsewhere, the party will need to pick up one seat in a red state like Alaska, Georgia or Kansas.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, the Democratic path to a Senate majority looked long and arduous. It has started to look easier.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style
keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Here are our highlights from show-goers’ style.
lead_paragraph: Here are our highlights from show-goers’ style.

headline: Shoefie Mania During New York Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: The rise of shoe-gazing imagery on Instagram gives new meaning to the term “street style.”
lead_paragraph: Shoefies (sometimes also referred to as “selfeet”) have become a growing form of downward selfie for the Instagram set among the shoe-gazing and footwear-obsessed — and perhaps those too shy for a full-on self-portrait.

headline: Readers Respond: Wary Support for Obama’s ISIS Strategy
abstract: In comments on various articles about the president’s speech, readers discussed ISIS and the perceived need for the U.S. to respond to recent events in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s plan to conduct air strikes in Syria was met with measured praise and continued skepticism in reader responses to Op-Ed columnists and an editorial on the president’s speech.

headline: Hey, Mr. D.J.
abstract: Photographs of the True School NYC Summer Park Jam, a weekly series of family-friendly outdoor gatherings that celebrate the most essential element of hip-hop culture: the D.J.
lead_paragraph: On the banks of the Bronx River, the music rises as the sun sets. It’s an old-school evening, and the D.J. digs deep in the crates and blasts Tito Puente’s “Ran Kan Kan,” moments later following with the Moments’ “Girls.” The French version, no less.

headline: 2015 Dodge Challenger
abstract: After outliving its sell-by date, the biggest pony car gets a redo and an infernal new edition.
lead_paragraph: After outliving its sell-by date, the biggest pony car gets a redo and an infernal new edition.

headline: 2015 Dodge Challenger R/T Scat Pack
abstract: A retro Dodge updates the art of shredding tires.
lead_paragraph: A retro Dodge updates the art of shredding tires.

headline: Now in Mild, Spicy or Thermonuclear
abstract: For 2015, Dodge has revised the Challenger line without changing the basic engineering or the car’s perfectly proportioned appearance. Except, that is, for one lunatic version called the SRT Hellcat.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF. — As cars age, the market usually ignores them. There’s nothing new, nothing fresh, nothing exciting about a car that looks like one more goose in the flock of off-lease geese that have migrated to the used ponds. Entering its eighth year, the Dodge Challenger should be a dead duck.

headline: Wu-Tang Clan Joins a Tribute to The Source in Brooklyn
abstract: The Wu-Tang Clan will take the stage at Barclays Center in what organizers are calling an “official reunion.”
lead_paragraph: The Source, a music and culture magazine that has been an important voice in the development and chronicling of hip-hop, is celebrating its 25th anniversary with Source360, a concert at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, which the magazine says will be an annual event.

headline: Off Broadway Run of ‘American Psycho’ Is Dead
abstract: The musical adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis’s novel had been scheduled to run at Second Stage Theater.
lead_paragraph: The highly anticipated Off Broadway production of the musical “American Psycho” has been canceled after the show’s commercial backers pulled the rights from Second Stage Theater, its artistic director, Carole Rothman, said on Friday. No explanation was given; the commercial backers at Act 4 Entertainment, who were teaming up with Second Stage to develop the show in hopes of an eventual transfer to Broadway, did not immediately return phone calls.

headline: The Optical Illusion on the Walls at Thomas Tait’s Spring 2015 Presentation
abstract: The winner of the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize will present his spring/summer 2015 collection against a backdrop transformed by the French visual artist and photographer Georges Rousse.
lead_paragraph: “I love a fashion show,” says the Canadian-born, London-based fashion designer Thomas Tait. “Some people question the need for them, but there is something that happens at a fashion show that can never be replicated in any other way.” With Monday’s spring/summer 2015 runway, his first since winning the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize in May, Tait will prove that point. Attendees will file into a derelict warehouse in central London to watch Tait’s presentation against a backdrop transformed by the French visual artist and photographer Georges Rousse. Known for his large-scale installations that seem to float in space like an optical illusion, Rousse created various graphic treatments on the walls and pillars, seen for the first time here, which spell out “déchiré” (ripped) in one room. Spoiler alert: his color palette, electric reds and midnight blues, comes from Tait’s collection.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
abstract: Readers ask about a 1940s Times Square sign, and a word with ties to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Q. Would you know who posed for the giant Camel billboard in 1940s Times Square that showed the man blowing big smoke rings?

headline: ‘Frozen’ Finds a Theme Park Home at Epcot
abstract: To accommodate the new attraction, Walt Disney World is taking out Maelstrom, a 1980s-era flume ride that still has fans.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Walt Disney World is ripping out one of its biggest cult hits in the name of Elsa and Anna.

headline: A Cross-Dresser Turned Inside Out
abstract: Marissa Perel’s production centers on a young woman who disguises herself as a man to study at a yeshiva, where she then falls in love with a man.
lead_paragraph: In Marissa Perel’s “More Than Just a Piece of Sky,” a bedroom becomes a yeshiva that in turn becomes a planet where a sense of difference creates new ways of seeing oneself and others. Ms. Perel, a multidisciplinary artist whose works often combine choreography and performance art, has turned for source material to “Yentl,” a 1983 movie directed by and starring Barbra Streisand that was inspired by a story from Isaac Bashevis Singer.

headline: Swimming in High School, Drowning in Life
abstract: In “Dry Land,” two girls on a high school swim team form a complicated friendship as one of them faces the terrible fact of a pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: The two girls don’t know the protocol for sitting on someone’s stomach for medical reasons. So they improvise, awkwardly and goofily, with one planting her rump on the midsection of the other, which leads to both of them convulsing into giggles. The girl being sat upon laughs so hard that she wets herself.

headline: Sweet and Spicy Roast Chicken
abstract: Melissa Clark roasts juicy chicken thighs with carrots, onions and dates for a twist on a classic dish for the Jewish holidays.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark roasts juicy chicken thighs with carrots, onions and dates for a twist on a classic dish for the Jewish holidays.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a five-bedroom home in Pelham, N.Y., and a log cabin in Ewing, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a West Chelsea condo, and co-ops in the East Village and Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: A New Track and a New Tack
abstract: James L. Dolan says he is spending less time on the Knicks and more time with his blues band, perhaps a sign that he really will give Phil Jackson a wide berth to run the team.
lead_paragraph: The band was warming up when the lead singer arrived at a Midtown studio shortly after 4 p.m. Monday.

headline: House Tour | John Richardson
abstract: The art historian John Richardson shows writer Ian Buruma his Connecticut estate and cautions against too much tasteful decorating.
lead_paragraph: The art historian John Richardson shows writer Ian Buruma his Connecticut estate and cautions against too much tasteful decorating.

headline: Straight From the Source
abstract: Mary Wilson is only the second owner of her 1964 Dodge Custom 880 convertible. The first: Anna Thomson Dodge, whose husband, Horace E. Dodge, was one of the founders of the Dodge Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Mary Wilson is only the second owner of her 1964 Dodge Custom 880 convertible. The first: Anna Thomson Dodge, whose husband, Horace E. Dodge, was one of the founders of the Dodge Brothers.

headline: For a Holiday, Sweet Kisses Spice
abstract: Honoring tradition while keeping the meal interesting.
lead_paragraph: Every Rosh Hashana, Jews smear honey on sliced apples and thick pieces of challah with the idea that a sweet New Year’s meal will usher in a sweet new year. It’s a symbolic ritual I’ve never questioned, since it’s also a tasty one. And who wouldn’t want to hedge their bets in such a pleasant way?

headline: A Violent Tale Induces a Familiar Flinch
abstract: “No Good Deed” stars Idris Elba as an escaped convict with a violent history against women, invading the house of a stay-at-home mother.
lead_paragraph: With less than 24 hours’ notice, Screen Gems announced that it would cancel Wednesday’s press screenings for “No Good Deed.” Officially, this unusual step was intended to help the studio protect a plot twist. This twist, it turns out, hardly warrants any fuss or curiosity.

headline: Subway Tunnel to Open, Storm Repairs Finished
abstract: The N and R trains will run between Brooklyn and Manhattan for the first time since major Hurricane-Sandy-related fixes were begun in mid-2013.
lead_paragraph: Subway service through a storm-damaged tunnel between Brooklyn and Manhattan is set to resume in time for the commute on Monday morning, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s website.

headline: Square to Raise $100 Million at a $6 Billion Valuation
abstract: The funding comes after a difficult year for Square, a five-year-old company that has appeared to shift its strategy.
lead_paragraph: Square, the San Francisco e-commerce start-up, plans to raise at least $100 million in a new round of venture capital funding, according to a person briefed on the investment.

headline: The Assault Weapon Myth
abstract: Handguns are used in the vast majority of murders each year.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past two decades, the majority of Americans in a country deeply divided over gun control have coalesced behind a single proposition: The sale of assault weapons should be banned.

headline: Emma Stone’s Peekaboo Chloé Dress
abstract: A crochet panel made for a daring look on an actress usually known for her girl-next-door style.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Emma Stone

headline: Tougher Than They Look
abstract: Researchers have written for years about resilience in the elderly. Now they’re trying to measure it.
lead_paragraph: Resilience, the subject of a large-scale study published recently in The Gerontologist, reminds me of what a Supreme Court justice once said of pornography: It’s hard to define, but we know it when we see it.

headline: Formative Lessons in the Hudson River School
abstract: An exhibition at the Thomas Cole National Historic Site in Catskill, N.Y., explores the crucial period when Frederic Edwin Church was the pupil of Thomas Cole.
lead_paragraph: In 1844, Frederic Edwin Church left his parents’ home in Hartford, Conn., to spend two years in Catskill, N.Y., as the pupil of Thomas Cole. At 18, Church had already demonstrated skills as a draftsman and was enthusiastic about accompanying Cole on sketching outings in the Hudson Valley. Cole was 43, an established landscape painter who championed the majesty of the American wilderness. Not only was their time together formative for Church, who became one of the most acclaimed artists of the 19th century, but it also cemented what would later be called the Hudson River School, the country’s first cohesive art movement.

headline: After Breach, JPMorgan Still Seeks to Determine Extent of Attack
abstract: Over two months, hackers gained entry to dozens of the bank’s servers, said three people with knowledge of the bank’s investigation into the episode.
lead_paragraph: The headache caused by the attack on JPMorgan Chase’s computer network this summer may not go away anytime soon.

headline: Europeans Bracing for Netflix
abstract: As Netflix prepares to start streaming in six European countries next week, some politicians and rival businesses there are assailing the company over issues like competition and taxes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Netflix poised to make its debut in six European countries next week, the expansion of that online streaming giant’s international territory is stirring a mix of anticipation, anxiety and “House of Cards”-style political intrigue.

headline: Anniversary Dinners for Relais & Châteaux
abstract: Relais & Châteaux, a network of more than 500 luxury hotels and restaurants, will observe its 60th anniversary with dinners in which chefs from around the world will collaborate.
lead_paragraph: Relais & Châteaux, a network of more than 500 luxury hotels and restaurants around the world, is celebrating its 60th anniversary with a series of more than 30 dinners throughout North America and the Caribbean.

headline: Melding Voice and Piano in Psychedelic Mysticism
abstract: Dawn Upshaw and Gilbert Kalish headlined a performance of George Crumb’s “Ancient Voices of Children” for Nonesuch Records’ 50th-anniversary celebration at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Dawn Upshaw turned her back to the audience and leaned over the uncovered strings of a grand piano at the beginning of the second half of Thursday evening’s concert at the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Steadying herself on the instrument’s frame with her hands, she bent over deeply and began to sing — cooing, pleading, beseeching sounds that grew more frantic and shrill until they sounded like curses and incantations. Refracted by the piano’s strings, echoes floated up from the instrument and hovered about her like an iridescent aura.

headline: Learning How to Exert Self-Control
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Children and Childhood', 'Research']
abstract: The researcher who became “the marshmallow man” for his work with children has some lessons for us all.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — NOT many Ivy League professors are associated with a type of candy. But Walter Mischel, a professor of psychology at Columbia, doesn’t mind being one of them.

headline: Immutable Truths in Shifting Octaves
abstract: The dark, slow and trenchant sound of Andy Bey will be at Cafe Noctambulo, a new club at Pangea in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: The bass-baritone voice of the jazz singer Andy Bey is elemental and complicated, a purr and a pushed-out moan, a compound of tones from different parts of his body.

headline: Iran’s Participation in Meeting to Aid Iraq Is ‘Not Appropriate,’ Says Kerry
abstract: The French hosts of a meeting to coordinate assistance to the Iraqi fight against Islamist militants have not ruled out Iran’s attendance, but the United States is arguing against the country’s inclusion.
