lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that “it would not be appropriate” for Iran to attend an international conference on the security crisis in Iraq that is to be held in Paris next week because of what he called the role that Iran’s paramilitary Quds Force is playing in the fighting in neighboring Syria.

headline: Met Opera Cuts 22 Nonunion Jobs, Mainly Through Layoffs
abstract: Three weeks after negotiating a deal for union pay cuts, the Metropolitan Opera is eliminating 22 of its 254 nonunion administrative jobs.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, which promised to match the pay cuts that its major unions agreed to last month with equivalent cuts to its nonunion payroll, said on Friday afternoon that it was eliminating 22 of its 254 administrative positions, mostly through layoffs.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Carnegie Hall Makes Room for Future Stars
abstract: A new education wing, built as part of a renovation that also includes a roof terrace, reflects Carnegie’s evolution from an old-line temple of music to something of a teacher of music.
lead_paragraph: The old joke held that the way to get to Carnegie Hall was to “practice, practice, practice.” Now musicians will have more places to practice once they get there: The scaffolding that has shrouded Carnegie for four years is coming down this week to reveal the hall’s new education wing, with new practice rooms, and a roof garden more than a century in the making.

headline: White House Photo Ops, Old School
abstract: Among other themes, “The Roosevelts: An Intimate History,” a 14-hour PBS documentary series, examines how Theodore and Franklin D. Roosevelt managed their images.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey C. Ward had to cut away from watching a presidential news conference to talk to a reporter about “The Roosevelts: An Intimate History,” the new Ken Burns documentary series he wrote.

headline: A Family Sedan for the Speedway
abstract: The 2015 Charger Hellcat will have the same supercharged 707-horsepower Hemi V8 found in the Challenger Hellcat and will be the most powerful sedan from any mainstream manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: Its wheelbase is 4.2 inches longer and it has two additional doors, but the Dodge Charger sedan is virtually a mechanical twin of the Challenger coupe. So it was straightforward enough to move the parts that turn a Challenger into a Hellcat over to the Charger. The 2015 Charger Hellcat, which arrives this fall at an expected price above $60,000, will be powered by the same supercharged 707-horsepower Hemi V8 found in the Challenger Hellcat.

headline: 4G Wireless in the Car: Speeding With Impunity
abstract: High-speed 4G wireless connections have come to the car, with Audi and G.M offering the service.
lead_paragraph: It’s not considered perverse to desire a vehicle that can go twice the legal speed limit. Do buyers want cars with faster Internet connections as well?

headline: An Original Dodge, Direct From the Founder’s Family
abstract: What makes this 1964 Dodge Custom 880 convertible so special are its remarkable owners, one of whom was a member of the Dodge family.
lead_paragraph: GROSSE POINTE SHORES, MICH. — A price guide for collector cars might tell you how much an all-original, option-packed, low-mileage 1964 Dodge Custom 880 convertible should sell for. What that book cannot tell you is the value added by the provenance of a particular car — its history of ownership and experiences.

headline: Sting of Guzzler Tax, Frozen for Decades, Fades
abstract: Despite increasingly challenging revisions to fuel-economy standards, fewer cars are incurring the gas-guzzler penalties stipulated by the Environmental Protection Agency.
lead_paragraph: Even the fastest, most powerful new cars can be classified as fuel-sipping stewards of the environment — by the federal government’s measure, anyway.

headline: Readers Respond: Becoming a Real Person
abstract: In comments, readers parsed David Brooks’s column about the role of higher education in moral development.
lead_paragraph: Have elite universities been so pared down to career academies that their future graduates won’t be titans, but zombies?

headline: Miley Cyrus, the Drag Queen Artist Milk and Other Faces from New York Fashion Week
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around New York City this week.

headline: The Way to Beat Poverty
abstract: We had been trying to help people in Zimbabwe and Cambodia, and then we found ourselves helpless to assist one of our daughter’s best friends.
lead_paragraph: AS our children were growing up, one of their playmates was a girl named Jessica. Our kids would disappear with Jessica to make forts, build a treehouse and share dreams. We were always concerned because — there’s no polite way to say this — Jessica was a mess.

headline: Palins Said to Be Involved in Brawl at Party in Alaska
abstract: The police in Anchorage are investigating reports of a “verbal and physical altercation” at the party last weekend.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — It began as a birthday party that drew local snowmobile racers, construction workers and other longtime Alaskans last Saturday night. It turned into a brawl with members of Sarah Palin’s family in the center of it, according to witnesses at the party.

headline: Nazi Saboteurs in the Amagansett Sands
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art', 'Sabotage (Crime)']
abstract: A new exhibition in East Hampton presents the details of a 1942 landing in Amagansett by four saboteurs and a young Coast Guardsman’s quick response.
lead_paragraph: It could have been just another quiet evening in Amagansett, but that changed dramatically after a 21-year-old Coast Guard seaman stumbled upon four suspicious-looking men hanging out on a beach during his regular late-night patrol.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Africa, Pakistan, Srinagar and Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, Pakistan, Srinagar and Liberia.

headline: Pearls Spotted All Over New York Fashion Week
abstract: Designers including Rodarte, Adam Selman and Joseph Altuzarra used the iridescent gemstone as a trimming in their collections.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the start of London Fashion Week, but editors can’t stop talking about the pearl trend from New York. Rodarte sent a model in a glistening dress with a net skirt and a pearl embellishment walking through its fantastical set of fluorescent lights and shattered Swarovski crystals. Adam Selman, who designed the infamous sheer dress Rihanna wore to the CFDA Awards, added the gemstone to many of the pieces in his rather sporty collection, like a boxy chambray top and shorts with a floating seam connected by pearls. And Joseph Altuzarra’s typically sexy, sharp collection included black dresses with pearls dangling from the trim.

headline: Chameleon and Lion Sample Songbook
abstract: “Cheek to Cheek,” the forthcoming album by Tony Bennett and Lady Gaga, represents the latest pop dalliance with the Great American Songbook.
lead_paragraph: Tony Bennett was waiting, in a Brioni tuxedo and an uncertain silence, onstage at Frederick P. Rose Hall in Manhattan. Moments earlier, he’d been singing the Tin Pan Alley tune “Goody Goody,” while Lady Gaga — polymorphic pop star, supersize cult hero and, for the moment, his co-headliner — muttered coquettish protestations from an enormous rocking chair, cartoon-chic in a pink cocktail dress, a wide-brim black hat and satiny opera gloves.

headline: For a Big Break, a Break From Ballet
abstract: In a mix of happenstance and connections, three members of New York City Ballet will soon perform in major musicals.
lead_paragraph: One morning this month, Megan Fairchild and her blue-ribbon ballet technique were the center of attention at a packed New York rehearsal. So far, so ordinary for a principal dancer with New York City Ballet — except that the rehearsal was taking place near Times Square and was open to the press. It was at the Lyric Theater, where Ms. Fairchild is to make her Broadway debut in a revival of “On the Town” that starts previews on Saturday.

headline: HSBC to Pay $550 Million to End Mortgage-Related Suit
abstract: HSBC agreed to settle a lawsuit by the F.H.F.A. over mortgage-backed securities it sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: HSBC agreed on Friday to pay $550 million to settle a lawsuit filed in 2011 by the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the federal regulator that oversees the government’s two mortgage finance companies, over troubled mortgage-backed securities sold in the lead-up to the financial crisis.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Boards of Directors', 'Brain', 'Discrimination', 'Hijacking', 'Magazines', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: The Weekly Wrap
abstract: Highlights from the past week on Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Insider highlights:

headline: Eternal Lovers, Chasing Their Happiness in a Harsh World
abstract: “Romeo & Juliet,” by Dances Patrelle, brings in dancers from Los Angeles Ballet for the starring roles.
lead_paragraph: In Dances Patrelle, a company led by the artistic director Francis Patrelle, a much-adored teacher, ballet is a circle of life. The cast of his “Romeo & Juliet,” currently enjoying a revival at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, pairs professional dancers — and not-too-shabby ones at that — with students. But a choreographer needs to be more than a nurturing spirit, and Mr. Patrelle’s long-winded “Romeo,” performed on Thursday, is not nearly as enduring as Shakespeare’s.

headline: Owner of Dozens of Newspapers Seeks Buyers
abstract: Digital First Media, a struggling collection of 76 daily newspapers and the nation’s second-largest newspaper company by circulation, has put itself up for sale.
lead_paragraph: Digital First Media, a struggling collection of 76 daily newspapers including The San Jose Mercury News, The Los Angeles Daily News, The Denver Post and The St. Paul Pioneer Press, has put itself up for sale.

headline: A Drink Before the Scottish Independence Vote
abstract: Even if the Scots vote to leave, the British will always have Scotch.
lead_paragraph: Will five million Scots vote to secede from Britain and form their own independent state? Or will 300 years of shared history and the likely turmoil of a transition lead them to stick with the union? Polls leading up to next week’s election have pointed to a close vote.

headline: Richard Schechner’s ‘Imagining O’
abstract: “Imagining O” meshes Shakespeare and “Story of O” at the Alexander Kasser Theater in Montclair, N.J.
lead_paragraph: “Imagining O” meshes Shakespeare and “Story of O” at the Alexander Kasser Theater in Montclair, N.J.

headline: Ophelia and Friends, Dominated but in Control
abstract: In “Imagining O,” Richard Schechner meshes Shakespeare with “Story of O,” depicting women as strong and defiant.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Tall and imposing in a long, strapless dress, a young man in a feathered mask towered behind the avant-garde director Richard Schechner, who was threatening his audience on Wednesday night. His exhilarating and erotic new production, “Imagining O,” was about to start.

headline: Cries of Gloom, Resignation and Heartbreak, Plus Faith
abstract: Among new releases are albums redefining soca; presenting Atlanta hip-hop with a foreboding strain; and offering some songwriting with disparate influences.
lead_paragraph: Bunji Garlin

headline: A Deal From the Cavendish Tournament
abstract: A diagramed deal from the Cavendish tournament in Monte Carlo last week.
lead_paragraph: The diagramed deal was my favorite from the Cavendish tournament in Monte Carlo last week. It was declared by Andrea Manno, a young Italian who lives in Palermo.

headline: Hurtling Bodies, Frozen in Time
abstract: “Stills,” a series of harrowing, six-and-a-half-foot-tall photographs depicting bodies falling from buildings was first created by the artist Sarah Charlesworth in 1980.
lead_paragraph: “Stills,” a series of harrowing, six-and-a-half-foot-tall photographs depicting bodies falling from buildings — often frozen in midair — was first created by the artist Sarah Charlesworth in 1980. Charlesworth, who died last year, was part of the so-called Pictures Generation, that group of artists who emerged in the 1970s and ’80s whose works often used existing images or carefully staged tableaus.

headline: A Visceral Fusion of Film and Music
abstract: For the second year, the New York Philharmonic eases back into a new season with “The Art of the Score: Film Week at the Philharmonic.”
lead_paragraph: For the second year, the New York Philharmonic eases back into a new season with “The Art of the Score: Film Week at the Philharmonic.” The fun begins with a program dedicated to the often-sensuous scores from Cinecittà, with “La Dolce Vita: The Music of Italian Cinema.” On Tuesday and Wednesday, the Philharmonic’s music director, Alan Gilbert, conducts excerpts from the soundtracks to classics like “La Dolce Vita,” “The Leopard” and “L’Eclisse.” The violinist Joshua Bell, the soprano Renée Fleming and the singer-songwriter Josh Groban join in. (7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, nyphil.org.)

headline: Past and Present, Dolefully United
abstract: Audiences in the United States get a rare opportunity to see the great Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien’s films on the big screen.
lead_paragraph: “The dead stay dead, but money’s real,” says a character in “Good Men, Good Women,” a 1995 film by the great Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien. Except in “Good Men,” the dead are like the past, tethered to the present in mournful, rapt communion. Audiences in the United States don’t get many opportunities to see Mr. Hou’s movies on the big screen, which makes the Museum of the Moving Image’s retrospective “Also Like Life: The Films of Hou Hsiao-hsien” (through Oct. 17), essential viewing.

headline: Frights That Tickle the Funny Bone
abstract: Tim and Eric, those early adapters of the short satirical video, serve up a new series, a “Twilight Zone” with a deadpan sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: Tim and Eric, those early adapters of the short satirical video, are still around, and in the Thursday-into-Friday Adult Swim block, they serve up a pretty amusing new series, a “Twilight Zone” with a deadpan sense of humor.

headline: A Family’s Rough Ride Through an American Era
abstract: Meryl Streep, Edward Herrmann and Paul Giamatti voice three famous Roosevelts in Ken Burns’s seven-part documentary.
lead_paragraph: “The Roosevelts: An Intimate History,” Ken Burns’s seven-part documentary about (sorry, Adamses, Kennedys, Clintons and Bushes) the most important political bloodline in American history, may constitute more than you really want to know about Theodore, Franklin and Eleanor. But look at it this way: If you commit to the whole series, which begins on Sunday on PBS, you’ll also be getting, at no extra charge, a survey of an amazingly transformative half-century that made the United States what it is today.

headline: Adapting Listerine to a Global Market
abstract: With products like Listerine Zero, popular where alcohol is forbidden, and Green Tea Listerine, big in Asia, Johnson & Johnson is trying to appeal to foreign tastes.
lead_paragraph: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J. — Walking into the Listerine “stink lab” is like stepping into a gigantic human mouth.

headline: Letter from Israel’s Unit 8200
abstract: In a letter sent to commanders and the prime minister, 43 veteran officers of a vaunted intelligence unit said they would refuse required reserve duty.
lead_paragraph: In a letter sent to commanders and the prime minister, 43 veteran officers of a vaunted intelligence unit said they would refuse required reserve duty.

headline: Prizes Without Passion
abstract: At the Toronto Film Festival, a focus on geniuses (played by Benedict Cumberbatch and Eddie Redmayne) and deranged heirs (Steve Carell).
lead_paragraph: It is hard to pinpoint the moment when the Academy Awards became more important than the movies. I’m exaggerating — maybe. The truth is that even those of us who loathe this race can find it tough to resist. That’s why, at the Toronto International Film Festival, after watching Benedict Cumberbatch play Alan Turing in “The Imitation Game,” I found myself pulled into the Oscar guessing game, as helpless as an addict trying and failing to go clean.

headline: N.F.L. Rocked Again as Adrian Peterson Faces a Child Abuse Charge
abstract: Peterson, a star running back for the Minnesota Vikings, has been charged in a child abuse inquiry in Montgomery County, Tex., involving his son.
lead_paragraph: A warrant for the arrest of Adrian Peterson, one of the National Football League’s top stars, was issued Friday after he was charged in a child abuse investigation in Texas, the latest criminal case to rock the country’s most popular sport.

headline: A Week of Dan Barber’s Aprons
abstract: Worn by the chef from July 29 to Aug. 4 while cooking at his two restaurants, Blue Hill in Manhattan and Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Worn by the chef from July 29 to Aug. 4 while cooking at his two restaurants, Blue Hill in Manhattan and Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

headline: Fed Rallies New Team to Forestall Next Crisis
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A committee headed by Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer will oversee the work of the Office of Financial Stability Policy and Research and help the bank set the pace of its retreat from economic stimulus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stanley Fischer, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, will lead a new internal committee focused on threats to financial stability, the Fed said on Friday.

headline: G.M. Stops Some Corvette Sales Over Air Bags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The automaker will fix driver’s side air bags in about 2,000 Corvettes because they could separate from their steering wheels.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has told car dealers to stop delivery of certain 2015 Chevrolet Corvettes because they may have faulty air bags and parking brake cables. The automaker will fix driver’s side air bags in about 2,000 Corvettes because they could separate from their steering wheels. Another 800 Corvettes, most of which are at dealerships, are being held back from buyers because they may have been built with defective rear parking brake cables, increasing the risk that parked cars could roll away. Automotive News reported that G.M. was issuing two additional recalls for the vehicles, according to the stop-sales orders sent to dealers, but neither has been publicly announced. Alan Adler, a G.M. spokesman, would not confirm them.

headline: Nevada Woos Tesla Plant in Tax Deal, but Economic Benefits Prompt Debate
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A crucial issue is that whenever a state offers an incentive for a company to build a factory, the economic stimulus is rarely concentrated in the surrounding area.
lead_paragraph: When Nevada lured Tesla Motors to the Reno area to build a giant battery factory, a triumphant governor, Brian Sandoval, proclaimed that every dollar his state was spending in tax incentives and other subsidies would yield $80 in economic activity.

headline: The Process Behind the Painting
abstract: One thing highlighted at the beginning of “Rothko to Richter: Mark-Making in Abstract Painting from the Collection of Preston H. Haskell,” in Princeton, is that our concept of traditional art history has changed.
lead_paragraph: It has been over a hundred years since abstraction was adopted in Western painting, and we’re still trying to make sense of it. Despite the rather clunky subtitle and the fact that the exhibition is drawn from a single collection, “Rothko to Richter: Mark-Making in Abstract Painting from the Collection of Preston H. Haskell” offers an excellent, compact survey of some of the key arguments.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Edge in House Elections
abstract: Readers react to an article analyzing why Democrats can’t take control of the House.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Coal’s Price Tag, in Toxic Emissions and Disease
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Respiratory System', 'Law and Legislation', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The Citizens Climate Lobby and the Union of Concerned Scientists respond to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: J.W. Anderson on His 10 Most Prized Possessions
abstract: The Northern Irish designer, who shows his spring/summer 2015 collection at London Fashion Week tomorrow, shares with T his photographs and words about his favorite things at his home.
lead_paragraph: In the six years since founding his label J.W. Anderson, the Northern Irish designer Jonathan Anderson has emerged as one of fashion’s leading lights. His cerebral collections — the newest of which will debut at London Fashion Week tomorrow — were recently anointed by an investment from LVMH. And his new role as the creative director of the venerable Spanish house Loewe has granted him membership to fashion’s most elite club: the small set of designers responsible for not one, but two, labels (Karl Lagerfeld, Alexander Wang).

headline: Nutrition for the Elderly
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Elderly', 'Malnutrition', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: The National Association of Nutrition and Aging Services Programs responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,331 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,331 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Access to College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Lynn Pasquerella, the president of Mount Holyoke College, responds to an Upshot article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: On Long Island, a Worthy Plan for Coastal Flooding
abstract: Steve Bellone, the Suffolk County (N.Y.) executive, responds to an Op-Ed article, “A Beach Project Built on Sand.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Is What an Abortion Looks Like
abstract: We need to stop competing to tell the saddest story.
lead_paragraph: DENTON, Tex. — I MET Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator and Democratic candidate for governor, for the first time last week, and I told her how much it meant to me that she wasn’t afraid to talk about abortion. But we need a much larger conversation about abortion — one that also includes, without prejudice, the stories unlikely to generate much sympathy. Stories like mine.

headline: Detained, Beaten and Tortured by Separatists in Donetsk Ordeal
abstract: Extrajudicial detentions have become commonplace in eastern Ukraine, where one man says his brutal ordeal ended only when his abductors realized they might have the wrong man.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — FOR months as this region slipped deeper into war, with armed gunmen on patrol and artillery shells slamming into the regional capital daily, Aleksandr and his wife, Olga, had learned to take precautions. With people disappearing from the streets every week, they usually went everywhere together, and when apart kept in constant touch by cellphone.

headline: This Art Is Indeed Long (66 Feet). And Very Heavy (About 12 Tons).
abstract: “Points of View,” three large bronze towers by the artist Tony Cragg, all 66 feet and 12 tons of it, was installed in Madison Square Park in Manhattan on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Brooke Kamin Rapaport, the curator who shepherded an art world set piece in Madison Square Park on Friday, called what was being installed “the great levitating sculpture.”

headline: New York Fashion Week Isn’t All About the Clothes: Best of the After-Parties
abstract: Here are our highlights from the parties at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Here are our highlights from the parties at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Years of Single-Minded Devotion Begin to Pay Off
abstract: Chris Kirk developed an intense focus on golf before he was a teenager, and now he is tied for second after two rounds of the Tour Championship.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Chris Kirk was celebrating a baseball title with his teammates when he startled his father, who was also his coach, by saying: “Dad, this is the coolest thing ever. It’s a good time to end my baseball career.”

headline: Where a Sip of Whisky Usually Cures All, a Secession Vote Proves Bitter
abstract: As the referendum on Scotland nears, tensions are growing on Islay, where many residents worry their community will be deeply and enduringly fractured.
lead_paragraph: ISLAY, Scotland — On Islay, an island with a population of around 3,000, disagreements have never run deep. The last big dispute goes back more than two decades; it involved the conservation of an indigenous butterfly.

headline: Inmate’s Death in Overheated Rikers Cell Is Ruled Accidental
abstract: The ruling by the New York City medical examiner in the case of a mentally ill veteran who died in an overheated cell at Rikers Island raises questions of culpability in the case.
lead_paragraph: The death of a mentally ill veteran in an overheated cell at Rikers Island this year was accidental, the New York City medical examiner’s office ruled on Friday in a case that drew scrutiny to abusive conditions at the jail complex.

headline: Mistrust Lingers as Ferguson Takes New Tack on Fines
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Police', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: The trust level was not high in court and at the police clerk’s window in Ferguson, Mo., this week as municipal penalties were scaled back in an effort to repair the city’s frayed relationship with the black community.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — There were lots of jitters at the Ferguson police clerk’s window this week, as steady streams of drivers with unpaid traffic tickets and pending arrest warrants turned themselves in as part of a new city initiative to repair its frayed relationship with black residents.

headline: The Top 10 Moments from Spring/Summer 2015 New York Fashion Week
abstract: From Hood by Air’s canine catwalker to Rihanna in the front row, a roundup of memorable happenings both on and off the runways.
lead_paragraph: T’s senior market editor rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

headline: Embrace of Social Media Aids Flood Victims in Kashmir
abstract: Social media companies, government agencies and still-connected individuals have cooperated to help locate some 12,000 people amid the flooding and communications difficulties.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — Early this week, as the flooding in Kashmir was entering a new and terrifying phase, the Indian Army’s public information office received a call from Raheel Khursheed, a former journalist and digital obsessive who serves as the director of news, politics and government at Twitter India. He had a proposal.

headline: Doctor Who Worked on Joan Rivers Steps Down From Post at Medical Clinic
abstract: Dr. Lawrence B. Cohen, who performed an endoscopy on Joan Rivers before she went into cardiac arrest, is no longer acting as the medical director or doing procedures at Yorkville Endoscopy.
lead_paragraph: The doctor who performed an endoscopy on Joan Rivers before she went into cardiac arrest has stepped down as medical director of the Manhattan clinic where she was treated and he is no longer doing procedures there, the clinic announced on Friday.

headline: Social Worker Spreads a Message of Acceptance to Mormons With Gay Children
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Caitlin Ryan, a California social worker, developed a program that uses supportive meetings, videos, handbooks and research to help Mormon families accept their gay children.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Late on election night in 2008, Caitlin Ryan sat in her apartment here, cat in her lap, computer at her side, watching the results on television. Sometime after Barack Obama was declared president, briefly lifting her mood, she saw the news she had been dreading: Proposition 8 was going to win, striking down same-sex marriage in California.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 6 Georgia takes on No. 24 South Carolina in an early-season rivalry game and No. 12 U.C.L.A. faces Texas this weekend.
lead_paragraph: 6 GEORGIA

headline: Friday Night Music: Cheryl Wheeler
abstract: A bit of beauty to end a hard week.
lead_paragraph: For some reason I’ve been taking a music trip down memory lane, back to the late 80s, when I was listening a lot to several singer-songwriters — Suzanne Vega, Shawn Colvin, Patty Griffin, and Cheryl Wheeler; this song is as gorgeous as I remembered:

headline: The New Look
abstract: Fashion can be an incubator of ideas, and men’s fashion is currently shifting our thinking, altering how we view ourselves and our world.
lead_paragraph: While many men care about what they wear — the style, cut, fabric and even maker of their clothing — few would claim to be followers of “men’s fashion,” a term that seems like an oxymoron to most. Yet today’s slimmer jackets, tighter shirts and straighter-legged pants — even your naked ankles — are the distinct sartorial fallout of the designs that trekked down the runways of New York and Paris over a decade ago. Think trickle-down economics, but for fashion. You could likely trace the ancestral lineage of the clothes in your closet to their radical progenitors: Raf Simons, Hedi Slimane for Dior Homme or Thom Browne.

headline: New Sanctions to Stall Exxon’s Arctic Oil Plans
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: The United States government took aim at Exxon’s project in the Arctic Ocean, ordering American companies to cut off exports to Russian oil exploration within 14 days.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Exxon Mobil’s ambitions in Russia appear to have been dashed, at least until the Ukraine crisis is resolved.

headline: Professor’s Angry Tweets on Gaza Cost Him a Job
abstract: The University of Illinois rescinded a job offer to a professor over concerns about the tenor of his criticism of Israel’s Gaza offensive on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: The trustees of the University of Illinois voted on Thursday to block the appointment of Steven Salaita, a Palestinian-American professor who had been offered a tenured position last year, following a campaign by pro-Israel students, faculty members and donors who contended that his Twitter comments on the bombardment of Gaza this summer were anti-Semitic.

headline: When Fighting Fires Becomes Something Else
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: When answering calls, firefighters don’t expect to find murder victims, but sometimes they do, as in a recent Queens murder-suicide.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters from two houses in SoHo, Engine 55 and Ladder Company 20, rushed to Henry Street in Chinatown one June morning two years ago. Smoke filled a ground-floor apartment.

headline: Both Sides Cite Urgency in Court Appeal of a Texas Law on Abortion Clinics
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'State Legislatures', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Judges for a federal appellate court heard arguments over a Texas law that could lead to the closing of more than a dozen abortion clinics.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In March, a federal appeals court here gave Texas Republicans and anti-abortion groups a major victory in their legal battle to enforce the tough new abortion law that the Legislature passed last year, upholding one contested part of it as constitutional.

headline: Government Push for Yahoo’s User Data Set Stage for Broad Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Documents from the case paint a vivid portrait of the high-stakes battle that pitted Yahoo against some top officials in the Bush administration over what was legitimate gathering of foreign intelligence and what was illegal snooping.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s hard to fathom after a year of revelations about widespread government surveillance of Internet users, but in 2007, the government’s authority to demand such data from technology companies without a search warrant was very much in doubt.

headline: The Man in the Middle for the Nittany Lions
abstract: How Coach James Franklin handles being the most visible face of Penn State’s football program will probably test him far more than anything on the field will.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — At 6 a.m., Penn State’s campus is quiet, other than sleepy students staggering out of the library and a few joggers. The stoplights are not activated yet, so James Franklin can drive from his house to the Lasch Football Building in about four minutes.

headline: Ex-President of Haiti Put Under House Arrest
abstract: Jean-Bertrand Aristide was placed on house arrest in a corruption investigation, an order protested by his supporters whom claimed there was no provision in Haitian law for such a penalty.
lead_paragraph: The deteriorating political climate in Haiti took an unusual and confusing turn this week when Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the twice-exiled former president of Haiti, was ordered by a court not to leave his home as part of a corruption investigation.

headline: Ohio: Answers Sought in Prison Break
keywords: ['Prison Escapes', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'School Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: T. J. Lane, a 19-year-old serving life in prison for killing three students in a school cafeteria in 2012, was transferred with two other inmates to a maximum-security prison on Friday after briefly escaping a lower-security site, the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction said.
lead_paragraph: T. J. Lane, a 19-year-old serving life in prison for killing three students in a school cafeteria in 2012, was transferred with two other inmates to a maximum-security prison on Friday after briefly escaping a lower-security site, the Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Correction said. They were moved to the Ohio State Penitentiary in Youngstown, a day after they climbed a fence and escaped a prison in Lima, setting off a nine-hour search. The agency said it was investigating details, including a report that guards warned prison officials about an escape plot, and a panel is expected to make recommendations about improving prison procedures.

headline: Plea Deal for Ex-Police Officer in Huge Disability Scheme
abstract: In return for a reduced sentence, John Minerva, a retired New York City police officer, agreed to testify against former colleagues.
lead_paragraph: A retired police officer, described by prosecutors as a ringleader in a huge scheme to defraud the Social Security Administration, pleaded guilty on Friday and agreed to testify against his former colleagues in return for a reduced sentence.

headline: Don’t Throw the Bums Out
abstract: How grumbling about politicians in fact makes Washington worse.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — WHEN Mark Twain snarled that politicians were “dust-licking pimps,” millions of furious Gilded Age citizens agreed. Millions more would today. There is a bipartisan consensus that our leaders are fools, a collective feeling in a long tradition of grumbling about American politicians. The problem, as Twain’s generation discovered, is that blaming all politicians makes it harder to throw out the real bums.

headline: The Homework Squabbles
abstract: Specialists answer a speed round of questions on how parents should best approach the after-school task.
lead_paragraph: Homework has a branding problem. Or, to be a little less pointy-headed about it, everybody hates homework.

headline: Barbra Streisand, a Voice to Be Reckoned With
abstract: Ms. Streisand uses her still formidable pipes to sing duets or to riff on current affairs.
lead_paragraph: Barbra Streisand is very excited about the new iPhone. She thinks “The Goldfinch” is good, but not quite the masterpiece it’s being hailed as. She can’t get enough of “The Americans,” is ambivalent about “Boyhood,” and thinks there are too many action movies these days, although she enjoyed “Guardians of the Galaxy.”

headline: Bob Crewe, Songwriter for Frankie Valli and Four Seasons, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Crewe, who wrote for other music acts as well, was perhaps best known for “Can’t Take My Eyes Off You,” a No. 1 hit for Mr. Valli.
lead_paragraph: Bob Crewe, who helped create a parade of indelible pop music hits, most notably for Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons, including “Sherry,” “Walk Like a Man,” “Rag Doll” and Mr. Valli’s soaring anthem of adoration “Can’t Take My Eyes Off You,” died on Thursday in Scarborough, Me. He was 83.

headline: At SoulCycle Tribeca, The Spinning Stops; Panic Ensues
abstract: Renovations at the flagship studio disrupt schedules and upset clients.
lead_paragraph: In an email last week, Monet Berger received some upsetting news. “I nearly cried when I read it,” Ms. Berger said. “My heart sank.”

headline: Inside the T Men’s Fall Fashion Issue
abstract: The issue checks in with an eclectic mix of guys who are pursuing their passions.
lead_paragraph: T’s fall men’s fashion issue celebrates guys who pursue their passions. On the cover is the young English actor Jack O’Connell, whose electric performances and rough-and-tumble ways have him perched on the cusp of stardom — if he can only keep it together long enough to reach the potential that many, like his “Unbroken” director Angelina Jolie, see in him. René Redzepi, owner of one of the world’s top-ranked restaurant, Noma, is a closet taco fanatic, so Jeff Gordinier follows the Scandinavian chef to Mexico in search of bold new flavors and, possibly, the next big thing in food. We travel to the rural Connecticut estate of the Picasso biographer John Richardson, which deftly mixes high and low, refined and roguish, the tasteful and the gaudy. Elsewhere, T pays a visit to the NBA’s finishing school for rookies, where draftees receive advice on fashion, sex and table manners, and are taught to repeat the mantra “I don’t want to go broke”; Marin Hopper remembers the way her father, the actor Dennis Hopper, found spiritual reckoning — and plenty of good parties — in Taos, N. M.; Alex Fury sounds off on a men’s wear moment that is, at long last, challenging notions about sexuality, power and gender politics; and Jody Rosen travels to a sprawling forensics lab in hippie Oregon to investigate the $19 billion trade in illegal wildlife, which has ties to the Russian mob and Islamic extremists. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Atlanta Hawks G.M. Danny Ferry Takes Leave Over Racial Remarks
abstract: Ferry will take what the Hawks called an indefinite leave of absence after disparaging remarks he made about the African-born British player Luol Deng came to light.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Before this week, General Manager Danny Ferry was widely appreciated for restoring hope among Atlanta Hawks followers with a makeover of the roster and coaching staff in only two seasons on the job.

headline: Rainbow Sheens and a Tip Draw a Focus to Dumping in Newtown Creek
abstract: Neighbors noticed oil slicks on the surface of the murky waterway between Brooklyn and Queens this summer, and authorities have identified a potential culprit.
lead_paragraph: Whoever was dumping oil into Newtown Creek this summer may have assumed that nobody would notice, given that the murky waterway between Brooklyn and Queens had been forsaken for so long.

headline: Candidates Playing Possum
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Control of the Senate hinges on the outcome of just a few close races. Which candidates will show up and debate their opponents?
lead_paragraph: Election season! Tension mounts! Longtime public servants are aware that the least little slip and they could be out the door. Forced, like ousted House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, to labor in the sweatshops of the investment banking industry.

headline: Lawmaker Assails Foreign Donations to Think Tanks
keywords: ['Think Tanks', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Representative Frank R. Wolf wrote a letter to the Brookings Institution this week saying that think tanks that provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking donations from some foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prominent Washington think tanks that routinely provide Congress with policy advice should refrain from taking foreign government donations, particularly from nations like Qatar that have been associated with financing extremist groups, a senior House lawmaker wrote this week in a letter to the president of the Brookings Institution.

headline: U.S. Scientists See Long Fight Against Ebola
abstract: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more and could infect hundreds of thousands, say scientists mapping its spread for the American government.
lead_paragraph: The deadly Ebola outbreak sweeping across three countries in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more, much longer than anticipated, and could infect hundreds of thousands of people before it is brought under control, say scientists mapping its spread for the federal government.

headline: N.F.L. Stands By Its Leader
abstract: Roger Goodell is very good at doing exactly what his owners want.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, the year Roger Goodell was named commissioner of the National Football League, the Washington Redskins were the most valuable team in football, according to Forbes magazine, with a valuation of $1.4 billion. Washington’s revenue that year was $303 million, with profits of more than $108 million. In second place came the New England Patriots, valued by Forbes at $1.18 billion, followed by the Dallas Cowboys at $1.17 billion.

headline: Liberian President Pleads With Obama for Assistance in Combating Ebola
abstract: Liberia’s president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, warned that without American assistance, the Ebola epidemic could send the country into the civil chaos that enveloped it for two decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The president of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, has implored President Obama for help in managing her country’s rapidly expanding Ebola crisis and has warned that without American assistance the disease could send Liberia into the civil chaos that enveloped the country for two decades.

headline: A Showdown on the Pay Gap
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Unjust disparities in pay have an insidious ripple effect.
lead_paragraph: Closing the persistent wage gap between men and women is important, not only as a matter of fairness but as a matter of rudimentary family economics: Women are the primary or co-breadwinner in more than 60 percent of American families. That makes it all the more urgent to address the conspicuous discrepancy that sees a woman working full-time making 77 cents on average against $1 for a man working full-time.

headline: Ray Rice Case Draws Attention to a Crime Often Obscured
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Football', 'Law and Legislation', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Many thought Rice received preferential treatment by prosecutors after punching his fiancée, but in most cases, domestic assaults do not lead to jail time.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — To many who viewed the video of the N.F.L. star Ray Rice assaulting his fiancée in the elevator of a casino here, the contrast between the viciousness of his attack and the leniency of his legal punishment was both baffling and infuriating.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Mr. Bratton Reverses to Go Forward
abstract: The New York City police commissioner has acknowledged that the culture of his department needs changing.
lead_paragraph: Police Commissioner William Bratton appeared before the New York City Council on Monday and gave a master class in the art of defusing conflict and the deft reversal. Sitting before Council members who have sharply criticized the Police Department’s focus on petty offenders, the “broken windows” strategy that many say culminated in the brutal arrest that killed Eric Garner on Staten Island in July, Mr. Bratton more or less ceded the point.

headline: Obama Sees Iraq Resolution as a Legal Basis for Airstrikes, Official Says
keywords: ['War Powers Act (1973)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president has cited an earlier authorization by Congress as a basis for his campaign against ISIS.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House believes that Congress’s 2002 authorization of the Iraq war — and not just the 2001 authorization to fight Al Qaeda — provides a legal justification for President Obama’s air campaign against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Obama administration said Friday.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Social Media', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Michael Kors was the most tweeted-about designer over the course of New York Fashion Week, easily beating Ralph Lauren and Alexander Wang.

headline: The Sluggish Fight Against Ebola
abstract: American and other efforts are not moving fast enough to keep up with the increasing infection and death rates.
lead_paragraph: Efforts by the United States, other nations and international organizations to curb the widening epidemic of Ebola in West Africa are falling short — too little help arriving too late. The World Health Organization estimates that as many as 20,000 people could be infected over the course of the outbreak. President Obama has called the epidemic a “national security priority” and pledged to use American military assets to help the beleaguered countries, primarily Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, to bring the epidemic under control. The Agency for International Development and the Defense Department are already rushing personnel and supplies to the scene.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Permits Wisconsin Voter ID Law
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Identification Devices', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Elections']
abstract: The order was a blow to opponents of such requirements, who had been heartened by a lower court’s finding that the law had abridged citizens’ right to vote.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A federal appeals court on Friday permitted Wisconsin to restore a requirement that voters provide photo identification before casting their ballots, allowing the long-debated state law to take effect in time for a hard-fought election on Nov. 4.

headline: André Balazs, the Man Who Holds the Keys

lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a low-ceilinged room in the basement of the Chiltern Firehouse hotel, down the hall from the restrooms and smoking alcove, 12 reservationists work the phones full time, mainly saying “no.”

lead_paragraph: Representative Mark Sanford, whose extramarital affair destroyed his marriage, roiled South Carolina politics and gave new meaning to the phrase “hiking the Appalachian Trail,” turned to Facebook on Friday to announce the breakup of his engagement to the Argentine woman he once called his soul mate.

headline: Veiled Criticism for France as Ministers Stress Eurozone Stability

lead_paragraph: MILAN — The rule book for the stability of the euro came under strain Friday at a meeting of finance ministers after France warned this past week that it would miss its deficit target again.

lead_paragraph: A police officer and a paramedic testified on Friday that when they entered the hotel room of a woman accused of murdering her son, she was awake and coherent, on the floor next to a bed where her 8-year-old son lay dead.

headline: Donald Sinden, British Actor of Stage and Screen for 60 Years, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Sinden appeared in “Mogambo,” was nominated for a Tony for his role in Alan Bennett’s “Habeas Corpus,” and starred in long-running British television comedies.
lead_paragraph: Donald Sinden, a British actor whose versatility and deep, resonant voice kept him steadily employed on stage, screen and television for more than 60 years, died on Friday at his home in Kent, England. He was 90.

headline: Facing Perilous Fights, Obama Turns to History and Donors
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Anthems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: President Obama commemorated the 200th anniversary of the British bombardment that inspired the lyrics to “The Star-Spangled Banner” on Friday, before he was promptly plunged into today’s problems.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Peering at an aging manuscript — with the ramparts of Fort McHenry, its ever-present American flag, and the gleaming waters of Chesapeake Bay just outside — President Obama came here Friday to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the British bombardment that inspired the lyrics to “The Star-Spangled Banner.”

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Agrees to New Drug Policies
abstract: The union approved new rules on substance abuse and performance-enhancing drugs. The league, however, said the proposed deal had “significant unresolved issues.”
lead_paragraph: After years of bickering, the N.F.L. Players Association unanimously approved new policies on substance abuse and performance-enhancing drugs on Friday, paving the way for an overhaul of a program that dates to 2006.

headline: Latest Development: A Role on Broadway
abstract: An après-theater supper with Michael Cera, a star of “This Is Our Youth.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Cera visited the Plaza Hotel for the first time last week.

headline: The Mechanics of Homework
abstract: Right now, homework is feeling like an instrument of torture designed to destroy my relationship with my children. But we go through this every September. It will get better.
lead_paragraph: The homework wars among education wonks, teachers and parents don’t, as my friend and colleague Bruce Feiler writes in “The Homework Squabbles,” his This Life column for Sunday Styles, matter much on the scale at which most families are dealing with homework. To us, the question of how valuable homework is has to be set aside daily in the name of the backpacks, folders, binders and worksheets full of the stuff that our children actually bring home. And it’s worth noting that this idea of “too much homework” as a national problem is a myth. Instead, homework is something of an ironic twist in the American inequality story, with the more pressing problem being with the children who have too little rather than those who have too much.

headline: Simone Rocha, Born to Fashion, Makes Her Own Mark
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Since introducing her first collection in 2010, she has in short order become one of the highlights of London Fashion Week.

headline: Paper Job
abstract: Josh Knapp delivers a tough Saturday brain-twister.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I chose the headline for today’s post because it made me mist up a bit. Cluing COLUMNIST as “Paper job” is very clever, but a reminder for those of us who make a living writing that the print side of publishing is on its knees, if we’re going to be charitable. Whether it can be saved or whether it will stick around as an archaic reminder of the golden days of publishing is a question I will leave for better minds than mine.

headline: Clinton Silent on 2016 Bid as Campaign-Style Actions Begin to Speak Volumes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton has said that she will decide next year whether to undertake a presidential campaign. But the Clinton operation is already quietly laying the groundwork for a candidacy.
lead_paragraph: She is building stamina through tough new workouts with a personal trainer and yoga. She is talking about how to address income inequality without alienating corporate America. And she is reviewing who’s who in the Democratic Party in Iowa, a crucial early voting state in the presidential cycle.

headline: Cosimo Matassa, Whose Studio Created a Rock ’n’ Roll Sound, Dies at 88
abstract: Recording performers like Little Richard and Fats Domino as if they were playing for live audiences, Mr. Matassa was an engineer who became known for “the New Orleans sound.”
lead_paragraph: Cosimo Matassa, whose used-record business in New Orleans led him to sell new records, which led him to open a tiny studio that helped jump-start rock ’n’ roll by recording early hits by the likes of Fats Domino and Little Richard, died on Thursday in New Orleans. He was 88.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) DALLAS BUYERS CLUB (2013) A fiercely gaunt Matthew McConaughey, in an Oscar-winning role, portrays Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after learning in 1985 that he is H.I.V. -positive, decides to treat himself by hunting down medication not then legal in the United States. Eventually, he begins a subscription service, selling contraband medicines for a monthly fee. Jared Leto (above left, with Mr. McConaughey), in another Oscar-winning performance, plays the transgendered Rayon, who becomes Ron’s business partner. And Jennifer Garner is the doctor who, after initially opposing the plan, turns into an ally. What is largely missing from this drama, directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and inspired by real events, “is the sense that Ron’s efforts are part of a larger movement,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Ron’s bravery and determination are entirely credible, thanks to Mr. McConaughey’s disciplined, high-spirited performance and the filmmakers’ interest in the complexity of the character. But his actions unfold in something of a vacuum.” He added, “There is warmth and intelligence here, and undeniable sincerity, but also a determination, in the face of much painful and fascinating history, to play it safe.”
