headline: Bill Cunningham | New York Fashion Week
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Dresses', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Though much of the designers’ offerings were special-occasion clothes, their audience spoke loudly that the shirt, in all its manifestations, should triumph.
lead_paragraph: There are holes for the head, the arms and the legs. But it is what the designers create around those holes that mesmerizes the audience. The New York spring fashion collections ended Thursday night. Though much of the designers’ offerings were special-occasion clothes, their audience spoke loudly that the shirt, in all its manifestations, should triumph. Donna Karan showed a spectacular cocktail shirtdress. Ralph Lauren dramatized it for an evening gala. The newest development is the exaggerated cuff, often covering the hand, which Michael Kors dramatized. Jenna Lyons, the designer for J. Crew, polished it all off with the proportion and balance of the shirt to the rest of the ensemble. Even the daily look of the top French Vogue editors was plaid or denim shirts with faded jeans. If women of the 21st century are to compete in business with men, they cannot continue to dress as decorative symbols of a husband’s success. How they dress for private events is today’s art of fashion.

headline: From White Knight to Thief
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', "Great Depression (1930's)"]
abstract: Wall Street crime, 1930s style: the astonishing downfall of the financier Richard Whitney, who helped shore up the market at the start of the ’29 crash.
lead_paragraph: In August 1941, Richard Whitney, the former financier and New York Stock Exchange president, emerged from prison at Sing Sing, on parole after serving three years of a five- to 10-year sentence for grand larceny.

headline: Cars to Park and Hills to Climb
abstract: A district manager for a valet parking service also participates in Paralympics events — and is in training to climb Mount Kilimanjaro.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Edwards, 39, is a district manager for Towne Park, a national company that manages valet parking and other hospitality services for hotels, health care facilities and other businesses.

headline: Jeers and Cheers Over Tax Inversions
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A basic question is lost in the hubbub of companies’ moves abroad: What to do when corporate tax revenue falls?
lead_paragraph: General Electric began selling toasters to Americans 109 years ago but that homey relationship is ending. Last Monday, G.E. said it was selling its entire appliance division to a foreign company, Electrolux of Sweden, for $3.3 billion.

headline: Susan Story of American Water: A Job Description Is Just the Start
abstract: A chief executive says that throughout her career, she has always seen part of her work as “looking around for what’s not getting done that would bring value.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Susan Story, chief executive of American Water, the utility company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Looking Another Culture in the Eye
abstract: How to communicate in a global workplace? It takes skill — and an abundance of flexibility.
lead_paragraph: I was born and raised in Minnesota, but as an adult I have mostly lived in Europe and Africa. I teach cross-cultural management at the international business school Insead, near Paris. For the last 15 years, I’ve studied how people in different parts of the world build trust, communicate, make decisions and perceive situations differently, especially in the workplace.

headline: Caesars’ Debt: A Game of Dealer’s Choice
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Casinos']
abstract: Caesars Entertainment offered some of its debt holders an attractive deal — and other holders are angry about the implications.
lead_paragraph: The house always wins. That’s worth remembering when you’re in a casino. It also seems to be true for some people who hold Caesars Entertainment debt.

headline: If a Company Won’t Talk, Its Former Employees Will
abstract: Conn’s, the Texas-based chain, long resisted speaking with the Haggler over a customer’s complaint. But former workers, and another customer, were willing to talk about sales practices.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Sibling: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Smartphones: The Corporate Personality Test
abstract: The smartphone offerings of Apple, Amazon, Microsoft and Samsung have a lot to say about the companies’ approach to most everything.
lead_paragraph: It was a big week for smartphones. Apple unveiled two new iPhones — as well as a new smartwatch, which you can think of as a phone for your wrist. Amazon slashed the price of its new phone, and Microsoft, searching for new applications and content for its own struggling mobile platform, sought to acquire the company behind the blockbuster game Minecraft. What can we glean about these three companies — and a fourth, Samsung — from their smartphones?

headline: Battle of the Marne Was Foreseen as Decisive
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Battle of the Marne in 1914 was foreseen as decisive by the French and German generals.
lead_paragraph: On September 6, the General Commander-in-Chief of the French Armies, General Joffre addressed the following order of the day to his troops :

headline: Why the Economic Gender Gap Will Eventually Close
abstract: Research shows real differences in men’s and women’s economic behavior, but suggests more equitable times to come.
lead_paragraph: Debates over the supposed differences between men and women are a staple of pop culture. But two new books offer an economic look at the evidence, giving support to both pessimistic and optimistic perspectives on the direction of gender relations and the prospects for more fairness and equality.

headline: Bracing for Change on Scotland’s Border, Whatever the Referendum Result
abstract: Polls show that the referendum on Scottish independence will be close, and people in England’s northernmost town fear that life will never be the same again — even if Scots vote to stay in the union.
lead_paragraph: BERWICK-UPON-TWEED, England — This is England’s northernmost town, and it has changed hands between the Scots and the English more than a dozen times in the last 1,400 years. It hasn’t been a true border outpost since the unification of the two countries more than 300 years ago, but it may soon become one again.

headline: Battling a Neighbor’s Runoff
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Plumbing', 'Cooperatives', 'Noise']
abstract: This week’s subjects include basement flooding, a music loving dog and a co-op building’s rumor mill.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Phoebe English, London’s Newest Designer to Watch, on Her Hometown Haunts
abstract: The young Brit, who presents her spring 2015 collection today, shares her favorite places to eat, drink, unwind and get inspired.
lead_paragraph: Bulletproof vests, smashed cliffs, bleak winter beaches and Victorian mirrors are just a few of the references the British fashion designer Phoebe English draws on in her work. Since graduating three years ago from the master’s program at Central Saint Martins, where she studied under the legendary professor Louise Wilson, the young designer has sought to translate abstract ideas into wearable garments, allowing a certain haunting rawness to linger on the surface. Her collections — which Dover Street Market has carried since her debut in 2011 — feature details such as exposed net pockets, unfinished hems and fabrics that appear turned inside-out. For spring/summer 2015, which she will present today, English collaborated with the London-based print designer and illustrator Helen Bullock and played with the idea of “shedding skin, doubles and built-up surfaces,” she says.

headline: Acapulco Tries a Rewind to Its Jet Set Days
abstract: A big, new resort might represent a reversal of Acapulco’s reputation as a drug-gang crime center.
lead_paragraph: A new 814-room hotel in Acapulco, a historic coastal resort beset by bad publicity stemming from Mexico’s drug wars, is the latest sign of a comeback for the city.

headline: How Likely Is It That Birth Control Could Let You Down?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Charts of probabilities of unintended pregnancy while using different contraception methods, for up to 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Charts of probabilities of unintended pregnancy while using different contraception methods, for up to 10 years.

headline: Beyond Marriage
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Parenting', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Families and Family Life', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: We need to develop a new ethic of responsible parenthood.
lead_paragraph: MARRIAGE is disappearing. More than 40 percent of new mothers are unmarried. Many young adults drift into parenthood unintentionally. They may be cohabiting at the time of their child’s birth, but about half of these couples will have split up by the time their child is 5 years old. College-educated young adults are still marrying before having children and planning their families more intentionally. The rest of America, about two-thirds of the population, is not.

headline: Hunter Original: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: After Penn State Scandal, Reshaping a Father’s Legacy
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Books and Literature', 'College Athletics', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Football']
abstract: Jay Paterno, the son of the football coach Joe Paterno, has written a book in defense of his father, who was caught up in the Jerry Sandusky sex abuse scandal at Penn State.
lead_paragraph: Enough has been written about the Penn State child sexual abuse scandal to fill a shelf at a library in State College. But Jay Paterno, a son of the football coach Joe Paterno, may be trying to get the final word on his father’s role.

headline: Variety: A Psychological Diagramless
abstract: Fred Piscop gets analytical on us.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Thank goodness for the EGO, or at least Freud’s conception of it. Without it, we would be uncontrollable lizard brains, seeking only to fill the id’s wants, needs and desires. The EGO part of the personality, Freud maintained, was what separated us from the animals.

headline: Air France-KLM Warns of Flight Cancellations as a Strike Looms
abstract: A dispute with pilots over the carrier’s planned expansion of a low-cost unit has the potential to disrupt the travel plans of tens of thousands of passengers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France-KLM warned on Saturday that it was preparing to cancel around 60 percent of its scheduled flights on Monday because of a dispute with pilots, a move that has the potential to disrupt the travel plans of tens of thousands of passengers.

headline: At Oregon, the Mascot Looks Awfully Familiar
abstract: In the 1940s, Oregon’s athletic director, a friend of Walt Disney’s, received permission for the university to call Donald Duck its own.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — The Oregon Duck — the Duck — was onstage, sitting between four men in suits while wearing a jaunty hat, a neckerchief and no pants. The Duck poured Froot Loops and milk and a pound of sugar into a bowl, then pretended to eat it. Crystals of sugar cascaded because, of course, the Duck has no lips.

headline: Unique Mix of Coaches Strives for One Voice
abstract: Mike Krzyzewski and his assistants are figuring out the best way to communicate as the United States plays for the FIBA World Cup gold medal against Serbia.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A few days before the United States men’s basketball team gathered last summer for a training camp in Las Vegas, the coaches of the team — Mike Krzyzewski and the assistants Jim Boeheim, Tom Thibodeau and Monty Williams — met to discuss, among other things, a seemingly innocuous topic that, in reality, was critical: language.

headline: After a Hall of Fame Induction, a Caddie Is Intent on Laying It Up
abstract: Steve Williams, who caddied for four notable golfers in his career and was inducted into the Caddie Hall of Fame last week, said he was ready to spend more time with his family in New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The newest member of the Caddie Hall of Fame is Steve Williams, or as his presenter at last week’s ceremony, Steve Sands of the Golf Channel, called him, Stevie.

headline: What Were They Thinking? Ugly Video, Blind Justice
abstract: What about this act of violence surprised professional football men? And what about it failed to move and anger New Jersey prosecutors?
lead_paragraph: Say this for Ray Rice: His left cross was of professional quality, a short, explosive punch. And his fiancée’s head snapped back as if she’d been shot.

headline: J.W. Anderson: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Struggling to Starve ISIS of Oil Revenue, U.S. Seeks Assistance From Turkey
abstract: The territory ISIS controls in Iraq produces thousands of barrels of oil that can fetch millions on the Turkish black market, and U.S. officials are leaning heavily on Turkey to take action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is struggling to cut off the millions of dollars in oil revenue that has made the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria one of the wealthiest terror groups in history, but so far has been unable to persuade Turkey, the NATO ally where much of the oil is traded on the black market, to crack down on an extensive sales network.

headline: Putin Intent on Taking ‘All of Ukraine,’ Premier Says
abstract: Only the military backing of NATO can defend Ukraine, the prime minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, told a conference of security experts in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A week into a fragile cease-fire between government troops and pro-Russian rebels in Ukraine, that country’s prime minister offered a pessimistic assessment of its chances of holding and said President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia intends eventually to conquer “all of Ukraine.”

headline: Trying to Hit the Brake on Texting While Driving
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: People keep texting when they’re behind the wheel, so an engineer has found a technological solution. The problem: He can’t do it on his own.
lead_paragraph: People know they shouldn’t text and drive. Overwhelmingly, they tell pollsters that doing so is unacceptable and dangerous, and yet they do it anyway. They can’t resist. So safety advocates and public officials have called for a technological solution that does an end run around free will and prevents people from texting in the first place.

headline: A Texting Driver’s Education
keywords: ['Text Messaging', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Books and Literature', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: After a deadly 2006 accident, Reggie Shaw was in denial. Now he’s on a mission against the use of phones behind the wheel.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 22, 2006, Reggie Shaw, 19, climbed into his sport utility vehicle to head to a painting job. He picked up a Pepsi at the local gas station and started over the mountain pass between Tremonton, Utah, his hometown, and Logan, the big city to the east, near the Idaho border.

headline: Recapturing a Game and Days Gone By
abstract: A new stadium has lured the Class AA Birmingham Barons back from the suburbs, as well as the author’s mother-in-law, an old fan of her hometown team.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — A mild night here in summer can feel like a little miracle. “A great gift,” Ann Keith called it as she sat watching baseball in her hometown for the first time in 20 years. She wore a hot pink jacket for comfort, not style.

headline: New York Fashion Week Street Style
abstract: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC has taken over our Instagram account for the spring 2015 fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: Here are our highlights from New York Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: That Applause at Camden Yards? It’s for the Thorn in Baltimore’s Side
abstract: During most of Derek Jeter’s career, he and the Yankees used the Orioles as their personal American League doormat. But that did not stop the crowd in Baltimore from cheering him on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Something felt wrong, very wrong, Friday at Camden Yards as the Orioles and the Yankees opened a weekend series.

headline: Best of the New York Fashion Week After-Parties
abstract: Here are our highlights from the parties at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Here are our highlights from the parties at New York Fashion Week.

headline: Fruits of the Wine-Dark Sea
abstract: A meal at Nissos can be reminiscent of the Greek islands. But Syosset is a lot closer.
lead_paragraph: A recent visit to Nissos, a Greek restaurant that opened in Syosset in June, emphasized why I wait at least a month to review a new place. Friends who were there earlier this summer described the service as comical; now adjectives like attentive, concerned, smooth and speedy apply.

headline: The Mets Face a Vista of Empty Seats and a Lawsuit
abstract: The Mets’ steadily dwindling crowds at Citi Field are the backdrop to a federal lawsuit filed last week by a former ticket sales executive accusing the team of discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Citi Field was so empty as the Mets took the field Thursday night, it looked as if every spectator could have fit comfortably in the lower bowl. Even then, people would have had room to spread out. When Curtis Granderson casually tossed a ball into the stands, it landed rows from the nearest fan.

headline: Honoring a Teacher Who Fought for Equality
abstract: It was Prudence Crandall’s progressive sense of justice, not her academic boldness, that got her into trouble with the community and eventually earned her a museum in Canterbury with her name on it
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the small Prudence Crandall Museum in Canterbury come ready to learn about an unfamiliar local contribution to the struggle for American civil rights, or to have one they already know reinforced for them.

headline: Oakland Stumbles Toward a Playoff Berth
abstract: The Athletics held the best record in baseball on July 31, but since then they have struggled to survive an unsettling late-summer slide.
lead_paragraph: Jon Lester pulled on his cowboy boots in the visitors’ clubhouse in Chicago on Tuesday after a victory over the White Sox. Lester pitches for the Oakland Athletics, but his boots still bear the “B Strong” logo from Boston, where he led the Red Sox to the World Series title last October.

headline: Running or Receiving, Jets’ Chris Johnson Simply Wants to Touch the Ball
abstract: Drafted by the Titans as a running back but often employed as a receiver, Johnson wants to be known as a complete player.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Upon meeting Chris Johnson at the 2008 N.F.L. scouting combine, Anthony Lynn did what he always does when setting his eyes on a running back for the first time: he looked at Johnson’s legs. Those legs were spindly and thin, not unlike the rest of him, and Lynn questioned whether Johnson’s body could hold up for a full season.

headline: Soul, Plus Kitchen
abstract: A gem of a performance space, Towne Crier Cafe, which is in a new location in Beacon after 25 years in Pawling, takes its food seriously.
lead_paragraph: Music venues can be trying places for those who love good food. If they offer anything beyond overpriced drinks, it is often not more than stale nuts and pretzels, or from a full menu, tired salads and anonymous brown meats.

headline: Bracing for Scotland’s Referendum
abstract: As Scotland prepares for its referendum on independence, many English and Scots that live in border towns feel an acute uncertainty that could remain no matter which way the vote goes.
lead_paragraph: As Scotland prepares for its referendum on independence, many English and Scots that live in border towns feel an acute uncertainty that could remain no matter which way the vote goes.

headline: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: In Jordan, Ever Younger Syrian Brides
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Marriages', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: For many Syrian families in Jordan’s refugee camps, marrying girls off at younger ages is seen as necessary, but women’s advocates say that they are trading immediate dangers for longer-term ones.
lead_paragraph: MAFRAQ, Jordan — The bride-to-be was so young and shy, she spent her engagement party cloaked in a hooded robe that swallowed her slim figure but could not quite hide the ruffled pink dress her fiancé’s family had rented for her.

headline: On the Field, the Babble Is Usually Towering
abstract: Football is called a game of action, not words. But in the modern game, between the plays at least, it seems as if no one shuts up.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — About 125 times during a typical N.F.L. game, an official retrieves the football at the end of a play and places it on the turf for the next play. It is meant to signal a resumption of the action.

headline: Should Fin Whales Be a Source of Wonder or Meat?
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Meat', 'Whales and Whaling']
abstract: A fresh look at Iceland’s fin whale hunts and meat exports to Japan.
lead_paragraph: Here are two very different views of humans’ relationship with the world’s second biggest animal, the fin whale. Above is a special moment during a whale-watching excursion in Canadian waters (which I wrote about here). Below is an image of one of more than 100 fin whales slaughtered this year by a business in Iceland that, according to a new report by conservationists, is exporting most of the meat to Japan.

headline: In English Town, Worry Over Scottish Referendum
abstract: England’s northernmost town, Berwick-upon-Tweed, has changed hands between the Scots and the English more than a dozen times in the last 1,400 years and could become a true border town once again.
lead_paragraph: England’s northernmost town, Berwick-upon-Tweed, has changed hands between the Scots and the English more than a dozen times in the last 1,400 years and could become a true border town once again.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 14
abstract: President Obama vowed to “degrade and ultimately destroy” ISIS in a speech he gave on Wednesday. Lawmakers and analysts will discuss his strategy on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: The reaction to President Obama’s speech on Wednesday vowing to “degrade and ultimately destroy” the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria militant group is still reverberating throughout the country.

headline: We’re All Nerds Now
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Geek obsessions are increasingly becoming totems of mainstream cool.
lead_paragraph: IN 2005, Randall Munroe, a young NASA robotics expert, posted to the web a comic about the mystical number pi. Among the infinite string of digits were letters that spelled out, “Help I’m trapped in a universe factory.”

headline: 2114: A Library Project
abstract: Mark Twain’s 100-year embargo on his autobiography helped make it a best seller in 2010. Will that work with books published 100 years from now?
lead_paragraph: The hope that creative work survives its creator is usually empty. Shakespeare boasted that his sonnets would outlast monuments and the memory of princes, and they have. But it’s rare for an artist to keep audiences interested over generations. Most creative endeavors are ravaged by what Shakespeare called “sluttish time.” Even the list of Nobel laureates in literature is filled with now-unfamiliar names.

headline: Throw the Bums Out
abstract: When you enable men who beat women, you’re in danger of getting sacked.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN Roger Goodell was growing up here, he had the best possible example of moral leadership. His father, a moderate New York Republican appointed by Gov. Nelson Rockefeller to Bobby Kennedy’s Senate seat after the assassination, risked his career to come out against the Vietnam War.

headline: Should We All Take a Bit of Lithium?
keywords: ['Lithium (Metal)', 'Water', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Research', 'Dementia', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Lithium (Drug)']
abstract: Suicide seems to be less common where the lithium is more plentiful in drinking water.
lead_paragraph: THE idea of putting a mind-altering drug in the drinking water is the stuff of sci-fi, terrorist plots and totalitarian governments. Considering the outcry that occurred when putting fluoride in the water was first proposed, one can only imagine the furor that would ensue if such a thing were ever suggested.

headline: Lil Buck
abstract: A jook dancer on the philosophy of being formless, eating vegan in Memphis and wearing out his dancing sneakers in two and a half weeks.
lead_paragraph: Charles Riley, known as Lil Buck, is a dancer who specializes in jookin, a type of street dance in Memphis, his hometown. He is probably best known for a viral video of him performing an interpretive dance to Camille Saint-Saëns’s “The Swan,” accompanied by Yo-Yo Ma.

headline: The Economics of Scotland’s Choice
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Editorials', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'British Pound (Currency)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Independence could make Scotland vulnerable to serious problems that cannot be easily dismissed.
lead_paragraph: The supporters of Scottish independence in Thursday’s referendum argue that breaking away from Britain will give Scotland the “powers it needs to build a more prosperous country and a fairer society.” Indeed, separation from Britain would allow the Scottish government, which is generally more liberal on economic and public policies, to set its own course for a society closer to that of a Scandinavian country.

headline: Jobs With Nonprofits
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Readers respond to a letter urging college graduates to consider work in the public sector.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a letter urging college graduates to consider work in the public sector.

headline: What’s Their Plan?
keywords: ['Sunni Muslims', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Shiite Muslims']
abstract: The fight against ISIS is a two-front campaign. We keep making it about us and Obama. But that’s the wrong way to look at it.
lead_paragraph: THERE are three things in life that you should never do ambivalently: get married, buy a house or go to war. Alas, we’re about to do No. 3. Should we?

headline: The Lighthouse Keepers
abstract: Can we preserve these isolated structures, without turning them into tourists’ theme parks?
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — LIGHTHOUSES are symbols of our most isolated stretches of coastline, a reminder that such places exist not just in our past, but in our present. They are attracters of ghost stories, smugglers’ tales and shipwrecks. There is something mysterious about a lighthouse, and in our modern age, when so much of the world is overmapped, so severely known, that mystery abides.

headline: The Middle East’s Friendless Christians
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Minorities', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz’s stunt at a conference on religious persecution has only increased his co-religionists’ isolation.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the long, grim history of Christianity’s disappearance from the Middle East is written, Ted Cruz’s performance last week at a conference organized to highlight the persecution of his co-religionists will merit at most a footnote. But sometimes a footnote can help illuminate a tragedy’s unhappy whole.

headline: Are Liberal Jewish Voters a Thing of the Past?
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Hasidism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The Hasidic population boom is transforming the religion’s traditional profile in New York.
lead_paragraph: FOR generations, American Jews, and particularly Jewish New Yorkers, have largely been identified as ardent liberals.

headline: A Risky Bet on Syrian Rebels
abstract: America’s success at training security forces in other countries is mixed at best.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s new strategy for routing ISIS, the extremist Sunni group that controls large areas of Iraq and Syria, rests substantially and precariously on having rebels in Syria fight ISIS, even as they battle the forces of the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad. The plan is full of hope and fraught with obstacles.

headline: Foles and Philadelphia Are Primed to Exploit Indianapolis
abstract: Highlighting players for fans and fantasy owners to watch.
lead_paragraph: Jason Sablich and Justin Sablich highlight players for fans and fantasy owners to watch. They will answer lineup questions on Twitter, @5thDown-Fantasy.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Monet of One’s Own
abstract: We can fall in love with works of art, just as we fall in love with songs.
lead_paragraph: I SLIPPED away from work on a recent Monday to take my two nieces to the Garry Winogrand photography exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. I doubt there’s a better way to play hooky in New York right now.

headline: Behind the Minimalist Hair and Makeup at J.W. Anderson
abstract: The makeup artist Aaron De Mey and the hairstylist Anthony Turner reveal the tricks and products used to create the show’s pure, unadorned beauty statement.
lead_paragraph: “We’re really trying to amplify a no-makeup state — with no mascara and no eyelash curling either,” said the New Zealand-born, New York-based makeup artist Aaron De Mey backstage at J.W. Anderson this afternoon. Crafting such a pure look called for enhanced skin preparation involving exfoliation around the nose and on the lips and an application of M.A.C Lightful Softening Lotion to intensely hydrate the skin. “I’m keeping it elevated, aristocratic — and taking the sex out of it, essentially,” explained De Mey. “No shine, but instead a matte fragility.” M.A.C’s Mixing Medium Matte was pressed onto the skin with the index finger, patted lightly around the cheek and nose and swept softly over the forehead and chin. De Mey also used M.A.C Select Cover-Up concealer under the eyes, softly blending it with a tapered brush. “The girls feel like themselves as I’m retaining the natural rosy color in their cheeks,” he explained, “which adds to the look of aristocratic purity.”

headline: Leadership Team Overseeing Portuguese Bank Resigns
abstract: The team selected to turn around the “good” bank created after the bailout of Banco Espírito Santo abruptly resigned.
lead_paragraph: The “good” bank created after the bailout of the Portuguese lender Banco Espírito Santo last month was dealt a setback on Saturday when the three-person management team selected to turn around its business abruptly resigned.

headline: House of Holland: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Jets (1-0) at Packers (0-1)
abstract: Matchups to watch include Jets’ defensive tackles vs. Packers’ Eddie Lacy.
lead_paragraph: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Cardinals (1-0) at Giants (0-1)
abstract: Matchup to watch includes Cardinals’ Dan Williams vs. Giants’ offensive line.
lead_paragraph: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Useless Creatures
abstract: We act as though animals matter only when they benefit humans.
lead_paragraph: This article contains no useful information. Zero. Nada. Nothing. If usefulness is your criterion for reading, thank you very much for your time and goodbye, we have nothing more to say. The truth is that I am bored to tears by usefulness. I am bored, more precisely, of pretending usefulness is the thing that really matters.

headline: Paths to War, Then and Now, Haunt Obama
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Before recently announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just hours before announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists last week, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East — the frenzied weeks leading up to the American invasion of Iraq a decade ago.

headline: Vikings’ Adrian Peterson Booked on Charge of Child Abuse
abstract: Peterson, a running back, surrendered to the Montgomery County, Tex., sheriff’s office and was freed on $15,000 bond.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Peterson, the star Minnesota Vikings running back charged with child abuse, surrendered to Montgomery County, Tex., authorities early Saturday morning and was freed on $15,000 bond.

headline: State Police Officer Dies in Pennsylvania Ambush
abstract: A second officer was in stable condition after a late-night attack at the State Police barracks in Blooming Grove.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officers from three states were searching on Saturday for a suspect or suspects who ambushed two troopers at a state police barracks in northeastern Pennsylvania, killing one and wounding the other.

headline: Beijing Hosts Debut of Formula E as Engines Whir Rather Than Roar
abstract: The world’s first fully electric motor racing series features battery-powered racecars that can accelerate from 0 to 60 miles per hour in three seconds.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The world’s first fully electric motor racing series, featuring battery-powered racecars that can accelerate from 0 to 60 miles per hour in three seconds, opened here Saturday.

headline: The Flavors of the World Piled on a Bun
abstract: The toppings-enthusiastic Destination Dogs, a New Brunswick restaurant and bar, offers both the usual dog and the unusual.
lead_paragraph: As a lifelong hot dog connoisseur, I enjoy my tubular meats unadorned. It took me almost two decades to put anything but mustard on my Rutt’s Hut ripper. Regional variations like the salad-topped Chicago dog are curiosities to me.

headline: 2 Bystanders Injured in Manhattan in Off-Duty Officer’s Tussle for Gun
abstract: The narcotics investigator, who police said appeared to be intoxicated, faces assault and weapons charges; and the victims’ injuries do not appear to be serious.
lead_paragraph: An off-duty New York State narcotics investigator was arrested on Friday night after his gun discharged during a struggle with an acquaintance, the police said, injuring two bystanders and sending pedestrians running for cover.

headline: Artfully Collaged Coifs at Phoebe English
abstract: At the up-and-comer’s spring/summer 2015 show, the models sported low buns threaded with woven string and copper wire, smeared with glitter and topped with Lucite headpieces.
lead_paragraph: At the up-and-comer Phoebe English‘s spring/summer 2015 show today, the coifs were as artfully constructed as the clothes, which featured colorful brushstrokes and handcrafted netting. The hair had a similarly bricolaged feeling: The sides of each model’s head were smeared with glittery gel, low buns were threaded through with woven string and copper wire, and a Lucite piece rested atop each crown like a vertebral column. The effect was something like what an art student might dream up for a particularly festive party.

headline: Barbecue, Jambalaya and Points in Between
abstract: At When Pigs Fly South, a modest eatery in Sharon that resembles a Southern roadside barbecue shack, the pigs that matter most are those from which its plates of ribs and pork shoulders are derived.
lead_paragraph: Pigs, and plenty of them, adorn the space at When Pigs Fly South. There’s a chubby one hanging just above the entrance, and another two, with wings, mounted on the wall inside. Others are on the counter, where food orders are placed, and still more rest on windowsills around the one-room dining area.

headline: Return to Iowa Offers Clinton a Chance to Help Democrats, Including Herself
abstract: At the 37th annual Iowa steak fry on Sunday, Hillary Rodham Clinton will wade back into the brand of retail politics that confounded her in 2008.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Hillary Rodham Clinton will wade back into Iowa and the unique brand of retail politics that so confounded her during the 2008 campaign on Sunday, taking her first steps back toward the presidential stage in the state that did so much to doom her White House ambitions.

headline: Yankees Halt Orioles to Show They’re Not Dead Yet
abstract: After losing a doubleheader to the Orioles on Friday, the Yankees bounced back, led by the ex-Met Chris Young.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Despite the emotional toll of Friday’s doubleheader sweep at the hands of the Baltimore Orioles, the Yankees were still alive on Saturday in the chase for one of the two wild-card spots in the American League, at least technically.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Women’s Champion Builds War Chest for Title Defense
abstract: Hou Yifan’s victory in this year’s Grand Prix series may help her defend the women’s world championship.
lead_paragraph: Hou Yifan of China won her third straight Grand Prix series title last week at a tournament in the United Arab Emirates. The victory could be an insurance policy in her push to repeat as the women’s world champion. It helped her just last year in recapturing the title.

headline: Celebrity Spoonerisms
abstract: Patrick Blindauer returns. With Tony Orbach. Please don’t hurt me.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — OH HAPPY DAY, Patrick Blindauer is back. Have no fear, he’s relatively harmless this time, and there is absolutely no truth whatsoever to the rumor that he is using Tony Orbach as a human shield just to be on the safe side.

headline: Back to the Slums of His Youth, to Defuse the Ebola Time Bomb
abstract: Liberia remains desperately short on everything needed to halt the spread of Ebola, but an epidemiologist is working block by block to fill a crucial need: the support of residents.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — The girl in the pink shirt lay motionless on a sidewalk, flat on her stomach, an orange drink next to her, unfinished. People gathered on the other side of the street, careful to keep their distance.

headline: ISIS Video Shows Execution of David Cawthorne Haines, British Aid Worker
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A video released by the group shows the aid worker kneeling in a desert landscape that looks identical to where two American journalists were killed by the group in the past month. Moments later, he is beheaded.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria released a video Saturday of the third beheading of a foreign hostage, a British aid worker. The execution was a clear message to Britain, a vital ally of the United States as it builds an international coalition to target the militant group, which has made stunning advances across Syria and northern Iraq in recent months.

headline: J.W. Anderson Reworks the Wallaby
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: chunky sky-blue heels that resembled the classic ’60s leisure shoe.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Rashi Fein, Economist Who Urged Medicare, Dies at 88
abstract: Dr. Fein’s ethical and humanitarian perspectives on national health care were influential from the Truman administration to President Obama’s Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Rashi Fein, an influential economist who strove to bring ethical and humanitarian perspectives to the nation’s health care system and helped lay the intellectual groundwork for Medicare in the 1960s, died on Monday in Boston. He was 88.

headline: North Korea Says Reports of Abuse Are Produced by Political ‘Racket’
abstract: The nation, condemned by a United Nations panel for gross human rights violations, issued its own report that made no mention of prison camps and claimed that individual freedoms were strong.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea, a country widely condemned for egregious rights violations, issued its own report on Saturday on the state of human rights in the country, disputing outside criticism and suggesting that accusations of abuses are politically motivated.

headline: With Governor’s Indictment, Scrutiny of Grand Jury System
abstract: The indictment of Gov. Rick Perry by a Travis County grand jury has put the spotlight on the state’s quirky system that gives judges a choice in how to seat a grand jury.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — The indictment of Gov. Rick Perry by a Travis County grand jury has put the spotlight on the state’s quirky system that gives judges a choice in how to seat a grand jury.

lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

abstract: The Texas Organizing Project’s leaders believe Hispanics could be motivated to vote when they realize the polarity of positions on government-subsidized health care in the current election cycle.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — When Armando Rodriguez opened the front door of his home here on the city’s west side, Chris Ornelas of the Texas Organizing Project met him with one question.

headline: Afghanistan Boldly Raises Its Colors, as Never Before
abstract: Flying from a specially erected pole more than 200 feet high, the black, red and green flag, at 97 feet by 65 feet, is big enough to drape over an intact Dreadnoughtus dinosaur fossil.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — To find a flag as big as the one hoisted over Kabul’s historic Wazir Akbar Khan hill on Wednesday, you would have to go pretty far — possibly as far as a Walmart parking lot somewhere in the Great Plains.

headline: An Unconventional Crooner Finally Finds Her Place
abstract: “The Big Picture,” Kat Edmonson’s first major label record is the result of years spent studying her mother’s record collection of film scores, classic crooners and big-band era jazz.
lead_paragraph: The morning that the music video for her new song “Rainy Day Woman” premiered online, Kat Edmonson had a revelation in the shower of her Brooklyn apartment.

headline: Mark Sanford’s Breakup Post Caught His Fiancée Off Guard
abstract: Maria Belen Chapur said she had asked Mr. Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina, to make the break public, but first learned about his Facebook announcement from the news media.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina surprised the political world on Friday with his announcement that he was ending his engagement to the woman with whom he had an extramarital affair, the revelation of which stunted his rising-star career five years ago.

headline: Malaysia Risks Enraging China by Inviting U.S. Spy Flights
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Malaysia reportedly offered to allow P-8 Poseidon aircraft to fly out of the country’s most eastern area, a move that would give the United States greater proximity to the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Malaysia’s reported invitation to the United States to fly spy planes out of East Malaysia on the southern rim of the South China Sea seems likely to intensify China’s anger at American surveillance of the strategic waterway and its disputed islands, analysts say.

headline: Building Legacy, Obama Reshapes Appellate Bench
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: After a change in Senate filibuster rules, judges appointed by Democrats now hold a majority of seats on the United States Courts of Appeals, a tilt that has far-reaching consequences for President Obama’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats have reversed the partisan imbalance on the federal appeals courts that long favored conservatives, a little-noticed shift with far-reaching consequences for the law and President Obama’s legacy.

headline: Tug of War for Bishop’s Body, or Its Parts, Delays Sainthood
abstract: The remains of Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, who died in 1979, are in a crypt in Manhattan, but the Diocese of Peoria, Ill., is laying claim to them.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Peoria, Ill., has already constructed a museum in honor of Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, a native son whose Emmy-winning television show during the 1950s brought Catholicism to the American living room. It has documented several potential miracles by him and compiled a dossier on his good works for the Vatican.

headline: Kerry Scours Mideast for Aid in ISIS Fight
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As Secretary of State John Kerry received broad assurances but no public commitments from Egypt as he tried to assemble a coalition to fight ISIS, Australia on Sunday committed aircraft and military advisers to the effort.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry received broad assurances but no public commitments from Egypt on Saturday as he continued his tour of the Middle East to try to assemble a coalition behind an American campaign against the extremist group known as the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Germany’s Offshore Wind Push
abstract: The small German island of Heligoland, a popular tourist destination, is undergoing dramatic change as the wind industry takes over.

headline: Anthro 101: Intro to Flirting
abstract: The following poems about the erotic aspects of the start of the academic year were all found this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: The seasonal agony known as going back to school isn’t usually a sexy process, but every now and then, in between buying textbooks and arranging class schedules, scholars catch one another’s eyes. The following poems about the erotic aspects of the start of the academic year were all found this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Series', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Electric utility executives all over the world are watching nervously as technologies they once dismissed as irrelevant begin to threaten their long-established business plans.
lead_paragraph: HELIGOLAND, Germany — Of all the developed nations, few have pushed harder than Germany to find a solution to global warming. And towering symbols of that drive are appearing in the middle of the North Sea.

headline: Billy Horschel Faces Off With Rory McIlroy at the Tour Championship

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After their third round at the Tour Championship, Rory McIlroy shook Billy Horschel’s hand and said, “See you tomorrow.”

headline: At Sputtering Ferrari, Shake-Up at the Top Could Change Tradition
abstract: Ferrari’s tradition of selling road cars to support the racing operations could change after an upheaval among the top management of the iconic Italian company last week.
lead_paragraph: At the Ferrari headquarters in Maranello, Italy, a few miles outside Modena, there is much to remind a visitor of the guiding principle set down by the company’s founder, Enzo Ferrari, in the years after World War II. Ferrari decreed that the main business of his company would be racing, primarily in Formula One, and that success on the track would trump all else, including building and selling the production cars that have become icons of style and performance over the past 60 years.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 14, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I am convinced that wind and sun will be the central sources of energy, not only in Germany but worldwide. The question is: How can we turn the energy transition into a success story?”

headline: Frank Torre, Inspiration to a Yankees Manager, Dies at 82
abstract: Torre is best remembered by New Yorkers for cheering from his hospital bed as the Yankees, led by his younger brother Joe Torre, won the 1996 World Series.
lead_paragraph: Frank Torre, an older brother of Joe Torre’s, played first base for seven seasons in the major leagues and hit two home runs for the Milwaukee Braves when they defeated the Yankees for the 1957 World Series title.

Toth, the bride’s maternal grandfather and a justice of the peace in New Hampshire, who received a one-day solemnization from Massachusetts; Janet K. Parker, the groom’s godmother, participated.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union Seeks Final Drug Agreement
abstract: A day after player representatives approved an overhaul of the N.F.L. protocols on drugs and performance-enhancing substances, the players union said it hoped to have a final agreement “very soon.”
lead_paragraph: A day after player representatives approved a sweeping overhaul of the N.F.L. protocols on drugs and performance-enhancing substances, the players union said it hoped to have a final agreement, including information on players who might get reduced suspensions, “very soon.” After the union’s vote to approve the plan on Friday, the league said there were still “significant unresolved issues” without specifying what those issues were. On Saturday, George Atallah, a spokesman for the union, said the vote had authorized union negotiators “to finalize full policies with the N.F.L. as soon as possible.”

headline: Floyd Mayweather Jr. Remains Unbeaten With Decision Over Marcos Maidana
abstract: Mayweather improved to 47-0 in a welterweight rematch with Maidana that included an accusation of biting in the eighth round.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In the lead-up to Saturday night’s welterweight rematch between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Marcos Maidana, Floyd Mayweather Sr. was vocal about his preference that his son not fight the 31-year-old Argentine contender. The two had met on May 3, in a contest that Mayweather Sr. said Maidana had fought unfairly.

abstract: Lunch hour today includes Richard Nicoll at 11, to be followed by Marios Schwab at noon, and the more seasoned Matthew Williamson, also an alumnus of Pucci, at 1 p.m.
lead_paragraph: Not for nothing has this city significantly improved its coffee offerings. The fashion shows Sunday begin at a brisk, penitent 9 a.m. with Preen by Thornton Bregazzi (not one guy, but the surnames of a married couple who began their business in a Portobello Road boutique, Biba-style). That’s regardless of what fringe-tangling debaucheries might have occurred at the Marchesa after-party last night. Fortunately, a pallid, bleary and unshowered look is perfectly O.K. in London; indeed, one might argue it confers a certain intellectual credibility.

headline: In Southern China, Residents Wary of the Government Protest a Plan to Burn Waste
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Residents of a county in the province of Guangdong say they do not trust official reassurances about the environmental safety of a planned incinerator.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Residents of a county in southern China thronged the streets in protest over the weekend to oppose a proposed garbage incineration plant, defying government warnings and police detentions. The protest was the latest of a succession of demonstrations against waste-disposal projects by pollution-weary Chinese citizens.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The Supreme Court in North Korea on Sunday sentenced one of the three Americans known to be held in the country to six years of hard labor for committing “hostile acts” against the North.

headline: ‘Just a Stepmother’ Sending a Son to College Without Tears
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: Being happy as my stepson leaves us for college isn’t a sign of a lack of connection or love. It’s a sign of pride.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, my husband and I dropped our oldest off at college. After days of packing, we crammed the items necessary for dorm life into the car for the four-hour drive to campus, and left the rest behind. When I closed the door on his empty room, I did not shed a single tear.

headline: In Ray Rice Scandal, TMZ Scores on a Fumble
abstract: The N.F.L.’s light punishment for the Baltimore Ravens running back pushed the gossip site to outmaneuver the rest of the media to get the goods.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L., arguably the three most powerful letters in branding, bumped into three other letters — TMZ — and was thrown for a huge loss.

headline: Arab Nations Offer to Fight ISIS From Air
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Kurds']
abstract: American officials have made it clear they do not want the airstrikes to get ahead of the ground action against ISIS, which they said would take time to mass.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday that “several” Arab nations had offered to join in airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, but any sustained military campaign does not appear imminent, and is likely to require an even more significant commitment from other nations and fighting forces in the region.

headline: 1914: M. Henri Pol Will Go On Caring for Paris Sparrows
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: An elderly man in Paris assured he would continue looking after sparrows despite the war, in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Still here? Of course, I’m still here!’’ exclaimed M. Henri Pol, as with a wide sweep of the arm he scattered a generous handful of carefully-prepared bread pellets over the gravel path in the Tuileries Gardens. ‘‘It’s quite natural. I don’t see that there is any reason for congratulating me.’’ ‘‘These Parisian birds are unhappy enough already,’’ continued M. Pol, preparing more bread. ‘‘Nobody worries about them in the gardens, and they are growing thin and worrying because they no longer see the children playing. This is not the time to leave them, for what would become of them if the Germans came into Paris? ‘‘So I must stop here with them. In ‘70 I already passed through the upheaval of a war. But in those days I was of an age when I could shoulder a rifle, and I did not know my birds. I would have you believe that then I did not throw my powder to the sparrows.’’ ‘‘To-day, alas, I am good for nothing but to be a bird-charmer. Yet, you know, each one does what he can, and, although I am not well off, these little birdies will be assured of bread.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 15, 1914

headline: What Moving the Capital Would Mean for Argentina
abstract: Argentina may move its capital from bustling Buenos Aires to a provincial city in the sleepy north. What would this mean for the country’s infamously stormy economy and contentious political climate?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a rough year for Argentina. Another economic default looms on the heels of its second sovereign debt crisis in 13 years. Inflation rates are now second highest in the world, after Venezuela. And as if things couldn’t possibly get worse, the national soccer team lost (by a hair) in the World Cup final against Germany earlier this summer.

headline: A Vital Center for a Bronx Community Closes
abstract: For more than three decades, the Highbridge Community Life Center was an esteemed link for waves of immigrants in the west Bronx neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Mariana Lopez came to this country from Cuba in 2008, possessing few things besides one: an intense desire to get ahead. With no friends or family, she settled into an apartment near Yankee Stadium, waitressed in a restaurant at night and wondered how to fit into this fabled land.

headline: ‘No Good Deed’ Tops Weekend Box Office
abstract: That thriller, from Sony, had $24.5 million in ticket sales at North American theaters over the weekend. It cost less than $14 million to make.
lead_paragraph: The low-budget thriller “No Good Deed” opened to a solid $24.5 million in ticket sales at North American theaters over the weekend, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data. Starring Idris Elba and Taraji P. Henson, “No Good Deed” (Sony) cost less than $14 million to make.

headline: Choose Your Own Rhythm
abstract: The BEAT Festival, which includes music, theater and dance in an array of public spaces in Brooklyn, kicked off on Thursday at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: Every year, it seems, the BEAT Festival expands to encompass a larger swath of Brooklyn. The third edition of this 10-day, mostly outdoor extravaganza (the name stands for Brooklyn Emerging Artists in Theater) stretches from Downtown Brooklyn to East New York to Sunset Park, including music, theater and dance in an array of public spaces: a farmers’ market, Green-Wood Cemetery, Barclays Center plaza.

headline: When Novels Were Bad For You
abstract: Today we think of fiction as the wholesome alternative to reading online — but a few centuries ago, novels were the suspect medium.
lead_paragraph: When people bemoan the alleged ill effects of reading online, they often hold up reading a good novel as the more wholesome alternative. But a few hundred years ago, novels were the suspect medium, accused of leading people astray and ruining them for real life.

headline: Democratic Mash-Up in the Park
abstract: Over the weekend, City Center brought the Fall for Dance Festival to Central Park for two free performances.
lead_paragraph: “Democracy is better when everybody has a stake in culture,” Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, said from the stage of the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Friday night. From 1962 to 1980, the Delacorte wasn’t just about Shakespeare, but also a destination for dance. For the second year in a row, City Center teamed up with the Public to bring the Fall for Dance Festival to the Delacorte for two free performances. (Because of the weather, Saturday evening’s show was held on Sunday.)

headline: Wild Words, Brain Worms, and Civility
abstract: Zombies with a purpose.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith writes that one should not be rude about people you disagree with, because they might turn out to be right. Indeed; what possible purpose can be served by, say, referring to Austrian economics as a brain worm? Oh, wait.

headline: Cameron Announces Response Plan to Beheading of British Aid Worker
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron said Britain would support American military action against the ISIS, but he did not commit his country to a more vigorous military role against the group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Following an emergency meeting on Sunday with Britain’s top security and military officials to form a response to the beheading of a British aid worker by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Prime Minister David Cameron laid out a plan to support American military action in those two countries but made no commitment to a more vigorous military role.

headline: Flyaway Locks at Marios Schwab
abstract: Like the silhouettes in the collection, the models’ hair was deliberately askew.
lead_paragraph: At his spring/summer 2015 presentation today, Marios Schwab showed a parade of angular shapes: wrap skirts, slit-front tunics, strategic slices at the shoulders of shirtdresses. The hair, too, was deliberately askew. The center-parted coifs, some worn down and others pulled into loose ponytails, featured purposefully pulled-out strands that formed diagonal lines as the models walked. Flyaways have never looked so good.

headline: Handling of Ray Rice Case Puts Roger Goodell Under Heightened Level of Scrutiny
abstract: The N.F.L. and Goodell are facing mounting criticism for the handling of Rice, who was suspended indefinitely only after the release of an unequivocal video of him assaulting a woman.
lead_paragraph: Linda Sánchez stood among her fellow members of Congress as she watched Roger Goodell enter the hearing room. It was October 2009, evidence of football damaging brains had been mounting for three years, and the House Judiciary Committee — along with many football fans — awaited what Goodell would say under oath about a subject shaking his sport.

headline: 1964: Director, a Success Both Sides of the Curtain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roman Polanski was a rising star of international cinema in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Roman Polanski, a pocket-sized, playful Puck of a youthful Pole, is bringing off the very neat feat of becoming a successful movie director in his native Communist homeland and in the highly competitive circles of the capitalist West movie world. His first feature film, ‘‘Knife in the Water,’’ shot in Warsaw, won him a prize at the Venice Film Festival two years ago and put him on the cover of an issue of ‘‘Time’’ magazine devoted to international moviemaking.

headline: Penn State Follows the Lead of Christian Hackenberg, Its Teenage Quarterback
abstract: Hackenberg, a 19-year-old sophomore, behaves like the adult of the revitalized Nittany Lions, standing for something beyond the obvious tangible rewards of the game.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — The quarterback walked into the interview room appearing to be significantly taller than his listed height of 6 feet 4 inches. The mind wasn’t playing tricks because Christian Hackenberg, a 19-year-old sophomore who behaves like the adult of the revitalized Penn State football program, seemed to grow in the past week as he embodied a rare heartening narrative in the increasingly toxic world of football.

headline: The Secrets to the Soft Waves and Glowing Skin at Mary Katrantzou
abstract: Long, bendy locks and softly highlighted facial features spoke to the designer’s earthly vision.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Mary Katrantzou‘s spring/summer 2015 show today, the talk was of tectonic plates, the beginning of the world and not-quite-a-mermaid influences. To capture the designer’s earthly vision, the hairstylist Syd Hayes perfected a long wave with a pronounced bend in the front for additional shape. “It feels to me like she’s by the sea,” he said. “The hair is natural and clean, but there’s a bit of oil and movement.” Hayes first prepped the hair with L’Oreal Elnett Heat Protect Styling Spray Volume, then used a large barrel curler to create the soft, just woken-up waves. “There are no party curls here,” he said. “I want the hair to look as if it’s dried naturally.” He then finished with Elvive Smooth-Silk Intense Anti-Frizz Serum through the ends for definition and shine.

abstract: A three-year, 300-billion-euro effort to spur the European economy won broad backing from finance ministers.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — European Union finance ministers endorsed plans over the weekend to leverage hundreds of billions of euros to finance new infrastructure projects and spur demand as part of efforts to avoid a period of Japanese-style economic stagnation across the region.

headline: A ’60s Femme Fatale of Rock Reincarnated
abstract: Nico, the 1960s chanteuse and muse to musical greats of the time, is resurrected by the singer and performance artist Tammy Faye Starlite in “Nico: Underground.”
lead_paragraph: The dark eyes, peering from just under a fringe of blond bangs, wander the room before seeming to fix on some odd vision. The mind, too, tends to flit freely, moving from cogent reminiscence to random non sequitur like a needle skipping across a record. And the voice, a husky, German-accented drawl that seems to sigh with every syllable, suggests some serious inner disengagement with the world, or maybe just disgust with it.

headline: Despite Cease-Fire, Fighting Escalates in Eastern Ukraine City
abstract: The battle in Donetsk between rebels and Kiev government forces was one of the most serious clashes in a 10-day-old cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Heavy fighting broke out Sunday between Ukrainian and rebel forces on the north side of Donetsk, killing at least six people in one of the most serious clashes since the 10-day-old cease-fire came into force. The airport, where Ukrainian troops are almost surrounded, was on fire, billowing black smoke, and a house and a city market burned just off the main boulevard inside the city.

headline: In This Horror Film, Blood Is All Too Real
abstract: Dan Reed’s documentary “Terror at the Mall” uses footage from security cameras and cellphones, as well as photographs, to document a Shabab attack on civilians in Kenya.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, gunmen from the Shabab militant group in Somalia laid siege to the Westgate shopping mall in Nairobi, Kenya. Armed with AK-47s and grenades, they stalked their victims from a gourmet burger restaurant at the entrance to the vegetable aisle of a grocery store at the back.

headline: Cast Adrift in a Realm of Choices
abstract: In Ian McEwan’s latest novel, “The Children Act,” a British judge is drawn into medical choices facing a family of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
lead_paragraph: In many Ian McEwan novels, there is a moment of crisis or extremity that shatters his characters’ lives, reveals the innermost workings of their hearts or triggers a reassessment of everything they’ve believed.

lead_paragraph: SportAccord has started the World Mind Games Online Tournament, in which anyone may compete in bridge, go and chess. It will run from Monday to Nov. 15. Full details are at www.onlinewmg.com.

headline: Offense Makes Strides, but Giants Pay for Turnovers and Special-Teams Play
abstract: The offensive game improved considerably in Week 2, but like last year’s team, the Giants stumbled at the worst times and ultimately could not hold on to the football.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At home, playing against a backup quarterback and leading in a game for the first time this season, the Giants finally felt comfortable.

headline: Sharon Jones to Join Label Mates at the Apollo
abstract: The fiery soul singer was added to the Apollo Theater’s fall-winter lineup, organizers announced on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The fiery soul singer Sharon Jones was added to the Apollo Theater’s fall-winter lineup, organizers announced on Sunday. Ms. Jones will star alongside her band, the Dap-Kings, and the singer Charles Bradley during a three-night revue that is to feature many other musicians on the Daptone Records label. The extended concert, “Daptone Super Soul Revue,” is scheduled for Dec. 4-6 and is to be recorded live for an album. Ms. Jones, above, is familiar to the Apollo stage, but other Daptone acts, like Antibalas and the Budos Band, will be making their Apollo debuts. The album will place Daptone musicians in a long line of celebrated artists with live Apollo albums, including James Brown, B. B. King and Hall & Oates. Additionally, Harry Belafonte and the former New York City Mayor David N. Dinkins were added to an October panel discussion of the connection between Harlem and South Africa. The previously announced season lineup includes a celebration of New Orleans jazz, a tribute concert to Bob Marley and the holiday show “Ellington at Christmas.”

headline: Amy Winehouse Statue Is Unveiled in London
abstract: A statue of the British singer was unveiled on Sunday in London on what would have been her 31st birthday.
lead_paragraph: A statue of the British singer Amy Winehouse was unveiled on Sunday in London on what would have been her 31st birthday. The bronze work, above, was created by the London sculptor Scott Eaton and features Winehouse’s signature beehive hairstyle, a hand on one hip and stilettos on her feet. Mr. Eaton said the statue was meant to capture Winehouse’s “attitude and strength but also give subtle hints of insecurity,” the BBC reported. The statue was placed in Camden, the neighborhood where Winehouse lived before her death in July 2011 at 27. “Now Amy will oversee the comings and goings of her hometown forever,” her father, Mitch Winehouse, told the BBC. Amy Winehouse won six Grammys in her brief career. She had publicly struggled with alcohol and drug addiction before dying at her home of accidental alcohol poisoning.

headline: NPR Adds to Live Shows, With Almost 24 Planned
abstract: The events, supported by the Kresge Foundation and corporate sponsors, are intended to make money for NPR.
lead_paragraph: NPR, following the lead of other news and radio organizations, is widely expanding its live stage shows, with a slate of nearly two dozen events planned nationwide in the coming months.

headline: Shakespeare, in Mandarin
abstract: The British government will donate 1.5 million pounds ($2.44 million) to the Royal Shakespeare Company to translate all of Shakespeare’s works into Mandarin for the first time.
lead_paragraph: How do you say “All the world’s a stage” in Mandarin? The British government will donate 1.5 million pounds ($2.44 million) to the Royal Shakespeare Company to translate all of Shakespeare’s works into that language for the first time. The grant, announced by the Department of Culture, Media and Sport, will finance a company tour of China in 2016 and allow for select Chinese dramatic works to be translated into English. In bringing Shakespeare’s canon of plays to readers, directors and actors in China, the government hopes to forge “stronger links with China,” according to a statement by Sajid Javid, the British culture secretary. “Sharing the very best of our respective cultures is a brilliant way to make this happen,” he said. The translations continue a Shakespeare-centered cultural exchange between the two nations: In 2012, China’s National Theater performed for the first time at the Globe Theater in London, putting on “Richard III” in Mandarin. The British government will donate an additional £300,000, or about $488,000, to support exchanges between China and the British Museum. The Royal Shakespeare Company tour will coincide with the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death.

headline: One Generation of Composers, Three Orchestral Suites
abstract: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival presented “The Grand Overture,” vibrant performances of orchestral suites at St. Paul’s Chapel in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The ability of occasion and setting to enhance the power of a musical experience has been demonstrated many times, seldom more clearly, for many New Yorkers, than on Sept. 11, 2011. For the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Trinity Wall Street presented a solid day of concerts alternating between Trinity Church and St. Paul’s Chapel, several blocks to the north.

headline: Enemies Beyond the Ends of the Earth
abstract: Destiny, a science-fiction game from Activision and Bungie, is new but already on pace to become a billion-dollar success.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dinklage, the “Game of Thrones” star, narrates much of the action in the new science-fiction video game Destiny in a tone that alternates between boredom and bewilderment. Concerns about his performance emerged this summer when devoted players checked out early, unfinished versions of the game. One much-derided and flatly delivered line became an Internet meme and was scrubbed from the game’s official release this month: “That wizard came from the moon.”

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Toronto Film Festival Winners Announced
abstract: “The Imitation Game” took the Grolsch People’s Choice Award, the event’s most prestigious prize.
lead_paragraph: Winners of the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival were announced on Sunday, with “The Imitation Game” taking the Grolsch People’s Choice Award, the event’s most prestigious prize. The film, directed by Morten Tyldum, stars Benedict Cumberbatch (“Star Trek: Into Darkness,” “Sherlock”) as Alan Turing, the brilliant mathematician who helped the British government crack the Enigma code used by the Germans during World War II and was later persecuted for being gay. (Six decades later, he was given a royal pardon.)

headline: Fallen Brazilian Mogul Eike Batista Accused of Insider Trading
abstract: Eike Batista was accused of manipulating the share price of his now-bankrupt petroleum company OGX.
lead_paragraph: The fortunes of Brazilian businessman Eike Batista took another hit over the weekend, as the Rio de Janeiro public prosecutor’s office accused him of manipulating the share price of his now-bankrupt petroleum company, OGX, and engaging in insider trading.

headline: Trading Parking Lots for Affordable Housing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Parking lots can be turned into development sites to expand and improve affordable housing in New York City, three fellows at the Institute for Public Architecture propose.
lead_paragraph: What is the solution to affordable housing in New York?

headline: Commanding the Stage With Words and Dancing Feet
abstract: Youssou N’Dour sang in four languages as he fronted the band Le Super Étoile in concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Ushers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music fought a brief, losing battle against concertgoers surging into the aisle to dance when the Senegalese singer and bandleader Youssou N’Dour performed there on Friday night. All the better: Mr. N’Dour — a superstar across Africa and the French-speaking world since the 1980s, a 2012 presidential candidate in Senegal and the winner of the 2013 Polar Music Prize — leads one of Africa’s greatest and most nimble bands, Le Super Étoile. With the audience on its feet, the synergy between performers and listeners only grew.

headline: Like Handel and Bach, a Pair of Contemporaries
abstract: Steve Reich and Philip Glass, pioneers of Minimalism, collaborated for three concerts celebrating the 50th anniversary of Nonesuch Records.
lead_paragraph: Phasing, the signature technique of Steve Reich’s early music, involves rhythms that begin in sync and gradually shift just far enough from each other to create blossoming landscapes of patterns and tensions. Eventually, even if just in passing, synchronicity returns and resolution occurs.

headline: United States Wins FIBA World Cup Title in a Rout of Serbia
abstract: The Cleveland Cavaliers’ Kyrie Irving scored 26 points and was named the tournament’s most valuable player.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Kenneth Faried preened from atop a folding chair. Anthony Davis grabbed the assistant coach Monty Williams in a bear hug. James Harden leapt onto DeMarcus Cousins’s back. The names may have been considerably different from those at the London Olympics, but the outcome for the United States national basketball team was the same: another championship.

headline: This Is Your Music on Lots of Caffeine
abstract: The chamber band Alarm Will Sound helped celebrate Nonesuch Records’ 50th anniversary, part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.
lead_paragraph: Like being “locked in overnight at a Starbucks.” That’s how the composer John Adams described a program on Friday, one of two given by the chamber band Alarm Will Sound at Nonesuch Records’ 50th anniversary celebrations, part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.

headline: ‘Scandal’ Inspires Clothing Line at The Limited
abstract: The popular television series has spawned an apparel collection described in its advertising campaign as “fearless fashions for ladies who lead.”
lead_paragraph: DURING New York Fashion Week, which ended on Thursday, there was considerable discussion of designs and designers to die for. Beginning on Monday, the women’s apparel retailer The Limited is hoping to stimulate conversations, both actual and virtual, about dresses to double-cross for, skirts to skulk around in and suits to back-stab for.

headline: Q. and A.: Yong Zhao on Education and Authoritarianism in China
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Children and Childhood', 'Creativity', 'Education', 'Education (K-12)', 'No Child Left Behind Act', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'United States Economy']
abstract: If Western nations fear the rise of an authoritarian and prosperous China, the best thing they can do is not copy its test-driven education system, writes Yong Zhao, since it cannot deliver the creativity the world needs.
lead_paragraph: Yong Zhao, a professor of education at the University of Oregon, has come far. Born in what he calls “one of the most ordinary villages in China,” he is now an authority on Chinese and American education and the author of “Who’s Afraid of the Big Bad Dragon: Why China Has the Best (and Worst) Education System in the World,” being published this week.

headline: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not
abstract: Andrea Carla Michaels returns to shake things up.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Ah, that’s nice. Andrea Carla Michaels’s puzzles are some of my favorite early-week grids, because they fall so nicely — smooth, with mostly instant recognition of the answers. Lively. I solve online, smiling, and my fingers don’t stop typing until I receive the congratulations message. That’s a satisfying Monday puzzle. It makes you feel like a crossword master of the universe.

headline: Tricked-Out Chelsea Boots at Jonathan Saunders
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a grommeted patent leather twist on the classic style.
