headline: Music Emanating From a Factory Is Hardly Machine-Made
abstract: At the Basilica Soundscape festival, a growing event, the atmosphere competed with the music.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — The Basilica Soundscape festival of music and other things, in an old train-wheel factory by the river here, declared itself sold out Friday and Saturday at around 1,000 people per night. Those people had each paid $35 a ticket, which is probably underselling the pleasure of taking a short and pleasant train ride and standing in an old train-wheel factory by the river.

headline: Anti-Euro Party Wins More Seats in Germany’s State Legislatures
abstract: The party, Alternative for Germany, won 10 percent of the vote in Thuringia and 12 percent in Brandenburg, according to exit polls.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An upstart party that is skeptical of the common European currency, and often strikes a radical tone, won seats in two more state legislatures in eastern Germany on Sunday, gathering momentum it hopes to use to further its platform.

headline: Museum to Hone Image of the P.R. Profession
abstract: The collection of the Museum of Public Relations, which includes over 500 books and 100 hours of video interviews, is being made accessible to the public.
lead_paragraph: Shelley Spector, a longtime public relations executive, acknowledges the stereotype of members of her profession as a thorn in the side of reporters, clogging voice mail and email inboxes with endless and often misdirected pitches on behalf of clients.

headline: Scots Must Vote Nae
abstract: This show of petty nationalism is un-Scottish.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — To most Americans, Scotland means golf, whisky and — if they go there — steady drizzle. Even to the millions of Americans whose surnames testify to their Scottish or Scotch-Irish ancestry, the idea that Scotland might be about to become an independent country is baffling.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Sept. 15
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Drones and the Democracy Disconnect
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Philosophy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Can the sort of honorable military battles that strengthen our national identity possibly be fought by drones?
lead_paragraph: With President Obama’s announcement that we will open a new battlefront in yet another Middle Eastern country — in Syria, against ISIS (the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria) — there is widespread acknowledgement that it will be a protracted, complex, perhaps even messy campaign, with many unforeseeable consequences along the way. The president has said we will put “no boots on the ground” in Syria; he is wary of simply flooding allies on the ground with arms, for fear that they will fall into the wrong hands — as they already have. Obama wants to strike against ISIS in a part of Syria that is currently outside the authority of the Syrian government, which the president has accused of war crimes, and is thus, in our eyes, a legal no-man’s land. He has also made clear that he is ready to go it alone in directing attacks on ISIS — he has asked for Congress’s support, but is not seeking their authorization. All these signs point to drones playing a prominent role in this new war in Syria.

headline: How to Get It Wrong
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Recession and Depression', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Economists were worse than economics and policy makers were worse still.
lead_paragraph: Last week I participated in a conference organized by Rethinking Economics, a student-run group hoping to promote, you guessed it, a rethinking of economics. And Mammon knows that economics needs rethinking in the wake of a disastrous crisis, a crisis that was neither predicted nor prevented.

headline: Election Victories Strengthen Putin’s Grip Around Russia and Crimea

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Candidates loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin appeared to be headed to overwhelming victories on Sunday in regional and local elections across Russia, according to preliminary results, including in Crimea, and the special district of Sevastopol, where the first voting was taking place since Russia’s invasion and annexation of the peninsula last spring.

keywords: ['Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Dolphins and Porpoises']
abstract: Fewer than 100 vaquitas are living today, their population nearly wiped out by poachers sweeping up another rare species and shrimp fishermen casting huge nets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FELIPE, Mexico — It is a rare moment when scientists can point to an animal at the edge of extinction and predict when it might disappear forever. But it is happening here, under the golden waters of the desert-rimmed sea, where a small porpoise has almost vanished.

headline: Ray Rice and His Rage
abstract: Domestic violence is a societal scourge that must be constantly called out and constantly condemned.

headline: Germans Rally to Protest Anti-Semitism Over Gaza War

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Thousands of Germans, many wrapped in Israeli flags, gathered at Berlin’s historic Brandenburg Gate on Sunday for a rally against anti-Semitism, which has flared up in Europe following Israel’s invasion of Gaza.

lead_paragraph: At first, I tried to ignore the unsettling signs that my job was in danger: the gentle prodding from my bosses, who suggested that I needed to broaden my responsibilities; the effusive praise for a charming, newly hired colleague, who was shaking things up with his get-up-and-go.

headline: No Answers After Win, Only More Questions
abstract: A weary Floyd Mayweather Jr. retained his W.B.A. and W.B.C. welterweight titles Saturday night, then fielded questions about a possible bout against Manny Pacquiao.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — His walk into the postfight news conference was slow and deliberate. He wore black sweats and dark sunglasses, attire that seemed to fit his mood. He had won the fight, as expected. But this time, he did not appear to want to celebrate.

abstract: Pets, cellphones, bikes, basketballs and artificial body parts are among the items pickup crews have retrieved from the tracks.

abstract: Mr. Sample became a jazz star as a pianist in the 1960s and an even bigger star a decade later when he began playing electric keyboards.
lead_paragraph: Joe Sample, who became a jazz star in the 1960s as the pianist with the Jazz Crusaders and an even bigger star a decade later when he began playing electric keyboards and the group simplified its name to the Crusaders, died on Friday in Houston. He was 75.

abstract: The president of a stamp company is offering $50,000 for each of two missing “Inverted Jennies” — stamps that were stolen nearly 60 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Working swiftly and silently, someone cut the rope securing the leg of the display case and inched it forward. A sheet of protective glass was slid back, and four rare stamps were plucked from their display frame.

keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After limiting a privilege to dismiss lawsuits in the name of national security, the attorney general has intervened in a defamation case against United Against Nuclear Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first year in office, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. put new limits on when the government could dismiss lawsuits in the name of protecting national security. Now, in what he has said is likely his final year, Mr. Holder has claimed broad authority to do just that in a case unlike any other.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The fortunes of President Bashar al-Assad have suffered over the past two months, with battlefield setbacks and new signs of doubt emerging within his political base, as the civil war in Syria drags on with no end in sight.

abstract: In marrying 20 couples, including some who had already lived together, the pope continued to project the image of a more forgiving church.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Cautioning that marriage is “not a television show” but a symbol of “real life” with “joys and difficulties,” Pope Francis married 20 couples from the Diocese of Rome on Sunday, some of them less than paragons of traditional Catholic values.

headline: Gambling on the Games
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s plan for casino betting on athletic events is unlikely to save Atlantic City, but it could damage the integrity of sports.
lead_paragraph: The gambling industry in New Jersey is in deep trouble. Five of Atlantic City’s major casinos are closing or threatening to close before the end of the year. Thousands of workers have been laid off, and more layoffs are expected, as competing casinos spring up in neighboring states like Pennsylvania and New York. New Jersey’s unemployment rate is 6.5 percent, higher than the national rate.

headline: In Florida Student Assaults, an Added Burden on Accusers
abstract: Last year, the Tallahassee police’s handling of a rape accusation against Jameis Winston drew attention to its failure to adequately investigate. Now, an examination shows a pattern to the handling of such complaints.
lead_paragraph: After downing a double dose of NyQuil to fight a cold, the young woman woke in a man’s dormitory room with a vague memory of someone being on top of her, but no recollection of sexual contact. Three days later she found a condom in her vagina. She repeatedly confronted the man, who insisted that nothing had happened, and his roommate, who had told her he saw them having sex, then said he was joking.

lead_paragraph: The rate of growth on premiums for employer-based health coverage in the first five months of this year was one of the lowest in 16 years. Despite longstanding concerns that employer-sponsored coverage might become too costly to sustain, that market seems to have stabilized for now.

But late in the fourth quarter, after the sunlight faded and the Packers had taken the lead, there was nothing but noise, a din that swallowed up the Jets as they pursued a tying touchdown.

headline: Conservative Experiment Faces Revolt in Reliably Red Kansas

He is the type who agonizes over big purchases, trying to save as much money as possible. headline: Andy Stapp, Who Tried to Unionize the Military, Dies at 70
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Organized Labor', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Vietnam War']

He was 70.

One can imagine a latter-day Ralph Nader at some point taking on the modern auto industry with a jeremiad about the potential perils of microchipped cars, maybe in a book titled “Unsafe at Any Click.”

headline: ‘Django Unchained’ Actress Accuses Los Angeles Police of Mistreatment
abstract: The Los Angeles Police Department is investigating Daniele Watts’s claim that she was treated unfairly by police officers who detained her after she was seen kissing her boyfriend in a car.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Department is investigating a black actress’s claim that she was treated unfairly by police officers who detained her after she was seen kissing her white boyfriend in a car, and a claim by the boyfriend, a celebrity chef, that racial profiling played a role.

headline: Regulator Slow to Respond to Deadly Vehicle Defects
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An investigation by The New York Times has found that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration frequently has been slow to identify problems, tentative to act and reluctant to employ its full legal powers against companies.
lead_paragraph: General Motors published an article in February on its Chevrolet website trumpeting an achievement certain to help sell a lot of cars.

headline: To N.F.L. Fans, the Sport’s Troubles Vanish Between the Lines
abstract: Issues like domestic abuse didn’t seem to impinge on Giants fans’ eager expectation of a game against the Cardinals at MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ. — On a gorgeous day outside MetLife Stadium, George Fitzgerald, a Giants fans of 32 years’ standing, tossed around a football with his brothers and son.

headline: Line by Line, E-Books Turn Poet-Friendly
abstract: Digital publishers have gotten better at creating e-books that preserve a poet’s meticulous formatting, but some writers are still leery of surrendering their work to the digital realm.
lead_paragraph: When John Ashbery, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, first learned that the digital editions of his poetry looked nothing like the print version, he was stunned. There were no line breaks, and the stanzas had been jammed together into a block of text that looked like prose. The careful architecture of his poems had been leveled.

headline: With Early Ryder Picks, Tom Watson Misses a Mark
abstract: Five U.S. Ryder Cup team members finished in the bottom 11 of the Tour Championship field. Billy Horschel, who is not on the squad, finished first to win the FedEx Cup title.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — If Tom Watson wanted a week off for his United States team members between the Tour Championship and the Ryder Cup, so be it. In return, Watson should have been obliged to hold off on naming his captain’s picks until after the last putt dropped Sunday at East Lake Golf Club.

headline: London Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 4
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Models (Professional)', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: So here we are in the home stretch with shows like Mulberry, Burberry, Christopher Kane, Tom Ford and more.
lead_paragraph: One of the nicest things about this city’s fashion week is that unlike in other cities, where the fashion “week” is usually at least seven days, bookended by little previews and after-spasms, this one is a whirlwind five. So here we are in the home stretch.

headline: Select Drugs Cause Most Childhood Poisonings
abstract: Twelve active ingredients were involved in almost half of hospitalizations of children for prescription drug poisoning, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Almost all prescription medicines in the United States come in bottles with child-resistant caps. Still, more than 9,000 children younger than 6 are hospitalized annually for the accidental ingestion of prescription drugs; three-quarters of these are 1- and 2-year-olds,  a new study reports.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Brandishing what constitutes a rebellious side in golf, Billy Horschel often turns his cap backward upon holing out at No. 18. He has pondered playing an entire round with that slacker look, even after being advised that the PGA Tour might assess a fine.

headline: Heineken Rejects Takeover Proposal by SABMiller

(ABC) DANCING WITH THE STARS The comedian Tommy Chong (above right with his professional dance partner, Peta Murgatroyd), the fashion designer Betsey Johnson, the track star Lolo Jones and the actor Antonio Sabato Jr. are among the new crop of dancers competing for the disco-ball trophy in this two-hour season premiere. Julianne Hough, a onetime professional on the show — whose brother, Derek Hough, will partner the YouTube sensation Bethany Mota — returns to sit alongside Len Goodman, Carrie Ann Inaba and Bruno Tonioli at the judges’ table.

lead_paragraph: A bony, 73-year-old Dominican pitcher stood atop a mound at the northern edge of Manhattan, tossing curveballs and sliders to the rhythm of salsa music. In the batter’s box, a portly man with a white goatee, gnawing on a wad of tobacco, awaited the pitcher’s long, exaggerated delivery.

headline: Yankees Grab Lead in the Ninth, but Then It Slips Through Their Hands

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — For the past couple of weeks, the Yankees have suffered several seemingly devastating losses, only to remain mathematically alive in the race for the second American League wild-card spot. Sunday’s loss seemed devastating enough to finally do them in for good.

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Derek Jeter sat at the same lectern and spoke into the same microphone that he did a year and three days earlier, but the words and the tone this time were different.

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — For much of Team Sky’s history, the black, custom-built buses that deliver its riders to most races were informally known as the Death Stars because of the team’s extraordinary dominance.

headline: Should Parents Limit How Much Time Children Spend on Tech Devices?
abstract: Do your parents limit how much time you spend on technology? Do they set limits on the types of things you are allowed to do with screens?
lead_paragraph: Smartphones, iPads, game systems, laptops, desktops and TVs. For decades, Americans had only one or two screens in their home. Now a single household might have dozens. Are children spending too much time staring at screens?

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Meghan Daum on the Confessions of Lena Dunham
abstract: Meghan Daum, a columnist at the Los Angeles Times, wrote this week’s cover story about Lena Dunham. Here, she discusses her first impressions of Dunham, the actor’s political leanings and more.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Daum, a columnist at The Los Angeles Times, wrote this week’s cover story about the writer, actress, screenwriter, producer and director Lena Dunham. Daum’s new book of essays, “The Unspeakable: And Other Subjects of Discussion,” will be published in November by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.​

headline: A Car, a Camera and the Open Road
abstract: The road trip — a quintessential American rite of passage — has a dark, surreal and sometimes funny side, all captured in a new book.
lead_paragraph: For a country whose central myths involve travel and its sidekick, reinvention, Americans are often clueless about the true nature of the road. It is not about freedom, rubber, the wind in your hair and “Born to Be Wild” on the stereo. The road is about hardship. It’s the thing between the places we want to be — it’s where we are when we’re 50 miles from nowhere. Look at a typical car commercial, with a hot-looking red sedan carving beautiful S-curves on an empty highway: You’ll never, ever be on that road, any more than you’ll wind up at the end of it with the ad’s blonde supermodel.

headline: Ask Well: Plantar Fasciitis Relief
abstract: If you have stairs or a sturdy box in your home, along with a backpack, timely relief for plantar fasciitis may be possible.

headline: After Dog Rescues, Chinese Activists Left With a Daunting Task
abstract: Bills keep mounting for animal welfare advocates who have stepped forward to take responsibility for hundreds of dogs recently seized by the authorities in China.
lead_paragraph: Every morning since late August, Li Wei has started her day by putting on rubber boots and wading through a barrel of disinfectant before entering a shed filled with dozens of dogs that would have wound up on restaurant tables were it not for rescuers like herself. She and other volunteers in Lucun, a village on the southwestern outskirts of Beijing, then get to the day’s chores: feeding the dogs, filling their water bowls, washing the floor and helping veterinarians administer rabies shots. When the sickest animals die, the volunteers carry the bodies out for burial. They can’t afford cremation, Ms. Li said.

headline: Paris Airports Quiet as Air France Pilots Strike
abstract: Unions have threatened to strike through Friday in a dispute over a plan to shift a large part of the airline’s operations to a low-cost subsidiary.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France canceled roughly half of its flights on Monday, upending the travel plans of tens of thousands of passengers. The airline warned that disruptions were likely to worsen on Tuesday after a strike by its pilots.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Obama administration is open to talking with Iran on the security crisis in Iraq, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Monday, even after Iran’s supreme leader angrily said Tehran would no longer discuss Middle East issues with the United States.

keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Education (K-12)', 'Privacy', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Technology companies are collecting a vast amount of data about students, touching every corner of their educational lives — with few controls on how those details are used, Natasha Singer reports.

headline: A Burning Man-Style Finale for a Giant Rabbit in Taiwan
abstract: An 82-foot-tall rabbit created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman met with a calamitous end, catching fire as it was being disassembled after drawing huge crowds at an arts festival in Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: For 11 days, the giant white rabbit peacefully lolled on the grassy roof of a hangar at a former air base in northern Taiwan. But after the Taoyuan Land Art Festival ended on Sunday, the 82-foot-tall work by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman met a calamitous end.

headline: Maker of Costly Hepatitis C Drug Sovaldi Strikes Deal on Generics for Poor Countries
keywords: ['Sovaldi (Drug)', 'Hepatitis', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The maker of one of the costliest drugs in the world announced on Monday that it had struck deals with seven generic drug makers in India to sell lower-cost versions of the medicine — a $1,000-a-pill hepatitis C treatment — in poorer countries.

headline: In a Season of Deadly Rains in India, Does the New Prime Minister Believe in Climate Change?
abstract: In the wake of devastating monsoon floods in northern India and Pakistan, Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s confusing comments on climate change are troubling.
lead_paragraph: More than 450 deaths were reported as monsoon floods ravaged parts of northern Pakistan and the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir last week. The area is weathering the heaviest rainy season in more than half a century. A photo essay compiled for The Atlantic illustrates the awful scale of the devastation.

headline: Police Detain Tie Liu, Beijing Writer and Underground Publisher
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: After charging the 81-year-old with “creating a disturbance,” officers hauled away computers and his cellphone, as well as books and periodicals.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At 81 years old and after decades imprisoned in labor camps as a foe of the Communist Party, the Beijing writer and underground publisher Tie Liu had said that he was too old to seriously worry the security police anymore. But they raided his home over the weekend and detained him on a charge of “creating a disturbance,” his wife and friends said on Monday.

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Limiting Choice to Control Health Spending: A Caution
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Consumer Protection', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: In the 1990s, consumers rebelled against the restrictions imposed by health maintenance organizations. There’s a risk it could happen again.
lead_paragraph: To what extent will the recent moderation in the growth of health care prices and spending continue? This is a big question, and the answer relies on many factors. But for plans offered in the new health insurance exchanges as well as a substantial minority of employer-sponsored plans, it may depend, in part, on how long consumers are willing to trade lower premiums for less choice. History offers a cautionary tale.

headline: The Problem With Going Into Business With a Friend
abstract: Of all the dramas that entrepreneurs discuss with one another over drinks, the merging of personal relationships with business seems to cause the most pain.
lead_paragraph: I spent a recent night consoling an associate who had fallen out with her best friend. They tried to start a business together, and she quit her high-paying job to do it. Three months in, the friend had yet to commit full-time and wasn’t pulling her weight. They couldn’t agree on how to split either the tasks or the ownership stakes. Tension built and eventually exploded, and the business died before it was born. Their 15-year friendship was over.

headline: What the Apple Watch Says About Apple
abstract: The Apple Watch is both a product and the embodiment of Apple’s values — taste, trust and utility — that have long guided the company’s product and design decisions.
lead_paragraph: Watching Timothy D. Cook last week as he introduced the Apple Watch to the world was almost touching, in his channeling of his predecessor. The back-and-forth pacing of the stage, the hand gestures, the cadence of his speech and the script unabashedly filled with superlatives — “We set out to build the best watch in the world” — were all reminiscent of the late Steven P. Jobs.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 15, 2014

headline: Morning Agenda: Investors Hungry for Alibaba I.P.O.
abstract: Alibaba’s bankers may raise the price range of the initial public offering this week. | William Ackman plans to list a fund in Amsterdam. | Heineken rejected a takeover approach made by SABMiller. | Apple’s chief gave an interview to Charlie Rose.
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS HUNGRY FOR ALIBABA I.P.O. | With the Alibaba Group expected to price its initial public offering on Thursday, investors are lining up to get a piece of the Chinese e-commerce giant. The flood of orders has been even stronger than expected. Just five days into the company’s journey to promote itself to prospective buyers, Alibaba’s underwriters told their sales staffs at the end of last week that they planned to close orders for the I.P.O. by this Wednesday, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. Given the intense interest, the company’s bankers may eventually raise the price range for the offering, pushing it past a fund-raising goal of $21.1 billion. That could make it the biggest I.P.O. of all time.

But conservationists warned that the plan did not go far enough.

headline: 1889: Possible Murder Clue Found
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A suspicious item was found in the Jack the Ripper case in 1889.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What may prove an important discovery in connection with the recent murder in Whitechapel was made on Saturday night [Sept. 14]. The fireman Etherden was standing on the floating fire station at Charing Cross when he noticed something floating gently by. He succeeded in reaching it and found that it was a brown paper parcel which contained a chemise covered with blood. The parcel was at once handed to the police at Scotland Yard. There is a large class of people here who are potently affected by Jack the Ripper and they form an amusing class. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 16, 1889

headline: Ray Rice Is Expected to Appeal Suspension by N.F.L.
abstract: Rice could make several arguments to the N.F.L., but representing Rice will be tricky for the players union and the national backlash against him has been strong.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. Players Association is expected to appeal the indefinite suspension given last week to Ray Rice, the former Baltimore Ravens running back, after a graphic video of him punching his fiancée was released, according to a person with knowledge of the decision.

headline: Beating Back the Risk of Diabetes
abstract: The factors that improve your chances of avoiding the Type 2 variety of the disease are unmistakable: weight loss and exercise.
lead_paragraph: This year, nearly two million American adults and more than 5,000 children and adolescents will learn they have a potentially devastating, life-shortening, yet largely preventable disease: Type 2 diabetes. They will join 29.1 million Americans who already have diabetes.

headline: 1914: Prisoners Escape Paris Crowd
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Parisians are eager to see prisoners of war in 1914.
lead_paragraph: More than 300 German prisoners were expected at the Gare de l’Est in Paris on Monday afternoon. But such a large crowd gathered that the Prefect of Police arranged at the last minute that they should be sent round by the Grande Ceinture Railway from Noisy-le-Sec to Juvisy. The rumor of their coming also promised that a real general would be among them. A correspondent of the ‘‘Liberté,’’ who discovered the train on a siding at Juvisy station, saw the general in the flesh and learned that a document had been found on him, signed by the Emperor, nominating him the Assistant Governor of Paris! — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 16, 1914

headline: The Plaster Master
abstract: A Dallas-based sculptor uses an underappreciated medium to make seductive works of art.
lead_paragraph: “Sexed-up Greco-Roman” is how George Sellers describes his latest collection of furniture, lighting and peculiar objects. The Dallas-based sculptor, who started his career apprenticing with a master stone carver in Italy, works almost exclusively with the underappreciated medium of plaster. “We study the frescoes and paintings on ceilings, but look right past the incredible moldings,” says Sellers, whose seductive, gothic pieces — an alabaster snake coiled around the base of a lamp, tables with branchlike legs so angular they look arthritic — are available exclusively at Flair, a high-end design shop in New York, next month. From $400, flairhomecollection.com

headline: General Motors Defect Now Faulted in 19 Deaths
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: The tally, announced on Monday by the lawyer Kenneth Feinberg, is higher than the 13 fatalities the automaker has linked to a defective ignition system.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from General Motors’ faulty ignition switch is rising.

headline: Royal New Zealand Ballet Names New Director
abstract: The Italian dancer and choreographer Francesco Ventriglia will take over following the departure of Ethan Stiefel.
lead_paragraph: The Italian dancer and choreographer Francesco Ventriglia has been appointed as the director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet, following the departure of Ethan Stiefel from the position on Sept. 1. The appointment, announced on Monday by the company, comes after an intensive recruitment process that followed the surprise resignation of Mr. Stiefel, a former American Ballet Theater principal dancer, who took on the job in 2011. Mr. Stiefel raised the profile of the company, bringing it on tour to New York and inviting guest stars from Ballet Theater to dance with the company.

headline: Today in Small Business: 30 Start-Ups to Watch
abstract: An iconic hardware store closes after nearly 100 years in business. Why “Shark Tank” doesn’t represent the real world of investing. And how Urban Outfitters became “the official clothing store of Outrage Twitter.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

abstract: This is a good week to start test-driving new fall looks, or at least narrow down your wish list.
lead_paragraph: Forecast: Low to mid-70s this week, possible precipitation on Tuesday.

abstract: Goucher College hopes allowing videos instead of transcripts will lead to a more diverse applicant pool, but the plan already has its critics.
lead_paragraph: You may be familiar with the video résumé. Now meet its younger sibling: the video college application.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Executive shufflings at Condé Nast and a reorganization of advertising sales at the Weather Company.
lead_paragraph: Ambassador Hotel Collection, Tulsa, Okla., chose Howerton & White, Wichita, Kan., as its agency of record. Spending was estimated at $2 million. The company — whose four hotels are becoming part of the Autograph Collection under the Marriott banner — had previously used various local agencies for advertising.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Readers are unhappy with the back-to-back commercial practice.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Afghan Court Confirms 5 Death Sentences in Rape Case That Led to Outrage
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Capital Punishment', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Confessions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture']
abstract: Five of the seven defendants in a gang rape case were condemned to death, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan appeals court confirmed death sentences on Monday against five of the seven defendants in a notorious robbery and rape case, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.

headline: Mississippi Death Row Case Faults Bite-Mark Forensics
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Forensic Science', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: Eddie Lee Howard Jr. was convicted of murder largely because of what many experts call a far-fetched match of his teeth to purported bite wounds.
lead_paragraph: In one of the country’s first nationally televised criminal trials, of the smirking serial murderer Ted Bundy in Florida in 1979, jurors and viewers alike were transfixed as dental experts showed how Mr. Bundy’s crooked teeth resembled a bite on a 20-year-old victim.

headline: For Inspiration in Creating College Ratings, Look to Health Care
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Tuition', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A cautionary tale as the Obama administration prepares a system that it hopes will improve college quality and hold down tuition costs.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is preparing a system of college ratings that it hopes will improve college quality and hold down tuition by arming consumers with better information.

headline: Zandra Vinegar and Rafael Cosman’s Wide-Eyed Bullfrog Puzzle
abstract: How will the frogs breed? Check out this puzzle by Rafael Cosman and Zandra Vinegar.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago it was ants. Last week, bugs. This week our nature theme continues with bullfrogs, all beautifully illustrated by the Spot the Frog artist Mark Heath. The puzzle is an original collaboration by Zandra Vinegar, a recent graduate of MIT who lives, does math, builds furniture, and teaches in Berkeley, Calif., and Rafael Cosman, who is in his senior year at Stanford University, where he studies computer science.

headline: Yayoi Kusama’s Pumpkin Art, a Smorgasbord of Sake and More From the Cultural Calendar
abstract: Plus: an emotional new show from Mickalene Thomas, an arts fest in the Catskills and Bryan Voltaggio’s dinner for a great cause.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday, Frederick, Md.Combat child hunger by eating a meal from top chefsBryan Voltaggio has teamed up with the Washington, D.C.-based nonprofit Share Our Strength to host a fund-raising dinner at his flagship Maryland restaurant, Volt, featuring five award-winning American chefs. To date, Voltaggio has raised more than half a million dollars toward ending childhood hunger in the U.S.6 p.m., Volt restaurant, 228 N. Market St., Frederick, Maryland, ce.strength.org

headline: Off the Drugs, Onto the Cupcakes
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Food', 'Sugar', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Weight']
abstract: Programs to rehabilitate substance abusers are starting to become conscious of diet, learning that sugar addiction can replace drug addiction.
lead_paragraph: Rodney Zimmers was 21 years old and 135 pounds when he got off heroin and cocaine for good. Three years later, he was still drug free but had ballooned to 250. He blames his weight gain on the high-calorie, high-sugar food served in rehabilitation.

headline: Beer Merger of Heineken and SABMiller Could Clear Antitrust Hurdles
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Beer', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A combined Heineken-SAB Miller would have a strong global profile, and the two companies could group or sell off assets to meet any antitrust concerns, writes Robert Cole of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Heineken has rebuffed a takeover approach from SABMiller as “non-actionable.” As you might expect from a combination of the world’s second- and third-biggest brewing companies after ABInbev, there are major competition concerns.

headline: Greed Continues to Fuel Penny Stock Frauds
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Fraud in the market for penny stocks continues unabated, two criminal cases filed last week show, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: In his celebrated portrayal of fraudulent sales practices in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Martin Scorsese did not show the victims who bought the penny stocks that fueled the profits of Jordan Belfort and the brokers at Stratton Oakmont. One would think that a blockbuster movie might teach investors a lesson about trusting such brokers, but fraud in the market for penny stocks continues unabated, as two criminal cases filed last week show.

headline: Veteran Banjo Player Wins Bluegrass Honor
abstract: The banjo player Eddie Adcock, 76, won the Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Bluegrass and Banjo.
lead_paragraph: For any musician, winning a prestigious industry award brings the approval of your peers and the validation of your work. For Eddie Adcock, the winner of this year’s Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass, the distinction and the $50,000 cash prize that accompanies it mean even more.

headline: Christopher Kane: Spring 2015 RTW

lead_paragraph: London

headline: Richmond, Va., Makes a Bold Appeal for L.G.B.T. Tourists
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: A regional tourism organization has begun a campaign in which the city comes out of its closet.
lead_paragraph: The cry “Come out, come out, wherever you are” has taken on new meaning as more Americans who are lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (L.G.B.T.) come out of the closet, telling friends and family about their sexual orientation. A regional tourism organization is now echoing the process a person goes through in coming out to present a city as a welcoming destination for L.G.B.T. visitors.

headline: Capitoline Museums in Rome to Join With University of Missouri to Catalog Artifacts
abstract: The university will research and analyze 249 pieces of black-glazed pottery, performing tests that the Roman institution can not afford on its own.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Beginning this semester, students at the University of Missouri will get a hands-on opportunity to study ancient artifacts through a pilot project with the Capitoline Museums in Rome.

headline: Vikings’ Adrian Peterson Cleared to Play as His Lawyer Denies a New Abuse Allegation
abstract: The Vikings said the star running back, who faces child abuse charges in Texas, would participate in practices and meetings this week.
lead_paragraph: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — Adrian Peterson, the Minnesota Vikings’ All-Pro running back who faces child abuse charges in Texas, never appeared in the locker room while it was open to the news media Monday. The only indication Peterson was back at the team’s Winter Park headquarters came from a note taped to the chair at his locker, summoning him to report for a random N.F.L. drug test.

headline: Minecraft’s Creator, the Ambivalent Billionaire
abstract: After Microsoft’s $2.5 billion agreement to buy his company, the creator of Minecraft has written one of the most unusual, refreshingly honest letters ever written by a company founder who just became incredibly rich.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In Minecraft, Markus Persson created one of the biggest, most enchanting games of the past decade. And now he has written one of the most unusual, refreshingly honest letters penned by a company founder who just got incredibly rich.

headline: Google Introduces Android One Phone for Emerging Markets
abstract: Beginning in India, where a new line of smartphones will cost as little as about $100, the tech giant is teaming up with manufacturers and giving them hardware designs to make phones less expensive.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — Google chose India to introduce on Monday the first of a series of affordable smartphones under its Android One initiative, a bid by the company to win over the “next billion” users in emerging economies.

headline: O.E.C.D. Urges Stimulus Measures for Eurozone
abstract: The organization recommended that the European Central Bank pump money into the economy, as the Federal Reserve has done with its bond buying.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Central Bank should begin large-scale bond buying to ensure that weak price pressures do not further undermine demand in the eurozone, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Monday, as it cut its forecast for growth in the developed world.

headline: Philadelphia Museum Losing Its Maurice Sendak Collection
abstract: The Rosenbach Museum and Library will send thousands of Sendak items to Connecticut, where a Sendak museum is planned.
lead_paragraph: A small museum and library in Philadelphia, the Rosenbach Museum and Library, is about to lose one of its biggest draws: a large collection of Maurice Sendak manuscripts, drawings and other materials – some 10,200 pieces – that the author and artist deposited with the institution, starting in the late 1960s.

headline: Inside the World of Longsword Fighting
abstract: Longsword enthusiasts are resurrecting ancient sword technique as a modern, organized sport, with timed bouts and complex rules.
lead_paragraph: Longsword enthusiasts are resurrecting ancient sword technique as a modern, organized sport, with timed bouts and complex rules.

headline: Orange Offers to Acquire Spanish Rival for $4.4 Billion
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:18 p.m. | Orange of France offered Monday to acquire Jazztel, the Spanish telecommunications provider, in a deal valued at 3.4 billion euros, or about $4.4 billion.

headline: Egyptian Activist Alaa Abd El Fattah Is Released on Bail
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Mr. Abd El Fattah, a blogger from a prominent family of writers and activists, was jailed under a new law restricting protests but released by a judge who cited potential “embarrassment.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Monday released the left-leaning activist Alaa Abd El Fattah from prison on bail in a rare example of leniency in the thousands of cases of political dissenters arrested since the military takeover last year.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe discusses tech product announcements and the lull in innovation plaguing Internet 2.0.
lead_paragraph: With characteristic pomp and circumstance (and a performance by U2), Apple unveiled a host of new products last week: iPhones that are bigger and slimmer; a mobile payments system that will supplant credit cards; and a smart watch that tracks fitness, updates baseball scores, and opens hotel rooms with a flick of the wrist. Oh, and it also tells time. The digital wizardry is spectacular, but are the products real game changers?

headline: “Honey Skin” and Matte Red Lips at Burberry Prorsum Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: For a collection inspired by the birds and the bees, Wendy Rowe created a golden flush, “tawny eyes” and brick-hued pouts.
lead_paragraph: “This collection is all about the birds and the bees,” said the Burberry makeup artist Wendy Rowe backstage before the label’s show this morning. “How that translates to the makeup is with honey skin and a tawny eye.” Rowe used a selection of colors on the lids, depending on each model’s skin tone, to mimic the effect of a subtle shadow. She then used Burberry’s New Eyebrows (out in October) to sculpt arches. “Not only is the color amazing, you can create a shadow rather than a solid block of color,” she said. “It’s completely foolproof and doesn’t look drawn on; it’s not heavy, it’s more sophisticated.” The models’ skin, meanwhile, positively glowed under an insect- and flower-printed, greenhouse-like tent. Rowe first treated the face with Fresh Glow Luminous Fluid Base in Golden Radiance before highlighting the cheeks. “The Golden Radiance works on any skin tone and you can’t see it,” she explained. “It just gives you a lift of a tan, which we want for summer.” For lips, Burberry’s Lip Definer in Brick Red was treated with a dusting of Fresh Glow Powder for a matte finish. “Yes, the red lip can, of course, look classic,” Rowe added. “But we want to keep it modern — that’s why we kept the eyes nude and the skin slightly darker.”

headline: A Pioneer as Elusive as His Particle
abstract: The Nobel laureate Peter Higgs, 85, whose public appearances have been as rare and fleeting as the tracks of the Higgs boson, discussed his life’s work in an interview at an Edinburgh cafe.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH, Scotland — On Oct. 8 last year, when the Nobel Prize in Physics was to be announced, Peter Higgs decided it would be a good day to get out of town.

headline: An Uzbek Specialty, for a Special Occasion
abstract: Plov, a rice dish cooked with beef, onions, carrots and cumin seeds, is beloved as the national dish of Uzbekistan, and is fitting for tables on Rosh Hashana.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet street in Rego Park, Queens, sits the small clapboard house of Aron Aronov, who speaks 10 languages, reads dictionaries for pleasure and once traveled as an interpreter for Richard M. Nixon.

headline: A Sister, and Brother, in Arms
abstract: When Teresa Fazio’s brother Mike followed her into the military, the Marine in her was impressed. The sister in her was terrified.
lead_paragraph: Just before Sept. 11, 2001, my teenage brother Mike, fresh from Air Force training, pressed something small into my palm: two pin-backings stubbed on a curled shape in dusky silver. Jump wings.

headline: Democrats Put Cultural Issues in Their Quiver
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Democrats are using wedge issues in states like Virginia, North Carolina and Colorado to stoke concerns about Republicans among moderate voters, especially women.
lead_paragraph: RESTON, Va. — After a generation of campaigns in which Republicans exploited wedge issues to win close elections, Democrats are now on the offensive in the culture wars.

headline: To Escape Fighting in Ukraine, Shakhtar Donetsk Takes an Indefinite Road Trip
abstract: The professional soccer team Shakhtar Donetsk relocated to Kiev because of intense bombardment in the city over the last few months.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Plumes of thick black smoke and a rapid-fire echo of explosions rose into the afternoon sky.

headline: Fighting Poisons With Bacteria
abstract: Scientists are looking at the vast and untapped microbial community that lives near the roots of rice plants for ways to protect the crop from arsenic.
lead_paragraph: When Harsh Bais grows rice plants in trays of water in his greenhouse at the University of Delaware, he can easily spot the ones that have been exposed to arsenic: They are stunted, with shorter stems and shrunken, yellow-tinged leaves.

headline: The Juan MacLean Triumphs Over Tragedy With a Sparkling New Dance Album
abstract: Five years after losing its drummer, the Brooklyn-based act is back with a new collection of disco-inflected tracks — one of which, “You Were a Runaway,” streams here.
lead_paragraph: When John MacLean began making disco-inflected dance music for his old friend and LCD Soundsystem honcho James Murphy’s influential DFA label, he added a “The” in front of the Spanish variant of his name to ensure that his recordings could be more than just a solo project. In the 14 years since then, none of The Juan MacLean‘s many collaborators have become more central to the music than the singer and frontwoman Nancy Whang.

headline: Wildlife Agency Seeks Educational Use For Crushed Ivory
abstract: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service is seeking ideas on how to use the crushed remains of illegal ivory it has confiscated and destroyed. The agency wants to use the rubble in a way that increases awareness about the consequences of the illegal trade in ivory.
lead_paragraph: As you may have heard, the United States Fish and Wildlife Agency and counterparts elsewhere, including in China and France, have been crushing tons of confiscated elephant ivory in the fight against elephant poaching.

headline: Conical Teeth and Crocodilian Snouts: On the Dinosaur Beat with Ken Chang
abstract: The Times’s Kenneth Chang shares the backstory to reporting on an ancient subject.
lead_paragraph: Science reporter Kenneth Chang reported in a Sept. 11 article about the unveiling of a new skeleton of a large swimming dinosaur. The Times’s de facto dinosaur reporter explains how he works the dino beat — and how the story about the Spinosaurus found its way into the paper.

headline: Walkabout: Marriott Encourages Tipping; Air France Pilots Strike
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Please Give Marriott International is placing envelopes in more than 160,000 rooms in the United States and Canada to encourage tipping the people who clean guest rooms. (CNN)

headline: In New Orleans, a Printing Collective That Does Things the Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: A throwback to a pre-digital era, the recently founded Baskerville Studio is a home to classic book arts practiced on century-old machines.
lead_paragraph: As a late summer downpour passes through New Orleans, Amelia Bird leans over a hulking platen press inside Baskerville Studio. An embossed plastic label that reads “Beulah, Born 1901″ identifies the apparatus, one of three, each weighing thousands of pounds, at the nonprofit printing collective located in the city’s up-and-coming Bywater neighborhood. Bird spins a wheel of the antique machine with weary pleasure, then rolls out yellow ink and puts down sheets of paper one at a time. She’s producing a poster concept by the fellow Baskerville member Jeffrey Goodman that uses digitally designed polymer plates and metal type. The end product will be distributed as a souvenir during the film exhibitor Shotgun Cinema’s upcoming screening of the Talking Heads’s 1984 documentary “Stop Making Sense” held at the nearby Marigny Opera House.

headline: Confession in Etan Patz’s Killing: ‘I Tried to Stop, but I Couldn’t’
abstract: A videotaped statement from Pedro Hernandez, the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz in 1979, was made public for the first time on Monday. His lawyer argued that the statement is a false confession.
lead_paragraph: The confession came in a soft, unwavering tone. He recalled when he first spotted the boy, standing on the sidewalk outside a bodega where he worked at West Broadway and Prince Street in SoHo.

headline: Investing Against the Odds, and the Facts
abstract: The improbability of beating a market index with individual stock picks is irrefutable. If you choose to ignore that fact, you should at least understand why.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, I was on a hike with a friend and mentioned that while we’d started at about 9,000 feet, we’d reach an elevation of 12,000 feet by the end of the trail. My friend replied, “That’s a fact I just don’t believe.”

headline: Online Orders for New iPhones Exceed 4 Million
abstract: The company said Monday that orders for its new iPhones — the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus — topped four million in the first 24 hours they became available for order online. That is double the number of early online orders for the iPhone 5 two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Early signs show that bigger iPhones are already leading to bigger sales for Apple.

headline: A Rising Guitarist Tries a New Challenge
abstract: Blake Mills has quickly grown a reputation as a virtuosic guitarist, but his songwriting takes center stage on his album “Heigh Ho,” being released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Eric Clapton recently called him “the last guitarist I heard that I thought was phenomenal.” The producer Don Was says he is “one of those rare musicians who come along once in a generation.” He has played with the likes of Beck, Lana Del Rey and Neil Diamond.

headline: That Itchy Feeling? It May Just Be Love
abstract: The musical “Bedbugs!!!” finds humor in mutant insects that terrorize New York City.
lead_paragraph: “A theatrical blast of fresh air” might seem an odd way to describe a show in which large quantities of (fake) insecticide are sprayed about the stage, but that’s just the right phrase for “Bedbugs!!!,” at the ArcLight Theater.

headline: N.F.L. Players Union on Its Role in a Possible Appeal by Rice
abstract: A spokesman for the N.F.L. players union answered questions about the expected appeal of the indefinite suspension given to Ray Rice after the release of video of him punching his then-fiancée.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. Players Association is expected to appeal the indefinite suspension given last week to Ray Rice, the former Baltimore Ravens running back, after a graphic video showing him punching Janay Palmer, then his fiancée, was released. The union has until 11:59 p.m. Eastern on Tuesday to appeal.

headline: Cairo Courtroom Erupts in Celebration at Dissidents’ Release
abstract: Democracy activists cheered as an Egyptian judge ordered the release on bail of three prominent dissidents jailed for attending a protest last year.
lead_paragraph: After a series of verdicts that have disheartened democracy activists in Egypt, there were rare images of celebration in a Cairo courtroom on Monday when a judge ordered the release on bail of three prominent dissidents imprisoned for attending a protest last year.

headline: Deciphering the Menu
abstract: A new book from a Stanford University linguistics professor looks at how we describe what we eat.
lead_paragraph: The menu at Root & Bone, a Southern restaurant that opened in Alphabet City in June, is loaded with precision-engineered descriptions like “Drunken Deviled Eggs,” “Crispy Free-Range Bucket of Bird” and a breadless BLT that promises to “tickle your pickle.”

headline: Medieval Weapon Finds Modern Appeal
abstract: Renewed interest in historical European martial arts has turned swordfighting with blunted medieval weapons into a niche organized sport with annual competitions.
lead_paragraph: A hotel ballroom in Ellicott City, Md., seemed an unlikely setting for a four-day competition involving ancient martial arts, Longpoint 2014.

headline: Flight Upgrades Much Harder to Secure, Even for Elite Travelers
abstract: While free upgrades to the front of the plane were once a common perk for frequent fliers, such giveaways now are largely limited to the ultra-elite.
lead_paragraph: Paul Dougherty flies more than 100,000 miles each year on United Airlines, which places him in one of the top tiers of the airline’s frequent-flier program. This entitles Mr. Dougherty to early boarding, free checked baggage and spiffy luggage tags.

headline: Reconsidering What to Call an Extremist Group
abstract: Editors have decided to adjust how The Times refer to an Islamic extremist group that controls territory in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Philip B. Corbett is the associate managing editor for standards and oversees The Times’s style manual.

headline: Motorsports Monday: Formula E Has a Bang-Up Beijing Debut
abstract: A silent new racing series got its start; Brad Keselowski won the first race of the Chase competition.
lead_paragraph: Lucas di Grassi inherited the lead in the final turn and won the inaugural Formula E series event for electric cars on Saturday in Beijing, after Nicolas Prost and Nick Heidfeld crashed while dueling for the victory.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Curious Incident’ Off to a Strong Start
abstract: “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” had solid sales in its first week of preview performances.
lead_paragraph: One of the most anticipated new plays of the fall season on Broadway, “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” had solid ticket sales for its first set of preview performances last week, while the new revival of A.R. Gurney’s “Love Letters” was off to a slower start, according to box office data released on Monday.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in London. Here, the model Catarina Santos before (left) and after (right) makeup by Thomas de Kluyver and hair by Duffy.
