headline: About Urban Outfitters’ Blood-Stained Kent State Sweatshirt…
abstract: Urban Outfitters apologized “sincerely” for giving offense.
lead_paragraph: Let us dwell for a moment — in the name of schadenfreude — on the mini tempest involving the clothing chain Urban Outfitters, which for some unfathomable reason offered up what sure looks like a blood-splattered version of a Kent State University sweatshirt.

headline: Alibaba Raises Fund-Raising Target for I.P.O. to $21.8 Billion
abstract: The company raised the price range for its initial public offering to $66 to $68 for each American depositary share, according to a regulatory filing on Monday, pushing up its potential haul from the stock sale to as much as $21.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: With demand for the Alibaba Group’s stock market debut proving even stronger than expected, the Chinese e-commerce giant has done the only logical thing: set its fund-raising sights even higher.

headline: Nominee for European Post Voices Concern About U.S. Tech Giants
abstract: Günther Oettinger, the E.U.’s nominee for digital economy commissioner, said that were Google to manufacture goods like cars and TVs, European businesses could be consigned to playing a small role in innovative products.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Google should be blocked from expanding into making goods like cars and televisions, the European Union’s nominee for digital economy commissioner said over the weekend.

headline: Porsche’s Pop-Up Shop
abstract: The German sports car maker sets up a temporary store in Manhattan’s meatpacking district.
lead_paragraph: The sign on the door — The Sound of Porsche — might suggest the roar of an engine. But inside Porsche’s pop-up store on 14th Street next to the High Line in Manhattan’s meatpacking district is a music store, the old-style kind with bins of vinyl and listening stations.

headline: London Fashion Week: Giles Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: Scots Are Told ‘Painful’ Split Would Follow a Yes Vote
abstract: In advance of Thursday’s referendum on Scotland’s independence, Prime Minister David Cameron emphasized the economic risks of a “yes” vote.
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — With Scotland’s independence referendum apparently too close to call, Prime Minister David Cameron on Monday used his final speech to Scots before Thursday’s vote to warn that there would be no turning back from a “painful divorce” from Britain.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: In Performance | Lance Coadie Williams
abstract: Mr. Williams plays a preacher with a secret in “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s comedy that explores attitudes toward homosexuality in black culture. The show is at Playwrights Horizons through Oct. 12.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Williams plays a preacher with a secret in “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s comedy that explores attitudes toward homosexuality in black culture. The show is at Playwrights Horizons through Oct. 12.

headline: Well Leaks, Not Fracking, Are Linked to Fouled Water
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Water Pollution', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'AQUIFERS', 'Research', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Environment']
abstract: The process of hydraulic fracturing, suspected by some environmentalists of letting natural gas get into aquifers, was not seen to blame for the pollution.
lead_paragraph: A study of tainted drinking water in areas where natural gas is produced from shale shows that the contamination is most likely caused by leaky wells rather than the process of hydraulic fracturing used to release the gas from the rock.

headline: A Strikeout With Love and God
abstract: Joshua Ferris’s “To Rise Again at a Decent Hour,” shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize, is about an atheistic but Philo-Semitic dentist who has no luck with women.
lead_paragraph: When Joshua Ferris’s “To Rise Again at a Decent Hour” arrived in May, there was no reason to suspect it would make history. But Mr. Ferris, along with Karen Joy Fowler (“We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves”), is one of the first two Americans with novels to be shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize in 2014. (This is the first year in which writers from the United States have been eligible.) Happily for Mr. Ferris, it is also the year he far surpassed his first two books.

headline: Replaying the 30s in Slow Motion
abstract: Now on the political side.
lead_paragraph: When the 2008 crisis struck, anyone who knew even a bit of history had nightmares about a replay of the 1930s — not just the depth of the depression, but the downward political spiral into dictatorship and war. But this time was different: the banking crisis was contained, the plunge in output and employment leveled out, and modern Europe’s democratic political culture proved more resilient than that of the interwar years. All clear!

headline: Air-Bag Investigation: The View From Honda
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Rick Schostek, executive vice president of Honda North America, responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Two for One in Each Tune
abstract: New albums by Barbra Streisand, Jason Moran and Mark Turner are released.
lead_paragraph: An invitation from Barbra Streisand to record a duet is still the closest thing in pop to a royal summons. Her newest duets album, “Partners” (Columbia), with its blurred edges and pastel shades, is even mistier, gauzier and more texturally diffuse than such confections as “Guilty.” The instrumentation and the vocal tracks are so processed in pursuit of a high-gloss perfection that any sense of two people standing side by side and singing their hearts out is lost.

headline: In Ferguson, a System of Injustice Through Fines
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Karin D. Martin of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice writes that the widespread practice of fine collection “raises challenging questions of fairness.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Season Premiere of ‘Sons of Anarchy’ Sets Ratings Record on FX
abstract: The show scored the best ratings of any program in the history of FX, with 9.25 million viewers between the live telecast and three days of playback.
lead_paragraph: The premiere of the final season of the FX drama “Sons of Anarchy” scored the best ratings of any program in the 20-year history of the cable channel, with 9.25 million viewers between the live telecast and three days of playback.

headline: White-Collar Sentences
abstract: The general counsel for Families Against Mandatory Minimums discusses guidelines for insider trading sentencing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Shifting Identity of Paris’s Biennale des Antiquaires
abstract: The decorative arts fair at the Grand Palais has become less a guidebook on how to live once you’ve made it and more a show to be considered one object at a time.
lead_paragraph: Nobody turns out to support decorative arts like the French do, and every two years the beau monde of Paris show up en masse for the Biennale des Antiquaires. Once, this event was for Wall Street titans seeking to furnish their apartments on Park Avenue. Hubert de Givenchy could be seen squiring the wives of junk-bond kings, advising and conferring with the certainty that pretty much all of them wanted to live in environments like his.

headline: The Long History of a Famous Sprint
abstract: “Olympics Über Alles” hopscotches among decades as it recounts how Marty Glickman and another Jewish runner were pulled from an American relay team in the Berlin Games.
lead_paragraph: Before he became a pioneering sports broadcaster, Marty Glickman was a Syracuse University track and football star, and “Olympics Über Alles,” now at St. Luke’s Theater, recalls the notorious behavior that victimized him in 1936. Or would, if it could get out of its own way.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Iraq, India, Mexico and Romania.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, India, Mexico and Romania.

headline: A Hip Basement Plays Host to Mozart and Mendelssohn
abstract: It was a classical music night at SubCulture, a performance space on Bleecker Street, as the pianist Weiyin Chen teamed up with the Camerata RCO players from Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: SubCulture, the inviting performance space on Bleecker Street that celebrates its first anniversary this week, combines elements of a downtown basement music club with a traditional 120-seat recital hall. A welcoming bar serves drinks and snacks, but not during performances, which distinguishes SubCulture from Le Poisson Rouge, the other, very popular basement performance space on Bleecker Street.

headline: A Show Within a Show About Another Show. Anyway, It’s Complicated.
abstract: The online-only curiosity “Play It Again, Dick” is billed as a “Veronica Mars” spinoff, but it doesn’t do that description justice.
lead_paragraph: The online-only curiosity “Play It Again, Dick” is billed as a “Veronica Mars” spinoff, but it doesn’t do that description justice. The most interesting thing about it is that a project featuring so many of the actors and characters from an existing series could feel so little like the original.

headline: A Burial Ground Doubling as a Stage
abstract: “Crossing Over: A Performance Adventure in Green-Wood Cemetery” used several devices to enliven that Brooklyn burial ground.
lead_paragraph: There are about 600,000 graves in Green-Wood Cemetery, located on 478 picturesque acres in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. On Friday beginning at dusk, participants in “Crossing Over: A Performance Adventure in Green-Wood Cemetery” entered the graveyard in small groups and roamed through those vast, verdant grounds along sloping pathways lit with Tiki torches, hanging lanterns and electric votive candles. We stopped at the burial sites of significant figures in New York’s performance history and, every so often, stumbled across a kind of choreographed reincarnation, as dancers appeared atop tombs, among headstones, inside catacombs.

headline: What Is the Right Way to Fight ISIS?
keywords: ['War Powers Act (1973)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Readers suggest how the United States and international community should react to Islamic militants.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Stylized: One Dance Does Not Fit All
abstract: Trajal Harrell presents in full his seven-part “Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church” at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: In the world of contemporary performance, shows come and go pretty quickly. “It happens for three nights, and then it’s over” is a common refrain, voiced sometimes with appreciation for the form’s evanescence but more often in distress over its scarce economic resources.

headline: Taking a Health Hazard Home
keywords: ['Pork', 'Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus', 'Factory Farming', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Bacteria', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Of the 22 industrial hog farm workers tested in a new study, 10 carried antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria in their noses for up to four days, raising public health questions.
lead_paragraph: A new study of a small group of workers at industrial hog farms in North Carolina has found that they continued to carry antibiotic-resistant bacteria over several days, raising new questions for public health officials struggling to contain the spread of such pathogens.

headline: A Baptism of Sorts in the Hollywood Hills
abstract: Daniel Ezralow’s new company offered its first program at the Ford Amphitheater in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nearly a century ago, the Ford Amphitheater was built in the Hollywood Hills as a site for Christian pageants. Although in more recent decades it has been home to secular performances, the mood there was consecratory on Saturday night as Daniel Ezralow’s new company, Ezralow Dance, made its debut.

headline: Science of Stem Cells
abstract: There is much hope and enthusiasm behind stem cell therapy. However, the science still has catching up to do.
lead_paragraph: There is much hope and enthusiasm behind stem cell therapy. However, the science still has catching up to do.

headline: An Empire Where the Curtain Would Not Fall
abstract: Howard Panter’s theater corporation has global intentions, but New York is crucial to his plans.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Howard Panter saw the budget for the 2005 Broadway transfer of “Sweeney Todd,” which he had produced a year earlier here in the West End, one line item surprised him — $50,000 for the pots and pans that would adorn the minimalist set. He told his producing partners in New York that he and John Doyle, the show’s director and designer, would go to a little junk shop down in the seaside port town of Hastings and get everything for just 500 pounds (or about $900 at the time).

headline: Surveillance Video of Robbery
abstract: The police are looking for three men who removed a cash register from behind the bar of Crema, a Mexican restaurant, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The police are looking for three men who removed a cash register from behind the bar of Crema, a Mexican restaurant, on Friday.

headline: How Keeping a Diary Can Surprise You
abstract: A new study suggests that looking back at records of our everyday experiences is a lot more fun than we might expect.
lead_paragraph: Many of us associate keeping a diary with our emotionally volatile teenage years. But new research suggests that recording our run-of-the-mill, daily experiences, rather than just our highs and lows, could bring us unexpected joy.

headline: At Manhattan Restaurant, a Robbery and an Oblivious Customer
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Restaurants']
abstract: A man having a drink at Crema, on West 17th Street, did not seem to notice a robbery taking place until the cash register had been ripped from its base.
lead_paragraph: When masked men, including one who drew a machete, robbed an upscale Mexican restaurant in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, the servers quickly edged out of the way or ducked out of sight.

headline: After 17 Years, ‘The View’ Isn’t So Clear Anymore
abstract: Most of what went on in the first episode of the new season of “The View” was rather stilted, despite the presence of new hosts.
lead_paragraph: The old bracketed the new “View.”

headline: Q. and A.: Adam Brookes on China, Secrets and Spies
abstract: Adam Brookes, formerly a longtime China correspondent for the BBC, has written “Night Heron,” a suspenseful page-turner that takes the reader from China’s far west to the streets of Beijing, pulsing with power, danger and intrigue.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a quarter century since the fall of the Soviet Union, but the settings for classic espionage and suspense novels have been slow to take root in the obvious new center of intrigue: Beijing. Adam Brookes, formerly a longtime China correspondent for the BBC, changed all that this year with the publication of “Night Heron,” a page turner that takes the reader from China’s far west to the streets of the fascinating Chinese capital, pulsing with power and danger.

headline: Betty Catroux-Style Shags at Tom Ford
abstract: The sideswept coif was the perfect complement to the rock-‘n’-roll-influenced spring/summer 2015 collection the designer showed this evening.
lead_paragraph: Betty Catroux-style shag cuts with sideswept bangs that slyly revealed smoky, kohl-rimmed eyes — a signature Tom Ford beauty look since his heyday at Gucci — were the perfect complement to the rock-‘n’-roll-influenced spring/summer 2015 collection the designer showed this evening.

headline: Robert Griffin III and the Sunk Cost Fallacy
abstract: Washington paid dearly to draft the quarterback in 2012, but that should have nothing to do with the team’s decisions about his future.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Redskins have a controversy over who ought to be their quarterback, and it illustrates one of the most pernicious mistakes in economic decision-making that all of us make. It’s about the sunk cost fallacy.

headline: The Trials of Stem Cell Therapy
abstract: Though enthusiasm for potential advances in disease and injury treatments often outstrips the science, thousands of clinical trials are now underway to figure out how to best use stem cells.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Irastorza was just 31 when his heart stopped beating in October 2008.

headline: What to Do When a Patient Admits an H.I.V. Phobia
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hypochondria', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes']
abstract: Is there any harm in prescribing drugs to a patient who believes she has been infected with H.I.V., even when all the evidence says she has not been exposed to the virus?
lead_paragraph: A pretty young woman was sitting in the examining room with her right forefinger stretched out on the table for inspection. I had never seen her before, but at first glance, she looked fine, and so did the finger.

headline: Quasicrystals and the Whimsy of Nature
abstract: A puzzling form of solid matter once regarded as impossible comes into view.
lead_paragraph: This occasional column explores topics covered in Science Times 25 years ago to see what has changed, and what has not.

headline: The Hidden Cities of World War I
abstract: Quarries and connecting trenches were nothing less than small cities, where the walls bear witness to the people who fought – and died – in World War I.
lead_paragraph: Quarries and connecting trenches were nothing less than small cities, where the walls bear witness to the people who fought – and died – in World War I.

headline: Among Malaria Parasites, Real Feel for Mosquitoes
abstract: Research suggests that malaria parasites in the blood can actually sense when their carriers are around, and increase their numbers accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible that malaria parasites circulating in the blood can actually sense that there are mosquitoes around? And that they react by increasing their numbers so the mosquitoes are more likely to carry them to a new host?

headline: Playful Rings
abstract: Fun, colorful objects to brighten your hand.
lead_paragraph: Fun, colorful objects to brighten your hand.

headline: ISIS Draws a Steady Stream of Recruits From Turkey
abstract: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Having spent most of his youth as a drug addict in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Turkey’s capital, Can did not think he had much to lose when he was smuggled into Syria with 10 of his childhood friends to join the world’s most extreme jihadist group.

headline: Calpers, Nation’s Biggest Pension Fund, to End Hedge Fund Investments
abstract: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System said it would liquidate its hedge fund investments in the next year on concerns that the investments are too complicated and expensive.
lead_paragraph: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the nation’s largest pension fund, will eliminate all of its hedge fund investments over the next year on concerns that investments are too complicated and expensive.

headline: The Case of the Missing Horseshoe Crabs
abstract: Harvesting pressure and habitat loss have contributed to a population decline in New York and around the Northeast over all.
lead_paragraph: Q. What happened to the horseshoe crabs I used to see from the bike path under the Throgs Neck Bridge, where the East River joins Long Island Sound?

headline: Spot Chosen for Comet Landing
abstract: The robotic Philae will shoot for the cross marks for a Nov. 11 landing on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.
lead_paragraph: The robotic Philae will shoot for the cross marks for a Nov. 11 landing on Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko. After detaching from the European Space Agency’s Rosetta spacecraft, Philae will aim for the spot known as Site J for what could be the first-ever soft landing on a comet.

headline: Tree-Protecting Ants Can’t Protect Themselves
abstract: The small bodyguards who defend acacia trees in Eastern Africa against elephants and giraffes are being killed off by other ants.
lead_paragraph: In the savannas of Eastern Africa, ants live in the thorny, hollow bulbs of acacia trees and feed on the trees’ nectar. The ants also act as bodyguards, defending the trees from hungry elephants and giraffes by biting and stinging them. Now, an invasive species known as the bigheaded ant is killing the native ants.

headline: A Green Blanket on the Arabian Sea
abstract: A vast bloom of phytoplankton in an oxygen-starved zone may change the food chain and disrupt local fishing, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: A winter bloom of phytoplankton is forming a thick carpet over an oxygen-starved dead zone in the northern Arabian Sea, a new study reports. Composed of tiny organisms called Noctiluca scintillans, the bloom thrives in low-oxygen conditions and colors the sea an emerald green each winter.

headline: An Alliance of Major Players to Guide Open-Source Software
abstract: Google, Walmart and Facebook are among companies in a new organization dedicated to creating standards and practices for the creation of big free software.
lead_paragraph: The combined force of cloud computing and mobile devices is changing our world, putting nearly infinite amounts of machine intelligence into billions of hands and millions of businesses.

headline: London Fashion Week: Peter Pilotto Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Google Report Shows Governments’ Increasing Demands for Users’ Data
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Google fielded 15 percent more requests for user data in the first six months of 2014 than in the previous six months.
lead_paragraph: Governments of all sizes are demanding that Google hand over growing troves of data about its users, according to the Internet giant’s latest transparency report. The report is a tally of all the times a government has used its legal authority to demand that Google hand over internal data about the people who use Google products like Gmail, YouTube or its namesake search engine.

headline: Yoko Ono’s Instagram Project, Alabama Chanin’s Virtual Dose of Southern Charm and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Art Entangled in Nature
abstract: The portraits of nature gathered here cover centuries, fixing on that space where the naturalist’s eye and the artist’s intersect.
lead_paragraph: At its core, “Of Green Leaf, Bird, and Flower” delights in that oh-so-human urge to catalog and collect, to understand, and then to pass that insight on to others — making it a book in which science and art blissfully hold hands.

headline: New York Files an Antitrust Suit Against the Maker of an Alzheimer’s Drug
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: The state attorney general said Actavis’s plan to stop selling an older tablet in favor of a newer one was an attempt to maintain a monopoly.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s attorney general filed an antitrust lawsuit on Monday seeking to stop a pharmaceutical company from forcing patients with Alzheimer’s disease to switch to a new version of a widely used drug. The lawsuit contends that the switch is designed to blunt competition from low-priced generic versions of the medication.

headline: Tomas Maier’s Outpost in Midtown
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The creative director of Bottega Veneta, Mr. Maier, explains his very special desk situation.
lead_paragraph: In the fifth of a video series on designers in their offices, Tomas Maier, the creative director of Bottega Veneta, explains his very special desk situation. (The conversation has been edited and condensed.) VANESSA FRIEDMAN

keywords: ['September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Tomas Maier, the creative director of Bottega Veneta, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his clean white office space in New York City helps him appreciate the happy accidents in his clothing.
lead_paragraph: Tomas Maier, the creative director of Bottega Veneta, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his clean white office space in New York City helps him appreciate the happy accidents in his clothing.

headline: Airlines Head Abroad, and Also Inland
abstract: The growing importance of international air traffic is redrawing route maps, even to cities away from the coastal United States.
lead_paragraph: HERE are some things to ponder from back in 36-B, with your knees pressed against the seat in front and your elbows wedged between you and the armrests.

headline: London Fashion Week: Tom Ford Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: More Than My Head Talks
abstract: On the East Side.
lead_paragraph: OK, I didn’t actually think I was giving a big talk this week, but one thing led to another and we will have a public lecture at Hunter College this Wednesday. I wonder what it will be about?

headline: Middle Eastern Petrochemical Plants Are Targets of Hackers
abstract: A pervasive form of financial malware has been modified and is now being used to hack into Middle Eastern petrochemical companies.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Security researchers at IBM said they had uncovered a series of hacking attacks aimed at Middle Eastern petrochemical companies.

headline: Try a D.I.Y. Fix for Public Housing
keywords: ['Vocational Training', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Why couldn’t the housing authority train tenants to do basic maintenance, and pay them for it?
lead_paragraph: IN most of America, when the paint starts to chip or the sink starts to drip, the homeowner fixes it. In New York, a city of renters, he calls the landlord. Or, if he is one of the 400,000 people living in a building owned by the New York City Housing Authority, known as Nycha, he calls maintenance.

headline: To Crush ISIS, Make a Deal With Assad
abstract: Syria has no “moderate opposition” to help us. But maybe Assad could.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — LAST week, President Obama virtually declared war on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. But it is hard to reconcile the seemingly urgent need to confront the threat posed by this organization with the chosen means of doing so.

headline: U.S. to Commit Up to 3,000 Troops to Fight Ebola in Africa
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Epidemics', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Under pressure to do more to confront the Ebola outbreak sweeping across West Africa, President Obama is expanding military and medical resources to combat the spread of the deadly virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to do more to confront the Ebola outbreak sweeping across West Africa, President Obama on Tuesday is to announce an expansion of military and medical resources to combat the spread of the deadly virus, administration officials said.

headline: Tiger Woods Striving to Return at His Tournament in December
abstract: Woods used the unveiling of his tournament’s new title sponsor to provide updates on his physical condition and his coaching search.
lead_paragraph: WINDERMERE, Fla. — After the playing of a video clip of highlights from Tiger Woods’s golf trip to India in February, Woods stepped to the microphone Monday at Isleworth Golf and Country Club and joked, “That’s my last good round I played all year.”

headline: Seeing the Invisible
abstract: This animated documentary celebrates the 17th-century citizen scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, whose discovery of microbes would change our view of the biological world.
lead_paragraph: This animated documentary celebrates the 17th-century citizen scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, whose discovery of microbes would change our view of the biological world.

headline: ‘Animated Life: Seeing the Invisible’
abstract: This animated documentary celebrates the scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, whose discovery of microbes would change our view of the biological world.
lead_paragraph: In 1674, Antonie van Leeuwenhoek looked at a drop of lake water through his homemade microscope and discovered an invisible world that no one knew existed. He was an unlikely pioneer — a haberdasher and city official by trade. In this film, we celebrate this 17th-century citizen scientist and a discovery that would ultimately change our view of the biological world, and our place in it.

headline: New DNA Test Sought in Identical Twin’s Rape Case
abstract: Prosecutors in Massachusetts hope the case will be a breakthrough for criminal cases involving identical twins.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The rape suspect, court papers said, was identified by a longtime friend who said they committed the crime together. The suspect’s DNA was tied to the crime. But prosecutors hoping to present an airtight case had a concern: The suspect, Dwayne McNair, has an identical twin, meaning the DNA testing pointed not to one person, but two.

headline: Surfer’s Travels Accompanied by Whales and Wipeouts
abstract: For a top professional surfer, airplane turbulence is nothing compared with crushing waves and shark worries.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was 17 years old, I started entering Association of Surfing Professionals events as a wild-card competitor. To say flying was a grind would be an understatement. You basically wind up going across the globe to surf in hopes that you’re good enough to qualify for an event. To be honest, I never wanted to look at a boarding pass again.

headline: As Bond-Buying Ends, Yellen Now Will Chart Course for Federal Reserve
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The Fed will next need to focus on the central bank’s power to set interest rates, but economic and strategic questions will shape their decisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s chairwoman, the easy part is over. The first phase of the Fed’s retreat from its economic stimulus campaign, plotted by her predecessor, is nearly complete. Now, as Ms. Yellen nears the end of her first year in office, it is her turn to chart the way forward.

headline: U.N. Moves Peacekeepers in Golan Over Safety Fears
abstract: The United Nations said it moved members of its Golan peacekeeping force to the Israeli-controlled side because the area had “deteriorated severely.”
lead_paragraph: Concerned about another attack or mass abduction targeting its Golan Heights peacekeepers, the United Nations said Monday that it had withdrawn many of them to the Israeli-controlled side of the peacekeepers’ buffer zone after unidentified armed groups from Syria moved menacingly close to their positions on the Syrian side.

headline: District of Columbia Officials Push for Statehood at a Senate Committee Hearing
abstract: It was the first congressional hearing on the issue in more than two decades, with the first bill introduced in the House in 1983.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Local officials implored a Senate panel on Monday to approve a bill that would grant statehood to the District of Columbia and give its residents the same electoral rights enjoyed by other Americans.

headline: At Work in a Bronx That Brims With Creativity
abstract: A photography exhibition at the Andrew Freedman Home on the Grand Concourse highlights the borough’s growing arts community.
lead_paragraph: Lazarus Nazario started painting more than two decades ago in the East Village, but like many other artists she was forced to move by rising rents, to Chinatown and, later, Staten Island and New Jersey.

headline: Going to War With the Allies You Have
abstract: Is the coalition in the fight against ISIS reliable enough?

abstract: In the wake of the recent Home Depot breach, you have to wonder if data theft has become a condition of modern life.
lead_paragraph: What is it going to take to get serious about data breaches?

headline: General Motors’ Fuel Pump Recall Reveals Patchwork Approach to Auto Safety
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Under regional recalls, carmakers limit notification and repairs to specific states or regions based on factors, like extreme heat, that cause a part to fail.
lead_paragraph: In July 2013, an angry and worried Connecticut owner of a 2007 Chevrolet Equinox wrote federal regulators to complain about a gasoline leak that a dealer refused to repair under a recall. The reason, General Motors argued, was that Connecticut did not get hot enough.

headline: French Premier’s Push Toward Center Opens Rift on the Left
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls has called a rare confidence vote for Tuesday, as he tries to corral his Socialist Party away from what he calls “old Socialism.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hours after President François Hollande purged leftist members of his government last month for opposing his economic policies, Manuel Valls, France’s combative prime minister, climbed a stage before hundreds of cheering French executives and called for a new relationship with business to lift France from its malaise.

headline: Obama Must Get Congress’s Backing for the Fight Against ISIS
keywords: ['War Powers Act (1973)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: We should not stretch the open-ended 9/11 authorization to cover new airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE current threat posed by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, will test not only the resolve and strategic judgment of America and its allies, but also our nation’s fidelity to a basic constitutional principle.

headline: The Best Selling Sports Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: An Olympic runner’s story of survival in World War II topped the list of the 10 best selling sports books in August 2014, according to The New York Times Best Sellers List.
lead_paragraph: The 10 best selling sports books in August 2014, according to The New York Times Best Sellers List.

headline: Goodbye, Organization Man
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Ebola Virus', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: The global failure to address the Ebola epidemic stems from a much broader crisis in our culture of government.
lead_paragraph: Imagine two cities. In City A, town leaders notice that every few weeks a house catches on fire. So they create a fire department — a group of professionals with prepositioned firefighting equipment and special expertise. In City B, town leaders don’t create a fire department. When there’s a fire, they hurriedly cobble together some people and equipment to fight it.

headline: Medal of Honor Awarded to 2 Vietnam-Era Soldiers
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama honored Specialist Donald P. Sloat and Sgt. Maj. Bennie G. Adkins for their acts of valor nearly 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Specialist Donald P. Sloat’s squad was conducting a patrol through the dense jungles of Vietnam in January 1970 when a soldier triggered a booby trap rigged with a live hand grenade, which Specialist Sloat quickly picked up.

headline: Kashmiris Cope With Flooding, and Resentment of India
abstract: A week after disaster struck, many say that aid response by the government is too little, too late.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — When an Indian military helicopter hovered low over a relief camp set up in a mosque in Kashmir’s capital on a recent afternoon, a crowd formed on the ground below, but it was not the grateful, grasping crowd one might expect amid a natural catastrophe.

headline: Warning of Terror Risk, Regional Leaders Show Their Focus on Safety
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Gov. Chris Christie met with the homeland security secretary to review counterterrorism procedures.
lead_paragraph: Two governors with eyes on the national political stage joined a mayor who is still untested in matters of national security to send what was meant to be an unambiguous message on Monday to New Yorkers: We are working hard to protect you.

headline: U.S. Pushes Back Against Warnings That ISIS Plans to Enter From Mexico
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Counterterrorism officials said they are far more concerned that a militant will enter the country in a quite typical way: legally, on a commercial airline flight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Militants for the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have traveled to Mexico and are just miles from the United States. They plan to cross over the porous border and will “imminently” launch car bomb attacks. And the threat is so real that federal law enforcement officers have been placed at a heightened state of alert, and an American military base near the border has increased its security.

headline: SABMiller’s Bid for Heineken Opens the Door to Possible Beer Industry Mergers
abstract: The bid by the second-largest beer company in the world fueled speculation of deals on the horizon, but closing them may not be so easy.
lead_paragraph: When Anheuser-Busch InBev moved to take full control of the Mexican beer maker Modelo, it thought the deal would be a cinch.

headline: Arizona Republican Official Resigns After Remarks About Medicaid Recipients
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Sterilization (Biological)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Russell Pearce, who had been a polarizing figure on the immigration issue, said he was quoting someone else in calling for birth control for those getting Medicaid.
lead_paragraph: The former Arizona lawmaker who sponsored the state’s stringent anti-immigration law resigned as a top state Republican official late Sunday amid criticism for remarks he made supporting mandatory birth control or sterilization for Medicaid recipients.

headline: Smartwatches and Weak Privacy Rules
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Mobile Applications', 'Wearable Computing', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The country should welcome innovative health devices but should also pass legislation to protect individual privacy.
lead_paragraph: Even before Apple announced a smartwatch that can measure someone’s heart rate and the number of steps climbed in a day, wearable devices and mobile apps that log your every move and vital sign were growing in popularity. Apple’s size and influence as a trendsetter has now focused attention on the privacy implications of these machines and software.

headline: Don’t Hide the Syrian Aid Vote
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The vote on whether to arm and train Syrian rebels should be entirely separate from the spending bill to keep the government running.
lead_paragraph: It’s bad enough that Congress — instead of doing its job by passing appropriations bills to finance government operations for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1 is, once again, relying on a stopgap spending bill that will keep the lights on only through mid-December. But it’s far worse that House leaders — at the urging of the White House — are using that bill as the vehicle for a major foreign policy decision: arming and training Syrian rebels to fight against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the extremist Sunni group known as ISIS.

headline: Atlanta Hawks’ Owner Stumbles on Line Between Business and Bias
abstract: After outrage over an email by Bruce Levenson, corporate leaders have begun a conversation about singling out demographic groups in marketing and the language used to do it.
lead_paragraph: “My theory is that the black crowd scared away the whites and there are simply not enough affluent black fans to build a significant season ticket base.”

headline: Needing More Drivers, Taxi Service for Women Delays Start
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Women and Girls', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: More than 100 women have signed up to drive for SheTaxis in New York City, in Westchester County and on Long Island, but the company says it wants 500 drivers before it accepts passengers.
lead_paragraph: A new livery service for women that was supposed to start operating on Tuesday in New York City, in Westchester County and on Long Island has been delayed until later this month to allow the company to recruit more female drivers, a representative said.

headline: Loved and Hated, Former Premier of Thailand Is Erased From Textbook
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Textbooks', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'History (Academic Subject)']
abstract: In a plugged-in Thailand, it is unclear to what degree the military junta can remove Thaksin Shinawatra from the public’s consciousness.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — His legacy is inseparable from the past decade of political tumult in Thailand, but high school students will not find the name Thaksin Shinawatra in the history textbooks that the country’s military junta recently ordered schools to use.

headline: Electoral Chaos in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Editorials', 'Identification Devices', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: An appellate court panel has added confusion to the state’s midterm elections by permitting officials to enforce a controversial voter ID law.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to understand the reasoning of the federal appeals court panel that permitted Wisconsin officials to enforce a controversial voter ID law less than two months before Election Day. That’s partly because the panel’s five-paragraph order, issued late Friday only hours after oral arguments, offered the barest rationale for lifting the stay that Judge Lynn Adelman of the federal district court had placed on the law in April.

headline: F.C.C. Revisits Net Neutrality Exemption for Mobile Broadband
abstract: The commission will consider changing a 2010 policy that excluded cellular companies from rules that prevent Internet providers from slowing down or blocking websites and apps.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — High-speed cellular Internet access has been largely exempt from regulations aimed at preventing Internet providers from slowing down or blocking websites and applications. But wireless broadband’s special status is quickly losing support.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 15, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In League Ruled by Fiat, Response Seen as Flailing

lead_paragraph: The decision by N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to increase Ray Rice’s suspension from two games to an indefinite ban has done little to quell the criticism that has surrounded the league this past week in its handling of domestic violence cases.

headline: Utah Victim Was Fleeing, Autopsy Finds
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Darrien Nathaniel Hunt, a black man who was shot to death by the police, suffered six wounds, all from behind, a private autopsy suggested.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, Utah — Independent autopsy findings suggest that a 22-year-old black man was running from the police in Utah when he was shot six times and killed last Wednesday, and not lunging at officers with a samurai sword, as official police reports said, a lawyer for the man’s family said Monday.

headline: Pressure for High Marks at Harvard Extends to Its Investment Chief

lead_paragraph: The chief investment officer of the Yale endowment, David F. Swensen, set the bar for universities starting in 1988 when he created a widely imitated blueprint for high-octane investment returns with heavy doses of private equity and other alternatives to stocks and bonds.

headline: For James Foley’s Family, U.S. Policy Offered No Hope
abstract: After Mr. Foley was kidnapped by ISIS, the government offered sympathy but little active support, his family said, leaving them overwhelmed and unsure of what to do.
lead_paragraph: The email appeared in Michael Foley’s inbox a year after his brother James disappeared on a reporting trip in northern Syria. It made clear that the people holding him wanted one thing above all else: money.

headline: Clarity Emerging as Playoff Races Wind Down
abstract: The postseason picture got less fuzzy this weekend with three teams on the verge of claiming division titles and some jockeying among the wild-card hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: This is a good week to run a carpet-cleaning business or a beverage distribution center in Baltimore, Atlanta or Anaheim, Calif. By midweek, the Baltimore Orioles, the Washington Nationals and the Los Angeles Angels could all be toasting division championships with sloppy and soggy clubhouse celebrations.

headline: U.S. to End Coverage Under Health Care Law for Tens of Thousands
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: The Obama administration said it would terminate health insurance for 115,000 people on Oct. 1 because they had failed to prove they were eligible for coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that it planned to terminate health insurance for 115,000 people on Oct. 1 because they had failed to prove that they were United States citizens or legal immigrants eligible for coverage under the Affordable Care Act. It also told 363,000 people that they could lose financial aid because their incomes could not be verified.

headline: Game Day Reports: Off-the-Field Violence
keywords: ['Football', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Domestic Violence', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In a week when a domestic violence video emerged and a child abuse indictment was handed down, what stood out most were personal perspectives.
lead_paragraph: In a week when the definitive Ray Rice domestic violence video emerged and the child abuse indictment against Adrian Peterson was handed down, it became clear that wise voices were needed on sports networks. These are serious subjects, not highlights or game analysis, or the legal areas that sports outlets have built an expertise in, like drugs and concussions.

headline: Required School Purchase
abstract: Gary Cee just won’t be quiet.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m not saying that Gary Cee is a “motormouth,” as in his revealer, or that he goes ON AND ON AND ON, but he is a radio D.J. who makes a living talking to listeners, so it’s not surprising that he came up with this cute theme.

headline: Challenger Upends Brazilian Race for Presidency

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When Dilma Rousseff and Marina Silva were both cabinet ministers, they clashed on everything from building nuclear power plants to licensing huge dams in the Amazon.

headline: Smugglers Rammed Migrants’ Boat, Sinking It, Group Says
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Drownings', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Palestinians', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Human traffickers rammed a boat filled with migrants they were smuggling from North Africa to Europe, making it sink in the open sea and “deliberately drowning” hundreds of the migrants, the International Organization for Migration said Monday.

lead_paragraph: Shakhtar’s soccer matches these days are not in Donetsk, which has been battered by months of shelling. The team has moved its base to Kiev, the capital of Ukraine.

headline: Last-Minute Campaigner Awaits Final Tally in a Close Assembly Race
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Hasidism']

headline: Thomas Hale Boggs Jr., 73, Lobbying Giant, Is Dead
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Boggs, the son of two prominent members of Congress, used his familiarity with the levers of power to build a firm that became synonymous with Washington lobbying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thomas Hale Boggs Jr., who was the son of two prominent members of Congress and yet, as a pioneer of the capital’s lobbying and fund-raising industry, was the one who came to be called “King of the Hill,” died on Monday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He would have been 74 on Thursday.

headline: Tony Auth, Pulitzer-Winning Cartoonist, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Auth was an anchor of The Philadelphia Inquirer’s editorial page, a witty whistle-blower in what he depicted as a complicated and often corrupt culture.
lead_paragraph: Tony Auth, a Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist who for more than 40 years drew sharp and often darkly comic lines of attack across the spectrum of American life, finding absurdities in all corners of it, died on Sunday in Philadelphia. He was 72.

headline: Winless Giants See Reasons for Hope
abstract: The Giants were so inept in the preseason and so dominated in a season-opening rout last week in Detroit that they were buoyed by a near victory Sunday against the Arizona Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The winless Giants on Monday learned that one of their prized free-agent acquisitions, the nickel cornerback Walter Thurmond, would be lost for the season with a torn pectoral muscle.

headline: Hollywood’s Old-Time Star Makers Are Swooping In on YouTube’s Party
abstract: The star-making system of the future, it turns out, needs the star-making system of the past — or at least a swarm of agents and managers has decided it does.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few months ago, CBS Films wanted Bethany Mota, an 18-year-old video blogger, to make a cameo appearance in the movie “The Duff” and tell her 7.2 million YouTube followers about the experience. CBS figured that Ms. Mota, known for making fashion videos from her Los Banos, Calif., bedroom, would jump at the chance.

headline: New Rochelle Struggles Amid Rice’s Unraveling
abstract: Now that Ray Rice, a hometown football hero, has been dismissed from the Baltimore Ravens and suspended indefinitely from the National Football League, the New Rochelle High School community is struggling to determine how to react.
lead_paragraph: Before the video of Ray Rice punching his future wife became public last week, he was a hometown football hero, a former star who brought bragging rights to New Rochelle High School. Mr. Rice, who grew up in a housing project in the city, led his squad to a state championship in 2003 and has donated duffel bags, compression shirts and headphones to his former team.

headline: A New Spring in a Guard’s Step
abstract: Operations offer a dose of optimism for Nets point guard Deron Williams and his team after the disappointment of last season.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Deron Williams hobbled down the red carpet of his annual charity dodge ball event with a boot around his right foot. It was an ominous sight that set the tone for yet another frustrating season for Williams, the Nets point guard.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Hit Targets Near Baghdad Held by ISIS
abstract: The offensive is the first expansion of the United States’ campaign against the Islamist militant group that President Obama outlined last week in a speech to the nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States, as promised by President Obama, has stepped up its airstrike campaign in Iraq, hitting targets near Baghdad in the effort to help the Iraqi government win back territory seized by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Pentagon officials said Monday.

headline: Jets’ Botched Timeout and Other Mix-Ups Leave Blame to Go Around
abstract: On Monday, the Jets deconstructed their self-destruction against the Packers: the missed assignments, the improper technique and the mistakes, mental and physical.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets deconstructed their self-destruction on Monday. The missed assignments. The improper technique. The mistakes, mental and physical, that precipitated their 31-24 collapse of a loss in Green Bay.

keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators had ample information to identify the dangerous ignition defect in General Motors’ Chevrolet Cobalt and other cars as early as 2007, a House committee investigating the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has found.

lead_paragraph: Once the first Miami Marlin had reached base Monday night, Jacob deGrom retook the mound, lowered his head and exhaled. The Citi Field crowd stood and applauded.

headline: New Hydroelectric Plant to Be Built for New York
abstract: Once completed, the $72 million plant at the Cannonsville Reservoir could produce enough electricity to power 6,000 homes.
lead_paragraph: It seems as natural as, well, water: Harness the energy potential of a 95-billion-gallon reservoir to run four turbines and generate electrical power cleanly and at a profit.

headline: Mother Both Calm and Confused After Son’s Death, Paramedic Says
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The trial of Gigi Jordan, a pharmaceutical executive charged with killing her 8-year-old son in 2010, continued with testimony from the paramedic who found Ms. Jordan with the child in their room at the Peninsula Hotel in New York.
lead_paragraph: The paramedic entered a 16th-floor room at the Peninsula Hotel just after noon on Feb. 5, 2010, and found a small boy lying face up on a bed. It took him a minute, he testified on Monday, to determine that the boy, Jude Mirra, was dead.

headline: Rafael Pineiro, First Deputy Police Commissioner, to Retire
abstract: A 44-year veteran of the force was also the department’s highest-ranking Hispanic.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Pineiro, the New York Police Department’s second-highest-ranking official, will retire at the end of October, officials said on Monday.

headline: Judge Convicts Police Officers in 2011 Assault on a Teenager
abstract: Surveillance video of the officers punching and kicking a teenager in the Bronx helped lead to their convictions.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers were convicted on Monday of misdemeanor assault in the 2011 beating of a teenager in an alley near their Bronx police precinct station house, the district attorney’s office said.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Near Returning, but Yankees’ Wild-Card Hopes Are All but Gone
abstract: The Yankees trail by six games in the race for the second American League wild-card spot. They now have only 13 games to make up the deficit.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — It was difficult to tell where the more important Yankee game was being held Monday. There was one at night at Tropicana Field in front of an announced crowd of 16,058, and there was the one earlier in the day in Tampa at Steinbrenner Field in front of about two dozen reporters, a handful of prospects in street clothes and Jennifer Steinbrenner Swindal, the Yankees’ general partner and vice chairwoman, who watched from the stands.

headline: Longtime Yankees Executive Is Retiring
abstract: Originally hired by the team in 1989, Mark Newman, now the Yankees’ senior vice president for baseball operations, plans to spend more time with his family.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Yankees’ senior vice president for baseball operations, Mark Newman, who was part of player development during the glory years of the early 1990s and in later years when the fruits of the system were less obvious, is retiring after 26 years with the team.

headline: The Brave Work of the Bouroullec Brothers, This Year’s London Design Medalists
abstract: The quirky French product designers are the first honorees of the London Design Festival from outside the U.K.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, beginning with Zaha Hadid, the organizers of the London Design Festival have bestowed the London Design Medal on a leading local talent. This year, the prize leaps outside the U.K. for the first time — and breaks with tradition by recognizing a team instead of an individual — with the renowned product designers Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec.

headline: At the Swiss Institute, a Survey of Eccentric Chair Designs
abstract: The first-ever design exhibition at the SoHo space spotlights an eccentric selection of functional and not-so-functional seating curated in homage to Ionesco’s play “The Chairs.”
lead_paragraph: In Eugène Ionesco’s 1952 absurdist tragedy, “The Chairs,” the last two survivors of an apocalypse speak to a group of chairs that purportedly have invisible occupants. That the vacant seats are not the only witnesses to the couple’s suicide at the end of the play — the chairs in the actual audience being occupied by viewers — heightens the sense of lost promise. In those chairs lies the slightness of the distinction between useful objects and relics. “We are after the end of the world, in our culture and in our perception of stuff,” says the Greek-Norwegian curator and architect Andreas Angelidakis, who conceived of the inaugural design exhibition at the Swiss Institute as a sequel of sorts to Ionesco’s play: just chairs, no people. He credits his therapist with the reference. “These are not the key pieces of modernist design, but an eccentric selection,” Angelidakis says of the survey, “Fin de Siècle,” opening tonight. “I didn’t curate it as museum overview, but as a casting director. Each chair was picked based on character, like casting actors.”

headline: Number of Americans Without Health Insurance Falls, Survey Shows
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Research']
abstract: Federal researchers found that the number of uninsured declined substantially in the first quarter of this year.
lead_paragraph: Federal researchers reported on Tuesday that the number of Americans without health insurance had declined substantially in the first quarter of this year, the first federal measure of the number of uninsured Americans since the Affordable Care Act extended coverage to millions of people in January.

headline: Fixing Climate Change May Add No Costs, Report Says
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: A global commission is challenging the widespread belief that efforts to reduce global warming would carry a steep price.
lead_paragraph: In decades of public debate about global warming, one assumption has been accepted by virtually all factions: that tackling it would necessarily be costly. But a new report casts doubt on that idea, declaring that the necessary fixes could wind up being effectively free.

headline: New Estimates on Health Coverage Are Accurate but Outdated
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The government released reliable estimates of how many people had health insurance in early 2014. It won’t tell us much about the Affordable Care Act, though.
lead_paragraph: The federal government released some very reliable estimates of how many people had health insurance in the first three months of 2014. But the data won’t tell us much about how many people got insurance through the Affordable Care Act.

headline: ‘A National Admissions Office’ for Low-Income Strivers
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Income Inequality', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS']
abstract: QuestBridge has quietly become a force in college admissions. On some elite campuses, 1 in 10 students come from the program.
lead_paragraph: Arianna Trickey was opening a piece of mail in her bedroom during junior year of high school when a pamphlet fell out of the envelope. The pamphlet seemed to offer the impossible: the prospect of a full scholarship to several of her dream colleges.

headline: Afghanistan: Bomb Explodes in Kabul Outside Gates of U.S. Military Base
abstract: A large blast was felt throughout central Kabul in the middle of the morning rush hour Tuesday when a bomb was set off in front of the gates of an American military base.
lead_paragraph: A large blast was felt throughout central Kabul in the middle of the morning rush hour Tuesday when a bomb was set off in front of the gates of an American military base, not far from the United States Embassy and the Afghan Supreme Court building. There were no initial details of casualties, but Twitter postings from the scene showed wounded Afghans. The area is normally crowded with car and foot traffic at that hour.

headline: Cameron Implores Scots to Stay in U.K.
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain visited Scotland on Monday, three days before an independence referendum, to tell Scots why they should remain a part of the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain visited Scotland on Monday, three days before an independence referendum, to tell Scots why they should remain a part of the United Kingdom.

headline: Russia: Putin’s Loyalists Dominate Vote
abstract: Candidates loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin won elections for governor in all 30 regions that held elections on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Candidates loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin won elections for governor in all 30 regions that held elections on Sunday, as balloting reflected the Kremlin’s total domination of political opponents and its iron grip on the country’s political system. Candidates from United Russia, the party that endorsed Mr. Putin for president in 2012, won 28 of the races. The winners of the remaining two races, in the Orel and Kirov regions, were allies of Mr. Putin but not members of the party. In Crimea, which Russia invaded and annexed this year, United Russia won overwhelming majorities in voting for the regional Parliament and for the Legislative Assembly in Sevastopol, the special military district that is home to Russia’s Black Sea Fleet. United Russia also won large majorities in the parliaments of 13 other regions.

headline: Botox Maker Allergan Agrees to Hold Meeting That Could Lead to Takeover
abstract: The move will give shareholders a chance to hold a meeting on Dec. 18 to vote out a majority of the board and give Pershing Square and Valeant a green light on their $53 billion bid.
lead_paragraph: Allergan has made a small measure of peace with Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management, the unlikely pair attempting a $53 billion hostile takeover of the Botox maker.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) ALAN ALDA AND THE ACTOR WITHIN YOU: A YOUNGARTS MASTERCLASS For more than 30 years the organization now known as the National YoungArts Foundation has offered scholarships and mentors to emerging high school artists. In this installment of the Emmy-nominated “MasterClass” series — directed by the Oscar-winning filmmakers Karen Goodman and Kirk Simon and featuring sessions between acclaimed artists and students — Mr. Alda, above at far right, leads six young actors through a series of improvisational challenges. “Improvising enables us to make something that we didn’t expect,” he says. His advice for pursuing a career in the arts: “Every time you get slapped down, don’t break. Just bend.”

headline: London Repeats Offer of New Powers if Scotland Votes No
abstract: With two days left before Scots vote in a referendum on independence, the leaders of the three main British political parties sought to avert secession.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With two days of fevered campaigning left before Scotland votes in a referendum on independence, the leaders of the three main British political parties renewed a pledge on Tuesday to grant Scots “extensive new powers” if they reject secession.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Porpoise Is Ensnared by Criminals and Nets
abstract: When will the vaquita, the world’s smallest marine mammal, go extinct in the wild unless drastic steps are taken to save it, according to scientists?
lead_paragraph: In the article “A Porpoise Is Ensnared by Criminals and Nets,” Elisabeth Malkin writes about the endangered vaquita.

headline: Will Portland Always Be a Retirement Community for the Young?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: As American cities compete for college-educated workers, Portland has a unique problem: It has way too many.
lead_paragraph: Like many residents of Northwest Portland, Matthew Hale doesn’t own a car. Instead, he prefers to walk or ride the bus to the city’s innumerable coffee shops and breweries and live-music spots. On weekends, he and his wife have no problem hitching rides to the Pacific Coast or the Cascade mountain range. Everywhere he looks, Hale told me, there are people just like him — bearded, on skateboards, brewing kombucha. “It’s really chill,” he says.

headline: The Hidden Cities of World War I
abstract: Quarries and connecting trenches were nothing less than small cities, where the walls bear witness to the people who fought – and died – in World War I.
lead_paragraph: The last veterans of World War I died a few years ago. When we think of that war today, we imagine an age of Edwardian sensibilities, ragtime music and people with little connection to our modern world.

headline: Do Teachers Assign Too Much Homework?
abstract: When you get home after school, how much homework will you do? Will it keep you up late? Will it cause stress in your family? Or do you have homework under control?
lead_paragraph: When you get home after school, how much homework will you do? Will it keep you up late at night? Will it cause stress in your family? Or do you have homework under control?

keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Sturgeon (Fish)', 'Three Gorges Dam (China)']

lead_paragraph: In the English naturalist Isabella Bird’s 1899 account of her travels on the Yangtze River, she noted that fishermen regularly caught sturgeon “weighing from 500 to 700 pounds” off the port in the town of Jingzhou.

headline: U.N. Investigators Cite Atrocities in Syria
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The “madness” in the civil war includes acts by Islamic extremists as well as by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, the panel said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As Western and regional powers prepared to step up the fight against Sunni militants of the Islamic State, United Nations investigators presented details Tuesday of more atrocities committed by Islamic extremists and the government in Syria, warning that there could be no battlefield solution to the “madness” in the civil war there.

headline: Daily Report: Regulators Reconsider Mobile Broadband’s Net Neutrality Exemption
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wireless Communications']

lead_paragraph: High-speed cellular Internet access has been largely exempt from regulations aimed at preventing Internet providers from slowing down or blocking websites and applications. But wireless broadband’s special status is quickly losing support, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: House Expected to Vote on Training Syrian Rebels to Fight ISIS
abstract: Republicans will insist on a careful accounting of how the plan fits into a larger strategy to defeat the militant group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House will vote on Wednesday on whether to grant President Obama the authority to train and equip Syrian rebels to battle the Islamic State, but Republicans will insist on a detailed accounting of how the program fits into a broader strategy to defeat the militants, Republican leaders said Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Opel, the European unit of General Motors, said on Tuesday it would cut production and hundreds of jobs in Russia amid declining sales and profitability, and dispatched a senior manager from Germany to take charge of operations there.

headline: Remind Me Again, Why Am I in Business?
abstract: I learned to fly airplanes. I started riding bicycles, attended music camps and took my family on great trips. Obviously, I was spending less time at the business.
lead_paragraph: It sneaked up on me about six years ago. After years of building one business and then another, I felt the need — and felt that I had earned the right — to take some “me” time and some more time with my wife and children. I decided it was time to start having more fun and to reassess my talents and my interests.

headline: The Anti-ISIS Coalition
abstract: A view from the ground.
lead_paragraph: A view from the ground.

headline: Morning Agenda: Allergan’s Olive Branch
abstract: Allergan made a small measure of peace with its would-be acquirers. | Calpers said it would eliminate all of its hedge fund investments. | Fielding strong demand, Alibaba Group raised the price range for its I.P.O. | Beer brewers could be contemplating another round of deal-making.
lead_paragraph: ALLERGAN’S OLIVE BRANCH | The Botox maker Allergan on Monday night made a small measure of peace with Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management, the pair pursuing a $53 billion hostile takeover bid, when the three companies agreed that Allergan would hold a planned special meeting on Dec. 18, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. At the meeting, Allergan shareholders will have a chance to vote out the majority of the board, a move that could open the door to a takeover. The meeting was already set for that date, but there was a chance it could have been delayed because of litigation related to the takeover bid. Valeant and Pershing Square also agreed to drop pending litigation against Allergan in Delaware, where they had sued to force the meeting.

headline: In Performance: Lance Coadie Williams of ‘Bootycandy’
abstract: Mr. Williams plays a preacher with a secret in Robert O’Hara’s comedy at Playwrights Horizons.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features a scene with Lance Coadie Williams as a preacher with a secret in “Bootycandy,” Robert O’Hara’s play about attitudes toward homosexuality in black culture. In his review, Charles Isherwood calls the show a “searing and sensationally funny” comedy from a fearless playwright “who wants to make his mark by shaking up the world, one audience at a time.”

headline: Wasted Words
abstract: In many cases, extraneous words gum up our prose. Here’s one common construction that can almost always be improved by being shortened: The [noun] is an [adjective] one.
lead_paragraph: I don’t subscribe to the view that good editing invariably requires the ruthless elimination of every single word that is not logically essential to a sentence. Sometimes idiom or the natural cadence of English favors phrases that aren’t stripped to the bone. There’s nothing wrong with “hurry up,” even though “hurry” means the same thing.

lead_paragraph: A House committee investigating the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration found that the agency had ample information to identify the dangerous ignition defect in General Motors’ Chevrolet Cobalt and other cars as early as 2007.

abstract: Reports by United Nations agencies showed that a goal of reducing child mortality by two-thirds is years behind.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations on Tuesday reported significant declines in the rates of child mortality and hunger, but said those two scourges of the developing world stubbornly persist in parts of Africa and South Asia despite major health care advances and sharply higher global food production.

headline: How Many Foreign Fighters Have Joined ISIS?
abstract: Some reports say that foreign nationals are traveling to Syria in droves to join the Islamic State. How many foreign fighters are there really, and do they present a direct threat to the West?
lead_paragraph: The killings of James Foley, Steven J. Sotloff and a British aid worker, David Cawthorne Haines, by an apparently British militant — just months after Mehdi Nemmouche, a French citizen who fought with ISIS, shot four people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels — have contributed to the growing concern about the number of disaffected and radicalized youth from the West joining ISIS, and what the trend may mean for security at home.

headline: Police Chief Quits Over Child Sexual Abuse Scandal in English Town
abstract: Commissioner Shaun Wright said he was retiring after a report found that as many as 1,400 children had been sexually abused in the northern town of Rotherham.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The police commissioner in charge of the northern English town of Rotherham resigned on Tuesday after weeks of pressure and intense public outrage over a sexual abuse scandal in the town involving as many as 1,400 children.

lead_paragraph: Afghan security forces and NATO soldiers surveyed the scene of a deadly suicide attack near the United States embassy in Kabul.
