lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Adam Kirsch discuss whether reactions to books all come down to taste.

headline: IBM Offers a Data Tool for the Mainstream, With Watson’s Help
abstract: The tool, which combines Watson’s smarts and the basics of data management, is intended to help get analytics in the hands of every business user.
lead_paragraph: Developing technology is one thing; democratizing it is another. The latter involves finding the innovation that opens the door to widespread adoption with usefulness and usability.

headline: Report Finds Slight Growth in Population of Inmates
abstract: A Justice Department report showed a jump in inmates at state prisons last year, while the number of federal prisoners showed a modest drop for the first time in years.
lead_paragraph: Breaking three consecutive years of decline, the number of people in state and federal prisons climbed slightly in 2013, according to a report released Tuesday, a sign that deeper changes in sentencing practices will be necessary if the country’s enormous prison population is to be significantly reduced.

headline: 1939: Women Adopt Military Style
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Hair', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The war invades women’s fashion in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fashionable London women who have joined auxiliary war-time services today [Sept. 16] were reported to be abandoning the expensively-cultivated coiffure for a boyish shingle in order to wear regulation service caps. At the same time West End manicurists reported that fingernails are being cut shorter with rounded tips. Service regulations require that no curls show and ban the use of nail polish. Many shops are featuring a ‘‘hair harness’’ to keep softly waved coiffures under control during work hours, but allowing a fully feminine appearance when the wearers are off duty. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 17, 1939

headline: German Court Lifts Ban on Uber Ride Service
keywords: ['Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: A judge in Frankfurt said that Taxi Deutschland, which had brought the case against the American ride-hailing service, had waited too long to do so.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a series of legal setbacks in Europe and North America, the ride-hailing service Uber got some welcome news on Tuesday.

headline: 1964: Madrid Blames U.S. for Raid
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Spain blamed the U.S. for the attack on seamen off Cuba in 1964.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain said today [Sept. 16] the United States must be held responsible for the attack on a Spanish freighter Sunday off Cuba in which the vessel’s captain and two other officers were killed. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the United States has ‘‘military control’’ over the area where the attack occurred. He said Spain believed that the U.S. government had sufficient information ‘‘to clarify the situation in a sector where its responsibility in all that happens … is evident.’’ The ministry said that Spain ‘‘is not disposed to tolerate acts of piracy against her merchant fleet.’’ The Sierra Aranzazu, en route to Havana, was attacked 60 miles east of Cuba by two small boats. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 17, 1964

headline: Bow Down to Bauhaus
abstract: Coincidentally, a number of fashion designers took inspiration from the German art and design school for their fall collections. The result: a strong set of graphic dresses and coats that hit at the knee.

headline: Monk Parrots Nestle Nicely in Queens and Beyond
abstract: Some 50 years after the parrots showed up, how they wound up in the United States is still a matter of debate.
lead_paragraph: Stuck with two cockatiels and a lonesome love bird in a cage in Liz Lynch’s sunroom in Howard Beach, Queens, Elvis the parrot seems like just another ordinary pet shop purchase.

headline: U.N. Sees Need for $1 Billion to Fight Ebola
abstract: With the number of cases doubling in just three weeks, the outbreak risks ballooning into a “humanitarian catastrophe,” a senior official said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Ebola virus outbreak in West Africa risks ballooning into a humanitarian catastrophe without a major surge in international efforts to contain it, senior United Nations officials said Tuesday, estimating the cost of this effort at $1 billion.

headline: Death and Poppy Seed Bagels
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Told that her favorite bagel place was out of poppy seed and that the owner had died, a shopper made her priorities clear.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: When the Honeymoon Is Over: Settling Into Real Life After a Move
abstract: After a few months of treating life in our new town like one big vacation, the reality of everyday life is catching up with us, and everyone — especially the kids — is a little testy.
lead_paragraph: When my husband and I uprooted our 11-year-old son and 8-year-old daughter to move to Nashville from Atlanta, we timed it to happen over the summer. We thought it would be easier to handle the move-related chaos in a season when everything’s a little more laid back. Can’t find the box with sheets and pillows in it? That’s O.K. There’s no rush on bedtime. Don’t have an oven in the kitchen yet? No problem. Let’s throw something on the grill and eat outside.

headline: In Kentucky, Health Law Helps Voters but Saps Votes
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Series', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Although expanded coverage made the state an early success story, there is little evidence it will help Democrats there in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Affordable Care Act allowed Robin Evans, an eBay warehouse packer earning $9 an hour, to sign up for Medicaid this year. She is being treated for high blood pressure and Graves’ disease, an autoimmune disorder, after years of going uninsured and rarely seeing doctors.

headline: In Latin America Travel, Considering Safety Before Fun
abstract: Monica Drake, the editor of the Travel section, discusses choosing destinations to cover when hard news may trump travel.
lead_paragraph: Monica Drake is editor of the Travel section. She shared her thoughts on last weekend’s annual Latin America edition.

headline: Former Amaranth Trader Settles Manipulation Suit
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: A former energy trader at a Connecticut hedge fund that collapsed in 2006 after losing $6.6 billion on natural gas has agreed to pay $750,000 to settle a regulator’s lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A former energy trader at a Connecticut hedge fund that collapsed in 2006 after losing $6.6 billion on natural gas has agreed to pay $750,000 to settle a regulator’s lawsuit.

headline: Perceptions Haven’t Caught Up to Decline in Crime
abstract: The decrease in violent crime is one of the most striking trends over recent decades, but that wasn’t reflected in a recent YouGov online panel.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a narrative you rarely hear: Our lives are safer. This message is so rarely heard that half of all respondents to a recent YouGov poll suggested that the violent crime rate had risen over the past two decades. The reality, of course, is that it has fallen enormously.

headline: Setback for India’s Ruling Party
abstract: The Bharatiya Janata Party, coming off a huge victory in May’s parliamentary elections, did poorly in by-elections in three northern states.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Bharatiya Janata Party, coming off a huge victory in May’s parliamentary elections, suffered a political setback on Tuesday with a poor showing in state legislative by-elections in three northern Indian states, including one that was swept by Hindu-Muslim tensions in the weeks leading up to the vote.

headline: A Pay-Gap Fix Goes Down Again in the Senate
abstract: Senate Republicans refuse to allow a vote on an act to narrow the discrepancy between men’s and women’s wages.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, just as they did last April, and a couple of times before that, Senate Republicans moved in lockstep to block an up-or-down vote on the Paycheck Fairness Act.

headline: The Power of Fearing the Worst
abstract: A psychologist argues that if you use it right, pessimism can work to your advantage.
lead_paragraph: Worriers, rejoice. Your fears may actually be the makings of your success.

headline: Appreciating Arthur Russell, Pop Music’s Most Influential Unknown Star
abstract: A new compilation featuring tracks by José González (which premieres exclusively at T), Robyn and Hot Chip pays tribute to the pioneering experimental and dance musician.
lead_paragraph: Though he’s not widely known, Arthur Russell — the avant-garde multi-instrumentalist who bridged classical, dance and experimental music in the 1970s and ’80s before succumbing to AIDS in 1992 — has been one of the most influential forces in popular music. A new compilation, “Master Mix: Red Hot + Arthur Russell” — the latest in the 24-year-old Red Hot + series dedicated to raising money to fight HIV/AIDS — is helping to voice that legacy by putting his compositions in the hands of artists like Robyn, Devendra Banhart and Hot Chip.

headline: At de Blasio City Hall, Scorn (and Quiet Affirmation) for Bloomberg Years
abstract: As Mayor Bill de Blasio and his surrogates continue to issue barbs at Michael R. Bloomberg, former Bloomberg administration officials have increasingly moved to defend him.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration unveiled a promotional video this summer in its bid to lure the Democratic National Convention to Brooklyn in 2016, most viewers saw a slick, breezy collage of a pulsing New York City — schoolchildren and Citi Bikes, culinary wonders and brochure-worthy parks.

headline: New North American Tour for the Former Cat Stevens
abstract: The singer-songwriter Yusuf, once known as Cat Stevens, will release a new album and tour six cities in North America this fall.
lead_paragraph: Yusuf, the singer-songwriter formerly known as Yusuf Islam, and before that as Cat Stevens, has joined the roster of Sony Legacy, which will release “Tell ‘Em I’m Gone,” his first new studio album in five years, on Oct. 27, Sony announced. The label also announced that the singer would undertake his first North American tour since 1976.

headline: Sears Turns to Its Chief for a Loan
abstract: Sears is borrowing $400 million from its chief, the billionaire Edward S. Lampert, through his hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Sears Holdings has closed stores, sold real estate and spun off assets, all in an effort to repair its troubled finances. Now, the retailer is turning to its chief executive for a loan.

headline: Under Pressure, Ukraine Leader to Seek Aid on U.S. Visit
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A White House meeting with President Obama and an address to a joint session of Congress on Thursday will likely generate fresh moral support, if little else, for Ukraine in its conflict with Russia.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Seeking elusive military and economic aid from the United States, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine headed to North America on Tuesday, while also facing increasingly skeptical questions both here and abroad about the slow pace of change.

headline: Alibaba’s Small Increase in I.P.O. Price Is Puzzling
abstract: It is surprising that Alibaba lifted the maximum price for its coming stock market debut by just $2 in the wake of what has been described as “overwhelming” demand from investors, Peter Thal Larsen writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Pricing initial public offerings is an inexact science. Predicting how investors will value a large, fast-growing Chinese e-commerce group involves even more guesswork. That makes Alibaba’s decision to lift the maximum price for its coming stock market debut by just $2 a share to $68 puzzling.

headline: U.S. General Open to Ground Forces in Fight Against ISIS in Iraq
abstract: Remarks by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, open the door to a riskier, more expansive American combat role than the president has publicly outlined.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top military adviser said Tuesday that he would recommend deploying United States forces in ground operations against Islamic extremists in Iraq if airstrikes proved insufficient, opening the door to a riskier, more expansive American combat role than the president has publicly outlined.

headline: American Ballet Theater Starts a YouTube Channel
abstract: The company is sharing videos that feature dancers, as well as behind-the-scenes reports.
lead_paragraph: In line with a growing trend among ballet companies, American Ballet Theater has created its own YouTube channel, the company announced. “With our initial phase of videos, we hoped to give users a sampling of the content,” said a spokeswoman, adding that the channel would be continually refreshed with new material. Most of the videos currently posted date back to May and June.

headline: Electric Vehicles Are Cleaner, but Still Not a Magic Bullet
abstract: The advantage of E.V.s in forestalling climate change has increased as power plants abandon coal, a new report from the Union of Concerned Scientists says.
lead_paragraph: The Union of Concerned Scientists said on Tuesday that in 60 percent of the United States, electric vehicles are now responsible for fewer heat-trapping global warming emissions per mile than even the most efficient hybrids.

headline: 800 Million People Still Malnourished, U.N. Says
abstract: Despite a decline in hunger levels, 11.3 percent of the world’s population does not get enough to eat, the United Nations said in a new report.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — More than 800 million people worldwide do not get enough to eat, even as the world produces more than twice as much food as it needs, according to new figures released Tuesday by the United Nations.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Case Against Tipping
abstract: Tech upgrades for small businesses. How to use Instagram to promote products. Should we ban states and cities from offering tax breaks for jobs?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Venturing Into ISIS Recruiting Territory: A Reporter’s Chronicle
abstract: A Times correspondent goes into the heart of the Islamic State’s recruitment center in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Hacibayram, a ramshackle neighborhood in the heart of Ankara’s tourist district, has morphed into an recruiting hub for the Islamic State over the past year. Locals say that up to 100 residents have gone to fight for the group in Syria. Ceylan Yeginsu, a Times correspondent who is from Turkey, visited Hacibayram to report on recruitment efforts and to find out why young boys from the area enlist as fighters for the group, often referred to as ISIS. Here she describes how she got her front-page story.

headline: U.S. Moves to Reduce Global Warming Emissions
abstract: The Obama administration is moving to cut emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, powerful greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday announced a series of moves aimed at cutting emissions of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, powerful greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change.

headline: Martin Amis’s ‘Zone of Interest’ Makes European Publishers Squirm
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The novel, set in a concentration camp, has touched off concerns about sensitivity in Europe, where Mr. Amis’s French and German publishers have rejected it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In France, they say they’re puzzled by the humor. In Germany, they say it will be difficult to market. Martin Amis’s latest novel, “The Zone of Interest,” a satire set in a concentration camp during the Second World War, is having trouble gaining traction in Europe, where his longtime French and German publishers have rejected it.

headline: A Rock Pilgrim’s Progress
abstract: “How to Build a Girl,” Caitlin Moran’s first novel, tells a comic coming-of-age tale in the 1990s about a teenager from the British hinterlands who reinvents herself as a rock critic.
lead_paragraph: “The only true currency in this bankrupt world,” Philip Seymour Hoffman (as Lester Bangs) says to a young rock journalist in the movie “Almost Famous,” “is what you share with someone else when you’re uncool.”

headline: CBS Replacing Rihanna Song on Football Broadcast After Singer Complains
abstract: Rihanna criticized CBS on Twitter after the network, whose pregame show focused on the Ray Rice story, pulled her song from “Thursday Night Football.”
lead_paragraph: After a series of Twitter posts from the singer Rihanna criticizing CBS for dropping her song from last week’s premiere of “Thursday Night Football,” the network has decided to remove the song from its telecasts for the remainder of this season.

headline: A Health Care Hot Potato
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Despite the success of the Affordable Care Act in Kentucky, state Democrats are having a hard time winning over even those Republicans who admit they are benefiting from the law.
lead_paragraph: Despite the success of the Affordable Care Act in Kentucky, state Democrats are having a hard time winning over even those Republicans who admit they are benefiting from the law.

headline: Versace Helps a Restoration
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The fashion house is donating 1.5 million euros to work on the historic Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II in Milan.
lead_paragraph: This Friday, Versace is opening a new boutique in Milan’s more-than-a-century-old landmark, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the latest example of luxury houses helping to refurbish historic sites throughout Italy.

headline: Anya Hindmarch: Upstaging the Merchandise
keywords: ['Handbags and Purses', 'London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Anya Hindmarch sent out shiny balloons, teacups, men in skeleton suits — oh, and handbags.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was to hell in a handbag basket at Anya Hindmarch.

headline: Number of Children Living in Poverty Drops Sharply, Census Bureau Reports
abstract: The number of American children living in poor households fell by 1.4 million in 2013, a report says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The poverty rate declined last year for the first time since 2006, the Census Bureau reported on Tuesday. But at the same time, it said, there was no statistically significant change in the number of poor people or in income for the typical American household.

headline: London Fashion Week: Simone Rocha Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London fashion week diary of Alexandra Waespi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Alexandra Waespi.

headline: What Does ‘British’ Style Really Mean?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The old stereotype of crazy creative types no longer really holds true, as designers such as Christopher Kane and Simone Rocha show.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the penultimate evening of London Fashion Week, Samantha Cameron, Britain’s first lady and British Fashion Council ambassador, and Natalie Massenet, the council’s chairwoman, co-hosted a cocktail event at 10 Downing Street to celebrate what both women were careful to call “British fashion,” a.k.a. the “most successful of our creative industries,” according to Ms. Cameron — bigger than film, music and advertising.

headline: Chiquita Offers Concessions to European Regulators for Fyffes Merger
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Chiquita and Fyffes didn’t disclose the concessions they were willing to make. Their announcement comes as two Brazilian companies are pursuing their own bid for Chiquita.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Chiquita Brands International and Fyffes said on Tuesday that they were in discussions with European regulators about a series of possible concessions to obtain clearance for their proposed inversion deal.

headline: A Last Word on the Cruz Affair
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Palestinians', 'Religion and Belief', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Zionism']
abstract: A response to the Texas senator’s defenders in the Middle East Christians debate.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column used Ted Cruz’s now-famous performance at a summit organized to raise awareness of Christian persecution in the age of ISIS as a window into the difficulties that the Middle East’s swiftly-disappearing Christians have finding patrons in the American political scene. The column didn’t have space to do justice to the various arguments raised in defense of Cruz’s provocations — the most notable of which was his challenge to a mostly-Arab audience to acknowledge that “Christians have no greater ally than the Jewish state,” which prompted boos and sent things spiraling downhill. So let me say a word about those arguments here.

headline: Pitch Strikes a Raw Nerve
abstract: There was more drama — arguments, ejections, hit batters and a dugout-emptying near brawl — but the result was much the same for the Yankees as in the rest of this painful trip.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Before the game, the Tampa Bay Rays gave Derek Jeter a kayak, a check and a uniform top; thoughtful gifts to honor a 20-year career, which is coming to an end in frustrating, unfamiliar fashion. Later in the game, they gave him and his teammates reason to fight.

headline: Y Combinator, a Start-Up Incubator, Goes to College
abstract: The popular early stage venture funding outfit plans to teach its own college-level class at Stanford University on becoming a successful start-up.
lead_paragraph: Stewart Brand, a counterculture icon of the 1960s, is known for a phrase technologists love to quote: “Information wants to be free.”

headline: E.P.A. Cuts Size of Loan New York Sought for Tappan Zee Bridge
abstract: In a blow to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s bridge plan, the agency denied most of a $511 million request, saying it was not for environmental use.
lead_paragraph: In a significant blow to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan for financing a new Tappan Zee Bridge, the federal Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday rejected most of New York State’s request for a $511 million low-interest loan to help pay for the project, saying the state had planned to use the money almost entirely for construction, rather than its required purpose: enhancing the environment.

headline: Inside a Souvenir From France
abstract: Claudette, a French restaurant just north of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, takes its place in New York’s Gallic revival.
lead_paragraph: The age of French dining in New York that blossomed in the unpromising soil of the Corona ash dumps during the 1939 World’s Fair, at the French Pavilion’s restaurant, seemed to come to its close about 10 years ago as mastodons like Lutèce lumbered into the fossil record. Today, that seems less like the end of an epoch than a salutary cooling-off period.

headline: Bessie Awards to Honor Arthur Mitchell and Chuck Davis
abstract: Mr. Mitchell, a founder of the Dance Theater of Harlem, and Mr. Davis, the founder of the DanceAfrica festival, will be recognized for their contributions to the world of dance.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Mitchell, a founder of Dance Theater of Harlem and Chuck Davis, the founder of DanceAfrica, will be honored at the 30th annual Bessie Award ceremony on Oct. 20 at the Apollo Theater, officials announced. Mr. Mitchell will receive an award for lifetime achievement in dance and Mr. Davis will receive an award for outstanding service to the field of dance.

headline: Grand Jury in Michael Brown Shooting Gets More Time
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A judge has given an extension of 60 days to the grand jury considering whether to indict Darren Wilson, the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who killed Michael Brown, 18.
lead_paragraph: A judge has given an extension of 60 days to the grand jury considering whether to indict Darren Wilson, the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who killed Michael Brown, 18. The jury must decide by Jan. 7 whether Officer Wilson, who is white, will be criminally charged in the death of Mr. Brown, who was black and unarmed.

headline: A Night at the Museum
abstract: More and more artful, and art-filled, hotels are popping up across the globe, blurring the lines between culture and accommodation.
lead_paragraph: Hotels dotted with paintings and prints are hardly rare, but taking a cue from “Al’s Grand Hotel” — Allen Ruppersberg’s bookable, seven-room installation, which popped up on Sunset Boulevard for six weeks in 1971 and was restaged at this year’s Frieze New York — more and more properties are blurring the lines between artwork and accommodation. The 21c Museum Hotel in Louisville, Ky., recently commissioned Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe to create “Asleep in the Cyclone,” an immersive “architectural collage” that doubles as a 500-square-foot guest room. Everything inside (from the geodesic-domed ceiling to the fake books and magazines) has been created or curated by the American art duo to evoke a ’60s-era hippie commune. Across the pond, one of the suites at the Beaumont in London — set to launch this fall in the Mayfair district as the first hotel from the restaurateurs behind the Wolseley and Brasserie Zédel — has been designed by Antony Gormley as a three-level “inhabitable sculpture.” Featuring fumed-oak interiors, the conjoined cubes of stainless steel mimic the British artist’s own body, a recurring theme in his work. Next spring, Living Architecture plans to unveil “A House for Essex” in the U.K., designed by the Turner Prize winner Grayson Perry in collaboration with the architecture firm FAT. With its ceramic-tile facade and aluminum roof sculptures, not to mention the handmade tapestries and artworks inspired by a fictional local character, it looks like something out of a fairy tale.

headline: Program Pairs Low-Income Students with Elite Colleges
abstract: Many selective colleges are outsourcing their search for low-income students to a program called Questbridge.
lead_paragraph: Many selective colleges are outsourcing their search for low-income students to a program called Questbridge.

headline: Temporary Agreement Is Intended to Allow Gaza to Import Materials for Rebuilding
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian officials reached a temporary accord to move reconstruction material into Gaza, a senior United Nations official said.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Momentum for the rebuilding of the Gaza Strip advanced on Tuesday, with a senior United Nations diplomat briefing the Security Council on a temporary deal between Israeli and Palestinian officials to import cement and other building materials.

headline: Long-Running Art Moscow Fair Canceled
abstract: Its founder cited international tensions and a virtually nonexistent local market.
lead_paragraph: Art Moscow, Russia’s longest-running contemporary art fair, has been canceled this year because of international tensions and a virtually nonexistent local market, its founder and organizer, Vasily Bychkov, has announced in an interview with The Art Newspaper Russia.

headline: May the Force Be With You
abstract: Four lamps from Lee Broom are on display at the London Design Festival, including the Tube, which looks like a glowing light saber.
lead_paragraph: On display at the London Design Festival this week is Nouvel Rebel: four lamps, a set of candlesticks and a martini glass all designed by Lee Broom in marble, crystal or some combination of both. The collection features two styles of pendant lamps with Carrara marble centers encased in lead crystal, and a globular table lamp with a crystal hemisphere. But the most impressive of the lot may be an exceedingly thin (5 mm) marble tube with a single strip of LEDs inside. When lit, the lamp, called Tube (shown), looks like a glowing light saber. It “was inspired by the very basic fluorescent tube light you would get in factories or warehouses,” said Mr. Broom, a former theater designer based in the East End. “I wanted to create something very industrial, but very hand crafted.” Tube is about 35 inches long and 2.75 inches in diameter, and costs about $5,310. The Future Perfect design store is taking advance orders. Information: 212-473-2500 or thefutureperfect.com.

headline: Former Putin Aide Reinforces Dangers of Sanctions
abstract: European Union and American sanctions have pushed Russia to a point between growth and recession, said Aleksei Kudrin, a former finance minister.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for its policies in Ukraine. European leaders and the head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have done the same.

headline: Bertrand de Billy Cancels Vienna State Opera Appearances
abstract: The French conductor Bertrand de Billy announced that he was canceling his upcoming performances because of differences with the company’s management.
lead_paragraph: The Vienna State Opera continues to bleed conductors. Less than two weeks after the surprise resignation of its music director, Franz Welser-Möst, the French conductor Bertrand de Billy announced this week that he was canceling his upcoming performances there because of differences with the company’s management.

headline: Hoping War-Weary Tourists Will Return to Israel
abstract: After a drop in visitors during this summer’s Gaza conflict, tourism officials are looking for a rebound.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in the Old City of Jerusalem, while fighting raged in Gaza, Bilal Abu Khalaf hosted a group of Israeli tourists at his textile store in the Christian Quarter — one of Jerusalem’s tourist gems.

headline: Exploring the World’s Jewish Communities
abstract: Harry D. Wall talks about finding a lesser-known side of Jewish culture, which community surprised him and more.
lead_paragraph: “Why does everything about Jewish history have to be long and sad and filled with persecution?” This was the refrain Harry D. Wall said he heard all too often from his children during their travels, so he set out to correct that with Jewish Discoveries.

headline: French Premier Prevails in Confidence Vote
abstract: The vote had been called by Prime Minister Manuel Valls after a cabinet reshuffle purged leftists who were critical of divisive austerity measures.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s embattled Socialist government survived a parliamentary vote of confidence on Tuesday aimed at shoring up support for tough economic policy changes at a time when the economy is flat and President François Hollande’s popularity is the lowest of any French president in decades.

headline: Stratford Festival to Offer Shakespeare in Movie Theaters and on TV
abstract: The Stratford Festival in Ontario will start a long-term project by filming three Shakespeare plays in HD and showing them in movie theaters and on television.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been meaning to catch some of the Stratford Festival’s renowned Shakespeare productions but haven’t been able to get up to Ontario, the festival has a remedy at hand. As the first installment of a long-term project, in which the festival hopes to document its productions of the entire Shakespeare canon, three of this year’s stagings will be filmed in HD. The films will be screened in cinemas around the world in 2015 and television broadcasts by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation will follow, as will on-demand digital releases.

headline: Alibaba’s Governance Leaves Investors at a Disadvantage
abstract: As Alibaba readies to go public, it is important for public investors to be aware of serious corporate governance issues involving the company, Lucian Bebchuk writes in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Lucian Bebchuk is professor of law, economics and finance and director of the program on corporate governance at Harvard law School.

headline: Bill Targets Pro Sports Leagues’ Tax-Exempt Status
keywords: ['Football', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, has introduced the bill, which would disallow leagues, most notably the N.F.L., from claiming status as tax-exempt nonprofits.
lead_paragraph: Amid uproar over the N.F.L.’s handling of domestic abuse cases involving some of its players, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, has introduced a bill that would disallow major professional sports leagues, most notably the N.F.L., from claiming status as tax-exempt nonprofits.

headline: In Rotterdam, Produce Real and Digital
abstract: The indoor market Markthal in Rotterdam will have fresh food–and a 36,000-square-foot digital mural showing items available in the building.
lead_paragraph: Rotterdam’s spacious indoor market, Markthal, will have a colorful opening on Oct. 1, with the “Horn of Plenty” digital mural that adorns the walls and ceiling of the arch-shaped building.

headline: LoyalBlocks Simplifies Mobile App Creation for Small Merchants
abstract: In just 10 minutes, the company says, it can help businesses create their own customized loyalty apps.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest challenges small, brick-and-mortar businesses face is marketing, with many spending their budgets on efforts that don’t have much of an impact on sales. One alternative some have tried is creating loyalty apps, but creating a mobile app is not something most small-business owners know how to do and the platforms that exist are often too complicated and expensive.

headline: London Fashion Week: Fashion East Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: Senators Take Auto Agency to Task Over G.M. Recall
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The top official from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration faced withering criticism over the agency’s failure to detect a deadly ignition defect in G.M. cars.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top auto regulator faced withering criticism across Capitol Hill on Tuesday over its failure to identify a deadly defect in General Motors cars — even as its top official tried again and again to shift the blame back to the automaker.

headline: A History of Misses for RadioShack
abstract: The electronics retailer could have been today’s Amazon, but instead it lunged repeatedly in multiple directions, seeking to master one new concept after another, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: In an alternate universe, RadioShack would rule the world, supplying all of your electronics needs from computers to cellphones, and even making them. But in this world, RadioShack is almost bankrupt, having missed almost every opportunity to be the center of the technology revolution.

headline: Gelato for Breakfast? You Bet
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Restaurants', 'Books and Literature', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: The chef Brooks Headley recommends white bread and some Ben & Jerry’s.
lead_paragraph: Wait a second. Brooks Headley, the pastry chef from Del Posto, is encouraging you to make an ice cream sandwich with store-bought white bread and a tub of Ben & Jerry’s Cherry Garcia?

headline: If Desserts Could Wear Tattoos
keywords: ['Desserts', 'Restaurants', 'Books and Literature', 'Chefs', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: Brooks Headley, the punk rock pastry chef, fixates on the purity of fresh fruit and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: When you flip open a cookbook called “Fancy Desserts,” you don’t expect to find a photograph of two elephants mating.

headline: On New Measurements of Aging
abstract: Warren Sanderson, a professor of social and behavioral sciences at Stony Brook University, is working on ways to define aging other than the passing of years. “Everything is changing about 65-year-olds,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Pediatricians chart children’s growth at every visit, tracking how they conform to age-appropriate standards. What if standard measures of aging were similarly available?

headline: You Can’t Feed a Family With G.D.P.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income', 'Poverty', 'Families and Family Life', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: The census numbers on what American families made last year are as mediocre as they are predictable.
lead_paragraph: The most important thing to know about the state of the United States economy was revealed in a report Tuesday morning that Wall Street barely noticed.

headline: Employee of Law Firm Wilson Sonsini Charged With Insider Trading
abstract: For the second time in three years, federal authorities have charged an employee of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati with using confidential information to make illegal stock trades.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities, for the second time in three years, charged an employee of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati, a prominent law firm, with using confidential information about corporate deals to make illegal trades in stocks.

headline: Abenomics Meets Ibiza in K.K.R.’s Latest Investment
abstract: K.K.R.’s purchase of Pioneer’s D.J. audio equipment business is the modern-day equivalent of providing gold-rush pickaxes to participants in the rave rush, Jeffrey Goldfarb writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Henry Kravis is spinning a different sort of club deal. The old kind, in which several private equity shops would make an acquisition together, led his Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to join the recent hefty settlement of a lawsuit over allegations of collusion with other firms. In this new version, K.K.R. is buying Pioneer’s D.J. audio equipment business for $550 million. Mr. Kravis is laying down a smooth groove in a funky M.&A. market.

headline: At Buckingham Palace, a Dancing Guard Throws Decorum to the Wind
abstract: The pirouetting guard has enchanted crowds in London with his subversive performance and challenged the notion that such things are simply never done.
lead_paragraph: The guards who stand sentry outside Buckingham Palace are the embodiment of decorum and regularity. Many British children have grown up with little dolls of them in their sentry boxes (I was one). Innumerable tourists over decades have watched them make their nobly pointless little marches to and fro between A and B. They are absurd, glorious, dependable, stiff-upper-lip, constant: They mean “There’ll always be an England.”

headline: Chinese Leader Visits Sri Lanka, Challenging India’s Sway
abstract: President Xi Jinping of China arrived in Colombo, the capital, to sign a raft of agreements, after visiting the Maldives to sign agreements there.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — President Xi Jinping of China arrived in Sri Lanka on Tuesday for a 23-hour trip to this island nation to sign a raft of agreements as China chips away at India’s traditional dominance in the region.

headline: Dempsey and Hagel Speeches and Protests
abstract: Comments by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on the United States’ campaign against ISIS were interrupted by anti-war protesters.
lead_paragraph: Comments by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on the United States’ campaign against ISIS were interrupted by anti-war protesters.

headline: Scottish Referendum Could Hinge on the Undecided
abstract: On Twitter and Facebook, and in comments to The Times, undecided Scottish readers talked about their concerns over which way to vote on independence.
lead_paragraph: Public opinion polls show Scotland’s independence referendum is too close to call ahead of the Sept. 18 vote, which could come down to those still undecided — at least 6 percent of potential voters have not made up their mind.

headline: How to Fake Your Next Vacation
abstract: A Dutch artist faked a trip to Southeast Asia through a series of carefully manipulated Facebook photos, demonstrating the power and ubiquity of deception in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: Zilla van der Born, a Dutch national, spent five weeks traveling through Southeast Asia and documented the trip in photos on Facebook. She posed for pictures while dining on dumplings, snorkeling among colorful fish in azure waters and visiting ornately decorated Buddhist temples — compiling the lot into a series of videos for her Vimeo account. All in all, Ms. van der Born seemed to have enjoyed a busy, albeit conventional, trip to Phuket, Luang Prabang or some other regional tourist hub.

headline: Governor and Sponsors Voice Concerns With N.F.L.
abstract: Gov. Mark Dayton of Minnesota called Adrian Peterson, the Vikings’ running back, “a public embarrassment,” and Anheuser-Busch said it was disappointed by recent episodes in the league.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L., it seems, has been unable to keep up with the roiling storm over its handling of multiple domestic violence cases that have captured the nation’s attention and started to eclipse the action on the field.

headline: Campus Cops With M-16s
abstract: Nearly 120 colleges and universities have acquired military equipment through a federal surplus program since 1998.
lead_paragraph: After Ferguson cops greeted unarmed protesters with tear gas and combat vehicles, there was public gnashing of teeth over whether police departments really need military gear, acquired from the Pentagon through the federal 1033 transfer program. Some national politicians, notably Republican Senator Rand Paul, criticized the militarization of law enforcement.

headline: Craig Green: Fashion’s Newest Wunderkind
abstract: The designer creates clothing out of junk and lives with his parents.
lead_paragraph: The designer creates clothing out of junk and lives with his parents.

headline: Q. and A.: What Would an Independent Scotland Entail?
abstract: What could a vote for independence mean for Scotland and Britain? Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: Scotland has been England’s junior partner in the United Kingdom since 1707. But three centuries is no time at all in the view of many Scots, who regularly re-enact 14th century sword battles they had with the English and have insisted on self-determination, on and off, ever since. That prospect is now nearer than ever. Scottish voters will decide on Thursday whether to become independent once again.

headline: Federal Judge Upholds U.S. Effort to Regulate Overseas Trading
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Unencumbered by costly litigation, which was filed by some of Wall Street’s top trade groups, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is now able to reach far beyond American shores in its oversight.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:54 p.m. | A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the Obama administration’s effort to rein in the sort of overseas trading that imploded in the financial crisis, upending Wall Street’s plan to roll back the regulatory overhaul.

headline: Pennsylvania Officials Identify Suspect in Ambush at Barracks
abstract: The suspect, Eric Matthew Frein, was the subject of a wide search on Tuesday after the police obtained a warrant charging him with murder, among other offenses.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania authorities on Tuesday identified a 31-year-old man “with antigovernment leanings” as the suspect in last week’s ambush at a state police barracks that left one trooper dead and another wounded.

headline: Letter From the Environmental Protection Agency
abstract: In its decision to reject most of the state’s request for a $511 million loan, the E.P.A. wrote that “construction activities arising from transportation projects do not advance water quality.”
lead_paragraph: In its decision to reject most of the state’s request for a $511 million loan, the E.P.A. wrote that “construction activities arising from transportation projects do not advance water quality.”

headline: Fourth Downs in Week 2: When Risk-Taking Paid Off
abstract: N.F.L. coaches who went for it on fourth down were rewarded, but as usual, many others were too conservative.
lead_paragraph: The season is only two weeks old, and I’m sorry to report that the name-calling has already started: Some of my readers are calling me an Internet troll.

abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

abstract: Daniel Boulud opens in Boston; restaurants opening or closing in Manhattan and Queens.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Gehry’s Changes to Memorial Rejected by Eisenhowers
abstract: Two grandchildren of Dwight D. Eisenhower say proposed changes by Frank Gehry to his memorial to the former president do not satisfy their concerns.
lead_paragraph: The modifications proposed by the architect Frank Gehry to his design of a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower planned for the Washington Mall are insufficient, members of the Eisenhower family say.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Red Band Society’
abstract: The new Fox series takes place in a youth hospital.
lead_paragraph: The new Fox series takes place in a youth hospital.

headline: Food News Around New York
abstract: Stamps honor American chefs, MatchaBar opens in Williamsburg and the Good Batch bakery in Clinton Hill.
lead_paragraph: To Post: Mini-Portraits of American Chefs

headline: Ferguson, a Month Later
abstract: Since Michael Brown was killed, a major issue has emerged in Ferguson: the problem with arrest warrants and municipal fines.
lead_paragraph: Last week Frances Robles, a national correspondent, reported on changes in the way that Ferguson, Mo., handles arrest warrants and municipal fines. She shared her experience reporting the story, and what the town is like a month after the death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager who was killed by a white police officer.

headline: Around the N.F.L., the Catch-and-Run Is Gaining
abstract: Short passes have helped increase completion percentages and decrease yards per completion, but in Houston, Cincinnati and Philadelphia, receivers are making things happen after the catch.
lead_paragraph: In the N.F.L., the short pass is the new run. Through two weeks, teams have completed 63.5 percent of their passes, a rate that would easily break last year’s record-setting 61.2 percent. Thirty-four quarterbacks have attempted at least 30 passes this season, and half of them have completed at least 64.9 percent of their passes. In many ways, it has never been easier for a quarterback to complete a pass.

headline: The Union’s Fake Canadians
abstract: Why did so many black soldiers in the Civil War claim to be from America’s neighbor to the North?
lead_paragraph: In August 1864, two dozen black men gathered at Benton Barracks in St. Louis to be mustered into the Army. Each registered as a substitute for a draftee, and each was paid an enlistment bounty. But, according to the rolls, there was something remarkable about these men: All of them were foreigners. William Thompson, Washington Taylor and Henry Taylor were from England, the rolls attested; William Wood was from Jamaica, and the remaining 20 men were from Canada.

headline: 2 Companies Will Take Americans to Space Station
abstract: The companies won the competition to begin flights as early as 2017.
lead_paragraph: Boeing and the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation are the winners in the competition to carry American astronauts to the International Space Station, NASA announced on Tuesday.

headline: Hostage Saved, Time to Get the Kids
abstract: “The Mysteries of Laura,” on NBC, stars Debra Messing as a smart-mouthed detective who is also raising incorrigible twin boys.
lead_paragraph: The opening scene is straight out of the TV Cop Show Cliché Handbook: a high-speed chase, a car wreck, a hostage-taking, a put-down-the-gun standoff. Right out of the handbook, that is, until the officer in that standoff, having shot and wounded the suspect, pulls out a wet wipe to clean the blood off the hostage.

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Mysteries of Laura’
abstract: The new NBC series stars Debra Messing as a detective.
lead_paragraph: The new NBC series stars Debra Messing as a detective.

headline: Stream the New Album From Japan’s Original Indie Rock Star, Shintaro Sakamoto
abstract: “Let’s Dance Raw,” the follow-up to his cult-classic 2011 solo debut, is out today — and can be listened to in its entirety here.
lead_paragraph: In Japan, Shintaro Sakamoto is a bona fide star. His former psychedelic-rock trio, Yura Yura Teikoku, sold out large venues whenever they played; they even toured the United States with the indie stalwarts Yo La Tengo. But since disbanding the group in 2010, he has favored a more low-key approach, eschewing live shows and retreating to the studio to produce his first solo album, “How to Live with a Phantom,” in 2011. That release, a mellow affair with jazzy guitar, Latin percussion and soft sax, called to mind the chilled-out feel of ’70s yacht rock and the sonic perfectionism of Steely Dan. When the label arm of the influential New York record emporium Other Music issued it in the United States, it became a cult classic. (The former Girls frontman and Hedi Slimane muse Christopher Owens, for one, has professed his love in multiple interviews.)

headline: A Pakistan Airlines Delay Leads to a Near Mutiny
abstract: The delayed departure of a flight on Monday caused several enraged passengers to reject two politicians from the plane before it could even take off.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Flight delays are nothing unusual at Pakistan’s ailing state carrier, Pakistan International Airlines, long hobbled by political interference, a bloated staff and epic financial losses.

headline: After American Airlines-US Airways Merger, Agents Vote to Unionize
abstract: About 86 percent of customer service employees at the merged American Airlines-US Airways voted in favor of union representation.
lead_paragraph: Customer service agents for the merged American Airlines and US Airways have voted overwhelmingly in favor of union representation, the National Mediation Board announced on Tuesday.

headline: Images of an Uzbek First Daughter Under House Arrest

lead_paragraph: A British public relations firm released images on Tuesday showing Gulnara Karimova, the flamboyant eldest daughter of President Islam Karimov of Uzbekistan, under house arrest.

headline: Joan Rivers Biography Is Acquired by Little, Brown
abstract: The author is the journalist Leslie Bennetts, who covers the entertainment industry for Vanity Fair.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers was an assiduous chronicler of her own life, in print as well as during her stand-up routines. In her 81 years, she produced a string of advice and humor books and several revealing memoirs, with self-mocking titles like “I Hate Everyone … Starting With Me.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Le Canon in Nice, France
abstract: “A modern Niçoise cuisine du marché” is how the chef of this bistro, which opened early this year, describes his cooking.
lead_paragraph: Initially, Le Canon, a bistro that opened in Nice early this year, comes off as the sort of hipster restaurant that might easily be spotted in Brooklyn or Shoreditch in London: Edison bulbs overhead; ’50s-era cafe chairs and Formica-topped tables; a soundtrack heavy on funk. But when Sébastien Perinetti, the friendly owner and a Nice native, props the daily chalkboard menu up on a chair, it’s a great read that could be found only on the French Riviera.

headline: Globalization Is in Retreat? Not So Fast
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: While some observers see a “reshoring” of global manufacturing to the United States, the globalization trend is far from over.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, executives at the Dutch multinational Royal DSM, a globe-girdling maker of nutritional supplements and high-tech materials, used to require a battery of internal studies to decide where to do a deal or locate a new manufacturing plant.

headline: Obama Presses Leaders to Speed Ebola Response
abstract: President Obama, warning that the disease could take hundreds of thousands of lives, called on other nations to help the United States as it leads the fight.

headline: Feather-Trimmed Slippers at Simone Rocha

headline: To Aid Children’s Cancer Care, Mothers Go Bald
abstract: To raise funds and awareness for pediatric cancer research, mothers shave their heads in solidarity with their cancer-affected children.
lead_paragraph: A mother stands in front of my camera. “I don’t know what I’m supposed to do,” she says anxiously, so she smiles stiffly, as you might in a school picture. “Just be yourself,” I encourage. When she leaves my makeshift studio, set up at the Prudential Center in Boston for the occasion, I feel I’ve failed. The images reveal nothing about how she was feeling. Instead, I’ve taken a smiling portrait of a woman with no indication that she was about to undergo a serious, emotional transformation.

headline: Judge Lifts Temporary Ban on Uber

lead_paragraph: There are so few obstacles left for middle-class teenagers to struggle against. Parents and teachers are permissive, bullying is stomped upon, acne can be treated, and only the most exacting religions discourage gay or interfaith relationships.

lead_paragraph: Mere seconds after the band Joyce Manor’s introductory guitar punch at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, the crowd started an eager mosh, exultantly tossing cups of beer into the air. Up onstage, the frontman Barry Johnson was in upheaval, too, but mostly of the internal kind.

For every “Billy Elliot” or “Hairspray” there are a raft of also-rans — but I won’t salt the wounds by going down the list.

lead_paragraph: You might think an hourlong musical is an inadequate vehicle for capturing the Triangle garment factory fire of 1911, a horrifying and shameful episode in American history involving the deaths of 146 garment workers, most of them female immigrants.

headline: A Great Symphony, and Then Two More Takes on It
abstract: The Argento Chamber Orchestra and the JACK Quartet played around with Mahler’s Ninth on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Mahler’s great, valedictory Ninth Symphony, about 90 minutes long and prevailingly intense, is more often than not left to fill an evening by itself. But the Argento Chamber Ensemble and the JACK Quartet built an ambitious program around it on Monday evening in the Music Mondays series at Advent Lutheran Church on the Upper West Side, adding two shortish contemporary works more or less based on the Ninth.

headline: Changing States of Matter, and a Whole New Meaning to Vaping
abstract: The Bed-Stuy Veterans did a lunch-hour brukup show on Friday as part of the third annual BEAT Festival in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon at MetroTech Commons in Downtown Brooklyn, the mercurial dancer known as Ghost came out of character for a minute to address the crowd assembled around a small outdoor stage. Surrounding him were fellow members of the Bed-Stuy Veterans, a dance crew devoted to the Jamaican-born style brukup, which migrated from Caribbean dance halls to Brooklyn streets in the mid-1990s. The lunch-hour show was part of the third annual BEAT Festival, an eclectic series of theater, music and dance throughout Brooklyn.

headline: Is Hubby Unfaithful? And Other Household Intrigues
abstract: “The Fatal Weakness,” which ran on Broadway in 1946 and is being restaged at the Mint Theater, is a domestic comedy with a twist.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a play is more interesting in the future than in its own time. “The Fatal Weakness,” a domestic comedy with a drama at its core, was apparently unloved in its day; its 1946 Broadway premiere ran for only 119 performances despite having Ina Claire, a prominent stage actress, in the lead role. But here in 2014, the Mint Theater Company is making this George Kelly work an amusing, affecting reminder that the institution of marriage has been under siege for much longer than we tend to think.

lead_paragraph: Rackspace, a web hosting company, said in May that it was exploring strategic alternatives, including a possible sale. Potential buyers had approached the company hoping to strike a deal, and the company wanted to conduct a thorough review of its options.

lead_paragraph: There is a certain kind of desperation that just about anyone who has rented an apartment in Manhattan can recognize.

abstract: The combination of the savory, woody rosemary and the sweet fruit may inspire you to eat the breads at breakfast, lunch and dinner.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, at the height of the summer tomato season, I gave you a recipe for a delicious whole wheat focaccia with tomatoes and fontina. I was so enthralled with the bread that I decided I’d come back to it and post a week’s worth of focaccia recipes.

lead_paragraph: Adam Wingard narrates a sequence from his film “The Guest,” written by Simon Barrett and featuring Dan Stevens and Maika Monroe.

headline: London Fashion Week Social Media Roundup
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Really a five-day marathon, the second leg of fashion month continued with shows from brands like Burberry and Tom Ford. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: Though short in terms of time (it lasts exactly five days), London Fashion Week packs a punch. Just ask Alexandra Jacobs, who developed an entirely new phobia from the sheer stress of dashing from show to show: F.O.N.G.T.O.T., or Fear of Not Getting There On Time — #fongtot for those who are on Twitter. Fortunately, hashtags and acronyms didn’t slow the critics down too much as they surveyed the offerings both of megabrands like Burberry and Tom Ford, and of less established designers like Simone Rocha, Margaret Howell and Hunter. The truncated week brimmed with moments: unexpected ones (Birkenstocks at Burberry), unnerving ones (a moving runway at Anya Hindmarch) and even political ones (Vivienne Westwood’s comment on the Scottish referendum).

headline: A Dangerous Visitor Makes Himself at Home
abstract: In “The Guest,” a man with suspect intentions ingratiates himself with a dead soldier’s family.
lead_paragraph: As one of the sharper young horror directors working today, Adam Wingard likes to take familiar genre setups — the serial killer or the home invasion — and warp them just enough to pique our interest. Together with the writer Simon Barrett, whose canny scripts flip and swerve at unexpected moments, Mr. Wingard is building a résumé that pays at least as much attention to character and story as it does to scares and body count.

headline: Strange, Gorgeous Art Made From Single-Cell Organisms Under a Microscope
abstract: The practice was popular in the Victorian era, but there is only one artist seriously pursuing it today. Matthew Killip’s short film “The Diatomist,” which premieres exclusively with T, explores his unusual world.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you’ve never done much thinking about the beauty of algae, but the Victorians did. Microscopists of the era used to arrange diatoms — single-cell organisms encased in jewel-like glass shells that likely date to the Jurassic Period — into stunningly beautiful mosaics that resemble stained glass in miniature. The last surviving diatomist is an Englishman named Klaus Kemp, who became fascinated with the practice as a teenager. Because the Victorians left no records behind, Kemp had to figure it out for himself. He’s still at it today, supporting himself by selling his creations to a small but avid group of collectors. The filmmaker Matthew Killip spent an afternoon with Kemp at his home in England in December of 2013, documenting his unique practice at the intersection of science and art. Killip’s film, “The Diatomist,” premieres exclusively here.

headline: Gunman Gets 20 Years in Georgia School Seizure
abstract: A lawyer for Michael B. Hill said her client had seized the school in an effort to provoke the police into killing him in a “very misguided” suicide attempt.
lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ga. — Nearly 13 months after he clutched an assault rifle and seized an elementary school here, a Georgia man with an extensive history of mental illness was ordered on Tuesday to serve 20 years in prison.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Palestinians', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Is American intelligence data being used to persecute Palestinians?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN Moscow this summer, while reporting a story for Wired magazine, I had the rare opportunity to hang out for three days with Edward J. Snowden. It gave me a chance to get a deeper understanding of who he is and why, as a National Security Agency contractor, he took the momentous step of leaking hundreds of thousands of classified documents.

headline: Trade Schools Sued for Lending Practices
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Vocational Training', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Consumer Protection', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal agency sued Corinthian Colleges, a major for-profit trade school chain, on Tuesday, charging that it lured students with lies about job placement and used illegal tactics to collect on student loans.
lead_paragraph: A federal agency sued Corinthian Colleges, a major for-profit trade school chain, on Tuesday, charging that it lured students with lies about job placement and used illegal tactics to collect on student loans. The agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, asked a court to erase $569 million in debts arranged by Corinthian for current and former students. The company, which denied the charges, faces heavy losses and sanctions by government regulators, and it agreed in July to sell or close nearly all of its more than 100 campuses. The company said the new lawsuit would make that process more difficult.

headline: Tony Stewart Case to Go Before Grand Jury
abstract: A grand jury will determine if Stewart, a former Nascar champion, will be charged in the death of Kevin Ward Jr., who was killed when he was struck by Stewart’s racecar in August.

headline: Let’s Reject the ‘Inevitable’
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Corporations', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy and Power', 'Ozone']
abstract: Taking back the power on climate change.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday’s “People’s Climate March” in New York City could be the biggest demonstration yet for action on climate change. The march is scheduled to coincide with the United Nations Climate Summit, which begins two days later. Despite the advance billing and the official nature of the summit, the march is what matters. The U.N. Summit will be a clubby gathering of world leaders and their representatives who will try to figure out ways to reward polluters for pretending to fix a problem for which they’re responsible in the first place; a fiasco.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even as government’s role in health care remains deeply divisive in the United States, the National Health Service remains a beloved cornerstone of Britain’s welfare state. Polls last year showed that Britons are prouder of the health service than they are of the monarchy. They even showed off their affection for the system in the opening ceremony of the 2012 London Olympics.

headline: In Patz Killing, Testing the Weight of Threadbare Confessions
abstract: Pedro Hernandez’s confession to murdering Etan Patz has details that seem to be at odds with what is known about that day 35 years ago, but, for now, the focus of the case is on whether Mr. Hernandez made a truly voluntary decision in waiving his right to silence.
lead_paragraph: All that kept the orange Rikers Island jumpsuit from swallowing Pedro Hernandez whole were the hand-rolled pants cuffs, turned high enough to clear his canvas shoes. Accused of murdering a child named Etan Patz 35 years ago, Mr. Hernandez stood not much taller than the shoulders of the shortest of the court officers who led him into State Supreme Court in Manhattan this week.

headline: An Urgent Campaign Against Ebola

The question now is whether ramped-up medical assistance from the United States and other countries will arrive fast enough to change the course of the rapidly expanding epidemic.

headline: U.S. Steel’s Canada Subsidiary Files for Creditor Protection
abstract: The Canadian company has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel Canada was granted creditor protection on Tuesday, the latest chapter in its tumultuous recent history. U.S. Steel said that the Canadian company, known as Stelco before its purchase in 2007, has posted an operating loss of $2.4 billion over the last five years. With the filing, the Canadian unit’s results will no longer be included in U.S. Steel’s financial statements. In 2009, U.S. Steel shut down the Canadian operation and locked out its workers while demanding pension changes. That prompted a lawsuit from the government of Canada, charging that the company had failed to live up to foreign investment laws. An agreement to make further investments in Canada ended that action, although the company continues to battle unions. A lawyer for U.S. Steel Canada told the Ontario Superior Court that it had liabilities of between 3.86 billion and 4.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.52 billion and $3.9 billion), and assets worth between 1.9 billion and 2.3 billion Canadian dollars, according to The Globe and Mail. The largest creditor is U.S. Steel, which the court was told is owed 1.6 billion Canadian dollars. It will provide the subsidiary with up to 185 million Canadian dollars to keep it operating until the end of 2015.

headline: Mexico: Tourists Being Airlifted After Hurricane Odile
abstract: Military and police planes began airlifting tourists from the resort town of Los Cabos on Tuesday as residents began to tally the wreckage left by Hurricane Odile.
lead_paragraph: Military and police planes began airlifting tourists from the resort town of Los Cabos on Tuesday as residents began to tally the wreckage left by Hurricane Odile, the strongest storm to hit the Baja California peninsula in almost 50 years. The Category 3 storm smashed luxury hotels and swept away poor neighborhoods, but officials said there were no deaths. Electricity and phone service were cut off across the state of Baja California Sur, and the Los Cabos airport was closed to commercial flights.

headline: South Korea: American Fails in Effort to Swim to North
abstract: An American was arrested Tuesday night on a river that borders North Korea, the South Korean news media reported on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: An American was arrested Tuesday night on a river that borders North Korea, the South Korean news media reported on Wednesday. The South Korean news agency Yonhap, quoting an anonymous government source, said that the American man had attempted to swim to North Korea. “All we can say at this point is that our border guards arrested an American man last night on the riverbank near the border,” said a Defense Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the inquiry was continuing. Yonhap said that the American, in his early 30s, had been found on the riverbank shortly before midnight. After he was apprehended, he told South Korean officials that he had intended to go to North Korea to meet its leader, Kim Jong-un, Yonhap reported. The United States Embassy said it was aware of the reports and had been “in touch with the appropriate South Korean authorities.”

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:30 P.M. (Showtime) FRUITVALE STATION (2013) On Jan. 1, 2009, Oscar Grant III, a 22-year-old African-American father, was shot in the back by a white Bay Area Rapid Transit police officer on a subway platform in Oakland, Calif., his killing captured on cellphone. Ryan Coogler’s feature directorial debut reconstructs the final 24 hours in the life of Mr. Grant (played by Michael B. Jordan, above, with Ariana Neal) who, after two stints in a state prison, had returned to selling drugs after losing his job at a supermarket because of chronic lateness. Octavia Spencer plays his mother, still able to boss him around, and Melonie Diaz the mother of his daughter, with whom he’s trying to stay. Mr. Coogler’s “main intention — and his great achievement, as well as Mr. Jordan’s — is to make Oscar a fully human presence, to pay him the respect of acknowledging his complexities and contradictions,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The radicalism of ‘Fruitvale Station’ lies precisely here, in its refusal to turn a man into a symbol. Nearly every black man, whether or not he is president, tends to be flattened out by popular culture and the psychopathology of everyday American life, rendered as an innocent victim, a noble warrior or a menace to society. There is a dehumanizing violence in this habit, a willed, toxic blindness that ‘Fruitvale Station’ at once exposes and resists.”

headline: With Much at Stake, Chinese Leader Visits India
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is hosting President Xi Jinping with hopes of encouraging Chinese investment and reducing a trade imbalance between their countries.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, celebrated his 64th birthday on Wednesday by hosting President Xi Jinping of China in his home state, Gujarat, as the leaders of Asia’s two giants laid the foundation for a relationship that will carry huge stakes for both countries.

headline: Sherborne Steps Up Pressure on Electra Private Equity Before Shareholder Vote
abstract: In a letter to Electra Private Equity shareholders, the activist investor Edward J. Bramson said a change in approach in Electra’s strategy could increase the value of its shares by about $1.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The activist investor Edward J. Bramson stepped up his pressure on Electra Private Equity on Wednesday, as he seeks two seats on the company’s board.

lead_paragraph: Q. Do you still have to defragment the hard-disk drive on a Windows 8.1 computer to keep it from running slow?

headline: National Book Awards Nominees, Nonfiction
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'National Book Awards', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The nonfiction nominees for the 2014 National Book Award include Roz Chast’s “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?” and John Lahr’s biography of Tennessee Williams.
lead_paragraph: The National Book Award nominees for the 2014 nonfiction prize were announced on Wednesday. The 10 nominated works include two books about World War II, a coming book from Walter Isaacson about technological innovation and, for the first time in the nonfiction category, a graphic memoir, from the New Yorker cartoonist Roz Chast.

headline: A Ruckus Offstage, Then On
abstract: The season rescued, collaborators at the Metropolitan Opera brace for Richard Eyre’s new production of “Le Nozze di Figaro.”
lead_paragraph: Mozart’s great comedy “Le Nozze di Figaro,” which opens the Metropolitan Opera’s season on Monday, begins with hopefulness, dissolves into chaotic upheaval and, rescued at the last minute, concludes with reconciliation, peace and celebration.

lead_paragraph: Trian Partners, the hedge fund founded by the billionaire Nelson Peltz, publicly urged DuPont on Wednesday to split itself up despite efforts by the industrial conglomerate to shed some of its businesses.

headline: Morning Agenda: Investors Reflect on Calpers Move
abstract: When Calpers said it would eliminate its hedge fund investments, other investors took note. | RadioShack has missed numerous opportunities to be the center of the tech revolution. | A lottery ruse is among a number of fraudulent schemes involving a MoneyPak prepaid card. | The iPhone 6 is reviewed.
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS REFLECT ON CALPERS MOVE | The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the nation’s largest pension fund, has long been a trendsetter among public pension plans. So when Calpers said on Monday that it would eliminate all $4 billion of its hedge fund investments over the next year, the industry took note, Mary Williams Walsh and Alexandra Stevenson report in DealBook. The reasons for its decision — that hedge funds can just seem too complicated and costly — also resonate with many public workers, retirees and the plans’ trustees.

headline: Ex-Currency Trader Braves Tumultuous Market
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Charles-Henri Sabet, a former backgammon champion and foreign exchange executive, is building a trading business as technological and regulatory forces are reshaping the market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two weeks ago, Charles-Henri Sabet, a 52-year-old former Swiss backgammon champion and longtime foreign exchange trader, took over as executive chairman of the London Capital Group, an online trading services firm that has struggled in recent years. He quickly turned to hiring senior executives.

lead_paragraph: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — Jonathan Dwyer of the Arizona Cardinals was arrested in a domestic violence investigation Wednesday as the N.F.L. continued to find itself under siege for its handling of such cases.

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — President Obama on Wednesday repeated his vow to destroy Islamist terrorists in Syria and Iraq, but he insisted that the United States would not go it alone and promised a military audience that he would not send them back into direct combat.

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The step, largely formal, prolongs a heated battle over the fate of one of the country’s most prominent dollar stores.
lead_paragraph: Family Dollar Stores again rejected on Wednesday a $9.1 billion takeover approach from Dollar General and urged shareholders not to tender their shares to the discount retailer’s bigger rival.

headline: An Eternal Hipster, Riffing at a Timeless Venue
abstract: He plays piano in a jazz group, but Jeff Goldblum being Jeff Goldblum, the evening would not have been complete without a lot of chatter.
lead_paragraph: The actor Jeff Goldblum, when off the screen, personifies the type of smart guy you might describe as “the Eternal Hipster.” Never at a loss for words, never losing his cool, he wears a sly smile.

headline: In Brutal Year, 7th Journalist Is Killed in Afghanistan
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The stabbing of Palwasha Tokhi adds to a toll that was already the deadliest for the news media in the country since the fall of the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan woman has become the seventh journalist killed in Afghanistan so far this year, an Afghan media group said Wednesday, adding to a toll that has already made 2014 by far the deadliest year for the news media here since the fall of the Taliban.

headline: Jordan Finds Energy Sources in Unlikely Places
abstract: A deal with Israel for natural gas represents a remarkable tie for two nations with a history of tension, and reflects how badly Jordan needs energy.
lead_paragraph: When the oil gusher lottery came to the Middle East, Jordan seemed to have drawn a losing ticket. And now that some of the neighbors it depended on for fuel supplies, like Iraq and Egypt, have convulsed with political or sectarian strife, Jordan is frantically looking for other sources — and finding them in unexpected places.
