headline: Promise Made for Harlem Watchtower’s Restoration, but Not in Ink
abstract: This fall, the parks department plans to take apart a 19th-century watchtower and, eventually, restore and return it to Marcus Garvey Park.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan is about to lose its last antebellum watchtower.

headline: 1914: Paris Auto Trade Stalls
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The war slowed automobile trade in Paris in 1914.
lead_paragraph: In common with so many other businesses, the automobile industry has been brought almost to a standstill by the war. A walk up the Champs-Elysées is sufficient to prove this. Hoardings block nearly all the window fronts of the numerous auto shops. Other shops have been turned into workrooms, where scores of women may be seen sewing diligently. One of the few auto firms still doing business in Paris is the Packard Company. An advertisement in the Herald announces that Packard automobiles may be hired for journeys in France at 1 franc 50 per kilomètre. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 18, 1914

headline: Adam Scott Splits With Caddie, Who Hopes to Travel Less
abstract: The caddie Steve Williams, 50, had expressed a desire to scale back the number of weeks he spent on the road, a plan that did not appeal to Adam Scott.
lead_paragraph: Adam Scott is in the market for a caddie after parting with Steve Williams, who helped guide him to his only major championship, the 2013 Masters, and to the world No. 1 ranking during their four-year partnership.

headline: U.S. Army Chief Says Ground Troops Will Be Needed Against ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Gen. Ray Odierno, the Army chief of staff, said “rooting out” militants on the ground would be necessary, but he did not say it had to be done by Americans.
lead_paragraph: WIESBADEN, Germany — The United States general who beat back Islamic extremists in Iraq in 2007 suggested on Wednesday that the battle against Islamic State jihadis would only succeed with the use of ground forces.

headline: Will Congress Bother to Debate War Against ISIS?
abstract: As the conflict escalates, Congress is about to shut its doors for the election season and head home.
lead_paragraph: As the American war against the Islamic State escalates, Congress is about to shut its doors for the election season and head home. The most it will do is authorize some limited assistance to Syrian rebels, but the Senate will probably not even take a vote on that, instead burying the aid inside an emergency spending bill so that its members won’t have to be held accountable.

headline: Post-Lehman, Money Market Fund Protections Still Weak
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Money Market Accounts', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Money market funds played a central role in Lehman Brothers’ failure and helped spread the contagion. But, Jennifer Taub, of Vermont Law School, says, the problems remain unsolved.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Taub is a professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” was published in May by Yale Press.

headline: 1939: Soviets Invade Poland
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet Union attacked Poland in 1939.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union entered the war at dawn yesterday by invading Poland along its entire 500-mile eastern frontier, an hour after the Polish Ambassador in Moscow had refused to receive a note of explanation from the Soviet government. Violent fighting between Polish and Russian troops was reported at Molodeczno, sixty-five miles southeast of Vilna. At almost the same time, German artillery and planes began a day-long bombardment of the center of Warsaw. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 18, 1939

headline: Fake News Story Causes Real Headache at Coney Island
abstract: A hoax article about a roller-coaster crash opens a window onto the weird world of untrue news.
lead_paragraph: For fans of the new Thunderbolt roller coaster at Coney Island and anyone who might be thinking of riding it, an article making the rounds on social media last week contained sobering news.

headline: Union Square: A Place to Converge, and Buy Kale
abstract: The neighborhood has a bustling farmer’s market, refurbished playgrounds and new shops and restaurants. But none of this comes cheap.
lead_paragraph: When Victoria Baradi Anderson moved into the Union Square neighborhood in 1998, she was attracted to its central location and easy subway access. “I was single and enjoying the night life,” she said. After graduating from college and living with her parents for a year, she bought a studio on East 14th Street for less than $100,000. There was little in the surrounding streets that appealed to her, including the 3.6-acre park that gave the area its name and “was not as nice as it is now,” she said.

headline: How Insurers Are Finding Ways to Shift Costs to the Sick
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: By charging different prices for generic drugs, health insurers may be violating the spirit of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Health insurance companies are no longer allowed to turn away patients because of their pre-existing conditions or charge them more because of those conditions. But some health policy experts say insurers may be doing so in a more subtle way: by forcing people with a variety of illnesses — including Parkinson’s disease, diabetes and epilepsy — to pay more for their drugs.

headline: Words to Live By
abstract: A follow-up to the middle-grades novel “Wonder” offers a snippet of story and a pithy saying for each day of the year.
lead_paragraph: After R. J. Palacio’s “Wonder” was published in 2012 and became a middle-grades juggernaut, many hoped the author would continue the story of August Pullman, the Manhattan boy born with serious facial deformities, and his friends and family. “Wonder” ends as Auggie is finishing fifth grade at Beecher Prep, his first year in school after being home-schooled for the surgery-filled first decade of his life. He is given a special award recognizing his courage by the school’s principal. But then what? Palacio’s characters were hard to say goodbye to, and in the current series-heavy world of children’s books, it seemed natural that there would be more to come.

headline: IBM Offers Workers Training and Pay Cuts
abstract: IBM is cutting the pay of some of its services workers by 10 percent while they are being trained in cloud, mobile and big data computing.
lead_paragraph: IBM is cutting the pay of some employees in its services business by 10 percent for six months while they spend up to one day a week in training programs.

headline: Best Seat in the House
abstract: Loewe’s creative director Jonathan Anderson reimagines the archetype of a chair.
lead_paragraph: When Jonathan Anderson took over as Loewe’s creative director last September, he had a clear mandate: to liven up the 168-year-old Spanish fashion and leather goods label. In just over a year he’s done precisely that, spearheading a seaside ad campaign featuring archival and newly commissioned images by Steven Meisel and unveiling youthful new takes on Oxford shoes and crocodile bags. But that wasn’t enough for the London-based fashion darling who is now reimagining a wood-and-leather armchair that the architect Javier Carvajal designed in 1959 for one of Loewe’s Madrid stores. “There was something so pure in the wooden archetype of the chair,” says Anderson, who gave it a splashy new color palette. “I wanted to interrupt that aesthetic.”

headline: The Ultimate Cuban Comfort Food: Picadillo
abstract: A stew of ground beef and tomatoes gives a taste of island home cooking.
lead_paragraph: Here is one of the great dishes of the Cuban diaspora: picadillo, a soft, fragrant stew of ground beef and tomatoes, with raisins added for sweetness and olives for salt. Versions of it exist across the Caribbean and into Latin America. James Villas, the elegant hedonist who for many years was the food and wine editor of Town & Country magazine, championed one from St. Lucia, in the Lesser Antilles. But many Cubans claim the dish as their own, a taste of the pre-revolutionary island at its homey best. “Picadillo has a sentimental resonance,” said Betty Cortina, a Cuban-American food writer who is the editor of The Miami Herald’s lifestyle magazine, Indulge. She even took a recipe for picadillo with her to college at the University of Florida. “Everyone who is of Cuban descent has a recipe for it, and each one of those is the most authentic. It’s a comfort food, probably the most consummate example of one in Cuban cuisine.”

headline: What ‘Blade Runner’ Got Wrong
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'Political Advertising', 'Social Media']
abstract: The film predicted a future of ad-covered blimps and buildings. What’s actually happened is somewhat different, but, to some, equally scary.
lead_paragraph: Ubiquitous, intrusive advertising has long been a feature of dystopian fiction — directors and writers seem convinced that one of the many things that will make the future terrible is its sheer density of ads. But we now live in the future that dystopians of the 1980s and 1990s were predicting, and what’s happened isn’t quite what they feared — though, to some, it’s still pretty scary.

headline: N.F.L. and Union Agree on Drug Plan
abstract: After years of feuding over drug-testing protocols, the N.F.L. and the players union have reached an agreement on a new plan for performance-enhancing drugs.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. and the players union announced Wednesday that after several years of feuding over drug-testing protocols, they had reached an agreement on a new plan. The most significant change is that players will be tested for human growth hormone for the first time.

headline: Ada Kokosar, Stylist and Street-Style Star, on Where to Eat, Drink, Shop and Unwind in Milan
abstract: On the first day of the city’s fashion week, the Italian-born recent New York transplant, who is gaining notice for her international editorial work and refined fashion sense, shares a comprehensive list of her favorite hometown hangouts.
lead_paragraph: A cursory glance at any leading street-style site will invariably turn up images of the freelance stylist Ada Kokosar, a striking blonde whose refined fashion sense and patrician looks call to mind a latter-day Carolyn Bessette Kennedy. The Slovenian-Italian is also gaining notice for her editorial shoots for a range of international glossies. And though she’s currently based in New York, she grew up outside Milan and lived there for 10 years. Here, to kick off Milan’s spring/summer 2015 fashion week, she shares a comprehensive list of her favorite haunts there.

headline: Heavy Rains Swell Rivers in Serbia
abstract: Residents in the Serbian village of Tekija cleared areas of debris as streams flowed through their housing and buried cars in the mud.
lead_paragraph: Residents in the Serbian village of Tekija cleared areas of debris as streams flowed through their housing and buried cars in the mud.

headline: Valeant’s Last Shot to Woo Owners of Botox Maker Allergan
abstract: The mid-December vote on replacing a majority of Allergan’s board is Valeant’s last best hope for its $51 billion hostile takeover.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals gets one last shot to woo Allergan owners. The two drug companies have dropped litigation and locked in a mid-December date for a special vote by Allergan’s shareholders on replacing a majority of the company’s board. That vote could set the stage for a $51 billion hostile takeover. Before then, the focus will be on Valeant’s results. It’s the buyer’s last best hope, assuming the Botox maker Allergan doesn’t find another deal first.

headline: 36 Hours in Central Park, New York
abstract: With its endless trails, hidden nooks, museums and nearby night spots, Central Park is that rare tourist destination that is also a pleasure ground for locals.
lead_paragraph: With its endless trails, hidden nooks, museums and nearby night spots, Central Park is that rare tourist destination that is also a pleasure ground for locals.

headline: Unsigned Music Competition Names a Winner: Goodbye June
abstract: Goodbye June, an eclectic Nashville band with Southern hard rock and metal influences, is the top winner in a contest for unsigned artists, judged by musicians and critics.
lead_paragraph: Goodbye June, an eclectic Nashville band with Southern hard rock and metal influences, has won the top prize in the third annual Unsigned Only Music Competition, a contest open to bands and solo performers not signed to major labels or their affiliates.

headline: 36 Hours: Central Park, New York
abstract: Spot birds and gaze at stars, explore gardens and go for a row, snack on a roof and sway to some jazz during a weekend in the city’s sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: In 1859, the sanctuary of undulating hills, bridges and lakes taking shape in the heart of Manhattan was described in The New York Times as a “noble work, which is so clearly destined to be the honor and delight of New York.” Neglect and decline in the 1970s threatened to snuff out that utopian vision of Central Park, but today, after years of restoration, it is verdant and flourishing — the rare tourist destination that is also a pleasure ground for locals. Depending on the season and cycle of life, one might be sunbathing or ice skating, sailing a toy boat or rowing a real one, listening to Shakespeare, rock music or the call of one of 230 species of birds.

headline: Official on Arrest of Russian Tycoon
abstract: Vladimir Markin, the Russian Investigative Committee spokesman, discussed the investigation of the Sistema chairman Vladimir Yevtushenkov on charges of money laundering.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Markin, the Russian Investigative Committee spokesman, discussed the investigation of the Sistema chairman Vladimir Yevtushenkov on charges of money laundering.

headline: When Plan to Help Others Sell in China Fails, a Start-Up Changes Tack
abstract: Export Now was created as an easy, low-cost way for American businesses to export to China, but when that didn’t work, the company took a new tack.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Frank Lavin, who had raised $5 million from family and friends, went live with an e-commerce platform, Export Now, that was conceived as an easy, low-cost way for American small businesses to sell their goods in China. The basic pitch: “Sell into China without leaving your desk.”

headline: Can the U.S. and China Find Harmony in Pursuing Climate Progress?
keywords: ['Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A close look at the intensifying dance between the United States and China over how to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Goodell, who’s written fine books on “big coal” and the batch of climate-manipulating ideas known as geo-engineering, has written an invaluable feature on China’s energy and climate plans for Rolling Stone: “China, the Climate and the Fate of the Planet.”

headline: Classical Playlist: Puccini, Messiaen, Schubert and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: PUCCINI: ‘La Fanciulla del West’Eva-Maria Westbroek, Carlo Ventre and other singers; Frankfurt Opera and Chorus; Sebastian Weigle, conductor(Oehms Classics OC 945; two discs)The more I listen to Puccini’s “La Fanciulla del West” (“The Girl of the West”), set in California during the Gold Rush, the more I am coming around to the conviction of many Puccini scholars that this may be the composer’s harmonically richest and most thematically integrated score. Those qualities come through strongly in a new recording, taken from live performances in 2013 at Oper Frankfurt, conducted with sweep and subtlety by Sebastian Weigle. The winning cast is headed by the gleaming, expressive soprano Eva-Maria Westbroek as Minnie, the title character. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Swiss Pump Maker in Merger Talks With Dresser-Rand
abstract: Sulzer, a Swiss maker of pumps and other industrial equipment, says it is in talks with the oil services equipment maker about a deal that could be valued at $5.5 billion or more.
lead_paragraph: Sulzer, a Swiss maker of pumps and other industrial equipment, said on Wednesday that it was in talks with the Dresser-Rand Group about a deal that could be valued at $5.5 billion or more.

headline: Pay Gap Is Smaller Than Ever, and Still Stubbornly Large
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Compensation', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Family Leaves']
abstract: Women were paid 78 cents for every dollar a man earned last year, a record-high percentage.
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau released new data Tuesday on the pay gap between men and women, showing a statistically insignificant increase. But the news is better than it might seem.

headline: Today in Small Business: When You Don’t Love Your Company Name
abstract: How being videotaped changes employee behavior. How RadioShack missed almost every opportunity. And does Urban Outfitters offend on purpose?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Jameis Winston Suspended for First Half of Florida State-Clemson Game
abstract: Florida State’s star quarterback, the reigning Heisman Trophy winner, was penalized after shouting an obscene comment on campus.
lead_paragraph: Florida State said Wednesday that quarterback Jameis Winston, last season’s Heisman Trophy winner, would be suspended for the first half of the top-ranked Seminoles’ home game Saturday against No. 22 Clemson after he shouted an obscene statement in the student union Tuesday.

headline: Have You Tried Selling Products in China?
abstract: For less than the price of a plane ticket to China, Export Now promised to ship a small business’s goods to China and put them online in a massive market. Most small businesses were not interested.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published a conversation with Frank Lavin, who introduced an e-commerce platform two years ago, Export Now, that was conceived as an easy, low-cost way for American small businesses to sell their goods in China. The basic pitch: “Sell into China without leaving your desk.”

headline: A Time-Traveling Stoppard Play
abstract: Tom Stoppard’s play “Indian Ink” is finally getting its Off Broadway premiere at the Roundabout Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Indian Ink” was the last play Tom Stoppard wrote that didn’t soon become a New York event. When it opened at the West End in the mid-90s, his “Arcadia” was a London hit and played in a star-studded production at Lincoln Center. But for some reason, Lincoln Center, which went on to produce his “The Invention of Love,” “The Coast of Utopia” and “Rock ’n’ Roll,” passed on “Indian Ink,” an intellectually lively, time-traveling drama that moves between a poet in the 1930s and an academic in the future examining her life.

headline: Panel Urges Overhauling Health Care at End of Life
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The committee said the health care system was geared toward delivering costly additional care that patients often do not want.
lead_paragraph: The country’s system for handling end-of-life care is largely broken and should be overhauled at almost every level, a national panel concluded in a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Billionaire Placed Under House Arrest in Russia
abstract: Vladimir P. Yevtushenkov, the majority shareholder in the conglomerate Sistema, has been accused of money laundering, but some say his arrest was politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The house arrest of a billionaire sent shock waves through the Russian stock market on Wednesday in a case that for its sheer size, if nothing else, was already drawing comparisons to the jailing of the oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky.

headline: With the iPhone 6 Plus, Apple Aims for Versatility
abstract: Clunky though the term may be, a phablet — part phone, part tablet — is a device that offers welcome versatility.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to make peace with the term phablet.

headline: House Votes to Authorize Aid to Syrian Rebels in ISIS Fight
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A House divided along unusual and unpredictable lines voted to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant group Islamic State, backing President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An unusual but overwhelming coalition in the House voted Wednesday to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels to confront the militant Islamic State, backing President Obama after he personally pleaded for support.

abstract: With circular tops and clean lines, a midcentury workhorse enters the modern era.
lead_paragraph: With circular tops and clean lines, a midcentury workhorse enters the modern era.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Posts Recall of 25,000 Fiat 500L Models
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The agency also announced it was opening an investigation of Ford Fiesta door latch problems.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling some 25,500 of its 2014-15 Fiat 500L models because a knee air bag designed to protect the driver’s legs in a frontal impact may malfunction, according to a report from the automaker posted on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The report is dated July 30, but the agency did not post it until Wednesday.

headline: Clip: ‘The Equalizer’
abstract: A scene from Antoine Fuqua’s film “The Equalizer,” featuring Denzel Washington and Chloë Grace Moretz.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Antoine Fuqua’s film “The Equalizer,” featuring Denzel Washington and Chloë Grace Moretz.

headline: The ISIS Threat: Teaching About the Complex War Raging in Iraq and Syria
abstract: In this lesson, students will analyze videos, maps, graphs and images related to ISIS and then discuss how the U.S. and the world should respond to ISIS’ rise in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Update | March 17, 2015: We have published a related lesson, “Teenagers and Extremism: Investigating the ISIS Recruitment Pipeline.”

headline: Lethal Violence in Chimps Occurs Naturally, Study Suggests
abstract: A new survey suggests that violence is a natural part of chimp behavior and not the result of actions by humans that push the animals to lethal attacks.
lead_paragraph: Are chimpanzees naturally violent to one another, or has the intrusion of humans into their environment made them aggressive?

headline: U.N. Leader Plans Stronger Presence in Ebola Zone
abstract: The move by the secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, signaled his concern with the response so far and the limitations of the World Health Organization’s ability to handle it alone.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, said on Wednesday that he planned to establish a new on-the-ground mission in West Africa to coordinate the struggle against Ebola, a move that signaled his concern with the response so far and the limitations of the World Health Organization’s abilities.

headline: Syrian Forces Are Seen Stepping Up Attacks on Rebels as U.S. Sets Sights on ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Fighters who oppose the government of President Bashar al-Assad and the Islamic State are being pummeled by a new wave of attacks and assassination attempts.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — One bomb struck an insurgent meeting place and weapons storehouse. Another hit the Islamic law court. A third hit a heavy machine gun position, but not just any position — the leader of the largest local insurgent formation was manning a gun there, and was killed.

headline: Forever Wild at Heart
abstract: An exhibition at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts examines the eerie paintings and drawings of the filmmaker David Lynch.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It was in 1967 that David Lynch had his Road-to-Damascus moment. Then a promising student at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts here, he was working one night on a dark painting of a garden when it seemed to him that wind was rushing out of the painting and the plants were moving. “I’m looking at this and hearing this,” he recalled years later, “and I say, ‘Oh, a moving painting.’ And that was it.”

headline: Lecrae, a Christian Rapper, Hits No. 1
abstract: “Anomaly,” the latest album by the Christian rapper Lecrae, is the first to hold the No. 1 spots on both the gospel and Billboard 200 charts.
lead_paragraph: “Anomaly,” the latest album by the Christian rapper Lecrae, makes its debut at No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart for the week ending Sept. 14. The album, Lecrae’s seventh, is his first to top the all-genres chart; his last album, “Gravity” (2012), reached No. 3. That said, “Anomaly” is also No. 1 on two other Billboard charts – gospel, which Lecrae has now topped six times, and Christian, where “Anomaly” is his fifth No. 1.

headline: 20 Years After ‘It’s Perfectly Normal,’ What’s Changed?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Sex', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: If you’re looking to start a conversation about sexuality with your child, “It’s Perfectly Normal,” with its science-based, rigorously researched approach, makes for solid footing on which to begin.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Perfectly Normal,” the go-to guide for teenagers and adults on adolescent sexual health and development, was first published 20 years ago, in 1994. Fifteen years ago, the author Robie H. Harris and the illustrator Michael Emberly followed it with “It’s So Amazing,” subtitled “A Book About Eggs, Sperm, Birth, Babies and Families” (what else could you even need to know?).

headline: With New Health Law, Shopping Around Can Be Crucial
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In the Affordable Care Act marketplaces so far, insurance filings show good news for the federal budget and aggressive shoppers. But people who don’t shop could get stuck with a big bill.
lead_paragraph: If you bought health insurance at an Affordable Care Act marketplace this year, it really pays to look around before renewing your coverage for next year.

headline: Fed Signals No Hurry to Raise Interest Rates
abstract: Downgrading its economic forecasts, the Federal Reserve continued to say it would hold rates near zero for a “considerable time.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is in no hurry to raise interest rates.

headline: Costume Institute to Work With Wong Kar-wai in a Show Focused on China
abstract: Mr. Wong, the film director, will serve as artistic director for “Chinese Whispers: Tales of the East in Art, Film and Fashion,” opening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in May.
lead_paragraph: With the help of the film director Wong Kar-wai, the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take on its biggest subject yet next year: China and the country’s influence over centuries on fashion, art and film.

headline: Fantasy Football: Matchup Breakdown for Week 3
abstract: Highlighting some of the players to consider starting, and those to avoid, in Week 3 of the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: One could build a fantastic fantasy football team with only the players who left Week 2 games with significant injuries.

headline: Occupy Wall Street Activists File Suit Over Control of Twitter Account
abstract: Several activists are accusing a former comrade of taking sole control of the shared account @OccupyWallStNYC and locking out the organizers he had once collaborated with.
lead_paragraph: Three years after the Occupy Wall Street movement began, an unlikely conflict has emerged over one of the cause’s most precious tools: a Twitter account.

headline: Reading The Times With Billy Collins
abstract: Monk parrots, carnage in Kabul, dancing palace guards, and a touch of Yeats. Reading the paper with the former poet laureate Billy Collins.
lead_paragraph: The former poet laureate Billy Collins’s ideal day begins with coffee and poetry. Either he reads someone else’s poems or writes one of his own. Then, he says, “I feel it’s safer to enter the larger world!” Mr. Collins sometimes reads The Times online, but prefers print on big pages. “The pages of The Irish Times are even bigger, like sails or flags, and, of course, knowing how to fold a newspaper is an art, as with sails and flags,” he says.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Adam Wingard Narrates a Sequence From ‘The Guest’
abstract: Adam Wingard discusses a scene from his film, written by Simon Barrett and featuring Dan Stevens and Maika Monroe.
lead_paragraph: Music adds to the mysteries found in “The Guest,” the new thriller from the director Adam Wingard and the screenwriter Simon Barrett starring Dan Stevens. In this video, Mr. Wingard discusses a sequence between David (Mr. Stevens) and Anna (Maika Monroe), the girl whose parents have offered the drifting David a place to stay. Mr. Wingard says the scene’s featured song, “Haunted When the Minutes Drag” by Love and Rockets, inspired the film’s style.

headline: Let the Phone Be Your Political Adviser
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Mobile apps offer news and opinion on politicians and issues, and even information straight from Congress and the White House.
lead_paragraph: LIKE it, loathe it or tolerate it with gritted teeth, politics influences our daily lives. One way to keep on top of the latest in political intrigue is on your smartphone.

headline: App Smart | Keeping Track of Politics
abstract: As we head into election season, Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will help you stay on top of news, analysis, and when politicians are using double-speak to make their points.
lead_paragraph: As we head into election season, Kit Eaton reviews three apps that will help you stay on top of news, analysis, and when politicians are using double-speak to make their points.

headline: Bad Vaccine Kills Dozens of Children Inside Syria
abstract: Volunteer medical organizations said the vaccine afflicted dozens of children in insurgent-held areas of Idlib Province.
lead_paragraph: An improperly mixed or possibly sabotaged measles vaccine has killed as many as 50 children in insurgent-held areas of northwestern Syria, volunteer medical organizations and physicians reported Wednesday, forcing the suspension of a large-scale United Nations vaccination campaign intended to stop the spread of measles, rubella and polio.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Alberta Ferretti Spring/Summer 2015

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Backs Limits on Testosterone Drugs
abstract: New rules could reduce the number of men who would be prescribed the medicines, as well as coverage from insurance companies for their use.
lead_paragraph: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — An expert panel voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday for the Food and Drug Administration to impose strict new limitations on the multibillion-dollar testosterone drug industry, recommending that the agency tighten labels for the medicines so they are not prescribed to men who only have problems related to aging, such as low energy and libido. The F.D.A. often takes the advice of such panels.

headline: F.T.C. Fines Yelp and TinyCo for Violating Children’s Privacy Rules
abstract: The commission found that the two companies violated the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act, known as Coppa.
lead_paragraph: Updated | WASHINGTON – Tiny Pets, Tiny Zoo, Tiny Monsters and other mobile apps aimed at children have been downloaded more than 34 million times, often – not surprisingly – by children. But TinyCo, the maker of the apps, failed to recognize that strict rules apply to collection of information from children online, according to federal regulators.

headline: Obama Vows No U.S. Ground War in Iraq

lead_paragraph: In an address at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida, President Obama insisted that the United States would not get drawn into direct combat in Iraq.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)', 'Harry Potter (Fictional Character)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Research']
abstract: Recent research suggests that the impact of the “Harry Potter” series may be far more significant than a shared cultural experience and a rich vocabulary of spells. Is it possible that reading Harry Potter makes us better people?
lead_paragraph: If you’re on Facebook, there’s a big chance you’ve seen a friend list 10 books “that have stayed with them in some way.” And if you’ve seen such a list, there’s a big chance the “Harry Potter” series by J.K. Rowling was among the 10.

lead_paragraph: American security officials outlined threats to the United States from the terrorist group the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, during a congressional hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Getty Foundation Announces Grants for 20th-Century Buildings
abstract: The Getty Foundation’s “Keeping It Modern” program focuses on the conservation of 20th-century architecture.
lead_paragraph: As part of a new philanthropic effort focused on the conservation of 20th-century architecture around the world the Getty Foundation in Los Angeles on Wednesday announced the first 10 grants for significant modern buildings.

headline: Lashing Out at His Tormentors, at Last
abstract: Perfume Genius’s new album, “Too Bright,” due out Tuesday, is a transformative leap for the artist.
lead_paragraph: As he held a giant hamburger, Mike Hadreas, who records as Perfume Genius, noticed that his nail polish perfectly matched the bottle of ketchup on a restaurant table. “When I play shows, I’ll do it up more with some lipstick,” he said.

headline: Off-the-Record Session With the President on ISIS Raises Concerns
abstract: Readers question the ‘symbiotic relationship’ between the president and the press.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s session last week with opinion columnists and magazine writers included some journalistic big guns. And the subject could not have been more important: his strategy on dealing with the terrorist group known as ISIS.

headline: Grungy Waves at No. 21
abstract: Messy hair packed an extra dose of attitude into the label’s spring 2015 fashion show.
lead_paragraph: Complete with embellished red plaid and army-green jackets, No. 21’s spring 2015 collection featured its fair share of grunge. To complete the mood, perfectly messy hair was parted down the middle and kept off the face to reveal a very ’90s, bordeaux-colored lip.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: A Connection as Vital as It Is Toxic
abstract: Lila and Elena, friends since their childhood in postwar Naples, both attract and repel each another in Elena Ferrante’s “Those Who Leave and Those Who Stay.”
lead_paragraph: Nothing you read about Elena Ferrante’s work prepares you for the ferocity of it. And with each new novel in her revelatory Neapolitan series, she unprepares you all over again. The story follows the lifelong friendship-hateship of Lila and Elena, two women from an impoverished neighborhood in Naples, a city that “seemed to harbor in its guts a fury that couldn’t get out and therefore eroded it from the inside.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing

lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Time-Lapse: ‘Scenes From a Marriage’
abstract: A time-lapse video of the transformation of New York Theater Workshop for its production of “Scenes From a Marriage,” conceived by Ivo van Hove.
lead_paragraph: A time-lapse video of the transformation of New York Theater Workshop for its production of “Scenes From a Marriage,” conceived by Ivo van Hove.

headline: A Generation of Unintended Laughs
abstract: “America’s Funniest Home Videos” turns 25, with YouTube a surprising part of its continued success.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — “A relic of a bygone time.” “The uncoolest show on TV.” “Inexplicably never-ending, like a Cher farewell tour.”

headline: On Film, a City Shows Its Noir Side
abstract: For more than a decade, the Boston shown in movies has been a dark moody place far removed from the historic city tourists see.
lead_paragraph: Boston is a city of venerable neighborhoods, rich cultural history and academic distinction. But lately, at least on film, it seems as if it’s a city of melancholy. It has taken a turn for the bleak on the big screen, where in little more than a decade, films like “The Town,” “The Departed” and “Mystic River” have depicted a sense of corruption and unrest, with characters often at a breaking point. The darkened streets and bad behavior are once again illuminated in “The Equalizer,” opening Sept. 26 and featuring Denzel Washington as a man with a mysterious past who seeks solace, and an ordinary life, in the city. But trouble is often nearby (mostly in the form of Russian gangsters and crooked cops), and he must take matters into his own hands in an effort to make the dark side of the city a little brighter.

headline: Justice Department Urges Banks to Implicate Employees
abstract: Comments by Marshall L. Miller, the No. 2 official in the Justice Department’s criminal division, reflect the agency’s renewed interest in charging individual bank employees rather than just the banks.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has a suggestion for banks hoping to avoid criminal charges: Rat out your employees.

headline: The Fed Is Boring Again. That’s a Relief.
abstract: After years of improvising a response to an unprecedented crisis, the Federal Reserve is going back to its usual self: slow-moving and deliberate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FOR the last six years, Federal Reserve policy has been sexy, or at least as sexy as monetary policy can ever be.

headline: A Musical Gala With a Cinematic Spotlight
abstract: The New York Philharmonic began its season on Tuesday with music from Italian movies and help from Renée Fleming, Joshua Bell and Josh Groban.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a little hard to figure out exactly when the New York Philharmonic was officially opening its season this fall. The subscription series concert season begins on Tuesday with a substantive and enticing program at Avery Fisher Hall: Alan Gilbert will conduct Mahler’s First Symphony and the American premiere of the compelling composer Unsuk Chin’s Clarinet Concerto.

headline: Magdalena Jasek Transforms Backstage at Alberta Ferretti
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Magdalena Jasek before (left) and after (right) makeup by Diane Kendal and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Artificial Sweeteners May Disrupt Body’s Blood Sugar Controls
abstract: New research in mice suggests artificial sweeteners may disrupt the ability to regulate blood sugar, causing changes in metabolism that can be a precursor to diabetes.
lead_paragraph: Artificial sweeteners may disrupt the body’s ability to regulate blood sugar, causing metabolic changes that can be a precursor to diabetes, researchers are reporting.

headline: Tension, Quiet and What’s in Between
abstract: Molissa Fenley’s dances at Judson Memorial Church play on shifts between tension and tranquillity.
lead_paragraph: Molissa Fenley’s dances flourish in wide-open spaces, where the air around bodies becomes just as tangible as the sculptural shapes she creates for her dancers. It’s hard to say if that quality relates to her early years growing up in Nigeria, but an uncluttered space like Judson Memorial Church, where her company returned Tuesday evening, provides a luminous setting for the breadth of her movement in her refined and systematic modern dances. Somehow, it’s like gazing into the horizon of a foreign land.

headline: Apartment Accommodations, Hotel Services
abstract: The new site BeMate.com will offer guests accommodations in apartments and services from local hotels.
lead_paragraph: Travelers who like the less-touristy idea of booking an apartment when they’re visiting a new city but also want the amenities of a hotel can now have both with BeMate.com, a service that launched Wednesday with 2,500 apartments in 10 cities including New York, Miami, Florence, Amsterdam and Madrid.

headline: Scottish Vote Weighs Pride Against Risk
abstract: While Scots have been warned repeatedly about the dire consequences of voting for independence from the United Kingdom, half — more or less — are expected to do so anyway.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The people of Scotland decide Thursday whether national pride outweighs economic risk.

headline: New ‘Genius Grant’ Winner Alison Bechdel to Write New Graphic Memoir
abstract: “The Secret to Superhuman Strength” by Ms. Bechdel, a new MacArthur fellow, has been sold to Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, which plans to publish it in 2017.
lead_paragraph: The cartoonist and graphic memoirist Alison Bechdel was in a castle in Umbria as part of an artist’s residency in Italy when she learned that she had been selected as one of 21 MacArthur “genius” grant recipients this year. She bought a case of prosecco to share with the other artists in residence.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Fausto Puglisi Spring/Summer 2015

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

abstract: A new exhibition of the artist and filmmaker’s work is at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition of the artist and filmmaker’s work is at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

headline: Multinational Companies Court Lower-Income Consumers
abstract: Companies once had little interest in lower-end consumers, but some now recognize the potential of that vast market.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — When General Electric engineers here wanted to develop a more affordable baby warmer for India’s small, private hospitals, they initially replaced the fat, rubberized wheels standard on high-end models with smaller metal ones. They figured it was a quick, easy way to cut costs.

headline: Air France Strife Shows Challenges for European Business
abstract: Work force resistance, entrenched regulatory regimes and a stagnant regional economy are among impediments confronting managers of Europe’s legacy airlines.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The airline industry, particularly in Europe, is a highly competitive international business. But old, border-bound ways can be hard to eradicate.

headline: Gotham City, Emphasis on the Goth
abstract: The new Fox drama “Gotham,” set in Batman’s city when Bruce Wayne was a boy, relies heavily on visual effects to create a setting out of time and place.
lead_paragraph: The star of “Gotham,” perhaps the most anticipated new drama of the television season, is not Batman, who probably won’t make an appearance (in that form) for the entire run of the series.

headline: There’s a Lesson Here; All You Have to Do Is Listen
abstract: The conductor Roger Nierenberg uses his Music Paradigm program to teach corporate employees and managers leadership skills through music.
lead_paragraph: I couldn’t have been more skeptical. I couldn’t have been more wrong.

headline: Consumer Finance Agency Seeks to Broaden Oversight of Auto Loans
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to extend its authority to include 38 non-bank auto lenders that provided financing to 6.8 million consumers last year.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau wants to expand its oversight to include an important player in the auto loan market: non-bank auto finance companies.

headline: Artists Take Over Two Outdoor Malls in Massachusetts and Florida
abstract: Art Production Fund has installed the works of Deborah Kass and Jessica Craig-Martin in advertising spaces at a pair of high-end shopping centers.
lead_paragraph: As the daughter of two art collectors — the fashion designer Lisa Perry and the hedge fund manager Richard Perry — Samantha Perry David grew up surrounded by Jeff Koons sculptures and Andy Warhol paintings. Now the head of upMarkets, a division of the retail real estate firm WS Development, David realized there was a dearth of public art at two of its properties, the luxury shopping center The Street in Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Hyde Park Village in Tampa, Fla. So she called on two of her mother’s friends, Yvonne Force Villareal and Doreen Remen of Art Production Fund, to do something about it. “We were compelled by this notion because there is no public art within that community,” Force Villareal says, “and we always strive to bring the vision of contemporary artists to new audiences that have little exposure to such projects.”

headline: A Devil Dog Tears Into People, and Other Tales
abstract: “Mr. Pickles” and “Tim & Eric’s Bedtime Stories” are cheerfully grisly late-night offerings on Adult Swim.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’re pleased to be living during the golden age of television, you might find yourself overdosing on oversexed political soap operas or noir detectives with anguished back stories. For those moments when you want something a little different — well, more than a little different — there’s Adult Swim, which this week adds two new shows to its catalog of late-night, 15-minute transgressions against coherence and good taste.

headline: India vs. Wales at Commonwealth Championships
abstract: The 4th Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships took place in Glasgow last week.
lead_paragraph: The 4th Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships took place in Glasgow last week.

headline: A New Crew Salvages Old ‘Molly Brown’
abstract: “The Unsinkable Molly Brown,” having a run in Denver, is about as changed as a revival can be.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — In a rehearsal room here, the librettist-lyricist Dick Scanlan and the director-choreographer Kathleen Marshall were watching their cast read through a scene when someone flubbed a recently altered line. “I know it’s hard when we change everything, but that’s the gig,” Mr. Scanlan told the weary-looking ensemble.

headline: Offstage Maneuvers Torpedo a Musical
abstract: Two veteran Broadway producers helped torpedo an Off Broadway theater’s premiere of the musical “American Psycho” and are in talks to bring it directly to Broadway next fall.
lead_paragraph: Two veteran Broadway producers helped torpedo an Off Broadway theater’s premiere of the high-profile musical “American Psycho” and are now in talks to bring it directly to Broadway next fall, several theater executives with the show said on Wednesday.

headline: New York State Judge Rejects Word in Redistricting Ballot Question
abstract: A new commission’s plan to redraw legislative district lines would be “little more than a recommendation to the legislature,” a State Supreme Court justice wrote.
lead_paragraph: A New York State judge ruled on Wednesday that a ballot question on the formation of a commission to redraw legislative district lines could not refer to the proposed panel as “independent,” because most of its members would be appointed by leaders of the Legislature.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Serbia, Israel and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Serbia, Israel and Turkey.

headline: Embellished Shower Slides at Fausto Puglisi
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: A luxurious riff on the classic leisure slip-on.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In the Cascades, a Trifecta for Outdoor Enthusiasts
abstract: Washington’s Stehekin Valley has great scenery, comfortable lodging and good food and relatively few visitors. Just don’t expect an easy path to get there.
lead_paragraph: It is the outdoor enthusiast’s trifecta: spectacular scenery, great lodging and food, and no crowds. Two out of three is easy enough to come by. National Park jewels like the Yosemite Valley have iconic views and great places to stay and eat, but also trails so crowded you wish they’d install passing lanes. Backpacking is a great way to access mind-blowing scenery without the traffic jams, but the quality of your lodging and food will be limited to what you’re willing to carry.

headline: A Wine Region Flourishes in Central Washington
abstract: One of the state’s fastest-growing wine regions, Lake Chelan now has almost two dozen wineries clustered around its southern end.
lead_paragraph: When the apple market collapsed about 15 years ago in the region around Lake Chelan in central Washington State, a handful of farmers decided to make the transition from apples to grapes. Though the apple market has recovered, there’s been no turning back for these erstwhile orchardists. Along the shores of Lake Chelan, wineries have been popping up as quickly as bubbles in a newly uncorked bottle of Champagne.

headline: Q. and A.: Xiao Zhen on Trying to End ‘Gay Conversion Therapy’ in China
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: China decriminalized homosexuality in 1997 and declassified it as a mental illness in 2001, but clinics promising to “convert” gay people abound in a country where pressure to join the heterosexual mainstream is high.
lead_paragraph: A 30-year-old man going by the pseudonym Xiao Zhen has attracted attention in recent months as the first person in China to file a lawsuit against a clinic offering “gay conversion therapy,” treatments aiming to change sexual orientation that many medical experts criticize as ineffective and harmful. With the help of the Beijing LGBT Center, an organization representing gay, bisexual and transgender people, Xiao Zhen has sued the Xinyupiaoxiang Counseling Center in Chongqing, as well as Baidu, China’s leading Internet search engine, for posting the ads that led him there.

headline: Total Failure on Auto Safety
abstract: To prevent another recall debacle, Congress badly needs to strengthen the federal agency responsible for investigating auto defects.
lead_paragraph: Here is one clear lesson from the General Motors recall debacle: Congress badly needs to strengthen the federal agency responsible for investigating auto defects. Reports released this week paint a disturbing picture of how regulators failed to identify an ignition defect in millions of G.M. cars that has now been linked to at least  19 deaths and could be responsible for many more.

headline: On Ground Troops in Iraq, Obama and his Generals Appear at Odds
abstract: Is there a disagreement over the kind of strategy needed to succeed against ISIS?
lead_paragraph: Speaking to military personnel at CENTCOM in Tampa on Wednesday, President Obama was unequivocal about his unwillingness to deploy ground troops again in Iraq.

headline: Proposal Would Require Think Tanks to Disclose Funding by Foreign Governments
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Think Tanks', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Lawmakers would like to improve transparency before prominent think tanks’ scholars testify on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Expressing concern that prominent think tanks may be covertly trying to push the agendas of foreign government donors, the House of Representatives is considering a rule that would require that their scholars testifying on Capitol Hill disclose any such support — a proposal that won immediate bipartisan endorsement on Wednesday.

headline: A Bezos Company Will Make Engines for Rockets
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Blue Origin, owned by Jeff Bezos, agreed to work with United Launch Alliance, which has sent nearly all United States spy and military satellites into space in the last decade.
lead_paragraph: The space race is shaping up as a matchup of billionaires, with Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, facing off against Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX and Tesla, over the future of human spaceflight.

headline: Fed to Cut Bond Buying
abstract: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said that the Federal Open Market Committee would taper monthly bond buying to $15 billion to keep interest rates near zero.
lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said that the Federal Open Market Committee would taper monthly bond buying to $15 billion to keep interest rates near zero.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted September 12 through 15 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 12 through 15 with 1,009 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 854 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Obama Faulted in Terror Fight, New Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: With Americans’ fears about a terrorist attack on the rise, a New York Times/CBS News poll finds the public is questioning President Obama’s strategy for combating the militant organization calling itself the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in his presidency, more Americans disapprove of President Obama’s handling of terrorism than approve of it, as discontent about his management of foreign affairs and the fight against Sunni militants in Iraq and Syria weighs on an anxious and conflicted public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: The Moment at Hand
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: On gay marriage, Judge Richard Posner’s journey from “no” to “maybe but not yet” to “yes and now” suggests he is a stand-in for many of us.
lead_paragraph: Two stories appeared on the website of The New York Times within hours of each other early this month. One reported that the drugstore giant CVS had stopped selling tobacco products in its 7,700 stores. The other announced: “Gay Groups to March in St. Patrick’s Day Parade as a Ban Falls.” These two developments had nothing obvious in common beyond their newsworthiness. And yet to anyone who has spent the past couple of decades living on planet Earth, the two stories conveyed the same powerful message: Look how times have changed. What was scarcely imaginable not too many years ago has come to pass.

headline: Fiction Long List Announced for National Book Awards
abstract: Marilynne Robinson, Elizabeth McCracken and Phil Klay are among the writers whose work is on the 2014 fiction long list for the National Book Awards.
lead_paragraph: The long list of nominees for the 2014 National Book Award for fiction, due to be released on Thursday, is an eclectic collection that includes two debut volumes of short stories, a first novel from the lead singer and songwriter for the indie folk rock band the Mountain Goats and a dystopian novel, as well as works from literary heavyweights including Jane Smiley, Marilynne Robinson and Richard Powers.

headline: Tracking a Microtrend Among Affluent Parents
abstract: When children are off to boarding school, some parents are staying connected by buying homes nearby.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Green, a Home section correspondent, writes about parents who buy second homes in order to be closer to their children at boarding schools.

headline: Punishment or Child Abuse?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Slavery', 'Children and Childhood', 'Corporal Punishment', 'Bible', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Too many black parents believe beatings make kids better people.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE indictment last week of the N.F.L. player Adrian Peterson by a Texas grand jury for reckless or negligent injury to a child has set into relief the harmful disciplinary practices of some black families. Mr. Peterson used a “switch,” a slim, leafless tree branch, to beat his 4-year-old son, raising welts on the youngster’s legs, buttocks and scrotum. This is child abuse dressed up as acceptable punishment.

headline: On Johnny’s Knee
abstract: Grown, with children of my own, I still dreamed of the abuser I once thought of as my father.
lead_paragraph: My phone pinged.

headline: On Eve of Alibaba’s I.P.O., Senator Urges S.E.C. to Look at Risks in Some Chinese Offerings
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Senator Bob Casey urged the S.E.C. to make sure companies set up like Alibaba are making proper disclosures and complying with securities regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group may be preparing for a new life as a publicly traded company on the New York Stock Exchange. But one senator is urging securities regulators to take care in letting certain other Chinese companies do the same.

headline: Eddie Adams: 10 Years On, and War Will Never Be the Same
abstract: A decade after the death of Eddie Adams, does photojournalism risk being supplanted by propaganda or fabricated images?
lead_paragraph: A decade after the death of Eddie Adams, does photojournalism risk being supplanted by propaganda or fabricated images?

headline: Kent & Curwen: Playing a Game With New Rules
abstract: Kent & Curwen on Madison Avenue is looking for a place amid the frequent, frenetic changes in men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: Kent & Curwen is an estimable British house that bills itself, on its website, as “outfitters to gentlemen of sport.” Chunky cricket sweaters, loud polo shirts, fulsomely striped college ties — you know, what used to pass for men’s wear.

headline: Bringing Beauty Fanatics and Makeup Muses Together
abstract: BeautyCon, a 3-year-old conference held in Los Angeles, draws thousands of teenage and 20-something women who are hoping to be the next Michelle Phan.
lead_paragraph: BeautyCon, a 3-year-old conference held in Los Angeles, draws thousands of teenage and 20-something women who are hoping to be the next Michelle Phan.

headline: U.S. Courts Close 2 Payday Lenders Accused of Fraud
abstract: Two federal agencies sued groups that deposited money into consumers’ bank accounts without their consent, and then made unauthorized withdrawals.
lead_paragraph: Federal agencies have taken legal action to shut down two networks of online payday lenders, saying they made fraudulent loans to unwitting consumers and then used the loans as a pretext to withdraw millions of dollars from their bank accounts.

headline: Where Old Friends Show Off
abstract: Galerie Kreo exhibits deceptively humble works of design in its new London space.
lead_paragraph: In May, the Paris-based Galerie Kreo, which is known for experimental contemporary design and flashy clients like Karl Lagerfeld and Azzedine Alaïa, opened a London outpost near Berkeley Square in Mayfair. For its latest exhibition in the new space, Kreo is showing off rare works by old friends, including Jasper Morrison, Pierre Charpin and Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec. The exhibition, called “Des Formes Utiles,” explores the relationship between function and form with restrained interpretations of mirrors, tables, lights and ladders, including Studio Wieki Somers’s flowerlike “Aoyama Lamp” ($42,000, edition of six), and Konstantin Grcic’s “London Calling” a Shaker-pure set of oak library steps (about $46,000, edition of eight).

headline: Curiously Recycled
abstract: Scrabble tiles? Human molars? The artist Clare Graham, who has a new a show in Los Angeles, calls them media.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles artist Clare Graham, refashions humble materials in interesting ways — say, thousands of bottle caps wired together to form snakelike sculptures. In “Clare Graham & MorYork: The Answer Is Yes,” his comprehensive new show at the Craft and Folk Art Museum in Los Angeles, the artist has created his own cabinets of curiosity.

headline: Japanese Classics, Every Day
abstract: “Simplified Beauty,” a show in East London, displays contemporary Japanese objects.
lead_paragraph: Sheridan Coakley, founder of the British furniture company SCP, admires Japanese designers for their mastery of the art of the everyday. With Reiko Kaneko, he has organized “Simplified Beauty,” an exhibition of specially commissioned Japanese objects displayed in his store in the East London neighborhood of Shoreditch.

headline: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler, Design Within Reach, Gracious Home and Jensen-Lewis
abstract: Sales on cookware, glassware and hardware
lead_paragraph: Broadway Panhandler is discounting some knives, cookware and glassware by up to 62 percent, Friday through Sept. 28, or while supplies last (a set of eight Riedel Ouverture Magnum red wine glasses, regularly $96, is about $60); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), 212-966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: A Celebration of Silver, Seen in Ravishing Detail
abstract: “Georg Jensen: Reflections” is one connoisseur’s take on the Danish luxury company.
lead_paragraph: “Like one’s reputation, sterling silver requires vigilance, lest they both tarnish and lose their luster,” writes Murray Moss in the new monograph “Georg Jensen: Reflections” (Rizzoli New York, $85). Mr. Moss, the design curator and consultant, leaves behind the well-trod path of history and instead explores what makes people want to care for the 110-year-old Danish company’s wares.

headline: New York City Police Add Security Amid a Call for Attacks
abstract: The police stepped up security in response to the possible threat of a terrorist attack in Times Square, even as officials cautioned that they had no information about specific plans against the city.
lead_paragraph: The police in New York stepped up security on Wednesday in response to the possible threat of a terrorist attack in Times Square, even as officials cautioned that they had no information about specific plans against the city.

headline: Roy McMakin: His Art Is Another’s Furniture
abstract: The artist’s new pieces include a chest of drawers inspired by porn.
lead_paragraph: The 58-year-old artist Roy McMakin insists that he is not a furniture designer. He calls his latest introductions — a chair, a sofa, two tables, a cabinet and a chest of drawers, all on display at the Lora Reynolds Gallery in Austin, Tex. — a “grouping,” not a collection. Mr. McMakin developed a cult following for his functional art after opening Domestic Furniture, a Los Angeles showroom, in 1987. He shut its doors in 1994, moved to Seattle and, three years later, founded Big Leaf Manufacturing, a workshop that produces Domestic Furniture designs. He now lives in San Diego while maintaining architecture and design studios in Seattle. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

lead_paragraph: Scott Wiener, a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, made an unusual public announcement on Wednesday: He takes Truvada, a daily antiviral pill, to greatly reduce his risk of contracting H.I.V.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As hospitals merge and buy up physician practices, creating new behemoths, one federal agency is raising a lonely but powerful voice, suggesting that consumers may be victimized by the trend toward consolidation.

keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds']

lead_paragraph: AUDITIONS for “Shark Tank,” the ABC show where aspiring entrepreneurs pitch their businesses as an investment opportunity to a panel of successful businesspeople, called “sharks,” are usually held in major cities like Chicago, Los Angeles and New York.

abstract: Should law students be able to get compensation for internships that count toward graduation?

abstract: The special House committee on Benghazi got off to a quiet start in a hearing on Wednesday, but outside groups on the left and the right continued their maneuvering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special House committee on Benghazi seemed determined to prove on Wednesday that it would not be the bickering, partisan panel that many expected. But the outside political class did not get the memo.

abstract: Objects designed by master builders offer something special — maybe even a touch of genius?
lead_paragraph: The designs of modernists like Le Corbusier, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Frank Lloyd Wright are like the classics of rock ’n’ roll: groundbreaking works that inspired legions of followers.

headline: Five Years Later, Chrysler’s Gamble on Ram Trucks Is Paying Off
abstract: The Ram truck division is increasing market share with an emphasis on fuel economy and upgraded interiors.
lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — In December, the sprawling, four million-square-foot factory here where workers assemble Ram pickup trucks, along conveyors that weave for more than 30 miles, suddenly went quiet.

headline: Poor Fitness in Military Poses Peril, Report Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Obesity', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: A report from a group of retired military leaders, which has campaigned for improved childhood nutrition, shines a light on obesity in the military and its risks to readiness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An increase in the number of overweight and out-of-shape service members who are unable to run long distances or perform physical tasks like push-ups poses a direct threat to the United States’ ability to defend itself, a group of retired military leaders fighting for improved childhood nutrition said Wednesday.

headline: The Catwalk Serves as a Billboard

headline: Shopping for Flair? The Moto X Smartphone Fits the Bill
abstract: Motorola is introducing the new Moto X model hoping to lure Android shoppers with something a bit different.
lead_paragraph: MOST phones look about the same. Without a case, they are flat rectangles with slightly rounded edges and they come in black, white and occasionally gold.

headline: On Spanking and Abuse
keywords: ['Corporal Punishment', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Drawing blood isn’t an expression of love. It’s an expression of anger and exasperation that morphs into abuse.
lead_paragraph: According to reports about the Adrian Peterson felony abuse indictment, Peterson’s 4-year-old son pushed another of Peterson’s sons off a video game. Peterson then retrieved a tree branch — called a “switch” — stripped off its leaves, shoved leaves into the boy’s mouth and beat him with his pants down until he bled.

headline: Gap Between Manhattan’s Rich and Poor Is Greatest in U.S., Census Finds
abstract: While incomes of the lowest earners have stagnated, those of the wealthiest New Yorkers have soared, benefiting in part from the resurgence of the financial industry.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan is becoming an island of extremes.

headline: Sunrise, Sunset and a Space for Each
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The pair of apartments could have been combined, but they worked even better as their own separate worlds.
lead_paragraph: When a design-conscious couple from Los Angeles moves to New York, the last thing you’d think would appeal to them is what some people refer to as a “developer special”: a big new building with little to distinguish it beyond the fact of its newness.

headline: Life With Hundreds of Birds
abstract: Michele Raffin has hundreds of birds in her California backyard, also known as Pandemonium Aviaries, where she cares for talkative parrots and is breeding endangered pigeons.
lead_paragraph: Michele Raffin has hundreds of birds in her California backyard, also known as Pandemonium Aviaries, where she cares for talkative parrots and is breeding endangered pigeons.

headline: 362 Birds, and Unruffled
keywords: ['Birds', 'Books and Literature', 'Breeding of Animals', 'Rescues', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: One rescue led to many, many others and a teeming two-wing backyard sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: LOS ALTOS, Calif. — Michele Raffin’s approach to life, love and especially birds has changed dramatically since the day nearly 15 years ago when she stopped to rescue an injured dove by the side of a road.

headline: Venezuela: Move to Revoke Actress’s Citizenship
abstract: The government said Wednesday that it would seek to revoke the citizenship of the actress Maria Conchita Alonso, left, a fervent critic of its socialist-inspired policies.
lead_paragraph: The government said Wednesday that it would seek to revoke the citizenship of the actress Maria Conchita Alonso, left, a fervent critic of its socialist-inspired policies. Ms. Alonso was born in Cuba and moved to Venezuela as a child, becoming a naturalized citizen. She has lived for years in the United States. The Interior Ministry will take judicial action to revoke her citizenship, according to the Information Ministry website. In May, Ms. Alonso said in an interview with the Voice of America, “I wish that the United States would invade with bullets to remove all those wretched communists from Venezuela.” Venezuela is mired in an economic crisis, with inflation of 63 percent a year and shortages of basic goods, problems for which the government frequently blames its opponents. Ms. Alonso competed in the Miss Venezuela pageant in 1975 and has appeared in many films, including “Predator 2.”

headline: Miss New York’s Red-Cup Juggling
abstract: Twitter reacts to the talents of the new Miss America.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the Miss America pageant crowned its latest winner, Kira Kazantsev, the third consecutive winner from New York (labeled a “three-peat” by Twitter users). For the talent portion, Ms. Kazantsev sang Pharrell Williams’s “Happy” while tapping and flipping a red plastic cup, a routine that some assumed was inspired by the 2012 musical comedy “Pitch Perfect,” starring Anna Kendrick as an a cappella singer. Others thought it looked like a college drinking game. Making matters worse, the following tidbit appeared on the screen during her performance: “Loves anything Jane Austin.” This misspelling of the renowned author’s name added to the barrage of tweets.

headline: New York City Council Hears Push for Benefits by Jazz Veterans
abstract: Speakers at a hearing sought the Council’s support for a union campaign for pension payments from owners of six jazz clubs.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of a City Council committee hearing at City Hall on Wednesday, notes began to stream, slowly and unexpectedly, from a flugelhorn, alternating between blares and warbles, but unmistakably forming the spiritual “Nobody Knows the Trouble I’ve Seen.”

headline: Wisconsin: Full Court Asked to Halt Voter ID Law
abstract: Opponents of a law requiring voters to provide photo ID asked a federal appeals court to reconsider a ruling last week that cleared the way for the law to take effect for the Nov. 4 elections.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of a law requiring voters to provide photo ID asked a federal appeals court on Wednesday to reconsider a ruling last week that cleared the way for the law to take effect for the Nov. 4 elections. Arguing that the abrupt reinstatement of the requirement would create chaos and confusion and prevent some residents from voting, the opponents, including the American Civil Liberties Union, asked that judges from the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit re-examine the decision last week by a three-judge panel of the court. The law was first approved by lawmakers and signed by Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican, in 2011, though it has been delayed since 2012 as legal fights play out in state and federal courts.

headline: Michigan: One-Week Delay Ordered in Bankruptcy Trial
abstract: A trial on Detroit’s plan for erasing debts and remaking city services will be delayed for a week, a federal bankruptcy judge said.
lead_paragraph: A trial on Detroit’s plan for erasing debts and remaking city services will be delayed for a week, a federal bankruptcy judge said on Wednesday. The delay, which will halt testimony in the case for all of next week, is to give the remaining critics of Detroit’s plan a chance to rework their legal case after another critic, Syncora Guarantee, a bond insurer, unexpectedly dropped its objections and settled with the city. The trial over the exit plan proposed by Detroit, the largest city ever to seek bankruptcy protection, began on Sept. 2 and is scheduled to run into October.

headline: A Sobering Future for New York’s Dive Bars
abstract: New York’s hard-core drinking joints are threatened by gentrification.
lead_paragraph: As a dive bar should, the Subway Inn smelled like stale beer and sweat one Thursday last month as a throng of well-wishers crowded three deep for a last hurrah.

headline: Fashion Photography Is the Art World’s Rising Star
abstract: With the explosion of street-style blogs, Instagram and Pinterest, fashion photography has become the new visual language.
lead_paragraph: “Fashion photographers are the new painters,” Peter Lindbergh said as he prepared the show of his dramatic black-and-white images that opened last week at the Gagosian Gallery in Paris. Who would have guessed in the heady 1980s — when Mr. Lindbergh’s new, natural images of Linda Evangelista, Cindy Crawford and others created the supermodel — that the art world would lose its disdain for fashion photography’s commercialism?

headline: Sex Is the Least of It
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representative Mark Sanford of South Carolina has gone from the Love Guv to the Facebook Congressman.

lead_paragraph: Josh Ostrovsky, who is Jewish and weighs a paunchy 250 pounds, would prefer that you not call him a fat Jew.

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto will soon undergo chemotherapy for treatment of two unusual, malignant tumors, a physician told reporters on Wednesday.

headline: A Dutch Town Honors U.S. Soldiers’ Wartime Bravery at Germany’s Edge
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Museums']
abstract: Nijmegen, the Netherlands, recently completed a showpiece bridge, in memory of a bold daylight crossing of the Waal River by the Americans in World War II.
lead_paragraph: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands — When Henny Meijer was 2 years old, his hometown was liberated by American soldiers. Hearing the commotion on the street, his 8-year-old brother ran to greet them with a neighbor — a woman who was handing the Americans orange flowers — when a soldier threw himself on the boy.

headline: Tests for a Still Broken Iraq
abstract: If the new government is to succeed, it will need to take immediate steps to bring about cooperation between sectarian factions.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting, but shortsighted, to believe that the recently reconfigured government in Iraq is a dependable ally in the new military operation the Obama administration began this week to take back territory seized by the Islamic State, a Sunni extremist group.

headline: Closing Arguments Ahead in Rowland’s Corruption Trial
abstract: John G. Rowland, the former governor of Connecticut who served prison time after a previous corruption trial, made it clear he was not going quietly on this one.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — As former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut politely observes the proceedings from his front-row seat, the gloves have been coming off all week here at his federal trial on corruption charges, with both sides trying to tie up loose ends before the closing arguments on Thursday.

headline: Calling Ripley’s: The Fanny Pack Is Cool, and More Shopping News
abstract: A new take on that tourist fixture the fanny pack is hip; pearls are a big trend this season; clothes bearing doodles and drawings and more.
lead_paragraph: The fanny pack as we know it has been reinvented as a belt bag. Now a city-sleek accessory, the old-time tourist essential could make going hands-free cool, and everyday practical. It will look best with other streamlined basics: slung low over a striped shirt and jeans, say, or a leather skirt and crisp button-down.

headline: Vacillations on Discipline Put a Behemoth on Shaky Ground
abstract: The N.F.L., the multibillion-dollar cultural giant that offers sanctioned violence and controlled mayhem during its season, has been reduced to a group of amateurs.
lead_paragraph: We take for granted that politicians are compromised at best, corrupt at worst, and that misconduct within the financial industry is a given.

headline: Kerry on U.S. Strategy Against ISIS
