lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry reiterated to lawmakers that there would be no American ground troops in combat against ISIS fighters in Iraq and Syria.

headline: V.A. Official Acknowledges Link Between Delays and Patient Deaths
abstract: In a contentious hearing, an official from the Department of Veterans Affairs’ watchdog agency confirmed for the first time that delays in care may have contributed to patients’ deaths.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a contentious hearing before Congress, a senior official from the Department of Veterans Affairs’ watchdog agency acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that delays in care had contributed to the deaths of patients at the department’s medical center in Phoenix.

headline: Elizabeth Whelan, Who Challenged Food Laws, Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Whelan was an epidemiologist who started a national organization to question conventional wisdom on food, chemicals and the environment.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Whelan, an epidemiologist who crusaded against what she called junk science by starting a national organization to question conventional wisdom on food, chemicals and the environment, died on Sept. 11 in Manahawkin, N.J. She was 70.

headline: At Bushwig, Pushing the Boundaries of Drag
abstract: In Bushwick, the Bushwig festival embraces the shocking, the subversive ... and the wigs.
lead_paragraph: In the age of “RuPaul’s Drag Race,” it may seem that all aspiring drag stars are slick and waxed, not a polyester hair out of place. But not in Bushwick.

headline: Scotland: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
abstract: In the week ahead of a historic referendum on Scottish independence, campaigners from both sides took to the streets to sway the vote, which could break a three-century-old union.

headline: Biden, a Catholic School ‘Kid,’ Praises Nuns Under Fire From the Vatican
keywords: ['Nuns', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: The vice president gave his support to a group of women that the Vatican says pay too much attention to social justice and too little to promoting church teaching on issues like abortion and same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — At a Vatican meeting a few years ago, Pope Benedict XVI unexpectedly asked Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for some advice. “You are being entirely too hard on the American nuns,” Mr. Biden offered. “Lighten up.”

headline: Amazon Refreshes Its Kindle Line
abstract: The updated tablets aim at a variety of audiences: from adults who want to work on their tablets to children.
lead_paragraph: It has been said that people don’t want tablets, they want iPads.

headline: Police Marksmanship Contest Held in Albuquerque Amid Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Firearms', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: As police officers gather to practice marksmanship some people wonder if such an event is appropriate in a city under pressure over shootings of civilians.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — At a shooting range on the western edge of this mountain-fringed city, a police marksmanship competition being held this week has all the trappings of a tailgate party in the desert: Men smoke cigars in the parking lot and lounge under tents in foldout chairs. The scent of hot dogs wafts across the range as bullets sail into human-shaped targets.

headline: Milwaukee Brewers Look to End Season of Extremes on an Upswing

headline: Screening a Show and Shaking the Tree

On the show, Henry Louis Gates Jr., one of the hardest working academics in show business, traces the lineage of notable guests to uncover secrets and shake family trees.

She took to working out after shifts and posting photos of herself in colorful fitness clothes. About a year ago, the photos started gaining a certain kind of fame for what many considered Ms. Selter’s best asset: her bottom.

headline: Deciding Who Gets Overtime Pay
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Overtime', 'Editorials', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The Labor Department needs to update the salary threshold so an additional 6.1 million salaried workers could become eligible for overtime.
lead_paragraph: Under federal labor law, if you are an employee making, say, $11.50 an hour — which passes for decent pay these days in many jobs — you would be entitled to time-and-a-half for every hour beyond 40 hours a week. However, if you earn $460 a week in salary you often are not entitled to time-and-a-half for overtime no matter how many extra hours you work — even though your salary works out to $11.50 an hour.

The couple for whom she was carrying the baby asked her to have an abortion, offering to pay her $10,000 to do so.

headline: A Surrogate and a Mother: Partners in Pregnancy Share Their Story

I was a young mother, and back when I had my first, people talked to me about “options.” Adoption wasn’t really my thing, but I knew that there were people who had trouble having babies and I knew that someday I wanted to help.

A Catholic vicar-general offered a homily. A Muslim imam unfurled a small rug and knelt in prayer, his singsong voice rising above the stone mausoleums toward the blue of the Mediterranean.

headline: Independence Referendum Is a Win for Scotland’s Children
abstract: With voter turnout expected to be around 80 percent and polls predicting a thin margin, a glaring message of the referendum has been that every vote counts. For children, that lesson is a victory in itself.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — The people of Scotland will make a momentous decision on Thursday about the fate of a 307-year-old union. They will vote “yes” or they will vote “no” on the question of whether Scotland should become a country independent from Britain. There has been much rhetoric on both sides of the divide about the potential ill effects of separation (or not) on Scottish children. Everyone agrees that nothing less than the well-being of future generations is at stake. And yet it is worth noting, amid the crossfire, that one effect of the referendum on our children is overwhelmingly positive: They are experiencing participatory democracy at its height.

Bloomberg and Susan Brown — compete against a backdrop of the New York City skyline in this four-day event, held for the first time at Trump Wollman Rink in Central Park. headline: News Corp. and Google in a War of Words
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Search Engines']
abstract: The publishing giant accused the search giant of being a “vast, powerful, often unaccountable bureaucracy,” and Google fired back with a tabloid reference to a hamster sandwich.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Is Google a pirate? Does Rupert Murdoch really love hamsters?

headline: Where States Stand on Surrogacy
abstract: States with surrogacy laws.
lead_paragraph: States with surrogacy laws.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets Keep an Eye Out
abstract: Today’s agenda on Wall Street almost seems like it was conceived by Alfred Hitchcock. | Banks hoping to avoid criminal charges should rat out their employees, a Justice Department official said. | Some brokers countersue investors who have sued them.
lead_paragraph: MARKETS KEEP AN EYE OUT | Today’s agenda on Wall Street almost seems like it was conceived by Alfred Hitchcock. With residents of Scotland going to the polls to vote for independence, with Alibaba expected to price its huge initial public offering and with investors still puzzling over the latest pronouncement from the Federal Reserve, markets today could be in for plot twists.

headline: Work, Love and Therapy, in So Many Bytes
abstract: Christoph Waltz plays a hapless laborer in Terry Gilliam’s latest fanciful foray into a dystopian future, which revisits some of the themes in the director’s “Brazil.”
lead_paragraph: The opening images of “The Zero Theorem” could hardly be more arresting: a man, naked and hairless, sits in front of an oversize computer screen in surroundings that are at once archaic and futuristic. The technology is advanced, while the décor hovers somewhere between late Victorian and mid-20th-century modern. The man’s name, which people often forget or get wrong, is Qohen Leth. He lives in an abandoned church and commutes on foot through chaotic city streets to a soul-crushing job doing something with data for a corporation owned by an elusive Big Brother-like figure known only as Management.

headline: Looking Back to 1821, Insurers Foresee a $100-Billion Hurricane
abstract: If the great 1821 hurricane struck the East Coast today, it would leave a $100-billion trail of losses.
lead_paragraph: It may be extremely quiet here at what’s typically the peak of the Atlantic hurricane season, but that’s no reason to relax. All it takes is one great storm.

keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The Internet Party, founded by Kim Dotcom, the entrepreneur behind the Megaupload file-sharing site, has a chance of winning a place in New Zealand’s Parliament.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — It was not an ordinary political rally, but it has been anything but an ordinary election.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: An Unlikely Alliance at the Barricades
abstract: To recount the story of how gay activists joined forces with British miners in 1984-85, the creators of “Pride” tracked down participants and extracted their stories, warts and all.
lead_paragraph: As the van passed through the coal fields of Wales and approached the union hall in an unfamiliar town, Jonathan Blake felt a knot tightening in his stomach.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Max Mara Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: A Poet’s Advice to “Go Ahead & Like It”
abstract: Jacqueline Suskin, known for cranking out poems on the spot at farmers’ markets and events in and around Los Angeles, releases a book to inspire the inner poet in each of us.
lead_paragraph: In our digital era of numbly clicking “like” as we impassively watch our friends’ lives scroll by on Facebook and Instagram, along comes an analog antidote: “Go Ahead & Like It,” a new art book/self-help guide by the Los Angeles poet Jacqueline Suskin. The 29-year-old is well known around town for Poem Store, a self-described “performance poetry piece” she sets up at farmers’ markets, events and weddings. To create each poem, she asks for a subject and then briskly pecks out evocative lines on a vintage Hermès typewriter in exchange for whatever amount the recipient deems it to be worth.

headline: Amy Adams, MaxMara’s Newest Hollywood Connection
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Ms. Adams is front row in Milan, helping put a face to the brand.
lead_paragraph: How do certain celebrities wind up in the front row at fashion shows? Trying to make sense of front-row celebrity seat assignments is a recurring question as the third round of spring 2015 shows races along in Milan.

headline: Visa to Evaluate Stake in Monitise, a British Mobile Payment Processor
abstract: Shares of Monitise, a British mobile payment developer and processor, lost more than a quarter of their value on Thursday after Visa said it was evaluating what to do with its stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Shares of Monitise, a British mobile payment developer and processor, lost more than a quarter of their value on Thursday after Visa said it was “considering its options” regarding its stake in the company.

headline: A Straw Purchaser Gets 8 Years in Prison
abstract: Dawn Nguyen is going to jail for a long time. How many straw purchases will be made while she is behind bars?
lead_paragraph: Dawn Nguyen, 25, was sentenced on Wednesday to eight years in federal prison for being the straw purchaser of guns that were later used to kill two upstate New York firefighters.

headline: John Lahr: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh” is not a fan of science fiction. “Life on earth is mysterious and terrifying enough.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Tennessee Williams: Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh” is not a fan of science fiction. “Life on earth is mysterious and terrifying enough.”

headline: I’d Walk 1,700 Miles With a Camel
abstract: “Tracks” is based on Robyn Davidson’s memoir about her 1,700-mile walk across the Australian desert in 1977, accompanied only by four camels, a dog and the occasional National Geographic photographer.
lead_paragraph: “Tracks,” a high-mileage, low-energy story about an Australian woman, her trusty dog, four charming camels and the siren call of adventure, comes coated in a layer of sand. At times, the sand rolls on and on like an endlessly unfurling, magically variegated carpet that shifts from blood red to burnt sienna, pale pink and dung brown. At other times, it violently rises off the desert floor, swirling and churning into dusty whirlpools. The adventurer, Robyn Davidson (Mia Wasikowska), may blink — at the sandy dust and one deranged hallucination — but she keeps going, at times with nothing other than some cloth between her and a seemingly asphyxiating end.

headline: Living City | A Tale of Two Bridges
abstract: With thousands of bridges in New York State deemed structurally deficient, there are two choices: repair or rebuild. The 60-year-old Tappan Zee Bridge and the Brooklyn Bridge are the latest examples.
lead_paragraph: With thousands of bridges in New York State deemed structurally deficient, there are two choices: repair or rebuild. The 60-year-old Tappan Zee Bridge and the Brooklyn Bridge are the latest examples.

headline: With Eye on 2016, Christie Resists Climate Change Plan
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie is adamant that New Jersey not participate in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, though most legislators say it would be good for the state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey explores a 2016 presidential campaign, he is under growing pressure from his State Legislature to rejoin a regional cap-and-trade program that would limit New Jersey’s carbon emissions — and likely hurt his chances for the Republican nomination.

headline: Skeleton of Tappan Zee Bridge’s Successor Begins to Surface in the Hudson
abstract: Less than a year after construction began, the new bridge is making progress toward the opening of its first span, in 2016. Includes a video: two ways to deal with an old bridge.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — The shape of the new Tappan Zee Bridge is emerging from the green-gray waters of the Hudson River.

headline: Scotland, Self-Interest and Self-Government
abstract: Referendum-day thoughts on the case for Scottish independence.
lead_paragraph: From the perspective of America’s national interest, the prospect of an independent Scotland — which could, though probably won’t, become a reality after today’s referendum vote — has relatively little to recommend it. Scottish secession would hardly be disastrous for the U.S., but it would come with all sorts of modest downsides: It would weaken our most reliable ally for the long term and create an immediate (if likely manageable) crisis at a time when the world is quite sufficiently unstable already; it would lead to various military and strategic headaches (again: none insurmountable, but not ideal right now); and it would sow further instability in secession-prone regions across Europe where political differences might not be settled quite so civilly (including one within the British Isles themselves).

headline: Li Na, Two-Time Major Winner, Is Retiring With Knee Woes
abstract: The reigning Australian Open winner Li Na, who became the first Grand Slam titlist from Asia by winning the 2011 French Open, announced her retirement in a letter posted on social media.
lead_paragraph: The former French Open and Australian Open champion Li Na, the first Asian player to win a Grand Slam singles title, announced Friday morning in Beijing that she was retiring because of worsening of knee injuries that had plagued her throughout her career.

headline: Throwback Thursday | Happy Birthday, New York Times
abstract: It cost one cent, was only four pages long, and was then called The New York Daily Times, but on Sept. 18, 1851, The New York Times published its first issue.
lead_paragraph: It cost one cent, was only four pages long, and was then called The New York Daily Times, but on Sept. 18, 1851, The New York Times published its first issue.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Leila Nda before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Sam McKnight.

headline: Seeking Refuge in Italy
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Waves of refugees risking their lives to make passage to Europe have stirred global sympathy.
lead_paragraph: Waves of refugees risking their lives to make passage to Europe have stirred global sympathy.

headline: A 260-Year-Old Shrine Unlocks Its Doors to Women
abstract: The policy will take effect immediately, and the Scottish club said some women would be put on a fast track for membership to avoid languishing on the long waiting list.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — A coastal fog hung over the Old Course for much of the day Thursday, forcing golfers to strain to follow their shots. But clarity of a historic nature emerged just a few yards from the first tee, where the Royal and Ancient Golf Club voted overwhelmingly to admit its first female members.

headline: Teenager Who Disappeared From Brooklyn School Is Found
abstract: Nashaly Perez Rodriguez, a 15-year-old with severe emotional problems, was found at a friend’s home in East New York, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl with severe emotional problems who walked out of her Brooklyn school this week and was missing for two days was found safe at a friend’s home on Thursday, officials said.

headline: Scotland’s Independence Vote Shows a Global Crisis of the Elites
abstract: A push for independence is driven by a discontent with the ruling class that applies to varying degrees in the United States and, especially, the eurozone.
lead_paragraph: When you get past the details of the Scottish independence referendum Thursday, there is a broader story underway, one that is also playing out in other advanced nations.

headline: New Islamic State Video Features British Hostage as Group Spokesman
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'Propaganda']
abstract: The Islamic State released a new message with a British hostage, the journalist John Cantlie, warning the West against another war.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The Islamic State released the latest in a series of propaganda videos on Thursday, a slickly produced introduction to what it promised would be a multipart series on the group and the folly of efforts by the United States to fight it.

headline: A Decision Clinched by a Yard
abstract: Dr. Anthony Watkins and Dr. Khadijah Booth Watkins went looking for an apartment for their family. The search always returned to Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, when Dr. Anthony C. Watkins and Dr. Khadijah Booth Watkins moved into hospital staff housing, a two-bedroom rental was fine for them and their young son. A few years after their second son arrived, the family moved within the building to a three-bedroom.

headline: Twilio to Send Multimedia to Phones
abstract: Twilio, a company that offers cheap voice and short messaging services to mobile phones via Amazon Web Services, said it could now handle images and video. That means things like picture identification and real estate peeks can get to your phone for pennies.
lead_paragraph: The cloud just covered a little more of the old tech business.

headline: 1889: Beer Crisis in Bavaria
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Planned tax rises threatened a beer crisis in Bavaria in 1889.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Great discontent has been created in Bavaria by the announcement that the Finance Minister proposes to introduce a bill in the Bavarian Diet for increasing the tax on malt, which would mean a rise in the price of Bavarian beer. It is well to remember that what amounted to a revolution was once started in Bavaria through beer becoming dearer. The Beer Riots of 1848 were the forerunners of disturbances that led to the abdication of Louis I. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 19, 1889.

headline: A Paris Vacation, Cooking Class Included
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Le Pavillon des Lettres hotel in Paris is offering a package in which guests take a cooking class with a member of the culinary team from the restaurant Grand Véfour.
lead_paragraph: For many travelers heading to Paris, a fine-dining meal at one of the many notable restaurants is a must, but the Le Pavillon des Lettres hotel has a new package for its guests that goes beyond the standard dinner out.

headline: When Pizza Is Political
abstract: Two writers have identified a new development in the rhetoric of gender and snacking, and pizza is right at its cheesy center.
lead_paragraph: Pizza has long been many things to many people — it’s a badge of hometown pride; it’s a test of appropriate manners; it’s the next Yo. So it should perhaps come as no surprise that when two writers identified a new development in the rhetoric of gender and snacking, pizza was right at its cheesy center.

headline: Poland Says Russian Veto Should Be Limited at U.N.
abstract: President Bronislaw Komorowski said he would ask the United Nations to change the rules so that Moscow cannot veto Security Council actions in the region.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Frustrated by the United Nations’ passive response to Russian aggression in Ukraine, President Bronislaw Komorowski of Poland has said he intends to call on the organization to change its rules to prevent Moscow from vetoing Security Council actions on the region.

headline: Man Is Arrested as Northern California Wildfire Rages, Threatening Thousands of Homes
abstract: The wildfire in Placerville, east of Sacramento, burned through 71,000 acres and threatened over 2,000 homes, and was only 5 percent contained.
lead_paragraph: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — If California needed a reminder that it was suffering the worst drought — and the hottest year — in recent history, it came in a flash on Thursday, after one of the 200 fires smoldering across this state this week exploded overnight, tripling in size to 71,000 acres and forcing the evacuation of 2,000 people, many of whom had been enjoying a September vacation in the El Dorado National Forest near here.

lead_paragraph: Milan

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

abstract: Aron B. Wieder, who had hoped to become New York State’s first Hasidic Jewish assemblyman, conceded to Elisa A. Tutini, an employee of the Town of Monroe.
lead_paragraph: A Rockland County legislator who hoped to become the state’s first Hasidic Jewish assemblyman has been defeated in a closely contested primary for the Democratic nomination for an open Assembly seat.

headline: What ‘ASAP’ Really Means
abstract: Consider an I-need-it-now request as the start of a negotiation, the Workologist suggests.
lead_paragraph: Does anyone take “as soon as possible” seriously anymore? Sometimes I work late or rearrange priorities to complete an ASAP request — only to learn later that the project sat on someone else’s desk, ignored, for days or weeks afterward.

headline: Investors Reward Bayer for Adopting a Sharper Focus on Health Care
abstract: Investors seem to prize focus over diversity as Bayer’s stock price was rewarded after the company announced a separation of its plastics and polymers business, Quentin Webb writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Bayer’s float of its plastics business could sow the seeds for another sale. Investors added more than $5 billion to the $114 billion market capitalization of the German blue-chip company on Thursday, after it unveiled plans to float MaterialScience, its capital-intensive plastics and polymers business.

headline: Prada’s Spring 2015 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week. [See the live stream.]

headline: Wrought in Rhimes’s Image
abstract: With shows like “How to Get Away With Murder” and “Scandal,” Shonda Rhimes is redefining the image of African-American women on TV.
lead_paragraph: When Shonda Rhimes writes her autobiography, it should be called “How to Get Away With Being an Angry Black Woman.”

headline: Why Take a Stance on God?
abstract: Neither atheists nor believers know whether God exists, but there’s still a reason for them to defend their beliefs.
lead_paragraph: This is the 10th in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Keith DeRose, a professor of philosophy at Yale University and the author of “The Case for Contextualism: Knowledge, Skepticism, and Context.”

headline: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 3
abstract: For Week 3, fantasy football players may want to watch out for the Broncos’ Emmanuel Sanders, who should draw most of cornerback Richard Sherman’s attention in this Super Bowl rematch.
lead_paragraph: For Week 3, fantasy football players may want to watch out for the Broncos’ Emmanuel Sanders, who should draw most of cornerback Richard Sherman’s attention in this Super Bowl rematch.

headline: Living With Cancer: Making Room
abstract: Cancer treatment and its aftereffects can prompt a cleaning binge and emptying of shelves. But for what, exactly, are we making room?
lead_paragraph: When I started clearing my closet a few weeks after the 18th chemo infusion, I struggled against bitterness about my changed body. After all, someone else could wear the clothes that no longer fit me. Then why not bundle them up, along with jackets, shirts, pants and shoes unworn because they were a professional uniform no longer needed?

headline: Crowdfunding Site SeedInvest Strikes Deal to Widen Its Reach
abstract: SeedInvest is teaming up with Gust, a 10-year-old network that includes thousands of angel investors, to offer start-up financing deals to a broad base of investors.
lead_paragraph: Helping start-ups raise cash is a hot area for entrepreneurs, ever since the government relaxed rules on asking for capital.

headline: Migrants, Funerals and Loss: Reporting on a Humanitarian Crisis in the Mediterranean
abstract: Jim Yardley, the Rome bureau chief, explains how he reported his front page story about the humanitarian crisis involving 120,000 migrants who’ve sought refuge in Italy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 120,000 migrants have flooded Italy’s border this year. The migration has created a large-scale humanitarian crisis for Italy and for the migrants, nearly 2,800 of whom have died. Jim Yardley wrote a front-page article for Thursday from Pozzallo, Sicily, and explains how he got his story.

headline: Lost in Their Own Lives
abstract: Men and women are forced to make detours into unfamiliar territory in Donald Antrim’s first story collection.
lead_paragraph: The most underrated quality in fiction nowadays is intelligence; the most overrated, imagination. Donald Antrim possesses both — but his intelligence is what makes you sit up straighter when you begin his new collection, “The Emerald Light in the Air.” Very quickly you realize you are reading something different from the mass of competent, earnest and depressingly dull short stories that are as commonplace now as ever (only the styles change).

headline: Deceiving Voters With Ballot Language
abstract: The proposed redistricting commission is not “independent.”
lead_paragraph: In New York, state elections officials write the ballot language for constitutional amendments.  It should not be a difficult job. Their task is to make the proposals clear and straightforward—no slanting, no tricks.  It doesn’t always work that way in Albany.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: India Takes Tough Stance With China on Kashmir
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India made clear to the Chinese president that India’s patience with an uncertain border situation has worn thin.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Smiles rarely left the faces of the top leaders of India and China here on Thursday, but India’s new prime minister sent a tough message to his Chinese guest by pressing him for a resolution to a border dispute that has escalated abruptly.

headline: A Comparison of City Traffic, Traveling in Time
abstract: When he was 70 minutes late for a campaign stop in 1964, Robert F. Kennedy found a new issue. Which cities have the worst traffic today?
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “City Traffic Gives Kennedy an Issue” appeared on Sept. 15 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Health Care Act Still Covers 7.3 Million
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration said 7.3 million of those who enrolled had paid their premiums and still had coverage, the vast majority paying less than $100 a month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Thursday that 7.3 million people who bought private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act had paid their premiums and were still enrolled.

headline: Ukraine Leader’s Plea Nets Less Than He Wanted
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine addressed a joint session of Congress and sought advanced weaponry to fend off what he called an ongoing invasion by Russian forces, but so far, the United States has promised only nonlethal assistance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine on Thursday implored Congress to provide Ukraine’s soldiers with heavy military equipment as his country seeks to repel what he called a continuing invasion by Russian forces.

abstract: A new video released by the Islamic State featured John Cantlie, a British journalist being held captive, acting as a spokesman of sorts for the organization.
lead_paragraph: A new video released by the Islamic State featured John Cantlie, a British journalist being held captive, acting as a spokesman of sorts for the organization.

lead_paragraph: For spring 2015, styles by Alberta Ferretti, Stella Jean, Frida Giannini, Alessandro Dell’Acqua and more.

headline: ISIS Vote Weighs Heavily on Senators With 2016 Ambitions
abstract: The Senate vote Thursday on arming Syrian rebels will be a display of how hard-learned lessons from past presidential campaigns are at work.
lead_paragraph: The Senate vote set for late Thursday afternoon on whether to allow the American military to arm and train Syrian rebels will be a display of how hard-learned lessons from the past and uncertainties about the future — both practical and political — are at work, especially for those with an eye on a promotion.

headline: Today in Small Business: The World’s Most Mysterious Nutella Emporium
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell tells entrepreneurs, “Be disagreeable.” Yelp settles a lawsuit. And what will happen to whiskey prices?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Behind the ‘Scenes From a Marriage’
abstract: For Ivo van Hove’s production, the New York Theater Workshop’s East Village home has been emptied to create an entirely new playing space — or spaces.
lead_paragraph: Ivo van Hove is a director who loves classic plays. It’s just hard to tell sometimes. He doused Hedda Gabler in V8 juice. He parked a fully clothed Blanche DuBois in a bathtub. He staged a food fight in “The Misanthrope.” A dramaturgical provocateur, he’s not keen on keeping the story straight.

headline: Judge Accused of Assaulting Wife Is Urged to Resign
abstract: In a sign that the outrage about domestic violence in the National Football League has expanded, a federal judge in Alabama faced abrupt and potent pressure to resign after he was charged with striking his wife last month at a luxury hotel in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The message from a furious public to the National Football League over the past few weeks has been clear: Charges of domestic violence should have serious consequences.

headline: It Takes a Village of Photographers in Brooklyn
abstract: This tear’s version of Photoville celebrates everything from prize-winning conflict photographers, Pulitzer winners and the borough of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This tear’s version of Photoville celebrates everything from prize-winning conflict photographers, Pulitzer winners and the borough of Brooklyn.

headline: Fendi, Alberta Ferretti, Max Mara: A Different Declaration of Independence
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: At Fendi, the clothes conveyed confidence and a point of view that belonged to the present.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Whether or not the pundits are right and the Scottish situation goes viral across Europe and beyond, with other nationalist groups announcing their intentions to leave whatever union they happen to be in (the Catalans, Spain; the Veneto, Italy; the Québécois, Canada; the Texans, the United States — it could happen), one thing is certain: Fashion has seen independence as a potential trend.

headline: Clip: ‘Tracks’
abstract: A scene from the film, featuring Mia Wasikowska and Adam Driver.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, featuring Mia Wasikowska and Adam Driver.

headline: A Group Exhibition Traces the Evolution of Fiber Art
abstract: “Thread Lines” at the Drawing Center includes textile-art titans like Louise Bourgeois and Sheila Hicks, and emerging talents.
lead_paragraph: If the Drawing Center seems a strange place for a sweeping show about textile art, consider the concept of the line. The distance between two points is, as the artist Sheila Hicks says, from her Paris studio, “the mother thinker of all form-making, whether it be two- or three-dimensional. It is the direct conductor from brain to materialization.” Rendered in fiber, that line is just pulled a little tighter, and the tension is on full display in “Thread Lines,” opening Sept. 19.

headline: 1964: Dr. King Gets Papal Pledge
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1964, Martin Luther King Jr. obtained endorsement from the Vatican for his struggle.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. said today [Sept. 18] that Pope Paul VI promised him he would publicly denounce racial segregation. ‘‘Pope Paul was very open and forthright in his statements on the situation,’’ the U.S. Negro leader told reporters after a 25- minute talk with the pope. ‘‘He said he was a friend of the Negro people and that he was following our struggle in the United States. The pope told me that he would make a personal and public declaration against racial segregation. However, he said he could not accept violence and I made it clear that we did not support violence either,’’ he said. Dr. King said before meeting the Pope that he felt a statement reaffirming Roman Catholic opposition to racial segregation would be ‘‘a profound help for us.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 19, 1964

headline: Trial of Uighur Scholar Ends in China
abstract: The court did not announce a verdict in the case of the scholar, Ilham Tohti, who was tried on charges of separatism.
lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China — The trial of a prominent ethnic Uighur economics professor, Ilham Tohti, on charges of separatism ended on Thursday evening with no verdict or sentencing, which will be announced later, a lawyer for Mr. Tohti said.

headline: It Takes a Village of Photographers in Brooklyn
abstract: This year’s version of Photoville celebrates everything from prizewinning conflict photographers to Pulitzer winners and the borough of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This time of year the Brooklyn waterfront has plenty of contenders: from Pulitzer Prize-winning photojournalists to up-and-coming photographers (and even a selection of Instagram images from around the world). Welcome to Photoville, the annual pop-up village and open-air mega-exhibit that’s showcased in cargo containers transformed into galleries.

headline: Clip: ‘This Is Where I Leave You’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Shawn Levy.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Shawn Levy.

headline: Raising Teenagers: Protect When You Must, Permit When You Can
abstract: There’s not much we can do to rush neurological maturation along in our teens, but we can help kids practice their burgeoning skills of self-control as they emerge.
lead_paragraph: I don’t think this comes as news to anyone here, but it can be a real challenge to parent and to educate adolescents. My own specimens (boys, 11 and 15) spend their days vacillating between energetic and catatonic, optimistic and morose, ebullient and apathetic. Some days, I doubt that they will be able to forge a safe and successful path into adulthood without my constant help and intervention.

headline: Carla Körbes, at 33, Announces Retirement From Ballet
abstract: Carla Körbes, a principal dancer at Pacific Northwest Ballet and formerly with New York City Ballet, will retire at the end of the 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: When a ballerina of a certain age and stature — Alessandra Ferri, Kyra Nichols and, most recently, Wendy Whelan — announces her retirement, it’s heartbreaking, but makes sense. When a dancer, just 33, decides to do the same, it’s shattering, especially when that ballerina is Carla Körbes.

headline: Ebola Deaths Doubled in a Month, Health Group Says
abstract: In Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, a total of 5,335 people have been infected and 2,622 have died, while the tally a month ago was 2,458 infections and 1,346 deaths.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The number of people in West Africa who have contracted the Ebola virus and died from the hemorrhagic fever that it causes has doubled in the past month, the World Health Organization reported on Thursday.

headline: To Mark I.P.O., Alibaba to Make Gift to Its New Market Home
abstract: Alibaba is expected to give an intricate Tao doll, patterned after the mascot for its Taobao marketplace, to the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, as a sign of respect.
lead_paragraph: With the Alibaba Group poised to hold one of the biggest initial public offerings on record, the Chinese Internet giant plans to mark the momentous occasion in its own way.

headline: Covering the House’s Vote on the Islamic State
abstract: Jonathan Weisman, a congressional reporter in Washington, discusses his front-page article on the House’s vote to authorize aid for the rebels in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Weisman, a congressional reporter in Washington, wrote today’s front-page article on the House’s vote to authorize aid for the rebels in Syria. Mr. Weisman shares how he separated the facts from the spin to cover both sides of the debate.

headline: Women’s Project Theater to Present New Laura Eason Play
abstract: The project’s new season is its first since a contentious executive change in July.
lead_paragraph: The world premiere of a new play by Laura Eason (“Sex With Strangers”) is a highlight of the 2014-15 season of the Women’s Project Theater. The season is the organization’s first since Lisa McNulty became its producing artistic director in July.

headline: Science’s Sexual Assault Problem
abstract: Female scientists conducting field research are under threat — and often from their own team.
lead_paragraph: AS, Norway

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 3 Player Tiers
abstract: The Tier 1 running back group has seen a radical change since Week 1. Only LeSean McCoy has lived up to his top draft pick.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Readers Respond: ‘The Great Unraveling’
abstract: In comments, readers parsed — in high-minded appeals, sharp rebukes and snark — Roger Cohen’s column about the devolution of international order.
lead_paragraph: They were the best of comments. They were the worst of comments.

headline: Scottish Voters Cast Referendum Ballots
abstract: Alex Salmond, the leader of the Scottish National Party, and voters, sounded off after casting their ballots.
lead_paragraph: Alex Salmond, the leader of the Scottish National Party, and voters, sounded off after casting their ballots.

headline: Military Looks March Through the Spring/Summer 2015 Runways
abstract: After Marc Jacobs’s uniform-inspired collection closed out New York Fashion Week, the theme has crossed the Atlantic to Milan.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs always manages to have his finger on the pulse. After his uniform-inspired spring/summer 2015 collection closed out New York Fashion Week, military details — utilitarian pockets, camouflage and desert khakis — have crossed the Atlantic to Milan. No. 21’s and Gucci’s shows, with their ’70s and grunge themes, respectively, had green, surplus-inspired dresses peppered into the mix.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘3 Christs’
abstract: The artist Ward Sutton on the elements that inspired his design for a play about three men who think they are Jesus Christ.
lead_paragraph: Three paranoid schizophrenics, each of whom thinks he is Jesus Christ, come together in the play “3 Christs,” now being staged at Judson Memorial Church by the Peculiar Works Project. The show recreates a University of Michigan experiment by Dr. Milton Rokeach, who had the men live and work together to see what would happen. Rokeach’s published study, “The Three Christs of Ypsilanti,” is the basis for the stage adaptation by S. M. Dale and Barry Rowell.

headline: Fingers Stand In for Forks
abstract: At Abyssinia in Harlem, the flatbread does the heavy lifting with the Ethiopian dishes.
lead_paragraph: The description “ground mildly spiced chickpeas” does not prepare you for what arrives, which looks less like a self-sufficient dish than a sauce or a displaced soup, as red as the desert. It’s not that mild, either, thanks to a nice shock of berbere, an Ethiopian spice blend dominated by red chile, with gentler warming notes from cinnamon, cardamom and cloves.

headline: Poroshenko Makes Appeal to U.S. Congress
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine has appealed to the United States Congress for support of his strategy in handling Russian-backed separatists.
lead_paragraph: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine has appealed to the United States Congress for support of his strategy in handling Russian-backed separatists.

headline: Iran and the ‘Coalition of Repenters’
abstract: Mohammad Javad Zarif suggested that the U.S. was making common cause with the countries who helped the Islamic State grow into a global threat.
lead_paragraph: No one has presented a more articulate case for Iran to Western audiences than the foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif. He and President Hassan Rouhani proved that last year when they attended their first United Nations General Assembly after Mr. Rouhani’s election.

headline: U.S. Aims to Curb Peril of Antibiotic Resistance
abstract: The Obama administration’s measures are part of the first major federal effort to confront a public health problem that takes at least 23,000 lives a year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced measures to tackle the growing threat of antibiotic resistance, outlining a national strategy that includes incentives for the development of new drugs, tighter stewardship of existing ones, and improvements in tracking the use of antibiotics and the microbes that are resistant to them.

headline: To Get More Out of Science, Show the Rejected Research
abstract: A proposal aims to address the problem of studies that go unpublished even though their findings can be important.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, the federal government spent over $30 billion to support basic scientific research. These funds help create knowledge and stimulate greater productivity and commercial activity, but could we get an even better return on our investment?

headline: Finding Their Gym on the City’s Streets
abstract: A workout group known as the Rise blends an enthusiasm for rigorous fitness with an ethos of camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: AS dawn began its daily blanching of the bright lights in Times Square one morning, a cluster of early birds cheerfully dragged one another in wheelbarrow formations, pair by pair, up the steps of the TKTS booth. Yawning workers in suits hustled past, while police officers looked on ambivalently. A couple of tourists raised their cellphones to capture the spectacle for posterity, or at least for Instagram.

headline: Upgrading to iOS 8 on an Old Phone? Prepare for Trouble, but Do It Anyway
abstract: Apple’s new operating system, iOS 8, is going to struggle to run on your old phone or tablet. But it offers enough security features to merit switching anyway.
lead_paragraph: Do you have an old iPhone or iPad? Have you been planning on upgrading to iOS 8, Apple’s newest operating system, which was made available this week? Are you excited about the switch, fancying a free way to have a better-looking interface with new features?

headline: Fantex Signs Chicago Bears’ Alshon Jeffery for an I.P.O.
abstract: Alshon Jeffery, a 24-year-old wide receiver, plans to offer a 13 percent stake in his future income from playing contracts, endorsements and other activities related to football.
lead_paragraph: Alshon Jeffery, a 24-year-old wide receiver for the Chicago Bears, had an inauspicious start to his football season this month when he injured his hamstring in a loss to the Buffalo Bills.

headline: A Show of Stevie Nicks Portraits by Stevie Nicks
abstract: A selection of self-portraits taken by Ms. Nicks from 1975 to 1987 will go on display at the Morrison Hotel Gallery in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Morrison Hotel Gallery, which specializes in music photography – not only photographs of musicians, but also photography by musicians – will present a show of self-portraits by Stevie Nicks from between 1975 and 1987. The pictures for the show were selected by Dave Stewart, the Eurythmics guitarist, who co-produced her “In Your Dreams” album.

headline: In France, Artifacts of America’s Role in World War I
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Series', 'Cemeteries', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The country is full of American war monuments, from the grand to the intimate.
lead_paragraph: At 3 a.m. on Nov. 3, 1917, as the men of Company F, 16th Infantry Regiment, First Division were mostly sleeping in trenches and dugouts near the French village of Bathelémont, the Germans attacked with artillery and shock troops.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Giver’ and ‘The Dark Side of Young Adult Fiction’
abstract: Some ideas for connecting “The Giver” to a larger discussion about the popularity of dystopian literature, as well as options for going further to explore other aspects of the book with the help of Times and Learning Network resources.
lead_paragraph: ” ‘The Giver,’ a powerful and provocative novel, is sure to keep older children reading. And thinking.”

headline: Prada’s Platform Patchwork Boots
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: ’70s-style pieced-leather stompers.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Leader Vows French Role in Airstrikes on ISIS in Iraq
abstract: President François Hollande indicated that France’s role in fighting the Islamic State would be limited to air support in Iraq, with no French airstrikes in Syria.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande said Thursday that France was willing to join the United States-led campaign against the Islamic State, including airstrikes against militants in Iraq, saying the world was confronting unremitting brutality.

headline: Confession to Etan Patz’s Killing Came Hours Into Interview, Detective Testifies
abstract: Pedro Hernandez at first denied having anything to do with the boy’s 1979 disappearance and killing, the detective said at a court hearing.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of murdering Etan Patz in 1979 at first denied having anything to do with the boy’s disappearance during an eight-hour interview in 2012 with the police. He averted his eyes when detectives first showed him a poster with a photograph of Etan, a 6-year-old blond-haired boy. He said he had never seen him.

headline: Hagel on the Fight Against ISIS
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told lawmakers that the fight against the Islamic State would not be brief or easy.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told lawmakers that the fight against the Islamic State would not be brief or easy.

headline: Prada: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: New York City’s Unemployment Rate Drops to Lowest Level Since 2009
abstract: The rate, at 7.3 percent, fell faster in August than in any month on record, the State Labor Department said.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate fell faster in August than in any month on record, to 7.3 percent from 7.8 percent in July, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Flower Power Ponytails at Fendi
abstract: On the designer’s spring 2015 runway, both hairdos and eyelids were topped with colorful leather.
lead_paragraph: At Fendi’s spring 2015 show today, ponytails were topped with colorful leather pieces almost as long as the models’ hair. The pretty flowers even inspired the makeup look; but instead of trying to recreate the exact shade of blue found in the leather flowers, makeup artists snipped off some of the leather from the headpieces and glued the strips above the lash line. Talk about a double-duty hair accessory.

headline: A Pakistani Scholar Accused of Blasphemy Is Shot Dead
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: Muhammad Shakil Auj, the dean of Islamic studies at the state-run University of Karachi, was vilified for a speech he gave in the United States in 2012.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — A liberal Muslim scholar who had been accused of blasphemy for a speech he gave during a visit to the United States was shot and killed in Karachi on Thursday, the city police said.

headline: Stand-Up Man
abstract: A biography of Bill Cosby chronicles the outspoken comedian’s rise to stardom, along with personal and professional setbacks.
lead_paragraph: There are at least two vexing revelations within the pages of Mark Whita­ker’s wonderfully thorough biography of America’s most accomplished comedian. The first is how remarkably unfunny Bill Cosby’s countless riffs and bits come across on paper. (“It’s the Lord, Noah!” “Right!” Sure.) The second is the number of failed or short-lived television series — other than the one that forever altered television — that bear the name Cosby. Both are keys to the man’s complicated ­ascendance.

headline: Donating the Body
abstract: He wanted his body given to a medical school or research organization. It wasn’t that simple.
lead_paragraph: All his adult life, Paul Ward heard his parents say they wanted their bodies given to a medical school after their deaths. “They felt that training a new doctor would be a gift to society,” he said.

headline: Pabst Is Sold to Russian Beverage Company
abstract: The brewer of Pabst Blue Ribbon, as well as Colt 45 and Old Milwaukee, is being sold for more than $700 million in cash, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: A Russian beverage company said on Thursday that it was acquiring the Pabst Brewing Company, which makes the Pabst Blue Ribbon beer popular with barflies and hipsters alike and other brands like Colt 45 and Old Milwaukee.

headline: Clip: ‘A Walk Among the Tombstones’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: James Morris and Michael Volle to Join Met’s ‘Meistersinger’
abstract: The two singers will fill in for Johan Reuter as Hans Sachs in “Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg.”
lead_paragraph: They are once and future Wotans: James Morris, who positively owned the role at the Metropolitan Opera for 16 complete “Ring” cycles, and Michael Volle, who will pick up Wotan’s spear when the “Ring” returns to the Met in the 2018-19 season.

headline: Clinton Shifts to Domestic Issues, With a Focus on Women
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democrats have said the ability to mobilize women, particularly those struggling with minimum wage jobs, could determine whether the party holds the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton has spent the past several months discussing her foreign policy record as secretary of state, but on Thursday she officially dived back in to kitchen table issues during a panel discussion about equal pay for women, affordable child care and paid sick leave.

headline: Allergan-Valeant Fight Holds Lessons for All Corporate Shareholders
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Corporations', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Despite the end of a lawsuit involving Allergan, bylaws intended to inhibit shareholder actions are all the rage in corporate America, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in a Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: “This is quite a horse-choker of a bylaw. And tell me what the defense to that is,” Chancellor Andre G. Bouchard of the Delaware Chancery Court skeptically said to Allergan’s lawyer last week.

headline: Security Council Unanimously Passes Ebola Resolution
abstract: The resolution declared the outbreak of the Ebola virus in West Africa a threat to international peace and security.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council, in a highly unusual move, on Thursday declared the Ebola crisis in West Africa to be a threat to international peace and security, unanimously passing a resolution that calls on countries worldwide to urgently send medical personnel and supplies to contain the outbreak.

headline: At the Met, Honoring Kimonos and a Scholar of the Same
abstract: The work of the textiles historian Terry Satsuki Milhaupt anchors “Kimono: A Modern History,” an exhibition coming to the Met.
lead_paragraph: The textiles historian Terry Satsuki Milhaupt had nearly finished her comprehensive book on kimonos when she committed suicide in 2012. Her widower, Curtis J. Milhaupt, heroically completed her work, “Kimono: A Modern History” (Reaktion Books/University of Chicago Press), and a show of the same title, based on her scholarship, opens on Sept. 27 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and runs through Jan. 24.

headline: Forget About Scotland. Crucial Metallica Vote Is Under Way.
abstract: Metallica is asking fans to vote on which concert recordings should be released as special LPs.
lead_paragraph: Can’t get enough of Metallica? If that’s the case, you probably already know that the band, like many others – the Allman Brothers, Widespread Panic and Pearl Jam, among them – has been making soundboard recordings of nearly all its concerts, available for download at livemetallica.com for the last decade. The concerts are available in a variety of audio formats, mostly priced between $9.95 (for mp3s) and $17.95 (for HD FLAC), with more than two dozen concerts, including a San Francisco show from this year, available free.

headline: Man Down
abstract: Jeff Hobbs tells the story of Robert DeShaun Peace, who went from a New Jersey ghetto to Yale but never truly escaped his past.
lead_paragraph: There are places in America where life is so cheap and fate so brutal that, if they belonged to another country, America might bomb that country to “liberate” them. This book is a mesmeric account of such a place — a ghetto near Newark — that asks the consummate American question: Is it possible to reinvent yourself, to sculpture your own destiny?

headline: Larry Ellison to Step Down as Oracle’s Chief
abstract: The top job at the database giant will be shared by Mark V. Hurd, now co-president, and Safra Catz, who is co-president and chief financial officer.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley just got a little less colorful.

headline: Silent Star Gets Full Orchestration
abstract: An often overlooked aspect of Charlie Chaplin’s creative output, the music he composed, is being explored this weekend in New York.
lead_paragraph: A CENTURY after his Little Tramp character first appeared on screen, Charlie Chaplin is remembered for many things: as the derby-hatted, mustachioed comic symbol of the silent screen; as one of the first true international superstars; as an actor, writer and director who helped elevate film to a respected art form even as he enjoyed enormous popular success.

headline: 1913: Arguing With Einstein
abstract: Albert Einstein’s first appearance in The New York Times came, as might be expected, in connection with his theory of relativity.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: TerraCycle’s Struggle to Turn Trash Into Compelling TV
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Small Business', 'Television', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: The chief executive of the waste-recycling company TerraCycle tried to balance promotion with entertainment in the reality-television series “Human Resources.”
lead_paragraph: As we began filming TerraCycle’s reality-television show, “Human Resources,” we quickly became aware of the challenges of walking the line between promotion and entertainment. We wanted our clients, customers, vendors, investors and staff to be comfortable with the direction of the show. But we also wanted to keep the content engaging and entertaining enough for viewers.

headline: Moyers Says Show Really Is Ending This Time
abstract: The PBS show “Moyers & Company” will come to a conclusion on Jan. 2.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:07 p.m. | Bill Moyers has notified public television stations that his weekly series “Moyers & Company” will end after the Jan. 2 program.

headline: Wheelies: The Lotus Layoffs Edition
abstract: Group Lotus says it may have to cut up to 325 jobs; Fiat Chrysler’s new global headquarters will be in London’s upscale West End.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: New-Look M.L.S. Considers a Season Without Chivas USA
abstract: Commissioner Don Garber said Thursday that Chivas USA may not play during the 2015 season, even if Major League Soccer finds a new owner for the club.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer unveiled new logos for the league and its teams on Thursday, but it may soon put one of those teams in storage.

headline: An Infamous Art Forger on His Most Convincing Works
abstract: Mark Landis charitably donated precious art works to museums for over 30 years. But they weren’t real. Here, he shares the stories behind some of his best fakes, the subject of a new documentary, “Art and Craft.”
lead_paragraph: When, in 2011, the Times first told the story of Mark Landis — the prolific art forger who, over the course of 30 years, duped nearly 60 American museums into accepting his facsimiles of art works — the article raised as many questions as it answered. Where was Landis now? Why was he doing this? And did his donations — which he delivered in the name of “philanthropy,” sometimes while costumed in the robes of a Jesuit priest — actually constitute breaking the law?

headline: Moschino: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: School of Visual Arts Showcases Work of Cinema Graduates
abstract: A free film festival, After School Special, celebrates the work of the School of Visual Arts graduates in cinema.
lead_paragraph: When the Miser thinks of film schools in New York City, the big two, Columbia’s (famous alums: Kathryn Bigelow, James Mangold) and New York University’s (Amy Heckerling, Martin Scorsese) spring to mind. But when it comes to Hollywood credits, another local institution, the School of Visual Arts, better known for its fine arts and design programs, has bragging rights of its own.

headline: Net Neutrality Comments to F.C.C. Overwhelmingly One-Sided, Study Says
abstract: The Sunlight Foundation found that less than 1 percent of the comments about net neutrality sent to the F.C.C. were clearly opposed to net neutrality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – More than 3.7 million comments poured into the Federal Communications Commission over the four months that it was seeking public input on its proposal for “Promoting and Protecting the Open Internet,” also known as net neutrality.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Dsquared Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Looking to Adopt, but Finding Trouble
abstract: In “Reclaim,” an American couple trying to adopt a Haitian girl find themselves ensnared by a trafficking and kidnapping ring.
lead_paragraph: The elements are familiar in Alan White’s thriller “Reclaim”: white, affluent Americans stuck in a lower-income tropical city with police officers of ambiguous morals (one played here by Luis Guzmán); foot pursuits through slums; and car chases with gunplay on winding country roads. There’s even an auto teetering on a cliff as the driver tries to yank the passengers out just in time.

headline: Out of the Freezer and Into the Fight Ring
abstract: “Iceman,” directed by Law Wing-cheong, centers on a Ming dynasty warrior who encounters old foes when he is revived after a centuries-long deep freeze.
lead_paragraph: ICEMAN

Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, show times and ticket information are available at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: For This Con Artist, No Crime That Pays
abstract: “Art and Craft” looks at Mark A. Landis, who liked donating faked paintings to American museums, and the museum official determined to expose him.
lead_paragraph: Mark A. Landis, the cadaverous, soft-spoken art forger profiled in the documentary “Art and Craft,” is not a fictional character, except perhaps in his own mind. In 30 years of deception, he has donated at least 100 pieces — many of them doctored photocopies of small works — to at least 46 museums in 20 states.

headline: A Concert Not Live, but Always Living
abstract: “A Lot of Sorrow,” a video by the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson, shows the indie-rock band the National playing a single song, “Sorrow,” for 12 hours.
lead_paragraph: Ragnar Kjartansson and the indie rock band the National have made a wonderful thing in “A Lot of Sorrow,” their six-hour video at Luhring Augustine Bushwick. It is Minimalist in structure: the same song over and over again, yet unimaginably expansive.

headline: Arizona Cardinals Distance Themselves From Jonathan Dwyer
abstract: The team placed running back Jonathan Dwyer on the reserve/nonfootball illness list, opening a spot on their roster, a day after he was arrested on charges of aggravated assault against his wife and 17-month-old son.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — A few months ago, the Arizona Cardinals teammates Jonathan Dwyer and Larry Foote and their wives flew to San Diego for a Christian couples conference. The men had both played for the Pittsburgh Steelers from 2010 to 2013, and they bonded over their religious beliefs. Foote remembered Dwyer and his wife attending numerous Bible studies together. He thought they had a strong connection.

headline: Citigroup Tells Appeals Court of Its Argentina Quandary

lead_paragraph: Argentina is holding a gun to the head of Citigroup, a lawyer for the bank told a three-judge panel in Manhattan on Thursday.
