headline: Beware the Old Sailor Bearing Tea
abstract: Directed by Kevin Smith, “Tusk” is a weird, even goofy, hybrid of kidnap drama and Frankensteinian horror.
lead_paragraph: TUSK

headline: At Home in War. In War at Home.
abstract: In “Fort Bliss,” Michelle Monaghan finds rough going returning to her family after a tour in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: A story about finding peace during wartime, “Fort Bliss” turns on the struggles of an Army medic, Maggie Swann (Michelle Monaghan), who’s trying to make it back to normal after a tour in Afghanistan. You first meet her while she’s dodging battlefield bullets. Soon she’s slicked in someone else’s blood, and on her way to a commendation. A few beats later, though, Maggie has moved onto the El Paso base that gives the movie its name and is trying to reconnect with her confused, alienated 5-year-old, Paul (Oakes Fegley), after a lengthy separation.

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 19-25
abstract: A selected guide to talks, walks, readings, exhibitions, parades, festivals and other events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Photoville (through Sept. 28) Drop-bys are definitely encouraged at this photographic village, held inside and outside 63 shipping containers at Pier 5 in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Joralemon Street and the East River, Fulton Ferry. Presented by United Photo Industries, this is the third year of this free event, which also features panel discussions, workshops and other activities, some interactive. Among the images on display are untitled works like the portrait above by Nicole Wells, a finalist in the Head On Portrait Prize in Australia, and the one by Stanley Greene, top, one of 10 large prints in “Za’atari,” a collection focusing on a Syrian refugee camp that includes works by other photographers. Doug Menuez’s “Geek Sex. Adobe Systems, Mountain View, California, 1991,” below, from his book “Fearless Genius: The Digital Revolution in Silicon Valley 1985-2000,” captures a mirthful mood. In a highlight event on Sept. 27 at 6:30 p.m., Tyler Stableford will discuss his photos documenting farmers, ranchers, beekeepers and others across the country; a reception will precede the talk at 5 p.m. Photoville hours: Fridays and Thursday, 4 to 10 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 10 p.m.; and Sundays, noon to 8 p.m. A beer garden is on site, Pier 5 in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Joralemon Street and the East River, throughout the event. More information is available at 718-215-9075 or photovillenyc.org. It’s a view of the world from the shores of the East River. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: A Down Yankees Fan Gets a Pinstripes Pick Me Up
abstract: “Henry & Me” is an animated film about a cancer-stricken boy who’s transported to a dreamlike place where Yankees greats play on.
lead_paragraph: HENRY & ME

headline: For Trees Under Threat, Flight May Be Best Response
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Global Warming', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: A refuge won’t save the threatened whitebark pine from climate change, so scientists are pondering a radical idea: moving the trees to where they will be more comfortable.
lead_paragraph: The whitebark pine grows in the high, cold reaches of the Rocky and Sierra Mountains, and some trees, wind-bent and tenacious, manage to thrive for more than a thousand years.

headline: A New Way to Build Equity
abstract: A conservative-leaning organization and a housing advocacy group join forces to promote a new 15-year mortgage designed to help borrowers build equity more quickly.
lead_paragraph: The conservative-leaning American Enterprise Institute has found an unlikely ally in the Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America, a housing advocacy organization, to help roll out a new 15-year mortgage designed to allow borrowers to build equity more quickly.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Prada Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Good vs. Evil, Both Bloody
abstract: In “A Walk Among the Tombstones” the private investigator Matthew Scudder, from the Lawrence Block novels, pursues a case that leads him to an underworld of brutality.
lead_paragraph: Nasty, brutal and unforgiving, “A Walk Among the Tombstones” is one of those rare contemporary cinematic offerings: intelligent pulp. It was written and directed by Scott Frank, a script writer whose credits include “Get Shorty” and “Minority Report,” which means that he’s spent time transposing the likes of Elmore Leonard and Philip K. Dick to the screen. Mr. Frank is working with uglier, less pleasurable material here: a 1992 novel by Lawrence Block featuring his continuing character Matthew Scudder. It’s a story of good and evil in which men are as tough as nails and women little more than meat. The nail image is a metaphor; the meat less so.

headline: In Empires’ Remnants, Wonders of Survival
abstract: “Assyria to Iberia at the Dawn of the Classical Age,” at the Met, is a display of imperial might, and a roll call of states and kingdoms gone.
lead_paragraph: What are we losing? News reports tell us that the terrorist group referred to as the Islamic State is not only destroying architectural monuments in Syria and Iraq, but is also doing brisk business selling looted antiquities abroad. The specifics of these sales — what has gone where — are so far unclear. But you can get a sense of what might be heading for destinations unknown with a visit to “Assyria to Iberia at the Dawn of the Classical Age” at the Metropolitan Museum, a big, complicated, magnificently esoteric show of a kind the Met persists in doing better than anyone, even as audiences increasingly shy away from the unfamiliar.

headline: Pallbearers Par Excellence
abstract: “This Is Where I Leave You” stars Jason Bateman as a man who loses his marriage and job and then must gather with his family to mourn for his father.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Judd Altman discovers his wife in bed with his boss, he learns that his father has died. The old man’s dying wish was that the Altman family — his widow and their four children — observe the Jewish custom of sitting shiva, even though he was never especially religious. That means spending seven days together in a big suburban house, accepting condolences amid platters of food. For Judd, embodied by Jason Bateman with his usual air of beleaguered responsibility, a family reunion following a marital calamity is a nightmare. For “This Is Where I Leave You,” Shawn Levy’s adaptation of Jonathan Tropper’s comic best seller, it’s a promising start.

headline: Two Ways to Accessorize Power
abstract: Téa Leoni’s “Madam Secretary,” on CBS, follows in the footsteps of “The Good Wife” as the latest powerful woman on TV.
lead_paragraph: A minaret at sunrise and the soft lament of a Muslim call to prayer. Nobody needs to wait for a location — Damascus, Baghdad, Tehran — to be tapped out in military-style type.

headline: Alibaba Raises $21.8 Billion in Initial Public Offering
abstract: Investors flocked to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating China’s burgeoning e-commerce industry.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet juggernaut, raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial stock sale on Thursday, as investors flocked to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating China’s burgeoning e-commerce industry.

headline: Christie’s to Sell Works From Twombly’s Collection
abstract: Several pieces from Cy Twombly’s collection, not including work he made himself, will be sold by Christie’s in November.
lead_paragraph: When Cy Twombly collectors hear that Christie’s is planning to sell 11 works from his foundation on Nov. 12 and 13, they will immediately assume they will be a selection of that artist’s work from all periods and media.

headline: Clip: ‘The Maze Runner’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Wes Ball.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Wes Ball.

headline: Get Out the Magnifying Glass
abstract: A photo produces a Venetian Gothic surprise after many viewings, the tiny Dunlap & Company hat store.
lead_paragraph: My eye has brushed over an 1880s stereoview of a hotel at Broadway and Fifth Avenue many times. But I was paying closer attention last spring, and something behind the hotel caught my notice only then: a fuzzy, half-obscured fragment of architecture with the pointed arches and polychromed voussoirs that are a trademark of the Venetian Gothic style, very rare now in New York.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: fake sugar, ebola and longevity. Test your knowledge of this week’s developments.
lead_paragraph: In the news: fake sugar, ebola and longevity. Test your knowledge of this week’s developments.

headline: A Life-Size Labyrinth Is the Bane of These Boys
abstract: “The Maze Runner,” a young-adult dystopian story, finds a platoon of boys lost in a strange setting.
lead_paragraph: THE MAZE RUNNER

headline: SAP Buys Concur Technologies for $8.3 Billion
abstract: The company will pay $129 a share, a 20 percent premium to Concur’s closing price on Wednesday, expanding its suite of web services offerings.
lead_paragraph: SAP said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Concur Technologies, an enterprise software company based in Seattle, for about $8.3 billion.

headline: Long Gone, and Still Elusive
abstract: A program at Martha Graham examines a lost work from 1953, “Voyage,” imagining how it might have looked.
lead_paragraph: Under the direction of Janet Eilber, the Martha Graham Dance Company has been on a mission to demystify. One part of that effort is “Graham Deconstructed,” a series of “behind the scenes” performances, wrapped in commentary, that take place in the Graham studios. There, on Tuesday and Wednesday, the program began with an open rehearsal of Graham’s 1947 “Errand Into the Maze,” a lucid rendering by PeiJu Chien-Pott and Ben Schultz. But then came something odder: not a deconstruction of Graham’s 1953 “Voyage,” or a reconstruction of it, but, instead, a new Grahamesque work imagining its creation.

headline: John Cantlie and ISIS’ Video Strategy
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Propaganda', 'Terrorism', 'Social Media', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Some background on how video plays a big role in the propaganda strategy of the militant group the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Some background on how video plays a big role in the propaganda strategy of the militant group the Islamic State.

headline: Never Prejudge a Pack Rat
abstract: In “Life’s a Breeze,” helpful offspring clean out their mother’s home, unwittingly jettisoning her life savings.
lead_paragraph: From its name, the Irish-Swedish co-production “Life’s a Breeze” might sound like a jaunty romp, but the title actually comes from an air freshener. The device hangs on a wall after the siblings of the symbolically named Small family surprise their dotty mother, Nan (Fionnula Flanagan), by cleaning her cluttered home. The thing is, they’ve tossed the mattress where she has secretly stored 50 years of savings, which she estimates at just under one million euros ($1.3 million).

headline: A Very Barbie Beauty Look at Moschino
abstract: For spring 2015, Jeremy Scott was not shy about recreating Mattel’s classic doll, complete with bouncy hair, bright pink lips and a bit of beauty artifice.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Scott sent Barbie down the runway in his spring/summer 2015 Moschino collection today. Even without the clothes, the beauty look alone — long, bouncy hair and bright pink lips — was enough to immediately conjure up Mattel’s classic doll. Backstage, the makeup artist Lucia Pieroni explained that she even wanted the models’ skin to look “like a luxury plastic, but elegant.” A touch of M.A.C. Mineralize Skinfinish added what she called a “waxy-gloss” touch to the cheekbones. And of course no Barbie look would be complete without a little bit of artifice: two kinds of false lashes on each girl, one short (for depth) and one long, Pieroni explained, “for extra fluffiness.”

headline: Home Depot Says Data From 56 Million Cards Was Taken in Breach
abstract: Home Depot confirmed on Thursday that 56 million cardholders’ account information had been compromised in a five-month cyberattack, making the breach the largest known attack on a retailer.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | SAN FRANCISCO — Home Depot said on Thursday that the account information of 56 million cardholders was compromised in what is the largest known breach of a retail company’s computer network.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a six-bedroom in Edgemont, N.Y., and a five-bedroom estate in Great Neck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a Hell’s Kitchen condo, an Upper East Side co-op and Park Slope townhouse.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Failed Bank’s Broken Vows Mean Little
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal judge dismissed an F.D.I.C. suit against nine former officials of Cooperative Bank of Wilmington, N.C., even though examiners had tried to persuade the bank to change its practices.
lead_paragraph: Where were the regulators when small banks across the country were succumbing to the lure of easy money and embarking on a strategy of rapid growth that would end up destroying many of them?

headline: M. Lamar: ‘Negrogothic, a Manifesto, the Aesthetics of M. Lamar’
abstract: The composer M. Lamar offers a bracing alternative to the dispiriting traffic in blandly competent art clogging the gallery system these days.
lead_paragraph: With “Negrogothic, a Manifesto, the Aesthetics of M. Lamar,” the composer M. Lamar offers a bracing alternative to the dispiriting traffic in blandly competent art clogging the New York gallery system these days. Surrealistic, campy and ferociously expressionist, Mr. Lamar’s multimedia work is a heady blend of music, performance, film and political allegory that grapples with the legacy of slavery in America.

headline: Anger Management
abstract: Answers to questions about inviting neighbors to a party; giving cigarettes to the homeless; and handling a colleague’s work habits.
lead_paragraph: When our children were growing up (they are in college now), one of our neighbors did not invite our daughter to her children’s birthday parties. My husband insisted we invite all the neighborhood children to our parties. For years, I have harbored anger toward this woman who excluded our daughter. (Who would make a child so miserable?) Now, we are giving a neighborhood party for another couple that is moving away. Do I invite the family I have hated for 13 long years?

headline: Bible Belt Soul Search
abstract: Roberto Minervini’s “Stop the Pounding Heart” is the story of a young Texas girl in a strict Christian home who finds herself attracted to a rodeo rider.
lead_paragraph: In Roberto Minervini’s “Stop the Pounding Heart,” nonprofessional actors play versions of their real-life selves. This practice, which can blur the distinction between drama and documentary and allow a glimpse at truths otherwise invisible to the camera, flourished in the Italian neorealism of the 1940s and the work of Iranian filmmakers like Abbas Kiarostami and Mohsen Makhmalbaf in the 1990s. Mr. Minervini, an Italian director who has now made three features in rural Texas, extends this tradition with impressive sensitivity and skill.

headline: Anissa Mack: ‘Deep Deep Pepsi’
abstract: The shift in Ms. Mack’s latest works is depressing, even if it’s a comment on the absence of soul and authenticity in the art-fair system.
lead_paragraph: Anissa Mack’s abiding interest in Americana has taken many immersive, socially minded forms. In what is probably her best-known project, “The Last Full Weekend Each September,” she produced entries for every single category of a crafting contest at a county fair in Durham, Conn. Her latest works, however, seem made for a different kind of fair: an international art fair, with its own list of approved categories for visual expression. This shift is depressing, even if it’s intended as a comment on the absence of soul and authenticity in the art-fair system (and in some places, you’re not sure that it is.)

headline: Kansas Justices Back Senate Candidate’s Withdrawal
abstract: The withdrawal of Chad Taylor, the Democratic nominee, was upheld by the Kansas Supreme Court Thursday, helping the independent Greg Orman and dealing a blow to the incumbent Republican Pat Roberts’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas Supreme Court on Thursday sided with the Democratic candidate for Senate in his attempt to drop off the November ballot, creating a tougher contest for the Republican incumbent, Pat Roberts, in a race with a strong independent candidate.

headline: The Nurse, the Musician and the Video Artist
abstract: In “Swim Little Fish Swim,” a couple with a small child and little else in common are changed when a young Frenchwoman comes into their lives.
lead_paragraph: SWIM LITTLE FISH SWIM

headline: Harun Farocki: ‘Parallel’
abstract: The primary attraction of this show is the New York debut of the artist’s final work, “Parallel I-IV.”
lead_paragraph: The death of the German filmmaker and writer Harun Farocki this summer at 70 was a huge loss. Few artists of his international standing so consistently combined formal daring and probity with an agitator’s temperament. Beginning in the 1960s, his films, using images old and new, staged and documentary, concentrated on examining mechanisms of political control embodied in the chemical weapons industry, the prison system, consumer culture and surveillance or other electronic technology.

headline: Alone in a Skull, Talking to Himself
abstract: “Embers,” a radio play by Samuel Beckett, is staged for a theater audience at the Harvey Theater as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Next Wave Festival.
lead_paragraph: Close your eyes. No, no — not right this second. Wait until you get to the theater. You won’t want to close them then, but do.

headline: Before a Night at the Opera, a Day Backstage
abstract: Sara Krulwich, The Times’s culture photographer, spent a day chronicling the intense backstage work that precedes opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Sara Krulwich, The Times’s culture photographer, spent a day chronicling the intense backstage work that precedes opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Sophie Crumb and Aline Kominsky-Crumb
abstract: Ms. Kominsky-Crumb has been an artist since childhood, and her new show is a joint effort with her daughter, Sophie.
lead_paragraph: At 66, the artist/cartoonist/writer Aline Kominsky-Crumb has emerged from the shadow of her husband, Robert Crumb, the underground comics great. Her first solo in a New York gallery was in 2007. Now she is showing new work in tandem with her daughter, Sophie Crumb. Emphasizing another family tie may not be the best idea right now, especially since she could easily have handled the whole space.

headline: A Life in Journalism, Written in the First Person
abstract: Gail Sheehy’s memoir, “Daring: My Passages,” is effusive, fulsome and detailed but surprisingly unrevealing.
lead_paragraph: Gail Sheehy’s memoir is extremely effusive, mostly about herself. Some of that takes the form of writerly self-congratulation. Some attests to her wild sexual allure. Some consists of exaggerated claims for the importance and originality of her work. And the worst involves editorial choices that could easily have been avoided. Memoirists, you need not include every flattering remark that anyone ever made about you, even in the interest of full disclosure.

headline: Cannibalistic Gerbils and a Cryogenic Mother-in-Law
abstract: “Space Station 76,” a science-fiction-drama parody, stars Liv Tyler and Patrick Wilson.
lead_paragraph: SPACE STATION 76

headline: Fill ’er Up, but Hold the Gas
abstract: “Pump” chronicles the history of dependence on oil and features a biofuels success story in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Produced in conjunction with the nonprofit Fuel Freedom Foundation, “Pump” is less a movie than a webpage in motion. But the arguments have an appealing logic for those concerned about the environment. The film explores America’s dependence on oil, from John D. Rockefeller to the dismantling of the nation’s streetcars, and traces oil’s effects on the broader economy.

headline: In Lilting Singsong, Dublin’s Burbling Essence
abstract: In “riverrun,” a solo show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Olwen Fouéré plays the character who personifies the River Liffey in “Finnegans Wake.”
lead_paragraph: James Joyce’s last recorded words as he lay dying in Zurich in 1941 were, “Does nobody understand?” If Joyce had his “Finnegans Wake” in mind, probably not. One of the most famously difficult works of 20th-century prose, the novel is a linguistic mash-up of slang, pun, poetry and nonsense.

headline: Share Your Experiences in New York’s Work World
abstract: We want to hear about the biggest changes that have taken place in your working life over the last few years as the city has struggled its way out of a historic recession.
lead_paragraph: We want to hear about the biggest changes that have taken place in your working life over the last few years as the city has struggled its way out of a historic recession.

headline: Man Arrested in California Wildfire
abstract: Authorities in Northern California have charged a man with arson in connection with a fire that has raged across Northern California.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Northern California have charged a man with arson in connection with a fire that has raged across Northern California.

headline: Finding My Own Rescuer
abstract: An accident at 16 made him a paraplegic, and 24 years later, we were engaged, and I was terrified of losing him.
lead_paragraph: “I’m alive.”

headline: Angsty Reunion of Callow Collegians
abstract: The romantic comedy “Hollidaysburg” centers on recent high school graduates who reunite around Thanksgiving in their hometown.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Hollidaysburg” feels a bit like being conscripted into a focus group. This slight rom-com by Anna Martemucci is the first fruit of “The Chair,” a contest on the Starz network in which two novice directors vie to make the better movie from the same screenplay. Depending on how well audiences respond, Ms. Martemucci could win $250,000. (Disclaimer: I have not seen any episodes of “The Chair.”)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Scotland and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Scotland, Germany, Washington and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Scotland, Germany, Washington and Syria.

headline: This Land Is His Land
abstract: Woody Guthrie Publications is releasing “My Name Is New York,” a three-CD audiobook with a walking guide and interviews and songs about the city where he lived for 27 years.
lead_paragraph: YOU say you want to have a close encounter with Woody Guthrie, to follow his footsteps to greatness, to lay eyes on the places where American music history was made: where Woody first met Pete Seeger; where Bob Dylan first showed up on Woody’s doorstep; where Woody strummed and plucked with Lead Belly, Sonny Terry and Brownie McGhee; where he wrote “This Land Is Your Land,” “Vigilante Man,” “The Sinking of the Reuben James” and many, many hundreds of other songs; where he painted “This Machine Kills Fascists” on his guitar; where he raised his kids, more or less; and where his short, hard, full life ended.

headline: Color, Chemistry and Creativity
abstract: Color converges with art criticism to help shape the Color Field paintings in two shows, one featuring Helen Frankenthaler, the other Morris Louis.
lead_paragraph: Color Field painting arrived, in the late 1950s, at a moment of simultaneous exhaustion and innovation: fatigue with the Abstract Expressionist hegemony on the one hand, and radical new developments in paint chemistry on the other.

headline: A Sexploitation Filmmaker’s Work and Relationship
abstract: “A Life in Dirty Movies” explores the work of Joe Sarno, known for his 1960s soft-core films, and his long relationship with his wife and collaborator, Peggy.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday

headline: A Day at the Operas
abstract: We go backstage at New York’s Metropolitan Opera, as singers, musicians, wig makers, scenic artists and others race to be ready for the big season opening on Sept. 22.
lead_paragraph: We go backstage at New York’s Metropolitan Opera, as singers, musicians, wig makers, scenic artists and others race to be ready for the big season opening on Sept. 22.

headline: On Road to Scotland’s Decision, Gambles and Fateful Steps
abstract: In the mid-1990s one in four Scots voted for the nationalists, compared with more than 40 percent who supported Labour. Today the referendum on independence is too close to call.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Over a Michelin-starred dinner of Scottish venison and red Burgundy in February 2012, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain outlined his strategy for defeating a Scottish independence referendum.

headline: Congress Gives Final Approval to Aid Rebels in Fight With ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawmakers sidestepped the debate over the extent of American military action until the lame-duck session of Congress later this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate gave overwhelming approval on Thursday to the training and arming of Syrian rebels, then fled the Capitol with the House for the fall campaign, sidestepping the debate over the extent of American military action until the lame-duck session of Congress later this year.

headline: Labor War Over, Met’s Operatic Army Mobilizes
abstract: Just under a month after the Metropolitan Opera agreed to major cuts, the opera house is swarming with workers busily getting ready for the season’s opening night.
lead_paragraph: The trucks pulled in behind the Metropolitan Opera House, and stagehands began unloading sets for Bizet’s “Carmen,” hauling them onto a mammoth elevator, similar to those on aircraft carriers, and storing the disassembled pieces of Spain below the stage between a patch of Scotland from Verdi’s “Macbeth” and bits of Paris from Puccini’s “La Bohème.”

headline: Reign of Blood and Costume Design
abstract: Isabelle Adjani tries to weather the St. Bartholomew Day’s Massacre in Patrice Chéreau’s “Queen Margot.”
lead_paragraph: A roistering spectacle, heavy on intrigue, murder and fabulous brocaded gowns, Patrice Chéreau’s “Queen Margot” (1994) returns on Blu-ray and DVD (courtesy of the Cohen Film Collection), restored to the original 159-minute director’s cut awarded the third-place Jury Prize at the 1994 Cannes Film Festival. The Palme d’Or went to “Pulp Fiction,” a title that could have fit Chéreau’s blood-soaked, lustful chef d’oeuvre as well.

headline: Under New Plan, Iraq’s Fight Against Militants May Fall to Its Provinces
abstract: Separate plans promoted by the Iraqi government and by a provincial leader stem from the same conviction: that insurgents are best fought with homegrown troops.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Gov. Atheel al-Nujaifi wants his province back.

headline: Black Fathers, Present and Accountable
abstract: Zun Lee has produced a photo book that challenges the persistent narrative that African-American fathers are absent from their children’s lives.
lead_paragraph: Zun Lee has produced a photo book that challenges the persistent narrative that African-American fathers are absent from their children’s lives.

headline: What Were They Thinking?
abstract: In “Hack My Brain,” the host Todd Sampson submits himself to assorted exercises that are supposed to improve his mental prowess.
lead_paragraph: A whole industry has materialized to exploit the fear that we’re all much stupider than we need to be. Supposed brain-workout apps like Elevate. Pills that claim to improve memory and concentration. On Friday night, the Science Channel works the same territory with a three-part dose of nonsense called “Hack My Brain,” an Australian import in which a guy you’ve probably never heard of submits himself to assorted exercises that are alleged to improve neuro-this-and-that.

headline: Independent Nation With Films to Match
abstract: Georgian cinema is exotic, and can be forbidding as well as fiercely beautiful.
lead_paragraph: Squeezed between the Black and Caspian Seas, as it was among the Roman and Persian, and Ottoman and Russian empires, Georgia is a small realm with a spectacular natural setting and a proud past. “I am a representative of the last living Mediterranean culture that has its roots in antiquity,” the self-exiled Georgian filmmaker Otar Iosseliani once told an interviewer in a bit of patriotic hyperbole.

headline: Waiting Until November to Weigh In
abstract: Texas is about to hear from a group of voters who skip the primaries but turn out for general elections.
lead_paragraph: Texas is about to hear from a group of voters who skip the primaries but turn out for general elections. We have the Democrats, the Republicans and the Novembers.

headline: Before a Night at the Opera, a Day Backstage
abstract: Sara Krulwich, The New York Times’s culture photographer, spent a day chronicling the intense backstage work that precedes opening night at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: As the Metropolitan Opera prepared for this season’s opening night, Sara Krulwich, a New York Times staff photographer, spent a day backstage documenting the intense preparations. Although a labor dispute almost derailed the season, there is no shortage of work to be done: More than 1,500 people work there some days, and this time of year is the busiest.

headline: In China, Dreams of Vying for an Oscar
abstract: A film from mainland China has yet to win an Academy Award, and Chinese officials are eager for the cultural validation that an Oscar brings.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The question that hounds every major Chinese film director was put to Jiang Wen at a news conference here this month. Mr. Jiang and his business associates had organized the event to generate buzz over the coming “Gone With the Bullets,” a gangster film set in 1920s Shanghai that is a follow-up to “Let the Bullets Fly,” the top earner in the Chinese film industry four years ago.

headline: Marta Placzek Transforms Backstage at Prada
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Marta Placzek before (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: The Civil War’s Most Famous Clown
abstract: Dan Rice wasn’t just one of the most well-known entertainers of the 1860s. He used his circus career to vault into national politics.
lead_paragraph: A clown ran for public office – and no, that’s not the beginning of a joke. On Sept. 15, 1864, America’s most famous circus clown, Dan Rice, accepted the Democratic nomination for the Pennsylvania State Senate. And it was just his first foray into politics: Even while continuing his career as a clown, a state convention later considered him as a candidate for Congress, and, in 1867, he made a brief but legitimate run for president.

headline: The Senate Ducks a Clear Vote on Aid for Syrian Rebels
abstract: The aid was approved late in the afternoon, but only as a small piece of an emergency-spending bill needed to keep the government running through mid-December.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a pretty significant issue,” Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska, said angrily this afternoon in the understatement of the day.

headline: A Prada Show Worth Waiting For, Purple Sand and All
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Over the four-city fashion month swing, editors say, only a small number of shows can define a season. Marc Jacobs’s show is one of them in New York. And the Prada show most certainly is in Milan.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs had his pink house and Miuccia Prada had her purple sand.

headline: Soft-Core Auteur’s Love Story
abstract: “A Life in Dirty Movies,” a documentary by Wiktor Ericsson, recaps a couple’s collaborative career in sexploitation movies
lead_paragraph: “Her breasts were quite fantastic,” Peggy Steffans Sarno is saying early in “The Sarnos: A Life in Dirty Movies” as she watches a sensuous scene in one of the old soft-core pornographic films directed by her husband, Joseph W. Sarno. “To lie down and still have a breast — most of them just lie flat when you lie down. So she was really good. And I forget her name.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | Sept. 19, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “A Walk Among the Tombstones,” “Tracks” and “This Is Where I Leave You.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “A Walk Among the Tombstones,” “Tracks” and “This Is Where I Leave You.”

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: When Medicine Is Futile
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Elderly', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Doctors need to be able to say “no” when more treatment won’t help.
lead_paragraph: MY father would have been thrilled to read “Dying in America,” a new report by the Institute of Medicine that argues that we subject dying patients to too many treatments, denying them a peaceful death. But he would have asked what took us so long. A physician from the late 1950s to the late 1990s, my dad grew increasingly angry at how patients died in this country, too often in hospitals and connected to machines and tubes he knew would not help them.

headline: ‘Happy in Tehran’ Dancers Are Given Suspended Sentences
abstract: Though the punishments — lashings and six-month prison terms — were suspended, they could be carried out if any of the six defendants commit further actions deemed illegal in Iran.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A group of young Iranian men and women known as the “Happy in Tehran” dancers, arrested in May for videotaping themselves cavorting to Pharrell Williams’s popular dance hit, were informed on Thursday of their punishments: 91 lashes and six months of imprisonment for each.

headline: State Invites More Toll Roads Amid More Signs of Resistance
abstract: While Texas officials argue that the state can no longer pay as it goes for road construction, objections to a proliferation of toll projects are mounting.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — Billions of dollars in toll roads are being developed across Texas, but leaders say the state is still a hot spot for new projects.

headline: Events in Westchester for Sept. 21-27, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Death on a Bike
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The loss of a single cyclist has a chilling effect on everyone who pedals for work, exercise or pleasure. Can’t we get it right?

headline: Global Heat Records Set for Month and Season
abstract: The globe smashed more heat records last month, including earth’s hottest August and summer, federal meteorologists said.
lead_paragraph: The globe smashed more heat records last month, including earth’s hottest August and summer, federal meteorologists said on Thursday. May, June and August all set global heat records this year. Meteorologists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the average world temperature in August was 61.36 degrees Fahrenheit, breaking a record set in 1998. Scientists at NASA, who calculate global temperature in a slightly different way, also found that August was the hottest on record. The month was especially hot in the Pacific and Indian Oceans and Africa, but cooler in parts of the United States, Europe and Australia. For the United States, it was the coolest August and summer since 2009. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration records go back to 1880. But it is more than just one month. It was the warmest meteorological summer — June, July and August — on record for the globe, again beating out 1998. This year so far is the globe’s third warmest on record. “It’s not a done deal, but we are increasingly moving” toward breaking the hottest year record set in 2010, said Derek Arndt, NOAA’s climate monitoring chief. “This is the outcome of warming over the long term.” (AP)

headline: Iraq: Deadly Attacks Strike Baghdad
abstract: At least 29 people were killed and more than 65 wounded in attacks in and around the predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Kadhimiya in Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: At least 29 people were killed and more than 65 wounded on Thursday night in attacks in and around the predominantly Shiite neighborhood of Kadhimiya in Baghdad, raising the day’s death toll to at least 45. The attacks were part of a broad upswing in sectarian violence in the capital since the Sunni extremists calling themselves the Islamic State surged toward the city a few months ago. Bombings and assassinations against both Sunnis and Shiites have become a daily occurrence. Earlier Thursday, at least 16 people were killed and dozens were wounded by four explosions and a mortar attack in and around Baghdad, police officials said. Then in the Kadhimiya area, two car bombs killed at least 24 people. A short time later, a dozen mortar rounds fired into the same area killed at least five more. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attacks.

headline: Syria: Opposition Investigates Vaccine
abstract: Officials of the Syrian opposition coalition said they had created a commission of inquiry into the deaths of children caused by adulterated measles vaccine administered this week.
lead_paragraph: Officials of the Syrian opposition coalition said Thursday that they had created a commission of inquiry into the deaths of children in insurgent-held Idlib Province caused by adulterated measles vaccine administered this week. The announcement came amid new indications that the disaster had been the result of negligence and not sabotage, and that it was possibly caused by a mixing of vaccines and an anesthetic used to relax muscles during surgery. The opposition coalition, which considers itself the interim government in that part of the country, said on its website that the commission would submit a final report on Sept. 25. The announcement also said 30 children had died. Conflicting accounts on Wednesday said 15 to 50 children had died within minutes of receiving the vaccine. The World Health Organization and Unicef, which have been overseeing an extensive vaccination campaign in Syria, have expressed concern that the vaccine disaster will discourage parents from protecting their children from measles, rubella and polio. The diseases are making a comeback in Syria because of the war and the collapse of public health services. Save the Children, a charity that helped plan the vaccination campaign and financially supported it in Idlib, said in a statement that it was “deeply saddened and shocked” by the deaths and expressed readiness to “ensure there is clarity about how this tragic situation occurred.”

keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: One of fashion’s cruelest means of trickery is to offer the illusion of wealth when the reality is too distant to inhabit.
lead_paragraph: For a long time as a private citizen and for some number of years as a journalist, I thought a lot about fashion, both about the individual choices people made when they got dressed in the morning and about what it meant culturally and socially when those choices began strikingly to resemble one another. It became a consuming pastime to see what trickled down and what migrated up — round-toe platform stilettos, for instance, from the world of 11th Avenue at 3 a.m. to the world of Madison Avenue and 65th Street at noon.

headline: Corrections: September 19, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: School’s in Session for Eager Rangers Coach, and Name Tags Would Help
abstract: The veteran defenseman Dan Boyle and the rookie wing Kevin Hayes are among the acquisitions the Rangers made in the off-season.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — On June 13, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault was crestfallen as he sat on a podium at Staples Center, barely able to speak after a wrenching defeat in the Stanley Cup finals. On Thursday, he was as excited as a schoolboy.

headline: Against Blue Jays, Derek Jeter and Yankees Show Signs of Life
abstract: The hopes of the Yankees’ claiming one of the final two wild-card spots are dwindling, but not dead, as the Kansas City Royals are scuffling and the Oakland A’s are listing.
lead_paragraph: The flashbulbs portion of the season has finally arrived. That was one of the first surefire signs of Derek Jeter’s final regular-season homestand at Yankee Stadium: the winking lights from digital cameras greeting his every at-bat.

headline: The Other Side of a Derek Jeter Hustle Play
abstract: The former Blue Jays catcher Ken Huckaby, now a Class A hitting coach for Toronto, injured Derek Jeter on a play on opening night in 2003.
lead_paragraph: The young man from the Lansing Lugnuts’ front office offered an email address for Ken Huckaby. “You’re welcome to try, but I should tell you that someone did a story recently on the Derek Jeter thing and Ken kind of regretted it,” said Ben Owen, the team’s digital media and marketing manager.

headline: Former Jets Captain Returns to the Site of Past Heroics and Strife
abstract: Santonio Holmes, the talented but sometimes volatile receiver, will return to MetLife Stadium on Monday night to face the Jets as a member of the high-powered Chicago Bears.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Pittsburgh Steelers were troubled by off-the-field problems when they dealt wide receiver Santonio Holmes to the Jets before the 2010 season in a transaction that appeared to revolve more around making a statement about conduct than football.

headline: Court Ruling in Kansas Makes Senate Race a True Tossup
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Third-Party Moves (US)']
abstract: The basic contours of the race are consistent with the serious possibility of an independent victory, a victory that could decide Senate control.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman size up a smelly fork, a SmartRing and cookies made of bugs.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman size up a smelly fork, a SmartRing and cookies made of bugs.

headline: Three Rising Talents Spotted at the London Design Festival
abstract: T rounds up a few young standouts (all of whom happen to be women) involved with this week’s fair.
lead_paragraph: While the London Design Festival is known for extravagant installations and special commissions for the industry’s top talents, the city is also a breeding ground for new designers and brands. Set apart from the commercial pressures and intense competition of design capitals like Milan, London has an anything-goes attitude that attracts some of the best and brightest. And in various projects there — including the Airbnb-sponsored project “A Place Called Home” centered in Trafalgar Square — top-shelf names can share the spotlight with those just building their portfolios. Here, a few standout rising talents we spotted this week.

headline: Loose Waves Parted Down the Middle: the Ultimate Spring 2015 Hairstyle
abstract: There's no reason to wait until next year to sport this very wearable 'do (take it from Cara Delevingne and Kate Moss).
lead_paragraph: During New York Fashion Week, we were convinced that braids would be the ultimate spring/summer 2015 beauty look (Donna Karan, Michael Kors, Suno). But today, it’s become clear that long, loose waves parted down the middle will be the way to wear your hair when the weather warms up again next year. (Or, for that matter, right now.)

headline: Word of the Day | reparable
abstract: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past two years.
lead_paragraph: reparable •\ˈre-p(ə-)rə-bəl\• adjective

headline: The Muddled Message in ISIS’ Latest Agitprop Video
abstract: British journalist John Cantlie appears with a promise to expose Western media, but viewers must be skeptical of every word he speaks under presumed duress.
lead_paragraph: The latest propaganda video by the Islamic State is horrible to watch, but the message is muddled.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (E!) FASHION POLICE: CELEBRATING JOAN Melissa Rivers leads a 90-minute tribute to her mother, Joan Rivers, above, who died Sept. 4, in which the “Fashion Police” team of Kelly Osbourne, Giuliana Rancic and George Kotsiopoulos narrates behind-the-scenes footage and outtakes from the show and recounts personal stories. The special crowns an all-day marathon, from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., of “Fashion Police” episodes, including Ms. Rivers’s 80th-birthday celebration and her last stints dissecting the good, the bad and the downright ugly at the MTV Video Music Awards and Primetime Emmys.

headline: Scotland’s ‘No’ Vote: A Loss for Pollsters and a Win for Betting Markets
abstract: Prediction markets give much more reliable forecasts than pollsters, as do surveys of what voters expect will happen.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s Scottish referendum was interesting not just for what it said about Britain, but also for what it said about the state of political forecasting. I’m calling it a loss not only for the pro-independence movement — the “No” campaign won 55.3 percent of the vote — but also for the pollsters.

headline: Milan Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 3
abstract: At the midpoint of the Italian shows, it’s Giambattista Valli, Etro, Missoni, Versace and lots of accessories today.
lead_paragraph: How do you know you’re at the shows in Milan and not one of the other stylish capitals?

headline: After Losing Scottish Independence Vote, Alex Salmond Will Resign
abstract: A day after Scots voted against his plan to secede from Britain, Alex Salmond said he would step aside as first minister and leader of the Scottish National Party.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Alex Salmond, who led Scotland’s failed bid for independence, announced on Friday that he would step down as first minister of Scotland and leader of the Scottish National Party later this year.

headline: Chinese Fans Celebrate Li Na’s Historic Career
abstract: On Chinese social media, news of Li Na’s retirement surpassed the initial public offering of Alibaba and the independence referendum in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by the Chinese tennis star Li Na that she was retiring triggered an outpouring of support from Chinese fans who said they were sorry to see her leave the court but endorsed her decision to stop after her latest injury.

abstract: The celebrated folk singer spent 27 years in New York. Two of his grandchildren, Anna Canoni and Cole Rotante, visit some of the New York locations where he lived.
lead_paragraph: The celebrated folk singer spent 27 years in New York. Two of his grandchildren, Anna Canoni and Cole Rotante, visit some of the New York locations where he lived.

headline: Vivendi Picks Telefónica in $9.3 Billion Deal for Brazilian Telecom Unit
abstract: The agreement follows a battle between Telefónica and its European rival Telecom Italia, which both put forward competing bids last month for the Vivendi unit, Global Village Telecom.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French conglomerate Vivendi said on Friday that it would sell its Brazilian telecommunications unit to the Spanish carrier Telefónica for 7.24 billion euros, or $9.3 billion, paving the way for Vivendi’s exit from the telecommunications business.

headline: Test Yourself | From Caribbean Dance Halls to Brooklyn Streets
abstract: Can you choose the best word to complete each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the five paragraphs that make up the Sept. 17 article “Changing States of Matter, and a Whole New Meaning to Vaping.”

abstract: A re-creation of the famed facade of the New York Stock Exchange was placed in the main courtyard of the company for celebrations of the first day of trading.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Over the course of its 15-year history, Alibaba has struggled to separate itself from a reputation for selling fake products online.

headline: Should Texting While Driving Be Illegal in Every State?
abstract: Why do think many teenagers choose to text and drive, even though it has been proven to be so dangerous — even more dangerous than drunken driving?
lead_paragraph: Arizona, Missouri and a handful of other states still do not have any ban on texting while driving. And most states still allow driving with a hand-held cellphone. This, despite the fact that 3,328 people were killed in 2012 alone in distracted driving crashes, and motor vehicle crashes are the No. 1 cause of death for teenagers in the United States.

headline: Black Fathers, Present and Accountable
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Discrimination', "Father's Day", 'Korean-Americans']
abstract: Zun Lee has produced a photo book that challenges the persistent narrative that African-American fathers are absent from the lives of their children.
lead_paragraph: An anxious little girl hugs her father as a shark swims overhead in an aquarium. A man feeds his baby as he keeps a mindful eye on his three other rambunctious children. A single father reveals the tattoo on his forearm that depicts him as his son’s guardian angel. A young man poses proudly with the teacher he sees as a father figure.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 19
abstract: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images of preparations for the People’s Climate March and construction of the new Tappan Zee Bridge.
lead_paragraph: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes images of preparations for the People’s Climate March and construction of the new Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: China Fines GlaxoSmithKline Nearly $500 Million in Bribery Case
abstract: The fine is the largest ever imposed in the country, and the British drug maker’s former chief executive there was given a suspended prison sentence.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Global multinationals have invested billions of dollars in China over the last decade, with the prospect of selling to 1.4 billion people. But the promise of China’s growth is increasingly offset by the dangers of being caught up in the country’s anticorruption campaigns and rising economic nationalism.

lead_paragraph: The Scottish referendum returned a majority for staying in the United Kingdom.

headline: Cubs’ Owners Are Rebuilding While Root, Root, Rooting
abstract: The Ricketts family, which bought the Cubs in 2009 and promised a winner, has faced all sorts of bedevilments on the field and off. And then there are the neighbors across the street.
lead_paragraph: It is a typical Sunday at Wrigley Field, that old Eden of a ballpark, with the sun beaming bright, a breeze blowing in from the lake, a good crowd on hand and the last-place Chicago Cubs already losing, 7-0. As is his custom, Tom Ricketts strolls through the aisles of the upper deck, greeting the fans.

headline: New York Today: Storm-Soaked Photos
abstract: Friday and the weekend: A glimpse of the Photoville show, crisp weather, and climate events galore.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cool Friday.

headline: When Tips Are Not Enough
abstract: A recent campaign aims to convince hotel guests to tip more, but critics say tips are a poor substitute for wages.
lead_paragraph: A new program seeks to raise hotel housekeepers’ pay by soliciting tips from guests — but some say forcing workers to rely on gratuities perpetuates inequality.

headline: Obama Unveils Push for Young People to Do More Against Campus Assaults
abstract: The campaign will feature celebrities and television ads in an effort to enlist students in the fight to end violence against women on campus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has tried to use the power of his office to combat sexual assaults on college campuses. On Friday, he got some help.

headline: Alibaba’s Shares Close Up 38% on First Day of Trading
abstract: The Alibaba Group, the e-commerce behemoth in China, makes a splashy debut to close the day up 38 percent from its I.P.O. price of $68 a share.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, the e-commerce giant, closed the day at $93.89 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up 38 percent from its initial public offering price in a strong trading debut. The stock began the day at $92.70 a share.

headline: Russian Steelmaker Evraz Considers I.P.O. of North American Unit
abstract: Russian’s largest steelmaker said it may file a registration statement to begin the offering process “in the foreseeable future” for its North American business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Evraz, the largest steelmaker in Russia, said on Friday that is was considering an initial public offering of its North American unit.

headline: Congressional Conservatives Tip Scales to the Right on the Sunday Shows
abstract: Members of Congress from the conservative end of the ideological spectrum have made 57 percent of the appearances, versus 42 percent for liberals.
lead_paragraph: The parade of politicians on the Sunday morning talk shows veers to the right, not the left.

headline: Chemical Maker Arkema in Talks to Buy Total’s Adhesive Unit
abstract: Total, the French oil giant, has agreed to enter exclusive talks to sell its Bostik business to Arkema, which was spun out of Total in 2006. The bid values the unit at about $2.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The specialty chemical maker Arkema said on Friday that it had offered to buy Bostik, one of the world’s largest adhesive makers, from the French oil giant Total in a bid that values the unit at 1.74 billion euros, or about $2.2 billion.

headline: Business Owners Share Their Frustrations With Social Media
abstract: Unlike the other members of the business group, Susan Parker of Bari Jay, a dressmaker, retains an outside agency to manage her company’s social media use.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners discussed their approaches to social media. The conversation quickly turned to Facebook.

headline: Big Weekend for Apple May Herald Strong Demand for iPhone 6
abstract: Eager Apple fans have been lining up to experience the new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus, and investors will be watching for clues about how well the new models will sell.
lead_paragraph: For Apple, the unveiling of the new iPhones is like the debut of a blockbuster movie. Eager fans lined up to be the first to experience the new gadgets. And investors will closely watch first-weekend sales, in much the same way movie producers track box office numbers.

headline: Iraqi Cleric’s Speech Strikes a Balance
abstract: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani warned of threats to Iraqi independence, but he stopped short of opposing the military campaign against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the influential Shiite cleric, on Friday urged vigilance against Western political interference in Iraqi affairs but stopped short of opposing the American-led military campaign against the extremists of the Islamic State.

headline: Daily Report: Ellison Retires as Oracle’s Chief
abstract: The top job at the database giant will be shared by Mark V. Hurd, now co-president, and Safra Catz, who is co-president and chief financial officer.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley just got a little less colorful.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Scotland Rejects Independence From Britain in Historic Vote
abstract: What is your reaction to the results of Scotland’s referendum? Why?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Scotland Rejects Independence From Britain in Historic Vote,” Alan Cowell and Steven Erlanger write about the results of the independence referendum.

headline: In Milan, a Different Front Row
abstract: Unlike New York’s starry shows, there are few celebrities in the front rows here.
lead_paragraph: In February, after Katy Perry arrived nearly an hour late to Moschino’s fashion show in Milan, she was greeted by a chorus of boos when she posed for photographers before taking her front row seat.

headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba Makes Its Debut
abstract: Alibaba is set to start trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol BABA. | Markets showed relief that the United Kingdom would not face a tumultuous breakup. | Lawrence J. Ellison announced his retirement as chief executive of Oracle.
lead_paragraph: ALIBABA MAKES ITS DEBUT | The Alibaba Group raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial public offering last night, as investors rushed to buy a piece of the company that is poised to continue dominating China’s burgeoning e-commerce industry, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced reports. The shares priced at $68 each, the top of an already raised range, giving the e-commerce behemoth a market value of about $168 billion — much more than eBay, Twitter and LinkedIn combined. The stock sale was among the largest on record, surpassing offerings from Facebook and General Motors. Alibaba could still raise more money if its underwriters make use of an overallotment option to sell more shares.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: South Korea Says It Fired Warning Shots at Patrol Boat From North
abstract: North Korea does not recognize the disputed sea border where the incident occurred Friday, and its patrol ships have occasionally crossed it.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A North Korean patrol boat crossed a disputed western sea border with South Korea on Friday and retreated after warning shots were fired by the South Korean Navy, according to the South’s military.

headline: Voting in Scotland’s Independence Referendum
abstract: Voters in Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum that had threatened to break up a 307-year union.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum that had threatened to break up a 307-year union.

headline: Parents, the Children Will Be Fine. Spend Their Inheritance Now.
abstract: Most retirees want to leave something for their children, but while such devotion is understandable it may be misplaced.
lead_paragraph: Once people hit retirement, they do not know how long they will live or how long their money will last. Still, the vast majority of retirees with children cling to an intention to leave something behind, even though many of those offspring have no expectation of receiving an inheritance.

headline: Chinese React to Scotland’s Display of Self-Determination
abstract: Scotland’s decision to remain in the United Kingdom is precisely the result Beijing wanted to see, but the democratic process on display was not lost on ordinary Chinese.
lead_paragraph: Now that Scottish voters have rejected independence at the ballot box, China’s senior leadership is undoubtedly breathing a sigh of relief.

lead_paragraph: BOLTON LANDING, N.Y. — After sparring through commercials and news releases, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Rob Astorino came face to face here on Friday.

headline: The Expanding American Waistline
abstract: Average waist circumference — but not B.M.I. — has increased significantly in the United States, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Average waist circumference — but not body mass index— increased significantly in the United States between 1999 and 2012, a new study reports.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Relocation of Business', 'Referendums']
abstract: Fears about what currency Scotland might use and whether independence would undermine trade ties faded as the referendum results came in overnight.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Scottish business leaders largely expressed relief on Friday after a sleepless night of watching the vote returns come in.

headline: Lockdown Begins in Sierra Leone to Battle Ebola
abstract: The population was ordered to stay indoors, while nearly 30,000 volunteers were enlisted to identify households where people infected with the Ebola virus are hiding.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — The most ambitious and aggressive government campaign against the Ebola epidemic gripping parts of West Africa began on Friday when Sierra Leone ordered everyone in the country to remain indoors for three days, suspending commerce, emptying the streets and halting this beleaguered nation in its tracks in an attempt to stop the disease from spreading.

headline: Exile in Brooklyn, With an Eye on Georgia
abstract: After a steep fall from grace, the former president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, is planning his life’s next chapter from a tower on the Williamsburg waterfront.
lead_paragraph: AT the Smorgasburg food fair in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Mikheil Saakashvili motored in fluorescent green sneakers among bearded men with tattoos and women in revealing overalls. They lined up for Cheese Pops, Dun-Well Doughnuts and other local delicacies. He ordered a fresh coconut.

lead_paragraph: Kyle Massey is an assistant news editor. He has worked at The Times since 1999. Kevin Roche, a news technology specialist, contributed.

headline: Household Net Worth Has Rebounded
abstract: Adjusted for the change in the Consumer Price Index, household wealth is at a record high, 4 percent above the 2007 level.
lead_paragraph: THE net worth of American households is now 20 percent higher than it was before it began to decline in 2007, the Federal Reserve reported this week. It said the households together were worth $81.5 trillion at the end of the second quarter, higher than ever and up 10 percent from a year earlier.

headline: Derek Jeter, a Yankee Before the Pinstripes
abstract: At 18, the shortstop could field, hit, run and throw – but he had a little something extra too.
lead_paragraph: One summer morning in 1991, Dick Groch was driving to a baseball game in Battle Creek, Mich., when he made an unplanned detour to a high-school field in Mount Morris, somewhere between the state’s thumb and forefinger. Groch, a scout who covered the Midwest for the New York Yankees, decided he’d stop by a “talent identification” camp there. He didn’t expect to see anything special; the event, he figured, was just a way for some local coach to make a little extra money. Besides, the Yankees were considering Jeffrey Hammonds, an outfielder from Stanford, and Jim Pittsley, a hard-throwing right-hander, as possible picks in the next draft. But Groch thought, why not break up the day?

headline: Reply All: The 9.7.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: BILL GATES’S BIG IDEA FOR A HISTORY CLASS

headline: Why Is Our Sci-Fi So Glum About A.I.?
abstract: Semi-brainless B-movies about expanding the human brain keep coming.
lead_paragraph: When I was 12, I invented a superhero named Boy Genius, a guy my age who awakens one morning with access to 100 percent of his brain power. This allows him to tap into frightening and exhilarating gifts — telekinesis, telepathy, teleportation. Like most superheroes, Boy Genius is both blessed with and plagued by his abilities. The U.S. government becomes aware of his existence, which means he dodges men in black while also fending off middle-school bullies and tormentors.

headline: Turning Microcelebrity Into a Big Business
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: All it takes is blood, sweat and selfies.
lead_paragraph: In the bowels of the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., two D.J.s — Andrew Taggart (short, Ken-doll hair, cocky smile) and Alex Pall (tall, thick-rimmed glasses, cocky smile), known together as the Chainsmokers — were led down a hallway by a gaggle of people in lanyards, followed by their manager and the photographer who travels with them and documents their every move — for their future presidential library, I have to assume. It was late June, and they had just come in from Canada, where they played another gig a few hours before. Had it not been for the double booking, their manager swears they would have been closer to the top of the bill.

headline: David Suchet: ‘Part of Me Died With Him’
abstract: The actor is — and is not — Hercule Poirot.
lead_paragraph: The actor talks to Hope Reeves about embracing Christianity, joining Twitter and saying goodbye to Hercule Poirot.

headline: Bitten to the Quick
abstract: An invasion of mites forced me to make a difficult decision.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2013, a family of pigeons nested in scaffolding outside my apartment building two blocks off St. Nicholas Avenue in Manhattan’s Washington Heights. From the window of my first-floor apartment, I heard the cheeping of baby birds and affectionately observed their downy forms and tiny black-tipped beaks: my very own slice of nature.

headline: A Quick-Change Artist
abstract: Switching prices; clipping the public crossword.
lead_paragraph: My next-door neighbor, who recently quit her job to pursue painting, asked if she could practice by making a portrait of my child. She said she would charge me the cost of supplies since it was for practice, and I agreed. When she finished the painting, she notified me that she had decided to charge me several hundreds of dollars because she had learned inart class the importance of correctly pricing her work. Although I was upset by the change in price, I did not want to ruin the relationship, so I paid what she asked. What was the right thing to do? NADIA, CHICAGO

headline: Investment Kitty
abstract: A mortgage comes with a cat; a swine pheromone has an effect on dogs.
lead_paragraph: A mortgage comes with a cat; a swine pheromone has an effect on dogs.

headline: Who Made That Maraschino Cherry?
abstract: The Frankenstein’s monster of the fruit world.
lead_paragraph: The modern maraschino cherry is “a real cherry with the cherry flavor removed,” explains Darcy O’Neil, a chemist and the author of “Fix the Pumps,” a history of the soda fountain. The original version, by contrast, was a marasca cherry — a sour, dark variety cultivated on the coast of Dalmatia (now part of Croatia) beginning in the mid-19th century. It was brined in ocean water, then preserved in a liqueur made from its own juices, as well as leaves and ground-up pits.

headline: Let a Hundred McMansions Bloom
abstract: Converting Chinese rice fields into luxury villas.
lead_paragraph: In the Dianshan Lake region, less than 40 miles west of central Shanghai, the appetite for speculative real estate has driven developers into China’s most fertile land, the Yangtze Delta. Only about half of the luxury villas like those on the following pages, which can be as big as 6,300 square feet and sell for as much as $1.5 million, are occupied — mostly as second homes. The rest sit empty, as the housing sector staggers under a surplus. The photographer George Steinmetz, who visited the area last fall, describes the transition as converting “rice farms to high-end McMansions.” As that process plays out, the country’s domestic rice consumption is set to soon outpace rice production. Marnie Hanel

headline: Apple Versus Cops
abstract: The company won’t provide information such as photos, messages and calling histories stored on the phones of its customers to law enforcement agencies.
lead_paragraph: With the release of its latest phone software this week, Apple took an important step forward in protecting the privacy of its customers by giving them more control over their data.

headline: Europe Reacts to Scotland’s Vote
abstract: Leaders from Britain, Scotland, Spain and the European Commission spoke after Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from Britain, Scotland, Spain and the European Commission spoke after Scotland rejected independence from Britain in a referendum.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: In Senate Battle, the Wild Cards Become Alaska and Kansas
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: The two states would probably decide the election if it were held today, and they pose unusual challenges for election forecasters.
lead_paragraph: The last few weeks of public polling have offered contradictory and surprising results, like surveys showing the Democratic Senate candidate in Colorado either up by six percentage points or down by eight. Nonetheless, the polls have clarified the fight for the Senate. States like North Carolina and Michigan have moved toward the Democrats, while Arkansas and Louisiana have drifted toward the Republican column. The result is that the list of battleground states has shrunk, with perhaps only Alaska, Iowa and Kansas remaining as true tossups.

headline: Introducing Our Newsletter
abstract: The Upshot newsletter will be sent on Fridays, always with at least one new article and a collection of our best material from that week.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. We’ll be sending this out on Fridays, always with at least one brand-new piece, like Nate Cohn’s above. We’ll also be giving you a chance to catch up on some of our best material from earlier in the week, and we'll give you a sense of what you can expect in coming days. Let us know what you think, via Twitter, Facebook or in the comments on this page. A couple of notes on subjects that have attracted high reader interest in recent days:

headline: Thinking Twice on Alibaba
abstract: What excites investors in Alibaba isn’t just its size, but its prospects of getting bigger. But is it reasonable to assume its dominance will persist?
lead_paragraph: Investors love a good story.

headline: Distilling Portland in a Glass
abstract: The amenity paradox — the fear that the things that make a place great could be threatened if too many people move there — inspires a cocktail.
lead_paragraph: Portland, Ore., has earned a reputation as a haven for the Birkenstocks-wearing, unicycle-riding, kombucha-guzzling overeducated and underemployed, as I wrote about in a column this week.

headline: Tropical Storm Brings Manila to Standstill
abstract: The deluge turned some of Manila’s low-lying streets into raging rivers and sent people onto rooftops as water rose above 10 feet in some parts of the city.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The worst flooding to hit Manila this year brought the city of 12 million to a standstill on Friday, killing at least one person and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of thousands of others.

headline: Digging In on Election Fight, Hong Kong Students Prepare for Boycott
abstract: Two years after university students successfully pushed back against plans to introduce new curriculum believed to be pro-Beijing, hopes for a quick victory in the election ruling fight are low.
lead_paragraph: In September 2012, some 8,000 black-clad students assembled in front of the main library of The Chinese University of Hong Kong to protest the government’s push to introduce so-called national education into Hong Kong schools. The proposed curriculum changes, denounced by protesters as political indoctrination by the Chinese Communist Party, were shelved indefinitely.

headline: Made in L.A. | Blue Nelson
abstract: T Contributing Editor David Netto meets Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.
lead_paragraph: T Contributing Editor David Netto meets Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.

headline: Big Ticket | Mansion of a Different Hue for $42.5 Million
abstract: An otherwise nondescript brick mansion in Greenwich Village is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: In another example of the increasingly expensive quest for stand-alone downtown mansions, a relatively new building at 802 Greenwich Street, oft-castigated for having a forbidding salmon-hued exterior devoid of traditional Greenwich Village charm, sold for $42.5 million and was the week’s most expensive sale, according to city records.

headline: The Lobby Curator
abstract: Alexander DiPersia, an actor, has branched out into a career as a curator for private and public spaces.
lead_paragraph: Alexander DiPersia has deep roots in real estate. In 1924, one of his great-grandfathers, William Kaufman, established a Manhattan development firm that today manages nearly four million square feet of commercial space. Mr. DiPersia, an actor, never joined the family business, but through a family-cultivated appreciation for art, he happened onto an auxiliary career as a curator for private and public spaces that started with several lobbies in the Kaufman portfolio.

headline: Dumbo Roars
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A flurry of new building is underway in Dumbo, cementing its transition from scruffy passage between the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges to an area synonymous with high real estate prices.
lead_paragraph: Not all that long ago, before the Brooklyn waterfront became a must-do on seemingly every tourist’s list, Dumbo’s converted warehouses and Belgian-block streets were inhabited by artists and young families, drawn by cheap rents, postindustrial architecture and relative isolation.

headline: The Car Whisperer
abstract: Meet Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.
lead_paragraph: Meet Blue Nelson, an auto dealer and collector who travels the world in search of rare rides.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Bacon Bowl
abstract: How Alibaba shared the wealth with employees. Rewarding customers for writing negative Yelp reviews. And why it’s definitely time to take a break!
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Harry Truman, Five-Card Stud and the Cold War
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Poker (Card Game)', 'Cold War Era', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The metaphor of poker was used by many presidents, but Truman was the one most publicly identified with the game.
lead_paragraph: This photograph may seem to show President Harry Truman, behind closed doors, playing poker while pondering the future of the Cold War world.

lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Wedding Q.&A.
