lead_paragraph: Not Much Left for a Tip

headline: 1939: Slovaks Are Terrorized
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazis arrest workers in Slovakia in 1939.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Reports reaching here indicate that new acts of terrorism are being perpetrated in Bohemia and Slovakia. Following a revolt at the Skoda works, the Gestapo made hundreds of arrests. In many cases, families of arrested workers received a few days later the papers of the member of their family arrested and a primed notice warning them that they were not to wear mourning or to speak of the death. It is believed probable that the Gestapo carried out executions at Prague, in the basement of the Petchek Bank. Other executions have been reported from Brno, where a revolt has been suppressed. Rudolf Beran, former Premier, has been arrested. A number of executions have taken place at Zilina, in Slovakia, without the Slovak authorities being advised. To their inquiry the Gestapo replied that it was ‘‘obliged to take all measures of prudence necessary to prevent acts directed against the German Army.’’— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 20, 1939

headline: Etro’s Swaying, Bohemian Footwear
abstract: Fringed, knee-high moccasins added to the southwest spirit of Veronica Etro’s spring 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: 1964: Khrushchev to Help Africans
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Khrushchev voices support for nations in Africa in 1964.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At a Kremlin reception for the 1,000 delegates to the leftist World Youth Forum here, Mr. Khrushchev declared Soviet support for Angolan fighters against ‘‘Portuguese Fascism,’’ the struggle of Negroes in the Congo against ‘‘conquerors and traitors’’ and the struggle against ‘‘racist oppression’’ in South Africa. If they want arms, ‘‘we are ready to discuss the question in a brotherly fashion and give our help,’’ he said. Mr. Khrushchev told the youth forum delegates: ‘‘I did not look at hydrogen or atomic bombs, but I saw an assortment of weapons used for infantry, artillery, tanks and rockets. I saw them and I said: ‘See what man has built for man. It’s terrible.’’’ In his 45-minute extemporaneous speech, Mr. Khrushchev gave his third clarification of his remarks last week about Soviet weaponry. He was quoted then as saying the Soviet Union had a ‘‘terrible new weapon.’’ Today he said he had been misquoted in the ‘‘bourgeois press.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 21, 1964

headline: Home Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Weighty Responsibility of Inheriting a Collection
abstract: Experts advise taking time and being cautious in assessing the treasured creations or possessions of a loved one.
lead_paragraph: AFTER her mother died, Jaye Smith surveyed the boxes around the big, rambling house where she had lived on Staten Island for 50 years and thought, “We’ll worry about them later.”

headline: Week 3 N.F.L. Matchups
abstract: A look at how teams match up for this weekend’s games.
lead_paragraph: Broncos (2-0) at Seahawks (1-1)

headline: Civil War (and Family) History
abstract: Laird Hunt learned about his Civil War-era ancestors while doing research for his novel “Neverhome.”
lead_paragraph: Laird Hunt set out to research a very particular slice of Civil War history while writing his novel “Neverhome,” reviewed by Karen Abbott this week, about a woman who disguises herself as a man to fight for the Union.

headline: Letters: When the Troops Came Home
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Robert Timberg’s “Blue-Eyed Boy,” William Giraldi’s “Hold the Dark” and more.
lead_paragraph: When the Troops Came Home

abstract: New books by Raffaella Barker, Elizabeth Gaffney, Jennie Rooney and Jacqueline Winspear.
lead_paragraph: FROM A DISTANCE  By Raffaella Barker  Bloomsbury, paper, $17.

headline: A Musical Tour of the World
abstract: The new Music of the World app available through Spotify helps users identify music from various countries and regions.
lead_paragraph: Which rhythms keep the kids of Curaçao on their feet all night? Which beats keep the Burkina Faso markets bumping all day? Immersive travelers who want to know the tunes the locals are humming can get an assist from a new app on Spotify.

headline: A Believer in Vacant Lots
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Karen Washington of the Bronx went from novice gardener to urban farming pioneer.
lead_paragraph: Karen Washington, a community activist who has been called “urban farming’s de facto godmother,” found her bliss when she moved to the Bronx nearly 30 years ago and began growing vegetables in her backyard. Gardening was not part of her heritage.

headline: Not Dead Yet
abstract: There’s plenty of life left in the aging protagonists of Margaret Atwood’s “tales.”
lead_paragraph: “Stone Mattress,” Margaret Atwood’s first collection since “Moral Disorder” in 2006, begins with three linked stories about women who have been romantically involved with a middling poet named Gavin Putnam. Constance, the protagonist of the first, has become a fantasy novelist in the decades since their relationship ended (she calls herself C. W. Starr, in the tradition of J. K. Rowling and P. D. James), famous for an invented world called Alphinland that she claims Gavin never understood: “It was a dangerous place, and — granted — preposterous in some ways, but it was not sordid. The denizens of it had standards. They understood gallantry, and courage, and also revenge.”

headline: Bloody Hell
abstract: An Irish woman leaves behind a sick brother and an abusive home life in this coming-of-age novel.
lead_paragraph: God alone might’ve written the ­Bible, but the Irish provided the punctuation. While the Roman Empire ­collapsed into the vernacular across the European continent, monks in the cold stone ­monasteries of that cold stone island hand-copied ­Latin and Greek versions of Scripture. Their “manuscripts” revived ­antiquity’s systems of notation, resurrecting spaces between words and pauses between thoughts, and turned the Flesh of body text into the Word of divine ­revelation through the sacrament of quotation. The first thing God says to the first man, Adam, is, Don’t pick the fruit from a certain tree. The second thing God says is that the man must have a partner, and so He puts Adam to sleep and removes a rib He turns into a woman: a half-formed thing, a dependent.

headline: Behind Closed Doors
abstract: In Sarah Waters’s novel of illicit love in 1920s London, a widow and her spinster daughter take a young couple into their home.
lead_paragraph: In Sarah Waters’s previous and much-­acclaimed novels, whether they’re set in the Victorian period (“Tipping the Velvet”) or in the 1940s (“The Night Watch”), the tectonic plates beneath the storytelling are formed by British society — how its attitudes shift, how they don’t. Along class lines. About lesbian sex. Concerning the place of women.

headline: Serrated Edges
abstract: In two books, Deborah Levy explores exile, estrangement and the deferral of desire.
lead_paragraph: “Elliptical” is an adjective often used to describe Deborah Levy’s jagged, imagistic style. Her snapshots of relationships, most of them disintegrating, are blunt, rueful and deadpan. Her characters confess a Didionesque anomie toward life’s limited possibilities.

headline: In Cleveland, Adding Life Where Grit Once Prevailed
abstract: The Gordon Square stretch of the old Detroit-Shoreway industrial area has been revitalized with galleries, bistros and residents.
lead_paragraph: About two miles west of downtown Cleveland, the gritty Detroit-Shoreway was once a vibrant neighborhood before it was hit hard by the exodus of big manufacturing companies in the early decades of the 20th century. Lately, new businesses, arts groups and residents have settled in the Gordon Square Arts District, a revitalized mile-long stretch of Detroit Avenue. A recent $30 million capital campaign included new streetscapes and signage. Visitors can catch a show at the Cleveland Public Theater, walk through galleries at 78th Street Studios or grab a late-night bite at XYZ Tavern. And this spring, the Near West Theater will have a $7.3 million new home.

headline: On the Lewis and Clark Trail
abstract: The author and illustrator Maira Kalman sketches her observations from a trip in search of history — and espresso.
lead_paragraph: The author and illustrator Maira Kalman sketches her observations from a trip in search of history — and espresso.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Ian McEwan, whose novel “The Children Act” is No. 4 on the hardcover fiction list, keeps a tally on his website of academic dissertations and theses discussing his work.
lead_paragraph: Ijan Makjuan: The British novelist Ian McEwan — whose latest book, “The Children Act,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 4 — keeps a tally on his website of academic dissertations and theses discussing his work. There are dozens of them, as befits a writer of McEwan’s stature, and their titles should give even unversed readers a fair sense of his interests (as well as the interests of literary scholars today): “Pervasive Perspectives: Gender Relationships in the Fiction of Ian McEwan”; “The Child in Time: Postmodern Representations of Childhood in the Novels of Ian McEwan”; “A Mind With a View: Cognitive Science, Neuroscience and Contemporary Literature”; “The Epistemology of Evil in Ian McEwan’s Novels.” Sex, childhood, postmodernism, science, the nature of evil: Yep, that’s ­McEwan. (The paper about evil was written by a Serbian philosopher, Zorica Djergovic-Joksimovic, who later expanded her research into a book with the wonderful title “Ijan Makjuan: Polifonija Zla,” or “Ian McEwan: The Polyphony of Evil.”) McEwan recently told The Wall Street Journal that fans sometimes stop him in the street. “But literary fame is quite delightful compared to Hollywood fame or rock ’n’ roll fame or footballer fame,” he said, “because the kind of people who like literary fiction tend to come up blushing or squirming with embarrassment, trying to make themselves disappear but just wanting to tell you before they fade away that your work has meant a great deal to them. And then they vanish before you can even say thank you.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: JONATHAN SWIFT: His Life and His World,  by Leo Damrosch. (Yale University, $22.) Swift (1667-1745) distinguished himself as novelist (“Gulliver’s Travels”), satirist (“A Modest Proposal”), essayist, poet and political pamphleteer. Damrosch’s commanding biography aims at sweeping away misconceptions about Swift’s parentage, love life and moral and religious views — many of which were encouraged by Swift himself.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THIRTEEN DAYS IN SEPTEMBER: Carter, Begin, and Sadat at Camp David,  by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $27.95.) How marathon sessions of bare-knuckle diplomacy forged a framework for peace between Israel and Egypt in 1978.

headline: Bookshelf: Laughs
abstract: New picture books include Mac Barnett’s “Sam and Dave Dig a Hole.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Mac Barnett’s “Sam and Dave Dig a Hole.”

headline: Be Polite With Your Books
abstract: The etiquette of borrowing, recommending and reshelving books.
lead_paragraph: What is the etiquette anyway regarding the making of a literary reference in casual conversation? Say, for instance, you want to refer to your newborn’s recent gastric exclamation as an “airborne toxic event.” The allusion is self-contained enough — i.e., your audience will be amused even without knowing its provenance — that you don’t need to footnote it with “DeLillo. ‘White Noise.’ ”

headline: Past Treatment
abstract: A child psychologist is troubled by her own adolescence.
lead_paragraph: There may be no bigger mystery to a child than her own family — those adults who pretend not to notice even the most glaring issues, who make peculiar requests and then refuse to explain a thing. For Julia, the central character in Margaret Forster’s psychological puzzle-box of a novel, even basic factual information can be mystifying. Were her actions as a girl harmless or grave? She herself doesn’t know, and the uncertainty colors the rest of her life.

headline: She Wears the Britches
abstract: Disguised as a man, Laird Hunt’s heroine joins the Union Army.
lead_paragraph: How do you solve a problem like Ash Thompson? The heroine of “Neverhome,” Laird Hunt’s enthralling new novel set during the Civil War, is at once sentimental and aloof, a savior and a killer, a folk hero who shuns her own legend, a fierce and wounded woman who finds strength in her troubled past. Above all she is a liar, but one whose every word has the sheen of truth. “I was strong and he was not,” she begins her tale, “so it was me went to war to defend the Republic.” Yet it becomes clear that Ash is hardly motivated by patriotism, and that an equally devastating war awaits her return home.

headline: This Is What a City Under Bombardment Looks Like
abstract: A short video and photographs documenting indiscriminate bombing in Aleppo, Syria, prompt reflections of how we experience war from a distance, through images or in words.
lead_paragraph: “Who believes today that war can be abolished? No one, not even pacifists,” writes Susan Sontag in a 2002 essay for The New Yorker, “Looking at War.” “We hope only (so far in vain) to stop genocide and bring to justice those who commit gross violations of the laws of war.” We seek, too, to stem the suffering of those caught in war’s cross hairs.

headline: Walks on the Wild Side
abstract: Swallowing their fears, these adventuresome characters set off down unfamiliar streets and explore unknown worlds.
lead_paragraph: “Someone goes on a journey” is one of the guiding precepts of narrative; “Are we there yet?” is one of the guiding precepts of childhood. Picture books must inhabit the middle of this Venn diagram, offering stories as scenic and driving as any novel, at a pace more novel than driving through scenery. Four new package deals have come across my desk; let’s see what we can book.

headline: Secret Histories
abstract: Students at a therapeutic boarding school discover a way to return to the past, before their personal traumas.
lead_paragraph: Early in Meg Wolitzer’s acclaimed novel “The Interestings,” two boys at summer camp indulge in unlikely late-night mischief when, by the glow of their flashlights, they sneak passages of “All the President’s Men.” Wolitzer’s characters are often wildly bookish. In her first novel, “Sleepwalking,” three “death girls” worship Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton and another, invented, suicidal poet; in “The Uncoupling” sex lives are undone by a high school production of “Lysistrata”; and in “The Wife,” the heroine marries her college creative writing professor. In “Belzhar,” her second novel for young readers — after the ingenious “The Fingertips of Duncan Dorfman,” a middle-grade book — Wolitzer tells a flashlight-worthy story that illuminates some dark corners of adolescent desire.

headline: Rare Bird
abstract: In this middle-grade novel, a girl finds a way forward after the loss of her mother.
lead_paragraph: A book called “Nest” with a main character called Chirp might seem almost too cute. But Esther Ehrlich’s debut middle-grade novel is anything but saccharine; in fact, its ambition is to be rigorously realistic about tragedy in a child’s life. That so grave a work would festoon itself with whimsy speaks to the book’s virtues and its potential limitations. This is a book to take seriously, that has a lot to say. But is it for the child readers it’s targeting?

headline: Waging Two Wars
abstract: A picture book about an African-American regiment in World War I that confronted racists as well as the German Army.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 17, 1919, the 369th Infantry Regiment returned to New York from France. Under a bright sun and cloudless sky, before a crowd of 250,000, the most decorated ­African-American combat unit to serve in World War I marched under the newly erected Victory Arch at 23rd Street and up Fifth Avenue. White observers were awed by the spectacle of some 3,000 black soldiers in French helmets, bayonets gleaming, parading in disciplined lock step formation, while black residents flooded the streets and cheered wildly, welcoming home their loved ones and heroes. Capped by this extraordinary moment, the 369th was etched in history as the Harlem Hellfighters.

headline: My Reddit “AMA” — Put Me on the Spot!
abstract: On Sept. 25 at 3 p.m. I will be holding another “AMA” (Ask Me Anything) on reddit. I’ll be taking questions on my new book with Sheryl WuDunn, “A Path Appears,” on how to make a difference, as well as anything else you care to ask me about.
lead_paragraph: Next week I’ll hold another “AMA” (Ask Me Anything) on reddit. I’ll be taking questions on my new book with Sheryl WuDunn, “A Path Appears,” on how to make a difference, as well as anything else you care to ask me about. (The book comes out Sept. 23, so if you order now and speed read, you can ask me about stories in the book.)

headline: Putting Soul Back Into Business
abstract: A new book offers suggestions on how organizations can reinvent themselves, and a first step is putting trust in employees, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: The most important and inspiring business book I’ve ever read was written by a first-time author from Belgium who self-published his book in March. It’s called “Reinventing Organizations: A Guide to Creating Organizations Inspired by the Next Stage of Human Consciousness,” and the author’s personal story is nearly as inspiring as the content of the book.

headline: Notes on a Shortstop
abstract: A scout’s musings on the teenage Derek Jeter — provided by The New York Yankees, from Steiner Sports — notes his “active feet” and “long lean sinewy body.”
lead_paragraph: A scout’s musings on the teenage Derek Jeter — provided by The New York Yankees, from Steiner Sports — notes his “active feet” and “long lean sinewy body.”

abstract: This week, Mark Whitaker talks about his biography of Bill Cosby; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jeff Hobbs discusses “The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Mark Whitaker talks about his biography of Bill Cosby; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Jeff Hobbs discusses “The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Cosby: His Life and Times’
abstract: This week, Mark Whitaker and Jeff Hobbs.
lead_paragraph: This week, Mark Whitaker and Jeff Hobbs.

headline: Don’t Make Me Land This Plane
abstract: Sometimes both parties to a dispute have right on their side, but they still can’t both win.
lead_paragraph: One day, not too long ago, my two daughters, seated in the same room, found themselves at a standoff. One wished to watch a Rainbow Loom video. The other wanted to read in a quiet, video-free room. Things escalated, as these things do; there were available compromises, but it seems one couldn’t be reached. After a period of loud dispute, both were ejected from the room by the authorities, and not without harsh words. Both eventually resumed their activities in other locations.

headline: South Korea Is Awarded Berths in 2018 Olympic Tournaments
abstract: South Korea has been granted automatic entry into the 2018 Olympic ice hockey tournament in Pyeongchang despite the country’s low ranking in the sport.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s men’s and women’s national teams have been granted automatic entry into the Olympic ice hockey tournaments at the 2018 Winter Games in Pyeongchang, the International Ice Hockey Federation announced Thursday, despite the country’s low ranking in the sport.

headline: The Look of Milan 2
abstract: As fashion week moves on, styles from Prada, Blumarine, Moschino, Sportmax, Just Cavalli and more.
lead_paragraph: As fashion week moves on, styles from Prada, Blumarine, Moschino, Sportmax, Just Cavalli and more.

headline: At Moschino, Barbie’s Sexy New Wardrobe
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: When the music amped up at Jeremy Scott’s first full collection for Moschino, out came a pussycat-bow blouse, pouf skirt and pink sweat suit.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Flattened like a panini by the large crowd waiting to get into the Moschino show at the Palazzo Serbelloni on Thursday evening, I was reminded of the notorious Black Friday stampedes at Walmart.

headline: Weeknight Dinner Success Starts With Lemon, Olive Oil and Salt
abstract: Salt, olive oil and lemon are the items to reach for day after day, meal after meal, to create pretty much anything I feel like eating.
lead_paragraph: I have 24 kinds of chiles and over 50 dried herbs and seasonings in my spice drawer. There are dozens of oils and vinegars stuffed into my pantry, fresh herbs in pots on the deck, and a collection of condiments that I suspect is multiplying like bunnies behind the refrigerator door.

abstract: Mian
lead_paragraph: Mian

headline: Exxon Halts Oil Drilling in Waters of Russia
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The latest round of sanctions by Washington and the European Union ordered companies to cut off help to Russian oil exploration in the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil announced on Friday that it was winding down its $700 million exploration in Russia’s Kara Sea, the first major sign that Western sanctions are biting into the company’s ambitious plans to explore for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Etro Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Alibaba’s massive IPO and what it will mean for China.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba is the name on every trader’s lips today as shares of the e-commerce giant — which raised nearly $21.8 billion in its initial public offering yesterday — began trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The Hangzhou-based company opened at an astonishing $92.70, making it roughly the size of J.P. Morgan.

headline: Scotland’s Pro-Unity Vote
abstract: For the cautious majority, the allure of self-rule failed to quell the real advantages of union.
lead_paragraph: In the end, Scottish voters stepped back from breaking with the rest of Britain. The decision to maintain the 307-year-old union was the right one. Scotland already enjoys a significant degree of autonomy, and Britain’s prime minister, David Cameron, has promised more. Besides, separation would have been a plunge into a dangerous unknown. But this will not be the end of the dream of independence — not for the Scots, nor for the Catalans, Flemish, Basques and other people who nurture the dream.

headline: Back in Public, Vowing to Do More
abstract: The N.F.L. commissioner spoke publicly about the issue Friday, apologizing for his role in poor decision-making, promising a revamped personal conduct policy and saying he has not considered resigning.
lead_paragraph: After more than a week out of view with a national debate raging over domestic violence and the future of the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that he would form a committee to lay the groundwork for overhauling the league’s personal conduct policy.

headline: British Food Delivery Giant Forms Joint Venture in Brazil
abstract: Just Eat, which has been expanding globally, has agreed to merge its Brazil operations with iFood, owned by the mobile company Movile in São Paulo.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Just Eat, the British online food-ordering giant that has been expanding globally, has decided to join the competition in Brazil rather than continue fighting it.

headline: The Bradbury Chronicles: Hundreds of Items Owned by Author Going to Auction
abstract: Items including awards and even bottles of wine owned by Bradbury are to be auctioned this month.
lead_paragraph: About 450 items owned by Ray Bradbury, the prolific science fiction author who died in 2012, are to be auctioned Sept. 25 by Nate D. Sanders, a Los Angeles auction house. The offerings include letters, contracts and other signed items; awards; personal memorabilia; and a collection devoted largely to animation and science fiction art. There is also furniture and even a couple of bottles of vintage wine. Bradbury’s estate expects the auction to bring between $800,000 and $1 million.

headline: Reporting Bad Behavior to Facebook
abstract: Plus, how to turn off alerts on your Kindle Fire HDX.
lead_paragraph: Q. If I report hate speech from a “friend” on Facebook to the site, does that person get notified that I filed a complaint?

headline: Video Reviews of ‘A Walk Among the Tombstones,’ ‘Tracks’ and ‘This Is Where I Leave You’
abstract: Times critics on “A Walk Among the Tombstones,” “Tracks” and “This Is Where I Leave You.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “A Walk Among the Tombstones,” “Tracks” and “This Is Where I Leave You.” See all of this weeks reviews.

headline: The New Conservative Love Affair With Canada
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: American conservatives have found a lot to like about our northern neighbor, but they should be careful exactly what they wish for.
lead_paragraph: You may remember your liberal friends threatening to move to Canada after George W. Bush was re-elected. But something surprising has happened in the last few years: Conservatives have fallen in love with Canada. The conservative journalist John Fund wrote in National Review this month that Canada is becoming “more American than America.” That’s the same John Fund who wrote a 1995 Wall Street Journal staff editorial calling Canada “an honorary member of the third world.” A lot can change in two decades.

headline: Rare Jane Austen Manuscript Goes on Exhibit
abstract: Visitors at Jane Austen’s House Museum in Chawton, Hampshire, can see the 11 booklets that formed “The Watsons,” a novel Austen abandoned, as well as a needle case and other domestic tools belonging to the writer.
lead_paragraph: The Jane Austen news just keeps coming.

headline: Rule Changes Increase Flexibility in Pretax Health Care Accounts
abstract: Employers have the option of letting participants carry over as much as $500 to the next plan year, rather than forfeit it.
lead_paragraph: AS open enrollment season approaches for those with workplace health benefits, employees may want to take a fresh look at health care flexible spending accounts, if their employers offer them, because the rules for the accounts have changed.

headline: Michael Bloomberg, Now a U.N. Climate Envoy, Presses the Case for Urban Action
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Michael Bloomberg, a mayor turned U.N. climate envoy, explains what cities can do to blunt climate change and its impacts.
lead_paragraph: I recently had a chance to ask former New York City Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg about the fresh push he’s making for urban action to blunt climate impacts and greenhouse gas emissions as the new United Nations Special Envoy for Cities and Climate Change. He’ll be a very busy man next week, as the city hosts the People’s Climate March, a U.N. “summit” on climate change and Climate Week.

headline: Bright Future Not Certain for British Oil and Gas Production
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Now that Scotland has rejected independence, oil companies and the government are expected to turn more attention to the issue of falling production.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The vote to keep Scotland in the United Kingdom removed a cloud of uncertainty for the British energy industry. But the long-term challenges still loom.

headline: Review: ‘This Is Where I Leave You’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “This Is Where I Leave You.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “This Is Where I Leave You.”

headline: Barred From Facebook, and Wondering Why
abstract: Some users find themselves kicked off for reasons that seem arbitrary, and being reinstated can be a frustrating process.
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL LETWIN, a lawyer living in Brooklyn, went to sign into his Facebook account, as he does almost daily, and received a surprising — and unpleasant — message.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman size up a smelly fork, a SmartRing and cookies made of bugs.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Gladwell, longtime New Yorker scribe, counterintuitive theorist and entertaining public speaker whose best seller ‘‘David and Goliath’’ challenges the way we think about adversity and success, takes on Sarah Silverman, controversial comedian, actress and equal-opportunity offender who once sang “You’re Going to Die Soon” to a group of senior citizens. An album of her HBO comedy special, “We Are Miracles,” is out now.

headline: The Fresh-Air Amenity
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The developers of a 53-unit condominium in TriBeCa, a warehouse conversion, take a different approach to courtyard space.
lead_paragraph: In a city that can treat its courtyards like walled-off terrariums — things to behold but not to touch — 443 Greenwich Street is taking a different approach and creating a space to be enjoyed like a park.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Cosby: His Life and Times’
abstract: Mark Whitaker discusses his new biography of Bill Cosby, and Jeff Hobbs talks about “The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Neil Drumming reviews Mark Whitaker’s “Cosby: His Life and Times.” Mr. Drumming writes:

headline: After Woman Is Struck, Debate on Cycling in City Is Revived
abstract: A bicyclist riding in Central Park swerved to avoid a group of pedestrians and hit the woman, who was in critical condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The long-simmering conflict between bicyclists and pedestrians in New York City flared again after a 58-year-old woman was struck by a bicyclist and critically injured in Central Park on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Facts & Figures: Don’t Know Much About Government
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Thirty-five percent of survey respondents could not name a single branch of government.
lead_paragraph: A new survey finds that Americans don’t know much about government.

headline: Review: ‘A Walk Among the Tombstones’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Walk Among the Tombstones.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Walk Among the Tombstones.”

headline: Day for Night in Norway
abstract: On a slow cruise up the country’s coast, gazing at the big views and looking for the midnight sun.
lead_paragraph: The Hurtigruten website modestly describes its cruise up the Norwegian coast as “the world’s most beautiful voyage.” When I read this, I could not help but think of that old Monty Python skit in which a man writes the world’s funniest joke — a joke so funny that everyone who reads it instantly dies from laughter. I wondered if beauty, pressed toward hyperbole, could become similarly perilous. Would the decks of the ship be littered with tourists smitten by the sublime?

headline: Larry Ellison Keeps a Hand on the Wheel at Oracle
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Mr. Ellison’s 25 percent stake in the company — and dual role as chairman and chief technology officer — ensure he’s far from relinquishing control, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Larry Ellison is ceding the driver’s seat at Oracle while keeping one hand on wheel. The founder of the software giant is stepping down as chief executive officer, but his 25 percent stake in the company — and dual role as chairman and chief technology officer — ensure he’s far from relinquishing control. Splitting his former job between two executives could, however, lead to a bumpy transition.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Missoni Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: What Are the Guerrilla Girls Doing Now?
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', "Women's Rights", 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: Readers ask for an update on the Guerrilla Girls, a collective of anonymous artist-activists, and for some jokes from Joan Rivers about New York City.
lead_paragraph: Q. In reading about Pussy Riot, the female Russian punk rockers who protest the leadership of Vladimir V. Putin, I have seen references to the Guerrilla Girls. What are they up to now?

headline: Taking Their Umbrage Where They Can Get It
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections']
abstract: Democratic candidate are once again trying to accuse Republicans of waging a “war on women,” but they have a lot less to work with than in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Like many candidates attacked over budgets, Thom Tillis, a Republican running for the Senate from North Carolina, responded in a recent debate by disputing his opponent’s numbers.

headline: Tune Into The Times
abstract: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories.
lead_paragraph: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

headline: A Beltway Battle That’s a Bipartisan Dream: Washington-Baltimore World Series
abstract: A season of regional baseball bliss has given the cities, both with their own Beltways, dreams of a World Series clash between the Nationals and Orioles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few words in America draw as much disdain as “the Beltway,” a roadway connoting political dysfunction, dowdy hemlines and general cultural remove.

headline: In Hope Solo Case, Soccer Turns a Blind Eye Toward Domestic Violence
abstract: Hope Solo, the star goalie of the United States national women’s team, has been allowed to play and wore the captain’s armband despite accusations she punched her sister and nephew.
lead_paragraph: There were smiles all around Thursday night when Hope Solo extended her shutout record to 73 in the United States national women’s soccer team’s 4-0 victory over Mexico in Rochester.

headline: Weighing a Political Comeback, Sarkozy Says He Will Seek His Party’s Presidency
abstract: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France announced on Facebook that he would seek the post, a first step toward declaring his candidacy for the presidency in 2017.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Former President Nicolas Sarkozy used his Facebook page on Friday to announce that he would seek the presidency of his party, a first step toward declaring his candidacy to run once again for the presidency of France in 2017.

headline: Court Dismisses Citibank Appeal in Argentina Case
abstract: Citigroup’s next step is to go return to Federal District Court to argue that the court’s order preventing it from paying Argentine bondholders leaves it facing severe sanctions from Argentina.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s impassioned call to the United States Court of Appeals to reconsider a judgment by a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan has failed to gain support.

headline: Do You Need a Worse Phone?
abstract: The Apple Watch is coming, but some say less-sophisticated phones are the more sophisticated choice.
lead_paragraph: As America prepares for the advent of a phone you can wear on your wrist, some are calling for a move in the opposite direction: toward worse phones, not better.

headline: A Well-Received Concerto of Curves
abstract: When Jaguar’s design director ordered up a special model of the classic Mark 2, it was for his own use. Now a limited run is planned.
lead_paragraph: Ian Callum, the design director for Jaguar, apparently has his touch on the pulse of the market even when he isn’t trying.

headline: Rowland, Ex-Connecticut Governor, Is Convicted in Campaign Finance Case
abstract: Prosecutors had accused John G. Rowland of obstructing justice, falsifying documents and committing other violations of campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Former Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut, who nearly a decade ago was forced to resign from office in disgrace, was found guilty in federal court on Friday of engaging in corrupt political acts even after serving prison time for his previous conviction.

headline: A Conversation With Michael Harris, Author of ‘The End of Absence’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: Mr. Harris tries to remind people in his new book that solitude in the digital age is important to find a sense of self.
lead_paragraph: Michael Harris, a former magazine editor, is the author of “The End of Absence,” a book that tries to remind people what life was like before the Internet.

headline: Marni Hosts a Pop-Up Flower Market in Milan
abstract: To mark its 20th anniversary, the label is sponsoring a one-day garden exhibition and shop open to the public this Sunday, the day of its spring/summer 2015 show.
lead_paragraph: “I love flowers for their liveliness and vitality,” says the Marni designer Consuelo Castiglioni. And it shows: For the past two decades, blossoms have been a significant and recurring component in Castiglioni’s witty, often deeply personal collections. While it remains to be seen whether Castiglioni will send any garden motifs down the runway this Sunday, Marni flower power promises to be in full effect at the nearby Rotonda della Besana in Central Milan, where the brand will host a one-day pop-up flower market open to the public on the same day to celebrate its 20th anniversary.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty to Passing Tips in ‘Post-it’ Insider Trading Ring
abstract: A former mortgage broker admitted on Friday to being the glue that held together an insider ring that sharing information about corporate deals at restaurants and Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: A former mortgage broker from Brooklyn admitted on Friday to being the glue that held together an insider trading ring that involved the passing of stock tips on Post-it notes and napkins in meetings at restaurants in Midtown Manhattan and at Grand Central Terminal.

headline: A Pop-Beat Mask for Melancholy
abstract: The Swedish pop singer Tove Lo, whose first full-length album comes out this month, says she tries to inject a note of gritty darkness into her catchy tunes.
lead_paragraph: The changes that fame has wrought on the life of the Swedish pop singer Tove Lo start with the pronunciation of her name. “You can say too-veh loo if you want, that’s the way I say it in Sweden,” she said. “But every country besides Sweden says Tove [rhymes with rove] Lo, so I’ve just kind of gotten used to it.”

headline: A Dancer’s Creative Evolution
abstract: Troy Schumacher, a City Ballet dancer, has created his first work for the company, to be staged Tuesday at its opening night gala.
lead_paragraph: There’s an electricity in the air at New York City Ballet in September. On a recent day, wan-cheeked young women carried limp practice tutus over their arms, scurrying down fluorescent-lit hallways like Alice’s White Rabbit, perennially pressed for time. The bustle has been particularly intense this year, with four new works scheduled, three at the company’s opening night gala at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday. (A new ballet by Alexei Ratmansky will be unveiled next month.)

headline: Haunted by Eternity, the Cosmos or the Confines of a Grim Life
abstract: Listening to Jesse Winchester’s reflective final album and the latest from Lia Ices, Electric Wire Hustle, Moreno Veloso and more.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Winchester

headline: Catalan Secessionists, Despite Scotland Independence Loss, Continue Push to Leave Spain
abstract: The regional Parliament in Barcelona overwhelmingly backed an independence vote, which the government in Madrid says would be illegal.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Undaunted by the defeat of the Scottish independence movement a day earlier, separatists in the Catalonia region of northeastern Spain pressed ahead on Friday with plans to hold a similar vote there.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Aims Beyond Its Latin Ethnicity
abstract: CW’s “Jane the Virgin” is one of the latest efforts to create a show that will appeal to an English-speaking Hispanic audience and a wider viewership.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the protagonist of “Jane the Virgin” bears little resemblance to any other character on television, never mind any viewer.

headline: A Proving Ground For Young Stars
abstract: Pace University’s second season of Voce: Rising Opera Stars in Recital opens with the soprano Julia Bullock and the tenor Joseph Kaiser
lead_paragraph: The song recital, which requires attention and patience from both performers and audiences, is perpetually an endangered species. (Full-scale opera, with its costumes and grandeur, comes across as rather more fun.) But since they value intimacy, textual specificity and communicative ability, recitals remain crucial proving grounds for young artists. Voce: Rising Opera Stars in Recital, a series at Pace University started last year by the veteran impresario Matthew Epstein, has already been a valuable addition to the vocal scene. This season’s first concert, on Sunday, features the potent combination of the soprano Julia Bullock, a star at the Juilliard School in recent productions of Massenet’s “Cendrillon” and Janacek’s “The Cunning Little Vixen,” and the tenor Joseph Kaiser, over the past few years a Met stalwart in Mozart, Handel and Britten. (3 p.m., Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan, 212-346-1715, schimmel.pace.edu.)

headline: The Case for Delayed Adulthood
keywords: ['Brain', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Youth', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Boredom', 'Marriages', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Taking longer to grow up and settle down may be better for a young person’s brain.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most notable demographic trends of the last two decades has been the delayed entry of young people into adulthood. According to a large-scale national study conducted since the late 1970s, it has taken longer for each successive generation to finish school, establish financial independence, marry and have children. Today’s 25-year-olds, compared with their parents’ generation at the same age, are twice as likely to still be students, only half as likely to be married and 50 percent more likely to be receiving financial assistance from their parents.

headline: Rock Star in All His Permutations
abstract: An ambitious exhibition at the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art documents David Bowie as a musical and performance pioneer.
lead_paragraph: People who have doubts about the David Bowie exhibition opening at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago on Tuesday may find some misgivings soothed by the show’s ambitious catalog. It documents Mr. Bowie as a musical and performance pioneer whose means of visual expression included drawings, paintings and many shape-shifting, gender-bending ensembles — sometimes his own designs — for stage, cover art, videos and photos. Only about a third of the garments made the trip from the show’s point of origin, the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. But they will include 11 for Ziggy Stardust, Mr. Bowie’s best-known character, and the Union Jack coat he collaborated on with Alexander McQueen. There will also be ephemera dating to Mr. Bowie’s childhood (he was born David Robert Jones in 1947) and examples of handwritten lyrics and projections of his most influential music videos. The material should convey Mr. Bowie’s wide-ranging achievement and also — as the museum’s news release says — repatriate him “into the territory of cutting-edge visual and performing art that is his natural home.” (mcachicago.org.)

headline: Anticipated Premieres
abstract: The choreographers Justin Peck and Kyle Abraham have been blessed and cursed by critics as the potential voices of their generation.
lead_paragraph: In their respective genres — ballet and contemporary dance — the choreographers Justin Peck and Kyle Abraham have been blessed and cursed by critics as the potential voices of their generation. Both have highly anticipated premieres this week. Hype aside, both are smart and refreshing artists, consistently offering satisfying theatrical experiences.

headline: A 50th High School Reunion, and a Generation to Follow
abstract: The Class of 1964 is the first graduating class of the post-World War II baby boom and the leading edge of the generation retreating to retirement.
lead_paragraph: CHERRY HILL, N.J. — TONI DEGIROLAMO and Dick Worthington had been seeing each other for a while when they decided to go on a date to the Garden State Drive-In a half-century ago.

headline: Olivia Benson as Mama Bear
abstract: The star of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” Sgt. Olivia Benson, portrayed by Mariska Hargitay, tackles motherhood.
lead_paragraph: After 15 seasons as the heart of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” Sgt. Olivia Benson has pretty much been there, done that, when it comes to crime and punishment. But gunshots, stabbings and kidnappings — or having Taylor Swift name her kitten after you — are nothing compared to her latest task: motherhood. The series’s 16th round, debuting Wednesday at 9, finds Benson’s primal instincts raging when the biological mother of the foster son she inherited in last season’s finale is burned almost beyond recognition. That murder leads Benson and her squad to a sex-trafficking ring that markets its under-age prostitutes on Craigslist. When its members threaten the life of Benson’s child, hello mama bear.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Tod’s Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: 2015 Cadillac Escalade
abstract: Its glory days of the mid-2000s are long past, but the redesigned Cadillac Escalade seems content to coast on its reputation.
lead_paragraph: Its glory days of the mid-2000s are long past, but the redesigned Cadillac Escalade seems content to coast on its reputation.

headline: Bomb Kills 2 Lebanese Soldiers Near Border With Syria
abstract: The attack on a Lebanese Army convoy took place near the town of Arsal, the scene of battles that erupted last month between the army and militants operating in Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two Lebanese Army soldiers were killed and two were wounded on Friday when their convoy was hit by a roadside bomb outside the town of Arsal, near the border with Syria. The town was the scene of battles that erupted last month between the army and militants from the group Islamic State and the Nusra Front, which is affiliated with Al Qaeda.

headline: Japan’s Premier Seeks Summit Meeting With South Korean President
abstract: In a conciliatory gesture after years of tensions, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan sent a letter to President Park Geun-hye of South Korea proposing the meeting.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The office of President Park Geun-hye said on Friday that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan had sent a letter proposing a summit meeting, a conciliatory gesture after years of tensions between America’s most important allies in Northeast Asia.

headline: John Boehner’s Theory of the Leisure Class
abstract: You’re all bums on welfare.
lead_paragraph: And, I’m back — I’ve been in a grueling battle against deadlines, which is not quite over, so blogging may remain scarce for a while longer. But I’m sticking my toe in for the moment — and whaddya know, oops, he did it again. John Boehner says that unemployed Americans are pretty clearly malingerers, bums on welfare who have decided that they don’t feel like working:

headline: The Secret to Last-Minute Tart: Keep Pastry Dough in the Freezer
abstract: Practice and careful measurement will assure that you always have the pastry ready for a tart.
lead_paragraph: If I have a sweet pastry shell in the freezer, I know I’m ready to entertain. A dinner party requires a dessert, and what is more pleasing than a beautiful fruit or lemon tart?

headline: How to Get the Fresh-Faced Glow at Blumarine
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: The radiant models exuded youthful sophistication on this morning’s runway in Milan.
lead_paragraph: This morning in Milan, fresh-faced models stepped into Blumarine’s spring 2015 collection of garden-party frocks, skirts and coats (no pants in sight!). Sure, they had just gotten a good night’s sleep. But the makeup artist Tom Pecheux helped enhance their bright and even complexions with a mix of skin-care products, foundation, concealer, blush and bronzer. “The inspiration is youth,” he said, explaining that he aimed to create the “superfresh and young girl that acts like a woman.” On the runway, models’ eyes were wide and bright thanks to a bit of shimmer on the inside corner of the eye, some gloss on the brushed eyebrows and the absence of dark mascara. The finishing touch was the sexy and easy-to-pull-off-in-real-life hairstyle that seems to be dominating runways this season: relaxed waves, parted down the middle.

headline: Expedia and HomeAway Expand Rental Partnership
abstract: A partnership between Expedia and HomeAway will offer more than 100,000 home rentals.
lead_paragraph: Expedia and HomeAway have decided to expand a pilot partnership begun last year offering HomeAway listings through Expedia’s website.

headline: U.S. and Mexico Aid Tourists Stranded After Hurricane Odile
abstract: Several days after the storm, the American military, the State Department and the Mexican authorities continued to airlift stranded tourists from the Cabo San Lucas area.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Several days after a powerful hurricane hit one of Mexico’s most popular Pacific resorts, the American military, the State Department and the Mexican authorities continued to airlift stranded tourists from an area afflicted by looting and still lacking electricity and potable water.

headline: Phoney Baloney (Personal and Trivial)
abstract: Apple not of my eye.
lead_paragraph: Just to say: What is it with the huge lines waiting for the new iPhone? Yes, smartphones are quite useful and sometimes even fun; I’m not a heavy app user, but I’m still on the thing many times a day. But even if the iPhone 6 has nifty new features, how can you get so excited over something that is, when all is said and done, an incremental change?

headline: Chinese Media Company Signs On To Broadcast Broadway Shows
abstract: A joint venture between the Chinese company and Broadway Worldwide aims to screen between two and four shows a year, including in the Asian market.
lead_paragraph: Broadway has been slow to embrace the high-definition broadcasts increasingly beamed out by performing arts organizations around the world. A new venture hopes to speed that up.

headline: Summery Turbans at Missoni
abstract: In the same colors and patterns as the clothes, silk scarves completed the label’s breezy spring 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: There were swaths and swaths of silk on Missoni’s spring 2015 runway — even on the models’ heads, where hair was wrapped up in an array of silk scarves printed with the same colors and patterns as the clothes. The turbans lent an extra summery feel to the light, breezy collection.

headline: Versace: Summer 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Obama Starts Campaign Against Assault
abstract: President Obama announced a new nationwide public service campaign, “It’s on Us,” aimed at urging young people to do more to prevent campus sexual assaults.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced a new nationwide public service campaign, “It’s on Us,” aimed at urging young people to do more to prevent campus sexual assaults.

headline: Jack Devine: The Spymaster Who Goes to Mass
abstract: After a long career in the C.I.A., Mr. Devine can spend Sundays reading the newspaper and museum-hopping.
lead_paragraph: Speaking about life after the Central Intelligence Agency, Jack Devine became nostalgic. “I’m having a lot of fun,” he said, “but I’m not allowed to overthrow governments.” Mr. Devine, 73, who chronicles his 32 years at the C.I.A. in the memoir “Good Hunting: An American Spymaster’s Story,” had a role in the Iran-contra affair, the arming of Islamist rebels against the Soviets in Afghanistan, and the capture of Pablo Escobar. After leaving the C.I.A. in 1999, he helped start a corporate intelligence firm, the Arkin Group. He and his wife, Patricia, split their time between the East 70s and Ocean City, N.J., where he rows competitively in summers. Does he miss overthrowing governments? “I’m lying if I say I didn’t,” he said.

headline: Their Latest and Greatest Adventure
abstract: The adventurous bride and groom met in Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: When Breezy Jackson went to Antarctica in 2009 for a job driving what she calls “monster trucks” for the United States Antarctic Program, friends who had worked on the ice warned her that the community of seasonal workers there had a reputation for temporary relationships.

headline: ‘You See Your Boys, You Stop’: At Le Basket in Greenwich Village
abstract: Le Basket is a deli in Greenwich Village with an outdoor seating area that doubles as a beer garden where it’s always happy hour for bike messengers on their way home.
lead_paragraph: You’re a bike messenger in New York City and you’ve just finished your day, clocking in more than 50 miles racing around town contending with traffic and chaos. You’d like to unwind with your colleagues over a beer. The obvious, if unlikely, choice is Le Basket, a deli at the corner of Broadway and East Third Street whose utilitarian outdoor seating area doubles as a beer garden where, thanks to the bike messengers who stop there on their way home, it’s always happy hour.

headline: As Central Park Gondolier, He Helms a Love Boat
abstract: Andrés García-Peña inherited his gondolier job from a friend, and works on the boat from May through October.
lead_paragraph: Dusk was descending on Central Park Lake when a couple from Connecticut stepped onto Andrés García-Peña’s gondola.

headline: What Would We Do Without It?
abstract: New books trace the changes air-conditioning brought; politics and change in Newark; and idiosyncracies of the five boroughs of New York City.
lead_paragraph: With summer just about officially over, we can dispassionately explore what the world was like a little more than a century ago, before Willis Carrier installed his “apparatus for treating air” in a Williamsburg, Brooklyn, printing plant.

headline: How That Meal Got to the Table
abstract: Here’s the way to walk into a supermarket and walk out with dinner.
lead_paragraph: I rarely go to the market with a blank slate. Some notion of the ultimate goal — dinner — informs my shopping. Nonetheless, I frequently let the market guide me; dinner is not a rigid “paint by numbers” affair, even if I plan a particular dish. It’s more like a pencil sketch, with some elements that may be erased and redrawn, the way a chef comes up with a daily special.

headline: Where They Danced the Virginia Reel
abstract: Notable sites on East Fourth Street include No. 29, the Merchant’s House Museum, whose parlor and staircase were copied for the 1949 film “The Heiress,” and the Swift Hibernian Lounge, an Irish pub.
lead_paragraph: From the 1830s to the 1850s, East Fourth Street was a high-society Manhattan address with neighbors named Astor and Vanderbilt. Charles Dickens and Washington Irving sojourned in the area, which then was called Bond Street. The MERCHANT’S HOUSE, at No. 29, built in 1832, stands as a testament to that period, seeming as unchanged and as fragile as Miss Havisham’s wedding dress. It is also imperiled.

headline: Salesforce Boss Tips His Hand on Company’s Big News
abstract: Maybe the chief executive of Salesforce did himself a favor when he gave away one of his big surprises for an upcoming show. His data analysis cloud for the masses is likely one of many, with more on the way. Can his be different?
lead_paragraph: Marc Benioff raised the bar against himself last week, accidentally announcing that his company would do something big in data analytic technology that customers access through so-called cloud computing.

headline: Hook, Line and Ring
abstract: For couples who still want to cast the net — for fish.
lead_paragraph: For couples who still want to cast the net — for fish.

headline: What Does a Whole Lot of Cash Do to a Designer?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: LVMH reportedly took a 45 percent stake in Marco de Vincenzo’s label earlier this year, and will invest more than $10 million into the label.
lead_paragraph: Over two years, the two fashion giants, LVMH and Kering, have opened a new front in their war for fashion supremacy, aiming at gobbling up as many young designers as possible. Kering has taken stakes in Christopher Kane and Joseph Altuzarra, while LVMH has invested in J.W. Anderson, Maxime Simoens, Nicholas Kirkwood and Marco de Vincenzo.

headline: To Save the Planet, Don’t Plant Trees
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Air Pollution', 'Environment']
abstract: Reforestation might seem like a simple solution to climate change, but the science shows it could make global warming worse.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — AS international leaders gather in New York next week for a United Nations climate summit, they will be preoccupied with how to tackle the rising rate of carbon emissions. To mitigate the crisis, one measure they are likely to promote is reducing deforestation and planting trees.

headline: Scandinavians Split Over Syrian Influx
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Norway is skeptical of Sweden’s open door for asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: THE narrow victory of the left-leaning Social Democratic Party in Sweden’s elections last Sunday marked a broad shift in its politics. But a new coalition government is unlikely to reconsider one of the country’s most challenging policies: its response to the Syrian civil war. Sweden has taken an open-door approach to people fleeing the conflict, accepting more Syrians than any other European country.

headline: Sad Dads in the Empty Nest
abstract: When kids leave home, is it worse for fathers?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — MY mother-in-law called the other day to see how I was doing. My husband and I had just taken our daughter — our firstborn — to college, renting a giant Lincoln Navigator to transport the requisite duffel bags and notebooks and drawer units and bedding and mini-fridge and Keurig. Now we were home, contemplating her room and the beloved detritus of her childhood — old snow pants, dog-eared Pendragon books, corkboard photo collages — and my mother-in-law wanted to make sure I was holding up.

headline: Guided By Voices Calls It Quits, Cancels Tour
abstract: The veteran indie rock band, which reunited in 2010, is breaking up mid-tour.
lead_paragraph: The innovative and often experimental indie band Guided by Voices announced on its website on Thursday that it was calling it quits, again. The band, led by the prolific singer and songwriter Robert Pollard, was founded in 1987 and broke up, the first time, in 2004. Mr. Pollard reconvened the group’s most successful lineup – the version that toured and recorded from 1993 to 1996 – in 2010, and made six albums with the band, including two (“Motivational Jumpsuit” and “Cool Planet”) released this year.

headline: Debate on Independence Lingers in Scottish Homes
abstract: Relatives have found themselves on opposite sides of a rift opened by the most momentous decision their country has faced since joining Britain.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Fiona Ivanski and her husband, Vincent, woke early the morning after the Scottish independence referendum, even though they had barely slept. Anxious to discover the verdict on Scotland’s future, they sat down on their living room couch at 6:08 a.m. Friday and turned on the television.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from India, Sierra Leone, Scotland and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Sierra Leone, Scotland and New York.

headline: U.S.T.A. Faces Suit Over Sabbath Schedule
abstract: A Long Island senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members says the U.S.T.A. has refused to change its schedule to accommodate the players’ observance of the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: A senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members is suing the United States Tennis Association over its refusal to change a tournament schedule to accommodate the players’ observance of the Sabbath.

headline: Bach, Played in Living Color
abstract: The violinist Christian Tetzlaff revisited the 92nd Street Y on Thursday and the works he performed there in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The juxtaposition was peculiar, no question. Hearing Christian Tetzlaff play Bach’s sonatas and partitas for unaccompanied violin, some of the most intellectually stimulating and emotionally fulfilling music ever written, on Thursday evening, I kept thinking of a child’s coloring book. Bach drew those wildly imaginative and fanciful but spare lines of melody and counterpoint, leaving it to the player to add color.

headline: Up From Pain
abstract: I had to stop hating my abuser to start loving myself. I had to let go of my past so that I could step into my future.
lead_paragraph: I WAS away at college doing much of nothing, just pushing back against sorrow as it pressed down. My mother called. She told me someone wanted to speak to me. There was a silence on the line, and then words: “What’s going on, boy?”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Detroit Muscle in a Jersey Warehouse
abstract: The setting may have lacked the glamor of Pebble Beach or Amelia Island, but the cars being auctioned by the U.S. Marshals Service were blue-chip collectibles.
lead_paragraph: The setting may have lacked the glamor of Pebble Beach or Amelia Island, but the cars being auctioned by the U.S. Marshals Service were blue-chip collectibles.

headline: Right Up to Retirement, Derek Jeter Is Still Playing the Game
abstract: These days, the Yankees offer endless reminders of their glorious past at Yankee Stadium. Case in point: Derek Jeter, who homered on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: He flexed his knees and settled into the batter’s box like a man into his garden, needing just another moment to root his right foot into the dirt. Then he pulled his left shoulder in, as if to fit into a crowded subway car, waggled his bat and awaited the pitch.

headline: The Berlin Wall’s Fall, Commemorated by Light
abstract: The 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall will be observed in November with miles of light along its former route.
lead_paragraph: The 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall will be observed with miles of light during the weekend of Nov. 7 to 9.

headline: Ondria Hardin Transforms Backstage at Etro
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Milan. Here, the model Ondria Hardin before (left) and after (right) makeup by Mark Carrasquillo and hair by James Pecis.

headline: The Wolf Sits Down Within the Flock
abstract: William Deresiewicz, who’s caused a stir in Ivy League circles with his book “Excellent Sheep,” is on a tour of those colleges to discuss his critique of them and his advice.
lead_paragraph: Many colleges assign common reading to their incoming freshmen, in the hopes that a book like “The Kite Runner” or “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks” will inspire uplifting campuswide conversation about ethics, values, justice and the good life.

headline: Have Questions About Fall Cooking?
abstract: Join New York Times Food editor Sam Sifton and reporter Melissa Clark for a Q. and A. about fall cooking on The New York Times Facebook Page.
lead_paragraph: Fall is quickly approaching, so what better way to welcome the season than by cooking a comforting, hearty meal, or indulging in a fall fruit dessert?

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Versace Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: And Then My Car Chimed In, After It Nudged Me in the Rear
abstract: Today’s automobiles are beeping and chirping at us, raising lights like stage curtains, playing little movies on our screens and serenading us with theme melodies.
lead_paragraph: Your car has something to tell you: Hello. Goodbye.

headline: New Script, but Still Playing the Heavy
abstract: The 2015 Escalade remains mostly unchanged, a cartoonish rear-drive barge laden with the pomp and pretension that used to be Cadillac’s mainstay.
lead_paragraph: We’re accustomed to product placements in movies, so when I took my 4-year-old son to see the animated “Planes: Fire and Rescue,” I wasn’t surprised to see a Cadillac Escalade on the screen. The character’s name, just to drive home the point, is Cad Spinner.

headline: Seized and Sold: The Marshal Holds a Muscle Car Auction
abstract: A valuable muscle car collection seized by the United States Marshals Service was auctioned in a few-frills affair in Lodi, N.J., netting about $2.5 million.
lead_paragraph: LODI, N.J. — The first car offered was a 1970 Ford Mustang, a rare 21,000-mile Boss 429 model in Grabber Green. Not that anyone could tell the color — the lighting, a splotchy mess of glare and shadow, was that bad.

headline: Coal Fades, So Electrics Get Cleaner
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: An analysis by the Union of Concerned Scientists showed that, for the majority of the country, electric vehicles are cleaner than even the most efficient hybrids.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as modern mass-market electric vehicles became available, skeptics began asking if they actually delivered an environmental benefit. After all, they argued, charging batteries from a generating plant that burns fossil fuels simply relocates the greenhouse gas emissions to someone else’s neighborhood.

headline: In a Daze, Reaching for Clarity
abstract: “More Than Just a Piece of Sky,” inspired by “Yentl,” the 1983 Barbra Streisand film, is part of the Queer New York International Arts Festival.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Perel has a show at the Chocolate Factory Theater, but she won’t get out of bed. It isn’t a case of indolence, exactly, or even fatigue. The bed is onstage, and her lying in it is the central conceit of “More Than Just a Piece of Sky.” The work, which I saw on Thursday, is supposed to be like a dream.

headline: Where Drums Glow, and Dreams Go Dark
abstract: The Miller Theater opened its new season on Thursday with a diverse program, including “Colombine’s Paradise Theater,” a fantasia featuring the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, the archetypal characters of commedia dell’arte have been mined so thoroughly by composers, dancers and dramatists that you would think that there is nothing fresh to uncover. Thankfully, the composer Amy Beth Kirsten did not feel this way.

headline: Two Couples, Refracted Through a Prism of Emotion
abstract: “Illusions,” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, examines the marriages and the friendship of two couples.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Viripaev, a well-regarded Russian playwright and screenwriter, apparently likes a challenge. He certainly sets himself one with “Illusions,” his New York debut, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. It’s as if he asked himself, “Can I create a play out of four actors who don’t act so much as recite, and who never address one another?”

headline: The Scots’ Decision: Let’s Stay British
abstract: Readers have varied reactions to the outcome.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Global Warming', 'Newspapers', 'Piracy at Sea', 'Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs']
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: The Weekly Wrap
abstract: Highlights from the past week on Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Times Insiders. Don’t miss this week’s highlights. Among them:

headline: Readers Respond: On Spanking and Switching
abstract: Readers wrote on race, righteousness and revulsion in comments on Michael Eric Dyson’s op-ed essay, “Punishment or Abuse.”
lead_paragraph: Race, righteousness and revulsion threaded through reader conversations about the lines between spankings, whoopings and abuse in responses to opinion pieces regarding NFL player Adrian Peterson’s indictment on child abuse charges.

headline: A Drug Mule for the Medicare Set
abstract: Some across-the-border negotiations provide an elderly woman’s prescriptions at a fraction of the cost at home.
lead_paragraph: My mother has many attributes, but athleticism has never been one of them. She always hesitates before stepping onto an escalator and rarely walks beyond our circular driveway. So when her physician ordered her onto a treadmill last winter, it hardly seemed surprising that her heartbeat jumped dramatically, even when the pace was not brisk. She is 80, after all.

headline: For the Red Bulls, Nearly Every Game Is a Must-Win
abstract: The Red Bulls have six games left in the M.L.S. regular season as they struggle to qualify for the postseason.
lead_paragraph: Last year at this time the Red Bulls were on their way to winning the first significant trophy in club history — the Supporters' Shield, which is given to the No. 1 team over all during Major League Soccer’s regular season.

headline: Gemma Ward’s Comeback, Michelle Obama’s Fashion Fete and Cara Delevingne’s Acting Gig
abstract: Plus, the return of Bill Blass, Audrey Hepburn’s modeling granddaughter and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: On Raising Children Outside of Marriage
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Parenting', 'Poverty']
abstract: Readers offer ways to reduce the number of one-parent children.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Black Lung Disease: The Mining Association’s View
abstract: The National Mining Association takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Paleo Lifestyle: The Way, Way, Way Back
abstract: Paleo has charged toward the mainstream, not just as a hugely popular diet, but also as a cave-man-inspired lifestyle that has spawned a fast-growing industry.
lead_paragraph: Which is more primal, hard cider or a strawberry margarita?

headline: A 10-Step Paleo Immersion Plan
abstract: Here are 10 steps to becoming a full-time Paleo-ite.
lead_paragraph: Want to turn back the clock 20,000 years? Here are 10 steps to becoming a full-time Paleo-ite.

headline: Josh Charles Almost Takes a (Comedic) Wrong Turn
abstract: A night out with the actor from the new movie “Bird People” included a meet-up with Amy Schumer and a cameo at the Slipper Room.
lead_paragraph: The actor Josh Charles was having drinks at the Derby on Orchard Street last Tuesday, on his way to a comedy show upstairs at the Slipper Room, when he spotted a blond woman walking outside whom he recognized.

headline: Themes for a March: Solar City, Natural Haven
abstract: Union members and artists applied the final touches on floats they will be showing at the People’s Climate March on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: When the Workers Arts Coalition, a group of union members and artists, gathered to plan their float for the People’s Climate March this Sunday, they had no shortage of design ideas: A sculpture of a human body decorated with different ecosystems? A performance piece with union guys singing in light-up vests? There was a robot, of course, said Jaime Lopez, an electrician and a founder of the group. “A ‘Climatron,’ ” Mr. Lopez said, “built out with all kinds of awesome weapons, fighting climate change.”

headline: Under Cover: Gary Hart, First of Many
abstract: While early concepts for this week’s cover included portraits of Hart in Red Rocks, Colo., where he announced his presidential candidacy in 1987, the art direction quickly shifted to include images of other politicians brought down by scandals.
lead_paragraph: In the Sept. 21 cover story, Matt Bai writes about Gary Hart, a onetime shoe-in for the Democratic presidential nomination whose political career came to an end when The Miami Herald reported that he was having an affair. While early cover concepts included portraits of Hart in Red Rocks, Colo., where he announced his presidential bid in 1987, the art direction quickly shifted to include images of other politicians brought down by scandals — because, as Gail Bichler, the magazine’s design director, points out, “Bai’s story really deals with the media crossing a line for the first time and making a politician’s personal indiscretions into news.”

headline: Vocabulary Renewed, a Dialogue Continues
abstract: Cuban music and jazz merged emphatically in a program that opened Jazz at Lincoln Center’s season on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Cuban music tends to involve a direct discussion: between voice and drums, between voice and chorus, between horn sections. Jazz tends to spread a discussion around, or build a hive of many discussions at once.

headline: A Band of Many Identities, but Always Furious
abstract: The progressive-rock band King Crimson kicked off a four-night stand at the Best Buy Theater on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The calm, professorial demeanor of Robert Fripp — King Crimson’s founder, guitarist, composer and core member since 1968 — may well be rock’s longest-running feat of misdirection. Starting the band’s four-night stand at Best Buy Theater on Thursday night, Mr. Fripp sat in the back row of King Crimson’s new seven-man lineup, facing the band more than the audience and directing most of his attention to his guitar throughout the concert.

headline: Amy Cuddy Takes a Stand
abstract: A successful pose has helped Ms. Cuddy become a leading voice on TED Talks.
lead_paragraph: The TED conference has made a star of many unlikely people, but perhaps no one more so than Amy Cuddy, a social psychologist and associate professor at Harvard Business School, whose talk promises personal transformation with nary a pill, cleanse or therapy bill.

headline: Making a Splash on Campus
abstract: In the university recreation center arms race, the latest idea is to turn a piece of campus into something approaching a water theme park.
lead_paragraph: When Louisiana State University surveyed students in 2009 to find out what they most wanted in their new recreation complex, one feature beat out even massage therapy: a lazy river.

headline: The Climax in a Tale of Green and Gritty
abstract: The third and final phase of the High Line is like a Rorschach test, signifying different things — about urban renewal, the environment, gentrification — to different people.
lead_paragraph: If the newest, last stretch of the High Line doesn’t make you fall in love with New York all over again, I really don’t know what to say. Phase 3 of the elevated park, which opens on Sunday, is a heartbreaker, swinging west on 30th Street from 10th Avenue toward the Hudson River, straight into drop-dead sunset views. It spills into a feral grove of big-tooth aspen trees on 34th Street.

headline: Fatal Flaws: Crisis in Auto Safety
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The New York Times has exposed missteps and delays by automakers and federal safety regulators in responding to deadly defects in automobiles during what became a record year for recalls.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has exposed missteps and delays by automakers and federal safety regulators in responding to deadly defects in automobiles during what became a record year for recalls.

headline: Walls of Photos Uniting Little Italy
abstract: An outdoor exhibit on the walls of a Little Italy landmark features a local photographer’s then-and-now images spanning 75 years.
lead_paragraph: An outdoor exhibit on the walls of a Little Italy landmark features a local photographer’s then-and-now images spanning 75 years.

headline: Chairman’s Team Wins Commonwealth Championship
abstract: The final of the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Team Championship in Glasgow last week was between Wales and the Chairman’s team.
lead_paragraph: The 48-board final of the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Team Championship in Glasgow last week was between Wales (Gary Jones, Tim Rees, Patrick Jourdain, Tony Ratcliff, John Salisbury and Mike Tedd) and the Chairman’s team (David Bakhshi, Andrew McIntosh, David Mossop and Paul Hackett and his twin sons, Jason and Justin, all from England).

headline: Torturer to the Stars
abstract: Sebastien Lagree’s Megaformer machines put the sweat in Pilates.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Sebastien Lagree knelt down and plucked a spring rigged up to an elliptical machine.
