He climbed aboard the Frankenstein-ian creation, one of many scattered about the Burbank, Calif., headquarters of his company, Lagree Fitness, which occupies a warehouse that brings to mind a mad scientist’s lab.

headline: Disrupting the Playground
abstract: To see technology’s future, look no further than nursery school.
lead_paragraph: “Car service app seeks to disrupt the disruptors with permits” — CNBC.com

headline: Lola Kirke: No Sisterly Shadow
abstract: As the younger sister of Jemima Kirke, a star of HBO’s “Girls,” Lola Kirke is having a breakout moment of her own as an actress.
lead_paragraph: AGE 23

headline: Evening Hours | Grand Dames
abstract: Celebrating Carnegie Hall and Angela Lansbury.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating Carnegie Hall and Angela Lansbury.

headline: Friday Night Music: Cheryl Wheeler, Summer Fly
abstract: Who wakes up at night to pull you in?
lead_paragraph: Now that I’m revisiting … I couldn’t find a live performance with good sound, so here’s the record performance. I think this was my favorite song of hers; resonates with a lot:

headline: The Birth of DoBro
abstract: “Work in Progress/In Progress Work,” an exhibition about the gentrification of Downtown Brooklyn, is on display through Sept. 28 at Photoville, an exhibition space in Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: Every day for the past few years, the photographer Jason John Würm has left his apartment in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, turned right at his front door and walked through Fulton Mall to the Jay Street subway station. He began to notice changes: old stores closing, new stores moving in, construction projects getting underway — your basic gentrification.

headline: North Korea Agrees to Weigh Steps on Human Rights
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: The North Korean government said it was willing to consider some recommendations by a United Nations commission, but rejected others.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — More than half a year after a landmark report by a United Nations commission of inquiry pinned responsibility for crimes against humanity on North Korea’s leadership, the North’s ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva said Friday that the North had accepted a wide range of recommendations for improving its human rights record.

headline: Fraud Charges for Strip-Club Owner Who Publishes a Westchester Newspaper
abstract: Selim Zherka (known as Sam), publisher of The Westchester Guardian and regular critic of county politicians, was denied bail after prosecutors portrayed him as a dangerous thug.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — He is the gadfly of Westchester County, the publisher of a free weekly newspaper who regularly rips into the county’s political establishment with shoot-from-the-hip accusations that embarrass their targets even if the details are not always on target.

headline: A Kingdom Still Whole, but Far From United
abstract: A debate over regional and national autonomy set off by Scotland’s failed referendum on independence has just begun, promising a constitutional shake-up in the United Kingdom.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Scotland chose decisively against independence on Thursday, but it was not a vote for the status quo in Britain.

headline: ‘Redskins’ Doomed Debate: Pizza Edition
abstract: A pizza chain in Washington offers a ‘Redskins’ sale. Six hours later, it apologizes.
lead_paragraph: I’ve lately taken to asking sports fans in Washington what they think is the over-under on how long the pro football team in Washington will be called the Redskins. One person this week told me five years — and someone overhearing the conversation immediately said, “Under.” On Friday, a political journalist whom I asked guessed one year.

headline: New Leader Likens Poland to ‘Reasonable Polish Woman’
abstract: The new prime minister’s comments were met with criticism that she had added to female stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s incoming prime minister, Ewa Kopacz, said Friday that she intends to take a somewhat different, more feminine approach to the job.

headline: Big Factories Go to Work on Biofuel
abstract: One commercial plant opened this month and two others are close, but technical and economic hurdles remain.
lead_paragraph: EMMETSBURG, Iowa — Charlie Kollasch, a farmer supplying raw material to a huge new ethanol factory here, stood inside a big red shed on his property, showing off the V-shaped metal frame studded with prongs that he and his son had installed on top of a flatbed truck.

headline: Sculptor and Photographer Shine Light on Relics
abstract: In a Riverhead exhibition, Michael Combs subverts the idea of “tradition,” fabricating irony from raw building materials, and in a Southampton exhibition, Ulf Skogsbergh romanticizes American tradition using digital technology.
lead_paragraph: The conceptual sculptor Michael Combs and the photographer Ulf Skosbergh both find poetry in the banal and express it by deconstructing and reconstructing history’s detritus. But their perspectives and processes are very different. Mr. Combs, who was born on Long Island, subverts the idea of “tradition,” fabricating irony from raw building materials. Mr. Skogsbergh, born in Sweden, romanticizes American tradition using digital technology.

headline: After Sweep, Australia Adds Security at Parliament
abstract: The move came a day after 15 people were detained in raids that the prime minister said were based on signs that militant Islamists were planning attacks.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Australian government intensified security at the national Parliament building on Friday, a day after the police detained 15 people in an operation that the prime minister said had been prompted by signs that militant Islamists were planning “demonstration executions.”

headline: Angus Lennie, Actor in ‘The Great Escape,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lennie was also known for his television work, which included episodes of “Doctor Who,” “Rumpole of the Bailey” and “The Saint,” as well as a long-running role in “Crossroads.”
lead_paragraph: Angus Lennie, a diminutive Scottish actor who played the persistent but ultimately despairing “tunnel man” known as the Mole in the 1963 prison-camp movie “The Great Escape,” died on Sunday in London. He was 84.

headline: F.D.A. Plans to Revise Food Safety Rules
abstract: To account for concerns raised by small brewers, cheese producers and others, the agency revised provisions for water testing, manure, compost and spent grains.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed changes to new rules that will govern food safety in the United States. In an effort to account for concerns raised by small brewers, artisanal cheese producers and other food producers, the agency revised provisions for water testing, as well as those on manure, compost and spent grains. Brewers had objected to rules requiring them to write food safety plans for the spent grain they sell as animal feed. The changes will be open to public comment for 75 days; final rules are to be issued in 2015.

headline: Fighting Enmity Against Sikhs With Art, Talks and Superhero Garb
abstract: Vishavjit Singh, one of several hundred thousand American Sikhs, has reclaimed his religion while trying to help others understand it.
lead_paragraph: ALFRED, N.Y. — Standing before his living-room mirror one morning in August 2001, Vishavjit Singh put his fumbling fingers to the task of wrapping on his turban for the first time in a decade. It slumped to one side. Then the creases were not crisp enough. Finally, he got it right, and headed to his job as a software engineer in suburban New York.

headline: Jeter’s Real Gift
abstract: Even though baseball is in love with numbers, numbers don’t really tell you what he meant.
lead_paragraph: During the chaos and excitement of awaiting our firstborn child, my wife and I were decorating the nursery. Our son was due to arrive in late June of 2008 and we planned to put his crib in a baseball-themed room. So, in a rare act of handiwork, I tapped my inner do-it-yourself to paint the vaulted ceiling, and helped my wife pinstripe the walls.

headline: A Soaring Debut for Alibaba
abstract: The Chinese Internet giant, which raised $21.8 billion in its stock sale, instantly became one of the biggest publicly traded technology companies in the world.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited public market debut of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet titan, did not disappoint on Friday, eclipsing every other company that has started to sell stock so far this year.

headline: In Brooklyn Park, Chants Extol Full Moon as Thefts Empty Bike Shed
abstract: The meditative chanting from a nearby sound bath may have provided cover for the thieves who made off with the mountain bikes.
lead_paragraph: A friend’s email to Andrew Kluger arrived on a cloudy afternoon two Mondays ago.

headline: The Hits Just Kept On Coming
abstract: “Dinner With the Boys,” making its world premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, is a hokey comedy that’s far more enjoyable than it really should be.
lead_paragraph: There’s no drum in sight. But you can almost hear the ba-dum-bum following the jokes in “Dinner With the Boys,” a hokey comedy that’s far more enjoyable than it really should be.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 1 Florida State will be missing Jameis Winston as they face No. 22 Clemson and Florida will take on No. 3 Alabama this weekend.
lead_paragraph: 22 CLEMSON at 1 FLORIDA STATE

headline: Cadillac Makes Big Plan to Woo Luxury Market
abstract: The automaker will produce a new, larger sedan meant to equal the offerings of German rivals and to polish its reputation, particularly in China.
lead_paragraph: General Motors’ struggling Cadillac division is hoping that bigger is better.

headline: One Big Unhappy Economy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Editorials', 'Productivity']
abstract: Global growth that is “job-rich and inclusive” is possible in theory; politically, not so much.
lead_paragraph: Unhappy economies, it turns out, are all unhappy in the same way. A recent report on job markets globally showed that too few jobs are being created worldwide, and even fewer good jobs are. Wages are flat or falling in all major economies as corporate profits claim an increasing share of productivity gains.

headline: The Met Opera Stands Firm
keywords: ['Opera', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Editorials', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A decision to go forward with a controversial production is a win for the principle of artistic freedom.
lead_paragraph: True to its artistic mission, the Metropolitan Opera remains firmly committed to presenting “The Death of Klinghoffer,” the widely praised opera that has drawn the scorn of protesters who plan to demonstrate outside the Met’s season opening on Monday at Lincoln Center. The Met’s board of directors and Peter Gelb, its general manager, are entirely correct in insisting the opera must proceed as planned next month.

headline: Hurricane Watch in the Rockaways
abstract: The surfing community in this Sandy-battered enclave is flourishing, happy with the upside of another hurricane season.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the hurricane season, an interesting breed of aquatic New Yorkers — surfers — are religiously scrolling apps for the most promising waves. They could not resist dropping by Rockaway Beach this week to ride the remnants of Hurricane Edouard pounding the Atlantic beachfront of Queens. “We’re rooting for Edouard — up to a point,” said Conrad Karl, an obsessive surfer who is happy to frolic at a hurricane’s farther edges.

headline: Women Allege Harassment and Abuse on Forest Service Firefighting Crews
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A complaint alleges that the agency failed to stop workplace harassment and sexual abuse and retaliated against women who reported it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Current and former female firefighters of the United States Forest Service have filed a complaint with the Department of Agriculture alleging that they suffered job discrimination, harassment and sexual abuse at the hands of male co-workers and that top agency officials failed to stop it.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Stardust
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Young people obsessed with fashion displayed wildly eccentric and creative styles of dress at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Young people obsessed with fashion displayed wildly eccentric and creative styles of dress at New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Peaceful Decision in Scotland, but Misery Elsewhere
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Epidemics', 'Football', 'Referendums', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: If only all of the news we follow could be as satisfying as the referendum on Scottish independence.
lead_paragraph: If only all of the news we follow could be as satisfying as the referendum on Scottish independence!

headline: Fleeing Gaza, Only to Face Treachery and Disaster at Sea
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A Gazan’s son is among the hundreds missing after a migrant ship sank off Malta, and his plight illustrates the risks facing Palestinians seeking illegal passage to Europe.
lead_paragraph: ABASSAN, Gaza Strip — Samir Asfour, 57, held a mobile phone that never stopped ringing in one hand, a cigarette in the other. His Palestinian passport was sticking out of the chest pocket of his white jalabiya.

headline: Milan Shows So Good, Let’s See Them Again
abstract: Fashion shows are expensive and brief. So why not double the fun?
lead_paragraph: Fashion shows are expensive and brief. So why not double the fun?

headline: Republicans Switch Firm Handling Obama Suit
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A lawyer withdrew from the case, reportedly under pressure from colleagues concerned about its political aspects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Friday replaced the firm handling their lawsuit against President Obama after the lawyer representing them pulled out over what was said to be political backlash among his colleagues at the firm, Baker Hostetler.

headline: Roger Goodell Vows to Change N.F.L.
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell apologized for his role in poor decision-making surrounding domestic violence cases and promised a revamped personal conduct policy to address future cases.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell apologized for his role in poor decision-making surrounding domestic violence cases and promised a revamped personal conduct policy to address future cases.

headline: Sierra Leone’s Aggressive Attack on Ebola
abstract: Sierra Leone imposed a three-day national lockdown, ordering people off the streets and into their homes in an effort to stamp out the deadly disease.
lead_paragraph: Sierra Leone imposed a three-day national lockdown, ordering people off the streets and into their homes in an effort to stamp out the deadly disease.

headline: Beloved Vendor of Ices in South Bronx Is Killed
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Alfredo Thiebaud, founder of Delicioso Coco Helado, which sells tropical-flavored summertime treats from pushcarts, was pinned on the ground by an electric gate.
lead_paragraph: Alfredo Thiebaud sold creamy coconut ice in paper cups on the streets of the South Bronx in the 1970s, undeterred by the crime and poverty that drove other people away. He built a fleet of pushcarts, all doling out tropical flavors that became synonymous with summertime and homelands far away.

headline: The Gandhis and Kings of Our Time
abstract: In Bethel, an exhibition, on loan from the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Justice and Human Rights in Washington, pays homage to activists photographed by Eddie Adams.
lead_paragraph: All but one of the quotations painted on the walls at the Museum at Bethel Woods Center for the Arts for an exhibition of photographs of human rights activists are from Robert F. Kennedy.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 19, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Democrats Pin Senate Hopes on a Kansan
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The Senate race in Kansas has become the most scrutinized contest in the country, with Republicans scrambling to protect the incumbent and Democrats putting their hopes on an independent.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The Senate race in Kansas may suddenly be the most crucial contest in the country. Republicans are scrambling to protect a longtime incumbent. Bob Dole is back on the campaign trail. The state’s Democrats have no candidate and are trying to say as little about that as possible. And a 45-year-old investor from suburban Kansas City may hold the key to control of the Senate in January.

headline: Exercising the Right to Rant
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Insider Trading', 'Taxation', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: Never to worry! Our elected representatives have averted a government shutdown by decreeing that we will keep spending whatever it is we’ve been spending for a while.
lead_paragraph: Congress is gone. But not forgotten.

headline: Testimony in Etan Patz Case on Handling of Suspect
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Interrogations', 'Missing Persons', 'Confessions']
abstract: A defense lawyer for Pedro Hernandez tried to elicit testimony on Friday that detectives who interrogated a man suspected of killing Patz gently steered him to a confession, using expressions of sympathy, appeals to his religion and even a group hug.
lead_paragraph: A defense lawyer tried to elicit testimony on Friday that detectives who interrogated a man suspected of killing Etan Patz in 1979 gently steered him to a confession, using expressions of sympathy, appeals to his religion and even a group hug.

headline: Hospitals in Kashmir Struggle After Flooding, Deepening a Health Crisis
abstract: Nearly two weeks after heavy flooding, many hospitals in the region are barely functioning and infectious waters have yet to recede.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — When the floodwaters of the Jhelum River rushed over the gates of the G. B. Pant Hospital, the top pediatric hospital here, on Sept. 6, the lights were the first to go. Half an hour later, the generators on the ground floor were drowned in water. Minutes after that, the oxygen tank that supplied air to the ventilators for newborns shut down.

headline: But Will the Cows Like It?
abstract: “The Farm Project 2014” in Garrison presents 51 objects and installations, including brightly painted metal assemblages, 3D-printed creatures and massive stone constructions.
lead_paragraph: The rolling hills of the 140-acre Saunders Farm are once again populated not only by Black Angus cattle and Queen Anne’s lace, but also by sculptures. “The Farm Project 2014” presents 51 objects and installations, including brightly painted metal assemblages, 3D-printed creatures and massive stone constructions. Small ceramic heads clustered on a stone wall seem animated in conversation. In a shaded area, a chair is poised in the limbs of a tree.

headline: Clayton Kershaw Keeps Aiming for New Heights
abstract: The Dodgers’ star is poised to lead the major leagues in earned run average for the fourth season in a row, something no pitcher has done.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — There has been no doubt, for a while now, that Clayton Kershaw is the best pitcher in baseball. Dan Haren was aware of this when he joined the Los Angeles Dodgers this spring after more than a decade with other teams. But Haren still had to be reminded of just what he was about to witness.

headline: Turkish President’s Allies Increasing Pressure on Times and Reporter
abstract: The New York Times and one of its Istanbul correspondents have been denounced with growing furor in reaction to an article and photograph about the recruitment of fighters in Turkey by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s president and his supporters have been denouncing The New York Times and one of its Istanbul correspondents with growing furor for the past three days, reacting to an article and photograph about the recruitment of fighters in Turkey by the Islamic State, the militant group that has seized parts of neighboring Iraq and Syria.

headline: In Domestic Violence Cases, N.F.L. Has a History of Lenience
abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell promised stiff discipline for players, but the league’s response to domestic abuse charges has been inconsistent.
lead_paragraph: On April 10, 2007, after more than 50 National Football League players had been arrested in the previous football season, Commissioner Roger Goodell was widely hailed for instituting a newly stringent personal conduct policy. Mr. Goodell threatened to banish players for off-the-field transgressions and installed himself as the judge and jury presiding over every case.

headline: Omnipresence: New Stop-and-Frisk?
abstract: In the projects of Brownsville, Brooklyn, the New York Police Department’s strategy, Omnipresence, is what it says. Despite promises of change, to some it feels like stop-and-frisk by another name.
lead_paragraph: In the projects of Brownsville, Brooklyn, the New York Police Department’s strategy, Omnipresence, is what it says. Despite promises of change, to some it feels like stop-and-frisk by another name.

headline: In Death, Florida Family Reveals a Spiral of Domestic Abuse
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Domestic Violence', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: Extreme poverty, drug addiction and debt plagued the Spirit family for years before, the police said, Don C. Spirit killed his daughter, six grandchildren and himself on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BELL, Fla. — Sarah L. Spirit was 22 years old and eight months pregnant with her fourth child when she called the police in desperation: Her father was violent, she was afraid of him, and she had nowhere to go.

headline: Share Your Story of Detroit
abstract: New York Times journalists would like to hear from current, former and new residents of Detroit about their experiences living in the city.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists would like to hear from current, former and new residents of Detroit about their experiences living in the city.

headline: U.S. Hopes Face-Saving Plan Offers a Path to a Nuclear Pact With Iran
abstract: Before the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, negotiators have discussed a plan to remove the pipes that connect Iran’s nuclear centrifuges.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, the United States has shown considerable ingenuity in its effort to slow Iran’s production of nuclear fuel: It has used sabotage, cyberattacks and creative economic sanctions.

headline: Looking Back to Gain a Fresh Perspective
abstract: A musical confrontation with his past has changed Wayne Escoffery, a tenor saxophonist from New Haven, according to those who know him well.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Escoffery is a big man with a small earring and a face caught between a smile and a scowl — except, that is, when his lips are fit snugly around the mouthpiece of his tenor saxophone, summoning strikingly soulful sounds from it.

headline: Boxing Is in Elijah Holyfield’s Blood, but Football Is in His Future
abstract: Evander Holyfield’s son Elijah has emerged as a highly recruited running back coveted by many of the nation’s top programs.
lead_paragraph: CLARKSTON, Ga. — The public address announcer’s setup for the opening kickoff — “back for Woodward Academy, No. 13, Elijah Holyfield” — was still echoing through the stadium Friday when the ball descended into the player’s midsection.

headline: Life’s Good
abstract: Erik Agard’s Saturday puzzle will challenge you.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Man, it’s tough out there for a solver, especially on a Saturday. You scan the clues — more than once — hoping to find even one Fill in the Blank or gimme, and sometimes you think you know what should be written in the grid, but you really don’t, do you? You wrote CAD instead of CUR at 40 Down too, didn’t you? Not to worry; it’s Saturday. It’s O.K. for our brains to be at half-mast.

headline: Indonesians, Optimistic About New President, Spend Freely
abstract: Any problems that may lie ahead, among them poverty and corruption, have failed to dent Indonesians’ confidence and willingness to splurge.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia is saddled with endemic corruption, poverty and shoddy infrastructure. Yet its consumers are among the world’s most optimistic, hopeful that a new government will lift the fortunes of the fourth-most-populous nation and put the economy on a par with emerging powerhouses like China and Brazil.

headline: ‘Stop-and-Frisk’ Ebbs, but Still Hangs Over Brooklyn Lives
abstract: In the Brownsville neighborhood of Brooklyn, the police still maintain a heavy presence, and residents are wary of drawing their attention even in innocuous daily actions.
lead_paragraph: In the housing projects of eastern Brooklyn, some young men no longer clasp hands when greeting each other, they say, fearful that their grasp might be mistaken for a drug deal and invite a search by the police. Friends heading to the bodega sometimes split up, worried that walking in a group will attract police attention.

headline: At U.N., Kerry Thanks Other Nations for Their Support in Fighting Islamic State
abstract: In drumming up support in the fight against a terrorist group, the secretary of state suggested that Iran had a role to play.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday expressed gratitude to a host of allies for bolstering the American-led campaign against terrorist groups in Iraq and Syria, singling out the French for airstrikes and Saudi clerics for condemning the Islamic State as an “order of Satan.”

headline: Ex-Employees Say Home Depot Left Data Vulnerable
abstract: Before a major data breach, Home Depot was slow to raise its defenses against hackers despite alarms from security experts as far back as 2008.
lead_paragraph: The risks were clear to computer experts inside Home Depot: The home improvement chain, they warned for years, might be easy prey for hackers.

headline: Getting It Wrong
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Football', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Speaking after one of the N.F.L.’s worst weeks, Roger Goodell, the league’s commissioner, ended up saying what he has already said before.
lead_paragraph: I turned on ESPN about 15 minutes before Roger Goodell’s Friday afternoon news conference. There was a round table of analysts and reporters, led by Bob Ley, the journalist who covers the serious side of sports for the network. If I hadn’t known better, I would have thought they were prepping for a coming news conference by a politician in trouble rather than the commissioner of the National Football League.

headline: Judge Questions Plea Deal With Man Tied to Lethal Qaeda Bombings
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: In Manhattan federal court, Lewis A. Kaplan noted that Adel Abdul Bary, who passed messages for Osama bin Laden, was initially charged with multiple murder counts.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian terrorism defendant pleaded guilty in Manhattan on Friday to charges that he had helped Osama bin Laden pass messages that claimed responsibility for the deadly 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa and that issued new threats.

headline: Where Apples Are the Entertainment in New Jersey
abstract: A look at the pick-your-own-apples experience at Phillips Farms in Milford, Sun High Orchards in Randolph and Windy Brow Farms in Newton.
lead_paragraph: Visitors who come to pick apples at Phillips Farms in Milford won’t find a petting zoo, corn maze or giant inflatable moon bounce.

headline: With John Tavares Back, Islanders Are Eager for Season
abstract: The Islanders and their captain, Tavares, opened training camp Friday for what will be their last season in Nassau County before a move to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: There is much to wonder about the Islanders’ coming season. The team’s surplus of forwards, two new goaltenders and the return of a healthy captain, John Tavares, will all bear watching.

headline: Group to Sue After M.T.A. Rejects Ad That Refers to Muslims Killing Jews
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Transit Systems', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Palestinians', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The American Freedom Defense Initiative proposed an ad for New York City buses that the transportation agency said “would imminently incite or provoke violence.”
lead_paragraph: A pro-Israel group behind a public transit advertisement that refers to Muslims killing Jews plans to sue the Metropolitan Transportation Authority after the agency rejected the ad. The authority said the ad would be seen as a call to violence against Jews amid turmoil in the Middle East and security concerns in New York.

headline: The Horses in Central Park Are to Show, Not Work
abstract: Equestrians competing in a four-day competition in New York City include the daughters of former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Bruce Springsteen.
lead_paragraph: New York City remains divided between those who would have carriage horses trot the streets and those who would rather send them out to pasture. But on Friday night, the city’s greenest paddock — Central Park — was nevertheless filled with horses, though of a very different sort than those hired nearby on West 59th Street.

headline: Artisanal Effort at a Chain Hotel
abstract: As the food revolution has spread, many hotel chains now pay serious attention to serving good, often artisanal and interesting food. Such is the story at Parallel Post, the restaurant at the Trumbull Marriott.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that hotel dining rooms were scorned by gourmets, but in the past 20 years or so, as the food revolution has spread across the country, many hotel chains have joined in and now pay serious attention to serving good, often artisanal and interesting food.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 20, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “No open palm anymore; we just do elbows.”

headline: Breaking Silence, but Offering Little
abstract: Roger Goodell emerged in public on Friday, but in his news conference he offered little in the way of enlightenment or information.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Commissioner Roger Goodell should have extended his public silence about the domestic violence crisis that has been roiling the N.F.L.

headline: Guinter Kahn, Inventor of Baldness Remedy, Dies at 80
abstract: After a long, fierce legal battle, Dr. Kahn gained recognition for helping discover a baldness remedy that is sold under the brand name Rogaine.
lead_paragraph: Guinter Kahn liked to say that there had always been three things in history that could never get a patent: a divining rod, a perpetual motion machine and anything to grow hair. He was wrong about the last one.

headline: Seafood With New England Flavor
abstract: Subtitled Oyster Bar & Grill, Ocean House, in Croton-on-Hudson, has offerings including a variety of oysters and the latest catch, served in a small, spare space reminiscent of the New England shore.
lead_paragraph: Despite its out-of-the-way location and its history as a funky diner, the Ocean House restaurant has transformed its deficits, and without nets and ships’ wheels. Colonial-blue trim suggests an old fisherman’s cottage on a briny New England shore. But it’s the Hudson River that runs beyond the front door of Ocean House in Croton-on-Hudson.

headline: Part of the Berlin Wall Comes Down, Again
abstract: Five segments of the concrete border that once divided Berlin have been on display at East 53rd Street in Manhattan since 1990. But recently, they vanished.
lead_paragraph: The Berlin Wall has come down again.

headline: Ellsbury Shows His Worth, and His Fragility, to the Yanks
abstract: Jacoby Ellsbury doubled, homered and scored twice, but left the game in the fourth inning with a hamstring strain as the Yankees struggled to stay in the playoff race.
lead_paragraph: Jacoby Ellsbury showcased the type of talent on Friday that the Yankees expected of him when he signed for more than $150 million in the off-season: doubling, homering, scoring twice, manning center field and using his speed to prompt an error on a throw to first base that allowed a crucial run to score.

headline: A Former Fish Joint Cleans Up
abstract: The Salivar’s Restaurant in Montauk moved and got a makeover, even a gussied-up new name (Clam and Chowder House at Salivar’s Dock), but lost some of its scruffy charm.
lead_paragraph: Back in the day, Salivar’s Restaurant in Montauk was a typical dockside fishermen’s joint. The kind of place where a band of tattooed scalawags would jostle in after a three-day tuna hunt, throw back a few bushels of clam strips and the better part of a keg of Old Milwaukee, and then retire to the pool table, above which loomed the stuffed head of a great white shark.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Recap:  Sexual Politics  and the Early-20th-Century Woman
abstract: Do the early-20th-century men hold all the cards?

headline: Jameis Winston Out for Entire Game as Florida State Extends Ban
abstract: Initially suspended for the first half against No. 22 Clemson, the Heisman-winning quarterback will now sit the entire game for making an obscene comment in the student union.
lead_paragraph: Florida State reversed course late Friday, suspending quarterback Jameis Winston for the whole game, instead of the first half, against No. 22 Clemson on Saturday night.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (HBO) THE SECRET LIFE OF WALTER MITTY (2013) Ben Stiller, who also directed this adaptation of the James Thurber short story, stars as Walter, a dutiful drone in the photography department of Life magazine who finds himself on a caper far beyond his wildest imagination when the negative for the publication’s final print edition goes missing. Kristen Wiig plays the crinkly-nosed co-worker on whom Walter has a crush; Adam Scott is the leader of the new tech-jerk bosses who have Walter’s job on the line. And Sean Penn is the mysterious photographer behind Walter’s travels to Iceland, Afghanistan and other stunning far-off places. “Though it is a celebration of modesty, there is also quite a lot of vanity in ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. There is also a contradiction: “An ordinary fellow should not have to be quite so special to win our admiration. And this version of Walter Mitty undermines some of the democratic whimsy that has made his story such an appealing and durable modern myth. He used to be one of us: a self-deluded dreamer charmed by his unruly creative powers, a willing prisoner of his appetite for escapism. But now our identification gives way to envy, and he is another one of those enchanted people the rest of us can only dream of becoming.” The movie is followed at 9 by “On the Run Tour: Beyoncé and Jay Z,” a concert special filmed on Sept. 12 and 13 at the Stade de France, near Paris, featuring performances of more than 40 songs during the couple’s only stop outside North America on the tour.

headline: Milan Fashion Week Morning Report, Day 4
abstract: Tomas Maier for Bottega Veneta, maker of those very subtle, extremely expensive woven purses, shows at 9 a.m.
lead_paragraph: To put things in sports terms (sort of) in case you clicked here by mistake: Today the two opposing teams of Italian fashion — colorful flamboyance and understated tailoring — clash helmets on the gridiron.

headline: Breach Prompts Review of White House Security
abstract: After a Texas man with a knife made it into the entrance of the first family’s residence, the Secret Service said there would be increased patrols and surveillance while the episode was scrutinized.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The director of the Secret Service ordered an internal review of its security procedures around the White House after a man armed with a knife who jumped the fence at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue on Friday night managed to make his way through the front door of President Obama’s home before being stopped, officials said Saturday.

headline: Corrections: September 20, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Intruder Gets Through White House Doors Before Arrest
abstract: Omar J. Gonzalez, 42, of Copperas Cove, Tex., was arrested after jumping the White House fence and making it through the North Portico doors on Friday night, the Secret Service said.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man who jumped the White House fence made it through the North Portico doors on Friday night before being apprehended, the Secret Service said. The intruder, Omar J. Gonzalez, 42, of Copperas Cove, Tex., was arrested and taken to George Washington University Hospital after complaining of chest pains, said Ed Donovan, a Secret Service spokesman. None of the Obamas were home when the security breach occurred, about 7:20 p.m., but White House staff members were evacuated as a precaution, Mr. Donovan said. Mr. Gonzalez was not armed, he added, and the incident was being reviewed.

headline: Indie-Rock Antiheroes Get a Stadium Singing Along
abstract: The reconstituted Replacements kicked up a solid ruckus Friday night, as a fervent crowd took its non-hit oldies to heart.
lead_paragraph: Better late than never, in a way. More than 20 years after the Replacements initially broke up, leaving behind a fervent cult following but disappointing album sales, the reconstituted band had a stadium singing along on Friday night. Yes, Forest Hills Stadium is a fairly small stadium. But the crowd’s voices were loud through both verses and choruses, song after song.

headline: Turkey Obtains Release of Hostages Held in Iraq
abstract: Forty-nine hostages held by Islamic State militants were returned to Turkey on Saturday after what Turkey said was a covert operation led by its intelligence agency.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey secured the release of 49 hostages who had been held for more than three months in Iraq by the jihadists of the Islamic State on Saturday, marking a moment of joy for Turkey while raising questions about how it had managed to set them free.

headline: Afghan Presidential Rivals Finally Agree on Power-Sharing Deal
abstract: In negotiations over the disputed presidential election, Abdullah Abdullah, who is widely expected to lose, has insisted that the count not be made public.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The two candidates for president of Afghanistan have agreed on a power-sharing deal that will give the losing candidate substantial influence in the next government, initialing the American-brokered deal Saturday night and promising to sign it at a formal ceremony on Sunday.

headline: Analytics: What Readers Thought About Bill Gates’s Idea For a History Curriculum
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin’s article on Bill Gates’s support for a new “Big History” curriculum inspired debate online about his qualifications. Here’s what readers said.
lead_paragraph: The following graphic appears on the Reply All page in the Sept. 21 issue of the magazine.

headline: Making Big Data Think Bigger
abstract: Data-driven management has so far focused mostly on increasing efficiency and productivity, but new graphic tools aim to help executives set a strategic course.
lead_paragraph: Big-data management promises a significant shift in the way decisions are made across the economy. Abundant new sources of data from the web, sensors and smartphones, mined for patterns and insights by smart software, will mean that more and more decisions will be based on data and analysis rather than experience and intuition.

headline: Pope Sets Tone in U.S. by Naming Inclusive Prelate as Chicago Archbishop
abstract: Bishop Blase J. Cupich of Spokane, Wash., has been chairman of the bishops’ committee responding to the sexual abuse crisis, and has been unusually forthright in criticizing the church’s record on abuse.
lead_paragraph: In his first major appointment in the United States, Pope Francis named Bishop Blase J. Cupich of Spokane, Wash., on Saturday to be the next archbishop of Chicago, replacing a combative conservative with a prelate whose pastoral approach to upholding church doctrine is more in keeping with the pope’s inclusive tone.

abstract: They agreed to extend the walkout until at least Friday and asked to meet with France’s prime minister to make their case.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly a week after beginning a strike to protest Air France-KLM’s new European strategy, the airline’s French pilots voted on Saturday to extend their walkout until at least Friday and asked to meet with France’s prime minister to make their case against the plan.

headline: To Win Back Older Voters, Democrats Talk Up Social Security
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Medicare', 'Social Security (US)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Looking to voters 65 and older who have been the party’s weak spot and who reliably turn out in midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are stepping up their appeals to older voters in the final stretch before the midterm elections, spurred by polls showing the party has regained some support lost in the Obama years. The question is whether they can narrow the gap with Republicans enough to offset their broader disadvantages given widespread dissatisfaction with President Obama.

headline: Chinese Tourists Find a Movable Feast Best Left Behind
