abstract: The French capital is the No. 1 destination in Europe for Chinese tourists, but many have unrealistic expectations of the city.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Before arriving in the French capital, Wu Shuyun, a 56-year-old Chinese housewife, imagined Paris to be like a pristine film set for a romantic love story, picturing herself as a glamorous princess surrounded by elegant Parisians, decked out, perhaps, in Chanel.

headline: Twists and Ties of Fabric Liven Up Simple Silhouettes
abstract: For spring 2015, designers make a statement with the humble knot.
lead_paragraph: Trending on spring 2015 runways: knotted garments. We saw it first in New York at The Row, where Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen turned sleek silhouettes into interesting shapes with the addition of knots or crossed lengths of fabric in either the front or the back of dresses and shirts. Then in Milan, the Sportmax collection was all about tied-up skirts, trousers and sarong-like dresses. And again today in Milan, almost all the looks in Bottega Veneta’s laid-back, luxurious collection — loose trenches and cashmere leggings — were cinched at the waist. The styling was at its best in its most exaggerated form: a hooded sweatshirt with an oversize knot in the middle that looked almost like a corsage.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: A Busy Border in Iraqi Kurdistan
abstract: Thousands move daily across the 650-mile border that now separates Kurdistan and territory controlled by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Thousands move daily across the 650-mile border that now separates Kurdistan and territory controlled by the Islamic State.

headline: Back and Forth, Wearily, Across the ISIS Border
abstract: Over the course of each day, thousands journey between Iraqi Kurdistan and the territory under the control of the extremist militants of the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: MAKTAB KHALID, Iraq — Around 6 each morning, with the sun already a threat, an officer at a security checkpoint here in northern Iraq rolls back the concertina wire just enough to allow travelers to pass one at a time.

headline: Variety: An Acrostic That Will Make You Tut
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon offer an acrostic that might make you tut.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, if there’s one thing I learned from today’s acrostic, it’s that I need to memorize how to spell “ORESTEIA.” That one always confuses me.

headline: Jil Sander: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Suspicions Run Deep in Iraq That C.I.A. and the Islamic State Are United
abstract: A deputy prime minister publicly blamed the agency for creating the extremist group, and interviews suggested that most of the few thousand people at a demonstration Saturday subscribed to the same theory.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The United States has conducted an escalating campaign of deadly airstrikes against the extremists of the Islamic State for more than a month. But that appears to have done little to tamp down the conspiracy theories still circulating from the streets of Baghdad to the highest levels of Iraqi government that the C.I.A. is secretly behind the same extremists that it is now attacking.

headline: Explosion Rocks Eastern Ukraine Hours After an Amended Cease-Fire Is Signed
abstract: A huge explosion shattered the stillness of an early fall morning in Donetsk, illustrating the fragility of a cease-fire agreed upon two weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — A giant explosion shattered the stillness of an early fall morning here just hours after Ukraine and pro-Russian rebels signed the latest version of their cease-fire accord, illustrating the fragility of a truce agreed upon two weeks ago.

headline: Catching Up With an Old Hand
abstract: The pianist Kirk Lightsey, a first-tier fixture on the New York jazz scene, will headline at the Village Vanguard in a rare performance in the city.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when the pianist Kirk Lightsey was a first-tier fixture on the New York jazz scene, at Greenwich Village clubs like Bradley’s and Sweet Basil. That time spanned roughly a decade, beginning with his arrival in the early 1980s and ending with his abrupt move to Paris in 1992. He has led a productive career in Europe since then, but his nearly total avoidance of New York has made him seem like that rarest of species: the one that got away.

headline: New Zealand’s Ruling National Party Is Re-elected
abstract: The party of Prime Minister John Key cruised to victory with a historic level of support, winning 48 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — The dominant center-right National Party was re-elected on Saturday to a third term in government with a historic level of support, despite an election campaign tainted by political scandals and resignations.

headline: U.N. Reports Yemen Deal With Rebels
abstract: Fighting between the transitional government and Shiite rebels continued Saturday in the streets of the capital, Sana
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The special adviser to the United Nations on Yemen said late Saturday night that the government had agreed to a deal with a rebel group to end weeks of protests and days of violence around the capital.

headline: U.S. Seeks Ryder Cup Miracle of Its Own
abstract: Two years after their Ryder Cup unraveling at Medinah Country Club, the American team keeps looking for reasons to believe it can beat a stacked team from Europe.
lead_paragraph: Two years after its Ryder Cup unraveling at Medinah Country Club, the United States team keeps looking for reasons to believe in a brighter day.

headline: Emilio Pucci’s Spring 2015 Collection at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The latest women’s collection from Emilio Pucci at Milan Fashion Week. [See the live stream.]

headline: The Sock-and-Shoe Combo Gets an Upgrade at Jil Sander
abstract: For spring 2015, Rodolfo Paglialunga updated minimalist basics — even socks, which are made with soft, nappa leather.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: In Ruins of Ukrainian Town, Residents Crave Food, Water and Peace
abstract: As residents began repairing the damage in Luhansk and taking stock of the calamity around them, many said they no longer cared about the politics that caused it all.
lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — Rebel fighters picked their way through the debris of this city’s airport last week, pointing out the bloodstained stretchers and the corpse of a Ukrainian soldier tangled in the wreck of a burned vehicle. The battle for control of the city of Luhansk, one of the most ferocious of the six-month conflict in southeastern Ukraine, had left the airport and surrounding villages in ruins.

headline: Breaking Through the Fog of San Francisco’s Weather Reputation
abstract: When considering the temperature ranges in cities across the country, San Francisco doesn’t seem so extraordinary.
lead_paragraph: The first thing visitors in San Francisco learn: Wear layers.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Jil Sander Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Modest Drop Earrings Shine for Spring 2015
abstract: On the runway, designers lean away from flashy, statement earrings in favor of classic motifs and simpler designs.
lead_paragraph: The singular statement earring is all the rage this season; but come next spring, expect to resume wearing the complete pair again. On spring 2015 runways, big, flashy sets have given way to smaller, more delicate drop earrings. In New York, the Altuzarra designers enhanced their ultrafeminine collection with classic cameo drop earrings. Even Miuccia Prada, who is known for her love of statement jewels, scaled back the bling and instead sent modest clusters of crystals down the runway on models’ ears. And today at Bottega, the designer Tomas Maier complemented his cozy collection with small Southwest-inspired turquoise earrings.

headline: A Writerly Chill at Jeff Bezos’ Campfire
abstract: Every fall, Jeff Bezos of Amazon hosts a literary weekend on condition that writers not discuss the event. Now Amazon’s battle with Hachette is sapping some of the good will.
lead_paragraph: When Jeff Bezos tells writers to keep quiet, they obey.

headline: After Blazing Trail, Li Na Exits and Leaves a Gap
abstract: Li’s retirement deprives the WTA of the opportunity to create a genuine rivalry at the top, and it also raises questions about the evolution of the sport in China.
lead_paragraph: Despite all of her evident athletic talent and all of her personal sacrifices, Li Na was a late bloomer in tennis, which is one reason — but only one reason — it feels as if she retired too soon.

headline: A Casual, No-Nonsense Updo at Bottega Veneta
abstract: The label invites women to come as they are, with everyday hair, and step into its spring 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: For spring 2015, designers seem to invite women to “come as you are” with the messy, everyday hairstyles they’ve sent down the runway. At Bottega Veneta today, imperfect updos were a welcome break from the long, tousled, parted-down-the-middle waves trending down the runway. With a little length peeking out of the back, and strands of hair pulled out around the face, it’s a style any woman can pull off (if they don’t already) with little-to-no effort.

headline: On Cue, the Cardinals Rise in September
abstract: For five months, St. Louis never held first place alone, but when the Milwaukee Brewers went into a skid, the Cardinals were there.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The monthly records of the St. Louis Cardinals read like the yearly win-loss marks of a solid, dependable starting pitcher:

headline: A Florida Race Strains Wallets and Loyalties
abstract: The contest for governor between Rick Scott, the incumbent, and Charlie Crist, who switched parties, is costing tens of millions of dollars and disorienting voters.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When Bill Clinton attended a recent campaign rally for his party’s candidate for governor here, he whipped up the crowd with keystone Democratic issues — higher wages, better-funded schools and affordable health care.

headline: Farewell, Rob Ford
abstract: Why Toronto will secretly miss its mayor.
lead_paragraph: IN 1950 the mayor of Toronto, the Hon. Hiram E. McCallum, objected to the display of a painting in an art exhibit at the Canadian National Exhibition. “Sailors and Floozies” had outraged the mayor and other moral guardians of the city by depicting seamen cavorting with strumpets.

headline: Affordable Housing for Retirees
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Elderly', 'Baby Boomers', 'Editorials', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: The graying of the baby boomers means many more people are at risk of homelessness, and governments at all levels are poorly prepared to help.
lead_paragraph: The population explosion among retirement-age Americans that demographers have long predicted has arrived. The number of adults 50 and over is expected to reach 132 million by 2030, an increase from 2000 of more than 70 percent. By that time, one in five citizens will be 65 or older.

headline: Katie Paterson
abstract: A Scottish conceptual artist on the referendum, fossil hunting and bouncing Beethoven off the moon.
lead_paragraph: Katie Paterson is a Scottish conceptual artist. Her most recent work is “Future Library” — 1,000 seedlings growing in a Norwegian forest, which will be cut down in 100 years and made into previously unpublished books.

headline: The Unlikeliest of Coalitions
abstract: Sectarian tensions, mistrust and other obstacles make organizing an alliance a lot like solving a Rubik’s Cube.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration needs to bring together a reliable international coalition as the backbone of its campaign to defeat the Islamic State, the Sunni extremist group that controls large parts of Iraq and Syria. So far, more than 40 countries have offered to help, and none are more important than the Sunni Muslim countries that are needed to give legitimacy to the American-led effort.

headline: Helping the Needy
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Poverty', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Parenting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Readers discuss an article by Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn on how to fight poverty.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss an article by Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn on how to fight poverty.

headline: Two Redheaded Strangers
abstract: On the Honeysuckle Rose, Willie and Maureen talk pot, politics and a certain trip to the White House in the Carter years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN Willie Nelson invites you to get high with him on his bus, you go.

headline: Grand Illusion in Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The White House is trying a cheaper version of what didn’t work in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: ACROSS years of war and at an extraordinary cost, the United States built an army that was supposed to prevent jihadists from gaining a sanctuary in the heart of the Middle East. It had American-trained leaders, American-made weaponry and 250,000 men under arms — far more troops and firepower than any insurgent force that might emerge to challenge it.

headline: Too Young to Die, Too Old to Worry
abstract: At some point, you have to start indulging in the pleasures of the present.
lead_paragraph: THIS weekend, the singer and songwriter Leonard Cohen is celebrating his 80th birthday — with a cigarette. Last year he announced that he would resume smoking when he turned 80. “It’s the right age to recommence,” he explained.

headline: Hidden Interests, Closer to Home
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Think Tanks', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The Times could do a lot more to alert readers about conflicts of interests of sources used by the paper.
lead_paragraph: THE article ran above the fold on the front page early this month, a Times investigation into the influence of foreign money within American research organizations.

headline: Three Cheers for Pluralism Over Separatism
abstract: Here’s why the no vote in Scotland was a good thing.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — THIS was an interesting week to visit Britain and Spain — first to watch the Scottish separatists push for independence and then to watch Basque and Catalan separatists watching (with disappointment) the outcome of the vote. One reaction: I’m glad a majority of Scots rejected independence. Had they not, it would have clipped the wing of America’s most important wingman in the world: Britain. Another reaction: God bless America. We have many sources of strength, but today our greatest asset is our pluralism — our “E pluribus unum” — that out of many we’ve made one nation, with all the benefits that come from mixing cultures and all the strengths that come from being able to act together.

headline: Alicia Keys Asks: Why Are We Here?
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Philanthropy', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Music']
abstract: Alicia Keys wants to galvanize an infantry that moves from being frustrated about the world to improving it.
lead_paragraph: ALICIA KEYS is a superstar singer who has mostly kept her clothes on and gossip off. So what is she doing in this photo, dressed only in a peace sign?

headline: Climate Realities
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Environment', 'Water Pollution', 'International Relations']
abstract: The world is now on track to more than double current greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere by the end of the century.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — ON Tuesday, world leaders will converge at United Nations headquarters in New York for a summit meeting on the climate that will set the stage for global negotiations next year to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the threat of global climate change. The summit is titled “Catalyzing Action,” a decidedly hopeful characterization.

headline: Getting Married Is Easy
abstract: It’s simple. I just stopped behaving badly and dating disasters.
lead_paragraph: I DID not expect to fall in love at 46, and I did not expect to plan a wedding at 47. Except that I always expect to be surprised.

headline: Venezuela’s Crackdown on Opposition
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The government’s abuses are dangerous for the region and warrant strong criticism from Latin American leaders.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan government early this year responded to a wave of street protests by jailing opposition leaders, deploying the army against unarmed protesters and tightening control of the media. The deplorable tactics have largely driven an inspiring opposition movement underground, depriving Venezuelans of the right to challenge a leader who has put a once-prosperous nation on a perilous track.

headline: The Vain and the Desperate
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Our political process repels many leaders who might do us good and leaves us with a sometimes motley crew.
lead_paragraph: IN case you missed it, our nation’s officeholders, current and former, have been working overtime to make us proud.

headline: Who Runs the Girls?
abstract: Life in the club scene, where female empowerment is just a line in a song.
lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, I attended a party at a nightclub in the meatpacking district of Manhattan with about 10 young women, most of them models, and two club promoters, men whose job was to bring beautiful women to exclusive parties. Beyoncé’s hit single “Run the World (Girls)” boomed, and the girls danced to the beat, singing, “Who run the world? Girls! Girls!” One promoter joined in, with his own twist on the chorus: “Who run the girls? Boys! Boys!” The men high-fived, and everyone laughed.

headline: Can a Computer Replace Your Doctor?
abstract: Do state-of-the-art gadgets really help patients?
lead_paragraph: AS a former physician, I shivered a bit when I heard Dr. Vivek Wadhwa say he would rather have an artificial-intelligence doctor than a human one. “I would trust an A.I. over a doctor any day,” he proclaimed at a recent health innovation conference in San Francisco, noting that artificial intelligence provided “perfect knowledge.” When asked to vote, probably a third of those in attendance agreed.

headline: Slamming a Door on Hedge Funds
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Hedge Funds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Critics of public pensions’ investments in hedge funds received a big boost when Calpers said it would divest its $4 billion portfolio of such funds over the next year.
lead_paragraph: Are public pension funds over their crush on hedge funds?

headline: Steven Mollenkopf of Qualcomm: If You Don’t Know, Just Say So
abstract: “I really enjoy the unknown and uncertainty,” a C.E.O. says. “I like when things are up in the air or changing. That’s where I tend to feel most comfortable.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Steven Mollenkopf, the C.E.O. of Qualcomm, the mobile-phone technology company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Taxi Financing Firm Isn’t Switching Lanes
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Ride-sharing services are shaking its industry, but Medallion Financial likes its niche in the taxi medallion loan market.
lead_paragraph: With its $17 billion valuation, Silicon Valley pedigree and disruptive technology, Uber has been making waves worldwide.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 21
abstract: Congress approved funding for equipping Syrian rebels against Islamic States and lawmakers will discuss their votes on several of the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: Congress voted to back President Obama’s decision to train and equip the Syrian rebels to fight the militants of the Islamic State. At the United Nations, Secretary of State John Kerry added to the international coalition of countries joining the American-led campaign against the extremists in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Underwater Inspiration
abstract: The seascapes program director for Conservation International says she has learned much “from the ocean and from the people whose lives are connected to it.”
lead_paragraph: Laure S. Katz, 30, is the seascapes program director for Conservation International, based in Arlington, Va., where her job includes leading scuba expeditions across the Asia-Pacific region to help develop marine protection programs.

headline: Dancing With the Start-Ups
keywords: ['Celebrities', 'Venture Capital', 'Start-ups', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Some celebrities — both established and up-and-coming — are lavishing their promotional love on new companies rather than big brands. Often, the deals involve equity.
lead_paragraph: Since at least Sarah Bernhardt’s time, celebrities have looked for ways to parlay their name recognition into extra cash. Back in the 19th century, Bernhardt — the most celebrated actress of her day — endorsed a popular brand of soap. “I have used Pears’ Soap and find there’s nothing in the world so pleasing and satisfying,” she enthused in one ad.

headline: As Life Imitates Brutal Sport, Cheers Have Uneasy Resonance
abstract: Sunday’s game between the Chicago Bears and the San Francisco 49ers showed just how entangled the N.F.L.’s manufactured world of make-believe is with the hard realities of American life.
lead_paragraph: Amid the images and reports of battered women and children, there may finally be consensus that N.F.L. games are superfluous, that the standings matter less than the blotter, bruises and brain scans. But the games go on as scheduled, as if nothing happened, no matter how far the league veers wildly off script.

headline: Venezuela Moves Jailed Former Police Official to House Arrest
abstract: The opposition has long demanded the release of the official, Iván Simonovis, who was jailed in connection with the killing of protesters in 2002, but the Supreme Court said that he would be returned to jail once his health improved.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A jailed former police official whose nearly decade-long stay in prison has become a rallying cry for the political opposition was moved to house arrest, his wife and court officials announced on Saturday.

headline: Zenefits’ Leader Is Rattling an Industry, So Why Is He Stressed Out?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Small Business', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Start-ups', 'Software']
abstract: Parker Conrad’s start-up, which helps small businesses navigate employee benefits, has shown phenomenal growth. Yet he is anything but sure of its success.
lead_paragraph: Parker Conrad’s start-up, Zenefits, is thought to be one of the fastest-growing companies in recent Silicon Valley history, and his investors and associates describe him as an uncommonly talented software visionary. But lately, Mr. Conrad often finds himself petrified, his days a series of white-knuckled attempts to escape the clutches of sudden, inadvertent failure.

headline: Return of the Bums on Welfare
abstract: Attributing unemployment to benefits that don’t exist anymore.
lead_paragraph: Thinking some more about John Boehner’s resurrection of the notion that we’re suffering weak job growth because people are living the good life on government benefits, and don’t want to work. It has long seemed to me that the issue of unemployment benefits is where the debate over economic policy in a depression reaches its purest essence. If you’r on the right, you believe — you more or less have to believe — that unemployment benefits hurt job creation, because you’re “paying people not to work.” To admit that depression conditions are different, that the economy is suffering from an overall lack of demand and that putting money into the pockets of people likely to spend it would increase employment, would mean admitting that the free market sometimes fails badly. And of course disdain for the unemployed helps a lot if you want to oppose any kind of aid for the unfortunate.

headline: In Scotland and Beyond, a Crisis of Faith in the Global Elite
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Referendums', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Elections', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The independence movement in Scotland was another sign of widespread dissatisfaction with an established order that has failed to deliver.
lead_paragraph: In Scotland this week, a measure to become an independent country and end the United Kingdom as we know it failed, but it would have succeeded with a swing of just 5 percent of the vote. Earlier in the week, a right-wing anti-immigration party in Sweden claimed its largest-ever share of parliamentary votes. And in the United States, new census data released this week showed that middle-income American families made 8 percent less last year, adjusted for inflation, than they did in 2007.

headline: Coming Soon, a Century Late: A Black Film Gem
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art will present what curators say is the earliest extant footage of a feature film with a black cast, featuring the vaudeville star Bert Williams.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the seven reels from 1913 lay unexamined in the film archives of the Museum of Modern Art. Now, after years of research, a historic find has emerged: what MoMA curators say is the earliest surviving footage for a feature film with a black cast. It is a rare visual depiction of middle-class black characters from an era when lynchings and stereotyped black images were commonplace. What’s more, the material features Bert Williams, the first black superstar on Broadway. Williams appears in blackface in the untitled silent film along with a roster of actors from the sparsely documented community of black performers in Harlem on the cusp of the Harlem Renaissance. Remarkably, the reels also capture behind-the-scenes interactions between these performers and the directors.

headline: In Checking Accounts, the Less You Have, the More You May Pay
keywords: ['Checks and Checking Accounts', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The annual cost of a checking account can range from zero to more than $700, according to a WalletHub survey. The biggest fees may fall on those who overdraw their accounts.
lead_paragraph: Financial complexity doesn’t happen only on Wall Street. Even a basic checking account is often no longer simple, because account rules and fees can vary widely — so widely, in fact, that the annual cost can range from zero to more than $700, according to the 2014 survey of checking account costs by WalletHub, a consumer finance information and social networking site.

headline: Why Federal College Ratings Won’t Rein In Tuition
abstract: An ambitious plan to create a better-informed marketplace for education doesn’t take into account how public universities are funded.
lead_paragraph: College costs have been rising for decades. Slowing — or even better, reversing — that trend would get more people into college and help reduce student debt. The Obama administration is working on an ambitious plan intended to rein in college costs, and it deserves credit for tackling this tough job.

headline: In Suburban Seattle, New Nests for China’s Rich
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: The land of Microsoft’s millionaires is now making room for Beijing’s. Wealthy Chinese have become the biggest foreign buyers of area real estate.
lead_paragraph: As wealthy Chinese stash more of their fortunes overseas, they’re bidding up the value of everything from Bitcoins and Burgundy to Picassos and pink diamonds.

headline: How to Thwart a Texting Driver
abstract: Readers respond to “Hitting the Brake on Texting.”
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Heimatsicherheitsamt (Trivial)
abstract: Jawohl we can.
lead_paragraph: Josh Marshall returns to an old topic — the strangely un-American terminology the Bush administration imposed after 9/11. As he says, Homeland Security really doesn’t sound like the America I thought we believed in.

headline: Push for New Pact on Climate Change Is Plagued by Old Divide of Wealth
abstract: At a United Nations gathering on Tuesday, leaders will face a divide between the rich countries responsible for extensive carbon emissions and the poor countries that stand to suffer most as a result.
lead_paragraph: At 1 p.m. on Sunday, tens of thousands of demonstrators in Manhattan are expected to make as much noise as they can — with whistles, trumpets, even the tolling of church bells — to raise an alarm about the risks of climate change. Similar demonstrations are planned across the United States and in 161 other countries.

headline: Franca Sozzani, Vogue Italia Editor, on the Magazine Industry
abstract: Ms. Sozzani was sitting her office Saturday afternoon, reflecting on her particularly long Milan Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: MILAN – Franca Sozzani, the 64-year-old editor of Vogue Italia, was exhausted.

headline: Pass the Word: The Phone Call Is Back
abstract: New messaging apps are celebrating the sound (and the nuance) of the human voice.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, it seemed that the old-fashioned phone call was going out of style. Smartphones were on the rise, and many people were using them for everything except making calls.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Regardless of Defeats, Coughlin Won’t Lose His Passion
abstract: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin has not only endured adversity but also become the paternalistic coaching face of New York.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — To familiarize an inquiring news media with his next opponent, to convey the formidable challenge awaiting his 0-2 Giants on Sunday against the 2-0 Houston Texans at MetLife Stadium, Coach Tom Coughlin went to a midweek news conference armed with facts, figures and the occasional fulmination.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The Times.
lead_paragraph: A Chance For the N.F.L. To Lift Society

headline: After Surgery, Surprise $117,000 Medical Bill From Doctor He Didn’t Know
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Series', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Hospitals']
abstract: In a growing practice, medical assistants, consultants and other hospital staffers, often called in without patients’ knowledge, are charging hefty fees.
lead_paragraph: Before his three-hour neck surgery for herniated disks in December, Peter Drier, 37, signed a pile of consent forms. A bank technology manager who had researched his insurance coverage, Mr. Drier was prepared when the bills started arriving: $56,000 from Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan, $4,300 from the anesthesiologist and even $133,000 from his orthopedist, who he knew would accept a fraction of that fee.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Stardust
abstract: Young people obsessed with fashion displayed wildly eccentric and creative styles of dress during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: All was normal outside the shows during New York Fashion Week. Young people obsessed with fashion displayed wildly eccentric and creative styles of dress, getting the madness out of their systems before entering the professional fashion world, which is about commerce, not arty dressing. Lord & Taylor’s window, left, caught the spirit, as did Thom Browne, with whimsical accessorizing on very practical clothes. His show — on a grass runway, below — was like buckets of stardust falling on a fashion world that takes itself too seriously.

headline: Polly Bergen Dies at 84; Emmy-Winning Actress
abstract: Ms. Bergen won an Emmy in 1958 for her portrayal of the alcoholic torch singer Helen Morgan and was nominated for another 50 years later for her recurring role on the television show “Desperate Housewives.”
lead_paragraph: Polly Bergen, an actress, singer and businesswoman who won an Emmy Award in 1958 for her portrayal of the alcoholic torch singer Helen Morgan and was nominated for another 50 years later for her role on “Desperate Housewives,” died on Saturday at her home in Southbury, Conn. She was 84.

headline: U.S. Suspects More Direct Threats Beyond ISIS
abstract: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States begins what could be a lengthy military campaign against the Islamic State, intelligence and law enforcement officials said another Syrian group, led by a shadowy figure who was once among Osama bin Laden’s inner circle, posed a more direct threat to America and Europe.

headline: A Rich History of Duels Between Captains’ Picks
abstract: The success or failure of the picks by Tom Watson of the United States and Paul McGinley of Europe may well help to determine the winner.
lead_paragraph: In assembling the Ryder Cup teams representing the United States and Europe, the captains made picks that were treated as afterthoughts: the three golfers joining the nine who qualified on a points-for-performance basis in weekly tournaments worldwide over two years. But in the aftermath of the matches that begin Friday at Gleneagles in Scotland, the success or failure of the picks by Tom Watson of the United States and Paul McGinley of Europe may well have helped to determine the winner.

headline: Nascar Rocks!
abstract: Michael Ashley waves his checkered flag as we zoom to the end of our solving week.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — For a puzzle whose title purports to be about racecars, this one had me singing while I solved. We have Michael Ashley’s theme about song titles punned up as what seem to be interview questions asked of racedrivers, but there’s quite a bit of extra musical goodness in his grid as well.

headline: Provincial Vote Is Seen as a Test for Sri Lanka’s President
abstract: The candidates for chief minister of Uva Province are seen as proxies for President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s coming battle for re-election.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Voters in a southeastern Sri Lankan province headed to the polls on Saturday in what is widely seen as a crucial test of whether President Mahinda Rajapaksa is likely to win a third term in the coming months.

headline: Monarch Butterfly: A Journey of 2,000 Miles Guided by Mysterious Maps
abstract: Each autumn, thousands of monarch butterflies sweep southbound through New York City in one of the world’s most famous migrations.
lead_paragraph: Each autumn, thousands of monarch butterflies sweep southbound through New York City in one of the world’s most famous migrations. A journey of more than 2,000 miles will eventually take them to central Mexican fir forests, where they will winter on south-facing slopes in numbers large enough to break tree boughs. It is a migration substantially unlike those of birds.

headline: Pasta With Caramelized Lemons
abstract: Melissa Clark caramelizes lemons and adds them to linguine with parsley and celery leaves.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark caramelizes lemons and adds them to linguine with parsley and celery leaves.

headline: Many Veterans Adapt to a Strange World, One With Walls
abstract: A national effort to eliminate homelessness among veterans has made significant strides, finding places for 51,000. The program’s future, however, is in doubt.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For 30 years after Vietnam, Art Harmon’s address was a dry wash under the 210 freeway, where he tried to forget his tour as a 19-year-old helicopter gunner.

headline: Demanding Liberty or Death, or Maybe a Touchdown
abstract: The Rutgers cannon, which has a link to the Revolutionary War, is set off three times before each home game, once at halftime, once at game’s end, and after every score by the Scarlet Knights.
lead_paragraph: Chartered in 1766 as Queen’s College, Rutgers was renamed in 1825 in honor of a trustee, Henry Rutgers, a brewery heir from Manhattan who was a colonel in George Washington’s army during the American Revolution. That military connection might be one reason the class of 1949 bought a cannon to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the first college football game, a 6-4 Rutgers victory over Princeton.

headline: Polish Player With Texas Ties Wins U.S. Masters Title
abstract: Bartlomiej Macieja, the chess coach at the University of Texas at Brownsville, finished a half-point ahead of a Ukrainian grandmaster that the Masters tournament in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: A Polish grandmaster who coaches a Texas university’s chess team won the United States Masters Championship over Labor Day weekend in North Carolina. The winner, Bartlomiej Macieja, who runs the chess program at the University of Texas at Brownsville, finished a half-point ahead of Yaroslav Zherebukh, a grandmaster from Ukraine. The field included 17 other grandmasters.

headline: Behind Quaint Exterior Beats State-of-Art Heart
abstract: Through an unusual public-private partnership, an auditorium that opened in 1926 was repurposed to create a new performing arts center in San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — With the press of a button, the H-E-B Performance Hall in the Tobin Center for the Performing Arts can be transformed from a concert venue with traditional raked seating to a flat-floored dance hall. A mechanized “flexible floor” system elevates the seats on platforms, flips the platforms over, and then lowers them to create a flat, stained maple floor. The process takes 23 minutes.

headline: Caution Until the End: Last-Minute Surprises
abstract: The possibility of a turnaround fuels trailing candidates, and however far-off, it is true that what voters are talking about in September is not always the same in November.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.​

headline: Former Hampton Creek Executive Says He Will Not Advise Company
abstract: The discrepancy between the accounts of Hampton Creek and Ali Partovi, a top executive who left after nine days on the job, suggests that the split between the two was not as amicable as the company has said publicly.
lead_paragraph: A top executive at Hampton Creek, the high-profile food and technology start-up, who left after only nine days on the job said on Friday he would not remain as an adviser, despite an earlier statement by the company that he would.

headline: Candidate’s Vow to Kill Tuition Law Makes Some in His Party Squirm
keywords: ['Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: State Senator Dan Patrick, who is running for lieutenant governor in Texas, wants to repeal the Dream Act, just as Republicans are trying to appeal more to Hispanic voters.
lead_paragraph: If elected lieutenant governor in November, State Senator Dan Patrick, a Republican, has vowed to work to repeal the law that allows undocumented students to pay in-state tuition at Texas community colleges and universities.

headline: Questioning an Ambitious Chancellor’s Vision
abstract: While the aggressive transformation of the University of Houston has drawn praise, it has also prompted questions about the college’s role in both the community and the university system.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Charles Haston was wearing a shirt emblazoned with the University of Texas at Austin longhorn logo when he showed up for orientation at the University of Houston — home of the Cougars — in the fall of 2008.

headline: Fans’ Adoration of Derek Jeter Continues, but the Yankees’ Winning Streak Does Not
abstract: The love directed toward Jeter was plentiful Saturday at Yankee Stadium, where a loss to the Blue Jays ended the Yankees’ three-game winning streak, hurting their faint playoff chances.
lead_paragraph: The love directed toward Derek Jeter, who is playing in his final few games at Yankee Stadium, is abundant. Each time he walks to the plate, he is greeted by a standing ovation. Almost every time he does something as routine as fielding a ground ball, the crowd chants his name.

headline: Terence Moakley, Advocate for Disabled, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Moakley, a quadriplegic, was not above staging public stunts to show how difficult it could be for the disabled to get around.
lead_paragraph: Terence J. Moakley, a persistent advocate for the disabled who fought for wheelchair users to have access to taxicabs and transit systems, died on Sept. 5 in Manhattan. He was 69.

headline: G.M. Recalls Impalas and Cadillacs Over Risk of Brake Fires
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Brakes']
abstract: The parking brake on the affected vehicles may remain partly engaged, causing the pads to generate enough heat to cause a fire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Motors is recalling more than 221,000 vehicles because of a parking-brake defect that can cause brake pads to stay partly engaged, which can lead to “excessive brake heat that may result in a fire,” according to documents posted Saturday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s website.

headline: De Blasio Orders a Greener City, Setting Goals for Energy Efficiency of Buildings
abstract: Pledging to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 80 percent by 2050 from 2005 levels, the de Blasio administration plans to overhaul the energy standards in city buildings.
lead_paragraph: In a sweeping effort to reduce its environmental impact, New York City is planning to overhaul the energy-efficiency standards of all its public buildings and to pressure private landlords to make similar improvements.

headline: Response Uneven to Jameis Winston’s Wrongdoing
abstract: Florida State’s decision to lengthen the suspension of its star quarterback may have come about because of an uneasy coexistence between big business and amateurism at the top tier of college sports.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, shortly after he was suspended for the first half of Saturday’s game against Clemson for shouting an obscene comment in the student union the day before, Jameis Winston realized the significance of his action: It might cost his team a loss — a loss it could ill afford as it strives to defend its national title.

headline: Lane Kiffin, Alabama’s New Offensive Mind, Shows His Mettle Against Florida
abstract: Blake Sims, thriving under the guidance of Kiffin, the new offensive coordinator, had 445 passing yards as the No. 3 Crimson Tide routed the Gators.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — When Coach Nick Saban filled Alabama’s offensive-coordinator vacancy, he could have selected from the cream of the coaching fraternity. Many college football observers were baffled after he picked the problematic Lane Kiffin rather than a fresh up-and-comer or a less polarizing veteran.

headline: Paris Falls Out of Love With the Padlocks on Its Bridges
abstract: Thick glass, with nothing to hitch a lock to, has begun replacing the panels where thousands have symbolized everlasting devotion by fastening hardware.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The regal Pont des Arts may be one of the most romantic bridges in Paris, at least to judge by the thousands of couples from around the world who have clamped padlocks to the railings as tokens of their desire to be “locked in love forever.”

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: What’s On TV Sunday
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (CBS) MADAM SECRETARY Téa Leoni stars as Elizabeth McCord, a college professor and former C.I.A. analyst turned newly appointed secretary of state, who battles office politics and circumvents protocol as she navigates issues in the White House and abroad. Then there are matters with her husband and two children at home. Tim Daly plays her supportive spouse; Bebe Neuwirth is her chief of staff; Geoffrey Arend is her speechwriter; Keith Carradine is the president, and her former mentor; and Zeljko Ivanek (above left, with Mr. Carradine and Ms. Leoni) is his Dick Cheney-esque chief of staff. “Hillary Rodham Clinton is the obvious inspiration, but this is Hillary with a human face: Téa Leoni, who has a husky voice and a loose, engaging manner, is an unusually likable beauty,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “As Elizabeth McCord, she has all the brains and determination of the original and none of the political ambition and baggage.” Ms. Stanley added that a closer model for Mrs. Clinton can be found in the character of Alicia Florrick, the wife of a politician brought down by a sex scandal in “The Good Wife.” That show’s sixth season begins at 9:30, with Alicia refusing to run for state’s attorney. “She stands by his side for a while, then leaves him and restarts her legal career from scratch,” Ms. Stanley said. Of the two series, “ ‘The Good Wife’ stands out because it strikes the right balance of network-mandated virtue and cable-inspired vice. ‘Madam Secretary’ has some good moments, but it would be better if its heroine were just a little bit worse.”

headline: After Rancor, Afghans Agree to Share Power
abstract: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Their campaign workers traded blows over ballot boxes during an election widely seen as fraudulent. Some of the warlords backing them have muttered about starting a parallel government, a potential recipe for civil war in Afghanistan. And they’ve just come out of a vote so discredited that some officials don’t want the final tallies announced.

headline: Taking a Call for Climate Change to the Streets
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The People’s Climate March in Manhattan was a spectacle even for a city known for doing things big, and it was joined, in solidarity, by demonstrations on Sunday across the globe, from Paris to Papua New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: Legions of demonstrators frustrated by international inaction on global warming descended on New York City on Sunday, marching through the heart of Manhattan with a message of alarm for world leaders set to gather this week at the United Nations for a summit meeting on climate change.

headline: Can We Build a Safer Internet?
abstract: We sometimes assume the Internet is a naturally cruel and lawless place. But social networks may be able to influence our behavior on them, for good and ill.
lead_paragraph: We often take it as a given that the Internet is a cruel place, a natural haven for those who seek to harass and threaten others. But to some people, social networks are not mere conduits for our worst impulses. They’re structures whose design can influence how we behave, for good as well as for ill.

headline: 1939: Reich Maps Show France Partitioned, Says Daladier
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France accused Germany of partition plans in 1939.
lead_paragraph: In a radio speech, Premier Edouard Daladier stated maps showing the dismemberment of France had already been printed in Germany, thus proving that Hitler’s assertion that he wanted nothing from France was as false as his past statements regarding Austria, Czecho-Slovakia and Poland. He refuted Hitler’s attempt to disclaim war responsibility, said it was futile for Germany to try to dissociate France and England, and declared French soldiers would fight to the end to crush the system of threats and alarms. A Radio Agency report from Brussels said some dikes of the Albert Canal had been opened to cause floods between Antwerp and Liège, thus making it impossible for an enemy army to pass the north and northeastern frontiers with offensive weapons. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain said England’s war budget would be presented to the House of Commons Wednesday. German radio stations started anti-French broadcasts. After a prolonged silence, Propaganda Minister Josef Goebbels summoned newspaper men to his office to tell them Germany did not intend to invade Holland or Belgium and to deny that there had been riots in Slovakia. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 22, 1939

headline: 1964: Otto Grotewohl Dies at 70
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The East German prime minister died in 1964.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — East German Premier Otto Grotewohl died of a stroke today after a long illness that had kept him politically inactive for several years. He was 70. It was expected he would be succeeded by Willi Stoph, who has been acting premier. Mr. Grotewohl, a former Social Democrat, was regarded as a traitor by West European socialists because of his leading role in merging the Social Democratic party with the Communist party in 1946 to form the Communist-run Socialist Union party. A spokesman for the West German Socialist party said Mr. Grotewohl will always bear the stigma of sacrificing the Social Democratic party in the Soviet zone of Germany. ‘‘He was also responsible for the death and imprisonment of thousands of fellow Social Democrats,’’ the spokesman said. ‘‘Politically, he has been a dead man for the past few years,’’ he said, ‘‘but he still served as bait for the regime.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 22, 1964

headline: The Tramp Returns, With Exuberant Backing by the Philharmonic

lead_paragraph: After its sorry gala concert to open the season last Tuesday night, a slick tribute to music from Italian cinema titled “La Dolce Vita,” the New York Philharmonic resuscitated its artistic pedigree and proved how rewarding its venture into performing film scores can be on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. As part of the series The Art of the Score, a beautifully restored print of Charlie Chaplin’s classic 1936 comedy “Modern Times” was screened as the Philharmonic performed Chaplin’s original score, meticulously reconstructed by the composer and conductor Timothy Brock, who led the orchestra in his impressive Philharmonic debut.

Pledges will be made to halve the destruction of the world’s forests by 2020 and stop it by 2030. The World Bank will lead a big push to put a global price on emissions of greenhouse gases.”

headline: $750,000 Grant  For Gibney Dance
abstract: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation will contribute $750,000 to Gibney Dance to support its Dance in Process residency program.
lead_paragraph: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation will contribute $750,000 to Gibney Dance to support its Dance in Process residency program, bolstering an impressive fund-raising year for the organization, which operates a dance company, two dance centers and a community action program for victims of domestic abuse. In January, the Agnes Varis Trust announced a $3 million gift that allowed Gibney Dance to take over and renovate a 36,000-square-foot space at 280 Broadway, next to City Hall, that Dance New Amsterdam relinquished when it declared bankruptcy a year ago. Over three years, the Mellon gift will provide 30 artists with a three-week residency at Gibney’s other Manhattan space, 890 Broadway in the Flatiron district, where the company has been based since its founding in 1991. In 2011 the company significantly expanded its footprint in the building with additional studios; with the Mellon grant, it is establishing a choreographic center there. The Dance in Process program has been in pilot mode for the past two years with virtually no financial backing. “The Mellon support will give it real depth and will really ground it,” Gina Gibney, the chief executive and artistic director of Gibney Dance, said in an interview. “We will be able to support these dance artists at a whole new level.” The residency will focus specifically on midcareer artists, a demographic often left out of major funding support in favor of so-called established or emerging artists.

In exchange for the ball, Gardner took the fan and his children a couple of bats, and he signed some baseballs for them as Masahiro Tanaka walked by on his way to a news conference.

headline: Oh, Go Take a Walk
abstract: Philosophers and writers have said it for centuries, and now scientists agree: Walking is not just a way to get from point A to point B or to get your daily dose of exercise — it also stimulates the mind.
lead_paragraph: It’s something that you do every day without giving it a moment’s thought. Most of us treat walking as a necessity, a mode of transportation or a way to cut some calories.

headline: Batman, as a Boy Bereaved, and Ally
abstract: “Gotham,” on Fox, takes place in a Gotham City when Bruce Wayne is still a boy and James Gordon is not yet the police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: “Gotham” begins with classic Batman visuals: a hooded figure crouches between a pair of gargoyles before jumping off a building. Except that it’s not Bruce Wayne, a.k.a. the Batman, who’s going off the roof. He’s still 8 years old and has yet to beat up his first criminal. At that moment he’s leaving a movie theater with his parents.

Weiner, the former congressman brought down by unseemly photos and an itchy Twitter finger, and Representative Mark Sanford, whose romantic misadventures with an ex-wife and an ex-fiancée continue to accumulate.

I used the phrase, sitting in her tiny studio at Columbia University on Thursday, as we discussed “Carry That Weight.” This is the succinct and powerful performance piece that is her senior art thesis as well as her protest against sexual assault on campus, especially the one she says she endured.

abstract: CT screening for lung cancer can save thousands of lives each year.
lead_paragraph: THE war against cancer can be confusing, with providers, insurers and policy makers debating the effectiveness of treatments, prevention programs and research. But there is one significant victory within our grasp. There is, increasingly, a consensus that CT screening for lung cancer can save thousands of lives each year.

headline: Selling Prozac as the Life-Enhancing Cure for Mental Woes
abstract: In the late 1980s and the ’90s, Prozac was seen as a life preserver for those drowning in anguish. It was also a marvel of commercial branding.
lead_paragraph: When it came to pharmacological solutions to life’s despairs, Aldous Huxley was ahead of the curve. In Huxley’s 1932 novel about a dystopian future, the Alphas, Betas and others populating his “Brave New World” have at their disposal a drug called soma. A little bit of it chases the blues away: “A gramme” — Huxley was English, remember, spelling included — “is better than a damn.” With a swallow, negative feelings are dispelled.

headline: The Week Ahead: Citizens Financial Stock Offering, and a New BlackBerry

headline: Why Poor Students Struggle
abstract: The price of success in college is often their own identities.
lead_paragraph: I WAS rushing to change trains at Delancey Street in downtown Manhattan earlier this year when a tall young man stepped in front of me, blocking my way through the crowd. He said my name and I looked up.

headline: Who’s On Trial, Eichmann or Arendt?
abstract: Adolf Eichmann was banal precisely because he was a fanatical anti-Semite, not despite the fact.
lead_paragraph: The new English translation of Bettina Stangneth’s “Eichmann Before Jerusalem: The Unexamined Life of a Mass Murderer,” is the latest in a long line of scholarship that aims to illuminate the inner life of Adolf Eichmann, one of Nazi Germany’s most notorious, and most analyzed, figures. Based on troves of memoir, notes and interviews given by Eichmann in Argentina, where he lived under the pseudonym Ricardo Clement between 1950 and 1960, it is an impressive historical study — one that underscores the fanatical nature of Eichmann’s anti-Semitism.

headline: ISIS Forays Send Waves of Refugees Into Turkey
abstract: The refugee crisis near the Syrian border town of Ayn al-Arab could be one of the greatest refugee flows since the civil war in Syria began, said a United Nations official.

headline: White House May Check Tourists Blocks Away
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The checks were under consideration after an episode in which a man with a knife managed to get through the front door of the president’s home after jumping over the fence on Pennsylvania Avenue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service is considering screening tourists and other visitors at checkpoints before they enter the public areas in front of the White House in response to the episode Friday in which a man with a knife managed to get through the front door of the president’s home after jumping over the fence on Pennsylvania Avenue, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: The Great Pennsylvania Poultry Disaster
abstract: If some hipster named Seth could raise chickens on a roof in Williamsburg, I could do it far better in the woods. Or so I thought.
lead_paragraph: BUSHKILL, Pa. —

headline: Taking a Spin Through New York City’s History
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: As part of a course titled “History of the City of New York,” Professor Kenneth T. Jackson, 75, and 200 Columbia University students take an all-night bike ride, pedaling by New York City landmarks and historic sites.
lead_paragraph: The professor in History 3535 said some things that professors do not usually say during a history class, among them, “Move over — we have to let the cab through.” It was nearly 2 a.m., hardly the normal time to be lecturing 200 students.

headline: The Great Beefsteak Raid
abstract: The story of the Civil War’s biggest cattle rustle.
lead_paragraph: Since ancient times, men have stolen one another’s cattle. They’ve done so for various reasons: greed, hunger, adventure, prestige. In the Old West, cattle rustling was elevated to a fine art, involving “mavericking” and brand manipulation through the use of the proverbial “long rope and a hot iron.” But never in the history of cattle stealing in America has there been a more blatant display of strategy, nerve and determination than that shown by Gen. Wade Hampton and his force of rebel cow thieves.

headline: Girl, 14, Is Killed by Gunfire on a New Jersey City Street
abstract: Two girls were shot in Paterson, N.J., on Saturday night, the police said, and a city councilman said the girl who died, Nazerah Coleman, was an innocent bystander.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old girl was killed and another teenager was injured in a shooting on Saturday night in Paterson, N.J., less than three months after a 12-year-old was killed in another shooting, officials said.

headline: Those Lazy Jobless
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Welfare (US)']
abstract: Republicans are still at it, blaming the victims of a depressed economy.
lead_paragraph: Last week John Boehner, the speaker of the House, explained to an audience at the American Enterprise Institute what’s holding back employment in America: laziness. People, he said, have “this idea” that “I really don’t have to work. I don’t really want to do this. I think I’d rather just sit around.” Holy 47 percent, Batman!

headline: Warner Bros., After Shake-Up and Shaky Summer, Digs In
abstract: Over a year into a shake-up that put Kevin Tsujihara in the chief executive’s seat at Warner, the studio has yet to find its footing.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Summer was brutal at Warner Bros., and not just because the thermometer hit 105 degrees on its sun-scorched lot here last week.

abstract: Western governments set about devising a strategy for speeding prosecution of those responsible for grave crimes in the conflict in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Western governments have begun private talks aimed at coming up with fresh strategies to speed the process of judging those responsible for grave crimes in the conflicts in Syria and Iraq.

keywords: ['Child Pornography', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Privacy', 'Posse Comitatus Act (1878)', 'Search and Seizure', 'Appeals Courts (US)']

lead_paragraph: In a field office near Brunswick, Ga., a federal agent working as an undercover cybersleuth signed on to a large file-sharing network sometimes used by traders in child pornography.

headline: Though Adversaries on the Surface, U.S. and Hezbollah Share a Goal
abstract: In practice, Hezbollah and the United States are already working — separately — on a common goal: to stop the extremist Islamic State from moving into Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — They are sworn enemies who insist they will never work together, but in practice, Hezbollah and the United States are already working — separately — on a common goal: to stop the extremist Islamic State from moving into Lebanon, where Hezbollah is the most powerful military and political player and currently shares with Washington an interest in stability.

lead_paragraph: The market debut of the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet titan, hit the stock markets like a meteor last week, ending its first day of public trading on Friday worth a staggering $231 billion.

abstract: The Yankees salute departing stars with days in their honor, sometimes on two or three occasions years apart.
lead_paragraph: When Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera were celebrated by the Yankees during the current and previous seasons, they demonstrated the wisdom of advance planning.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Philanthropy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Endowments', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The family whose legendary wealth flowed from Standard Oil is planning to rid its $860 million Rockefeller Brothers Fund of investments in companies trading in nonrenewable energy.
lead_paragraph: John D. Rockefeller built a vast fortune on oil. Now his heirs are abandoning fossil fuels.

headline: The Famous Can Present a Minefield for Doctors
abstract: The treatment of Joan Rivers at a Manhattan endoscopy clinic last month may be the latest example of what medical professionals call “V.I.P. Syndrome,” in which famous patients get special care that doesn’t always work out for the best.
lead_paragraph: As F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, "Let me tell you about the very rich. They are different from you and me.” It is an observation that holds true, apparently, even in the operating room.

headline: Feeding the Family, Feeding Resentment
abstract: Has home cooking been overly glorified, guilt-tripping harried parents, particularly mothers, who have too much to do already?

headline: From Pole to Pulpit, a Club and a Church Do Battle
keywords: ['Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: A pastor’s nearly nine-year battle to close a strip club has succeeded in getting the dancers to his church on Sundays, albeit as part of a topless protest against him.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Ohio — To shield churchgoers from the topless protesters, curtains are hung around the parking lot of New Beginnings Ministries. The pastor, William R. Dunfee, said families including children have been entering through a back door.

headline: Children’s Health Insurance at a Crossroads
keywords: ["State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A program that now covers some eight million low-income children and is largely federally financed should be maintained.
lead_paragraph: Federal financing for a beneficial health insurance program for low-income children, known as the Children’s Health Insurance Program or CHIP, will run out next year unless Congress agrees to extend it. Bills are pending in both the House and the Senate to extend financing for four years, to 2019. Congress should approve the extension in the lame-duck session after the midterm elections so that families and state officials will know what the future holds. The program needs to be maintained amid uncertainty as to whether other good coverage will be available for these children.

headline: A Shaky Step Forward in Afghanistan
abstract: A brokered solution to the electoral dispute was far from democratic but sets the stage for a milestone: a peaceful transfer of power.
lead_paragraph: Afghans got a new president on Sunday, following a bitter fight over the fraud-plagued runoff election on June 14. The outcome was a brokered political accommodation that was far from democratic, but it nonetheless set the stage for an important milestone: a transfer of power that gives the government a fighting chance of containing the Taliban and mending a nation scarred by decades of war.

headline: With One Battle Over in Scotland, Another Begins
abstract: In the town near Gleneagles, where the Ryder Cup will begin Friday, people have swapped the political passions of last week for the breezier enthusiasms of preparing for one of golf’s greatest events.
lead_paragraph: AUCHTERARDER, Scotland — With one struggle concluded and another set to begin, this ancient slate-gray town in the russet-leaved approaches to the Scottish Highlands has been busy in recent days, swapping the political passions of last week for the breezier enthusiasms involved in preparing for what many local residents regard as the greatest sporting event ever to be staged in Scotland.

headline: Candidate’s 1998 Strip Club Visit Stirs Kansas Governor’s Race
abstract: Paul Davis, a candidate for governor, said he was not arrested or charged in the incident and accused Republicans of “a desperate smear campaign.”
lead_paragraph: The Democratic candidate for governor in Kansas found himself on the defensive this weekend after acknowledging that he was caught up in a police raid of a strip club years ago.

headline: EMC Said to Have Held Talks Over ‘Merger of Equals’ With HP
abstract: Under the terms of the proposed deal, EMC and HP would have united in a so-called merger of equals. But the negotiations ended several weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: The EMC Corporation, the computer storage company now facing pressure from a big activist hedge fund, had held discussions with Hewlett-Packard about a merger, though those talks have since ended, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: On One Brooklyn Block, Two Violent Crimes Bring Broader Scourge to Surface
abstract: By day, a handsome block of Irving Place in Clinton Hill projects a vibrant wholesomeness, but residents say that come nightfall the area is marred by crime.
lead_paragraph: By day, the handsome block of Irving Place that runs between Gates and Putnam Avenues in Brooklyn projects a vibrant wholesomeness. Women push strollers past the red-brick Mount Zion Tabernacle Church; young couples tote Trader Joe’s bags past a photo gallery; and watchful neighbors walk dogs in front of Public School 56.

headline: Browns Recall Glory, Then Keep It at a Distance
abstract: Cleveland had a chance to beat Baltimore on Sunday, and to simultaneously shift some of the focus off the troubles of the Ravens and the N.F.L., but it was not to be.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Browns, a proud but forlorn N.F.L. franchise, had hoped to provide fans with a signal that positive change was on the way for a team — and a city — that has not won a major professional championship in any sport in 50 years.

headline: For Migrants, a Difficult Journey Through Mexico
abstract: Mexico is trying to disrupt the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States. Many are determined to make the trip anyway.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is trying to disrupt the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States. Many are determined to make the trip anyway.

headline: A Chance at College for Ex-Offenders
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Crime and Criminals', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Editorials', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Juvenile Delinquency']
abstract: Colleges are screening out applicants based on criminal records, but those records are often inaccurate and misleading or contain only trivial offenses.
lead_paragraph: There is a widely overlooked obstacle to higher education that confronts at least 70 million Americans who have criminal records — often for relatively trivial transgressions in the distant past. Many colleges ask applicants about criminal convictions before deciding on their suitability as students. And since criminal records are often inaccurate and misleading, these screening systems are inherently unfair.

headline: Jerry Brown Seeks More Electric Cars in California
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The governor signed bills to make it easier for low-income Californians to obtain plug-in vehicles ahead of speaking engagements at the United Nations’ Climate Summit 2014.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown of California has signed several bills to help build the market for electric cars in his state, two days ahead of speaking alongside world leaders at the United Nations this week for a summit meeting on climate change.

headline: Soldiers’ Graves Bear Witness to Russia’s Role in Ukraine
abstract: Even as the Kremlin tries to deny its involvement and families are pressured to keep quiet, the deaths of soldiers sent to fight in Ukraine are impossible to ignore.
lead_paragraph: SELIZOVO, Russia — In a far corner of a small cemetery outside this tiny village by the Oka River, a black flag proclaiming the military might of Russia’s tank forces ripples in the wind above the recently dug grave of Sgt. Vladislav A. Barakov. A photograph of the baby-faced soldier in full dress uniform sits propped against a wooden cross with a small plaque that says he died on Aug. 24. He was 21.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Whenever the writer picks up a drug for his pet, he gets questions like patient’s name, date of birth and if any counseling is needed.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Fall TV Season Has Buzz, but It’s Growing Softer
abstract: Although cable and online television are making inroads on the network television season system, it remains intact, driven by economic factors and the struggle to determine what shows are strongest.
lead_paragraph: It is a throwback, an archaic model, a vestige of a fading business. So why does a ripple of excitement continue to surround the start of another television season?

headline: In the Rhine Valley, Clamoring for Relief From Ramped-Up Rail
abstract: A vital stretch along Europe’s most important north-south rail route is being overrun with train traffic, spoiling the quality of life for residents in a region famous for its natural beauty.
lead_paragraph: LINZ AM RHEIN, Germany — The bluffs along Germany’s Rhine Valley have attracted tourists since the Romantics sung of their rustic beauty in the mid-19th century. Around the same time, the first railways were built, bringing visitors who admired the crumbling castles atop the vine-clad banks, as well as the region’s white wine.

headline: Mexico Makes Route Tougher for Migrants
abstract: Mexico has taken unusual steps to stem the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States, sweeping trains, setting up checkpoints and raiding hotels and flophouses.
lead_paragraph: TIERRA BLANCA, Mexico — Soon after crossing from Guatemala into Mexico last week, the group of Honduran migrants spotted the police swarming the freight train known as “The Beast” that has dangerously but reliably ferried tens of thousands of people north, clumped atop and hanging off box cars.

headline: Siemens Agrees to Buy Dresser-Rand, an Oil Services Company, for $7.6 Billion
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']

lead_paragraph: Siemens, the German engineering conglomerate, announced late Sunday a deal for the Dresser-Rand Group, an oil products and services company.

headline: Damning Testimony and Telling Emails in Rowland Trial
abstract: An examination of the evidence presented in the trial of John G. Rowland illustrated the fact that despite an earlier conviction, the former governor of Connecticut was still inclined to take, and ask for, favors.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — He was a thrice-elected governor, and last week he became a twice-convicted felon. Watching John G. Rowland come and go each day for his 13-day trial in federal court here offered some surreal moments, and not just because the people of Connecticut had seen this story unfold before.

headline: U.S. Ramping Up Major Renewal in Nuclear Arms
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: An expansion comes under a president who campaigned for “a nuclear-free world” and made disarmament a main goal of American defense policy.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A sprawling new plant here in a former soybean field makes the mechanical guts of America’s atomic warheads. Bigger than the Pentagon, full of futuristic gear and thousands of workers, the plant, dedicated last month, modernizes the aging weapons that the United States can fire from missiles, bombers and submarines.

headline: Report Found Distorted Data on Jail Fights at Rikers Island
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: The top official at Rikers Island ordered portions of a report critical of two wardens be removed, then city officials gave federal investigators the edited version.
lead_paragraph: After years of teenage inmates being slashed, stabbed and maimed, it appeared that the jail for adolescents at Rikers Island had finally been brought under control. In April 2011, a new warden and deputy warden were named, and almost immediately, official tallies of inmate fights fell by two-thirds.

headline: Growing Imbalance Between Germany and France Strains Their Relationship
abstract: French leaders are facing the pressure of their own weakened economy and the continuing austerity push of the German chancellor, Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was a clear illustration of the dysfunction of the French-German partnership, the axis that for decades kept Europe on a united and dynamic track.

abstract: Thousands of Russians marched through Moscow on Sunday in an antigovernment demonstration criticizing President Vladimir V. Putin for what they saw as his warmongering in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Thousands of Russians marched through Moscow on Sunday in an antigovernment demonstration criticizing President Vladimir V. Putin for what they saw as his warmongering in Ukraine.

headline: In Tense Woods, Pennsylvania State Police Shift From Prey to Hunters
abstract: After one of their own was killed and another wounded, law enforcement officers have taken to the Pennsylvania forest to find the person responsible.
lead_paragraph: CANADENSIS, Pa. — The Pennsylvania State Police recommend that you remain in your homes. That you not go into the surrounding woods. That you lock all doors and vehicles, keep the exterior of your home well lit, and if you see a shed open that you remember having closed, report it immediately.

headline: Publications See Pinterest as Key Ally
abstract: Magazines like Better Homes and Gardens and Self increasingly see the photo-sharing site as a critical source of traffic — and emerging trends to cover.
lead_paragraph: Autumn is not yet upon us, but Jill Waage, a top editor at Better Homes and Gardens, has already predicted some of the biggest trends of the coming holidays. Painted pumpkins are about to replace carved pumpkins. Snowman cookies with jiggly eyes will overtake traditional gingerbread men. And decorative ribbons on Christmas presents are going to get much more creative.

headline: Oculus Brings the Virtual Closer to Reality
abstract: Virtual reality technology may attract big money from tech giants, but a conference to showcase one company’s products gave plenty of space to the small fry.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Virtual reality is virtually here — although its first incarnation will come with short battery life, images that do not quite track eye movements and a tendency to induce motion sickness.

abstract: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Manhattan for a rally to demand action on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Manhattan for a rally to demand action on climate change.

abstract: Revealing surprising plot twists and turns of a television show is no longer always seen as a social faux pas, and some experts are studying why.
