headline: Family’s Video Appeals to Iran for Release of American
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Iranian-Americans', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: A video featuring the terminally ill father of Amir Hekmati, who has been incarcerated for three years, was released near the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Anticipating the arrival of Iran’s president in New York on Monday for the annual meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, the family of Amir Hekmati, a former United States Marine incarcerated in Tehran for three years, has called attention to the case by releasing a video in which his father, who has terminal brain cancer, appeals to Iranian leaders for Mr. Hekmati’s freedom.

headline: Sharing Economy Faces Patchwork of Guidelines in European Countries
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Taxation']
abstract: For technology start-ups like Airbnb and Uber, efforts to gain a stronger foothold in European countries have been complicated by varying regulations from different governments.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Start-ups like Uber and Airbnb want European consumers to embrace their companies. Yet when it comes to persuading policy makers, these companies have run into regulatory hurdles that have exposed the European Union’s uneven response to technological innovation.

headline: De Blasio Turns Slow Day Into Adventure
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio took a quick trip to Pittsburgh with his press secretary, Phil Walzak, that included baseball, beer and a performance by a Johnny Cash cover band.
lead_paragraph: It was looking like a slow Saturday for Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: Promises of Greater Home Rule for Scots Turn Contentious
abstract: After voters rejected independence from the United Kingdom, politicians quickly began bickering over how to transfer more powers to Scotland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When more home-rule powers were offered to Scotland in the heat of the country’s independence referendum campaign, the promises came with rare and unqualified support from the three main British political parties, all desperate to avert a Scottish breakaway.

headline: Robert E. Poli, Leader of Pivotal Strike by Air Traffic Controllers, Is Dead at 78
abstract: Mr. Poli received harsh criticism after the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization went on strike in 1981 as President Ronald Reagan responded by dismissing 11,500 controllers in what is now viewed as a seminal moment in the decline of organized labor.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Poli, who led the tumultuous 1981 air traffic controllers’ strike, which prompted President Ronald Reagan to dismiss 11,500 controllers and is viewed as a pivotal moment in the decline of organized labor, died on Sept. 15 at his home in Meridian, Idaho. He was 78.

headline: Kenny Wheeler, Influential Sound in Jazz, Dies at 84
abstract: Critics hailed the ingenuity of Mr. Wheeler’s compositions, which were unfailingly melodic but often veered in unexpected directions, and the understated grace of his playing style.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Wheeler, a jazz trumpeter, flugelhornist and composer who was as comfortable improvising with uncompromising avant-gardists like the saxophonist Anthony Braxton as he was writing challenging arrangements for a big band, died on Thursday in London. He was 84.

headline: A Beauty Line Rooted in the Amazon Rain Forest Introduces a Body Collection
abstract: Rahua adds a trio of items to its existing lineup of natural hair products.
lead_paragraph: The eco-conscious brand Rahua boasts the ultimate in natural resources, the Amazon rain forest, as the foundation of its hair products. There, women in the Quechua-Shuar tribes have cultivated rahua oil, derived from the rare Ungurahua nut, for centuries. That they have long, silky hair is no coincidence — the oil tames and fortifies strands, even in the region’s hot and humid climate. About two decades ago, the hairstylist Fabian Lliguin began using it on his clients in New York. He even bottled it to create a 100 percent natural line of hair products: shampoos, conditioners, treatments and sprays. And today, his company introduces its first set of potions for the body — a shower gel ($30), body lotion ($48) and oil ($57) — infused with additional ingredients indigenous to the Amazon rain forest such as Sacha Inchi and Buriti oils.

headline: A Topsy-Turvy Take on Existence
abstract: The American artist Joel Morrison sees a fragile order behind Mary Jo Bang’s spectral meditation on an unseen photograph.
lead_paragraph: The American artist Joel Morrison sees a fragile order behind Mary Jo Bang’s spectral meditation on an unseen photograph.

headline: Behind the Groundbreaking Design of Aphex Twin’s Record Covers
abstract: As the reclusive genius Richard D. James releases his first album in 13 years, the graphic designer with whom he has frequently collaborated discusses their work together.
lead_paragraph: Ever since a distinctive three-armed logo appeared in the early ’90s on the sleeves of the albums of Aphex Twin — the alias of the prolific electronic music producer Richard D. James — it has remained a vital emblem for dance music fans around the world. So when a lime-green blimp bearing that insignia appeared over London (and mysterious stencils of it appeared on sidewalks around Manhattan and Brooklyn) back in mid-August, electronic music fans rejoiced, knowing that after 13 years, a new Aphex Twin album was coming. Since his disappearance from public view, James’s influence has only grown: His example led Radiohead to embrace electronic music throughout the aughts, he’s been sampled by Kanye West and the electronic dance music poster boy Skrillex has called the Aphex Twin track “Flim” his favorite of all time.

headline: A Globalizer for N.Y.U. in Abu Dhabi
abstract: Bill Bragin, Lincoln Center’s director of public programming, will head New York University’s performing arts center in Abu Dhabi.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Bill Bragin, the music programmer whose hyper-multicultural lineups put Joe’s Pub on the international map, surprised the New York arts world by moving uptown to Lincoln Center. Now he is making an even bigger move, to Abu Dhabi.

headline: A Better Baby I.C.U.
abstract: By many measures, a neonatal intensive care unit with single-family rooms produces better results than one with a shared, open-bay arrangement, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: By many measures, a neonatal intensive care unit, or NICU, with single-family rooms produces better results than one with a shared, open-bay arrangement, a new study has found.

headline: Word of the Day | insurgent
abstract: This word has appeared in 431 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: insurgent •\in-ˈsər-jənt\• adjective and noun

headline: A Half-Marathon Record
abstract: Deena Kastor, 41, set a Masters world record in the half-marathon, finishing the Rock ’n’ Roll Philadelphia Half Marathon in 1 hour 9 minutes 36 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Deena Kastor, 41, set a Masters world record in the half-marathon, finishing the Rock ’n’ Roll Philadelphia Half Marathon in 1 hour 9 minutes 36 seconds. Her time was 20 seconds faster than the mark set by Irina Permitina of Russia in 2008.

headline: Softening the Blow
abstract: Some examples of edits ordered by Dora B. Schiro, then the New York City Department of Correction commissioner, to a 2012 report drafted by investigators.
lead_paragraph: Some examples of edits ordered by Dora B. Schiro, then the New York City Department of Correction commissioner, to a 2012 report drafted by investigators.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) STARRING BRIGITTE BARDOT Turner Classic Movies celebrates the 80th birthday (it’s actually not till Sunday) of Ms. Bardot, the French actress for whom the term “sex kitten” was coined, with five of her signature films. The tribute begins with “And God Created Woman” (1956), which helped rocket Ms. Bardot to international stardom — and popularized the bikini in the process — in her role, directed by Roger Vadim, as a wanton teenage orphan in love with one brother (Jean-Louis Trintignant, above, with Ms. Bardot) but married to the other (Christian Marquand). “This round and voluptuous little French miss is put on spectacular display and is rather brazenly ogled from every allowable point of view,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times, calling her “a phenomenon you have to see to believe.” The lineup continues with Michel Boisrond’s “Une Parisienne” (1957), with Ms. Bardot as a daughter of the French president who falls in love with his chief of staff (Henri Vidal) and flirts with a prince (Charles Boyer), at 9:45; Marc Allégret’s “Plucking the Daisy” (1956), in which she portrays a provocative Parisian schoolgirl, at 11:30; “The Night Heaven Fell” (1958), with Ms. Bardot, whose marriage to the film’s director, Mr. Vadim, ended in 1957, as a convent girl who moves in with relatives in Spain and romances a murderer (Stephen Boyd), at 1:30 a.m.; and Jean-Luc Godard’s “Contempt” (1964), in which a film adaptation of “The Odyssey” produced by an American (Jack Palance) and directed by Fritz Lang (as himself), causes friction between a screenwriter (Michel Piccoli) and his wife (Ms. Bardot), at 3:15.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Buyers of new compact S.U.V.s are mostly 45 and older. Only the Outlander and the Encore drew less than a 20 percent share of buyers between 45 and 64, and among Encore buyers, 23.5 percent were 65 to 74.
lead_paragraph: Buyers of new compact S.U.V.s are mostly 45 and older. Only the Outlander and the Encore drew less than a 20 percent share of buyers between 45 and 64, and among Encore buyers, 23.5 percent were 65 to 74.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Alibaba I.P.O. Underwriters Increase Deal Size to Record-Setting $25 Billion
abstract: After Alibaba’s shares leaped 38 percent on their first day of trading on Friday, the company’s underwriters decided to exercise a so-called green shoe.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, has officially set the record for the biggest initial public offering ever, after its bankers on Friday increased the size of the deal by 15 percent to $25 billion, two people with knowledge of the matter said on Monday.

headline: Battle Heats Up Between Electra Private Equity and Sherborne
abstract: The British private equity firm accused Edward J. Bramson’s Sherborne Investors Management of making “unverifiable statements and unsubstantiated claims” in its effort to reshape Electra.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The war of words is heating up between the activist investor Edward J. Bramson and Electra Private Equity.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Climate Change Demonstrators March in Manhattan
abstract: What event took place on Sunday that sought to draw attention to the issue of climate change?
lead_paragraph: In the article “Climate Change Demands Issued at Events Worldwide,” Lisa Foderaro writes about Sunday’s People’s Climate March.

headline: Test Yourself | A Punk Pastry Chef
abstract: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the Sept. 17 Dining article “If Desserts Could Wear Tattoos.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the Sept. 17 Dining article “If Desserts Could Wear Tattoos.”

headline: How Should Nations and Individuals Address Climate Change?
abstract: What can be done to address climate change, as individuals, community members and global citizens?
lead_paragraph: You have probably heard or read about, or perhaps participated in, one of the 2,700 climate change-related events that took place around the world on Sunday.

headline: Walls of Photos Uniting Little Italy
abstract: An outdoor exhibit on the walls of a Little Italy landmark features a local photographer’s then-and-now images spanning 75 years.
lead_paragraph: Last November, I got a call from Msgr. Donald Sakano, the pastor of the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral in Manhattan, about a former parishioner, Dom Quartuccio. Dom was born and raised in Little Italy and has enjoyed a successful career as a commercial photographer. But now, at the age of 90, he was concerned about his legacy.

headline: Upstart Bank Aldermore to List Shares in London
abstract: The online lender is the latest so-called challenger bank to Britain’s traditional financial powers to seek an initial public offering in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Aldermore said on Monday that it intended to pursue an initial public offering later this year, becoming the latest “challenger” bank to Britain’s traditional financial powers to seek to list its shares in London.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Matt Bai on Gary Hart and the Journalism That Brought Him Down
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Matt Bai wrote this week’s cover story about the scandal that brought down Gary Hart’s presidential campaign in 1987 and how this event changed political journalism. Here, he discusses what first interested him about Hart’s story.
lead_paragraph: Matt Bai wrote the Sept. 21 cover story about the scandal that ended Gary Hart’s presidential campaign in 1987. Bai is the national political columnist for Yahoo News and former chief political correspondent for The New York Times Magazine. The article is an adaptation from his coming book, “All the Truth Is Out: The Week Politics Went Tabloid.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Rural Library Chain Closes, Citing ‘Tremendous Pressure’
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Rural Areas', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: A nongovernmental organization that had run a rural library project with as many as 22 libraries across China has announced it is closing down, pointing to “tremendous pressure” from the local authorities.
lead_paragraph: A nongovernmental organization that had run a rural library project with as many as 22 libraries across China has announced that it is closing down, citing “tremendous pressure” from the local authorities.

headline: In Art of Ryder Cup, Pairings Are the Master Stroke
abstract: For a Ryder Cup captain, success essentially boils down to one skill: finding the right two-man combinations to win points from opponents.
lead_paragraph: Tom Watson can only hope his pairings strategy lasts longer this week than the one he tried the first time he was United States Ryder Cup captain.

headline: Should We Continue to Prosecute Nazi War Criminals?
abstract: The recent conviction of the “accountant of Auschwitz” reinvigorated the debate about prosecuting aging Nazi war criminals.
lead_paragraph: The recent conviction of a 93-year-old Auschwitz guard reignited a debate about prosecuting the remaining few Nazi war criminals. Most observers call for a no-holds-barred hunt for the Holocaust perpetrators who have evaded justice for decades, but others point to their old age, legal issues and difficulty in proving the crimes, arguing that after nearly 80 years, the pursuit should come to a conclusion.

headline: Daily Report: China’s Great Firewall Toughens for Google and Others
abstract: Chinese authorities have tightened censorship over Internet traffic in recent weeks, and Google and its services are particularly affected.
lead_paragraph: Google’s problems in China just got worse, Keith Bradsher and Paul Mozur report.

headline: Hong Kong Students Boycott Classes in Democracy Fight
abstract: The strikers, who said they would skip class all week, are at the vanguard of a series of protests against limits set by China for selection of the city’s leader.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of Hong Kong university students abandoned classes on Monday to rally against Chinese government limits on voting rights, a bellwether demonstration of the city’s appetite for turning smoldering discontent into street-level opposition.

headline: Welcome to First Draft
abstract: Monday marks the debut of First Draft, the new digital exploration of political developments and Washington news from the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: PhotoCredit Stephen Crowley/The New York Times

headline: Merck of Germany to Acquire Sigma-Aldrich for $17 Billion
abstract: The deal is expected to increase Merck’s presence in North America and give it added exposure to markets in Asia. It represents a 37 percent premium to Sigma-Aldrich’s closing price on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Merck of Germany said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the life sciences company Sigma-Aldrich for $17 billion.

headline: For Migrants, a Difficult Journey Through Mexico
abstract: Mexico is trying to disrupt the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States. Many are determined to make the trip anyway.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is trying to disrupt the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States. Many are determined to make the trip anyway.

headline: New York Today: The U.N. Meets
abstract: Monday: The General Assembly convenes, glorious weather, and climate protests continue.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning to you.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 22, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Sept. 23, 2014

headline: The Caucus Ends Its Campaign
abstract: The Caucus on Monday suspended its campaign. Follow First Draft, a fast-paced political briefing on all things Washington and elections.
lead_paragraph: After eight years, five campaign cycles and nearly 20,000 items, The Caucus on Monday suspended its campaign.

headline: Study Finds Small-Business Health Plans Are Cheaper on SHOP
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: But a researcher who produced the data could not explain why.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, in a post answering basic questions about how the Affordable Care Act affects small business, we raised the issue of how insurance premiums purchased on the marketplaces set up for small businesses, known as SHOP exchanges, compare to premiums for insurance purchased off the exchanges. It was something of an unsatisfying discussion.

headline: Vintage to Release García Márquez E-Books
abstract: Nine of Gabriel García Márquez’s works will be released in digital-format English versions in October.
lead_paragraph: Six months after his death at 87, Gabriel García Márquez is finally getting a digital makeover.

headline: Siemens Makes $7.6 Billion Bet on Fracking in U.S.
abstract: With its all-cash deal to buy Dresser-Rand Group, the German engineering conglomerate is positioning itself in the American energy sector, which is seeing a boom in shale oil.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The German engineering conglomerate Siemens already makes a range of products for the American energy sector, including gas turbines and equipment for generating electricity from wind.

headline: Gillibrand’s Weight Watcher Revealed, and a Presidential Nominee Is Sunk
abstract: Gillibrand’s Weight Watcher Revealed, and a Presidential Nominee Is Sunk
lead_paragraph: PhotoCredit Left, Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; right, Christopher Gregory/The New York Times

headline: Morning Agenda: Alibaba’s I.P.O. Aftermath
abstract: Alibaba soared in its public market debut. | Siemens agreed to buy the Dresser-Rand Group. | EMC weighed a deal with H.P. | Public pension funds may be souring on hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: ALIBABA’S I.P.O. AFTERMATH | For months, investors eagerly awaited the Alibaba Group’s public market debut. Now, with the Chinese e-commerce giant’s first day of trading solidly in the rearview mirror, nearly everyone is likely breathing a sigh of relief. After pricing at $68 a share, Alibaba’s stock finished Friday up 38 percent, at $93.89, giving the company a market value of $231 billion, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The company officially set the record for the biggest initial public offering ever, after its bankers on Friday decided to exercise a so-called green shoe option, allowing them to increase the size of the deal by 15 percent, from $21.8 billion to $25 billion.

headline: In Context, Health Premium Increases Don’t Actually Look Like Increases
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: When inflation and the cost of old insurance markets are considered, the premiums available to consumers willing to shop around are remarkably low.
lead_paragraph: In the Affordable Care Act marketplaces, which now serve 7.3 million Americans, some premiums are going up while others are going down. Based on data available so far, we reported last week that the average premiums for last year’s most popular plans would rise 8.4 percent, but that people willing to switch plans could get much better deals — an average 1 percent increase, and even decreases in some markets.

headline: A History of the United Nations in Pictures
abstract: A look at the visitors and the activities at the United Nations over the years.
lead_paragraph: A look at the visitors and the activities at the United Nations over the years.

headline: Schools Under Fire for Too Much Pomp in Military Training
abstract: College administrators in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui have come under criticism for conducting head-of-state-style reviews of students participating in military-style training.
lead_paragraph: College administrators in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui have come under criticism for conducting reviews of students participating in military-style training in a style reminiscent of a head of state. At two private colleges in Hefei, school officials rode in black Audis, the car favored by government cadres, and one of the officials parroted lines that could have come from the Chinese president’s mouth on a National Day celebration.

headline: Mitsubishi to Buy Salmon Producer for $1.39 Billion
abstract: Cermaq, which has operations in Chile and Canada, as well as in Norway, is one of the biggest companies in the world in salmon farming
lead_paragraph: Cermaq, a Norwegian state-controlled salmon producer, has agreed to be acquired by the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan for $1.39 billion.

headline: First Draft’s First Day
abstract: Carl Hulse, The Times’s chief Washington correspondent and managing editor of First Draft, a political news stream and morning email that began today, shares what went in to beginning the project.
lead_paragraph: Carl Hulse is The Times’s chief Washington correspondent and managing editor of First Draft, a political news stream and morning email that began today. He explains what went in to beginning the new project:

headline: Alaska Ad Finds a Target in Begich’s Support of Gun Rights
abstract: Dan Sullivan releases a new ad criticizing Senator Mark Begich on gun control.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mark Begich of Alaska was one of just five Democratic senators who voted against a bipartisan gun control bill last year, helping to ensure its failure.

headline: David Carr: By the Book
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Pamela Paul, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, extends the “By the Book” column to Times writers and editors. This week she spoke with David Carr.
lead_paragraph: In a new Insider feature, Pamela Paul, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, extends the “By the Book” column to Times writers and editors.

headline: Auxilium’s Board Rejects Takeover Approach From Endo
abstract: The Pennsylvania biopharmaceutical company agreed in June to acquire QLT and reincorporate in Canada, but received an unsolicited bid from Endo International earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: Auxilium Pharmaceuticals said on Monday that its board of directors had rejected an unsolicited takeover approach from Endo International, a pharmaceutical company that struck an inversion deal last year and reincorporated in Ireland.

headline: Tesco Says It Overstated Profit Forecast
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The British grocery retailer said the half-year profit forecast it had given was overstated by £250 million and it had suspended four executives.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tesco, the large British grocery retailer, disclosed on Monday that it had overstated its expected half-year profit by about $400 million and that it had suspended four senior executives.

headline: First-Weekend Sales of Apple’s iPhone 6 Models Top 10 Million
abstract: The strong demand for Apple’s new devices mirrors growing consumer interest in smartphones with bigger screens.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s investors obsess over early iPhone sales like Hollywood producers tracking opening ticket sales for a blockbuster movie.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: Tibetan Student Burns Himself to Death in Protest
keywords: ['Immolation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The 22-year-old man was protesting Chinese rule. It was the first self-immolation in five months, a human rights organization said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Tibetan student burned himself to death last week in protest of Chinese rule in the first self-immolation in five months, an international human rights organization reported on Monday.

headline: Life in Belle Epoque America
abstract: And now for something prurient.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic has an article about a website that sets up “mutually beneficial relationships” between wealthy older men and college students. Yes, it’s prurient, and I’m probably a dirty old man for even linking to it — although what really caught my eye was just how closely reality echoes Woody Allen’s (speaking of dirty old men) story “The Whore of Mensa“.

headline: Ready for Impact: The Clintons’ Annual Extravaganza
abstract: The Clinton Global Initiative gathering kicks off Monday.
lead_paragraph: What do you get when you put Hollywood starlets, a couple of Nobel Peace Prize winners, chief executives of several multinational corporations, the king of Jordan and a current, a former and a potentially future United States president together in the lobby of a middling Times Square hotel?

headline: Explosions Kill at Least 2 in Restive Region of China
abstract: The blasts in Xinjiang occurred on the same day that 17 officials were punished for failing to prevent attacks in July that left almost 100 dead.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A series of explosions in the Xinjiang region of northwest China has killed at least two people and caused an unknown number of injuries, state news media reported Monday.

headline: Verbatim: Bloomberg on Balancing Work and Life
abstract: Michael Bloomberg said he returned to his company recently “because the alternative was staying home and talking to Diana about feelings.”
lead_paragraph: “Because the alternative was staying home and talking to Diana about feelings” — Michael R. Bloomberg, explaining why he returned recently to the company he founded. He was referring to Diana Taylor, his girlfriend.

headline: A Super-Simple, Step-by-Step Guide to Determine if Your Team Mascot Is Offensive
abstract: What matters is the consensus view of the people your team is named for.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of debate in the news about whether the team name of the Washington N.F.L. team is racially offensive and ought to be changed. On Friday, David Leonhardt saw a reason to predict that the team name “Redskins” was not long for this world.

headline: A Nosedive in Public Approval for Obama on Immigration
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Recent polling shows a steep drop in the public’s approval of his handling of immigration.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s poor approval ratings have been widely reported. But what is especially striking, in a recent New York Times/CBS survey, is how precipitously the president has fallen on the issue of immigration.

headline: The Temporary-Equilibrium Method (Very Wonkish)
abstract: Not Truth, but Utility.
lead_paragraph: David Glasner has some thoughts about macroeconomic methodology, reacting to my own previous piece, that I mostly agree with, but not entirely. So, a bit more.

headline: In Milan, Sneakers and Slides
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Sneakers', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Designers are eschewing the towering stilettos of yore for flat footwear.
lead_paragraph: Designers are eschewing the towering stilettos of yore for flat footwear.

headline: A Tower Will Rise Next to, and Over, a Paint-Spattered Landmark
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Plans for the Nordstrom Tower have been adjusted so that it will jut out over the 1892 Art Students League building.
lead_paragraph: In a city built on unlikely juxtapositions, there may be no odder neighbors than the Art Students League, which occupies an ornate French Renaissance-style building at 215 West 57th Street, and the Nordstrom Tower, an ultramodern pillar, at least 1,500 feet tall, that will rise beside it.

headline: The ’70s in Milan
abstract: The ubiquity of the decade in both catwalk and accessory presentations this week was almost unprecedented.
lead_paragraph: The ubiquity of the decade in both catwalk and accessory presentations this week was almost unprecedented.

headline: An Article on Shonda Rhimes Rightly Causes a Furor
abstract: The article intended to praise the TV producer, but it insulted black women instead.
lead_paragraph: The article on the television producer Shonda Rhimes hadn’t yet appeared in Sunday’s paper, but the virtual world was ablaze in protest over it on Friday after it was published online.

headline: P2 Capital Partners Raises Pressure on Epiq, a Maker of Legal Software
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: After Epiq Systems, a software company that provides legal documents for bankruptcy and class-action cases, rejected a $1.1 billion take-private offer from P2 Capital Partners, the hedge fund increased its stake in the company to 17 percent.
lead_paragraph: After several months of discussions, Epiq Systems, a software company that provides legal documents for bankruptcy and class-action cases and discovery, rejected a $1.1 billion offer from the hedge fund P2 Capital Partners to take the company private.

headline: The White House Front Door, When Entered Properly
abstract: A brief history of the White House’s North Portico.
lead_paragraph: The White House door that a knife-carrying fence jumper waltzed through on Friday night, prompting a review of procedures by the Secret Service, is not just the entrance to one of the nation’s most supposedly secure facilities. It is also one of the most famous entryways anywhere, where world leaders are greeted and departing presidents meet their successors.

headline: 1889: Five Miles a Minute
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Concepts for high-speed rail travel were discussed in 1889.
lead_paragraph: After the telephone and the phonograph one can believe almost any imaginable electrical miracle, and therefore the claim that an electric railway motor has been invented which, on a specially constructed road, can whisk passengers and freight along at the rate of 300 miles an hour does not seem incredible. In fact, it is asserted that a speed of 180 miles an hour has already been attained on an experimental road. Should the invention prove successful, it will bring London within an hour of Paris — exclusive of the Channel passage — and will enable the Londoner to do business in the city and to sleep in the Scottish Highlands every night. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 23, 1889

headline: Final Trends and Tidbits to Know From Milan
abstract: As the shows came to a close, the conversations continued.
lead_paragraph: The reports have been written, the reviews are in, but after the sensory extravaganza that was Milan Fashion Week, some outstanding questions may still be niggling. In an effort to wipe the slate clean and to allow us all a fresh start in Paris, here are four questions that bubbled up in conversations from the catwalk to cocktails, and responses to keep you in the know:

headline: Nothing Natural About This
abstract: From a PVC raincoat to a bonded latex cable-knit, synthetic materials are making a range of everyday fashion staples feel unexpectedly subversive.
lead_paragraph: From a PVC raincoat to a bonded latex cable-knit, synthetic materials are making a range of everyday fashion staples feel unexpectedly subversive.

headline: Ask Us Anything: First Draft’s Politics Help Line
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Political Advertising', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We’re reprising the fact-checking effort from the 2012 presidential election, but putting a First Draft spin on it.
lead_paragraph: Have a question about what seems to be an exaggerated claim in a campaign advertisement? Or the accuracy of a statement made on the trail?

headline: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to Open United Nations Meetings
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Ebola Virus', 'Global Warming', 'International Relations', 'Millennium Development Goals', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Ban Ki-Moon, the United Nations secretary general, will open the international Climate Summit and the 69th session of the General Assembly this week with some of the most difficult challenges of his tenure dominating the agenda including Ebola and ethnic violence around the world that is driving populations from their homes.
lead_paragraph: On Monday at the United Nations, the first world conference on indigenous peoples began, the day before Ban Ki-Moon, the United Nations secretary general, opened the Climate Summit. Wednesday, the secretary general opens the 69th session of the General Assembly. It has been an important week for the United Nations, and for Mr. Ban, who will speak before the General Assembly meeting.

headline: Spanking Isn’t Culture. It’s a Cycle of Abuse.
keywords: ['ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'School Discipline (Students)']
abstract: Adrian Peterson shouldn’t sell himself short. He is where he is today in spite of his father, not because of him, and what he learned from him now threatens his career and his family.
lead_paragraph: As the debate rages over Adrian Peterson’s child abuse charges, his defenders, including Charles Barkley, have suggested that this particular kind of discipline — lashing a child with a switch — is “cultural” and therefore beyond reproach.

headline: What to Wear This Week: Sept. 22
abstract: This is an appropriate time to consider utilitarian fashion without having to wait for those spring looks to hit the stores.
lead_paragraph: During the recent New York spring shows, Marc Jacobs presented several cargo looks that seemed to borrow from a police officer’s uniform. There were also military-inspired dresses at No. 21 and Gucci. Then, at Milan Fashion Week, we saw a similar idea at the Salvatore Ferragamo show.

headline: 1939: Line of Demarcation Decided
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Plans for the partition of Poland were revealed in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Following the departure from Moscow yesterday morning of a German military mission charged with the negotiation for the partition of Poland between Germany and Russia, the D.N.B., official German news agency, announced that both governments ‘‘had fixed the line of demarcation between the German and Russian armies,’’ a Havas dispatch from Berne said. According to the D.N.B. communiqué, Germany abandons the idea of re-establishing the German and Russian occupation zones agreed upon in the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk in 1917. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 23, 1939

headline: Medicaid Gives the Poor a Reason to Say No Thanks
abstract: Now that some programs are charging premiums, people may be discouraged from obtaining health insurance.
lead_paragraph: There are generally two ways that people with insurance pay for health care in the United States: premiums, which get you insurance before you receive care, and a variety of cost-sharing mechanisms — like deductibles, co-pays and coinsurance — that come into play when you do receive it.

headline: First Draft | Biden on Gridlock
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. says a main reason for gridlock in Washington is that politics have become too personal.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. says a main reason for gridlock in Washington is that politics have become too personal.

headline: ‘The Voice’s’ Secret to Longevity
abstract: The NBC singing competition has managed to keep its judges’ panel fresh and lively, qualities that were apparent at a recent luncheon.
lead_paragraph: After a press lunch the other day with cast members from “The Voice,” NBC sent everyone home with goodie bags. The contents included a bottle of Ketel One vodka, around which was tied an index card containing a recipe for “Carson Daly’s Hangover-Curing Magical Bloody Mary.”

headline: First Draft Video: Biden on Fixing Washington
abstract: “Politics has become too personal,” said Mr. Biden in an exclusive interview with First Draft.
lead_paragraph: As a four-decade veteran of the Senate and now the White House, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been in the middle of plenty of political scuffles and has seen Washington at its worst up close.

headline: What Is the Right Way to Travel?
abstract: The bucket list encourages us to seek activities for their novelty. But how might we travel in a way that encourages meaningful experience?
lead_paragraph: Wherefore the bucket list? Rebecca Mead recently wrote a blog post for The New Yorker about “Kicking the Bucket List,” a plea for abolishing the practice of seeking experiences for the sake of accomplishment. Instead, Ms. Mead lobbies in favor of an approach to life that engages deeply with a smaller range of experiences.

headline: Hong Kong Students Rally for Reform
abstract: Pro-democracy protesters explain why they gathered at the Chinese University of Hong Kong for the start of a week-long boycott of classes.
lead_paragraph: Pro-democracy protesters explain why they gathered at the Chinese University of Hong Kong for the start of a week-long boycott of classes.

headline: Woman Hit by a Bicyclist in Central Park Dies
abstract: Jill Tarlov, 58, of Fairfield, Conn., had been in critical condition since Thursday; the bicyclist who hit her has not been charged with any crime.
lead_paragraph: A woman whom a cyclist struck in Central Park last week died Sunday night, her family said on Monday

headline: Today in Small Business: How a Store Smells
abstract: How Zulily found its voice and increased its social media presence through humor. Fifteen mistakes to avoid in a content marketing strategy. Should a business owner contact police about a deceitful former employee?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Wine as the Supporting Player in an Ensemble Cast at Home
abstract: Enjoying wine at home: a guide for the avid drinker.
lead_paragraph: People who love wine generally consume more of it at home than anywhere else. And regardless of the quality of their glasses or the extent of their cellars, those who most enjoy wine at home share one attribute: a commitment to drinking it.

headline: Seeking a Same-Sex Marriage Case Fit for History
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Battling for a place in the ages, some of the best lawyers in the nation have spent many pages arguing that their case was the right one in which to establish a nationwide right to same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The jockeying among the titans of the Supreme Court bar for a place at the lectern when the justices hear the next same-sex marriage case is as understated as it is unmistakable.

headline: Theatrics to Come on the U.N. Security Council
abstract: Venezuela may represent the Latin American and Caribbean nations – and sit right next to the United States.
lead_paragraph: There could be major drama on the United Nations Security Council next year if, as widely expected, Venezuela gets a seat adjacent to that of its nemesis, the United States, to represent Latin American and Caribbean nations.

headline: What Wake-up Call? Catering to Sleepers-In
abstract: Hotels, cruise lines and tour companies are now creating activities for travelers who like to sleep.
lead_paragraph: The travel industry is geared toward early risers: activities and tours tend to begin in the morning, and breakfast is usually served for a limited time. That’s finally changing with more hotels, cruise lines and tour companies catering to travelers who like to sleep in or want a leisurely start to their day.

headline: Climate Change Protesters Tangle With Police at Wall St.
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators, protesting what they said was capitalism’s influence over environment-harming practices, struggled to get to their destination. About 100 were arrested.
lead_paragraph: About 100 climate change protesters were arrested on Monday as hundreds marched through the streets of Lower Manhattan, at one point clashing with the police as they tried to push through barricades sealing off Wall Street.

headline: Prosecutor Warns That Rikers Island Problems May Prompt U.S. Lawsuit
abstract: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, indicated that the de Blasio administration was not moving fast enough to address a culture of violence at the New York City jail complex.
lead_paragraph: As alarm mounted this year over conditions at the Rikers Island jail complex, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio largely managed to escape scrutiny, because the problems were rooted in its predecessor.

headline: Iggy Pop to Lecture at British Radio Festival
abstract: The punk rock godfather will deliver the fourth annual John Peel Lecture at Radio Festival 2014, in October.
lead_paragraph: Iggy Pop has been lots of things – a thrashing founder of punk rock, a film and television actor, the author of an autobiography, a radio show host and even an opera singer (in John Moran’s avant-garde opera “The Manson Family”). But if you were looking for someone to deliver a lecture, he might not leap immediately to mind.

headline: Why Is Unemployment High? Lazy Americans, Boehner Says
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner seemed to blame lazy Americans for the stalled economy.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner opens virtually every news conference with, “Mr. President, where are the jobs?” a dig at an Obama economy that he says is still not working. But last week, he appeared to undermine his own message when he suggested that the unemployed were not victims of failing economic policies, but of sloth.

headline: Gary Hewitt’s Numberplay Comment Enhancer
abstract: A short introduction to using Gary Hewitt’s comment enhancer for the Numberplay blog.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Numberplay blog, like many blogs featured in The Times online, offers a terrific way to connect with a community of passionate and articulate readers from around the world. Numberplay conversations are a lot like those you’d find gathered around any blog, with a couple additional features: The conversations are about math, which means formulas may be sprinkled into the mix, and they’re also highly collaborative.

headline: A Light Touch
abstract: Cedric Hartman’s understated floor lamp became an immediate design classic when it launched in 1966 — and has never fallen from favor.
lead_paragraph: Cedric Hartman’s understated floor lamp became an immediate design classic when it launched in 1966 — and has never fallen from favor.

headline: Charles Plosser and Richard Fisher, Both Dissenters, to Retire From Fed
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Charles Plosser, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said that he would retire in March. Richard Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve of Dallas, is required to step down in April.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Federal Reserve officials who have warned loudly and persistently that the Fed is overreaching in its economic stimulus campaign plan to retire next year after completing terms on the Fed’s policy-making committee.

headline: Gary Hewitt’s Train Puzzle
abstract: How to decide where best to board your train, in a puzzle from Gary Hewitt.
lead_paragraph: Before we get to this week’s puzzle — several days ago I asked Donald Knuth, the legendary computer scientist currently at Stanford University, how he would have solved our recent Bugs on a Square problem, which is a classic among software engineers. He responded by saying he would have worked the problem out with algebra (and not a simulation, which surprised me). And then he followed with a fitting analogy for the kind of puttering that defines Numberplay.

headline: Many Americans Want More Religion in Their Politics
abstract: Many are upset about the declining role of religion in politics.
lead_paragraph: The Pew Research Center reported Monday that 72 percent of Americans believe religion is losing its influence on American life, a striking development in a nation where religious arguments, religious leaders and religious voting blocs have long played an important role.

headline: Morgan Exhibition Will Feature Lincoln’s Words
abstract: “Lincoln Speaks: Words that Transformed a Nation” will mark the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination and the end of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The Abraham Lincoln juggernaut that will get under way next year – on the 150th anniversary of his assassination and the end of the Civil War – will include a major component in New York, centered around perhaps Lincoln’s greatest legacy: his words.

headline: In the Studio | Alber Elbaz of Lanvin
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Alber Elbaz, the creative director for Lanvin, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his all-black office in Paris is the only place he feels “skinny and beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: Alber Elbaz, the creative director for Lanvin, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how his all-black office in Paris is the only place he feels “skinny and beautiful.”

headline: A Quick Lesson in Politics for Donald Trump
abstract: If the Republicans were to win control of the Senate in November, Senator Mitch McConnell would become Senate Majority Leader, not Speaker of the House.
lead_paragraph: First Draft context: If the Republicans were to win control of the Senate in November, Senator Mitch McConnell would most likely become Senate majority leader, not speaker of the House.

headline: Weeks of U.S. Strikes Fail to Dislodge ISIS in Iraq
abstract: After six weeks of Western air support, Iraqi forces have scarcely budged the militant fighters from their hold on more than a quarter of the country.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — After six weeks of American airstrikes, the Iraqi government’s forces have scarcely budged the Sunni extremists of the Islamic State from their hold on more than a quarter of the country, in part because many critical Sunni tribes remain on the sidelines.

headline: ScienceTake | Ice Fish Don’t Melt
abstract: Natural antifreeze in the blood of Antarctic fish also keeps ice crystals from normal melting.
lead_paragraph: Natural antifreeze in the blood of Antarctic fish also keeps ice crystals from normal melting.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies reorganizes its handling of the Cadillac account.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Adams joined Maxus, part of the GroupM unit of WPP, in a new post, chief digital officer for North America, based in New York. He had been senior vice president and lead for North American media at iCrossing, part of the Hearst Corporation. At iCrossing, Christine Bensen was promoted to succeed Mr. Adams with the title of senior vice president for media and head of the media practice.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Remembering the glorious artwork of two car-ad illustrators, Art Fitzpatrick and Van Kaufman.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Valuing SoftBank in Alibaba’s Aftermath
abstract: A decline in SoftBank’s shares after the I.P.O. is a reminder that the investment is both blessing and burden, writes Una Galani of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba’s runaway initial public offering has turned the spotlight back onto SoftBank’s valuation quandary. Following the Chinese e-commerce company’s successful New York listing, the Japanese conglomerate’s 32 percent stake eclipses the value of its other businesses. The 5 percent drop in SoftBank’s shares on Monday is a reminder that the investment is both blessing and burden.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Case a Chance to Make History
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Same-Sex Marriage Case A Chance to Make History
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court finally takes up the issue of same-sex marriage, it will no doubt make history. And the battle for the history books is a fierce one for America’s legal luminaries.

headline: Cash-Stuffed German Companies on a Global Buying Spree
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A rare bright spot in the European economy in recent years, many of the biggest German companies have begun capitalizing on their strength, striking big deals for overseas competitors.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s businesses have been the rare bright spot in the European economy in recent years, generating jobs and profits even as neighboring countries face persistent unemployment.

headline: An Attack on Guns Tests Good Will Toward Giffords
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Tucson Shooting (2011)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gabrielle Giffords is set to find out just what sort of leeway being the nation’s most recognizable — and well liked — gunshot victim gives you when it comes to political attack ads.
lead_paragraph: Gabrielle Giffords is about to find out just what sort of leeway being the nation’s most recognizable — and well liked — gunshot victim gives you when it comes to political attack ads.

headline: Portraits of Women Take Over an Oxford Dining Hall
abstract: Hertford College’s all-male portrait gallery will be filled with photographs of distinguished women.
lead_paragraph: Hertford College, one of the first colleges at Oxford University to admit women for both housing and instruction, is celebrating 40 years of coeducation by belatedly giving women a full place at the table, figuratively speaking.

headline: Testing Future Conditions for the Food Chain
abstract: Researchers are trying to mimic the growing conditions expected to arise decades in the future as the air fills with heat-trapping gases and other pollutants from human activity, with some worrisome results.
lead_paragraph: SAVOY, Ill. — From afar, the three young men tramping through a corn field here looked like Midwestern farm boys checking their crop. And a fine crop it seemed to be, with plump ears hanging off vibrant green stalks.

headline: Humanity’s Long Climate and Energy March
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The giant climate march in Manhattan was just one facet of humanity’s long climate and energy march.
lead_paragraph: The People’s Climate March, a globe-spanning set of demonstrations centered in Manhattan, was a testament to environmentalists’ fortitude and organizational skills and a spreading sense that humanity’s fossil-fueled path — and, for some, the economic model underpinning it — is not sustainable. I was glad to see big contingents of students in the crowds, representing the generation that inherits the epic task of shifting humanity’s energy menu.

headline: Jack Ma on Alibaba, Entrepreneurs and the Role of Handstands
abstract: Alibaba’s founder spoke of building his company and creating jobs, Bill George writes in an Another View column. “They call me ‘Crazy Jack,’” Mr. Ma said. “I hope to stay crazy for the next 30 years.”
lead_paragraph: Bill George is a professor of management at Harvard Business School and a former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic.

headline: White House Will Use Locks More Often
abstract: White House Not Changing the Locks Just Yet
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:34 p.m. |

headline: New Initiative for Special Olympics Aims for More Spontaneity, Less Marketing
abstract: A campaign featuring a red ball concentrates on unity, and also serves as a lead-up to next year’s Special Olympics World Games.
lead_paragraph: A red ball is the star of a campaign for the Special Olympics, aimed at youth around the world, that seeks support and encouragement for people with intellectual disabilities.

headline: Michigan Music School Concert to Feature Gershwin’s Piano
abstract: The last piano George Gershwin owned will be part of a concert at the University of Michigan’s music school in October.
lead_paragraph: The last piano George Gershwin owned and performed on – a Steinway Model A, made in 1933 and delivered to Gershwin in January, 1934 – will make its 21st-century public debut in a free concert at the University of Michigan’s School of Music, Theater & Dance, in Ann Arbor, Mich., on Oct. 10, the university announced.

headline: At a New Amsterdam Pop-Up, Dining Among Rembrandts in the Sky
abstract: Heavenly Rembrandt is a temporary restaurant serving up fine cuisine and lectures from a 35th-floor boardroom installed with the artist’s etchings.
lead_paragraph: “Cooking is like painting with taste, so I was fascinated by the idea of creating a menu based on Rembrandt’s work,” says the Dutch chef Wilco Berends, explaining why he chose to head the kitchen at Heavenly Rembrandt, a pop-up dinner-only restaurant that is set to be one of the most intriguing events in Amsterdam this fall. The interdisciplinary project, which opens tonight, is a collaboration between the Het Rembrandthuis museum, which occupies the house where the painter lived and worked from 1639 to 1658; Berends, who normally cooks at his Michelin-starred De Nederlanden restaurant in Vreeland; and the Rembrandt Tower boardrooms, a plush suite of private meeting rooms atop the 35-story, 500-foot-tall Rembrandt Tower, the city’s tallest building.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Tracks’
abstract: The Times film critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Tracks.”
lead_paragraph: The Times film critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Tracks.”

headline: Leading French Chef Has Plans for New York
abstract: Anne-Sophie Pic, the fourth female chef in the world to be awarded three Michelin stars, plans to open two restaurants in the city next year.
lead_paragraph: Anne-Sophie Pic, one of only a few female chefs in the world to be awarded three Michelin stars, for her restaurant in the South of France, will extend her reach to New York City next year.

headline: Raids by ISIS Push Flood of Refugees Into Turkey
abstract: Turkey’s deputy prime minister said the Islamic State’s advance was causing a crisis “worse than a natural disaster” in his country.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — More than 130,000 refugees have flooded into Turkey from Syria in recent days, fleeing attacks by Islamic State militants on their villages, Turkey’s deputy prime minister said on Monday, though local officials in Syria said Kurdish militias had blunted the militants’ advance there.

headline: Verbatim: The Clinton Family Business
abstract: Bill Clinton speaks on why Chelsea and Hillary Clinton are taking a bigger role the family’s philanthropic foundation.
lead_paragraph: — Bill Clinton, on why Chelsea and Hillary Clinton are taking a bigger role in the family’s philanthropic foundation.

headline: Criticism of Study Detecting Ripples From Big Bang Continues to Expand
abstract: Astronomers who say they detected ripples from the Big Bang appear to have underestimated the extent to which interstellar dust could have contaminated their results.
lead_paragraph: Stardust got in their eyes.

headline: Barclays Hires Former Citigroup Banker to Head Wealth Management
abstract: Akshaya Bhargava will join the bank on Oct. 13 as chief executive of wealth and investment management. He founded InfraHedge, a platform for institutional investors in hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British lender Barclays said on Monday that it had hired a former banker at Citigroup to head its wealth management business.

headline: No Comment Necessary: ‘Officer-Involved Shooting – You Can Win With the Media’
abstract: Post-Ferguson, the St. Louis County and Municipal Police Academy is offering a training course for public-relations disasters.
lead_paragraph: Post-Ferguson, the St. Louis County and Municipal Police Academy is offering a training course on how to “win with the media,” which promises “numerous practical tips for handling the media in an officer-involved shooting.”

headline: Pennsylvania State Police Say They Are Close to Capturing Suspect in Troopers’ Shooting
abstract: Lt. Col. George Bivens said investigators were “following up very aggressively” on tips regarding the whereabouts of Eric M. Frein, the focus of an intensive manhunt now in its 10th day.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMING GROVE, Pa., — Pennsylvania authorities said Monday that they believed they were closing in on a self-taught survivalist accused of killing one state trooper and wounding a second during an ambush earlier this month outside a police barracks in the Pocono Mountains.

headline: Hurd: Oracle Takes On Microsoft in the Cloud
abstract: The opening keynote at Oracle’s annual conference will be about its“unique opportunity to be the leader of the next generation of cloud,” according to Mark Hurd, the new co-chief.
lead_paragraph: Not to give too much away, but Mark Hurd, the newly minted co-chief executive of Oracle Corporation, is ready for a battle. It starts this Sunday night, and it features his boss, Lawrence J. Ellison, throwing down against Microsoft for control of corporate cloud computing applications.

headline: Talk in Synagogue of Israel and Gaza Goes From Debate to Wrath to Rage
abstract: Israel’s occupation of Arab lands and its standoff with the Palestinians have become so divisive that many rabbis say it is impossible to have a civil conversation about Israel in their synagogues.
lead_paragraph: With the war in Gaza still raging, Rabbi Sharon Kleinbaum offered an unusual prayer for peace last month during a Friday night service at the large predominantly gay synagogue she leads in New York. Cautioning her flock not to “harden our hearts” against any who had suffered, she wove throughout the prayer the names of young Israeli soldiers — as well as Palestinian children — who were killed in Gaza.

headline: Muti Withdraws From Rome Opera Performances
abstract: Riccardo Muti will not conduct two scheduled performances at Teatro dell’Opera di Roma this season, saying that conditions at the theater did not “guarantee the serenity I need.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — Riccardo Muti will not conduct two operas scheduled for the upcoming season at the Teatro dell’Opera di Roma, citing “recent, persistent problems” at the storied — and strike-plagued — theater. Carlo Fuortes, the opera’s general manager, announced the split on Sunday, citing a personal letter by the maestro stating that conditions at the theater did not “guarantee the serenity I need to ensure the success of the performances.”

headline: If Nothing Else, a Speech From Obama on Climate
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: White House outlines President Obama’s speech to the U.N. Climate Summit.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama addresses the United Nations Climate Summit on Tuesday, he won’t be announcing a breakthrough on environmental policy. Opposition in Congress to carbon taxes remains high, and expectations for progress around the world are low, as rich and poor countries continue to clash over long-simmering environmental disputes.

headline: Picking the ‘Right’ Hedge Fund Involves More Than Looking in the Past
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Investors should take note of the path taken last week by Calpers, a financial adviser writes.
lead_paragraph: Early in my career, I worked at a large brokerage firm. My job included answering calls from people with questions. One question kept coming up: What does your Individual Retirement Account return? The first few times, I thought it was a joke. But it didn’t take long for me to realize that people just didn’t understand the difference between an I.R.A. and the investments held in an I.R.A.

headline: Pursuit of Individuals in Corporate Misconduct Still Arduous
abstract: The government is pledging to hold individuals accountable for corporate wrongdoing, but bringing charges could prove elusive, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department went on a bit of a charm offensive last week to emphasize to the public that prosecutions for corporate misconduct should not end with just a settlement with the company, which these days usually means paying a hefty fine that causes its stock price to rise. Instead, prosecutors want to focus on reaching individuals within an organization who are responsible for the wrongdoing, including those in the so-called C-suite, where senior officers preside over the operation.

headline: Portland Will Still Be Cool, but Anchorage May Be the Place to Be
abstract: Scientists trying to predict the consequences of climate change see few havens from future storms, floods and droughts. But some regions will fare much better than others.
lead_paragraph: Alaskans, stay in Alaska. People in the Midwest and the Pacific Northwest, sit tight.

headline: A Reading of “Long-Exposure Photograph of a Man” by Mary Jo Bang
abstract: The American poet reads her verse on an unseen photograph.
lead_paragraph: The American poet reads her verse on an unseen photograph.

headline: New Chief of Spy Unit Is Appointed in Pakistan
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The new head of the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence agency, Lt. Gen. Rizwan Akhtar, may offer American officials hope of a better relationship.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military chief, Gen. Raheel Sharif, on Monday appointed a close ally as head of the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence spy agency, consolidating his power at a time of sharp tension with the country’s civilian leaders and fluctuating policy toward the Taliban.

headline: Veteran Bon Appetit Writer Named as Editor in Chief of Saveur
abstract: Adam Sachs, the writer of Bon Appetit’s “Obsessivore” column, will replace James Oseland, who has served as Saveur’s editor since 2006.
lead_paragraph: The food magazine Saveur has announced that Adam Sachs, a veteran writer of GQ and Bon Appetit, will become the magazine’s next editor in chief.

headline: For Polar Bears, a Climate Change Twist
abstract: When sea ice melts and polar bears meet snow geese on their nests, the effects of climate change get complicated.
lead_paragraph: LA PÉROUSE BAY, Manitoba — The sea ice here on the western shore of Hudson Bay breaks up each summer and leaves the polar bears swimming for shore. The image of forlorn bears on small rafts of ice has become a symbol of the dangers of climate change.

headline: Fast Food for Polar Bears
abstract: Polar bears have become a symbol of the danger of climate change, but in the Western Hudson Bay, scientists have found that our understanding of climate change may not be as simple as it seemed.
lead_paragraph: Polar bears have become a symbol of the danger of climate change, but in the Western Hudson Bay, scientists have found that our understanding of climate change may not be as simple as it seemed.

headline: Obama Not Bailing on a Judicial Nominee
abstract: Obama is not pulling back on his support of Judge Boggs yet.
lead_paragraph: As First Draft reported this morning, Michael Boggs’s prospects of being confirmed to the federal bench in Georgia are not looking good.

headline: Draghi Pessimism on European Recovery Stirs Expectations of Stimulus
abstract: The European Central Bank president’s remarks at a news conference gave rise to speculation that quantitative easing may be in store.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, gave a more pessimistic view of the eurozone economy on Monday than he did just a few weeks ago, in a statement that could encourage speculation that a stronger stimulus plan is in the works.

headline: In California, a Marriage of Dance and Design
abstract: Anna Halprin, the 94-year-old dance pioneer, on collaborating with her husband, Lawrence, and a flock of artists and architects.
lead_paragraph: In 1966, the landscape architect Lawrence Halprin and the dance pioneer Anna Halprin invited 40 young people to Northern California to participate in a roving summer workshop. Moving from San Francisco north to Sea Ranch, the modernist coastal development master-planned by Mr. Halprin, the architects, artists and dancers investigated the common ground between the couple’s two professions: the environment. They staged a happening in Union Square, took blindfolded walks, built a village of driftwood and dropped paper from trees. A new exhibition at the Graham Foundation in Chicago, “Experiments in Environment: The Halprin Workshops, 1966-1971,” explores the Halprins’ interdisciplinary creative process through photographs, films, drawings and the scores that gave the participants’ movement a shape and a purpose. Mr. Halprin died in 2009, but Ms. Halprin, 94, spoke about the workshops and her continuing dance practice earlier this month. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Weekly Quandary: Whose Last Name?
abstract: Tennessee law forbids combining a mother and father’s surnames into a single name for baby — or giving an infant a mother’s last name without both parents’ “mutual assent.”
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, follow up on the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary came via email, but it was an email with a specific source: an article about a couple in Tennessee, Kim Sarubbi and Carl Abramson, who combined their surnames to give their first two children a single, blended last name instead of a hyphenated one.

headline: Air France Pilots Vow to Extend Strike Indefinitely
abstract: The pilots’ union dismissed an offer by management to postpone the implementation of a new European strategy until the end of this year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Air France pilots rejected a proposal from management on Monday and vowed to extend indefinitely a strike that has grounded tens of thousands of passengers over the last week and threatens to wipe out tens of millions of dollars in revenue.

headline: What We Talk About When We Talk About Chris Brown
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the challenges of appraising Chris Brown.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the challenges of appraising Chris Brown.

headline: A Mother in Jail for Helping Her Daughter Have an Abortion
abstract: An exclusive interview with Jennifer Whalen, who is serving time for ordering pills online for her 16-year-old daughter to induce a miscarriage.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 12th, Jennifer Whalen, a 39-year-old mother of three in the rural town of Washingtonville, Pa., went to jail to begin serving a 9-to-18-month sentence. Whalen’s crime was, in effect, ordering pills online that her older daughter took in the first several weeks of an unplanned pregnancy, when she was 16, to induce a miscarriage. The medication was a combination of mifepristone (formerly called RU-486) and misoprostol. The drugs have been available from a doctor with a prescription in the United States since 2000 and are used around the world to induce miscarriage.

headline: The Collapse of Western Civilization
abstract: Naomi Oreskes talks about her new book that attempts to imagine how historians of the future might view our actions — or lack thereof — to combat climate change.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Oreskes talks about her new book that attempts to imagine how historians of the future might view our actions — or lack thereof — to combat climate change.

headline: Amazon Workers Strike in Germany
abstract: Workers of the online retailer took action again on Monday in a long-running dispute over pay and conditions.
lead_paragraph: Workers of the online retailer took action again on Monday in a long-running dispute over pay and conditions.

headline: The Legacy of a Falling Spider
abstract: A trip to Africa after ninth grade helped the Frugal Traveler cultivate a skill that would prove professionally useful years later.
lead_paragraph: One of my frugal trademarks is being willing to sleep just about anywhere. A Chinese hotel stinking of cigarettes with a mattress as soft as quarried granite, a jail-cell-size Guatemalan room with filthy walls for $6, the passenger seat of a compact rental car on the side of a Puerto Rican highway, it’s all good.

headline: Fullscreen Sells Control to Joint Venture Between AT&T and Chernin Group
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: The deal with Fullscreen, a digital media company that connects online personalities and brands, is said to be valued about $200 million to $300 million.
lead_paragraph: The Fine Brothers, Connor Franta and Our2ndLife may not ring a bell to people over the age of 30.

headline: Hamilton Wins in Singapore and Logano in New Hampshire
abstract: Lewis Hamilton took over the points lead with his win, while Joey Logano advanced in Nascar’s Chase for the Championship.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton on Sunday won the Singapore Grand Prix, taking over the points lead for the 2014 Formula One drivers championship.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’: An Opera and a Protest
abstract: Sampling the outpouring of letters taking issue with an editorial.

headline: At Met’s Opening Night, Protesting a Production
abstract: Several hundred protesters gathered outside the Met on Monday for a noisy demonstration calling for it to cancel its performances of John Adams’s “The Death of Klinghoffer.”
lead_paragraph: Some traditions of opening night at the Metropolitan Opera go back decades, like beginning with “The Star-Spangled Banner,” while others are more recent, like showing the operas free on outdoor movie screens at Lincoln Center and Times Square. When operagoers arrived for opening night on Monday, they were greeted with an even newer tradition: street protests.

headline: Amazon Workers Walk Off the Job in Germany Over Wage Dispute
abstract: A total of 2,000 workers refused to show up for their shifts on Monday in an effort to force Amazon to accept an agreement in line with other retailers.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Amazon employees in Germany, frustrated by the company’s refusal to hold wage talks, walked off their jobs Monday in a coordinated strike at four of the company’s distribution centers.

headline: Piaget’s Groundbreaking 1970s Cuff Watch, Renewed
keywords: ['Collectors and Collections', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Watches and Clocks']
abstract: The jeweler created this gold-and-jade design to commemorate its 140th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: If there ever was an object that perfectly captured the louche sexiness and that somehow tremendously appealing drab green of the ’70s, this Piaget watch is it. Inspired by similar designs in its archive, the Swiss jeweler has created this decadent cuff to commemorate its 140th anniversary. The watch has a natural jade dial and is set in a gold cage with 236 brilliant-cut diamonds that give the illusion of rising from the wrist like a great pyramid.

headline: Why Are We So Obsessed With ‘Gilmore Girls’?
abstract: Netflix will soon be streaming all seven seasons of “Gilmore Girls.” Why has the show, which concluded its run in 2007, garnered such a cultish following?
lead_paragraph: After the WB series “Gilmore Girls” concluded in 2007, I gradually managed to acquire all seven seasons on DVD, unable to part with the quirky but infinitely relatable characters, the charming small town I wanted to live in and the lightning-speed dialogue peppered with references waiting to be decoded. As soon as I had the entire collection, the 42 discs started disappearing in my friends’ homes. To this day, they claim innocence.

headline: Beauty in the Beets
abstract: Beetroots, whether roasted, steamed or raw, easily find their way into new salads, side dishes and main dishes. The greens are interchangeable with other mild-tasting greens like Swiss chard and spinach.
lead_paragraph: I sometimes wonder when I’ll run out of ideas for beets, as year after year around this time I’ve devoted a week’s worth of Recipes for Health to beets and their greens. But it hasn’t happened yet. Beetroots, whether roasted, steamed or raw, easily find their way into new salads, side dishes and main dishes. They are friendly with Mediterranean seasonings of all kinds: Greek, Middle Eastern, North African, Italian and Provençal. The greens are interchangeable with other mild-tasting greens like Swiss chard and spinach; one bunch of beets gives you two vegetables to work with. With the beets and their greens you get two sets of nutrients: anthocyanins and betalains, known for their antioxidant properties, from the beetroots, and vitamins K and A, as well as other phytonutrients – lutein and zeaxanthin – from the greens. Both are excellent sources of folate, and beets are a very good source of manganese, potassium and copper.

headline: Popcast: What We Talk About When We Talk About Chris Brown
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss Chris Brown and the challenges of appraising a polarizing figure.
lead_paragraph: Chris Brown’s new album, “X,” has been a long time coming — it was first announced a year ago, before he served a few months of jail time unrelated to his 2009 felony charges for assaulting his then-girlfriend, Rihanna. Jon Caramanica wrote about “X” this week, but our Popcast conversation is less about the album than the complicated task of writing about Mr. Brown as a music critic.

headline: Staying Cool When the Fat Hits the Fire
abstract: A strong game with a frying pan is a good way to improve your cooking. But remember: always keep an eye on the heat.
lead_paragraph: When I’m with a chef, I always ask for the secret to good cooking.

headline: New ‘Super PAC’ Aims for Better Beer
abstract: Three Pennsylvania law students have formed a “super PAC” dedicated to better beer.
lead_paragraph: A reminder that all you need to form a “super PAC” is a bank account and a stamp: Three Pennsylvania law students have formed Americans for Better Brewing, a new super PAC presumably devoted to, well, higher quality beer. The committee, also known as Six-PAC, is based in Newville, Pa., not far from Penn State’s Dickinson School of Law in Carlisle, where the PAC’s “officers” are students, according to postings on various social networks. No word on whether student beer money will be used to provide funding.

headline: When Johnny Came Questioning Home
abstract: Walter Anderson’s first play, “Almost Home,” returns to 1965 and to the dreams and nightmares of the Vietnam War era.
lead_paragraph: When the stage lights go up at the Acorn Theater on Harry Feiner’s set for “Almost Home,” a dingy Bronx apartment kitchen in 1965, every prop looks period-perfect. As the play unfolds, Michael McDonald’s costumes and Quentin Chiappetta’s subtle but evocative sound design prove just as commendable.

headline: Dispute Over High School’s Canceled ‘Spamalot’ Leads to Director’s Departure
abstract: A Pennsylvania high school principal cited concern over gay themes in rejecting a planned production of “Spamalot.”
lead_paragraph: Controversy is intensifying in South Williamsport, Penn., over a high school principal’s cancellation of a student production of the acclaimed musical “Spamalot.” School officials on Friday dismissed the show’s director after months of back-and-forth arguments – which drew unflattering media attention – over whether the principal canceled “Spamalot” because of the show’s gay content. Supporters of the production are organizing a rally for Monday evening before the meeting of the town’s school board, while the theater director is considering options in response to her firing.

headline: Human Role in Warming of Northwest Played Down
abstract: The study concludes that a century-long trend of rising temperatures in the American Northwest is largely explained by natural shifts in ocean winds.
lead_paragraph: A new and most likely controversial analysis of Pacific Ocean weather patterns concludes that a century-long trend of rising temperatures in the American Northwest is largely explained by natural shifts in ocean winds, not by human activity.

headline: Outgrowing Childhood Horrors in Beslan
