abstract: Ten years after Chechen separatists took over a school in Beslan, resulting in the death of 186 students, the survivors find a way forward.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after Chechen separatists took over a school in Beslan, resulting in the death of 186 students, the survivors find a way forward.

headline: Battling Red Tape, in America and China
abstract: When I bought a company in California last year, I was struck by how similar the bureaucratic hoops were. There actually were more of them in California than I typically face in China.
lead_paragraph: We all carry stereotypes, especially of people we have yet to meet and places we have yet to visit. Sometimes these stereotypes are reinforced by movies and literature, which makes me cringe: I hate to think that foreigners might conclude that Mrs. Cleaver of “Leave it to Beaver” is representative of American women or that John Wayne’s callused tough guys who grit their way through anything are typical of American men.

headline: White House Intruder Arrested in July With Cache of Weapons
abstract: The man who jumped the White House fence last week had been arrested in July by Virginia State Police with a cache of automatic weapons, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: The man who scaled the White House fence on Friday and ran into the front door of the presidential residence had been arrested by Virginia State Police in July with a cache of automatic weapons, a sniper rifle and “a map of Washington, D.C., with writing and a line drawn to the White House,” law enforcement officials said.

headline: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Cancels Concerts
abstract: The orchestra locked out its musicians earlier this month, and has canceled the first seven weeks of its season, through Nov. 8.
lead_paragraph: The management of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra announced on Monday that because of ongoing labor negotiations with its musicians, it has canceled the first seven weeks of its season, from Sept. 25 through Nov. 8.

headline: In Stand-Up and Sitcoms, Nonchalantly Blazing a Path
abstract: Mark Whitaker’s biography, “Cosby: His Life and Times,” recounts the comedian’s path from poverty to a vastly influential force on national television and in other arenas.
lead_paragraph: Mark Whitaker’s biography of Bill Cosby is, like its subject, old school. It’s square, competent, gentle, G-rated, dignified and, in the end, a bit distant.

headline: Antifreeze Proteins Keep Antarctic Fish Alive and Icy
keywords: ['Ice', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Proteins', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The proteins that latch on to ice crystals in the body of the fish and prevent them from growing also prevent the ice from melting.
lead_paragraph: Fish in McMurdo Sound and elsewhere in the seas around Antarctica have to survive in temperatures below freezing. It’s not surprising, then, that they have evolved natural antifreeze proteins.

headline: White House Intruder’s Past Raises Concern
abstract: Omar Gonzalez, the intruder, was arrested in July in Virginia after the state police there found several loaded semiautomatic weapons in his car after a high-speed chase on Interstate 81.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secret Service officers stopped Omar Jose Gonzalez last month as he carried a hatchet in front of the White House, but let him go even though he had been arrested this summer in Virginia with a mini-arsenal of semiautomatic weapons, a sniper rifle and a map clearly marking the White House’s location.

headline: Magic, With Four Main Ingredients
abstract: A vinaigrette to replace all the store-bought dressings.
lead_paragraph: Open your refrigerator: how many bottles of salad dressing are lurking in the door? If you’re an average American shopper, you add one or two bottles to that sticky collection every couple of months.

headline: Three Divergent Visions of Our Future Under Climate Change
abstract: Three books — one optimistic, one cataclysmic and one polemic — discuss what climate change might bring.
lead_paragraph: First, some cheerful news from the Future of Western Civilization Department: Cliff swallows in the Great Plains are evolving to have shorter wings. This helps them to swerve more easily away from speeding cars on the interstate. “Over time,” a behavioral ecologist at the University of Tulsa says, “we’ve begun to notice that we were seeing fewer dead birds on the roads.”

headline: Poroshenko’s Presence at U.N. General Assembly Is in Doubt
abstract: It was unclear whether President Petro O. Poroshenko would travel​ to New York to deliver his address as scheduled on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The foreign minister of Ukraine said Monday that it was unclear whether President Petro O. Poroshenko would travel​ to New York to deliver his scheduled address before the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday. It is possible, Foreign Minister Pavlo Klimkin told reporters, “there will be a change in the program.” He offered no details except to say that the crisis in the country could compel Mr. Poroshenko to remain in Ukraine.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted September 10 through 14 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted September 10 through 14 with 1,000 adults throughout the United States.

headline: The Secret History of Mexican Cooking Was Written by Women
abstract: Many of the Mexican chefs moving into the limelight are male, but it was the women of the country who forged the extraordinary recipes in the new Phaidon tome “Mexico: The Cookbook.”
lead_paragraph: As my taco pilgrimage through Mexico with the Danish chef René Redzepi of Noma was winding to a close in the languorous city of Mérida, I was starting to worry that we were going to miss out on one of the dishes I was most looking forward to. By then we had chewed and slurped our way through everything from the tasting menu at Pujol, chef Enrique Olvera’s gastronome-magnet in Mexico City, to fresh coconuts bought by the side of a jungle road. But we still hadn’t had cochinita pibil.

headline: Will Lee Named Editor of People.com
abstract: Mr. Lee will join the website on Oct. 20. He is leaving The Hollywood Report’s website, where he is vice president of digital content and programming.
lead_paragraph: People on Monday announced a crucial hire who will help determine the magazine’s digital future.

headline: Obama to Meet With Netanyahu at White House
abstract: The White House said Monday that President Obama would hold a series of bilateral meetings during the United Nations General Assembly this week.
lead_paragraph: The White House said Monday that President Obama would meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Oct. 1 in Washington.

headline: Global Warming Concerns Grow
abstract: More than half of Americans said global warming was caused by human behavior, the highest level ever recorded by The New York Times/CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: While few Americans regard the environment as the nation’s foremost challenge, most say it should be a priority, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. And more than half say global warming is caused by human behavior, the highest level ever recorded by the national poll.

headline: An Animal Gamble in the Arctic
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Walruses', 'Whales and Whaling', 'Seals (Animals) and Sealing']
abstract: The Arctic is changing — fast. Two experts who have spent decades working there believe that the marine mammals who call the high latitudes home are now locked into a human-forced ecological game of chance.
lead_paragraph: The Arctic is changing — fast. Two experts who have spent decades working there believe that the marine mammals who call the high latitudes home are now locked into a human-forced ecological game of chance.

headline: Woman Arrested at Kennedy Airport With Marijuana and Guns, Officials Say
abstract: A Canadian traveler, Nyesha McPherson, was charged after the authorities discovered the weapons and 33 pounds of the drug in her checked luggage on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A 24-year-old woman was arrested at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday morning after the authorities discovered two handguns, hundreds of rounds of ammunition and 33 pounds of marijuana concealed in her luggage.

headline: A Future as Clouded as Their Past
abstract: When the Anasazi abandoned the cities they had worked so long to build on the Colorado Plateau, it had something to do with climate, but drawing lessons from their opaque past may be as difficult as predicting our clouded future.
lead_paragraph: We won’t ever know what the Anasazi were thinking on the eve of the 13th century when they abandoned the cities they had worked so long to build on the Colorado Plateau. The reasons had something to do with climate — a great drought and, perhaps on top of that, a mini ice age. If that wasn’t enough to defeat a thriving culture, there was the turmoil that came from just not knowing. Why were the sky and earth behaving so strangely? Why wasn’t the old magic working anymore?

headline: U.N. Food Program Warns of Cuts to Its Relief Efforts
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The World Food Program says that because of reduced resources, rations for refugees from Syria and elsewhere will be reduced.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Just months after a United Nations Security Council resolution pressed Syria to open several of its border crossings to humanitarian aid convoys, money has dried up and allotments of grain and lentils are set to shrink significantly next month, the head of the World Food Program said Monday.

headline: BlackRock Urges Overhaul of Corporate Bond Trading
abstract: In a paper released Monday afternoon, the giant asset manager said that the market for trading corporate bonds was “broken” in a way that hurts ordinary investors and companies borrowing through the market.
lead_paragraph: The giant asset manager BlackRock is initiating an aggressive call for the overhaul of a bond market that sits at the center of the United States financial industry and many retirement portfolios.

headline: ‘Kissing Congressman’ Enlists Wife in Campaign Ad
abstract: Representative Vance McAllister, Republican of Louisiana, who was caught on a security video kissing a staff member, has released a new campaign ad featuring his wife, Kelly, which features the couple sitting side by side.
lead_paragraph: The “kissing congressman” is hoping family forgiveness translates to forgiveness among the Louisiana electorate.

headline: A New High Mark for ‘Lion King’
abstract: The musical version of “The Lion King” topped Broadway’s box office last week, and has set a record for the largest global gross, with $6.2 billion in sales worldwide.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 17 years of performances in New York, “The Lion King” is still frequently the top-grossing show on Broadway each week, as it was last week. But now the musical holds the global box-office record as well.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Spring/Summer 2015 Milan Fashion Week
abstract: T’s senior market editor rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.
lead_paragraph: T’s senior market editor rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

headline: Arab Bank Liable for Supporting Terrorist Efforts, Jury Finds
abstract: The closely watched case in New York City was the first civil case brought against a bank under the Anti-Terrorism Act to go to trial, and the verdict was expected to have a broad impact.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury on Monday found Arab Bank liable for knowingly supporting terrorism efforts connected to two dozen attacks in the Middle East, the first time a bank has ever been held liable in a civil suit under a broad antiterrorism statute.

headline: Congress to Weigh In on White House Security
abstract: The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform has invited the director of the Secret Service to testify at a hearing next Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After the latest incursion at the White House, the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform has scheduled a hearing on Secret Service operations for next Tuesday.

headline: How Will the U.N. Address Ocean Policy?
abstract: Ocean policy has tended to get short shrift in almost all the U.N. climate talks.
lead_paragraph: Q.

abstract: Photos from Turkey, China, Spain and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, China, Spain and Pakistan.

headline: Disputing Report, Steve Bisciotti Says Ravens Didn’t Seek Leniency for Ray Rice
abstract: Bisciotti, the team’s owner, denied many central elements of last week’s ESPN article about the Ravens’ handling of the Rice episode.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti, responding to an investigative report released Friday, said his team did not lobby the league to be lenient in punishing running back Ray Rice after he was arrested and charged with assaulting his fiancée in February.

headline: Walkabout: Air France Strike Continues
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Deadlock The strike by Air France pilots, already considered one of the most disruptive in the history of the company, will trigger the cancellation of at least 62 percent of the airline’s flights worldwide on Monday. (Forbes)

headline: High Above the Earth, Hoping for Turbulence
abstract: Tagging along on a test flight to show off a new radar system for evaluating bad weather from the cockpit.
lead_paragraph: NORMALLY, pilots are happy to keep thunderstorms at a good distance, but that wasn’t the case on board a twin-engine Convair 540 turboprop airplane that I took a demonstration flight in last month. Up in the cockpit, 21,000 feet above Texas, Markus Johnson and Joe Duval were actually looking for trouble in the form of bad weather.

headline: During the Bustle of Travel, Moments of Kinship
abstract: A Hyatt executive meets a woman on a flight who is moving her family to London for work and shares her own story of a similar experience.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in California, and nearly every year I would fly across the county to visit my grandparents, who lived in Washington and Chicago.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: In Performance | Andrew Rannells
abstract: Andrew Rannells performs the song “Midnight Radio” from the musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” with the show’s composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar. “Hedwig” is on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Rannells performs the song “Midnight Radio” from the musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” with the show’s composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar. “Hedwig” is on Broadway at the Belasco Theater.

abstract: Cory Booker met with motorcyclists at a rally in support of veterans in Woodbridge, N.J., on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: [Photo: View on Instagram.]

headline: 3 Missing Afghan Soldiers Turn Up at Canadian Border
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The soldiers who were visiting the United States for a training exercise disappeared on Saturday, and may have been trying to defect.
lead_paragraph: Three Afghan soldiers in the United States on a training exercise were located Monday at a Canadian border crossing near Niagara Falls, two days after disappearing from a Massachusetts shopping mall, officials said Monday.

headline: A Watchdog for the Police Is Accepting Complaints
abstract: Philip K. Eure’s office has started up its website and is encouraging whistle-blowers to come forward.
lead_paragraph: For months now, Mayor Bill de Blasio has peppered his remarks on improving relations between the police and the community with references to the new office of the inspector general for the New York Police Department. The office, the mayor has suggested, would be an early warning system for potential flare-ups of the sort that engulfed the department over its stop-and-frisk policies.

headline: She Came to Do Good and Stayed to Do Well
abstract: In “Khoobsurat,” a daffy physical therapist charms an aristocratic family.
lead_paragraph: Disney, never a stranger to princesses, crowns another as it ventures further into Bollywood with Shashanka Ghosh’s romantic confection, “Khoobsurat,” a variation on Hrishikesh Mukherjee’s 1980 film, “Khoobsoorat.” And the studio’s specialty proves a pretty good fit.

headline: MGM Buys Big Stake in Mark Burnett’s Reality TV Production Company
abstract: The studio also purchased LightWorkers Media, which focuses on religious-themed programming; it will be run by Roma Downey, Mr. Burnett’s wife.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer became a reality TV giant on Monday.

headline: A New Home Page Feature
abstract: On Tuesday, The Times will begin Watching, a new home page feature that will keep an eye on developing and breaking news from The Times and other sources.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Mabry is an editor at large at The Times.

headline: Sale of a Landmark Skyscraper Puts Spain on the Map of Chinese Investors
abstract: Strengthening commercial ties will be on the agenda when Spain’s prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, makes his first state visit to China.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — In June, one of China’s richest men, Wang Jianlin, bought a landmark office tower in Madrid that had stood empty for years. The Franco-era building, Spain’s tallest skyscraper when it opened in 1953, had become a symbol of the Spanish real estate market’s collapse in 2008.

headline: On the Cusp of Climate Change
abstract: Animal and plant species around the world may be threatened by warmer global temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Animal and plant species around the world may be threatened by warmer global temperatures.

headline: On This Day: Lincoln Frees (Some of) the Slaves
abstract: On this day in 1862, less than a week after Antietam, the bloodiest day of battle in American history, a broken nation came a step closer to healing as Lincoln announced that he would issue the Emancipation Proclamation.
lead_paragraph: PhotoCredit

headline: Hotels Use Online Reviews as Blueprint for Renovations
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Consumer Reviews']
abstract: Hotel managers are relying more and more on reviews from websites like TripAdvisor for direction regarding renovations and upgrades of their facilities.
lead_paragraph: When it was time for Omni Hotels and Resorts to start a new round of renovations, executives made a point of installing more electrical outlets and better bathrooms.

headline: Deconstructing the Whole to Reveal the Sum of Its Parts
abstract: The New Juilliard Ensemble, conducted by Joel Sacks, performed Harrison Birtwistle’s “Cantus Iambeus” and other works on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: An orchestra is like an organism, people say when they want to illustrate the tightness and unity of a group’s playing. But on Saturday evening at the Juilliard School, the New Juilliard Ensemble’s performance of Harrison Birtwistle’s “Cantus Iambeus” (2005) was a reminder that an organism is hardly a unified thing.

headline: Composing Outside the Lines
abstract: The South Korean composer Unsuk Chin, who lives in Berlin, speaks about her unconventional approach and her comfort level in New York.
lead_paragraph: “Verboten” often becomes the first word to impress itself on the mind of a visitor to Germany, so numerous — and explicit — are the rules. It’s also a word that the South Korean composer Unsuk Chin encountered early on when she moved to Hamburg in 1985 to take up studies with Gyorgy Ligeti, the restlessly innovative Hungarian composer who was a dominating figure in 20th-century music.

headline: Too Much of a Good Thing
abstract: Carbon dioxide keeps the earth unfrozen by retaining the sun’s energy, but our use of fossil fuels is extracting it too rapidly.
lead_paragraph: Every year, Americans dispose of about 1,000 pounds of garbage apiece — the coffee grounds, takeout containers, candy wrappers, used Huggies, empty syringes and old sock monkey puppets we entrust to our local sanitation workers and never think about again.

headline: A Marathon Mash-Up of Two Creative Worlds
abstract: Last week, Trajal Harrell presented a marathon performance of his seven-part series, “Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church,” at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most spellbinding dancing New York has seen all year occurred last week during Trajal Harrell’s seven-part series, “Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church.” The series also contained other performances that were extraordinary in nondance ways. Four dancers (Rob Fordeyn, Thibault Lac, Stephen Thompson, Ondrej Vidlar) were phenomenal, redefining grace before our eyes, and the drag artist François Chaignaud, though at his worst when dancing, compellingly and bewilderingly demonstrated multiple layers of identity.

headline: Milan Fashion Week Social Media Roundup
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Stylish hordes moved forth from England to Italy for the third week of fashion month. Here’s a recap of what happened, traced through the Styles staff’s Twitter feeds.
lead_paragraph: Not 24 hours after London Fashion Week concluded, the fashion crowd had already migrated to Italy for Milan Fashion Week. As the world hurtled forward at a look-there-or-you’ll-miss-it pace driven by the Scottish referendum, the Alibaba I.P.O. and the release of the latest iPhone, Italian designers slowed down and plumbed the past for inspiration — out of nostalgia for the heyday of Italian fashion, perhaps? Not all were looking backward: Fendi existed distinctly in the moment, and a contemporary Barbie seemed to be Jeremy Scott’s latest muse at Moschino. One change in attendance was notable and noticed: Though celebrity models like Naomi Campbell and Kendall Jenner stalked the catwalk, actual celebrities were mostly missing from the front row.

headline: Obama Defends the Secret Service
abstract: After two incidents involving security breaches at the White House over the weekend, President Obama said he was grateful for the Secret Service and the protection it provides.
lead_paragraph: After two incidents involving security breaches at the White House over the weekend, President Obama said he was grateful for the Secret Service and the protection it provides.

headline: Opera Singers Try a More Intimate Genre
abstract: Several opera singers brought their talents to French art music and some American works at the Schimmel Center.
lead_paragraph: There are certain styles that are difficult to convey well: Most competent pianists, for example, can play Chopin decently, but it takes a more particular gift to win over an audience with Bach or Boulez. On the vocal front, the intimate, enigmatic French art song — a genre (like chamber music) that is often best suited to salon-style formats — can be challenging to render convincingly.

headline: Serving Up Gumshoes and Gumbo
abstract: The “NCIS” franchise tries a Southern locale, New Orleans, where a severed leg might turn up in a crate of freshly netted shrimp.
lead_paragraph: Eggs Creole sounds pretty good. Adding andouille sausage is probably a tad more than a healthy breakfast needs, but, whatever, this is New Orleans. It’s the rémoulade sauce on the side that suggests that “NCIS: New Orleans,” a new entry in the hit CBS franchise that begins on Tuesday, is trying a little too hard to live up to a recipe.

headline: S.E.C. Makes Largest Ever Whistle-Blower Award
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: The individual’s identity is a mystery, but that person is now $30 million richer thanks to a program established under Dodd-Frank.
lead_paragraph: The identity is a mystery, but someone who provided important information to  regulators in a securities fraud enforcement action is suddenly $30 million richer thanks to a federal whistle-blower law.

headline: Climate Change Underfoot
abstract: Some species being displaced by rising global temperatures are not easy to see, but scientists still worry that the impact on ecosystems could be significant.
lead_paragraph: Some species being displaced by rising global temperatures are not easy to see, but scientists still worry that the impact on ecosystems could be significant.

headline: Q. and A.: Jörg Wuttke on the Future of China’s Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Nearly a year after President Xi Jinping announced that China’s economy would increasingly be guided by market forces, many foreign companies are finding life more difficult.
lead_paragraph: After decades of a “golden age” fueled by cheap manufacturing and exports, China’s economy may have entered a more mature “silver age,” says Jörg Wuttke, president of the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China. Like any maturity, this phase, which President Xi Jinping has spoken of as the “new normal,” is marked by complex challenges.

headline: Cyberheroes in Disguise, Toiling at Dull Day Jobs
abstract: As Season 4 of “Person of Interest” opens, the show’s scattered surveillance agents have been forced to assume new names and take workaday jobs.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says CBS like the ratings for “Person of Interest.” Last season, this surveillance-age thriller was the fourth-most-watched network drama in prime time, behind two “NCIS” shows and “The Blacklist.” But among younger viewers — the 18-to-49 demographic — it fell all the way to 16th, behind shows like “Sleepy Hollow” and “Chicago Fire.”

headline: When Cooking, Invest Time. Or Work. Not Both.
abstract: For feed-the-family fare each day, you need to be more efficient.
lead_paragraph: We could talk about cooking as a function of chemistry and physics. Better to talk about elbow grease. Specifically, a physical theory of everyday cooking, The Time-Work Continuum.

headline: Albums by Leonard Cohen, Otis Brown III and Lee Ann Womack
abstract: Reviews of Leonard Cohen’s “Popular Problems,” Otis Brown III’s debut album and Lee Ann Womack’s first album in six years.
lead_paragraph: LEONARD COHEN

headline: Seeding a Slogan? Clinton Talks Up Choice and Chance in Email Blast
abstract: While Hillary Rodham Clinton has said that she’ll likely announce a decision about running for president next year, she might be trying out a campaign slogan already.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has said that she’ll likely announce a decision about running for president sometime next year. But from the sound of things, she might be trying out a campaign slogan already.

headline: As Blondie Turns 40, a Look Back Through Chris Stein’s Lens
abstract: The band’s guitarist is also a longtime photographer. His collected shots are the subject of a new Rizzoli book — and included in a new Jeffrey Deitch-curated exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Since Blondie formed 40 years ago, one thing has remained constant: if the band’s co-founder Chris Stein isn’t onstage with a guitar slung around his neck, chances are he’s off somewhere with a camera, taking pictures. Now, the results of his four-decade-long hobby have been compiled in a new book, “Chris Stein/Negative: Me, Blondie, and the Advent of Punk” (out tomorrow from Rizzoli), and will appear in an exhibition curated by Jeffrey Deitch at the Chelsea Hotel’s Storefront Gallery alongside band memorabilia and images by the likes of Annie Leibovitz and Robert Mapplethorpe. “I was just in the middle of this milieu and I took pictures,” Stein says matter-of-factly on the phone from Vienna, a recent stop on Blondie’s anniversary tour.

headline: A Microscopic Issue of Unknown Consequences
abstract: Climate change may impact even the smallest organisms, like photosynthesizing microbes that play a critical role in the desert and scrub environments in the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Even the microbes, it seems, may be on the move.

headline: Bad Boy Theater, With Cocaine as Co-Star
abstract: The rapper Stitches, whose video “Brick in Yo Face” has gone viral, performed on Sunday at the Amityville Music Hall on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: AMITYVILLE, N.Y. — “I’m gonna pick one person,” Stitches said. Out in the Sunday night crowd at the Amityville Music Hall here, several young men — and one or two young women — were thrusting their hands to the sky, clamoring for a shot at immortality. Or at least a chance at touching a modern starburst, which here meant having Stitches — the Miami rapper whose manic, pneumatic-intensity video for “Brick in Yo Face” has been one of this year’s most unlikely viral phenomena — throw a brick in their face, and have it explode in a puff of powder.

headline: Defamation Law Reminds Critics of Indonesia’s Past
abstract: Recent cases have rekindled a debate about a law that can send to prison those who speak ill of Indonesia electronically, as activists call for an end to legislation they consider a blemish on Indonesia’s transition to a robust democracy.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When an Indonesian law student posted an online rant saying the historic city of Yogyakarta in Central Java was “poor, stupid and uncultured,” she earned more than the ire of its residents. She ended up in a police detention cell, charged with cyberdefamation.

headline: U.S. Acts to Curb Firms’ Moves Overseas to Avoid Taxes
abstract: The rules would make it more difficult for American companies to lower their tax bills by relocating overseas and would wipe out the benefits for those that do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew announced rules on Monday that are aimed at making it more difficult for American companies to lower their tax bills by relocating overseas and that would wipe out the benefits for those that do. It is the administration’s latest move to sidestep a paralyzed Congress and tackle a politically charged element of President Obama’s agenda.

headline: Kerry Participates in Unesco Event
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and Irina Bokova, the chief of Unesco, will appear together at a program on antiquities Monday, three years after the United States pulled funding for the agency.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | Three years after the United States pulled its funding from Unesco over the admission of Palestinians as full members, Secretary of State John Kerry made an unusual appearance Monday evening alongside the agency’s executive director, Irina Bokova, to draw attention to one of Unesco’s principal mandates: the need to protect antiquities.

headline: Deaths From Faulty Switch in G.M. Cars Edge Higher
abstract: The victim compensation program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than found eligible a week ago.
lead_paragraph: The death toll from accidents involving General Motors cars with a defective ignition switch has edged up again. In a weekly update of claims filed to the victim compensation program run by the compensation expert Kenneth R. Feinberg, the program disclosed that 21 death claims had been deemed eligible for payment. That is two more than Mr. Feinberg found eligible a week ago and significantly more than the 13 deaths the company had estimated for months. G.M. has given Mr. Feinberg sole discretion to determine the number of eligible claims for deaths and injuries associated with the faulty switch, which can cause power to cut out in a moving car, disabling air bags, power steering and power brakes. G.M. recalled 2.6 million cars with the switch this year, more than a decade after engineers inside the company first spotted a problem. The latest numbers show a total of 16 eligible injury claims, including four in the most serious category of injury — those resulting in quadriplegia, paraplegia, double amputation, permanent brain damage or pervasive burns.

headline: Jack Black, Diane Keaton, Marisa Tomei and a Host of Artists Turn Out in L.A. to Support Reproductive Rights
abstract: Held by the influential Night Gallery to benefit Planned Parenthood, “Sexy Beast” featured live and silent auctions and several jaw-dropping dance performances.
lead_paragraph: WhoA potpourri of artists, collectors, celebrities and executives of Planned Parenthood Los Angeles (PPLA), the beneficiary of live and silent auctions organized by the gallerists Davida Nemeroff and Mieke Marple of L.A.’s critically beloved Night Gallery. Diane Keaton mingled with the artist Mary Weatherford and the curator Paul Schimmel, of Hauser, Wirth & Schimmel. Marisa Tomei posed for photographs while the gallerists David Kordansky and Sarah Gavlak mixed with noteworthy artists like Nicole Miller, Alexandra Grant, Sam Falls, Sayre Gomez, Lisa Anne Auerbach, Jonas Wood, Kaari Upson, Piero Golia, Kour Pour, Sam Durant, Rosson Crow, Casey Jane Ellison and Math Bass. The award-winning choreographer Ryan Heffington could be seen getting costumed dancers ready. Jack Black hosted.

headline: Botox Maker Allergan Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Salix
abstract: A deal could derail Valeant and Pershing Square’s $53 billion takeover attempt of Allergan.
lead_paragraph: Allergan, the Botox maker fending off a hostile bid by Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management, had had talks to acquire Salix Pharmaceuticals, another drug maker, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: ‘Scandal’ Isn’t Just a Thrill Ride. It’s an Education.
abstract: Shonda Rhimes was a guest lecturer for a Q. and A. put on by the Smithsonian Associates at the Museum of Natural History, just steps away from the Justice Department, where many of her characters have done dark and twisted things.
lead_paragraph: The characters on Shonda Rhimes’s “Scandal” have fixed presidential elections, murdered Supreme Court justices and had affairs in the White House. But the writer’s room, she said, is even wilder.

headline: For Most Women in Film, Their Roles Are Silent
abstract: A study, supported by the United Nations women’s agency, found that movies released in the 10 most profitable markets worldwide exhibited evidence of “deep-seated discrimination and pervasive stereotyping of women and girls by the international film industry.”
lead_paragraph: Women are more seen than heard in movies worldwide. A tiny fraction of them are cast as lawyers or doctors. Women and girls are twice as likely as men and boys to be shown on screen naked, partially clothed or in sexually revealing clothes.

headline: It’s Not Genghis Khan’s Mongolia
abstract: Winters and summers that have grown more extreme imperil a country’s herding tradition.
lead_paragraph: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia — For all of his victories and skills, Genghis Khan always insisted that the god Tengri — the Eternal Blue Sky — deserved the credit for his triumphant success in uniting the vast Mongol Empire in the early 13th century.

headline: Shining Star Power on a Crucial Subject
abstract: “Years of Living Dangerously,” an Emmy-winning documentary series about climate change that ran on Showtime this summer, is now available on streaming services and on DVD.
lead_paragraph: Harrison Ford is struggling to keep from jumping out of his chair.

headline: Forecasts: Hopes and Fears About Climate Change
abstract: Answers from two dozen scientists, authors, and world and national figures.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen scientists, authors, and world and national figures answered two questions: What is your greatest worry about climate change? What gives you hope? Here are some of their answers, condensed for space.

headline: Venezuela: Clorox Plans to Leave Over Price Controls
abstract: The Clorox Company said Monday that it was shutting down its business in Venezuela because government price controls on its products had led to millions of dollars in losses.
lead_paragraph: The Clorox Company said Monday that it was shutting down its business in Venezuela because government price controls on its products had led to millions of dollars in losses. The company said it was pulling out of the country entirely and would sell its assets. It has three factories, about 450 employees and annual sales of about $77 million in Venezuela. Clorox, which is based in California, said in a statement that for nearly three years it had to sell more than two-thirds of its products at prices fixed by the government, even as high inflation caused its costs to rise sharply. It said recent price increases “were nowhere near sufficient.” Clorox sells bleach and other household cleaning products in Venezuela. Venezuela suffers from inflation of more than 60 percent a year and shortages of many basic goods, a situation that could be exacerbated by Clorox’s exit. President Nicolás Maduro, a socialist, says the economic woes are caused by capitalists and political opponents waging an economic war against the country.

headline: Album Review: Bernard Sanders’s ‘We Shall Overcome’
abstract: Jon Pareles, music critic for The New York Times, reviews Senator Bernard Sanders’s recently unearthed folk album.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing apolitical about “We Shall Overcome,” the album Bernard Sanders, the independent senator from Vermont, recorded in 1987 when he was the mayor of Burlington, Vt.

headline: New Leader for Council in Charge of Public Service Ads
abstract: Lisa Sherman will be only the fifth head of the Advertising Council, which began 72 years ago as the War Advertising Council.
lead_paragraph: THE ADVERTISING COUNCIL, the organization that has worked with Madison Avenue since 1942 on public service campaigns for charities, nonprofits, social causes and the federal government, is naming a new leader who has experience in all three of its constituencies: agencies, marketers and the media.

headline: Mets Said to Be Near a Contract Extension for Sandy Alderson
abstract: Alderson, the team’s general manager, took over before the 2011 season and is working with the Mets toward a three-year deal, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: The Mets are working toward completing a three-year extension for General Manager Sandy Alderson, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Obama Judicial Choice Is Urged to Withdraw
abstract: Senator Patrick J. Leahy has determined that Michael P. Boggs, a judicial nominee from Georgia, does not have the support of the Judiciary Committee and urged him to withdraw.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a setback for the White House, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, has determined that Michael P. Boggs, an embattled judicial nominee from Georgia, does not have the support to clear the committee, effectively killing his nomination.

headline: How a Times Cybersecurity Reporter Protects Her Data. And What You Can Do to Protect Yours.
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: Times technology reporter Nicole Perlroth shares her thoughts on cybersecurity, on how she protects her online identity, and how you should protect yours.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Perlroth covers cybersecurity and privacy. Last week she wrote on Home Depot’s confirmation that hackers had broken into its in-store payments systems in what could be the largest-known breach of a retail company’s computer network. She shares her thoughts on security and personal data with Times Insiders.

headline: HealthCare.gov Is Given an Overhaul
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Federal health officials said the shorter application on HealthCare.gov has fewer pages and fewer screens to navigate, and allows people to sign up with fewer clicks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is redesigning HealthCare.gov and says that 70 percent of consumers will be able to use a shorter, simpler online application form to buy health insurance when the second annual open enrollment period begins in mid-November.

headline: Will Radcliff, 74, Creator of the Slush Puppie, Dies
abstract: In the 1960s, he began studying the aesthetics of flavored ice drinks and reviewed the options on texture and flavoring, as well as drinking containers.
lead_paragraph: Flavored ice drinks had been around since the Romans, and machines had been churning them out under various brand names for almost as long, it seems, when Will Radcliff, a peanut salesman, had the ice beverage inspiration that made him rich.

headline: Black Bear Kills Rutgers Student During a Hike in New Jersey
abstract: Darsh Patel, 22, and four friends were in the Apshawa Preserve in West Milford when the animal began to follow them, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Rutgers University student was killed by a black bear over the weekend, the police said on Monday, the first such recorded death in New Jersey.

headline: Obama Isn’t Finished Yet
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Term Limits (Political Office)']
abstract: The final years of his second term could still be great ones, as they were for Reagan and Clinton.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ON Sept. 18, 1986, more than two years before the end of Ronald Reagan’s presidency, the columnist George F. Will, one of Reagan’s earliest and strongest supporters, pronounced the Reagan administration dead. “When an administration collapses, quickly and completely,” Mr. Will wrote, “a reasonable surmise is that the administration, like a balloon, had nothing in it but air.”

headline: Inside the Quartet
abstract: The Kronos Quartet explains the special mystery of how a quartet communicates.
lead_paragraph: The Kronos Quartet explains the special mystery of how a quartet communicates.

headline: Top Republicans Send Warning — and Appeal — to Donors
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Top Republicans warn that a campaign cash disadvantage could cost them the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every election year, often about this time, top officials in one of the two political parties fret publicly about being at a financial disadvantage.

headline: Monitors of Afghan Vote Are Said to Back Secrecy
abstract: Western officials observing the election pressed for the final numbers to be withheld, as demanded by the losing candidate before he joined a unity government, multiple sources said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The decision by Afghan election officials to announce a new president on Sunday without releasing the final vote count came as a result of pressure from senior Western officials, including the head of the United Nations mission that sponsored a total audit of the vote, according to three Western diplomats and three senior election officials.

headline: Yoshiko Yamaguchi, 94, Actress in Propaganda Films, Dies
abstract: Ms. Yamaguchi starred in Japanese propaganda films during the occupation of China in the 1930s and ’40s. After escaping execution after the war, she helped normalize relations between the nations.
lead_paragraph: Yoshiko Yamaguchi, a singer and actress who starred in Japanese propaganda films during Japan’s brutal military occupation of China in the 1930s and ’40s and who, after narrowly escaping execution by the Chinese after the war, helped normalize relations between the nations, died on Sept. 7 in Tokyo. She was 94.

headline: The Price of Abandoning Yemen
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Pro-Iran rebels have taken charge. The victim is democracy.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — IN 2011, Yemenis rejoiced at the toppling of their dictatorial president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who had ruled for 33 years. It was the third successful revolution of the Arab Spring, following the overthrow of dictators in Tunisia and Egypt. But, as elsewhere, reconciliation did not follow revolution.

headline: What to Expect From Narendra Modi at the United Nations
abstract: Since taking power in May, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has had runaway success with major speeches in part because of their character – colloquial, earthy and extemporaneous. Will that tone translate to the United Nations General Assembly?
lead_paragraph: What should we expect from Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New York?

headline: Ukraine’s Neglected and Battered Army Inspires Citizens to Pitch In
abstract: As casualties have mounted among Ukraine’s outgunned soldiers, citizens and support groups for wounded soldiers have begun to rally behind their army in a rush of patriotic feeling.
lead_paragraph: DNIPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — Well-wishers mill around the entrances of the two main hospitals in this city in east-central Ukraine — men who greet friends with hugs and backslaps or share a cigarette, women who arrive to visit the wounded, sorting food parcels and pouring cups of sweet tea.

headline: Fraternities at Wesleyan Are Ordered to Become Coed
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Women and Girls', 'Hazing']
abstract: After a series of high-profile episodes and calls from its student government for change, the university announced that its residential fraternities must all admit women as members and residents.
lead_paragraph: After a series of high-profile episodes and calls from its student government for change, Wesleyan University has announced that its residential fraternities must all admit women as members and residents.

headline: Giants’ Ground Game Sharpens Eli Manning’s Aim
abstract: A more effective running game, which has racked up 243 yards in the Giants’ last six quarters, has reduced the pressure on Manning to put up big passing statistics.
lead_paragraph: The Giants’ new quarterback coach, Danny Langsdorf, said during training camp that the team wanted Eli Manning to complete 70 percent of his passes in the regular season. It is an understatement to say that Langsdorf’s comment produced something of an uproar. Nationwide, the remark elicited mostly guffaws. Manning had completed only 57.5 percent of his passes the previous season. His career completion percentage was 58.5, and his career high in any season was 62.9 percent in 2010.

headline: Months After Buying Beats, Apple’s Plans for Its Music Service Remain Unclear
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Headphones and Headsets', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Apple paid $3 billion for Beats, which makes headphones and also offers streaming music — a service that analysts say could be discontinued, though Apple remains vague.
lead_paragraph: When Apple agreed in May to pay $3 billion for Beats, it acquired not only a successful headphone line but also a fledgling online music service, a move that many analysts interpreted as a move into the fast-growing world of streaming music.

headline: Group Backing Islamic State Vows to Kill French Citizen
abstract: The kidnapping in Algeria by jihadists followed a call by ISIS to begin retaliatory attacks on Westerners.
lead_paragraph: A jihadist group in North Africa aligned with the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of a Frenchman in a mountainous region of Algeria, hours after the Islamic State called for attacks on Westerners. In the video released Monday, the little-known group Jund al-Khilafah said France had 24 hours to halt attacks on the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, or see its citizen executed.

headline: Plaintiffs Claim Bias During Closing Argument Against Texas Voter ID Law
abstract: The challenge to the identification rules, which went into effect in 2013, could affect procedures in Texas for the Nov. 4 general election.
lead_paragraph: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. — A law requiring Texas voters to show government-issued identification before casting a ballot is the latest example of the state’s long history of discrimination against minorities and puts unjustified burdens on the right to vote for more than half a million Texans, lawyers challenging the law told a federal judge here on Monday.

headline: Aging Tech Giants Like EMC Look to Deals to Help Bolster Revenue
abstract: The computer storage company’s talks with HP, Cisco and Oracle highlight the continuing problem with aging technology giants pursuing growth and relevance.
lead_paragraph: Investors expected a noisy fight over breaking up the EMC computer storage company when the hedge fund Elliott Management surfaced in July as the company’s big new shareholder.

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap:  ‘Batman’ Before Batman
abstract: The Fox series, billed as a new chapter of the “Batman” saga, debuted on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 1

abstract: Demonstrators protesting the financial industry’s role in climate change rushed barricades the police had set up near Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators protesting the financial industry’s role in climate change rushed barricades the police had set up near Wall Street.

headline: Fresh Graves Point to Undercount of Ebola Toll
abstract: While the Sierra Leone Health Ministry has confirmed 10 Ebola deaths, a Freetown cemetery said it had added 110 graves in eight days alone.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — The gravedigger hacked at the cemetery’s dense undergrowth, clearing space for the day’s Ebola victims. A burial team, in protective suits torn with gaping holes, arrived with fresh bodies.

headline: A Tailor-Made Publisher Taking Over Jeff Bezos’ Washington Post
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Frederick J. Ryan Jr., the new publisher of The Washington Post, is known for his style and social connections — in many ways the polar opposite of Jeff Bezos, the owner.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Frederick J. Ryan Jr. juggles black-tie invitations, while Jeff Bezos shuns the social limelight for reading about space travel.

headline: Before Yankees Take Field, Crack of Derek Jeter’s Bat Earns Cheers
abstract: Yankee Stadium is opening an hour early for three of Jeter’s final four home games so fans can witness their team’s retiring captain take batting practice.
lead_paragraph: Nick Galasso did not have many luxuries growing up, but few things made him happier as a child than coming to Yankee Stadium to watch Mickey Mantle take batting practice.

headline: High Hopes for Russia Are Fading on Wall St.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: Russia, which was supposed to be a growth market for Wall Street, is turning out to be a potential financial and political nightmare amid the Ukraine situation and America’s sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has an office in Moscow. So do Citigroup and Morgan Stanley. JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America Merrill Lynch, too.

headline: In East River, Bangladeshi Women Find Their Catch of the Day
abstract: As a group of fisherwomen hunt for small, shiny spearing for their dinners, onlookers wonder how safe the fish are to eat.
lead_paragraph: It may seem like an unusual spot to catch dinner, across the East River from Manhattan’s imposing skyline. And the tiny fish that a group of fisherwomen trap in these waters may not seem like dinner at all.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 22, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Behind the Chevron Case
abstract: This lawyer may have movie-star good looks, but he has a lot to answer for, too.
lead_paragraph: “I am the target of what is probably the most well-funded corporate retaliation campaign in U.S. history,” Steven Donziger emailed me early Monday afternoon.

headline: Snap Out of It
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s been a bad summer, but it’s important to keep things in perspective.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been living in and visiting New York for almost a half-century now. One thought occurs as I walk around these days: The city has never been better.

headline: Backsliding on Nuclear Promises
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama is investing billions in modernizing America’s nuclear arsenal, when improving the security of stockpiles would be better use of the money.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past six years, President Obama has talked about working toward a world without nuclear weapons. Yet his administration is now investing tens of billions of dollars in modernizing and rebuilding America’s nuclear arsenal and facilities, as The Times reported in detail on Monday. And after good progress in making nuclear bomb material more secure around the world, Mr. Obama has reduced his budget requests for that priority. This is a shortsighted and disappointing turn.

headline: Airstrikes by U.S. and Allies Hit ISIS Targets in Syria
abstract: Airstrikes, conducted with several Arab allies, unleashed a torrent of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs on the militants’ de facto capital, Raqqa, Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and allies launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in Syria early Tuesday, unleashing a torrent of cruise missiles and precision-guided bombs from the air and sea on the militants’ de facto capital of Raqqa and along the porous Iraq border.

headline: Finding Risks, Not Answers, in Gene Tests
abstract: Tests to find mutations that predispose people to types of cancer have outpaced the understanding of what they mean.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer was 39 and perfectly healthy, but her grandmother had died young from breast cancer, so she decided to be tested for mutations in two genes known to increase risk for the disease.

headline: Oleg Ivanovsky, Soviets’ Space-Age Designer, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Ivanovsky worked on the first satellite to orbit Earth and the craft that carried the first man into space.
lead_paragraph: Oleg Ivanovsky, a Russian engineer in the early years of the space race who helped design Sputnik, the first satellite to orbit Earth, and Vostok 1, the craft that carried the astronaut Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, died on Thursday. He was 92.

headline: John Lewis: Comic Book Hero
abstract: Representative John Lewis of Georgia talks comic books on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: Representative John Lewis spoke at the 1963 March on Washington, worked alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and serves as senior chief deputy whip in Congress. On Thursday, he got on Facebook to talk about a new passion: comic books.

headline: Turkish President Hints That Prisoner Exchange Won Release of Hostages Held by ISIS
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, speaking in New York, said Turkey’s historical position made his country well suited to help solve conflicts in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said Monday that Turkish and American officials were in discussions about how to battle the Islamic State militant organization, now that his government had secured the freedom of 49 Turkish citizens held hostage by that group in Iraq for more than three months.

headline: Another Explanation for Ineptitude? Save It
abstract: Three days after Commissioner Roger Goodell answered reporters’ questions without saying anything meaningful, it was the Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti’s turn with the shovel.
lead_paragraph: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — Here’s a message to every N.F.L. and team official who has been involved, even tangentially, in the Ray Rice scandal: Please stop talking.

headline: U.S. Asks U.N. to Add Names to Sanctions List
abstract: The United States and France have asked the Security Council to impose sanctions on as many as 15 people suspected of ties to terrorism, including the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States and France are asking the United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions on as many as 15 suspected terrorist fighters, recruiters and fund-raisers, including some connected to the Islamic State, American officials said on Monday.

headline: A Marriage in Trouble, in Triplicate
abstract: “Scenes From a Marriage,” a play adapted from a 1973 TV mini-series, uses three sets of actors to portray the same couple.
lead_paragraph: This is the way we were, and the way we are, and the way we will be. And we are fools if we think we can separate any of these versions from the others.

headline: Valuable Finds
abstract: Gerry Wildenberg makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you have to mine deeply to find the GOLD NUGGETs in the lode. We have six of them in today’s puzzle, if you don’t count the central revealer at 38 Across.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap: Horseman With No Head; Ben Franklin With No Breeches
abstract: Am I the only one who found the Season 2 premiere to be a bit of a letdown?
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 1, “This Is War”

headline: Submit Your Questions on the United Nations Meetings
abstract: New York Times reporters answer questions on the United Nations climate summit, the 69th session of the General Assembly and other topics.
lead_paragraph: With the opening of the United Nations climate summit and the start of the 69th session of the General Assembly, the international community prepares to address an agenda that includes a daunting set of issues: Global warming, combating the march of the militant group the Islamic State and the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa dominate the agenda. We invite you to submit questions for New York Times reporters on these and other issues throughout the week of United Nations meetings when we provide live coverage.

headline: For Many, a Nation That Seems Less Free From Moscow’s Dominance Than Ever
abstract: Many politicians and analysts say that Ukraine has capitulated to Russia and that President Vladimir V. Putin won what he wanted to win in the attacks on Ukraine — a shaky and less sovereign nation.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukrainians have been promised sweeping change in the seven months since their collective anger chased the last president out of his mansion.

headline: Ravens’ Owner Says He Learned Lesson
abstract: Steve Bisciotti, the Baltimore Ravens’ owner, said that if cases similar to Ray Rice’s arose in the future, his team would not make the same mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Steve Bisciotti, the Baltimore Ravens’ owner, said that if cases similar to Ray Rice’s arose in the future, his team would not make the same mistakes.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Takes On Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Editorials', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: The commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 80 percent by 2050 in New York City is a long march to a distant goal. The difficult follow-through is next.
lead_paragraph: “Mayor de Blasio Commits to 80 Percent Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions by 2050,” said the Sunday news release, outlining what would be a truly impressive feat if he actually were able to make good on that promise. But there is not going to be any 89-year-old, 10-term mayor named de Blasio declaring a local victory in the battle to save the planet. This is a long march to a distant goal. The commitment Mr. de Blasio made over the weekend — an excellent and necessary one — was to do his part now to keep the city moving in the right direction: Promised Land, that way.

headline: Hiring a Woman for Her Womb
abstract: Can anything be done to ensure that birth surrogacy is safe, ethical and protective of both the birth mother and the intended parents?

headline: New York and New Jersey Getting U.S. Aid to Protect Transit Networks Against Storms
abstract: Federal officials announced that the two states will receive about $3.3 billion to prepare their transportation networks against future storms.
lead_paragraph: With the two-year anniversary of Hurricane Sandy approaching, federal officials announced on Monday that New York and New Jersey will receive about $3.3 billion to prepare their transportation networks against future storms.

headline: Record of Abuse Accusations Preceded Florida Killings
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Domestic Violence', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The killings in Bell, Fla., culminated a cycle of domestic abuse that spanned at least two decades, court and the state social service agency’s records show.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Florida man who killed his daughter, her six children and himself on Thursday was accused of hitting one of the children with a belt last year, according a report by the state child welfare agency, which said there was an open investigation into the family at the time of the killings.

headline: U.S. Strikes Follow Plea by Syrian Opposition Leader on Behalf of Kurds
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The leader of the moderate Syrian opposition appealed for American airstrikes to halt the fierce attacks by militants from the Islamic State against Kurdish communities in northern Syria.
lead_paragraph: The leader of the moderate Syrian opposition appealed Monday for American airstrikes to halt the fierce attacks by militants from the Islamic State against Kurdish communities in northern Syria, just hours before the United States and allies began a campaign against the terrorist group.

headline: A Mentor Whose Experience Goes Far Beyond Pitching
abstract: After a 2006 case of septic shock, Dave Wallace passed on jobs because he did not feel up to them physically. Now 67 and with the Orioles, he is the oldest pitching coach in the majors.
lead_paragraph: The oldest pitching coach in the major leagues might also be the most grateful. Dave Wallace, who turned 67 this month, will be coaching in the playoffs next week.

headline: The New York Jail Scandal Continues
abstract: News that city officials sanitized a report about Rikers Island raises many questions on whether the city is ready to reform the jail system.
lead_paragraph: A Justice Department investigation that last month uncovered a chamber of horrors at the Rikers Island jail in New York City was bad enough in its depiction of corruption and brutality in the city jail system. Now comes the news that the Department of Correction had sanitized a 2012 report that it later turned over to federal investigators, eliminating passages recommending demotion for two officials who were derelict in their jobs and failed to supervise the jail they oversaw.

headline: Health Agency’s New Assessment of Epidemic Is More Dire Still
abstract: New figures from the World Health Organization suggest that the Ebola virus could become a constant presence in West Africa and cause more than 20,000 cases by Nov. 2.
lead_paragraph: New figures published Monday by the World Health Organization reveal a far worse outlook than it had previously anticipated for the Ebola epidemic in West Africa.

headline: With Brodeur Gone, Elias Is Steadying Influence on Devils’ Roster
abstract: Patrik Elias enters his 19th season with 983 career points, a franchise record, but without a longtime teammate, goaltender Martin Brodeur.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Devils forward Patrik Elias is used to watching teammates come and go.

headline: As U.S. Bombs Fall, British Hostage of ISIS Warns of Another Vietnam
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Propaganda', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The terrorist group issued a new installment in its propaganda “lecture series” delivered by the British hostage.
lead_paragraph: As American airstrikes began raining down on the de facto capital of the Islamic State in Syria on Monday night, the militant group issued a new installment in its “lecture series” delivered by a British hostage, John Cantlie.

headline: Derek Jeter Shares Spotlight in Yankees’ Victory
abstract: Michael Pineda carried a one-hitter into the eighth inning, and Jose Pirela, who was making his major league debut, had a big night, scoring on a Jeter double.
lead_paragraph: Jose Pirela made his major league debut for the Yankees on Monday and became the 57th person to play for the team this season, setting a club record. Now, 56 people can say they played with Derek Jeter in his final season.

headline: Program to Give Legal Help to Young Migrants
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Children and Childhood', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: The New York City Council and two philanthropic foundations are combining forces to provide services to some 1,000 unaccompanied immigrant children facing possible deportation.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council and two philanthropic foundations are combining forces to provide legal representation and other services to some 1,000 unaccompanied immigrant children facing possible deportation under a new accelerated court process.

headline: Royals’ 11-Minute Loss Precedes a Win Against the Indians
abstract: The Indians picked up ground in the American League wild-card race by beating the Royals in the completion of a game suspended Aug. 31, but they gave it back by losing the second game.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Once the Kansas City Royals-Cleveland Indians game ended Monday evening, fireworks went off; Indians employees ran on top of the dugouts waving flags; and Scott Atchison, the pitcher who got the save, was interviewed on the field.

headline: Warming Temperatures Threaten Fragile Balance in Canadian Arctic
abstract: Hot summers are becoming more frequent, an ominous sign for the polar desert ecosystems that rely on stable ground ice.
lead_paragraph: Ellesmere Island, Nunavut — It’s August, and there’s snow on the ground. The six-week summer has already passed; our 24-hour daylight will drop to 16 in just a month’s time. Small, brittle leaves crunch underfoot as I walk across tundra that’s already beginning to freeze for the long winter ahead.

headline: In the Navy
abstract: Open up to the elegant subtlety of a watch with a dark blue face and band.

headline: With Talko App, Ray Ozzie Creates a Permanent Voice
abstract: Ray Ozzie, onetime chief software architect at Microsoft, has a way to make phone conversations as permanent and searchable as other Internet communication.
lead_paragraph: If you want to really change the world, Ray Ozzie has concluded, change the conversation. In this case, change it into a medium in which wireless speech becomes a durable, searchable part of the computer world.

headline: Modicum of Suspense as Mets’ Year Winds Down
abstract: With a 76-80 record after a weekend sweep of Atlanta, the Mets have a chance to finish at .500 or better, something they have not done since 2008.
lead_paragraph: We interrupt Derek Jeter Week with an unexpected announcement: The Mets — yes, the Mets — have suddenly put some suspense into the final week of their season.

headline: Health Researchers Will Get $10.1 Million to Counter Gender Bias in Studies
abstract: Grants will be used to include more human participants — generally women — in clinical trials and to ensure that laboratory animals, even cell lines, are representative of both genders.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to begin addressing persistent gender bias in laboratory research, the National Institutes of Health announced Tuesday that it will distribute $10.1 million in grants to more than 80 scientists studying a diverse array of subjects, including drug addiction, fetal development, migraines and stroke.

headline: Hapless in Big Moments, Jets Fall to the Chicago Bears
abstract: The Jets did not catch. They did not bat down passes. They committed turnovers. They did not sustain drives. And they did not monitor Martellus Bennett, who scored what proved the winning touchdown.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rex Ryan windmilled his arm and stamped his foot and flung his hat to the turf, and at that moment it required a supreme amount of willpower for him not to run on the field, gather the Jets and give them an impromptu lesson in fundamentals.

headline: Why Senate Control Matters
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elections, Senate', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: No major laws are likely to pass in the next two years, regardless of which party controls the Senate. The reasons that the midterms matter are subtler.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats need to find a way to succeed in two red states this year. If they can do that — preventing Republican victories in some combination of Alaska, Arkansas, Kansas, Louisiana or North Carolina — Democrats can pull off a modest upset and keep control of the Senate this year. Otherwise, Mitch McConnell will probably achieve his dream of becoming Senate majority leader.

headline: TV Ratings Soar Amid N.F.L.’s Woes
abstract: On Sunday, CBS’s late afternoon game, Seattle’s overtime win over Denver, produced a 16.9 preliminary overnight rating, a 16 percent jump over the comparable game last season.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L generates the highest ratings in sports, and even the league’s mishandling of its domestic violence crisis seems to have done little to change that.

headline: North Carolina, in Political Flux, Battles for Its Identity
abstract: The state often seems as if it is moving in two directions at once, with the Democratic and Republican parties exhibiting gains and their members coexisting as neighbors.
lead_paragraph: SILER CITY, N.C. — In Raleigh, conservative Republicans may be running North Carolina like they own it, but go almost anyplace in the state, even to this former textile town that looks like a movie-set re-creation of an older, more traditional South, and the political picture quickly blurs.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) AMERICAN MASTERS: THE BOOMER LIST Timothy Greenfield-Sanders, above with Amy Tan, traverses the baby boomer generation with the help of 19 celebrities — one born each year, from 1946 to 1964 — as the last members turn 50. Subjects including Samuel L. Jackson (born in 1948), Billy Joel (1949), Ms. Tan (1952), Eve Ensler (1953), Kim Cattrall (1956), Rosie O’Donnell (1962) and John Leguizamo (1964) discuss their achievements, struggles and identities, as well as the movements that have shaped their lives in the environment, civil rights, politics, technology and the arts. In “Joan Rivers: A Piece of Work” (2010), at 10:30 on Channel 13, Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg “tagged along with their subject, racking up miles and yowzah moments in her relentless pursuit of fame, money, attention, love, kicks, masochistic thrills or whatever it is that makes Ms. Rivers, née Joan Alexandra Molinsky, run,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Following Ms. Rivers the year she turned 75 (she died on Sept. 4 at 81), they begin by moving in close to her cosmetically altered face — without makeup. “To their credit,” Ms. Dargis said, “the filmmakers don’t try to make her look good, and while they omit some of her uglier routines, they don’t (perhaps can’t) ask you to love her.”

abstract: What you need to know for the first day of Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Finally, at long last, they’ve arrived — or have they?

abstract: Students in Hong Kong are gearing up for their own civil disobedience, with plans to stage sit-in protests in the city’s Central business district in coming days and weeks.
lead_paragraph: Angus Li, a 19-year-old sociology major at Hong Kong Baptist University, does more than take part in student demonstrations: He accessorizes for them.

headline: China Sentences Uighur Scholar to Life
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The punishment of Ilham Tohti, a professor widely considered to be a moderate voice among ethnic Uighurs, was among the harshest imposed on a dissident in years.
lead_paragraph: ALTAY, China — A university professor who has become the most visible symbol of peaceful resistance by ethnic Uighurs to Chinese policies was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday after being found guilty of separatism by court officials in the western region of Xinjiang, which Uighurs consider their homeland.

headline: Omar J. Gonzalez, Accused of White House Intrusion, Is Recalled as Good but Troubled Neighbor
abstract: The veteran accused of breaching White House security started behaving strangely in recent months, neighbors in Texas said.
lead_paragraph: COPPERAS COVE, Tex. — To his neighbors in this military town at the edge of Fort Hood, Omar J. Gonzalez was friendly and big-hearted, an Iraq war veteran who read stories to the neighborhood children and was quick to respond whenever someone needed help carrying groceries or a jump-start for a troublesome car.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 2 Palestinian Suspects in Murders of Jewish Teenagers
abstract: A military spokesman said that the suspects Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha were found in Hebron, in the West Bank, and refused to surrender.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli troops closed a significant chapter in the summer’s bloody escalation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict on Tuesday by cornering and killing the two men they suspected of kidnapping and murdering three Israeli teenagers in June.

headline: Jimmy Choo, Luxury Shoe Brand, to List Shares in London
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: The British shoe company, which shot to fame on the feet of the stars of “Sex and the City,” is planning an offering next month that could value the new holding company at more than $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:09 p.m. | LONDON — The luxury shoe company Jimmy Choo, which shot to fame on the feet of the stars of “Sex and the City,” said on Tuesday that it planned to pursue an initial public offering later this year in London.

headline: Philippines Pulls Troops From Zone Near Syria
abstract: The United Nations peacekeeping force in the Golan Heights, of which Filipinos formed about one quarter, has been subjected to attacks by Syrian insurgents.
lead_paragraph: The four-decade-old United Nations peacekeeping operation in the Golan Heights region between Israel and Syria, largely curtailed last week because of Syria’s civil war, was further undermined on Tuesday with confirmation that the Philippines contingent was going home.

headline: As China’s Antigraft Efforts Increase, a Call for Padded Interrogation Rooms
abstract: The orders for the rooms, which are intended to prevent officials suspected of corruption from injuring themselves, come amid a huge increase in the number of graft cases under investigation in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: The rooms are padded, but not for anyone’s comfort. The announcement from the anticorruption authorities in Beijing that all of the capital’s districts and counties must install at least three “discussion rooms” was instead meant to drive home the government’s unrelenting resolve in prosecuting corrupt officials.
