headline: In Airstrikes, U.S. Targets Militant Cell Said to Plot an Attack Against the West
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American forces took advantage of the strikes against the Islamic State in Syria to try to also wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell that the White House said was plotting against the United States or Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American forces took advantage of the airstrikes against the Islamic State extremist group in Syria to try to simultaneously wipe out the leadership of an unrelated cell of veterans of Al Qaeda that the White House said Tuesday was plotting an “imminent” attack against the United States or Europe.

headline: How a Lopsided Recovery Fueled the Dollar-Store Wars
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: Times have been tough for discount retailers and their customers — and thrilling for a merger-happy Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Guzman has been shopping at the FamilyDollar store in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, since he was a kid, but lately something feels different. The service has gotten worse, the lines have grown longer and shoppers have responded accordingly. “It used to be packed here,” Guzman told me on a recent Saturday. “But it died out.” Guzman, who finished high school this year and makes $9.50 an hour as an assistant manager at an outsourcing company, ought to be right in Family Dollar’s core customer group. But that day, he opted out. Cringing at the $4.25 price tag on a broom, he walked across the street to a local 99-cent store instead.

headline: Are You a Nerd or a Geek?
abstract: Has our society fully embraced geek culture? Can someone now declare, without shame or embarrassment, “I am a nerd”?
lead_paragraph: Gadget wristwatches are all the rage. “The Big Bang Theory” often tops TV ratings. Gaming is definitely mainstream. Has society embraced geek culture?

headline: 1939: Sigmund Freud, Psychoanalyst, Dies Refugee in England at 83
abstract: Sigmund Freud’s obituary from The New York Herald Tribune in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Sigmund Freud, originator of psychoanalysis and considered by many as the greatest single influence on the thought of the twentieth century, died at his home in Hampstead, England, early yesterday morning at the age of eighty-three. He had been in poor health since leaving Vienna, after the 1938 Anschluss, and taking up his residence in England. In September last year, he had undergone a serious operation.

headline: Outgrowing Childhood Horrors in Beslan
abstract: Ten years after Chechen separatists took over a school in Beslan, resulting in the death of 186 students, the survivors find a way forward.
lead_paragraph: Every year, as the anniversary of the 2004 terrorist attack on a Russian school in Beslan nears, photographers descend on the small town to document the lingering effects of the hostage crisis in which 331 people – 186 of them students – were killed. The surviving children, many of whom were injured, are usually photographed looking somber, often inside the school’s ruins.

headline: Philips to Split Into Two Companies as Part of Overhaul
abstract: The Dutch electronics giant will split into two entities: one focused on health care and technology, and one on lighting.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Tuesday that it planned to split itself into two companies: one focused on health care and technology, and the other on lighting.

headline: Eurozone Growth Is Slowing, Survey of Purchasing Managers Suggests
abstract: The survey showed that business activity in September was still expanding, but just barely, with the index falling to its lowest level this year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The eurozone’s economic expansion continued to lose traction in September, a private-sector report said on Tuesday, the latest indication that the stagnation of the second quarter might be taking hold.

headline: Season Opens, and the Intrigue Is at Last Onstage
abstract: After a summer of acrimonious contract negotiations, the opera began its season with a production of “Le Nozze di Figaro” by the British director Richard Eyre.
lead_paragraph: That the Metropolitan Opera opened its season as scheduled on Monday night with a new production of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” was good news, no matter what your take on the show. This summer, as acrimonious contract negotiations between the administration and the unionized workers reached a bitter impasse, the possibility of a lockout that could threaten the season was all too real.

headline: Does Online Education Widen Offline Gaps?
abstract: Many people praise online education as an equalizing force, but some argue that online resources can amplify certain inequities even as they lessen others.
lead_paragraph: The value of online education at the college level has been a subject of much dispute. But at The Daily Dot, Cabell Gathman considers the role of the Internet in teaching high school kids — and raises larger questions about how online resources might amplify some inequities even as they lessen others.

headline: Four Reasons the G.O.P.’s National Edge Isn’t Translating to Senate Races
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Why are Democrats holding up reasonably well as Republicans pull ahead in national polling? There are four possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have taken a clear lead over the last month on the question of whether likely voters favor a Republican-controlled Congress or one dominated by Democrats. Some polls using this generic question show the Republicans ahead by as many as 7 points among likely voters, a tally rivaling the polls immediately before the Republican landslide in 2010.

headline: Daily Report: Future of Beats Music Service Remains Unclear Under Apple
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: When Apple agreed in May to pay $3 billion for Beats, it acquired not only a successful headphone line but also a fledgling online music service, a move that many analysts interpreted as a move into the fast-growing world of streaming music, Ben Sisario and Brian X. Chen report.

headline: Movies for Entrepreneurs: ‘We Are the Dreamers of Dreams’

headline: Rights Groups Say China Exports ‘Tools of Torture’
keywords: ['Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Chinese companies are selling law enforcement equipment that can be used for torture, fueling abuses in Africa and Asia, rights organizations reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese companies, some of them state-owned, are profiting from the production and export of law enforcement equipment that can be used for torture, fueling human rights abuses in Africa and Asia, two international human rights organizations said in a report released on Tuesday.

headline: 1889: Pining for Italian Annexation
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An Egyptian town asks to be annexed by Italy in 1889.
lead_paragraph: SUAKIN — Owing to the unjust policy alleged to be pursued by the Egyptian officers, the inhabitants of Agig have petitioned the Italian authorities in East Africa to annex that place. If the Italians should take Agig, there is no doubt that English commercial prospects in that quarter will be adversely affected. Some dervishes made a raid yesterday upon cattle near Suakin, but a body of native cavalry recovered possession of the animals. A sure sign of the peaceful intentions of most of the natives of the Eastern Soudan is furnished by the fact that the inhabitants of Tokar, Khor, Arbat and Odrus intend to grow cotton this season. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 24, 1889

headline: Obama Faces the World After Bombs Fall in Syria
abstract: President Obama heads to New York on Tuesday morning to address world leaders just hours after opening a new front in the war against Islamic extremists with an aerial barrage in Syria. The fight against the Islamic State and his climate change policy will be high on Mr. Obama’s agenda this week.
lead_paragraph: PhotoFighters from the Nusra Front among destroyed buildings south of Damascus, Syria, on Monday. Airstrikes were focused on fighters from the Nusra Front in northern Idlib Province. Credit Rami Al-Sayed/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']

lead_paragraph: While President Obama and more than 100 other heads of state are expected to participate in the United Nations Climate Summit today, President Xi Jinping of China, the country making by far the biggest contribution to the atmospheric buildup of greenhouse gases, will not appear.

headline: Morning Agenda: Crackdown on Inversions
abstract: The U.S. announces rules intended to deter inversions. | Wall Street is losing hope in Russia. | The Allergan takeover web is getting increasingly tangled. | Aging tech giants are trying to stay relevant.
lead_paragraph: U.S. CRACKS DOWN ON INVERSIONS | Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew announced rules on Monday that are intended to deter United States companies from relocating overseas through mergers to lower their tax bills in a maneuver known as an inversion, Julie Hirschfeld Davis reports in The New York Times. The rules are intended to make inversions more difficult and less profitable.

headline: Larry Ellison Bought an Island in Hawaii. Now What?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: How the tech billionaire came to own 87,000 acres, three hotels, a wastewater-treatment plant, a cemetery and 380 cats.
lead_paragraph: Henry Jolicoeur is a retired French Canadian hypnotherapist and a glass-products importer who enjoys making very low-budget documentary films. In the summer of 2012, Jolicoeur read that Larry Ellison, a founder of the Silicon Valley giant Oracle and the fifth-richest man in the world, had bought 97 percent of the Hawaiian island of Lanai — not a 97 percent stake in some kind of company, but 97 percent of the physical place. Jolicoeur was curious, so he booked a flight and packed his camera.

headline: In Performance: Andrew Rannells and Stephen Trask of ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’
abstract: Mr. Rannells, who plays the title character in the Broadway musical, sings the number “Midnight Radio,” accompanied by the show’s composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the number “Midnight Radio” from the Broadway musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” performed by the actor Andrew Rannells with the show’s composer, Stephen Trask, on guitar. Mr. Rannells, who replaced Neil Patrick Harris in the title role, is scheduled to star through Oct. 12, after which he will be replaced by Michael C. Hall. The show is at the Belasco Theater.

headline: Do the Math
abstract: Numbers are among the most basic facts we report — and many corrections could be avoided if writers and editors took more care to make sure the numbers are right.
lead_paragraph: Like names and dates, numbers are among the most basic facts The Times reports — and getting those facts right is the foundation of our journalism. Many errors, and many blows to The Times’s credibility, could be avoided if writers and editors took more care to make sure the numbers are right.

headline: Federal Prison Population Drops for First Time in 34 Years
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will announce Tuesday that the federal government will end its fiscal year next week with 4,800 fewer prisoners, the first time since 1980 that the inmate population has declined from year to year.
lead_paragraph: The federal government will end its fiscal year next week with 4,800 fewer prisoners, the first time since 1980 that the inmate population has declined from year to year. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will trumpet the decline Tuesday and release Justice Department figures projecting a continued decline of 2,000 prisoners next year and 10,000 the following year.

headline: Reminiscences of a Cold War Breakthrough
abstract: President Ronald Reagan’s former arms control director yearns for the days of bare-knuckled politics.
lead_paragraph: Ken Adelman yearns for the days when politics was more of a bare-knuckled affair that allowed for officials to stray from their talking points and make unexpected moves.

headline: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar, on Life Under Scrutiny in China
abstract: In interviews from 2010, Ilham Tohti, the Uighur professor who was sentenced to life in prison on charges of separatism, talked about the news media’s approach to Xinjiang, the stress his family had endured and his treatment by security officials.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, as China has been buffeted by surging violence in the far western region of Xinjiang, foreign journalists seeking analysis from local scholars relied on one man to make sense of news events: Ilham Tohti, the Uighur economics professor who could always be counted on to give an insightful and spirited assessment of the central government’s latest development initiative in Xinjiang — or the most recent “strike hard” security clampdown. The reliance on one person was not ideal, but pervasive fear long ago persuaded other Uighur academics to keep their mouths shut.

headline: Terrorists Threaten ‘Collapse’ of U.S., Scott Brown Ad Says
abstract: Scott Brown releases a new ad in the New Hampshire Senate race attacking Senator Jeanne Shaheen, his Democratic opponent, along with President Obama, for their positions on fighting the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: After Congress voted last week to authorize the training and arming of Syrian rebels in the fight against the Islamic State, political operatives prepared for more ads featuring the militant group. After all, nothing lends itself to an attack spot more than an incumbent candidate with a voting record on a tough issue.

headline: German Prosecutors Charge Deutsche Bank Executives
abstract: Jürgen Fitschen ​and several former leaders of the bank have been accused of colluding to give false testimony in a long-running lawsuit over the collapse of a bank client’s media empire​.
lead_paragraph: ​FRANKFURT — German prosecutors filed criminal charges on Tuesday against the co-chief executive of Deutsche Bank​, Jürgen Fitschen, ​and several former bank leaders, accusing them of colluding to give false testimony in a long-running lawsuit over the collapse of a bank client’s media empire​.

headline: Should Writers Avoid Sentimentality?
abstract: Roland Barthes said, “It is no longer the sexual which is indecent, it is the sentimental.” Zoë Heller and Leslie Jamison debate whether sentimentality is still a cardinal sin for writers.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Roland Barthes said, “It is no longer the sexual which is indecent, it is the sentimental.” This week, Zoë Heller and Leslie Jamison debate whether sentimentailty is a cardinal sin for writers.

headline: Ebola Cases Could Reach 1.4 Million Within Four Months, C.D.C. Estimates
abstract: In the worst case, Liberia and Sierra Leone could have 21,000 cases by Sept. 30 and 1.4 million by Jan. 20; in the best model, the epidemic in both countries would be “almost ended” by then.
lead_paragraph: Yet another set of ominous projections about the Ebola epidemic in West Africa was released Tuesday, in a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that gave worst- and best-case estimates for Liberia and Sierra Leone based on computer modeling.

headline: 1914: Prussian Women in Resistance
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prussian women take up arms against the Russians in 1914.
lead_paragraph: PETROGRAD — The “Army Gazette” has information that the Austro-German General Staff is now engaged in the formation of purely German and Hungarian regiments from the Landwehr and Landsturm, in order to counteract and outnumber the Slav regiments. A correspondent of the Retch declares that there are many women among the prisoners from the East Prussian frontier, captured for taking part in fighting. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 24, 1914

headline: Ukraine’s Best Pitch Might Come From the Sidelines
abstract: Ukraine plans to haunt this year’s gathering of world leaders at the United Nations like the ghost of the organization’s charter.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine plans to haunt this year’s gathering of world leaders at the United Nations like the ghost of the organization’s charter. Article 2 of the charter states that all member states will refrain from “the use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state.”

headline: Brain Trauma Extends Reach Into Soccer
abstract: The advanced case of C.T.E. in Bellini, a Brazilian who died in March, indicated again to researchers that the brain disease is not connected merely to boxers and American football players.
lead_paragraph: Bellini, a Brazilian soccer star who led the team that won the 1958 World Cup and was honored with a statue outside the Estádio do Maracanã in Rio de Janeiro, had a degenerative brain disease linked to dozens of boxers and American football players when he died in March at age 83.

headline: Abu Ghaith, a Bin Laden Adviser, Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
abstract: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, 48, who was convicted of conspiracy to kill Americans, providing material support to terrorists and conspiring to do so, warned that his penalty would bring dire consequences.
lead_paragraph: A Kuwaiti-born cleric who sat with Osama bin Laden in an Afghan cave hours after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and later became a fiery spokesman for the Qaeda leader, was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

headline: Startling Sight Where Blasts Are the Norm
abstract: Looming over the new campaign are memories of recent American-led interventions in Libya and Iraq, which ultimately led to new waves of instability.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When the predawn blasts rattled their windows and jolted them from sleep, residents of Raqqa, the Syrian city that is the de facto capital of the Islamic State, thought they were in for a new round of airstrikes from the Syrian government.

headline: FIFA Set to Approve Stoppages for Head Injuries
abstract: Under a new rule, referees will be able to stop games for up to three minutes so that an injured player can be examined by a team doctor.
lead_paragraph: Faced with increasing criticism regarding its handling of head injuries, FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, is expected to confirm a new policy this week that will allow referees to stop games for up to three minutes so that an injured player can be examined by a team doctor.

headline: A Twitter Oops From Gingrich
abstract: Sometimes it helps to check the tape.

headline: Ordering Abortion Drugs for Her Daughter Earns a Mother Jail Time
abstract: On Sept. 12th, Jennifer Whalen, a 39-year-old mother of three, went to jail to begin serving a 9-to-18-month sentence. Whalen’s crime was, in effect, ordering pills online that her older daughter took in the first several weeks of an unplanned pregnancy, when she was 16, to induce a miscarriage. The drugs have been available from a doctor with a prescription in the United States since 2000 and are used around the world to induce miscarriage. Read more.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 12th, Jennifer Whalen, a 39-year-old mother of three, went to jail to begin serving a 9-to-18-month sentence. Whalen’s crime was, in effect, ordering pills online that her older daughter took in the first several weeks of an unplanned pregnancy, when she was 16, to induce a miscarriage. The drugs have been available from a doctor with a prescription in the United States since 2000 and are used around the world to induce miscarriage. Read more.

headline: Tool Called Dataminr Hunts for News in the Din of Twitter
abstract: Dataminr, software that analyzes Twitter postings for patterns that indicate breaking news, became commercially available to news organizations on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, several producers at CNN received an alert from a new digital news-gathering tool that they were testing: A teenager in Los Angeles had posted a tweet saying that the pop music heartthrob Justin Bieber had been arrested.

headline: In Farewell Speech, Karzai Calls American Mission in Afghanistan a Betrayal
abstract: Speaking to his cabinet and senior staff members, the departing Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, said the United States “did not want peace for Afghanistan.”
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In his nearly 13 years as the leader of Afghanistan, Hamid Karzai’s most memorable public stances always seemed driven by some deep emotion, and an almost compulsive need to express it. There was heartbreak for families killed by errant airstrikes, outrage at the scheming of hostile neighbors, palpable longing to preside over a peaceful end to the Taliban insurgency.

headline: Obama Comments on Strikes Against ISIS
abstract: The president spoke on Tuesday after the United States military launched airstrikes overnight against Islamic State targets in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: The president spoke on Tuesday after the United States military launched airstrikes overnight against Islamic State targets in Iraq and Syria.

headline: Kerry Pushes for Human Rights Accountability in North Korea
abstract: Seeking to move the issue of human rights abuses in North Korea up the diplomatic agenda, Secretary of State John Kerry made a passionate appeal to world leaders to seek accountability for perpetrators of torture, rape and other atrocities.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to push the issue of human rights abuses in North Korea up the diplomatic agenda, Secretary of State John Kerry made a passionate appeal to world leaders to seek accountability for perpetrators of torture, rape and other atrocities.

headline: White Tiger Kills Visitor at Zoo in India
abstract: Security personnel who came to the scene were not equipped with tranquilizer guns and failed to save the 20-year-old man.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A young man was mauled to death by a white tiger at the New Delhi zoo on Tuesday after he fell into a moat in the animal’s enclosure and was unable to climb out to safety, witnesses said.

headline: Who Needs a Cuddle Buddy? Everyone, It Turns Out
abstract: A new app called Cuddlr helps users locate someone to cuddle with. The idea of cuddling with a total stranger may seem uncomfortable, but it may be more important than we think.
lead_paragraph: When I was in college, there was a Facebook group called “Will someone just please lie on top of me?” This was in an era when Facebook groups existed mainly as quirky avatars of real-life groups of friends, not as message boards for organizations or marketing for companies. It was a large group comprising people who didn’t necessarily know one another.

headline: Making Registering to Vote as Easy as Posting to Facebook
abstract: Rock the Vote and Kendall Jenner are launching a digital registration tool that allows users to register to vote completely from a smartphone (in states that allow online registration).
lead_paragraph: In its mission to get young people to vote, Rock the Vote is trying a new method this cycle: Make it easier.

headline: Republicans in Congress Support Obama on ISIS, to a Point
abstract: Republicans come out in support of the airstrikes against ISIS in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:11 p.m. | After all the ice-breaking dinners, congressional picnics and on-again-off-again “grand bargain” negotiations, President Obama has finally found a way to bring Republicans his way: bomb Syria.

lead_paragraph: The innovative musicians perform and discuss the special mystery of how a quartet communicates as part of an experiment capturing their sound and movement.

headline: Schwarzenegger Named a Tourist Ambassador for Madrid
abstract: Officials chose Arnold Schwarzenegger as their first honorary ambassador of tourism, hoping the star of “Conan the Barbarian” will attract visitors to the Prado and other museums.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years after Arnold Schwarzenegger played the pulp-fiction warrior in “Conan the Barbarian,” the actor is returning to the southern region of Spain — where the film was shot — to collect new honors. But this time he carries a lofty title: Madrid’s first honorary ambassador of tourism.

headline: A Flexible Ticket to Asia and the Southwest Pacific
abstract: SkyTeam, the airline alliance, is offering a flexible multi-destination ticket to Asia and the Southwest Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Even with tourism in Asia and the Southwest Pacific on the rise, a trip to the region can be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for both business and leisure travelers.

headline: How to See More of Your Best Friends? Move Away
abstract: When the demands of parenthood, career, and general midlife busy-ness made it tough to see friends as much as we wanted to, we moved away, and saw them more.
lead_paragraph: When my husband and I were making our pros and cons list several months ago, deciding whether to relocate with our 11-year-old son and 8-year-old daughter to Nashville from Atlanta, the biggest “con” was the idea of leaving behind our dear friends.

headline: Tiger Global, Big Investor in Tech Start-Ups, Said to Plan New $1.5 Billion Fund
abstract: The firm, which has invested in Alibaba Group and the sunglasses maker Warby Parker, has begun raising a new fund, just five months after raising another $1.5 billion vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Tiger Global Management, the $15 billion investment firm that has invested in the likes of the Alibaba Group and the sunglasses maker Warby Parker, has begun raising a $1.5 billion fund, just five months after raising another $1.5 billion vehicle, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton recreates a classic chicken and gravy dish from The Times’s former food editor Craig Claiborne. This Southern recipe first appeared in the newspaper in 1983.

headline: U.S. Invokes Iraq’s Defense in Legal Justification of Syria Strikes
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The airstrikes were carried out without the permission of the Syrian government or the United Nations Security Council.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States said on Tuesday that the American-led airstrikes against the Islamic State — carried out in Syria without seeking the permission of the Syrian government or the United Nations Security Council — were legal because they were done in defense of Iraq.

headline: Bargains From MossPOP, Garnet Hill and Others.
abstract: Home goods and furniture, for two- and four-leggers.
lead_paragraph: During the Mosspop.com “We’re Only Human” warehouse sale, many items are up to 70 percent off, while supplies last (a collapsible funnel from Normann Copenhagen, originally $25, is $15; Michael Young’s doghouse for Magis, above, originally $1,000, is $400), 212-204-7111, mosspop.com.

headline: Ebola: A Grave Site Report
abstract: Adam Nossiter reflected on his visit to a burial site in Freetown, Sierra Leone; gravediggers there suggest Ebola’s death toll is higher than reported.
lead_paragraph: Adam Nossiter, The Times’s West and Central Africa bureau chief,  reported on Tuesday from Freetown, Sierra Leone. He spoke with gravediggers there. Mr. Nossiter’s conversations with the burial teams point to a severe undercount in the Ebola death toll. The reporter provides a sense of his experience at the Freetown burial site.

headline: Make Dinner: A Home Cooking Manifesto
abstract: The message of the moment is to embrace the act of cooking dinner. It is an easy habit to form, and offers many benefits.
lead_paragraph: Just cook. That is the message of the moment, the act to embrace. Just cook dinner. It is a habit as easy to form as a bad one, and more beneficial by far.

headline: A Debut Video From Laetitia Sadier of Stereolab
abstract: Just in time for Paris Fashion Week, T debuts “Something Shines,” the French chanteuse and musician’s new solo album.
lead_paragraph: The French chanteuse and multi-instrumentalist Laetita Sadier is perhaps best known as the front woman of the sprawling avant-pop outfit Stereolab, whose dozens of EPs and albums through the 1990s and 2000s set her multi-lingual, explicitly politicized vocals to a backdrop blending Krautrock, minimalist composition, bossa nova and northern soul, among other genres. When the band went on hiatus in 2009, Sadier began releasing records under her own name. Her newest effort, “Something Shines,” is out on Drag City today. Sadier describes its sound as “a ’70s-style production that is rich, luxuriant, powerful and free.”

headline: Climate Summit Opens as Leaders Attempt to Address Divide Over Warming
abstract: President Obama was scheduled to address the climate meeting, as was Zhang Gaoli, the vice premier of China.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:15 p.m. | The New York Times’s Coral M. Davenport is at the United Nations Climate Summit, where the secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, and other world leaders are addressing issues of global warming. Ms. Davenport and Mark Lander report that President Obama, emboldened by the use of his executive powers to fight climate change at home, sought to marshal world leaders on Tuesday behind a vast international effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions and curb global warming. lead_paragraph: Over the summer Representative Renee Ellmers of North Carolina said her male colleagues could improve their messaging by bringing policy discussions “down to a woman’s level.” Finally a new Americans for Shared Prosperity ad has attempted to do just that.

headline: Tanya Tagaq Wins Canada’s Polaris Prize
abstract: Ms. Tagaq, an Inuit throat singer, beat Arcade Fire and Drake for the best recording by a Canadian musician or group.
lead_paragraph: If you are among the many music fans who complain that music award shows are too predictable, you might consider keeping tabs on the Polaris Music Prize from now on. The prize is for the best recording of the year made by a Canadian musician or group, and there were some big names on this year’s short list – Drake and Arcade Fire, most notably. But the winning work, selected by an 11-member jury of Canadian critics and announced at a gala concert in Toronto on Monday evening, was “Animism,” by Tanya Tagaq, an Inuit throat singer. The prize is 30,000 Canadian dollars (about $27,000). The four-hour concert can be seen on YouTube.

headline: Soda Makers Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Dr Pepper Join in Effort to Cut Americans’ Drink Calories
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Calories', 'Obesity', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Labeling and Labels', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Beverages']
abstract: The three companies said they would change practices like marketing to encourage less consumption of calorie-heavy drinks.
lead_paragraph: The three largest soda companies — Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and the Dr Pepper Snapple Group — have pledged to cut the number of sugary drink calories that Americans consume by one-fifth in about a decade, through a combination of marketing, distribution and packaging.

headline: Into Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A few different ways of looking at our intervention.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t that much to say, now that bombing has officially begun, that I didn’t say in my skeptical blog post following the president’s initial announcement of a wider war, and my skeptical Sunday column on the same subject. You can read Dan Drezner and Jeffrey Goldberg for cautiously pessimistic and cautiously optimistic takes, respectively; my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Omar Al-Jawoshy have a not-entirely encouraging take on the tactical state of play in Iraq; Daniel Trombly and Yasir Abbas have a very interesting piece in The Daily Beast on what it would actually mean to degrade the Islamic State’s fighting capacity; and Dexter Filkins on the Kurds in the New Yorker is the higher-level must-read of the week.

headline: Vitamin E and Selenium Fail to Prevent Cataracts
abstract: Vitamin E and selenium are unlikely to lower cataract risk, though selenium might have a small effect, a large new study found.
lead_paragraph: Many health supplement companies, and some medical experts, have recommended vitamin E and selenium for reducing the risk for cataracts. But a large new study has found they are unlikely to provide benefit, though selenium might have a small effect.

headline: Ban Ki-Moon: ‘Extremist Groups Pose an Immediate Threat’
abstract: “I think it is undeniable — and the subject of broad international consensus — that these extremist groups pose an immediate threat to international peace and security,” Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general said Tuesday that even though airstrikes by the United States and its allies were not carried out at the “request” of the Syrian government in Damascus, large parts of that country are out of the government’s control.

headline: Students and Residents Air Concerns After High School’s Cancellation of ‘Spamalot’
abstract: A Pennsylvania high school cancellation of a production of “Spamalot” roils members of the community.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:42 p.m. | At a school board meeting on Monday night residents and students of South Williamsport, Pa., spoke out about the controversy over the cancellation of the high school’s planned production of the Broadway musical “Spamalot.” According to an article on Tuesday in The Williamsport Sun-Gazette, students focused less on “Spamalot” – which had been canceled by school administrators because of a gay subplot – than on their split feelings regarding the director of the musical, Dawn Burch.

headline: Hannah’s Self-Aware Alter Ego

headline: Behind Jean Paul Gaultier’s Goodbye
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: As the designer abandons ready-to-wear, there may be lessons to be learned.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When Jean Paul Gaultier announced at the beginning of the women’s wear season’s four-ring, four-week circus that this Saturday’s show would be his last ready-to-wear collection, and that he was going to concentrate on couture and fragrance and special collaborations like costumes and interiors instead, it seemed like the end of an era.

headline: A Landmark Bar Is Moving Again
abstract: Milk & Honey, which opened as a Lower East Side speakeasy in 2000, is being forced to relocate.
lead_paragraph: Milk & Honey 2.0 lasted less than two years.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Words to Remember Him By

abstract: Fashion names tell their favorite Gaultier stories, from Hamish Bowles’s turn on the runway to Coco Rocha’s shared sunset.
lead_paragraph: The news that Jean Paul Gaultier was shutting down his ready-to-wear business, with his last show scheduled for Saturday in Paris, prompted recollections from industry notables who have long considered Mr. Gaultier one of the more original people in fashion — on and off the runway.

headline: A Bush Will Stump in Tight North Carolina Senate Race

lead_paragraph: Facing a tough race against Senator Kay Hagan, Republican challenger Thom Tillis has been bringing in some big political guns in hopes that their star power will rub off.

headline: Restaurant Report: Westward in Seattle
abstract: Do you prefer good food or good views? Here, you don’t have to choose.
lead_paragraph: The appeal of Seattle’s waterfront restaurants — with views of freshwater lakes and majestic Puget Sound — often starts and ends with those vistas. Westward, which opened last September, doesn’t fall into that category. The views are spectacular; located on the north shore of Lake Union, the restaurant overlooks the lake and, beyond it, the Space Needle and city skyline. But it is what’s on the menu that bumps Westward into a different tier.

headline: Giving the Paris Cafe Scene a Jolt
abstract: Over the last few years, more than a dozen new-generation coffee spots have emerged, offering alternatives to cookie-cutter Parisian cafes.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Channa Galhenage, a Londoner, moved to Paris to work in human resources. A longtime coffee devotee, he was shocked by the espresso he tasted in many French cafes.

headline: Journalist Kidnapped in Somalia Is Released
abstract: Captors freed Michael Scott Moore, a German-American kidnapped while researching piracy, after a ransom was paid, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A German-American journalist who was abducted more than two years ago while in Somalia researching a book about piracy was freed by his captors on Tuesday, German officials said.

headline: Today in Small Business: Why Jewelry Stores Hide the Price Tags

lead_paragraph: The conservative author and documentary filmmaker Dinesh D’Souza was spared prison time on Tuesday after pleading guilty earlier this year to violating federal campaign finance laws.

lead_paragraph: Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon, two of the world’s most sought-after ballet choreographers, will create a new work for Wendy Whelan’s farewell performance with New York City Ballet on Oct. 18, the company said.

headline: Cadillac Tries to Make a Fresh Start in New York
abstract: General Motors is seeking to help the brand shed its stodgy image and recapture a mystique that melted away nearly two decades ago.
lead_paragraph: The last time Cadillac, a symbol of American success, was the top-selling luxury car brand in the United States was in 1997. Since then, its executives have tried seemingly everything — from new models to new management to new marketing — to revive its flagging fortunes, with little to show for it.

headline: Political Helpline: Parsing Two Religion Polls

headline: When in Love With an Egyptian Queen, Go Bold
abstract: A new take on Shakespeare’s “Antony and Cleopatra” at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton focuses on the raging romance rather than the battles.
lead_paragraph: Passions, power, allegiances — everything shifts during Shakespeare’s “Antony and Cleopatra.” In a staging directed by Emily Mann at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, the only constant is the production itself — it’s always beautifully bold.

headline: Guido Palau and David Sims on What Changed Fashion Photography
abstract: The hairstylist and photographer credit their early collaborative years as the starting-off point of their careers. Today, they celebrate their latest book, “Hair,” and talk to T about the evolution of their creative landscape, style gangs and fantasy hair.
lead_paragraph: The fashion world often revolves around creative alliances. And in the case of the British photographer and T contributor David Sims and the hairstylist Guido Palau, early collaborations proved to be the spark that ignited their careers. Both hail from similar backgrounds, having grown up around “not sophisticated London,” as Palau describes it, listening to a lot of David Bowie, punk and New Wave music. They formed an easy friendship in the mid ’80s and soon teamed up behind the lens, building a portfolio of test pictures that would define their respective styles: Sims would often cast lanky kids off the street, letting them do whatever they felt like in front of the camera, while Palau created “non-hair” that was usually messy, unwashed and always offhandedly cool. The look was a precursor to grunge and quickly caught the attention of Calvin Klein, who hired the duo to shoot his CK campaign featuring Kate Moss in 1993. It was a pivotal moment for Sims and Palau, yet neither realized it at the time. “I didn’t think even for a minute we’d end up making anything like a living from it,” says Sims. “Or be successful,” adds Palau.

headline: PATH Service Between Midtown and New Jersey to Be Suspended
abstract: Train service will be shut down through Tuesday night while crews try to repair power cables that caught fire in a tunnel on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PATH train service between Midtown Manhattan and New Jersey will be suspended through Tuesday night while crews try to again repair power cables that caught fire in a tunnel beneath the streets of Chelsea on Sunday.

headline: Obama Presses Chinese on Global Warming
abstract: President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China to make the same effort to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama, emboldened by his use of executive powers to fight climate change at home, challenged China on Tuesday to make the same effort to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions and join a worldwide campaign to curb global warming.

headline: Fall Television Season Opens With Strong Ratings
abstract: The 8 p.m. hour of television on Monday night attracted about 50 million viewers on the four broadcast networks.
lead_paragraph: In as big an affirmation as the television business might be able to offer that strong programming still can draw a real crowd, the 8 p.m. hour of television Monday night attracted about 50 million viewers on the four broadcast networks, with another 14 million or so watching football on ESPN.

headline: Concrete Slab Crushes Construction Worker in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: The 27-year-old victim was working to secure the foundation of a building next to a construction site on West 37th Street, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A concrete slab weighing thousands of pounds crashed to the ground on Tuesday, trapping and killing a worker at a Midtown Manhattan construction site, fire officials said.

headline: For Cardinals, Success by Way of Castoffs
abstract: By finding players other teams rejected and making the most of their talents, Arizona won 10 games in 2013 and is 3-0 this season.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the Arizona Cardinals won only five games, prompting the organization to make significant changes. Steve Keim was promoted to general manager on Jan. 8, 2013; nine days later, Bruce Arians was hired as coach. Keim and Arians immediately helped turn around the Cardinals: Despite being in the N.F.L.’s toughest division, Arizona surprisingly won 10 games in 2013. And with a 3-0 start this season, Keim and Arians are again exceeding expectations.

headline: Russia Moves to Extend Control of Media
abstract: Lawmakers passed a preliminary bill limiting foreign ownership of media outlets, which would force several publications to change ownership or close.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Parliament passed a preliminary bill on Tuesday that would limit foreign ownership of Russian media outlets to 20 percent, targeting several prominent publications critical of the government and extending the Kremlin’s control over the nation’s independent news media.

headline: First Draft Focus: A Receiving Party
abstract: The mechanics of a presidential receiving party at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: President Obama never has to walk alone. At Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, he is greeted by a receiving party of Col. John Millard and his wife, Jamie. The colonel greets Mr. Obama when he travels though Andrews, but his wife is only present when Michelle Obama is there. They walk with the first family between aircraft, and the stroll is usually bookended by a salute at each end.

headline: U.S. Curbs on Inversions May Deter Some Pharmaceutical Deals
abstract: Some American-led transactions may survive on strategic logic. But pure tax-avoiding combinations look tricky, Neil Unmack and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews write.
lead_paragraph: The clampdown by the United States on tax-driven cross-border mergers and acquisitions should deter half-baked pharmaceutical deals. Some American-led transactions, like AbbVie’s recent agreement to buy its British rival Shire, may survive on strategic logic. But pure tax-avoiding combinations look tricky.

lead_paragraph: Fordham University’s new law school and residence hall building, designed by Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, has been completed opposite Damrosch Park, the first phase of Fordham’s 15-year master plan for its Manhattan campus adjoining Lincoln Center.

headline: At Paris Fashion Week, Hedi Slimane’s ‘Sonic’ Exhibit Opens
abstract: “Sonic,” an exhibition of black-and-white photographs taken by the Saint Laurent designer, Hedi Slimane, opened on Sept. 18 at the Fondation Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent.
lead_paragraph: Rock ‘n’ roll has arrived, to a reverential hush, at the Fondation Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent. “Sonic,” an exhibition of black-and-white photographs taken by the Saint Laurent designer, Hedi Slimane, opened on Sept. 18 and will be on view through Jan 11.

keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, more than 100 world leaders gathered at the United Nations to open a climate summit meeting that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon hopes will provide momentum to a new round of negotiations toward a global environmental agreement to be signed in Paris next year.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – German technology initial public offerings are like city buses. You can wait ages for one to show up, and then two come by at once.

headline: Damien Hirst Collaborates With Deyrolle, Paris’s Treasure Trove of Taxidermy
abstract: The artist has assembled a cabinet of curiosities using items from the storied boutique. An online auction mirroring its contents will take place next month on Paddle8.
lead_paragraph: Deyrolle, the storied Paris taxidermy and entomology shop, has been cataloguing specimens of the natural world since 1831, providing a resource for researchers, scientists and artists — including Salvador Dalí and Jean Dubuffet — along the way. Now, just in time for Paris Fashion Week, the boutique is showcasing a collaboration with the artist Damien Hirst, whose work addresses themes of man’s relationship to nature. Hirst has assembled a cabinet of curiosities — titled “Signification (Hope, Immortality and Death in Paris, Now and Then)” — drawn from Deyrolle’s collections. In it, his favored leitmotifs (butterflies, skulls) are mixed with manmade objects (bottles of Raid and the British household cleaning product Domestos), teasing out themes of nature versus manufacture, the organic versus the inanimate.

headline: From Nuclear Freeze to Global Warming – and Back
abstract: Climate activists should note that the arms-reduction movement is experiencing significant setbacks.
lead_paragraph: In June 1982, up to a million demonstrators gathered in Central Park calling for a nuclear freeze. They were protesting the Reagan-era nuclear arms buildup and other developments they saw, not unreasonably, as a threat to civilization and to life on Earth, including talk by some Reagan aides about fighting and winning a nuclear war.

headline: Colin Farrell and Vince Vaughn to Star in Season 2 of HBO’s ‘True Detective’
abstract: The second edition of “True Detective,” once again written by Nic Pizzolatto, will begin production this fall.
lead_paragraph: HBO will try to repeat the success of its series “True Detective” this season with two more stars with long Hollywood credits: Colin Farrell and Vince Vaughn have signed to be the team that follows Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson.

headline: Flooding Risk From Climate Change, Country by Country
abstract: A new analysis of sea levels and flood risk around the world offers more evidence that the brunt of climate change will not be borne equally.
lead_paragraph: More than a quarter of Vietnam’s residents live in areas likely to be subject to regular floods by the end of the century. Four percent of China’s residents — 50 million people — live in the same kind of areas. Across the globe, about one person in 40 lives in a place likely to be exposed to such flooding by the end of the century, absent significant changes.

headline: Getting Value Out of Old iPhones After Upgrading
abstract: Last weekend, Apple sold millions of shiny new iPhones to people who already had cellphones. Now, thanks to a growing electronics-reselling industry, many of those old devices have somewhere to go.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are in for the opening weekend of Apple’s new iPhones: 10 million sold in just three days. That’s a lot of new iPhones, and a large number of them are going to people upgrading from older cellphones.

lead_paragraph: A good sharp knife is a cook’s best friend. It will help you to work with precision, and quickly. A dull knife conspires against you and slows you down.

headline: Choice of Gala León as Spain’s First Female Davis Cup Captain Stirs Debate
abstract: León’s appointment has spurred criticism from men’s players and coaches, including the suggestion that she could face a “logistical” problem in entering a men’s locker room.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Gala León’s appointment as Spain’s first female Davis Cup captain could be a milestone for women in Spanish sports. For now, though, it has instead fueled a debate about whether a woman is fit to coach a man.

headline: Heading to Cyprus, by Way of Going Home
abstract: An American woman embarks on the next journey of her professional soccer career, with a club team in Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — As I drove into Chapel Hill, N.C., on Route 15-501 recently, I was starkly reminded of how different I am now from when I would make that same drive as a student and soccer player at the University of North Carolina. Sometimes, the best way to evaluate how you’ve changed is in relation to what stays the same.

headline: On a Russian Farm, Where Frustration Grows
abstract: A production of “Uncle Vanya” at the Pearl Theater gains immediacy from its loose-limbed translation.
lead_paragraph: Chekhov didn’t make it to the People’s Climate March that flowed through Midtown Manhattan on Sunday — being dead does get in the way — but he was with the environmental activists in spirit. In “Uncle Vanya,” which opens the season at the Pearl Theater Company, this playwright’s 19th-century worries over an ailing earth are startlingly contemporary.

headline: Chinese President Sends Signal Against Political Change in Hong Kong
abstract: President Xi Jinping lends his authority to efforts to restrict democratic expansion during meeting with some of territory’s leading tycoons.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — President Xi Jinping of China has used a meeting with some of Hong Kong’s leading industrialists to reinforce Beijing’s unyielding position against political change in the former British colony, lending his personal authority to the government’s efforts to undermine the pro-democracy movement here and to signal to the city’s business elite that it should toe the official line.

headline: A Family Rooted in Two Realms
abstract: The new ABC comedy “black-ish” follows a black family struggling with what it means to be prosperous.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people in the television business are said to be curious to see how “black-ish,” ABC’s new comedy, is received when it has its premiere on Wednesday night. What they should really be curious about, though, is where the series goes after its funny but talking-point-heavy first episode.

headline: A Vintage Miami Beach Hotel Gets a Makeover
abstract: The renovated Shelborne Wyndham Grand South Beach will feature a restored floating staircase by the architect Morris Lapidus and a new restaurant by the chef Masaharu Morimoto.
lead_paragraph: The original 1940-vintage Shelborne hotel was grand in its day, expanded in 1950 by the architect Morris Lapidus in the postwar building boom that lured vacationers to Miami Beach.

headline: Recording Academy to Honor Dylan
abstract: Bob Dylan was named the person of the year for 2015 by the charitable arm of the Recording Academy.
lead_paragraph: The MusiCares Foundation has named Bob Dylan its person of the year for 2015, and has assembled a starry roster of performers to pay tribute to him at the foundation’s 25th annual benefit gala in Los Angeles on Feb. 6, the foundation announced on Tuesday. MusiCares is a charitable arm of the Recording Academy, the organization that presents the Grammy Awards; its tribute concert is among the events leading up to the 57th Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 8.

headline: The Rising Designer Atlantique Ascoli Opens Up Her Paris Black Book
abstract: To kick off Paris Fashion Week, the chic native — whose shirting-based collection is stocked at Barneys New York and Dover Street Market — shares a list of her favorite places around town with T.
lead_paragraph: Atlantique Ascoli is to design-world lore what Charlotte Gainsbourg is to music legend: a Parisian daughter of two extremely cool people who grew up to create extremely cool things on her own. Ascoli’s mother, the fashion designer and onetime model Emmanuelle Khanh, personified Parisian chic in the ’70s and ’80s; her father, Quasar Khanh, is an avant-garde icon who pioneered inflatable furniture and a glass-cube car, among other inventions. Such an upbringing, Ascoli says, taught her to “be open, regardless of the situation.”

headline: Prolific but Unassuming, a Troupe in High Gear
abstract: For Miro Magloire’s New Chamber Ballet, celebrating its 10th anniversary, limited means can force ingenuity, delivered with an unassuming tone.
lead_paragraph: In the fifth-floor studios of City Center on Friday, Miro Magloire was sharing statistics about what his New Chamber Ballet had accomplished in the 10 years, “pretty much to the day,” since the company first performed there. The largest sum was large indeed. The number of ballets presented, almost all of them premieres: 93.

headline: Existential and Erotic, Like a Flower Yielding to a Butterfly
abstract: The Utsav festival at the Kennedy Center featured a venerable exponent of India’s Kathak tradition and a celebrated dancer of the Bharata Natyam style.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The three-day celebration of India’s maestros of music and dance, presented under the name Utsav last weekend at the Kennedy Center, was nonpareil. This was a sequel to Utsav’s first edition in 2013; I hope others will follow. I hope, too, that word will spread more widely. Although attendance at the Terrace Theater was very good, the festival seemed to draw largely people of Indian descent.

headline: A Sorceress Stirs Up a Sense of Adventurousness
abstract: Handel’s “Alcina,” at the Whitebox Art Center, aroused memories of the adventurous New York City Opera, which folded last year.
lead_paragraph: So much has been missing since the dissolution of New York City Opera last year. While smaller organizations and festivals have filled some of the void, a particular regret is losing the intriguing, inventive directorial vision City Opera showed at its best. Imagine comparing Christopher Alden’s staging of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro,” scheduled for that company last season and canceled, with the traditional Richard Eyre version that opened the Metropolitan Opera’s season on Monday.

headline: Vocals and Instruments, Weaving a Bach Tapestry
abstract: The conductor Scott Metcalfe led the instrument ensemble Tenet and a vocal counterpart, the Sebastians, in four Bach motets on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The early-music vocal ensemble Tenet opened its season on Saturday evening at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church with resplendent performances of four Bach motets, conducted by Scott Metcalfe. The group has sung this richly virtuosic choral music in the past, but here, following a practice that scholars believe Bach employed, it joined forces with the period-instrument ensemble the Sebastians, with each instrumentalist doubling one vocal line. A soprano might be twinned with a violin, for instance; a baritone with a bassoon. Some of the tenor parts, with their difficult-to-match range, were doubled by an oboe da caccia, the scimitar-shaped “hunting oboe” of Bach’s time, with its distinct, throaty sound.

headline: Evoking a Paris Nightclub in the 1920s
abstract: The Knights performed “An Evening at Le Boeuf sur le Toit,” inspired by the jazz-era Parisian nightclub, at Roulette in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A glassy-eyed woman stood at the front of the stage, holding a red Christmas stocking, as the violinist Colin Jacobsen and the pianist Steven Beck played Schnittke’s sardonic “Silent Night,” at Roulette in Brooklyn on Thursday evening. A man unwrapping the presents next to her found a pistol, a noose and scissors in the boxes.

headline: Music Director Laments Lockout
abstract: Robert Spano, music director of the Atlanta Symphony, has made a public plea on behalf of his locked-out performers, an unusual step for a conductor.
lead_paragraph: When the well-regarded Atlanta Symphony Orchestra locked out its musicians in a labor dispute for the second time in two years and then announced this week that it was canceling the beginning of its 70th-anniversary season, its music director, Robert Spano, found himself worrying about what the silencing of the ensemble would mean for Atlanta.

headline: Laure Heriard Dubreuil on What to Pack for Paris
abstract: The French-born, New York- and Miami-based owner of The Webster reveals what’s in her suitcase this Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Laure Heriard Dubreuil calls her Paris Fashion Week schedule “grueling,” before adding, “but I love it!” The CEO and founding partner of the influential Miami boutique the Webster — and a stateside Parisienne — plans to take in runway shows at Chanel, Christian Dior, Saint Laurent, Givenchy and Céline. Also on Dubreuil’s docket: Esteban Cortazar’s much-anticipated presentation; a slew of market appointments for the hundred-plus brands that the Webster stocks; co-hosting Pierre Hardy’s 15 Ans Déjà disco-themed party; and completing a swimwear collection for Erès, to debut at Art Basel Miami Beach in December.

headline: Treasury Takes a Modest Step on Inversions
abstract: Proposed Treasury regulations will change the economic calculus for tax-motivated inversions but will not deter deals with a real business motivation, Victor Fleischer writes in the Standard Deduction column.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department’s notice of proposed regulations to curb so-called inversions is smart and narrowly tailored. The new rules would take away some — but not all — of the reasons that a company might want to give up United States citizenship.

headline: Pivotal Drive at Previous Tournament Didn’t Occur on Course
abstract: A time zone mix-up led to Rory McIlroy’s needing a police escort to make his tee time at Medinah Country Club, setting up a Sunday singles session for the ages.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — As the top-ranked player and lodestar of the European team, Rory McIlroy is right back where he was two years ago at the last Ryder Cup, won by the Europeans with a Sunday singles session for the ages. McIlroy was instrumental in the upset of the Americans, but not before giving his squad of elders a few more gray hairs.

headline: Sirius XM Loses Lawsuit on Royalties for Oldies
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The ruling by a federal judge in California, based on the state’s copyright laws, was in favor of the Turtles, a ’60s group that sued for copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: In a case that could have wide implications for the digital music business, a federal judge in California ruled on Monday that Sirius XM, the satellite radio giant, was liable for copyright infringement for failing to pay royalties on recordings made before 1972.

headline: Academic Skills on Web Are Tied to Income Level
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Income Inequality', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Income', 'Illiteracy']
abstract: A new study indicates that the higher the income level of a student’s family, the more adept the student will be on how to use the web.
lead_paragraph: Wealthier students tend to perform better on tests of reading comprehension than their poorer peers, a longstanding trend that has been documented amply. But with the Internet having become an indispensable part of daily life, a new study shows that a separate gap has emerged, with lower-income students again lagging more affluent students in their ability to find, evaluate, integrate and communicate the information they find online.

headline: Former Vatican Ambassador Is Facing Sexual Abuse Trial
abstract: Jozef Wesolowski, a defrocked archbishop, has been accused of sexually abusing boys he met on the street while serving in the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican said on Tuesday that it had placed under house arrest and opened criminal proceedings against one of its former ambassadors, Archbishop Jozef Wesolowski, who has been accused of sexually abusing boys he met on the street while serving in the Dominican Republic.

headline: First Draft Focus: White House Adds Another Fence, Kind Of
abstract: A second, temporary fence has been placed outside the North gates of the White House.

headline: The Ancestors of ISIS
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Jihadist states have a history, and it shows they always fail.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — IN the last few years, there has been a dramatic rise of a seemingly new type of polity: the Islamic rebel state. Boko Haram in West Africa, the Shabab in East Africa, the Islamic Emirate in the Caucasus and, of course, the Islamic State in the Middle East, known as ISIS, or ISIL — these movements not only call for holy war against the West, but also use their resources to build theocracies.

headline: A Health Care Success Story
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Medicare']
abstract: How the Affordable Care Act helped transform a Texas city.
lead_paragraph: IT may have been the most influential magazine article of the past decade. In June of 2009, the doctor and writer Atul Gawande published a piece in The New Yorker called “The Cost Conundrum,” which examined why the small border city of McAllen, Tex., was the most expensive place for health care in the United States.

headline: A Mayor’s Words Inflame a Debate Over Spanish Attitudes on Women
abstract: Francisco Javier León de la Riva, the mayor of Valladolid, has faced calls to step down after he said he had qualms about sharing an elevator with a woman because she might falsely claim rape.
lead_paragraph: VALLADOLID, Spain — The mayor of this city defended his recent comments about women who make false rape claims as “unfortunate words.” But for many women here, his remarks were a good example of why violence against women remains a serious problem in Spain.

headline: Scott Brown Loses Cosmo’s Support
abstract: Cosmopolitan, which once gushed over Mr. Brown as America’s Sexiest Man, has now endorsed the woman he is trying to unseat, Senator Jeanne Shaheen, in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Scott P. Brown had a broad grin on his face when he posed nude for Cosmopolitan back in the 1980s. But his smile may vanish if he picks up the latest issue.

headline: ISIS Crisis
abstract: The mounting tension involved in the fight against the Islamic State is not going away anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: There is a tension at the heart of President Obama’s campaign to confront the Islamic State, and it explains a lot about why he has so much trouble articulating and implementing his strategy. Quite simply, it is the tension between two vital goals — promoting the “soul-searching” that ISIS’s emergence has triggered in the Arab-Muslim world and “searching and destroying” ISIS in its strongholds in Syria and Iraq.

headline: Companies Take the Baton in Climate Change Efforts
abstract: Forty companies pledged on Tuesday to help cut tropical deforestation in half by 2020 and stop it entirely by 2030.
lead_paragraph: With political efforts to slow global warming moving at a tortuous pace, some of the world’s largest companies are stepping into the void, pledging more support for renewable energy, greener supply chains and fresh efforts to stop the destruction of the world’s tropical forests.

headline: In Central Park, Cyclists Still Compete With Pedestrians
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Two days after a woman walking on West Drive died after being struck by a bicycle, many riders ran red lights there.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a Connecticut woman died of injuries sustained after she was hit by a bicycle, pedestrians and cyclists were vying for space on the popular loop road in Central Park where the accident occurred.

headline: U.N. Climate Summit Harvests a Host of Commitments
abstract: The U.N. Secretary General builds public and private commitments that could slow global warming and blunt its impacts.
lead_paragraph: It’s heartening to review the summary of governmental and private climate and energy commitments compiled by United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon at the end of his daylong climate change summit. They range from a substantial new push to reduce and eventually eliminate forest loss to boosted investment in a planned clean-energy corridor in Africa.

headline: U.S. Is Carrying Out Vast Majority of Strikes on ISIS, Military Officials Say
abstract: The Obama administration tried to convey a resolute coalition, but the vast majority of attacks were by American warplanes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The vast majority of airstrikes launched against Sunni militant targets in Syria have been carried out by American war planes and ship-based Tomahawk cruise missiles, military officials said Tuesday, in what they described as the successful beginning of a long campaign to degrade and destroy the Islamic State.

headline: Cracking Down on Corporate Tax Games
abstract: New rules from the Treasury Department should slow the practice of American companies avoiding taxes by merging with foreign rivals. Now Congress should act.
lead_paragraph: New rules from the Treasury Department are likely to slow the offensive practice that allows American companies to avoid taxes by merging with foreign rivals. Known as corporate inversions, these are complex, modern variations on the practices of yesteryear, when companies dodged their taxes by moving their addresses to post office boxes in the Caribbean.

headline: While Syrian Volunteers Seek Support, Crisis Worsens at Home
abstract: Members of the Syria Civil Defense, an opposition group, traveled to the United Nations to seek support. But their minds were on colleagues at home aiding those they say were injured in airstrikes targeting militants.
lead_paragraph: Raed Saleh woke up in his Manhattan hotel room at 8 a.m. on Tuesday to news of airstrikes at home in Syria.

headline: Wrong Turn on Syria: Helping Assad?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad stands to benefit from the Obama administration decision to carry out airstrikes in Syria.
lead_paragraph: It’s fair to assume that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was awed, but not shocked, by the barrage of bombs that American planes dropped early Tuesday over insurgent-held areas in northern Syria. It appears, in fact, that he was quite pleased.

headline: Under Affordable Care Act, 25 Percent Increase in Health Insurers Is Predicted
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists see opportunity in facial stubble.

headline: Blacks, Baseball and the Civil War
abstract: The national pastime was inextricably linked to the struggle for abolition and civil rights in the late 19th century.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War era revolutionized the still-nascent game of baseball in America – and not just for whites. During the war black baseball clubs increased; in the postwar period they sought recognition and equal treatment by white clubs and state and national baseball associations. But as in so many parts of national life, those achievements were ultimately limited and soon foreshortened: While black players gained respect from some members of the ball-playing fraternity, racist stereotypes, discrimination and segregation barred them from achieving equality on America’s diamonds.

headline: Philippines Concerned About China, Leader Says
abstract: Territorial disputes and mixed messages have been confusing, President Benigno S. Aquino III said.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Philippines expressed concern on Tuesday about what he called the “hot to cold” messages from China in the protracted territorial disputes with his country — and others in the region — over areas of the South China Sea.

headline: Wrong Turn on Syria: No Convincing Plan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: Why bombing Syria now is a bad decision that draws America into a new war with no plan for long-term consequences.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has put America at the center of a widening war by expanding into Syria airstrikes against the Islamic State, the Sunni extremist group known as ISIS and ISIL. He has done this without allowing the public debate that needs to take place before this nation enters another costly and potentially lengthy conflict in the Middle East.

headline: Detective in Etan Patz Case Admits He Added Words to Suspect’s Transcript
abstract: The officer, at a hearing in Manhattan, said Pedro Hernandez did not say “I am here voluntarily” during a 25-minute videotaped confession to the police.
lead_paragraph: Just before he was about to confess his role in the death of Etan Patz, the suspect offered a blander assertion, according to a transcript of his confession: “I am here voluntarily.”

headline: In Offense-Rich Big 12, Defense Rises
abstract: Oklahoma and Baylor appeared to be well positioned to challenge college football’s reigning kingpin, the Southeastern Conference, thanks to improved defenses.
lead_paragraph: In Morgantown, W.Va., on Saturday night, it looked like just another Big 12 scoring spectacle — for a half. There were sparks flying on the scoreboard, receivers out of breath and defenses flummoxed. No. 4 Oklahoma was tied, 24-24, with West Virginia, and all the conjecture that the Sooners, a national championship contender, had made strides in fixing their defense during the past two seasons seemed overblown in the 30-minute offensive bonanza.

lead_paragraph: Inversions, the hottest deal structure on Wall Street, appear to be safe for now. But they just became less profitable and more difficult to pull off.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Julia Pierson’s drive-time last Friday night was spent in her car listening to the radio traffic of her officers and agents as she headed home after a day immersed in the gritty details of how to protect President Obama and 140 world leaders at the United Nations this week.

headline: America Out of Whack
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Income Inequality', 'Corporations', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Productivity', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Why aren’t the rewards of economic growth distributed more fairly?
lead_paragraph: There is something out of whack in America. Instead of promoting equality, public policy has left millions locked into lives of restricted opportunity while bestowing the benefits of growth on the very few.

(Rich Medina) bops between two turntables, scratching and spinning, Mr. Grant tells the story of his life in rhymed couplets.

headline: Get Off the Ground
abstract: The return of Andy Kravis.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — For those of you who have not yet met him, Andy Kravis is sort of phenomenal. He’s an attorney working as a fellow at Lambda Legal, and he’s not only an indie crossword puzzle constructor, but he also blogs the occasional puzzle over at Diary of a Crossword Fiend and was the first season winner of NBC’s “The Million Second Quiz Show.”

headline: Wall St. Bankrolls Ex-Executive as He Sues Over A.I.G. Bailout
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief of A.I.G., has now raised several million dollars from three Wall Street investors to help cover the cost of the case.
lead_paragraph: One might call it “chutzpah,” as several irate lawmakers did, or “rubbing salt in the wounds” of the American taxpayer. But to a few Wall Street financiers, a lawsuit that accuses the government of shortchanging the American International Group in its 2008 bailout is something else: a promising investment in a cause they support.

headline: Accused of Bilking Client, Long Island Democrat Ends State Senate Bid

lead_paragraph: David Denenberg, the Democratic candidate in a highly competitive State Senate race on Long Island, abruptly ended his campaign on Tuesday after his former law firm accused him of fraud.

headline: Owner of Grand Central Vies With Developer Over Skyscraper on an Adjacent Block
abstract: Andrew S. Penson offered $400 million for a block where he could build a tower, next to Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: A little-known investor who owns Grand Central Terminal made a $400 million offer on Tuesday to buy an adjoining block where he plans to build a skyscraper so tall that it would loom over the Chrysler Building.

headline: Europe’s Anti-Semitism Comes Out of the Shadows
abstract: In the wake of the conflict in Gaza, three communities became flash points of violence and began contending with hatred they thought was buried in the past.
lead_paragraph: SARCELLES, France — From the immigrant enclaves of the Parisian suburbs to the drizzly bureaucratic city of Brussels to the industrial heartland of Germany, Europe’s old demon returned this summer. “Death to the Jews!” shouted protesters at pro-Palestinian rallies in Belgium and France. “Gas the Jews!” yelled marchers at a similar protest in Germany.

headline: Suit Details Firing and Suicide of 92nd Street Y Director
abstract: Deborah Adler filed a lawsuit against the 92nd Street Y, claiming contract violations and employment discrimination against her husband, Sol.
lead_paragraph: The event raised $4.2 million and featured a performance by the singer Jennifer Hudson, but that is not what Deborah Adler mentions when she thinks back to the 92nd Street Y’s spring gala in May 2013. “Several board members came over to me and said he needs to take a little time off — he’s looking a little tired,” she recalled on Tuesday.

headline: The Cost for Arab Bank Is a Complex Calculation

headline: Rookie Mistakes Haunt Geno Smith in Second Year With Jets
abstract: The Jets yearn for Smith to smooth out his rough edges like other second-year passers, but his progress is being overshadowed by the continuation of egregious turnovers.
lead_paragraph: Rookie quarterbacks are expected to be confused by various defensive looks, leading to critical turnovers and red-zone failures, amid other problems. Geno Smith fit that profile last season with 21 interceptions and four fumbles, many of them putting the Jets into deep holes and significantly contributing to their 8-8 record.

headline: Cleared After Nearly 23 Years in Prison, but Not Free
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: Everton Wagstaffe, after a New York State appellate court threw out his conviction in a kidnapping that ended in a teenager’s death, was sent to an immigration detention center.
lead_paragraph: Striding across a jailhouse visiting room on Saturday, Everton Wagstaffe — innocent in the eyes of the law, a prisoner of the persistence that liberated him — craned his neck to see who was waiting. He grinned broadly, stuck out his hand to welcome visitors, then apologized for an undetectable shortfall in personal hygiene.

headline: Caldwell Jones, Shot-Blocking Basketball Star, Dies at 64
abstract: Caldwell Jones, who helped the Philadelphia 76ers to three N.B.A. finals appearances, was a top defender who also had smooth, slithery move to the basket, a fluid hook shot and a reliable short-range jumper.
lead_paragraph: Caldwell Jones, a beanpole of a center and power forward who blocked more than 2,200 shots in his 17-year pro career and played in three National Basketball Association finals with the Philadelphia 76ers, died on Sunday in Stockbridge, Ga. He was 64.

headline: In Colorado, a Student Counterprotest to an Anti-Protest Curriculum
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Strikes', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Hundreds of high school students left class in response to a Jefferson County school district proposal to oversee a curriculum that would promote patriotism and respect.
lead_paragraph: ARVADA, Colo. — A new conservative school board majority here in the Denver suburbs recently proposed a curriculum-review committee to promote patriotism, respect for authority and free enterprise and to guard against educational materials that “encourage or condone civil disorder.” In response, hundreds of students, teachers and parents gave the board their own lesson in civil disobedience.

headline: Pati Hill, Author Turned Artist of the Photocopier, Dies at 93
abstract: Ms.Hill began as a model, then wrote books and then became an artist, using the IBM photocopier as her medium.
lead_paragraph: Pati Hill, an acclaimed author of fiction in the 1950s and ’60s who later turned to visual art, distinguishing herself with images made from a relatively new artistic tool — an IBM photocopier — died on Friday at her home in Sens, France. She was 93.

headline: Orioles’ Power Surge Pushes Yankees to the Brink of Elimination
abstract: The Yankees dropped to five games out of the A.L.’s second wild-card spot with five games left, meaning that another loss would knock them out of postseason contention.
lead_paragraph: Manager Joe Girardi, like many Yankee fans watching at home and at Yankee Stadium, had a happy vision in his head. It had to do with the man at the plate, Derek Jeter, who was batting with two outs in the ninth inning, the Yankees trailing by a run and a runner on first base.

headline: Protection for Wolves Is Restored in Wyoming
