lead_paragraph: A federal judge restored Endangered Species Act protection for wolves in Wyoming on Tuesday, ruling that the federal Fish and Wildlife Service accepted a state commitment to maintain the wolf population without requiring adequate safeguards.

headline: Australian Police Say Terror Suspect Was Killed After Slashing Officers
abstract: The man wounded two members of a police counterterrorism task force, one of whom shot him, the authorities said.

Use both the video above and the article to answer the questions below.

headline: Militant Cleric Acquitted of Terrorism Charges

lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — A militant Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada walked free on Wednesday after a state security court here acquitted him on terrorism charges, punctuating 15 years of legal battles with the Jordanian and British authorities.

headline: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico to Address U.N. General Assembly

lead_paragraph: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico is expected to promote a series of steps to modernize and remake the Mexican economy and raise the standard of living when he addresses the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday morning.

headline: Study Links Anxiety Drugs to Alzheimer’s Disease
abstract: Alzheimer’s occurs more often among older people who have used benzodiazepines for long periods, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: I swear I don’t go looking for alarming news about benzodiazepines, drugs widely prescribed for insomnia and anxiety. But it shows up with some frequency, so, mindful of your fervidly held views on the subject, I am donning a hazmat suit to bring you the latest findings from the medical journal BMJ.

headline: Workers Unite at an Argentine Hotel
abstract: When Argentina’s financial crisis left workers at the Hotel Bauen unemployed, they took over the hotel and ran it themselves.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of Argentina’s financial crisis, Martín Barzilai dropped in on meetings where workers who had lost their jobs defiantly organized themselves to revive the businesses their bosses had closed.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to the Performance and Protest Piece ‘Carry That Weight’?

headline: On a Shoestring, India Sends Orbiter to Mars on Its First Try
abstract: A spacecraft nicknamed MOM successfully reached Mars orbit Wednesday, making India the first nation to accomplish the feat on a maiden voyage.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian spacecraft affectionately nicknamed MOM reached Mars orbit on Wednesday, beating India’s Asian rivals to the Red Planet and outdoing the Americans, the Soviets and the Europeans in doing so on a maiden voyage and a shoestring budget.

headline: Why ‘The Cosby Show’ Still Matters
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Families and Family Life', 'Media', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Television', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Three decades after their NBC debut, the Huxtables remain one of the most beloved — and politically effective — sitcom families in television history.
lead_paragraph: No one expected “The Cosby Show” to change the world. If anything, NBC executives hoped the show might survive by riding the coattails of its namesake — the comedian Bill Cosby, who based much of the sitcom on extracts from his highly popular stand-up act and real-life interactions with his own family.

headline: Hong Kong’s Former No. 2 Official Says Beijing Paid Him $1.42 Million
abstract: Rafael Hui Si-yan, Hong Kong’s former chief secretary, testified that he received the money in late 2007 from a friend who said it was from “someone from Beijing” but refused to identify the donor.

headline: A Birthday Party, of Sorts, for U.S. Prosecutors in New York
abstract: On Tuesday night, more than 700 lawyers, who either currently or once worked as a federal prosecutor in Manhattan, gathered to celebrate 225 years of legal history in New York.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the oldest, unofficial legal fraternities in the United States: lawyers who either currently or once worked as a federal prosecutor in Manhattan. And on Tuesday night, more than 700 former and current prosecutors got together for a birthday party that also posed a bit of security challenge for law enforcement.

headline: Amid a Maze of Alliances, Syrian Kurds Find a Thorny Refuge at the Border
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As one group of Kurds desperately flees from ISIS and into Turkey, another hopes with equal urgency to go in the other direction and fight the militants in Syria.
lead_paragraph: SURUC, Turkey — Turkish tanks dot the hills here, guarding against Islamic State militants advancing just across the Syrian border. Lines of police officers fan out across fields, brandishing shields to stem the flow of Syrian Kurds fleeing the militants.

headline: Civil Disorder, Out of the Curriculum and Into the Streets
abstract: Denver students protesting a proposed anti-protest curriculum-review committee appear to have learned lessons about the value of questioning authority, and irony.
lead_paragraph: Have you tried yet to teach your children how to change the world? Told them stories of world changers, like Mohandas K. Gandhi or the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, and how they led others in protest against the injustices they saw and believed society could not abide?

headline: Hunting for the Source of the World’s Most Beguiling Folk Music
abstract: A moving song by a Greek violinist led the writer to a hillside village across the ocean.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 1926, the Greek violinist Alexis Zoumbas recorded one of the most devastating bits of music I’ve ever encountered. The song, “Epirotiko Mirologi,” is a pentatonic lament — mirologi — that, for millenniums, has been sung beside fresh graves in Epirus, a historically contentious chunk of land on the Greek-Albanian border. The performance is a little over four minutes long, instrumental and largely improvised against the low anchoring drone of some unnamed accompanist dragging a bow across a double bass. Zoumbas was a technically proficient musician, even virtuosic, but his real gift was in effectively articulating disintegration. There is a palpable hysteria to his playing; each note trembles, as if he has recently suffered an emotional collapse of unknowable magnitude.

headline: Thai-Style Thai
abstract: At Kin Khao, the dishes reflect the home-cooked flavors of the owner’s youth.
lead_paragraph: Pim Techamuanvivit is an old-school restaurateur, a person who knows her cuisine inside out, but she has found an intriguing new way to run a non-European restaurant. Born in Bangkok in the ’70s, into a family where delicious food was cooked and showcased daily, she came to the United States in the early ’90s to study cognitive science, specifically the subject of group collaboration. The skills appear to have set her up perfectly for opening a restaurant.

headline: Morning Agenda: Wall St. Helps Out A.I.G.’s Ex-Chief
abstract: Wall Street investors are bankrolling A.I.G.’s former chief executive in his suit over the government’s bailout. | New inversion rules may lack bite. | Citizens Financial Group is making its public market debut. | In defense of hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: WALL ST. BANKROLLS A.I.G.’S EX-CHIEF | Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is getting by with a little help from his friends. To help cover the cost of a lawsuit that accuses the government of shortchanging A.I.G. in its 2008 bailout, Mr. Greenberg has raised several million dollars from three Wall Street companions, Ben Protess and Aaron M. Kessler write in DealBook. The investors, who are entitled to a cut of any damages Mr. Greenberg collects from the government, are said to have contributed about 15 percent of the tens of millions of dollars in legal costs. The lawsuit is set to go to trial next week in Washington.

headline: 1914: Germans Bring Up Guns
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: German troops are moving in the Belgian towns of Antwerp and Liege in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP — There is information from a reliable source to the effect that, in spite of the very heavy rain, the Germans are bringing up toward Antwerp siege guns with a range of at least seventeen miles. It is also stated on good authority that there has been during the past few weeks a movement of German troops at Liege. Opinions are divided as to whether these are going to Russia or coming to reinforce the Germans in Brussels. Antwerp is provisioned to stand a twelve months’ siege. Cattle has been arriving from America at the rate of 3,000 head a week for the past six weeks. Fearing that the Germans will cut off supplies from Ostend, the Belgians had several thousand head of cattle and many thousand pigs placed in pens in the fields surrounding every town. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 25, 1914

headline: Charlatans and Cranks Forever
abstract: Paul Ryan embraces magical thinking, as expected.
lead_paragraph: Back when Paul Ryan released his first big-splash budget — the one that had the commentariat cooing over its “seriousness” — it included a link to an absurd Heritage Foundation analysis claiming, among other things, that the plan would drive the unemployment rate down to 2.8 percent. (Heritage then tried, unsuccessfully, to send its nonsense down the memory hole and pretend it never happened.) Ryan defenders tried to claim that the plan didn’t actually rely on that Heritage stuff; but as some of us tried to explain, the plan actually didn’t add up, relying on a multi-trillion-dollar magic asterisk on tax receipts. And we predicted that sooner or later Ryan would embrace magical theories about how tax cuts increase revenue.

headline: The World at Night
abstract: A new picture book says goodnight in a blissful pastoral setting.
lead_paragraph: To be a modern bedtime story is to exist in the shadow of “Goodnight Moon.” That laconic little 1947 book is so indelible that after reading it to a child night after night for a few weeks, you feel Margaret Wise Brown’s cadences burrowed into your brain. It’s so subtly forceful that the flagrant red-and-green of Clement Hurd’s illustrations somehow never makes you think of Christmas, evoking instead the book’s own peculiar yet comforting universe.

headline: Fort Greene, Brooklyn: A Neighborhood With Many Faces
abstract: Several new high-rises, now in the works, will bring change to a landscape of low-rise brownstones, rowhouses and occasional frame houses.
lead_paragraph: Amid New York’s variegated urban landscape, Fort Greene has been known since the 19th century for its low-rise human habitat: intimately scaled, tree-lined blocks of brownstones, brick rowhouses and occasional frame houses. But a lofty new habitat is emerging on the neighborhood’s western edge, as a forest of mixed-use towers rises in the Brooklyn Cultural District around the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Peter Jay Sharp Building on Lafayette Avenue. Incorporating more than 1,200 new apartments into a kind of high-rise Lincoln Center, the district will be home in the next few years to more than 400,000 square feet of cultural space, including performance, rehearsal and studio facilities.

headline: 1939: Advice on Heating Issued
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1939: Advice on Heating Issued for air-raid shelters.
lead_paragraph: The Secretary General of the Passive Defense yesterday issued a communiqué denying rumors that Paris buildings containing air-raid shelters have been instructed to cut off their central heating systems. Proprietors of apartments and boarding houses were advised, however, to take certain precautions. Entrance to the furnace room must not be by way of the shelter. During air-raid warnings the shafts of heating systems must be closed. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 25, 1939

They both signed three-year contracts to continue managing the business, a web platform based in Los Angeles that was meant to make the process of restructuring through Chapter 11 bankruptcy more efficient.

headline: Ichabod Crane Rides Again in New Edition

lead_paragraph: Washington Irving’s short story “The Legend of Sleepy Hollow” has inspired films, music theater works, songs and television shows. (Those include “Sleepy Hollow,” the updated fantasy in which Ichabod Crane and the Headless Horseman have returned to life, now in its second season.) Kanye West even name-checked the story’s fictional setting in his song “Dark Fantasy” (2010).

lead_paragraph: The executive editor of The New York Times announced broad changes to the newspaper’s leadership on Wednesday, replacing titles that had been used for decades and promoting several senior editors.

headline: 36 Hours in Florence, Italy
abstract: See the skyline without battling crowds, sample pastries from a secret gem, sip artisanal beers and soak up culture during a weekend in the Tuscan capital.
lead_paragraph: Florence was thrust into the spotlight in February when its mayor, the dynamic 39-year-old Matteo Renzi, became Italy’s youngest prime minister. But the Tuscan capital he left behind appears to be flourishing. Once-neglected landmarks have been repurposed as contemporary cultural spaces. This spring, the historic Mercato Centrale market hall unveiled a new floor filled with stalls from the region’s top food artisans, and an ultramodern new opera house began hosting regular performances during the annual Maggio Musicale Fiorentino festival. Meanwhile, a spate of recent openings — bars, boutiques and restaurants squirreled away from the tourist throngs — suggests that the city’s upward trajectory isn’t changing course anytime soon.

lead_paragraph: The fall season on Broadway has come to life rather quietly, with a couple of well-received small-cast productions — “This Is Our Youth” and “Love Letters” — getting things going. Next, though, comes a good old classic Broadway comedy with a large cast; “You Can’t Take It With You,” which won a Pulitzer Prize in 1937.

headline: Painted-On Lip Rings at Dries Van Noten
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: The faux-piercings look has come full circle, showing up first on Rodarte’s runway in New York, and again today at Dries Van Noten in Paris.
lead_paragraph: “It’s all about a modern girl who loves going to festivals like Burning Man,” explained the makeup maestro Peter Philips about the Dries Van Noten beauty look this morning. “She’s a little alternative and she loves nature.” His earthy vision — totally clean skin, “no mascara, no eyebrows and no blush” — worked harmoniously with the nearly 120-foot-long moss-inspired carpet that spanned the runway, not to mention the wild fauna prints that surfaced over breezy, bohemian silhouettes. There was, however, “one subtle beauty element,” he said. “It’s a subtle golden line drawn down the center of the lip that resembles a lip piercing when it catches the light.” Safer and far less painful than the real thing, Philips’ faux-metal adornment simply requires a slick of Make Up For Ever’s Aqua Liner in Diamond Gold, applied via a fine MAC eyeliner brush. Looking back to the Rodarte runway, where eyebrows were studded with clip-on hoops, it seems piercings are making their mark for spring 2015.

headline: Shadows Return to Ellis Island
abstract: The French artist JR has installed century-old photographs in an abandoned building on the island.
lead_paragraph: In the century-old photo, seven children gaze straight at the camera, looking hopeful or somber, or perhaps simply stunned at their surroundings. They have just landed on Ellis Island.

lead_paragraph: Yusuf, the singer until recently called Yusuf Islam, but better known as Cat Stevens for his 1970s hits like “Peace Train,” has canceled a concert at the Beacon Theater in frustration over New York state laws on ticket scalping.

headline: Cup in Hand, Obama Stirs Dispute: Should Presidents Salute?
abstract: President Obama received criticism for saluting Marines with a coffee cup in his hand.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s social media team has touched off a cascade of criticism among service members and civilians alike over a video posted to the White House’s Instagram account that showed him saluting a pair of Marines with a cup in his hand. For veterans of a military that prides itself on discipline and strict adherence to protocol, it was careless at best and disrespectful at worst.

headline: Hurricane Sandy Blows Through Brooklyn Again
abstract: Laurie Anderson and the Kronos Quartet present “Landfall,” a Hurricane Sandy-inspired song cycle for string quartet, voice and electronics, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, Hurricane Sandy pummeled New York City, having made landfall near Atlantic City at 8 that evening. On Tuesday, “Landfall,” a song cycle for string quartet, voice and electronics by the performance artist Laurie Anderson, swept over the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater, setting the auditorium awash in elegiac string sounds and postmillennial gloom.

headline: Julien David Debuts His Spring/Summer 2015 Collection With a Dance Video
abstract: In this exclusive preview, the San Francisco Ballet principal Maria Kochetkova takes the clothes for a spin at the barre and beyond.
lead_paragraph: The Paris-born, Tokyo-based designer Julien David‘s collections frequently riff on activewear and streetwear. For his spring/summer 2015 range, called “Etudes et Preludes” — which he’ll show in Paris on Friday — David turned to what he calls “the athletic side of ballet dancing” for inspiration, specifically the work of his friend Maria Kochetkova, a principal at the San Francisco Ballet. In this exclusive preview of a short film by the director Antoine Wagner, Kochetkova takes the collection for a spin at the barre and beyond.

lead_paragraph: Marijuana is illegal in the United States. Yet 35 states and the District of Columbia permit some form of marijuana consumption for medical purposes, and, as of this year, two states now allow its recreational use.

headline: ISIS’ Harsh Brand of Islam Is Rooted in Austere Saudi Creed
abstract: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the leader of the Islamic State, adheres to Wahhabism, a severe form of Islam quick to denounce others, even fellow militant groups like Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Caliph Ibrahim, the leader of the Islamic State, appeared to come out of nowhere when he matter-of-factly proclaimed himself the ruler of all Muslims in the middle of an otherwise typical Ramadan sermon. Muslim scholars from the most moderate to the most militant all denounced him as a grandiose pretender, and the world gaped at his growing following and its vicious killings.

headline: Video: Security Council to Address Threat Posed by Foreign Fighters
abstract: The United Nations Security Council will meet this afternoon to discuss a binding resolution, proposed by President Obama, that would compel all countries to put in place domestic laws to prosecute those who travel abroad to join terrorist organizations and those who help them, including by raising funds.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council will meet this afternoon to discuss a binding resolution, proposed by President Obama, that would commit all countries to put in place domestic laws to prosecute those who travel abroad to join terrorist organizations and those who help them, including by raising funds. Mr. Obama will lead the meeting, an encore to his morning speech to the General Assembly where he presented a new plan for United States involvement – and international cooperation – in the Middle East.

headline: At Second Base, Stealing a Souvenir Moment With Derek Jeter
abstract: Few things in baseball are more routine than the small talk between infielders and runners, but conversations with Jeter have become cherished moments, especially lately.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Beckham was a rookie infielder with the Chicago White Sox when he had his first chance to chat with Derek Jeter at second base. It was Aug. 1, 2009, and Beckham had just hit a double, knocking the pitcher out of the game. During the pitching change, he and Jeter engaged in the typical mundane banter to fill the gap.

headline: A Lesson in Risk Management in a Jets Defeat
abstract: A decision to punt or kick on fourth-and-short often means you have to face a tougher fourth-down play later in the game.
lead_paragraph: Early in the fourth quarter of Monday night’s game between the Jets and the Bears, Coach Rex Ryan found himself with a difficult fourth-down decision. The Jets were down by 8 points and facing a fourth-and-2 at the Bears’ 24-yard line. There were 9 minutes 56 seconds remaining — plenty of time. Ryan did what coaches do more than 80 percent of the time in those situations: He sent out his kicker. Nick Folk kicked the field goal successfully, cutting the Bears’ lead to 5.

headline: Diversity, Strong Editing and Moving Forward From the Shonda Rhimes Furor
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: What’s next after a contentious reaction to a TV article and its focus on race.
lead_paragraph: In more than two years as public editor at The Times, I’ve encountered very few subjects that have aroused as much passion and reaction as an Arts & Leisure article about the TV producer Shonda Rhimes and the stereotype of the “Angry Black Woman” the story leaned on. I wrote about it on Monday, and quickly hundreds of readers responded in deeply felt comments; my email has been overflowing with more commentary; and many people I know, inside and outside The Times, have been eager to talk about it. And other writers (Emily Nussbaum at The New Yorker, Linda Holmes at NPR, and many others) have taken it up.

headline: New British Center Seeks to Offer Ideas on Preventing Financial Crises

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The list of remedies to prevent a future financial calamity is long, and depending how closely you look, complicated. Banks must hold more capital, the system must have less risk and more rules now govern more institutions.

headline: In Liberia, Home Deaths Spread Circle of Ebola Contagion
abstract: The C.D.C. said that only 18 percent of patients in Liberia are being cared for in proper medical centers, raising the risk of the Ebola virus spreading through communities.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — The family of the sick man, who had endured Ebola’s telltale symptoms for six days, took him by taxi to treatment centers here in the capital twice, only to be turned back at the gate each time for lack of beds. He died at home, his arms thrashing violently and blood spewing out his mouth, in front of his sons.

headline: A Calm Exterior, Sure, but There’s More Going On
abstract: “The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher” is Hilary Mantel’s latest short story collection.
lead_paragraph: Neither “Wolf Hall” nor “Bring Up the Bodies” is the Hilary Mantel book most relevant to “The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher,” her new volume of short stories. Instead, the germane book is her 2003 memoir, “Giving Up the Ghost.” That book describes a woman who is passive, illness-plagued and spooked. The narrators of these stories are much more like Ms. Mantel’s description of herself than like the ironclad Machiavellians who dominate her Thomas Cromwell trilogy-in-progress.

headline: Why Asexuals Don’t Want to Be Invisible Anymore
keywords: ['Celibacy', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Marriages', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: Asexuality is known as the “fourth,” or “invisible,” orientation. Now the community wants to be seen and better understood.
lead_paragraph: Julie Sondra Decker is a writer. She lives in Florida, likes playing Dance Dance Revolution, and has known since she was about 14 that she was not, nor would she ever be, sexually attracted to anyone. Ever. As she writes on her blog, “I’m thirty-six years old, not interested in dating or marriage, and not planning to have children.” In other words, “I’m an aromantic asexual woman.”

abstract: Alfa Romeo, which left the United States market two decades ago, makes a powerful return with its light, lithe 4C sports car.

headline: Yet Another No. 1 for Streisand
abstract: With “Partners,” Ms. Streisand has now had 10 albums top the charts, going back 50 years to “People.”
lead_paragraph: Another decade, another album, and yet another No. 1 for Barbra Streisand.

headline: Making Adjustments in the Search for the Perfect News Feed
abstract: Companies like Facebook and Twitter are experimenting with their feeds, sometimes to the chagrin of users who like things the way they are.
lead_paragraph: PEOPLE who frequent social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have come to rely on the news feed as a crucial filter that sifts through news, personal stories, trends and facts on their behalf.

headline: Stevens Says Ford Was Behind Crucial Affirmative Action Brief
abstract: The role of former President Gerald R. Ford in the filing of a friend-of-the-court brief in a Michigan affirmative action case.
lead_paragraph: The most influential friend-of-the-court brief in living memory has an unlikely history, Justice John Paul Stevens said in a speech on Tuesday night.

headline: High School Tech, in Football Playbooks and Classroom Lesson Plans
abstract: The rise of video in high school football is just part of a larger trend of how we live with screens. The schools featured in an article on Wednesday also evaluate teachers online, and have two-minute video snippets in the library.
lead_paragraph: The world of Texas high school football described in my article today is indeed rich in technology. But it reflects the way we increasingly live our lives on screens.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 4 Matchups
abstract: A safe running back option has been difficult to come by in 2014, but the Packers’ Eddie Lacy has a chance to turn things around in Week 4.
lead_paragraph: We expected volatility at running back in 2014, but there were supposed to be some safe fantasy options, those backs taken in the first round of drafts.

headline: Apple Pulls iOS 8 Software Update After iPhone Problems
abstract: The update was intended to fix various bugs in Apple’s mobile operating system, but it disabled cellphone service, among other problems.
lead_paragraph: Updated to add instructions for removing iOS 8.0.1.

headline: A Very British Dining Destination Pops Up on the Lower East Side
abstract: Mile High, a travel-themed dinner series, comes stateside for the first time to serve up Taittinger bubbles and treacle tart to adventurous New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: In England, a dinner series hosted by four British cousins has taken Londoners on culinary trips to Gothenburg, Beirut, Palermo, Maputo and Malaga — all without actually leaving the country. The themed meals, which popped up in various secret locations across the city and hark back to the golden age of travel (when jaunts required dressing a certain way and smoking wasn’t prohibited in flight), quickly began selling out. And so the founders of the project, dubbed Mile High, decided to bring its performance dinners stateside.

headline: Balenciaga: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Security Council Passes Resolution to Thwart Foreign Fighters
abstract: The United Nations Security Council adopted a legally binding resolution compelling countries to “prevent” and “suppress” their citizens from traveling abroad to join terrorist organizations.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen presidents and prime ministers sat around the horseshoe-shaped table at the Security Council on Wednesday afternoon to adopt a legally binding resolution compelling countries to “prevent” and “suppress” their citizens from traveling abroad to join terrorist organizations. President Obama, who led the meeting, said it was only the sixth time since the Council first met in 1946 that it held a session with so many member states’ top leaders.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Thursday and Friday
abstract: The suspension is for Rosh Hashana.
lead_paragraph: Because of Rosh Hashana, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Thursday and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Obama Calls for Action Over Words on Terrorism
abstract: The president calls for action over words on terrorism.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is taking a rare turn at leading a United Nations Security Council meeting, and he is pulling no punches on the need for a strong coalition to combat growing terrorist threats.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Balenciaga Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Sips From a Cider Spree in New York State
abstract: Hitting orchards, shops and restaurants on a decadent tasting tour.
lead_paragraph: My boots were soaked, and the air reeked of overripe apples. I felt as if I were bathing in the cider I’d come to drink. It was early October and steamy; if the leaves that blazed red from nearly every tree branch were seasonal stop signs, the gods of summer hadn’t seen them. I was a few miles from Cayuga Lake, the second-largest of New York’s 11 Finger Lakes, on a small but extraordinarily prolific orchard. The property’s fruit, which ranged from the palest wash of yellow to grapefruit pink to a purple so dark it looked like a fresh bruise, was hanging all around me and rotting underfoot.

headline: ‘Parks and Recreation’ Comes to Life in San Francisco
abstract: In San Francisco, any project can be endlessly debated, protested, voted on and litigated. Even soccer fields.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The parks department just wanted to replace four grass soccer fields with artificial turf.

headline: The Beauty of a Simple Ponytail at Rochas
abstract: The creative director Alessandro Dell’Acqua’s ’70s-inspired frocks were paired with the most laid-back of hairstyles on today’s spring 2015 runway.
lead_paragraph: At the spring 2015 Rochas fashion show in Paris today, the brand’s creative director, Alessandro Dell’Acqua, unveiled dreamy designs, including printed white dresses that look like they could have been plucked from the late ’70s (the way it looked in Sofia Coppola’s “Virgin Suicides”). Against all the embroidered flowers and lacy details, the simple ponytails — parted to the side and tied low on the back of the head — felt appropriately laid-back and youthful.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Turkey, Syria and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Turkey, Syria and India.

headline: Calle 13 Leads Latin Grammy Nominees
abstract: The Puerto Rican group Calle 13 was nominated for nine awards, including best album, best record and best song.
lead_paragraph: The Puerto Rican group Calle 13 has been nominated for nine Latin Grammy Awards, including the prizes for the year’s best album (“Multi_Viral”), best record (“Respira El Momento”) and best song (“Ojos Color Sol”). That is one less nomination than the group garnered in 2011, but more than any other group or soloist on this year’s list.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Middle East Rivals Trade Rhetorical Jabs at United Nations
abstract: Competing speeches at the United Nations by various Middle Eastern rivals that are also United States allies underscored the Obama administration’s delicate task in balancing competing interests in the region.
lead_paragraph: Whether they bumped into each other back stage could not be confirmed. But the General Assembly on Wednesday afternoon saw a parade of regional rivals coming in quick succession to the podium.

headline: Ex-Investor Relations Executive Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
abstract: The insider trading case against Michael A. Lucarelli, a former executive at Lippert/Heilshorn and Associates, was relatively minor. But he got attention for running barefoot from the court in August.
lead_paragraph: Michael A. Lucarelli, a former executive at an investor relations agency, admitted on Wednesday to insider trading based on information in news releases that had not yet been released.

headline: What the Indictment of ‘The Situation’ Tells Us About the Tax Code
abstract: The former “Jersey Shore” star Mike Sorrentino, who was indicted on tax fraud charges, did plenty of things to avoid taxes that were perfectly legal.
lead_paragraph: Somehow, the most shocking thing about the indictment of Michael Sorrentino for tax fraud is not that the “Jersey Shore” star may have been less than punctilious about paying the taxman. After all, Mr. Sorrentino, known as “The Situation,” has never projected the levelheaded public image you’d associate with careful income tax compliance. (Here is a video in which he slams his head into a wall. Here is the 911 call from when he was in a brawl at a tanning salon).

headline: Reading The Times With Ben Cole
abstract: Mr. Cole, the mobile product lead for Google.org, shares his thoughts on articles in The Times about tech news, world affairs and Lena Dunham.
lead_paragraph: Ben Cole is the mobile product lead at Google.org. He was a “technology pioneer” in Ghana and worked on Google Docs in Mountain View, Calif. Now he heads One Today, a mobile app that connects Google users with causes to create a more socially aware and engaged world. He read today’s Times on his mobile phone.

headline: Yankees Miss Consecutive Postseasons for First Time in Two Decades
abstract: The last time the Yankees failed to make the playoffs in consecutive years was 1992 and 1993, the final years of a 12-season playoff drought.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks, the Yankees held on to the belief that they could defy the odds and carry Derek Jeter to one more postseason. With their mediocre record, it was almost impossible. But they felt that if any team could generate such an improbable run, it would be a team with him on it.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Philosophers, criminals and collectors populate a selection of new books by Lars Iyer, Tod Goldberg, Joanna Scott and others.
lead_paragraph: WITTGENSTEIN JR.

headline: A Multitude of Voices for a Busy Young Pianist, From Bach to Liszt to Jazz
abstract: The pianist Inon Barnatan, starting a concert-packed season, gave a thoughtful recital at SubCulture on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Inon Barnatan is ubiquitous this season. An Israeli-born New Yorker, Mr. Barnatan is the New York Philharmonic’s first “artist in association.” So he’s at the piano for a chamber recital with Philharmonic instrumentalists in December, and makes his full Philharmonic debut in March. He’s a guest artist with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with a concert in November. He’s resident pianist for the Jerusalem Quartet’s Brahms survey at the 92nd Street Y in October. And, lest downtown feel left out, he was the star attraction at SubCulture’s second PianoFest on Tuesday night.

headline: Music Born of Dreams, a Concerto of Many Moods
abstract: The Philharmonic began its subscription series programs on Tuesday with the new Clarinet Concerto by Unsuk Chin and Mahler’s First Symphony.
lead_paragraph: The conductor Alan Gilbert, exuding excitement, looked almost relieved to be on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall with the musicians of the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday night. The occasion was the first of the orchestra’s subscription series programs this season, offering the American premiere of Unsuk Chin’s haunting Clarinet Concerto and a formidable account of Mahler’s First Symphony.

headline: Recalling Old Dreams in the Old Neighborhood
abstract: “Made in Brooklyn Revisited,” Randy Graff’s show at 54 Below, looks back at bouncy 1960s hits and at Broadway ballads about life and dreams.
lead_paragraph: Randy Graff fondly remembers that halcyon time “when Brooklyn was Brooklyn.” Ms. Graff, 59, who won a Tony for her role in the 1989 Broadway musical “City of Angels,” has put together a show, “Made in Brooklyn Revisited” at 54 Below that celebrates the borough and the creative talent nurtured there before the invasion of hipsters, double-wide strollers and artisanal this and that. Ms. Graff’s grandparents came to Brooklyn from “the old country” (her words).

headline: Soul Man With a Scottish Burr
abstract: Paolo Nutini performed songs from “Caustic Love,” his current album with nods to R&B, on Tuesday at the Apollo.
lead_paragraph: Moments after he stepped onstage at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night, Paolo Nutini was optimally unkempt. His hair had been pre-touseled, his body was tensed, and his face was contorted in concentration as he gripped his microphone and worked from croon to rasp in “Scream (Funk My Life Up).” Soon enough, one side of his shirt would come untucked from his jeans. Mr. Nutini, a Scottish songwriter, is a first-rate student of vintage American soul, and the Apollo stage was a historically apt place to prove it.

headline: India’s Top Court Revokes Coal Leases
abstract: The ruling, canceling 214 coal leases that an investigation had found had been sold below market price, drew wide attention in a nation with fuel shortages.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s top court on Wednesday canceled years’ worth of coal field leases, a judgment that drew wide attention in a nation with persistent fuel shortages.

headline: Synergy and Dissonance, Amid the Weight of History
abstract: Kyle Abraham, the resident commissioned artist at New York Live Arts, is presenting “The Watershed,” a reflection on civil rights milestones.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big deal in contemporary dance circles to be anointed a resident commissioned artist at New York Live Arts. On Tuesday the latest recipient of this honor, Kyle Abraham, unveiled “The Watershed,” the first half of what he’s been working on throughout that two-year, generously funded residency. (A second program of three shorter pieces opens on Thursday.)

headline: Balenciaga’s Beaded Pair of Cool, Neutral Flats
abstract: After a delayed start (the house was waiting for Kim, Kanye and baby North to arrive), the label’s spring 2015 collection, and the shoes that came with it, proved worth the wait.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: E.P.A. Unveils Second Phase of Plan to Reverse Great Lakes Damage
abstract: The latest phase of the Environmental Protection Agency’s initiative includes plans to clean up contaminated rivers and harbors and attack poisonous algae blooms.
lead_paragraph: The federal government issued a new blueprint Wednesday for its efforts to restore the Great Lakes, including plans to clean up 10 contaminated rivers and harbors and step up its attack on poisonous algae blooms that coat parts of three lakes each summer.

headline: Building a Force Field to Attain Higher Bliss
abstract: The New Age pioneer Iasos, using electronic keyboards and images from nature, conjured a meditative state at Baby’s All Right on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: It’s important to remember that music has both aesthetic value and use value, though at live performances, it’s generally the first of those things that gets priority. But people turn to music for plenty of reasons — sometimes they want to be entertained, sometimes they want to be healed, sometimes they want to be told they’re healable.

headline: From the Upshot: Senate Model Update
abstract: With 40 days to Election Day, today’s forecast from the Upshot Senate model gives the Republicans a 59 percent chance of taking control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: With 40 days to Election Day, today’s forecast from the Upshot Senate model gives the Republicans a 59 percent chance of taking control of the Senate.

headline: A Deal From the Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships
abstract: The winners of the Swiss Pairs event at the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships were David Bakhshi and Andrew McIntosh from England.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 14, the last day of the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships, held in Glasgow, there was a Swiss Pairs event. This consisted of eight six-board matches.

headline: Minimal Handbags
abstract: Luxury carryalls don’t have to trumpet their provenance.
lead_paragraph: Luxury carryalls don’t have to trumpet their provenance.

headline: Whit Stillman, Director of ‘The Cosmopolitans,’ on Paris’s Most Timeless Places
abstract: The sometime ex-pat and celebrated auteur behind such films as “Metropolitan” and “The Last Days of Disco” on what he calls “the classic places that remain classic.”
lead_paragraph: “I found the economics of Manhattan just … impossible,” said the American director Whit Stillman, seated at a café in Paris. “It was an exceptional time when Paris was a lot cheaper than living in New York.” Stillman moved to France in 1998 after making a trio of movies that examined the group dynamics of hyper-articulate youth: “Metropolitan,” “Barcelona” and “The Last Days of Disco.” During nearly a decade there, he explained, he “started having a social life in Paris with these expat types — colorful Fritz types.”

headline: In Fighting Tigers, Xi Inspires the Masses
abstract: China’s biggest anti-corruption campaign in decades is winning genuine support for the president, Xi Jinping, among many ordinary Chinese, especially those who are struggling economically.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping recently saved my family 20,000 renminbi. That’s $3,255 — useful money. He saved the family of a man I met in Zhuhai last week 30,000 renminbi — even more useful money.

headline: Turkey’s President Erdogan at the U.N.
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey spoke on Wednesday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: Don’t Execute Those We Tortured
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Torture', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Military Tribunals', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The United States must be held accountable, too, for breaking the law.
lead_paragraph: AFTER years of legal battles, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the alleged mastermind of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, will finally be put on trial before a military commission at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, though a trial date hasn’t yet been set. If he is convicted, as expected, he will almost certainly face the death penalty. And, assuming one believes in the death penalty, it would be hard to think of a stronger candidate for its use.

headline: A Suffragist’s Start
abstract: Designs for a dollhouse by a Victorian tween have a new life in literature.
lead_paragraph: Birdsall Otis Edey (1872-1940) was not quite in her teens when she made a paper doll’s house from cutup magazines and catalogs. She grew up to be a suffragist and a president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., wrote plays and poetry, and built a theater that seated 150 on her property in Bellport, N.Y. But it was the doll house collages that impressed Eric Boman when he saw an exhibition about Ms. Edey’s life at the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society. Mr. Boman, a photographer and writer, turned the artwork into a book, “The Paper Doll’s House of Miss Sarah Elizabeth Birdsall Otis, Aged Twelve,” which will be published next month (Thames & Hudson, $30). If Mrs. Edey had followed the path suggested by her dream home, she might have become an interior designer whose style was elegant, playful and scaled for drama. But why did she choose collage as her mode of expression? “Girls would draw and paint a doll’s house,” Mr. Boman said, “but this girl, I think, she didn’t think her handiwork was up to snuff.” Information: thamesandhudsonusa.com.

headline: When Blogging Becomes a Slog
abstract: It began as a passion; now it’s taking over their lives. Is the first generation of design bloggers getting ready to retire?
lead_paragraph: It started so innocently.

headline: Out of Detroit, Designs and Pride
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Tableware', 'Ceramics and Pottery']
abstract: Michele Varian honors her Detroit roots with a pop-up shop selling Motor City merchandise.
lead_paragraph: Michele Varian is hosting a pop-up shop in the basement of her Howard Street store, left, featuring goods from about 20 Detroit companies. A Detroit native, Ms. Varian said her origins have always been a “point of pride, before it was cool to the rest of the world.” The designs for sale include furniture by Alex Drew & No One; vessels by Adora Bella Ceramics, bottom right; metalwork from Smith Shop, top right; and terrariums by Lead Head Glass. Simply being made in Detroit did not qualify an object for admission, Ms. Varian emphasized; the goods also had to meet her rigorous style standards. “Everything in the show is something I’d buy for the store,” she said.

headline: Fewer Hero Points for Bed-Making Husbands
abstract: The Nova duvet cover from Crane & Canopy succeeds in simplifying a tedious chore.
lead_paragraph: Having lived in Switzerland, where he mastered the domestic arts by osmosis, my husband is a superior bed maker. I put him in charge of testing the Crane & Canopy Nova duvet cover, which promises to cut the time it takes to make your bed by 80 percent. The sample we received, Hayes Nova Grey, unfolded into a lustrous field of 400-thread-count, charcoal-colored cotton with white piping. A white panel about a foot wide was layered over the top, mimicking the look of a folded flat sheet while concealing a zipper. Using the standard inversion method, my husband turned the fabric envelope inside out, reached inside, plucked two corners of our duvet and gave a mighty shake. A tuck, a zip, a toss and some smoothing, and the bed was made, looking far more finished than usual. Time: 1 minute 44 seconds. A queen-size cover is $149; king, $169; matching shams, $60 a pair. Information: 888-686-8586 or craneandcanopy.com.

headline: Art, From Classic to Quirky
abstract: Stair Galleries in Hudson, N.Y., is auctioning highlights from the collections of Ashton Hawkins and Johnnie Moore.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Stair Galleries in Hudson, N.Y., will offer highlights from the wildly diverse collections of Ashton Hawkins, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s former counsel, and his husband, Johnnie Moore, from the couple’s homes in Manhattan and Athens, N.Y. The trove includes 18th- and 19th-century Russian silver, classical bronzes, Victorian and modern furniture and contemporary works by Jasper Johns, Alfred Stieglitz, Helen Frankenthaler, Paul Cadmus and David Hockney. On the block will be a screen-printed Campbell’s Soup Can T-shirt signed by Andy Warhol, a gift from the artist that is estimated to fetch $1,000 to $1,500; “Sin,” an unusual screen print ($6,000 to $10,000) by Ed Ruscha; a quirky portrait of Alfred Hitchcock by Hunt Slonem ($4,000 to $6,000); and Alfred Stieglitz’s “Steerage,” a large-format photogravure dated 1907 that has been hailed as one of the finest and earliest works of modernism in photography ($12,000 to $18,000). Information: 518-751-1000 or stairgalleries.com.

headline: Suffering for Her Art, and Beckett
abstract: For “Not I,” one of three solo Beckett pieces she will perform in Brooklyn, Lisa Dwan performs while immobilized in straps and metal brackets.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, ENGLAND — First comes a layer of thick black grease, applied from the neck to just below the eyes. The lips are carefully painted red. Then a blindfold, then clinging black fabric wrapped around the head. At that point, Lisa Dwan is guided up steps to a wooden board, her arms pinioned through metal brackets on each side, her head fitted into a small opening and secured in place by thick straps that cover her ears. Unable to see, unable to hear, she takes a deep breath and opens her mouth.

headline: On Patrol With the Weed Warriors
abstract: An invasive plant, aptly named mile-a-minute, threatens to take over the Northeast. Can a few gardeners and scientists stop it?
lead_paragraph: NEW MILFORD, Conn. — Kathleen Nelson can’t tell a Ford from a Chevy, but she can spot mile-a-minute weed 100 yards away.

headline: New Offerings for a New Season
abstract: New York City Ballet’s opening gala featured new works by three choreographers still in their 20s.

headline: Bags That Don’t Brag
keywords: ['Handbags and Purses', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Luxury carryalls don’t have to trumpet their provenance.
lead_paragraph: When Tyler Ellis describes Tyler Alexandra, her three-season-old line of handbags, she talks about “anonymous branding.” The interior of the elegant Tyler Alexandra doctor’s bag shown here is bright blue suede; it rests on tiny pinecone feet.

headline: Spirits They Can Live With
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Forget the ghosts: The 1750 house had plenty to exorcise just in the messy kitchen grease and the plumbing.
lead_paragraph: For the residents of Provincetown, Mass., the old Martin House conjures up a variety of impressions. Some see the shingled structure, built in 1750, as a place where fishermen once lived. Others identify it as the home of abolitionists. Still others will tell you it’s populated by ghosts.

headline: Watering Cans: A Garden of Delights
abstract: The technology is elementary but the styles are riveting.
lead_paragraph: Fall is an important time for gardens. “You’re cleaning up and preparing for the spring, as well as preparing the garden for winter,” said Camilla Hammer, a garden designer and urban farmer. But you also have to continue tending gardens planted earlier in the year, like the one that she and Julia Sherman, the author of the blog Salad for President, created on the roof of MoMA PS1, which is still going strong.

headline: Verbatim: D’Souza Sentencing
abstract: Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, before sentencing conservative author Dinesh D’Souza to probation for violating federal campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: — Judge Richard M. Berman of Federal District Court in Manhattan, before sentencing conservative author Dinesh D’Souza to probation for violating federal campaign finance laws.

headline: Big iPhone 6 Bulges in All the Wrong Places
abstract: The new phones don’t comfortably fit pockets and purses. The public has taken to Twitter and Facebook to grumble.
lead_paragraph: It’s the ultimate first world problem. You go to the Apple store, drop $400 for an iPhone 6 and then discover it doesn’t fit in your pocket.

headline: Travelport Prices Shares at Top of Range in I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Travel Agencies and Agents']
abstract: Travelport Worldwide, a company acts as a middleman for travel agencies and tour operators, has raised $480 million, valuing it at about $1.9 billion. It will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Eight years after being purchased by private equity firms, Travelport Worldwide is set to make its public markets debut.

headline: Uighur Scholar’s Life Sentence Is Seen as Reining in Debate on Minorities in China
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Political Prisoners', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The prison term given to Ilham Tohti drew international outrage and, according to analysts, indicated intolerance in Beijing for criticism of its approach to ethnic minorities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The news that a Uighur academic, Ilham Tohti, had been sentenced in China to life in prison on charges of separatism drew a torrent of international outrage this week. President Obama called for his release, the European Union condemned the sentence as “totally unjustified,” and rights advocates said they could not recall a similarly harsh penalty for a prominent intellectual whose main offense, it appeared, was criticizing government policies.

headline: Plans to Rebuild Our Nuclear Arsenal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: Readers say the Obama administration’s plans are misguided and dangerous.

abstract: Lightning in a Bottle in Bradley, Calif. is one of the larger and more influential of these “transformational festivals.”
lead_paragraph: Lightning in a Bottle in Bradley, Calif. is one of the larger and more influential of these “transformational festivals.”

headline: The Progeny of Burning Man
abstract: Transformational festivals emerge as a petri dish for art and culture in America.
lead_paragraph: It was 3 a.m. in Bradley, Calif., in the middle of a dusty dry lake bed, and Carl Weiseth, 33, was shoeless, shirtless and regaling a gathering crowd about last night’s escapade. “I didn’t make it back from the dance floor until the sun was starting to rise,” he told his audience, adding that he “passed out to the gentle vibrations of thumping electronic music for three to four hours.”

headline: Going the Distance to Lead the Faithful
abstract: Rabbis serve in remote areas during High Holy Days.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Rami Schwartzer, a Connecticut-born fourth-year rabbinical student at Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, won’t be spending the High Holy Days as he usually does. Instead, he has traveled nearly 1,600 miles to spend the Jewish New Year, which began Wednesday evening, in Cypress, Tex., leading services for a bunch of strangers with a borrowed Torah in a rented clubhouse.

headline: Me and the Universe
abstract: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.
lead_paragraph: An artist explains his relationship to the totality of the universe.

lead_paragraph: Three diagrams explaining how I fit in, from the Big Bang to the apocalypse. Read more »

headline: Biotech Firm Adaptimmune Attracts $104 Million Investment
abstract: New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm, led the financing round in Adaptimmune Limited, which is developing a treatment for cancer.
lead_paragraph: New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm that has backed the likes of Groupon and Salesforce, is now investing in a biotechnology company developing a treatment for cancer.

headline: Parental Politics in Colorado
abstract: Senator Mark Udall is outraged that his father is being mentioned in an opponent’s campaign ad.
lead_paragraph: Spouses and mistresses have long been fair game in politics, but parents have largely been off limits.

headline: Trying on a Persona
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The new 3.1 Phillip Lim store is a site for fantasies, but some whimsy you can live with.
lead_paragraph: There, at the rear of the new 3.1 Phillip Lim store: a big ol’ blanket coat, in a dry burgundy, made of a scratchy alpaca-mohair-and-so-on blend, deliberately oversize, cinched at the waist with a hidden drawstring. It is, if not the most expensive men’s item in the new store, certainly the most visually arresting. It is set apart, high on a platform, like the Christ the Redeemer statue that gazes out over Rio.

headline: Ukraine Picks Motley Group to Exchange for Prisoners
abstract: Many of those released by Ukraine in prisoner swaps said they had never fought for pro-Russian separatists, and had no idea how they ended up being detained.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — At first glance, the prisoner swap between the Ukrainian government and pro-Russian separatists appeared fair enough: On a deserted stretch of highway along the front line, each side released 28 captives, observing a principle of numerical parity.

headline: How Hip Are Cold Hands? Not Very
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jeans (Apparel)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: Utilitarian basics with a decidedly streetwise edge and more shopping picks.
lead_paragraph: Telfar Clemens of the hip unisex label Telfar, which is practically a household name among in-the-know night-life and fashion sets, designs streetwise garments that don’t require being the coolest kid in school to pull off. Mr. Clemens likes to tweak utilitarian basics, adding pockets to sweaters and jackets (the man loves a pocket) or thumb holes to oversize turtlenecks because he likes to have his hands covered in the winter. The label is a hit at retail, too: Opening Ceremony hosted a pop-up for the designer in August; Vfiles stocks the line. There’s also a fragrance in the works. “I’m ready for people to start smelling like Telfar,” he said.

headline: Store Openings, New Collections and Sales Starting Sept. 25
abstract: Free & the Brave opens a pop-up in celebration of the Global Citizens Festival; the 3.1 Phillip Lim sample sale begins; and Rag & Bone’s Cowichan cardigan is in stock.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Film on Lost Boys of Sudan Uses Keys to Stand Out
abstract: A campaign to build awareness of “The Good Lie” has joined with the Giving Keys nonprofit group, which sells keys with inspirational messages.
lead_paragraph: THE creators, producers and distributors of a new film are hoping that keys will be the key to helping their movie stand out in a crush of fall releases.

headline: Marathon Bombings Trial Will Remain in Boston
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the trial for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the bombings, would not be moved but would be delayed two months and is to start in January.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the Boston Marathon bombings, will take place in Boston but will be delayed two months and is to start in January.

headline: Drag Performers Fight Facebook’s ‘Real Name’ Policy
abstract: Activists argue that a Facebook policy excludes those who prefer to choose their names and exposes them to cyberbullying.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a drag performer in San Francisco named Lil Miss Hot Mess received a notice from Facebook. Her account had been suspended because she was not using what the company considered a “real name.” Lil Miss Hot Mess could not gain access to her posts, messages or photos.

headline: Lithuania Feels Squeeze in Sanctions War With Russia
abstract: The former Soviet bloc country depends heavily on its status as a transportation hub for Russia-bound goods, including its own agricultural products.
lead_paragraph: ZIBENAI, Lithuania — In the sanctions war between Russia and the West, Kasia Jankun’s 80 dairy cows seem to be losing.

headline: With China Set to Open Stock Trading, Investors Lay Groundwork
abstract: Bankers, brokerage firms and hedge funds have all been quietly expanding their Asian operations to take advantage of the biggest opening into China in years.
lead_paragraph: O’Connor, the $5.6 billion hedge fund owned by UBS, has been expanding its presence in Asia. It has hired traders from UBS’s proprietary trading desk to work in its Hong Kong and Singapore offices. In August, it hired John Yu, a former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors

headline: At amfAR’s Fashion Gala, Euros and Cocktails Flow Freely
abstract: As the party and auction in Milan pull out the stops, Grace Jones pulls out the wigs, all to raise money for AIDS research.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — If you’re at a Milan Fashion Week party, expect late hours.

headline: Are Bees Back Up on Their Knees?
abstract: Colony collapse may be over, but the pollination squad needs help.
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, beekeepers in Pennsylvania’s apple country noticed the first sign of many bad things to come. Once thriving beehives were suddenly empty, devoid of nearly all worker bees, but with an apparently healthy, if lonely, queen remaining in place. Over a period of just three months, tens of thousands of honeybees were totally gone. Multiply this across millions of beehives in millions of apiaries in the more than 22 states that were soon affected, and suddenly we faced a huge, tragic mystery. Up to 24 percent of American apiaries were experiencing colony collapse disorder (C.C.D.).

headline: David Macklovitch of Chromeo: Against the Tide in a Stylish Manner
abstract: Mr. Macklovitch is an icon in a counter-Williamsburg sort of way.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, before artisanal cocktail bars dotted Bedford Avenue and Pilates studios popped up along the Brooklyn waterfront, when David Macklovitch, one half of the electro-funk duo Chromeo, might have blended into Williamsburg. Tall and lanky, partial to black leather and dark Wayfarers, he brings to mind the type of guy who rides a motorcycle to gigs and chain-smokes between sets — or as he puts it, “a French rocker from the ’80s.”

headline: Jack Bryan: A Little Philosophy, A Lot of Filmmaking
abstract: Mr. Bryan is finding out what it takes to make good films.
lead_paragraph: AGE 29

headline: Joining With Rival Sony, Movie Executive Jeff Robinov Starts Studio 8
abstract: After ending on ugly terms with Warner Bros., Mr. Robinov is making a brash bet on a deeply troubled business and opening his own production company.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — In his 17 years in the movie division of Warner Bros., Jeff Robinov went in for the kill against Sony Pictures Entertainment time and again, competing for scripts, access to top filmmakers and prized release dates.

headline: Bill Simmons Suspended by ESPN for Tirade on Roger Goodell
abstract: Simmons, a writer and commentator, was suspended after he launched an obscenity-laced tirade against Goodell’s handling of the Ray Rice domestic violence case.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, ESPN’s Bill Simmons challenged his employer to discipline him for excoriating N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell’s handling of the Ray Rice domestic violence case. Simmons, on his Grantland.com podcast, repeatedly called Goodell a liar for saying that he had not seen the elevator video of Rice punching his fiancée.

headline: Big Data in the Classroom
abstract: Is the information collected from school software an invasion of student privacy?

headline: Cooking Videos Bring the Pros to Your Kitchen
abstract: Spatchcock. Clarify. Temper. These are among the cooking techniques included in a video collection for The Times’s new Cooking website and iPad app.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Gourley is an assistant editor and video producer for the food department.

headline: Hassan Rouhani, President of Iran, Experiences Rare Unscripted Moment
abstract: President Rouhani was giving a speech that was suddenly punctuated with an outburst by spectators concerned about political prisoners in Iran.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has been busy since his arrival in New York for the United Nations General Assembly with interviews and speeches. He will address the General Assembly on Thursday morning. So far, he has been repeating his country’s talking points on nuclear negotiations with the six world powers, the war in Syria and the West’s newfound anxiety over the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, ISIL and Jaish, which Iran also considers a terrorist organization.

headline: Navajo Nation’s Complaint Against the U.S.
abstract: The Navajo Nation will receive $554 million after agreeing to end its claim that the federal government mismanaged tribal resources.
lead_paragraph: The Navajo Nation will receive $554 million after agreeing to end its claim that the federal government mismanaged tribal resources.

headline: Navajos to Get $554 Million to Settle Suit Against U.S.
abstract: The Navajo Nation will receive $554 million after agreeing to end its claim that the federal government mismanaged tribal resources.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — In the largest settlement obtained by an American Indian tribe from the federal government, the Navajo Nation will receive $554 million to end a lawsuit alleging that the government mismanaged the community’s assets for more than 50 years.

headline: Montana’s Trail House in Bushwick, Brooklyn
abstract: Montana’s Trail House recreates a sliver of the backwoods in a former auto repair shop in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A taste of country living has taken root in deep Brooklyn. Opened in June, Montana’s Trail House recreates a sliver of the backwoods in a former auto repair shop.

headline: Leaders’ Speeches at U.N. Show Delicacy of Mission Against ISIS Militants
abstract: Remarks by leaders on Day 1 of the General Assembly hinted at the narrow, often competing, interests of some of America’s allies in the fight against terrorism.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Turkey berated other countries for not doing more to stop their citizens from leaving home to join terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq. Qatar cautioned that a new global war on terrorism ought not to “stabilize” the government of Syria. China welcomed American leadership on staunching the recruitment of foreign fighters for terrorist organizations, seizing on the moment to call for stricter rules to rein in the Internet.

headline: To Tuscan Wine Makers, a Preservation Plan Takes On Acrid Undertones
abstract: Tuscany’s regional government recently approved a new rural preservation plan, saying that too many vines had been planted and warned of the risk of soil erosion.
lead_paragraph: MONTALCINO, Italy — Its gentle sloping hills, olive groves, cypresses and sunflower fields have made Tuscany a muse to writers and artists for centuries. But the region is equally renowned for its verdant vineyards and their wines, some of the most prized in Italy and the world.

headline: In Israel, Values of a Holy Respite Are Adapted for a High-Tech World
abstract: Israel experiments with modern observances of the Jewish “shmita,” a traditional rest period for farmers that comes every seventh year.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The printers at Energiya Global sit idle as the company, which promotes solar power in developing countries, tries to go paperless. Energiya is also throwing open the doors to its funky, colorful headquarters for yoga workshops and Talmud classes. And instead of ordering in for the weekly staff lunch, employees this year will rotate cooking duties, donating the savings.

headline: Judge Denies BP’s Request to Recoup Overpayments to Oil Spill Victims
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: At a hearing in Federal District Court in New Orleans, Judge Carl J. Barbier rejected BP’s request that it be allowed to claw back the extra money paid out under an old accounting method.
lead_paragraph: The oil giant BP cannot recoup hundreds of millions of dollars it claims to have overpaid victims of a 2010 Gulf Coast oil spill, a federal judge ruled Wednesday.

headline: Report Rebukes Treasury for Bailout Pay Packages at G.M. and Ally Financial
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Inspectors General', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Top executives at General Motors and Ally Financial, both of which received bailouts from the U.S. Treasury Department in 2009, were paid excessively, according to a special inspector general report.
lead_paragraph: Top executives at General Motors and Ally Financial, both of which received bailouts from the United States Treasury Department in 2009, were paid excessively even as taxpayers lost money, according to a special inspector general report.

headline: De Blasio Walks Tightrope Between Municipal Politics and International Influence
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, a virtual unknown not so long ago, is now determined to cultivate a profile on the international stage.
lead_paragraph: He has bonded with the socialist mayor of Paris, tutoring her on the nuances of the American term “retrofit.” He has met with Italy’s foreign minister three times in the past four months. This week, he walked in the People’s Climate March in Manhattan alongside the United Nations secretary general and talked shop with the leaders of Buenos Aires, Melbourne and Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Arizona State’s D. J. Foster Draws Inspiration From ‘Guardian Angel’
abstract: When the No. 15 Sun Devils host U.C.L.A., one of the last things Foster will see before running on the field is a picture of his sister, Jennifer, who died of a drug overdose five years ago.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — D. J. Foster, Arizona State’s star running back, has a tattoo above his heart with “Sweet Dreams” inscribed below the smiling face of his sister, Jennifer.

headline: Treasury Imposes Terrorism Sanctions
abstract: The Treasury Department announced sanctions on 11 individuals and one organization it said helped finance the flow of fighters for terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department on Wednesday imposed sanctions on 11 people and one entity it said were sending financial and other support to terrorist groups, including the Islamic State. The sanctions are aimed at the funding streams that have allowed the terrorist organizations to flourish and recruit fighters from the Middle East, Europe and North Africa.

headline: Iraq: Militants Destroy Historic Church
abstract: Islamic State militants on Wednesday blew up an important site in early Christianity known as the Green Church in Tikrit.
lead_paragraph: Islamic State militants on Wednesday blew up an important site in early Christianity known as the Green Church in Tikrit. The group, also known as ISIS, has driven thousands of Christians and other religious minorities from their homes as it has consolidated its hold on a broad section of Syria and Iraq. It has destroyed or defaced several historic churches as well as many Muslim shrines that it considers prohibited by its puritanical version of Islam. After capturing the city of Mosul this summer, the Islamic State’s fighters took a sledgehammer to the tomb of the biblical figure Jonah. It replaced the cross above the historic St. Ephrem’s Cathedral in Mosul with its black jihadi flag, and it also destroyed a statue of the Virgin Mary.

headline: Florida Goes Down the Drain
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Climate change is the new unmentionable these days on Capitol Hill and in state capitols.
lead_paragraph: On Miami Beach, rising sea levels have interesting consequences. The ocean periodically starts bubbling up through local drainpipes. By the time it’s over, the concept of “going down to the water” has extended to stepping off the front porch.

headline: The Ebola Fiasco
abstract: World leaders fumbled the response to Ebola. Now, instead of a tiny cost in money, we will all pay hugely in lost lives and resources for other initiatives.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is a tragedy. But, more than that, the response to it has been a gross failure.

headline: Warnings on Big Medical Bills
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: In a system where a primary surgeon gets paid $6,200 and an assistant gets $117,000 for work on the same operation, patients need more information in how they are going to be charged.
lead_paragraph: It’s not an uncommon situation for patients to be billed by doctors for costly services they did not request or, in some cases, were not even aware they had received.

headline: Court Returns Inquiry Into Walker’s Finances to Wisconsin
abstract: A federal appeals court removed an injunction halting an investigation into whether the campaign of Gov. Scott Walker illegally coordinated with groups on fund-raising as he fought a recall effort.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — A federal appeals court on Wednesday removed an injunction halting an investigation into whether the campaign of Gov. Scott Walker illegally coordinated with conservative groups on fund-raising and spending as he sought to overcome a recall effort two years ago.

headline: Long Lines at Minority Polling Places
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Editorials', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It may not be a coincidence that some of the longest lines on Election Day occur in black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Some of the longest lines on Election Day occur at polling places in black and Hispanic neighborhoods. A new report says that’s not a coincidence.

headline: An Ouster on Derek Jeter’s Way Out
abstract: For the first and only time, Jeter is set to play a game at Yankee Stadium with his team eliminated from playoff contention, and looking to rebuild for the future.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter has played 1,390 regular-season games in the Bronx, and in every one of them, the Yankees have been alive for a playoff spot or have already clinched one. That could change on Thursday, when Jeter is set to play his first and only home game with the Yankees eliminated from the postseason.

headline: A New Focus on Foreign Fighters
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The United Nations Security Council should take on the growing threat of foreign fighters, but it must adhere to the rule of law and human rights.
lead_paragraph: In response to President Obama’s reassertion of American leadership in the Middle East, the United Nations Security Council moved to stanch the flow of foreign fighters, including those joining the Islamic State, by demanding that nations adopt laws to prevent their citizens from traveling abroad to join these groups.

headline: Iranian President Praises Cooperation in New York
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In appearances across New York, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran seems intent on conveying how different he is from his predecessor ahead of the United Nations General Assembly meeting.
lead_paragraph: In two days of back-to-back interviews, speeches and meetings in New York this week, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has gone to some lengths to sound much like President Obama in describing the need to defeat Islamic radicals and to seize what may well be a last opportunity over the next two months to reach an accord with the West over Iran’s nuclear program.

lead_paragraph: Brown University faces questions about how it responds to a student’s charge of sexual assault, two decades after similar accusations sparked a national reform movement.

headline: Ned Yost, the Royals’ Rugged Leader, Looks Inward
abstract: Fired as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers in 2008, Yost now has the Kansas City Royals in position to make the playoffs for the first time since 1985.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In late September 2008, after Ned Yost was fired as manager of the Milwaukee Brewers with 12 games left in the season, he went home to Georgia. He did not watch baseball or follow the playoff race. Instead, he worked on his 700-acre farm, building feeders.

abstract: As auto lenders reach out to those with poor credit, they are increasingly using starter interruption devices, technology that allows them to remotely disable a car, to spur timely payment.

headline: Emissions From India Will Increase, Official Says

lead_paragraph: In a blow to American hopes of reaching an international deal to fight global warming, India’s new environment minister said Wednesday that his country would not offer a plan to cut its greenhouse gas emissions ahead of a climate summit next year in Paris.

Cuomo of New York and Chris Christie of New Jersey on Wednesday ordered a more pronounced security presence across their states, with an increase of uniformed officers at airports, train stations and other key hubs.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some time last year, a Kuwaiti man in his early 30s who had spent more than a decade hiding from the American government arrived in northwest Syria, where he met up with other members of Al Qaeda who had begun putting down roots in a country torn by two years of death and chaos.

keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A report released by the F.B.I. on Wednesday confirmed what many Americans had feared but law enforcement officials had never documented: Mass shootings have risen drastically in the past half-dozen years.

headline: The Destruction of Gog and Magog
abstract: Alex Vratsanos asks us a well-known trivia question.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If I said to you that today’s constructor has let us know that he has left 10 body parts scattered around his grid, what would your first reaction be? Curiosity? Horror? An uncontrollable urge to call the police?

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Financial reports from investor-owned hospitals and surveys by several state hospital associations show that Medicaid expansion has reduced the number of patients who cannot pay their bills.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration increased the pressure on states to expand Medicaid on Wednesday, citing new evidence that hospitals reap financial benefits and gain more paying customers when states broaden eligibility.

abstract: The Obama administration on Wednesday issued new guidelines intended to strengthen oversight of federally funded research that could inadvertently produce biological weapons.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Wednesday issued new guidelines intended to strengthen the oversight of federally funded biology research that could inadvertently produce bioweapons.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
