abstract: A federal commission has endorsed the design by Frank Gehry, but a planning committee still must approve it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal commission on Wednesday endorsed a design for the proposed Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial that Eisenhower family members have criticized as undignified and too costly.

headline: Malloy Says Rail Service in Connecticut Will Expand
abstract: Starting Nov. 9, trains on Metro-North’s New Haven line will run on “subwaylike intervals,” said a commuter advocate, but some gaps will persist.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut announced a pre-Election Day present for beleaguered commuters on Wednesday in the form of additional train service between the New Haven station and Grand Central Terminal.

headline: From Expanded Home, Celebrating the Cultures of the African Diaspora
abstract: The Caribbean Cultural Center African Diaspora Institute is moving into a four-story former firehouse on East 125th Street.
lead_paragraph: When Marta Moreno Vega walked through the old firehouse, tattered pinups littered the floor, rats scurried along cracked walls, and parts of the Romanesque ceiling had fallen to the floor. But still she saw her dream: A space that could, once again, become an anchor in its East Harlem community.

headline: In M.T.A. Capital Budget, a Reappearing Cash Gap
abstract: The budget proposal released by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority put the cost of keeping the aging system in working order at $32 billion, outpacing available funding by over $15 billion.
lead_paragraph: Every five years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority unveils a glossy long-term plan for its vast system of trains, buses and bridges. This week, the capital proposal it released put the cost of keeping the aging system in working order at $32 billion.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: You come from a great tradition that stands for education, not ignorance; innovation, not destruction; the dignity of life, not murder. Those who call you away from this path are betraying this tradition, not defending it.

headline: Joseph D. McNamara, Father of Community Policing, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. McNamara, a former police chief in San Jose, Calif., and in Kansas City, Mo., was known for the farsighted policies he implemented and for his iconoclastic outspokenness.
lead_paragraph: Joseph D. McNamara, a onetime New York City patrolman who earned a doctorate from Harvard and went on to become a California police chief whose pioneering embrace of community policing and diversity in the ranks helped catalyze broad changes in police practices nationwide, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Security Pact Will Be Signed After Afghan President Is Inaugurated, Official Says
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The signing of the new security agreement is a key step that would provide a legal basis for American forces to advise Afghan forces after 2014.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A new security agreement authorizing the presence of American forces in Afghanistan after 2014 will be signed just days after the nation’s new president is inaugurated on Monday, a senior State Department official said Wednesday.

headline: Team Loses Case Against U.S.T.A.
abstract: A judge ruled against a senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members in its case against the United States Tennis Association.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled against a senior tennis team with Orthodox Jewish members in its case against the United States Tennis Association. The team, which had qualified for the U.S.T.A. Eastern Adult Section Championships, filed a lawsuit against the association in the Southern District Court of New York over the association’s refusal to change a tournament schedule to accommodate the players’ observance of the Sabbath. The tournament will be held as scheduled in Schenectady, N.Y., from Sept. 27 to 29.

headline: On His Own Terms

lead_paragraph: Stephan Janson might have followed in the footsteps of his idol Yves Saint Laurent, but instead chose a quieter life away from the frenzy of the fashion world as a couturier to some of the most discerning women in Europe.

headline: Boehner Out to Defeat Europe (In Golf)
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner, an avid golfer, is gearing up for the Ryder Cup, the intense competition between the United States and Europe that begins Friday in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner may be out hustling for Republican House candidates in New England, but he is also gearing up for the Ryder Cup, the always intense golf competition between the United States and Europe that begins Friday in Scotland.

headline: Holder Backs Suit in New York Faulting Legal Service for Poor

headline: South Carolina: Charges for Trooper Who Shot Unarmed Man in Traffic Stop
abstract: A South Carolina state trooper who was fired for shooting an unarmed man during a Sept. 4 traffic stop was arrested on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A South Carolina state trooper who was fired for shooting an unarmed man during a Sept. 4 traffic stop was arrested on Wednesday. The trooper, Lance Cpl. Sean Groubert, 31, was charged with assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature, according to The State, a newspaper based in Columbia, S.C. He was being held on $75,000 bond after a video of the stop was played at his bond hearing. The video showed him shooting a motorist who was reaching into his truck after the trooper had asked for his license and registration. The motorist, Levar Jones, 35, was released from a hospital after being treated for a gunshot wound to his hip.

headline: The Little Writing Prize That Could

lead_paragraph: In the thick of the literary awards season, as the National Book Foundation, the Man Booker judges and the Nobel committee all prepare to announce winners in coming weeks, an unlikely institution has bestowed a new prize on writers: Amtrak.

headline: Kay Hagan’s Surprising Strength
abstract: A few months ago, North Carolina looked like an excellent prospect for Republicans to gain a Senate seat. That’s no longer the case.
lead_paragraph: If there is any state where the Democrats are defying expectations — and where Republicans should be kicking themselves — it’s North Carolina.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) HOW TO GET AWAY WITH MURDER This latest entry from ShondaLand — Shonda Rhimes’s production company — to join ABC’s Thursday night lineup stars the Oscar-nominated Viola Davis as Annalise Keating, an intimidating law professor at a Philadelphia college, the likes of whom hasn’t been seen since Prof. Charles Kingsfield (John Houseman) caused the knees of aspiring legal eagles to knock in “The Paper Chase.” Aja Naomi King, Alfred Enoch, Jack Falahee, Karla Souza and Matt McGorry play Keating’s prized pupils, first seen toting a dead body in a rug around campus. Peter Nowalk created this series, which shuttles between the past and present as, thread by thread, it unravels who did what and why. In “Grey’s Anatomy,” leading in at 8, Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) seeks to regain control of her life as a new doctor (Kelly McCreary) comes on board and Derek (Patrick Dempsey) pushes to move to Washington. And in “Scandal,” at 9, Fitz (Tony Goldwyn) begins his second term in the White House determined to make a positive impact on the country; Mellie (Bellamy Young) copes with the loss of her son; and everybody tries to figure out where Olivia (Kerry Washington) and Jake (Scott Foley) have run off to.

headline: Russia Uses Its Natural Gas to Play the China Card, Again

If signed, the pact would authorize a new pipeline that could double the amount of natural gas Russia is scheduled to export to China and elevate Russia into a major supplier there.

headline: Where Texas Is a Dream State
abstract: Dreams come true — sort of — in Nancy Newberry’s “Halfway to Midland,” where she combines real and remembered moments to portray her home state.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Newberry wanted to make pictures of Texas that went past the facile folklore of the homestead, past the stereotypes of tumbleweeds and ten-gallon hats. Put in decidedly nonfolksy terms, she was fascinated by disjunctive cognition, that phenomenon in a dream where you simultaneously recognize something is and isn’t. In other words, something familiar — but just shy of normal.

The sentencing of Mr. Tohti on Tuesday prompted condemnation from the European Union, the United States and other governments.

headline: Philippines Says Local Terrorist Group Is Not Linked to ISIS

headline: The Woman Who Walked 10,000 Miles (No Exaggeration) in Three Years
abstract: For Sarah Marquis, a very long hike — like one she took from Siberia through the Gobi Desert, China and eventually Australia — can become a voyage of discovery.
lead_paragraph: A hundred years ago, when Robert Falcon Scott set out for Antarctica on his Terra Nova expedition, his two primary goals were scientific discovery and reaching the geographic South Pole. Arguably, though, Scott was really chasing what contemporary observers call a sufferfest. He set himself up for trouble: Scott brought Manchurian and Siberian ponies that quickly fell through the snow and ice; he planned, in part, for his crew to “man-haul,” meaning that the men would pull sleds full of gear, instead of relying on dogs. Even when Scott’s men faltered, they continued collecting specimens, including rocks. The expedition ended terribly; everybody who made the push to the pole died. Miserable, starving and frostbitten, one of Scott’s last four men killed himself by walking into a blizzard without even bothering to put on his boots.

headline: Morning Agenda: Devices Fuel Subprime Auto Boom
abstract: Subprime auto lenders are using technology to digitally repossess cars. | Trading opportunities beckon in China. | Harvard names endowment chief. | Wednesday was a big day for I.P.O.s
lead_paragraph: DEVICES FUEL SUBPRIME AUTO BOOM | Subprime lenders are increasingly relying on technology that allows them to track and disable delinquent borrowers’ vehicles with just a tap of a smartphone app, bringing auto loans into the lives of people with low credit scores, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write as part of DealBook’s Driven Into Debt series. One mother could not get her 10-year-old daughter to an emergency room after her lender remotely activated a device in her car’s dashboard that prevented her car from starting. Another borrower contends that her lender shut her car down while she was driving on the highway.

headline: Ebola Death Toll Is More Than 2,900, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The disease is spreading rapidly in Liberia and Sierra Leone, but the situation in Guinea seems to have stabilized, the United Nations health body said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The number of people killed by the Ebola outbreak in West Africa has reached at least 2,917, driven by the continuing rapid spread of the disease in Liberia and Sierra Leone, though in Guinea the number of new cases appears to have stabilized, the World Health Organization reported Thursday.

headline: Air France Scales Back Transavia Plan, Giving In to Striking Pilots’ Demands
abstract: Air France-KLM said it would operate only 48 percent of its flights on Friday after a move to scale back plans for Transavia failed to appease the union.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite bowing to an important union demand, Air France-KLM remained crippled on Thursday by an 11-day-old pilots’ strike.

headline: Afghanistan’s Failed Transformation
abstract: If the country is to survive in one piece, its new leaders must act fast to correct the failures of the last decade.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, after months of bitter wrangling, the two leading candidates in Afghanistan’s presidential election agreed to form a national unity government. Ashraf Ghani, a Pashtun technocrat, is to be president, and Abdullah Abdullah, a former foreign minister of mixed Tajik and Pashtun descent, is to be chief executive, a newly created post akin to prime minister. The power-sharing agreement came after an audit of the ballots cast in a June runoff, in an election widely believed to have been partially rigged. It has no basis in Afghanistan’s election law. And given the rancor that has come before, it may not hold very long.

headline: Guangdong Sees Surge in Dengue Fever Cases
abstract: Guangdong, China’s most populous province, has seen about 7,500 cases of dengue this year, Xinhua reported. Most years, Guangdong sees fewer than 1,000 cases of dengue, a mosquito-borne disease.
lead_paragraph: The southern Chinese province of Guangdong has seen a surge in dengue fever cases this year, raising fears that factors such as climate change and urbanization have accelerated the spread of the mosquito-borne disease in the region.

headline: 1889: Wissmann Plans Attacks
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Germans prepare for attacks in Tanzania in 1889.
lead_paragraph: The German Captain Wissmann has been at Bagamoyo for some time, and all the tailors in Zanzibar have been busy, making white cotton uniforms and bags for provisions. He is organizing a force of 2,000 men, with which he announces that he intends to proceed into the interior and attack Bushiri, who appears to be encamped somewhere near Mpwapwa. After defeating the Arab who has given him so much trouble, and hanging him if he falls into his hands, Captain Wissmann will proceed to Kilima ’Njara. — The New York Herald, European Edition, September 26, 1889

At Lucasfilm headquarters here, the pressure is arguably more intense on a new animated TV series: “Rebels,” making its cable debut early next month, not only represents a dramatic shift back to non-prequel stories — for the first time since 1998 — it also formally ushers in the studio’s Disney era.

Poroshenko of Ukraine said on Thursday that his office was in constant communication with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to sustain a truce in eastern Ukraine, and that Ukraine was now looking ahead to pursue membership in the European Union.

headline: Steven Pinker: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Language Instinct,” “The Blank Slate” and, most recently, “The Sense of Style: The Thinking Person’s Guide to Writing in the 21st Century” has never gotten in trouble for reading a book. “Just for writing them.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Language Instinct,” “The Blank Slate” and, most recently, “The Sense of Style: The Thinking Person’s Guide to Writing in the 21st Century” has never gotten in trouble for reading a book. “Just for writing them.”

headline: Not an August Wilson Kind of Boyhood
abstract: Billy Porter, who won a Tony Award for his role as a drag queen in “Kinky Boots,” has written a tribute to his mother in “While I Yet Live.”
lead_paragraph: When Billy Porter was a freshman at Carnegie Mellon University, he took an unusual approach to an essay for a history class. Instead of topic sentences and footnotes, he wrote a short story about a fictional character on a quest that covered the points of the assignment. He no longer remembers the specifics — it was 1987 — but he has never forgotten his professor’s reaction.

headline: Text to Text | The Bill of Rights and ‘The Bill of Rights We Deserve’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair the United States Bill of Rights with Sam Apple’s satirical “The Bill of Rights We Deserve.”
lead_paragraph: The Bill of Rights protects some of our most basic freedoms, such as the right to practice a religion, to assemble peaceably and to speak freely. Sometimes, however, our society seems to prioritize other freedoms not enshrined in the Constitution, such as the right to buy what we want, eat what we want and even binge-watch what we want. These are individual liberties that Sam Apple safeguards in his satirical “The Bill of Rights We Deserve,” which we pair with the original Bill of Rights in this Text to Text.

headline: Eric Cantor, Wall Street Defender, Gone But Not Forgotten
abstract: Congress will revive legislation to rein in “political intelligence gathering.”
lead_paragraph: There was no great ceremony when Eric Cantor departed Congress for a plush job on Wall Street this month. No need for tearful goodbyes for a politician who failed electorally but morphed into an instant multi-millionaire when a New York investment bank snapped him up as vice chairman.

headline: Unseemly Notes
abstract: Why it’s not 1955 anymore.
lead_paragraph: Something I didn’t know: David Brooks’s column that, among other things, lamented the failure of the wealthy to follow a “code of seemliness” was actually part of a broader complaint to that effect among conservative intellectuals. For example, Charles Murray’s “Coming Apart” is mainly about what has gone wrong with working-class values, but he devotes a fair bit of space to the “unseemly” ostentation of the elite; strange to say, he focuses on Hollywood producers rather than private equity managers, but still.

headline: Asymmetric Monetary Risks
abstract: Charles Evans says what must be said.
lead_paragraph: How much slack is there in the U.S. labor market? Good question. The measured unemployment rate is fairly low, but labor force participation also seems low, and I have doubts about studies purporting to say that it’s overwhelmingly long-term demographics. Wage gains are still slow. My guess is that there’s considerably more slack than the unemployment number might lead you to suspect, but the truth is that I don’t know.

headline: A Bit More Cash to Pave the Way for a Clinton Candidacy

lead_paragraph: The “super PAC” Ready for Hillary plans to convene as many as 400 donors and supporters in Manhattan in November, a last-ditch effort to raise money and lay the groundwork for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s increasingly likely 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: Ebola Epidemic Worsening, Sierra Leone Expands Quarantine Restrictions
abstract: More than a quarter of Sierra Leone is now sealed off after officials placed quarantine restrictions on hundreds of thousands more citizens.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — Acknowledging that the Ebola epidemic sweeping Sierra Leone was worsening, officials here put hundreds of thousands more citizens under quarantine on Thursday, sealing off more than a quarter of the country and warning travelers not to get out of their vehicles in the districts under isolation.

headline: Eric Holder Resigns, Setting Up Fight Over Successor
abstract: Replacing the U.S. Attorney General, who provoked the ire of Republicans as President Obama’s chief liberal warrior, could be a political nightmare.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s announcement on Thursday that Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. would leave the administration sets up an election-season scramble for a replacement to carry on Mr. Holder’s civil rights crusade, wage rhetorical combat with Congress and manage the legal complexities of a presidency increasingly drawn into war with terrorists.

headline: Buoyant Dollar Recovers Its Luster, Underlining Rebound in U.S. Economy
keywords: ['Euro (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Yen (Currency)']
abstract: After a prolonged weak spell, the dollar is once again the preferred currency of global investors, who see a resurgence in the American economy.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:10 p.m. | President Obama’s handling of the economy may be reviled by his political opponents, but he is receiving support from a surprising quarter: foreign exchange traders.

headline: My Father’s A.L.S.
abstract: My mother and I were out running errands one afternoon when she pulled the car over and told me the truth. It sounded like something from a horror movie.
lead_paragraph: When I was in college, my father David started walking with an odd, barely perceptible limp. He was in his mid-40s, a gregarious physician, teacher and researcher who was always upbeat. He told his four kids that he had a “back problem” — a deliberately vague cover story that I, for one, was willing to believe.

headline: Iran’s President Says West’s ‘Blunders’ Aided Rise of Islamic State
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president of Iran, Hassan Rouhani, said the West and Arab states should apologize for “blunders” that he said had given rise to extremist groups.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Hassan Rouhani of Iran delivered a searing indictment of Western and Arab states on Thursday in his annual speech to the United Nations, blaming them for sowing the seeds of extremism in the Middle East with “strategic blunders” that have given rise to the Islamic State and other violent jihadist groups.

headline: Upper Manhattan Nest for a Mother and Son
abstract: Laura Martin and her son, Dax Roy, sought to buy an apartment in Audubon Park.

headline: Diana Krall Tour and Album Delayed by Illness
abstract: Suffering from complications of pneumonia, Diana Krall has decided to postpone the release of a new album, “Wallflower,” and an accompanying tour.
lead_paragraph: Suffering from complications of pneumonia, the jazz singer and pianist Diana Krall has decided to postpone the release of a new album, “Wallflower,” and a United States tour, which was to have begun in Phoenix on Nov. 7. The album, which was scheduled to be released Oct. 21 and will be her 12th studio album, will be delayed until Feb. 3 of next year.

headline: A Recipe for Air Rage
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Emotions', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Sleep', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Stressed passengers packed into cramped cabins can bring emotions to a boil. But the situation isn’t all bleak — there are ways to make the best of a volatile situation.
lead_paragraph: Why do some travelers squabble about overhead bin space? Or feud over an armrest? Why, when a passenger reclines his seat, does another respond with rage befitting the pages of “Lord of the Flies”?

headline: In a Video, Police Chief of Ferguson Apologizes
abstract: In an online video, Chief Thomas Jackson expressed regret for the death of Michael Brown and the four hours it took officers to remove his body from the street.
lead_paragraph: Chief Thomas Jackson of the police force in Ferguson, Mo., issued a stark apology to the family of Michael Brown on Thursday, saying in a videotaped statement that he was sorry for the death of their son and for the four hours that the body of the unarmed 18-year-old lay in the street after he was fatally shot by a police officer.

headline: A Favorite Dane at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Nielsen Project, an effort to record the six Carl Nielsen symphonies and the concertos for flute, violin and clarinet, is nearly complete.
lead_paragraph: During his time with the New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein was a champion of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen (1865-1931). He recorded three of Nielsen’s six symphonies and two of the three concertos with the Philharmonic and won new admirers for Nielsen through his exciting performances.

headline: Art-Science Mix, Accelerated
abstract: CERN, the world’s largest particle laboratory, has a program for collaboration between artists and physicists. Early results can be seen in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Research on the Higgs boson isn’t the only work to come out of CERN, the world’s largest particle laboratory, in recent years. In 2011, the organization announced a new program, Collide@CERN, to support collaboration between artists and physicists on its campus in the suburbs of Geneva. The first two recipients of these creative residencies were the Swiss choreographer Gilles Jobin and the German visual artist Julius von Bismarck, who pooled their investigations to create “Quantum.”

headline: Showing a Career, From the Legs Up
abstract: One of the season’s most eagerly anticipated exhibitions opens at the Museum of Modern Art: “Robert Gober: The Heart Is Not a Metaphor.”
lead_paragraph: One of the season’s most eagerly anticipated exhibitions opens Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art: “Robert Gober: The Heart Is Not a Metaphor” is the first museum retrospective in the United States for the influential, critically acclaimed sculptor and installation artist. Mr. Gober rose to prominence in the 1980s on the strength of sculptures made with scrupulous craftsmanship in the form of old-fashioned, white enameled sinks. Variations on domestic objects like cribs, playpens and dog beds followed. Then came expansive installations like one with a wrap-around, hand-painted mural of a New England forest punctuated by sinks with running water and barred windows affording glimpses of blue sky.

headline: Grown Accustomed to Her Phone
abstract: A batch of new shows begins in the next few days, but the most fearless of them may be the ABC comedy “Selfie.”
lead_paragraph: A batch of new shows begins in the next few days, but the most fearless of them may be the ABC comedy “Selfie.” Whether that’s “fearless” in a good way remains to be seen.

headline: Big Sound at a Big House
abstract: Lorin Ashton, the disc jockey and producer who has been performing as Bassnectar since 2002, delivers deep bass in every idiom he can think of.
lead_paragraph: Lorin Ashton, the disc jockey and producer who has been performing as Bassnectar since 2002, delivers deep bass in every idiom he can think of: dubstep, hip-hop, hard rock, trap, electro. His music is geared for mass events with dizzying lights and bone-rattling sound systems like his marathon Bass Center VIII, which commandeers Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

headline: Housewives, Newly Desperate
abstract: A New York Film Festival retrospective, “Joseph L. Mankiewicz: The Essential Iconoclast,” honors that Hollywood director.
lead_paragraph: “The most intelligent man in contemporary cinema” wrote Jean-Luc Godard of the Hollywood director Joseph L. Mankiewicz in 1958. That assessment is borne out by the classic “All About Eve” (1950) with its great performances and witty, literate dialogue that set the template for the way sophisticated theater people are viewed. But a previous Mankiewicz movie, the lesser-known “A Letter to Three Wives” (1949), which is being celebrated in a New York Film Festival retrospective, “Joseph L. Mankiewicz: The Essential Iconoclast,” is just as perfect.

headline: I Tried to Make a Search Engine Write Me a Poem
abstract: The search engine Yossarian is supposed to increase creativity. I decided to test it out.
lead_paragraph: Before I started writing this, I took a creativity test. Many different such tests exist, but I took one of the best-known ones: Guilford’s Alternative Uses Task, which simply requires that you come up with as many applications for a particular object as possible. I picked a paper coffee cup. After 10 minutes (an amount of time I’d arbitrarily chosen), I had 39 uses, from the prosaic (“hold coffee”) to the probably impractical (“poke holes in the bottom and it could be a shower head for a short amount of time before it collapses”).

headline: Athleisure-Appropriate Hair at Paco Rabanne
abstract: For the label’s sporty spring/summer 2015 collection, the hairstylist Paul Hanlon created a ponytail meant to give the impression of a girl who’s just finished a run in the park.
lead_paragraph: “The clothes have a cool, sporty vibe, so I wanted the models’ hair to mirror that,” said the hair stylist Paul Hanlon backstage at today’s Paco Rabanne spring/summer 2015 show. The resulting creation: a low-slung, textural spin on the timeless gym-class ponytail, meant to give the impression of a girl who’s just finished her daily run in the park. “She’s strong, she’s not afraid to get outdoors and really immerse herself in the elements,” he explained, gesturing to a few small, glossy strands strewn across the forehead. Before securing lengths with a small black elastic tie, Hanlon added a mist of Toni & Guy’s Sea Salt Texturising Spray to the ends and worked Toni & Guy’s Groupie spray wax into the roots to “make the hair looked lived in and a little sweaty.” The final touch? “A quick blast of L’Oreal’s classic Elnett, and that’s it,” he said. “She’s good to go.”

headline: No Job, No Money and Now, No Wife
abstract: “Gone Girl,” David Fincher’s movie adaptation of Gillian Flynn’s best seller, focuses on a young wife who goes missing.
lead_paragraph: “Gone Girl,” the latest from that dark lord of cinema, David Fincher, opens with a man softly talking about his wife’s head. The image of his hand caressing a woman’s sleek blond hair in close-up indicates that it’s a lovely head, a lovely wife, too. Yet the violence of his words — he speaks of cracking her skull open and “unspooling” her brain — wakens an unease that trembles throughout this domestic horror movie. Those familiar with Mr. Fincher’s work may wonder, perhaps with a shudder or a conspiratorial smile, whether this head will share the fate of another head belonging to another pretty wife, a gift that was boxed and delivered in one of the hellish circles girdling his shocker “Seven.”

headline: 1964: Kenya Battling Somali Rebels
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Kenya struggles with Somali guerrillas in 1964.
lead_paragraph: GARISSA, Kenya — A few hundred armed fanatics have paralyzed normal life in almost half of Kenya since it attained independence in December. These tough guerrillas are Somalis, bent on forcing the Kenya government to cede to the neighboring Somali Republic the Somali-occupied northeastern part of Kenya in which about 250,000 of their countrymen live. There is no doubt in Nairobi that the Somali government in Mogadishu provided the terrorists with arms, ammunition and other supplies. There are about 800 of these so-called ‘‘Shifta,’’ operating in small groups of 30 or 40 men. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 26, 1964

headline: Revisiting the Original Classics of Surf Cinema
abstract: The reissue arm of the boutique Brooklyn record label Mexican Summer is releasing the soundtracks to the cult ’70s films “Crystal Voyage” and “Morning of the Earth.”
lead_paragraph: Surfing is back in a big way, and with it, a renewed interest in artifacts from the original heyday of surf culture. Early films like Albert Falzon’s “Morning of the Earth” (1971) and “Crystal Voyager” (1974) marked a moment when wholesome ’60s representations of surfing (the Beach Boys, Frankie Avalon) gave way to depictions that were entwined with the counterculture. Both films featured exhilarating camerawork (by the surfer George Greenough, also responsible for inventing the modern surfboard fin), heady but mellow psych-rock soundtracks and an underlying message about the sanctity of nature. This month, the boutique imprint Anthology Recordings, part of the influential Mexican Summer label, reissues these two rare film soundtracks on heavyweight wax. And tonight, the label is screening a rare archival print of “Morning of the Earth” at Anthology Film Archives in New York (no relation to the record label). A song from the soundtrack, “Open Up Your Heart” by G. Wayne Thomas, plays here with footage from the film.

headline: Tickets on Sale for ‘St. Matthew Passion’ Dress Rehearsal
abstract: Presenters of the Bach “St. Matthew Passion” at Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival have come up with an unusual way to expand their audience — and sell more tickets: they are opening the Oct. 4 dress rehearsal to audiences.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest to come by classical performance tickets in New York this fall has been for the Berlin Philharmonic’s staging of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion,” conducted by Simon Rattle and directed by Peter Sellars, which opens Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival on Oct. 7.

headline: Rodarte’s Designers Create a Limited-Edition Vinyl Album
abstract: For the latest edition of The Thing Quarterly, Kate and Laura Mulleavy packaged music by No Age with film stills by the artist and photographer Todd Cole.
lead_paragraph: Four times a year, John Herschend and Will Rogan, the visual artists behind The Thing Quarterly — a conceptual publication that comes in the form of an object — invite a different creative talent to conceive each new issue. For their latest edition, Issue 24, which debuts today in a limited run of 1,500, the duo tapped the Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy.

headline: Wheelies: The Police Wagon Edition
abstract: Ford unveils a police concept version of its Transit van; North American Car and Truck of the Year semifinalists are announced.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Pakistani Guard Shoots Prisoner Convicted of Blasphemy
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: The 70-year-old inmate, who is of Pakistani descent and was convicted of blasphemy after being accused of claiming to be a prophet, survived the attack, officials said.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A British citizen of Pakistani descent who had been sentenced to death on blasphemy charges was wounded Thursday after a prison guard opened fire on him in Rawalpindi, police officials said.

headline: A Musician Pastures His Flock Among the Lilies
abstract: In “The Song,” a country music singer faces temptations on the road and chooses the straight and narrow only after having indulged in pleasures and debaucheries.
lead_paragraph: THE SONG

headline: In Defense of Corporate Tax Dodging
abstract: No one really cares what Bill Clinton thinks about corporate taxes. But what he thinks is assumed to be what Hillary Clinton thinks, and she is expected to run for president.
lead_paragraph: In a passive aggressive way, former President Bill Clinton recently criticized new rules from the Obama Treasury Department to curb blatant corporate tax dodging.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news for Climate Week.
lead_paragraph: From Manhattan to Melbourne to war-torn Aleppo, at least half a million people (and more than a few polar bears) participated in 2,700 simultaneous climate events around the world on Sunday to demand action on climate change. In New York, organizers estimate nearly 400,000 people turned out for the People’s Climate March, on the eve of the U.N. Climate Summit.

headline: Public Theater to Offer Free Tickets by Lottery
abstract: The Public Theater will offer free tickets through a lottery to the first performance of each main stage show in the coming season.
lead_paragraph: The Public Theater announced on Thursday that it would distribute free tickets, by lottery, to the first performance of every main stage show during its 2014-2015 season. The free tickets, a program being started with the help of TodayTix, a theater ticket app, will be handed out both through a mobile lottery, which will begin a week before each preview performance, and through lotteries to be held in the lobby of the Public, at Astor Place and Lafayette Street.

headline: A Newswoman’s Long Goodbye
abstract: Ann Compton, the retiring White House reporter for ABC News, was feted yet again on Wednesday with a party at the Newseum.
lead_paragraph: Ann Compton, the retiring White House reporter for ABC News, has been celebrated by friendly rivals at NBC, by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, and twice by President Obama.

headline: U.S. Awards Grants to Explore and Evaluate Paid Leave
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: The Department of Labor is putting money behind its push to expand paid family leave in the United States. The issue could be a factor in coming elections — if enough voters ask about it.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Labor is putting money behind its push to expand paid family leave in the United States.

headline: Bravo, Prime Minister Cameron
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One democratic leader has decided to ask his country’s legislature to vote before going to war. Pity that it isn’t President Obama.
lead_paragraph: One democratic leader has decided to ask his country’s legislature to vote before going to war. Pity that it isn’t President Obama.

headline: Nine Publishers to Visit at the New York Art Book Fair
abstract: The preeminent celebration of contemporary art publications, which comes to MoMA PS1 this weekend, features a group of first-time, exclusive and lesser-known vendors worth checking out.
lead_paragraph: Every fall, the galleries of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, a former public school building, return to their roots when the museum is filled with books for the NY Art Book Fair (Sept. 26–28, with a preview Sept. 25), an annual event put on by the art book nonprofit Printed Matter. Tens of thousands of visitors mill through the building’s halls, courts and rooms, and the throngs are a testament to the quality of the publications for sale. This year’s edition, the ninth to date, will feature more than 350 booksellers, antiquarians, artists, institutions and independent publishers from 28 countries, including Estonia, Australia and South Korea. Here, some of the first-time, exclusive and lesser-known vendors not to be missed this year.

headline: New Television Season Raises Red Flags for Fox
abstract: The network had another night of poor ratings on Wednesday, a discouraging sign especially for its new, well-reviewed drama, “The Red Band Society.”
lead_paragraph: The third night of network television’s premiere week provided good news for another new series, the comedy “Black-ish” on ABC, while further cementing CBS’s solid start and planting more red flags for the Fox network.

headline: Video: The 4C Is Alfa Romeo’s Stylish Return to the United States
abstract: Amid flagging sales, Alfa Romeo left the United States in 1995 with its tail between its legs. The 4C brings the marque back with a bang.
lead_paragraph: Alfa Romeo left the United States market in 1995, after a year in which the Italian company sold only 523 cars. For comparison, Ford sells three times that many F-Series trucks every day. Alfa simply couldn’t justify the huge investment needed to comply with ever-tighter American safety and emission standards.

headline: A Chekhovian Bird of a Different Feather
abstract: Christian Camargo’s “Days and Nights” is a modern reworking of Chekhov’s “The Seagull.”
lead_paragraph: The cast list for “Days and Nights,” a modern reworking of Chekhov’s “The Seagull,” is so juicy that I approached the movie with lip-smacking expectations of scenery being chewed and spit out with histrionic gusto. Even at its worst, how bad could an updated version of the play be, if actors of the caliber of Allison Janney, William Hurt, Cherry Jones and Mark Rylance had signed on? The answer is worse than you could imagine.

headline: Franzi Mueller Transforms at Rick Owens
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Franzi Mueller before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: At Ryder Cup, a Formidable Pair Is Created in McIlroy and García
abstract: In crucial matchups, Rory McIlroy and Sergio García of Europe will face the Americans Phil Mickelson and Keegan Bradley, and Stephen Gallacher and Ian Poulter will face Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — On his way out of the FedEx Cup playoffs this month, Henrik Stenson stopped to consider a potential Ryder Cup pairing of his European teammates Rory McIlroy and Sergio García.

headline: Why We’re Talking About Mitt Romney
abstract: Why the 2012 nominee keeps being floated for 2016.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been mostly ignoring the various “Romney 2016!” trial balloons floated by various parties over the last six months or so (including by some of my dear friends, alas), but now that someone as sober and well-informed as Byron York has weighed in with a “this could happen” column, it’s worth saying something about why the possibility keeps coming up.

abstract: In “Plastic,” young credit card hackers cross a gangster who wants to be paid off.
lead_paragraph: PLASTIC

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Boehner Sees a Republican Senate and Has Big Plans
abstract: Speaker Boehner likes the chances of a Republican Senate majority come January.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner doesn’t want to go too far in forecasting Senate results in the midterm election, but he believes the odds on are the Republican side.

headline: Former Mattel Chief Robert Eckert Joins Friedman Fleischer & Lowe
abstract: Mr. Eckert, who retired as Mattel’s chief in 2011 after 11 years, said he would help the private equity firm run its portfolio companies.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Eckert, the former chairman and chief executive of Mattel, is starting a new chapter of his career in the private equity business.

abstract: Matthew Warchus narrates a sequence from “Pride.”
lead_paragraph: Matthew Warchus narrates a sequence from “Pride.”

headline: New and Old Media Artworks at Museum of Modern Art
abstract: MoMA’s “Cut to Swipe” exhibition will feature recent media artworks by James Richards and Ken Okiishi, as well as a pioneering installation by Dara Birnbaum.
lead_paragraph: Life has been busy for Stuart Comer, who arrived in New York from London just a year ago. Not only was he one of the three curators who put together the 2014 Whitney Biennial, but for his day job as the Museum of Modern Art’s chief curator of media and performance, he has also been quietly organizing a show that chronicles the evolution of the media arts through the museum’s recent acquisitions.

headline: Looking for Moose to Moon Over
abstract: My 7-year-old son had seen a moose on TV. I was going to show him the real thing. And so we headed for New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: My 7-year-old, Henrik, is an animal TV show addict. “Wild Kratts.” “Call of the Wildman.” Old “Crocodile Hunter” reruns.

headline: Every Word Borges Wrote, Writ Large in Brooklyn
abstract: In an inventive homage, Web-generated images of words from Borges’s writings will be projected on the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn this weekend.
lead_paragraph: In his fiction, the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges conceived of such poetic paradoxes as an infinite library, a single point that contains the universe, and a map of an empire at the exact scale of that empire. The artists Daniel Temkin and Rony Maltz have fashioned a clever homage to him in “Borges: The Complete Works,” part of the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn this weekend. Their piece is a twist on the word search: that staple of elementary school, in which actual words are embedded in a grid of seemingly random characters. Their 135,000-character puzzle (actually two, one for the original Spanish and another in English translation) contains every word Borges ever wrote. It can be reached via the web, where participants can find and “circle” words, using a keyboard. An image of the word search will be projected onto the Manhattan Bridge, and updated every 30 seconds to reflect newly circled words. Participation is free and open to all.

headline: In the Air | Clouds
abstract: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.
lead_paragraph: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.

headline: The Cairo Geniza, Under Piecemeal Restoration
abstract: Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan is leading a project to clean up and protect torn bits from a treasury of ninth-century writing.
lead_paragraph: Experts at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan are puzzling over curly bits of ancient paper recovered from a closet in a Cairo synagogue. Boxfuls of the formerly soggy and bug-infested fragments are undergoing delicate repairs and digitization in the hope that the texts can be reunited, at least virtually, with the rest of their manuscript pages, which are scattered at institutions worldwide.

headline: First Draft Focus: Palin, Roberts and Pancakes
abstract: Sarah Palin with supporters as she campaigned for Senator Pat Roberts, Republican of Kansas, at a pancake breakfast in Independence, Kan., on Thursday.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Nina Ricci Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: A Family Feeling, Wherever He Digs In
abstract: Garry Marshall, back in New York to direct a new play, sees old friends everywhere he turns, including the bar at the Ritz-Carlton.
lead_paragraph: LEAVE it to a native New Yorker who hasn’t lived here in 53 years to still know the best place to go.

headline: Matthew Warchus Narrates a Scene From ‘Pride’
abstract: The British drama “Pride” looks at a group of gay and lesbian activists from London who reach out to support a town of miners during a strike.
lead_paragraph: The British drama “Pride” looks at a group of gay and lesbian activists from London who reach out to support a town of miners in Wales during their strike in 1984. In this video, the director, Matthew Warchus, discusses a scene in which the miners hold a dance in their community hall. One of their new supporters, Jonathan (Dominic West), takes to the dance floor to show the locals some moves.

headline: Siah Armajani: ‘The Tomb Series’
abstract: Much of Mr. Armajani’s new work is oddly stark, raw and hermetic.
lead_paragraph: Siah Armajani was born in Iran in 1939 and came to the United States in 1960 to attend Macalester College in Minnesota. He settled in Minnesota and has lived there ever since, becoming an American artist of a kind we rarely find anymore: one steeped in America’s pro-democracy literary and philosophical traditions. Much of his work has taken the form of sculptural monuments, some realized on an architectural scale, celebrating historical figures he admires, from Whitman and Thoreau, to John Dewey and Frank O’Hara.

headline: Night’s Hero: Who Else?
abstract: With the eyes of a city and a sport upon him, Derek Jeter smacked the winning hit in the final at-bat of his final game at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: He almost started crying as he drove himself to Yankee Stadium in the afternoon. He had to turn away from his teammates before the game when they presented him with gifts, so overcome was he by the emotion. In the first inning, he said, he barely knew what was happening, and later, in the top of the ninth, his eyes welled with tears to the point that he worried that he might break down in front of the crowd of 48,613.

headline: Monika Sosnowska: ‘Tower’
abstract: “Tower,” a massive steel sculpture that cuts a 110-foot swath across Hauser & Wirth, is a cautionary symbol of the changes occurring in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Monika Sosnowska’s “Tower,” a massive steel sculpture that cuts a 110-foot swath across the main gallery of Hauser & Wirth, is a cautionary symbol of the changes occurring in Chelsea. Officially, it’s modeled on the framework Mies van der Rohe used for his famed Lake Shore Drive Apartments, with an eye to the impact of the International Style on Soviet-era architecture in Poland, where Ms. Sosnowska was born. But it’s difficult to look at it without thinking about the luxury condos going up right outside the gallery, along 10th Avenue, or about the way that works of such dehumanizing scale have come to seem banal in this art district.

headline: The Terrible Two
abstract: How we got stuck with a too-low inflation target.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein asks why the Fed (and just about all of its counterparts abroad) targets 2 percent inflation. I did some digging on this very issue in my paper for last spring’s ECB conference, and found that 2 was a convenient round number that seemed to provide a reasonable resolution to the conflict between the price stability crowd and economists worried about the two zeroes.

headline: Dan Colen: ‘Miracle Paintings’
abstract: Mr. Colen has dialed back the artistic swagger endemic to his 2010 debut with the Gagosian Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Dan Colen has dialed back the artistic swagger endemic to his 2010 debut with the Gagosian Gallery. He’s sized down the gallery’s big box space by about two-thirds — which should become a trend. Gone is the heavily ironic stance. Ditto the huge paintings festooned with swaths of chewing gum in lieu of brush strokes; trompe l’oeil canvases seemingly drizzled with confetti that conjure 1970s Lyrical Abstraction; and ostentatious ready-mades, including an inverted halfpipe and customized motorcycles tipped over like dominoes.

headline: Obama Makes ‘Personnel’ Announcement on Holder
abstract: Holder resigns from Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is joining President Obama at the White House to announce Mr. Holder’s resignation.

headline: Has Iran’s Leader Found His Own Voice?
abstract: We don’t understand much about the decision-making processes inside the Iranian leadership councils. But we have some hints.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Paul Graham: ‘Does Yellow Run Forever?’
abstract: Mr. Graham’s subjects include rainbow-streaked landscapes in western Ireland, storefronts in New York and tender portraits of a woman.
lead_paragraph: A sentimental lyricism, with strong Romantic leanings, distinguishes Paul Graham’s latest show of photographs, organized by Pace and Pace/MacGill, from his social-documentary efforts. Here, his subjects include rainbow-streaked landscapes in western Ireland, pawnshop storefronts in New York’s rougher neighborhoods and tender portraits of a woman — the photographer’s partner — asleep in various rooms in New Zealand.

headline: Sex and the Snow
abstract: In “Two Night Stand,” a couple react to being snowed in after a one-night stand.
lead_paragraph: TWO NIGHT STAND

headline: Marc Andreessen Sounds Warning on Start-Ups Burning Cash
abstract: The prominent venture capitalist took to Twitter on Thursday to warn against excessive spending by start-ups that have attracted capital from investors.
lead_paragraph: Fretting over a possible downturn in Silicon Valley is now a mainstream pursuit.

headline: Rival Palestinian Factions Agree to Resolve Differences, Leaders Say
abstract: Government news media reported that the leaders of Hamas and Fatah had made progress on the sticking points of their five-month-old reconciliation pact.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Leaders of rival Palestinian factions said Thursday that they had agreed to resolve their differences and allow the Palestinian Authority to return to the Gaza Strip so reconstruction could begin there next month.

headline: A Secret Restaurant Hatches Outside the Iconic Gamble House in Pasadena
abstract: The brainchild of the artist Bob Dornberger, it will feature a conveyor belt from the basement kitchen that delivers food as fast as diners can eat it.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dornberger’s new underground restaurant isn’t about passwords or unmarked doors, it’s about art. The latest incarnation of his ongoing experimental series, Secret Restaurant, pops up this Saturday at the Gamble House, a masterpiece of the California Arts and Crafts movement, in Pasadena. The central conceit: a conveyor belt that will deliver food from the basement kitchen to diners above ground.

headline: Lampert’s Hedge Fund Loses Participant in Loan to Sears
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The St. Joe Company, a Florida real estate firm, has declined to participate in a $400 million loan to the hedge fund that runs Sears Holdings. But the hedge fund said its loan commitment to Sears stands.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:07 p.m. |

headline: A New Guide to Hiking in California
abstract: The guide “Walkabout Malibu to Mexico: Hiking Inn to Inn on the Southern California Coast,” has information on seven trips in the state.
lead_paragraph: Heading to the beach in Southern California? Leave the freeways behind and start walking — that’s the recommendation of the author and hiker Tom Courtney.

headline: Unleashing Their Inner Sis, Boom, Bah
abstract: People who appreciate the spirit and rhythm of cheerleading routines can get some vigorous exercise by signing up for classes in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: AS a high school athlete who played on a few varsity teams, I appreciated cheerleaders but never quite saw myself stepping into their shoes. That is, until I saw myself in a mirror, holding a pair of black-and-red pompoms while in the arms-akimbo cheerleader stance.

abstract: Abraham H. Foxman of the Anti-Defamation League writes that “common anti-Semitic stereotypes are surprisingly resilient” in Belgium, France, Germany and Italy.
