abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: A Foreign Policy Turning Point or a Moral-Equivalence Blunder?
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For some observers, President Obama’s speech at the United Nations signaled a shift toward a more robust attitude in international relations. Others criticized its incoherence — or accused it of noting a false moral equivalence.
lead_paragraph: As United States planes continued their airstrikes against ISIS targets in Syria, President Obama spoke at the United Nations General Assembly in New York, giving an address that analysts called a major shift in foreign policy. It also incited outrage among some on the right for a remark about domestic conditions.

headline: The  Day the Mayor Dropped the Groundhog
abstract: A local celebrity dies. The mayor is implicated. The plot thickens.
lead_paragraph: A local celebrity dies. The mayor is implicated. A tangled web of deception is exposed — at least according to The New York Post.

headline: Ryder Cup 2014: To Find Ian Poulter, Europe’s Lightning Rod, Look for the Gelled Hair
abstract: At Gleneagles, all eyes are on Poulter as he tries to reprise his role as Ryder Cup hero against the American team when play starts Friday.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland

headline: Obama Can Still Earn His Nobel
keywords: ['Nobel Prizes', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The leader who didn’t have a strategy for dealing with Islamic State nihilists a few weeks ago just dropped an idea bomb on the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: You remember 2009 and the glow from Oslo — Barack Obama, Nobel Peace Prize winner. Wow. Less than a year into his presidency, he joined an elite group: Nelson Mandela, Lech Walesa, Martin Luther King Jr., Mother Teresa, the Dalai Lama. And for what? As near as anybody could tell, it was the only Nobel ever given for future good intentions.

headline: For the Aged, a Shrinking World
abstract: ‘The Little Bedroom,’ in French, takes a close look at two human beings sharing their grief while one takes care of the other.
lead_paragraph: THE LITTLE BEDROOM

headline: Tourists Urged to Avoid Ebola Zone in West Africa
abstract: As the world grapples with the outbreak, guidance for travelers.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola outbreak has gripped broad swaths of West Africa, reaching Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Nigeria and Senegal.

headline: Lanvin: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Jim Shaw: ‘I Only Wanted You to Love Me’
abstract: The uncannily imaginative Los Angeles painter and sculptor Jim Shaw has what the Romantic poet John Keats called negative capability.
lead_paragraph: The uncannily imaginative Los Angeles painter and sculptor Jim Shaw has what the Romantic poet John Keats called negative capability: the ability to be “in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact and reason.” He also has exceptional drawing skills, an expansive sense of humor, an acute moral compass and a connoisseurial eye for weird kitsch.

headline: As Bubba Watson Leads U.S. Charge at Ryder Cup, the Question Is to Where
abstract: The risk in assigning Watson a commanding Ryder Cup role is this: One can envision him leading a spirited charge to the summit or stepping off a cliff.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — Bubba Watson will have on the same pants, shirt and sweater combinations worn by his American teammates in this week’s Ryder Cup, but do not be fooled. The coordinated outfits cannot hide the plated suit of armor Watson wears to protect himself from expectations, scrutiny and rejection.

headline: Recognizing a Vibrant Underground
abstract: The “What Nerve!” exhibition showcases work by the Hairy Who, Funk, Destroy All Monsters and Forcefield, as well as related artists.
lead_paragraph: In 1962 the film critic Manny Farber published the provocative essay “White Elephant Art and Termite Art,” in which he distinguished two types of artists: the White Elephant artist, who tries to create masterpieces equal to the greatest artworks of the past, and the Termite, who engages in “a kind of squandering-beaverish endeavor” that “goes always forward, eating its own boundaries and, likely as not, leaves nothing in its path other than signs of eager, industrious, unkempt activity.”

headline: Alcohol and Excess During Thanksgiving Break
abstract: Shane Dawson’s “Not Cool,” one of two films to emerge from a Starz competition show called “The Chair,” is an attempt at a raunchy comedy.
lead_paragraph: NOT COOL

headline: A Star’s Wonderland of Space, Nature and Song
abstract: The tour behind the Icelandic singer’s album “Biophilia” is captured in a documentary.
lead_paragraph: BJöRK

headline: An Eggplant Parmigiana Recipe to Match Cornas
abstract: Jonathan Benno’s handsomely made eggplant and squash alla parmigiana stands up to the sturdy red wine Cornas
lead_paragraph: Summer turns gloriously Indian. Some of the harvest lingers, notably eggplant and the last of the zucchini, so it’s not too late to present Jonathan Benno’s handsomely made eggplant and squash alla parmigiana. And as this hearty baked vegetable dish suits the season, so does a sturdy red wine like Cornas, a regal expression of the complexity, dark fruit and spice of the syrah grape. Assembling the dish takes time. A wine that can age beautifully for decades deserves the effort. The eggplant can be prepared in advance and reheated. Serve it with grilled lamb chops strewn with black pepper, or by itself as a first course.  FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: On a Bloody Road Trip to Exorcise a Demon
abstract: In “Asmodexia,” a pastor and his granddaughter travel a stark landscape ridding the afflicted of an ancient demon and counting down the days to a mysterious resurrection.
lead_paragraph: ASMODEXIA

headline: 104-Year-Old Portal Bridge Presents $900 Million Problem for Rail Commuters
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Railroads', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Transportation', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: The New Jersey bridge, which is blamed for frequent delays on the Northeast Corridor, is in desperate need of replacement, but the project won’t be cheap.
lead_paragraph: It carries more passenger trains than any other railroad bridge in the Western Hemisphere, yet few people beyond those who rely on it have heard of it. It goes largely unnoticed, unless something goes wrong, which happens with irritating frequency. After all, the bridge is 104 years old.

headline: A Tiny Emissary From the Ancient Past
abstract: Viroids, naked loops of RNA, attack crops and other plants today, but new research suggests they existed at the earliest stages of life on Earth.

headline: Cornas Is No Country Bumpkin
abstract: Cornas in the northern Rhône Valley offers the rare combination of northern Rhône finesse combined with southern sun.
lead_paragraph: Of all the elements that go into producing great wine, one of the most crucial is also one of the most overlooked, except by those who provide it: sweat.

headline: A Malevolent Consort, Utterly in Command
abstract: Anna Netrebko makes her long-awaited debut as the scheming wife in “Macbeth,” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: For months, there had been so much buzz over how Anna Netrebko would fare this season when she sang Lady Macbeth for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, you would have thought that she was a highly anticipated newcomer rather than a house favorite who had sung there 134 times since 2002.

headline: What Becomes a Woman Most?
abstract: For Ari Seth Cohen, older women, their individuality on parade, have become an obsession and the subject of photographs, a blog and now a documentary.
lead_paragraph: “I saw all these incredibly dressed older women on the streets,” says Ari Seth Cohen, a photographer who recalls being very close to his grandmothers. His photos inspired a blog, a book and now a documentary, “Advanced Style.” Simon Doonan, the fashion pundit, calls Mr. Cohen’s concept “quite anarchic,” so it must be fabulous.

headline: A Stubborn Mother and Her Supplicant
abstract: “Lilting” centers on a young man’s attempts to communicate with a Cambodian-Chinese woman whose son, who recently died, was his lover.
lead_paragraph: The lachrymose British drama “Lilting” pivots on the prickly relationship between two people who are mourning a third. Junn (Cheng Pei Pei) is a Cambodian-Chinese woman who can’t understand English, and Richard (Ben Whishaw) is a plaster saint who struggles and struggles to be understood. With infinite patience, moist eyes and trembling lips and lashes, Richard attempts to overcome the differences — linguistic, cultural, generational and temperamental — between him and Junn, who doesn’t grasp that he also loved her dead son, Kai (Andrew Leung).

headline: Ad Attacks Skinny-Dipping Congressman
abstract: A new ad attacks Representative Kevin Yoder of Kansas for skinny-dipping in Israel last year.
lead_paragraph: A new ad from Kelly Kultala, a Democrat running for Congress in Kansas, fleshes out the issues facing the state while also criticizing her opponent for some high jinks on an overseas congressional trip.

headline: A Brother’s Betrayal, in Darkly Comic Tones
abstract: “It Was You Charlie,” written and directed by Emmanuel Shirinian, focuses on a man whose dream woman is wooed by his brother.
lead_paragraph: Abner Roth (Michael D. Cohen) has a birthday tradition: Every year, he and his brother, Tom (Aaron Abrams), go to see “On the Waterfront” at the Fox Theater in Toronto. (You presume that the movie house knows to program that film every year.) Like Marlon Brando’s character, Abner feels the sting of his brother’s betrayal. The day he turns 40, Abner learns that Tom is dating the love of Abner’s life, Madeleine (Anna Hopkins).

headline: Who Speaks for Dying Patients?
abstract: Doctors and others respond to an Op-Ed article, “When Medicine Is Futile.”

headline: France Proposes Tough Antismoking Measures
abstract: The rules to be submitted to Parliament include plain packages for cigarettes and restricting the public use of e-cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government on Thursday announced a plan to curb smoking that would introduce plain packaging for cigarettes, ban smoking on playgrounds and make it harder to use electronic cigarettes in certain public settings.

headline: Playing at the New York Film Festival
abstract: Images of films in the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Images of films in the New York Film Festival.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Rick Owens Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Trailer: New York Film Festival
abstract: A preview of films playing in the 52nd New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: A preview of films playing in the 52nd New York Film Festival.

headline: A Four-Work Leap Into the Forefront of Classical Ballet
abstract: A Balanchine-Tchaikovsky four-work program makes a case for the company’s position as the foremost of its kind in the world.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday evening, New York City Ballet, in a quadruple bill of works choreographed to Tchaikovsky music by its co-founder George Balanchine, and plunging its audience into the quintessence of classical ballet, strongly suggested that it has again become the world’s foremost ballet company. And perhaps the best news is that the troupe’s orchestra, led on this occasion by Clotilde Otranto, played the Tchaikovsky scores with a greater tonal beauty and eloquence of phrasing than I have heard from it. These scores are familiar, but the evening had moments when phrases seized the heart anew.

headline: A Music Lover Down to His Roots
abstract: “This Ain’t No Mouse Music!” tells of Chris Strachwitz and his Arhoolie Records, which released stars of blues, zydeco and other roots music.
lead_paragraph: THIS AIN’T NO MOUSE MUSIC!

headline: With a Loss, the Mets Are Guaranteed a Losing Record for the Sixth Straight Season
abstract: The Mets’ 3-0 loss to the Washington Nationals Thursday night, in the second game of a doubleheader, guaranteed that they would end with a losing record for the sixth straight season.
lead_paragraph: Someday, the Mets will finish above .500 again. But not this year. Instead, their 3-0 loss to the Washington Nationals on Thursday night, in the second game of a doubleheader, guaranteed that they would end with a losing record for the sixth straight season.

headline: Lessons by a Master and Teacher
abstract: A Steve Coleman set like the one at the Stone on Tuesday night can be a mental workout.
lead_paragraph: Steve Coleman began his early set at the Stone on Tuesday night with bright, slow, clear, solo alto-saxophone lines. They were rhythmic and unresolving, dealt out mostly in short or modest-length notes, and sounded like a teacher giving a demonstration.

headline: Frieze Art Fair Founders Step Aside for a New Director
abstract: Victoria Siddall will become director of the Frieze art fairs in New York and London; the co-founders Amanda Sharp and Matthew Slotover will “explore new projects for Frieze.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a surprise move, Frieze art fair announced on Thursday that in 2015 Victoria Siddall will become director of Frieze London and Frieze New York.

headline: Grab Some Popcorn, Settle Down, Start Debating
abstract: Opening with “Gone Girl,” the New York Film Festival includes a 3-D film by Godard and many other provocative titles.
lead_paragraph: Each of the world’s major film festivals has a special flavor and purpose. Some arrange the crown jewels of world cinema in a fancy European setting. Others line up horses for the Oscar race or parade indie darlings through the snow. The New York Film Festival, whose 52nd edition begins on Friday, takes its name and inspiration from the world capital of talk, and its clear and consistent ambition has been to start as many arguments as possible.

headline: You Can Make It Here, You Can Make It Anywhere
abstract: The documentary “Print the Legend” follows tech-savvy entrepreneurs in the world of 3-D printers.
lead_paragraph: PRINT THE LEGEND

headline: When Mortgage Rates Rise
abstract: Mortgage rates have remained relatively low this year, and little changed, despite previous predictions of an inevitable rise. But how long will this last?
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates have remained relatively low this year, and little changed, despite previous predictions of an inevitable rise. Borrowers, though, may be wondering how much longer this environment can last.

headline: The Dismal Science
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In “Seven Bad Ideas,” Jeff Madrick argues that the failure of economists to address the 2008 financial crisis is rooted in decades of intellectual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: The economics profession has not, to say the least, covered itself in glory these past six years. Hardly any economists predicted the 2008 crisis — and the handful who did tended to be people who also predicted crises that didn’t happen. More significant, many and arguably most economists were claiming, right up to the moment of collapse, that nothing like this could even happen.

headline: A Radical Response
abstract: In “The Shifts and the Shocks,” Martin Wolf proposes drastic measures to try to prevent another financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Martin Wolf is as grand and important as an economic journalist can ever become. A respected economist in his own right, Wolf has had top-level access to economic policy makers for decades now, seeing generations of finance ministers and central bank governors come and go. All of them care, deeply, about what he thinks and what he writes, and they tend to spend as much time as they can trying to persuade him of their point of view. The result is a classic virtuous cycle: He’s well informed because he’s extremely influential, and he’s influential because he’s extremely well informed.

headline: At Carven, Snakeskin Mary Janes With a Racing Stripe
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Flats that were sweet, yet full of surprises.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: A Titan of Blues, Folk and Rock
abstract: “Harlem Street Singer” examines the evolution of a music legend.
lead_paragraph: HARLEM STREET SINGER

headline: Attention Must Be Paid
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: A journalist examines a deadly accident and the risks of texting and driving.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Shaw is the man responsible for the most moving portion of “From One Second to the Next,” the director Werner Herzog’s excruciating (even by Werner Herzog standards) 35-minute public service announcement, released last year as part of AT&T’s “It Can Wait” campaign against texting and driving. In the film, Shaw, now in his 20s, recounts the rainy morning in September 2006 that he crossed the line of a Utah highway, knocking into a car containing two scientists, James Furfaro and Keith O’Dell, who were heading to work nearby. Both men were killed. Shaw says he was ­texting a girlfriend at the time, adding in unmistakable anguish that he can’t even ­remember what he was texting about. He is next seen taking part in something almost inconceivable: He enters the scene where one of the dead men’s daughters is being interviewed, and receives from that woman a warm, earnest, tearful, cathartic hug.

headline: A Tour Guide Goes Above and Beyond
abstract: “The Two Faces of January” is based on a 1964 Patricia Highsmith novel about two affluent American tourists vacationing in Europe.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to read the first exchange of looks that sets “The Two Faces of January” down its satisfying, shivering path. The vacationing American tourist, Chester MacFarland (Viggo Mortensen), is walking around the Acropolis with his wife, Colette (Kirsten Dunst), when he notices the other man observing him. It’s a glorious day, and the Americans are, true to the early 1960s time frame and their station, formally attired. She’s wearing a dress and hat, and carrying gloves and a purse. He’s wearing a tie, a three-piece suit, a straw hat and a pair of very dark glasses.

headline: No Pain, No Game
abstract: Has our passion for football made us blind to the sport’s dark side?
lead_paragraph: “The libertine,” wrote Simone de Beauvoir, “in hurting the object that serves him, ‘tastes all the pleasures which a vigorous individual feels in making full use of his strength; he dominates, he is a tyrant.’ ” She was quoting, indirectly and then directly, the Marquis de Sade.

headline: A Visionary’s Mark Is Still Being Seen
abstract: “What Would Mrs. Webb Do? A Founder’s Vision” details the career of the influential arts patron Aileen Osborn Webb.
lead_paragraph: Ignore the cheeky title, with its official hashtag (#WWMWD). “What Would Mrs. Webb Do? A Founder’s Vision,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, is a traditional and slightly stuffy complement to the manic, over-designed exhibition “Makers,” in the last few weeks of its run on two other floors of the museum.

headline: Recapturing the Spirit of That California Sound
abstract: The actress Rita Wilson, who released her debut album in 2012, performs through Oct. 4 at the Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: If you attended Rita Wilson’s opening night show at the Café Carlyle on Wednesday evening and closed your eyes at certain moments you could imagine you were cruising down a Southern California highway in the early 1970s. Sandwiched between the music of Joni Mitchell and Jackson Browne on the car radio was a promising new voice whose sound fit right in with theirs. Maybe that voice wasn’t as strong or as distinctive but it embodied the “laid-back” (pardon the vintage slang) spirit of soft rock from lotus land at a moment when the California dream still beckoned like a mirage.

headline: Tubercular or Penniless, They’ll Always Have Paris
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s performances of Franco Zeffirelli’s “La Bohème” resumed on Tuesday with a fresh cast configuration.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s production of “La Bohème,” Puccini’s masterpiece of emotional manipulation, is like any institution: it transcends the people, good or bad, who move through it. Before this season’s revival closes in January, the show, originally staged in 1981 by Franco Zeffirelli, will have gone through at least five cast configurations, and it’s teeming and colorful enough to survive any and all of them.

headline: A Potential Disaster in Any Language
abstract: “Gaïa Global Circus” is a thoughtful climate-change play by Pierre Daubigny, performed almost entirely in French with English supertitles.
lead_paragraph: He’s a modern-day Noah, looking to ride out the next great flood in an ark made of rotting plastic. Small balloons tethered to his jacket float jauntily above his head as he applies for a loan to build the boat. Turned down, he vows to go straight to the people.

headline: Ferguson Police Chief’s Sad Excuse for an Apology
abstract: If this is his idea of a conversation, I’d hate to see his idea of an argument.
lead_paragraph: It took four hours for the police in Ferguson, Mo., to remove the body of Michael Brown, the unarmed teenager killed by a police officer, from the street where it lay. It took the police chief nearly seven weeks to issue an apology to Mr. Brown’s family. His videotaped comment was late, oddly staged and very unclear about what exactly he was apologizing for and why (apart from perhaps a desire to keep his job).

headline: The Pleasure of Being a Difficult Woman
abstract: Self-effacing in person, Romola Garai, making her New York theater debut in Tom Stoppard’s “Indian Ink,” is drawn to strong-willed characters on the stage and screen.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in the backyard of a Brooklyn coffee shop, the British actress Romola Garai apologized, sincerely and often — for repeating herself, for liking poetry, for criticizing sexism in the entertainment industry. “Sorry,” she said. “This is so boring.”

headline: A Prodigal Son of Jazz Returns to Pay a Visit
abstract: The pianist Kirk Lightsey made a rare appearance in New York at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday, showing audiences what they’ve been missing.
lead_paragraph: “Wow, it’s been so long since I’ve been in this place,” the pianist Kirk Lightsey said after taking the stage at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. Surveying the room, he chortled, wearing a look of beatific astonishment. He introduced the members of his quartet, and then restated the obvious: “I’m so happy to be back in town; I’m just giddy.”

headline: Masters of Charity (and Deception)
abstract: “Believe Me,” directed by Will Bakke, wades into an ethical conundrum involving faith-based fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: BELIEVE ME

headline: Punch Lines, Reverberating in the Ruins
abstract: An exhibition of photographs at the Yeshiva University Museum depicts the tattered remains of Catskills hotels where many Jews vacationed in the postwar period.
lead_paragraph: Some 20 years ago, whenever the self-styled King of Simon Says (a.k.a. Allan Tresser) performed in the Catskills, he would display a pasteboard panel boasting of his television credits: As seen on “The Jack Paar Show”! And “Wonderama”! And ... well, I forget the rest, but not the idea: The king’s prime was decades past. And the billing presumed a similar vintage for his listeners as they prepared to obey whatever Simon Says — or doesn’t. But if Mr. Tresser had long since peaked, hadn’t the Fallsview Hotel of Ellenville, N.Y., in which he was resident tummler, also seen far better years? And the Nevele? And Kutsher’s? The last was celebrated in an elegiac 2012 documentary, “Welcome to Kutsher’s: The Last Catskills Resort,” which is being updated in December with a final section chronicling the hotel’s demolition to make way for a yoga retreat. In the 1980s, when films like “Dirty Dancing” or “Sweet Lorraine” were set in such hotels, they were already relics from another era.

headline: Interview: John Ridley
abstract: The writer and director John Ridley discusses his film “Jimi: All Is By My Side.”
lead_paragraph: The writer and director John Ridley discusses his film “Jimi: All Is By My Side.”

headline: Looking for Comedy In All the Wrong Places
abstract: The dancers Jeremy Wade and Mark Tompkins presented their improvised work “Stardust” at the Queer New York International Arts Festival.
lead_paragraph: In the underground theater of the Abrons Arts Center on Wednesday, all the right ingredients seemed to have been assembled for an evening of fun and maybe of magic. There was a fog machine, a wind machine, a rack of outré clothing. There were two microphones, two laptops stocked with music. Most important, there were two performers experienced in the risk-taking of improvisation.

headline: The Year When the Guitar Licks Ignited
abstract: “Jimi: All Is by My Side,” a biopic about the musician Jimi Hendrix, is set in 1966, when his popularity was on the verge of exploding.
lead_paragraph: A kaleidoscopic, impressionistic portrait of the artist as a far-out genius, “Jimi: All Is by My Side” doesn’t profess to be either the first or last word on James Marshall Hendrix. Rather, it looks at the year he went from discovery to detonation. It happened fast: In 1966, Hendrix — played with dreamy reserve here by André Benjamin, a.k.a. André 3000 of Outkast — was a cool cat who was calling himself Jimmy James and playing with Curtis Knight and the Squires, an R&B band. The following year he was off to London, where after changing his name and threads, he emerged as the star child Jimi Hendrix.

headline: A Career of Toasting Rebellions
abstract: “Dear Nemesis, Nicole Eisenman 1993-2013,” at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia, showcases Ms. Eisenman’s variety of interests and styles.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Queer is here to stay. So are feminism, art history, unruly flesh, anarchic laughter and painting. You’ll find them all in “Dear Nemesis, Nicole Eisenman 1993-2013,” at the Institute of Contemporary Art here, a spicy and tightly edited midcareer survey of one of the most interesting New York artists to come out of the 1990s.

headline: Sharing a Sofa With Dinosaurs
abstract: Richard McGuire’s comic “Here” becomes a full-length book, previewed at an exhibition at the Morgan Library and Museum.
lead_paragraph: GETTING from here to there can be hard enough. But it has taken Richard McGuire 25 years to do something even more complicated: get from here to here.

headline: The Story Behind Manhattan’s Original Fine-Dining Chinese Restaurant
abstract: Shun Lee Palace opened on East 55th Street in 1971 and introduced New Yorkers to the fancier side of Yangzhou-Sichuan and Shanghai cooking.
lead_paragraph: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: Chrysler Recalls 349,000 Vehicles for Faulty Ignition Switch
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The latest recall affects 2008 vehicles, including the Jeep Commander and Grand Cherokee S.U.V.s.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler announced on Thursday that it would recall 349,442 vehicles worldwide for faulty ignition switches that could cause cars to suddenly turn off while driving, adding to the recent wave of automobile recalls related to ignition problems.

headline: Underground Folk, Foraging for a Home
abstract: The stop-motion animation studio Laika (“Coraline,” “ParaNorman”) adapts a children’s book by Alan Snow.
lead_paragraph: In “The Boxtrolls,” old-fashioned stop-motion animation is combined with new-style 3-D cinematography to charming effect. The film, based on the book “Here Be Monsters!” by Alan Snow, tells a familiar story with familiar themes and characters — misunderstood monsters; a repulsive villain with comical henchmen; a hero with an identity crisis — but it does so with refreshing wit and energy. At times it might be a little dark and scary for the very youngest viewers, but their slightly older siblings are likely to appreciate the way this movie balances the silly and the sinister, the creepy and the cute, the nasty and the nice. Adults may also find themselves amused. This one did, at any rate.

headline: Made in the U.S.A., but Banked Overseas
abstract: Multinational companies avoid United States taxes largely by claiming that much of their income is earned in countries where taxes are low or nonexistent.
lead_paragraph: Imagine how frustrating it would be to have billions of dollars in cash but be unable to spend it as you wish unless you paid a large part to the Internal Revenue Service.

abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Finding Humane Care at the End of Life
abstract: What can be done to insure that the elderly get the care they want and need, particularly in their dying days?

headline: Spare Times for Sept. 26-Oct. 2
abstract: A selected guide to exhibitions, readings and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Chile Pepper Festival and Harvest Festival (Saturday) This 22nd annual celebration of the sweet and sassy capsicums at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden is a sure sign that harvest time is here. Red, yellow and green beauties are the stars, along with the spicy chocolates and hot sauces in which they appear. Tasting is encouraged, as well as listening to music ranging from Cajun tunes to Latin American dance rhythms.

headline: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: The Fascists were in town for a little good-will tour in late September 1934. It didn’t go well.
lead_paragraph: 80 YEARS AGO

headline: Heroically Handy With a Corkscrew
abstract: “The Equalizer” stars Denzel Washington as a seemingly bookish man who turns out to be an assassin on behalf of the wronged.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the best thing about “The Equalizer” is how long it takes to reveal what everyone watching it knows from the start. Directed by Antoine Fuqua and starring Denzel Washington, the movie was inspired by a 1980s television series about an elite C.I.A. assassin (played by Edward Woodward) who found a second career as a freelance vigilante, specializing in payback and in pre-emptive violence in defense of the innocent. Each bit of information in the previous sentence — to say nothing of the trailers and advertisements — is a clue that Mr. Washington’s character, Robert McCall, is not the bookish, solitary Boston guy he at first seems to be.

headline: A Side Dish of Confusion in Board Fight at Darden Restaurants
abstract: The owner of Olive Garden trumpeted the support of Egan-Jones in a press release, but the proxy adviser soon removed the report from its website.
lead_paragraph: The fierce battle for control of the board of Darden Restaurants heated up on Thursday, while also gaining an element of confusion.

headline: How Does Islam Relate to Christianity and Judaism?
abstract: Are they rivals, complementary developments or different expressions of a similar religious experience?
lead_paragraph: This is the 11th in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Sajjad Rizvi, a professor of Arab and Islamic studies at the University of Exeter and the author of “Mulla Sadra and the Later Islamic Philosophical Tradition.”

lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Teaching Parents to Help Stop the ‘Summer Slide’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: A program called Springboard helps low-income parents get involved and make a difference in their children’s education.
lead_paragraph: Last summer was the second one Tayonna Taylor, an incoming second-grader, spent working with a reading tutor: her mother. Tayonna, who wears glasses and had the sniffles, sat with her mother, Tasia Carlton, in late July in Emily Roggie’s classroom in Wissahickon Charter School in northwest Philadelphia.

headline: Sequoia Capital Returns to Investing in Brazil
abstract: Just a little more than a year after pulling back from South America, the firm has led a new $13.8 million round in Nubank, a financial services start-up led by one of its former executives.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Sequoia Capital, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, is bringing money back to Brazil.

headline: A Cause Unites Unlikely Partners in South Wales
abstract: “Pride” brings to film the true 1980s story of when gay activists chose to support union miners in Thatcher’s Britain.
lead_paragraph: The classic union anthem “Solidarity Forever,” sung by Pete Seeger, introduces “Pride,” a stirring film about the uneasy coalition of British mineworkers and gay and lesbian activists during a labor strike in the mid-1980s. Directed by Matthew Warchus (“Matilda the Musical”), it is the kind of hearty, blunt-force drama with softened edges that leaves audiences applauding and teary-eyed.

lead_paragraph: Gay men have fled Nigeria and sought asylum in the United States, settling into a Brooklyn residence where they seek to live freely and openly.

headline: Politics Helpline: History Between White House Intruder and Secret Service
abstract: Yes, the Secret Service was told of Omar Gonzalez’s previous arrest.
lead_paragraph: As part of our ongoing political helpline, we’re taking questions and answering them as fast as we can. A reader asked:

headline: Pakistan: Police Investigator Survives Attack in Karachi
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Improvised Explosive Devices']
abstract: A senior police investigator survived an assassination attempt on Thursday in Karachi after a bomb blast hit his convoy, police officials said.
lead_paragraph: A senior police investigator survived an assassination attempt on Thursday in Karachi after a bomb hit his convoy, police officials said. The investigator, Farooq Awan, a senior superintendent who leads a unit that tracks terrorists and militants, was wounded, as were seven other people, and a civilian passer-by was killed. Police officials said that according to an initial investigation, a vehicle filled with explosives was detonated by remote control as the convoy passed. Jundullah, a militant group that operates mostly in Karachi, claimed responsibility, according to local news media reports. Mr. Awan has been involved in the arrests of several high-profile militants, including Omar Saeed Sheikh, who was convicted in the 2002 killing of Daniel Pearl, a Wall Street Journal correspondent.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Sept. 26
abstract: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes scenes from the People’s Climate March and the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: A slide show from the past week in New York City and the region includes scenes from the People’s Climate March and the United Nations.

headline: One Small-Timer Finds His Posse
abstract: In “Hellaware,” Keith Poulson is a poseur photographer who makes a poseur band his muse.
lead_paragraph: HELLAWARE

headline: France Asks Veto Wielders to Stay Their Hands
abstract: When mass atrocities are involved, France proposes, it and the other four permanent members of the Security Council should refrain from using their veto powers, which too often prevent the council from taking any action.
lead_paragraph: Each of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council has always had a diplomatic weapon as powerful as the thunderbolt of Zeus: a veto over any measure it doesn’t like. The most common targets are draft resolutions that threaten the member’s national interests or those of its most vital allies.

headline: Eric Holder to Step Down
abstract: Eric H. Holder Jr., the first African-American to serve as United States attorney general, announced his resignation in a ceremony at the White House.
lead_paragraph: Eric H. Holder Jr., the first African-American to serve as United States attorney general, announced his resignation in a ceremony at the White House.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Sept. 26, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Equalizer,” “The Boxtrolls” and “Gone Girl.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Equalizer,” “The Boxtrolls” and “Gone Girl.”

headline: Parliament in Indonesia Rolls Back Election Rights
abstract: The outgoing Parliament unexpectedly passed legislation early Friday eliminating direct elections for provincial governors, district chiefs and mayors.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s outgoing Parliament unexpectedly passed legislation early Friday eliminating direct elections for provincial governors, district chiefs and mayors, a move denounced by critics as a major setback for the country’s democratic transition and a naked power grab by its wounded political elite.

headline: Clip: ‘Hellaware’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Drone Exemptions for Hollywood Pave the Way for Widespread Use
abstract: The decision by the Federal Aviation Administration has implications for industries like agriculture, energy and online retailing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The commercial use of drones in American skies took a leap forward on Thursday with the help of Hollywood.

headline: A Call to Action Against a Predator Fish With an Import Ban, an App and Even Rodeos
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Invasive Species', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Reefs', 'Marine Biology']
abstract: With gluttonous lionfish wreaking havoc on delicate reefs and fish stocks, Florida officials have banned imports of the fish and are encouraging spearfishing “rodeos” in vulnerable areas.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — They eat anything that fits in their mouths. They reproduce copiously and adapt effortlessly. And they have become as ubiquitous and pesky as rats — only prettier and more conniving.

headline: Woman Hides Camera to Reveal Life Under Islamic State Rule
abstract: A woman in Raqqa, Syria, documented life under Islamic State rule by concealing a camera in the folds of the cloak she is compelled to wear.
lead_paragraph: Before an American-led coalition launched airstrikes on Islamic State militants in the Syrian city of Raqqa this week, a female student there documented life under Islamist rule by concealing a video camera in the folds of the full-length cloak she has been compelled to wear since the fundamentalists seized control.

headline: With Whimsy, Burt’s Bees Introduces Its First TV Campaign
abstract: The ads for the 30-year-old personal care brand are its first ever for TV and highlight an expanding line of flavored lip balms.
lead_paragraph: LIP balms, as the names of some of the older products in the category make clear, were historically marketed to treat ailments: ChapStick, introduced around 1912, was for chapping, and Blistex, introduced in 1947, was for blisters and sores.

headline: As Era Ends, Derek Jeter’s Fans Fill the Seats, No Matter the Cost
abstract: Derek Jeter mania has been kindling in New York as the incomparable shortstop approached his final games, at Yankee Stadium on Thursday and at Fenway Park in Boston on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Being a baseball fan is like going on a diet or practicing politics: There are several different levels of extremity.

headline: U.S. Music Sales Drop 5%, as Habits Shift Online
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Royalties']
abstract: A drop in downloads and CD sales has so far not been offset by a boom in online streaming.
lead_paragraph: As the music industry evolves, there has been no doubt that online streaming services like Spotify, Pandora and YouTube are growing fast, and generating more revenue for artists and record companies.

headline: In Chile, an Animal Whose Numbers Please No One
abstract: Government-sanctioned culling of the guanaco in Tierra del Fuego has drawn opposition from animal rights activists and tourism officials.
lead_paragraph: CERRO SOMBRERO, Chile — The guidebooks for Tierra del Fuego somehow fail to mention the gunfire.

headline: Francis Removes Bishop Under Cloud in Paraguay
abstract: Some see the pope meting out discipline after an era plagued by misconduct and cover-ups, though the target of the dismissal protested the handling of related circumstances.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In another sign of his willingness to exert discipline in the church hierarchy, Pope Francis removed a conservative bishop in Paraguay on Thursday who was seen as a renegade by his fellow bishops and had sheltered a priest accused of molesting seminarians in several countries.

headline: Man Faces Second Trial in Killing of Florida Teenager
abstract: Michael Dunn faced a second set of jurors on Thursday, who will decide whether he fired in self-defense or murdered Jordan Davis during a dispute over loud music.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Nearly eight months after a jury here deadlocked over his guilt in the killing of an unarmed teenager, Michael Dunn faced a second set of jurors on Thursday who will decide whether he fired a gun in self-defense or murdered the teenager during a dispute over loud rap music booming from a parked car.

lead_paragraph: Liberals talk about circumstances; conservatives talk about character.

headline: A Murky Process Yields Cleaner Professional Records for Stockbrokers
abstract: A rare look into the way that clients’ complaints are expunged showed that regulators can be quick to dismiss negative marks from brokers’ records, even when investors fight back.
lead_paragraph: As a former stockbroker whose regulatory file included 41 customer complaints and a job termination, Kathleen J. Tarr was concerned that her reputation had been hurt by accusations that she had disputed. So, like an increasing number of brokers, she sought to have some negative information expunged from her record.

headline: Eric Holder’s Legacy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The attorney general took some laudable positions, but his record is marred by the role he played in matters of secrecy and national security.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, the nearly-six-year tenure of Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. has been one of the most consequential in United States history. His decision to resign, which he announced on Thursday, was long anticipated; he has said he will stay on through his successor’s confirmation. It is hard to imagine that anyone who could make it through the current Senate would have an impact comparable to Mr. Holder’s.

headline: The Good Order
keywords: ['Creativity', 'Books and Literature', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The arduous work of imposing order is critical to success in any realm, from the international state system to one’s own mind.
lead_paragraph: When she was writing, Maya Angelou would get up every morning at 5:30 and have coffee at 6. At 6:30, she would go off to a hotel room she kept — a small modest room with nothing but a bed, desk, Bible, dictionary, deck of cards and bottle of sherry. She would arrive at the room at 7 a.m. and write until 12:30 p.m. or 2 o’clock.

headline: With Climbing Graduation Rates Come Renewed Doubts
abstract: In a decade, Texas has gone from an example of the nation’s dropout crisis to the second-highest graduation rate in the country. But that climb has not been matched by success in measures of college and career readiness.

As the state weathered scandals over the way some districts calculated graduation rates, it became identified in national reports as the epicenter for chronically underperforming schools known as “dropout factories.”

headline: Obama Expands Marine Preserve in Pacific, Making It World’s Largest
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: President Obama signed a proclamation expanding a protected marine reserve in the Pacific Ocean, putting a total of 370,000 square nautical miles off limits to commercial fishing.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Thursday signed a proclamation expanding a protected marine reserve in the Pacific Ocean, putting a total of 370,000 square nautical miles off limits to commercial fishing. The designation makes the Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument six times larger than it was and will protect the coral reefs and unique marine ecosystems threatened by fishing and the effects of climate change. Mr. Obama’s action creates the largest marine reserve in the world and builds on his efforts to deal with environmental issues through executive action in the face of stiff Republican opposition in Congress.

headline: The Brains and Braun of Dieter Rams
abstract: A look at the facts and figures behind this designer’s work.
lead_paragraph: Chances are if you’ve shaved with an electric razor, blow-dried your hair or sparked up a cigarette in the past 60 years, you owe a debt of gratitude to Dieter Rams. During his four-plus decades working for Braun, many of which he also spent creating furniture for the British company Vitsoe, the German designer, 82, made a staggering number of stripped-down home goods and gadgets, many of which are as relevant now as the day they were conceived. Case in point: The same modular 606 Universal Shelving System bought in 1960 can still be seamlessly added to today and is as coveted by design aficionados as ever. But it is his ability to both inspire and confound successors like Jasper Morrison and Apple’s Jonathan Ive — spurred on by his prophetic principles of good design — that may be his greatest legacy. Describing Rams’s humble CSV 12 amplifier rotary switch in the foreword to the book “Dieter Rams: As Little Design as Possible,” Ive writes, “It could not be better, simpler, clearer or more beautiful.” In other words, less, but so much more.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) ‘SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET’ IN CONCERT WITH THE NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC “Live From Lincoln Center” kicks off its 40th-anniversary season with Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s musical thriller, starring the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel as the bloodthirsty barber and the British actress Emma Thompson as the adoring pie maker Mrs. Lovett. “There are trade-offs in seeing ‘Sweeney Todd’ in concert, of course,” Charles Isherwood wrote in The New York Times about this production, conducted by Alan Gilbert. “The plot’s intricate comings and goings are not easy to delineate clearly, and the horrific action is impossible without a full stage of scenery.” But “the upside to seeing (or rather, hearing) ‘Sweeney’ played by a world-class orchestra made up for such awkwardness,” he added. “Mr. Sondheim’s score seems to grow more majestic each time you hear it (and more boisterous with raucous good-bad spirits), and the forward thrust of the drama as it reels into nightmare territory remains a model of musical theater writing.” Johnny Depp takes on the title role and Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett in Tim Burton’s film version, at 1:45 p.m. on IFC.

abstract: Jobs newly advertised to civil servant applicants in Shanghai contain many criteria based on age, height, gender or where a person is officially registered, leading to a protest from a labor rights group.
lead_paragraph: Want to work as an assistant science educator at the Shanghai Science and Technology Museum, a civil service position? You must be “normal size,” according to a website for government jobs in Shanghai. That means a height of 160 to 175 centimeters (5-foot-3 to 5-foot-9) for women and 170 to 185 centimeters (5-foot-7 to 6 feet) for men.

headline: 1930: Mickey Mouse, Censored
abstract: Many first references in The Times to Mickey Mouse involved censorship of the character.
lead_paragraph: He was only a 2-year-old, but as any parent knows, a 2-year-old can land in plenty of trouble. On Nov. 16, 1930, the first article by The Times about Mickey Mouse carried the terse headline: “The Censor!”

headline: Bananas Merger Accord Revised by Chiquita and Fyffes
abstract: In an effort to fend off a rival bid, Chiquita shareholders would have 59.6 percent of the merged entity under the new terms, up from 50.7 percent.
lead_paragraph: When it was announced in March, Chiquita Brands International’s proposed acquisition of Fyffes of Ireland looked like a deft move.

headline: Today In Politics
abstract: How big a fight will President Obama put up over Attorney General Eric Holder’s successor? The question is captivating Washington.
lead_paragraph: Obama Could Push for Lame-Duck Approval of Attorney General

headline: Examining the Amazon Way
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Amazon’s accomplishments are dwarfed only by its ambitions. A former executive talks about the potential and the perils as the retailer enters its third decade, as well as why the dispute with Hachette is so important.
lead_paragraph: John Rossman, an executive at Amazon in the early 2000s, has written “The Amazon Way,” about the 14 leadership principles that drive the retailer, including obsessing over the customer, hiring and developing the best, and practicing frugality.

headline: Morning Agenda: Yahoo’s Decision Point
abstract: Yahoo is at a crossroad after Alibaba’s I.P.O. | Murky process dresses up stockbrokers’ records. | Wall St. still needs a leader on reform. | Battle over Darden’s board heats up.
lead_paragraph: YAHOO’S DECISION POINT | What’s next for Yahoo? After it sold shares worth $6 billion after taxes in the Alibaba Group, which went public last week, the once-mighty Internet giant is at a crossroad, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles write. Yahoo could use the proceeds from the Alibaba share sale to go on an acquisition spree to help reinvent itself and regain relevance. But the company’s previous takeover efforts have yielded few obvious gains, leaving shareholders more eager to receive the bulk of the cash rather than see it used for acquisitions.

headline: NYTLNreads | Recommendations From Students in an Online Course at Roosevelt University
abstract: Some recommendations from the students of Jan Bone, an 83-year-old New York Times reader who has been teaching for 42 years — the last two online.
lead_paragraph: We recently introduced a new feature, NYTLNreads, and are inviting teachers and students everywhere to participate by simply telling us what you’ve been reading in The Times recently, and why you’d recommend it to others.

headline: Pynchon’s Cameo, and Other Surrealities
abstract: One mystery in “Inherent Vice,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s adaptation of a Thomas Pynchon novel, is whether the author makes an appearance.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through a long lunch at Tavern on the Green on a sunny September day, the trim, tanned filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson, dressed in a Southern California beach bum’s uniform — Quiksilver shorts, faded blue T-shirt, crumpled white bucket hat — went silent. Mr. Anderson, 44, had been asked a simple question: Does Thomas Pynchon, the reclusive author of “Gravity’s Rainbow,” “Mason & Dixon” and “The Crying of Lot 49,” make an on-screen cameo in Mr. Anderson’s “Inherent Vice,” the first movie adapted from one of the writer’s celebrated novels?

headline: Something in Common With His Mentor
abstract: The rising pianist Justin Kauflin talks about this mentor, the trumpeter Clark Terry, and a documentary detailing their relationship.
lead_paragraph: “Dear Justin,” an elderly man recites, “challenges are a part of life, as you know. Your mind is a powerful asset. Use it for positive thoughts and you’ll learn what I learned. I believe in your talents and I believe in you.”

headline: No Longer Lost, He’s Taking the Lead
abstract: As “The Good Lie,” a film about Lost Boys who begin new lives in America, finally opens, one of the actors reflects on his own long, strange trip from Sudan.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — By the age of 14, Ger Duany had wandered barefoot for hundreds of miles through his native Sudan, spent four years in Ethiopian refugee camps and fought as a child soldier. On one occasion, he walked for so long that all his toenails fell off; on another, he fled from soldiers by swimming across a river choked with corpses. But Mr. Duany, one of thousands of so-called Lost Boys left homeless by a Sudanese civil war that began in the 1980s, isn’t one to complain.

headline: They Say Goodbye. We Say Hello.
abstract: “The Big Chill,” out in a new dual-edition release, may have set out to lament the end of the hippie era but in some ways celebrated the arrival of the yuppie age instead.
lead_paragraph: Some movies are born significant, some achieve significance, and some have significance thrust upon them — not always in the way their makers would have wished. An intended lament for the death of the hippie, “The Big Chill” (1983), directed and written (with Barbara Benedek) by Lawrence Kasdan, celebrated the birth of the yuppie instead.

headline: Bollywood Is Prancing Far Abroad
abstract: Bollywood films are gaining a foothold in many international markets, but Britain and the United States remain elusive.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Shah Rukh Khan has many titles. The 48-year-old Bollywood superstar is known as King Khan, King of Bollywood and Bollywood Badshah (or emperor). This summer Mr. Khan became a knight. In a glittering ceremony in Mumbai, the French foreign affairs minister, Laurent Fabius, conferred France’s highest civilian honor — the Knight of the Legion of Honor — on Mr. Khan. In the official news release, Mr. Fabius said, “The French people hail Shah Rukh Khan’s talent and generosity,” which transcend “cultural and historical differences.”

headline: BlackBerry Posts a Loss, but Shows Signs of Life
abstract: The company stressed its new focus on services and software for business, despite unveiling the Passport, an unusual new smartphone, just two days earlier.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Two days after unveiling its latest attempt to rekindle interest in its smartphones, BlackBerry announced a $207 million second-quarter loss on Friday.

headline: Wheelchair Bus Choreography
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A passenger marvels as the simple act of using a wheelchair ramp on the bus, once a contentious subject, proceeds like clockwork.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hold the Farewell Cake. Holder Is Fighting On.
abstract: Eric H. Holder Jr. has resigned as attorney general, but he’s in no hurry to go anywhere.
lead_paragraph: Don’t give Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. a cardboard box just yet. Though he is resigning, he says he is in no rush to pack his things and head for the door.

headline: Bill Gross, King of Bonds, Abruptly Leaves Mutual Fund Giant Pimco
abstract: William H. Gross, who built Pimco into one of the largest money managers in the world and has been called the Bond King, has quit the firm he founded and will join Janus Capital.
lead_paragraph: The bond king heard rumblings of a palace coup.

headline: Lykke Li on U2, Heartbreak and Washing Her Undies
abstract: The Swedish indie pop singer spoke during a break from her tour to support her latest album, “I Never Learn.” A remix of the album track “Gunshot” appears exclusively here.
lead_paragraph: Since bursting on the scene with her 2008 album “Youth Novels,” the Swedish chanteuse Lykke Li has carved out a niche with her mix of pulsating beats, hypnotic rhythms and coquettish vocals. But 2014 is serving as a banner year for the 28-year-old. In May, she released her third album, “I Never Learn,” which spawned the hit singles “No Rest for the Wicked” and “Gunshot” (a remix of which, by the Swedish producer Chords, premieres here). She also just kicked off a nationwide tour (which hits Radio City Music Hall on October 4) and is gearing up for an upcoming collaboration with the Swedish clothing line & Other Stories, which opens its first stateside store next month in SoHo. Here, Li talks about “I Never Learn,” appearing on U2’s new album and personal hygiene.

headline: Step 1: Don’t View the Other Party as a Demon
abstract: Forty senior Republican and Democratic staff members have just completed a crash course on how to talk to each other.
lead_paragraph: The dysfunction on Capitol Hill has come to this: Forty senior Republican and Democratic staff members have just completed a crash course on how to talk to each other.

headline: An End-of-Life Nightmare
abstract: Joseph Andrey, 91, wanted to die at home. As is often the case, he died in a hospital instead.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning on a case whose details may be all too familiar to readers of this blog: a daughter struggling futilely to obtain medical care for her father, who wished to die in his apartment. Read the full story.

headline: 4 Children Stabbed to Death in Southern China
abstract: The children were walking to school in Guangxi Province when a man driving a motorized pedicab chased them down with a knife, state media reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A man in southern China stabbed to death four children on their way to school on Friday, state media reported.

headline: Ryder Cup 2014: U.S. Rookies Rule Morning, and Then Europe Wakes Up
abstract: Jordan Spieth and Patrick Reed helped give the United States a lead after the morning session, but were benched in the afternoon, when Europe dominated to take a 5-3 lead.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — Long on energy and short on battle scars, is there a better combination for an afternoon Ryder Cup foursomes match on a hilly course?

headline: Derek Jeter Takes In, and Provides, a Memorable Final View at Shortstop
abstract: After his game-ending hit on Thursday night and the ensuing celebration, Jeter walked alone to his shortstop position one last time and took it all in.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He got cowboy boots in Texas, a surfboard in California and adulation everywhere. But the one gift Derek Jeter wanted most from his final season was the same thing he has wanted since he was a boy growing up next to a baseball field in Kalamazoo, Mich.

headline: A Museum Is in Aspen, but Not of It
abstract: The Aspen Art Museum could potentially show museums in other cities a way to showcase their local artists, but not yet.
lead_paragraph: Aspen, Colo. — The trend in boutique museum building reached a chilly, sun-gilded peak a few years ago and has leveled out, at least in the United States. These days we mostly get unsexy makeovers and add-ons, and the critical conversation has moved on. Still, celebrity commissions appear. A Renzo Piano-designed satellite for the Whitney Museum of American Art is underway in Lower Manhattan. And last month, a new home for the Aspen Art Museum designed by the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban, winner of the 2014 Pritzker Prize, made its debut here.

headline: A ‘50-Foot View’ of Fashion With Simone Oliver
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Models (Professional)', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Social Media']
abstract: Simone Oliver, online editor of the Styles section, discusses the importance of social media when it comes to covering a month of runway shows on the web as Fashion Week moves from Milan to Paris.
lead_paragraph: Social media is playing a larger role than ever in news coverage. Simone Oliver, the online editor for the Styles section, discusses social media’s importance to the coverage of a month of fashion shows. Fashion Week moved to Paris this week.

headline: As One Career Wraps Up, Finding That Next Role
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Employers are creating programs for their retirees that provide transitions to post-career jobs and volunteer opportunities.
lead_paragraph: WHEN she was just 10 years old, Mary Jackson began her teaching career on the back porch of her family’s home in Easley, S.C.

headline: Australia Alarms Rights Groups With Deal to Resettle Refugees in Cambodia
abstract: In an agreement with Cambodia, asylum seekers in Australia’s offshore centers could voluntarily relocate to one of the poorest countries in Southeast Asia.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia signed an agreement with Cambodia on Friday to resettle refugees there, despite strong protests from human rights groups that believe Australia is breaking international laws.

headline: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
abstract: A slideshow of arts events taking place across the world this coming week.

headline: North Korea Reveals Leader Is ‘Not Feeling Well’
abstract: In a rare revelation about the top leader’s health, North’s Central TV showed Mr. Kim walking with a limp while visiting a factory.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, is “not feeling well,” a state-run television station reported this week, in a rare revelation about his health.

headline: Where House Prices Shot Up, Rebound Is Slowest
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Fast growth is generally a factor in rising housing prices, but another factor is how high those prices peaked before the financial downturn.
lead_paragraph: WHEN an economy is growing rapidly, and the population is increasing, house prices are likely to rise.

headline: Bill Gross Made Pimco’s Investing Engaging With Farcical Antics
abstract: Bill Gross has long been one of the most respected investors on Wall Street. He has also been one of the most colorful.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:22 p.m. | As he approached the lectern at a financial industry conference in June, with a version of Santana’s “Smooth” playing over the speakers, William H. Gross was wearing sunglasses.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Today in Small Business: Unlimited Vacation
abstract: Ten things you may not know about Google AdWords. The economy grew at a 4.6 percent annualized rate in the second quarter. Inside the dollar-store wars.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Republicans Rally Base at Values Summit
abstract: Republicans rally the base at Values summit.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot of conservative star power shining out of the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington on Friday morning. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Sarah Palin are just a few of the Republican Party’s luminaries headlining the Values Voter Summit, which is running through the weekend.

headline: Ticking Time Bomb
abstract: An attack in Karachi reveals a web of lives connected by violence in this novel-in-stories.
lead_paragraph: Among people who routinely deal with violence, pain, cruelty and injustice — ­domestic violence counselors, aid ­workers, paramedics, public defenders, immigrant advocates — there’s a phenomenon known as secondary trauma. It’s also sometimes called vicarious trauma, or empathic strain. In her book, “Trauma Stewardship,” Laura van Dernoot ­Lipsky, a former social worker, defines it as being unable to live with the knowledge that, despite our best efforts, most of the world’s suffering goes “unnoticed and unattended.” “Still,” she writes, “people who are working to help those who suffer . . . must somehow reconcile their own joy — the authentic wonder and delight in life — with the irrefutable fact of suffering in the world.”

headline: Say You’re One of Them
abstract: Two families find themselves on opposite sides of Sri Lanka’s civil war in this debut novel.
lead_paragraph: In one of the many startling scenes in “Island of a Thousand Mirrors,” Nayomi Munaweera’s first novel, a Sri Lankan girl riding the train to school is suddenly surrounded by a machete-wielding mob, who demand proof she isn’t Tamil. In her panic, she recites the Buddhist sutras “preaching unattachment, impermanence, the inevitability of death,” an unholy trinity that could apply to all civil wars. This chilling exchange reminded me of a conversation I once had on a London bus with a Somali refugee, who swerved from banal chitchat into dark reminiscence. He recalled a moment in Mogadishu when he was forced to recite his genealogy, the string of grandfathers’ names that place all Somalis within their clans, and he borrowed a school friend’s lineage, as his own would have marked him for death.

headline: Road to Calabria
abstract: A son of Italian immigrants on his relationship with the ancestral homeland.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Luzzi takes the title of his brief, bittersweet new book, “My Two Italies,” from Shelley, who, in a letter of 1818, distinguished between the Italy of “the green earth and transparent sea, and the mighty ruins” and the human reality he encountered there: “The one is the most sublime . . . the other is the most degraded, disgusting and odious.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Caitlin Doughty, whose “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes” is No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list, is a young undertaker who has made it her mission to demystify death and promote a D.I.Y. approach to funerals.
lead_paragraph: The Dead: Nonfiction books usually rely on fairly pedestrian titles and subtitles to tell readers what’s inside — see for instance “The Roosevelts: An Intimate History,” by Geoffrey C. Ward and Ken Burns, No. 6 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. But every now and then a book arrives that reminds you naming can be an art in itself; the best subtitles work almost like line breaks in poetry, forcing you to re-evaluate what came before. So let’s pause a moment to appreciate Caitlin Doughty’s “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes,” new at No. 14, which has the sit-up-and-take-notice subtitle “And Other Lessons From the Crematory.” Doughty is a young undertaker from Los Angeles who has made it her mission to demystify death, encouraging customers and the public at large to embrace a D.I.Y. approach to funerals. “They are grossed out,” she told The Atlantic in a recent online interview, “but that’s because they’ve been told their whole lives that death and bodies are best kept to the ‘professionals’ and that they are dangerous. Most corpses are safer than living bodies. Corpses don’t decompose immediately. They’re not a time bomb of deadness waiting to attack. They’re your mom or your husband, or the shell of them, at least. . . . Your average corpse is completely safe.” I’m not sure how soothing I find this pep talk — it’s not putrefaction I fear, it’s death — but I do admire Doughty’s cheerful sang-froid. I bet she’s excellent at her job.

headline: Letters: ‘World Order’
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Henry Kissinger’s “World Order” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘World Order’

headline: Disquiet on the Set
abstract: In “Werner Herzog: A Guide for the Perplexed,” the filmmaker talks about his notoriously volatile relationship with the actor Klaus Kinski, among many other subjects.
lead_paragraph: “Werner Herzog: A Guide for the Perplexed,” the newly revised and expanded collection of interviews with the adventurous filmmaker, might leave readers even more perplexed but will entertain them along the way.

headline: All Atwitter
abstract: David Cronenberg’s debut novel centers on two journalists and their fascination with scandal and social media.
lead_paragraph: I seem to be in the middle of a minor “Cronenberg moment.” I recently pinned my thumb in a car door, so tightly I had to click the door open again to get it out. Days later the pain had faded, but the nail had turned black. After a few weeks’ growth, a feeble dividing edge of torn nail has crept from my cuticle, as the dead nail begins its crawl out, to be replaced by — what? A new nail, I hope. (Stay tuned.)

headline: Hedge Funds Lose Calpers, and More
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The decision by the California Public Employees’ Retirement System to terminate its $4.5 billion hedge fund portfolio to makes it the biggest public pension to turn its back on hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: Assets at hedge funds, once a niche investment vehicle for ultra-wealthy investors, hit a record $2.8 trillion this year. There are now more than 10,000 hedge funds and counting. Their steep fees have minted scores of billionaire managers and spawned not a few criminals in what has turned into a gold rush of the 21st century.

headline: Love and Fascism
abstract: A first novel set in World War II Germany.
lead_paragraph: Audrey Magee’s debut novel is a love story. Or it would be, if deep emotions were allowed to enter into it. Peter Faber is a soldier desperate to escape the fighting. Katharina Spinell is a typist desperate for some financial security. Brought together by an agency, they marry in separate simultaneous ceremonies. He gets honeymoon leave; she gets the promise of a widow’s pension if he dies. When they meet, they find that they’re attracted to each other — an attraction so intense that it survives years of wartime separation. They also happen to be Nazis.

headline: Daily Clip Report
abstract: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about the media and The Times that is emailed each day to senior executives and newsroom managers here.
lead_paragraph: Daily Clip Report is a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

headline: A Closet With a View
abstract: Based on the life of E. M. Forster, this novel traces a struggle for liberation both on and off the page.
lead_paragraph: The term “literary historical fiction” might be used for noncommercial novels set in the past and full of thoughtful allegorical implication. Or one could employ it for a highly specific subgenre, that portion of “fictional biography” consisting of novels about real-life writers. This territory seems to be expanding of late, with Colm Toibin’s re-creation of Henry James (“The Master”), Jay Parini’s incarnation of Melville (“The Passages of H. M.”) and David Lodge’s imagining of H. G. Wells’s energetic sex and writing lives (“A Man of Parts”).

headline: The Longest Game: Williams vs. Amherst
abstract: It was a milestone event in baseball history, in a rivalry that lives on today.
lead_paragraph: The final score was 73-32. Almost four hours had elapsed before the struggle was over.

keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The court agreed with the local authorities in the German capital, which ruled in August that Uber did not have the proper licenses or safety checks in place to operate in the city.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Germany can’t seem to make up its mind about Uber, the ride-sharing service.

headline: 1914: British Take Orange River
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: British forces fight German troops in South Africa in 1914.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — The important strategic position of Raman’s Drift, on the Orange River, has been occupied by British forces. The attack was made at daybreak. The Wachtmeister made a gallant attempt to hold the blockhouse commanding the Drift after his men had evacuated it, but he eventually surrendered. The patrol was then despatched up river. The Germans were discovered in a position from which they were dislodged after a smart skirmish and they retired. The South African force lost one killed, one wounded and two horses killed. The patrol then fell back. Regimental Sergeant-Major Thomas, of the 5th Regiment, behaved with the greatest gallantry, picking up a wounded rifleman and removing him out of danger while under heavy fire. Subsequent scouting disclosed the fact that an important grazing and watering station some miles within the border was held by the enemy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 27, 1914

headline: New York in 101 Objects
abstract: A new book and exhibition at the New-York Historical Society portrays some of the 101 objects that define New York.
lead_paragraph: A new book and exhibition at the New-York Historical Society portrays some of the 101 objects that define New York.

abstract: The University of Chicago has suspended negotiations to renew its agreement with the Confucius Institute, a global network of Chinese government-affiliated language and culture centers.
lead_paragraph: The University of Chicago has suspended negotiations to renew its agreement with the Confucius Institute, a global network of Chinese government-affiliated language and culture centers, in a setback for the controversial program ahead of its 10th anniversary on Saturday.

headline: An Upper West Side Boomlet
abstract: Half a dozen significant developments are either underway or close to it, in the heart of the neighborhood, the West 70s and 80s.
lead_paragraph: Downtown may be enjoying more buzz. But the Upper West Side, that not-too-edgy, not-too-bland land of large parks and elegant prewar facades, is holding up its end of the conversation.

headline: Certainties, Uncertainties and Choices with Global Warming
abstract: We can be certain about climate change uncertainty but still address the risk.
lead_paragraph: Steven E. Koonin, once the Obama administration’s undersecretary of energy for science and chief scientist at BP, stirred up a swirl of turbulence in global warming discourse this week after The Wall Street Journal published “Climate Science is Not Settled,” his essay calling for more frankness about areas of deep uncertainty in climate science, more research to narrow error ranges and more acknowledgement that society’s decisions on energy and climate policy are based on values as much as data. (The Journal seems to keep this headline on file; here’s a 2009 essay, “Climate Science Isn’t Settled,” by the M.I.T. climatologist Richard Lindzen.)

headline: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Political Compromise in Hong Kong
abstract: One of the most vocal and articulate supporters of greater democracy in Hong Kong, the former Chief Secretary Anson Chan, is trying to find room to compromise with the pro-Beijing camp on electing the top leader.
lead_paragraph: With students taking to the streets this week in Hong Kong and pro-democracy protesters planning to stage a sit-in protest in the coming week in the heart of Asia’s leading financial center, one of the most vocal and articulate supporters of greater democracy in Hong Kong, the former Chief Secretary Anson Chan, is trying to find some room to compromise with the pro-Beijing camp on how to elect the territory’s leader, the chief executive.

headline: Letting Go
abstract: “Darkness, Darkness,” John Harvey’s final novel in his series featuring Inspector Charlie Resnick, strikes an elegiac tone.
lead_paragraph: At the end of DARKNESS, DARKNESS (Pegasus Crime, $25.95), John Harvey advises us that this will be the final novel in his masterly series featuring Inspector Charlie Resnick. Is there any way we could take a vote on that? We’d hate to lose this Nottingham policeman whose love of jazz and compatibility with cats (named after the likes of Miles Davis and Dizzy Gillespie) distinguish him as the mellowest of detectives.

headline: The Melting Pot à La Mode
keywords: ['Paris Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Collections from Raf Simons at Dior, Alber Elbaz at Lanvin, Peter Copping at Nina Ricci and Rick Owens.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s hard not to wonder sometimes, as we sit idly by waiting for a show to start in, say, the Tuileries (where Nina Ricci was held) or the École des Beaux-Arts (Lanvin) or a hidden courtyard of the Louvre (Dior) or the Palais de Chaillot (Rick Owens) — or, indeed, any of the many historic French institutions where prêt-à-porter can be found — what Marine Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front, preacher of “France for the French,” euro-skeptic and increasingly popular potential presidential candidate, would think.

headline: Legal Battle Over French Comic Series Astérix Ends
abstract: A lengthy legal battle involving the French illustrator of the Astérix comic series ended on Friday, ruling in his favor in a lawsuit initiated by his daughter.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A lengthy legal battle involving the illustrator of the fabled French Astérix comic series ended Friday when an appeals court here rejected his only daughter’s claims that he was incapable of handling his literary estate.

headline: Artifacts That Encapsulate New York City
abstract: “A History of New York in 101 Objects” explores the transformative, quirky, surprising and provocative artifacts that have defined the city over four centuries.
lead_paragraph: What began as an article in the Metropolitan section has now, thanks to input from Times readers, grown into a book. A few years ago, the British Museum and BBC produced “A History of the World in 100 Objects.” But New York needed 101. From the iconic (the subway token and the Spaldeen) to the ironic (a draft for a musical version of Romeo and Juliet called “East Side Story”), “A History of New York in 101 Objects” explores the transformative, quirky, surprising and provocative artifacts that have defined the city over four centuries.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Earlier this week, London knocked Hong Kong out of first place as the most expensive city in the world to live and work, according to Savills, a British real estate agency.

lead_paragraph: Near the top of the list of tiresome tasks that the Internet has yet to solve is this one: trekking to the post office.
