headline: Who Made That Charcoal Briquette?
abstract: The so-called Vagabonds take on a timber challenge.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1919, a Michigan real estate agent named Edward G. Kingsford was invited on a camping trip by his wife’s cousin, the industrialist Henry Ford. In addition to Ford, the adventurers included Thomas Edison, the tire magnate Harvey Firestone and the naturalist John Burroughs. Although the group called themselves the Vagabonds, they traveled with chauffeurs and a chef in a convoy of six vehicles, one of which was a fully equipped kitchen truck.

headline: Why Government Websites Are Terrible and How to Fix Them
abstract: By exposing how confusing food stamp applications and other government online services can be, Citizen Onboard hopes to make them better.
lead_paragraph: “Your social security number (SSN) will be used to check identity” read the online application for California’s food-stamp program. However, “providing your SSN is not required when you first submit your application.” But also “we can deny you or any member of your household benefits for failing to provide an SSN.” Confused yet?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHITE GIRLS,  by Hilton Als. (McSweeney’s, $16.) Als, a staff writer for The New Yorker, weaves together analyses of literature, art, film and music with insights on the cultural and racial implications of white womanhood. (In these deeply personal essays, “white girls” is an expansive category, encompassing Louise Brooks and Truman Capote, Flannery O’Connor and Richard Pryor.) Our reviewer, Rich Benjamin, praised these kaleidoscopic portraits as “effortless, honest and fearless.”

headline: Popcast: Parsing Steve Coleman’s Genius
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the jazz saxophonist and composer, who recently was awarded a MacArthur fellowship.
lead_paragraph: The saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman became a MacArthur Fellow last week — joining the ranks of so-called “genius grant” winners — and is coming to the end of a two-week residency at the Stone in the East Village. Mr. Coleman has become of the most influential improvisers of the last half-century — mostly through decades of functioning as a one-man, nonacademic academy, the teacher of his own system. His sound, or his thought, can be traced through some of the other recent recipients of the award: Miguel Zenón, Jason Moran, Vijay Iyer and Dafnis Prieto, who have all played with him at one time or another.

He has an M.B.A. from M.I.T.’s Sloan School of Management in Cambridge, Mass., where he is executive director of the school’s Center for eBusiness.

The night’s honorees included the usual boldface names, like Linda Daschle — the lobbyist and wife of former Senator Tom Daschle — but also upwardly mobile transplants who have made this town their oyster.

headline: G.D.P. Report Emphasizes the Problem of Conflicting Economic Signals
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Gross National Product (GNP)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A report finds that the economy is running too hot, too cold and just right — all at once.
lead_paragraph: Friday morning’s revised G.D.P. report provides yet another reminder of just how hard it can be to figure out what’s actually going on in the economy. Depending on which numbers you emphasize, the economy is either going gangbusters, simply chugging along in its groove or has hit a rut.

headline: A Stolen Video of My Daughter Went Viral. Here’s What I Learned.
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Parenting', 'Privacy', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: I wanted the video of my 4-year-old talking about equality to be shared. But when it was stolen and shared by strangers, the experience changed how I think about posting images of my children online.
lead_paragraph: When my oldest daughter turned 9, I stopped sharing new pictures and videos of her on my blog’s Facebook page. She was growing up and looking more and more like the teenager she would eventually become, and I didn’t want strangers to recognize her out in public. I didn’t think it would be right if her friends could go online and see pictures I was posting on my public sites.

headline: A Sizzling Cocktail That Serves as a Climate Warning
abstract: This drink deliciously, if disturbingly, evokes the plight of the planet, starting off with cool, fruity notes and ending up “hot and polluted.”
lead_paragraph: The planet’s atmosphere is heating up, and fast. There is broad scientific consensus that as humans keep pumping carbon dioxide from burning coal and oil into the atmosphere, the gases will trap heat and drive the global average temperature up by more than 2 degrees Celsius (around 5 degrees Fahrenheit).

keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker says a problem with an electronic module could prevent air bags from deploying in a crash.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 745,000 sedans and sport utility vehicles in the United States for a problem with an electronic module that could prevent the air bags from deploying in a crash, the automaker said Friday. The action covers 2013-14 Ford C-Max, Fusion, Escape and Lincoln MKZ models.

headline: ISIS Lieutenant Emerges From Australian Red-Light District
abstract: A phone call said to have been made by Mohammad Ali Baryalei, a former Sydney bouncer who is now a leader in the Islamic State, set off a counterterrorism crackdown in Australia.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In Kings Cross, this city’s bawdy, alcohol-infused red-light district, Mohammad Ali Baryalei once patrolled the sidewalk outside the Love Machine club, his basso voice luring customers in, his muscle keeping the unwanted out. For a time, the police said, his was a world of prostitutes, drugs, gangs and gambling.

headline: 1939: French Ban Communism
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: France bans Communism in 1939.
lead_paragraph: The Daladier Cabinet yesterday decreed the dissolution of the French Communist party, the most powerful foreign section of the Comintern since Hitler suppressed its German branch six years ago. Communism now ceases to exist as an organized force in any major country of Europe with the exception of course, of Soviet Russia. The action of the French government in proscribing the Communist party comes as no surprise. It had been foreseen for weeks, ever since Soviet Russia signed the non-aggression pact with Nazi Germany and followed it up by making an agreement with that country for the partition of Poland. Even Leftist papers like ‘‘L’OEuvre’’ have been advocating the Abolition of the French Communist party since the outbreak of the war. Leon Blum, the Socialist party leader, in ‘‘Le Populate’’ made an urgent appeal to the French Communists to save their party, by formally renouncing their allegiance to Moscow. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 27, 1939

But he did leave a remarkable corner with his trademark ebullient Flemish tops, at West End Avenue and 90th Street. Will they ever recover from the butchering of the roof line in the 1950s?

headline: The Business Case for Diversity in the Tech Industry
abstract: Google argues that a diverse work force can help it come up with better products.

Among other programs, Google is running a series of workshops to help employees understand and combat their unconscious biases. Google hopes the plan will put people on alert to the many small ways that its culture may make outsiders uncomfortable.

headline: Readers Respond to Tactics of Subprime Auto Lenders
abstract: A wide range of responses poured in after the publication of the article, which detailed how lenders use technology to remotely disable the engines of borrowers who don’t pay on time.
lead_paragraph: An article about subprime auto lenders that was published Wednesday night in DealBook drew over 1,000 comments in less than 24 hours. The story centered on a piece of technology called the starter interrupt device, which allows lenders to remotely disable the engines of borrowers who don’t pay on time as well as to track those cars’ movements with GPS – raising questions about the price of privacy.

headline: Under Cover: Desert Voyages in Colored Hues
abstract: David Benjamin Sherry hauled his large-format 8-by-10 camera into Death Valley last year and to capture the desert light on film. One of the resulting images now illuminates the cover for the Sept. 28 Voyages Issue.
lead_paragraph: Deserts are places for pilgrims and mystics, settings for odysseys and renewals, spaces to journey through and be changed by. You can see the light there. The photographer David Benjamin Sherry hauled his large-format 8-by-10 camera into Death Valley last year and brought back some of that light on film. Then he went into the darkroom and, using color, added his own light, his own emotions — “to instill fear or joy,” in his words. One of the resulting images now illuminates the cover for the Sept. 28 Voyages Issue. Sherry’s images belong to a larger body of work, “Wonderful Land,” for which he spent months visiting well-known vistas around the West. His landscapes, colorized with hues not seen in nature, conjure clarity and disorientation, making the familiar strange again — which just happens to be what all good voyages do.

lead_paragraph: Doctors and nurses are finally volunteering to fight the Ebola virus in West Africa after a long period of paralyzing fear in which almost none stepped forward.

abstract: The agreement, brokered by European officials, aims to ensure gas flows over the coming six months, despite a dispute between Moscow and Kiev.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European officials said Friday that they had brokered a deal between Russia and Ukraine aimed at ensuring gas flows to keep factories running and homes warm over the next six months, despite a dispute over the size of Ukraine’s outstanding bills.

headline: Sounds Like a Gershwin Song
abstract: For two composers of musical theater, the melody is just beginning.
lead_paragraph: As the grooms kissed to seal their vows on a rooftop terrace in Long Island City, Queens, a quintet burst into the Gershwin tune “They All Laughed.” Most in attendance knew the words by heart and smiled knowingly as they listened and silently recalled the song: “They laughed at me, wanting you. ... Now they’ll have to change their tune. ... But ho, ho, ho, who’s got the last laugh now?”

headline: Book Review Podcast: Texting While Driving
abstract: Matt Richtel discusses “A Deadly Wandering,” and Mark Edmundson talks about “Why Football Matters.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Robert Kolker reviews Matt Richtel’s “A Deadly Wandering: A Tale of Tragedy and Redemption in the Age of Attention,” about Reggie Shaw, who crossed the line of a Utah highway in September 2006 while texting a girlfriend. Two men in another car were killed in the ensuing accident. Mr. Kolker writes:

headline: At Ryder Cup’s First Hole, a Rousing Start, With a Chorus
abstract: Teeing off at the Ryder Cup, where the players compete for country not cash, is turned into a unique experience by the vocal fans.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — You never know where a Ryder Cup match might finish, but you do know where one starts, which explained the crush outside of Gleneagles very early Friday morning.

headline: FIFA’s Sepp Blatter Says Corruption Report Will Remain Secret
abstract: Blatter, the president of FIFA, soccer’s world governing body, said no member had requested that the executive committee make the report public.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, insisted Friday that an investigative report into the bidding for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups should remain private, despite growing pressure for its release from inside and outside soccer’s world governing body.

headline: Vincent Piazza: 40 Blocks From Home, but a World Away
abstract: In five seasons of playing Lucky Luciano on HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire,” Mr. Piazza never had to shoot scenes on a Sunday. A native of Queens, he currently lives in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In five seasons of playing Lucky Luciano on HBO’s “Boardwalk Empire,” Vincent Piazza never had to shoot scenes on a Sunday. “Sunday is a reflective day, a thoughtful day,” he said. Now, with the show heading toward a promised bloody end later this fall, Mr. Piazza has plenty to reflect on, including, as of earlier this year, a new neighborhood to call home. A native of Queens, Mr. Piazza, 38, speaks with a New York brio that makes a 40-block move sound like a journey across temperate zones. His new home, which he shares with his girlfriend of a year and a half and a miniature longhaired dachshund, is near the Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge. But Queens is not too far away. “It’s a pretty incredible thing to know I can walk across the bridge and end up there if I ever need to,” he said.

headline: Air France Outlines Latest Proposal to Pilots’ Union
abstract: The company plans to hire up to 1,000 new employees in France, including 250 pilots, for its budget carrier, but held firm on a separate contract.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly two weeks into a French pilots’ strike, Air France-KLM outlined its latest proposal on Friday, while union leaders called for an independent mediator to help break the deadlock.

headline: Congress Avoids Being Least Productive Ever
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The 113th Congress tallied its 165th law this week, the lowest number ever by this time in a term.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:08 p.m. | Breaking News: The White House announced Friday that the president had signed 16 bills into law, pushing the total numbers of laws for the 113th Congress to 181. Improbably, that puts the current Congress into a tie with the 112th for the title of Do Nothing-est!

headline: Maison Martin Margiela: Spring 2015 RTW

headline: A Jab at Indonesia’s President-Elect as Parliament Curbs Local Voting
abstract: The departing Indonesian Parliament passed a law on Friday eliminating the popular vote for mayors, district chiefs and governors.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Democracy in Indonesia suffered a major setback, analysts inside and outside the county said on Friday, when the outgoing Parliament passed a last-minute law eliminating direct elections for mayors, district chiefs and governors.

headline: A Ballpark Tour, in Every Major League City
abstract: Over 85 days and 18,000 miles, photographer Ray Whitehouse visited all 30 stadiums, capturing a portrait of America through the lens of baseball.
lead_paragraph: Each spring, the start of the major league baseball season brings a fresh slate for teams and their fans, from the Green Monster in Boston to Dodger Dogs in Los Angeles. But as summer fades into the shorter days of autumn, the memories of a season past extend beyond the field, reaching into the slanted seats of the upper deck, onto the crowded sidewalks in front of a ballpark.

headline: For Some Tech Start-Ups Like Ello, Exclusivity Draws Demand
abstract: Why all the fuss about Ello, a new social network that is some amalgam of Twitter, Facebook and Medium, the online publishing start-up, rolled into one?
lead_paragraph: For the last 24 hours, I’ve been watching my Twitter feed tick by with mentions of Ello, a new social network that is some amalgam of Twitter, Facebook and Medium, the online publishing start-up, rolled into one.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Builders Turn Focus to Housing Market
abstract: The Durst family, who helped revitalize Times Square, is planning a vast development in Queens, a sign of the seemingly insatiable demand for luxury housing.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of New York City’s rapidly shifting real estate market, the Durst family, whose empire was built on a forest of Manhattan office towers, is plunging into the housing market with an ambitious plan for a sprawling residential development on the Queens waterfront.

headline: A Parting Sentiment, Lost in Translation
abstract: A reader who sent flowers to his grandmother’s funeral is shocked by how his message ultimately appeared on the accompanying note.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of companies employ phone reps with a less-than-ideal grasp of the English language. That can lead to halting conversations with phrases that, while grammatical, sound slightly off to American ears, such as “Thank you for patiently waiting.”

abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Transportation Authority Archivist Seeks Tollbooth
abstract: Mary Hedge, archivist at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Bridges and Tunnels Special Archive, preserves nearly a century of materials documenting the planning and construction of New York infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: It’s 66 degrees and low humidity — and that’s inside the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Bridges and Tunnels Special Archive in Lower Manhattan. But after five years on the job, Mary Hedge, the archivist, has grown accustomed to the carefully calibrated climate of her work space on the 22nd floor of 2 Broadway.

headline: In the Northwest, 3 Trips, Planned by Others
abstract: The Frugal Traveler surrenders itinerary control and follows the orders of others through Vancouver, the San Juan Islands and Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: In July, I got an email from my friend Caroline that read: “I asked my friend Deepa from Seattle about yoga resort kind of places and she said this place is cool.” She added a link to a retreat where sleeping options included quirky cabins with Hindi names and said the spa was “clothing-optional.”

headline: Charting Change in Madagascar
abstract: Hilary Bradt, a guidebook publisher, talks about how the island has evolved and when she discovered its “otherness.”
lead_paragraph: “A Glance at Madagascar.”

headline: Iowa Museum Regains a Grant Wood Notebook After Nearly 50 Years
abstract: A notebook of Grant Wood drawings is back at the Figge Art Museum in Davenport, Iowa, where it went missing for nearly 50 years.
lead_paragraph: A notebook of drawings by Grant Wood has found its way back to the Figge Art Museum in Davenport, Iowa, where it went missing nearly 50 years ago. The 48-page notebook contains sketches that Wood made in the 1920s for a large stained-glass window at the Veterans Memorial Building in Cedar Rapids.

headline: Can a Social Network Stay Ad-Free?
abstract: Ello bills itself as proudly devoid of ads — but at least one brand is already advertising its product there.
lead_paragraph: In a prominent sidebar on its site, the social network Ello describes itself as “Simple, beautiful & ad-free.” If you visit the Ello page of Sonos, a speaker company, you’ll still see that message, right next to this one: “Sonos speakers bring all the music on earth to every room in your home, wirelessly: www.sonos.com.”

headline: Palestinian Leader Urges U.N. to Back a Deadline to End Israeli Occupation
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas criticized Israel but did not offer his own time frame for an Israeli withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian Leader Urges U.N. to Press for Deadline to End Israeli Occupation

headline: In New Mexico, on the Cowboy Trail of Jack Thorp
abstract: The former New Yorker fell in love with the Rio Grande Valley, collecting the ballads and poems that embodied the land and its harsh beauty.
lead_paragraph: For years, when I pictured the Rio Grande, it was as the spindly, concrete-encased trickle that marks the dividing line between the United States and Mexico. In my mind, it was as much a military installation as a body of water. But the Rio Grande can roar. It can carve an 800-foot-deep gorge into the Southwestern plateaus. It can sustain vineyards, pecan orchards, pinto bean farms and lavender fields. It can drown riverside hot springs. It can flow so fast and full that its water turns the color of adobe.

headline: States of Mind: Why Alec Soth and Brad Zellar Went to Georgia
abstract: This week’s special Voyages Issue includes pictures from a road trip through Georgia taken by the photographer Alec Soth and the writer Brad Zellar. Recently, Zellar talked about their state sojourns.
lead_paragraph: The Sept. 28 Voyages Issue includes photographs from a road trip through Georgia that was taken by the photographer Alec Soth and the writer Brad Zellar. It was their seventh such expedition since 2012; they have also visited California, Colorado, Michigan, New York, Ohio and Texas. When Soth and Zellar are on the road — they spent two weeks in Georgia in July — they post photos and writings every day on their Tumblr, called The LBM Dispatch. Afterward, they print their version of a newspaper as a record of their trip. I recently talked to Zellar about their sojourns.

headline: Fantasy Football: Bortles, Cooks and Benjamin Among Top Rookies
abstract: Three weeks into the season, it has become evident how many skilled players have emerged from this rookie class.
lead_paragraph: Before Week 1, this year’s rookies were regarded by many as a mediocre group for fantasy owners. Only three weeks into the season, however, we can already see how many skilled players are in this class. Here, we break down the performance of these rookies by position, and highlight the most important players so far this season.

headline: Republicans Pull Ahead Again in Battle for Senate
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Recent polls in Iowa, Colorado and Alaska have given the G.O.P. renewed hope that they are within reach of 51 Senate seats.
lead_paragraph: If the polls of early September were a reminder that the Democratic path to 50 seats remains open, then the last two weeks were a reminder of how quickly that path could close.

headline: Hasty With the Will
abstract: Breaking the news of a changing inheritance, strangers with child care advice and opting out of a prayer meeting.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, I moved to Silicon Valley, got a job with people much, much smarter than I am, and prospered. I decided to leave the largest portion of my estate to a friend; she asked its value, and I told her. Since then, I have decided to leave more money to charity. And sadly, our friendship has soured. Thus I have changed my will and removed her bequest. Should I tell her?

headline: Make Art, Not Ads
abstract: The No Ad app replaces images of advertisements in the New York City subway system with images of artworks.
lead_paragraph: A new app called No Ad subverts the very idea behind most mobile software, enabling the user to make a political and artistic statement instead of simply providing a service or a distraction.

lead_paragraph: When my sons and I stopped by their father’s house to do our laundry one evening, we thought no one was home. Then we noticed him in the backyard with a young woman.

headline: Companies Rush to Fix Shellshock Software Bug as Hackers Launch Thousands of Attacks
abstract: Security experts advised home users to stay on top of software updates and check manufacturer’s websites, particularly for hardware like routers.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Department of Homeland Security advised Internet users and corporations about a newly discovered software bug that could affect hundreds of millions of systems, hackers had already begun exploiting the bug and companies were rushing to fix the issue for their users.

headline: Literary Biography of Jonathan Franzen to Appear Next Year
abstract: The author of four novels, Mr. Franzen is the focus of a Swarthmore College English professor who has also studied Faulkner, Proust and Kafka.
lead_paragraph: Few living novelists get the biography treatment. So why is the scholar Philip Weinstein, who has published critical studies of literary masters like William Faulkner, Marcel Proust and Franz Kafka, writing an in-depth study of the life and work of Jonathan Franzen?

headline: How Israel Silences Dissent
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Those who express sympathy for Palestinians have been threatened, even fired from jobs.
lead_paragraph: JAFFA, Israel — On July 12, four days after the latest war in Gaza began, hundreds of Israelis gathered in central Tel Aviv to protest the killing of civilians on both sides and call for an end to the siege of Gaza and the Israeli occupation of the West Bank. They chanted, “Jews and Arabs refuse to be enemies.”

headline: Black Swan Buns (and Crowns) at Undercover
abstract: The costume element of the label’s spring 2015 came to a head in the models’ ornamental hairstyles.
lead_paragraph: Undercover’s spring 2015 collection was very Swan Lake — ballerina tutus, swan-inspired accents — but with a Japanese twist, thanks to slightly theatrical, manga-inspired styling moments. The costume element peaked on the models’ heads, where crowns of colored leaves sat atop prim buns (and black-jeweled eyes). They, along with the occasional opulent mask, helped set the beautiful-yet-deranged tone of the show.

headline: Obama Urges Global Effort to Help Prevent Epidemics

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday called on nations around the world to develop more effective health care systems to prevent deadly outbreaks like the Ebola virus that is rapidly spreading across West Africa.

lead_paragraph: The old saw about past performance not necessarily being indicative of future results just found a new poster child: the bond king Bill Gross sitting on his Janus Capital throne.

lead_paragraph: A man beheaded a co-worker at a food processing company in Oklahoma on Thursday afternoon, and stabbed another employee before he was shot and wounded by a company executive, the police said Friday.

headline: So You’re Not a Physicist ...
abstract: That’s O.K. You can still use scientific terms to express yourself.
lead_paragraph: WHEN President Obama was asked, in 2012, to explain his caution in approaching advisers for guidance, he replied by invoking an idea from quantum physics. “It’s the Heisenberg principle,” he said. “Me asking the question changes the answer.”

headline: The New Classical Clique
abstract: Micro motives and the misleading of macro.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis thinks some more about macroeconomics gone astray; Robert J. Waldmann weighs in. For those new to this conversation, the question is why starting in the 1970s much of academic macroeconomics was taken over by a school of thought that began by denying any useful role for policies to raise demand in a slump, and eventually coalesced around denial that the demand side of the economy has any role in causing slumps.

headline: The One With the Replica Coffee Shop
abstract: A replica in SoHo of Central Perk, the coffeehouse where the pals on the sitcom “Friends” gathered, has proved popular.
lead_paragraph: The line stretched down Lafayette Street, past security officers in suits and earpieces, along Broome Street and back up Cleveland Place. Devotees of the sitcom “Friends” made the pilgrimage to SoHo on Tuesday to enter a pop-up replica of Central Perk, the coffeehouse where the gang on that long-running hit show sighed and shared the quirky woes of their 20-something lives. Warner Bros., in partnership with the Eight O’Clock Coffee company, had set up the shrine-museum, which will be open through Oct. 18, for the 20th anniversary of the show’s debut. The coffee is free. The gift shop items are not. Memorabilia are displayed — Phoebe’s guitar; Joey’s ceramic white dog; an invitation to Monica and Chandler’s wedding; the bronze picture frame from the door of the huge loft Monica and Rachel shared in the show’s early years. Fans got to sit on the show’s pumpkin-color couch for 22 seconds and have their pictures taken. Many of them had barely been born when the show was first broadcast.

headline: Jammy Goodness From the Inside Out
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Jams and Jellies', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Plums', 'Recipes', 'Desserts']

lead_paragraph: Spreading jam on scones is all well and good, but baking the jam directly into the scones is even better.

headline: Cooking With Cauliflower, a Feisty Vegetable That Can Take a Punch
abstract: Now that it’s in vogue, here are a few truths about cauliflower: It can stand up to bold seasoning and high heat.
lead_paragraph: Cauliflower, though now in vogue, was once the least appreciated of the large family of cruciferous vegetables, no doubt because of memories of encountering it boiled, flabby and timidly seasoned, if seasoned at all.

headline: This Gleneagles Is a Scruffy Cousin
abstract: The Ryder Cup began Friday at the revered Gleneagles golf resort in Scotland, but San Francisco hosts a distant relative: a city-owned namesake that is a gem in its own way.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Among the things said last week at the golf course at Gleneagles, but not the famous one in Scotland where the Ryder Cup is being played, were these:

headline: A Time Capsule’s Mr. Fix-It

lead_paragraph: “This is Bob’s world down here,” said Robert Yucikas, 70, ducking his 6-foot, 8-inch frame into a cryptlike basement extending underneath an Orchard Street sidewalk.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Along with its surprising military success, the Islamic State group has demonstrated a skill and sophistication with social media previously unseen in extremist groups.

headline: Love Them or Loathe Them, Reverse Mortgages Have a Place
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Personal Finances', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As more people enter retirement with modest savings and no private pension, they are going to need some of the equity they have built up in their homes.
lead_paragraph: Executives from reverse mortgage companies know plenty about consumers’ feelings around inheritance. After all, they’re in the business of encouraging older Americans to drain equity now from homes they may pass on to their heirs in the future.

headline: Creating a Role Twice, and in Stereo

lead_paragraph: SIDNEY, British Columbia — David Tennant has been here before. He has sat in this police interview room and stared across this metal table at a father suspected of killing his young son. He’s listened to this obviously false alibi, stood up in frustration and snapped, “O.K., Mark Solano, I’m arresting you for obstruction of a murder investigation.”

headline: More Change for a Traditional Force
abstract: The Berlin Philharmonic brings its incomparable sound to New York, with an unusual collaboration between Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter was with the Berlin Philharmonic last year, recording Dvorak’s Violin Concerto for the first time. After three days of work, the results were very good. But Ms. Mutter thought they could be even better.

lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Yemen, Hong Kong and Scotland.

headline: Sprinting Downcourt to the High Life
abstract: The Starz comedy “Survivor’s Remorse,” about challenges facing a newly successful basketball player, is loosely based on the lives of LeBron James and his manager.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The title of “Survivor’s Remorse,” Starz’s new six-episode comedy series about a fictional professional basketball player who has just signed his first multimillion-dollar contract, came from Maverick Carter, who is the manager and a childhood friend of the newly returned Cleveland Cavalier LeBron James, the most famous basketball player in the world. It is a phrase they had used often to describe their conflicting emotions about their enormous success, a life of private jets and manicured estates beyond anything they could have imagined when they were growing up in their poor and often dangerous Akron, Ohio, neighborhood.

headline: Some Are Talking, Some Can’t Stand Still
abstract: “Retrospective,” at MoMA PS1, is not a dance, but it is the work of a choreographer: Xavier Le Roy.
lead_paragraph: It is an exhibition, but nothing hangs on the walls. It is not a dance, yet there are dancers. It begins the instant a spectator enters the space. As for the performers? They move. They freeze into sculptural poses. They tell personal stories. And everything relates back to the work of one incisive and imaginative French choreographer: Xavier Le Roy.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A bitter and long-running legal dispute over the ownership rights to Marvel superheroes like Thor and the X-Men ended on Friday with a settlement between Marvel, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, and the heirs of the comic book artist Jack Kirby.

lead_paragraph: The 41st Blue Ridge Folklife Festival, set for Oct. 25 in western Virginia, will showcase musicians dedicated to preserving the art and authenticity of regional folk music.

headline: Esteban Cortazar Returns to the Runway
abstract: The former teenage prodigy is relaunching his namesake label with a show at Paris Fashion Week. Here, a first look at the spring/summer 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: There are fashion prodigies, and then there’s Esteban Cortazar. The designer debuted his first collection at New York Fashion Week at the age of 17 – the youngest person ever to do so – before moving to Paris at 23 to take the helm of creative director at Emanuel Ungaro, where he remained for two years. More recently, he has released capsule collections for Net-a-Porter under his own name, earning him countless “comeback kid” monikers in the press. Now 30, still living in Paris and armed with new backers, Cortazar is preparing for a full relaunch of his namesake line. And the spring/summer 2015 show, which will be held tomorrow at his spacious Marais studio, is shaping up to be one of Paris Fashion Week’s most anticipated events.

headline: Decoding a Trickster
abstract: Charting “Syro,” the first new Aphex Twin studio album as in 13 years.
lead_paragraph: Richard D. James, an electronic musician from Britain, is renowned for his lively yet mysterious dance music and his reclusive trickster persona. Since the early 1990s, he has made music under monikers like Aphex Twin, AFX and Caustic Window; the frenetic new “Syro” (Warp) is his first studio album as Aphex Twin in 13 years. With cryptic song titles like “minipops 67 (source field mix)” and “s950tx16wasr10 (earth portal mix),” “Syro” suggests that Mr. James remains his playful self. Here, I chart “Syro” and 41 of his other known solo releases. There may be even more.

headline: Grant Achatz, April Bloomfield, Anthony Bourdain and Others Dish on the Plates They Made for Daniel Boulud
abstract: The handmade items hang on the walls of Boulud’s new Washington, D.C., eatery to commemorate his many friendships in the food world.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Boulud opened his 16th restaurant, DBGB Kitchen and Bar, in Washington, D.C., earlier this month, the occasion marked a homecoming of sorts for the French-born chef. “D.C. is where I spent my first two and a half years in America,” says Boulud, who arrived in 1981 and assumed his first stateside job cooking for the head of the European Commission. “DBGB is a restaurant I would have loved to open after a couple of years in D.C., but I couldn’t afford to,” he adds. “I didn’t have any money, nor did I have a name strong enough that I could raise money.”

lead_paragraph: Shoe designer Christian Louboutin talks sneaking into Paris musicals as a preteen, a novel use for veal carpaccio, and how showgirls inspired some of his favorite designs.

headline: How to Stop Time
abstract: We will never stop dawdling. So why should we feel guilty about it?
lead_paragraph: IN the unlikely event that we could ever unite under the banner of a single saint, it might just be St. Expeditus. According to legend, when the Roman centurion decided to convert to Christianity, the Devil appeared in the form of a crow and circled above him crying “cras, cras” — Latin for “tomorrow, tomorrow.” Expeditus stomped on the bird and shouted victoriously, “Today!” For doing so, Expeditus achieved salvation, and is worshiped as the patron saint of procrastinators. Sometimes you see icons of him turned upside down like an hourglass in the hope that he’ll hurry up and help you get your work done so he can be set right-side up again. From job-seekers in Brazil to people who run e-commerce sites in New Orleans, Expeditus is adored not just for his expediency, but also for his power to settle financial affairs. There is even a novena to the saint on Facebook.

headline: The Woman’s Heart Attack
abstract: The research is based on men, whose clutching of the chest and sudden collapse bears little resemblance to the experience of most women.
lead_paragraph: IN medical circles, they call it the Hollywood Heart Attack. You’ve seen it: grimace of agony, clutching of chest, sudden collapse, the whole purple-prose panoply.

headline: In London, Houseboats Offer Alternative to High Rent, but New Problems Emerge
abstract: As rents skyrocket, canal homes are proliferating, putting berths at a premium and stretching the existing support system.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the Little Venice neighborhood of west London, the boats’ names appear as colorful as their paint does. The crimson Mayflower bobs in front of the dark green Esmeralda, not far from the navy blue Globetrotter, moored behind the violet Hobbit.
