headline: Cheek to Cheek to Cheek
abstract: The Argentine dancers Maria Blanco, Leonardo Sardella and Walter Perez paired off in several combinations at a tango performance on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Three Argentine tango dancers — Maria Blanco, Leonardo Sardella and Walter Perez — danced four duets on Tuesday at the Dardo Galletto Studios in Manhattan. The one-night event was of exceptional interest for several reasons.

headline: The Weekly Wrap
abstract: Highlights from the past week on Times Insider.
lead_paragraph: Hello, Times Insiders. Don’t miss this week’s highlights. Among them:

headline: Refugee Flow to Industrialized Nations Is Poised for a 20-Year High
abstract: More than 330,700 people applied for asylum in 44 countries in Europe, North America and parts of the Asia-Pacific region in the first half of the year, a U.N. agency reported.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Conflict and instability in the Middle East and parts of Africa look set to push the number of people seeking asylum in industrialized countries to the highest level in 20 years in 2014, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday, warning that the flow of refugees was increasing the strain on already overstretched humanitarian aid budgets.

headline: Flirting With Temptation, Deep Into the Night
abstract: Cia. Unión Tanguera, a French-Argentine company, infuses tango with theatrical touches in “Nuit Blanche.”
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: A tango show has just ended, but its seven dancers don’t feel like calling it a night. They feel frisky. Instead of going home to soak in a tub, they linger behind in the nightclub, toying with props — wineglasses, red beanbag chairs — while teasing one another as a “Nuit Blanche,” or “Sleepless Night,” takes hold.

headline: Transforming Sound Into Dizzying Sights
abstract: New York City Ballet presents a program of Igor Stravinsky’s work, choreographed by George Balanchine.
lead_paragraph: The rate at which New York City Ballet has been hurling its works back into the repertory at the start of its fall season is prodigious, even by this company’s own rapid-fire standards. The first four nights are bringing no fewer than 17 ballets. And the first three register like company proclamations of the causes in which it most believes. Tuesday provided 21st-century choreography, with three world premieres; Wednesday presented ballets by the founding choreographer George Balanchine to music by Tchaikovsky; and Thursday honored the company’s unmatched tradition of Balanchine choreography to music by Stravinsky.

headline: The Weather Is Cold, the Feelings More So
abstract: Alex Roe has revived “Icebound,” which won the 1923 Pulitzer Prize for drama, at the Metropolitan Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: Families were bigger then, and so were the casts of plays. In Alex Roe’s fine revival of “Icebound,” the Metropolitan Playhouse’s cozy upstairs theater is crowded with members of the Jordan family: grim grown sons and daughters, a sour daughter-in-law and two annoying grandchildren, all waiting in the parlor for the matriarch to die offstage, and all talking about how they’ll spend her money.

headline: Nursing Wounds Deeper Than Scars
abstract: Liz Lerman’s latest production, “Healing Wars,” deals with the traumatic effects of war on soldiers and on those charged with healing them.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — “Healing Wars,” the latest production by Liz Lerman, begins backstage. Audience members, en route to their seats, file through a maze of meticulously reconstructed scenes from the Civil War. Along with a costumed performer or two, each tableau vivant comes with wall text imparting an interesting fact: the number of women who disguised themselves as men to fight, the number of letters that the American Red Cross founder Clara Barton received and wrote. At the end of the line, there’s a real and much more recent veteran, the former Navy Gunner’s Mate Paul Hurley, calmly discussing his missing lower leg and his prosthesis.

headline: As Catalonia Weighs Independence From Spain, Leader Seizes Spotlight
abstract: The legal problems of Jordi Pujol, a former leader of the Convergence party, have cast a shadow over the party’s push for independence from Spain.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Jordi Pujol, the patriarch of Catalan politics, told lawmakers on Friday that money that he has admitted to hiding offshore was inherited and not earned from kickbacks or other corrupt practices during his 23 years in charge of the regional government.

headline: Facing Militants With Supplies Dwindling, Iraqi Soldiers Took to Phones
abstract: Soldiers’ frantic attempts to resupply ahead of a battle this week exposed some of the Iraqi Army’s glaring weaknesses as it tries to counter the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi unit, bunkered in a village in Anbar Province, had held the militants at bay for four days. But running perilously low on ammunition, food and water, the soldiers finally took matters into their own hands.

headline: Seeking Out the New, Still Rocking His Past
abstract: Robert Plant, once Led Zeppelin’s frontman, signaled yet another twist in his rock ’n’ roll road in a concert on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — Near the midpoint of his shrewdly rollicking concert at the Capitol Theater here on Thursday night, Robert Plant paused to recall a late-night drive down a Mississippi highway and the spell cast by an AM radio signal. He was setting the scene for “Turn It Up,” a brooding new song that builds on this premise. But his words also had the ring of testimony, like a secular salvation narrative.

headline: Provocations Sung Genially
abstract: Caetano Veloso, enlightened witness from the 1960s, was up to his old tricks in his performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: On Caetano Veloso’s current tour, his drummer Marcelo Callado has the word “Abraçaço” spelled out on his bass drum in masking tape, in the style of an oppositional, no-budget punk band. The word is a slang intensification of “abraço,” Portuguese for hug, a typical Brazilian signoff in a letter. (It’s also the title of the most recent album by Mr. Veloso, the Brazilian singer-songwriter, the best of three in what could be called, after the fact, a trilogy.) So, “a big hug,” written in the same style that you typically see words like Toxic Threat, or Riot Alarm.

headline: Bill Cunningham: Accessories as Co-Stars
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'September Fashion Week (2014)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The spotlight at fashion week was on accessories, especially whimsical ones: lock and chain necklaces from Chanel, or Lagerfeld fur doll ornaments from Fendi.
lead_paragraph: The spotlight at fashion week was on accessories, especially whimsical ones: lock and chain necklaces from Chanel, or Lagerfeld fur doll ornaments from Fendi.

headline: In the Face of Nudity, It’s All About Eye Contact
abstract: “Denuded,” by the Croatian choreographer Bruno Isakovic, puts much of its meaning into the performer’s breathing, direct gaze and small movements.
lead_paragraph: First, she removed all of her clothing. The act looked routine, as if she were preparing for a bath. She had the attitude of a nude model accustomed to disrobing for art students. Or, equally commonplace these days, of a contemporary dancer accustomed to performing in the buff.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Accessories as Co-Stars
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The spotlight at Fashion Week was on accessories.
lead_paragraph: The spotlight at fashion week was on accessories, especially whimsical ones: lock and chain necklaces from Chanel, or Lagerfeld fur doll ornaments from Fendi. Strawberry ice cream cones appeared on a handbag, hat and tee, while tweeds and other traditional fabrics were integrated with sneakers, speeding into the mainstream. Sandals and lacy footwear held their own. The black cameras of photographers captured shows, but the newest models wore gold.

headline: On This Day: Nixon and Kennedy Debate
abstract: On this day in history, Nixon and Kennedy met in the first publicly televised presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: From Ronald Reagan’s “there you go again” to Al Gore’s sigh, presidential debates have long featured flawed stagecraft and verbal stumbles.

headline: Ted Cruz and Rand Paul Make Appeals to Social Conservatives
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The presumed Republican presidential contenders reached out with personal stories and political reassurances at the Values Voter Summit.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas invoked the redemptive story of his parents, both plagued by too much drinking, to show the role that faith has played in his life. Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky, who took the stage as a video of a fetal ultrasound played for the crowd, said that liberty, virtue and God were intertwined, and he quoted Corinthians to make his point.

headline: Seven Beds, Hudson River Views
abstract: The outdoor presentation of “Everything by my side,” by Fernando Rubio of Buenos Aires, is part of the Crossing the Line festival.
lead_paragraph: It was perfect weather for hopping into bed, in public, with a total stranger. On Friday afternoon, the temperature was a glorious 75, and the water was glittering off Pier 45 in Hudson River Park.

headline: Evening Hours | Night of Grandeur
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera opens in its usual style, onstage and off.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera opens in its usual style, onstage and off.

headline: China’s Top Design Talent Descends on Beijing
abstract: The fourth incarnation of the city’s Design Week, beginning tomorrow across Beijing, is a showcase for the country’s artistry and innovation.
lead_paragraph: Across China, the start of October is synonymous with Golden Week, the public holiday commemorating the founding of the People’s Republic. But since the launch of Beijing Design Week in 2011, it’s also become an occasion to celebrate the country’s burgeoning design scene. Running from Sept. 26 – Oct. 3, the fourth edition of BJDW will be as massive and diverse as Beijing itself, featuring hundreds of events ranging from straight-laced industry forums at China Millennium Monument to experimental sound art on city buses. New additions this year include a design film festival, an original brand and e-commerce platform promoting Chinese designers, and Plug-IN Stations, architect-designed kiosks to help visitors and locals engage. Here, a selection of highlights from the Design Hop program, which spans four areas of the capital.

headline: No Time for Car Shopping? Click ‘Print’ to Make Your Own
keywords: ['Automobiles', '3-D Printers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A Phoenix company used a process known as 3-D printing to build a car made from the same composite that is used to make Lego bricks, reinforced with carbon fiber.
lead_paragraph: The sign’s message was clear enough: Please Do Not Touch. For some visitors, however, the temptation was too great.

headline: Christian Louboutin Shares Stories on Showgirls, Shoes and Theater
abstract: In our latest installment of this series, T’s senior market editor, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, interviews the shoe designer at the Studio 54 theater.
lead_paragraph: In the latest installation of our T Time video series, T’s senior market editor, Malina Joseph Gilchrist, interviews the shoe designer Christian Louboutin at the Studio 54 theater. Louboutin talks about sneaking into the second acts of musicals as a kid, interning at the famed Parisian cabaret Folies Bergère and the genesis of his signature red soles.

headline: Change the Oil ... or the Toner?
abstract: Some recent innovations in large-scale 3-D printing technology enabled Local Motors, a Phoenix-area company, to build the Strati, a 3-D printed vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Some recent innovations in large-scale 3-D printing technology enabled Local Motors, a Phoenix-area company, to build the Strati, a 3-D printed vehicle.

headline: A Century of Speed, Weather Permitting
abstract: Heavy rain at the Bonneville Salt Flats, “the best natural place on Earth to go fast in a vehicle,” has forced the cancellation of Speed Week.
lead_paragraph: “Designing a car that looks like an anchovy, has a 3,000-horsepower engine and is capable of going 500 miles per hour is not particularly difficult,” said Ron Main, builder of the Speed Demon, a needlelike racecar that holds the record, at a fraction over 439 miles per hour, as the world’s fastest vehicle powered by a piston engine.

headline: Less Tension, More Optimism
abstract: The Paris Motor Show is about to begin, and more than 80 vehicles are expected to make their world premieres.
lead_paragraph: The mood should be lighter and brighter at this year’s Paris Motor Show than at the last one in 2012, when environmentalists demonstrated, disgruntled autoworkers violently protested and police tear-gassed a crowd that broke through barriers outside the show.

headline: The Speed Trials at Bonneville
abstract: While it’s no longer the official fastest place on earth, competitors still flock to the Salt Flats — even when a soggy course forces the cancellation of Speed Week.
lead_paragraph: While it’s no longer the official fastest place on earth, competitors still flock to the Salt Flats — even when a soggy course forces the cancellation of Speed Week.

headline: In the Studio | Clare Waight Keller of Chloé
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: Clare Waight Keller, the creative director for Chloé, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how her visual references, books and photos requires three separate desks for work and stockpiling.
lead_paragraph: Clare Waight Keller, the creative director for Chloé, chats with Vanessa Friedman about how her visual references, books and photos requires three separate desks for work and stockpiling.

headline: Play Hits the Road; He Hits the Bank
abstract: The Tony-winning “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” by Christopher Durang, will be romping across regional stages this season as the most produced play on a Top 10 list.
lead_paragraph: For the playwright Christopher Durang, the view beyond the Hudson is looking very attractive these days. “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” his American comedic riff on Chekhovian themes, will be produced in 27 theaters around the country in the coming season. That puts it at the head of the annual Top 10 list of most performed plays, not including Shakespeare or holiday shows, compiled by American Theater magazine.

headline: The Artist’s Life, as Seen From a Piano Teacher’s Bench
abstract: After meeting Seymour Bernstein, a concert pianist who became a teacher, Ethan Hawke thought someone should make a documentary about him. So he did.
lead_paragraph: Lana Turner was discovered at a Hollywood soda fountain. John Wayne got his big break while working as a prop man. But the path that took Seymour Bernstein, an 87-year-old piano teacher, to the silver screen this year must rank as one of the most improbable of all.

headline: At Rikers, a Need for Accountability
abstract: The Doe Fund, the Justice Policy Institute and Assemblyman Daniel J. O’Donnell respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Thom Yorke, Radiohead Artist, Releases Album via BitTorrent
abstract: Mr. Yorke, Radiohead’s lead singer, said he wanted to test a new way for artists to release their work online.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Radiohead attempted a bold experiment in media distribution by letting its fans pay any price — even nothing — for the band’s album “In Rainbows.”

headline: From Scotland, a Bridge Hand That Might Need a Guess
abstract: Each of the daily bulletins at the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships included a card-play problem submitted by Jim Patrick of Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Each of the daily bulletins at the fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships, in Glasgow from Sept. 8 to 14, included a card-play problem submitted by Jim Patrick of Scotland. The diagramed deal caught my eye. It was originally described in “Tiger Bridge,” by Freddie North and Jeremy Flint.

headline: Casino Magnate Steve Wynn Sues Short-Seller for Slander
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Casinos', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Gambling', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In his suit, Mr. Wynn contended that the hedge fund founder James Chanos falsely claimed that Mr. Wynn’s company had violated laws against bribing foreign officials.
lead_paragraph: As far as billionaire spats go, the brewing fight between the casino billionaire Stephen A. Wynn and the short-seller James S. Chanos may be among the most unusual.

headline: Just Say No
abstract: Refusal is a style that reaches for something more refined, more personal, more true.
lead_paragraph: If part of being a happy person is having the ability to say yes — to new people, ideas and experiences — part of being a stylish one seems to be the ability to say no. Mastery of the art of refusal is something every person of great style I’ve ever come across shares: the confidence to reject trends or conventions — whether of living, dressing or decorating — that don’t feel uplifting or authentic.

headline: After One Product Recall, Fitbit Faces a New Safety Inquiry
abstract: A federal product safety investigation into the Fitbit Flex comes only months after the company recalled another of its activity-monitoring wristbands, the Fitbit Force, over complaints of skin irritation.
lead_paragraph: Fitbit, the popular maker of activity-monitoring wristbands, ran into trouble earlier this year after some consumers complained of severe skin irritations from the Fitbit Force.

headline: Network Premiere Week Prompts Cheers at ABC and Groans at Fox
abstract: ABC’s Thursday night of dramas posted impressive ratings, while Fox’s only bright spot was “Gotham.”
lead_paragraph: The traditional broadcast networks have faced an onslaught of challenges recently, including Netflix, binge viewing and a proliferation of hot shows on cable. But after the first four days of network premiere week, it appears that all is not lost.

headline: Indelible Photos of Derek Jeter
abstract: As Derek Jeter retires from the game he dominated, Barton Silverman looks back on his favorite moments photographing the Yankee star.
lead_paragraph: As Derek Jeter retires from the game he dominated, Barton Silverman looks back on his favorite moments photographing the Yankee star.

headline: For Arianna Huffington and Kobe Bryant: First, Success. Then Sleep.
abstract: It took years for Arianna Huffington and Kobe Bryant to learn that unwinding can be as valuable as driving hard toward their goals. Meditation is now an important part of their lives.
lead_paragraph: They may have seemed an unlikely pair, but it didn’t take long for Kobe Bryant, the Los Angeles Lakers star, and Arianna Huffington, co-founder and editor in chief of the Huffington Post Media Group, to develop the easy familiarity of old pals. Soon after Ms. Huffington, 64, arrived at Antonello Ristorante in Santa Ana, Calif., Mr. Bryant, 36, walked in, speaking fluent Italian to the waiters who trailed in his wake.

headline: Protesters Plead With Rouhani to Free British-Iranian Woman Jailed Over Volleyball
abstract: An Iranian student at Yale pressed Iran’s president this week to free a woman detained in Tehran “only for the act of trying to watch volleyball.”
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Rick Gladstone reported, President Hassan Rouhani was confronted by two protesters in New York on Wednesday, who held up images of political prisoners jailed in Tehran, a reminder that some of his reformist supporters are losing patience with his gradualist approach.

headline: At the Wedding Dresser, Altering Before the Altar
abstract: Susan Ruddie’s bridal atelier in Brooklyn, the Wedding Dresser, is also her home — and a destination for brides who need alterations to off-the-rack or vintage gowns.
lead_paragraph: Off the main drag of Flatbush Avenue and its jerk chicken counters and Caribbean grocers stocking fresh coconuts and live crabs is a six-story apartment building at 45 Linden Boulevard. With crown molding and an intricate tiled floor, the lobby evokes prewar opulence, now a little worse for wear. There are 57 units in the building, but 4E is surely the busiest. The space doubles as Susan Ruddie’s home and her bridal atelier, the Wedding Dresser. “We used to have a living room,” Ms. Ruddie said. “Now all the furniture is in storage.”

headline: Was Painless Parker a Vaudeville Joke or a Real Brooklyn Dentist?
abstract: A 1910 magazine article described Edgar Rudolph Randolph Parker, a rabid self-promoter, as “the most conceited charlatan that dental quackery has ever known.”
lead_paragraph: Q. I had always thought that the dentist named Painless Parker was a vaudeville joke, but my wife insists there was a real one in Brooklyn. Was there?

headline: Don’t Put the Sunblock Away Just Yet
abstract: Taking in the warm weather at Hudson River Park in Manhattan on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Taking in the warm weather at Hudson River Park in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: How the Roosevelts Achieved Peace in Our House
abstract: When the Ken Burns PBS series on the Roosevelts was shown, we all were riveted ... together.
lead_paragraph: In our multigenerational household, we typically spend our weeknights in our own entertainment zones. Call it a food court of different visual and audio tastes, but we always gravitate to our own age or gender groups once darkness falls on our home.

headline: Milton Cardona, Keeper of New York Salsa’s Beat, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Cardona played percussion on hundreds of albums ranging from Latin and Santeria music to fusions by the likes of David Byrne, Paul Simon and Herbie Hancock.
lead_paragraph: Milton Cardona, a Puerto Rican percussionist who was a mainstay of New York salsa, a studio musician on hundreds of albums and a Santeria priest who introduced sacred traditional rhythms to secular audiences, died on Sept. 19 in the Bronx. He was 69.

headline: In the Homestretch, Obama Comes On Strong
abstract: He loses an attorney general, but takes an assertive stance at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: “The enemy of my enemy is my friend,” says the ancient proverb. But don’t tell that to President Obama, who is furiously bombing Bashar al-Assad’s enemies in Syria while insisting that Mr. Assad’s regime is also the enemy. Best also not to remind Mr. Obama about leading from behind, or of his arguments against being drawn into the Syrian civil war or getting embroiled in any Middle Eastern conflicts.

headline: Inside the T Fall 2014 Design Issue
abstract: The issue explores the power of refusal when it comes to interiors and important life matters.
lead_paragraph: T loves to say yes — to new people, places and ideas — but this issue is all about the power of restraint. Take the Scandinavian architects Claesson Koivisto Rune, who create warm, pared-back spaces that are low on embellishments but high on style, as evidenced by a Stockholm apartment distinguished by a single, spectacular brass cube. Or the couturier Stephan Janson, who years ago left the limelight in order to dress a more discriminating set of women. And after creating interiors for clients like Vera Wang and Anna Wintour, the decorator Stephen Sills passed up the opportunity to move into a palatial home, choosing instead to pour his heart and soul into a tiny, perfect apartment. Elsewhere in the issue, the Brussels-based designers Jorge Almada and Anna-Marie Midy forgo modern luxuries in favor of cowboy charm in their rustic Mexican casita; Jody Rosen gets twisted up in a convention as old as time — the humble knot — and meets one of its greatest champions; Malcolm Gladwell and Sarah Silverman politely decline cookies made of crickets, among other dubious temptations; and we examine the legacy of the legendary Braun designer Dieter Rams, whose career can be best summed up with the words “less but better.” See all stories from the issue >>

headline: A Defining Question in an iPhone Age: Live for the Moment or Record It?
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'Smartphones', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: It is no longer enough to record seemingly every last moment of life with your smartphone, it seems. Near death is fair game, too.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue Flight 1416 was just minutes into its trip from Long Beach, Calif., to Austin, Tex., on Sept. 18 when Scott Welch, a passenger in Seat 5A, heard a suspicious pop. Moments later, smoke began to fill the cabin, clogging the air to the point that he could see only a few rows in front of him, he said. The starboard engine of the Airbus A320, he soon learned, had blown.

headline: Mexico Holds 8 in Army in Inquiry of 22 Deaths
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The arrests represent a reversal for officials who initially described the June encounter as a shootout.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY —  An army officer and seven soldiers have been detained by the Mexican Defense Department in connection with the killing of 22 people in what is being investigated as a possible massacre in western Mexico in June.

headline: The Bro Hug: Embracing a Change in Custom
abstract: Among young people and certain gregarious and gestural adults, the hug has become the default greeting, and handshakes have faded.
lead_paragraph: The danger is all too real: One weekend, you run into a work colleague at a bar in a city that is not the city you both work in. Mike? In Baltimore? In the same dive bar as you? Crazy!

headline: U.S. Considers a No-Fly Zone to Protect Civilians From Airstrikes by Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Kurds', 'No-Fly Zones']
abstract: The administration is open to establishing a buffer zone along the Turkish-Syrian border, where tens of thousands of Syrians have sought refuge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has not ruled out establishing a no-fly zone over northeastern Syria to protect civilians from airstrikes by the Syrian government, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Friday.

headline: A Night Out With Stephin Merritt, the Singer for Magnetic Fields
abstract: The singer from the Magnetic Fields has a new book, with Roz Chast, of short poems and illustrations.
lead_paragraph: Stephin Merritt strolled into Bryant Park just before 6 p.m. on Tuesday for a Scrabble social and discovered that he was the only person who showed up to play.

headline: Federal Court Declines to Take Up Wisconsin’s Voter ID Law
abstract: A federal appeals court on Friday narrowly decided against hearing arguments on a photo identification requirement for Wisconsin voters.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With a competitive election for governor of Wisconsin less than six weeks away, a federal appeals court on Friday narrowly decided against hearing arguments on a recently instituted photo identification requirement for the state’s voters.

headline: When It All Comes Down to Blurbs
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Sheila Weller discusses the fallout from her latest book, “The News Sorority,” about three of the most successful women in the news media.
lead_paragraph: It is a tabloid truism that tales of relationships between powerful women, no matter how nuanced, will be boiled down to a stereotype: “Catfight!”

headline: Roger Goodell Cites N.F.L.’s Efforts to Fight Abuse
abstract: Commissioner Goodell has met with players union officials, former athletes and law enforcement representatives in an effort to create a new personal-conduct policy.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to team executives on Friday, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said he had met with the players association, 11 former players and law enforcement officials to help create a new personal-conduct policy.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: Joe discusses what executives around the globe are doing to reduce emissions and embrace sustainable business practices.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan experienced historic marches, meetings, speeches and pledges this week as hundreds of thousands of people converged on the Big Apple to demand action on climate change. World leaders joined hundreds of business executives at the U.N. to reaffirm emission reduction commitments and pledge additional support for renewable energy initiatives. As the environmental activists and diplomatic representatives head home, it’s time to ask, “What’s next?” This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss the impact of the Rockefeller family’s divestment from fossil fuels and how businesses can take the lead in creating a green economy. Plus, Cadillac’s move to New York — where will they find enough parking for all those Escalades?

headline: Eight Mannequins at a Wisconsin Museum Tell of a Holocaust Tragedy
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Museums']
abstract: An exhibition at the Jewish Museum Milwaukee is a story of life and death, and a recollection during the High Holy Days of mortality and persecution.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Eight female mannequins stand in an exhibition room of the Jewish Museum Milwaukee here, clad in smart and urbane apparel, the sort that might have come from a “Thin Man” film, or something with Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire. The clothing went on display about two weeks ago. The fashions are both text and textile, a story of life and death told in fabric, and a recollection during the High Holy Days of mortality and persecution.

headline: ‘Like Mother Used To Make’
abstract: A short story from a writer participating in Literate Sunday, a writing workshop, literary social club and email list.
lead_paragraph: A short story from a writer participating in Literate Sunday, a writing workshop, literary social club and email list.

headline: Submissions Welcome. No Names, Please.
abstract: A bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, hosts short-story workshops where the authors are anonymous.
lead_paragraph: Walk into the Plank, a dim, creatively furnished dive in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on a Sunday around 5 p.m., and the number of patrons quietly reading is surprising. They are bent over their beer-stained pages while sitting at the bar, on nearby chairs and on the patio out back.

headline: Giants’ Former Pro Bowler Leads a High School Powerhouse
abstract: Antonio Pierce, a captain for the 2008 Super Bowl champion Giants, has taken over as head coach at Long Beach Polytechnic High, a dominant program in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif. — As Antonio Pierce, the football coach at Long Beach Polytechnic High, walked off the school’s lumpy grass practice field on a recent afternoon, a crisp, detail-oriented, two-and-a-half-hour practice behind him, he laughed at the question tossed his way.

headline: Iran Barkley Is Hoping to Fight Again, This Time to Be a Benefactor
abstract: Mr. Barkley, known in his boxing heyday as the Blade, is driven to fight again at age 54 to help a niece who has lung cancer and to improve his own finances.
lead_paragraph: Among the lean, glistening bodies of young boxers at Gleason’s Gym in Brooklyn, a man in his 50s climbed into a boxing ring and began circling slowly, throwing a few easy jabs and soft hooks.

headline: Policing and Minorities
abstract: Abigail Kramer of the Center for New York City Affairs criticizes Mayor Bill de Blasio’s defense of “broken windows” policing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Sentence of ‘Service’?
abstract: A reader objects to the notion of community service as an alternative to jail time.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Toronto, Restored
abstract: “We who live in Toronto do not define ourselves in any way by the antics, the misdemeanors and the lack of leadership by Rob Ford,” a resident writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Transmission of Ebola: Two Microbiologists Weigh In
abstract: Two experts say we shouldn’t waste time worrying if Ebola might in the future be transmitted through the air.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Protests in Venezuela
abstract: The chargé d’affaires of the Venezuelan Embassy objects to an editorial’s criticism of the country’s government.

headline: Tougher Shield for Soldiers Against Predatory Lenders
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Law and Legislation', 'Payday Loans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Loopholes in a law have left hundreds of thousands of service members across the country vulnerable to potentially predatory loans.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is proposing sweeping changes to a seven-year-old federal law that was intended to shield service members and their families from high-cost loans tied to their paychecks, a move that reflects the Defense Department’s growing recognition that lenders have exploited loopholes in the law.

headline: Colorado’s Perceived Left Turn Puts Governor in Tight Race
abstract: Gov. John W. Hickenlooper and his opponent, Bob Beauprez, are trying to appeal to urban and rural voters who are split ideologically.
lead_paragraph: JULESBURG, Colo. — When a Democratic mayor and former brewpub owner named John W. Hickenlooper was elected governor four years ago, he did it with support from voters like Mark Turner. Mr. Turner is a gun dealer, a small-town politician in eastern Colorado and an avowed enemy of partisan labels — “Just call me an American,” he says. He liked Mr. Hickenlooper’s wonky centrism and positive campaigning style.

headline: A Greek Politician Willing to Face the People
abstract: Rena Dourou’s election as prefect of Athens represents the biggest victory so far for the left-wing Syriza Party.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Rena Dourou, the new prefect of Athens and a member of the left-wing Syriza Party, was taking stock of the cavernous office she inherited recently, making plans to move to a cheaper and more functional alternative.

headline: Friday Night Music: Quilt
abstract: We haven’t had that spirit here since 1969.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know what I’d do without Bob Boilen — I think half or more the music I listen to over the course of a week comes from bands I discovered through his Tiny Desk Concerts. And here’s another — a young band that makes me want to drop acid and wear tie-died clothing, which is a great feeling when you’re 61.

headline: A Virtual Butterfly Hunt
abstract: We asked readers of NYTimes.com to send us monarch butterfly photographs.
lead_paragraph: In the most recent N.Y.C. Nature column, Dave Taft wrote about the monarch butterfly and its migration. Unlike migratory birds, individual butterflies do not complete the trip from the northern United States to Mexico and back.

headline: Raising Hands to Join Peacekeeping Forces
abstract: Mexico, Indonesia, Mongolia and Bangladesh pledge greater participation, and Japan says it will change its laws so it can send troops.
lead_paragraph: Japan said it would change its laws in order to be able to send soldiers on United Nations peacekeeping missions. Mexico said it would revive its involvement in United Nations peacekeeping. Indonesia, Mongolia and Bangladesh promised to prepare troops for rapid deployment.

headline: Beatification Brings Opus Dei Into the Open
abstract: The beatification Mass for a former leader of Opus Dei is an unusually public show of force for the movement, one of the most powerful and discreet in Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Beyond reverence, there is always a hint of mystery, even politics, at play whenever the Roman Catholic Church decides to advance someone toward sainthood. But when that step involves one of the more revolutionizing popes of recent history advancing a figure from one of the most powerful and discreet of Catholic movements, the mysteries and politics seem to run even deeper.

headline: Curses, Fooled Again!
keywords: ['Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Television', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Cameras']
abstract: The new “Candid Camera” reveals that today’s pervasive technology makes people easy targets.
lead_paragraph: I SPENT the summer producing new “Candid Camera” shows, and among the many things I observed after a 10-year hiatus was that people are more easily fooled than ever.

headline: A Difficult Passage From Church to Condominium
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Condominiums', 'Christian Science', 'Stained Glass']
abstract: To convert a Central Park West building to apartments, its new owners face problems like dealing with the stained-glass windows in the landmark exterior.
lead_paragraph: In its first 100 years, it was an architecturally distinguished setting for the formal Sunday services of the Christian Scientists who built it. Then, until a few months ago, it was the East Coast base of a gospel-infused nondenominational church from Los Angeles.

headline: To Hear Him Tell It on the Stage, Process-Serving Is a Lark
abstract: A man who works as a process server in the Bronx finds some humor in his work and adds it to his stand-up-comedy routine.
lead_paragraph: Angel Gutierrez, sporting a ball cap, with his beloved Pacino-as-Scarface arm tattoo peeking out from a T-shirt, arrived two weeks ago at a Bronx walk-up on his list. The front door was unlocked — a small gift — and he breezed in as if he lived there. He paused to press the buzzer for a top-floor apartment, but didn’t stop to wait for a reply.

headline: Judge Grants Temporary Stay in Argentina Default Case
abstract: The ruling by Judge Thomas P. Griesa of the Federal District Court in Manhattan allows Citigroup to make a $5 million payment to bondholders.
lead_paragraph: A group of New York hedge funds that sued Argentina is now asking a New York court to lower the temperature a little on the long-running and acrimonious dispute.

headline: Don Keefer, Actor, Dies at 98; Had Bad Thoughts on ‘Twilight Zone’
abstract: Mr. Keefer was in the original Broadway cast of “Death of a Salesman” and had a long career in television and movies.
lead_paragraph: Don Keefer played many distinctive roles in a long acting career. He was the son of Willy Loman’s neighbor in the original Broadway cast of “Death of a Salesman,” which opened in 1949, and for the next half-century he was a sought-after character actor onstage and in films, including “The Caine Mutiny,” Woody Allen’s “Sleeper” and “Liar, Liar,” starring Jim Carrey.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Derek Jeter’s Big Hit, an Echo of Ted Williams’s Final Swing
abstract: Williams, a Red Sox legend, launched a home run in his final trek to the Fenway plate in 1960, but his relationship with the home fans was not as cordial as Jeter’s.
lead_paragraph: There was no expectation Thursday night that Derek Jeter would end his final home game with a thunderclap of a hit. This has, after all, been his worst full season, statistically.

headline: John Mack Carter, 86, Is Dead; Led ‘Big 3’ Women’s Magazines
abstract: Mr. Carter is believed to be the only person to edit all of the so-called Big Three women’s magazines: McCall’s, Ladies’ Home Journal and Good Housekeeping.
lead_paragraph: John Mack Carter, a Kentucky-born journalist who had the singular distinction of editing all of the so-called Big Three women’s magazines and, in doing so, helped transform the genre during the feminist era, died on Friday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: Iranian President Sees Little Progress on Nuclear Dispute
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani was notably less optimistic on relations with the West than he was as a new leader a year ago.
lead_paragraph: With a blunt demeanor that bordered on pessimism, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran said Friday that he was unhappy over the lack of progress in resolving his country’s protracted nuclear dispute with the major powers, less than two months before their self-imposed deadline for reaching a comprehensive agreement.

headline: Rutgers to Endow Chair Named for Gloria Steinem
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', "Women's Rights", 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Chairs', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Reflecting Ms. Steinem’s long career as a journalist as well as a public intellectual, the chair will be in media, culture and feminist studies.
lead_paragraph: Rutgers University is to announce on Monday that it is endowing a chair named for Gloria Steinem, a symbol of modern American feminism.

headline: 3 Chinese Students, Missing for Months, Surface to Denounce Uighur Scholar
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: In a video broadcast nationally, one of the students said his former professor, Ilham Tohti, who was sentenced Tuesday to life in prison, worked to “hype” ethnic tensions with Han Chinese.
lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China — The three students appeared one after another in video images broadcast to millions of Chinese, sitting behind bars and denouncing Ilham Tohti, the man they had once called their mentor.

headline: Playing a Titanic Tuba
abstract: Carl Fischer Music owns what some believe is the world’s largest tuba. Playing it requires a strong set of lungs.
lead_paragraph: Carl Fischer Music owns what some believe is the world’s largest tuba. Playing it requires a strong set of lungs.

headline: Signaling Post-Snowden Era, New iPhone Locks Out N.S.A.
keywords: ['iPhone', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Security', 'Privacy', 'iOS (Operating System)']
abstract: The new iPhone creates a unique code that scrambles information, disrupting the investigative abilities of American law enforcement and intelligence agencies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Devoted customers of Apple products these days worry about whether the new iPhone 6 will bend in their jean pockets. The National Security Agency and the nation’s law enforcement agencies have a different concern: that the smartphone is the first of a post-Snowden generation of equipment that will disrupt their investigative abilities.

headline: With Players Out of Sight, Knicks Preview New Look
abstract: The Knicks are about to draw the curtain on a new system, a new coach, new goals and a new perspective.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The gymnasium at the Knicks’ training center houses two full-length courts. On Friday morning, the courts were separated by a large blue curtain. On one side was a news conference, featuring Phil Jackson, Derek Fisher and Steve Mills. From the other side came the sounds of bouncing basketballs and squeaking sneakers. The players who were making the racket were hidden from view.

headline: Georgia Senate Race Takes on Negative Tone
abstract: The Senate nominees in Georgia trade attack ads.
lead_paragraph: The tight race for Georgia’s open Senate seat has taken on a particularly harsh tone in recent days, with David Perdue, the Republican candidate, deploying attack ads that accuse Michelle Nunn, his Democratic rival, of financing groups with links to terrorism.

headline: Pennsylvania Priest Accused of Abuse Was Reported 5 Years Ago, Records Show
abstract: A Virginia-based charity says it reported complaints against the Rev. Joseph D. Maurizio Jr. to the Altoona-Johnstown Diocese.
lead_paragraph: Details of child sexual abuse that led to charges against a Roman Catholic priest on Thursday were reported to his Pennsylvania diocese nearly five years ago, court records show, but the church authorities did not remove him as a pastor.

headline: It’s a Giant. It’s a Novelty. It’s a Tuba Named Big Carl.
abstract: A music publisher is trying to bring Big Carl — a tuba that stands nearly 8 feet tall, contains 60 feet of tubing and weighs about 100 pounds — back to public view.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, there was a tuba named Tubby, a brassy musical instrument who boasted that he could sing. He was first given voice in 1945 through lyrics recorded by the comedian Danny Kaye and was later reincarnated by the Manhattan Transfer, Annette Funicello, Julia Child and Meredith Vieira. His story has been translated into dozens of languages.

headline: Not for the Faint of Heart
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Real fear and loathing on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, ads for congressional candidates would not look like promos for “Homeland.”

headline: Impasse Over Iran’s Nuclear Program
abstract: There has been no real sign of movement, but proposals under discussion could be the basis for a compromise.
lead_paragraph: With top leaders attending the United Nations General Assembly, this is the moment to break the logjam on a comprehensive deal limiting Iran’s nuclear program. But so far there has been no real sign of movement, much less a breakthrough, despite negotiations among Secretary of State John Kerry; Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif; and Catherine Ashton, the European negotiator. The fault lies mainly with Iran.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Move to Thwart Deadly Domestic Abuse
abstract: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office wants to determine whether those charged with even minor domestic violence crimes have the potential to kill.
lead_paragraph: With research suggesting that domestic violence-related homicides are predictable, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office has begun to study whether they are preventable.

headline: Losing the Race Against Ebola
abstract: Two new projections show the urgent need for faster action, to prevent hundreds of thousands or even a million deaths.
lead_paragraph: The race to control the expanding Ebola epidemic in West Africa looks increasingly dire. Official projections of how fast the virus will spread have soared while pledges of help from advanced nations and global organizations have failed to keep pace.

headline: Saturday’s College Football Games to Watch
abstract: No. 6 Texas A&M faces an Arkansas team that has not won a Southeastern Conference game since October 2012, and No. 13 Missouri plays South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: ARKANSAS vs. 6 TEXAS A&M

headline: Harlem’s Flower and Chess Man, Forced Into an Unwanted Move
abstract: For years, Sonny Gibbs sold flowers and taught chess at the edge of a playground, but the parks department banished him this spring because he had no permit.
lead_paragraph: For 23 years, Sonny Gibbs sold flowers at the edge of Abraham Lincoln Playground on 135th Street and Fifth Avenue in Harlem and taught chess to anyone who wanted to learn.

headline: Labor Rights for Home Care Workers
abstract: The states have had plenty of time to figure out how to carry out the new rule. Further delay would only prolong the indefensible.
lead_paragraph: A new rule that will give home care workers basic labor protections is supposed to go into effect on Jan. 1, 2015. But several states are pushing for delay, saying they need more time to work through how the rule will affect their Medicaid programs, which pay many home care bills.

headline: The Quickening Pace of Gun Sprees
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Gun Control', 'Editorials', 'School Shootings', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Research']
abstract: An F.B.I. survey has some information crucial to galvanizing support for stronger safety laws, but far more attention is needed.
lead_paragraph: It is a sorry commentary on the shooting sprees that regularly afflict the nation that only recently has the Federal Bureau of Investigation been authorized to delve into how prevalent the threat has become. The bureau’s new survey across the past 13 years concludes that horrific shootings like those in 2012 at the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., are occurring with greater frequency.

headline: The Doomed Icon on the Balcony
abstract: The John W. Engeman Theater at Northport is offering Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Evita,” the 1979 Broadway musical about a young woman from the sticks who rises to become Argentina’s first lady and spiritual leader.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Lloyd Webber’s musicals rarely garner critical acclaim but often achieve enormous staying power, on Broadway and in regional theaters. Consider “Evita,” one of the composer’s most popular shows, now at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport in a production that highlights the insistent allure of its melodies — and underscores some of its flaws.

headline: Paralysis Isn’t Inevitable
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Gun Control', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Hedge Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Solutions to “intractable” problems could be closer than we think.
lead_paragraph: One of the hardest things for us to do is to envision a future that is different from the present. For instance, we live in an age of paralyzed politics, so it is hard, in the here and now, to imagine what could change that. A second example: It is difficult to think of a scenario where federal gun legislation could be passed over the objections of the National Rifle Association. And a third: Income inequality has been the trend for some three decades; doesn’t it look as if it will always be that way?

headline: Words From a Good Buddy
abstract: The return of Martin Ashwood-Smith and George Barany offers us a way to remember a recent loss in the show business community.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — In a weird sort of way, this 69-worder by Martin Ashwood-Smith and George Barany has become a tribute puzzle. As Will Shortz notes below, this crossword was pushed up in the rotation to honor the passing of legendary performer JOAN RIVERS.

headline: In an Opulent Space, Invoking Quaintness
abstract: Cinque Terre, a new restaurant that opened in June in Huntington Station, offers Italian fare in three dining rooms.
lead_paragraph: I had high hopes for Cinque Terre, a new Italian restaurant that opened in June in Huntington Station. Anthony and Pam Page, the owners, also own the friendly and old-fashioned Verona in Farmingdale.

headline: Presidential Candidate in Navajo Nation Protests a Language Requirement
abstract: Chris Deschene, a former member of the Arizona House of Representatives, has struggled to speak his tribe’s language in his campaign for president of the Navajo Nation.
lead_paragraph: TUBA CITY, Ariz. — In his run for president of the Navajo Nation, Chris Deschene has presented voters with impressive credentials: A veteran of the Marine Corps, he is a lawyer, a trained engineer and a former member of the Arizona House of Representatives, where he represented part of the tribe’s reservation.

headline: Giants’ Offensive Evolution Continues in a 2-Win Week
abstract: On a team that appears to be suddenly dominant offensively, Eli Manning scored a rare rushing touchdown in a stampede of the Washington Redskins.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Lost in the pass-happy performance of Eli Manning during the Giants’ 45-14 stampede of the Washington Redskins on Thursday was the rarest of sights: an Eli Manning rushing touchdown.

headline: Collection of Trains to Be Sold at Auction
abstract: The owners of Railroads on Parade, which has delighted millions of visitors, are hoping that a wealthy patron will buy the model trains and keep them intact.
lead_paragraph: POTTERSVILLE, N.Y. — In the heart of the Adirondacks, about 25 miles north of the well-trafficked T-shirt shops and arcades of lower Lake George, a familiar but solitary tourist attraction is making its last run.

headline: Putting Tomatoes First, by Putting Them On Last
abstract: Papa’s Tomato Pies had operated in various spots in Trenton for more than 100 years but has a new home in Robbinsville.
lead_paragraph: The tomato vine is a link between seasons. In summer, you stand over the sink, with a slurry of juice and seeds running down wrists and chin, chomping a sun-warmed fruit. In fall, the oven looks all right again and you begin to think about covering what food you’ve got in crust. In New Jersey, the tomatoes are still rolling in, but the nights are cool. What sounds better than tomato pie?

headline: Violence on the Field Reflected on the Stage
abstract: In Stony Point in Rockland County, “Playing the Assassin” takes a good, solid shot at professional football while telling a gripping story.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League has plenty to worry about just now, and it isn’t going to concern itself with an 85-minute, two-character play at a small barn theater in Rockland County. But football executives, fans, coaches and players at all levels would be well-advised to see — and ponder — David Robson’s “Playing the Assassin,” the final offering of the season at Penguin Rep Theater.

headline: Again, Nets’ New Season Brings With It New Coach
abstract: Lionel Hollins, the latest coach to enter the revolving door that seems to come with the territory of leading the Nets, has a style that distinguishes him, at least verbally, from Jason Kidd, his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Brook Lopez was asked if he knew how many different people had coached the Nets since the team picked him in the 2008 draft.

headline: Slide Show: Scenes From the Values Voter Summit
abstract: Photos from the Value Voters meeting in Washington.

headline: Derek Jeter’s Final Farewell Begins, Hosted by His Greatest Rivals
abstract: After a tearful goodbye at Yankee Stadium, Jeter sat out the first game of the final series of his career, which will be played in Boston.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Derek Jeter’s driver dropped him off at the wrong entrance at Fenway Park.

headline: Three Cities in New Jersey Alter Bike Sharing Plans
abstract: Jersey City, Weehawken and Hoboken find that introducing a new transit system, even a modest one, can be tricky.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — In February, when Hoboken, Jersey City and Weehawken announced that they planned to introduce New Jersey’s first bike-share network, Dawn Zimmer, the mayor of this mile-square city, praised it as the blossoming of a great transportation partnership.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Recap: Soderbergh’s Efficient Tour de Force
abstract: The episode was a seamless, symphonic presentation of the hospital’s involvement in a single event, a race riot that turned lower Manhattan into a domestic war zone.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 7: “Get the Rope”

headline: Fans Come to See Isles in Future Home. Not All Succeed.
abstract: Some Islanders fans found that the view from their seats at Barclays Center was obstructed when they arrived for Friday night’s preseason game against the Devils.
lead_paragraph: John and Nizzette Conlon and their two sons, all Islanders fans from St. James, N.Y., walked to their seats in Section 3 at the southwest end of Barclays Center and took one flabbergasted look.

headline: Everywhere You Look at the Craftsman Ale House, Brews and Batter
abstract: A convivial beer bar in Harrison has eight varieties of beer on tap every day, and more than 130 available in bottles or cans.
lead_paragraph: Here, some recent tweets from the Craftsman Ale House (@TheCraftsman):

headline: Virginia: Suspect in Disappearance Awaits Hearing
abstract: The suspect in the disappearance of an 18-year-old University of Virginia student was flown back to Charlottesville from Texas on Friday to face abduction charges, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the disappearance of an 18-year-old University of Virginia student was flown back to Charlottesville from Texas on Friday to face abduction charges, the authorities said. The suspect, Jesse Leroy Matthew Jr., 32, was being held without bond at the Charlottesville-Albemarle Regional Jail until a hearing scheduled for Oct. 2, said a city spokeswoman, Miriam Dickler. He had been in custody in Galveston, Tex., since Wednesday, when he was arrested after a woman called the police to report a man camping on a beach. The police have said that Mr. Matthew was the last person seen with the student, Hannah Graham, before she disappeared on Sept. 13.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 27, 2014
lead_paragraph: We told them we would be slaughtered if they did not provide us with ammunition.

headline: In Pursuit of Everything
abstract: With its crazy-quilt menu and confusing atmospherics, Blue Plate Kitchen in West Hartford could serve as a primer on the dangers of trying to be all things to all people.
lead_paragraph: Set in the bustling hub of Bishops Corner in West Hartford, Blue Plate Kitchen seems to be a restaurant perfectly in tune with the spirit of the age.

headline: Royals Clinch First Postseason Berth Since 1985
abstract: Kansas City is back in the playoffs for the first time in 29 years, ending the longest active playoff drought for any team in the four major North American sports.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Once catcher Salvador Perez squeezed a foul pop-up the final out, first baseman Eric Hosmer embraced him. Then one by one, the rest of the Kansas City Royals converged to celebrate, players pouring out from the dugout and sprinting in from the bullpen. They jumped and shouted, and when they finally started to disperse, they hugged one another.

headline: Sex and Death, and Other Tough Subjects
abstract: Tony Kushner’s landmark AIDS drama “has difficult subject matter,” says Sean Harris, its director at Playhouse on Park, in West Hartford. “But it’s an important story.”
lead_paragraph: When the curtain goes up on “Angels in America” on Wednesday night at Playhouse on Park — when the ghost of Ethel Rosenberg sings a lullaby to Roy Cohn on his deathbed, when a Valium-loving young Mormon wife realizes her husband is gay, when heaven itself joins the wobbly Reagan-era fight against AIDS — it will be a highly personal triumph for its director, Sean Harris. And a huge risk for this five-year-old theater company in West Hartford.

headline: Enter Sandman
abstract: The opening production of Hartford Stage’s new season, “Ether Dome,” is about the 19th-century physicians, frauds and cranks who pioneered surgical anesthesia.
lead_paragraph: How much pain relief do doctors owe their patients? And how unorthodox can the remedies be? These could be up-to-the-minute talking points in a discussion of medical marijuana; they are also the questions animating the characters in Elizabeth Egloff’s play “Ether Dome,” about the 19th-century physicians, frauds and cranks who pioneered surgical anesthesia.

headline: Suit Protests Turf for Women’s World Cup
abstract: Several players said they would file a gender discrimination lawsuit in Canada next week against FIFA and the Canadian Soccer Association over plans to play the 2015 Women’s World Cup on artificial turf.
lead_paragraph: Several players said they would file a gender discrimination lawsuit in Canada next week against FIFA and the Canadian Soccer Association over plans to play the 2015 Women’s World Cup on artificial turf.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) MUSIC FOR CHANGE: THE GLOBAL CITIZEN FESTIVAL Jay Z, Alicia Keys, No Doubt, Carrie Underwood, Fun, the Roots and Tiesto headline this concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park, which features performances interspersed with the stories of people who enacted change in vaccines, education, sanitation and water, and hope to end extreme poverty by 2030. Tamron Hall oversees this hourlong prime-time special; Chris Hayes and Alex Wagner will host preshow coverage starting at 3 p.m. on MSNBC, with Ronan Farrow and Joy Reid reporting from backstage.

headline: Corrections: September 27, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
abstract: It’s Saturday but no rest for the fashionably weary.
lead_paragraph: The fashion week wheel, ever turning, is now spinning fast enough for the scene to blur. Yes, you may have to remind yourself, it is Saturday; it’s the weekend. That will give you something to chew over as you sit at Junya Watanabe’s show all the same, at the workweek hour of 9:30 a.m. No, there’s no rest for the fashionably weary. Saturday is packed. Haider Ackermann, the Colombian-born, Belgian-based specialist in louche luxe, follows at 10:30 a.m.

headline: Daughter for Chelsea Clinton (and Granddaughter for a Certain Couple)
abstract: The child, Charlotte, whose birth was announced on Twitter early Saturday, is the first for Ms. Clinton and her husband, Marc Mezvinsky.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton finally have the titles they have long wanted: Grandpa and Grandma.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Pro-Democracy Group Shifts to Collaborate With Student Protesters in Hong Kong
abstract: A gathering of thousands at the city’s government offices appeared to be an early start for bigger protests, which an established pro-democracy group expected to start on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The police in Hong Kong began tightening on Sunday a ring of security around thousands of pro-democracy protesters who have besieged the city government for three days. But by clearing the protesters and appeasing the Chinese Communist Party, the Hong Kong authorities could risk a bigger backlash from even more city residents, said experts.

headline: 100 Million Smart Things: A Conversation With Scott McGregor of Broadcom
abstract: The chief executive of Broadcom predicts a future of total facial recognition, DNA-based signatures and chips in our brains, and he wants his company’s semiconductors to be a part of all of it.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry is adding to its already impressive capacity for seeking the greatest possible scale. In a little over five years, it is said, 50 billion devices will be connected to the Internet. That is on top of data centers with millions of computer servers, several billion mobile devices, and all the gaming devices, personal computers, and other things with a chip inside.

headline: Analytics: What Readers Thought About A. O. Scott’s Claim That Adulthood Is Dead in American Culture
abstract: A. O. Scott’s essay on the death of patriarchy in American culture received more than 870 comments from readers. Here’s what they said.
lead_paragraph: The following graphic appears on the Reply All page in the Sept. 28 issue of the magazine.

headline: Leader of Catalonia Calls for Independence Vote
abstract: By signing the decree, the regional leader of Catalonia pushed the northeastern region into a risky and direct confrontation with the central government in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The regional leader of Catalonia signed a decree on Saturday to hold an independence vote, which the Spanish government has promised to block, pushing his northeastern region into a risky and direct confrontation with the central government in Madrid.

headline: Bad Economic Ideas
abstract: Talk to the invisible hand.
lead_paragraph: I review Jeff Madrick’s new book.

headline: Gross Gone
abstract: The bond king and his macro missteps.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know anything about what’s been going on internally at Pimco; I just read the same stories as everyone else. I have, however, written a lot about Pimco’s macroeconomic analysis (which drove its bond-investment decisions).

headline: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Mugler: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: BNP Paribas, After Scandal, Says Chairman Will Resign
abstract: Baudouin Prot is leaving in the wake of the institution’s guilty plea and fines in the United States for dealing with blacklisted countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The chairman of BNP Paribas, France’s largest bank, is stepping down as the institution seeks to move beyond the fallout from its guilty plea and nearly $9 billion in fines in the United States for its dealings with blacklisted countries.

headline: Pearls of Career Wisdom, Found in the Trash
abstract: Michael Cascio, a media consultant and former television executive, says nothing prepared him better for work and life than a summer job as a janitor.
lead_paragraph: As a business owner and television executive, I’ve interviewed lots of job candidates. They have their résumés ready, and they’re primed to show off their knowledge of the business. But they’re often thrown by a question I ask early in the interview: What did you do in the summers during college and high school?

headline: Turning Programming Into Child’s Play
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Parents who were frustrated by a lack of opportunities for their children to learn programming have designed products meant to appeal to children as young as 5.
lead_paragraph: Dash is a small blue robot that can be programmed to play the xylophone, kick a ball, act like a dog and deliver messages — for instance, a prerecorded rendition of the “Happy Birthday” song. Its head, which spins around, has a single, Cyclops-like eye. Sometimes Dash emits a cheerful chime — a sign that it approves of its programmer’s actions.

headline: How Ads Can Push Too Hard
abstract: Advertising slogans that are too aggressive when asking consumers to associate with a brand can be a turnoff, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: People like to associate with brands that reflect how they see themselves. That’s an axiom of advertising. And so we have slogans telling us that “Choosy Moms Choose Jif.” Or, “If you call yourself a sports fan, you gotta have DirecTV!”

headline: $199 Apple iPhone 6 Is Fiction, if Not Fantasy
abstract: Investors as well as consumers might want to look closely at the purchase plans that carriers are offering for Apple’s new iPhone 6.
lead_paragraph: What does it cost to buy a basic new iPhone 6? If you think the answer is $199, and you’re happy believing that, you may want to stop reading now.

headline: Giving Away Software to Make It More Valuable
abstract: Continuuity, a big-data start-up that spent three years developing data-analysis software, is donating it to the world as open source, and big business is taking notice.
lead_paragraph: A big-data start-up just destroyed itself to save itself. That is perhaps not a big deal, but it says a lot about where the world of big computing is headed.

headline: Penny Herscher of FirstRain: What Parents Can Teach a C.E.O.
abstract: A chief executive says the skills learned in raising a child are analogous to “nurturing a team and bringing a project to life.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Penny Herscher, the chief executive of FirstRain, a business analytics firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Looking at Productivity as a State of Mind
abstract: Policy makers often fret that worker productivity isn’t growing fast enough. And each of us also worries about individual productivity.
lead_paragraph: Policy makers often fret about the pace of worker productivity. But each of us also frets about the pace of our own individual productivity.

headline: Court Casts a New Light on a Bailout
keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: From the moment the New York Fed orchestrated the A.I.G. deal, the government has worked hard to keep its full picture from coming into view.
lead_paragraph: “I think by the time we get finished with this case and we have our trial, we’re going to have the full picture on everything that occurred regarding the government’s rescue of A.I.G.,” said Thomas C. Wheeler, a federal judge. “Why did they do it the way they did here?”

headline: Hotels Move Into Manhattan’s Garment District
abstract: Traditionally home to the New York’s fashion industry, the area offers a growing number of lodging options within walking distance to Broadway theaters.
lead_paragraph: For visitors to New York who are put off by the crowds — or the assertive super heroes — of Times Square, Manhattan’s garment district offers a growing number of lodging options within walking distance to Broadway theaters.

headline: 1914: British Prime Minister Urges Irish to Enlist
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Prime Minister Herbert Henry Asquith made a speech in Dublin “to summon Ireland, a loyal and patriotic Ireland, to take her place in the defence of our common cause.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mr. Asquith made a most stirring speech last evening at a citizens’ meeting in Dublin in support of the recruiting campaign. The meeting was held in the Round Room of the Dublin Mansion House, and was attended by 3,000 persons, mainly Nationalists, but including many Unionists, among them Professor Mahaffy. The Nationalist Lord Mayor of Dublin presided, and among the speakers were Mr. John Redmond, Mr. Joseph Devlin and Mr. John Dillon.

headline: Nautical Ropes Set Sail for Spring/Summer 2015
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Rope and Twine']
abstract: J.W. Anderson, Isabel Marant and Julien David have all incorporated the seafaring staple into their new collections.
lead_paragraph: Ahoy! Nautical ropes have looped in several European designers this season. The look was first spotted in London at J.W. Anderson, where the designer wove ropes into sleeveless shells. Isabel Marant showed knotted ropes as belts atop frayed tunic dresses. Finally, at his show in Paris yesterday, the Tokyo-based designer Julien David used roping as an embellishment on gray sweatshirt blazers.

headline: A Day Old, and Already a Potential Nominee (in 2052)
abstract: The Twitter universe reacts to the birth of Chelsea Clinton’s baby.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Clinton announced the birth of her daughter, Charlotte, with a tweet in the wee hours of Saturday morning. Much of Twitter responded with best wishes for the new mother, father and grandparents. But some have teasingly suggested there could be a third generation of the Clinton political dynasty.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword Puzzle
abstract: Rosalie Moscovitch gets cryptic with us.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Are you good at recognizing your cues? It helps if you want to become good at cryptic crosswords.
