lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: President’s Drive for Carbon Pricing Fails to Win at Home
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The United States, which is under growing international pressure to price carbon, is missing from a World Bank declaration calling on all nations to enact laws forcing industries to pay for carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama stood in the chamber of the United Nations General Assembly last week and urged the world to follow his example and fight global warming. But a major new declaration calling for a global price on carbon — signed by 74 countries and more than 1,000 businesses and investors — is missing a key signatory: the United States.

headline: Long Shots Loom as Spoilers in Tight November Races Across Nation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, Governors', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Third-Party Moves (US)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The outcome of an unusually large number of Senate and governor’s races this fall could be determined by the outsize role of third-party candidates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an election year shaped by voter anger toward the political establishment, the outcome of an unusually large number of close Senate and governor’s races could be determined by the outsize role of third-party candidates.

headline: Behind the Otherworldly Makeup at Haider Ackermann
abstract: The look at the designer’s spring/summer 2015 show combined matte-finish skin with glossy, white-lashed eyes.
lead_paragraph: “A tribe of otherworldly creatures,” was the makeup manifesto at Haider Ackermann today, according to the MAC makeup artist Yadim. “Everything is washed out and pale, but elegant with subtle traces of color,” he explained. The models’ ethereal transformations began with the complexion. “We’re buffing MAC’s Shell Cream Color Base onto the high contours, then patting a translucent finishing powder over the entire face,” Yadim said. “I know it’s unusual to mattify a highlighter, but Haider just loved it. We thought it made the girls look as though they were glowing from within.”

headline: Kicking the Facebook Habit
abstract: It’s had its moments. But I think I’ve broken the spell.
lead_paragraph: THE trouble began in 2009, on a rickety boat in the Peruvian Amazon. As I relaxed with a beer, my friend Fiorella snapped my picture with my phone. “Oh!” she said. “That’s a Facebook profile photo for sure!” And it was.

headline: In M.V.P. Race, as on Mound, Kershaw Is Hard to Beat
abstract: The left-hander missed April with an injury but still became the first pitcher to earn at least 21 victories in a season of no more than 27 appearances.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, Don Mattingly hit .352 with 31 homers, 113 runs batted in and the best on-base plus slugging percentage in the American League. He believed he should have won the Most Valuable Player award, but he finished second to Roger Clemens.

headline: For Many New Medicaid Enrollees, Care Is Hard to Find, Report Says
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A federal report says state standards for access to health care are rarely enforced and that Medicaid patients may wait for months or travel long distances to see a doctor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Enrollment in Medicaid is surging as a result of the Affordable Care Act, but the Obama administration and state officials have done little to ensure that new beneficiaries have access to doctors after they get their Medicaid cards, federal investigators say in a new report.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Mugler Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Columbine Goldsmith.

headline: Turkey Inching Toward Alliance With U.S. in Syria Conflict
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Terrorism', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Turkey is caught between conflicting interests: defeating Islamic militants across its border with Syria while not strengthening Kurdish separatists inside Turkey.
lead_paragraph: KARACA, Turkey — No American ally is closer to the threat of the Islamic State than Turkey, and no country could play a more important role in a coalition that President Obama is assembling to combat the extremist Sunni militants. Yet Turkey has been reluctant to enlist, in part because of the desperate conflict playing out on its border with Syria.

headline: With His Words and Deeds, Derek Jeter Never Entered Foul Territory
abstract: In 20 years of living onstage in New York City, Jeter was never caught in a compromising position and played his best defense in front of his locker.
lead_paragraph: Remember when Derek Jeter was spotted walking into a Toronto strip club with a former exotic dancer? Wait: That was his Yankees teammate Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Cuomo, With a Delegation, Arrives in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Governors (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York was among a delegation of governors and Defense Department officials visiting troops and receiving briefings on counterterrorism issues.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday as part of a delegation of governors visiting troops and receiving briefings on counterterrorism and security issues, his office said.

headline: India Official Found Guilty of Corruption
abstract: Jayalalitha Jayaram will have to step down as chief minister of Tamil Nadu after the court in Bangalore found her guilty of possessing wealth disproportionate to her known sources of income.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The powerful chief minister of the southern state of Tamil Nadu, Jayalalitha Jayaram, will be forced to step down after a court convicted her of corruption and sentenced her to four years in prison on Saturday, an unprecedented ruling against a sitting chief minister.

headline: Andjela Ilic Transforms at Haider Ackermann
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Spring 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Andjela Ilic before (left) and after (right) makeup by Yadim and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

headline: Ryder Cup 2014: Europe Takes Commanding Lead Over U.S. Team
abstract: After an encouraging morning for Tom Watson and his squad, the afternoon session on Saturday turned into another European romp, with the American team trailing, 10-6.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — With one day and 12 singles matches still to play, it is 10-6 again at the Ryder Cup: a score that rattles plenty of skeletons in European and American team rooms.

headline: U.S., Defending Kurds in Syria, Expands Airstrikes Against Islamic State Militants
abstract: The Pentagon said it had hit Islamic State targets in an area that has been subject to a weeklong onslaught by the militants, action that appeared to open a new front for American airstrikes in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said on Saturday that it had conducted its first strikes against Islamic State targets in a besieged Kurdish area of Syria along the Turkish border, destroying two armored vehicles in an area that has been the subject of a weeklong onslaught by the Islamic State.

headline: In a Final Act, Karzai Orders Execution of 5 Men in Rape Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Rights activists are concerned that the men’s confessions in the gang rape and robbery of four Afghan women may have been obtained by torture at the hands of the police.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hamid Karzai’s last major act as president of Afghanistan may well be his order on Saturday to execute five men who were convicted of rape after a trial that the United Nations’ top human rights official has denounced as unfair.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Hats Off to Junya Watanabe
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Hats and Caps', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: The designer offered up an over-the-top beauty fantasy at his Paris presentation today.
lead_paragraph: While natural, loose waves have been a prominent presence on the spring/summer 2015 runways, leave it to Junya Watanabe to offer up a much-needed dose of over-the-top beauty fantasy. At the designer’s show in Paris today, models sported orblike clear plastic hats — part swim cap, part space helmet — with colorful cutouts around the face. Each matched the model’s eye shadow (applied on one eye) and nail polish — and why not?

headline: Benefits of Joining the Herd
abstract: The Adirondack Grazers Cooperative, based in upstate New York, markets and sells beef for its 36 members. But it also provides hope at a time family farms are rapidly vanishing.
lead_paragraph: It was time for the running of the bulls.

headline: Narendra Modi, in U.N. Speech, Inserts India Into Terrorism Fight
abstract: Indian’s prime minister made his first speech at the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India reminded the world on Saturday of his country’s abiding battle against extremist groups, and took a swipe at countries that give them shelter before capping his speech with a call for an International Yoga Day.

headline: So Close to Goal Line and Yet So Far From It, Jets Feel Red-Zone Blues
abstract: The Jets are among the N.F.L.’s worst teams at scoring touchdowns once they have advanced to the red zone, the area from the opponent’s 20-yard line to its goal line.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Twelve times this season, the Jets have moved the ball into the red zone. The good news is that they advanced closer to the goal line. The bad news is that they advanced closer to the goal line.

headline: Doctors’ Billing Practices
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Readers discuss the unexpected bills, often shockingly high, that patients sometimes face.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the unexpected bills, often shockingly high, that patients sometimes face.

headline: Nir Barzilai
abstract: A researcher on aging talks about biking though Burgundy, the advantages of a parrot as a pet and making an Alzheimer’s playlist.
lead_paragraph: Nir Barzilai is the Israeli-born director of the Institute for Aging Research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

headline: Stranger Danger and Guns
abstract: Is knocking on a stranger’s door dangerous? If so, maybe that’s because we tolerate a society in which unregulated guns are prevalent.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, my iPhone vanished.

headline: The Great Firewall Gets Bigger
abstract: Businesses, researchers and ordinary people are finding it hard to complete even basic and innocuous tasks.
lead_paragraph: China’s Communist government has tightened its control over the Internet so much recently that businesses, researchers and ordinary people are finding it hard to complete basic and innocuous tasks, like placing ads on websites, sharing documents and reading technical documents. It seems the government of President Xi Jinping is so determined to crack down on dissent that it is even willing to stifle commerce and scientific research.

headline: Dismal Lessons From Libya and Yemen
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The dissolution of order in both nations should offer sobering lessons for the Obama administration as it engages in a new war.
lead_paragraph: As the United States barrels into a new war against Sunni extremists in Iraq and Syria, it has been easy to overlook the unraveling of Libya and Yemen.

headline: A Group Shout on Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Editorials', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Energy and Power', 'International Relations']
abstract: People on the streets, and executives in boardrooms, are helping to move the fight against global warming forward.
lead_paragraph: The marchers and mayors, the ministers and presidents, have come and gone. So what is the verdict on Climate Week, the summit meeting on global warming convened by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, in New York?

headline: From Pen and Phone to Bombs and Drones
abstract: Needing Arab allies to help in the fight against ISIS, we turn a blind eye to their record on women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE president was at the United Nations on Wednesday urging young people across the Muslim world to reject benighted values, even as America clambers into bed with a bunch of Middle East potentates who espouse benighted values.

headline: Who Had It Easier, Reagan or Obama?
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The final answer will have to come from historians years from now, but a look at several critical areas offers some hints.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past few weeks I’ve been reading Ken Adelman’s fascinating history “Reagan at Reykjavik: Forty-Eight Hours That Ended the Cold War.” Adelman, who led Reagan’s arms control agency, was an adviser at Reagan’s 1986 Iceland summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. Using some newly declassified documents, Adelman fills out the extraordinary dialogue between the two leaders that set in motion a dramatic cut in nuclear arms.

headline: Counting the Hungry
abstract: We’d like to believe we’re making progress against food insecurity. But are we really?
lead_paragraph: Buenos Aires — WE don’t know who they are. The people suffering from hunger are not our relatives, friends, co-workers; they probably don’t read this paper. We don’t know them, but at the very least we ought to know how many of them there are, because policy and aid decisions depend on that number; because very often their lives depend on that number. But we don’t know, because the hunger statistics reported by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization are flawed.

headline: The Wilds of Education
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Books and Literature', 'Censorship', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The landscape that students romp across shouldn’t be too tame.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to bullying, to sexual assault, to gun violence, we want and need our schools to be as safe as possible.

headline: The Cult Deficit
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Religious Cults']
abstract: Why a creative society needs fringe groups and gurus.
lead_paragraph: LIKE most children of the Reagan era, I grew up with a steady diet of media warnings about the perils of religious cults — the gurus who lurked in wait for the unwary and confused, offering absolute certainty with the aftertaste of poisoned Kool-Aid. From the 1970s through the 1990s, from Jonestown to Heaven’s Gate, frightening fringe groups and their charismatic leaders seemed like an essential element of the American religious landscape.

headline: God, Darwin and My College Biology Class
keywords: ['Evolution (Biology)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Education', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design']
abstract: Students need to know why science and religion cannot be reconciled.
lead_paragraph: EVERY year around this time, with the college year starting, I give my students The Talk. It isn’t, as you might expect, about sex, but about evolution and religion, and how they get along. More to the point, how they don’t.

headline: Judges on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Campaign Finance', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Does spending on judicial elections corrupt the courts’ impartiality?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FEDERAL judges are appointed for life and insulated from politics, and most of them do not think much of the distinctively American practice of electing judges. They make this clear by insisting that those elections, which take place in 39 states, be as political as possible.

headline: Like Father, Like Daughter, Like Son
abstract: Unearthing an old talent for sketching yields unexpected results.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — I DON’T remember when I learned to draw. By kindergarten, I knew what a maulstick was, and stick figures were not in my repertory. An education in art was something I acquired from my father, among the many things he has given me for life, like the shape of my feet and my quirky, maneuverable eyebrows.

headline: Object Lessons in History
abstract: Tracing defining moments through an AIDS poster, a musician’s trumpet, a light bulb.
lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, the BBC and the British Museum collaborated on a hugely successful radio series and book called “A History of the World in 100 Objects.” Last week, the Smithsonian followed up with its “History of the World in 1,000 Objects.”

headline: Building an Ark for the Anthropocene
abstract: Scientists are trying to figure out which species to save, and how.
lead_paragraph: WE are barreling into the Anthropocene, the sixth mass extinction in the history of the planet. A recent study published in the journal Science concluded that the world’s species are disappearing as much as 1,000 times faster than the rate at which species naturally go extinct. It’s a one-two punch — on top of the ecosystems we’ve broken, extreme weather from a changing climate causes even more damage. By 2100, researchers say, one-third to one-half of all Earth’s species could be wiped out.

headline: A Refugee Crisis at the Turkish Border
abstract: As Syrian Kurds fled Islamic State forces, Turkey was caught between conflicting interests in the fighting.
lead_paragraph: As Syrian Kurds fled Islamic State forces, Turkey was caught between conflicting interests in the fighting.

headline: Learning to Love Criticism
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Workplace Environment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Women are held back by caring about praise.
lead_paragraph: A NEW study by the linguist and tech entrepreneur Kieran Snyder, done for Fortune.com, found two differences between workplace performance reviews given to men and women. Across 248 reviews from 28 companies, managers, whether male or female, gave female employees more negative feedback than they gave male employees. Second, 76 percent of the negative feedback given to women included some kind of personality criticism, such as comments that the woman was “abrasive,” “judgmental” or “strident.” Only 2 percent of men’s critical reviews included negative personality comments.

headline: The Deposed Queen of NinjaVideo
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Hana Beshara, a founder of NinjaVideo, once a popular illegal video downloading site, was known as Queen Phara to its users. Now she’s putting her life back together after 16 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: Hana Beshara, a founder of NinjaVideo, once a popular illegal video downloading site, was known as Queen Phara to its users. Now she’s putting her life back together after 16 months in prison.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Air France Pilots Extend Strike After Request for Mediation Is Denied
abstract: The union representing about three-quarters of Air France pilots acted after Prime Minister Manuel Valls said there were no grounds for new negotiations with a mediator.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A costly strike by Air France pilots appeared ready to continue through the weekend after the French government said that it would not mediate the dispute, which has grounded more than half the airline’s flights for almost two weeks.

headline: For Muslims, Social Media Debate on Extremism Is Reflected in Dueling Hashtags
abstract: A prominent social media campaign has condemned extremist Islamic groups, but it has spawned a satirical reaction from Muslims who say it presumes that they are collectively responsible for the violence.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With concerns growing in the West about the recruitment of young people by extremist Islamic groups, President Obama brought new attention last week to Muslims who have condemned the radical movement when he singled out a British group for praise in his speech at the United Nations.

headline: What We’re Watching: Sunday Shows
abstract: The White House and lawmakers will weigh in on how the United States should respond to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: In a fervent speech to the United Nations on Wednesday, President Obama vowed to dismantle and destroy the Islamic State’s “network of death.” Antony J. Blinken, the deputy national security adviser, will discuss the president’s strategy on the Sunday network shows, including CBS’s “Face the Nation,” CNN’s “State of the Union” and “Fox News Sunday.”

headline: As an Analyst, Jon Gruden Needs a Lot of Coaching
abstract: Gruden, in his sixth season with “Monday Night Football” on ESPN, had a head-scratching performance during the Jets-Bears game.
lead_paragraph: Jon Gruden is in his sixth season with ESPN’s “Monday Night Football,” and I’m still waiting for him to become an interesting and entertaining analyst.

headline: The Maverick Inside the Knicks
abstract: At 69, Jackson is a rookie front office guy, unquestionably a power hire yet a member of the Knicks owner James L. Dolan’s team, with all that suggests and ultimately will mean.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson remains a tall, inimitable presence when entering a room, his stiff-legged gait, thinning gray hair and no-longer-lean body notwithstanding. Alongside the new Knicks coach, Derek Fisher, a smaller, younger man whom he has mentored, and Steve Mills, a general manager whom he has inherited, Jackson’s résumé and reputation loom large.

headline: 4 College Softball Players Killed and 11 Others Are Injured in Oklahoma Crash
abstract: A semitrailer truck crossed a median and collided with a bus carrying 15 players from the Lady Lions team at North Central Texas College on Friday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Four college softball players were killed and 11 others were injured on Friday night in Oklahoma after the bus they were riding in collided with a semitrailer truck, officials said.

headline: Yankee Hatred Is Losing Its Point
abstract: After a couple of down years for the Yankees, including Derek Jeter’s swan-song season, even some of the team’s devoted foes may have difficulty summoning the enmity required to staunchly oppose them.
lead_paragraph: It’s not clear whom my father hated more, the Yankees or Judge Judy. There’s no question whom he hated longer.

headline: Major Allergan Investor Joins Chorus Against Salix Deal
abstract: In a letter to Allergan’s board, Jackson Square Partners, which represents more than $1 billion in Allergan shares, questioned the company’s strategy to fend off a hostile takeover.
lead_paragraph: A third Allergan shareholder has come forward to insist that the Botox maker not agree to an all-cash acquisition that would thwart a takeover offer before a special meeting scheduled for Dec. 18.

headline: Tom Watson Not Showing the Same Steadiness He Did as a Player
abstract: Even if the Americans can erase a 10-6 deficit in the Sunday singles, the flaws in Watson’s captaincy in the Ryder Cup will not be easily forgotten.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — Say this for Tom Watson: He has remained true to himself during this Ryder Cup week even if he has not always been forthright with everyone else. The famous detachment Watson displayed as a player has been his calling card, where, as the captain of the United States squad, he has kept his players and the news media at a club’s length.

headline: Not-So-Classic Loafers at Acne Studios
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: slip-ons with printed leather, contrast piping and gold hardware.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India spoke on Saturday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India spoke on Saturday at the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly.

headline: As Jeter Ends Farewell Tour, Yanks Plan a Welcome Party
abstract: Derek Jeter went 1 for 2 in a loss to Boston that is set to be his next-to-last game, but the focus is already turning to Alex Rodriguez, who is eligible to return in 2015.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Even before Derek Jeter plays his final game for the Yankees, which is scheduled to take place here Sunday, the focus has turned from Jeter to Alex Rodriguez — from a cherished star to a tarnished one.

headline: In Alaska, a Battle to Keep Trees, or an Industry, Standing
abstract: A fight continues between preservationists focused on saving ancient forests and wildlife and an agency bound by politics and tradition to loggers, mills and economic development.
lead_paragraph: THORNE BAY, Alaska — The Tongass National Forest, a panoply of snow-dusted peaks and braided rivers, slender fjords and more than 5,000 islands draped over a stretch of Pacific coastline, is widely viewed as one of America’s great natural treasures. Under pressure from environmentalists, the Obama administration pledged four years ago to phase out logging of virgin woodlands here.

headline: James A. Traficant Jr., Cast Out by Congress in Bribery Case, Dies at 73
abstract: A colorful Democrat from Ohio, Mr. Traficant became the second member of the House of Representatives to be ousted since the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — James A. Traficant Jr., a flamboyant Democrat who was expelled from the House of Representatives after a bribery conviction in 2002, died on Saturday in Youngstown, Ohio, four days after he was injured in a tractor accident on his family’s farm. He was 73.

lead_paragraph: Early in the morning of June 30, 2010, Hana Beshara woke to a sharp rapping on the door of her condo in East Brunswick, N.J.

abstract: Todd Gross has our number.

headline: A Rare Arctic Land Sale Stokes Worry in Norway
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Foreign Investments', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Reserves (Natural Resources)', 'Coal']
abstract: A Chinese businessman with deep pockets is looking to buy land in Norway, creating a frenzy of speculation about moves by China to gain a permanent foothold in the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway — For anyone in the market for a majestic waterfront property with easy access to the North Pole, Ole Einar Gjerde has a deal. “We will throw in the polar bears for free,” said Mr. Gjerde, pitching the attractions of a huge tract of Arctic land two and a half times bigger than Manhattan but considerably less noisy. It has a human population of zero.

headline: Music Row Hopes to Keep Recording
keywords: ['Music', 'Country Music', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A historic recording studio in Nashville is fighting for survival after being scheduled for demolition to build luxury condominiums.
lead_paragraph: A historic recording studio in Nashville is fighting for survival after being scheduled for demolition to build luxury condominiums.

headline: As Music Row Shifts to Condo Row, Nashville Cries in Its Beer
keywords: ['Music', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Country Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: An artist manager and others are working to save the studio where Dolly Parton recorded “Jolene,” a space scheduled to be leveled to make room for condos.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — To bolster his argument that the cavernous and almost-famous music room known as RCA Studio A should be spared from the wrecking ball, Mike Kopp, an artist manager, dropped a needle onto an LP, playing one of the thousands of songs recorded here over the last half-century.

headline: As Tailgate Hits Rails, What Else to Do but Chug?
abstract: Cockabooses, or Gamecock-centric cabooses, became a more popular tailgate attraction when South Carolina was struggling to field a successful team.
lead_paragraph: Cursed with a mediocre football team until recently, South Carolina fans developed one of the most opulent ways to ensure a good time on Saturdays (and, perhaps, to drink enough to make the team’s performance irrelevant).

headline: Today’s Police Put On a Gun and a Camera
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Police', 'Archives and Records', 'Privacy']
abstract: With citizens’ videos of confrontations with the law proliferating, more police agencies are equipping officers to record their version of events.
lead_paragraph: PULLMAN, Wash. — Amateur videos of police officers doing their jobs have become part of the fabric of urban democracy, with embarrassing or violent images spreading via social media in minutes.

headline: Indian Leader Narendra Modi, Once Unwelcome in U.S., Gets Rock Star Reception
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has stirred hopes and excitement in sections of India’s large and far-reaching diaspora, is speaking at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Indians who draw crowds of adoring fans are usually tall and sultry, with washboard abs and elaborate outfits, Bollywood stars like Shah Rukh Khan — described by some as the Brad Pitt of India — or Priyanka Chopra, the bombshell actress, singer and model.

headline: Russian Diplomat’s Speech Depicts the West as Hypocritical
abstract: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov, addressing the United Nations General Assembly, described the world’s acute conflict zones in near polar opposite terms from the way the United States and Western European leaders have framed them.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s foreign minister delivered a strident denunciation of the United States and its allies on Saturday, using his speech at the annual United Nations General Assembly session to depict the West as an arrogant and hypocritical arbiter of “what is good or evil.”

headline: Colleges Make It Easier for Students to Show, Not Tell, in Their Applications
abstract: A new policy at Goucher College allows applicants to submit a two-minute video rather than a high school transcript.
lead_paragraph: TOWSON, Md. — Madeline McDonough had a wistful “what if?” moment, pondering the offer that her school, Goucher College, has made to applicants: Instead of showing us your grades, send us a video.

headline: Michael Harari, Israeli Agent Likened to James Bond, Dies at 87
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Olympic Games (1972)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Harari led the hit squad sent to avenge the murders of 11 Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich.
lead_paragraph: Michael Harari, an Israeli intelligence agent who led the hit squad that was sent to avenge the murders of 11 Israeli athletes by Palestinian terrorists at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, died on Sept. 21 in Tel Aviv. He was 87.

headline: Gerald Larue Dies at 98; Early Advocate of Right to Die
abstract: The family of Professor Larue, the first president of the Hemlock Society, who taught for decades at U.S.C., respected his wishes and declined to put him on a ventilator.
lead_paragraph: Gerald A. Larue, an ordained minister, scholar and eventual agnostic who, as the first president of the Hemlock Society, was an early and leading advocate of giving the terminally ill the option to end their own lives, died on Sept. 17 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Tanaka Insists He Feels Fine After Struggling
abstract: The Yankees’ high-paid rookie said that he considered himself healthy and that he believed he could resume normal off-season workouts in Japan.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The whirlwind rookie season of the Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka ended with a thud Saturday at Fenway Park. Tanaka — who signed a $155 million contract, made the American League All-Star team, tore an elbow ligament and returned — collected just five outs in a 10-4 thumping by the Red Sox.

headline: Advocates for News Media to Meet Turkish Officials
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Two advocacy groups left for Turkey to meet with the officials, who may include President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: An international delegation representing two leading press-freedom advocacy groups left Saturday for a weeklong visit to Turkey, where it plans to talk with Turkish officials, possibly including President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, about harassment and persecution of foreign and domestic journalists whose reporting is deemed hostile or unfair by the government.

headline: Then a Royal, Now a Political Player
abstract: Frank White, a retired Gold Glove second baseman for Kansas City, is hoping to parlay his popularity with local residents, if not his former team, into his first elected office.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At a corner deli near his childhood home, Frank White joked with the police major ahead of him in line, discussed roof repairs with a deacon from the Baptist church he has attended for decades, politely declined one fan’s invitation to speak at a coming event and still managed to eat a corned beef sandwich.

headline: Remembering Jim Traficant
abstract: Remembering James A. Trafficant, in videos and soundbites.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative James A. Traficant of Ohio, who died Saturday, left behind a vivid record during the almost nine terms he spent in the House, many of those moments coming during one-minute House speeches.

headline: Dinosaurs, Upstarts and a Push for Change
abstract: Ahead of the next Texas state legislative session, upstart competitors like Uber, Tesla and even Walmart are trying to disrupt business as usual by seeking help from lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.​

headline: A Texas Official’s D.W.I. Case Is Being Seen in a Softer Light
abstract: A two-year-old charge against Jack Stick, a lawyer for the Texas Health and Human Services Commission, has failed to garner the attention that followed the drunken-driving arrest of a Democratic district attorney.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — A top state official is stopped for drunken driving and refuses breath and blood tests. Police cite erratic driving and uncooperative behavior, and critics say the official is unfit to serve in public office.

headline: Royals Revel in the Climb After Vanishing Into Crevasse of Mediocrity
abstract: Clinching its first berth in the postseason since 1985, Kansas City was left giddy, exhausted and a bit relieved.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In the visitors’ clubhouse Saturday, only subtle clues remained from the Kansas City Royals’ celebration the night before. Everyone looked weary. The carpet was damp. And three Champagne bottles sat on a table in the middle of the room; everyone on the team was supposed to sign them.

headline:
Private Bank Fuels
Fortunes of Putin’s
Inner Circle
abstract: The rise of Bank Rossiya, controlled by close friends of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, illustrates how he has enriched loyalists whose influence over the economy has helped him maintain his iron grip on power.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Weeks after President Vladimir V. Putin annexed Crimea in March, an obscure regulatory board in Moscow known as the Market Council convened inside an office tower not far from the Kremlin to discuss the country’s wholesale electricity market. It is a colossal business, worth 2 percent of Russia’s gross domestic product, and a rich source of fees for the bank that had long held the exclusive right to service it.

headline: Austin City Limits, Now 40, Feels Younger Than Ever
abstract: A lot has changed in the 40 years since “Austin City Limits” first aired, and the program, which is now also an annual festival, has broadened its scope as it culls a younger audience.
lead_paragraph: When Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds taped an appearance on the music television series “Austin City Limits,” the program’s longtime producer, Terry Lickona said, “Can you believe, after 40 years for ‘Austin City Limits,’ 30 years for Nick Cave, this is the first time they’ve been on the stage in front of our cameras?”

headline: Debating What Is More Sacred: Private Land or Public Beaches
abstract: A recent Texas Supreme Court decision said that in the case of storms, private property remains private after the public beach has been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — Texas has long prided itself on its Open Beaches Act, which guarantees public access along most of the state’s 367-mile Gulf Coast.

headline: Jameis Winston, Standing Out for Positive Reasons, Leads Florida State Rally
abstract: Winston, F.S.U.’s star quarterback, has provided a series of distractions for his team off the field.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Jameis Winston may have already cost himself millions in N.F.L. money as his draft status plummets with each new drama. It is fair to say he has cost Florida State as well with a series of transgressions.

headline: Players for Hire Take European Club Title
abstract: A team from Azerbaijan won the European Club Cup with a roster of players from six countries.
lead_paragraph: The European Club Cup is one of the more unusual team events because it turns the world’s best players into chess mercenaries.

headline: In A.C.C., the Irish Go Far Afield To Retain a Sense of Independence
abstract: Notre Dame’s hectic travel schedule helps it retain the higher national profile it has had as an independent.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A typical college football regular season is 12 games, with most top programs figuring out a way to have seven home games.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 28, 2014.
lead_paragraph: I know the progress is great. This is my hometown, and I love to see it grow and expand. But I’d sure hate to see Music Row not be Music Row 20 years from now.

headline: 2011 White House Security Breach Left Obamas Angry at Secret Service
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Three years before an armed man climbed a fence and reached the White House entrance, shots fired at the White House were dismissed as backfire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were angry at the Secret Service for the way it handled a 2011 incident in which a gunman fired shots that hit the White House while one of their daughters was at home, The Washington Post reported on Saturday night.

headline: An Officer Is Shot in Ferguson, Mo.
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Authorities said the shooting seemed to be unrelated to continuing protests over the killing of Michael Brown last month.
lead_paragraph: A Ferguson, Mo., police officer was shot on Saturday night, in an altercation that authorities said was unrelated to continuing protests over the death of a teenager shot by a police officer there last month.

headline: Clouds Roll In
abstract: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.
lead_paragraph: Creative minds in fashion, art and design are looking up this season, gathering inspiration from the ether.

abstract: Thanks to a convergence of creativity, technology and big money, the Golden Age of Design may finally be upon us.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a convergence of creativity, technology and big money, the Golden Age of Design may finally be upon us.

headline: In Softbank, DreamWorks Animation May Have a Suitor

headline: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
abstract: The fashionable will hope for a traffic-free day today to get to shows that include Céline, Chloé and Givenchy.
lead_paragraph: Among the grievances editors love to share during Paris Fashion Week, few are bemoaned with as much as zest as the traffic. The city residents, for their part, are usually happy to exacerbate the issue with a street-blocking demonstration (here, called a manifestation) or two.

headline: Roche Breast Cancer Drug Perjeta Appears to Greatly Extend Patients’ Lives
abstract: Perjeta, approved by the F.D.A. in 2012, prolonged median survival time about 16 months in a trial of 808 people with metastatic breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: A drug used to treat advanced breast cancer has had what appears to be unprecedented success in prolonging lives in a clinical trial, researchers reported on Sunday.

headline: Corrections: September 28, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 28, 2014
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 1914: German Offensive Checked in Belgium
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: German troops are surprised in Belgium in 1914.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP — The following communiqué has been issued here : ‘‘Yesterday [Sept. 26], a detachment of German troops, comprising a brigade of infantry, two regiments of cavalry and six batteries of artillery—two of which were heavy artillery—was surprised in its march from Brussels on Termonde, via Alost. Attacked in front and on their flank, the German troops retired in disorder toward Assche, leaving in our hands many prisoners and wounded as well as several caissons. To-day, apparently with the intention of avenging this defeat, Malines was bombarded by long-distance guns and important forces made a general movement along our front. Between Malines and Alost the several German attacks against us failed. Toward Alost, our division of cavalry succeeded in taking the German left wing in the rear. In short, the German attack has failed and our troops have without difficulty preserved the positions acquired from Antwerp to Malines. There, however, the station has suffered severely. Many houses have collapsed, others are on fire. A dozen civilians have been killed.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 29, 1914

headline: Indelible Photos of Derek Jeter
abstract: As Derek Jeter retires from the game he dominated, Barton Silverman looks back on his favorite moments photographing the Yankee star.
lead_paragraph: By his count, Barton Silverman has been blessed by the photo gods four times. They came in the form of larger-than-life subjects who can make or break a photographer’s career: Joe Namath, Wayne Gretzky, Michael Jordan and most recently, Derek Jeter, whose final innings on a Boston diamond today conclude a storied 20-year career.

headline: Crackdown on Protests by Hong Kong Police Draws More to the Streets
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
abstract: Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Downtown Hong Kong turned into a battlefield of tear gas and seething crowds on Sunday after the police moved against a student democracy protest, inciting public fury that brought tens of thousands of people onto the streets of a city long known as a stable financial center.

headline: Dozens of Hikers Feared Dead on Japanese Volcano
abstract: Thirty-one climbers were feared dead on Mount Ontake, which had been busy with hikers who had gone to see the first signs of autumn.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Thirty-one hikers were feared dead near the peak of a volcano in central Japan on Sunday, a day after it suddenly erupted, a police spokesman said. However, the danger of another eruption and of a release of toxic gases made it impossible to bring most of them down and confirm their deaths.

lead_paragraph: 1964 at the U.N.: A Dispute With the Soviets and a Che Guevara Sighting

headline: 1964: Ex-President Of Syria Slain in Brazil
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Syria’s Ex-president is assassinated in Brazil in 1964.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Ex-President Adib Shishakli of Syria was shot dead yesterday [Sept. 27] on a street in the Brazilian town of Ceres, a radio station reported today. It said it was believed the killing was for political motives. Brig. Shishakli had been living in Brazil for some four years and operated a rice plantation. The shooting occurred in mid-afternoon in the middle of the main street. The assassin was described as a dark-haired young man of medium height wearing dark glasses and a green shirt. Police said he had lunched with Brig. Shishakli in a restaurant shortly before the shooting. Restaurant witnesses said the assailant seemed to be a well-educated, well-mannered youth who had not been seen before in this sparsely-settled cowboy country west of Brasilia. Police said he fled the town in an automobile. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 29, 1964

headline: The Google Formula for Success
abstract: The key to success in modern business is hiring and nurturing “smart creatives,” according to a new book co-authored by Eric Schmidt, former chief executive of Google.
lead_paragraph: Can Google’s winning ways be applied to all kinds of businesses? The authors of “How Google Works,” Eric Schmidt, Google’s former chief executive, and Jonathan Rosenberg, a former senior product manager at Google, firmly believe that they can.

headline: ‘Home Alone’ at 7, Safe and Learning to Stay That Way
abstract: My 7-year-old son asked to stay home while I ran errands in our neighborhood. I agreed, and our experiment was a success — except to those who insisted on seeing encouragement of independence as a “tragedy waiting to happen.”
lead_paragraph: There’s that scene in the Pixar movie “The Incredibles” in which Elastigirl is flying a jet toward the island where her husband, Mr. Incredible, is being held by the evil Syndrome. Missiles are coming toward the jet, and with no other options, Elastigirl turns to her daughter, Violet, for help.

headline: Air France Pilots End Two-Week Strike
abstract: The pilots’ union said on Sunday it would end a crippling strike but stopped short of accepting management’s plans for expanding a low-cost subsidiary.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The union representing thousands of striking Air France pilots said on Sunday that it would end a crippling two-week strike “in the interest of passengers and the company,” although it stopped short of accepting management’s plans for expanding a low-cost subsidiary.

lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials said Sunday that the weekend shooting of a Ferguson police officer was unrelated to weeks of protests over the death of an unarmed black teenager who was shot by a white officer here last month.

abstract: A 14-year-old boy died and three other teenagers were in the hospital with injuries after they were all stabbed while attending a birthday party, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old boy died early Sunday morning and three other teenagers were in the hospital with injuries after they were all stabbed while attending a birthday party in the Bronx, the police said.

abstract: At least, says one psychologist, don’t do them too often.
lead_paragraph: Do you like ice cream? Then don’t eat it — at least not every day.

headline: Ryder Cup 2014: Europeans Make Easy Work of U.S. for Third Straight Victory
abstract: Rory McIlroy and Graeme McDowell quickly erased any hope the Americans had of making a comeback in singles play.
lead_paragraph: GLENEAGLES, Scotland — It has become a rite of autumn: European golfers sinking putts, and Americans, and then showering one another with compliments and champagne.

headline: Want a Robot Pen Pal?
abstract: Robots can now write us letters. Will we read them?
lead_paragraph: Robots may not be writing science fiction just yet, but they can write you a letter.

headline: Activist Is Celebrated at the College He Helped Save
abstract: In 1976, Ramon J. Jimenez joined a protest that averted the closing of Hostos Community College. For his 66th birthday, friends gathered there to honor him.
lead_paragraph: Ramon J. Jimenez insists he does not live in the past, even if his office furniture does. Dingy and worn, it is vintage 1970s décor, evoking the era when he arrived in the South Bronx. He was an Afro-wearing, radical, Harvard-trained lawyer for whom causes and people were more important than billable hours and prestige.

headline: Synth Interlaced With a Personal Purgatory
abstract: In “Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes,” released on BitTorrent on Friday, Thom Yorke is both instantly recognizable and less crowd-pleasing than ever.
lead_paragraph: Disorientation, tolling piano chords, austerity, loops, malaise, bittersweet melody — yes, there’s a new album by Thom Yorke of Radiohead, “Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes,” which he suddenly released on Friday on BitTorrent Bundle, through file-sharing software. The album costs $6, of which Mr. Yorke receives 90 percent. It’s the same percentage he’d get on the more established Bandcamp, but with less tech fanfare.

headline: Dividing Along Tribal Lines
abstract: Brands such as Isabel Marant, Kenzo and Acne reflect the women who wear them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Isabel Marant, whose name has become shorthand for a certain brand of messy-haired Parisienne chic, took inspiration for her new collection, she said, from the tribes of Africa.

headline: 15 People Wounded After Shooting at Miami Nightclub
abstract: The victims ranged in age from 11 to 25, according to a police spokeswoman, who said the shooting took place around 1 a.m. Sunday at a club about four miles north of downtown Miami.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen people were shot and wounded, one critically, at a nightclub in Miami early Sunday, officials said.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE PARADISE, SEASON 2 Joanna Vanderham, above, returns as Denise Lovett, an ambitious country girl who last season took a job at a Victorian department store in a booming northern British city in this “Masterpiece Classic” adaptation of the 1883 Émile Zola novel “Au Bonheur des Dames.” Soon she had caught the eye of John Moray (Emun Elliott), the handsome if enigmatic owner of the establishment, whose affection was pursued by Lady Katherine Glendenning (Elaine Cassidy). But eventually Moray’s love for Denise won out, and he left Katherine at the altar. The new season picks up a year later as Moray pines away in Paris for Denise, who is back at the Paradise, their romance tested by the store’s regime of Katherine and her new husband, Tom Weston (Ben Daniels). In “Miss Marple, Season 7: Endless Night,” at 9, Agatha Christie’s spinster sleuth (Julia McKenzie) meets a chauffeur (Tom Hughes) who recounts his romance with an American heiress (Ms. Vanderham) and her death, foretold by a Gypsy, shortly after their marriage. And in “The Mystery of Agatha Christie With David Suchet,” at 10:30, Mr. Suchet, who starred in the long-running series “Agatha Christie’s Poirot,” ponders the writer’s life and legacy.

headline: In Kabul, Cuomo Seeks Insights on Terrorism
abstract: During a visit to Afghanistan, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo received briefings from military leaders that he said would inform his efforts to protect New York from terrorism.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Invoking one tragedy to warn of the prospect of another, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Sunday that the rise of the Islamic State had revived the trauma of the Sept. 11 attacks among New Yorkers while creating a fresh danger for their city.

headline: Obama Acknowledges U.S. Erred in Assessing ISIS
keywords: ['Television', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama told “60 Minutes” that the United States had placed too much trust in the Iraqi military, allowing the region to become “ground zero for jihadists around the world.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama acknowledged in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the United States had underestimated the rise of the Islamic State militant group, which has seized control of a broad swath of territory in the Middle East, and had placed too much trust in the Iraqi military, allowing the region to become “ground zero for jihadists around the world.”

headline: Denzel Washington and ‘The Equalizer’ Lead Box Office
abstract: Mr. Washington’s portrayal of a retired mercenary fighting Russian gangsters took in an estimated $35 million at North American theaters over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: There are few sure things in Hollywood, but Denzel Washington is certainly one of them. “The Equalizer” (Sony), starring Mr. Washington as a retired mercenary pitted against ultra-violent Russian gangsters, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in an estimated $35 million. “The Equalizer,” which reteamed Mr. Washington with the director Antoine Fuqua, cost Sony and Village Roadshow roughly $55 million to make. Sony, which is counting on the film to make up ground from some under-performing summer releases like “Sex Tape,” boasted on Sunday of its “no-holds-barred marketing campaign” for “The Equalizer” and called the results “spectacular.”

headline: Golden Ring Barrettes at Céline
abstract: Models at today’s show sported shiny, slightly wavy locks secured with graphic clips.
lead_paragraph: Phoebe Philo’s spring/summer Céline collection shown today embodied modernity — from the feminine yet clean-lined clothes to the graphic simplicity of the hair accessories. Models sported shiny, slightly wavy locks that were brushed back and secured with simple golden ring barrettes that mimicked the hardware on bags.

headline: First to Break 2:03, Kenyan Shatters Marathon Record
abstract: For the sixth time in 11 years, a world record was set on the Berlin course, this one in 2 hours 2 minutes 57 seconds.
lead_paragraph: World records at the Berlin Marathon are not so much set as incubated in laboratory conditions.

headline: Runner-Up in Afghan Elections Threatens to Boycott Inauguration
abstract: Abdullah Abdullah threatened to pull out of the inauguration Monday after his camp said it felt that the declared winner, Ashraf Ghani, violated an agreement not to publicly reveal the vote totals.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdullah Abdullah, the runner-up in Afghanistan’s presidential election, is threatening to pull out of the inauguration on Monday of the country’s new leadership, which could imperil the national unity government he has agreed to join with the winning candidate, Ashraf Ghani.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain faced a double embarrassment on Sunday, as his Conservative Party opened its final convention before May’s general election trailing the opposition Labour Party in the polls.

lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A radical monk from Myanmar who has preached hatred toward Muslims and is the spiritual leader of a movement to boycott Muslim businesses said Sunday that his movement would join hands with a Sri Lankan group to “protect Buddhism around the world.”

headline: On the Hunt for a Sprite on a Midsummer’s Night
abstract: Citizen scientists are hunting sprites, majestic emanations of light that flash for an instant high above storm clouds, whose effects on the physics and chemistry of the atmosphere remain an open question.
lead_paragraph: LAMY, N.M. — Every summer evening at 7 o’clock, Thomas Ashcraft receives a personalized weather report. It is monsoon season, and he is getting advice from a meteorologist in Colorado on where to look for the massive thunderstorms that erupt over the western High Plains.

headline: Advertising Week 2014: Exploring the Future of Television
keywords: ['Television', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Because television has been the mother’s milk of marketing, the technological changes that have revolutionized it are a major topic as advertising industry figures convene.
lead_paragraph: THOSE who remember the 1960s — putting aside the quip that if you remember the ’60s, then you really weren’t there — will recall a declaration that “The revolution will not be televised.” Decades later, it is television that is being revolutionized, effecting profound changes in how the advertising business operates and tries to make money.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Derek Jeter played his last game Sunday, ending his career with a play typical of his time in the majors, in which he hustled out an infield single for his 3,465th hit.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Encouraged by a Strong September, the Mets Can Hardly Wait Till Next Year
abstract: The Mets concluded their sixth consecutive losing season by focusing on silver linings — mainly their promising young pitching and a 15-10 record in September.
lead_paragraph: The summertime conditions may have confused some Mets fans who did not seem to want to leave Citi Field on Sunday afternoon. They waited as the players completed their postgame victory handshakes and Manager Terry Collins jogged out to center field to wave goodbye. Then they lingered in the parking lots. They wanted to see more baseball.

headline: Reminders of the Protest Era Stirred Into a ‘Postmodern Gumbo’
abstract: Two programs by Kyle Abraham at New York Live Arts echo a seminal civil-rights era album by Max Roach.
lead_paragraph: In the eight years since he founded his company, Abraham.In.Motion, Kyle Abraham has been mixing modes of movement to form his own; he cleverly calls his choreography “a postmodern gumbo.” Its sources range from ballet to Brazilian capoeira, from the Lindy Hop to the ’90s raves where, growing up in Pittsburgh, he got his start as a dancer. He has hallmarks, favorite moves: a head roll casting ripples down through the shoulders and arms; floor-skimming scoots with one leg in arabesque; squalls that erupt from the torso while the feet stand their ground, the body fighting against itself or something unseen.

headline: Workouts for the Mind, Dressed in Cheeky Humor
abstract: The Dutch choreographer Jan Martens presents two comical works as part of the Queer New York International Arts Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch choreographer Jan Martens does not put on airs. At the Abrons Arts Center on Friday, he introduced himself to New York in shorts and sneakers, sitting onstage taking selfies with a laptop. The images were projected on the wall behind him, along with the words he typed: a list of 10 fairly simple things he was attempting in the solo he was performing.

headline: With Perspective From Both Sides of His Desk, F.C.C. Chairman Ponders Net Neutrality
abstract: Tom Wheeler spent decades as a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, experience from which he has drawn in creating highly scrutinized policy guidelines for ensuring equal access to online content.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a lobbyist for the cable and wireless industries, Tom Wheeler played a role in shaping almost every major telecommunications policy and innovation over the last three decades.

headline: A Conductor Tries to Soar Amid High Expectations
abstract: Andris Nelsons went with a mixed program to start his reign as the music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Andris Nelsons era at the Boston Symphony Orchestra began on Saturday night when this exciting Latvian conductor led a festive program at Symphony Hall to begin his tenure as the ensemble’s 15th music director. Though just 35, Mr. Nelsons has become one of the most respected and sought-after conductors in the field. The buzz in Boston and the extensive media coverage his arrival has generated show that music lovers in this city are grateful to have him. As he walked to the podium on Saturday he was greeted with a long, rousing ovation; many people were on their feet.

headline: Jets and Geno Smith Picked Apart by Lions, and Fans
abstract: With a brutal three-game stretch looming, the Jets will face questions about their secondary, which allowed Matthew Stafford to throw for 293 yards, and Smith, who committed two turnovers.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The crowd chanted for Geno Smith’s backup. Smith cursed at a heckling fan. Sheldon Richardson afterward told those who booed to shut up.

headline: Woman Caught in the Paradox of Being Adrift and on a Journey
abstract: In “Lila,” Marilynne Robinson tells the back story of the heroine in her Pulitzer Prize-winning book, “Gilead.”
lead_paragraph: With her flawed but poignant new book, “Lila,” Marilynne Robinson has returned to the central characters in her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “Gilead” (2004) — the aging minister John Ames and his much younger wife, Lila — and to the themes of alienation and separateness (and the possibility of belonging) that animated her astonishing debut novel, “Housekeeping,” more than 30 years ago.

headline: Police Officer Is Shot in Ferguson
abstract: The police said that the shooting of an officer in the Missouri town appeared unrelated to the protests over Michael Brown’s death.
lead_paragraph: The police said that the shooting of an officer in the Missouri town appeared unrelated to the protests over Michael Brown’s death.

headline: A Half-Century of Intellectual History
abstract: “The 50 Year Argument,” directed by Martin Scorsese and David Tedeschi, looks at the history of The New York Review of Books.
lead_paragraph: Robert Silvers has assigned thousands of pieces for The New York Review of Books, so why not a documentary film? “The 50 Year Argument,” showing Monday on HBO, originated along the same lines as one of the lengthy, learned articles in The Review: Mr. Silvers sought out a talented essayist, in this case Martin Scorsese, and asked him to explore a subject — the magazine’s 50-year history — that he was passionate about but not expert in.

headline: A Vengeful Ranger Full of Attitude and on a Mission
abstract: Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is a new role-playing game set in the “Lord of the Rings” world.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure how old I was when I first tried to play a “Lord of the Rings” video game, but I suspect I wasn’t yet 10. It was in the 1980s, and my dad had brought home a computer cast off from his workplace. The machine was beige with a monochromatic green screen that sat above two floppy disk drives.

headline: A Free-Spirited Tribute to a Master of Jazz
abstract: “Very Very Threadgill,” a two-day music festival at Harlem Stage, celebrated Henry Threadgill’s legacy and influence in the American avant-garde.
lead_paragraph: During his introductory remarks at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Saturday night, Henry Threadgill succinctly noted that no amount of accolades could mean more to him than the support of a community of musicians engaging with his work. That reasonable assertion helped set the terms for “Very Very Threadgill,” an ambitious two-day festival of his music, and a celebration of his legacy and influence in the American avant-garde.

abstract: Every Daily Bulletin at the Fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships in Glasgow this month contained a card-play problem.
lead_paragraph: Every Daily Bulletin at the Fourth Commonwealth Nations Bridge Championships in Glasgow this month contained a card-play problem. This deal, from the qualifying stage of the main event, could have been used.

keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Pakistani official said Sunday that a vehicle parked near a house was the target of the American drone strike.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — An American drone strike in northwestern Pakistan killed at least four people suspected of being militants, Pakistani officials said Sunday.

headline: Local Success Story
abstract: Local success story Eric Sydney Phillips makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about Derek Jeter some more, just because he’s so awesome. No really, I can make this work. We can connect this to today’s puzzle. First, though, I’d like to personally thank Eric Sydney Phillips, who is making his New York Times debut with this 15×16 grid today, and Will Shortz for giving me the opportunity to once again point out how incredibly awesome Mr. Jeter is.

headline: Sectarian Violence in Myanmar Threatens Livelihood of Muslims
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Rioting causes small businesses owned by Muslims to suffer. Some worry that the violence could also affect tourism and foreign investment.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — It has been more than a month since Mandalay, Myanmar’s second-largest city, was rocked by deadly anti-Muslim riots. Broken windows and large dents in the facades of a dozen small Muslim-run businesses are the only visible reminders of when about 300 radical Buddhists rode into town wielding swords and bricks, killing two people.

headline: Turning a Book Tour Into a Literary Circus (and a Hot Ticket)
abstract: Now in author mode, the young TV star and filmmaker Lena Dunham is promoting her book of essays on a tour that includes literary authors and performances by “remarkable, special weirdos.”
lead_paragraph: Last month, the writer, actor and producer Lena Dunham started an ambitious project. Nearly 600 people responded to an open call for video auditions on her website, including a sand artist, a ukulele player, a cappella singers, gymnasts, performance artists and stand-up comics, even some exceptionally charismatic babies.

headline: A Great Lawn for a Global Cause
abstract: Central Park was the setting for the Global Citizen Festival, which attracted thousands of concertgoers and put a focus on poverty and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Definitionally, there is a certain amount of pill-swallowing at a concert like the Global Citizen Festival, which on Saturday — for the third year in a row — brought 60,000 people to the Great Lawn at Central Park.

headline: Harmonious in a Language That Needs No Translation
abstract: The Talea Ensemble performed “Written for Talea,” a concert of new works composed for the group, at Roulette.
lead_paragraph: During a concert of new works composed for the Talea Ensemble on Friday evening at Roulette, it sometimes seemed that limited material was being stretched to fill the time allocated by a commission, instead of being used more effectively in shorter works.

headline: India’s Budget Mission to Mars
abstract: India joins the space club.
lead_paragraph: India joins the space club.

headline: Vigil Is Planned for Uighur Writer
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The PEN American Center will hold a vigil for the Uighur writer and academic Ilham Tohti on Monday in response to his being sentenced to life in prison.
lead_paragraph: The PEN American Center will hold a vigil for the Uighur writer and academic Ilham Tohti on Monday evening in response to his being sentenced to life in prison. Mr. Tohti, left, an economics professor and vocal critic of the Chinese government on human rights and social issues, was sentenced last week by China on charges of separatism. The court stated that Mr. Tohti “bewitched” his students and “exploited foreign forces to create pressure to make Xinjiang an international matter.” Since his arrest in January, Mr. Tohti has received global attention from free-speech activists around the globe. In May he was awarded the 2014 PEN/Barbara Goldsmith Freedom to Write Award. Of the 38 writers who were in prison at the time they received the award, 35 have been subsequently released. The candlelight vigil on Monday is to feature the novelist Barbara Kingsolver, who will read a statement Mr. Tohti wrote in 2013, specifically in the event of his arrest. The vigil is scheduled for 8 p.m. outside the New School in New York.

headline: Wynton Marsalis to Open St. Louis Jazz Center
abstract: Wynton Marsalis will bring his Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra to St. Louis to open that city’s new jazz center on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Wynton Marsalis will bring his Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra to St. Louis to open that city’s new jazz center on Thursday. The center, newly remodeled and renamed the Harold & Dorothy Steward Center for Jazz, will be a hub and education space for a city that birthed jazz greats like Miles Davis and Clark Terry. The center, which previously housed Jazz at the Bistro, underwent a $10 million renovation this year in hopes of creating a counterpart to New York’s Jazz at Lincoln Center and San Francisco’s SFJazz. In addition to the main concert space, the center will contain rehearsal and practice rooms for instruction sessions. “We have to make sure it’s not just a question of preserving our jazz heritage,” Gene Dobbs Bradford, executive director of Jazz St. Louis, told The Associated Press. “We have to educate and train the next generation of great St. Louis musicians.” Other coming performers include a St. Louis native, David Sanborn; Joshua Redman; and Joey DeFrancesco. The space is named after the parents of Dave Steward, who is the chief executive of World Wide Technology and was the project’s lead donor.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Star to Tour With Band
abstract: American fans of “Downton Abbey” will be able to see one of its stars, Elizabeth McGovern, both on TV in English formal wear and live holding a guitar this winter.
lead_paragraph: American fans of the hit PBS show “Downton Abbey” will be able to see one of its stars, Elizabeth McGovern, both on TV in English formal wear and live holding a guitar this winter. Ms. McGovern, acclaimed for playing Countess Cora Crawley on “Downton,” will embark on her first United States tour with her folk-rock band, Sadie and the Hotheads, The Associated Press reported. Ms. McGovern has been on “Downton” since the show’s inception in 2010 and has received Emmy and Golden Globe nominations for her work. Sadie and the Hotheads formed three years earlier and has since featured performances by another “Downton” star, Michelle Dockery. The group will release its third album, “Still Waiting,” on Thursday, and the band’s tour is scheduled to begin on Dec. 4 in Washington. The Season 5 premiere of “Downton Abbey” in the United States will arrive one month later.

headline: Refugees Flood Turkish Border as Islamic State Steps Up Attacks on Syrian Kurds
abstract: New streams of Syrian refugees fled toward the border with Turkey as shelling hit the town of Kobani.
lead_paragraph: MURSITPINAR, Turkey — Shelling intensified Sunday on Kobani, the Syrian town at the center of a region of Kurdish farming villages that has been under a weeklong assault by Islamic State militants, setting fire to buildings and driving a stream of new refugees toward the fence here at the border with Turkey.

headline: China's Fruitless Repression of the Uighurs
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Minorities']
abstract: Ilham Tohti's only "crime" was to advocate for China's own policies for autonomy for ethnic minorities.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a court in China’s far western Xinjiang region sentenced Ilham Tohti, a member of the Uighur minority, to life in prison for the crime of “inciting separatism.” The conviction of this moderate scholar elicited international condemnation; the sentence was an order of magnitude longer than those given to other Chinese dissidents. But, far from being a show of strength, the sentence is a sign of the confusion and desperation behind the government’s policies toward Uighurs.

headline: Shiites in a Battered Neighborhood of Baghdad Fault One of Their Own
abstract: Few in Karada describe the violence in sectarian terms, but most blame Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, the former prime minister, for allowing public security to decay.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Families venture out only by day and as little as possible. Shopkeepers watch the curbs more than their stores, to prevent anyone from parking. The police have erected checkpoints on the avenues and closed the side streets, but more bombs keep coming.

headline: Downhill on a Forest Road
abstract: He didn’t stop his car for the dogs in the road, but maybe he should have.

headline: Georgia Colleges Prohibiting Tobacco, but Questions About Enforcement Linger
abstract: Starting Wednesday, tobacco products and e-cigarettes will be prohibited at the 31 public colleges and universities that make up the University System of Georgia.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ga. — Amid carefree talk of starting lineups, one public notice to the Sanford Stadium crowd on a recent Saturday stood out: Beginning Oct. 1, the University of Georgia will be among the academic institutions in this state that prohibit tobacco products from its campuses.

headline: Legacy of a Venerated Magazine Editor Lives Large on the Newsstand

lead_paragraph: When Adam Sachs was named editor in chief of Saveur last week, he became the head of an award-winning food magazine. He also became something else: the latest in a long line of magazine chiefs who worked under Art Cooper, a legendary former editor of GQ.

headline: The Benefits of ‘Binocularity’
abstract: Neuroscience encourages us to see humans through a single lens. But a full picture of what it means to be a person requires another.

headline: Narendra Modi Outlines Goals for India on Eve of a Visit With Obama
abstract: At Madison Square Garden, Prime Minister Narendra Modi telegraphed a wish list while also deftly rallying an influential diaspora to his side.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi, the prime minister of India, sold himself on Sunday as a onetime tea vendor who wanted to lift India to glory by cleaning up the country, clearing the way for business and preparing its young citizens to be the work force of an aging world. His speech at Madison Square Garden telegraphed a wish list on the eve of his first meeting with President Obama, while also deftly rallying an influential diaspora to his side.

headline: ‘Open Mind’ Host Continues Grandfather’s Vision for New Generation

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: Regardless of the company’s motive, the issues it raised are hugely important and won’t be brushed aside by bombast or counterattack.
lead_paragraph: Comcast has a long corporate tradition of smiling and wearing beige no matter what kind of criticisms are hurled at it. That public posture is in keeping with the low-key approach favored by Brian L. Roberts, the company’s chief executive, as he seeks to take over the world. It’s worked very well so far.

headline: The Mystery of the Missing Bees
abstract: The mystery of Colony Collapse Disorder has brought honeybees into the public eye. But the story of their plight — and its impact — is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: The mystery of Colony Collapse Disorder has brought honeybees into the public eye. But the story of their plight — and its impact — is more complicated.

headline: At Madison Square Garden, Chants, Cheers and Roars for Modi
abstract: Narendra Modi, who spoke at Madison Square Garden on his first trip to the United States since being elected in May, was treated like a rock star.
lead_paragraph: They wore his face on their chests, waved it on posters, chanted his name and quoted his slogans, 19,000 fans drawn to a single star. His image stared down from the big screen at Madison Square Garden and emerged on canvas in a live speed-painting onstage. And when the man himself emerged, the capacity crowd on Sunday in New York’s most storied arena roared as one, as if all the Knicks, all the Rangers, Billy Joel and Bruce Springsteen had suddenly materialized.

headline: Finally, the Truth About the A.I.G. Bailout
keywords: ['Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The A.I.G. case is an opportunity to explain the Fed’s decisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — TODAY is the start of the trial in Starr International Co. Inc. v. United States, the case alleging that the government’s 2008 bailout of A.I.G. amounted to an unconstitutional plunder of the company’s shareholders. Starr, a firm run by the former A.I.G. chief executive Maurice R. Greenberg, was the insurer’s largest single shareholder at the time. It saw the government grab almost 80 percent of its common stock amid the bailout (a proportion that eventually rose to 92 percent), and is asking for a cool $40 billion to make it whole.

headline: New York Media Outlets Revamp Site for Schools
abstract: WNYC, WNBC, WNJU and the New York Daily News will introduce a site with information in English, Spanish and Chinese, and with individual school pages that are easier to understand.
lead_paragraph: The New York public radio station WNYC and the commercial television station WNBC have forged an unusual relationship in recent months, sharing investigative coverage on air and online. Now the two are teaming up, along with WNBC’s Spanish-language sister station, WNJU, and The Daily News, on a reintroduction of SchoolBook.org, a WNYC-owned site offering news and data on the New York City public schools system.
