headline: Taliban Press for Advantage as Politicians Work on Maneuvers in Kabul
abstract: A brutal battle in Ghazni Province was the latest sign that the insurgency was becoming increasingly ambitious, posing the central challenge facing the country’s new president.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan security forces managed to defeat a weeklong Taliban assault on a strategic district in central Afghanistan, provincial officials said over the weekend, though the victory was tenuous and the toll was high. At least 64 people were killed, including some civilians who were beheaded by the insurgents, and a number of homes were torched.

headline: The Head-Scratching Case of the Vanishing Bees
abstract: Several years ago, beekeepers were vexed: Honeybees, those versatile workhorses of pollination, were vanishing by the millions.
lead_paragraph: In 1872, a merchant ship called the Mary Celeste set sail from New York, and four weeks later was found by sailors aboard another vessel to be moving erratically in the Atlantic Ocean 400 miles east of the Azores. Curious, those sailors boarded the Mary Celeste, only to find nary a soul. The cargo was intact, as were supplies of food and water. But there was no sign of the seven-man crew, the captain, or his wife and daughter, who had gone along for the journey. To this day, what turned that brigantine into a ghost ship remains a maritime mystery.

headline: Swimming Through Garbage
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Water Pollution', 'Swimming', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: An underwater view of the perilous state of our marine ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — YOU get a good feel for the health of the oceans when you stick your head in them for four weeks. This summer, I swam long distances in the Seven Seas: the Mediterranean, Adriatic, Aegean, Black, Red, Arabian and North Seas. The longest swim was 37 miles and took me two days.

headline: Nursing Homes Behind Bars
abstract: A nation addicted to imprisonment is approaching a crisis of elderly inmates.
lead_paragraph: After declining for three years in a row, the nation’s stubbornly huge prison population has crept back up again. About 1,574,700 people were in prison at the end of 2013, up 4,300 from 2012. (While the federal population actually dropped for the first time in more than 30 years, it was offset by a larger increase in state prisoners.)

headline: Fumbled Bid for Governor Imperils Ohio Democrats
abstract: Democrats had hoped a rousing fight in 2014 would energize the party’s grass roots and carry into the next presidential contest. Instead, they are facing a shutout in statewide races.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — With a wounded candidate at the top of their ticket, Democrats in Ohio have been forced to adopt a Plan B as they seek to avoid a disastrous shutout in elections for governor and other statewide offices.

headline: Iraq Army Woos Deserters Back to War on ISIS
abstract: The Iraqi military command has launched a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units.
lead_paragraph: QUSH TAPA, Iraq — The Iraqi military command has begun a campaign to re-enlist soldiers and officers who abandoned their units, a crucial step in its effort to rebuild an army that has been routed in battle after battle by Islamic State jihadists.

abstract: Some say it's a pipe dream, and vital steps shouldn't wait for one.

headline: Our Invisible Rich
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'United States Economy']
abstract: They have become so wealthy that most Americans can’t imagine how much they’re worth.
lead_paragraph: Half a century ago, a classic essay in The New Yorker titled “Our Invisible Poor” took on the then-prevalent myth that America was an affluent society with only a few “pockets of poverty.” For many, the facts about poverty came as a revelation, and Dwight Macdonald’s article arguably did more than any other piece of advocacy to prepare the ground for Lyndon Johnson’s War on Poverty.

headline: Costs Can Go Up Fast When E.R. Is in Network but the Doctors Are Not
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Doctors', 'Hospitals', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: When Jennifer Hopper raced to the emergency room after her husband, Craig, took a baseball in the face, she made sure they went to a hospital in their insurance network in Texas. So when they got a $937 bill from the emergency room doctor, she called the insurer, assuming it was in error.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Derek Jeter took off his Yankees uniform for the final time on Sunday and with that the last player from the glory teams spanning the 1990s and 2000s is gone. The dynasty is finally over, and the record shows it.

headline: Solitary Confinement to End for Youngest at Rikers Island

headline: Hong Kong Protesters Defy Officials’ Call to Disperse
abstract: The city’s wave of public protest extended into the working week as thousands ignored a government call to abandon street blockades across the city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A wave of protest in Hong Kong that engulfed the city could continue into the week as thousands of residents defied a government call on Monday to abandon street blockades, students boycotted classes and the city’s influential bar association added its condemnation of a police crackdown on protesters.

headline: The 2014 M.L.B. Playoffs Have a Neighborly Feel
abstract: Four potential World Series matchups involve teams from the same area. In an earlier round, the Dodgers and the Giants, longtime rivals, could meet.
lead_paragraph: This year’s postseason offers the most intriguing set of potential geographic matchups in years. There are four possible World Series matchups involving local rivals: Dodgers-Angels, Nationals-Orioles, Cardinals-Royals and A’s-Giants. An earlier round could feature a series between the Dodgers and the Giants, one of baseball’s most historic rivalries.

headline: Images of Hong Kong’s ‘Umbrella Revolution’ Tell a Story
abstract: Social media offered many images, both video and still, of the democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong. Here is a cross-section that captures the events.
lead_paragraph: In a city unused to political violence, many people in Hong Kong were shocked by what they saw as a harsh response by police officers who used tear gas, batons and pepper spray against pro-democracy demonstrators on Sunday.

headline: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
abstract: Female designers, including Stella McCartney and Chitose Abe of Sacai, top the schedule for Monday.
lead_paragraph: At the risk of being controversial, Paris Fashion Week is not yet an equal playground for male and female designers. That’s not to say the city doesn’t have top female talent — just look at Phoebe Philo of Céline, the much-watched (and much-copied) designer, who scored her runway show Sunday with Kate Bush’s “This Woman’s Work” to underline the point — but the balance still tips to the guys’ side.

headline: Colbert and Carell, Together Again Soon
abstract: Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell will be reunited once again for this year’s Montclair Film Festival fund-raiser in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell have been comedic peers since the early ’90s, when they performed in the improvisation troupe Second City in Chicago; later, they were correspondents on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.” The pair will be reunited once again for this year’s Montclair Film Festival fund-raiser in New Jersey, organizers are to announce on Monday. The event, “A Conversation With Stephen Colbert and Steve Carell,” is scheduled for 8 p.m. on Nov. 21 at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. These comedians are having busy fall seasons: Mr. Colbert is hosting “The Colbert Report” while planning for his move to “Late Show” on CBS, while Mr. Carell (above right with Mr. Colbert) is drawing Oscar buzz for his role in Bennett Miller’s “Foxcatcher,” which is scheduled to reach American movie theaters in November. The Montclair Film Festival event will include highlights of the two together at Second City as well as conversation on their formative years on “The Dana Carvey Show.” Mr. Colbert and his family live in Montclair, and his wife, Evie McGee-Colbert, is the vice chairwoman of the film festival’s board of directors. The fourth Montclair Film Festival will be in May.

headline: Beijing Blocks Reports on Hong Kong Democracy Movement
abstract: Chinese censors block Instagram, and a directive from the central propaganda department in Beijing orders websites to delete any mention of the pro-democracy uprising in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials moved quickly Monday to control news reports of the pro-democracy demonstrations that began in Hong Kong over the weekend and by Sunday night had turned into the largest street clashes in decades between civilians and the territory’s police force.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ashraf Ghani was inaugurated as president of Afghanistan on Monday, punctuating a season of grave political crisis with a peaceful transition of power that stood as a rarity in a country marked by four decades of war.

Candidates including Cory Gardner of Colorado, Thom Tillis in North Carolina, Ed Gillespie and Barbara Comstock in Virginia, and Mike McFadden of Minnesota have announced they want birth control pills to be available over the counter.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Research', 'Statistics']
abstract: The company, having done polls through video games in 2012, plans to have its automated digital assistant survey people through their mobile phones.

headline: From Around the World, Support for Hong Kong Protesters
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Social Media']
abstract: The democracy movement in Hong Kong is gripping people’s imaginations around the world and inspiring many small but impassioned demonstrations of support. Partly fueling them is the Asian city’s large diaspora.
lead_paragraph: From New York, London, Berlin, Tokyo, San Francisco, Taipei and Sydney — even Ferguson, Mo. — a global movement in support of the Hong Kong democracy demonstrations is making itself felt in sympathy rallies or photographs posted on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter. There’s a Twitter account: @GlobalSolidHK.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bond King Quits
abstract: William H. Gross abruptly leaves Pimco. | A.I.G. case sheds new light on bailout. | DreamWorks Animation in sale talks with SoftBank. | Allergan shareholders speak out.
lead_paragraph: BOND KING DEPARTS | William H. Gross, who built Pimco from scratch into one of the biggest money managers in the world, made waves in the business world on Friday when he abruptly quit the firm he founded to join the Janus Capital Group, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein writes. The exit came after Mr. Gross learned in recent weeks that top executives at Pimco and Allianz, the German insurer that owns it, had grown tired of his leadership and were weighing a change. In particular, there were concerns that his eccentric management style ‒ he wore sunglasses while giving a presentation at a conference and used his monthly investment letters to share intimate details ‒ was becoming a distraction.

He and other Italian prisoners have been held in a shed as they await their fate. Levi looks around in search of some means to quench his thirst:

headline: 1939: Nazis’ War Production Hurt
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany’s industries are hit during French attacks in 1939.
lead_paragraph: As the first consequence of the French Army’s advance during the opening four weeks of the war, chiefly against the sector from the Moselle to the Rhine, Germany has lost four-fifths of the industrial production and more than half of the coal output of the Saar Valley. As Hitler’s war machine is mainly built on coal and iron, the French advance, which has brought mines, steel mills and textile factories under French guns, has seriously crippled Germany’s war production in one of its most vital centers. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 30, 1939

headline: Helping Veterans Find Their Place, This Time on Campus
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Community Colleges', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Organizations like the Posse Foundation are trying to bring more veterans to the nation’s elite four-year colleges and universities.
lead_paragraph: As bow-tied waiters cleared plates and emptied coffee cups inside a plush meeting room at the Yale Club in Midtown Manhattan earlier this month, about 30 veterans from nearby community colleges listened to representatives from Yale, Dartmouth, Wesleyan and Vassar describe their veterans programs and answer questions about academics, financial aid and housing.

headline: Auto-Renewing Your Health Plan May Be Bad for You, and for Competition
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: People hate to shop around, particularly for things as complicated as health insurance. But that may open the door to bigger rate increases.
lead_paragraph: My colleagues Margot Sanger-Katz and Amanda Cox wrote recently that shopping around for the best price can be crucial for people renewing their coverage on the health insurance exchanges this fall. But evidence suggests that many people probably won’t do that. Not only is that bad for them, but it can also harm competition, which is bad for everyone.

headline: Eric Holder’s Mixed Legacy on White-Collar Crime

abstract: Mr. Holder’s tenure as attorney general was marked by multibillion-dollar settlements with big banks but few prosecutions of executives, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Eric H. Holder Jr.’s last year as attorney general was marked by multibillion-dollar settlements with big banks for their role in fueling the boom in subprime mortgages. They were a long-awaited response to the financial crisis but came after precious few prosecutions of corporate executives.

headline: Marmosets Find Videos Educational, if Not Viral
abstract: Wild marmosets in the Brazilian forest can learn quite successfully from video demonstrations featuring other marmosets, Austrian scientists report.
lead_paragraph: Wild marmosets in the Brazilian forest can learn quite successfully from video demonstrations featuring other marmosets, Austrian scientists have reported, showing not only that marmosets are even better learners than previously known, but that video can be used successfully in experiments in the wild.

headline: Celiac Disease, a Common, but Elusive, Diagnosis
abstract: A main reason for a lag in the detection of celiac disease is the long and confusing list of signs and symptoms, some of which may be mild enough to be easily ignored or attributed to another condition.
lead_paragraph: The trouble for Daniel Tully, then 12 and an excellent student and athlete in Brooklyn, began 20 months ago, when he developed what seemed like a virus that kept recurring, each time sending him to bed and keeping him from school for a week.

abstract: From a visa arriving hours before a government shutdown to staying one mile away from the protests in Red Square against American families adopting Russian children, there were plenty of chances for this adoption to fall apart.
lead_paragraph: The path to parenthood can be endlessly unpredictable. But John and Sheryl Nauta, one of the last families to adopt from Russia, recognize how much fate could have drastically halted that journey.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier Gives a Good Party
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'September Fashion Week (2014)']
abstract: The designer’s final ready-to-wear show had Champagne, cheers and confetti. It was a night when memories came flooding back.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The first indication that Jean Paul Gaultier’s final show for his ready-to-wear collection would be just a little different came with the announcement of the site. The show would be staged not at his complex on the Rue St.-Martin but at the venerable movie theater Le Grand Rex on the Boulevard Poissonnière, raising expectations for an already eager audience that had marked this date on the calendar ever since Mr. Gaultier announced the show would be his last.

headline: Nebraskans Raise Their Voices in Fight Against Keystone XL Pipeline
abstract: With a coalition of farmers, ranchers, Native Americans and urban environmentalists, the state has become the center of opposition to the project.
lead_paragraph: NELIGH, Neb. — From the edge of a rye field teeming with grasshoppers, Willie Nelson and Neil Young sang on Saturday in opposition to the proposed Keystone XL project, warning through lyrics that a “company wants to build a tar sand pipeline where it don’t belong.”

headline: He Kicked a Stray Cat, and Activists Growled
abstract: With pressure from animal rights activists, prosecutors in New York City and across the country are pursuing abuse cases more aggressively, but defense lawyers say the punishments go too far.
lead_paragraph: The video lasts all of 12 seconds: A stray cat — after being lured by a young man’s outstretched hand — is suddenly and violently kicked, its body propelled through the air, clearing a small fence and landing about 20 feet away, to a chorus of cackling laughter.

headline: Beware of Joy
abstract: When you’re having a good day, do you ever worry something bad is around the corner? Then you’ve felt “fear of happiness.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re a defensive pessimist (or even just a regular pessimist), you may already be familiar with the phenomenon known as “fear of happiness.”

The executives assumed duties that had previously been handled by Ed Brojerdi, whose title had been president and co-chief creative officer; Mr. Brojerdi was recently promoted to chief executive of Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners New York. lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are lots of open questions about the road the Supreme Court justices will take to a final decision about whether the Constitution guarantees a right to same-sex marriage. But one thing seems clear: The answer will arrive next June.

headline: Chemistry May Not Be Right for a SoftBank-DreamWorks Deal
abstract: Alibaba proved to be a good bet, but at some point SoftBank’s boss, Masayoshi Son, will have to more clearly explain his vision, Una Galani of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: SoftBank’s acquisition strategy is nothing if not animated, but it is not always easy to see a clear plot. The Japanese conglomerate’s next move could be a bid for DreamWorks Animation worth $3.4 billion, according to The Hollywood Reporter. SoftBank’s giant balance sheet could easily absorb the hit-and-miss earnings of film production. Yet with each big buy, it becomes less clear how the group’s parts fit together.

abstract: The author of “Sons of the Prophet” will return to the Laura Pels Theater with his new family drama, “The Humans.”
lead_paragraph: The Roundabout Theater Company will stage “The Humans,” a new play by Stephen Karam, in the fall of 2015, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Ads Declare That Sweeteners, Like Apples, Don’t Fall Far From the Tree
keywords: ['Sugar', 'Artificial Sweeteners', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', "Sweet 'N Low (Artificial Sweetener)", 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: The Cumberland Packing Corporation’s line of In the Raw products gets a family tree-themed marketing campaign.
lead_paragraph: The suggestion of “Sugar in the morning, sugar in the evening, sugar at suppertime” may be just the ticket for a successful song, but it is hardly a hit as dietary advice. Now, as Americans continue to vigorously debate the pros and cons of sweeteners, a leader in the category has started a campaign that portrays several of its products in a warm and fuzzy fashion.

headline: What to Wear This Week: Sept. 29
abstract: This week it will be warm enough for ankle-barring slacks that make slip-on sneakers the focus, yet cool enough to appreciate the closed toe.
lead_paragraph: If the floor-to-ceiling Halloween decorations in your local drugstore aren’t enough of an indication that summer is gone, maybe the dip in temperatures will be.

headline: Christopher Owens on Growing Up, Modeling and Quitting His Band Girls
abstract: The indie-rock icon and erstwhile model is about to release his second album, “A New Testament,” which features an unexpected country flavor.
lead_paragraph: Of all the paths to indie-rock stardom, Christopher Owens‘s has certainly been one of the most unlikely. He spent most of his childhood in Europe and Asia, sheltered from pop culture as a member of the religious cult Children of God. After escaping, he became the personal assistant to the eccentric Texas oil billionaire Stanley Marsh III. That unconventional background didn’t stifle Owens’s preternatural songwriting gifts, which were first revealed in his group Girls, which released two passionately received albums – 2009’s “Album” and 2011’s “Father, Son, Holy Ghost” – before splintering.

headline: Toxic Gases Delay Rescue on Volcano in Japan
abstract: High levels of poisonous gases near the peak of Mount Ontake led to a suspension of rescue operations after eight more bodies were recovered.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Rescue workers trying to reach fallen hikers on a volcano in Japan were forced to turn back on Monday for a second time because of high levels of poisonous gases near the smoldering peak.

headline: 1964: Silent Comic Harpo Marx Dies
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Harpo Marx dies in 1964.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — Harpo Marx, the one who never spoke, died in a hospital here last night following surgery. He was 75, according to his family. The death of Harpo, whose real name was Arthur, leaves only Groucho of the three brothers whose films had the world rocking with laughter in the 1930s. Harpo’s contribution to the Marx brothers’ act was a harp, a battered opera hat, baggy pants and an improbable frock coat, from which he pulled a wild assortment of junk. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 30, 1964

John Kasich, who holds a seemingly insurmountable double-digit lead over his foundering Democratic rival, Ed FitzGerald.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ever since Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq let slip during his United Nations visit last week that his government had uncovered information about an ISIS plan to attack the subways in New York and Paris, there has been a niggling sense of unease hanging over the final fashion city of the season.

headline: ‘Waterfall,’ a New Musical With Thai Inspiration, Aiming for Broadway
abstract: “Waterfall,” which centers on a Thai student who falls in love with the American wife of a Thai diplomat, is to run on the West Coast in advance of a planned New York run in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The veteran Broadway songwriters Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire (“Baby,” “Big”) are teaming up with theater artists from Thailand on a new musical romance, “Waterfall,” that will have productions in Pasadena, Calif., and Seattle next year before a planned move to Broadway in 2016, the creators and producers announced on Monday.

abstract: The inquiry began after the appearance of images of mistreatment, including a guard with his foot on the back of a refugee’s neck.
lead_paragraph: At least six guards at refugee camps in Germany’s most populous state are under investigation and suspected of abuse at three facilities, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: High-Gloss Pouts and Barely-There Brows at Giambattista Valli
abstract: For the designer’s spring/summer 2015 runway, the shine factor was key.
lead_paragraph: “As you can see, I am busy bleaching this young lady’s eyebrows with a little peroxide,” said the makeup artist Val Garland backstage at Giambattista Valli today while peering over her signature cat-eye specs. “It adds a modern uniformity to the look, which is otherwise very pretty and lustrous. Giamba absolutely loves gloss. He likes the girls to glow from head to toe on that runway.”

headline: No Comment Necessary: Will the 2016 Election Take Place?
abstract: Ben Carson thinks it’s possible that anarchy will derail the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon famous for saying the Affordable Care Act was “the worst thing that happened in this nation since slavery,” is thinking about running for president in 2016. But he’s not actually sure that an election will take place.

headline: Toolmaking May Have Risen Independently
abstract: A technique which early humans used to make knives by flaking off bits of stone was long thought to have originated in Africa and spread from there, but a new study suggests it arose independently in Eurasia.
lead_paragraph: The so-called Levallois technique — which early humans used to make knives and other instruments by flaking off bits of stone — was long thought to have originated in Africa 500,000 to 600,000 years ago, then taken to Eurasia as part of an exodus from Africa.

headline: Poll Contains Hidden Nugget of Good News for Thom Tillis

lead_paragraph: It’s not usually wise to focus too much on individual polls, but Sunday’s CNN/ORC poll in North Carolina is worth a little extra attention.

headline: Judge Recommends Firing Officers in Rikers Beating Case

headline: In Rare Rebuke for Rikers Officers, Judge Urges Firing of 6 Who Beat Inmate
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Guards', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The ruling, on a 2012 episode, highlights the infrequency of strong punishments for guards at a jail that has come under heavy federal scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: In April 2012, on a cellblock for inmates with mental illnesses, five Rikers Island guards and a captain hogtied Robert Hinton, cuffing his hands behind his back and shackling his ankles, then carried him face down, by his arms and legs, into a solitary confinement cell.

headline: Magic Opens Doors, No Tricks Required
abstract: The talents of Andrew Basso, an illusionist and escape artist, once got him into business class and generated new business.
lead_paragraph: MY perspective of traveling is probably similar to that of other business travelers, except that I’m in a nontraditional career. I’m an illusionist and an escape artist. Houdini is my hero. When I started flying to give performances I thought it was really exciting. That lasted for about 30 flights. Now, flying is so routine I don’t even think about it much. It’s like brushing my teeth.

headline: The Thermopylae of the West
abstract: How an outgunned Union force turned back the Confederate invasion of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1862, Confederate armies under Robert E. Lee and Braxton Bragg invaded the slaveholding states of Maryland and Kentucky, but their ambition to conquer the border South was famously quashed at the battles of Antietam and Perryville. Two years later, in September 1864, a Confederate army under Sterling Price invaded another slave state, Missouri, likewise intending to wrest it from Union control. This, too, ended in failure. But while nothing in Price’s campaign reached the scale or importance of those previous battles, the pivotal engagement, at Pilot Knob, Mo., was noteworthy for the odds overcome by the vastly outnumbered Union – indeed, some called it “Thermopylae of the West,” recalling that ancient battle in which a small band of Spartan warriors held off an overwhelmingly larger Persian force.

headline: Fall Foliage Travel Turns Adventurous
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Autumn (Season)', 'Adventure Travel', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The once-staid activity has become a lot more physical, combining nature appreciation with zip-lining, paintball and off-road Segway tours.
lead_paragraph: Leaf viewing has moved off-road, sometimes far off-road.

headline: The Child’s Village Leaves Lifetime Scars
abstract: A memoir by Charles M. Blow reveals his struggles with the standards of race and masculinity while growing up in small-town rural Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: When I was 10 and in the habit of following my father on his errands, I accompanied him on a trip to an electrical supply store. Just after we’d parked and gone inside, a clerk told my father that a police officer was about to give him a ticket. We rushed outside and, after receiving an apology for overlooking a no-parking sign, the officer let my father out of the ticket, provided he moved the car. I stood next to the officer as my father searched for another space. He asked how old I was and remarked that I was big for my age, a comment I was accustomed to hearing. Then he crudely asked if I was anatomically proportionate.

headline: The Latest Player in the Polling Game? It’s Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft gets into the polling business.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft on Monday will begin to apply its technological know-how to the world of politics with the release of of a new “Prediction Lab,” a website that will let people submit opinions and predictions on a range of topics.

headline: Crimped Strands at Stella McCartney
abstract: A restrained nod to the ’80s inspired the beauty look on the designer’s runway today.
lead_paragraph: Long, sleek ponytails have become commonplace at the spring 2015 fashion shows. And at first glance, it seemed like Stella McCartney’s models were wearing them on today’s runways. But upon closer inspection, the ‘do was actually streaked with a few chunks of crimped strands — a nice texture element that felt modern thanks to the resistance to crimp the whole head of hair. Pink lids and lips added to the very ’80s feel of the fresh beauty look.

headline: ‘Children of a Lesser God’ to Return to Broadway
abstract: The producer Hal Luftig plans to bring Mark Medoff’s play back to Broadway for the 2015-16 season, with Kenny Leon to direct.
lead_paragraph: “Children of a Lesser God,” a groundbreaking play about the relationship between a deaf woman and a hearing man, who clash over ideas about speech even as they fall in love, will be revived on Broadway during the 2015-16 theater season, the producer Hal Luftig announced on Monday. The director will be Kenny Leon, who won a Tony Award in June for staging the Broadway revival of “A Raisin in the Sun” last spring.

lead_paragraph: Bank of America has agreed to pay $7.65 million to settle federal charges that it violated record keeping and internal rules in overstating its capital levels.

headline: The Art of Recycling

lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the oldies are still the goodies.

headline: 65 Floors Up, a Classic Returns
abstract: The Rainbow Room, closed for five years, is scheduled to reopen Sunday after renovations that include a new cocktail lounge called SixtyFive.
lead_paragraph: The Rainbow Room was born with good bones, but that was 80 years ago. So when Tishman Speyer, the company that owns and manages Rockefeller Center, decided to reopen it five years after it closed, the goal was to restore the glitter to one of New York’s most romantic settings.

headline: Closing House Door, After White House One Was Left Open
abstract: letter to issa
lead_paragraph: Julia Pierson, the director of the Secret Service, will face a skeptical and angry crowd Tuesday morning when she testifies before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform about security breaches at the White House.

headline: American Apparel Hires New Interim Chief Executive
abstract: The retailer, locked in a public battle with its founder, said Scott Brubaker of the turnaround firm Alvarez & Marsal would temporarily take the company’s helm.
lead_paragraph: The troubled retailer American Apparel named a new interim chief executive on Monday in a bid to move on from a public battle with its founder and former chief, Dov Charney.

headline: Protests in Hong Kong Have Roots in China’s ‘Two Systems’
abstract: A look at why the political movements behind the protests would never have taken root in any other Chinese city.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong belongs to China. But the grass-roots political movements responsible for the protests underway in the heart of the city’s financial district would never have taken root in any other Chinese city.

headline: Swaths of Suede Storm the Spring/Summer 2015 Runways
abstract: The trend really picked up in Milan at Gucci and came to a head in Paris at Chloé.
lead_paragraph: A 1970s undercurrent is coursing through the spring/summer 2015 collections, which have championed the return of bohemian prints, bell bottoms, unruly hair — and suede. The material was first spotted in New York at Derek Lam, but it really started to trend in Milan. At Gucci, the creative director Frida Giannini presented a boho-charged collection of floral, beaded minidresses, colored fur vests and the suede belted dress above, that looked straight out of the brand’s archives. Yesterday in Paris, the designer Claire Waight Keller introduced a similar silhouette on the Chloé runway: a shorter, belted jacket paired with shorts. And finally at Loewe, the British designer Jonathan Anderson used leather and suede heavily in his debut show for the Spanish luxury leather-goods brand — which peaked with this buff suede trench coat with wide-leg trousers. The bag reinforced the message loud and clear: suede is in.

headline: Scientists Trace Extreme Heat in Australia to Climate Change
abstract: Five groups of researchers analyzing last year’s Australian heat waves came to the same conclusion: They could not have been as severe without human influence.
lead_paragraph: The savage heat waves that struck Australia last year were almost certainly a direct consequence of greenhouse gases released by human activity, researchers said Monday. It is perhaps the most definitive statement climate scientists have made tying a specific weather event to global warming.

headline: Being Mindful Can Help Guide a Decision
abstract: The process of taking a minute to notice our feelings can help shape our actions for the better, a financial planner suggests.
lead_paragraph: We’re really good at telling ourselves stories.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Worst Supreme Court Ruling
keywords: ['Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: The justice would overrule Citizens United.
lead_paragraph: In an interview for The New Republic, Jeffrey Rosen asked Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg to name “the worst ruling the current Court has produced.” Maybe her hemming-and-hawing was edited out, but it looks as though Justice Ginsburg didn’t hesitate at all in choosing Citizens United, in which the Court took the radical step of deciding that the First Amendment prohibits the government from restricting independent political expenditures.

headline: Prince Celebrating New Albums With a Paisley Park Livestream
abstract: Prince and 3rdeyegirl will stream the Paisley Park release party for their new records online on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: With two new albums to be released on Tuesday, Prince announced that he would celebrate the albums – his own “Art Official Age” and a collaboration with 3rdeyegirl, “Plectrumelectrum” – by throwing a party at Paisley Park, his studio complex in Chanhassen, Minn., and inviting his fans to tune in online.

headline: Netanyahu Links Hamas With ISIS, and Equates ISIS With Iran

headline: Weekly Quandary: Talking Racism and Sexism With Children
abstract: Parental silence on gender roles and racial differences won’t lead to race-blind and gender-neutral children. That doesn’t make racism and sexism any easier to talk about. How does your family do it?
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? In last week’s open thread, solitaire wrote:

headline: California Is Burning
abstract: A video highlights the desperate condition of farmers battling drought in California’s once-verdant Central Valley.
lead_paragraph: California’s Central Valley is one of the most fascinating places in America. The grassy, flat-bottomed basin occupies the core of inland California, roughly 13 percent of the state’s total land area, sprawled out between the Sierra Nevada range to the east and the Coast Ranges to the west. Once a primordial seabed, it’s now fertile ground.

headline: Consumer Agency Penalizes Flagstar Bank Over Mortgage Servicing
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s action against Flagstar Bank is a harbinger of others that could be brought under new mortgage servicing guidelines.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took aim at one of the most powerful players in the housing market: the mortgage servicing firms that have great sway in deciding whether struggling homeowners lose their homes to foreclosure or win a reprieve.

headline: For China, Limited Tools to Quell Unrest in Hong Kong
abstract: The Chinese leader must find a solution that keeps Hong Kong stable without sparking copycat calls for change in mainland China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s Communist Party has ample experience extinguishing unrest. For years it has used a deft mix of censorship, arrests, armed force and, increasingly, money to repress or soften calls for political change.

lead_paragraph: In case you missed it, Derek Jeter played his last game on Sunday, capping a 20-year career that featured five World Series titles, 14 All-Star appearances, 3,465 hits and 27 mentions in the Congressional Record.

headline: EMusic Returns to Indie Roots Amid Shift in Online Market
abstract: The pioneering digital music store said Monday that it would no longer carry music from the major labels Sony, Universal and Warner.
lead_paragraph: EMusic, a pioneering digital music store that has struggled to find its place in the rapidly shifting online market, has changed directions again.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Lorenzo Wins in MotoGP at Aragon; Márquez and Rossi Crash
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'Automobiles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters']
abstract: In a crash-plagued race, Jorge Lorenzo claims a MotoGP victory in his home country; Jeff Gordon wins the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Dover, Del.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Lorenzo won a crash-plagued MotoGP race at Motorland Aragón in Spain on Sunday, with the help of a prudent decision to switch bikes with just four laps left in the race, when rain started to pour down. The race leader, Marc Márquez, and his Honda teammate, Dani Pedrosa, tried to tough it out and ended up crashing in the wet conditions.

headline: Generating a Molecule With Star Quality
abstract: Scientists in England have generated a highly complex star-shaped molecule made of interlocking rings that could be used to produce materials that are light, flexible and resilient.
lead_paragraph: Scientists at the University of Manchester in England have generated a highly complex star-shaped molecule made of interlocking rings that could be used to produce light, flexible, resilient materials. The Star of David molecule, described in the journal Nature Chemistry, consists of two molecular triangles entwined three times into a hexagram with a perimeter of 114 atoms. It is modeled on the tough, light shells of certain viruses, the researchers said, and should produce a “chain mail” effect when linked with others like it.

headline: Yankees See Alex Rodriguez as a Starter, as Long as He Earns It
abstract: Besides addressing the Rodriguez situation, Manager Joe Girardi said in his end-of-season news conference that next year the team would seek ways to counter infield shifts.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after his team’s final game of 2014, Manager Joe Girardi returned to Yankee Stadium on Monday and addressed questions about the failures of the season and the preparations for 2015.

headline: Contaminants Everywhere
abstract: A wide range of chemicals are finding their way into rivers, fertilizers, plants and animals.
lead_paragraph: A wide range of chemicals are finding their way into rivers, fertilizers, plants and animals.

headline: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra’s President Quits
abstract: Stanley Romanstein resigned his position as president and chief executive of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which is in the midst of a labor lockout.
lead_paragraph: First the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra’s opening weeks of concerts were canceled after its musicians were locked out in a labor dispute. Now the orchestra’s president is gone.

headline: Red Floral Motifs Bloom on the Spring/Summer 2015 Runways
abstract: Yesterday, Phoebe Philo made it official: flowers and varying shades of crimson pair well together.
lead_paragraph: Florals are set to be a bona fide trend for spring/summer 2015 thanks to Céline, whose designer, Phoebe Philo, broke up the mostly muted collection with a series of floral dresses in the middle of yesterday’s presentation in Paris. Her red-on-black look echoed the red rose-printed pieces at Maison Rabih Kayrouz and Simone Rocha‘s ultrafeminine spring collection, which featured a series of floral prints on a crimson background.

headline: Science Events: Dancing Particle Physics and Science-Inspired Fashion
abstract: In a piece choreographed by the artist-in-residence at the CERN physics laboratory, dancers will begin with a sort of quantum twerk, a subtle jiggling motion that evokes the vibration of subatomic particles.
lead_paragraph: October events at the intersection of science and art.

headline: Michigan Coach Brady Hoke Chided for Sending Quarterback Back on Field
abstract: Shane Morris, the quarterback for 2-3 Michigan, remained in Saturday’s game after appearing dazed on a hard hit. On Monday, Hoke defended his actions.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Criticism of how Coach Brady Hoke and his staff handled a potentially concussed player, coupled with the Wolverines’ 2-3 start, has raised questions about Hoke’s future as coach of the proud Michigan program.

headline: Working Long Hours Tied to Diabetes Risk
abstract: Working long hours may increase the risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new review has found, but the risk is only apparent in workers of lower socioeconomic status.
lead_paragraph: Working long hours may increase the risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new review has found, but the risk is apparent only in workers of lower socioeconomic status.

headline: Amusement Park Ups and Downs
abstract: “Happyland” is a new MTV sitcom and drama set in an amusement park.
lead_paragraph: The average visit to Walt Disney World or any similar theme park isn’t a profound experience, but it’s an amusing enough diversion. That statement also describes “Happyland,” a series set behind the scenes at such a park.

headline: Overseas Trade Alters a Lizard’s Stocks
abstract: The rise of the global shipping trade has caused a fundamental shift in how species spread from one landmass to the next.

headline: Saint Laurent: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Rating Pain Relief
abstract: How is the effectiveness of pain relievers measured? Is there a list that quantifies them by strength?
lead_paragraph: Q. How is the effectiveness of pain relievers measured? Is there a list that quantifies them by strength?

headline: Polls Show Tight Senate Races in Critical States
abstract: Polls over the weekend shake up Senate races in Iowa, Louisiana and North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: With just over five weeks until Election Day, polls released over the weekend find close Senate races in Iowa, Louisiana and North Carolina, with the leads in each poll falling within the margin of sampling error.

headline: United’s Deal With Uber Raises Concerns
keywords: ['AIRPORTS', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing']
abstract: Some airport officials questioned the airline’s agreement with the ride-sharing service, which was made without consulting the airports involved.
lead_paragraph: UNITED AIRLINES has been reprising its old advertising slogan about the “friendly skies.” But some airports think the airline was a bit less than friendly when it formed a partnership with the ride-sharing company Uber without seeking airport input.

headline: Cisco: The Internet Needs More Control
abstract: Cisco has a novel approach for selling its big Internet vision, called Intercloud: There is no better way to impose government policies on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems is making an unusual case for itself: The Internet must be subject to a higher amount of control, and big companies will work with governments to make that possible.

headline: Forecasting the Fall of the Two-Hour Marathon
abstract: The trend of previous records suggests that a sub-two-hour marathon may be no more than a decade or two away.
lead_paragraph: Will the two-hour marathon be the four-minute mile of our day? Just as a sub-four-minute mile once seemed as if it might be beyond the limits of human speed and endurance, a sub-two hour marathon is both remarkably close yet seemingly impossible.

headline: Readers Debate Online Piracy and the Future of Digital Entertainment
abstract: Among the questions raised: Does the entertainment industry need to change its business model to address the reality of illegal streaming?
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, The New York Times published the story of a popular — and illegal — website that let people stream and download movies and television shows at their leisure. The site was taken offline in 2010 by the federal government, and the administrators behind the site were charged with conspiracy and copyright infringement. Nearly all served time in prison. The article touched a nerve among Times readers, eliciting hundreds of reactions about copyright infringement and intellectual property, and how the digital world complicates both.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Hong Kong, Turkey, Liberia and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hong Kong, Turkey, Liberia and Japan.

headline: Armed Intruder at White House Got to East Room
abstract: The man who jumped the White House fence made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent before he was tackled, a member of Congress said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An armed man who jumped the White House fence this month made it far deeper into the mansion than previously disclosed, overpowering a Secret Service agent inside the North Portico entrance and running through the ceremonial East Room before he was tackled, according to a member of Congress familiar with the details of the incident.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Walkabout: Flights Delayed in Chicago, But Resuming in Paris
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Standstill A fire set at an air traffic control center in Chicago late last week is still causing flight delays at both city airports. (The New York Times)

headline: Renewed Fighting Around Donetsk Airport Tests Ukraine Cease-Fire
abstract: The upsurge in violence comes at a particularly critical time as Russian, Ukrainian and rebel officials are working on the boundaries of a buffer zone.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Deadly fighting has broken out again between the government and rebels around the strategically important airport outside Donetsk, a continuing source of friction that is testing the resilience of a recent cease-fire agreement.

headline: In Performance | Anthony Wayne
abstract: Mr. Wayne, with Anthony Miller on piano, sings the title song from “Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical,” about the pop star Sylvester. The show runs through Oct. 5 at Theater at St. Clement’s.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Wayne, with Anthony Miller on piano, sings the title song from “Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical,” about the pop star Sylvester. The show runs through Oct. 5 at Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Toyota Recalls 790,000 Tacoma Pickups
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The 2005-11 model years may have a corrosion problem that could lead to fuel leaks. Harley-Davidson, Yamaha and Volkswagen also issued recalls.
lead_paragraph: Toyota is recalling 790,000 Tacoma pickup trucks from the 2005-11 model years worldwide, including about 690,000 in the United States, because a rear suspension part could break and possibly puncture the gas tank or damage a brake line, the automaker said Monday.

headline: White House Intruder Got Farther Than First Reported, Official Says
abstract: A man who jumped the White House fence this month overpowered a female Secret Service agent inside the North Portico entrance and made it through the East Room before he was tackled.
lead_paragraph: Armed Intruder at White House Got to East Room

headline: Visiting an Ailing Relative
abstract: A sobering new book argues that wild chimps are being assaulted from all sides: hunted for meat, killed for raiding farmers’ fields, trafficked as exotic pets and threatened by diseases like Ebola.
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, laboratory chimps are being sprung from their cages. Last year, the National Institutes of Health announced that it would be retiring most of its chimpanzees and sending hundreds of its hairy, knuckle-walking charges to live out their lives in sanctuaries.

headline: Austerity Leads Ensemble to Adapt
abstract: The Baroque ensemble Les Arts Florissants, founded by William Christie in Paris, is adjusting its protocols to account for changes in public funding.
lead_paragraph: William Christie plans to lead his Baroque ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, in a pair of concerts at Versailles next summer to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the death of Louis XIV, whose patronage established the French musical style that Mr. Christie has helped revive.

headline: A Strange Disappearance and What the Neighbors Have to Say About It
abstract: David Lang’s “The Difficulty of Crossing a Field,” a musical-theater piece about a man who suddenly vanishes, is given a concert performance in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In light of the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in March, David Lang’s “The Difficulty of Crossing a Field,” a musical-theater piece about a man who suddenly vanishes, has a particular resonance. With a libretto by Mac Wellman, the piece is based on the 1888 one-page story of the same name by the American journalist and fiction writer Ambrose Bierce, an abolitionist who was wounded in the Civil War and whose own disappearance at 71 — possibly in Mexico or by suicide in the United States — has never been explained.

headline: Atomic Espionage
abstract: The Manhattan Project employed nearly 400,000 people to create the first atomic weapons. The security apparatus around the effort was immense — but according to a newly declassified report, plenty of secrets got out.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan Project employed nearly 400,000 people to create the first atomic weapons. The security apparatus around the effort was immense — but according to a newly declassified report, plenty of secrets got out.

headline: Sharply Dressed Gangsters
abstract: “Peaky Blinders,” a BBC crime drama that takes place in early-20th-century England, is being released by Netflix on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: As a title, “Peaky Blinders” manages to be both more intriguing and more off-putting than usual. In early-20th-century Birmingham, England, apparently, the term referred to peaked caps worn by gang members that had razor blades sewn into the seams. In the new BBC series about those gangs, whenever someone whips off his cap during battle the action suddenly goes slow-motion and balletic, as if we’re watching a rhythmic gymnastics broadcast with blood instead of streamers.

headline: Copying PC Photos to an iPhone
abstract: Plus, what you can back up on a Nexus tablet.

headline: Keeping Up With Kendall Jenner on Twitter, A Journalistic Survey of Street Style and More
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Twangy Homilies About Shouldering Through the Pain
abstract: Lucinda Williams explores obstacles to overcome in “Down Where the Spirit Meets the Bone”; Christopher Owens bypasses torment in “A New Testament.”
lead_paragraph: Lucinda Williams made her first album for her own label, Highway 20 Records, a magnum opus: two discs, 20 songs and a summation of what has endeared her to a large, loyal following. She’s pithy and penetrating, bruised but steadfast, proud of the grain and drawl of her voice. Her music places itself in a vanishing, idealized Southland where country, soul, blues and gospel all share a common spirit and a vocabulary of twang, and where life lessons can be delivered by a bar band.

headline: Forces of Nature, Haunting, Changing and Just Plain Happy
abstract: The New York City Ballet all-Balanchine program brought out the best from Ashley Bouder, Wendy Whelan and Teresa Reichlen.
lead_paragraph: At New York City Ballet on Friday night, Ashley Bouder and Andrew Veyette kept bursting back onto the stage in “Donizetti Variations” with a twinkling, ebullient, heart-catching virtuosity that had seasoned audience members asking, “When was it last this good?” In the title role of “La Sonnambula,” Wendy Whelan paced through the sharply changing paths of her sleep with a bleak urgency that gave an unfamiliar darkness to this always amazing drama. And in “Firebird,” the contrasting capacities of Teresa Reichlen’s style for superhuman amplitude and quiet intimacy opened up fresh meanings in this ballet.

headline: The Partisan Court Blocks Extended Voting in Ohio
abstract: Make no mistake, this is about politics and race.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon the Supreme Court justices decided 5-4, on party (of-the-president-who nominated-them) lines, to block extended voting hours and days in Ohio, 16 hours before voting was to begin there. The decision affects everyone in the state but will disproportionately harm poorer and minority voters, who rely on weekend and evening hours to avoid forbiddingly long lines on Election Day.

headline: A Child of the ‘Troubles’ of Northern Ireland
abstract: The actress-author of “Belfast Blues,” Geraldine Hughes, tells her story against images of Northern Ireland’s history.
lead_paragraph: “Belfast Blues” is full of impressive physical moments, when the flow of Geraldine Hughes’s words is either emphasized or countermanded by the casually coiled force of her body. On Saturday afternoon at the Barrow Street Theater, where the show has returned to New York for a limited engagement, one moment in particular stood out: Ms. Hughes standing very still and straight, embodying a British soldier.

headline: Love, Loss and Local Color Make a Bluegrass Musical
abstract: “Bright Star,” a new musical by Steve Martin and Edie Brickell, is having its premiere run in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Darkness and light are blended in even proportions in “Bright Star,” a sepia-toned new musical by Steve Martin and Edie Brickell making its premiere at the Old Globe theater here. The characters in this musically vibrant if overstuffed show, set in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina during two separate decades of the 20th century, endure hardship, heartache and almost melodramatic loss. But, as the title suggests, their eyes remain fixed not on the black canopy of night but on the beacons of hope that pierce it. A telling song from the second act reminds us that no matter how gray the future seems, the “sun is gonna shine again.”

headline: Trial Opens in Atlanta School Cheating Scandal
abstract: Prosecutors alleged that teachers and administrators had engaged in a “widespread, cleverly disguised” conspiracy to cheat on standardized test scores.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The criminal trial of a dozen public school educators opened here Monday with prosecutors alleging that the teachers and administrators had engaged in a “widespread, cleverly disguised” conspiracy to cheat on standardized test scores in an effort to protect their jobs and win favor and bonuses from administrators.

headline: Clintons, Now Grandparents, Take Political Breather
abstract: Family duties are trumping political ones for the Clintons.
lead_paragraph: Family duty has taken precedent over politics, at least for awhile, as Hillary Rodham Clinton cuts back on her public schedule to spend time with her new granddaughter.

headline: The Difficulties of Nuclear Containment
keywords: ['Manhattan Project', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A recently declassified report makes it clear that the Manhattan Project was threatened by leaks and espionage, and it reveals a huge blind spot on the government’s part.
lead_paragraph: In December 1945, four months after atomic bombs brought an end to World War II, the United States Army published a secret report on security surrounding the Manhattan Project, the vast government effort that developed them.

headline: Supreme Court Blocks Order to Restore 7 Days of Voting in Ohio
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Four of the justices would have upheld a ruling from an appeals court that blocked the state’s reduction of early balloting to 28 days from 35.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday blocked an appeals court ruling that would have restored seven days of early voting in Ohio.

headline: Seeking Global Role, German Military Stumbles
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Ebola Virus', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Germany is trying to increase its involvement in global security after years of reluctance, but its limitations have drawn questions from politicians.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In a spectacle that a leading weekly likened to a slapstick movie, Germany’s military, especially its air force, has repeatedly stumbled in recent days as it tried to ratchet up its international involvement by delivering personnel and matériel to forces battling Islamic extremists in Iraq and aid supplies to Africa to ease the Ebola crisis.

headline: Nature in the Balance, Gene Tests, Artificial Sweetners and Diabetes
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Climate Change

headline: A Dog’s Life in Chad: Filling Up on Fish Guts and on Guinea Worms
abstract: A surprise has turned up in the fight against Guinea worm: In Chad, more dogs have it than people do — and fish guts are apparently to blame.
lead_paragraph: A surprise has turned up in the fight against Guinea worm: In Chad, more dogs have it than people do — and fish guts are apparently to blame.

headline: Biopics and Noir Dominate a Festival
abstract: The New York Film Festival goes heavy on biopics (from Europe) and film noir from North America.
lead_paragraph: With three high-profile mysteries — “Inherent Vice,” “Gone Girl” and “Maps to the Stars” — it might seem as though film noir was the dominant flavor of this year’s New York Film Festival. But another theme runs through four selections: artist biographies. Call it a continental face-off between North America and Europe.

headline: Route Taken by the White House Intruder
abstract: The intruder who jumped the fence this month made it to several rooms inside the White House.
lead_paragraph: The intruder who jumped the fence this month made it to several rooms inside the White House.

headline: Rom-Com Echoes of Ephron
abstract: Several new network comedies attempt to breathe life into a genre that has been lagging at the box office.
lead_paragraph: Three network comedies begin this week, and while they all have one obvious thing in common — the perils of dating in the age of Twitter, Tinder and Snapchat — what they really share is Nora Ephron.

headline: Japanese Swordsman With a Camera
abstract: Whether on Japan’s street or shores, Issei Suda takes pictures like a swordsman, with light swiftly slicing the scene.
lead_paragraph: Whether on Japan’s street or shores, Issei Suda takes pictures like a swordsman, with light swiftly slicing the scene.

headline: After Surgery, Predicting a Speedy Recovery
abstract: In a small study, researchers found that certain activity in patients’ immune systems correlated to different recovery times.
lead_paragraph: After surgery, some patients rebound quickly, and some endure weeks of fatigue or pain.

headline: Clip: ‘Men, Women & Children’
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Jason Reitman.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Jason Reitman.

headline: Nominee for European Digital Job Explains Positions in Hearing
abstract: Günther Oettinger, the nominee to be the European Union’s next digital economy commissioner, emphasized that he wanted to create greater connections across the 28-member bloc.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Telecommunications investment. Data protection reforms. Cellphone roaming charges.

headline: First Draft Focus: Around Town
abstract: President Obama returned to the White House on Monday after attending an event hosted by the Democratic National Committee in Washington.

headline: Judge Holds Argentina in Contempt of Court in Bond Payment Case
abstract: Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan stopped short of issuing sanctions, saying he would make a decision about them in the future.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:06 p.m. | For more than a year, Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan has warned that Argentina would suffer repercussions if it defied his orders regarding payments to bondholders.

headline: Vets Face Rising Worry Over Fleas
abstract: Anecdotal reports suggest fleas are getting harder to control, but vets and product makers said the products still work.
lead_paragraph: Are fleas making a comeback?

headline: McConnell Softens Image in the Homestretch
abstract: In a new ad, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky goes positive with the midterm elections a little more than a month away.
lead_paragraph: The rhetorical gunfight in Kentucky’s Senate race seems to have been holstered, for the moment.

headline: Spanish Premier Insists Vote on Catalan Independence Will Not Happen
abstract: A decree signed by Catalonia’s leader authorizing a secession vote prompted a terse response from Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who said such a vote would be unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Two weeks after Scotland voted against leaving Britain, another and more contentious secession fight is hurtling ahead in Europe, with Spain and its independence-minded region of Catalonia increasingly at odds and showing few signs of willingness to compromise.

headline: White House Has Long History of Unwanted Visitors
abstract: The White House has a long history of intruders.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service’s mishandling of a recent White House intruder, who got deeper into the presidential residence than previously thought, might make it appear that the agency has little experience with trespassers.

headline: Indian Anchor’s Scuffle in New York Draws Supporters and Critics
abstract: Indian journalists rallied Monday in support of a television host who was harassed by supporters of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: Standing outside Madison Square Garden on Sunday, ahead of a rally for India’s new prime minister, Narendra Modi, the Indian television anchor Rajdeep Sardesai reminded viewers back home that the New York arena had been the site for many famous events, including "Muhammad Ali versus Joe Frazier.”

headline: Growing, and Growing Vulnerable
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Global Warming', 'Islands', 'Coast Erosion', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: A new report from the National Research Council found that the effect of climate change is especially harsh on the United States barrier islands, which are also pressured by rapid development.
lead_paragraph: QUOGUE, N.Y. — As the president of the Fire Island Association, Suzy Goldhirsch has a message she says she often offers property owners. “We are living on a sandbar in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean,” she tells them. “We are in a high-risk environment. We on barrier islands are on the front lines of climate change.”

headline: The Odds, Continually Updated
abstract: In Bayesian statistics, new data is used to shape assumptions, the opposite of the frequentist (classical) approach.
lead_paragraph: Statistics may not sound like the most heroic of pursuits. But if not for statisticians, a Long Island fisherman might have died in the Atlantic Ocean after falling off his boat early one morning last summer.

headline: Why Drivers Get Away With Murder
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Law and Legislation', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: We have the laws to cut traffic deaths — but lack the will to enforce them.
lead_paragraph: IN June, Mayor Bill de Blasio signed 11 bills related to Vision Zero, the city’s initiative to eliminate traffic deaths and serious injuries over the next decade. One was Cooper’s Law, named for my 9-year-old son, Cooper Stock, who was struck and killed by a cab on Jan. 10.

headline: Hirohito: String Puller, Not Puppet
abstract: The Japanese government’s new biography perpetuates the false but persistent myth of a benign, passive figurehead.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — LAST month, I received a startling email from an employee at one of Japan’s largest newspapers, about a development I’d long awaited. The government was about to unveil a 12,000-page, 61-volume official biography of Emperor Hirohito, which a large team of scholars and civil servants had been preparing since 1990, the year after his death.

abstract: Readers discuss the benefits and drawbacks of expanded screenings.

keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Readers debate whether Israel discourages dissenting opinions.
