headline: Deaths Tied to G.M. Ignition Rise to 23, as Compensation Offers Go Out
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The family of a Pennsylvania boy who was gravely injured in an 2009 accident said it would accept the program’s offer, though it would not divulge the amount of the award.
lead_paragraph: The number of deaths linked to General Motors’ defective ignition switch has risen again — to 23, according to new figures posted Monday by the program set up to compensate victims.

headline: Chicago Flights Are Returning to Normal After Attack on Air Traffic Center
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said it hoped to have the damage to a communications center near Chicago repaired by Oct. 13.
lead_paragraph: Amid efforts to rebuild an air-traffic control communications center near Chicago after an attack by a contractor’s employee on Friday, the Federal Aviation Administration said Monday that a patchwork of equipment and procedures had allowed it to increase flights at O’Hare International Airport to about 80 percent of normal, and at Midway Airport to 90 percent of normal.

headline: The More Popular Obama Rallies the Base
abstract: Michelle Obama ventured to Wisconsin to campaign for the Democratic candidate for governor.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE – Some had waited six hours, standing outside in the unseasonable heat and then in a packed auditorium. But all seemed forgotten once the first lady finally came out on stage.

headline: As Catholic Church Seeks Proof, Venezuela Sees a Saint
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church is seeking evidence of miracles linked to Dr. José Gregorio Hernández, who died in 1919.
lead_paragraph: ISNOTÚ, Venezuela — Venezuela needs a miracle. Preferably two. But this is not about finding a way to reconcile the country’s bitterly divided politics or fix its crippled economy. It is about something more spiritual.

headline: Tony Stewart Ponders a Death He Can’t Forget
abstract: In his first news conference since his car struck and killed Kevin Ward Jr. in an Aug. 9 race, Stewart said he never considered quitting Nascar.
lead_paragraph: KANNAPOLIS, N.C. — Tony Stewart has been exonerated in the sprint-car accident that killed the driver Kevin Ward Jr. at Canandaigua Motorsports Park in upstate New York on Aug. 9. He may be cleared, but a soft-spoken Stewart said Monday that he was not past the anguish he has lived with since that night.

headline: The Hole in Holder’s Legacy
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The Justice Department under Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. failed to prosecute cases related to the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. gave a speech at the New York University School of Law on the subject of white-collar prosecutions. In it, he offered a full-throated defense of his department’s efforts in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. With his resignation announcement coming eight days later, one can’t help but view his speech as a kind of valedictory.

headline: Some Judicial Opinions Require Only 140 Characters
abstract: In a state where members of the Supreme Court are elected, one justice uses Twitter, and often, to connect to his constituents.
lead_paragraph: To judge by his Twitter feed, Don Willett seems like an all-around solid guy: native Texan, proud conservative, three charming kids, loves Blue Bell ice cream and Baylor football, skilled at selfies, and not above the occasional lowbrow joke.

headline: The Hague: Bosnian’s Trial Nears End
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Prosecutors on Monday demanded a life sentence for the former Bosnian leader Radovan Karadzic as his trial draws to a close.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Monday demanded a life sentence for the former Bosnian leader Radovan Karadzic as his trial draws to a close, accusing him of being the “driving force” to rid large parts of the ethnically mixed Bosnia of its non-Serb inhabitants during the 1990s. Mr. Karadzic, 69, denies responsibility for the killings. The Bosnian conflict, from 1992 to 1995, tore apart communities where different ethnic groups and Christians and Muslims had long lived together. It left more than 100,000 people dead and uncounted others maimed or traumatized by rape. Four years of court hearings dealt with the 11 charges, including genocide, brought against Mr. Karadzic. He is accused of being responsible for the siege of Sarajevo, the execution of more than 7,000 captive men and boys in Srebrenica, and the brutal “ethnic cleansing” of towns and villages in 1992. Mr. Karadzic has led his own defense and will speak on Thursday and Friday.

headline: F.C.C. Appears Poised to Loosen Sports Blackout Rule, Despite Protests by the N.F.L.
abstract: If the commission, which is expected to vote on the rule on Tuesday, strikes it down, cable and satellite providers could show games even if they are not sold out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, football fans in various markets wondered whether, come Sunday, they would be able to watch their lamentable but beloved team on television. If tickets to that week’s game were not sold out, the National Football League could keep the game off television in the local market as a way to protect gate receipts.

headline: Mexico: Students Missing After Protest
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Missing Persons', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Authorities in Guerrero are searching for 57 students from a teachers college who have been missing since Friday when gunmen fired on a demonstration they were attending.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Guerrero, one of Mexico’s most violent states, are searching for 57 students from a teachers college who have been missing since Friday when gunmen fired on a demonstration they were attending, killing three students and three others nearby. The gunfire also wounded 25 people. The Guerrero state prosecutor, Iñaky Blanco Cabrera, said that witnesses identified the gunmen as local police officers in Iguala, where the protest occurred, and that more than 20 had been detained. Mr. Blanco described the episode as an instance of “undoubtedly excessive force” by the officers. The federal interior secretary, Miguel Ángel Osorio Chong, called the conduct of the police “incredible” and said federal authorities would join the investigation. Witnesses said police officers had put the missing students on a bus and escorted them from the scene.

headline: Scenes From the Edge of War
abstract: Anne Barnard is in Turkey covering United States airstrikes in Syria, but finding that mostly they are notable only in their absence.
lead_paragraph: Anne Barnard is a correspondent based in Lebanon and covering the Middle East. Recently, she has been in Turkey, along with Karam Shoumali, a Times stringer, and Bryan Denton, a freelance photographer working for The Times, to cover the ripple effect of a war they can scarcely see. She reflects on life along the border between Turkey and Syria and the challenges of reporting there.

headline: A U-Turn for a Terminal Built in Texas to Import Natural Gas
abstract: Qatar Petroleum wants to export American gas by converting the terminal to export from import at a cost of at least $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: SABINE PASS, Tex. — The giant Golden Pass natural gas import terminal here, meant to bring Middle Eastern gas to energy-hungry Americans, sits eerily quiet these days, a sleepy museum to a bygone era.

headline: Vatican Investigates Missouri Bishop Who Shielded Pedophile Priest
abstract: The Roman Catholic Church is investigating Bishop Robert W. Finn, who was convicted in 2012 for failing to report a priest suspected of sexual abuse of children.
lead_paragraph: The only American bishop ever convicted of shielding a pedophile priest is now under investigation by the Vatican.

headline: Delayed Justice for the Navajos
keywords: ['Navajo Indians', 'Native Americans', 'Editorials', 'Land Use Policies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A $554 million agreement with the Navajo Nation is the latest and most encouraging development in a reversal by the Obama administration in settling to legitimate tribal claims.
lead_paragraph: The long struggle of American Indian tribes to be fairly compensated for decades of federal mismanagement of their tribal lands’ resources reached an important point last week with an agreement by the largest tribe, the Navajo Nation, to accept $554 million in settlement of long-running litigation over breach-of-trust claims.

headline: Shawn Vestal Wins PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize
abstract: Mr. Vestal’s collection of stories, “Godforsaken Idaho,” took home the $25,000 prize on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: The PEN American Center on Monday announced that Shawn Vestal is the winner of this year’s $25,000 PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction. Mr. Vestal earned the honor for “Godforsaken Idaho,” a collection of short stories. He received the prize from Louise Erdrich at a ceremony at the New School.

headline: A New Attack on Antibiotic Resistance
keywords: ['ANTIBIOTICS', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Livestock', 'Editorials', 'Factory Farming', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: The Obama administration announced a plan to help reduce the overuse of antibiotics, but there are many details still to be filled in.
lead_paragraph: Antibiotic-resistant germs are an increasing threat, causing at least 23,000 deaths and two million illnesses in the United States each year, and requiring treatment costing $20 billion in direct medical expenses. The Obama administration announced some good measures this month that should help reduce the overuse of antibiotics in humans and much, though perhaps not all, of the overuse in animal husbandry that together are fueling the emergence of drug-resistant germs.

headline: Ford Cuts 2014 Profit Estimate, Sending Shares Lower
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker expects a pretax profit of around $6 billion this year, down from an earlier forecast of $7 billion to $8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor warned on Monday that its profit for 2014 would be as much as $2 billion lower than earlier estimates, after a series of events that included a recall of hundreds of thousands of vehicles in North America.

headline: James Shields, an Imported Ace, Is an Important Piece for the Royals
abstract: Over the last two years, perhaps no one player has done more than Shields to change the culture and the mind-set in Kansas City.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Kansas City Royals traded for James Shields in December 2012, Dave Eiland, the team’s pitching coach, called Shields to brief him on the state of the pitching staff. Eiland felt that after decades of futility, a sense of resignation had set in.

headline: With ‘Crouching Tiger’ Sequel, Netflix Takes Aim at Hollywood
abstract: Netflix and the Weinstein Company said that they planned to release a sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.
lead_paragraph: In a first deal of its kind, Netflix and the Weinstein Company said Monday that they planned to release next year’s sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously across the globe on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.

headline: De Blasio’s Executive Order Will Expand Living Wage Law to Thousands More
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to sign the order, which also raises the hourly wage, on Tuesday. The administration estimates that about 18,000 wage earners will be affected.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to sign an executive order on Tuesday significantly expanding New York City’s living wage law, covering thousands of previously exempt workers and raising the hourly wage itself, to $13.13 from $11.90, for workers who do not receive benefits.

headline: ‘Gotham’ Recap: Batman as a Goth Boy, the Butler as an Angry Young Man
abstract: In Monday’s episode, titled “Selena Kyle,” the future Catwoman came out of the shadows.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 2, “Selina Kyle”

headline: China’s Crackdown in Hong Kong
abstract: The promise of “one country, two systems” was supposed to last until 2047. How far will President Xi go if protesters stand their ground?
lead_paragraph: If China had honored the political commitments it made before taking control of Hong Kong from Britain in 1997, it is likely there would be no protests in the city streets and no crackdown over the weekend by riot police using tear gas, pepper spray and batons against pro-democracy demonstrators.

headline: Opposition in Syria Is Skeptical of U.S. Airstrikes on ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Protests against American airstrikes have broken out across insurgent-held Syria over the past week, including among some of the very insurgents who spent years calling for them.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Across insurgent-held Syria over the past week, images have proliferated of protesters burning American flags, calling President Obama “the enemy of God,” and declaring that the American-led airstrikes against the Islamic State extremist group are helping the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Drug Patents Held Overseas Can Pare Makers’ Tax Bills
abstract: While not as advantageous as an inversion, biotech players are saving on taxes by transferring patents to foreign subsidiaries.
lead_paragraph: As the Obama administration tries to stop companies from avoiding taxes by moving their headquarters overseas, the makers of some of the world’s most lucrative and expensive medicines are using another tactic to reduce their payments to the government.

headline: A.I.G. Trial Witnesses Will Be Central Cast From 2008 Crisis
abstract: The trial focuses on whether or not A.I.G. received a fair deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six years after the government rescued the American International Group from the brink of collapse, the bailout came under a new microscope on Monday, with the opening of an unusual trial that challenges the legality of the government’s actions.

headline: Questions About Clippers Remain After Sale to Steve Ballmer
abstract: As the Clippers prepare for their first season since Ballmer bought the team, the Donald Sterling scandal is behind them, but they still need to prove they can make a title run.
lead_paragraph: PLAYA VISTA, Calif. — Los Angeles Clippers Coach Doc Rivers was sitting on stage, a microphone in hand, just starting to answer a question about the team’s new owner, Steve Ballmer, when he paused.

headline: Many Missteps in Assessment of ISIS Threat
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The question of how officials failed to anticipate the rise of ISIS resonates inside and outside the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By late last year, classified American intelligence reports painted an increasingly ominous picture of a growing threat from Sunni extremists in Syria, according to senior intelligence and military officials. Just as worrisome, they said, were reports of deteriorating readiness and morale among troops next door in Iraq.

headline: Lena Dunham’s About-Face: She’ll Share the Wealth With Tour Acts
abstract: Lena Dunham, who has earned millions, wasn’t going to pay the performers who vied for spots as entertainers on her book tour. But criticism changed her mind.
lead_paragraph: When Lena Dunham put out an open call for talent this past summer on her website, she was flooded with nearly 600 video responses. She was casting comedians, musicians and artists to perform as warm-up acts on an elaborate book tour for her new essay collection, “Not That Kind of Girl.” The seven performers ​she chose​ were so eager to be associated with Ms. Dunham that they apparently did not mind that the gig was unpaid.

headline: The Big Dangers of Fighting Bad Press
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A lawsuit filed by Stephen A. Wynn, the casino impresario, against an investor he accused of slandering him is the latest salvo in the growing tensions between vocal shareholders and corporations.
lead_paragraph: It’s a billionaire cage match.

headline: New System and Season Bring Carmelo Anthony and Knicks Fresh Perspective
abstract: As the Knicks prepared to begin training camp Tuesday at West Point, Carmelo Anthony addressed the news media with a renewed sense of optimism.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — If any doubt lingered over whether Carmelo Anthony had finally emerged from the dungeon of despair that was the 2013-14 season, he seemed determined to squash it on Monday when he took the dais at the Knicks’ training center.

headline: Club Shooting in Rough Miami Neighborhood Continues a Cycle of Violence
abstract: Miami police officers continued to try to make sense of what happened at 1 a.m. Sunday inside the Spot, a Caribbean nightclub, when gunfire broke out.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Along the battered storefronts and dilapidated homes in Liberty City, the barrage of gunfire that wounded 15 people inside a club over the weekend, many of them teenagers, has become an all-too-familiar ritual this year in a neighborhood long considered one of the poorest and most dangerous in Florida.

headline: More Debate on Plea Deal for Suspect in Terrorism
abstract: The defendant, Adel Abdul Bary, was accused of conspiring in the 1998 bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
lead_paragraph: The debate over whether federal prosecutors in Manhattan had granted too lenient a plea bargain to a terrorist defendant who, under its terms, would face no more than 25 years in prison, continued on Monday, with defense lawyers and prosecutors both asking the judge to accept the deal.

headline: A Winning Start Whets Appetites at Advertising Week
abstract: The opening panel at the annual gathering was meant to suggest that success on Madison Avenue could be just as rewarding — and elusive — as success on a field, pitch or gridiron.
lead_paragraph: THERE are no signs that Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP, the world’s largest agency holding group, plans to change careers. But if he were to do so, he might make a decent living on the conference circuit as a moderator.

headline: In Jets’ Dismal Start, Faith in Geno Smith Faces an Exacting Test
abstract: The Jets’ offense held a players-only meeting to vent some frustration over the team’s poor start to the season.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan sat at the round conference table in his office. An unlit candle, scented Bahama Breeze, rested in the middle. Madonna played softly on the speakers as Ryan gushed about his quarterback, Geno Smith.

headline: California Law on Sexual Consent Pleases Many but Leaves Some Doubters
abstract: Under the state law colleges must require “affirmative, conscious, and voluntary agreement to engage in sexual activity,” which can be verbal or communicated through actions.
lead_paragraph: Facing what many regard as an epidemic of campus sexual assault, some colleges have cracked down on binge drinking, others have reined in fraternities, while still others are training incoming students not to be passive bystanders when they see signs of trouble.

headline: Link Is Seen Between Virginia Student’s Disappearance and 2009 Killing
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The police say an arrest in connection with a missing University of Virginia student has given them a lead in the killing of a college student five years ago.
lead_paragraph: The arrest last week of a suspect in the disappearance of a University of Virginia student has led to a “significant break” in the investigation into the killing of another college student five years ago, officials said on Monday.

headline: Once Considered Won, Battle Against Invasive Beetles Is Renewed
abstract: Believed to be nearly eradicated, the voracious Asian long-horned beetle has been found in hundreds of trees in Long Island.
lead_paragraph: It is a menace from Asia that over the past two decades has ravaged tens of thousands of trees in several states. But after being wiped out in New Jersey, it seemed to be in retreat in New York thanks to a warlike response from federal and state governments. It was gone from Staten Island and Manhattan, and the battle against it was tilting toward eradication in Queens, in Brooklyn and on Long Island.

headline: Judge Rules Against Grooveshark in Copyright Infringement Case
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Royalties']
abstract: A federal judge in Manhattan found that the music service violated copyright law by uploading nearly 6,000 songs without permission.
lead_paragraph: In the music industry’s second big legal victory in a week, a federal judge in New York ruled on Monday that Grooveshark, an online music service long vilified by the major record companies, infringed on thousands of their copyrights.

headline: Cuomo’s Ad Faults Astorino on Health Care for Older Adults
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s ad attacks his Republican opponent, Rob Astorino, about dental services and prescription drug coverage for seniors.
lead_paragraph: First aired: Sept. 26, 2014

headline: Proctor’s Command
abstract: Kyle T. Dolan spins us a puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I’m not an avid television game show viewer, but a person would have to have been living under a rock not to be aware of “THE PRICE IS RIGHT.” Even so, I was only vaguely familiar with the SHOWCASE SHOWDOWN segment of the show, and wasn’t really familiar with its name. No matter; I thought that the setup for Kyle T. Dolan’s puzzle today was interesting and that kept me going, even if the puzzle itself didn’t solve “like a Tuesday” for me.

headline: ‘Sleepy Hollow’ Recap:  Ben Franklin Taps His Inner Frankenstein
abstract: Here, an offer: Ask Ichabod Crane about the perplexities of modern life.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 2, “The Kindred”

headline: Giants Say Extra Rest and Scouting Opportunity Give Them Edge on Falcons
abstract: Coach Tom Coughlin of the Giants, who are feeling a sense of rebirth after winning a second straight game on Thursday, used Sunday’s day off for a “live scout” of Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants woke Monday feeling more or less the same about themselves, while the league around them had changed.

headline: A Bid to Make the Park Lane Hotel a Landmark, but Not by the Usual Suspects
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The building, on Central Park South, was belittled even by its architect, and the bid for landmark status appears aimed at blocking plans for a higher tower.
lead_paragraph: The masterpieces of Central Park South are myriad: The Plaza, the St. Moritz, the Gainsborough Studios and the Essex House all come to mind.

headline: Revisiting the Lehman Brothers Bailout That Never Was
abstract: New accounts of events in 2008 as the New York Fed assessed the bank’s eligibility for rescue from bankruptcy have cast the firm’s collapse in a new light.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, time was running out to answer a question that would change Wall Street forever.

headline: Harlem Man Pleads Guilty to Assisting 2009 Death
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Kenneth Minor, 42, will receive 12 years in prison for his role in the 2009 death of Jeffrey Locker, who hired Mr. Minor to make his death look like a robbery.
lead_paragraph: One of the strangest cases of assisted suicide in recent New York history was resolved on Monday, as a Harlem man pleaded guilty to manslaughter for his role in stabbing a Long Island motivational speaker who wanted to die, and paid the man who helped him do so.

headline: At Montauk Point, Albacore on the Feed Prove a Tasty Pursuit
abstract: The autumn albacore scrum prompted a trip to the East End of New York with a Manhattan chef working on a project to introduce sustainable and less familiar wild fish to seafood menus.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the first faint hint of a cool snap kick-starts the migration of tiny bay anchovies by the billions out of the tidal creeks and back bays of the East Coast. Then, for a few weeks, the rolling sea turns into bloody mayhem as the little fish run into packs of hungry false albacore slashing through the schools of baitfish, lighting up the waves beneath Montauk Point with their glinting green flanks.

headline: Four Charged in a Bribery Scheme to Gain Clients in Arraignment Court
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Bail', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: A worker who interviewed defendants was paid as much as $1,000 per client that he steered to three lawyers and a paralegal, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: In the bowels of the Criminal Courts Building in Manhattan, as the newly arrested awaited arraignment, those who appeared to be wealthy were often handed an unsolicited piece of advice.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Sept. 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Ukraine Turmoil Keeps Veteran Moving
abstract: Ruslan Fedotenko, who played for 12 years in the N.H.L., is trying out with the Devils after the upheaval in his native country left him without a team.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Devils have invited veterans to training camp. A few even have their names engraved on the Stanley Cup.

headline: Song Sung Nostalgic: After Years of Hits, a Son of Erasmus Hall Returns
abstract: On Monday, Neil Diamond turned homeward and performed in Brooklyn for the first time since becoming a star, with a concert in Flatbush at Erasmus Hall High School.
lead_paragraph: Neil Diamond’s Brooklyn heritage is not as obvious as that of the Beastie Boys or Spike Lee. After all, he sings about Kentucky women, and his classic “Sweet Caroline” has been adopted as an anthem in enemy territory, at Fenway Park.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Man After Deadly Brooklyn Stabbing
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Assaults']
abstract: A man who was holding a knife in a home in Brooklyn died after being shot by the police and another man with stab wounds at the same site died at a hospital.
lead_paragraph: A man was shot and killed by a police officer in Brooklyn on Monday night and another man died after he was stabbed at the same location, officials said, in one of two episodes involving New York City officers who fired their weapons.

headline: Sheldon Patinkin, Force in Chicago Theater, Dies at 79
abstract: As a director at Second City and Steppenwolf and a department chairman at Columbia College, Mr. Patinkin helped to develop Chicago’s robust theatrical scene.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Patinkin, a writer, director and teacher who helped shape the theatrical life of Chicago over half a century, died there on Sept. 21. He was 79.

headline: Going Back, Back, Back, Back
abstract: On Tuesday, Kansas City will play its first postseason game since 1985, when it beat St. Louis in the World Series. Here’s a glimpse of what life was like back then.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Kansas City Royals will play their first postseason game in almost 29 years. Those Royals, led by George Brett, beat the St. Louis Cardinals in seven games to win the World Series. The year was 1985.

headline: From the Fat Radish, a Cure for the Common Cookbook
abstract: The team behind the popular Lower East Side restaurant are publishing a collection of 100 seasonal dishes meant to provide both information and inspiration. Here, they share a recipe with T.
lead_paragraph: When the Fat Radish opened four years ago on the lower Lower East Side, it was a harbinger of change for that rapidly transforming neighborhood and an indication of New York’s changing food preferences. The brainchild of Ben Towill and Phil Winser, childhood friends in England and the duo behind the catering concern Silkstone, it featured a menu with a British tilt, in keeping with the duo’s origins and the gastropub fad of the moment. But it worshipped at the altar of the vegetable, not the hearty cut of meat, and prized seasonal cooking above all else. Immediately, fashionistas and food cognescenti began trekking south of Delancey Street to indulge in the Fat Radish’s healthy comfort food, and in short order the duo opened two more spots: the East Pole, a slightly more upscale establishment on the Upper East Side, and the Leadbelly, an oyster bar across the street from the Fat Radish.

headline: 10 Designers on 10 Iconic Dieter Rams Designs
abstract: T asked some of the field’s top talents to weigh in on the legend’s noteworthy works.
lead_paragraph: As explored in “By the Numbers: Dieter Rams,” in T’s fall design issue, the designer’s prolific four-decade career at Braun and his work for the British company Vitsoe have earned him a place as a living icon. His 10 Principles of Good Design have earned exalted status in the design world. With those in mind, T asked 10 of the most exciting designers working today to talk about 10 of the most innovative products Rams had a hand in, and the influence his work has — or hasn’t — had on their careers.

headline: Word of the Day | inert
abstract: This word has appeared in 98 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: inert •\i-ˈnərt\• adjective

headline: Democrats Are Spending More on the Ground in Key Senate Races
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising', 'Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In more competitive states, Republican spending has tended to focus on broadcast advertisements and direct mail.
lead_paragraph: With a strong possibility that Democrats could lose control of the Senate in the midterm elections, they are investing heavily in voter turnout efforts.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) MAKERS: WOMEN IN COMEDY Last season, “Makers: Women Who Make America” chronicled 50 years in the women’s movement. This season, six new documentaries produced in collaboration with AOL focus on female trailblazers, starting with this examination of the rise of women in comedy, from subversive 1970s sitcoms like “Maude” to blockbusters like “Bridesmaids.” Chelsea Handler, Mo’Nique, Sarah Silverman, Joan Rivers, Ellen DeGeneres, Jane Lynch and Kathy Griffin share their perspectives; Leslie Mann narrates. Ms. Griffin will also host a screening of the documentary at makers.com at 8 p.m. on Wednesday, after which the show will be available for streaming.

headline: At Martyrs’ Day Ceremony,  Solemnity and Goose-Stepping
abstract: Led by President Xi Jinping and the other six members of the Politburo Standing Committee, the 15-minute event was meant to draw attention to those who sacrificed for China’s freedom from foreign aggression.
lead_paragraph: In a short, solemn ceremony in central Beijing on Tuesday, China’s top political leaders and a backdrop of 3,000 handpicked extras inaugurated the country’s newest national holiday — Martyrs’ Day.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday September 30, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It just boggles the imagination and is deeply destabilizing in terms of public confidence in the Secret Service and how it is carrying out its mission.”

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on September 30, 2014.

headline: The iPhone 6 Coming Soon to China, After Stern Look at Security
abstract: The Chinese government said that after it presented Apple with concerns about the iPhone 6’s security features, the company provided it with “official materials” to address them.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government on Tuesday granted Apple the final license required to release the new iPhone 6 in mainland China, but the announcement came with a twist.

headline: Zalando I.P.O. Values German Online Retailer at $6.7 Billion
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The online retailer, modeled on the American e-tailer Zappos, priced its stock at 21.50 euros a share, raising €605 million, and is expected to begin trading in Frankfurt on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The German online retailer Zalando announced late on Monday that it had priced its initial public offering near the top end of its expected pricing range, valuing the company at about $6.7 billion.

headline: Paris Fashion Week Morning Report
abstract: The penultimate day includes Chanel and Alexander McQueen.
lead_paragraph: As the song goes, it’s the final countdown.

abstract: Below is the first paragraph, broken up into shorter sentences of the Sept. 26 article “The One With the Replica Coffee Shop.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Below is the first paragraph, broken up into shorter sentences of the Sept. 26 article “The One With the Replica Coffee Shop.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | White House Intruder Got Farther Than First Reported, Official Says
abstract: How do these new details contrast with the picture Secret Service officials initially described?
lead_paragraph: In the article “White House Intruder Got Farther Than First Reported, Official Says,” Michael D. Shear writes about new revelations about the White House fence jumper.

headline: No Casualties After South Korean Tourist Boat Runs Aground
abstract: All 109 people on board were rescued, but the accident, the first notable ferry mishap since a disaster in April, drew attention in the country.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — All 109 people on board a South Korean tourist boat were rescued on Tuesday after their vessel ran onto a submerged rock, coast guard officials said.

headline: Told to End Protests, Organizers in Hong Kong Vow to Expand Them
abstract: Protest leaders responded with defiance Tuesday to the demand by Hong Kong’s top official, threatening to occupy government buildings.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s leader on Tuesday called for the pro-democracy demonstrators who have blocked major roads in the city to return home immediately, but protest leaders responded with defiance, threatening to expand the demonstrations and to occupy government buildings.

headline: Mitt Isn’t Ready to Call It Quits
abstract: Far from the scrum of the campaign trail, the former nominee reflects on the calls for his return.
lead_paragraph: “Hey, Ann, can you come here a sec?” Mitt Romney called out, sinking into the cushions of a walnut-colored easy chair, his legs outstretched on a matching ottoman. Romney’s blue work shirt was tucked into faded jeans; sockless ankles peeked out from his New Balance sneakers. He paused as Ann Romney entered from the kitchen, where she was baking chocolate-chip cookies. “Sweetie,” he continued, “what are some of the items we gave away at the Yankee swap?”

headline: R.B.S. Expects Fewer Charges for Bad Loans in 2014
abstract: The lender, which is 81 percent owned by the British government, said that it expected to “significantly outperform” its prior guidance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said Tuesday that its outlook continues to improve as the British lender benefits from further declines in charges for bad loans.

headline: Japanese Swordsman With a Camera
abstract: Whether on Japan’s street or shores, Issei Suda takes pictures like a swordsman, with light swiftly slicing the scene.
lead_paragraph: Postwar Tokyo’s bustling streets might seem very different from a traditional Japanese coastal festival. Not for Issei Suda, whose approach has always been the same.

headline: What Objects Tell the Story of Your Life?
abstract: Can you identify five or 10 objects that you would include in an exhibit or book about your life? Why did you select each of those objects?
lead_paragraph: Carefully curating a limited set of objects has lately become a popular way for museums and historians to tell vast histories (e.g., the history of the world, or of New York City). After all, artifacts can help us visualize the past and see complex events as something tangible or relatable.

headline: Eurozone’s Drop in Inflation Carries More Fears of Another Recession
abstract: With inflation dipping to 0.3 percent and unemployment remaining at 11.5 percent, the E.U. received more unwelcome news before the central bank meets.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The drop in eurozone inflation reported Tuesday was, in one sense, just a decimal point, another digit in the daily flow of depressing economic data. Yet it raised an increasingly urgent question: What will it take to arrest the Continent’s slow-motion descent toward another recession and, possibly, a renewed existential crisis?

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Sneak Peek at Iowa: What the Early Voting Suggests
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Absentee Voting', 'Elections, Senate', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Republicans are doing better at attracting early voters than in the past, but the ballot requests mostly reinforce that this will be a close contest.
lead_paragraph: There are still five weeks until the midterm elections, but early voting is underway in several of this year’s pivotal contests. As always, the state leading the way is Iowa, where more than 150,000 absentee ballots have already been requested and 15,000 votes have already been received.

headline: New York Today: The Living Wage Law Expands
abstract: Tuesday: A big move for the mayor, scattered sprinkles, and rescue animals get a cardinal’s blessing.
lead_paragraph: Good cloudy Tuesday morning to you.

headline: Fighting ‘Human Nature’
abstract: Some people claim that online misogyny is just natural male behavior. But for critics, this ignores the human capacity for change.
lead_paragraph: A variant of the oft-made argument that the Internet makes people terrible is the idea that people are naturally terrible, and the Internet just allows them to express their terrible selves. At Slate, Eric Michael Johnson seeks to rebut the latter notion, with an emphasis on the “natural” part.

headline: Europeans Accuse Ireland of Giving Apple Illegal Tax Break
abstract: A commission laid out its preliminary case over Apple’s taxes in Ireland, and it told the country it may order it to collect huge amounts of back taxes.
lead_paragraph: In a warning shot to companies shopping for tax deals around the globe, the European Commission publicly accused Ireland on Tuesday of giving illegal subsidies to Apple and cautioned that the country might need to collect back taxes from the company, which outside analysts said could reach into the billions of dollars.

headline: Protests in Hong Kong
abstract: Pro-democracy demonstrators take over Hong Kong’s streets.
lead_paragraph: Pro-democracy demonstrators take over Hong Kong’s streets.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 23-29, 2014
abstract: Have you been following the news this week? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news this week?

headline: Jiang Zemin, Former President, Makes Rare Appearance
abstract: Jiang Zemin, a former president and Communist Party chief who has often been rumored to be in poor health or even dead, is seen as still wielding influence in China.
lead_paragraph: Jiang Zemin, China’s former president and Communist Party chief, made a rare public appearance on Monday in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, smiling and clapping at a concert titled “Beautiful China, Glorious Dream” to mark the approach of National Day on Wednesday.

headline: Bill Gross, Calpers and the End of the Investment Guru
abstract: Betting on a system, rather than on the prospect of a lone genius, may well be the way of the future.
lead_paragraph: There were two big developments last week that seemed unrelated but are really part of the same big story of how finance is changing.

headline: EBay Does About-Face in Spinoff of PayPal Backed by Icahn
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The board of directors long resisted calls by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn to separate from PayPal, which generates almost half of eBay’s revenue.
lead_paragraph: At eBay’s annual board retreat in Half Moon Bay, Calif., in June, the company’s 12 directors found themselves moving in a somewhat unexpected direction: breaking up the company just as the hedge fund billionaire Carl C. Icahn had suggested.

headline: My Quest to Create Pride and Joy in Work Runs Into Reality
abstract: Should we hold those parts on the dock until the client catches up on its payments? What would you do?
lead_paragraph: In my most recent post, I talked about my attempts to find meaning in my work. I haven’t really figured this out yet, but I decided the answer lies in finding ways to create pride and joy in the work one does, whatever that work may be. With that in mind, I’ve tried looking at my company and its employees with fresh eyes.

headline: Daily Report: Netflix Aims at Hollywood’s New Releases
abstract: Netflix and the Weinstein Company said that they planned to release a sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters.
lead_paragraph: In a first deal of its kind, Netflix and the Weinstein Company said Monday that they planned to release next year’s sequel to the movie “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” simultaneously across the globe on Netflix and a select number of Imax theaters, Emily Steel and Brooks Barnes report.

headline: Review Suggests Extending Time for Setting Benchmark Currency Rates
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The recommendation of Britain’s Financial Stability Board that the period for setting currency rates be extended to 5 minutes from 1 minute comes in the wake of investigations into market manipulation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s Financial Stability Board said on Tuesday that the window for determining currency benchmark rates should be widened, one of a series of proposals the board made to change currency markets in the wake of investigations into whether those markets were manipulated.

headline: In Performance: Anthony Wayne of ‘Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical’
abstract: The song “You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)” comes from “Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical.
lead_paragraph: This week the actor Anthony Wayne and the pianist Anthony Miller perform “You Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)” from “Mighty Real: A Fabulous Sylvester Musical,” a show about the androgynous pop-funk-disco star Sylvester, whose signature falsetto was a sonic staple on dance floors in the ’70s and ’80s. The song, released in 1978, was a Top 40 hit for Sylvester. “Mighty Real,” directed by Mr. Wayne and Kendrell Bowman, continues through Sunday at the Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Games People Play, Both Online and Off
abstract: “Men, Women & Children” is Jason Reitman’s multistory film about middle-class families with teenagers, Internet connections and digital issues.
lead_paragraph: “Men, Women & Children,” Jason Reitman’s glum and thoughtful new film, is not quite as comprehensive as its title suggests. Based on a novel by Chad Kultgen, it surveys a handful of white, middle-class households in a suburban Texas town, each one including a teenager with a smartphone, an Internet connection and some of the attendant problems. Every kid seems to suffer from some kind of digital malaise, and the parents are hardly immune to the seductive, soul-imperiling glow of the interactive screen.

headline: Close but Not Quite
abstract: Words are not horseshoes; we get no points for coming close to the mark. Here are several recent instances where we stumbled over words with similar sounds or meanings.
lead_paragraph: Words are not horseshoes; we get no points for coming close to the mark.

headline: Amazon Is Not Holding Back on Paul Ryan
abstract: The retailer is discouraging sales of Hachette titles. The 2012 Republican vice presidential candidate’s new book is an exception.
lead_paragraph: All Hachette authors are equal, but some are more equal than others.

headline: Chinese Umbrellas for Hong Kong?
abstract: During heavy censorship in mainland Chinese media of the Hong Kong democracy demonstrations, some images of umbrellas circulating online took on a special significance.
lead_paragraph: In China’s heavily censored media, a symbol of Hong Kong’s democracy protests — the umbrella — made an occasional appearance on Tuesday, leaving the impression that some people were watching and offering a subtle comment on developments in the city.

headline: Morning Agenda: Lehman Revisited
abstract: New accounts of events from 2008 are casting Lehman’s collapse in a different light. | EBay to spin off PayPal. | The dangers of fighting bad press. | A.I.G. trial begins in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Could Lehman Brothers have been saved? Government officials have argued that the Federal Reserve did not have the legal authority to rescue the big investment bank, leaving it instead to die overnight. Now, new accounts of events from 2008 are casting the firm’s collapse in a different light, James B. Stewart and Peter Eavis write in The New York Times. The decision not to rescue Lehman, in hindsight, let problems at one bank snowball into a full-blown panic. Why, given all that happened, was Lehman the only bank that was not too big to fail?

headline: More Groups Join Project on the Brain
abstract: Federal agencies and private businesses and institutions are aligning their research with the Brain Initiative, which is studying the brain in action.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration plans to announce Tuesday that it has recruited new federal agencies and a number of universities, foundations and businesses to help pursue the goals of the Brain Initiative, which the president started in 2013.

headline: Support Strong for Regulating Politics and Nonprofits
abstract: A new poll finds support for Internal Revenue Service efforts to regulate the activities of nonprofit groups.
lead_paragraph: When the Internal Revenue Service proposed new rules earlier this year to rein in political activity by nonprofits, it caused an unusual meeting of the minds between the right and the left in opposition to the proposal, which was eventually withdrawn by the agency.

headline: Kirkus Announces Finalists for Book Prizes
abstract: Siri Hustvedt, Dinaw Mengestu, Roz Chast and Thomas Piketty are among the finalists for the first annual awards.
lead_paragraph: The literary journal Kirkus Reviews has announced the finalists for its first annual book prizes. The honors for fiction, nonfiction and young readers’ literature each come with a $50,000 award, making them among the most lucrative in the literary world.

headline: Communication Failure at the Museum
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A museum visitor knew she was hard of hearing, but she didn’t expect an exchange with a stranger to turn into mumbles and shrieks.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Remind, a Start-Up That Links Teachers and Parents, Raises $40 Million
abstract: The company said the new money, raised from existing investors including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, would help bolster software development and a push into Western Europe.
lead_paragraph: The simple act of connecting teachers with students and parents may not seem like a revolutionary business. But Remind, a start-up built around using smartphones to link the three groups, has gotten a big financial vote of confidence from prominent investors.

headline: Cat Kicker Incites Aggressive Prosecution: A Reporter’s Notebook
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ANIMALS', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Stephanie Clifford supplies an inside look at her reporting on the case of a man who is accused of kicking a cat in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This story is an example of why court coverage can be so interesting. I live in Brooklyn and find that almost every issue that touches lives here — including gun control, gentrification, housing, pay and relationships — comes through the courts one way or another.

headline: 1939: British Unmask Reich Defenses
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: British pilots drop leaflet over Germany and photograph German defenses in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With French artillery pounding at German positions on the Western front and the British Expeditionary Army nearly ready to go into action, the Air Ministry disclosed today [Sept. 30] that an almost endless series of British reconnaissance flights over the Siegfried Line during the first month of war enabled the British high command to build up ‘‘a comprehensive picture’’ of German defenses. British pilots have combined leaflet-dropping with high-speed camera work that has resulted in ‘‘a remarkable series of air photographs showing in clearest detail some of the most strongly fortified zones of the Siegfried Line.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Oct. 1, 1939

headline: How Cigarettes and Sexual Frustration Got Me Through 26.2 Miles
abstract: The writer entered the New York City Marathon lottery several times after moving back to New York six years ago, finally getting in this year. She explains how she trained for her first marathon, a decade ago: She didn’t.
lead_paragraph: I’ve entered the New York City Marathon lottery several times since moving back to New York six years ago. I’ve been dying to see what it would be like to run in a place where the crowds cheer you on and carry you forward.

headline: What’s the Matter With Alabama?
abstract: Job growth in the deep red.

lead_paragraph: Pro-democracy demonstrations continued as leaders threatened to expand their presence in response to the government’s orders to return home.

headline: ‘The Giving Tree’: Tender Story of Unconditional Love or Disturbing Tale of Selfishness?
abstract: Anna Holmes and Rivka Galchen reconsider Shel Silverstein’s classic, published 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Shel Silverstein’s “The Giving Tree” was published 50 years ago. This week, Anna Holmes and Rivka Galchen debate whether the book is a tender story of unconditional love, or a disturbing tale of monstrous selfishness.

headline: Hong Kong Protests Are Leaderless but Orderly
abstract: The crowds on the streets maintain fastidious attention to hygiene and good manners as they rally for democracy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — They sleep by the thousands on what are normally the busiest boulevards of this crammed, nonstop city. They live on crackers, bananas and bottled water. They clean up their trash, even taking the time to pick out plastic and paper for recycling. Their shield of choice, and the symbol of their cause, is the umbrella: protection against the sun, rain — and pepper spray used by the riot police.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Buy Biotech Company Alios BioPharma
abstract: The $1.75 billion deal for Alios BioPharma, which is working on treatments for viral diseases, is the first acquisition in some time for Johnson & Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson said on Tuesday that it would pay $1.75 billion in cash for Alios BioPharma, a private biotechnology company that is working on treatments for viral diseases.

abstract: Live streaming of House Oversight committee hearing on the White House security breach.

lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. said Tuesday that Kansas City Chiefs safety Husain Abdullah was mistakenly penalized by a game official when he knelt to pray after scoring a touchdown Monday night.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress declared Tuesday that they had lost confidence in the Secret Service to protect President Obama and his family and raised serious doubts that Julia Pierson, the director of the agency, was the right person to confront what they called systemic problems and a striking lack of candor about recent security breaches.

lead_paragraph: As a practicing ear, nose and throat specialist in Ahoskie, N.C., Dr. Raghuvir B. Gelot says that little has frustrated him more than the digital record system he installed a few years ago.

headline: EBay’s PayPal Plans Bolster Goldman’s Status as Top Spinoff Adviser
abstract: Among the advisers to eBay on its proposed breakup is Goldman Sachs. By most of the relevant measures of corporate spinoff data, Goldman is the No. 1 adviser.
lead_paragraph: EBay finally listened to the call of Carl C. Icahn and others in deciding to split off its enormous PayPal payments unit as a separate public company. And aiding the e-commerce titan in its decision-making is the most practiced adviser in the world of corporate spinoffs.

headline: Lindsey Vonn, Before Returning From Knee Injuries, Puts Her Competitors on Notice
abstract: Vonn, who is expected to begin her comeback Wednesday and who turns 30 in October, insisted she planned to race in the 2018 Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 10 months, Lindsey Vonn plans to ski again Wednesday when she makes a few modest turns on an Austrian training slope. It will be a cautious first step as Vonn tries to return from two devastating knee injuries, but it is meaningful progress, since Vonn senses that many in the ski community are discounting her comeback.

Previously we spoke to the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the comic Tig Notaro.

headline: Charges Are Dropped, and Identity of Accuser, Shrouded by City, Is Sought
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Informers', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Kenneth Creighton was jailed for five years pending trial in a 2006 shooting in the Bronx. Now he is asking that the name of an informant be revealed, but lawyers for New York City are resisting.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Kenneth Creighton was held in jail, suspected of involvement in the killing of a bystander outside a bodega in the Bronx.

headline: The Revolution Will Be Televised, Sort Of
abstract: “Transparent,” a new streaming series produced by Amazon, is changing television in more ways than one.
lead_paragraph: “Transparent,” a new, 10-episode series from Amazon Studios, has made quite a splash. The storyline follows the Pfeffermans, a family of fast-talking Angelenos led by Mort, a divorcé and recovering womanizer who, in the pilot episode, tries and fails to come out as transgender to his three children.

headline: Nigeria’s Actions Seem to Contain Ebola Outbreak
abstract: Every known Ebola patient in the country has now died or recovered, and the cure rate was unusually high for an African outbreak.
lead_paragraph: With quick and coordinated action by some of its top doctors, Nigeria, Africa’s most populous country, appears to have contained its first Ebola outbreak, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Tuesday.

abstract: Obama administration lawyers are debating whether the Treasury Department must inform those it lists as foreign terrorists when it uses warrantless surveillance as the basis for the designation, officials say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Obama administration lawyers have been debating whether the Treasury Department must inform the people or groups it lists as foreign terrorists when it relies on warrantless surveillance as the basis for the designation, according to officials familiar with the deliberations.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Kurdish fighters opened offensives against Islamic State militants in several parts of northern Iraq on Tuesday, seizing control of a border crossing with Syria that has been a major conduit for the insurgents, officials said.

headline: Mending Alliance, U.S. and Afghanistan Sign Long-Term Security Agreement
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The agreement, long delayed, allows 9,800 American and about 2,000 NATO troops to remain in Afghanistan after the international combat mission formally ends on Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and Afghan officials signed a long-term security pact here on Tuesday, nearly a year after the agreement was cast into limbo by a breakdown of trust at the highest levels of each allied government.

headline: Seatbelt Could Have Prevented Tracy Morgan’s Injuries, Walmart Says
abstract: Walmart argued in legal filings that the comedian was partly to blame for his injuries because he was not wearing a seatbelt when a Walmart truck crashed into his vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Walmart said that injuries sustained by Tracy Morgan and other comedians traveling with him in a June car crash involving a Walmart driver could have been prevented if the performers had been wearing seatbelts. Mr. Morgan, a former star of “Saturday Night Live” and “30 Rock,” was critically hurt, and another comedian, James McNair, was killed on the morning of June 7 when the luxury van they were riding in on the New Jersey Turnpike was struck and overturned by a Walmart tractor-trailer. Ardie Fuqua, a comedian, and Jeffrey Millea, Mr. Morgan’s assistant, were also injured.

headline: A Conspicuous Absence on Israel’s List of Top Baby Names
keywords: ['Names, Personal', 'Babies and Infants', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Arabs']
abstract: Israel’s population authority left Muhammad off the annual Top 10 list of baby names, even though it was No. 1, setting off a discussion about the status of the Arab minority.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Muhammad was by far the most popular name for babies born in Israel last year: 1,986 boys shared the name of the Muslim prophet, nearly twice the number of the top girls’ name, Tamar, at 1,092.

headline: Detailing Financial Links of Doctors and Drug Makers
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Doctors', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medical Devices', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: A new federal database sheds light on payments made to doctors, but the health care industry says technical problems and inaccuracies limit its value to patients.
lead_paragraph: Pharmaceutical and device makers paid doctors roughly $380 million in speaking and consulting fees, with some doctors reaping over half a million dollars each, during a five-month period last year, according to an analysis of federal data released Tuesday. Other doctors made millions of dollars in royalties from products they helped develop.

headline: Clinton Skips Events to Spend More Time with Her Family
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton scratched another midterm event off her itinerary to spend time with her granddaughter.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton scratched another midterm event off her itinerary to spend time with her granddaughter.

headline: Houses Built on Gossamer Wings
abstract: Phyllis Richardson’s new book offers a global, contemporary perspective on the heft of houses, highlighting projects from Chile to Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: “How much does your house weigh?” Buckminster Fuller asked in the 1920s, showing off his three-ton hexagonal Dymaxion House. He believed the technology used to mass-produce cars may as well be applied to houses, driving prices down and increasing mobility. Since then, many designers have wrestled with the size, cost, manufacturing and, indeed, heft of homes. In “Superlight: Rethinking How Our Homes Impact the Earth” (Metropolis Books, $35), Phyllis Richardson offers a global, contemporary perspective, highlighting recent projects from Chile to Vietnam. She also reconsiders what makes a project “light,” expanding the definition from pounds or kilograms to impact on the site, energy consumption (or generation) and the ability to cope with climate change. She spoke from London, where she lives in a Victorian house — with a polycarbonate and aluminum addition. (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

headline: Recalling the Empress of Radio Jazz
abstract: Stacy Sullivan struck haunting and seductive notes in a show at the York Theater dedicated to the memory of the jazz pianist Marian McPartland.
lead_paragraph: At her most compelling, the pop-jazz singer Stacy Sullivan has a voice so sultry that her sound might be described as heavy-lidded. Applied to a song like “Stranger in a Dream,” a haunting little-known ballad composed by the jazz pianist Marian McPartland with lyrics by Irving Caesar, she transports you to a twilight zone of wistful reflection that recalls the dreamier side of Peggy Lee.

headline: Rolling on the (Mekong) River
abstract: A new 20-suite riverboat is scheduled to start sailing between Cambodia and Vietnam later this year.
lead_paragraph: Question: If you’re a successful businessman in Lima, with a stable family life and kids in a good school, what’s your next move?

headline: The Power of Place: One Last Thought on Moving
abstract: Is our new city changing us? Or would we be changing anyway, simply by virtue of growing up, getting older, and evolving in our lives?
lead_paragraph: “Places do things to you,” Mohsin Hamid wrote in The New York Times Book Review when asked, “How does place influence writing?” It’s a question I’ve been pondering in a broader context lately: How does place influence living?

headline: A Needleful of Skepticism to Deliver Us
abstract: Eula Biss examines beliefs about filth and purity, from environmental toxins to vaccinations, in “On Immunity: An Inoculation.”
lead_paragraph: The summer of 2010 was a bummer for many reasons. Heat waves stewed the East Coast into submission.  Harvey Pekar and Tony Judt died. WikiLeaks dumped so many anxiety-inducing classified Afghan war documents that this sprig of dialogue from “Gravity’s Rainbow” seemed freshly plucked: “Everything is some kind of plot, man.”

headline: Winners Chosen in Program to Aid Female Composers
abstract: Julia Adolphe and Melody Eotvos have been chosen to receive $15,000 commissioning fees.
lead_paragraph: The League of American Orchestras and EarShot, the organizations administering a new program to provide commissions and premieres for scores composed by women, announced the winners of its commissions on Tuesday. They are Julia Adolphe, 26, a composer, writer and producer who lives in Los Angeles, and Melody Eotvos, 30, an Australian-born composer of both multimedia and traditional works who lives in Bloomington, Ind.

headline: With Big Pawprints to Fill, Zoo Prepares for Grizzlies
abstract: Since the Central Park Zoo’s famed polar bear Gus died last year, his pool has been empty, but a pair of Bronx grizzlies named Betty and Veronica are set to take his place in November.

headline: Verbatim: Protecting the White House
abstract: Representative Stephen Lynch, Democrat from Massachusetts, to Julia Pierson, saying that he does not believe the Secret Service takes seriously their duty to protect the president.
lead_paragraph: Representative Stephen F. Lynch, Democrat of Massachusetts, to Julia Pierson, the Secret Service director. He said he did not believe the Secret Service takes seriously its duty to protect the president.

headline: Jack Kirby Finally Gets His Due
abstract: Marvel settled a copyright lawsuit with the heirs of the legendary illustrator.
lead_paragraph: The Marvel entertainment juggernaut averted what could have become a nasty Supreme Court throw down last week when it settled a copyright lawsuit with the heirs of the legendary illustrator Jack Kirby, also known as “The King of Comics.” Kirby was the defining talent at the Marvel shop during the halcyon years that produced iconic characters such as the X-Men, Iron Man, The Fantastic Four, Spider-Man, Thor, the Silver Surfer and The Incredible Hulk. He never received the credit or money he was due and died in 1994.

headline: Doctors Fault Assumptions of Settlement With Retirees
abstract: In a court filing in Philadelphia, two doctors from the Brain Injury Association of America said the N.F.L.’s proposed settlement would exclude many players and limit their access to benefits.
lead_paragraph: A leading brain injury advocacy group said the proposed settlement between the N.F.L. and nearly 5,000 former players who sued the league for hiding from them the dangers of concussions is flawed because the definitions of eligibility are too narrow.

headline: 1964: Duvalier Gets Smuggled Planes
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Haiti’s dictator receives smuggled U.S. military equipment in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the face of a strict U.S. ban on all military equipment bound for Haiti, a group of Texas pilots is busily smuggling T28 fighter planes out of this country and into dictator François Duvalier’s eager hands. Over the last ten days at least two T28s have been flown from Texas airports into Mexico and then to Port-au-Prince, the Caribbean republic’s capital. The brutal Duvalier is anxious to use the planes to help in his fight against two bands of anti-government guerrillas who now virtually control the southern section of the country. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Oct. 1, 1964
