headline: F.C.C. Eliminates Its Sports Blackout Rule, Rebuffing N.F.L.’s Push
abstract: The National Football League argued that ending the rule would endanger the availability of games on free television, but the commission said that was unlikely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously Tuesday to eliminate its sports blackout rule, which for nearly 40 years has prevented cable and satellite systems from televising some National Football League games.

headline: Icahn Praises Breakup of eBay
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The activist investor said on Tuesday that it was “almost a ‘no brainer'” that eBay spin off PayPal, even if he couldn’t help but add that the decision came “a little later” than it should have.
lead_paragraph: EBay may have taken more than nine months to listen to the activist investor Carl C. Icahn and prepare a spinoff of its PayPal payments unit. But Mr. Icahn is happy that the company listened to him all the same.

headline: Oklahoma Man Is Charged in Beheading of Co-Worker
abstract: Alton Nolen, an employee at Vaughn Foods in the city of Moore, was accused of attacking two women after he was suspended for making inflammatory statements.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma man was charged Tuesday with first-degree murder in the beheading of a co-worker, but federal officials said they had found no links between him and Islamic extremist groups that have beheaded several Western hostages in the Middle East and North Africa in recent weeks.

headline: Piers Morgan Will Write for The Daily Mail
abstract: The former tabloid editor and CNN host will write several times a week for the popular American website of the British newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Piers Morgan, the British tabloid editor who replaced Larry King on CNN only to have his show canceled three years later, will join the American website of The Daily Mail as an editor at large, the newspaper said Tuesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: Paper or Plastic?
abstract: Mayor de Blasio plans to sign an executive order expanding New York City’s living wage law. Macy’s is hiring for the holidays. How to lose $1 million a month.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Pimco Perplex
abstract: Understanding Bill Gross’s terrible 2011.
lead_paragraph: It’s fairly clear that the events of 2011 are a large part of the story of Bill Gross’s abrupt departure from Pimco; as Neil Irwin says,

headline: First Draft Focus: Getting Out of the White House
abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India met again at the White House on Tuesday.

headline: How Fast Is It?
abstract: We’ve got a radar gun now. Tell us what moving objects in the city you’d like us to measure.
lead_paragraph: Zoooom! Bloooeep.

headline: Iris van Herpen: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Seattle Start-Up Factory Hires Former Amazon and Microsoft Executive
abstract: Ivy Softworks, a new start-up factory in Seattle, is seeking to create a better way of forming new tech companies. And now it has hired Brian Valentine, a prominent engineer and executive who worked for years at Microsoft and Amazon.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE – Ivy Softworks is a new start-up factory that has devised what its founder says is a better way to create tech companies. Now the plan has attracted Brian Valentine, a prominent engineer and executive who worked for years at Microsoft and Amazon.

headline: Catalan Leaders Suspend Plan for Ballot on Secession From Spain
abstract: The Catalan government said it would appeal a court order to suspend vote preparations and insisted that its plans for a ballot on independence from Spain were not over.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Catalonia’s regional government on Tuesday suspended its campaign for a planned independence vote in accordance with a ruling issued a day earlier by Spain’s Constitutional Court.

headline: Gone From Office, Bloomberg’s Still a Lightning Rod in Ad Wars
abstract: Bloomberg center stage in midterm air wars.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg may have returned to corporate America, but politics has not forgotten him.

headline: Tall and Spiked, but Little Deterrent to Intruders
abstract: Sixteen people have scaled the White House fence in the past five years, according to the Secret Service, which is nearly eight feet tall.
lead_paragraph: The White House perimeter fence is nearly eight feet high and adorned with ornamental spear-like tips. They are decorative but sharp enough to puncture the skin, as Diane Wilson learned last year.

headline: A Startling Look at How Profits Elude the Taxman
abstract: In several tax havens, the profits reported by American-controlled companies are many times the size of the actual local economy.
lead_paragraph: Statistics cited in debates about tax reform often have a sleep-inducing effect. But Jason Furman, the chairman of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers, recently offered some eye-popping numbers to underscore just how much revenue the United States loses when American corporations shift part of their operations abroad to avoid paying taxes at home.

headline: New Michelin Guide Has New York Star-Studded
abstract: Three restaurants have been upgraded to two stars, and 20 places are newly chosen or promoted.
lead_paragraph: The 2015 New York City Michelin Guide has upgraded Aquavit, Blanca and Ichimura to two stars, up from one star last year. The new rankings, released today, have New York rolling in stars, with 20 places newly anointed or promoted. More than half are in Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: Dallas Symphony Aims to Develop Musical Leadership
abstract: A program at the Dallas Symphony Orchestra is intended to turn music students on the threshold of professional careers into potential leaders and entrepreneurs.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra, in a partnership with the University of Texas at Dallas and several conservatories around the world, is starting an unusual program meant to turn music students on the threshold of professional careers into potential leaders and entrepreneurs in the music world. The D.S.O./Jaap van Zweden Scholars Program, as the enterprise is called, is named for the orchestra’s music director and is supported by a $10 million gift from Margaret McDermott, who also endows a scholar’s fund at the university.

headline: Wheelies: The Diesel Ram Edition
abstract: Chrysler says it will double production of the Ram 1500 EcoDiesel pickup; Cadillac’s chief says production may decline to combat swollen inventory.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Hotel Review: The Line Hotel in Los Angeles
abstract: This vibrant new hotel, created by the team behind the Ace and NoMad hotels in New York, sets out to capture the 24-hour energy of the Koreatown neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Rooms start at $249.

headline: Insider Case by S.E.C. Is a Step Removed From Herbalife Itself
abstract: In an apparent first for the S.E.C., the agency built the case on the premise that a hedge fund’s private investment playbook amounted to inside information.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | The hedge fund world often finds itself at the center of insider trading investigations after profiting from corporate secrets. But for the first time, regulators are saying that a hedge fund’s investment plan itself can be the secret.

headline: Chicken Fingers Are Off the Menu
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetarianism', 'Parenting', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Now that my daughter has become a vegetarian, I fear I am doomed to turn into the dreaded Restaurant Mom, tailoring meal planning to each of my children’s fancies.
lead_paragraph: When a friend mentioned last year that her 7-year-old daughter had gone vegan, I stifled a sigh of relief. “Thank God I’m not raising children in Brooklyn,” was my smug little thought.

headline: New York Film Festival: A ‘Genius’ Grant Winner and His Unblinking Camera
abstract: Joshua Oppenheimer, a newly minted MacArthur fellow, follows up his groundbreaking documentary “The Act of Killing,” about the 1965 government-directed mass killing in Indonesia, with a companion film, “The Look of Silence.”
lead_paragraph: No documentary in recent years has had a greater impact on both the public and filmmakers than Joshua Oppenheimer’s “The Act of Killing,” an examination of government-directed mass killing that took place in Indonesia in 1965. At the Toronto International Film Festival this month, no less than Martin Scorsese said he found the movie, which was nominated for an Oscar earlier this year, haunting and inspiring.

headline: Swedish-Owned Firm Defends Bid for Sensitive U.S. Phone Contract
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Telcordia, owned by the telecom giant Ericsson, accused its rival, Neustar, of fear-mongering and spreading misinformation by raising national security concerns about the deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A technology company vying to win the job of routing the country’s tens of millions of phone calls and text messages accused a competitor on Tuesday of using “scare tactics” and spreading misinformation by raising the specter of national security threats if the deal goes forward.

headline: Does the Cat-Kicker Deserve Jail?
abstract: Clearly this is a young man who needs help, but jail is not a promising place for him to get it.
lead_paragraph: Most people who saw the video of Andre Robinson viciously kicking a stray cat were justifiably horrified. He actually laughed at the cat’s misfortune.

headline: On the Trail of an Online Pirate
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter, discusses interviewing Hana Beshara, who spent time in prison for her role in a website that illegally streamed video.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter, profiled Hana Beshara, a founder of NinjaVideo, a now-shuttered streaming website. She discusses the challenge of tracking down Ms. Beshara, who served a prison term for her role in running the illegal site, and of describing a culture with a different understanding of copyright law.

headline: Reaffirming Vow, Prosecutor Says Rikers Reform Will Happen ‘One Way or Another’
abstract: Preet Bharara, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan whose office highlighted violence against teenage inmates at the jail, said he would sue New York City, if necessary, to force reform.
lead_paragraph: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan reasserted on Tuesday that he expected reforms to be made at Rikers Island and that he was prepared to go to court, if necessary, to accomplish them.

headline: In Tel Aviv, a Holy Day Is a Biking Day
abstract: In Tel Aviv, Yom Kippur has become a day when bikers using the municipal Tel-O-Fun sharing program ride through streets empty of cars..
lead_paragraph: For one day each year, Tel Aviv, the cosmopolitan and cultural heart of Israel, seems still.

headline: Leading the League? They’re Dominating It So Far
abstract: Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers leads a list of top players from the N.F.L.’s first month, now that 26 of the 32 teams have played a quarter of the schedule.
lead_paragraph: As the calendar turns to October, 26 of the N.F.L.’s 32 teams have played a quarter of their season. That makes this a good time to hand out awards for the top players from the league’s first month.

headline: An Ever-Expanding List of Unwelcome Visitors to the White House
abstract: Presidents have faced astonishing breaches at “the people’s house,” long before an intruder with a knife managed to slip past security and run around the State Floor this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American presidents like to refer to the White House as “the people’s house,” and over the past two centuries, a surprising number of uninvited people have made their way in.

headline: The Battle Against Herbalife
abstract: The billionaire William A. Ackman has mounted a $1 billion wager against Herbalife, a giant diet supplements company.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire William A. Ackman has mounted a $1 billion wager against Herbalife, a giant diet supplements company.

headline: California Will Allow Family Members to Seek Seizure of Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Plastic Bags']
abstract: The police and family members will be able to seek court orders authorizing the taking of firearms from people deemed dangerous.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California will be the first state in the country to allow private citizens to ask a court to seize guns from family members who they believe pose a threat to themselves or the public, under a measure signed into law by Gov. Jerry Brown on Tuesday.

headline: Heirloom Popcorn Helps a Snack Reinvent Itself
abstract: Heirloom varieties you pop yourself deliver more flavor than those store-bought bags.
lead_paragraph: SHELLSBURG, Iowa — Corn confronts you at every turn in Iowa. It blurs past the car window for hours. Stop for gas and you’re likely to find a patch growing out back.

headline: Popcorn Recipes: Tips for Popping Heirloom Corn Varieties
abstract: Kim Severson gives advice on making the corn you pop truly your own.
lead_paragraph: Cooking a pan of popcorn is so simple and satisfying that I’m always surprised when people say it seems like too much trouble. The results are far superior to anything that comes from a microwave or a bag.

headline: Moon Juice Debuts Wellness Products and an E-Commerce Site
abstract: Amanda Chantal Bacon’s cult Los Angeles cafes have spun off a range of healing herbs and products, which are now available online.
lead_paragraph: The Moon Juice founder Amanda Chantal Bacon has developed a cult following in Los Angeles and beyond for raw juices and organic vegan foods that promise good health. And Bacon (oh, the irony) may be her own best advertisement. Standing in her Silver Lake shop, which opened last year at a spot between the nearly three-year-old original location in Venice and the month-old kiosk at the Ace Hotel Downtown, the mother of one is all shiny chestnut hair and glowing good looks. And that’s due at least in part to the products on the shelves across from the juice bar: flower remedies, house shea butter and rose body balms, ayurvedic toothpastes and a few jumbo-size crystals for good measure. The items are part of Moon Juice’s new Apothecary offshoot, a platform that functions as “a curation of my medicine cabinet, drawer of bathroom goodies and kitchen cabinet,” Bacon says. “It is the best way I can answer the thousands of questions we get about what toothpaste to use and why, or more effective options for skin care that are edible.”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Indian Ink’
abstract: Romola Garai and Firdous Bamji in a scene from the Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of Tom Stoppard’s drama.
lead_paragraph: Romola Garai and Firdous Bamji in a scene from the Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of Tom Stoppard’s drama.

headline: Excerpt: ‘A Walk in the Woods’
abstract: Kathleen Chalfant and Paul Niebanck in a scene from the Keen Company revival of Lee Blessing’s two-character drama.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Chalfant and Paul Niebanck in a scene from the Keen Company revival of Lee Blessing’s two-character drama.

headline: 2014: Paul on Congressional Gridlock
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Term Limits (Political Office)']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, says term limits for members of Congress are one way to help fix Washington.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, says term limits for members of Congress are one way to help fix Washington.

headline: An Impresario Shines His Light on the Customer
abstract: Cherche Midi may be Keith McNally’s most thorough repudiation of the downtown scene and current dining trends of the six restaurants he operates.
lead_paragraph: We were halfway through appetizers at Cherche Midi, passing the steak tartare and spreading anchovy toasts with softly jiggly Parmesan custard, when one of my guests suddenly tilted his head and listened. He looked like the boy in a tornado movie who notices that the birds have stopped singing.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Spring 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Brooklyn Teacher Is Accused of Abusing Girls for 3 Years
abstract: Sean Shaynak, a math and science teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School, is accused of sexual abuse, forcible touching, kidnapping and disseminating indecent material, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The investigation began with one explicit picture, sent by a teacher at one of New York’s elite public high schools to one of his female students through a messaging app.

headline: A Bass Voice, Contained but Inviting
abstract: René Pape, a fixture with the Metropolitan Opera, conjured intimacy as he performed an austere recital on its stage on Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Is there a singer on the Metropolitan Opera’s roster more deserving of a solo recital on its stage than René Pape, who received that honor on Sunday afternoon? After nearly 20 years and 200 performances with the company, this German bass’s steady, wine-dark voice and suave presence have become indispensable.

headline: First Draft Video: Paul on Fixing Washington
abstract: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is the latest in the First Draft Fixing Washington video series, where he explains that “there is no monopoly of knowledge” in Washington in arguing for term limits.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is the latest in the Fixing Washington video series here on First Draft, where he explains that his colleagues aren’t as smart as they think they are.

headline: Sweet Ankle-Strap Shoes at Chanel’s Riot in the Streets
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld sent Cara Delevingne and Co. out for a louder-than-ever finale, quietly completed by these modest metallic flats.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Mulaney’
abstract: The new Fox sitcom stars the comic John Mulaney and Martin Short.
lead_paragraph: The new Fox sitcom stars the comic John Mulaney and Martin Short.

headline: Keeping the Creeps From Getting Too Close
abstract: The police drama “Stalker” stars Dylan McDermott and Maggie Q as detectives in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Can no one make a television show that’s not full of women being murdered, raped and terrorized? Perhaps something good will come of “Stalker,” a police drama that begins on Wednesday night on CBS: Maybe its excesses will be the tipping point that reins in this deplorable trend.

headline: Joël Robuchon to Reopen L’Atelier in Battery Park City
abstract: The chef is returning to New York with a new L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Modi Meets With Obama at White House
abstract: In September, during his first visit to the White House, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India discussed clean energy, trade and security issues with President Obama.
lead_paragraph: In September, during his first visit to the White House, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India discussed clean energy, trade and security issues with President Obama.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jon Mooallem on Larry Ellison’s Learning Curve for Island Ownership
abstract: Jon Mooallem wrote last Sunday’s cover story about the Hawaiian island of Lanai, 97 percent of which is owned by tech billionaire Larry Ellison. Here, he talks with Rachel Nolan about the trials that come with owning an island.
lead_paragraph: Jon Mooallem wrote the Sept. 28 cover story about the Hawaiian island Lanai, which is almost entirely owned by the tech billionaire Larry Ellison. Mooallem, a contributing writer for the magazine, is the author of ‘‘Wild Ones’’ and ‘‘American Hippopotamus.’’

headline: The Collapse of the Secret Service
abstract: Testimony from the director of the security force did little to persuade questioners of either party that she has the will to right the troubled agency.
lead_paragraph: When Omar Gonzalez vaulted the White House fence, pushed past a Secret Service guard and carried a knife all the way to the ceremonial East Room on Sept. 19, he did more than threaten the life of the first family and some of the nation’s highest officials. He shattered the idea that the White House is a sacred civic space, protected by the world’s most impenetrable security force.

headline: Europe Tries to Stop Flow of Citizens Joining Jihad
abstract: Rising numbers have joined the Islamic State and other groups, prompting fears of domestic terrorism when the fighters return home.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — European countries pressed ahead on Tuesday with efforts to deter the growing numbers of their citizens seeking to join radical Islamic movements in Iraq and Syria, as some experts warned that the United States-led military campaign against the Islamic State increased the risk that the groups would turn their attention to attacking Western targets.

headline: A $100 Weekend in Chicago
abstract: Sample everything from pizza to pancakes, classical music to the blues, during a frugal-friendly weekend in the Windy City.
lead_paragraph: Even the best-funded traveler can’t conquer Chicago in a weekend, or, for that matter, cover the basics: deep-dish pizza, Chicago-style hot dogs, skyline views, troves of historic architecture, Millennium Park, Wrigley Field (the second most charming baseball stadium in the country, at least to this Red Sox fan), a fine arts scene, famed Chicago blues and much more.

headline: Photos of the Day: Hong Kong and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Hong Kong, Turkey, Washington and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hong Kong, Turkey, Washington and India.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Get caught up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: A Toeshoe Marks the Spot of Color
abstract: The artist Suzanne Bocanegra indulges a childhood passion with the 12-hour piece “Little Dot,” presented at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: When the visual artist Suzanne Bocanegra was a girl, she was fascinated by Seurat’s 1890 painting “Young Woman Powdering Herself.” She also identified with “Little Dot,” a comic-book character, created in 1949, obsessed with dots, and as she gazed at the Seurat, an image composed of thousands of dabs of color, she imagined how fun it would be to count and sort them.

headline: A Prickly Friendship Endures, Even as Luck Wears Thin
abstract: In “Chinese Coffee,” two men talk through a middle-aged pas de deux.
lead_paragraph: “Chinese Coffee,” at the Roy Arias Stage II Theater, is an actors’ evening. It’s directed by a wonderful one, Louise Lasser (an ad for her acting studio is on the back of the program); features a very busy one, Austin Pendleton (himself a fine director); and was performed on Friday night for an audience stocked with lots of other ones, overheard discussing rehearsals, the odd one-woman musical and excellent directors around town.

headline: If You Have Unlimited Vacation, Will You Take It?
abstract: Richard Branson’s announcement that he’ll offer employees unlimited time off has some wondering if the policy really helps workers.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Virgin Group founder Richard Branson announced he’d be giving his employees unlimited time off — and in so doing, incited a debate about whether they’d actually feel they could take it.

headline: Massacre at Centralia
abstract: One of the worst crimes of the Civil War took place in an obscure corner of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: By the time Confederate Maj. Gen. Sterling Price invaded Missouri in September 1864, he had earned a reputation for his men’s lack of discipline. After authorizing the invasion, Price’s superior, Gen. Kirby Smith, felt it necessary to add, “You will scrupulously avoid all wanton acts of destruction and devastation. Restrain your men.”

headline: A Crispy Okra Recipe, a Loewy Casserole and More New York Food News
abstract: A recipe for crispy okra from Awadh; a Raymond Loewy Le Creuset casserole; a guide for canning and more.
lead_paragraph: To Snack: Recipe Puts Crispy Okra on Your Table

headline: Serving Without Protecting
abstract: A hearing into the White House security breach underscores the public shame of the Secret Service.
lead_paragraph: My mother used to leave the front door unlocked. She used to leave the side and back doors unlocked, too. This was mostly a function of sloppiness — she had four kids, three pets and a whole lot else on her mind — but when pressed about it, she reasoned that anyone bent on intrusion would find a way and that it was all a matter of chance in the end.

headline: Behind the Scenes at Paris Fashion Week With a Rising Model and Native
abstract: Amalie Gassmann, a Paris-bred IMG face and soon-to-be Bard student, recounts her whirlwind week.
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking new faces in Paris this week has been that of Amalie Gassmann — a San Francisco–born, Paris-raised 18-year-old signed with IMG Models, for which she’ll work during a gap year before enrolling at Bard College next fall. (She also happens to be the daughter of the T contributing editor Gay Gassmann.) This season, however, Gassmann opted to work the front rows instead of the runways, taking in some presentations and openings while making a few pit stops at her favorite Paris cafés. Above, she recounts her whirlwind week.

headline: A Photographer’s Guide to Nocturnal Life
abstract: Traer Scott had to find her own path as an artist. She found it at night, making portraits of nocturnal animals.
lead_paragraph: Traer Scott had to find her own path as an artist. She found it at night, making portraits of nocturnal animals.

headline: A River Trip in Tulip Season
abstract: Amras Cruises is offering a river trip in the Netherlands and Belgium called the Tulip Serenade during flower season.
lead_paragraph: Amras Cruises, a new Boston-based travel company operating cruises designed for English-speaking travelers, will offer a trip called the Tulip Serenade, a weeklong cruise through the waterways of the Netherlands and Belgium during flower season.

headline: Modern-Day Princess Hair at Valentino
abstract: Locks were twisted and pinned in the back and threaded through with gold charms for a fresh, festive update on the classic fairy-tale coif.
lead_paragraph: With its sumptuous embroidery and vibrant prints, Valentino’s spring/summer 2015 collection felt at once romantic and ultramodern. And the same was true of the models’ half-up hairstyle. Locks were twisted together with gold charms and wrapped around the back of the head for a fresh, festive update on the classic fairy-tale coif.

headline: In Chicago, a Tasting Tour of Barrel-Aged Beer
abstract: The city is a bastion of craft brews that gain character from time spent in bourbon barrels.
lead_paragraph: About an hour after my flight touched down at O’Hare, and five blocks after I hopped off the El’s Blue Line stop at Logan Square, Chicago embraced me with a warm hug in the form of a barrel-aged doppelbock — a mini goblet of sweet vanilla lusciousness with a boozy note of rum.

headline: Forsaking an Orb to Pursue the Light of His Life
abstract: In “The Old Man and The Old Moon,” at the New Victory, a man who keeps the moon stocked with light leaves his post, causing havoc.
lead_paragraph: The shaggiest dog you’ll ever see makes a late entrance in PigPen Theater Company’s enchanted “The Old Man and the Old Moon,” at the New Victory Theater. It’s a highly companionable creature who resembles (and, in fact, may be) an animated white bath mat. But it isn’t there just to charm us.

headline: How a Meteor Rose From a Hotbed of Hip-Hop
abstract: “Nas: Time Is Illmatic” revisits a rapper’s roots in a Queens housing project and credits his parents for striving to nurture his ambition.
lead_paragraph: NAS

headline: New Sitcom Tries Old Form: Laughs Allowed
abstract: A new show, “Mulaney,” on Fox, goes against the grain for network TV by using the traditional multicamera comedy format, shot on a stage with a studio audience.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard enough to establish a comedy series in the current climate of network television without disturbing the universe at the same time.

headline: Fantasy Football: Waiver Wire Picks for Week 5
abstract: After four weeks, there are still some valuable players available in fantasy football leagues, including Eli Manning, Eddie Royal and Travis Kelce.
lead_paragraph: With four weeks of claims gone, our waiver wire cupboard is getting a little bare. But there are still some good options floating around as we all scramble to fill in the holes during bye weeks.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen Spring/Summer 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Doting Father, Loving Husband, Nazi Leader
abstract: “The Decent One” uses the personal letters and photos of Heinrich Himmler to create a documentary illustrating his rise to power in the Third Reich.
lead_paragraph: THE DECENT ONE

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Ebola Is Diagnosed in Texas, First Case Found in the U.S.
abstract: Federal health officials say that hospitals in the United States have expected and prepared for the Ebola virus, for which a man is being treated in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: A man who took a commercial flight from Liberia that landed in Dallas on Sept. 20 has been found to have the Ebola virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday. He is the first traveler to have brought the virus to the United States on a passenger plane and the first in whom Ebola has been diagnosed outside of Africa in the current outbreak.

headline: September Was Warm on Broadway, Too
abstract: A month that often brings the doldrums to Broadway this year instead brought audiences and ticket sales at their highest levels since the 2008 recession.
lead_paragraph: September is no longer the month that Broadway dreads.

headline: Three Ballet Theater Principals to Retire
abstract: Paloma Herrera, Julie Kent and Xiomara Reyes will retire near the end of American Ballet Theater’s 2015 season.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater will celebrate its 75th anniversary this season by performing key dances from its past, staging a new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky, and appearing as the subject of a new public television documentary by Ric Burns. But it will also close a more recent chapter of its history, as three ballerinas retire.

headline: Illuminating a Life Made Visible by Death
abstract: Rachel Swarns, who writes the Working Life column, explains why she pursued the story of Maria Fernandes, who died in between work shifts.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Swarns is a writer for the Metro section. On Monday, in her Working Life column, she reported on the death of a woman who died in her car while napping in between shifts for two of her three jobs. The article struck a chord and has gotten a huge response. Ms. Swarns discusses why the story touched her and many readers.

headline: Chains Spurn Netflix Plan to Screen ‘Crouching Tiger’ Sequel
abstract: Regal Cinemas and Cinemark said Tuesday that they would not screen the film, which will debut simultaneously on Netflix and on some Imax screens.
lead_paragraph: Two major theater chains, Regal Cinemas and Cinemark, said Tuesday that they would not screen next year’s sequel to “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” the first major motion picture that will make its debut simultaneously on Netflix and on a select number of Imax screens.

headline: Modern Voice, Ancient Origins
keywords: ['Music', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Classical Music']
abstract: The composer Chou Wen-chung, 91, who will be honored with a Composer Portrait at the Miller Theater on Thursday, has devoted his career to bridging East and West.
lead_paragraph: In his youth, Chou Wen-chung, the 91-year-old subject of a Composer Portrait at the Columbia University Miller Theater on Thursday, had many strict teachers. One was Edgard Varèse, the temperamental French-born Modernist and godfather of electronic music, who once showed his displeasure by throwing a score of Mr. Chou’s on the floor and ordering him to urinate on it. Then there was Bohuslav Martinu, the Czech symphonist, who reacted to a fugue Mr. Chou had written using Chinese melodic material with a single, withering, “Why?”

headline: Looking at Two Sides of Rock Royalty
abstract: Prince has released two albums in one day: “Art Official Age,” a solo album, and “PlectrumElectrum,” backed by 3rdEyeGirl.
lead_paragraph: Prince has made his career as syncopated as his music, juggling silence and noise, arena sellouts and secretive recordings. His latest confounding move is the simultaneous arrival of two albums: “Art Official Age,” a studio production billed as his first solo album since 2010 (though he had help) and “PlectrumElectrum,” on which he’s backed by the three-woman rock trio he has been touring with, 3rdEyeGirl.

headline: Christopher A. Meyers
abstract: Mr. Meyers is the managing principal of Houlihan Lawrence, a family-owned residential real estate brokerage firm.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Meyers, 46, is the managing principal of Houlihan Lawrence, a family-owned residential real estate brokerage firm that focuses on the northern suburbs of Westchester, Dutchess and Putnam Counties in New York and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

headline: Microsoft Windows 10 Displays a Familiar Look
abstract: Microsoft believes the next version of its operating system is such a big change that it is calling the software Windows 10, skipping the more logical product name, Windows 9.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft believes the next version of its operating system is such a big change that it’s calling the software Windows 10, skipping the more logical product name, Windows 9, entirely.

keywords: ['Mixed-Use Developments', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: WYANDANCH, N.Y. — For years, this Long Island hamlet has been caught in the grip of poverty, blight and crime while the nearby Hamptons and other New York City suburbs in Suffolk County prospered.

lead_paragraph: On Monday, The New York Times wrote about a man charged with animal cruelty who is about to go on trial. The charges came soon after a video surfaced of him kicking a stray cat.

headline: Now as Provocateur, Summers Says Treasury Undermined Fed
abstract: In a paper, Mr. Summers and three co-authors argued that the lack of cooperation had slowed growth and left more Americans jobless.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Summers, the former chief economic adviser to President Obama, said on Tuesday that the Treasury Department had undermined the Federal Reserve’s stimulus campaign and that doing so was a large and expensive mistake.

headline: Ethics Office Urges Inquiry of Petri, Wisconsin Republican
abstract: Representative Tom Petri may have violated House rules by intervening on behalf of a Pentagon contractor in which he owned stock, the office said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Tom Petri, Republican of Wisconsin, may have violated House conflict of interest rules when he repeatedly intervened on behalf of a Defense Department contractor in which he owned more than $250,000 in stock, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

headline: In Trying to Save Darden, a Board Sealed Its Own Demise
abstract: Darden Restaurants directors have paid a steep price for refusing to give in to the demands of shareholder activists pushing for change, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Gestures of futile nobility seem mostly confined to the movies these days. And yet the directors of Darden Restaurants, the owner of Olive Garden and other quintessentially American restaurant chains, may have decided that they would rather commit corporate suicide than give in to the demands of two activist shareholders, Starboard Value and the Barington Capital Group. It would be touching if it didn’t appear to be so inexplicably foolish.

headline: George Shuba, 89, Dies; Handshake Heralded Racial Tolerance in Baseball
abstract: Shuba, a Dodgers outfielder, is remembered for a welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson on the day that Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseball’s color barrier.
lead_paragraph: George Shuba, the Brooklyn Dodgers outfielder who played in three World Series during the 1950s but who was best remembered for his welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson at home plate on the day Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseball’s color barrier, died on Monday at his home in Youngstown, Ohio. He was 89.

headline: East Jerusalem Area Sees Influx of Jewish Settlers
keywords: ['Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Jewish settlers moved early Tuesday into 26 apartments in seven buildings in a politically delicate, predominantly Palestinian neighborhood of East Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Jewish settlers moved early Tuesday into 26 apartments in seven buildings in a politically delicate, predominantly Palestinian neighborhood of East Jerusalem. Activists opposed to the move described it as the largest influx of settlers into the area in decades. The neighborhood, Silwan — just south of the Old City in territory Israel captured in the 1967 war then annexed — is home to about 50,000 Palestinians. It is also the site of archaeological ruins believed to be the City of David, a Jewish historical landmark. The Palestinians claim East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state, and most of the world considers it to be illegally occupied. A private investment company bought the properties over several years with the help of Elad, a settler organization dedicated to preventing any political division of Jerusalem. The Jewish population in the area is now expected to increase to 700 from 500, according to an Elad representative.

headline: Where Horses Run Wild
abstract: A growing number of wild horses in the Western United States pose a threat to ranchers and raise questions about how to control them.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of wild horses in the Western United States pose a threat to ranchers and raise questions about how to control them.

headline: Beating of African Students by Mob in India Prompts Soul-Searching on Race
abstract: Video of three African students being beaten in a New Delhi metro station prompted an online discussion of racism in India.
lead_paragraph: As India’s prime minister visited the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial with President Obama in Washington on Tuesday, a debate about racism was taking shape in the Indian news media, prompted by video of an angry mob beating three African students in a New Delhi metro station this week.

headline: As Wild Horses Overrun the West, Ranchers Fear Land Will Be Gobbled Up
abstract: There are now twice as many wild horses in the West as federal land managers say the land can sustain, and the system for keeping them under control is on the verge of crisis.
lead_paragraph: BEAVER COUNTY, Utah — When he was a boy on a 150,000-acre ranch here in the desert mountains, which are so remote that there is no power line and electricity comes from a turbine in a mountain spring, Mark Wintch would thrill at the sight of a rare band of wild horses kicking up dust as they disappeared over a rise.

headline: C.D.C. Announces First U.S. Ebola Case
abstract: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the infected individual came to the United States from Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the infected individual came to the United States from Liberia.

headline: New School Evaluations Will Lower Test Scores’ Influence
abstract: New York City’s assessments of schools will replace single-letter grades with more complex reports that Chancellor Carmen Fariña called “more transparent.”
lead_paragraph: New York City is overhauling its system for evaluating schools, de-emphasizing test scores in favor of measures like the strength of the curriculum and the school environment, and doing away with an overall A-through-F grade for each school, the schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, said on Tuesday.

headline: The Destruction of Mecca
abstract: The Saudis have bulldozed centuries of beauty and diversity in Islam’s holiest city.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Malcolm X visited Mecca in 1964, he was enchanted. He found the city “as ancient as time itself,” and wrote that the partly constructed extension to the Sacred Mosque “will surpass the architectural beauty of India’s Taj Mahal.”
